column2: In an Editorial Observer article on Tuesday about Minnesota’s gun laws: The law requires that local authorities “shall issue” concealed weapons permits when properly applied for. The article used the incorrect phrase “shall require” to describe this policy.
A federal judge ruled that the defendant, accused of working with Iraqi intelligence, could not be forced to take antipsychotic medication in an effort to make her competent to stand trial.

The federal judge presiding over the death penalty trial of a man charged with killing two undercover police detectives on Staten Island in 2003 has postponed jury selection in the case just days before it was set to begin, clearing the way for possible plea negotiations.

PROCLAIMING the beginning of a new era in Atlantic City gaming, Pinnacle Entertainment Inc. has agreed to buy the Sands Casino Hotel, the smallest of the 12 casinos in the city, for $250 million, with the intention of tearing it down and building an upscale casino-hotel complex.

THE Bridgeport Police Department has joined a handful of other departments around the state in putting officers on Segways, the futuristic-looking battery-powered upright scooters.

The tropical storm that barreled through the Northeast a week ago caused more damage to Con Edison’s system than any storm in the last two decades, company officials say, plunging nearly a quarter of the utility’s Westchester customers into darkness and leaving a vast trail of snapped trees and downed power lines.

Many Suffolk County residents found themselves warned off their neighborhood beaches over the Labor Day weekend, just as Long Islanders had been periodically throughout the rainy summer.

What he and other commuters on the Long Island Rail Road see these days is much different from what they saw before a $300 million renovation of the station that began more than five and a half years ago.

Little by little, the cafe inside Atticus Bookstore in New Haven has swallowed more and more of the space. It began with a couple of tables, a counter and display cases in 1981, when the cafe opened. There are now 20 tables occupying about a third of the store, and according to Caleb Fraser, an assistant manager, plans are slowly evolving for even more cafe space.

After surviving cancer, Janez Drnovsek said he was suddenly emboldened to speak his mind on all sorts of topics.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Sept. 8 — The daughter of Ralph J. Phillips, the fugitive who surrendered after a five-month manhunt, did what so many other people in this area of western New York did on Friday. She watched the live television coverage as troopers closed in on her father until she could stand it no longer.

Phillips, center, the fugitive suspected of shooting three state troopers -- one of whom later died -- surrendered in rural northern Pennsylvania. Troopers and residents cheered and clapped as he was driven away. The 50-year-old Austrian alarm systems specialist who stole the 16th-century gold-plated Benvenuto Cellini sculpture ''Saliera'' (''Saltcellar'') from the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna in 2003 was sentenced to four years in prison, the BBC reported. The thief, Robert Mang, held the masterpiece, valued at roughly $60 million, for three years and tried to collect a ransom of about $12 million before police identified him, and he turned himself in. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

SCUDDER--Rogers V. 93, of Groton. Rogers V. Scudder Teacher, Scholar, Author. Rogers V. Scudder, a beloved and renowned teacher of Latin, died on Sunday, August 27, 2006. He was 93 years old and lived in Groton, Massachusetts. Born in St. Louis in 1912, Mr. Scudder attended St. Louis Country Day School. He graduated magna cum laude in Comparative Literature from Harvard University in1934, earned a Diploma in Classical Archaeology at Oxford in 1955, and a masters degree from the University of Wisconsin, Madison, in 1958. MR. Scudder joined the American Field Service during World War II, and was an ambulance driver for part of that time. He served in the British Eighth Army for two years in Syria, North Africa and Italy. Mr. Scudder began his long and distinguished teaching career at the Roxbury Latin School in 1934 as an apprentice. Later, after a few years of teaching at Los Alamos School in New Mexico, he joined the faculty at Brooks School in 1936 where he taught until 1966. He joined the Groton School faculty in the spring of 1968 and continued to teach and then tutor until 2005. In the 1960s, he began his collaboration with Charles Jenney, Jr., on a fourVolume series of textbooks, which would become the most widely used Latin textbooks in the United States for nearly two decades. Mr. Scudder also served as The director of the Library at the American Academy in Rome from 1976-1983, overseeing its splendid collection in the fields of classical studies and the fine arts of the Italian Renaissance. An admired teacher and dormitory master, Mr. Scudder was known for his quick wit, which earned him legions of devoted students. When he arrived back from Rome to Groton School in 1984, he wrote: ''I return now to teach full time, a rather presumptuous undertaking for one of my advanced years.'' He continued to teach for another 20 years, generously sharing his wisdom, time and resources. So revered was he by the student body that the snack bar in the Student Center was named ''Scudder's'' in his honor. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Chapel at groton School on Sunday, September 24, at 1:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to a faVorite charity or institution.

Despite word of small last-minute cuts meant to soften the film's depiction of President Bill Clinton and his aides, members of his administration and Democratic officials yesterday stepped up their campaign to force ABC to cancel its disputed mini-series, ''The Path to 9/11.'' The Democratic National Committee delivered to the network a petition with more than 200,000 names that demanded withdrawal of the film, which the petition called ''right-wing propaganda.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Panel Finds C.I.A. Stance Undercuts Bush on War The C.I.A. last fall repudiated the claims by the Bush administration of prewar ties between Saddam Hussein's government and the Qaeda operative Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to a report by the Senate Intelligence Committee. A1 Indian Mosque Bombed A series of explosions struck in and near the largest mosque in a town in western India, killing more than two dozen people, wounding more than 100. Fines the Red Cross The Food and Drug Administration announced a $4.2 million fine against the American Red Cross because it had repeatedly failed to handle and collect blood supplies properly. Lieberman of Connecticut, who is running for re-election as an independent, has begun a complicated tango in a bid to woo Democrats, Republicans and unaffiliated voters. Mr. Lieberman's camp is operating without the benefits of a party apparatus. CLAY--Alina. On September 7, 2006. Loving mother and wife. Survived by son Victor Parker and grandsons Michael and Bradley Parker.

To the Editor: While reading ''Iraq's Endangered Journalists,'' by Ali Fadhil (Op-Ed, Sept. 6), I was shocked by his claim that ''foreign reporters have the advantage of being considered untouchable by the Iraqi police and security forces.''

At least four people were killed as fresh fighting broke out between Georgia and the separatist region of South Ossetia. South Ossetia, which has tacit backing from Russia, said Georgian interior troops attacked a village checkpoint, killing three Ossetian police officers; the Georgian government said its troops were chasing smugglers and that one Georgian officer was killed. Tensions in the region rose even higher than usual after gunfire struck a helicopter carrying the Georgian defense minister on Sept. 2. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

The Critical Shopper column on Thursday about the 24-hour operation of the main retail store of L. L. Bean, the outdoor outfitter in Freeport, Me., misstated the store's area code. The correct telephone number is (800) 441-5713.

An article in some copies on Aug. 27 about the funeral of Lance Cpl. Michael D. Glover, a marine from Queens who was killed by a sniper's bullet in Falluja, Iraq, referred incorrectly to the circumstances under which he left law school to go to Iraq. He took a leave of absence; he did not drop out. The article also misstated the year he left. It was 2005, not 2004.

WEISS--Harry, 91, of Manalapan, NJ, on September 7, 2006. Beloved husband of Lee (nee Katzman). Dear father of Iris and Stephen Handler and Diane and Mike Goldberg and the late Joel Powell. Loving grandfather of Alysa and Richard Slifkin, Richard and Rebecca Powell and Rhonda Handler and greatgrandfather of Justin Slifkin. Services Sunday, 11AM at Bloomfield - Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Ave., Manalapan, NJ.

In an Editorial Observer article on Tuesday about Minnesota's gun laws: The law requires that local authorities ''shall issue'' concealed weapons permits when properly applied for. The article used the incorrect phrase ''shall require'' to describe this policy.

An article last Saturday about a widening of the search for Ralph Phillips, an escaped inmate, after the ambush shootings of two state troopers in western New York misspelled the name of the road in Stockton where his former girlfriend has a home. (The error was repeated in an article in some copies on Monday about the death of one of the troopers.) It is Bachellor Hill Road, not Bachelor.

LYM--Robert. Goodbye, dear friend. Listening to Saturday afternoon at the opera and eating good food will always bring you joyously back into my life. Robert Bolton $(6$)LYM--Robert of New York City on September 6, 2006. Having joined I.M. Pei and Partners in 1956, he retired in 1985 as a Senior Associate in charge of interior design. American projects included the John Hancock Building and the Christian Science Center in Boston. Working on an international scale, he is especially remembered in Melbourne, Australia for his contribution to the twin towers there and his fostering of Australian art. He is survived by his loving sister, Jean Lym Yee (Berkeley, CA); nieces, Wendy Yee, Leslie Tibbetts and Sherry Mulloy; nephew, Glenn Lym; grandnieces Erin Shah , Minday Lym and Hilary Stabb; grandnephews Jamie Tibbetts and Toby and Scott Mulloy. He is also survived by Arthur Coake, his attentive and caring companion of 38 years; his close friend Joseph Matis; good friend, Joan Jacobson; his long time New York pals, Frank Thompson, Robert Bolton, Jon Wicklund and Mark Wilson and his Metropolitan Opera buddies Kit Gill and Merriwether Garn. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street on Saturday, 7-9 pm and Sunday 2-4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Central Park Conservancy or the Momentum Project.

To the Editor: ''Youthful Binge Drinking Fueled by Boredom of the Open West'' (front page, Sept. 2), about under-age drinking, may leave the impression that teenagers in the sparsely populated Plains and Western states are more at risk than teenagers in other parts of the country.

To the Editor: ''New Themes for the Same Old Songs,'' by Maureen Dowd (column, Sept. 6), notes the current Republican campaign that would equate the Democrats' supposed ''curtsying'' to Middle East tyrants with Chamberlain's bowing to Hitler.

The TV Watch column in Weekend yesterday, about the ABC mini-series ''The Path to 9/11,'' referred incorrectly to a conclusion of the commission that investigated the terror attacks. The commission said the accusation that President Clinton had ordered air strikes against Osama bin Laden in August 1998 to distract attention from the Monica Lewinsky scandal was one of several factors that ''likely had a cumulative effect on future decisions about the use of force'' against Mr. bin Laden. It did not conclude that the scandal distracted the Clinton administration from the terrorist threat.

F.C. Barcelona plans to return to the United States next summer, the club's president, Joan Laporta, said in an interview yesterday in Manhattan. ''We are thinking of repeating this year's experience, which was the best-run tour we have ever been on,'' he said.
GAMSU--Richard. Beloved husband of Toby, father of Elyse and Andy. Our deepest sorrow in the passing of our dear friend and confidant, we miss him already. Sharon/Albert Vitarelli

To the Editor: ''Departure of a Pragmatist'' (editorial, Sept. 8) concludes that the Medicare administrator, Mark McClellan, ''seems mostly to have succeeded'' in launching the administration's limited and inefficient drug benefit because of an 80 percent satisfaction rating with the new program. This overlooks the goal of insurance: to pool the resources of the many to protect the few.

An article on Thursday about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's return to Capitol Hill after he lost the Connecticut Democratic primary gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the Connecticut newspaper whose reporter, David Lightman, commented on the heightened media interest in the matter. It is the Hartford Courant, not Currant.

A court gave counterterrorism officers more time to question nine suspects who were arrested Sept. 1 in raids in London that led to a search of an Islamic school. Earlier this week, two others were released without charge and three were ordered detained until Monday. In the latest ruling, the police were given periods of up to a week to interview the nine remaining detainees, held on suspicion of recruiting and training Islamic terrorists. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

An obituary on Aug. 24 about Jeffrey Tennyson, an artist who collected hamburger artifacts, misstated the name of the comic strip in which the character of hamburger-loving J. Wellington Wimpy first appeared and the date of that appearance. It was ''Thimble Theatre,'' not ''Popeye''; ''Popeye'' was a later name for the strip. The character of Wimpy, at first unnamed, was introduced in the early 1930's, not in the 1920's.

The Central Intelligence Agency last fall repudiated the claim that there were prewar ties between Saddam Hussein's government and an operative of Al Qaeda, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to a report issued Friday by the Senate Intelligence Committee. The disclosure undercuts continuing assertions by the Bush administration that such ties existed, and that they provided evidence of links between Iraq and Al Qaeda. The Republican-controlled committee, in a second report, also sharply criticized the administration for its reliance on the Iraqi National Congress during the prelude to the war in Iraq.

Pull Over, 50 Cent The rap star 50 Cent, below, was pulled over on Eighth Avenue, at 35th Street, in Midtown Manhattan about 2 p.m. yesterday for driving dangerously in an uninsured Lamborghini. The rapper, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, was cited for making an unsafe lane change and driving with an expired license, and without insurance and a vehicle registration, according to a police spokesman. He was issued a summons on the charges and released. Hoax Author Speaks The fall issue of The Paris Review literary magazine will include an interview with Laura Albert, the woman who, under the name J T LeRoy, wrote the books ''Sarah'' and ''The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things,'' the magazine said yesterday. In a literary fraud, Ms. Albert and others helping her invented the fake persona of J T LeRoy, a cross-dressing, H.I.V.-positive, under-age former male prostitute. The magazine quoted Ms. Albert as saying, ''I never saw it as a hoax.'' Asked if she felt shame for deceiving her readers, she responded: ''I bleed, but it's a different kind of shame. I'm sad I was so injured.'' The New York Times first reported J T LeRoy's real identity early this year. Classical Notes Paul Lustig Dunkel will step down as music director and conductor of the Westchester Philharmonic after the end of the 2007-8 concert season, his 25th anniversary with the orchestra. Ian Bostridge, the British tenor, canceled a recital at Carnegie Hall scheduled for Dec. 13 because of family obligations, but Carnegie has added a recital by the tenor Ben Heppner on Oct. 25. Tickets for Mr. Bostridge's concert will be honored. Information: (212) 247-7800. The New York Grand Opera canceled its performance of Puccini's ''Tosca'' at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park on Sept. 20 because of scheduling conflicts. The opera had been originally planned for Aug. 1, but was rescheduled because of extreme heat. Footnote U2 is working on material for its next album with Rick Rubin, the producer whose résumé includes working with stars ranging from the Beastie Boys and the Red Hot Chili Peppers to Neil Diamond and Johnny Cash. According to a brief posting on U2's Web site, U2.com, Billboard reported, the band is also set to work with Green Day on a version of ''The Saints Are Coming,'' the 1978 song by the Scottish punk band the Skids.

After listening to recovery workers at ground zero and downtown residents emotionally describe how they had been ignored and insulted as they sought help for health problems after 9/11, members of a Congressional subcommittee roundly criticized the federal response yesterday and called for sharply increased medical spending. Subcommittee members, joined by Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer, accused the Bush administration of ignoring the health problems that arose among workers who toiled at ground zero and the claims of downtown residents who say they were also sickened by the dust. The administration has done little to prepare for a similar disaster in the future, they said.

Sotheby's in New York will auction more than 200 objects, including several Andy Warhol paintings, from the estate of David Whitney, the collector and curator who was the longtime companion of the architect Philip Johnson, the auction house said yesterday. Mr. Whitney, who died last year, acquired works by many artists before they became stars, including Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella, James Rosenquist and Jasper Johns. He left most of his works, including one of the world's best collections of works on paper by Mr. Johns, to the Menil Collection in Houston, which estimated their value to be at least $8 million. Sotheby's expected that the remaining items -- paintings, furniture, pottery and folk art -- would sell for $3.5 million to $5 million when they are auctioned on Nov. 16. Proceeds will go to the National Trust for Historic Preservation to aid in the maintenance of Johnson's famous Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., which is to open to visitors next year. RANDY KENNEDY

To the Editor: Re ''In Search of Accurate Vote Totals'' (editorial, Sept. 5):

An article in Business Day yesterday about the purloining of private phone records in a Hewlett-Packard investigation of news leaks misattributed a disclosure that a reporter for The New York Times, John Markoff, was a target of the effort. The information came from the California attorney general's office, not a lawyer for AT&T.

A front-page article last Saturday about the lack of preparation among some students applying for community college misspelled the surname of an official at the Community College of Baltimore County, who said students were shocked to learn they needed remedial courses. She is Donna McKusick, not McKusik. The article also misspelled the given name of a former talk show star, whose habit of personalizing issues on her program was likened to students in a remedial reading class who discussed a television documentary in personal terms. She is Ricki Lake, not Ricky.

An article last Saturday about a widening of the search for Ralph Phillips, an escaped inmate, after the ambush shootings of two state troopers in western New York misspelled the name of the road in Stockton where his former girlfriend has a home. (The error was repeated in an article in some copies on Monday about the death of one of the troopers.) It is Bachellor Hill Road, not Bachelor.

The debut of National Football League games on NBC left other networks in the dust on Thursday night. The Miami Dolphins-Pittsburgh Steelers game, below, drew 19.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen, the largest audience since the N.F.L. began scheduling season openers on Thursdays four years ago. Fox and CBS were in a close race for second place, with ABC a distant fourth over all, showing two reruns of ''Grey's Anatomy'' on its new night. At 8, the premiere of Fox's '' 'Til Death'' (8.8 million), the new comedy with Brad Garrett, could not contend with NBC's pregame show. But it still fared better than the premiere of Fox's ''Happy Hour'' (7 million), up against the kickoff at 8:30. Meanwhile, on the second-to-last episode of CBS's ''Big Brother 7: All-Stars,'' the departure of the fan favorite Janelle Pierzina helped to draw an average of 8.45 million viewers for the 8 p.m. hour, with a slight edge over Fox in the 18-to-49-year-old market. At 9, week two of Fox's ''Celebrity Duets'' was last(6.85 million), behind repeats of ''CSI'' (10.7 million) on CBS and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (7.8 million) on ABC. BENJAMIN TOFF

There is a temporary bank of lockers in the middle of the visitors' clubhouse at Camden Yards, enough to fit the 34 Yankees on the active roster. On this team, the term active is used loosely. Mariano Rivera is out for this weekend's series against the Baltimore Orioles with lingering tightness near his right elbow. Mike Mussina will miss Sunday's start with what he called a cranky shoulder. And Jason Giambi's left wrist is not getting better.

Battlefield Promotion With about five minutes left in the third quarter last Saturday, Wake Forest and Syracuse were tied at 10-10 when De'Angelo Bryant, a Wake Forest running back, fumbled. Ben Mauk, above, Wake Forest's junior quarterback, dived for the ball, arm first. Mistake.

9 P.M. (Lifetime) THE MERMAID CHAIR -- Save the date. Kim Basinger is back on television -- and no less beautiful -- after a 27-year gap in this made-for-television movie, based on the novel by Sue Monk Kidd, about a woman who falls in love with a Benedictine monk (Alex Carter, left, with Ms. Basinger) after she returns home to be with her mother. But aren't vows made to be broken? 7:30 P.M. (Discovery Kids) GROWING UP CREEPIE -- Her mother is a praying mantis, her father is a mosquito and her brother is a gnat. So what does that make Creepie Creecher, the star of this new animated series? A decidedly nonbuggy human girl, left as a baby to be reared by a family of insects, who is going to school for the first time and trying to find her way around a new world. One glitch: her best friend's father is the town exterminator. 8 P.M. (A&E) TRAPPED IN THE TOWERS: THE ELEVATORS OF 9/11 -- People who were stranded in elevators between floors on Sept. 11, 2001, tell their stories. Among them, Arturo and Carmen Griffith (above), husband-and-wife elevator operators in the twin towers, where they met and kissed for the first time. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICA'S MOST WANTED: AMERICA FIGHTS BACK -- The show begins its 20th season with a look back at some of the 900 fugitives it has helped capture. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MY HUSBAND IS GAY -- What happens when the life you love isn't the life you thought it was? This documentary looks at five couples in which the husbands have revealed that they are gay, and examines how that affects their wives. 9 P.M. (Food Network) WHERE THERE'S SMOKE -- Mary Sue Milliken is a chef, her husband, Josh Schweitzer, is an architect, and together they are designing her dream kitchen. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) SASQUATCH MOUNTAIN -- A monster from the mountains of Arizona. A bank robbery gone bad. And perhaps worst of all, police and criminals on the same side of the law in this television thriller. Things could get messy. 10 P.M. (BBC America) KYLIE MINOGUE: SHOWGIRL -- Last year, Ms. Minogue's ''Showgirl'' tour was cut short when she learned she had breast cancer. This special, filmed in May 2005 at Earls Court in London, presents highlights from one of the shows that did go on, including hits like ''Can't Get You Out of My Head,'' ''Spinning Around,'' ''I Should Be So Lucky'' and a jazzy ''Locomotion.'' At 11 p.m., Ms. Minogue talks with Cat Deeley (above right, with Ms. Minogue) about life before and after her diagnosis in ''The Kylie Interview.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, said the United States Embassy owed $1.6 million in unpaid traffic-congestion charges and fines, making it the worst offender in the city. Embassy employees have not paid the charges -- £8 ($15) a day for any car entering central London -- since July 2005, arguing that the charge is a tax; diplomats are exempt from taxes. But London officials say the charge is a toll, not a tax, and say that British diplomats pay tolls in America. SARAH LYALL (NYT)

On Thursday, her third night as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' Katie Couric, right, drew an estimated 9.5 million viewers, a loss of about 600,000 from the night before, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research released yesterday by CBS. On a night when ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' was pre-empted on the West Coast by the opening game of the National Football League season, Ms. Couric's chief competition, ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC, was seen by an estimated 6.6 million, down about a half-million from the previous evening. Because Ms. Couric's arrival at CBS has been supported by a marketing campaign on a scale more akin to that of a blockbuster movie than of a news program, and because the evening news audience tends to fluctuate from night to night, it will be some time before any conclusions can be drawn about whether her entry has raised CBS from its longtime No. 3 ratings position, behind NBC (the leader under Mr. Williams and Tom Brokaw before him) and ABC. JACQUES STEINBERG

''Last night at the wake I was very emotional, and that's when it hit me that this is real. I only then started to think that this was actually happening and I will be leading the city.'' LUKE RAVENSTAHL, who became mayor of Pittsburgh at 26 when the incumbent died. [A11]

John Weidman, president of the Dramatists Guild of America, apologized for a mistake he made in his censure of Hedy Weiss, a theater critic for The Chicago Sun-Times. On Aug. 16, when Ms. Weiss wrote a scathing review of the eight musicals at Stages 2006, a festival of shows in development presented by Theater Building Chicago, Mr. Weidman wrote to The Sun-Times condemning her for reviewing works in progress. But on Wednesday he wrote to the paper again, acknowledging that one of his main assertions -- that Ms. Weiss's decision to review was ''in violation of the express wishes of the theater'' -- was not true. He apologized for the error, saying he was given false information, but added that Ms. Weiss's coverage still remained ''irresponsible and unprofessional.'' The letter concludes: ''To the extent that I criticized Weiss inaccurately, I was unfair, and I regret it.'' CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

To the Editor: As a former Department of Veterans Affairs headquarters project manager who monitored returning Iraq and Afghanistan veterans, I agree with Paul Krugman's comment that the V.A. is a stunning success for quality medical care (''Health Policy Malpractice,'' column, Sept. 4). The Op-Ed page asked 10 experts to answer the following question: What is one major reason the United States has not suffered a major attack since 2001?

AS a result of the horror of Sept. 11, 2001, President Bush has transformed the way we fight terrorism and the tools we use. We successfully attack those very things our enemies need to operate and survive: leadership, communications, the ability to travel, weapons; foot soldiers and financing. The president has strengthened and transformed the intelligence community, integrated our military and intelligence assets, and broken down the barriers that kept domestic law enforcement and intelligence agencies from sharing information.
THE best news in our struggle against terrorism is that we have not been hit at home since the 9/11 attacks. Yet terrorists are patient. We remain a target and must expect another attack.

THE reason we have not been attacked on American soil is that the war started by radical Muslims is not against the United States, but against everyone who does not conform to their beliefs and way of life. It is the first global war we have experienced since globalization became a factor in our life, and the terrorist battlefield has included Madrid, London, Bali, Moscow, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and India. The terrorists have had a very busy five years.

S O why haven’t we been attacked in five years? Terrorists — especially those directed by or affiliated with Al Qaeda — are committed to carrying out spectacular attacks that maximize death, injury, economic damage and political symbolism. If their aim were merely to blow up the odd bus or to level a supermarket, doing so would be a very short order. But, the more spectacular the scale of a plot, the longer it takes to plan, the costlier it is to finance, the more operatives you need to carry it out, and the greater the chance that something will go awry.

THOUGH it may not be immediately apparent to the casual viewer, Al Qaeda is attacking when and where it chooses. It is an ideology-driven global insurgency on the march. It has not hit America because it has chosen not to. Whether it lacks on-the-ground capacity for a spectacular attack, is still in the planning stages or is busy elsewhere is under debate within our intelligence community. The point is that five years out, Al Qaeda is as dangerous as, if not more than, it was on 9/11.

O FFENSIVE action abroad has protected the homeland. Our military presence in Afghanistan and our aggressive policies around the globe have seriously disrupted the enemy. Through a mix of military and paramilitary action, pre-emptive strikes, deterrent threats and surveillance we have captured many terrorist leaders, destroyed training camps and structures of communication and control, and uncovered valuable intelligence troves.

ANOTHER attempt on the scale of the 2001 attacks hasn’t been necessary. The last one is still doing the trick, and the terrorists’ resources are limited. The fear induced by terrorism mirrors the irrational psychology that makes state lotteries an utterly reliable form of stupidity tax. A huge statistical asymmetry serves as fulcrum for a spectral yet powerful lever: apprehension of the next jackpot. We’re terrorized not by the actual explosion, which statistically we’re almost never present for, but by our apprehension of the next one.
THE most important counterterrorism activity since the fall of the Taliban has been the close cooperation of the C.I.A. with foreign intelligence services.

THE 9/11 attacks were a defining moment for the course of world politics and a strategic assault against the world’s leading power at the beginning of the 21st century. But the question is, were the terrorists successful? The answer is mixed. In the aftermath of 9/11, the world was united with America. Even in Arab and Muslim countries, the sense of shock and feelings of solidarity with America far outweighed any sympathies with the terrorists.
SINCE 9/11, terrorism has increased significantly around the globe, but the United States has been spared. Eurasia rather than America has been the main source and victim. Why?.

From hiding in Grandma’s bed to demolishing pig houses, the wolf is a stock character in children’s stories. The wily one also headlines the bill in WOLVES (Simon & Schuster, $15.95, ages 4 to 8), a picture book written and illustrated by Emily Gravett. Although full of facts about wolf physiology and habitat, “Wolves” isn’t exactly a feel-good book for bedtime reading. The thin narrative follows a rabbit that borrows a volume on wolves from the local library and as he strolls along reading, he learns about the species.
Louis-Ferdinand Céline’s universal paranoia decayed into the tawdry specificity of anti-Semitism.
A letter to the editor on Aug. 27 about the German naturalist Alexander von Humboldt misspelled the writer’s given name. He is Aldemaro Romero, not Aldemoro.

But friends and family said the 45-year-old firefighter lived as he died, forgoing his own comfort, in ways large and small, to ensure that of others.
