All dates are subject to change. September Wednesday AL Franken: God Spoke A year in the life of this comedian and political commentator, as recorded by the filmmakers Nick Doob and Chris Hegedus (''The War Room''). Artie Lange's Beer League Mr. Lange, a regular on Howard Stern's radio show, is the co-writer, producer and star of this comedy about an amateur softball team in danger of being dropped from its league. Frank Sebastiano is the co-writer and director; with Ralph Macchio, Laurie Metcalf and Seymour Cassel. Friday Aurora Borealis A Minneapolis drifter (Joshua Jackson) finds meaning in his life when he becomes a caretaker for his elderly grandparents (Louise Fletcher and Donald Sutherland). Juliette Lewis is a friendly and flighty physical therapist; James Burke directs. The Black Dahlia James Ellroy's fictionalized version of one of Los Angeles's most notorious murders, the 1947 killing of the aspiring actress Elizabeth Short (Mia Kirshner). Josh Hartnett and Aaron Eckhart are the two police investigators on the case; Scarlett Johansson is a mysterious look-alike for the dead woman who attracts the amorous attention of both men. With Hilary Swank; Brian De Palma, no stranger to doubles and dead bodies, directs. Confetti Three couples compete in a magazine's contest to hold the most original wedding of the year. Debbie Isitt directs this largely improvised mockumentary from Britain, which stars Martin Freeman from the British version of ''The Office.'' Everyone's Hero Christopher Reeve initiated this computer animated film about a boy's cross-country journey to meet Babe Ruth (Brian Dennehy) and help him win the World Series. Reeve, Colin Brady and Dan St. Pierre are the credited directors. With the voices of Whoopi Goldberg, Ed Helms, William H. Macy and Mandy Patinkin. Gridiron Gang Football becomes a route to self-esteem for a group of teenagers held in a juvenile home. Dwayne Johnson, known as the Rock, is the inspirational coach this time; with Xzibit, Leon Rippy and Kevin Dunn. Phil Joanou directed, based on a 1993 documentary by Lee Stanley and Jac Flanders. The Ground Truth The experiences of six men and women who volunteered for service in Iraq, as seen in a documentary by Patricia Foulkrod. Haven The financiers Bill Paxton and Stephen Dillane touch off a wave of trouble when they flee to the Cayman Islands to escape prosecution. Orlando Bloom is the local who gets tied in with them; Zoe Saldana and Agnes Bruckner also figure in the story. Written and directed by Frank E. Flowers. Keeping Mum The British comedian Rowan Atkinson tries to shake the kiddie image of the ''Mr. Bean'' films with this sex comedy about a clergyman who discovers his wife (Kristin Scott Thomas) is having an affair. With Maggie Smith and Patrick Swayze; written and directed by Niall Johnson. The Last Kiss Gabriele Muccino's Italian film ''L'ultimo Bacio'' gets its Americanized remake courtesy of the director Tony Goldwyn and the writer Paul Haggis. Zach Braff is the blithe young man horrified to discover that his longtime girlfriend is pregnant. With Jacinda Barrett and Rachel Bilson. The U.S. vs. John Lennon David Leaf's documentary looks at John Lennon's years as an anti-war activist. VaJRa Sky Over Tibet The director and cinematographer John Bush conducts a tour of Tibetan Buddhism's most sacred sites. Sept. 20 Old Joy Two old friends, one about to become a father (Daniel London) and one still drifting (Will Oldham), go on an overnight camping trip in the Cascade Mountains in Oregon. A funny, lyrical reimagining of the Falstaff tale by a genuinely independent filmmaker, Kelly Reichardt (''River of Grass''). Sept. 22 All the King's Men The fourth version (counting a couple of TV movies) of Robert Penn Warren's novel about a ruthless Southern governor, based on the life of Huey Long. Sean Penn stars; with Jude Law, Kate Winslet, Patricia Clarkson, James Gandolfini, Anthony Hopkins and Kathy Baker; directed by Steven Zaillian. In other words, let the Oscar season begin. [Article, Page 39.] American Hardcore The sweaty, shirtless rock music movement that dominated Reagan-era America gets the documentary treatment from the director and editor Paul Rachman. Flyboys American volunteers join the flying ranks of the Lafayette Escadrille in the early years of World War I. With James Franco, Martin Henderson, Jean Reno and plenty of distressed leather; directed by the veteran Tony Bill (''Hearts of the West''). Jackass: Number 2 More ill-advised stunts pulled off by Johnny Knoxville, Chris Pontius, Bam Margera and the rest of the cast of the groundbreaking MTV series. Jesus Camp The directors of the documentary ''The Boys from Baraka,'' Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, look at a popular summer camp for Christian children in Devil's Lake, N.D. Jet Li's Fearless According to the martial arts star Jet Li, this biography of Huo Yuanjia, the legendary founder of the Jingwu school of fighting, will be his last appearance in an action role. Well, he is 42. Ronny Yu directed, with what the fan press is reporting as an old school approach deliberately distanced from the CGI excesses of ''Crouching Tiger'' and its imitators. Renaissance The search for a kidnapped scientist in the Paris of 2054, rendered in a computer animation technique that turns live action into high-contrast, black-and-white images. Christian Volckman directed; the animation was supervised by Marc Miance. The Science of Sleep A shy Parisian (Gael García Bernal), who holds down a dull job during the day, feels alive only in his dreams, where he is the host of his own television show. But the young woman who lives across the hall (Charlotte Gainsbourg) threatens to lure him back to the real world. Michel Gondry (''The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'') wrote and directed. SÓlo con tu pareja Known as ''Love in the Time of Hysteria'' when it made the festival rounds in 1991, this early film by the acclaimed Mexican director Alfonso Cuarón is a comedy about a Don Juan given a false diagnosis of AIDS by a nurse who happens to be a vengeful former lover. Train Man A shy young Japanese, known on the Internet as Train Man, fumbles toward a relationship with a girl he meets on the subway. Masanori Murakami directs. Sept. 27 The Last King of Scotland The brutal rule of Uganda's Idi Amin (Forest Whitaker), as witnessed by the Scottish doctor (James McAvoy) whom Amin corralled as his personal physician. Kevin Macdonald directed; with Gillian Anderson and Kerry Washington. [Article, Page 46.] Sept. 29 Be With Me Three tales of love and death among the average citizens of Singapore. Eric Khoo wrote and directed, inspired by the stories of Theresa Chan. Broken Sky A languorously observed love triangle among gay men in Mexico City. Julian Hernandez wrote and directed. Facing the Giants A Christian high-school football coach calls on his faith to lead his team through a difficult season. Alex Kendrick directs; with James Blackwell and Bailey Cave. The Guardian A troubled young man (Ashton Kutcher) learns to shape up under the influence of a tough Coast Guard rescue swimmer (Kevin Costner). With Sela Ward. The director is Andrew Davis (''The Fugitive''). A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints Dito Montiel's autobiographical film about growing up tough in Astoria, Queens, stars Robert Downey Jr. as the adult Dito recollecting his colorful youth and Shia LaBeouf as his younger self, struggling on the streets of 1986. With Dianne Wiest, Melonie Diaz, Eric Roberts and Rosario Dawson. Open Season A wisecracking deer (with the voice of Ashton Kutcher) instructs a city-raised bear (Martin Lawrence) in the art of surviving in the wilderness. Roger Allers, Anthony Stacchi and Jill Culton directed this computer animation from Sony Imageworks; additional voices by Debra Messing, Billy Connolly, Jon Favreau and Jane Krakowski. School for Scoundrels Robert Hamer's roguish British comedy from 1960 gets a hipster remake from Todd Phillips (''Starsky & Hutch''). Jon Heder is the New York City loser who signs up with a mysterious life coach (Billy Bob Thornton) for instruction in the fine art of getting his own way. With Jacinda Barrett, Sarah Silverman, David Cross and Michael Clarke Duncan. Wondrous Oblivion An 11-year-old English boy begins learning the skills of cricket from the Jamaican family that has moved in next door, but his new friendships run up against the anti-immigrant sentiments of Britain in the 1960's. Paul Morrison wrote and directed; with Delroy Lindo and Emily Woof. Sept. 30 The Queen After playing Elizabeth I for HBO last year, Helen Mirren returns as her 21st-century sequel, Elizabeth II. Directed by Stephen Frears, the drama centers on the aftermath of Princess Diana's death, as the queen battles Tony Blair (Michael Sheen) over the appropriate degree of national mourning. James Cromwell is Prince Philip; Sylvia Syms as the Queen Mother. This film opens the New York Film Festival on Sept. 29. Scissors And Saws, Hit Men And Spies October Oct. 4 The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning -- Little Leatherface and how he grew, in a prequel to the 2003 remake of the 1974 horror film. With Jordana Brewster and Taylor Handley; Jonathan Liebesman directs. Wrestling with Angels: Playwright Tony Kushner A portrait of this New York playwright and social activist by the Oscar-winning documentarist Freida Lee Mock (''Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision''). Oct. 6 Alex Rider: Operation Stormbreaker The first film adapted from Anthony Horowitz's series of spy novels for young readers, about a teenager who becomes an agent for MI6. Alex Pettyfer is the protagonist; the supporting cast includes pretty much every recognizable face in Britain: Bill Nighy, Andy Serkis, Stephen Fry, Ewan McGregor, etc., plus Mickey Rourke with some unusually nasty facial hair. Directed by Geoffrey Sax. The Departed Martin Scorsese directed this transposition of the Hong Kong hit ''Infernal Affairs'' to Boston. A rookie undercover cop (Leonardo DiCaprio) infiltrates the local mob, while a young mob recruit (Matt Damon) does the same at the Boston Police Department. With Jack Nicholson, Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen, Ray Winstone, Vera Farmiga and Alec Baldwin. [Article, Page 37.] Employee of the Month Jessica Simpson as a Costco clerk who is enlisted as the prize in an in-store productivity competition. With Dane Cook; Greg Coolidge directs. 49 Up Michael Apted's ongoing documentary series returns to the group of Britons he first profiled when they were 7. Little Children Classes cross and destinies intersect in still another version of the Sundance Institute's favorite script formula, this time set among young married couples in suburbia. Written and directed by Todd Field (''In the Bedroom''), who raided his Rolodex for Kate Winslet, Jennifer Connelly, Noah Emmerich, Patrick Wilson and Jackie Earle Haley. [Article, Page 39.] Shortbus John Cameron Mitchell's follow-up feature to ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch'' has been heralded by Variety as ''unquestionably the most sexually graphic American narrative feature ever made outside the realm of the porn industry.'' Meanwhile classes cross and destinies intersect among a group of frisky New Yorkers, including Paul Dawson, Sook-Yin Lee, Lindsay Beamish and Raphael Barker. Oct. 11 Running with Scissors When his emotionally unstable parents break up, young Augusten Burroughs (Joseph Cross) is handed over to his mother's eccentric psychiatrist (Brian Cox) to be raised as a member of his zany family. Ryan Murphy wrote and directed from Mr. Burroughs's best-selling memoir. With Annette Bening, Joseph Fiennes, Alec Baldwin and Jill Clayburgh. So Much, So Fast A 29-year-old diagnosed with the paralyzing neural disease A.L.S. learns to cope with his illness in a documentary directed by Steven Ascher and Jeanne Jordan (''Troublesome Creek''). Oct. 13 Copying Beethoven The relationship between the aging Ludwig van Beethoven (Ed Harris) and his 23-year-old copyist (Diane Kruger, the Helen of ''Troy'') in a film directed by the Polish veteran Agnieszka Holland. Driving Lessons The red-headed Rupert Grint, of the Harry Potter films, goes solo as a young man whose loyalties are divided between his devout Christian mother (Laura Linney) and a colorful former actress (Julie Walters) who wants to teach him how to live, live, live. Aren't the rights to ''Auntie Mame'' available anymore? Jeremy Brock wrote and directed. The Grudge 2 The mysterious force in a Tokyo house that terrorized Sarah Michelle Gellar two years ago now goes after her sister, played by Amber Tamblyn. Takashi Shimizu, director of both the Japanese original and the American remake, handled this sequel as well. Infamous Also known as ''the other Truman Capote movie,'' Douglas McGrath's film stars the British actor Toby Jones as the celebrated author on the scene in Kansas as he researches ''In Cold Blood.'' In this alternate universe, Sandra Bullock is Harper Lee, and Daniel Craig is Perry Smith. Man of the Year Robin Williams as a popular talk show radio host who winds up running for president. Barry Levinson directs, perhaps with another ''Wag the Dog'' in mind; the supporting cast includes Christopher Walken, Laura Linney, Lewis Black and Jeff Goldblum. The Marine A very large man (John Cena) returns from war to discover that his lady friend (Kelly Carlson) has been kidnapped. He does what he's got to do, in a thriller directed by John Bonito. Tideland A child of heroin-addicted parents (played by Jeff Bridges and Jennifer Tilly) finds refuge with her grandmother in the country but soon enough finds herself living in a Gothic fantasyland populated by headless dolls. Jodelle Ferland is the girl; Terry Gilliam directed, his commercial instincts clearly undiminished. Oct. 18 Justice The parallel worlds of Brazilian street criminals and the upper-class judges who determine their fate, explored in a documentary by Maria Ramos. Sweet Land A young German woman (Elizabeth Reaser) arrives in post-World War I Minnesota as a mail-order bride. Ali Selim here directs his first feature, a prizewinner at the Hamptons International Film Festival. With Lois Smith and Ned Beatty. Oct. 20 Flags of Our Fathers A two-tiered screenplay by Paul Haggis (''Crash'') and William Broyles Jr. compares the actual raising of the flag on Iwo Jima with the bond-selling tour the survivors were sent on after they became national heroes. Clint Eastwood directed; the cast includes Ryan Phillippe, Jesse Bradford, Paul Walker, Jamie Bell and Barry Petter. Flicka When Lassie returns, can Flicka be far behind? Alison Lohman is the adolescent girl who befriends a wild horse. Directed by Michael Mayer (''A Home at the End of the World''); with Maria Bello and Tim McGraw. Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple Stanley Nelson's documentary tells the story of the Jonestown settlement in Guyana, where 900 members of a religious cult committed suicide on Nov. 18, 1978. Killshot Witnesses to a mob killing, a working-class couple (Diane Lane and Thomas Jane) are pursued by a pair of unbalanced hit men (Mickey Rourke and Joseph Gordon-Levitt). A change of pace for the director John Madden, who generally prefers more literary fare (''Proof,'' ''Shakespeare in Love''). Laura Smiles A suburban housewife (Petra Wright) slips into manic depression in this independent film written and directed by Jason Ruscio. With Kip Pardue and Jonathan Silverman. Marie Antoinette Sofia Coppola's historical epic envisions the well-known last queen of France as a happy blonde teenager (Kirsten Dunst) who just wants to have fun. The largely French-free cast includes Jason Schwartzman as Louis XVI, Rip Torn as Louis XV and the heaving bosoms of Judy Davis, Rose Byrne, Asia Argento, Molly Shannon, Shirley Henderson and Marianne Faithfull. [Article, Page 44.] Nightmare before Christmas 3-D The tech-heads at Disney have come up with a way of turning Henry Selick and Tim Burton's revisionist Christmas story of 1993 into a three-dimensional experience. The Prestige Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale are rival stage illusionists in 19th-century London; one of them might be using real magic. Michael Caine, Scarlett Johansson, David Bowie and Andy Serkis lend support in this film by Christopher Nolan (''Batman Begins''). Sleeping Dogs lie Called ''Stay'' when it stirred up some controversy at this year's Sundance Film Festival, Bobcat Goldthwait's comedy concerns a young woman (Melinda Page Hamilton) who's unsure if she should reveal a sordid detail from her sexual past to her fiancé. 20 Centimeters From Spain, the story of a transvestite (Mónica Cervera) who dreams of becoming a transsexual, but she'll have to raise the money for the operation first. When she falls asleep, she dreams in old-fashioned production numbers. Ramón Salazar directed. Oct. 25 Exit ''Exit'' is the name of a Swiss organization that helps terminal patients end their lives, in the only country in the world in which euthanasia is legal. Fernand Melgar directs this documentary. Oct. 27 Absolute Wilson The avant-garde theater artist Robert Wilson is profiled in a documentary by Katharina Otto-Bernstein. Babel Classes cross and destinies intersect in October's third and, one hopes, final version of the Sundance Institute's favorite script formula, this time spread to an international scale (California, Morocco, Tokyo) by one of the formula's most stubborn practitioners, Alejandro González Iñárritu (''Amores Perros,'' ''21 Grams''). With Brad Pitt, Cate Blanchett, Gael García Bernal, Rinko Kikuchi and Adriana Barraza. [Article, Page 46.] The Bridge Eric Steel's documentary looks at why San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge draws not only tourists, but suicides. Filming the bridge ''almost every daylight minute'' for all of 2004, Mr. Steel and his crew captured almost two dozen successful suicides and several failures. Catch a Fire Phillip Noyce's film is based on the true story of Patrick Chamusso (Derek Luke), a worker at a South African oil refinery who becomes radicalized during the apartheid years. Tim Robbins is the government agent assigned to his case. With Bonnie Henna. [Article, Page 46.] Climates A prizewinner at this spring's Cannes Film Festival, this new feature by the Turkish filmmaker Nuri Bilge Ceylan is centered on a middle-aged professor (played by the director) whose relationship with a younger woman, a television producer (played by the director's wife, Ebru Ceylan) is collapsing. Cocaine Cowboys How the cocaine trade turned Miami Beach into ''Miami Vice.'' A documentary directed by Billy Corben. Conversations with God The life story of the best-selling religious writer Neale Donald Walsch, starring Henry Czerny and directed by Stephen Simon. Cruel World A reality-show loser sets up his own TV studio, where he records the grisly deaths of his former competitors. Kelsey T. Howard directed this penetrating look at today's media culture; with Edward Furlong, Jaime Pressly and Susan Ward. THE House of Adam A gay detective investigates the murder of his lover at the hands of religious fanatics. Jorge Ameer wrote and directed this independent production; with John Shaw, Lexi Karriker and Tiffany McFarland. Saw III Still hacking away, the moralizing serial killer Jigsaw returns for the third entry in the grisly horror series from Lionsgate. Darren Lynn Bousman directed, as he did ''Saw II.'' The Photographer's Eye, and Other Visions November Nov. 1 As the Call, So the Echo A physician from New Mexico, Alex Moreano, closes his practice and goes to work in a malaria-stricken district of Vietnam, in a documentary directed by his son, Keir Moreano. Nov. 3 Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan The British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen trades in his Ali G persona for that of a hopelessly naïve Kazakhstani television correspondent making a documentary about the United States. With Pamela Anderson as herself; Larry Charles (''Masked and Anonymous'') directs. Commune Jonathan Berman's documentary explores the history and significance of the Black Bear Ranch, a California commune founded in the early 1970's. The Flock The Hong Kong director Wai Keung Lau (also known as Andrew Lau) makes his American debut with a thriller about a veteran F.B.I. agent (Richard Gere) who must train his young replacement (Claire Danes) while he is searching for a sex killer. Mr. Lau is, with Siu Fai Mak, half the team behind ''Infernal Affairs,'' the 2002 thriller that Martin Scorsese has just remade as ''The Departed.'' Flushed Away What happens when a mouse from the posh London neighborhood of Kensington gets flushed down a toilet and emerges in an underworld called Ratropolis. David Bowers and Sam Fell directed this animated film from DreamWorks; with the voices of Kate Winslet, Hugh Jackman, Ian McKellen, Andy Serkis and Bill Nighy. The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause Tim Allen, back again as the middle-class dad who finds himself appointed Santa Claus to the world; this time he invites his in-laws (Alan Arkin and Ann-Margret) to visit him and his new family at the North Pole, unaware that the villainous Jack Frost (Martin Short) is planning an assault on Santa's holiday -- which, it is said, originally had some obscure religious significance. Directed by Michael Lembeck. A Soap In Pernille Fischer Christensen's Danish film, an unlikely love affair blooms between a pre-op male-to-female transsexual (David Dencik) and the attractive young woman who lives in the apartment upstairs. Volver Penélope Cruz as a Spanish single mom whose own mother (Carmen Maura) returns from the dead to give her a hand. Pedro Almódovar wrote and directed the film, which won two awards at Cannes in May. It will be the centerpiece of the New York Film Festival this month. [Article, Page 37.] Nov. 8 Iraq in Fragments James Longley's panoramic view of Iraq in the grip of conflict won three prizes at the 2006 Sundance festival. The Last Atomic Bomb A documentary profile of the Nagasaki survivor and antinuclear activist Sakue Shimohira. Robert Richter directs. Nov. 10 Cautiva An Argentine teenager discovers that the people she thinks are her parents adopted her after her real parents were ''disappeared'' during the dirty war of the 1980's. Gastón Biraben directs. Fur Nicole Kidman acting away as Diane Arbus, the photographer of the grotesque who committed suicide in 1971. With Robert Downey Jr., Ty Burrell, Jane Alexander and Harris Yulin; directed by Steven Shainberg (''Secretary''). God Grew Tired of Us The documentary maker Christopher Quinn followed three young men, refugees from Sudan, as they try to adjust to life in the United States. A Good Year The director Ridley Scott abandons warfare and special effects for an adaptation of Peter Mayle's novel about an Englishman (Russell Crowe, the star of Mr. Scott's ''Gladiator'') who inherits a vineyard in Provence. With Albert Finney, Marion Cotillard and Abbie Cornish. Harsh Times An Army veteran (Christian Bale) falls into a life of crime when he returns to his old neighborhood in Los Angeles; his best friend (Freddy Rodriguez) tries to help him. Written and directed by David Ayer, the screenwriter of ''Training Day.'' The Return An emotionally alienated young woman (Sarah Michelle Gellar) has a vision of a woman being killed, and gets the creepy feeling that she's next. Directed by Asif Kapadia. Stranger than Fiction The writer-director Marc Forster (''Monster's Ball'') drifts into Charlie Kaufman's metacomedy domain with the story of a Chicago I.R.S. auditor (Will Ferrell) who discovers he's the protagonist of a murder mystery being written by a reclusive, best-selling writer (Emma Thompson). With Maggie Gyllenhaal, Dustin Hoffman and Queen Latifah. Nov. 15 Dance Party, USA From Portland, Ore., Aaron Katz's Mini DV feature depicts a long night of conversation between a 17-year-old slacker and the girl he's drawn to at a Fourth of July fireworks display. Wild Tigers I Have Known A gay 13-year-old (Malcolm Stumpf) decides to act on his attraction to an older boy (Patrick White) by disguising himself as a girl. Cam Archer wrote and directed; Gus Van Sant is among the executive producers. Nov. 17 The Aura The second and, as it unfortunately turns out, final feature film from the Argentine director Fabián Bielinsky (''Nine Queens''), who died in June. Ricardo Darin stars as an epileptic taxidermist with the unlikely dream of committing a perfect crime. Bobby Emilio Estevez wrote and directed this panoramic look at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles on June 6, 1968, the day Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated there. A cameo-heavy cast seems to include everyone Mr. Estevez has ever met, including Anthony Hopkins, Lindsay Lohan, Elijah Wood, Helen Hunt, Sharon Stone, Laurence Fishburne, Shia La Beouf and Mr. Estevez's father, Martin Sheen. [Article, Page 46.] Candy Heath Ledger and Abbie Cornish are substance-abusing bohemians in an Australian film directed by Neil Armfield. With Geoffrey Rush as their enabler, a chemistry professor. Casino Royale Daniel Craig takes his baby steps as James Bond, in an adaptation of Ian Fleming's first Bond novel (previously filmed as a comedy and a television drama). Eva Green, of Bernardo Bertolucci's film ''The Dreamers,'' is the Bond Girl; the Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen is the villain, a banker secretly financing terrorist organizations. With Giancarlo Giannini, Judi Dench and Jeffrey Wright; Martin Campbell (''GoldenEye'') directs. Come Early Morning The actress Joey Lauren Adams (''Chasing Amy'') wrote and directed this semiautobiographical tale of a woman from a small town in the South (Ashley Judd, as if you had to ask) with commitment problems -- until the handsome Cal (Jeffrey Donovan) shows up. Fast Food Nation Richard Linklater's fictional adaptation of Eric Schlosser's 2001 study of the strange things that go into fast food stars Greg Kinnear as a marketing executive sent by his burger chain bosses to investigate some of the more disgusting rumors about a meat-packing plant. The cast includes Bobby Cannavale, Catalina Sandino Moreno, Patricia Arquette, Luis Guzmán, Ethan Hawke, Kris Kristofferson, Avril Lavigne, Wilmer Valderrama and Bruce Willis. [Article, Page 46.] Flannel Pajamas The ups and downs of a love affair between a talky New Yorker (Justin Kirk) and a moody Montanan (Julianne Nicholson), as rendered in an independent feature written and directed by Jeff Lipsky.For Your Consideration The satirist Christopher Guest turns his gimlet eye to the independent film scene, in a mockumentary about three actors who learn they're up for Academy Awards. The cast includes several of Mr. Guest's regulars: Jennifer Coolidge, Eugene Levy, Michael McKean, Catherine O'Hara, Harry Shearer, Fred Willard and himself. Happy Feet A tap-dancing penguin with the voice of Robin Williams. Not a horror film, but a computer animation from the reformed Australian action director George Miller (''Mad Max''). Other voices: Hugh Jackman, Elijah Wood, Nicole Kidman, Brittany Murphy. The Piano Tuner of Earthquakes The Quay Brothers, creators of stylish puppet animations (''Street of Crocodiles'') return with a new feature that includes human beings. It's a Gothic tale set in a secluded castle, where the piano tuner of the title has been invited to refurbish a collection of automatons. With Amira Casar and Gottfried John. Slow Burn A district attorney (Ray Liotta) finds himself with a problem on his hands when his first assistant (Jolene Blalock) confesses to killing a man in self-defense. But a number of other candidates (including LL Cool J and Mekhi Phifer) claim the killing themselves. Directed by Wayne Beach. Tenacious D in 'The Pick of Destiny' A showcase for the comedy rock band formed by Jack Black and Kyle Gass, who star as a pair of Venice Beach musicians on the trail of a magic guitar pick. Cameos include Tim Robbins, Ben Stiller, Colin Hanks, Amy Poehler and Meat Loaf. Liam Lynch directs. Nov. 22 Backstage A teenage girl from the French provinces becomes obsessed with a popular singer (Emmanuelle Seigner) and forces herself into the star's messy life. Emmanuelle Bercot directed. Deck the Halls A mild-mannered family man (Matthew Broderick) gets into a dangerous competition with his manic next-door neighbor (Danny DeVito) over who can build the biggest and gaudiest Christmas light display. John Whitesell (''Big Momma's House 2'') directed. Déjà Vu The director Tony Scott (''Man on Fire'') teams up with the producer Jerry Bruckheimer (''Pirates of the Caribbean'') for the tale of a shy intellectual who spends a snowbound night at the home of a beautiful artist discussing his reasons for not sleeping with her. Just kidding! It's about a federal agent (Denzel Washington) whose investigation of a bombing incident sends him on a trip back in time, where he falls in love with a mystery woman. With James Caviezel, Adam Goldberg, Bruce Greenwood and Val Kilmer. The Fountain An ambitious time-traveling romance from Darren Aronofsky, centered on a man (Hugh Jackman) who seems to be simultaneously a conquistador in search of the fountain of youth, a scientist with a strained marriage (to Rachel Weisz) and a spaceman traveling toward goals unknown. With Ellen Burstyn. The History Boys Alan Bennett expanded his play about a British teacher (Richard Griffiths) confronting a class of precocious undergraduates for this film version, directed by Nicholas Hytner. With Clive Merrison, Frances de la Tour and Stephen Campbell Moore. [Article, Page 40.] Let's Go to Prison Bob Odenkirk's high-concept comedy stars Dax Shepard as a wrongly imprisoned man who finds himself sharing a cell with the son (Will Arnett) of the judge who sent him up the river. Treks Around the World, and the Long Road Home December Dec. 1 The Architect A successful Chicago architect (Anthony LaPaglia) is led to re-examine his life when he meets an angry resident (Viola Davis) of a public housing complex he designed early in his career. With Isabella Rossellini and Hayden Panettiere. Bug In William Friedkin's film of Tracy Letts's off-Broadway play, a Southwestern bartender (Ashley Judd) hooks up with a paranoid drifter (Michael Shannon) who is convinced that he has legions of insects living under his skin. With Harry Connick Jr. The Nativity Story Catherine Hardwicke, director of ''Thirteen'' and ''Lords of Dogtown,'' takes on the biblical tale of Mary and Joseph's journey to Bethlehem. The casting of young Keisha Castle-Hughes (''Whale Rider'') as Mary suggests that Ms. Hardwicke is sticking to her adolescent angle; the script is by Mike Rich (''Finding Forrester''). 3 Needles Tales from the struggle against AIDS on three cultural fronts: in Africa a novice nun (Chloë Sevigny) tries to educate villagers in safe sex; in China a black-marketeer (Lucy Liu) collects illicit blood donations; in Canada a porn star (Shawn Ashmore) hides his occupation and his illness from his mother (Stockard Channing). Thom Fitzgerald wrote and directed. Turistas Backpacking teenagers run into trouble in a remote Brazilian rain forest. John Stockwell's thriller is the first release of Fox's new youth-oriented division, Fox Atomic. With Olivia Wilde and Josh Duhamel. Van Wilder Deux: Rise of the Taj Taj, the rocking South Asian played by Kal Penn in ''Van Wilder,'' moves to the center of the would-be franchise when he ships off to Oxford and teaches the uptight locals how to have a good time. Mort Nathan directs. Dec. 8 Apocalypto From the Oscar-winning producer-director Mel Gibson, the dying days of the Mayan empire as experienced by a young warrior (Rudy Youngblood) who flees when he's selected by tribal elders as a human sacrifice. [Article, Page 39.] Breaking and Entering This one looks like Anthony Minghella's version of the popular intersecting lives formula. It's set in an urban renewal area in London, where a successful landscape architect (Jude Law) tracks down the 15-year-old (Rafi Gavron) who has been breaking into his firm's new offices. The boy's mother turns out to be an attractive Bosnian refugee (Juliette Binoche) who provokes Mr. Law's character into reconsidering his rocky relationship with his Swedish lover (Robin Wright Penn). With Martin Freeman, Ray Winstone and Vera Farmiga.The Good German Another chameleon change for the director Steven Soderbergh, who here adapts Joseph Kanon's novel about an American reporter (George Clooney) and his search for his lost mistress in the rubble of postwar Berlin. With Cate Blanchett, Beau Bridges and Tobey Maguire. The Holiday The mistress of the chick flick, Nancy Meyers (''What Women Want''), returns with the story of a British woman and an American woman who swap homes in hopes of finding new lovers -- which is certainly the only way Cameron Diaz and Kate Winslet would ever attract male interest. With Jude Law, Jack Black, Rufus Sewell and Edward Burns. Unaccompanied Minors Kids stuck in a Chicago airport invent their own holiday celebration. Paul Feig directed; with Dyllan Christopher and Tyler James Williams. Dec. 15 The Blood Diamond Intrigue in Africa, as local and international interests compete for possession of a rare gem. With Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Connelly; Ed Zwick (''Legends of the Fall'') is the director. Eragon A farm boy in a mythical land departs on a heroic quest. Edward Speleers plays the title character; with Djimon Hounsou, Jeremy Irons and John Malkovich, directed by the visual effects specialist Stefen Fangmeier. Home of the Brave Irwin Winkler's film follows three soldiers as they try to adjust to life back home after a tour of duty in Iraq. With Samuel L. Jackson, Jessica Biel, 50 Cent and Christina Ricci. The Painted Veil W. Somerset Maugham's novel of European infidelity in China was good enough for Greta Garbo in 1934; now, it's Naomi Watts as the unhappy wife of a doctor (Edward Norton) who has an affair with a colonial official (Liev Schreiber). John Curran (''We Don't Live Here Anymore'') directs. Pride More inspirational sports, as a new coach (Tom Arnold) tries to persuade the troubled teenagers of his Philadelphia high school to join the swim team. With Kimberly Elise, Terrence Howard and Bernie Mac; Sunu Gonera directs. The Pursuit of Happyness The Italian filmmaker Gabriele Muccino (''L'ultimo Baccio'') makes his English-language debut with Steven Conrad's script about an impoverished former stock trader (Will Smith) who is given custody of his small child (played by Mr. Smith's son, Jaden). Through sheer determination he works his way back to Wall Street. Based on a ''60 Minutes'' segment. Venus The lives of two aging actors (Peter O'Toole and Leslie Phillips) are disrupted by the arrival of a young relative (Jodie Whittaker). Given that it's written by Hanif Kureishi and directed by Roger Michell (''The Mother''), it's got to be better than it sounds. Dec. 20 Charlotte's Web The E. B. White children's classic, about a spider and a pig who conspire to keep the latter off the Christmas dinner table. Dakota Fanning plays a live-action Fern; Julia Roberts lends her voice to a CGI Charlotte. Also to be heard: Oprah Winfrey, Steve Buscemi, Kathy Bates, John Cleese, Robert Redford and Thomas Haden Church; Gary Winick (''Tadpole'') directs. The Hoax The writer Clifford Irving (Richard Gere) attempts to pull off the literary hoax of the 20th century, peddling an ''autobiography'' of Howard Hughes that he actually wrote himself. Lasse Hallstrom directs from a script by William Wheeler; the ensemble cast includes Hope Davis, Julie Delpy, Alfred Molina and Marcia Gay Harden. Dec. 21 Dreamgirls The much-loved musical about a 1960's girl group, as filmed by Bill Condon (''Gods and Monsters''). With Jamie Foxx, Beyoncé Knowles, Eddie Murphy and Danny Glover. [Article, Page 40.] Dec. 22 Curse of the Golden Flower Zhang Yimou's latest historical pageant stars Chow Yun-Fat and Gong Li as imperial rulers who fight each other and their three sons for power. The martial-arts sequences, as they were in Mr. Zhang's ''House of Flying Daggers,'' are the work of Tony Ching Siu-Tung (''A Chinese Ghost Story''). Family Law Daniel Burman, the semiofficial chronicler of Buenos Aires's Jewish population (''The Lost Embrace''), wrote and directed this story of a middle-aged lawyer (Daniel Hendler) who must face up to the death of his father (Arturo Goetz). The Good Shepherd Robert De Niro directs for the first time since ''A Bronx Tale'' in 1993. Matt Damon stars as a Yale graduate who rises through the ranks of the increasingly paranoid C.I.A. in the 1950's. With Angelina Jolie, William Hurt, John Turturro, Alec Baldwin, Billy Crudup, Michael Gambon and Joe Pesci. [Article, Page 37.] Hurricane on the Bayou Meryl Streep narrates this documentary about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. Greg MacGillivray directs. A Night at the Museum When a security guard (Ben Stiller) accidentally invokes an ancient spell, the exhibits at a natural history museum -- both dinosaurs and dioramas -- come to life. He teams up with a wax figure of Teddy Roosevelt (Robin Williams) to tame the chaos. The extensive cameo opportunities do not go neglected by the director, Shawn Levy: Ernest Borgnine, Steve Coogan, Ricky Gervais, Ed Helms, Dick Van Dyke and Owen Wilson join in the zaniness. Notes on a Scandal What happens when an art teacher at a British public school (Cate Blanchett) has an affair with a 15-year-old student (Andrew Simpson). Richard Eyre directed from Patrick Marber's adaptation of a novel by Zoe Heller. With Dame Judi Dench and Bill Nighy. Rocky Balboa In which America's favorite punch-drunk fighter (Sylvester Stallone) attempts the ultimate comeback: another sequel after a gap of 16 years. For those who are counting, it's the sixth in the series, which began in 1976. With Burt Young and Milo Ventimiglia; Mr. Stallone writes and directs. We Are Marshall A small town in West Virginia struggles to cope with the death of 75 members of the local university's football team and coaching staff in an airplane accident. Matthew McConaughey is the new coach who steps in to keep the program going. With David Strathairn, Anthony Mackie and Ian McShane; directed by McG. Dec. 25 Black Christmas Another remake of a 1970's horror film, in which the scantily clad residents of a sorority house are terrorized by a mysterious killer. With Michelle Trachtenberg, Lacey Chabert and Andrea Martin; Glen Morgan directs. Children of Men The gifted Mexican filmmaker Alfonso Cuarón (''Y Tu Mamá También'') tries his hand at science fiction. It's 2027, and the human race has lost the ability to reproduce, except for one woman (Julianne Moore) who finds herself inexplicably pregnant. Clive Owen is her protector. With Michael Caine, Chiwetel Ejiofor and Charlie Hunnam. Dec. 29 Miss Potter Beatrix Potter, that is. The author of the Peter Rabbit stories is played by Renée Zellweger in this part animated, part live-action film from the director Chris Noonan, who made the original ''Babe'' in 1995. With Ewan McGregor and Emily Watson. Pan's Labyrinth Hiding from the harsh reality of the Spanish Civil War raging around her, a little girl (Ivana Baquero) finds refuge -- of a sort -- in a fantasy involving mythical creatures who live beneath her garden. Shot in Spain by the Mexican director Guillermo del Toro (''Hellboy''); with Sergi López and Maribel Verdú. 2007: A Double Feature, Sequels and God April 6 Grind House The 42nd Street double feature experience, as re-created by Quentin Tarantino (who contributes a slasher movie parody, ''Death Proof'') and Robert Rodriguez (the science-fiction spoof ''Planet Terror''). With Rosario Dawson, Jeff Fahey, Rose McGowan and Danny Trejo. May 4 Spider-Man 3 The sensitive superhero (Tobey Maguire) goes up against the Sandman (Thomas Haden Church). With James Franco, Kirsten Dunst, Topher Grace, Bryce Dallas Howard and Theresa Russell. Sam Raimi directs. May 18 Shrek the Third The affable animated ogre with the voice of Mike Myers goes looking for a new king when Princess Fiona's father dies. Directed by Chris Miller and Raman Hui; with the voices of Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz, Julie Andrews and Antonio Banderas. May 25 Pirates of the Caribbean 3: At World's End Chow Yun-Fat, as a Chinese captain, joins Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, Keira Knightley, Geoffrey Rush and Bill Nighy in the final installment of the hyperactive franchise. Gore Verbinski directs. June 15 Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer Part 2 of this modestly scaled superhero franchise has the four super teammates (Ioan Gruffudd, Jessica Alba, Chris Evans and Michael Chiklis) run up against the Silver Surfer (Doug Jones). Tim Story directs. June 22 Evan Almighty In this sequel to ''Bruce Almighty,'' Morgan Freeman is still God, but this time he grants his powers to a starving Sudanese woman -- sorry, make that another white American male (Steve Carell), a Congressman whom God commands to build an ark. With Lauren Graham, John Goodman and Wanda Sykes; Tom Shadyac directs.

HE sits in his wheelchair as the family rushes around him. He cannot move much, or say more than hello. He cannot participate in the summer activities that everyone pursues with great vigor day after day. If it's warm enough, he goes out onto the deck and snoozes in the sun with the dogs. Unlike them, however, he doesn't jump up and make excited noises when people come. At most, he slowly turns his head and smiles. Everyone speaks to him politely, but not for long. What's the point? He can't say more than a couple of words, and it's hard to tell how much he understands. He is my stepfather, Peter, an 88-year-old man who in the last decade has been transformed from a lively and dynamic person into not much more than a body occupying space. He has post-polio syndrome, a condition that seeps the strength from his upper body as steadily as it weakened his legs when he was a teenager. A couple of strokes have further debilitated him. As my son, Asher, said to my mother one day, it's as if he's hardly a person anymore.

Dr. Staci Raeleen Eisenberg, the daughter of Diane and Donald Eisenberg of Seal Beach, Calif., was married last evening to Seth Barney Kosto, a son of Gale and Dr. Bernard Kosto of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jeremy S. Morrison officiated at Mount Hope Farm in Bristol, R.I. The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She completed a residency at the Harvard combined internal medicine-pediatrics program in Boston in June. She graduated cum laude from Princeton and received her medical degree from the University of Chicago. Her father is a lawyer in Long Beach, Calif. Her mother is the associate coordinator of the Learning Assistance Center at California State University, Long Beach.

The Media Frenzy column last Sunday, about the business challenges facing Time Warner, misspelled the given name of the chairwoman and chief executive of its Time Inc. unit, and omitted her middle initial. She is Ann S. Moore, not Anne.

All in the Family Moises Alou of the Giants, above, is closing in on 2,000 hits (1,983). In the Alou family, that ranks him second to his father, Felipe, who ended his career with 2,101 hits, and ahead of his uncles Matty (1,777) and Jesús (1,216). Streaks to Watch Ichiro Suzuki of Seattle, with 187 hits, and Michael Young of Texas, with 189, are trying to keep their streaks of consecutive 200-hit seasons alive. Suzuki has done it five straight seasons and Young three. Todd Helton of Colorado, who is hitting .302, is trying for his ninth consecutive season with at least a .300 average. Closing In on Record Trevor Hoffman of the Padres, above, is five saves from tying Lee Smith's career record of 478. Last month, Hoffman did not allow a run and converted all seven of his save opportunities. San Diego is scheduled to play 15 of its remaining 21 games on the road. Extra Bases With three hits Friday night, including a double and a triple, Grady Sizemore of the Indians became the fifth player since 1900 with at least 50 doubles, 10 triples and 20 home runs in the same season. THE WATCH LIST With Ben Broussard traded to Seattle, Ryan Garko figured to be the Indians' first baseman next season. But Kevin Kouzmanoff, below, hit .379 with 22 home runs in Class AA and Class AAA this season to earn a promotion this month. He hit a grand slam in his first big-league at-bat and homered the next day. Three terrible starts at Class AAA Norfolk last season might have proved to the Mets that Yusmeiro Petit's phenomenal statistics in the low minors did not match the reality of his ability. The Marlins are learning that the hard way. Petit turned in a mediocre season at Class AAA Albuquerque, and in 12 major league games, mostly in relief, he has an earned run average over 8.00. The left-hander JOSH OUTMAN, one of the pitching prospects who led Lakewood into the Class A South Atlantic League playoffs, could not earn a call-up after compiling a 7-1 record and a 1.93 E.R.A. in his past 10 starts. But if he ever does join the Phillies, he will have the best name of any pitcher in the majors. Statistics through Friday. Sources: MLB.com, STATS LLC

GLAZER--Ruth, a musician, teacher, and arts administrator with an indomitable spirit, determination and humor, died Thursday. She was 95 and resided in Topsham, ME. As a soprano she performed as a soloist with the Boston Symphony, the Dallas Symphony, and many more. She taught at Vassar College and Bennett College. She was Associate Professor and Concert Manager at Eastman School of Music. She has been married since 1952 to Frank Glazer, a concert pianist. She ''retired'' in 1979 to Maine where she founded several concert series that continue to thrive. She also was a member of the Maine Arts Commission. Her work was always marked by boundless energy, high standards, and the abIlity to get others to do the seemingly impossible. She is survived by her husband, Frank; three nephews, Frederick, Peter, and Geoffrey Gevalt; and five grandnieces and nephews. Plans for a memorial service are incomplete. Donations may be made to the Ruth Glazer Scholarship Fund at Portland Conservatory of Music in Portland, ME.

NORRIS--Frank A., passed away September 4, 2006 after a 12 year battle with multiple myeloma and AML. A native Fire Islander and dedicated member of the Ocean Beach community, Frank remained active in community affairs and with the Ocean Beach Association until the time of his death. Frank, a Korean War veteran, was a retired Con Edison executive and aerospace engineer holding patents for the guidance systems of rockets while employed by the Singer Company during the late '60's. Survived by his wife Doris Wolin, his children Linda Norris Stertz, Frank S. and Christopher, daughter-n-law Eva, stepchildren Lauree Wolin Mitchell and James Wolin, grandchildren Zachary, Nicholas, Brian, Jared, Tristan, and granddaughter - in - law Zoe Salzman. Memorial service will be announced. Should you wish, please make donations to the International Myeloma Foundation in lieu of flowers.

Boston: List price: $749,000, Bedrooms: 4, Bathrooms: 2.5, Interior: 2,700 sq. ft., Lot size: 0.15 acre, Date built: 1890 The star feature of this Queen Anne Victorian in the residential hilltop neighborhood of Ashmont Hill is the ''Zen master suite'' on the third floor. The bedroom and bathroom were redone with bamboo laminate floors and ipe wood, and the bathroom includes a 42-inch soaking tub for two people. The house is a mix of the old and the new; the kitchen is unrenovated, though the house does have all new pipes and electric wiring. The Ashmont T stop is only a few minutes away.

SCHNEIDER--Ethel Jane. Beloved wife of Julius (deceased). Mother of Steven, Ann, Faye and Jeffrey. Friend of Henry and Tina. Grandmother to twelve grandchildren. Sister of Selma and Bill. Teacher, toy store owner and realtor. Our loss is immeasurable. We will cherish your memory forever. Funeral services 12:30 PM, Sunday, September 10th, at Boulevard Riverside, Hewlett. Shiva at 6 Brandwood Drive, Dix Hills, after interment on Sunday, and at 4 Diana's Circle, Roslyn Estates, on Monday and Tuesday.

HE sits in his wheelchair as the family rushes around him. He cannot move much, or say more than hello. He cannot participate in the summer activities that everyone pursues with great vigor day after day. If it's warm enough, he goes out onto the deck and snoozes in the sun with the dogs. Unlike them, however, he doesn't jump up and make excited noises when people come. At most, he slowly turns his head and smiles. Everyone speaks to him politely, but not for long. What's the point? He can't say more than a couple of words, and it's hard to tell how much he understands. He is my stepfather, Peter, an 88-year-old man who in the last decade has been transformed from a lively and dynamic person into not much more than a body occupying space. He has post-polio syndrome, a condition that seeps the strength from his upper body as steadily as it weakened his legs when he was a teenager. A couple of strokes have further debilitated him. IT may have left no physical damage in its wake, but the recent communal storm in this oceanfront city over the future of its beaches has realigned the political and environmental landscape. Despite fears about the city's vulnerability to a major hurricane, the five-member City Council, three Democrats and two Republicans, voted unanimously in May to reject a $98.5 million beach preservation project by the Army Corps of Engineers that was designed to protect Long Beach from ocean flooding.

To the Editor: ''The Summer Next Time,'' Tom Lutz's interesting and clever Sept. 4 Op-Ed article, identifies one of the major reasons that college professor is a very popular occupation in spite of a poor years-of-education-to-income ratio -- a flexible work schedule. But an arguably more important reason is that a tenured professor is just about the only remaining position that provides a high degree of employment security.

The ''In the Region'' article last Sunday about apartments on the New Jersey waterfront with views of Manhattan misstated the prices of units at Hudson Park in Edgewater relative to New York City properties. They are priced at roughly half what a comparable property in Manhattan would cost; they are not roughly equal.

A review on Aug. 27 about ''Selected Letters of Martha Gellhorn,'' edited by Caroline Moorehead, misstated the given name of the Roosevelt aide for whom Gellhorn wrote a series of reports about the Depression. He was Harry Hopkins, not Harold.

DUMPED into theaters as an exploitation cheapie in 1968, this lyrical thriller is a minor American classic. As Dennis, a young man trying to get his feet on the ground after being released from a reformatory, Anthony Perkins, right, gives perhaps his richest performance, certainly his most touching. Just as Perkins was trying to leave behind the juvenile roles that had typecast him, Dennis, a basically decent fellow, is trying to become an adult. But even when he succeeds in hiding his past, he can't resist playing the smart aleck or slipping into a world of make-believe. Dennis persuades the town golden girl Sue Ann (Tuesday Weld, right) to slip into that world with him. The twist is that she's every bit the psychopath people assume Dennis is. And since she's bored with the small town and hates her mother, she's ready for anything. Lorenzo Semple Jr.'s screenplay is beautifully worked out, and the director, Noel Black, does a superb job of modulating the film's conflicting elements: the coming-of-age story and the thriller. Sensitive and unsettling, ''Pretty Poison'' at times suggests a smaller-scale version of ''Splendor in the Grass,'' without the Freudian gush. And when violence breaks out in the suburban setting, Mr. Black plays it straight, not for the cheap irony that won so much praise for Terrence Malick's phony, condescending ''Badlands.''

FOR failing to meet performance standards, the Clara T. O'Connell elementary school in Bristol, Conn., spent three years on the ''in need of improvement'' list under the federal No Child Left Behind program. When a new list came out last month, Connecticut had 290 elementary and middle schools on it, but the O'Connell School was not among them. It had achieved what no other school in the state had managed under the four-year-old program: It had worked itself off the list.

DEEP into suburbia, on a sound barrier that runs along the Taconic State Parkway here, a graffiti artist announces his presence with a single word painted in yellow and black: ''Me.'' Officials said that graffiti had reached new heights this summer. And in a town that bills itself as a retreat from more urban locales, politicians and police officers are taking the problem seriously.

A chart with an article last Sunday about research-and-development spending around the world did not label such spending by three countries: the United States, Japan and Germany. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/yourmoney.

CALLING it a Monday massacre may be a bit melodramatic, but last Monday was not a good day for pitchers trying to become 20-game winners. Steve Trachsel of the Mets, Carlos Zambrano of the Cubs and Jason Marquis of the Cardinals pitched for their 15th victories, and all lost. Curt Schilling, also with 14 victories, was supposed to pitch but did not because of an ailing shoulder. Winning that day was critical to those pitchers because they would have five starts at most the rest of the season, and 14 plus 5 does not equal 20.

GREENOUGH--Peter B. , on September 6th, 2006. Beloved husband of 49 years of Beverly Sills. Loving father of Lindley, Nancy, Diana, Meredith and Peter, Jr. and grandfather of Allyson and Geoffrey. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the New York City Chapter of the Multiple Sclerosis Society. Funeral private. $(6$)GREENOUGH--Peter B. The members and volunteers of the New York City Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society extend our hearfelt condolences to the family of Peter B. Greenough, and especially to our very dear friend and Trustee, Beverly Sills Greenough, on the loss of her husband, and our dear friend and volunteer, Meredith (Muffy) Greenough on the loss of her father. Beverly's exceptional devotion to Peter and her total commitment to his well being was an inspiration to us all. $(6$)GREENOUGH -- Peter. The Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of the March of Dimes mourn the passing of our esteemed volunteer, Peter B. Greenough. Together with Beverly Sills, his wife and fellow member of the National Board of Trustees, Peter had a remarkable record of service to our mission to save babies from birth defects, premature birth and other causes of infant death and disability. Peter was a member of the Board from 1974 to 1988 and later served as an Honorary Trustee. He was the first chairman of the March of Dimes Bioethics Committee, created in 1975, and served in that position until 1990; he continued to be active on the panel until 1993. Miss Sills, who began as a volunteer for the Mothers March in 1971, rose to become Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1991 to 1994. Peter's dedication and guidance were incalculable to our organization and he will be greatly missed. We send our deepest condolences to the entire family. James E. Sproull, Jr., Esq. Chairman, Board of Trustees Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D. President March of Dimes $(6$)GREENOUGH--Peter B. HE sits in his wheelchair as the family rushes around him. He cannot move much, or say more than hello. He cannot participate in the summer activities that everyone pursues with great vigor day after day. If it's warm enough, he goes out onto the deck and snoozes in the sun with the dogs. Unlike them, however, he doesn't jump up and make excited noises when people come. At most, he slowly turns his head and smiles. Everyone speaks to him politely, but not for long. What's the point? He can't say more than a couple of words, and it's hard to tell how much he understands. He is my stepfather, Peter, an 88-year-old man who in the last decade has been transformed from a lively and dynamic person into not much more than a body occupying space. He has post-polio syndrome, a condition that seeps the strength from his upper body as steadily as it weakened his legs when he was a teenager. A couple of strokes have further debilitated him. As my son, Asher, said to my mother one day, it's as if he's hardly a person anymore.

Some tourists bring home postcards or trinkets as souvenirs from a trip. Laura Burkhalter and William Ki brought home a yurt. Entranced by the felt-and-cotton tents that have sheltered generations of Mongolians on the steppes, they erected the yurt last year on an empty lot they owned in Los Angeles, and began using it as a retreat from their Hollywood apartment. The couple imported 14 more yurts, though a small one can weigh 500 pounds, and now sell them for between $3,500 and $21,500 (not including shipping) through their Web site, www.vishai.com.

LUNAR PARK, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.95.) Ellis's phantasmagorical tale is narrated by a writer -- named Bret Easton Ellis -- whose first novel, ''Less Than Zero,'' made him a literary celebrity in the 1980's. Leaving behind the shallow glitter of Manhattan, Bret strikes out for the suburbs, marries the movie-star mother of his son and plods through a teaching job at a local college. But bourgeois malaise turns to terror when Bret is stalked by the ghost of his alcoholic father and by his infamous creation, the deranged Patrick Bateman of ''American Psycho.'' In the Book Review, A. O. Scott called ''Lunar Park'' a ''tale of wild chemical and sexual excess'' that is ''shot through with longing.''

G. W. PABST'S tragic fable, from two plays by Frank Wedekind about a prostitute whose love for -- and conquest of -- a married man begins her spiral of decline, is one of the most beautifully filmed of all silent movies. Pabst's unobtrusive but masterly compositions and disarmingly delicate lighting effects are the stuff of rapture. Then again, when Louise Brooks, above, is your star, it's your duty to place her in a context of perfection. Brooks plays the doomed, exquisite Lulu, who, with her sable bob and mischievous, calculating smile, became an enduring symbol of jazz-age freedom and joyousness. If beauty and saucy charm were all Brooks had to offer, she would have ended up a caricature. But this performance is so vital and so infinitely shaded that it inspires wonder each time you see it. Brooks's Lulu is an image of relaxed modernity: she may be willful, petulant and manipulative, but she is also a woman striding toward an uncertain future in a world that doesn't provide easy comforts.

FOR me, last winter was the end of the affair with oil. My stocky furnace, grunting and firing in the basement, guzzled its way through four thousand dollars' worth. I decided I would no longer slake its fueloholic thirst, even at the summer lock-in price of just under $3 a gallon. ''Lock in to lunacy,'' I thought. Oil has become the liquid gold we long suspected. So I must balance my budget with my fear of the unknown: wood stoves.

Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy chief and Ali Larijani, Iran's top nuclear negotiator, said Saturday that they would continue last-ditch negotiations on Sunday in Vienna to see how far Iran would go to meet United Nations Security Council demand that it freeze its uranium-enrichment program or risk sanctions. Christina Gallach, Mr. Solana's spokeswoman, told reporters that the three hours of talks on Saturday had been ''positive and constructive.'' Mr. Larijani said, ''We had some good and constructive talks, we made some progress in some areas, and we shall continue tomorrow.''

IN the 50 years he has lived in Montclair, N.J., Rob Bianco has seen his share of monsoon-like downpours, blizzards, ice storms, even the remnants of hurricanes. But Mr. Bianco, the superintendent of public works for Montclair, had never seen anything like the storm that ravaged the leafy landscape of his hometown on July 18.

To the Editor: Re ''Staining the Land Forever,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Sept. 5), lays bare an appalling and systematic attack on our public lands and reveals that President Bush's failure to continue a bipartisan tradition to protect the American wilderness is no oversight. Although fear for the future is both understandable and warranted, it is too early to mourn for our wild lands. Rather than grieve, concerned citizens can join the burgeoning counterattack in their defense.

HOROWITZ--Martha, be loved wife of the late Dr. Felix, beloved mother of Lenore (David Forsted) and Lawrence I., wonderful grandmother to Hilary (Mitchell), Adam, Ben and Rona, great grandmother of Abigail Rose. Dear sister of Jean Weiner. Shiva will be observed at her children's homes.

The International Astronomical Union all but threatened to go out on strike last month unless the rest of the solar system ejected an errant, puny member from the exclusive planets' club. Thus, on the vote of a few residents of the hegemonic planet Earth, Pluto -- a celestial body whose only crime was to dare to wander in orbit to the beat of a different drummer -- was stripped of its 76-year-old classification. Pluto is now officially downgraded to a new category called dwarf planet, and all textbooks in all languages are ordered to refer to it with that adjectival derogation. World media, except a few unscientific sentimentalists (and the fictional Lois Lane's Daily Planet) are meekly complying.

New York's State Senate is planning a quick session in Albany on Friday, with an agenda that involves tidying up a few loose ends. That is always worrisome when it comes to New York's Legislature, especially in an election year. Gov. George Pataki, a Republican, is a lame duck, and it is possible that the Republican-led Senate will suddenly decide to confirm a lot of Mr. Pataki's appointments to lard up the state government before the executive branch changes hands. Bad idea. Voters should be alert to such mischief, while they hope for something better from Albany's upper house. There are a number of good bills that have already passed the Assembly, which the Senate could speed to Mr. Pataki's desk:

The State Department of Transportation has presented Waterbury officials with two plans for replacing the multidecked junction of Interstate 84, Route 8 and local roads, better known as the Mixmaster, in the city's downtown. Carmine P. Trotta, an assistant planning director at the department's Division of Intermodal Planning, said the plans were presented on Aug. 30.

To the Editor: Theater is not simply a forum for ideas. It is a forum for characters -- human beings and their hopes and disappointments, joys and pains. If they learn lessons, experience emotions, gain insights into questions larger than themselves and communicate those insights to an audience, it has a much greater effect on that audience than any political diatribe, no matter how brilliant. If you want polemics, read the editorial page. Robert Sevra Manhattan

IT may have left no physical damage in its wake, but the recent communal storm in this oceanfront city over the future of its beaches has realigned the political and environmental landscape. Despite fears about the city's vulnerability to a major hurricane, the five-member City Council, three Democrats and two Republicans, voted unanimously in May to reject a $98.5 million beach preservation project by the Army Corps of Engineers that was designed to protect Long Beach from ocean flooding.
