To the Editor: Re ''Stealth Students Test Tolerance of the Affluent,'' by Joseph Berger (column, Aug. 27): As a school social worker for 25 years, I have encountered creative, unbelievable but sometimes lifesaving excuses from parents who register their children in a neighboring town's school district. I would hardly label these children stealth students; rather they are often survivors of unsavory home circumstances.

Dates are subject to change. September NEW YORK MUSICAL THEATER FESTIVAL A version of a Greek tragedy for the preschool set (''Oedipus for Kids,'' with songs like ''A Little Complex'' -- get it?) and a musical look at the Kitty Genovese murder are only two of the more than 30 full productions of new musicals that this ambitious festival will present. Opens today. Through Oct. 1. Various locations. TheaterMania; nymf.org. THE TREATMENT Eve Ensler, who explored the female anatomy in ''The Vagina Monologues'' and ''The Good Body,'' is likely to explore the politics of torture with the same intimacy and anger. The actors Dylan McDermott and Portia play a traumatized military interrogator and the military psychologist assigned to conduct his therapy. Leigh Silverman directs. In previews. Opens Tuesday. First production in the Impact Festival 2006 (see below). Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street, East Village. Ticketmaster; impactfestival.org. THE BIRTHDAY PARTY Emily Mann, the artistic director of the McCarter Theater, revives Harold Pinter's first full-length play, set in a seaside boardinghouse, with Allan Corduner, a Mike Leigh regular. Poor Stanley, an irritable concert pianist, can't escape Mr. Pinter's menacing hoods, however hard he tries. The critics of the original 1958 production found it baffling, but compared with the author's later work, it's as clear as a spring day. In previews. Opens Friday. Through Oct. 15. McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place, Princeton, N.J., (609) 258-2787; www.mccarter.org. RICHARD II Michael Cumpsty was the melancholy Dane for the director Brian Kulick last season. In this one he is Shakespeare's doomed British monarch. In previews. Opens Sept. 17. Through Oct. 15. Classic Stage Company, 136 East 13th Street, East Village. TheaterMania; classicstage.org. THE PAIN AND THE ITCH Jayne Houdyshell, a Tony nominee last season for ''Well,'' returns in Bruce Norris's satire of the politics of class and race, as one family's Thanksgiving dinner goes awry. The play comes from the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago. Anna D. Shapiro directs. In previews. Opens Sept. 21. Through Oct. 8. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; playwrightshorizons.org. JOHN FERGUSON The intrepid Mint Theater Company has a knack for finding small masterpieces in the attic of American drama. Its first production of the season is a 1919 play by St. John Ervine, set in an Irish farmhouse in which a poor farmer awaits salvation via the mail boat from America. Martin Platt directs. The play was a success when it was presented in 1919 in New York by the young Theater Guild. With this production the Mint begins a three-year celebration of the renowned guild. In previews. Opens Sept. 25. Through Oct. 15. Mint Theater Company, 311 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 315-0231; minttheater.org. SUBURBIA Eric Bogosian has revisited and updated his 1994 play about a group of angry, unhappy Americans in their early 20's who hang out in front of a convenience store owned by Pakistani immigrants. It ain't ''Clerks 2'' by a long shot. Jo Bonney directs. In previews. Opens Sept. 28. Through Oct. 29. Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422; secondstagetheatre.com. IMPACT FESTIVAL 2006 As part of its 10th anniversary, the Culture Project will present an arts festival of more than 50 events throughout New York City focusing on human rights and political action. Theatrical works include ''Six Actors in Search of a Plot'' by the Palestinian writer Mohammed El-Thayer, the premiere of a political cabaret called ''Mental Missiles'' by Elizabeth Swados and a stage adaptation of Howard Zinn and Anthony Arnove's book ''Voices of a People's History of the United States.'' Opens Tuesday. Through Oct. 22. Various sites. SmartTix, TheaterMania; impactfestival.org. SAM SHEPARD FESTIVAL You've got to hand it to the Michael Chekhov Theater Company: all of Sam Shepard's 40-plus plays in a little less than two years? What are they thinking? But based on their revival of ''A Lie of the Mind'' last season, prospects for this new downtown theater are excellent. The full-length ''Shaved Splits,'' ''Seduced'' and ''Unseen Hand'' are due later this season. The immediate double bill is ''Forensic and the Navigators'' and ''States of Shock.'' Opens Wednesday. Through Oct. 6. The Big Little Theater, 141 Ridge Street, Lower East Side. SmartTix; chekhovtheatre.com. BIRTH AND AFTER BIRTH This 1972 play by Tina Howe (''Painting Churches''), an absurdist look at family matters and child rearing, didn't have its official premiere until 1995. Now it reaches New York for the first time. Christian Parker directs. Previews begin Wednesday. Opens Oct. 3. Through Oct. 29. Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. Telecharge; atlantictheater.org. THE DIFFICULTY OF CROSSING A FIELD Mac Wellman contributed the libretto and David Lang (''Bang on a Can'') the music for this chamber opera, an adaptation of an Ambrose Bierce short story set on a plantation in the post-Civil War South and presented by the ambitious Peak Performances in association with the Ridge Theater. With Jay O. Sanders. Bob McGrath directs. Sept. 14-17. Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, Montclair, N.J., (973) 655-5112; peakperfs.org. HEARTBREAK HOUSE The Roundabout Theater Company has chosen what could be a witty season start: a revival of Shaw's Chekhovian fantasia set on an English country estate. Robin Lefevre directs a starry cast that includes Philip Bosco and Swoosie Kurtz. Previews begin Friday. Opens Oct. 11. Through Dec. 10. American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300; roundabouttheater.org. A CHORUS LINE ''Dance: 10; looks: 3''; Broadway productions: now 2; 1 singular sensation. Endlessly touring the universe since its 1975 premiere at the Public Theater, ''A Chorus Line'' is returning to Broadway. Has it really been more than a decade and a half since it closed in 1990? It's old-home week for many on the production team: the director, Bob Avian, choreographed the original show with Michael Bennett, who directed; Baayork Lee, who will restage the original choreography, originated the role of Connie in that first production; Theoni V. Aldredge will be tweaking her original costume designs; and the set designer, Robin Wagner, is back for an encore. Of the writers, expect only the composer, Marvin Hamlisch, at the opening-night party. Michael Bennett died in 1987, as did the show's lyricist, Edward Kleban. The book's two authors, James Kirkwood and Nicholas Dante, died in 1989 and 1991. This time Charlotte d'Amboise is Cassie and Michael Berresse is Zach. Previews begin Sept. 18. Opens Oct. 5. Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; achorusline.com. JAY JOHNSON: THE TWO AND ONLY! The ventriloquist Jay Johnson turned the cheery Edgar Bergen-Charlie McCarthy trope on its head when he played the disturbing Chuck-and-Bob in Susan Harris's groundbreaking television comedy ''Soap.'' This solo show, which had its premiere in 2004 at the Atlantic Theater, will probably be just as disturbingly funny. Created by Mr. Johnson, Murphy Cross and Paul Kreppel and directed by Ms. Cross and Mr. Kreppel. Previews begin Sept. 19. Opens Sept. 28. Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge, TheaterMania. NIXON'S NIXON The MCC Theater brings back Russell Lees's political satire for the 10th anniversary of the play's world premiere. Gerry Bamman and Steve Mellor recreate the roles of Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger in this imagined late-night conversation between the two men in which they try to fix their places in history. The stakes are high: it's the night before Nixon's resignation. Jim Simpson directs. Previews begin Sept. 20. Opens Oct. 4. Through Oct. 28. Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, Greenwich Village. Ticket Central; mcctheater.org. THE PRIME OF MISS JEAN BRODIE Cynthia Nixon is the outspoken Scottish teacher at a girls' school in the New Group's first production of its 11th season. Scott Elliott directs the Jay Presson Allen adaptation of the classic Muriel Spark novel. Previews begin Sept. 20. Opens Oct. 9. Through Nov. 11. Acorn Theater on Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; thenewgroup.org. LOSING LOUIE Matthew Arkin (''Moonlight and Magnolias'') and Mark Linn-Baker (''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'') are in the Manhattan Theater Club's production of Simon Mendes da Costa's comedy, fresh from its West End success in London. Two generations of a family thrash out their tensions in a single bedroom over a 50-year period. Jerry Zaks directs. Previews begin Sept. 21. Opens Oct. 12. Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; manhattantheatreclub.com. THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN' When Twyla Tharp last took on a contemporary singer-songwriter, she came up with ''Movin' Out,'' the dance-centric Billy Joel compilation that became an unlikely Broadway hit (and won her a Tony Award for choreography). Can she do the same for Bob Dylan? Broadway theatergoers will find out later this month. Previews begin Sept. 25. Opens Oct. 26. Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Ticketmaster; timestheyareachangin.com. WRECKS How does Neil LaBute do it? Is the man a machine? Ed Harris stars in what must be the prolific playwright's millionth play, which promises, according to the press release, ''to thrill, surprise and challenge your assumptions about love, family and marriage.'' The solo show was first produced last winter at the Everyman Palace Theater in Cork, Ireland, also starring Mr. Harris. Mr. LaBute directs. Previews begin Sept. 26. Opens Oct. 10. Through Oct. 29. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; publictheater.org. KING LEAR André De Shields rages against his daughters specifically and fate generally as the first Lear of the season. (Kevin Kline's is expected at the Public Theater in the spring.) Here Mr. De Shields has the excellent Classical Theater of Harlem behind him. Alfred Preisser directs. A production with the Folger Theater in Washington. Sept. 29-Nov. 5. HSA Theater, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street, Hamilton Heights. SmartTix. classicaltheatreofharlem.org. (Performances at the Folger Theater: Jan. 11-Feb. 18, 201 East Capitol Street SE , Washington, 202-544-7077; folger.edu.) October HELL HOUSE Les Freres Corbusier is at it again. After slyly sending up the Church of Scientology in ''A Very Merry Unauthorized Children's Scientology Pageant,'' the experimental troupe has mischievously recreated a Hell House, as some evangelical Christians envision them at Halloween. Instead of goblins and ghosts, tableaus show young people tortured in hell for homosexuality, abortion or suicide on earth. The troupe will transform St. Ann's Warehouse for the run. Previews begin Oct. 1. Opens Oct. 10. Through Oct. 29. 38 Water Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779; artsatstanns.org or lesfreres.org. (The ''Children's Scientology Pageant'' will be revived from Nov. 29 to Jan. 7 at the Fourth Street Theater, 83 East Fourth Street, East Village. Telecharge.) EVIL DEAD: THE MUSICAL All-singing, all-dancing, all-zombie, this musicalization of the Sam Raimi series of horror films promises to give new meaning to the phrase ''summer camp.'' We'll have to see if songs like ''All the Men in My Life Keep Getting Killed by Candarian Demons'' are featured in the next Tony Awards telecast. The directors are Christopher Bond and Hinton Battle (who has won three Tony Awards for outstanding featured actor in a musical), the book and lyrics by George Reinblatt and the music by Mr. Bond, Mr. Reinblatt, Frank Cipolla and Melissa Morris. Living, dead and undead alike choreographed by Mr. Battle. Previews begin Oct. 2. Opens Nov. 1. New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; evildeadthemusical.com. THE TOOTH OF CRIME The director George Ferencz revives his acclaimed 1983 production of Sam Shepard's rock 'n' roll drama, here staged as (appropriately) a rock 'n' roll concert, in celebration of the 45th birthday of La MaMa E.T.C., where this production was first staged. At Mr. Shepard's request this will be the final production to be based on the original version of the text, which he has recently revised. Previews begin Oct. 3. Opens Oct. 5. Through Oct. 22. La MaMa E.T.C. Annex, 66 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710; lamama.org. Grey Gardens The smash-hit Playwrights Horizons musical transfers to Broadway. First they were the eccentric cousins of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, then the subjects of a documentary by the Maysles brothers. Now Christine Ebersole and Mary Louise Wilson reprise their roles as the Beales, daughter and mother. The show's book is by Doug Wright, music by Scott Frankel and lyrics by Michael Korie. Michael Greif directs, as he did at Playwrights Horizons. Previews begin Oct. 3. Opens Nov. 2. Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; greygardensthemusical.com. NIGHTINGALE Lynn Redgrave performs her third play, a solo that focuses on the idea of immortality, inspired by thoughts of her maternal grandmother, Beatrice Kempson. Ms. Redgrave has previously written about her father, Michael Redgrave, and her mother, Rachel Kempson. Family memories? Sure, but that's some family. Joseph Hardy directs. Previews begin Oct. 4. Opens Oct. 15. Closes Nov. 19. Mark Taper Forum, Los Angeles. (213) 628-2772; centertheatregroup.org. MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE The diaries and letters of an American peace activist who traveled to Gaza form the basis of Alan Rickman and Katharine Viner's play about a young woman whose death sparked worldwide controversy. Megan Dodds will reprise her role in this solo show, and Mr. Rickman will direct, as he did in the London production at the Royal Court Theater. Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 15. Through Nov. 19. Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village. Ticketmaster. BUTLEY It has taken a while for the Huntington Theater Company's 2003 Boston revival of Simon Gray's comedy to reach New York. Nathan Lane will again portray the title character, a professor battling an ex-wife, his boyfriend, his academic department and the bottle, armed only with a book of Beatrix Potter's nursery rhymes and a tongue so sharp it would send Oscar Wilde to a neutral corner. Nicholas Martin directs, as he did in Boston. Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 25. Through Jan. 14. Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. THE CLEAN HOUSE Sarah Ruhl's celebrated play seems to have been produced everywhere except New York over the last few years. In this Lincoln Center Theater production, Blair Brown portrays a successful doctor who hires a Brazilian woman, played by Vanessa Aspillaga, to put her house in order. But it doesn't exactly work out that way. The cast includes Jill Clayburgh, John Dossett and Concetta Tomei. Bill Rauch directs. Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 30. Through Dec. 17. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center. Telecharge; lct.org. TRANSLATIONS The Irish director Garry Hynes, the first woman to garner a Tony Award for best direction (''The Beauty Queen of Leenane''), stages this revival of the early Brian Friel play set in rural 19th-century Ireland. A production with the Manhattan Theater Club. Previews begin Oct. 8. Opens Oct. 13. Through Oct. 29. McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place, Princeton, N.J., (609) 258-2787; www.mccarter.org. (The Manhattan Theater Club will present the production at the Biltmore Theater on Broadway. Previews begin Jan. 4. Opens Jan. 25. 261 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; manhattantheatreclub.com.) EMERGENCE-SEE! In 2006 a 19th-century slave ship mysteriously appears off the coast of Manhattan. Daniel Beaty writes and performs this one-man show, in which he plays 40 characters and recounts the tale in slam poetry and song. Kenny Leon directs. Previews begin Oct. 10. Opens Oct. 22. Through Nov. 12. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; publictheater.org. POST MORTEM The Flea Theater opens its 10th-anniversary season with the premiere of A. R. Gurney's play, which examines the role of theater in an American culture under the sway of political conservatism and the religious right. The director, Jim Simpson, who heads the Flea, and Mr. Gurney have worked together before -- ''Mrs. Farnsworth,'' for example, in 2004. (And they will again in May when they meet for ''Crazy Mary'' at Playwrights Horizons.) Oct. 10-Dec. 9. Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa. TheaterMania; www.theflea.org. MIMI LE DUCK Eartha Kitt fans, rejoice: she returns to the stage in this musical, with book and lyrics by Diana Hansen-Young and music by Brian Feinstein. A Mormon housewife (Annie Golden) flees Idaho to seek her fortune in Paris. Ms. Kitt plays Madame Vallet, a faded Parisian torch singer. Tom Aldredge is also in the cast, which is directed by Thomas Caruso. Previews begin Oct. 11. Opens Oct. 31. New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street. Telecharge; newworldstages.com. TALE OF 2CITIES The two cities are New York and Los Angeles. The tale concerns the Brooklyn Dodgers, which left the New York borough for the West Coast in 1957. The author, Heather Woodbury, is part of the cast. The ambitious two-part production was commissioned by Performance Space 122 and UCLA Live. The two parts run in repertory weekdays, with both parts staged on Saturdays and Sundays. Previews begin Oct. 12. Opens Oct. 14. Closes Oct. 29. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street, East Village. TheaterMania; ps122.org. MY DEAH The Abingdon Theater Company is serving up a hot plate of Euripides, Southern-style, in this new play by John Epperson, a k a Lypsinka. Mr. Epperson's comic adaptation of ''Medea'' stars Nancy Opel (''Urinetown''), who plays My Deah Hedgepeth (that's Medea to you classics mavens), and Bryan Batt (''Beauty and the Beast''). Mark Waldrop (''When Pigs Fly'') directs. Previews begin Oct. 13. Opens Oct. 25. Through Nov. 12. Abingdon Theater Company, 312 West 36th Street, Manhattan. SmartTix. MARY POPPINS The Disney machine meets Cameron Mackintosh, the producer, and, if reports of the current London production are anything to go by, musical memories are made. In this New York premiere Ashley Brown portrays the title character of the classic children's book, the bumbershoot-equipped flying London nanny, and Gavin Lee has the role of Bert. Daniel Jenkins and Rebecca Luker play Mr. and Mrs. Banks. The songs are by Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman from the 1964 film, with new songs by George Stiles and Anthony Drewe, and a book by Julian Fellowes. Richard Eyre and Matthew Bourne (''Swan Lake'') are the directors, and Mr. Bourne is the choreographer, with Stephen Mear. Previews begin Oct. 14. Opens Nov. 16. New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, Manhattan. Ticketmaster; marypoppins.com. THE COAST OF UTOPIA It's going to take a good part of the season to open Tom Stoppard's latest American premiere. From Oct. 17 to March 10, Lincoln Center Theater will be presenting his epic trilogy about the intellectual forebears of the Russian Revolution. In his review of the National Theater production in London in 2002, Ben Brantley wrote in The New York Times that the pleasures of ''The Coast of Utopia'' ''are those of a fat novel that for all its long-windedness is a page turner.'' Set in the 19th century, the trilogy follows a group of adversarial friends for 30 years, from their largely privileged youth in Russia to exile in Western Europe. The 44 actors in 70 roles include Billy Crudup, Richard Easton, Jennifer Ehle, Josh Hamilton, David Harbour, Jason Butler Harner, Ethan Hawke, Amy Irving, Brian F. O'Byrne and Martha Plimpton. The first part, ''Voyage,'' begins performances on Oct. 17; ''Shipwreck'' on Dec. 6; and ''Salvage'' on Jan. 30. On the last three Saturdays of the run -- Feb. 24, March 3 and March 10 -- the three parts will be presented in one day. Jack O'Brien directs what will likely be the event of the season for the theater intelligentsia in New York. Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center. Telecharge; lct.org. THE INTERNATIONALIST Anne Washburn, whose ''Apparition'' tried to scare downtown audiences out of their wits last year, follows an American businessman's traumatic experiences as he makes his way in a foreign land. Originally produced by the playwrights cooperative 13P Off Off Broadway in 2005. Ken Rus Schmoll directs. Previews begin Oct. 18. Opens Nov. 5. Through Nov. 26. Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 353-0303; vineyardtheatre.org. REGRETS ONLY Paul Rudnick's new play, presented by the Manhattan Theater Club, is a comedy of marriage and manners set in contemporary high society. The rich and powerful here include Christine Baranski, George Grizzard and David Rasche. Contemporary high society should be so lucky to look, and talk, like this. Christopher Ashley directs. Previews begin Oct. 19. Opens Nov. 19. City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan. Citytix; manhattantheatreclub.com. SUDDENLY LAST SUMMER Blythe Danner plays the distraught widow Mrs. Venable in the Roundabout Theater Company revival of Tennessee Williams's gothic psychological drama. Carla Gugino is her young niece. Mark Brokaw directs. Previews begin Oct. 20. Opens Nov. 15. Through Jan. 21. Laura Pels Theater, at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, 111 West 46th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300; roundabouttheater.org. WAITING FOR GODOT The waiting for ''Waiting for Godot'' in the 100th-anniversary year of Samuel Beckett's birth is over. The brilliant Gate Theater production arrives in New York for only five days and six performances in a Beckett-approved staging by Walter Asmus. That supreme Beckett performer, Barry McGovern, plays Vladimir, and Johnny Murphy (best known in the United States as the lascivious middle-aged trumpeter in ''The Commitments'') portrays Estragon. Oct. 24-28. NYU-Skirball Center, 566 LaGuardia Place at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village. Ticket Central; www.skirballcenter.nyu.edu. LES MISÉRABLES The familiar sketch of that wan little French gamine is back, and if the producer Cameron Mackintosh is still up to his old tricks, she'll be plastered everywhere this fall when the grandiose, expensive musical adaptation of Victor Hugo's condemnation of poverty reopens on Broadway. This time Alexander Gemignani portrays Jean Valjean, Gary Beach is Thénardier, Norm Lewis is Javert and Daphne Rubin-Vega plays Fantine. Mr. Mackintosh will be building on the 6,680 performances of the original Broadway run, which closed only three years ago. At least ''A Chorus Line'' waited a decade and a half. Previews begin Oct. 24. Opens Nov. 9. Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; lesmis.com. THE WILD DUCK The National Theater of Norway visits Brooklyn in the year of the 100th anniversary of Henrik Ibsen's death, bringing with it Eirik Stubo's production of the playwright's midperiod masterpiece, with a bit of a difference. Mr. Stubo has set the drama of the Ekdals and the Werles in the 1950's. In Norwegian with English supertitles. Part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. Oct. 25-29. Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100; bam.org. DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS! the musical The Old Globe's adaptation of the children's tale comes to Broadway for a limited holiday-season run. Timothy Mason wrote the book and lyrics, Mel Marvin the music. Matt August directs. Oct. 25-Jan. 7. Hilton Theater, 214 West 43rd Street, Manhattan. Ticketmaster. THE LITTLE DOG LAUGHED Last season's Off Broadway hit by Douglas Carter Beane, a vicious satire about showbiz agents and prostitutes, transfers to Broadway. Julie White and Johnny Galecki reprise the roles they created in the original production at the Second Stage Theater. Scott Ellis returns to direct. Previews begin Oct. 26. Opens Nov. 13. Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. THE MAIL ORDER BRIDE/THE IMAGINARY INVALID Charles L. Mee's new comedy, ''The Mail Order Bride,'' and the Molière comedy that inspired it, ''The Imaginary Invalid,'' run in repertory, presented by Resonance Ensemble. The Molière satire of the medical profession is set in Paris, where Argan's hypochondria drains his family's bank account. Mr. Mee's satire is set in Brooklyn, where the aging Argan plans to marry a young Asian woman who soon enough is the object of a caterer's attention. Mr. Mee may be best known for his ''love'' trilogy: ''Big Love,'' ''True Love'' and ''First Love.'' Eric Parness directs Mr. Mee's play, Rebecca Patterson the Molière. Previews begin Oct. 27. Opens Nov. 3. Through Nov. 19. Beckett Theater, Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; resonanceensemble.org. COMPANY Stephen Sondheim fans, patiently waiting for a follow-up to last season's ''Sweeney Todd'' revival, get another, courtesy of the director John Doyle, who snagged a 2006 Tony Award for his staging of the barber's bloody tale. The Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park's production stars Raúl Esparza and the rest of the Cincinnati cast, who, as in ''Sweeney Todd,'' will be providing their own musical accompaniment. Previews begin Oct. 30. Opens Nov. 29. Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge; companyonbroadway.com. November THE BLUEST EYE This adaptation of Toni Morrison's novel about a young girl's coming of age in the 1940's arrives from the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago. The young girl is played by Alana Arenas. Lydia Diamond wrote the adaptation. Hallie Gordon directs. Nov. 3-19. The New Vic at the Duke on 42nd Street, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. DURANGO Julia Cho (''BFE'') takes an American road trip with a Korean-American family traveling to Colorado. Along the way, family secrets and cultural tensions are revealed. Chay Yew directs. A production with the Long Wharf Theater. Previews begin Nov. 7. Opening date to be announced. Through Dec. 10. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; publictheater.org. TWO TRAINS RUNNING The Signature Theater Company continues its commemoration of August Wilson, who died last year. This drama from Wilson's 10-play epic of the African-American experience in 20th-century America takes place in the last year of the turbulent 1960's, as a restaurant owner and a funeral director navigate the minefields of racially charged violence and rising political consciousness. Lou Bellamy directs. Nov. 7-Dec. 31. Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529; signaturetheatre.org. GREAT EXPECTATIONS Kathleen Chalfant wears Miss Havisham's tattered wedding dress in an adaptation of the Dickens novel by Bathsheba Doran, with incidental music by Michael Picton. Will Pomerantz, late of ''Godot Has Left the Building,'' directs. Previews begin Nov. 8. Opens Nov. 16. Through Dec. 3. TheatreworksUSA at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, Greenwich Village. Ticket Central; theatreworksusa.org. DARK MATTERS Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa follows his play of last season, ''Based on a Totally True Story,'' with a domestic mystery set in rural America. A woman disappears, then reappears, speaking of strange beings. Is she lying or just crazy? Or do those strange beings know something that rural America doesn't? Trip Cullman directs. Previews begin Nov. 8. Opens Nov. 16. Through Dec. 17. Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, 224 Waverly Place, Greenwich Village. SmartTix; rattlestick.org. RADIO CITY CHRISTMAS SPECTACULAR The 90-minute New York tradition includes a brand-new scene this year and Santa's 3-D flight over Manhattan, along with traditional songs and scenes and oh, those Rockettes. Nov. 9-Dec. 30. Radio City Music Hall. Ticket Master. radiocity.com. THE VERTICAL HOUR David Hare will be spending a lot of time on Broadway this season. He directs Joan Didion's memory play, ''The Year of Magical Thinking,'' in the spring. But first, his own new play, a world premiere about academics and politics. It stars Julianne Moore as an American professor and former war reporter whose unexpected meeting with an Englishman in Wales changes her life. Directed by Sam Mendes. Previews begin Nov 9. Opens Nov. 30. Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. Pirandello Project The working title for the choreographer and director Martha Clarke's new theater piece seems accurate. Using dance, music, text and visual imagery and set in turn-of-the-20th-century Sicily, the project is based on four stories by Luigi Pirandello that also formed the basis of the 1984 film ''Kaos'' by the Taviani brothers. Previews begin Nov. 10. Opens Dec 4. Through Dec. 31. New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village. Telecharge; nytw.org. WOYZECK Edward Hogg, the Isabella of last season's ''Measure for Measure'' from the Globe Theater in London, steps into the army boots of Georg Buchner's most unstable soldier in the Gate Theater of London's rock 'n' roll adaptation of the classic. Daniel Kramer directs. Opens Nov. 13. Through Dec. 3. St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779. www.artsatstanns.org 365 DAYS / 365 PLAYS You've heard of stunt casting. But stunt playwriting? Given that it's Suzan-Lori Parks who is doing the writing, this project is likely to be much more than that, but the gimmick is just as intriguing: Ms. Parks wrote a play a day -- one to five pages long -- from Nov. 13, 2002, to Nov. 12, 2003, for a total of 365 scripts. The Public Theater is curating performances of all 365 plays by a variety of New York companies over the next year, at the same time that the plays will be presented in various parts of the country, including Atlanta, Los Angeles and Denver. To start the project off, the Public will present the first seven plays on Nov. 13. The subject matter ranges from everyday domestic topics to Idi Amin and Johnny Cash. Free. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8760; publictheater.org. THE VOYSEY INHERITANCE David Mamet shifts gears, after his 2005 farce ''Romance,'' with this adaptation of Harley Granville-Barker's classic 1905 dissection of the nexus of family, corruption and money. Mr. Mamet's film of Terence Rattigan's play set in the same period, ''The Winslow Boy,'' turned out to be one of his most elegant, sensitive screenplays. Maybe he can pull off the same trick on the stage. Previews begin Nov. 15. Opens Dec. 6. Through Jan. 7. Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. Telecharge; atlantictheater.org. SPRING AWAKENING Charles Isherwood of The New York Times called the Atlantic Theater Company's new musical ''exhilarating'' when it opened Off Broadway last season. Now the adaptation of the classic Frank Wedekind play about youth, sex and repression moves to Broadway. The music is by Duncan Sheik, the book and lyrics by Steven Sater. The choreography is by Bill T. Jones, and Michael Mayer returns to direct. Previews begin Nov. 17. Opens Dec. 10. Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. HIGH FIDELITY Will Chase steps into John Cusack's shoes when he takes on the role of Rob in this book-to-film-to-musical Broadway adaptation of the Nick Hornby novel. It's about a rock-'n'-roll-obsessed record store owner who finds himself unable to put his romantic life into a satisfactory groove. Jenn Colella of ''Urban Cowboy'' is the woman who knocks his emotional tone arm for a spin. David Lindsay-Abaire, who wrote last season's ''Rabbit Hole,'' did the book, and Tom Kitt and Amanda Green wrote the songs. Walter Bobbie directs. Previews begin Nov. 20. Opens Dec. 7. Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. HEDDA GABLER From the Schaubühne theater in Berlin comes Thomas Ostermeier's production of Ibsen's midperiod play about a dissatisfied housewife (and it wouldn't be an Ibsen play without one). Mr. Ostermeier returns to the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave festival after his production of ''Nora,'' his rendering of ''A Doll's House,'' in 2004. In German with English supertitles. Nov. 28-Dec. 2. Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100; bam.org. TWO SEPTEMBER Mac Wellman returns to the theater he helped found, the Flea, with this new play set in post-World War II Vietnam. Expect the usual linguistic fireworks from the most loquacious Mr. Wellman. Loy Arcenas directs. Nov. 29-Dec. 16. Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa. TheaterMania. www.theflea.org. STRIKING 12 The pop-rock band GrooveLily (Gene Lewin, Brendan Milburn and Valerie Vigoda) takes center stage in this musical with a holiday theme. The book and lyrics are by Rachel Sheinkin (''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee''), Mr. Milburn and Ms. Vigoda; the music by Mr. Milburn and Ms. Vigoda. One New Year's Eve, a grumpy loner's life changes after he reads Hans Christian Andersen's tale ''The Little Match Girl.'' Ted Sperling directs. Theater and dates to be announced. December ANNIE The curly-haired, blank-eyed orphan and her adoptive father, Daddy Warbucks, take another swing through New York. The 30th-anniversary touring production, arriving in time for the holidays, is directed by the show's original lyricist, Martin Charnin. That's 30 years, by the way, of tomorrows. Dec. 6-30. Theater at Madison Square Garden. Ticketmaster; thegarden.com. THE SCENE Four participants in New York's entertainment world catch the playwright Theresa Rebeck's jaundiced eye in her bitter new comedy, directed by Rebecca Taichman. In his review of the production at the Humana Festival in April, Charles Isherwood wrote in The New York Times that it was a ''sharply observed, often blisteringly funny play.'' Previews begin Dec. 12. Opens Jan. 11. Through Feb. 4. Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422; secondstagetheatre.com. January A SPANISH PLAY Now here's a high-powered cast: Denis O'Hare from ''Take Me Out,'' Linda Emond from ''Homebody/Kabul'' and the legendary Zoe Caldwell toy with illusion and reality in the New York premiere of a play by the author of ''Art,'' Yasmina Reza. The toying is orchestrated by the director, John Turturro, no slouch in the acting department himself. Previews begin Jan 10. Opens Feb. 1. Classic Stage Company, 136 East 13th Street, East Village. Ticket Central; classicstage.org. FRANK'S HOME Frank Lloyd Wright goes Hollywood. Sort of. Richard Nelson's new play about the architect (played by Peter Weller) finds him moving to Los Angeles in the 1920's after completing the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo. Instead of glamour, he finds family tension and resentment among his adult children. With Harris Yulin as Louis Sullivan. Robert Falls directs. Previews begin Jan. 12. Opens Jan. 30. Through Feb. 18. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; playwrightshorizons.org. THE STARRY MESSENGER Matthew Broderick portrays an unambitious astronomy teacher who suddenly becomes interested in researching deeper questions about the universe in this new play by Kenneth Lonergan (''This Is Our Youth,'' ''You Can Count on Me''), who also directs. Previews begin Jan. 13. Opens Jan. 19. Through Feb. 18. Old Globe Theater, San Diego, (619) 234-5623; theoldglobe.org. UNDER THE RADAR In the second year of this performing arts festival, the series presents productions from, among other countries, Canada, Bolivia and Britain. Sites include the Kitchen and, in Brooklyn, St. Ann's Warehouse. Jan. 16-Jan. 28. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; publictheater.org. DUTCHMAN Amiri Baraka returns to the scene of a stunning crime: literally. The Cherry Lane Theater, where ''Dutchman'' was first produced, revives his scalding 1964 play about a black man who is seduced on a subway train by a white woman. Jan. 16-Feb. 10. Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, Greenwich Village. Telecharge; cherrylanetheatre.com. ALL THAT I WILL EVER BE Now that his ''Six Feet Under'' series has been interred in HBO's graveyard, Alan Ball returns to the stage with his first new play in more than 10 years, an examination of cultural imperialism as seen through the eyes of two Los Angeles men, one a native, the other an immigrant from the Middle East. Jo Bonney directs. Previews begin Jan. 17. Opens Feb. 6. Through March 11. New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village. Telecharge; nytw.org. WAKE UP MR. SLEEPY! YOUR UNCONSCIOUS MIND IS DEAD! But if Richard Foreman's new show is like any of his others, it won't be dead for long. The Ontological-Hysteric production features airplanes ''breaking through the language barrier'' and who knows what else. It's the author's second mixed-media project, following on the 2006 ''Zomboid!'' Sophie Havilland and the Bridge Project collaborate with Mr. Foreman on the accompanying video presentation, shot in Lisbon. Previews begin Jan. 18. Opens Jan. 25. Through April 29. Ontological Theater at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village. TheaterMania; ontological.com. ADRIFT IN MACAO Rick Blaine and Ilsa Laszlo must be spinning in their graves. Christopher Durang unleashes the New York premiere of his latest satire, a film noir parody set in the 1940's involving five eccentric characters stranded in an exotic Far East locale. And they sing because it's a musical. The songs are by Peter Melnick (music) and Mr. Durang (lyrics). If we're lucky, Peter Lorre and Sydney Greenstreet will get a pas-de-deux. Sheryl Kaller directs the Primary Stages production. Previews begin Jan. 23. Opens Feb. 13. Through March 4. 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, Manhattan. Ticket Central; primarystages.com. MARY ROSE According to the publicity material, this play by J. M. Barrie, best known for green-clad pixies who don't want to grow up, was a ''major obsession and inspiration'' for Alfred Hitchcock. This sounds plausible: the plot concerns a girl who may or may not be a ghost. Tina Landau will direct the first New York production of this romantic drama in 50 years. Previews begin Jan. 31. Opens Feb. 18. Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 353-0303.www.vineyardtheatre.org February HOWARD KATZ The American premiere of this tale by Patrick Marber (''Closer'') stars Alfred Molina as the title character, a talent agent experiencing a precipitous decline and fall. Doug Hughes directs the Roundabout Theater Company production. Previews begin Feb. 2. Opens March 8. Through April 29. Laura Pels Theater, at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, 111 West 46th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300; roundabouttheater.org. TALK RADIO A revival of Eric Bogosian's 1987 play about a controversial late-night radio talk show host will star Liev Schreiber on Broadway. Mr. Schreiber won a Tony Award the last time he was there, in 2005, as a slick real estate salesman in ''Glengarry Glen Ross.'' Robert Falls directs. Previews begin Feb. 9. Opening date to be announced. Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. KING HEDLEY II The characters from August Wilson's ''Seven Guitars'' return in this sequel of sorts, set in the despair-ridden Pittsburgh inner city of the 1980's. Part of the Signature Theater Company's Wilson retrospective. Feb. 20-April 15. Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529; signaturetheatre.org. OUR LEADING LADY Charles Busch's new play is about the actress Laura Keene as she prepares to appear on the stage with President Lincoln in the audience. Lynne Meadow, the artistic director of the Manhattan Theater Club, who directed ''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife'' by Mr. Busch, directs. Previews begin Feb. 22. Opens March 15. City Center Stage II, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan. Citytix; manhattantheatreclub.com. SOME MEN Terrence McNally's new drama begins at a gay wedding, then turns into a memory play that sweeps through recent history. Trip Cullman directs. Previews begin Feb. 23. Opening date to be announced. Through April 15. Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422; secondstagetheatre.com. HAMLET In the last few years the Wooster Group has merrily deconstructed Racine, O'Neill, Gertrude Stein and Jerzy Grotowski. But now, for the first time, it takes on Shakespeare, and with ''Hamlet.'' The director Elizabeth LeCompte has chosen the 1964 Electronovision version of Richard Burton's Broadway performance for her starting point. Dorothy, I don't think we're in Denmark anymore. A production in association with the Public Theater. Feb. 27-March 25. St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779; ticketweb.com, artsatstanns.org. JACK GOES BOATING Bob Glaudini's new play for the LAByrinth Theater Company is about a first date, with complications. Starring are the troupe's joint artistic directors, Philip Seymour Hoffman and John Ortiz, as well as Daphne Rubin-Vega and Beth Cole. Peter DuBois directs. Feb. 27-April 8. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; labtheater.org March THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING This solo play, starring Vanessa Redgrave, is based on Joan Didion's 2005 memoir about the year following the death of her husband, the writer John Gregory Dunne, in 2003, and the serious illness of their daughter, Quintana. Ms. Didion adapted her book for the stage. The British playwright David Hare directs. Previews begin March 6. Opens March 29. Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Telecharge. ESSENTIAL SELF-DEFENSE Adam Rapp, whose ''Red Light Winter'' was a Pulitzer Prize finalist last season, moves uptown for his new play, in which evil takes over a Midwestern town named Bloggs. Poets, librarians and a man who works as an attack dummy for a women's self-defense-class will try to save the day. Directed by Carolyn Cantor and produced with the Edge Theater, where Mr. Rapp is the resident playwright. Previews begin March 15. Opens March 29. Through April 15. Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; playwrightshorizons.org. BLACKBIRD Jeff Daniels stars in the New York premiere of a drama by the Scottish playwright David Harrower, about a woman in her 20's who confronts an older man with whom she was involved years before. Joe Mantello directs the Manhattan Theater Club production. Previews begin March 15. Opens April 10. City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan. Citytix; manhattantheatreclub.com. RADIO GOLF August Wilson's final play, and the last in his 10-play cycle about the African-American experience in 20th-century America, is set in the 1990's and examines real estate developers and the tensions arising from gentrification in a formerly run-down neighborhood in Pittsburgh. Kenny Leon directs. Broadway may be the next stop. Previews begin March 18. Opens March 23. Through April 8. McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place, Princeton, N.J., (609) 258-2787; www.mccarter.org. TERMS OF ENDEARMENT Larry McMurtry's novel was made into a film and now it has been adapted for the stage by Dan Gordon for a world premiere at the Alley Theater. Makes sense too, since Aurora and Emma Greenway fought their emotional battles in Houston. Linda Gray (Sue Ellen in the series ''Dallas'') plays Aurora. A production with the Hartford Stage Company, whose artistic director, Michael Wilson, directs. Previews begin March 30. Opens April 4. Through April 29. Alley Theater, 615 Texas Avenue, Houston, (713) 228-8421; alleytheatre.org. April LEGALLY BLONDE If it weren't based on a Reese Witherspoon film from 2001 (itself based on a novel by Amanda Brown), you'd swear this was a revival of a 1920's musical: a fun-loving young woman finds herself at a staid law school, where she turns everything topsy-turvy while turning heads. Nell Benjamin and Laurence O'Keefe wrote the music and lyrics and Heather Hach the book. Jerry Mitchell is the director and choreographer. Previews begin April 3. Opens April 29. Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway. Ticketmaster. KING LEAR The much-anticipated production of Shakespeare's darkest tragedy, with Kevin Kline as the foolish monarch who mistakes the words ''I love you'' for love itself. James Lapine directs. Dates to be announced. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-5555; publictheater.org. May CRAZY MARY Sigourney Weaver isn't the crazy lady, she's the crazy lady's cousin, a Buffalo matriarch trying to track down her family's inheritance. Mary (Kristine Nielsen), a patient in an asylum for the wealthy, may have the answer. The season's second new play from the productive A. R. Gurney (his ''Post Mortem,'' see above, begins performances in October at the Flea Theater) is directed by Jim Simpson, artistic director of the Flea and Ms. Weaver's husband. Previews begin May 11. Opens June 3. Through June 17. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Ticket Central; playwrightshorizons.org. LYTHGOE--Clive. The Board of Trustees of Horizon Concerts and its artists deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Music Director, Clive Lythgoe. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 10, at 4PM at the Chapel of St. George's Church, 209 East 16 St., New York, NY.

To the Editor: I was thrilled to see Rachel Donadio's essay about artists' colonies (''What I Did at Summer Writers' Camp,'' Aug. 20), but I wish she had dug a little below the commonly accepted vision of what sort of writer goes to an artists' colony and spoken to a lesser-known, more racially diverse group of former colonists. Unlike the wonderful writers she quoted (some of whom I'm acquainted with, all of whom I respect), I am not white, best-selling or a Pulitzer Prize winner. I am a three-time MacDowell fellow, a married African-American mother of two school-age children and a published novelist. The first time I went to MacDowell, I was seven months pregnant with my now 8-year-old daughter (no sex then, I'll tell ya). I worked on my most recent book, ''Third Girl From the Left,'' during two separate subsequent MacDowell stays. MacDowell (which, in the interest of full disclosure, I must admit I love so much that I volunteer as the president of the fellows executive committee), and the other artists' colonies mentioned, do much to foster the cultural life of this country, not just by providing an incubator for the better known but by providing an incubator for talented creative artists whether they are prominent or not, white or not. Sure, there are romances, high jinks and intrigues -- but as Michael Chabon points out, ''there's no substitute'' for a beautiful, caring place to work like a colony. Martha Southgate Brooklyn To the Editor: I wonder where Rachel Donadio heard the saying that ''the sex is better at Yaddo, but the work is better at MacDowell''? In 1949 I was invited to play violin in a summer festival of American contemporary music at Yaddo, where Dean Dixon led an orchestra consisting mostly of first-desk symphonic musicians, conservatory teachers and top professional freelancers. Distinguished composers attended in order to revise their latest compositions, which we played from manuscript, and they made up a Who's Who in American music: Charles Ives, Henry Cowell, David Diamond and others. And then there was undistinguished me: an 18-year-old Juilliard student who, to this day, cannot imagine why I was chosen for this Yaddo honor. I was probably one of the youngest ''artists'' ever to be invited to Yaddo, and my professional orchestra experience had been limited to the Juilliard training ensemble and summer concerts in Catskills hotels where, incidentally, the sex was probably better (and surely more prolific) than at Yaddo and MacDowell put together. I know nothing of the sexual scene in the MacDowell colony, and whether the creative output of its resident artists is superior to Yaddo's is debatable. But I can attest, as a curious teenager in 1949, that my stay in Yaddo might as well have been in a monastery. The height of excitement for the musicians every evening was a game of charades in the vast Yaddo library, while those distinguished gentlemen, the composers, went to bed early and, to the best of my knowledge, alone with their manuscripts. Les Dreyer Manhattan

WHEN Natalie Wells bought a home in Englewood, N.J., a year ago, she was unaware that her American pit bull terrier was illegal to own in the city. Shortly after moving in, she was told by one of her daughters about a city law that banned the breed, commonly called pit bulls, along with several similar breeds and Rottweilers. Under the 1999 law, even this year's best-in-show winner at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Rufus, a colored bull terrier from Holmdel, N.J., would be banned in Englewood.

Jessica Shane Elliott, a daughter of Carol B. and Thomas C. Elliott of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Zachary William Berk, the son of Carol S. and Stephen B. Berk of Narragansett, R.I., are to be married today at OceanCliff, a hotel in Newport, R.I. Judge Daniel A. Procaccini of Rhode Island Superior Court in Providence, is to officiate. The bride and bridegroom met at Northeastern University, where they received law degrees last year.

To the Editor: Re: ''Race Wasn't an Issue to Him, Which Was an Issue to Me'' (Modern Love, Sept. 3): I was pleasantly surprised to find someone articulate the dilemma I encounter when dating white men. My parents, an interracial couple who have been together for 38 years, raised me with the belief that love could conquer anything. I have consequently suffered many romantic disappointments with people, white and of color, who didn't grapple with race or who grappled differently than I did.

Indianapolis (14-2) at Giants (11-5) 8:15 p.m., Channel 4 MANNING VS. MANNING For marketing purposes, the game has been diluted from Giants versus Colts to Eli versus Peyton, below. The Manning brothers will become the first siblings in N.F.L. history to start at quarterback for opposing teams. As they have pointed out repeatedly, they will not be facing each other directly, but that will not stop non-Mannings from comparing their performances. Mostly, it will provide the latest measure for how the unproven Eli -- entering his third season -- stacks up against a perennial Pro Bowl player like Peyton. MICHAEL STRAHANAND OSI UMENYIORA VS. DWIGHT FREENEY AND ROBERT MATHIS They will not directly face each other, either, but the starting defensive ends for the Giants and the Colts were the two best pass-rushing tandems in the N.F.L. last year. Strahan (11 1/2 sacks in 2005) and Umenyiora (14 1/2) had more sacks than any teammates; Freeney (11) and Mathis (11 1/2) were next. Both offenses will try to keep them at bay, but the four should play a big role in determining who wins the Manning versus Manning matchup -- and the game. JOHN BRANCH (NYT)

HEWITT --Edward Ringwood, on August 16, 2006, at age 80. Son of the late Louise Schieffelin Hewitt and Abram Stevens Hewitt; great-greatgrandson of New York philanthropist Peter Cooper. He was a graduate of Harvard College and the University of Texas and served in the U.S. Navy in World War II. He was a geologist in the fields of oil, gas and mining, and a member of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists. He served for many years as a trustee of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. He also served on the vestry of Trinity Episcopal Church, Newtown, CT. He is survived by his wife, Sigrid Nauen Hewitt; his children, Luisa Hewitt Prichard, Andrew Hewitt, Catherine Hewitt (Paul Parcellin), James Hewitt (Susan) and Peter Hewitt (Deborah); his grandchildren, David Prichard, Rachel Prichard, Sarah Hewitt Lueck (Benjamin), Stephen Hewitt, Michael Hewitt and John Hewitt. He was preceded in death by a grandson, Calvin Hewitt, a sister, Camilla Hewitt and a daughter-in-law, Sandra Hewitt. He is also survived by a sister, Mary Hewitt Harshman (Richard) and four brothers, Stephen Hewitt, Jonathan Hewitt, Nicholas Hewitt, and Adam Hewitt, and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial service will be held on September 23, 2006 at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newtown, CT, at 1:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Cooper Union or to World Vision.

KATHRYN BIGELOW made ''Point Break'' as if she were determined to show up all the big boys as sissies. She pumps this movie full of adrenaline like someone determined to see how much helium a balloon can hold before it bursts. This is the sort of picture in which the hero (Keanu Reeves, above left) is named Johnny Utah, and a bad guy about to meet his maker exclaims, ''I'll see you in hell, Johnny.'' It would be ridiculous if it weren't so delirious. Utah is an F.B.I. agent who goes undercover to bring down a group of surfers financing their pursuit of the big waves with a string of bank robberies. His nemesis is Bodhi, the surfing guru-bank robber who, as played by the marvelous Patrick Swayze, above right, is like a stoned version of the chest-thumping he-man Robert Shaw portrayed in ''Jaws.'' The Carlos Castaneda of machismo, Bodhi is ready with a quasi-mystical justification of everything from riding a tube to planning a heist.
A caption last Sunday with the Theater entry in the Week Ahead report misspelled the surname of the character Karen Finley portrayed in ''Make Love.'' The character is Liza Minnelli, not Minelli.

ON Sept. 11, 2001, I was a lieutenant in the Port Authority Police Department. After the attack, I became the night commander of the rescue and recovery operation at ground zero, charged with recovering the remains of my fellow officers and the thousands of other victims of the World Trade Center collapse. I and the 30 to 50 officers under my command worked at ground zero six or seven days a week for more than eight months among the two-million-ton mountain of shattered concrete, twisted steel and human remains. Pulling 19,000 body parts out of the rubble, we became accustomed to matching arms and legs like pairs of socks. When we got home, we still smelled like ground zero, with bitter-tasting dust and an odor of decay in our hair and on our skin. I couldn't hug my wife and children until after I had taken several showers.

Dear mother-in-law of Carol and Julie. Forever in our hearts. Joseph M. Delfino, the Republican mayor of White Plains, and Bill Ryan, one of the city's Democratic county legislators, are not on the best of terms. Ever since 1993, when Mr. Ryan challenged Mr. Delfino, then a county legislator, for his seat and lost, the pair have argued over everything. One of their longest running fights has centered on a county-owned downtown parking lot. Mr. Ryan wants to build an affordable housing complex for the elderly there, and so does Mr. Delfino. But they disagree on who should control the project. Mr. Delfino said it should be the city; Mr. Ryan, the county. The project has languished for about six years, and in an attempt to get it moving, Mr. Ryan recently announced that he would lease the site to developers, a plan Mr. Delfino opposes. Mr. Delfino said he was fighting for the principle of home rule. ''It's our community here,'' he said, ''White Plains is run by a local government. Who knows better than the administration about the needs of the city?''

DEEP into suburbia, on a sound barrier that runs along the Taconic State Parkway here, a graffiti artist announces his presence with a single word painted in yellow and black: ''Me.'' Officials said that graffiti had reached new heights this summer. And in a town that bills itself as a retreat from more urban locales, politicians and police officers are taking the problem seriously.

To the Editor: Mount Yasur (below) on the island of Tanna in Vanuatu is billed as ''one of the most active and accessible volcanoes in the world,'' as reported in ''The Original Bali Hai'' by Jeffrey Gettleman (Aug. 27). It may be a little too accessible. When my wife and I visited Tanna as part of a training cruise on the tall ship Soren Larsen in 2004, we hiked to the rim of the volcano one evening and peered into the smoking, lava-belching interior. As if that wasn't impressive enough, a local guy wandered over and said that it was about time for a ''big one.'' Before we could contemplate what that might mean, there was a massive explosion. The mountain shook as globs of red-hot lava were thrown hundreds of feet over our heads. When molten rock began raining around us, we turned and ran. The local guy was smarter -- he stood his ground and watched the incoming glowing projectiles, the better to dodge any of them headed his way.

Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 4 JUDGE & JURY, by James Patterson and Andrew Gross. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) An aspiring actress and an F.B.I. agent join forces against a powerful mobster. 2 2 2 RICOCHET, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A detective is attracted to a judge's wife who he suspects is not telling the truth about a fatal shooting. 3 1 HUNTERS OF DUNE, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95.) Adventures of the fugitives fleeing the ''Honored Matres,'' based on Frank Herbert's final outline for the Dune series. 4 1 THE AFGHAN, by Frederick Forsyth. (Putnam, $26.95.) To foil a Qaeda plot, a British operative masquerades as a Taliban commander just released from Guantánamo. 5 3 2 INTO THE STORM, by Suzanne Brockmann. (Ballantine, $21.95.) Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Aug. 26, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest GALLATIN CANYON: Stories, by Thomas McGuane. (Knopf, $24.) McGuane's portraits of American manhood have the capacity to astonish. A MADMAN DREAMS OF TURING MACHINES, by Janna Levin. (Knopf, $23.95.) This novel's unreliable narrator is obsessed with the logical geniuses Alan Turing and Kurt Gödel. NOT FOR SPECIALISTS: New and Selected Poems, by W. D. Snodgrass. (BOA Editions, paper, $21.95.) A clarification of the poet's range of accomplishment, coinciding with his 80th birthday. FIRST AID, by Janet Davey. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, paper, $13.99.) A woman is torn between her quotidian family routine and her violent new lover in Davey's unsettling novel. AFTERMATH: World Trade Center Archive, by Joel Meyerowitz. (Phaidon, $75.) Photos by Mey-erowitz, who, exceptionally, had continuous access to ground zero during nine months of cleanup. WATCHING THE WORLD CHANGE: The Stories Behind the Images of 9/11, by David Friend. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) People poured into the streets that day, bringing their cameras. THE LAST TOWN ON EARTH, by Thomas Mullen. (Random House, $23.95.) In this remarkable first novel, a village imposes a strict quarantine against the 1918 flu, and so becomes a prison. ORSON WELLES: Hello Americans, by Simon Callow. (Viking, $32.95.) The second volume of Callow's big biography covers most of the 1940's. PATH OF DESTRUCTION: The Devastation of New Orleans and the Coming Age of Superstorms, by John McQuaid and Mark Schleifstein. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Two Times-Picayune journalists explain how New Orleans was lost. IN SEARCH OF NELLA LARSEN: A Biography of the Color Line, by George Hutchinson. (Belknap/Harvard University, $39.95.) The life of the accomplished Harlem Renaissance novelist. I FEEL EARTHQUAKES MORE OFTEN THAN THEY HAPPEN, by Amy Wilentz. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) How Wilentz, an Easterner, came to uneasy terms with her new life in California. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Brenda Ann Kenneally's photo essay (Aug. 27) put a scorching spotlight on the continuing tragedy of the disaster in the Gulf Coast region, laid bare by Hurricane Katrina. But we all know that the hurricane did more than expose the fault lines in New Orleans. It made visible the vulnerability of our nation's poor -- seen in your photos through the fragile existence of children, where upheaval and chaos are the norms and hope seems to present too great a risk. Most sadly, the photos could have been shot in virtually any city or town in our nation. As a whole year has passed, it's long overdue that we have a national discussion about race and opportunity in our country, about living-wage jobs and affordable housing that will light the way to economic security. Arnold S. Cohen President and C.E.O. The Partnership for the Homeless New York For me, the pictures in your photo essay were disturbing not only because they are of children who have lost everything but also because they are of children who have never known anything but poverty. The hurricane has merely exacerbated what we as a society chose to ignore the first time. Valerie Miller Ardmore, Pa.

FIVE years ago my brother and I spoke regularly. Five years ago we drank together, teased each other without mercy and, occasionally, even expressed feelings of affection. After 9/11 we did not. My brother is a 20-plus-year veteran of the New York City Fire Department, a former marine with a degree in history whose politics are conservative. He is four years older and quite a bit larger than me. I am a 20-plus-year veteran of big-agency advertising, a creative director turned fiction writer whose politics, not surprisingly, do not lean conservatively. Until five years ago, this was not such a big problem. There were plenty of other things to talk about, and we knew that despite our differences, there was still much to appreciate about each other.

At Hamburgão, the five-year-old Brazilian burger-and-sandwich shop in the heart of the Ironbound district in Newark, you may find yourself asking, ''Where's the beef?'' Not that there's a shortage at Hamburgão, whose name means ''big hamburger'' in Portuguese. It's just that it can be hard to see, covered as it is by voluminous toppings. The Cheese Tudo burger, for example, places mozzarella, fresh ham, bacon, a fried egg, kernels of corn, crunchy potato sticks, lettuce, tomato and mayonnaise on top of a 5-ounce patty ($5). Although the toppings may seem like overload, they aren't. The only problem is fitting a little of everything into your mouth in one bite. It's impossible.

Caroline Burwell, 31, was thinking of that dreamboat Paul McCartney -- sweet, adorable early Paul -- and his thoroughly mod band mates when she came up with her fall collection for boys. ''The Beatles were the inspiration, their boy-band period,'' Ms. Burwell said. ''They looked so cute in their paisley florals and polka dots.'' Her Burwell New York label has updated the look for sizes 2 through 8, with Liberty of London flowered paisley shirts ($92), a handmade cashmere turtleneck sweater Ringo might have worn ($216) and a pinstripe vest ($82) with matching pants ($96, all at Barneys New York). Of course, cashmere turtlenecks and velveteen smoking jackets ($138, Scoop Kids) are hardly built for traipsing through playgrounds. They are more suited to future Hugh Hefners with generous allowances -- or maybe just for boys who want to be fab at 4. SUSAN GUERRERO

RADER--Sue. 93. Beloved mother of two, sister of one, grandmother of four and great-grandmother of six. Graduate of City College. Services today, 1 PM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

Dates are subject to change. September DREAMING OF A SPEECH WITHOUT WORDS: THE PAINTINGS AND EARLY OBJECTS OF H. C. WESTERMANN Works from 1949 to 1959 by the artist best known for wonderfully original wood sculptures that resemble the creations of a zany folk artist. Through Nov. 19 at the Contemporary Museum, Honolulu, (808) 526-0232; tcmhi.org. Travels to Montclair (N.J.) Art Museum (Feb. 10 to May 27); Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, Philadelphia (June 30 to Oct. 21); Cantor Center for Visual Arts at Stanford University (Nov. 21, 2007, to March 2, 2008). SITE SANTA FE'S SIXTH INTERNATIONAL BIENNIAL: STILL POINTS OF THE TURNING WORLD Organized by the critic and curator Klaus Ottmann, this year's biennial presents individual installations by only 13 artists, including Jennifer Bartlett, Patty Chang, Peter Doig, Robert Grosvenor and Catherine Opie. Through Jan. 7 at SITE Santa Fe, N. M., (505) 989-1199; sitesantafe.org. NO RESERVATIONS: NATIVE AMERICAN HISTORY AND CULTURE IN CONTEMPORARY ART To challenge common ideas about American Indian-influenced art, this exhibition presents artworks by 10 Native and non-Native Americans who have come of age since the Indian rights movement of the 1960's and 70's. Through Feb. 25 at Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, Ridgefield, Conn., (203) 438-4519; aldrichart.org. COSMOPHILIA: ISLAMIC ART FROM THE DAVID COLLECTION, COPENHAGEN More than 120 objects, drawn from one of the world's great repositories of Islamic art, focus on ornamentation in ceramics, metal, ivory, wood, stone, crystal, parchment and paper pieces from the 7th to 19th centuries. Through Dec. 31 at McMullen Museum of Art, Boston College, (617) 552-8100; bc.edu/artmuseum. Travels to Smart Museum of Art, University of Chicago (Feb. 1 to May 20). TEMPLES AND TOMBS: TREASURES OF EGYPTIAN ART FROM THE BRITISH MUSEUM The full range of the British Museum's pre-eminent Egyptian antiquities collection is reflected in these masterworks and lesser known objects, made of stone, wood, terra cotta, gold, glass and papyrus from about 2686 B.C. to the fourth century A.D. Through Nov. 26 at the Oklahoma City Museum of Art, (405) 236-3100; okcmoa.com. Travels to Cummer Museum of Art and Gardens, Jacksonville, Fla. (Dec. 22 to March 18); North Carolina Museum of Art, Raleigh (April 15 to July 8); Albuquerque Museum of Art and History (Nov. 16, 2007 to Feb. 10, 2008); Fresno Metropolitan Museum of Art, History and Science (March 7 to June 1, 2008). ONE WAY OR ANOTHER: ASIAN AMERICAN ART NOW Paintings, sculptures, installations and videos by 17 young American artists of Asian descent. Through Dec. 10 at the Asia Society and Museum, Manhattan, (212) 288-6400; asiasociety.org. Travels to Blaffer Gallery, University of Houston (Jan. 20 to March 31); Berkeley Art Museum, Calif., (fall 2007); Japanese American National Museum, Los Angeles (spring 2008). JOHN ARMLEDER, ABOUT NOTHING. WORKS ON PAPER 1962-2007 Known as a Fluxus artist in the 60's and 70's, a Neo-Geo sculptor in the 80's and most recently as a publisher, Mr. Armleder, who is Swiss, creates a site-specific installation using hundreds of his own works on paper. Through Dec. 17 at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia, (215) 898-5911; icaphila.org. ENIGMA VARIATIONS: PHILIP GUSTON AND GIORGIO DE CHIRICO Guston recalled that he decided to become a painter as a teenager, after seeing paintings by de Chirico. This show of 30 paintings from early and late in the careers of both artists explores influences, affinities and parallels among their works. Through Nov. 25 at the Santa Monica (Calif.) Museum of Art, (310) 586-6488; smmoa.org. MOVING PICTURES: AMERICAN ART AND EARLY FILM, 1880-1910 The intriguing idea here is to compare paintings depicting movement with movies from the early years of cinema. The show includes 100 paintings by artists like John Singer Sargent, Thomas Eakins and George Bellows and 50 films made by Edison, Lumière and the American Mutoscope and Biograph Company. Wednesday through Dec. 9 at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780; nyu.edu/greyart. Travels to the Phillips Collection, Washington (Feb. 17 to May 20). CÉZANNE TO PICASSO: AMBROISE VOLLARD, PATRON OF THE AVANT-GARDE The career of Vollard, the Paris art dealer who gave Cézanne his first solo exhibition, is explored through works once exhibited in his gallery. Seven pictures from Cézanne's first show are included, along with paintings from an 1896 van Gogh retrospective, Picasso's first French exhibition and Matisse's first solo show. Thursday through Jan. 7 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Manhattan, (212) 535-7710; metmuseum.org. ECOTOPIA: THE SECOND I.C.P. TRIENNIAL OF PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO This year's version of the triennial will feature artists who focus on nature and ecological concerns. Among the 40 photographers and video makers selected are Robert Adams, Mitch Epstein and Thomas Ruff. Thursday through Jan. 7 at the International Center of Photography, Manhattan, (212) 857-0000; icp.org. MASTERS OF AMERICAN COMICS Arriving in New York after a presentation in Los Angeles, this big, two-museum exhibition displays works by 14 of the most influential 20th-century American comic artists. The Newark Museum will focus on artists like George Herriman and Chester Gould from the first half of the century; the Jewish Museum on later artists like R. Crumb, Gary Panter and Chris Ware. Friday through Jan. 28 at the Jewish Museum, Manhattan, (212) 423-3200, .thejewishmuseum.org and at the Newark Museum, (973) 596-6550, NewarkMuseum.org. LOUISE LAWLER: TWICE UNTITLED AND OTHER PICTURES (LOOKING BACK) With a coolly critical eye, Ms. Lawler has studied the intersections of art, commerce and power for almost three decades. Her photographs of art taken in the homes of collectors and of objects like etched drinking glasses and paperweights will be among about 60 works in her first museum retrospective. Saturday through Dec. 31 at the Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus, Ohio, (614) 292-3535; wexarts.org. MASSIVE CHANGE: THE FUTURE OF GLOBAL DESIGN Organized by the designer Bruce Mau and the Vancouver Art Gallery, this ambitious, internationally touring exhibition explores the impact of contemporary design on the modern world. It studies the latest innovations in urban design, transportation, information design and new materials. Saturday through Dec. 31 at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, (312) 280-2660; mcachicago.org. BIEDERMEIER: THE INVENTION OF SIMPLICITY The early-19th-century Biedermeier style in Germany, Austria and Northern Europe emphasized simplicity, elegance and utility in furniture, decorative arts, ceramics, glass and paintings. The first major North American exhibition devoted to the period will present more the 400 examples, many from European collections. Saturday through Jan. 1 at the Milwaukee Art Museum, (414) 224-3200; mam.org. I SEE NO STRANGER: EARLY SIKH ART AND DEVOTION Emerging in Northern India in the 16th century, Sikhism grew to be the world's fifth-largest religion. This exploration of Sikh art and culture will display about 100 objects from the 16th through 19th centuries, drawn from national and international collections. Sept. 17 through Jan. 29 at the Rubin Museum of Art, Manhattan, (212) 620-5000; rmanyc.org. DOMAINS OF WONDER: MASTERWORKS OF INDIAN PAINTING A selection of some 125 Indian manuscript pages and album paintings from the San Diego Museum of Art's renowned Edwin Binney III Collection. It offers a chronological and geographical overview of Indian court painting from the 14th to the early 20th century. Sept. 20 through Nov. 26 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, (617) 267-9300; mfa.org. TREASURES/TESOROS/TESOUROS: THE ARTS IN LATIN AMERICA, 1492-1820 A blockbuster with 250 works -- paintings, sculpture, furniture, gold and silver objects, ceramics and textiles -- from South and Central America will reflect the interaction of indigenous and colonial Spanish and Portuguese cultures. Sept. 20 through Dec. 31 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, (215) 763-8100; philamuseum.org. Travels to Antiguo Colegio de San Ildefonso, Mexico City (winter and spring, 2007); Los Angeles County Museum of Art (summer 2007). SIMPLY DROOG, 10 + 3 YEARS OF CREATING INNOVATION AND DISCUSSION Droog Design, a Dutch collective, has been producing witty and surprising spins on lamps, chairs, wallpaper and other conventional forms since 1993. This show, which had its debut in Munich in 2004, will present more than 160 designs. Sept. 21 through Jan. 14 at the Museum of Arts and Design, Manhattan, (212) 956-3535; americancraftmuseum.org. BEAUTY SURROUNDS US To inaugurate the Diker Pavilion, the new $5 million art and performance space in its George Gustave Heye Center building, the museum will exhibit 77 objects from the permanent collection, including wood carvings, ceremonial clothing, musical instruments, textiles and games. Opens Sept. 23 at the National Museum of the American Indian, Manhattan, (212) 514-3700; AmericanIndian.si.edu. PICASSO AND AMERICAN ART Picasso's influence on American artists is the theme of a show juxtaposing Picasso's works with those of Stuart Davis, Arshile Gorky, Willem de Kooning, Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns and others. Sept. 28 through Jan. 28 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Manhattan, (800) 944-8639; whitney.org. Travels to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (Feb. 23 to May 28); Walker Art Center, Minneapolis (June 17 to Sept. 9, 2007). BOB DYLAN'S AMERICAN JOURNEY, 1956-1966 The first big museum exhibition to study Mr. Dylan's early career will present historical artifacts -- handwritten lyrics, letters, instruments and photographs -- as well as films of performances by and interviews with him and others. Sept. 29 through Jan. 6 at the Morgan Library and Museum, Manhattan, (212) 685-0008; themorgan.org. October ALABAMA FOLK POTTERY This scholarly study of folk pottery will present about 70 pieces made in Alabama from the 19th to mid-20th century. Oct. 1 through Jan. 7 at the Birmingham (Ala.) Museum of Art, (205) 254-2566; artsbma.org. CONSTABLE'S GREAT LANDSCAPES: THE SIX-FOOT PAINTINGS In 1818-19 the English landscape painter John Constable began his greatest works, a series of six-foot-wide canvases that are the subject of this exhibition. ''The Hay Wain,'' ''View on the Stour Near Dedham'' and ''Hadleigh Castle'' will be featured, along with full-size oil-on-canvas sketches. Oct. 1 through Dec. 31 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, (202) 737-4215; nga.gov. Travels to Huntington Library and Art Gallery, San Marino, Calif. (Feb. 3 to April 29). A DEAF ARTIST IN EARLY AMERICA: THE WORLDS OF JOHN BREWSTER JR. John Brewster Jr. (1766-1854) was noted as among the best of the Early American itinerant portrait painters. This exhibition, organized by the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., presents about 50 of his acutely simplified portraits and considers how his deafness affected his art and life. Oct. 4 through Jan. 7 at the American Folk Art Museum, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040; folkartmuseum.org. GILDED SPLENDOR: TREASURES OF CHINA'S LIAO EMPIRE (907-1125) Based on archaeological findings over the last 10 years, this exhibition of more than 200 recently excavated objects from Inner Mongolia explores the impact of the Khitan people on China after they established the Liao Dynasty. Oct. 5 through Dec. 31 at the Asia Society and Museum, Manhattan, (212) 288-6400; asiasociety.org. Travels to Museum of Asian Art, Cologne (January to April 2007); Museum Rietberg, Zurich (May to July 2007). KLEE AND AMERICA The quirky Swiss-German Modernist painter Paul Klee was warmly embraced by American collectors in the 1930's and 40's, and this show of more than 80 works from American institutions and collections examines the reasons. Oct. 6 through Jan. 28 at the Menil Collection, Houston, (713) 525-9400; menil.org. DENVER ART MUSEUM A new addition, the $90.5 million Frederic C. Hamilton building designed by Daniel Libeskind, will provide almost 40,000 square feet of new exhibition space this fall in a futuristic jumble of angular, intersecting volumes. Three yearlong exhibitions based on private collections will inaugurate the expansion: ''Breaking the Mold: The Virginia Vogel Mattern Collection of Contemporary Native American Art;'' ''Radar: Selections From the Collection of Vicki and Kent Logan,'' a show of modern and contemporary art; and ''Japanese Art From the Colorado Collection of Kimiko and John Powers.'' Opens Oct. 7 at the Denver Art Museum, (720) 865-5000; denverartmuseum.org. LUCIO FONTANA: VENICE/NEW YORK The first major United States exhibition since 1977 to be devoted to this Italian avant-gardist known for slashing and puncturing his painted canvases and metal panels. Oct. 10 through Jan. 21 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Manhattan, (212) 423-3500; guggenheim.org. TROPICÁLIA: A REVOLUTION IN BRAZILIAN CULTURE Inaugurating the Bronx Museum's new $19 million building, designed by Arquitectonica, this exhibition examines one of the most influential movements to emerge from of South America in the last 50 years. It includes art by Lygia Clark, Lygia Pape, Hélio Oiticica and others, as well as examples from film, music, advertising, fashion, television and theater. Contemporary artists influenced by tropicalismo, including Arto Lindsay, Marepe and Ernesto Neto, are also included. Oct. 7 through Jan. 28 at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, (718) 681-6000; bronxmuseum.org. PIPILOTTI RIST Surveying the 20-year career of the inventive and influential Swiss video artist, this show offers two new video installation, a feature film and early videos, including the unforgettable ''Ever is Overall'' (1997) in which a pretty young woman smashes car windows to a catchy musical sound track. Oct. 14 through Jan. 14 at the Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston, (713) 284-8250; camh.org. NEW IRELAND: ART OF THE SOUTH PACIFIC Sculpture, masks and other ritual objects, made from wood, vines, shells, fiber, feathers and other materials by 19th-century natives of the South Pacific island New Ireland. Oct. 15 through Jan. 7 at the St. Louis Art Museum, (314) 721-0072; slam.org. Travels to Musée du Quai Branly, Paris (April 2 to July 8); Ethnologisches Museum Staatliche Museen zu Berlin (Aug. 10 to Nov. 11, 2007). COURBET AND THE MODERN LANDSCAPE The 19th-century French painter is most celebrated for his vigorous social realism and erotic images of women. This 47-picture exhibition, organized by the J. Paul Getty Museum, is the first international loan exhibition to focus on his landscapes. Oct. 15 through Jan. 7 at the Walters Art Museum, Baltimore, (410) 547-9000; thewalters.org. BARCELONA AND MODERNITY: PICASSO, GAUDÍ, MIRÓ AND DALÍ The first comprehensive exhibition to focus on the Catalan Renaissance, a period of extraordinary artistic fertility centered in Barcelona from the late 1880's until Franco took power in 1939. The show offers more than 200 works: paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints, posters, decorative objects, furniture and architectural models. Oct. 15 through Jan. 7 at the Cleveland Museum of Art, (216) 421-7350; clemusart.com. Travels to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Manhattan (March 7 to June 3).
