EHON: THE ARTIST AND THE BOOK IN JAPAN An examination of Japanese illustrated books that is billed as the largest ever assembled. The more than 200 items from the 8th to the 21st century include Buddhist sutras, painted manuscripts, portraits, landscapes, calligraphic verses and photographic books. Works by noted artists like Hiroshi Sugimoto, Kitagawa Utamaro and Takashi Murakami will also be on view. Oct. 20 to Feb. 4 at the New York Public Library, (212) 869-8089; nypl.org. IN THE BEGINNING: BIBLES BEFORE THE YEAR 1000 To narrate the Christian Bible's origin and evolution, this landmark show will display some the earliest biblical fragments in existence, along with later, lavishly bound and illustrated volumes. Oct. 21 through Jan. 7 at the Freer Gallery of Art/Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, Washington, (202) 633-4880, asia.si.edu. JOHN LATHAM: TIME BASE AND THE UNIVERSE Until his death this year Latham worked in painting, assemblage, film, performance and other forms, trying to create a unified artistic, philosophical and scientific basis for his visionary art. This is the first survey of this British artist's 50-year career to appear in the United States. Oct. 22 through Jan. 8 at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, Queens, (718) 784-2084; PS1.org. DOMENICO TIEPOLO: A NEW TESTAMENT The Venetian painter Domenico Tiepolo (1727-1804), son of the great Baroque painter Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, created the most extensive known cycle of pictures illustrating the New Testament: 313 large, virtuoso drawings in ink and wash. This exhibition will present some 60 of the best pages. Oct. 24 to Jan.7 at the Frick Collection, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700; frick.org. CALIFORNIA AS MUSE: THE ART OF ARTHUR AND LUCIA MATHEWS The designers Arthur and Lucia Mathews, originators of the California Decorative Style, were major figures in the West Coast art and culture world from around 1890 to 1920. This show offers more than 150 examples: murals, paintings, drawings, graphic design, illustrations, furniture and decorative objects. Oct. 28 through March 25 at the Oakland Museum of California, (510) 238-2200; museumca.org. BRICE MARDEN: A RETROSPECTIVE OF PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS From his monochromatic abstractions of the 70's to his recent compositions of meandering colored lines, Mr. Marden has produced the most consistently sensuous and elegant American painting of the last four decades. This retrospective will present 50 paintings and 50 drawings from all phases of his career. Oct. 29 to Jan. 15 at the Museum of Modern Art, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400; moma.org. Travels to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (Feb. 17 to May 13). THE MODERN WEST: AMERICAN LANDSCAPES, 1890-1950 Designed to question common perceptions about art of the American West, this exhibition brings together about 100 paintings, watercolors and photographs by Frederic Remington, Georgia O'Keeffe, Thomas Hart Benton, Jackson Pollock and others, as well as examples of American Indian art. Oct. 29 through Jan. 28 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, (713) 639-7300; mfah.org. Travels to Los Angeles County Museum of Art (March 4 to June 3). November ALBERS AND MOHOLY-NAGY: FROM THE BAUHAUS TO THE NEW WORLD Two pioneers of 20th-century Modernism inspire this extensive exhibition organized by the Tate Modern in London. The German-born Josef Albers (1888-1976) and the Hungarian Laszlo Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946) taught at the Bauhaus in the 1920's and became influential teachers in the United States. On view will be paintings, sculpture, photography, film and furniture designs. Nov. 2 through Jan. 21 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Manhattan, (800) 944-8639; whitney.org. RON MUECK The London-based Australian sculptor known for magically realistic sculptures of people will show 10 works, including the famous smaller-than-life ''Dead Dad'' and the more than eight-foot-tall ''Head of a Baby.'' Nov. 3 through Feb. 4 at the Brooklyn Museum, (718) 638-5000; brooklynmuseum.org. MORRIS LOUIS NOW: AN AMERICAN MASTER REVISITED Though not so fervently admired today as in the 60's, Louis's stained Color Field paintings can still captivate. This focused, scholarly show will present about 30 works from his last, most innovative period, 1951 to 1962. Nov. 4 through Jan. 24 at the High Museum of Art, Atlanta, (404) 733-4444; High.org. Travels to the Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego (Feb. 17 to May 6). WRESTLE Inaugurating Bard's newly expanded Center for Curatorial Studies, also known as the Hessel Museum of Art, this exhibition puts on view more than 200 works from the permanent collection, including pieces Cindy Sherman, Richard Prince, Paul McCarthy and Robert Gober. Nov. 12 through spring at the Hessel Museum of Art, Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, (845) 758-7598. PRAYERS AND PORTRAITS: UNFOLDING THE NETHERLANDISH DIPTYCH A show of more than 40 diptychs -- hinged, two-panel, devotional works -- from the 15th and 16th centuries. Some long-separated panels will be reunited and works by masters like Rogier van der Weyden and Hans Memling will be included. Nov. 12 through Feb. 4 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, (202) 737-4215; nga.gov. Travels to Koninklijk Museum voor Schone Kunsten, Antwerp (March 3 to May 27). GLITTER AND DOOM: GERMAN PORTRAITS FROM THE 1920'S Some of the liveliest portraiture ever produced was done in the 1920's in the Weimar Republic. Fiercely incisive images of upstanding professionals and shady bohemians by Max Beckmann, Otto Dix, George Grosz, Christian Schad and others will make up this show of about 40 paintings and 60 drawings. Nov. 14 through Feb. 19 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Manhattan, (212) 535-7710; metmuseum.org HOLY IMAGE, HALLOWED GROUND: ICONS FROM SINAI Built in the sixth century, the Monastery of St. Catherine at Mount Sinai in Egypt is the world's oldest continuously operating Christian monastery. It also owns one of the world's finest collections of Byzantine icons and manuscripts, from which this exhibition has been selected. Nov. 14 through March 4 at the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, (310) 440-7300; getty.edu. AFRICA COMICS As an art form and a medium of cross-cultural communication, African comics dispense humor, social awareness, history and myth. Organized in conjunction with Africa e Mediterraneo in Bologna, Italy, this exhibition of recent examples is the first on the subject to be seen in the United States. Nov. 15 through March 18 at the Studio Museum in Harlem, (212) 864-4500; studiomuseum.org. JOSEPH CORNELL: NAVIGATING THE IMAGINATION The first full-scale survey of this great American Surrealist in 25 years includes boxes, collages, films and graphic designs among its 200 works. Nov. 17 through Feb. 19 at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Washington, (202) 275-1500; americanart.si.edu. EL GRECO TO PICASSO: TIME, TRUTH, AND HISTORY The Guggenheim's entire rotunda will be filled with a survey of Spanish painting that is being billed as the most historically comprehensive ever presented in the United States. Among some 135 paintings borrowed from European and North American museums will be major works by Velázquez, Goya, Picasso, Miró and Dalí. Nov. 17 through spring 2007 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Manhattan, (212) 423-3500; guggenheim.org. MAGRITTE AND CONTEMPORARY ART: THE TREACHERY OF IMAGES Exploring René Magritte's considerable influence on American and European artists of the post-World War II generation, this exhibition will display 60 Magrittes with paintings and sculptures by 30 artists active over the last 40 years, including Richard Artschwager, John Baldessari, Marcel Broodthaers, Robert Gober, Jeff Koons and Sherrie Levine. Nov. 19 through March 4 at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, (323) 857-6000; lacma.org. SKIN AND BONES: PARALLEL PRACTICES IN FASHION AND ARCHITECTURE A selection of works by an international roster of fashion designers and architects explores the themes of space, movement, the body, shelter, identity and process, as well as stylistic parallels, like Minimalism and Deconstruction found in buildings and clothing. Nov. 19 through March 5 at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, (213) 626-6222; oca.org. December NATIONAL DESIGN TRIENNIAL: DESIGN LIFE NOW The museum's third triennial will present works by 87 designers and firms in the fields of architecture, furniture, film, graphics, animation, science, medicine and fashion. Dec. 8 through July 29 at the Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Manhattan, (212) 849-8400; cooperhewitt.org. January STRANGE NEW WORLD: ART AND DESIGN FROM TIJUANA Works by 20 artists and architects from the explosively growing border city of Tijuana, Mexico, examine the complexities of urban life, migration, the media and globalization. Jan. 13 through April 7 at the Santa Monica (Calif.) Museum of Art, (310) 586-6488; smmoa.org. A ROSE HAS NO TEETH: BRUCE NAUMAN'S FORMATIVE YEARS Mr. Nauman made some of his most ground-breaking art while living in Northern California in the 1960's. This exhibition gathers fiberglass sculptures, casts of negative spaces and the artist's own body, neon light works and his early films and videos. Jan. 18 through April 15 at the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, University of California, Berkeley, (510) 642-0808, bampfa.berkeley.edu. MATISSE: PAINTER AS SCULPTOR A major show of 40 of Matisse's most important sculptures, with related paintings and drawings. Additional works by Cézanne, Brancusi, Giacometti, Picasso and other modern masters will help put into context Matisse's three-dimensional achievements. Jan. 21 through April 29 at the Dallas Museum of Art and Nasher Sculpture Center, (214) 922-1200; DallasMuseumofArt.org. Travels to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (June 10 to Sept. 4); Baltimore Museum of Art (Oct. 28, 2007, to Feb. 3, 2008). RICHARD PRINCE: EARLY WORKS This exhibition of more than 30 drawings, prints, altered text works and mixed media photo-collages from 1974-77 promises to alter existing views of the influential Mr. Prince's career. Jan. 28 through June 24 at the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6100; neuberger.org. MARTIN RAMIREZ One of the 20th century's great discoveries in art was Martin Ramirez (1895-1963). As a psychiatric patient in a California state hospital, he created mysterious and formally assured drawings of trains, tunnels, mountains, Madonnas and animals. The first Ramirez retrospective in more than 20 years will include approximately 70 of his hair-raising works. Jan. 23 through April 29 at the American Folk Art Museum, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040; folkartmuseum.org. MERCE CUNNINGHAM: DANCING ON THE CUTTING EDGE, part i The celebrated avant-garde choreographer has collaborated with artists -- Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg among them -- over his 50-year career. He has worked with younger artists too, including Ernesto Neto, Charles Long and Christian Marclay, whose sets and costumes for Cunningham productions will be the focus of this exhibition. Jan. 26 through April 29 at the Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, Fla., (305) 893-6211; mocanomi.org. PHILIP-LORCA diCORCIA A photographer known for his uncommonly vivid street photography and his staged, intensely intimate pictures of people indoors has his first solo museum exhibition in the United States since 1993. Feb. 9 through April 29 at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, (617) 266-5152; icaboston.org. FRANCIS BACON IN THE 1950's Organized at the Sainsbury Center for Visual Arts in Britain, this exhibition offers a detailed picture of an extraordinarily productive decade in the career of a great British painter. Some of his best-known images will be on view, including screaming popes, scary dogs, sphinxes, self-portraits, heads of William Blake and existentially isolated men. Jan. 27 through April 15 at the Milwaukee Art Museum, (414) 224-3200; mam.org. Travels to Albright-Knox Gallery, Buffalo (May 5 to July 30). JASPER JOHNS: AN ALLEGORY OF PAINTING The first and most influential decade of one of the most influential 20th-century American artists will be examined in this show of about 80 works, organized by four themes: targets, mechanical devices, the naming of colors and imprints of the body. Jan. 28 through April 29 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, (202) 737-4215; nga.gov. Travels to Kunstmuseum Basel (June 2 to Sept. 9). VIJA CELMINS: A DRAWINGs RETROSPECTIVE Working with meticulous care and extraordinary skill, Ms. Celmins has quietly produced some of the most resonant paintings and sculptures of the postwar era. This exhibition -- organized at the Pompidou Center in Paris, where it runs Oct. 25 through Jan. 8 -- includes about 70 works on paper from all phases of her career, including her vividly realistic images of the moon, oceans, deserts, clouds, and stars. Jan. 28 through April 22 at the Hammer Museum, Los Angeles, (310) 443-7000; hammer.ucla.edu. February HIGH TIMES/HARD TIMES While enormous developments in vanguard New York art occurred from 1967 to 1975, painting was said to have almost died. This exhibition will prove, however, that many excellent painters did innovative work in that period. Among the 37 artists represented are Jo Baer, Lynda Benglis, Mel Bochner, Louise Fishman and Elizabeth Murray. Feb. 15 through April 22 at the National Academy Museum, Manhattan, (212) 369-4880; nationalacademy.org. GEORGIA O'KEEFFE: CIRCLING AROUND ABSTRACTION An unusually focused exhibition will concentrate on abstract tendencies in O'Keeffe's painting and in particular on her use of circular and oval forms. Feb. 10 through May 6 at the Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach, Fla., (561) 832-5196; norton.org. Travels to the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum, Santa Fe, N.M. (May 25 to Sept. 9, 2007); Minneapolis Institute of Arts (Oct. 7, 2007, to Jan. 6, 2008). SAN FRANCISCO PSYCHEDELIC The psychedelic music scene in 1960's San Francisco is the focus of this exhibition, with about 75 documentary photographs by Herb Greene, Jim Marshall, Bob Seidermann and others, and 25 concert posters and album covers. Feb. 10 through June 10 at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, (612) 870-3000; artsmia.org. PISSARRO: CREATING THE IMPRESSIONIST LANDSCAPE With 45 paintings from major museums and private collections, this exhibition focuses on the decade 1864-74, when Camille Pissarro transformed himself from a traditional landscape painter into a pioneering Impressionist. Feb. 11 through May 13 at the Baltimore Museum of Art, (443) 573-1700; artbma.org. Travels to Milwaukee Art Museum (June 10 to Sept. 9); the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, to Jan. 6, 2008). UNTAMED: THE ART OF ANTOINE-LOUIS BARYE Some 130 works by the pre-eminent animal sculptor of the 19th century, including bronzes, oils, watercolors and drawings from the Walters's own Barye holdings, considered the world's most extensive. Feb. 11 through May 6 at the Walters Art Museum, Baltimore, (410) 547-9000; thewalters.org. GEORGE STUBBS One of the all-time great painters of horses and other animals, the English artist Stubbs (1724-1806) will have 20 pictures on view, drawn from English collections and including major works never shown before in the United States. Feb. 14 through May 27 at the Frick Collection, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700; www.frick.org. TAMAYO: A MODERN ICON REINTERPRETED Rufino Tamayo (1899-1991) was among Mexico's most celebrated Modernist artists. This exhibition presents 100 paintings made over the course of his seven-decade career in Mexico City, New York and Paris. Feb. 17 through May 27 at the Santa Barbara (Calif.) Museum of Art, (805) 963-4364; sbma.net. KARA WALKER: my complement, my enemy, my oppressor, my love For two decades Ms. Walker has explored -- acutely, imaginatively and bravely -- the psychology of race in America. This mid-career survey will include the storytelling silhouettes cut from black paper for which she is best known, as well as paintings, works on paper, light projections and films. Feb. 17 through May 13 at the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, (612) 375-7600; walkerart.org. Travels to the Whitney Museum of American Art (Nov. 11 to Feb. 3, 2008). JEFF WALL Large back-lighted photographic transparencies depicting elaborately staged, sociologically suggestive events have made Mr. Wall a most influential artist. This retrospective presents about 40 works made since the late 1970's. Feb. 25 through May 14 at the Museum of Modern Art, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400; moma.org. Travels to Art Institute of Chicago (June 30 to Sept. 30); San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (Oct. 27 to Jan. 27). March WACK! ART AND THE FEMINIST REVOLUTION Billed as ''the first comprehensive, historical exhibition to examine the international foundations and legacy of feminist art,'' this show will include works in many different mediums from 1965 to 1980, made by about 100 artists from North America, Latin America, Europe, Asia, Australia and New Zealand. March 4 through July 30 at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, (213) 626-6222; moca.org. GLOBAL FEMINISMS The first exhibition to be presented by the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, a new 8,300-square-foot gallery and educational space dedicated to feminist art and culture. The show will include art in all mediums since from 1990, by some 80 women from around the world. March 23 through July 1 at the Brooklyn Museum, (718) 638-5000; brooklynmuseum.org. VAN GOGH AND EXPRESSIONISM Organized with the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, this ambitious show will examine the influence of van Gogh's painting on German and Austrian Expressionists. Along with his paintings there will be work by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Gustav Klimt, Egon Schiele and others. March 23 through July 2 at Neue Galerie, Manhattan, (212) 628-6200; neuegalerie.org. VENICE AND THE ISLAMIC WORLD, 828-1797 The influence of Islamic culture on Venice over almost a thousand years is the subject of this timely exhibition. Including Islamic as well as Venetian objects, it will study the phenomenon of Orientalism and show how contact with the Islamic world brought new technological, artistic and intellectual information to the West. March 27 through July 8 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Manhattan, (212) 535-7710; metmuseum.org. AWAKENINGS: ZEN FIGURE PAINTING IN MEDIEVAL JAPAN The first systematic examination of medieval Zen figurative painting to appear in an American museum, this show will exhibit about 60 Japanese and Chinese works from the 13th to 17th century. March 28 through June 24 at the Japan Society, Manhattan, (212) 832-1155; japansociety.org. KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE Though not the flashiest, Durand was among the best painters of the Hudson River School. An exhibition of some 75 works will be the first survey of his career in more than 35 years. March 30 through July 29 at the Brooklyn Museum, (718) 638-5000; brooklynmuseum.org. Travels to Smithsonian American Art Museum, Washington, (Sept. 14 to Jan. 6, 2008); San Diego Museum of Art, Calif. (Feb. 8 to June 1, 2008). April BEYOND THE WHITE CUBE: A RETROSPECTIVE OF BRIAN O'DOHERTY/PATRICK IRELAND Author of the memorable essay ''Inside the White Cube,'' the critic Brian O'Doherty uses the pseudonym Patrick Ireland when he creates his environments, using string to outline spaces in two and three dimensions. His 50-year retrospective will include paintings, sculpture, installations and drawings. April 24 through July 12 at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780; nyu.edu/greyart. GEGO, BETWEEN TRANSPARENCY AND THE INVISIBLE The Venezuelan sculptor Gertrude Goldschmidt (1912-94), known as Gego, specialized in abstract, weblike wire constructions and installations. This exhibition will focus on the play of line and light in her prints and drawings. April 21 through July 21 at the Drawing Center, SoHo, (212) 219-2166; drawingcenter.org. KAREN KILIMNIK The influential Ms. Kilimnik emerged in the early 1990's, making installations, paintings and drawings that looked like the creations of a teenage girl preoccupied by fashion, celebrities, movies and nostalgic fantasies. This will be her first major career survey. April 21 through Aug. 5 at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia, (215) 898-5911; icaphila.org. May IKE TAIGA AND TOKUYAMA GYOKURAN: jAPANESE MASTERS OF THE BRUSH This husband and wife were master brush painters in 18th-century Japan. This exhibition of more than 200 works, including screens, hand scrolls, hanging scrolls and fan paintings, will display their work in the United States for the first time. May 1 through July 22 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, (215) 763-8100; philamuseum.org. OUDRY'S PAINTED MENAGERIE A life-size portrait of a famous rhinoceros named Clara and portraits of 13 other denizens of Louis XV's royal menagerie are featured in these paintings by Jean-Baptiste Oudry (1686-1755), the foremost animal painter of his day. Porcelain objects, jewelry, paintings, prints, drawings and posters will illustrate the 18th-century phenomenon of exotic animal celebrity. May 1 through Sept 2 at the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, (310) 440-7300; getty.edu. LOUISE NEVELSON The career of this major American sculptor, known for her often mysterious Cubist assemblages of found wooden elements, will be surveyed for the first time in more than 30 years. On view will be about 60 works from private and public collections. May 4 through Sept. 16 at the Jewish Museum, Manhattan, (212) 423-3200; thejewishmuseum.org. EDWARD HOPPER With his no-nonsense technique and formal economy, Hopper captured the mournful soul of America like no other modern artist. This retrospective, the first in Boston in 50 years, will present nearly 100 paintings, watercolors and prints from 1925 to 1950, the period in which he made of his most memorable pictures. May 6 through Aug. 19 at the Museum of Fine Art Arts, Boston, (617) 267-9300; mfa.org. Travels to National Gallery of Art, Washington (Sept. 2007 to Jan. 2008); Art Institute of Chicago (February to May 2008). MARY HEILMANN The influential, much loved painter of rigorous, insouciant and rambunctious abstractions receives her first museum retrospective. About 75 works made since 1972 will be included, and Ms. Heilmann's interests in ceramics, decorative arts, film and music will also be explored. May 13 through Aug. 26 at the Orange County Museum of Art, Newport Beach, Calif., (949) 759-1122; ocma.net. GERDA TARO Taro (1910-37), who became a legend in Paris for her documentary photography during the 1930's, was also the companion of Robert Capa, whose career she helped start. She was killed by a tank while photographing the Spanish Civil War. This show will be drawn from the center's collection, which has the most extensive holdings of Taro's images. Sept. 21, 2007 through Jan. 6, 2008 at the International Center of Photography, Manhattan, (212) 857-0000; icp.org. ANISH KAPOOR One of Britain's most celebrated sculptors, Mr. Kapoor is known for abstract works in which color, reflective materials and organic forms conspire to confound and heighten visual perception. This selection of work made since 1992 will be his first major survey in the United States in 15 years. May 25 through Sept. 3 at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, (617) 266-5152; icaboston.org. June SITUATION COMEDY: HUMOR IN RECENT ART If nothing else, this show promises to be amusing. It will present more than 60 examples of painting, sculpture, photographs and videos by 30 artists for whom comedy in one from or another is a primary motivation. Participants include Tom Friedman, Luis Gispert, Rodney Graham, William Pope L., Dana Schutz, Michael Smith and John Waters. June 1 through Sept. 3 at the Museum of Art, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., (954) 525-5500; moafl.org. RICHARD SERRA This sculptor will receive a 40-year career retrospective, ranging from his early installations of raw sculptural materials like rubber, neon and lead and precariously balanced metal slabs to his enormous, graceful works of rolled steel called Torqued Ellipses. Three new works have been commissioned for the exhibition. June 3 through Sept. 10 at the Museum of Modern Art, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400; moma.org. SYMBOLS OF POWER: NAPOLEON AND THE ART OF THE EMPIRE STYLE, 1800-815 The first comprehensive survey of Empire Style decorative arts will exhibit about 150 objects -- furniture, silver, bronzes, jewelry, textiles, wallpaper, ceramics and paintings -- to explore how Napoleon appropriated imperial emblems and imagery from Egyptian and Roman antiquity to associate his rule with great civilizations. June 17 to Sept. 16 at the St. Louis Art Museum, (314) 721-0072; slam.org. Travels to Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (Oct. 21 to Jan. 27, 2007). THE MIRROR AND THE MASK: PORTRAITURE IN THE AGE OF PICASSO The art of portraiture went through radical changes during the 20th century. This ambitious exhibition, organized with the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum of Art in Madrid, where it runs from Feb. 6 to May 20, will track the portrait's development from 1890 to 1980 through more than 80 paintings and a smaller number of sculptures by Cézanne, van Gogh, Picasso, Matisse, Beckmann, Bacon and others. June 17 through Sept. 16 at the Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, Tex., (817) 332-8451; kimbellart.org. a MIRROR OF NATURE: NORDIC LANDSCAPE PAINTING 1840-1910 Four Scandinavian museums collaborated on this major show of 115 landscape paintings that were influenced by the romance of Old Norse culture and by modern trends from artistic centers like Rome, Paris and Dresden. June 24 through Sept. 2 at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, (612) 870- 3200; artsmia.org.

FOR failing to meet performance standards, the Clara T. O'Connell elementary school in Bristol, Conn., spent three years on the ''in need of improvement'' list under the federal No Child Left Behind program. When a new list came out last month, Connecticut had 290 elementary and middle schools on it, but the O'Connell School was not among them. It had achieved what no other school in the state had managed under the four-year-old program: It had worked itself off the list.

So much for honor among, er, co-conspirators. Last year, Wal-Mart accused Robert E. Hey Jr., a vice president, of helping his boss, Thomas M. Coughlin, a board member, to steal tens of thousands of dollars from the giant discount retailer by filing improper expense reports.

If we are fortunate, we will open our newspapers this morning knowing that there have been no major terrorist attacks on American soil in nearly five years. Did we just get lucky? The Op-Ed page asked 10 people with experience in security and counterterrorism to answer the following question: What is one major reason the United States has not suffered a major attack since 2001, and what is the one thing you would recommend the nation do in order to avoid attacks in the future? Giving Muslims Hope THE best news in our struggle against terrorism is that we have not been hit at home since the 9/11 attacks. Yet terrorists are patient. We remain a target and must expect another attack.

BAILEY--Glenn W, 81, founder and former Chairman of Bairnco Corporation, died in Stamford, CT of pancreatic cancer. A resident of Hobe Sound, FL and Darien, CT, he is survived by his wife of 54 years, Cornelia Tarrant Bailey. He will be greatly missed by all who loved and admired him. Donations in his memory can be made to the Richard L. Rosenthall Hospice Residence, 35 Shelburne Road, Stamford, CT 06902.

PERHAPS partly because it was made at a time when movies often threw in a little something for everyone, there's a sappy love story tucked into the corners of ''Frankenstein.'' But it's inconsequential: there could be nothing in ''Frankenstein'' more romantic than Boris Karloff's monster, right. With his heavy-lidded gaze and his twisted smile, he's not quite human and yet more human than we can almost bear. To honor the movie's 75th anniversary, Universal unveils this special edition with extras that have not appeared on previous releases. (On the same date Universal will also release the 75th anniversary edition of ''Dracula.'' And Sept. 19 marks the release of the Boris Karloff Collection, featuring some of his lesser-known films, including ''Tower of London'' and ''The Strange Door,'' which co-stars Charles Laughton.) We learn that Karloff would entertain his fellow actors on-set with Cockney ditties, and insisted on breaking for tea.

What, exactly, makes a retirement home a gay retirement home? That is the intriguing question that was being answered as residents moved in to RainbowVision, a new development in Santa Fe, N.M., that bills itself as ''the first full-service resort retirement community welcoming the gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender'' population.

WADA--Michiyo, widow of Billy Wada of famed downtown Mita Japanese restaurant, passed away Wednesday, August 30, 2006. A memorial service will be held at the Church Center of the United Nations, 44th St. at 1st Ave. at 1 PM, Sunday, September 10. The family asks for donations to the Japanese American Association in lieu of flowers. For info: 917-405-3845.

Little by little, the cafe inside Atticus Bookstore in New Haven has swallowed more and more of the space. It began with a couple of tables, a counter and display cases in 1981, when the cafe opened. There are now 20 tables occupying about a third of the store, and according to Caleb Fraser, an assistant manager, plans are slowly evolving for even more cafe space. The cafe has proved to be wildly popular for its hearty soups, generous sandwiches and salads, coffees and other beverages, as well as baked goods, including cookies, tarts, muffins and scones. A popular order is soup and half a sandwich or salad for $8.20. Half a sandwich and half a salad at the same price is also a favorite combination, with eight sandwiches or panini and seven salads to choose from.

Sharapova Wins U.S. Open Maria Sharapova, losing her trophy lid, beat Justine Henin-Hardenne in the U.S. Open final. Roger Federer and Andy Roddick play today for the men's title. SPORTSSUNDAY Shuttle Blasts Off Safely After Weeks of Delays After two frustrating weeks of delays, the space shuttle Atlantis and its six astronauts took off on a mission to resume construction of the International Space Station for the first time since the Columbia disaster. PAGE 24 Pope Begins Bavarian Tour Pope Benedict XVI arrived in his home country, Germany, to begin a personal six-day pilgrimage to the Bavarian places that shaped him as a child. PAGE 21 New Jersey Firefighter Killed A firefighter answering an erroneous report of people trapped in a burning building in Union City, N.J., rushed inside and was killed by a backdraft of flames. PAGE 35 New Magazine on Real Estate In the debut issue of Key magazine, how to invest in property without owning any; what $750,000 will buy in London, Nashville and 10 other cities around the world, and contractors' secrets on how to renovate inexpensively. KEY MAGAZINE The Fall Season A mature Matt Damon and Penélope Cruz, and a nervous Diddy are just some of the highlights to be found in the annual preview of the new season. ARTS & LEISURE

DORFMAN--Dr. Sam H. 89 and 11 months. Cherished husband of Gertrude. Darling father of Fern, Michael, Urszula and Edmond. Beautiful grandfather of Russell. Devoted brother of Mayme, Beatrice and Sophie. Dearest son of Sadie and Harry. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School, City College, and Auburn University School of Veterinary Medicine. Most wonderful and dedicated veterinarian to dear pets and their families for almost 50 years. Former President of the New York City Veterinary Medical Association. He will always be an inspiration to his family and friends for how to live life wholeheartedly and selflessly, always putting others first and giving unconditional love. His grace, wisdom, kindness, compassion, intel ligence, humor and sensibilities have enriched our lives and will always be remembered. He was our center.

IT may have left no physical damage in its wake, but the recent communal storm in this oceanfront city over the future of its beaches has realigned the political and environmental landscape. Despite fears about the city's vulnerability to a major hurricane, the five-member City Council, three Democrats and two Republicans, voted unanimously in May to reject a $98.5 million beach preservation project by the Army Corps of Engineers that was designed to protect Long Beach from ocean flooding.

ORA, the year-old restaurant alongside the Community Theater in Morristown, had me hooked five minutes after I sat down. That's when our server brought us a round of amuse-bouches, quivery little pea-green parfaits in shot glasses. She described the dish well, but I almost wished she'd let us figure it out for ourselves. It was kiwi foam, topped by a layer of Greek yogurt and a dab of black-olive-and-sun-dried-tomato tapenade: a set of familiar flavors and textures -- sweet, sour and salty; airy, chewy and crunchy (from the kiwi seeds) -- brought together in an utterly unexpected way, all in the space of about two cubic inches.

Dr. Meredith Susan Wepner, a daughter of Shelley and Roy H. Wepner of Demarest, N.J., was married last evening to Judd Benjamin Grossman, the son of Nancy and Stanley M. Grossman of Harrison, N.Y. Cantor Theodore Aronson officiated at Pleasantdale Chateau, a caterer in West Orange, N.J. The bride and bridegroom met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which she graduated magna cum laude and he cum laude. He also received a law degree there.

Jay Leno The Iranian minister of health has announced they have a cure for AIDS. I'm guessing the key ingredient is enriched uranium. The president of Iran is coming to the United States. How would you like to be behind him in airport security?

Rob Walker (Consumed, Aug. 27) might have mentioned that buying cured pork is a Spanish family tradition, often around Christmas. The chosen shank that hangs (or is propped in a special ham stand) in many Madrid apartments is part staple and part status symbol: the more expensive the ham you can offer your guests, the better off you must be. Matthew Fishbane New York

To the Editor: After reading ''The New Tastemakers'' by Jeff Leeds [Sept. 3], I went immediately to my laptop to try out Pandora Media's Music Genome Project. On a whim, I entered Leonard Cohen's classic ''Hallelujah'' and waited for the database to work its magic. While none of the recommended songs was familiar to me, each was banal in the extreme and in no way matched the genius of Mr. Cohen's work.

DEEP into suburbia, on a sound barrier that runs along the Taconic State Parkway here, a graffiti artist announces his presence with a single word painted in yellow and black: ''Me.'' Officials said that graffiti had reached new heights this summer. And in a town that bills itself as a retreat from more urban locales, politicians and police officers are taking the problem seriously.

Dr. Rachel Fetner, the daughter of Jacqueline S. Fetner and Mark W. Fetner of East Rockaway, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Jeremy Sage Rosof, a son of Patricia J. F. Rosof and Alan H. Rosof of New York. Rabbi Stanley Platek is to officiate at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers, with Rabbi Laurence Sebert participating in the ceremony. The bride, 31, will keep her name. She is an endocrinologist in Great Neck, N.Y. She graduated from Yale and received her medical degree from the State University at Syracuse. Her father is a director of ''Eyewitness News'' on WABC-TV in New York. Her mother is the speech therapist at John F. Kennedy Middle School in Bethpage, N.Y.

MAGNUSON--Paul A. Of Maplewood, New Jersey, passed away on September 7th. A Professor of English Literature at New York University, Paul is survived by his wife, Bonnie, his two daughters, and his brother. A private memorial service will be held. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation in his name to the New York Public Library, Friends Office, Room M-6, 476 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10018. For information: The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood, NJ.

THE last century embraced the cult of the leader. Not only Hitler and Churchill of course, but also Joyce, Stravinsky and Balanchine seemed to attract armies of devoted followers. In art the fountainhead was Picasso, so commanding that even those who claimed to reject his work were nevertheless influenced by it. Everything in the crazy quilt of later Modernism has been said to trace from his singular authority. But a new century rewrites the previous one. Young artists don't obsess about Picasso the way older ones did. It remains to be seen whether his prestige, which for nearly 100 years has been unimpeachable, will survive the next 100 intact.

Wendy Carol Lowengrub, the daughter of Carol and Morton Lowengrub of Bloomington, Ind., is to be married today to Jordan Asher Katine, the son of Joan and Edward Katine of Schenectady, N.Y. Rabbi Josh Zweiback is to perform the ceremony at Holbrook-Palmer Park in Atherton, Calif. The bride, 38, is a lawyer at Agilent Technologies, a maker of scientific test and measurement tools in Santa Clara, Calif. She is also a mixed-media artist. She graduated from Brandeis and received a law degree from Indiana University.

Perhaps nothing has a greater effect on the outcome of a football game than a fumble or an interception. With one turnover at the wrong time, players can be released, coaches fired and seasons lost. So it is no surprise that coaches stomp and scream until they are blue in the face about eliminating turnovers. But doing so is easier said than done. Why? Because turnovers have more to do with luck, or the lack thereof, than they do with poor execution. But if coaches and players know that, they have not let on.

Among the many burdens placed on the shoulders of Giants quarterback Eli Manning, add the legacy of Tom Coughlin. Many of the lofty expectations of the 2006 Giants have been pinned to Manning, who begins his third N.F.L. season tonight against the Indianapolis Colts and quarterback Peyton Manning, his older brother.

The Bergen County clerk has rejected the bid by Mayor Steve Lonegan and the Bogota Borough Council to ask voters in a referendum in November whether English should be made the borough's official language. The borough is challenging her decision in court. County Clerk Kathleen Donovan said one of the two ballot questions Bogota submitted for her review -- about the purchase of two fire trucks -- was ''clearly appropriate.'' As for the other, she said, ''I asked for a legal opinion on it because it seemed to be outside of the scope of a local government question.''
MITCHELL--Robert D. (August 18): Badly, badly missed; scintillating and tenacious in intellect and in friendship. Constance Cooper Laurel Ann Wilson

Mark McGinley, a 26-year-old trader who worked on the 92nd floor of the World Trade Center, was one of the almost 3,000 people who died in the terrorist attack five years ago tomorrow. SEAN McGINLEY, his brother, made an effort to keep Mark's memory alive by reaching out to other men who had lost brothers that day. ''BROTHERS LOST: STORIES OF 9/11'' (CINEMAX, Monday night at 7), the documentary he made about his experiences, includes interviews with 31 men. But, as Sean McGinley says, ''it was almost like it all added up to one story.'' In the middle of a sea of documentaries and news specials about Sept. 11 comes BRIAN SLOAN's ''WTC VIEW,'' a quirky, low-budget film that has its broadcast premiere on Sunday (LOGO, 10 p.m.). MICHAEL URIE stars as the young gay man who, on Sept. 10, 2001, places an ad looking for a roommate for his apartment, which has a fabulous view of the twin towers. Unlike most mainstream films on the subject, this one concentrates not on the attack itself or the people who died. Instead it focuses on what average New Yorkers were thinking, talking about and absorbing in the days afterward. After the second tower collapsed, the lead character's best female friend kept her appointment at the hairdresser. If you want to escape the 9/11 coverage, the best route may be to the past. TCM is showing classic episodes of ''THE DICK CAVETT SHOW.'' These are interviews with major stars, starting Thursday night at 8 with a 1971 show devoted entirely to WOODY ALLEN. Promoting his film ''Bananas,'' Mr. Allen was 35 at the time, 13 years into psychoanalysis (''I try not to give him any accurate information about myself'') and divorced from Louise Lasser (''I would marry again''). He plays the clarinet twice.

Every fifth day, the Dodgers right-hander Derek Lowe relies on baseball's nastiest sinker to frustrate hitters. He has a 14-8 record and leads the majors by recording 79.6 percent of his outs on ground balls. The four other days he spends playing some of the country's most famous golf courses. His best round is a 67, and he shot a 76 at Winged Foot Golf Club on Thursday. Next week, when the Dodgers are in Chicago, Lowe has a tee time at Medinah, the site of last month's P.G.A. Championship. On road trips, Lowe said, he packs his clubs before he packs his clothes. BEN SHPIGEL WHO IS THE BETTER ATHLETE, TIGER WOODS OR MICHAEL JORDAN? Tiger intimidates people more than any athlete I've ever seen, even more than Jordan. There's a reason why everyone who is paired with him in the final round of a tournament suddenly forgets how to play golf. Have you ever looked at them? They're beaten before they even step on the course. SO, WOULD YOU STILL WANT HIM IN YOUR IDEAL FOURSOME? Are you kidding me? Absolutely. The chance to play 18 with him would be amazing. WHO ELSE WOULD BE IN IT? Can you just have three clones of Tiger? If not, I'd have to pick Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer. HOW MANY SHOTS WOULD THEY HAVE TO GIVE YOU? Probably a shot a hole. And, since this is my fantasy, we'd be playing at Augusta National. That's the ultimate. But then again, they know that course so well, so it would probably be more. Maybe I'd take them out the night before and get a few drinks in them.

To the Editor: Re ''Where the Songs Remain the Same'' (Sept. 3): In the article about the resurgence of rock 'n' roll cover bands in the suburbs, a singer-songwriter who resists doing covers is quoted as saying that ''we're baring our souls'' and ''people ought to respond to that.''

GUNDLACH--Robert. 90, well-known New York set designer and member of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, died August 8, 2006 after a brief illness in Mitchellville, MD, where he had lived for four years at The Cullington Retirement Community. His diverse career encompassed movies, television, and theatre. He also had been a Vice-President and Trustee of The United Scenic Artists, New York Local 829. Survivors include his wife of fiftyone years, Marguerite (Maggie Brown) Gundlach, of Mitchellville; a son, David Brown Gundlach, of Cold River, NY, and two brothers, Wiliam Gundlach (Captain U.S. Navy retired), of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Richard Gundlach, of Staten Island, NY.

To the Editor: Readers who seek profoundly stimulating and meaningful travel experiences in the developing world, as described in Claire Spiegel's ''Niger: Using Vacation to Help the World's Poor'' (Journeys, Aug. 20), may be interested in programs offered by American Jewish World Service (A.J.W.S.). The organization works in partnership with grassroots organizations in Africa, Asia and the Americas to alleviate poverty, hunger and disease among the people of the developing world regardless of race, religion or nationality.

Salsa will take over Battery Park on Sunday in the free River to River Festival, with amateur salsa dancers competing in the afternoon for a slot in an evening program with award-winning professionals. The audience is invited to a dance party at the end, but two-left-footers beware. The complex rhythms and direction shifts of salsa are not for klutzes. Battery Park, just north of the Staten Island ferry terminal, rivertorivernyc.com. The Japanese troupe YUBIWA HOTEL arrives with a new evening-long piece with the wonderfully nutty title of ''Candies: girlish hardcore,'' opening on Thursday at Japan Society. The all-female troupe, in its American debut, is known for multimedia examinations of the contemporary woman in Japan. ''CANDIES'' peers beneath the frills and lace of stereotypical girlhood to expose the erotic, grotesque and occasionally violent, according to advance word. To add to the charming peculiarity of the event, the company director, SHIROTAMA HITSUJIYA, was named one of the ''World's 100 Most Influential Japanese Women'' by Newsweek Japan this year. 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 752-3015 or japansociety.org; $28, $22 for society members. Finally, the downtown-dance artists BETH GILL and CHRIS PECK will fill the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, with 60 Brooklynites and their brown plastic recorders in the three-hour ''BROOKLYN ADULT RECORDER CHOIR.'' The factory is a dark warren of spaces that includes a studio theater, reachable by see-through industrial stairs, a gloomy basement, and dark and unexpected niches and cavelets, so this dance and performance spectacle promises to be unusual at the very least. The engagement begins Thursday, which also happens to be ''pay what you will'' night for Queens residents. 5-49 49th Avenue, (212) 352-3101 or theatermania.com.

RICK CAHILL has gone back once, just once, since that bright, terrible day five years ago when he stood a few blocks away and watched the north tower collapse and take his eldest son with it. He does not plan to go back again tomorrow. He has someplace else he would rather be, nearer to where his son lived than to where he died. Mr. Cahill and his son Scott were in the municipal bond business, commuters to Lower Manhattan from their home in West Caldwell, and he was working at his office on Rector Street when the first plane hit the World Trade Center. Scott was on the 104th floor of the north tower, in the offices of Cantor Fitzgerald. Mr. Cahill kept trying the cellphone, but got nothing. He made it back across the river to New Jersey by ferry that day, then home to the town where he had raised his family, and where he found comfort in his sorrow.

HETKIN--Berenice Berke, a woman of artistic proclivities and many interests died at the age of 86 on June 3, 2006 in her hometown, New York City. A professional interior designer for over 50 years, Berenice was equally proud of her achievements as a painter, illustrator, portraitist, performing artist and political activist. She studied at Columbia University, entering at age 14, and later at the Parsons School of Design and at the Ecole des Beaux Arts, Fontainebleau, France. When World War II broke out, she postponed further, studies and went to work for British War Relief and later the USO, performing as a vocalist and sketching the world at war on the homefront, in New York and in Montreal. Berenice became recognized as a skilled portraitist, meeting and drawing, to name a few, Hector Villa-Lobos, Andres Segovia, Charles De Gaulle, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Edward R. Murrow and a great number of United Nations ambassadors and delegates of the post-war infant organization at Lake Success, New York, where she was artistcorrespondent for ONA and several magazines. Her portrait of Edward R. Murrow is on display at CBS Broadcasting. Politically, Berenice headed the New York Speakers Bureau for Americans for Democratic Action and was active in the Democratic Party. In 1953 Berenice married Alfred H. Hetkin, a prominent New York real estate law attorney. Their marriage lasted more than 20 years. After the death of Mr. Hetkin, she remained close to her stepdaughter Maria Illo. Survivors are step granddaughter Shanti Reinhardt Kanter and step-great grandson, Kainoa Emmanuel Kanter, of Los Angeles, California, and distant cousins: Ilaria Lezzi De Breto of Virginia, Minnesota, Melody Brod Johnson of Boulder, Colorado, Daniel Ira Broad of Rockville, Maryland and Harriet Rubin of New York City.

ONE fact always jumps out from the illustrious life of Ambroise Vollard (1867-1939), the prescient, hyperactive, disorganized, cat-loving and, ultimately, multimillionaire art dealer prominent in the Paris art world from the 1890's to the 1930's. In November 1895 he gave a French painter named Paul Cézanne his first solo exhibition. At the time Vollard, still in his 20's, had already exhibited van Gogh and Manet. Within nine years he would give Picasso his first Paris exhibition and Matisse his first show anywhere. On Thursday Vollard will become the first art dealer accorded a large-scale exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''Cézanne to Picasso: Ambroise Vollard, Patron of the Avant-Garde'' has been organized in concert with the Art Institute of Chicago and the Musée d'Orsay in Paris, where it will also travel next year. With more than 200 works, it will devote rooms to the paintings, both famous and little seen, by Cézanne, Renoir, Gauguin, van Gogh, the Nabis and the Fauves.

To the Editor: In your editorial defending the Connecticut estate tax (''Death and Taxes in Connecticut,'' Aug. 27), you claim there has not been an exodus of seniors moving their legal residence to other states, primarily Florida, to escape the tax. But estate tax attorneys testified before the Finance Committee (of which I am the ranking member) that this is exactly what is happening. Retirees are motivated by taxes. Connecticut reduced the movie production tax to induce producers to come here. It stands to reason that the opposite also happens, namely that mobile retirees, not tied to jobs or schools, will move if the state imposes an estate tax.

FOR me, last winter was the end of the affair with oil. My stocky furnace, grunting and firing in the basement, guzzled its way through four thousand dollars' worth. I decided I would no longer slake its fueloholic thirst, even at the summer lock-in price of just under $3 a gallon. ''Lock in to lunacy,'' I thought. Oil has become the liquid gold we long suspected. So I must balance my budget with my fear of the unknown: wood stoves.

To the Editor: Re ''The Wrong Battle in Pakistan'' (editorial, Sept. 3): Pakistan joined the coalition to fight terrorism because of its own conviction and vital national interest. We have killed or captured more than 680 foreign Al Qaeda terrorists. We have banned all organizations that were suspected of involvement in terrorism.

BANKI--Paul Ervin. September 8, 2006. Textile engineer and specialist. Hungarian Holocaust survivor and refugee. Beloved husband of Judith, adored father of Susan, caring brother-in-law to Gerald and Elaine Hershcopf, loving uncle to Jane, Don and Sam Schreck. Services Monday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam.

WHEN Natalie Wells bought a home in Englewood, N.J., a year ago, she was unaware that her American pit bull terrier was illegal to own in the city. Shortly after moving in, she was told by one of her daughters about a city law that banned the breed, commonly called pit bulls, along with several similar breeds and Rottweilers. Under the 1999 law, even this year's best-in-show winner at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Rufus, a colored bull terrier from Holmdel, N.J., would be banned in Englewood.
FINGAR--Sol. (Uncle Solly) September 7, 2005. Always remembered with love. Debrah
SORKIN--Harry W. Time has not diminished my memories or my love. Always in my heart, Roz

To the Editor: It is easy to fall into the trap of assuming that biological accounts of human behavior deny environmental influences and assume an immutable nature. Even Richard Rorty, a retired professor of comparative literature and philosophy, falls into this trap in his review of my book ''Moral Minds'' (Aug. 27). Contrary to Rorty's portrayal, the idea that we are born with a universal moral grammar, like the idea that we are born with a universal grammar for language, doesn't deny the role of culture, nor does it make certain outcomes inevitable. Rather, it lays out a framework for exploring which aspects of our biology enable us to acquire a particular moral system, and which aspects of our moral principles are universal and which vary across cultures. In the same way that something about the biology of humans enables us, uniquely, to acquire certain types of languages, something about our biology must enable us, but not other animals, to acquire certain types of moral systems. The point is not that the content of moral systems is identical across cultures; the point is that people in all cultures can switch into a mode of cognition and emotion called ''morality'' with distinctive psychological properties. The men who stone witches or murder their unchaste sisters believe they are doing so for moral reasons, and it behooves us to understand the state of mind they are in. Rorty also misses the crucial distinction between how people judge moral actions and whether they would actually carry them out in the relevant situation; an exploding research literature shows that one does not imply the other. Furthermore, subjects with different cultural and demographic backgrounds often deliver identical moral judgments, while being unable to justify their choices. If people can't recover the principles that guide their judgments, then they certainly can't teach them to their children! This is the sense in which general-purpose learning fails and the analogy to language is significant. Contrary to Rorty, this doesn't mean that scientists should override parents, judges or teachers. But we all can benefit from a better understanding of the way that biological processes guide our unconscious, moral judgments and thereby exert powerful influences over how we perceive the world. By recognizing their influence we can better design our legal and educational systems. Contrary to Rorty's pessimism about the contributions of the sciences to our understanding of morality, I think it is essential for scientists and humanists to collaborate in sculpturing the work that lies ahead. If we share a universal moral grammar that enables us to acquire any of the world's moral systems, this ''should provide us with a sense of comfort, a sense that perhaps we can understand each other.'' Marc Hauser Cambridge, Mass.

To the Editor: After reading a Sept. 5 letter that suggests that Günter Grass's best option would have been ''full disclosure, and the earlier the better,'' I must come forward with my own post-Holocaust past. I respect Mr. Grass even more since he disclosed recently, but very late in his life, that he was drafted into Hitler's Waffen SS at age 17.

The Habitats article last Sunday about the Garrison family's home on Shelter Island, N.Y., misidentified their previous hometown, a town in Tennessee that was the site of the 1925 Scopes ''monkey trial.'' It is Dayton, not Dalton.

The mayor of West Haven, John M. Picard, expressed dismay that the city has only just deposited $10 million in property tax checks that had gone uncashed since July. Mr. Picard said on Tuesday that the checks were found last month by an employee substituting in the tax collector's office. He said that the clerk responsible for making the deposits was on vacation when they were found.

DADOURIAN--Haig R. of New York City, died September 5, 2006, after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Born on December 15, 1936, Brooklyn, NY to Elise and Dadour Dadourian, Survivors of the Armenian Genocide. Graduated from Columbia School of Business, NYC. During his forty year business career, he was president of InterRoyal Corporation and Deluxe Storage Systems and Vice President of Dadourian Export Corporation, Commercial Furniture and Real Estate Companies. He was a devoted family man who loved his Armenian Church and Heritage. Served as Chairman of The Diocesan Council of the Eastern Diocese of the Armenian Church Of North America for 12 years. Received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2004 for distinguished record of service to the Armenian Church and Community. Beloved husband of Astrid for 48 years. Loving father of Leslie, Jeanine and Melanie and devoted grandfather of Aram, Steven, Mattheu and Nina. Family will receive friends at St. Vartan's Cathedral, 2nd Ave and 34th St on Sunday September 10, 2006 from 58pm. Funeral service at St. Vartan's Cathedral Monday September 11 at 10:30am.

To the Editor: Kim McLarin's essay made me question where we have come with regard to race relations in America. Could it be that Ms. McLarin was just not ''that into'' her boyfriend? Was it really his race that mattered? The law of attraction knows no color, and it is tough enough for intelligent, creative women, of any ethnicity to find a mate. As a still-single African-American woman in her late 30's, I am open to dating men of all ethnic backgrounds. Yes, it can be frustrating to date someone who does not see eye-to-eye with you at times, but I do believe that race is one issue true love can transcend. Gail Taylor Yellow Springs, Ohio
PLOTKIN--Joan Sugar. July 21, 1930 to September 10, 1976. We think of you, miss you and love you every day. Love Always, Your Family

To the Editor: Regarding ''Banning liquids: Forget Legroom. What About More Water?'' (Practical Traveler, Aug. 27), by Michelle Higgins: We flew from Stockholm to Newark on Aug. 14 via Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) shortly after the security alert.

PROCLAIMING the beginning of a new era in Atlantic City gaming, Pinnacle Entertainment Inc. has agreed to buy the Sands Casino Hotel, the smallest of the 12 casinos in the city, for $250 million, with the intention of tearing it down and building an upscale casino-hotel complex. ''It's the right thing for Atlantic City,'' said George Toth, the president of the Sands. ''I just think to try to run the small type of gaming house we were running no longer fits the model in a destination city. We didn't have shopping or a swimming pool, so we were just limited. Today in the gaming field, you have to offer a lot more things.''

Alisa Ann Miller and Jason Artemiuk were married yesterday. Sosan Theresa F. Flynn, a Zen Buddhist priest, officiated at Dunton Hot Springs, a resort in Dolores, Colo. Ms. Miller, 36, is keeping her name. She is the president and chief executive of Public Radio International in Minneapolis, which is a producer of ''The World'' and ''Studio 360'' and distributes ''This American Life'' and other public broadcasts. She graduated from the University of Nebraska and received a master's degree in public policy and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.

American Banker, a trade publication in New York, said it would present a lifetime achievement award to Angelo R. Mozilo, chief executive of the Countrywide Financial Corporation, noting that he had built the company from a start-up to the country's biggest mortgage lender. Mr. Mozilo, of course, is also a champion of innovations like no-money-down adjustable-rate mortgages, some with low introductory ''teaser'' interest rates. With home prices falling and interest rates rising, many borrowers are finding themselves with higher monthly payments -- some even as their houses are now worth less than what they owe on them.

The top-ranked Buckeyes, led by Troy Smith's 269 yards passing, rolled to a 24-7 victory at No. 2 Texas, ending the Longhorns' 21-game winning streak. Irish stomp Penn State Rutgers routs Illinois COVERAGE, PAGES 12-13

KUMBLE--Helen, on September 9th, 2006. Born on January 27th, 1909, to David and Annie Schwartz. Beloved mother of Steven Kumble and Susan Perrotti. Adored grandmother of Todd and Roger Kumble, Andrew Collens and Jody Fidler. Great-grandmother of ten. Service private.

Jets (4-12 last season) at Tennessee (4-12) 1 p.m., Channel 2 JONATHAN VILMA VS. KEVIN MAWAE It is going to be like practice again when Vilma and Mawae, below, a former Jet, square off. The two years they were teammates, Mawae gave Vilma pointers on how to make his intentions harder for offensive linemen to read, things like not cheating toward the line if he was blitzing or not putting a lot of pressure on his toes if he was doing a slant or a stunt. And he would give Vilma a daily dose of his own tricks. ''He does that holding that he'd do and get me ready for the game,'' Vilma said. ERIC MANGINI VS. JEFF FISHER Since this is Mangini's regular-season coaching debut, he is the game's wild card. Fisher does not know what to expect from Mangini, whose tendencies remain a mystery to all. Fisher, who has the second-longest tenure among current N.F.L. coaches, created his own intrigue by refusing to name the starting quarterback, forcing the Jets to prepare for Kerry Collins, Billy Volek and Vince Young, which Mangini called a ''really solid decision on Jeff's part.'' The outcome may come down to which coach makes better adjustments on the fly. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)

PICASSO is coming to New York, but where you might least expect him: the Whitney Museum of American Art. Though Picasso himself never visited the United States, his work did, and it profoundly influenced the way oil hit canvas in mid-20th-century America. The Whitney is celebrating that influence with ''Picasso and American Art,'' which is to open on Sept. 28. But that's not all. Fans of Picasso headed here might also want to check out the other Picasso collections in town. And two other museums are having Picasso-related shows this fall. When the Whitney exhibition opens, there will be well over 100 Picassos -- paintings, sculptures and drawings -- on view in Manhattan. (And one, ''Woman in Gray,'' at the Brooklyn Museum).

SPIKE LEE wields cinema like a bat, swinging hard and fast and frequently striking out, but when he connects -- fuggedaboutit, it's out of the park. Total misfires (''She Hate Me'') and unqualified triumphs (''Do the Right Thing'') are rare. His films typically oscillate from excellence to indulgence, often within a single scene. Thematic conflicts in a Spike Lee joint -- class, race, sex -- are inextricable from this artistic struggle: talent vs. discipline, precision against hyperbole, strength with actors wrestling a weakness for schematic characterizations. A genre framework can circumscribe these tensions. Recently released on DVD, the witty, well-received heist picture ''Inside Man'' suggests that Mr. Lee would make a splendid old-school Hollywood auteur, shading the margins of mainstream entertainments with his pet themes and trademark quirks. See also ''Clockers,'' his underrated adaptation of a crime thriller by Richard Price. But that isn't the pained and stubborn artist who gave us ''When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts,'' an epic account of Hurricane Katrina now playing on HBO and one of the year's must-see documentaries. Nor is it the filmmaker who risked addressing 9/11 with as bold, foolish and affecting a film as ''25TH HOUR,'' screening at the BAMcinématek on Monday. Adapted by David Benioff from his own novel, ''25th Hour'' says goodbye to Monty (Edward Norton), a New York drug dealer preparing to serve a seven-year prison sentence. To the strains of Terrence Blanchard's score (unusually subdued when it's not moaning hysterically), the movie riffs on regret and resignation as it winds through Monty's parting moments with his girlfriend (Rosario Dawson), father (Brian Cox) and two best friends (Philip Seymour Hoffman and Barry Pepper). The film's audacity -- or for some viewers, its Achilles' heel -- is to connect this bruised melodrama to the dark wound at ground zero. Accusations of opportunism are hard to refute; the intended effect is inchoate by design. But its numb lament feels even more powerful in light of recent handlings of 9/11, whether as hyperrealist action film (''United 93'') or patriotic superproduction (''World Trade Center''). 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100.

To the Editor: ''Upgrade the Canal? Many Panamanians Are Saying No'' (news article, Sept. 3) states that ''many Panamanians intend to vote against the expansion.'' But the latest polls show that fewer than 20 percent of respondents say they'll vote against the expansion. The article does not mention the thorough cost estimates developed by the Panama Canal Authority. These estimates have been supported by international consultants and reviewed by renowned experts. Instead, the article quotes a disgruntled retired canal employee, whose employment ended in 2000, as a source regarding the project's cost.

HABER--Gertrude Shapiro, on September 9th, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Allen Shapiro and the late Sidney Haber. Beloved mother of Marcia and Paul Kreindler and the late Arthur Shapiro. Grandmother of Robin and Jonathan Lane, Wendy and Randy Rosler. Great-grandmother of Adam and Abby Rosler, Celia, Cassidy and Mason Lane. Service Monday, 10 am, at Beth Moses Cemetery.

GUSTAVO DUDAMEL has quickly come a long way from his boyhood in Barquisimeto, Venezuela, when he used to conduct toy soldiers. He has attracted glowing praise from Simon Rattle, Claudio Abbado and Daniel Barenboim, and a reputation as a rising star of the podium. And he's still just a tender 25. Mr. Dudamel is one of five musicians selected here as artists on the cusp of promising futures. He is a product of one of the classical music world's most extraordinary phenomena: Venezuela's youth orchestra system. Financed by the government and the Inter-American Development Bank, it has yielded scores of youth orchestras and trained hundreds of thousands of players, many from poor neighborhoods.

To the Editor: Re ''Once a Progressive State, Minnesota Is Now a Fief of the N.R.A.'' (Editorial Observer, Sept. 5): Verlyn Klinkenborg expresses surprise that Minnesota now allows handguns in public places, including libraries filled with kids.
To the Editor: Re ''Where the Songs Remain the Same'' (Sept. 3):

DUNBAUGH--Edwin Lane. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Edwin Lane Dunbaugh, Ph.D., Distinguished Professor Emeritus of History who was an integral part of the Hofstra community since 1954 and who witnessed the growth of the University over the ensuing 50 years. Professor Dunbaugh was proud of his military service during WWII where he served as a naval medical corpsman. He graduated from Franklin and Marshall College cum laude and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He was a recipient of Fulbright Scholarship to the University of Vienna where he worked on his doctoral dissertation and received his Ph.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. Professor Dunbaugh was not only a scholar of history, co-authoring a popular text, ''Mainstreams of Civilization,'' but also authored seven books on the history of steamboats, an abiding personal and intellectual interest which made him a leading scholar on the subject. Throughout his lengthy career, Professor Dunbaugh shared his great enthusiasm and passion for European History and the History of the Ancient World with his students. In 1970, in recognition of his exceptional skills as a teacher, the graduating class conferred upon him the prestigious and coveted Distinguished Teacher of the Year Award. He will be remembered by the Hofstra Community as a great scholar and devoted friend and will be greatly missed by his many students who became his lifelong friends. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. In tribute to the memory of Professor Dunbaugh, all Hofstra University flags will be lowered to half staff. John D. Miller Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

INDIAN restaurants have opened with welcome regularity in Westchester, each offering dishes as diverse and discrete as the region of India that is their inspiration. Now Bukhara Grill has come to town, with a kitchen that knocks out the lush dishes of Northern India with unique skill, balancing the myriad flavors so well that each taste plays and teases briefly on the tongue before merging into a delicious whole. The restaurant's décor is hardly impressive. There is a cold hollowness in its unadorned walls and a ceiling so high that one can easily overlook two crystal chandeliers, an odd match for bare pine tables better suited to a cozy log cabin. But what the restaurant lacks in ambience it makes up for with some mighty gorgeous food.

How does a residential community deal with an unruly house where renters run wild and the landlord doesn't seem to care? In North Caldwell, the police have been summoned to a house on Henry Street 37 times this year on complaints of noisy, destructive behavior by Montclair State University students, Chief Joseph Clark said. The last straw was a party over Labor Day weekend, when 128 of the 205 people packing the house were charged with under-age drinking and other offenses.
Not all New York hipster culture has moved to Brooklyn. Some of the artists, musicians, dancers and nightlife impresarios who are keeping downtown alive.

An article last week about the coming theater season included outdated information for the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank. The company announced after the section went to press that it would include ''The Pavilion'' by Craig Wright, Jan. 17 to Feb. 4, instead of a new play that was to be developed through a collaboration with New Dramatists.

Atari revived one of its most popular games last week: Follow the bouncing executive. Bruno Bonnell stepped down as chief executive again, this time to make way for David R. Pierce, a former movie and music industry executive. Mr. Bonnell, who also runs Infogrames, the French game maker, first took the reins at Atari, the video game pioneer now down on its luck, when Infogrames bought it and other video game assets from Hasbro in 2000. Four years later, he hired James Caparro to succeed him at Atari's helm.

To the Editor: ''Without Raising a Voice, a Choir Soars'' (Sept. 3) describes a technology-assisted performance by the Regional Day Augmentative Choir in Hamilton, N.J. We have had similar performances for more than 10 years at Cerebral Palsy of North Jersey's Horizon School in Livingston, thanks to several enthusiastic speech therapists, many dedicated teachers and assistant teachers, a talented musician, a very patient and well-informed technology staff, and a supportive administration.
ROSENTHAL--Peter. 11/1/46-9/10/01. Beloved father, son, husband, brother and friend, he is missed by all and in our hearts forever.

The closing late last year of George's in Sayville, a 12-year-old spot serving German fare, and the opening in May of the Smokehouse Grill in its place illustrate two trends in Long Island dining. Diners in Sayville and elsewhere are saying goodbye to bratwurst and hello to pulled pork. German restaurants are a dying breed here. With the demise of George's, their number dropped to around a dozen, by my count, perhaps half of what it was 20 years ago.

Nell Freudenberger, a writer, and Paul Logan, an architect, were married yesterday at a friend's home in East Hampton, N.Y. John Lithgow, the actor, who is a pastor of Rose Ministries and the bride's godfather, officiated. Ms. Freudenberger, 31, is keeping her name. She is the author of ''The Dissident'' (Ecco, 2006), a novel, and ''Lucky Girls'' (Ecco, 2003), a collection of stories. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard and received a Master of Fine Arts degree in fiction from New York University.

MILLER--Betty Ann, of Poughkeepsie, NY, passed away peacefully in her home on Friday, September 1, 2006. She was born in New London, CT to William and Phyllis Richmond. She married Mr. Mark Miller on April 19, 1975 in her parents' home in Mystic, CT. She is survived by her husband Mark, her son Timothy, and her sisters Phyllis and Barbara.

The sun may never shine again but the warmth of your love sustains me for you are my one true love. Our time together was too short but had our spectacular life has been an honor and privilege. My Hero, Morris, I will always love you and miss you. Your devoted wife, Gail

To the Editor: Re ''The Central Truth,'' by Thomas L. Friedman (column, Sept. 8): While I have generally been an admirer of Mr. Friedman's writings, I cannot understand his continuing belief that invading Iraq was a correct course of action.

Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said Saturday night that he was prepared to meet the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, even without the release of the Israeli soldier captured by militants in Gaza. Mr. Olmert, after meeting with the British prime minister, Tony Blair, said that ''I intend to meet Chairman Abbas'' in the near future.

Bedford Hills Elementary School started the school year on Wednesday with a substitute principal and many unanswered questions after the principal, Victoria Graboski, was arrested and charged with failing to report a case of suspected child abuse involving a 9-year-old girl who attended the school. Ms. Graboski is on paid administrative leave while the district investigates the matter. Five other school employees, including at least two teachers, were also put on leave in connection with the investigation.

To the Editor: As a race-obsessed Negro myself, I can certainly relate to Ms. McLarin's frustrations in engaging whites in discussions about race. My impression is that most whites feel accused when discussing race.

Clothing from the designer Rachel Roy recalls a time when women had impeccable manners, hourglass figures and the good sense to flaunt them with clothes on. Ms. Roy, who presented her fourth collection in New York City last week, finds inspiration in silhouettes from the 1930's, 40's and 50's, when ''women were allowed to look feminine and strong at the same time,'' she said. From an aesthetic standpoint, she added, ''Dresses with high waists and full flowing skirts make women look a lot slimmer.'' Ms. Roy, 32, who lives in TriBeCa with her husband, the hip-hop mogul Damon Dash, and her 6-year-old daughter, Ava, is ladylike in the extreme. ''I wear a dress or skirt with a belt, shoes and a bag almost every day,'' said the designer, who enforces a no-denim policy in her office. (On weekends, however, she likes vintage Levi's and current Chloé jeans, which she described as ''long and high-waisted, very Bianca Jagger in the 70's.'')
