BEDDARD--Anita P. You are dearly loved, missed and remembered. Devon, Fred and Michael

ON Sept. 11, 2001, I was a lieutenant in the Port Authority Police Department. After the attack, I became the night commander of the rescue and recovery operation at ground zero, charged with recovering the remains of my fellow officers and the thousands of other victims of the World Trade Center collapse. I and the 30 to 50 officers under my command worked at ground zero six or seven days a week for more than eight months among the two-million-ton mountain of shattered concrete, twisted steel and human remains. Pulling 19,000 body parts out of the rubble, we became accustomed to matching arms and legs like pairs of socks. When we got home, we still smelled like ground zero, with bitter-tasting dust and an odor of decay in our hair and on our skin. I couldn't hug my wife and children until after I had taken several showers.

Let's say, instead of whatever you're actually doing, that you're standing on the little wooden deck of my house. It's off the kitchen, on the third floor, sort of -- it's hard to count the floors, really, because the house is built on a hill, quite steep, like all San Francisco real estate. It's pretty precarious if you think about it, and you're thinking about it, and so you say, ''What's this house built on?''

To the Sports Editor: Andre Agassi's final, emotional farewell from tennis (''Final Score Is Love,'' Sept. 4) served to remind even the least sports-minded reader why the game of tennis -- or any other game that involves competition and supreme effort -- is worth our time. Agassi's rise to the heights of the game, and his graceful departure, showed us what can happen when we match our talent with heart and determination to do better. And those lessons apply far beyond the United States Open.

BONDER--Diane A. This notes the sad and untimely death of independent filmmaker Diane A. Bonder, 46. Diane died at her home in Brooklyn on June 23, almost a year after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. She was predeceased by her beloved father John Bonder and mother Geraldine (Cleerdin) Bonder, and is survived by her partner Terri Burger, her aunt Virginia, uncle Bob, cousin Mark and his children Lauren and Steven, as well as by her dear friends--her other family. Diane made lo-fi experimental film and video in documentary, poetic, and semi-narrative styles. She maintained a longstanding relationship with Millennium Film Workshop, where she taught herself the optical printing techniques which became part of her signature visual style. Retrospective screenings of her work have been held at MoMA, Hall Walls (Buffalo) and Millennium Film Workshop, and Diane was a regular contributor to both the Mix NYC and Mad Cat Women's Festivals. In addition to residencies at UCross (Wyoming) and Squeaky Wheel (Buffalo, NY), she received numerous grants including NYFA and NYSCA in 2003. Her work has screened throughout the US and internationally and received many awards. A former resident of Northampton and Boston, MA, Diane graduated with her BA from UMAss Amherst, studied photography at the Photographic Resource Center in Boston and received her MFA from Rutgers University. In 1996 Diane made Brooklyn, NY, her home. In addition to being an accomplished and prolific filmmaker, she also ran her own graphic design company, Rat Star Designs, catering primarily to nonprofit organizations. Diane was loving, strong, passionate, creative, feisty, frugal, determined, loyal and an inspiration. Cherished and loved by her many close friends and family, she will be forever missed. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held beginning at 11:30 AM, Saturday, September 16, at St. Mark's Sanctuary (Dan space), 131 East 10th St., Manhattan. A fund has been established to support experimental filmmakers in Diane's name. Contributions may be sent to the ''Diane Bonder Memorial Fund'' at Millennium Film Workshop, 66 East 4th St., NYC, NY 10003.

When a new music season wakes up, it is usually the New York City Opera that is first to stir. The company opens on Wednesday with the 11th in its long-running series of Handel productions. In ''SEMELE,'' we are to be treated to conflict and revenge among the gods by way of Ovid. ELIZABETH FUTRAL sings the title role. ANTONY WALKER conducts. The production is directed by STEPHEN LAWLESS. For the mortal Semele, social mobility comes in jolts. First an eagle snatches her from humankind and takes her to the heavens and the arms of Jupiter. Egged on by Juno, his thwarted wife, Semele oversteps in her quest for immortality and is consumed by fire. Bar patrons today can take comfort that from her ashes will rise Bacchus, the ancient god of booze. First done in 1744, ''Semele'' followed Handel's successful switch to oratorios. The heavy tilt toward chorus numbers against a counterweight of wholly operatic da capo arias makes it something of a hybrid dangling between the concert stage and the theater. The libretto has a distinguished source, William Congreve. ''Semele'' was put on in Washington a quarter of a century ago, but the people at the City Opera think that these will be its first professional performances in New York City. After Wednesday's opening night, ''Semele'' will be repeated Friday and next Sunday afternoon, with four more performances to follow. Bizet's familiar ''Carmen'' will be intertwined with Handel's less familiar piece. ''Carmen'' plays on Thursday and repeats on Saturday, with 12 more performances to come. Joining Ms. Futral in mutual sexpottery is RINAT SHAHAM taking Bizet's title role. ARI PELTO will conduct this JONATHAN EATON production. ''Semele,'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Friday at 8 p.m.; ''Carmen,'' Thursday at 7 p.m. and Saturday at 1:30 p.m.; New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500.; $25 to $125.

JESSE FRIEDMAN bit into a bagel with lox last Sunday and ripped into the criminal justice system in Nassau County as if he had just been charged that morning, and not in 1987, with hundreds of sex crimes against children. Convicted as a sexually violent predator -- the highest-risk category, Level 3 -- he is barred from parks and places with many children. Bagel stores are not off limits, so he sat in one on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and discussed his case and how it was affected by the 2003 film ''Capturing the Friedmans.''

RICK CAHILL has gone back once, just once, since that bright, terrible day five years ago when he stood a few blocks away and watched the north tower collapse and take his eldest son with it. He does not plan to go back again tomorrow. He has someplace else he would rather be, nearer to where his son lived than to where he died. Mr. Cahill and his son Scott were in the municipal bond business, commuters to Lower Manhattan from their home in West Caldwell, and he was working at his office on Rector Street when the first plane hit the World Trade Center. Scott was on the 104th floor of the north tower, in the offices of Cantor Fitzgerald. Mr. Cahill kept trying the cellphone, but got nothing. He made it back across the river to New Jersey by ferry that day, then home to the town where he had raised his family, and where he found comfort in his sorrow.

FIVE years ago my brother and I spoke regularly. Five years ago we drank together, teased each other without mercy and, occasionally, even expressed feelings of affection. After 9/11 we did not. My brother is a 20-plus-year veteran of the New York City Fire Department, a former marine with a degree in history whose politics are conservative. He is four years older and quite a bit larger than me. I am a 20-plus-year veteran of big-agency advertising, a creative director turned fiction writer whose politics, not surprisingly, do not lean conservatively. Until five years ago, this was not such a big problem. There were plenty of other things to talk about, and we knew that despite our differences, there was still much to appreciate about each other.

To the Editor: Re ''Stealth Students Test Tolerance of the Affluent,'' by Joseph Berger (column, Aug. 27):

To the Editor: Kim McLarin's essay spurs resentment in me, a white woman. I see her rejection of a white man as honest yet racist. She says that whites are averse to discussing race -- this is regretfully true. But she absolves herself of willfully maintaining the division. If she wants whites to discuss race and be faced with it, she must understand their hesitation.

Armin H. Meyer, a former United States ambassador to Lebanon, Iran and Japan, died Aug. 13 in Washington. He was 92. The cause was Parkinson's disease, said his daughter, Kathleen White of Bethesda, Md.

FOR me, last winter was the end of the affair with oil. My stocky furnace, grunting and firing in the basement, guzzled its way through four thousand dollars' worth. I decided I would no longer slake its fueloholic thirst, even at the summer lock-in price of just under $3 a gallon. ''Lock in to lunacy,'' I thought. Oil has become the liquid gold we long suspected. So I must balance my budget with my fear of the unknown: wood stoves.

WHEN Natalie Wells bought a home in Englewood, N.J., a year ago, she was unaware that her American pit bull terrier was illegal to own in the city. Shortly after moving in, she was told by one of her daughters about a city law that banned the breed, commonly called pit bulls, along with several similar breeds and Rottweilers. Under the 1999 law, even this year's best-in-show winner at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Rufus, a colored bull terrier from Holmdel, N.J., would be banned in Englewood.

Criterion issues a major upgrading of Akira Kurosawa's exhilarating epic ''Seven Samurai'' (Sept. 5). The original ''Star Wars'' trilogy comes out on DVD as the films were first released theatrically (Sept. 12). A bunch of new extras adorn the reissue of the sweet teenage romance ''Save the Last Dance.'' Gretchen Mol's sunniness belies the title ''The Notorious Bettie Page'' (Sept. 26). Mandy Moore delivers the jaw-dropper of the year in the satire ''American Dreamz'' (Oct. 3). Barry Levinson and James Toback's elegant ''Bugsy'' gets a new extended cut, and the stuff dreams are made of, John Huston's seminal thriller ''The Maltese Falcon'' (Oct. 3) gets a newly remastered three-disc release. ''I'm Alan Partridge'' (Oct. 10), the BBC sitcom that made Steve Coogan a star, has its American DVD debut. The films directed by Al Pacino, including the documentary, ''Looking for Richard,'' are released in ''Al Pacino: An Actor's Vision.'' Criterion releases Alfonso Cuarón's first film, unseen on these shores, ''Sólo Con tu Pareja'' (''Only With Your Partner,'' 1991) on (Oct. 17). Elizabeth McGovern walks off with the dandy thriller ''The Bedroom Window'' (Oct. 17). ''The Astaire & Rogers Collection, Volume 2'' (Oct. 17) includes ''Carefree'' and ''Flying Down to Rio.'' ''Reservoir Dogs'' (Oct. 24) gets the 15th-anniversary treatment. Dean and Jerry finally make it to DVD in ''The Martin & Lewis Collection, Volume 1'' (Oct. 31).

He does not plan to go back again tomorrow. He has someplace else he would rather be, nearer to where his son lived than to where he died. STRAUS--Alice Goodkin, 84, a VP at Valerie Wilson Travel and former radio soap opera star, died September 5 in New York after a brief illness. She was born November 16, 1921 in Detroit and grew up in Chicago. She had leading roles in a number of well-known radio programs: Myrt and Marge, Stella Dallas, Kitty Foyle and Chicago Theater of the Air. In 1945 she married the late Martin L. Straus III and moved to New York where she lived until her death. Upon her retirement she became an active volunteer at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital where in 2004 she was cited as ''Volunteer of the Year.'' She also organized trips for the visually impaired on her favorite ship, the QEII. She is survived by her two children, Patricia May Staab of Springfield, IL and Michael L. Straus of Achworth, GA, three grandchildren, Amanda Staab Londrigan, Paul Staab IV and Christopher (Topher) Straus. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 7, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Macula Foundation at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital.

THE Bridgeport Police Department has joined a handful of other departments around the state in putting officers on Segways, the futuristic-looking battery-powered upright scooters. Police Chief Bryan T. Norwood said the department bought four Segways last month for $5,500 each to use on regular patrols and at events like concerts. He said officers from the bicycle unit were trained to ride the Segways first.

Kim Cornett of Arlington, Va.: ''The botanical gardens were really peaceful, so it was weird to think that just five minutes away was the ramshackle elegance of the city center. At the top is this waterfall, there were teenage couples making out and just a ton of kids swimming in swim trunks or underwear or nothing, just trying to cool off. They were showing off and diving and flipping and seeing who could climb the farthest up this slippery rock and then do something outrageous to come down, or stealing each other's clothes and running away. I'm probably romanticizing it, but it seemed like unadulterated joy, just kids enjoying the simple pleasures: a chance to get cool and kind of be.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Nothing symbolizes the relationship between people and property quite like the key. Its ritual transfer is the final, emotional act of buying a house; the key literally gets you in the door. Hence the name of this magazine -- and why, for this inaugural issue, we asked seven artists to create their own visions of the key. Their works can be seen on the cover and on the following pages.

ROWAN--A. James. The Department of Neurology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine regrets to announce the death of A. James Rowan, M.D. Dr. Rowan received his undergraduate training at MIT and his Medical Degree from Stanford University School of Medicine in 1961. He completed his Neurology residency at the Neurological Institute of New York at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and the London Hospital in England. During his career he held medical appointments at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons before joining Mount Sinai in 1980 as Professor of Neurology and Director of Electroencephalography in the Epilepsy Programs. Dr. Rowan was a pioneer in the field of Epilepsy. He has been an invited participant to symposia throughout the US and around the world and has authored numerous books, articles and chapters on this topic. He will be especially remembered for his commitment and devotion to teaching residents and medical students, and he was a beloved teacher. He taught students the science and humanity of the practice of Neurology and was awarded ''Teacher of the Year'' on numerous occasions. He will be sorely missed.

An article on Aug. 27 about the Paris Opera Ballet production of Balanchine's ''Jewels'' referred incorrectly to the rights history of another Balanchine ballet, ''Symphony in C.'' Balanchine gave the rights to the dance to Betty Cage, the general manager of New York City Ballet, not his longtime balletmaster John Taras. (Cage gave the rights to Taras and Taras passed them on to the School of American Ballet.)

TO those caught up in the loose-hipped calypso beat wafting over Peekskill this time last year, the One World Arts and Culture Fest at the Paramount Center for the Arts might have seemed little more than well-organized fun. But like a good many events masquerading as simple entertainment, the festival, which returns for a second run on Sept. 13, was the beginning of a larger mission for Jon Yanofsky and his staff, who had watched the region metamorphose and had not liked what they believed was a limited cultural response to the changes.

KUPERBERG--Jeanne. The Officers and Directors of the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York were saddened to learn of the death of Jeanne Kuperberg, beloved wife of ABO Governor, David Kuperberg. Our condolences and prayers are with David and his children, Russell (Rusty) and Danielle. May she rest in peace. IN the 50 years he has lived in Montclair, N.J., Rob Bianco has seen his share of monsoon-like downpours, blizzards, ice storms, even the remnants of hurricanes. But Mr. Bianco, the superintendent of public works for Montclair, had never seen anything like the storm that ravaged the leafy landscape of his hometown on July 18.

RICK CAHILL has gone back once, just once, since that bright, terrible day five years ago when he stood a few blocks away and watched the north tower collapse and take his eldest son with it. He does not plan to go back again tomorrow. He has someplace else he would rather be, nearer to where his son lived than to where he died. Mr. Cahill and his son Scott were in the municipal bond business, commuters to Lower Manhattan from their home in West Caldwell, and he was working at his office on Rector Street when the first plane hit the World Trade Center. Scott was on the 104th floor of the north tower, in the offices of Cantor Fitzgerald. Mr. Cahill kept trying the cellphone, but got nothing. He made it back across the river to New Jersey by ferry that day, then home to the town where he had raised his family, and where he found comfort in his sorrow.

To the Editor: Re ''How to Become a World Citizen, Before Going to College'' (Sept. 3), about how some high school graduates were postponing college enrollment by a year to take part in service programs or internships:

BEFORE the accident that paralyzed Christopher Reeve, it was all you could do to convince people that such a charming, good-looking guy was also a wonderful actor. After the accident he became so beloved that his performances were almost beside the point. It would be fitting if this eight-disc collection (two discs for each of his four Superman movies) focused attention on the beauty of Reeve's performances as the man from Krypton and his alter ego, Clark Kent. Reeve was blessed with some of the best comic timing the movies have seen since the heyday of screwball. His Superman takes great pleasure in playacting the super nerd Kent. You feel a prankster's joy behind Kent's every klutzy move, every whinging bit of jealousy he admits to feeling over the adoration Margot Kidder's Lois Lane, above, has for Superman.

FOR failing to meet performance standards, the Clara T. O'Connell elementary school in Bristol, Conn., spent three years on the ''in need of improvement'' list under the federal No Child Left Behind program. When a new list came out last month, Connecticut had 290 elementary and middle schools on it, but the O'Connell School was not among them. It had achieved what no other school in the state had managed under the four-year-old program: It had worked itself off the list.

SEAN O'CASEY'S one-act play ''The Cooing of Doves,'' typed and marked up by the playwright, lay on a reading table at Princeton University's Firestone Library. Neither yellowed by history's aura nor piously unblemished, the unbound stack of 18 pages looked more like a term paper than a century-old artifact in the university's new Leonard L. Milberg Irish Theater Collection. In fact, the manuscript, which became the second act of O'Casey's seminal work ''The Plough and the Stars,'' looked so ordinary that Paul Muldoon, the poet and Princeton professor, at first overlooked it while perusing other samples of the collection, which was donated in his honor. The university announced the gift Aug. 29.
A report on Aug. 27 about the marriage of Alexandra Block and Curtis Weiss omitted the names of the bridegroom's parents. They are Doreen and Steven Weiss of Chicago.

HE sits in his wheelchair as the family rushes around him. He cannot move much, or say more than hello. He cannot participate in the summer activities that everyone pursues with great vigor day after day. If it's warm enough, he goes out onto the deck and snoozes in the sun with the dogs. Unlike them, however, he doesn't jump up and make excited noises when people come. At most, he slowly turns his head and smiles. Everyone speaks to him politely, but not for long. What's the point? He can't say more than a couple of words, and it's hard to tell how much he understands. He is my stepfather, Peter, an 88-year-old man who in the last decade has been transformed from a lively and dynamic person into not much more than a body occupying space. He has post-polio syndrome, a condition that seeps the strength from his upper body as steadily as it weakened his legs when he was a teenager. A couple of strokes have further debilitated him. As my son, Asher, said to my mother one day, it's as if he's hardly a person anymore.

To the Editor: Re ''The Last Stand of the 6-Percenters?'' (Sept. 3), which compared an online brokerage firm with traditional, full-service real estate brokers: The article did not discuss all the benefits provided by full-service brokers who may -- or may not, in these competitive times -- charge 6 percent in commissions.
POVERMAN--Leo. A memorial service will be held for Leo Poverman on September 16, 2006, at 10 AM at the Shady Hill School, 178 Coolidge Hill Rd., Cambridge, MA. Contact Susan Poverman 617-547-6665.

They say it takes a village to raise a child, but Rick Mockler and Ann Block think maybe it just takes a co-housing development. The couple had just had a daughter when they heard about a new community called Muir Commons in Davis, Calif., where residents own their homes but share the common property surrounding them. Unlike a gated community, a co-housing development is designed and managed by the residents themselves, who make up the rules, share the workload and see their neighbors as an extended clan. ''Because people live in proximity and know one another so well, there's a lot of spontaneous interaction, like a concert or a movie night in the common house, and so many activities for the kids,'' says Mockler, who is now a vice president of CoHousing Partners, a group that develops co-housing communities in California. ''We've lived here for 10 years. It's a great way to raise a family.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''30 Seconds With Jonathan Papelbon'' (Sept. 3): When Papelbon, the Red Sox' closer, was asked what athlete he admired most outside of baseball, he named Tiger Woods. Tiger Woods? It is a joke that Papelbon and so many others believe that professional golfers are athletes.

Lori Beth Marino and Megan Ann McCarroll affirmed their partnership yesterday evening at a former Vanderbilt summer house in Oakdale, N.Y., now part of Dowling College. The Rev. Laura Tria, an interfaith minister, led a commitment ceremony. Ms. Marino (above, right), 32, is a lawyer at Avaya, the telecommunications equipment company in Basking Ridge, N.J. She graduated with distinction from Cornell and received her law degree cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania.
A classical recording review on Aug. 27 of Jay Greenberg's Quintet for Strings misspelled the surname of the cellist. He is Darrett Adkins, not Atkins.

I wasn't surprised to learn that many prominent Democratic centrists admire Barry Goldwater (Deborah Solomon, Aug. 27). While Goldwater is widely viewed as the father of modern conservatism, the truth is that the party he came from is scarcely visible today. The neocons and the religious right have essentially written United States policy for six years, gobbling resources, spending money and interfering with personal choices in a way that Barry himself most likely would have abhorred. Jeff Robertson Yellow Springs, Ohio

AS Jamaica station came into view, Joe Singh of Deer Park stood by the train door and looked out the window. What he and other commuters on the Long Island Rail Road see these days is much different from what they saw before a $300 million renovation of the station that began more than five and a half years ago. ''It's much better than it was before,'' Mr. Singh said. ''There is a better covering from the rain. The platforms were covered before, but it wasn't as good.''

Andy Warhol had quite an interesting life. One of the most celebrated artists of the 20th century, he was born in Pittsburgh to Czech immigrants. Making his way to New York, he became a successful graphic artist, specializing in illustrations of shoes for advertisements. He exhibited his drawings to no critical notice, eventually dabbling in paintings of dollar bills, comic strips and soup cans; at first he painted them by hand, then later turned to screen printing. By 1962 he was the leading figure in American Pop Art.

WHEN affluent suburbanites travel, they can be quite fussy, demanding that airplanes show up and take off like clockwork and that anything less is -- to use a word the fastidious favor -- unacceptable. But when they're lounging in their backyards, they want the skies to be jet-free, or at least noise-free; if jets must be seen, they should not be heard. The problem in hubs like New York is that the two desires are fast becoming irreconcilable. American airlines handled 739 million passengers last year; by 2015 that number is expected to balloon to 1 billion. No one wants an airport sprouting next door, with all the attendant whines, drones and roars, so the Federal Aviation Administration has been trying to squeeze in more flights by rejiggering the way planes use air space in the corridor between Philadelphia and Connecticut.
To the Editor: Re ''Paying to Play at School'' (Aug. 27), about school districts charging fees to play school sports:

''Can Hezbollah be disarmed?'' James Traub asks, and concludes, probably not (Aug. 27). The peacekeepers, however, would be required to prevent rearmament by blocking Syrian supply routes. Someone is sure to ask: If supplies to Hezbollah are to be cut off, shouldn't supplies from the United States to Israel be equally forbidden? That is shocking, from an American point of view. The Israelis are the ''good guys,'' while Hezbollah is ''bad.'' But a large portion of the world does not see it that way, reminding us that the first United States response to the July fighting was not to call for a cease-fire but to prepare to send an emergency supply of weapons to Israel. Bernice L. Voutz Tacoma, Wash.

THE Jacob Burns Film Center's annual fund-raising awards dinner and auction is a flashy affair, featuring dignitaries from the film industry and bidders who pool together to try to win big prizes, like a ride in the Fuji blimp. At this year's event, which will celebrate the nonprofit center's fifth anniversary, the items up for auction include a weeklong vacation in Nantucket and, perhaps the most-sought-after prize, an in-home concert performed by the Tokyo String Quartet.

GOTTHILF--Daniel L., on September 3rd, 2006 after a brief illness. Born in 1924, he was a WWII fighter pilot, honors graduate of the University of Michigan, CPA, former senior Vice President/Finance of Savin Corp., author of Treasurer's and Controller's Desk Book and numerous articles for business and financial journals and, at the time of his death, engaged in a private accounting practice, as a peer reviewer for accountants, and as an AAA arbitrator. While Dan loved his work, he loved his family and friends more. He was widely respected and relied upon for his good counsel, unfailing kindness and keen intelligence. He is survived by his adored/adoring wife Lois Kreisel, daughter Hon. Marcy Friedman, stepchildren Susan and Jeffrey Klein, Jane and Tony Lopez, grandchildren, and brothers Arnold and Randy Gotthilf.

An estimated 10,000 to 15,000 tons of oil spilled in mid-July from a power station south of Beirut that was bombed by Israeli warplanes could now threaten not just the Lebanese coastline -- where international and teams are working to remove the washed-up oil -- but also the beaches of Cyprus, Turkey, Greece and Israel. ''When the currents change this autumn and winter, the oil, which has been moving south, will start to move north, circling from right to left like a clock, and will eventually hit those coastlines,'' said Fouad Hamdan, director of the environmental group Friends of the Earth Europe. ''It is not only the worst environmental disaster ever in the Eastern Mediterranean Coast,'' Mr. Hamdan said, comparing it to the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989, ''but another serious economic blow to tourism in the area, as this oil could keep showing up for years.''

Lisa Hollister Sorensen and Daniel Francis Johnson were married yesterday afternoon at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. Dr. William L. Steele, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, 43, will keep her name. She is a photographer. Her work has been shown at Noel Fine Art Gallery in Bronxville and Fine Focus Gallery in Quogue, N.Y. She graduated from the College of Wooster in Ohio. She is a daughter of Clara T. Sorensen and the late Paul G. Sorensen of Bronxville, N.Y.

An article last Sunday about the students who received perfect scores on the new SAT tests misstated the fraction of the writing score based on multiple-choice questions. It is two-thirds, not three-quarters.

INTERNATIONAL 3-21 Desperation in Darfur Camps Fear is mounting in refugee camps in the Darfur region of Sudan as it grows more likely that African Union peacekeepers will leave or be ejected. Kofi Annan, secretary general of the United Nations, warned the Sudanese government that it would be held responsible for what happens to the population in Darfur. 1 Iraqi Leader Plans Iran Visit Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq plans to visit Iran to discuss security and political matters with leaders there, a spokesman for the prime minister said. 6 Pope Visits Bavarian Home Pope Benedict XVI arrived in his home country on a pilgrimage to the places that shaped him as a child. Benedict is expected to address his concerns of secularism in Europe, and the precipitous shrinking in the church, in his visit. 21 Nuclear Pact in Central Asia The former Soviet republics of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan in Central Asia signed a nuclear-free-zone treaty that commits the region's rich uranium deposits to peaceful uses but leaves loopholes that could allow Russia to transport nuclear weapons through the region. 18 Blair Tells Party to Stay Hungry Prime Minister Tony Blair warned Britain's Labor Party that it would lose power if it did not show it was ''hungry for power'' and halt the ''irredeemably old-fashioned'' feuding around his succession. 12 Major's Case Investigated Maj. Jill M. Metzger, a United States Air Force officer who was found Friday after being missing in Kyrgyzstan for more than three days, was flown from the Central Asian country, the Air Force said. United States officials said in a statement that it appeared she had been abducted, but the investigation had not ended. 18 NATIONAL 22-32 Rhode Island G.O.P. Feud With a barrage of tough television advertisements, the Republican Party has mobilized to beat back a conservative primary challenge to Senator Lincoln Chafee in Rhode Island. The outcome could help determine whether Democrats have a shot at taking back the Senate. 1 Battle Over Quality Water Raising cattle in the parched American outback of eastern Montana and Wyoming has always been a battle to find enough water. Now there is more than enough water, but the wrong kind, ranchers say, and they are fighting to keep it out of the river. 22 Escaped Prisoner Caught An escaped prisoner accused in the abduction and rape of a young woman was captured after the authorities swarmed an apartment and found him hiding in a closet. The prisoner was found in Birmingham, Ala., about 90 miles north of the state prison where he escaped. 22 Shuttle Lifts Off After two weeks of postponements, the space shuttle Atlantis made a thunderous ascent into partly cloudy skies, carrying its crew of six to a rendezvous with the International Space Station. 24 Aging Creatively With Artists The Burbank Senior Artists Colony in California is the country's first apartment community for creative older people. 1 NEW YORK/REGION 35-40 New Muslim Immigrants After a post-9/11 decline, Muslims appear to be moving into the United States again in surprising numbers, according to statistics provided by the Department of Homeland Security and the Census Bureau. 1 Firefighter Killed in New Jersey A firefighter responding to an erroneous report of people trapped in a fire rushed into a burning apartment building in Union City, N.J., and was fatally injured, fire officials said. 35 SPORTSSUNDAY SP 1-16 Sharapova Wins U.S. Open Maria Sharapova defeated Justine Henin-Hardenne to become the United States Open champion. THE NEW YORK MUSICAL THEATER FESTIVAL returns with 34 new musicals, including ''FLIGHT OF THE LAWNCHAIR MAN,'' written by PETER ULLIAN (''Elliot Ness in Cleveland'') with music and lyrics by ROBERT LINDSAY-NASSIF (''Opal'') and starring CHRISTOPHER SUTTON and DONNA LYNNE CHAMPLIN (Pirelli in the recent revival of ''Sweeney Todd''). The musical, directed and choreographed by LYNNE TAYLOR-CORBETT (''Swing!'') is about a man from Passaic, N.J., who dreams of, well, flying in his, um, lawn chair. It was presented last year by Goodspeed Musicals in Connecticut, but when it had its premiere, it was the best-reviewed third of a trio of mini-musicals at Prince Music Theater in Philadelphia, where it was directed by HAROLD PRINCE -- yes, that Harold Prince. Opens Wednesday, 37 Arts Theater, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 352-3101; $20. AMI DAYAN's adaptation of ALAN DRURY's widely produced 1975 play, ''THE MAN HIMSELF,'' opening Sunday at 59E59 Theaters, is Mr. Dayan's second variation on the play. The original, produced by the National Theater in London, was about an Englishman's drift toward fascism. In 1992, for a theater festival in Israel, Mr. Dayan reimagined the title character as an Israeli soldier in the extremist Kahane movement. This time the character, played by Mr. Dayan, is a manager at an electrical goods warehouse in contemporary Denver who is drawn to radical Christian fundamentalism. ''It was such a mad idea I had to say yes,'' Mr. Drury, who collaborated with Mr. Dayan on the adaptation, told The Denver Post. Through Oct. 1, 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200; $25. And on Tuesday the CULTURE PROJECT kicks off its seven-week Impact Festival with the world premiere of EVE ENSLER's ''TREATMENT,'' about a troubled former soldier and military interrogator (DYLAN McDERMOTT) and the psychologist (PORTIA) who is assigned to him for routine treatment. Opening Sept. 12, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 307-4100; $55.
To the Editor: Re ''A Play of Ideas Can Make a Difference. Discuss'' by Charles Isherwood [Sept. 3]:

IF you were an employee of a company and were disgruntled with its performance, who would you want to hold accountable? The chief executive, who is popular with key constituents and wields clout over your financial well-being? Or at least one, if not two, of the chief executive's top lieutenants, both unpopular, and presumably easy to scapegoat? That, essentially, is the question that faces State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. as he grapples with the biggest political issue in his race to unseat United States Senator Robert Menendez: the war in Iraq.

CITRON--Rose. Died peacefully Friday September 8 with her family by her side at S loan-Kettering. She is survived by her daughter Dassi (Bill Woolis), son Jerry (Jenny Tate) and granddaughters, Simone, Danielle, Chloe, Eve. A holocaust survivor, she will be remembered for her tireless energy, resilience, courage and perseverance. She touched many and was well loved. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam on Monday September 11, 11:30am. Donations: Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital or Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity.

JONES--Douglas W. A memorial service will be held to celebrate the life of Douglas on Friday, September 15th, at noon, at the Kaplan Penthouse, in the Rose Building, at 165 W. 65th St, at Lincoln Center. His many friends and colleagues are invited.

In late August the heavily galleried streets of Chelsea could be mistaken for a ghost town. The only things missing are tumbleweeds and a Sergio Leone soundtrack. But the limousines started finding their way back last week as the first in a burst of new shows opened. And this week the streets will be even busier as more shows open and crowds take advantage of the last precious month of milling-outside weather. Shows by two veteran provocateurs, one American and the other German, are among those worth seeing. At the Gladstone Gallery is an exhibition of the black-and-white architectural photographs of CATHERINE OPIE, who first made her name with gorgeously formal pictures of herself and others, often heavily pierced and tattooed, in drag, in sadomasochistic gear and sometimes in pain. But for the last decade Ms. Opie, a professor of photography at the University of California, Los Angeles, has turned her camera on the facades of houses in Bel-Air and Beverly Hills, the freeways and minimalls of Los Angeles, and the often crumbling roadside scenes that she has come upon while driving around the country. Ms. Opie, who has called herself ''a twisted social documentary photographer,'' manages to infuse these banal urban and suburban landscapes with the same kind of other-ness and vague unease of her portraits. Through Oct. 14, 515 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-9300. The German artist GEORG HEROLD, who is having an exhibition at the Friedrich Petzel Gallery, has also long worked at the intersection of the mundane and the mutinous. In his case the materials he uses -- baking powder, vodka bottles, lone bricks stuffed into expanses of foam rubber, underwear stretched on wire, ''paintings'' made with shellacked caviar -- flirt humorously and provocatively with definitions of art and with art's power (or lack of it) to make political statements. Mr. Herold has described his work as constructions of ''stupid materials,'' but they are ones that can ask intelligent and interesting questions. Through Oct. 21, 537 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9467.
WEXLER--Melissa Ann. 5/9/ 58-9/12/81. Sweet Missy, you still light up our lives when we think of you. Love, Mommy Arline Joachim and Eddie

For most Americans, bigger means better when it comes to home size. But for a small number of people, the extreme opposite is true. They prefer to live in tiny dwellings that are to normal-sized houses what bonsai are to trees: miniaturized but not diminished. These super-downsized homes are eco-friendly, affordable and built with an extraordinary attention to detail.

The Ocean County College Board of Trustees has reinstated Karen Bosley as the faculty adviser to the student newspaper after a federal judge issued a preliminary injunction ordering Ms. Bosley's return. She had held the post for 35 years. She was removed from her job advising the Viking News staff at the end of the spring semester, which she contended was a result of the paper's criticism of the college president, Jon H. Larson. A college spokeswoman has said Ms. Bosley's contract as adviser was not renewed because of her job performance.

Alma Winemiller is the old maid's old maid. And Amanda Plummer is all over her like a swarm of drugged Southern bees in Hartford Stage's heartfelt and heart-wrenching new production of ''Summer and Smoke.'' Tennessee Williams often said that Miss Alma, as almost everyone calls her, was his finest female character and the one most like him. She is a Mississippi minister's daughter, still relatively young in the years just before World War I but already spinsterish, admiring of the ''everlasting struggle'' between good and evil represented by Gothic cathedrals, and eventually dependent on and grateful for ''little mercies,'' like her prescription for sleeping tablets.

WHEN Natalie Wells bought a home in Englewood, N.J., a year ago, she was unaware that her American pit bull terrier was illegal to own in the city. Shortly after moving in, she was told by one of her daughters about a city law that banned the breed, commonly called pit bulls, along with several similar breeds and Rottweilers. Under the 1999 law, even this year's best-in-show winner at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Rufus, a colored bull terrier from Holmdel, N.J., would be banned in Englewood.

WHEN affluent suburbanites travel, they can be quite fussy, demanding that airplanes show up and take off like clockwork and that anything less is -- to use a word the fastidious favor -- unacceptable. But when they're lounging in their backyards, they want the skies to be jet-free, or at least noise-free; if jets must be seen, they should not be heard. The problem in hubs like New York is that the two desires are fast becoming irreconcilable. American airlines handled 739 million passengers last year; by 2015 that number is expected to balloon to 1 billion. No one wants an airport sprouting next door, with all the attendant whines, drones and roars, so the Federal Aviation Administration has been trying to squeeze in more flights by rejiggering the way planes use air space in the corridor between Philadelphia and Connecticut.

To the Editor: After reading ''Dust to Dust: An Affair Post 9/11'' (Modern Love, Aug. 27), I wondered if the author, Nikki Stern, considered the wife of the man with whom she had her three-and-a-half-year affair? When that woman learns of her husband's betrayal, the truth of her life will be undermined by the lies in which Ms. Stern collaborated. Her world will no longer be a secure, predictable place either. Connie Platt Denver

To the Editor: I take issue with ''Big Bag, Bigger, Biggest,'' (Pulse, Sept. 3). The text that accompanies the photographs says that these purses are perfect for carrying as much as ''three diet delivery meals'' and can double as a refuge when one needs to ''hide from those hectoring paparazzi.''
To the Editor: Re ''Paying to Play at School'' (Aug. 27), about school districts charging fees to play school sports:

For most Americans, bigger means better when it comes to home size. But for a small number of people, the extreme opposite is true. They prefer to live in tiny dwellings that are to normal-sized houses what bonsai are to trees: miniaturized but not diminished. These super-downsized homes are eco-friendly, affordable and built with an extraordinary attention to detail.

BOGATY--Helene Marer, 86, of Westborough, MA, formerly of Englewood, NJ; beloved mother of Lewis Bogaty and Daniel Bogaty and his wife Fran Taylor; grandmother of David, Tanya, and Michael Bogaty, and beloved wife of the late Harry Bogaty; dear sister, aunt and friend. Died peacefully on July 16, after an illness. A good and gracious woman of many talents and high principles who acted to help others.

To the Editor: I took my teenage sister to see Nilaja Sun's ''No Child,'' about the crumbling public education system. My sister, deeply affected, asked, ''Is it really like that in some schools?'' The play had a small but significant effect on her future civic consciousness. I remember seeing ''Sarafina!'' when I was 11, aware of the headlines about apartheid but not the human stories connected to it. The musical turned me into the voter, citizen and writer I am today. Plays may not significantly affect election results. But they have a place in shaping the next generation of thinkers. Quiara Alegría Hudes Manhattan The writer is a playwright whose credits include ''Elliot: A Soldier's Fugue.''

Gisela Alvarez, the daughter of Dr. Angelina Espiritu Alvarez and Dr. Edgar Miciano Alvarez of LaGrangeville, N.Y., was married last evening to Ian Lester, a son of Frances Lester and Thomas Harry Lester of Manhattan. The Rev. Kay Greenleaf, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Troutbeck Estate in Amenia, N.Y. The bride, 30, is keeping her name. She is a project director and supervising lawyer at Advocates for Children of New York, a nonprofit organization for protection of student and family rights in New York City public schools. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard and received a law degree from New York University.

Even when a company no longer exists, its scandals sometimes linger on. Teleglobe International Holdings Ltd. of Canada acquired ITXC, an international telephone service provider in Princeton, N.J., in 2004 and became part of Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd. of India a year later.
The byline on the Journeys column about grandparent-grandchild travel on Page 5 in today's Travel section is misspelled. The writer is Caren Osten Gerszberg, not Gerzberg.

NEW YORK The News -- Katie Couric made her debut as a network news anchor. Behind the News -- The reviews were mixed for Ms. Couric, with many critics describing her first broadcast as a journalistic hodgepodge, mixing the serious (a report from Afghanistan) with the not-so-serious (a first photo of Tom Cruise's baby). For all the buildup about a new era at CBS News, in the end her broadcast didn't seem all that different from the others. But the opening night audience, estimated at 13.6 million viewers, was the largest for the network's signature newscast in eight years. DETROIT The News -- The Ford Motor Company brought in an aircraft industry executive, Alan J. Mulally, to help run it. Behind the News -- For William Clay Ford Jr., the company's chairman, the move was an admission that Ford needed new approaches to increase sales and profits. But some strategies Mr. Mulally adopts may end up sounding familiar to Ford executives. In overhauling the commercial aircraft business at Boeing, where he worked for 37 years, Mr. Mulally studied some Ford projects, including the development of the Taurus in the mid-1980's. MEXICO The News -- Mexico's highest electoral court declared Felipe Calderón the country's new president, after two months of dispute. Behind the News -- Mr. Calderón, a conservative who will take office Dec. 1, reached out to supporters of his leftist rival, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, saying he was open to some of their ideas. But Mr. López Obrador, whose claim of widespread voting fraud was rejected by the court, would have none of it. He refused to recognize Mr. Calderón's victory and plans to establish an alternative government. JAPAN The News -- Princess Kiko gave birth to a boy, defusing a debate in Japan about whether women should be allowed to ascend to the imperial throne. Behind the News -- The infant, as yet unnamed, was the first male born in the imperial family in 41 years. Both Princess Kiko and her sister-in-law, Crown Princess Masako, have daughters, but under the imperial system they cannot become empress. A panel of experts last year had recommended the system be changed, but action on the recommendations was postponed when Princess Kiko's pregnancy was announced. WASHINGTON The News -- Ronald Reagan will return to Washington in the form of a statue at the National Statuary Hall in the Capitol. Behind the News -- The good news for fans of Mr. Reagan was bad news for the admittedly fewer fans of another Republican, Thomas Starr King, whose bronze will be removed. King, a Civil War-era California politician who preached national unity, fell victim to rules allowing only two statues per state. In approving plans to enshrine Mr. Reagan, the California Legislature decided that the missionary Junipero Serra could stay, but that King had to go.
To the Editor: Re ''Route 110 Plan Worries Some Merchants'' (Sept. 3):

The growing threat of Islamic fundamentalist terrorism hasn't been a boon to most of the world, but it has had one surprising side effect: increased storage space in Singapore. Thanks to a law designed to counter the terrorism threat, some Singaporeans have ended up with walk-in closets that double as bomb shelters, or shelters that double as closets, depending on their point of view.

Fans of the lyrical qualities of 19th-century paintings -- purity, serenity, sentiment -- will find a visit to the Bush-Holley Historic Site in Cos Cob immensely appealing. There, the latest installation in a series of exhibitions devoted to artists who lived and worked in the Greenwich area presents the work of John Henry Twachtman (1853-1902), one of America's most genteel and popular Impressionist painters. Twachtman is a particularly appropriate choice for this museum. He was a cornerstone of a lively late-19th-century art colony centered on the Bush-Holley House -- where he lived from time to time as a guest and painted and taught other artists. He also bought a 17-acre property in Greenwich, where he did his finest work. The current exhibition is a selection of paintings produced on his Greenwich property, coupled with a handful of works done on his travels to Massachusetts, California and Europe.

The tropical storm that barreled through the Northeast a week ago caused more damage to Con Edison's system than any storm in the last two decades, company officials say, plunging nearly a quarter of the utility's Westchester customers into darkness and leaving a vast trail of snapped trees and downed power lines. By the end of the week, company officials estimated that as many as 76,000 customers in Westchester, or about 300,000 people, had lost electricity as a result of the storm, in many cases for days. Tropical Storm Ernesto felled about 100 trees and 900 wires throughout the county, creating more than 2,000 repair jobs for emergency crews, said William McGrath, Con Edison's vice president for the Bronx and Westchester.

QUATTRO FIGLI (''Four Sons'' in Italian) is so engaging that it is easy to overlook some inconsistency in the cooking. Several factors account for the charm of this small Greenwich restaurant: one vibrantly lemon-painted wall with wry, stylized drawings; white wood trim so immaculate it looks newly painted; artful displays of lemons along the room divider; colorful Fiesta-style tableware; and an overall spotlessness. Add a cheerful, welcoming staff led by the owner, Robert Rosenfeld, who is also the official greeter, and a short menu that differs from the usual Italian, and the result is an upbeat dining experience. As for the food, it all tastes freshly made, and many dishes really hit the mark, beginning with olives marinated in olive oil and good crusty house-made bread.

''They won't let us in? Can you get in?'' If she had had an extra thousand bucks, Eileen Conaty would not have had to ask how to get past the police barricades to attend a $1,000-a-person fund-raiser for United States Senator Robert Menendez headlined by Bill Clinton. Then again, if she had had an extra thousand dollars, Ms. Conaty would probably not have needed to go. After all, she confided, she was on something of a mission.

What was supposed to have been summer's last hurrah instead became another quest for any available stretch of sand and surf. Many Suffolk County residents found themselves warned off their neighborhood beaches over the Labor Day weekend, just as Long Islanders had been periodically throughout the rainy summer. Downpours and the elevated bacterial levels in the water that resulted led Suffolk and Nassau County health officials to close or issue warnings against swimming at a patchwork of beaches and parks for days at a stretch in June, July and August.

An article last Sunday about Dave Zinczenko, the editor-in-chief of Men's Health who has built a franchise based on men's viewpoints, referred incorrectly to the rise in circulation from July 2000, when he took over, through the first half of 2006. According to the Audit Bureau of Circulation, the average paid monthly circulation has increased 226,000 to 1,856,000 from 1,630,000. The increase was not ''more than 100,000,'' which was the rise in average monthly circulation for the full years 2000 through 2005.

MANSBRIDGE--Ronald, 100. On September 1, 2006, peacefully in his home in Weston, Connecticut. Born 11 November 1905 in England, son of George Frederick Mansbridge, inventor of the Mansbridge electrical condenser, and Florence Quye Mansbridge. Educated at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, Mansbridge founded the American Branch of Cambridge University Press and served as its manager for 40 years. Beloved husband of the late Georgia St Clair Mullan (d. 1988) and Janet Dunning Van Duyn (d. 2003). Greatly loved by his two children, Jane and Bruce; his two grandchildren, Nathaniel Mansbridge Jencks and Travis Marshall Mansbridge; and by his stepdaughters, Barbara Van Duyn and Ruth Pratt. A memorial service will be held Sunday, September 24 at 2 PM at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to Amnesty International, 5 Penn Plaza, NYC 10001 or the Tyndale Society, 1000 Regent University Dr, Virginia Beach, VA. 23464.

Heather Schultz, a daughter of Lora and Neil Schultz of Katonah, N.Y., was married on Monday to Dr. Steven Horowitz, a son of Eileen and Kenneth Horowitz of Willowbrook, Staten Island. Rabbi Yaakov Lehrfeld officiated at the Surf Club. The bride and bridegroom met at the State University of New York Downstate Medical School in Brooklyn, where she is a fourth-year student and where he received his medical degree.

The 1999 World Series began with Orlando Hernández of the Yankees going against Greg Maddux of the Atlanta Braves. Each pitched brilliantly, but the Yankees won Game 1 on their way to a four-game sweep. Nearly seven years later, the two venerable pitchers finally got another crack at each other. The rematch took place at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon. Granted, the circumstances were far different.

IN the 50 years he has lived in Montclair, N.J., Rob Bianco has seen his share of monsoon-like downpours, blizzards, ice storms, even the remnants of hurricanes. But Mr. Bianco, the superintendent of public works for Montclair, had never seen anything like the storm that ravaged the leafy landscape of his hometown on July 18.

The remnants of Tropical Storm Ernesto hit Fairfield County last weekend, bringing winds that downed trees and knocked out power to tens of thousands of homes. The storm had been downgraded to a tropical depression, and its center had already veered toward Pennsylvania by the time it struck Connecticut last Saturday, but winds in some areas in the state were gusting at nearly 60 miles per hour, said Todd Miner, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University.

Broken Ground A special section in Monday's paper will be devoted to recounting the re-imagining and rebuilding of ground zero, a story of colorful characters and powerful emotions. Portraits of Grief The families of the victims of 9/11 have had five years to reflect, to mourn, to recover. Interviews with some found markedly different stages in the healing process.

LASTER--Oliver. On September 8, 2006. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Dr. Andrew and Michele, Geri and Scott Macomber, Dr. Steven and Louise. Cherished grandfather of Kyle, Bryan, Nick, Ian, Sophia and Grant. Devoted brother of Richard and Lee Laster. Services 9:30 am, Monday, ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.
86 Elm Place, Nutley, N.J. 1930's American, 3 bedrooms, 1 bath. (1943 to 1960)

The Shore Institute of the Contemporary Arts in Long Branch has unveiled its big fall exhibition titled ''Stuff It!'' -- a riotous ensemble of artworks employing stuffed objects. It is a victory of a kind for this plucky institution, for in May it nearly closed for lack of funds. But it was saved by an anonymous donation of $20,000 from a famous Shore rock musician. It has also just received a grant of $22,000 from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts. The exhibition was organized by Doug Ferrari, an artist who founded the institute and mortgaged his home two years ago to open the nonprofit space. For this exhibition he has chosen artists from all over the country, drawing on submissions through an informal national open call, along with recommendations from friends and other artists. Most of the artists are women, and all of the contributors seem to make art that involves filling, stuffing, inflating, upholstering or padding of one kind or another.

HIRSCHHORN--David. We remember David with love and treasure memories of family gatherings with his beloved mother Amelia. With his dear Barbara, Dan, Michael, Debbie, Sarah, and all their family, we mourn the loss of a man of brilliance, honor and integrity. Jacqueline B. Schneider, Mrs. Henry Schneider $(6$)HIRSCHHORN--David. American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev deeply mourns the passing of David Hirschhorn. David was a passionate and loyal supporter of Ben-Gurion University for nearly 30 years. As family spokesman and president of the Jacob and Hilda Blaustein Foundation, he nurtured the special relationship between the Blaustein family and BGU's world-renowned Jacob Blaustein Institutes for Desert Research. In 1994, David received an honorary doctorate from BGU for his commitment and devotion to the University and to the development of the Negev. The support from this distinguished family has greatly impacted BGU's desert reclamation programs being implemented today in more than 40 countries. David's vision and passion will be sorely missed, but his legacy continues. We extend our profound condolences to his wife Barbara and his entire family. Carol D. Saal, President Amos Drory, Executive Vice President

FOR failing to meet performance standards, the Clara T. O'Connell elementary school in Bristol, Conn., spent three years on the ''in need of improvement'' list under the federal No Child Left Behind program. When a new list came out last month, Connecticut had 290 elementary and middle schools on it, but the O'Connell School was not among them. It had achieved what no other school in the state had managed under the four-year-old program: It had worked itself off the list.

DEEP into suburbia, on a sound barrier that runs along the Taconic State Parkway here, a graffiti artist announces his presence with a single word painted in yellow and black: ''Me.'' Officials said that graffiti had reached new heights this summer. And in a town that bills itself as a retreat from more urban locales, politicians and police officers are taking the problem seriously.

For men who think cleanliness is next to girliness, Lucky Tiger may be just the tonic. The latest entry in a growing niche of skin-care products that might be called newstalgics, Lucky Tiger is a collection of men's grooming products based on formulas the company says have been made since 1935 ($17 to $28.50 at www.nordstrom.com). The stalwartly masculine line -- which includes face scrubs, liquid shave cream, moisturizer and eye serum -- has been updated with ingredients like organic honey, jojoba and green tea. Lest too much cucumber and hibiscus seem less than macho, the label on each strapping brown bottle depicts that classic swashbuckler's quandary: the lady or the tiger?

The Ethics and Compliance Officer Association, working with the University of Chicago Graduate Business School and Harvard's School of Public Health, will recruit corporate guinea pigs to test the assertion: Is honesty the best policy, at least in business?
The public editor column on Aug. 27 about how to distinguish good polling from bad misspelled the surname of the director of surveys for CBS News. She is Kathy Frankovic, not Frankovich.

GALINGER--Sally B. Died of natural causes. Daughter of the late George and Minnie Galinger and sister Corinne G. Alpert. She is survived by brother-in-law Robert Alpert, Highland Park, IL; and nephew Steven G. Alpert (Sarah, Hannah and Monika), Dallas, TX. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Devereux Pocono Center, 1547 Mill Creek Rd., Newfoundland, PA 18445.

IT may have left no physical damage in its wake, but the recent communal storm in this oceanfront city over the future of its beaches has realigned the political and environmental landscape. Despite fears about the city's vulnerability to a major hurricane, the five-member City Council, three Democrats and two Republicans, voted unanimously in May to reject a $98.5 million beach preservation project by the Army Corps of Engineers that was designed to protect Long Beach from ocean flooding.

BILLER--Jack Michael. 75, A Brooklyn Boy who loved Vermont died July 13. Jack was a loyal husband who leaves a loving wife, Irene, two stepchildren Lisa and Michael, two grandchildren Benjamin and David. He leaves a sister Barbara, her children Ronnie and Amy, and several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by two brothers Paul, Irving, and parents, Bertha and Dave. Jack was a graduate of The High School of Music and Art, Cooper Union and New York University. He retired from the Brooklyn High School system where he taught art for 35 years to hundreds of students. He was an artist and writer with a wry sense of humor and good singing voice. He was a Lance Corporal in the Marine Corps during the Korean conflict. A memorial service will be held September 17 in West Rupert, VT., where he and his wife have a summer home for over 22 years.

The Caucus offers a 9/11 roundup, as does the Hotline Blogometer. And assorted others have their own idiosyncratic takes on the day. (Meanwhile, police and fire unions are said to sharply criticize both Mayors Giuliani and Bloomberg on 9/11 in interviews to be broadcast at 7 and 10:30 tonight on NY1.)

Dell, which lately seems to be playing the role of Joe Btfsplk, the Li'l Abner character who walked around with a rain cloud over his head, had more bad news today. The Justice Department has subpoenaed records and an investigation by the audit committee -- commenced after the S.E.C. began asking questions -- has determined that there may have been misstatements in past financial reports. Details are sparse, but the company's 10-Q for the quarter ended Aug. 4 has been delayed, and the company said it would suspend buybacks of its shares.
Many hedge funds, particularly those that invest in equities, tend to exhibit "style creep," according to a new paper by a quartet of economics professors.

Paying tribute, whether through the tolling of a bell for each person lost on Flight 93, or through the reading of the names at ground zero, or the quiet remembrance at the Pentagon, marked the daylong passage of the fifth anniversary of Sept. 11. From Sheryl Gay Stolberg, a White House correspondent and others who fanned out over the three sites, here's the span of the day at midafternoon. At the gaggle on Air Force One, Press Secretary Tony Snow observed, like so many others, that the day opened in New York and in Shanksville with a bright blue sky, as it has every year since then. (Washington's weather was quite bleak today, however.) President Bush made no remarks at the Shanksville or Pentagon ceremonies. The White House released excerpts from the speech Monday night:
How about opening up my blog with what I'm listening to as I head to Africa?

In the spring, when I was picking a student to travel with me to Africa, I was deluged with 4,000 essays. One that grabbed me was the entry from Casey Parks -- even though she later confessed she had written it in about 20 minutes on a bus ride and barely looked it over afterward. Casey won the contest, and this site is going to be her blog on that Africa trip. No doubt lots of the entries are also going to be dashed out while she's jouncing along a road.

As New Yorkers are buzzing over the start of Fashion Week, the head of the French conglomerate PPR seems to be in a shopping mood. In an interview with Le Figaro magazine, Francois-Henri Pinault said that his company, which already owns the high-end fashion houses Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, might acquire some additional luxury brands.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Sept. 11 column, "Promises Not Kept"

As the déjà vu election continues in Connecticut, Ned Lamont's supporters are noting Wall Street Journal/Zogby Interactive poll numbers that show the race (and other Senate contests) tightening. Joe Lieberman's lead is shrinking. Or is it? There are serious questions about the validity of Internet panel polls.

It is easy to conclude that the wrenching events of Sept. 11, 2001, had few long-term effects on Wall Street or the financial-services industry, Michael Santoli writes in the latest issue of Barron's. But he begs to differ -- and offers a long, convincing article detailing the ways in which everything changed.
Americans paused at ground zero for moments of silence, tributes and a recitation of the names of those who were killed on Sept. 11, 2001.

Turns out that one of the key Iowans that Governor Pataki hired to help him campaign there is forbidden, as a state senator there, from working for a political action committee. So he gave back $15,000 to Pataki's PAC.
Hewlett-Packard said Monday it has been ''informally contacted'' by the United States Attorney's Office concerning a company investigation into press leaks of confidential information.
Barr Pharmaceuticals moved back into the pole position in the race for the Croatian drugmaker Pliva on Monday, after disclosing a revised $2.5 billion takeover bid that trumped one from Actavis.
The Nordic and Baltic bourse group OMX is holding exploratory discussions about being acquired by the Nasdaq Stock Market, The Financial Times said on Monday.
New York collections from Diane von Furstenberg, Lela Rose, Oscar de la Renta, Tracy Reese and Tuleh.

News flash: Made-for-TV movies are not unimpeachable sources of truth. Two conservative columnists join the liberal critics of the ABC docudrama "The Path to 9/11." John Podhoretz, writing in The New York Post, says it is "entirely unworthy of your time":

The reading of the names, in year five, began Monday morning at ground zero, this time with the spouses, partners or other family members participating in the memorial listing of the 2,749 people lost there.Those amplified words echo through the airspace there, as families clutch photos of their loved ones to their chests and carry flowers to the reflecting pools.

There are times, when a clock flashes 9:11, that I can't get the acrid smell of smoke from the long-burning fires out of my senses. You could smell it uptown as well as downtown, depending on the shifting winds. Or the times when I am simply unable to forget the shadows the towers cast as I biked my way through lower Manhattan, throughout the 90's, or the wind tunnels they created along the alleys surrounding them, sometimes so cutting that I would run into the Financial Center and buy a sweatshirt to cover me.
The political chess game over national security continues this week on Capitol Hill - with the added dramatic element of the Sept. 11 anniversary.
The fifth anniversary of 9/11 dominates the newspapers this morning, as politics, for the most part, recedes for a day.
From the Times/CBS Poll, published last Thursday, are follow-up interviews with respondents. The national poll was conducted Aug. 17-21 and the New York City poll conducted Aug. 23-27.
Rexel, the French electronics distributor, could be floated in what would be the largest leveraged initial public offering ever, The Times of London said Monday.
Scottish Power and Scottish & Southern Energy have held talks about a 20 billion pound ($37 billion) merger to create Britain's biggest utility, The Telegraph reported Monday.

Outside of the memorialization of the day, there are quite a few articles worth mentioning on individual races (a lot of focus on Rhode Island's hot Senate primary on Tuesday between the incumbent Republican, Lincoln Chafee, and Mayor Steve Laffey of Cranston), as well as takeouts on other House and Senate races worth watching.

Two groups of private equity firms are vying to acquire Freescale Semiconductor for more than $16 billion in what would be the largest buyout ever in the technology sector, people involved in the negotiations told The New York Times.
The University of Missouri graduate student introduces herself and her family before leaving on a two-week reporting trip to Africa. (Producer: Naka Nathaniel)
The computer maker Dell is delaying the filing of its latest quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said on Monday.
Group 4 Securicor said on Monday it expects to sell off the rest of its cash services business in Germany by the end of the year after the business continued to make heavy losses in the first half.

Newell Rubbermaid, the consumer products maker, is close to a deal to sell its preschool toys business to a privately owned toy maker for an undisclosed amount, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday.
The steelmaker Ipsco has agreed to acquire a steel-tube producer, the NS Group, for $1.46 billion, the companies said on Monday.

Jim Kolbe, the retiring congressman from Arizona's Eighth Congressional District, wanted a moderate Republican to replace him, but disappointment appears increasingly likely. His favored primary candidate, state Representative Steve Huffman, appears to be splitting the moderate G.O.P. vote with Mike Hellon, a former state party chairman.
A telecommunications entrepreneur, Walter Anderson, pleaded guilty to tax evasion and fraud on Friday in connection with what authorities said was the nation's largest-ever criminal tax case.
Jean-Martin Folz, who has presided as chief executive of Peugeot Citroën during a three-year decline in profitability, will retire in January, the company said on Friday.
Sportingbet's chairman, Peter Dicks, was released in New York on Friday after posting $50,000 bail while he fights extradition to Louisiana on criminal charges of illegal Internet gambling.

When Sumner Redstone fired Viacom's chief executive, Tom Freston, last week, the move brought on fresh speculation as to whether Thomas E. Dooley, the new senior executive vice president, is actually the media world's own "deep throat."
So much for honor among, er, co-conspirators.

A Hewlett-Packard board meeting ended inconclusively on Sunday, with no word on whether the chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, would be asked to resign over her role in an investigation that dug up the phone records of company directors and journalists.

The Broadcom Corporation, a computer chip maker under investigation for stock options backdating, discovered more irregularities that will double its expenses to at least $1.5 billion, the company said Friday.

Although he has put off a meeting with Detroit automotive leaders until after the November elections, President Bush called the chairman of Ford Motor on Friday, only days after the struggling automaker named a new chief executive.
KSL Capital Partners of Denver has raised more than $1 billion for its first buyout fund, KSL Capital Partners II, far exceeding an initial target of $750 million.
A consortium spearheaded by Qatar's state-owned investment fund is the frontrunner to buy Thames Water for about 7 billion pounds ($13 billion), according to The Observer.
Aquarius Technologies, a provider of waste water treatment technology, has raised $7.5 million in Series A financing.

With its newly formed $111 million venture capital fund, Wasatch Advisors plans to invest in late-stage, venture-backed companies and translate its public market expertise into initial public offering profits.
Pinnacle Financial Partners has completed the private placement of $20 million in trust preferred securities.
General Motors is planning its bond market comeback.

Hertz and the Vanguard Car Rental Group, the operator of the National Car Rental and Alamo Rent A Car brands, are both planning public offerings at a time when the rental car industry faces a major business shift:
Man Group, the British hedge fund manager, is likely to choose New York for a listing of its brokerage arm if it goes ahead with the much-rumored spin-off of the business, The Observer reported.

The Chicago Board Options Exchange is moving toward becoming another publicly traded financial marketplace. Its chairman and chief executive, William Brodsky, said Friday that the bourse plans to move ahead despite a lawsuit from its rival, the Chicago Board of Trade.
Citigroup named Dean Barr as the head of its Tribeca Global Management unit, succeeding Tanya Styblo Beder, in an effort to jump-start the hedge fund unit's sagging returns.
When the big Wall Street brokerage houses begin reporting third-quarter results next week, profit margins will not be the most important thing on investors' minds.
A magazine considered by some as juicy insider info and derided by others as navel-gazing is about to get a corporate cousin.

Discrepancies between what investment banks say they trade and what exchanges report has the NASD, the private industry regulator, wondering if the financial institutions are engaging in some serious misconduct.
Five years ago, the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center decimated Keefe, Bruyette & Woods's corporate headquarters and killed a third of its workforce.

Barrick Gold of Toronto announced plans Monday to sell its 50 percent stake in South Deep mine in South Africa. The deal, with a South African mining company, Gold Fields, is worth more than $1.5 billion, Barrick Gold said.

Genting, a gaming company owned by Malaysia's third-richest family, will buy Stanley Leisure, the largest British casino operator, for 483.6 million pounds ($901 million) to reduce a reliance on Asia as competition mounts.
The number of mergers reviewed by federal antitrust agencies rose in 2005, but fewer deals ran into trouble with regulators than in previous years.

The European Commission issued an unprecedented warning yesterday to Germany and Spain against reaching a private deal that would enable the German energy group E.ON to win its 27 billion euro takeover bid for a Spanish rival, Endesa, after months of political rows.
The board of Banca Popolare Italiana is expected to shortlist prospective bidders this week in the next key step in the consolidation of the Italian banking industry.
As two of its largest rivals, Lucent and Alcatel, got a step closer to sealing a multibillion dollar merger last week, questions persisted about how Nortel Networks would struggle to play catch-up.

Yahoo has been oft-cited as an ideal takeover candidate for software giant Microsoft, and even more so now that Google and Apple appear to be drawing ever closer to one another to topple Bill Gates' s empire.

Telecom Italia said Sunday that its board would discuss the restructuring of its mobile and fixed-line phone operations on Monday, a move that could lead to the sale of all or part of its mobile arm, Telecom Italia Mobile, or T.I.M..

In their continuing quest for bigger game, private equity firms have set their sights on what would be a record-setting technology buyout. A consortium of firms including Texas Pacific Group, Blackstone Group and Permira were near a deal Sunday night to buy Freescale Semiconductor, a former unit of Motorola, for more than $16 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. But the offer was topped by a rival bid from a group including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Silver Lake Partners, setting the stage for a bidding war, these people said.

Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain offered help for the Lebanese Army and vowed to renew efforts to bring peace to the Middle East.

After setting records in May, June and July, China’s trade surplus ballooned last month to a new record of $18.8 billion as exports soared, according to preliminary customs figures released on Monday.
The Palestinian Authority president said today that he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas meant to the end the Palestinians’ international isolation.
Two groups of investment firms were vying to acquire Freescale Semiconductor for more than $16 billion late Sunday night, people involved in the negotiations said.
Americans paused at ground zero and the two other 9/11 sites for moments of silence, tributes and a recitation of the names of those who were killed.
Dawn in Lower Manhattan today began much as it did on the day five years ago that left an indelible scar on the nation.
