For his nearly three decades in the State Senate, Martin Connor has become known not only for the time he spent as the Democratic leader, but as one of the state’s most experienced election lawyers, working for Democratic candidates throughout the state.

Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, was inducted on Saturday into the French Legion of Honor Order. Mr. Kelly was given the medal that symbolizes his induction at a ceremony at the French Consulate. The order dates to 1802, when it was created by Napoleon Bonaparte. President Jacques Chirac of France tapped Mr. Kelly for the honor, which recognized his crime-fighting efforts after the 2001 terrorist attacks.

Two men were fatally shot about 2 p.m. yesterday in an East New York apartment building in what one witness said “looked like an ambush.” One of the victims, Dajuan Mitchell, 19, was found on the sixth-floor landing of a building at 428 Sheffield Avenue, shot twice in the torso and once in the groin, the police and witnesses said. The second victim, Eric McDonald, 22, was found on the fourth-floor landing, also shot twice in the torso. The police released few details as to a possible motive for the shooting, but said it remained under investigation. Both men were pronounced dead last night at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center.

The principal of Derby High School has proposed fines for students whose cellphones are confiscated for ringing in class. The principal, Michael Novio, told The New Haven Register that he has proposed fines that would start at $3, and increase to $5 for a second offense and $10 for a third. He said the fines would be used to sponsor an after-prom party. The fines must be approved by the board of education. The Connecticut Association of Boards of Education says it is not aware of any other schools that fine students for using cellphones. Most just hand out detention.

A sky-diving instructor and another man making a tandem jump were killed shortly before noon yesterday, the authorities in Gloucester County said. The men, Paul Joseph, 30, of Monroe Township, and Reed Michael Loeschke, 28, of Hoboken, fell to their deaths when their main and reserve parachutes opened only partially, the authorities said. The men were found in the yard of a vacant home in Washington Township and were pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Joseph was an instructor at Freefall Adventures, a sky-diving school at Cross Keys Airport in Monroe. He and Mr. Loeschke were making a tandem jump, in which an instructor and inexperienced diver are tied together. An official at Freefall Adventures did not immediately return a phone call seeking information yesterday.

An off-duty emergency medical technician was killed early yesterday when the driver of an Acura sedan switched lanes, apparently without seeing the motorcycle, to avoid hitting a stalled vehicle, the police said. The 25-year-old medical technician, whose name the police did not immediately release, lost control of the 2006 Yamaha motorcycle on Kings Highway near Snyder Avenue in Remsen Village. He crashed into a utility pole and then into a bus-stop sign, the police said. The man, who worked at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, according to fire department officials, was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital Center. A passenger on the motorcycle, a 20-year-old woman, was in serious but stable condition yesterday, the police said.

A baby boy was found on the steps of the 103rd Precinct station house in Jamaica about 9 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. The infant, found inside a black diaper bag along with formula, diapers and clothing, was healthy and wrapped in a yellow blanket. According to the police, whoever left the child was apparently taking advantage of the state’s safe haven law, which allows a parent to anonymously leave an infant at locations — including hospital emergency rooms, police stations or firehouses — without fear of prosecution. However, the police said parents should notify someone at the drop-off location that they are leaving a baby. The police are asking anyone with information about the infant, who was taken to St. John’s Queens Hospital, to call (800) 577-8477.

A barge slammed into an Amtrak bridge on Saturday, delaying trains and stranding boat traffic for several hours. The 310-foot barge came loose from a tugboat about 3:30 p.m. It was not known how the towline snapped. The bridge was shut down for two hours because the barge destroyed a 75-foot-long fender below the bridge designed to protect piers. Trains were eventually allowed to resume travel over the bridge, but at lower than normal speeds.

Spier New York, an agency known for book advertising, has been acquired and absorbed by Warren Kremer Paino Advertising in New York. Financial terms were not disclosed. Twenty-eight Spier employees will join the 32 employees at Warren Kremer. The president at Spier, Bethany Chamberlain, is leaving, as is the creative director at Spier, Ted Mendelson; his duties will be absorbed by Kim Huelsman, executive creative director at Warren Kremer. Peter Warren remains chairman at Warren Kremer and Tom McCartin remains president.

Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic of Montenegro, the longest-serving political leader in the Balkans, appears to have secured four more years in office, according to unofficial results from parliamentary elections held Sunday. The results showed that Mr. Djukanovic's coalition had won a majority in the 81-seat Parliament. It was unclear if the coalition had won an absolute majority of votes. Official results were expected later Monday.

CRUNCH TIME AT ABC -- On Wednesday, the ''Today'' show on NBC -- the ratings leader in morning TV -- will introduce a new co-host, Meredith Vieira, who is succeeding Katie Couric. At ABC's ''Good Morning America'' the senior executive producer, Jim Murphy, will use the transition at ''Today'' to try wooing enough people over to ABC to erase what was a nearly 900,000-viewer advantage. Mr. Murphy is also trying to make sure that loyal viewers do not abandon ''Good Morning America'' as it goes through a major transition of its own: the departure of Charles Gibson. [Page C1.] CARTOONS ON THE CELLPHONE -- ''Lil' Bush,'' a cartoon show about the adventures of a grade-school version of President Bush and his pals made its debut on Amp'd cellphones on Sept. 1. Six five-minute episodes are to be released every week for six weeks, and each is to be available on demand afterward. The series is another example of cellphone service companies looking to attract subscribers -- and draw more money out of existing ones -- with original content, especially video. [C5.] SHOWTIME AT APPLE -- On Tuesday, Apple will hold another of Steven P. Jobs's marketing events to unveil what is expected to be his next campaign: to transform the distribution of movies as thoroughly as he has revolutionized the recording industry with iTunes. [C1.] GAMES FOR CASUAL PLAYERS -- Video game makers are starting to go after the casual or coffee-break gamer, who indulges in short-term play and not necessarily of the action-packed genre. [C7.] THE MARKETING OF 9/11 -- Marketers and the news media, acutely aware of the sensitivities surrounding Sept. 11, 2001, are still trying to determine where the fine line lies between commemoration and exploitation. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.] SHOPPING AND SOCIALIZING -- Several sites on the Internet -- like ThisNext.com, Kaboodle.com, Wists.com and StyleHive.com -- are spearheading a new category of e-commerce called social shopping that tries to combine two favorite online activities: shopping and social networking. Like MySpace, the sites are designed for browsing and blogging, with some shopping-related technology twists included. ''Online shopping is more accurately described as purchasing, because it's so directed and goal-specific,'' said Gordon Gould, ThisNext's chief executive, left. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] THE PRETEXT MASQUERADE -- At the heart of the controversy swirling around Hewlett-Packard is the technique known as pretexting -- obtaining the calling records of people under a pretext, like masquerading as a customer. The shady subculture of pretexting has been getting renewed attention since it came to light last week that a subcontractor for an investigative firm working for H.P. used pretexting to obtain the call records of company directors and reporters. [C1.] FOR OPEC, PRICE CONCERNS -- What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet today, the major question on delegates' minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but just how far they might drop. Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the last month, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers. [C1.] REGIONAL NEWS AND LAYOFFS -- On Thursday, The Dallas Morning News is expected to announce that more than 100 newsroom staffers have accepted buyout packages, shrinking the size of the staff by slightly less than 20 percent. As a result, what was once a newspaper with national reach will focus mainly on local and regional news. [C4.] RESTRUCTURING IN ITALY -- Telecom Italia, the telecommunications company, said yesterday that its board would discuss the restructuring of its mobile and fixed-line phone operations today, a move that may presage the sale of all or part of its mobile arm, TIM. [C4.]

The terror attack on the World Trade Center five years ago today presented New York's government and civic leaders with the monumental challenge of reimagining and rebuilding ground zero. The effort began in good will. But it quickly devolved into a clash political agendas and business interests and conflicting visions of how tragedy should be memorialized. Today, ground zero remains a 16-acre, 70-foot hole in Lower Manhattan where only subterranean construction has begun. A special section in today's paper is devoted to recounting this New York story, with its mix of colorful characters, powerful emotions and valuable real estate. BY DEBORAH SONTAG

MONTESANO--Irma. Of White Plains, passed away peacefully on September 8th, 2006, at her home. Irma Pierro was born in the Bronx on November 12th, 1916, and was married to the late Nicholas Montesano of White Plains. Irma taught in the White Plains public school system from 1962 to 1982. She is survived by her loving sons Roger and Neil.

ANY--Marcelle. A rare jewel. Marcelle Any, beloved wife of Albert, cherished mother of Alan and Carol, loving grandmother of Lauren, Eileen, and Andy, devoted sister and daughter, died peacefully on Thursday evening, September 7th, 2006. She was 84 years old. Born in Bombay, India, to Iraqi Jewish parents, she came in 1947 to the United States, where she married and settled in NYC. In 1960, she and her family moved to Larchmont, NY. Generous and gentle, consoling and self-effacing, for nearly 60 years she was the emotional mainstay of her family, succoring and soothing them through their troubles with her steady guidance and unwavering encouragement. An accomplished seamstress, knitter, and crocheter, she made whole wardrobes of unique and delightful clothes for her children and grandchildren. Nearly everyone who met her was captivated by her beauty and gentle kindness. The Book of Proverbs asks, ''Who can find a woman of valor?'' Her husband did. She is and will be forever missed.

Vice President Dick Cheney on Sunday backed away from his insistence last year that the insurgency in Iraq was in its ''last throes,'' but in a contentious television interview he said that even if he had known in 2003 that his claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction were mistaken, ''we'd do exactly the same thing.'' Mr. Cheney's appearance on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC was part of the administration's drive before the fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to change the minds of Americans who tell pollsters that they now believe the invasion of Iraq was a misguided diversion in the battle against terrorism.
MOND--Bertrand, September 11, 2002. Dear Bert, it's been four years since we lost you. How much we miss the exceptional man you were. Love, Phyl

OLDSTEIN--Jack. 81, passed away September 10, quietly, at his Tamarac, FL, home with his family and friends by his side. Born in Brooklyn, Jack was preceded in death by his cherished wife of 31 years, Norma Ness Oldstein. He is survived by his beloved children, daughter Wendy Oldstein and son-in-law Mark Komen of Narbarth, PA, son Larry Oldstein of Boulder, CO, and daughter Amy Oldstein, of Scarsdale, NY. Also surviving are granddaughters Victoria and Madeline Komen, and sisters Betty Champion of Lake Worth, FL, and Florine Harris of Yonkers, NY. Jack graduated Brooklyn College and Columbia University Graduate Teachers College. He was an accomplished athlete, captain of the Columbia fencing team, and a lifelong tennis player. Mr. Oldstein was the enthusiastic, pipe-smoking founder and president of Dependable Lists, Inc, NY, from 1954 until its sale in 1985. Well respected and a pioneer in the direct marketing industry, Mr. Oldstein was profiled in the New York Times in 1982. Services to be held on Wednesday, September 13, 2006, 10 am, at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 Broad St West, Mt. Vernon, NY. Donations may be made to Vitas Hospice Charitable Fund, 877 - 800 - 2951, or www.vitascharityfund.org. Cards may be sent to Amy Oldstein, 281 Garth Rd, Apt B1C, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

Bally Total Fitness, Chicago, named the Eastwest Marketing Group, New York, to handle its creative and promotional advertising and marketing account, which had been handled internally at Bally and by various outside agencies. Spending was estimated at $75 million.

Showdown in Iowa The biggest game not featuring two top-25 teams this week will be Iowa State's trip to No. 16 Iowa. The Hawkeyes needed two overtimes to escape Syracuse with a 20-13 victory. The Hawkeyes played without their starting quarterback, Drew Tate (abdominal muscle strain); his status for Saturday was listed as day to day. Line of the Week 24 for 29, 333 yards, 3 TD's Erik Ainge of Tennessee, below, continued his remarkable transformation under the offensive coordinator David Cutcliffe. His seven touchdown passes in two weeks have already surpassed his total for last year. A big game against Florida on Saturday could launch him into the Heisman race. Injury Toll Georgia lost its starting quarterback, Joe Tereshinski, for up to six weeks with a high ankle sprain. The Bulldogs will look to the freshman Matthew Stafford when they play host to Alabama at Birmingham on Saturday. Also, Tennessee lost two of its defensive starters for the season -- cornerback Inky Johnson (injured shoulder) and tackle Justin Harrell (torn left biceps). Seasons on the Brink Could Tobacco Road be repaved next off-season? North Carolina State Coach Chuck Amato is in hot water after the Wolfpack (1-1) lost to Akron on Saturday. North Carolina Coach John Bunting is in a similar spot after the Tar Heels (0-2) were blown out at home by Virginia Tech. Duke (0-2) does not have a good shot at a victory until Navy visits Nov. 4. Going for It Scrapping conservatism and going for the victory worked for Akron Coach J. D. Brookhart. The Zips went for a touchdown instead of a field goal on third-and-1 at North Carolina State, and tailback Dennis Kennedy crossed the goal line as time expired for a 20-17 victory. Air Force Coach Fisher DeBerry was not as lucky, and the Falcons lost, 31-30, after their 2-point conversion attempt against Tennessee failed with 1:35 remaining. Illinois State also came up short on a 2-point conversion attempt in a 24-23 loss at Kansas State. No Letdown in Boise Boise State's former coach, Dan Hawkins, is struggling. He fell to 0-2 at Colorado with a loss to Colorado State. But the Broncos' new coach, Chris Petersen, is doing just fine. He is 2-0, including an impressive 42-14 victory against Oregon State on Thursday. Boise State tailback Ian Johnson, who rushed for 240 yards in that game, has seven touchdowns, tied for No. 1 in the nation.

BLINDER--Richard. At the very week when Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York marks the restoration of its main sanctuary, the leadership and members of the Temple express their profound sadness on the passing of Richard Blinder. The firm of which he was such an integral part, Beyer, Blinder & Bell, was the Temple's partner in the physical revival of our spiritual home. Richard Blinder and all his brilliant associates provided the inspiration and the methodology for this historic task. May his memory be a blessing, and may his family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Marcia Waxman, President George Asch, Secretary $(6$)BLINDER--Richard L., FAIA. Founding Partner, Beyer Blinder Belle. Richard was just now at the pinnacle of his career-on the rise with no end in sight. We just wish he had stayed long enough to enjoy the fruits of his new work in China. Over the last ten years he found himself realizing more and more his vision of what architecture could be. He was a modest man--and yet his buildings are bold, clear and magnificent. Daisy Expósito-Ulla, a longtime executive at agencies specializing in the Hispanic market, is returning to advertising by buying a majority stake in an agency, CMS/Partners in New York, that was started last year by former colleagues. Financial terms were not disclosed. Ms. Expósito-Ulla will become chairwoman at the agency, renamed D Expósito & Partners. Her former colleagues, Fernando Fernández and Gloria Constanza, who were partners at CMS/Partners, will be partners at the renamed agency. Ms. Expósito-Ulla had most recently been chairwoman and chief executive at the Bravo Group in New York, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands division of the WPP Group.

TV on the Radio ''Return to Cookie Mountain'' (Interscope) An elegy, a squall, a survey of ruins, a call for resolve, an impetus to dance, an incantation, a reverie, a taunt, a surge: TV on the Radio's ''Return to Cookie Mountain'' is all of these and more. The second full-length album by Brooklyn's best band, it expands TV on the Radio's music in multiple directions. It's more experimental yet catchier, more introspective yet more assertive, by turns gloomier and funnier, and above all richer in both sound and implication. ''Return to Cookie Mountain'' is simply one of this year's best albums.

He is survived by beloved daughters Deborah (Robert) Tom and Lisa (Adam) Waldbaum and cherished grandchildren Joshua and Sam Waldbaum. A loving and selfless man; he will be missed by all. Services Tuesday, September 12, 10 a.m., at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY, 800-992-9262.
SCHONBERG--George. Gone 11 years. So absent--so present. Love always, Doris

For a year after Sept. 11, reporters for The Times offered capsule portraits of 2,400 victims, including the eight below. Their families have now had five years to reflect, to mourn, to recover. Interviews with a sampling of them found that, while they were at markedly different stages in the healing process, many have found constructive ways of embracing life without forgetting. Widows and widowers have remarried. Children have gone on to college or begun first grade. Some people have settled into new homes, new geography. And a few, while still struggling with their loss, have arrived at surprising places that they could never have foreseen. PAGES A14-15

Justin Timberlake ''FutureSex/LoveSounds'' (Jive/Sony BMG) 4The new Justin Timberlake album is sure to be one of the year's biggest releases. But part of its charm is how small it sounds. He sings much of the album in a shy falsetto, and no matter how nasty his pickup lines are (not very, in case you're wondering), he sounds like a nice guy. The album cover shows him driving a well-shod heel into a disco ball, and you almost expect the back to show him carefully sweeping up the pieces.

D. R. Drive between Grand and 61st Streets; Grand Street from the F. D. R. The former Giants linebacker Harry Carson was presented with his Pro Football Hall of Fame ring at halftime. He was inducted earlier in the summer. JOHN BRANCH (NYT)

An obituary on Aug. 30 about Rainer Barzel, a conservative political power in postwar West Germany, misstated the constitutional rank of one office he held. As president of the Bundestag, somewhat akin to the speaker of the United States House of Representatives, he ranked just below the federal president, who is the head of state, and not the chancellor, who is the chief of government.

THOMPSON--Nigel. ''Now your priests are dead and I am left alive. But in truth, it is I who am dead and they who live. For, as always, the spirit of the dead will always survive in the memory of the living.'' With love, Rosie

7 P.M. (Cinemax) BROTHERS LOST: STORIES OF 9/11 -- On Sept. 11, 2001, Sean McGinly lost his brother Mark (above right, as a child with Sean), a metals trader who worked on the 92nd floor of the World Trade Center. In the five years since, Mr. McGinly has tried to keep his brother's memory alive through contact with other men who lost brothers as well. This documentary explores the men's common bond. 8 P.M. (NBC) FLIGHT 93 -- On Sept. 11, as two planes hurtled toward the World Trade Center and another toward the Pentagon, a fourth -- United Airlines Flight 93 -- was in the midst of a midair struggle as passengers and crew members tried valiantly to keep its terrorist pilot from hitting his mark. In this special, Jane Pauley interviews family and friends of some of those on the flight, which crashed in a field near Shanksville, Pa., and uses new audiotapes to chronicle the acts of heroism aboard. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Strange, um, bedfellows: Bellick moves in with Michael, Lincoln and Nika. Meanwhile, a nice family picks up a hitchhiking T-Bag. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE PATH TO 9/11 -- Part 2 of a dramatization of events -- some factual, some apparently not so -- incorporated in ''The 9/11 Commission Report.'' 9 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICA REBUILDS II: RETURN TO GROUND ZERO -- Mariska Hargitay narrates this second installment in a trilogy, begun in September 2002, that aims to be a definitive record of the recovery and reopening of the World Trade Center site, including the proposed Freedom Tower (right, in an architectural rendering). 9 P.M. (Speed) KYLE PETTY'S CHARITY RIDE ACROSS AMERICA -- Rev those engines. For the 12th year, the Nascar greats Kyle and Richard Petty lead more than 250 motorcyclists from Idaho to North Carolina to raise money for children's hospitals. 10 P.M. (Showtime) WEEDS -- Celia (Elizabeth Perkins) eases up on Isabelle's (Allie Grant) plus-size modeling aspirations once she realizes her daughter might be headed for the big time. Only now a light bulb, however dim, is starting to turn on in Celia's prettily puzzled head. What exactly does her friend Nancy (Mary-Louise Parker) do to keep herself busy? 10 P.M. (Sundance) DUST TO DUST: THE HEALTH EFFECTS OF 9/11 -- Five years after the Environmental Protection Agency assured the public that it could breathe easily regarding health hazards associated with the attacks on the World Trade Center, some of the first responders on the scene in Lower Manahttan (above, six weeks after Sept. 11) are seriously ill or dying. This documentary tries to discern the facts from the fiction, and the science from the politics. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Here are glimpses of some of those who lost family members in the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the World Trade Center, and of their lives since. They were written by Cara Buckley, Glenn Collins, Anthony DePalma, Robin Finn, Jan Hoffman, Tina Kelley, N. R. Kleinfield and Andy Newman. Their stories appear alongside photographs of the victims. With the exception of Ms. Buckley, the writers interviewed families they had spoken to five years ago. The families were chosen by the reporters; some who were contacted chose not to participate. STEPHEN KEVIN TOMPSETT Worrying Enough for Two For Dorry Tompsett it is a daily struggle, trying to make sure her daughter does not mother her too much.

When Mike Nugent warmed up Sunday before the Jets' season opener against the Tennessee Titans, several of his field-goal attempts missed to the right. Sometimes a bad warm-up session does not mean anything. But Sunday was not one of those days -- Nugent's aim never improved.
SCHNEIDER--Ethel. We mourn with the Schneider family the passing of our dear friend with all our love. Sandra and Arthur Fishman

Alan Broadbent ''Every Time I Think of You'' (Artistry Music) Those familiar with Mr. Broadbent's dark, churning string arrangements for Charlie Haden's Quartet West and for the singer Jane Monheit will welcome this intensely moody album for jazz piano trio and strings that mixes standards and original compositions. Featuring Mr. Broadbent on piano, Brian Bromberg on bass, Kendall Kaye on drums, and the Tokyo Strings, ''Every Time I Think of You'' belongs to a select group of recordings for jazz piano and orchestra, the best of which is the 1965 classical-jazz fusion ''Bill Evans Trio with Symphony Orchestra.''

The Colts used to have the league's most reliable kicker in Mike Vanderjagt. Vanderjagt, who signed with the Cowboys in the off-season, missed Dallas's opener with an injury. Adam Vinatieri, the kicker the Colts were surprised to find left on the market by the New England Patriots, kicked four field goals for the Colts on Sunday night, all with a ligament injury in his plant foot.

John Mayer ''Continuum'' (Columbia) John Mayer has been wrestling with himself. A couple of years ago, after earning music industry acclaim and the widespread adoration of American girls (and their mothers), he tacked toward stripped-down guitar rock. His last album chronicled a jam-heavy tour with the bassist Pino Palladino and the drummer Steve Jordan. It sounded great, though it must have made some in Mr. Mayer's camp a little nervous.
FRIEDMAN--Paul J. September 11, 2001 at 8:46AM on Flight 11. Our Paul, a gentleman and gentle man. Endless love from Mom and Family.

To the Editor: On this fifth anniversary of 9/11, I recall the overwhelming grief and helplessness that day. As time passed we needed to grieve, for America, for New York, but mostly for those who died, their families and the children they wouldn't see grow up, and, for some, the children they never even knew.

An obituary on Sept. 2 about the artist Buffie Johnson misstated the dimensions of the panels that made up the mural she painted for the Astor Theater in New York in the late 1950's. Although the finished mural was 45 feet high, each of its 224 panels measured roughly 5 feet by 10 feet; the panels themselves were not 45 feet high.

A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Aug. 30 about the number of female law clerks hired by Supreme Court justices included incorrect figures on the clerks hired by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in two court terms and misstated the percentage of her clerks since 2000 who have been female. In the 2005-2006 term, two of four O'Connor clerks were women -- not one of three. In 2004-2005, two of four were women -- not one of four. From the 2000 term until Justice O'Connor's retirement in January 2006, 52 percent of her clerks were female, not 46 percent. A corrected chart can be found at www.nytimes.com/2006/08/30/washington/30scotus.html.

In addition to the inescapable news media coverage, numerous memorials and plenty of political controversy connected to today's anniversary, many books offer insight and information. ''The Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11'' provides historical sweep -- 50 years' worth -- to the attack. Five years later, and two years after publication, the official report of the 9/11 commission is still high on the list, as is ''Without Precedent: The Inside Story of the 9/11 Commission,'' by its co-chairs, Thomas H. Kean and Lee H. Hamilton. SHELLY FREIERMAN

An obituary on Aug. 24 about Jeffrey Tennyson, an artist whose obsession with hamburgers led to a collection of hamburger artifacts that included a music box modeled on the hamburger-loving cartoon character J. Wellington Wimpy, misstated the name of the comic strip in which Wimpy first appeared and the date of that appearance. It was then ''Thimble Theatre'' (not ''Popeye''), and the character of Wimpy, first unnamed, was introduced in the early 1930's, not the 1920's.

Deal on a Constitution For Iraq Is Teetering An agreement struck 11 months ago by Shiite and Kurdish leaders to win Sunni Arab support for a new constitution is fraying, causing concern among some political leaders that it could jeopardize Iraq's fragile governing coalition. The dispute peaked as a large Shiite faction continued to fight for quick approval of legislation giving provinces the authority to create autonomous states, which Sunnis oppose. Opponents of Brooklyn's proposed Atlantic Yards project were hoping to send a message to local pro-Yards pols today -- by retiring a few of them.

John Spencer, now the Republican candidate for United States Senate, declared victory at a Polish-American community center in Yonkers, with a nice spread of pierogis for his fans and few words for his now-vanquished opponent, K.T. McFarland.

Lincoln Chafee fought off conservative challenger Steve Laffey in the most watched contest of a busy primary day Tuesday, the Republican Senate race in Rhode Island. Laffey conceded after Chafee posted a 54 percent to 46 percent victory.

State Senator Ada Smith of Queens, after a year in which she was reprimanded by her colleagues, faced accusations of harrassment by former aides, and was abandoned by longtime supporters, now appears to be out of a job, according to unofficial election results.She was narrowly beaten by Shirley Huntley, a first-time candidate who a former president of a community school board. The tally was 5,364 votes to 5,262, which could change if more ballots emerge to be counted.

Only slightly less baroque than the Republican Senate primary has been the 10th congressional district Democratic primary, where Charles Barron and Roger Green, two local pols who wanted to defeat incumbent Edolphus Towns, spent most of the last week taking potshots at each other instead of Mr. Towns.

In the Republican Senate primary, John Spencer has defeated K.T. McFarland, based on unofficial results. The race inspired few voters to go the polls and had rapidly devolved into personal attacks involving marital infidelity, out-of-wedlock children, mental stability and personal revelations about past parental abuse.
Andrew Cuomo has defeated Mark Green and Sean Patrick Maloney to win the Democratic nomination for New York attorney general, based on unofficial returns.
Another non-surprise: Hillary Rodham Clinton has defeated her anti-war challenger, Jonathan Tasini, based on unofficial returns.

The campaign of K.T. McFarland's is camped out, sans candidate, at what is presumably a McFarland stronghold: The Women's National Republican Club on 51st street near 5th Avenue.

The Committee on Capital Markets Regulation, announced today, includes representatives of every industry group interested in relaxing regulation of securities markets, and of increasing regulation of those who would sue them. It is not an official body, but it includes former close associates of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, and the news release announcing the formation of the group included praise from Mr. Paulson.

Six a.m., Paris time, and my body still thought it was midnight. My first international flight felt a little surreal, with two hours of sleep peppered by vivid dreams induced by my anti-malraial medication. Riding in a bus with Nick over to our connecting flight, I looked out at the sun rising and couldn't believe any of it was true.

Roughly 200,000 New York City voters who had recently moved were given the wrong information about where they could vote in today's primary, according to officials at the Board of Elections.In a mailing sent to their new homes, these voters were told to go to their old polling places, which is technically not legal.

The Politicker reports sightings of Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the polling place where they both voted early this morning, less than an hour apart. Mr. Spitzer entered with a daughter on each arm and declined to say who won his vote for attorney general: "I'm sworn to secrecy. I had two daughters in there, and I'm not telling you which daughters."
Bree found. So beautiful.

With few Republicans expected to vote in today's primary elections, the two candidates for the party's United States Senate nomination -- K.T. McFarland and John Spencer -- were chasing the few, the scattered and the dedicated.

Dewey Ballantine, the New York law firm that is a top adviser to investment banks on mergers and acquisitions, is in talks with Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe of San Francisco about a possible merger. The American Lawyer reported Tuesday that the leaders of both firms confirmed the talks.
Sheriff -- er, make that Hewlett-Packard chairwoman -- Patricia C. Dunn finally got her man. She had to apologize and give up her title to make it happen.
Luella Bartley, Proenza Schouler, Phillip Lam and more.
Cloudlike clothes to upstage stars.
Time Inc. will formally put several magazine properties up for sale Tuesday, according to a report on AdAge.com.
So, at one Chelsea apartment, the robo-calls were coming in fast and furious.
Jack Bell sat down for an interview with Red Bulls Coach Bruce Arena, who returned to M.L.S. and New York after being let go as United States national team coach.

Following Monday's news that two groups of investment firms are vying to take Freescale Semiconductor private, which may result in the largest-ever leveraged buyout in the technology sector, Merrill Lynch analyst Joe Osha has published a report listing his top 10 candidates for leveraged buyouts in the chip industry.

Gold Kist, a chicken company that is being pursued by a larger competitor, the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation. said on Tuesday that it had hired Gleacher Partners to assist it with a review of its strategic plans.
The German truck maker MAN is seriously considering a bid for Sweden's Scania and may act in the next few days, a source told Reuters on Tuesday.

Turnout was relatively light to moderate in the heart of David Yassky territory in the Slope, with Bill De Blasio stationed for several hours outside P.S. 321 in Park Slope campaigning for Yvette Clark.

Nine states have primaries on Tuesday, and all eyes are on the Republican Senate primary in Rhode Island. The incumbent, Lincoln Chafee, long considered a moderate Republican who has defied his party time and again, has had a lot of national party backing in his race against the more conservative candidate, Steve Laffey, the Mayor of Cranston. The powerful Club for Growth has backed Mr. Laffey, and run a series of attack ads against Mr. Chafee.
The Times just dipped into the hottest race in Arizona over the weekend, the Eighth Congressional District where Republicans are vying to replace retiring Congressman Jim Kolbe.

The SenateTwo powerful figures are fighting for the Democrats' nod to run for retiring Senator Paul Sarbanes' seat. Congressman Ben Cardin is leading former N.A.A.C.P. President Kweise Mfume in most polls. Most observers consider Mr. Cardin the stronger candidate against Republican Lt. Gov. Michael Steele, who is expected to win the G.O.P. primary.
Three are running for the Republican Senate nomination against Democratic incumbent Thomas R. Carper: Christine O'Donnell, Michael Protack and Jan Ting.

First Congressional DistrictThe greatest primary challenge to the Republican incumbent, Gil Gutknecht, came not from his opponent, Greg Mikkelson, but from a Democratic lawsuit. Lawyers unsuccessfully argued that Mr. Gutknecht's petitions to qualify for the primary were invalid because some of the signatures were collected before the candidate filing period. Mr. Gutknecht's name is now likely to appear on the November ballot as well, against the Democrat Tim Walz.Fourth C.D.Republicans are worried that primary voters will choose a convicted felon, Jack Shephard (who lives in Italy and would face arrest for arson charges if he returned), instead of Obi Sium, an Eritrean-American, because of the latter's name. The winner on Tuesday will face (or maybe not?) the Democratic incumbent, Representative Betty McCollum.Fifth C.D. The race to replace the retiring Democrat Martin Sabo in Minnesota's Fifth District attracted national attention because one of the front-runners in the Democratic primary, Keith Ellison, would be the first Muslim elected to Congress. Other viable candidates include State Senator Ember Junge, the former state party chairman Mike Erlandson and Minneapolis City Council Member Paul Ostrow. Alan Fine is unopposed for the G.O.P. nomination.

First Congressional DistrictAfter an unsuccessful bid for president in 2004, Michael Callis, a stonemason, is setting his sights a little lower, challenging Representative Jeb Bradley for his seat in the Republican primary. Jim Craig, Gary Dodds, Dave Jarvis and Carol Shea-Porter are running for the Democratic nomination.Second C.D.A frequent pick-off target for Democrats, Representative Charles Bass of New Hampshire's Second, a Republican, is expected to easily defeat Mayor Bob Danderson of Berlin, who is working to appeal to anti-incumbent sentiments, and Mary Maxwell of Concord, who attracted attention for accusing the government of involvement in the 9/11 terror plot. A rematch the with Democratic nominee, Paul Hodes, is likely.

The Senate Believe it or not, Senator Hillary Clinton does face a primary challenger. His name is Jonathan Tasini, and his big-name endorsements include the historian Howard Zinn and Daniel Ellsberg (of Pentagon Papers fame). Former Mayor John Spencer of Yonkers and a former Reagan aide, Kathleen Troia McFarland, are locked in a bitter fight to face Clinton.
Bristol-Myers Squibb's chief executive, Peter Dolan, and the drugmaker's general counsel will resign after federal regulators called for their departures as part of a criminal investigation.

The SenateCongressman Bernard Sanders, an independent, is on the ballot in the Democratic Senate primary, but he has vowed to decline the nomination if he wins. Others running are Larry Drown, Craig Hill, Peter Moss and Louis Thabault. Republican contenders include Greg Parke, Richard Tarrant and Cris Ericson - who has called for impeachment proceedings against President Bush and legalization of marijuana.The House The national Republican Party is backing Martha Rainville, who has a military background, in the primary against State Senator Mark Shepard. The G.O.P. thinks Ms. Rainville has the best chance at the open seat against the Democrat Peter Welch as the independent At-Large representative, Bernard Sanders, runs for Senate. The Los Angeles Times scopes out whether the winner of Mr. Sanders' seat could help decide who controls the House.

First Congressional DistrictRepresentative Paul Ryan, a Republican, did not attract big-name challengers, but Don Hall, Mike Herbert, Steven Herr, Ruth Santa Cruz Bradley and Jeffrey Thomas are vying for the Democratic spot.
Some recent updates to the Election Guide for Sept. 12.

We've grown quite accustomed to the hand-shaking at the Eastern Market and the early-morning door-knocking. And we kind of liked the handouts of oranges by one candidate (guess which) while we were weeding our garden, as well as the new wristlet to add to our collection. Plus, we know we're going to miss Mayor Anthony Williams's ties.
The Sept. 11 memorial services, President Bush's speech and remembrances are well-covered on all fronts.
A bar-code scanning system maker, Metrologic Instruments, said on Tuesday that it agreed to be bought for about $420 million by its founder and other investors.

Patricia C. Dunn, the person at the center of Hewlett-Packard's widening controversy over an internal leak investigation, will resign as the company's chairman in January, Hewlett-Packard said Tuesday.

FTI Consulting, a Baltimore-based adviser in litigation and corporate restructurings, has jumped into the public relations business with Monday's $260 milion acquisition of FD International of London. The deal for FD, known as Financial Dynamics, represents the highest price ever paid for a financial public-relations company, according to The Financial Times, which said it demonstrates the "increasing value that corporate clients place on issues such as reputation management."

In a package cheekily titled "Time For Us To Go," Washington Monthly recruits a handful of Republicans who wish electoral doom for their own party this fall, and perhaps beyond. Christopher Buckley confesses that he wants a Democratic Congress and a Democratic president:

Dubai Ports World will start a second round of bidding on Tuesday for its port assets in the United States, with Morgan Stanley, the Carlyle Group and SSA Marine among the finalists in the highly politicized sale, The Financial Times reported.
Ushering in a week of earnings results from the major securities firms, the Goldman Sachs Group said Tuesday that third-quarter profits slipped 1 percent from a year ago.

Citigroup said on Tuesday it is shedding its Citigroup Venture Capital buyout unit amid renewed activity among banks in the buyout sector and, according to The Financial News, to avoid conflicts with clients and its own new private equity fund.

A consortium of investors led by Grupo Televisa, Mexico's largest media company, is considering a plan to make a $13 billion bid for Univision Communications after losing an auction for the company this summer, The New York Times reported.

He may be 75 years old, but Rupert Murdoch, head of the media giant News Corporation, is hardly stodgy about the world of digital media. Consider Tuesday's announcement that the company will pay $188 million for a controlling stake in Jamba, a maker of content for mobile phones whose cackling "Crazy Frog" ringtone was one of the industry's biggest hits.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International disclosed Monday that federal regulators had begun an inquiry into stock trades that were made this spring when the company released results of a drug trial.

Tyco's former tax chief surrendered to federal authorities on Monday on charges he falsified the manufacturing conglomerate's 1999 tax return to evade more than $50 million in taxes, federal investigators said.

The European Commission is widening an antitrust review of Intel to investigate whether the company pressured an electronics retailer to exclude chips made by Advanced Micro Devices, a spokesman for the European Union said Monday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected a request for documents from a dismissed agency lawyer on Friday and denied that political considerations had played a role in an insider trading investigation.
After laying dormant for two years, the Justice Department's criminal probe into accounting transgressions at Freddie Mac is apparently over, according to company officials.
Richard A. Grasso, the former New York Stock Exchange chief, would like a new judge for his trial in the civil case filed against him by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer.
A group of Cyberonics shareholders led by Metropolitan Capital Advisors, which disclosed a 7.3 percent stake in the company, says it will press for the election of three board nominees.
The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline Holdings has agreed to pay the Internal Revenue Service $3.4 billion to settle claims that it underpaid federal taxes since 1989 by in effect shifting profits abroad.

A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to press reports.

As its directors continued to confer on the future of its chairwoman, Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks in the board.
H.I.G. Capital allowed only returning investors into its latest buyout fund to keep its focus solidly on the mid-market.
Vestar Capital has agreed to buy a health care marketing and medical publishing company, MediMedia USA, from the Carlyle Group, Cinven and Apax Partners.

As two private equity groups engage in a $16 billion duel over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, the amount of debt that the winner may need for the deal is generating alarm.

Linux Networx announced a $37 million Series D round of venture funding from new investors Lehman Brothers and Canaccord Adams, and existing backers Oak Investment Partners and Tudor Ventures, to expand its work force and advance its software for supercomputing systems.

So far, 2006 is shaping up as an active year for early-stage companies to receive venture capital funding. According to the MoneyTree Report, a quarterly study put out by PricewaterhouseCoopers and the National Venture Capital Association, 74 startup and seed companies raised money from venture investors during the second quarter of this year, up from 54 last year.

A venture capital fund based in Century City, Calif., backed by the likes of Harvard, Boeing and other big-league investors, and consulting with such disparate advisers as the Columbia University business school dean and KISS singer Gene Simmons, has run into trouble over allegations that its founders solicited political contributions form their start-ups.
The British business travel services group Hogg Robinson will rejoin the stock market as a 400 million pound ($749 million) company next month.
Three tech companies, DivX, Riverbed Technology and CommVault Systems, will attempt to go public next week, hoping for standout performances in a choppy year for newly issues technology shares.
Analysts issued bullish comments Monday on First Data as the transaction-processing giant moved ahead with plans to spin off its Western Union money-transfer business.
Climate Change Capital, the London-based boutique "green" investment bank, has raised nearly $1 billion to start trading in carbon dioxide emissions.

One sell-side executive says that a rebound in Nasdaq could create a wave of I.P.O. filings from small financial services companies that are focused on tech companies, but the leaders of many of those boutiques say they are some time away from making that jump.
Garda World Security has acquired two cash-handling companies in the Midwest and is in advanced negotiations for a third.

Banc of America Securities agreed on Monday to sell a small part of its prime brokerage business that offers outsourced trading to hedge funds to Baypoint Trading, a San Francisco-based specialist in the field.
Intel has sold a business that manufactures optical network components to Cortina Systems for $115 million in cash and stock, the companies announced Monday.

Rupert Murdoch and Crazy Frog, a popular ringtone, may seem like unlikely partners, but the News Corporation was set to announce on Tuesday that it would buy a majority stake in Jamba, the maker of the ringtone, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Canada's Crescent Point Energy Trust is paying about $700 million for Mission Oil & Gas, doling out top dollar for a junior explorer with a major position in the potentially rich Bakken oil field in Saskatchewan.

Stock in Stanley Leisure, the biggest casino operator in Britain, rose as high as 879 pence on Tuesday, topping the 860 pence bid in a takeover attempt by Genting, a conglomerate based in Malaysia, and setting off speculation that a counterbid might emerge.

Barr Pharmaceuticals' latest bid for the Croatian drug maker Pliva was not as aggressive as some analysts had expected, given the fierce competition between Barr and its rival bidder, the Actavis Group, to become the world's third-biggest maker of generic drugs.

Is the Russian government looking to partner up with Airbus parent EADS? That was the question on the mind of market watchers Tuesday after the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the French-German military contractor, confirmed that a bank owned by the Russian government had acquired more than 5 percent of the company.

Telecom Italia, in a reversal of a recent and expensive consolidation, announced plans on Monday to spin off its fixed-line and mobile phone businesses into two companies. The chairman, Marco Tronchetti Provera, also said he would consider offers to buy the mobile phone business, Telecom Italia Mobile, which is estimated to be worth $53 billion.

Thomas E. Mann and Norman Ornstein have worked in and around Congress for more than 36 years, beginning their careers in 1969 as Congressional fellows. They later moved to think tanks and academia, where they continued to study and write about the workings of Congress, the first branch of government.
The historian and publisher Joachim Fest, who was seen as one of Germany’s leading authorities on Nazism, died at 79.
Tour a handful of exclusive properties in Dublin, where housing prices are among the world's most costly.

A California psychiatrist is searching for a drug to treat stuttering, organizing clinical trials and even testing treatments on himself. His efforts are just part of a transformation in the medical view of stuttering -- from what was once widely considered a nervous or emotional condition to a neurological one that is at least partly genetic.
When a self-help book author, played by Anne Heche, is jilted while on a book tour in Alaska, she says goodbye to champagne and tulle and hello to blubber and bear traps in “Men in Trees” on ABC.
Voters and the candidates cast ballots in Tuesday’s primary.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
A sampling of opinion on Tony Kornheiser's regular-season debut as an analyst on the new "Monday Night Football" on ESPN:
I can think of plenty of good reasons to play fantasy football.1) To keep in touch with old friends2) To bring people together at work3) To avoid household chores and pressing family obligations
Jehad Nga photographed churches chiseled from stone, with replicas of the Ark of the Covenant and very real skeletons in Ethiopia.
Mariano Rivera, who has not pitched this month because of tightness near his right elbow, will wait until Wednesday to play catch.

New York Democrats chose Eliot Spitzer in the governor's race, Andrew M. Cuomo for attorney general and Yvette D. Clarke in Brooklyn’s 11th Congressional District. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was renominated. In Rhode Island, Senator Lincoln Chafee held off a conservative challenger.
After months of intrigue, the identities of Web video star lonelygirl15 and her producers are revealed.
The program will try to replicate the success of a Rockefeller program that increased the production of grains like wheat, corn and rice in Latin America and Southeast Asia.
Similar painkilling drugs, including Celebrex, do not share the same risks, two new studies say.
The stations are all profitable, the company said, but it wants to focus on its newspapers and digital properties.
It will be the first time that high-income beneficiaries will have higher premiums for Medicare coverage.
A device due out next year will wirelessly stream video and music from a Macintosh computer to a television.
In his first state visit to Iran, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki today asked for support in quelling violence.
President Bush’s spokesman rejected Democrats’ charge that last night’s speech sought to capitalize on the attacks.
Michael Dell said today that he deserved a share of the blame for recent problems at Dell Computer and reaffirmed his support for his chief executive, Kevin Rollins.
The court order could help improve the climate for talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians.
The board bowed to a federal monitor’s pressure after a mishandled attempt to solve a patent dispute.
A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Tuesday.
Patricia C. Dunn came under scrutiny because of her role in ordering an investigation of news leaks from the board.
Islamic militants attempted to storm the embassy in a brazen attack using automatic rifles, hand grenades and at least one van rigged with explosives.
They hooked up the newest part of the International Space Station: a 35,000-pound truss with a solar array.
Burundi and the rebel National Liberation Force signed a cease-fire deal solidifying the end of a 12-year civil war.
The first group of Ugandan rebels have turned up at a neutral camp in southern Sudan as part of a truce to end 19 years of conflict with the government, the chief mediator said Monday.
The Yankees erupted for six runs in the seventh inning against Jim Hoey, beating the Orioles and sparing a loss for Randy Johnson.
The overhauled Vikings, who added a new coach and a new, if aging, quarterback in the offseason, took a giant leap forward by upsetting the Redskins.
A 21-year veteran of the city’s Sanitation Department died yesterday morning after suffering a heart attack while at work in Brooklyn, officials said.
The Marlins pounded the soon-to-be division champion Mets into submission, notching the most hits against them this season.
People live longer in Bergen County, N.J. — an average of about 80 years — than in any other county in the northeastern United States, according to a Harvard study.
Asafa Powell of Jamaica, the world-record holder in the men’s 100 meters, has pulled out of next weekend’s 100 at the World Cup in Athens, his manager, Paul Doyle, said yesterday.

J. J. Redick pleaded guilty yesterday in Durham, N.C., to drunken-driving charges and received one year of probation. Redick, a former Duke star and the first-round draft pick of the Orlando Magic, also had his license suspended for 60 days, was ordered to pay $410 in fees and court costs, and must perform 24 hours of community service, according to the district attorney’s office.
cycling.

Frantisek Kaberle, who scored the Stanley Cup-winning goal for the Carolina Hurricanes last season, had shoulder surgery yesterday and could miss four to six months. Jim Rutherford, the Hurricanes’ general manager, said he did not know which shoulder was injured.

Philadelphia re-signed the free-agent forward Simon Gagné to a five-year contract last night, ending a summer of difficult negotiations. The 26-year-old Gagné, a former first-round pick, is coming off the best season of his career, scoring 47 goals and collecting 79 points.

The lawyer for the Tour de France winner Floyd Landis submitted a petition to the United States Anti-Doping Agency yesterday to dismiss Landis’s case, disputing the accuracy of the scientific testing done at the lab in France.

Nashville announced yesterday that it had signed goalie Tomas Vokoun to a four-year extension and given him the franchise’s richest contract at $22.8 million. Without Vokoun, who was out because of blood clots, the Predators lost in the opening round of the playoffs last spring.

The Charlotte Bobcats signed the Argentine forward Walter Herrmann yesterday. The 6-foot-9 Herrmann, 27, averaged 9.8 points and shot 47 percent from 3-point range for Argentina in the recent world championship.

Marion Jones has been included on the United States team for this weekend’s I.A.A.F. World Cup in Athens. Jones has not confirmed her participation, USA Track & Field said in a statement yesterday, but her manager, Charles Wells, said she planned to compete in the 100 meters. Jones was cleared of doping last week after her B sample tested negative for the banned blood-boosting drug EPO.

The Olympic bronze medalist Toby Dawson announced his retirement from moguls skiing yesterday to work on his golf game and continue a low-key effort to find his birth parents in South Korea. Born in South Korea, Dawson was adopted by two ski instructors in Vail, Colo.

Clemson received permission yesterday from the N.C.A.A. to provide assistance like local transportation and child care to a freshman football player who is taking care of his younger brother. Ray Ray McElrathbey, 19, has temporary custody of his 11-year-old brother, Fahmarr, because of his mother’s drug problems and his father’s gambling addiction.
Gold Fields said that it would acquire a 50 percent stake in the South Africa’s South Deep mine from Barrick Gold of Toronto in a deal worth more than $1.5 billion.
The European Commission widened its investigation to determine if Intel pressured an electronics retailer to exclude chips made by Advanced Micro Devices.

Two Cuban exiles who have vehemently opposed Fidel Castro will avoid a trial on weapons charges after each pleaded guilty to a single criminal conspiracy charge. The men, Santiago Alvarez, 65, and Osvaldo Mitat, 64, were scheduled for trial this week and would have faced up to 20 years in prison if convicted. But prosecutors reduced the charges in a last-minute plea deal, and the men now face a maximum sentence of five years. The men were arrested last year after the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized machine guns, a grenade launcher and thousands of rounds of ammunition. They are scheduled for sentencing Nov. 14.

Police officers swarmed a high school campus in Arlington after a 911 call about armed teenagers who turned out to be students working on an art project. The school was locked down for about 30 minutes while the police sorted it out. The students were photographing themselves re-enacting scenes from the Vietnam War, but a driver who spotted their mock rifles called the police.

A diver shot a large grouper with a spear gun on Saturday, but then drowned, apparently when the fish sped into a hole, entangling him in the line attached to the spear, investigators said. The 42-year-old man, whose name was withheld, was free-diving in about 25 feet of water off the lower Florida Keys. “It looks like the fish wrapped the line attached to the spear around the victim’s wrist,” said Detective Mark Coleman of the Monroe County Sheriff’s Department. “The fish then went into a hole in a coral rock, effectively pinning the man to the bottom of the ocean.”.

A federal judge refused to block a law that requires state voters to present identification before casting a ballot. The ruling, by Judge Roslyn Silver of Federal District Court, came a day before today’s state primary, the first statewide election for which voters will be required to show identification. The 2004 law requires that voters at polling places produce government-issued picture identification or two pieces of other nonphoto identification specified by the law. It also requires proof of citizenship when registering to vote. Parts of the law were aimed chiefly at illegal immigrants. Critics said that the law would disenfranchise voters, particularly members of minority groups and older people.

As Linda Schrenko, the former state schools superintendent, began serving an eight-year federal prison sentence, her top aide, Merle Temple, was handed the same sentence for helping her in an embezzlement plot. Ms. Schrenko reported to prison to begin serving a sentence for embezzling about $600,000 in federal education money to finance a failed 2002 campaign for governor and a face lift. Mr. Temple, Ms. Schrenko’s former campaign manager and former lover, was sentenced by Judge Clarence Cooper of Federal District Court.

The Miami-Dade Public Defender’s Office filed motions in juvenile court seeking to stop the practice of shackling detained juveniles with handcuffs and leg irons in court. Juveniles in the state appear in court wearing shackles and handcuffs regardless of the alleged offense, said Carlos Martinez, Miami-Dade’s chief assistant public defender. “By allowing children to appear before them in chains, judges are conveying a message to the children that they are dangerous animals,” Mr. Martinez said.

Thousands of striking Detroit teachers defied a judge’s order to return to work as school officials and the union resumed contract talks in the two-week dispute. Judge Susan Borman on Friday ordered the 7,000 teachers to go back to work, but a district spokesman, Lekan Oguntoyinbo, said the overwhelming majority remained off the job. Janna Garrison, president of the Detroit Federation of Teachers, said individual teachers were free to decide whether to work or strike.

Tropical Storm Gordon formed in the open Atlantic and was expected to head in the general direction of Bermuda, forecasters said. It was centered about 425 miles northeast of the Leeward Islands, forecasters said.

Japanese wholesale prices rose 3.4 percent in August from a year earlier, matching July’s rise, which was the fastest pace of growth in more than 25 years, and signaling that inflationary pressure is gradually building on high oil prices. But the data is unlikely to heighten expectations of an early interest rate increase by the Bank of Japan because consumer price growth remains subdued, with companies still reluctant to fully pass on rising raw material costs to consumers. The 3.4 percent rise in the corporate goods price index matched economists’ consensus forecast as well as the year-to-year rise in July, which was the largest since March 1981, the Bank of Japan said.

Deutsche Lufthansa said it would pay $85 million to settle 80 class-action lawsuits in the United States in a price-fixing inquiry involving its air cargo unit. The payment would release the airline and Swiss International Air Lines, which it is taking over, from pending lawsuits in the United States, Lufthansa said. The settlement is subject to court approval. Lufthansa Cargo is among nine airlines accused of violating antitrust laws by fixing prices in the $50 billion global air cargo market. European Union and United States authorities requested information from at least 12 carriers in February; the inquiry focused on surcharges for fuel and security risks.

A Canadian steel maker, Ipsco, said it was buying the NS Group, a maker of steel pipes and tubes used in oil fields, for about $1.46 billion. The deal will be used to broaden Ipsco’s sales to the energy industry, the chief executive, David Sutherland, said. “This is a transaction that’s all about growth, and if anything, what we will see over the next three years is a growth in the output of all of their facilities, as well as the continuing demand on our own,” Mr. Sutherland said in a conference call. Ipsco agreed to pay $66 a share for the NS Group, which was a 43 percent premium to its closing price on Friday. After the transaction is complete, the new company is expected to have combined annual revenue of more than $4 billion. Ipsco, which is based in Regina, Saskatchewan, and has executive offices in Leslie, Ill., operates three steel mills and six pipe mills in the United States and Canada. The NS Group is based in Newport, Ky.

Barr Pharmaceuticals raised its bid for Pliva, a maker of generic drugs, to $2.5 billion, topping a rival bid from an Icelandic rival, the Actavis Group. Barr bid 820 kuna ($141.21) a share for Pliva, more than the competing bid of 795 kuna a share from Actavis. The companies said Pliva, which is based in Zagreb, Croatia, would give them the ability to compete with the generic-drug industry leaders. Barr, which is based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said the acquisition of Pliva would create a company with $2.5 billion in annual revenue and about 170 generic products in development. It would also have about 60 applications at the Food and Drug Administration, Barr said. Actavis is based in Hafnarfirdi, Iceland.

ITHACA, N.Y. — On a recent Sunday evening, the veteran folk musician Rod MacDonald was singing, “Terror,” a scathing commentary about the Bush administration’s post-9/11 policies. “You want the power to say who lives and dies,” he crooned. “The power to say what’s true and what’s lies.”.

The United States Trade Representative Susan Schwab will sign a deal in Ottawa today that is intended to end a long-running dispute over Canadian lumber exports, the trade representative’s office said. Ms. Schwab and David Emerson, Canada’s minister for international trade, are scheduled to give final approval to the softwood lumber agreement, which would halt years of litigation over Canada’s claims that the United States unfairly slapped duties on lumber Canada. In July, American and Canadian officials gave initial approval to a pact that requires the United States to pay back about $4.3 billion in duties on wood imports, or about 80 percent of the total duties it collected during the dispute.

Iliad, a French telecommunications company, said it planned to build a fiber optic communications network throughout Paris for 1 billion euros. Iliad said development of the network would begin next year and would take five years to complete. Building and owning its own fiber optics network would allow the company to save on renting telephone lines from France Télécom, Iliad said. It would lease any excess capacity on the network to competitors. “Demand for bandwidth is showing no sign of abating,’’ Iliad’s chief executive, Michael Boukobza, said at a news conference. But investors were concerned about the cost, and stock in Iliad, which is based in Paris, fell nearly 12 percent.
President Bush’s language reflected his concern that the country no longer viewed itself as at war. But his new approach has its own risks.
The announcement signified the conclusion of a civil rights case that sought to erase vestiges of segregation that lingered long after Brown v. Board of Education.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,661 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:.
Officials argued that the programs put low-income and minority applicants at a distinct disadvantage.
Anbar Province will continue to deteriorate without reinforcements, according to the report.
The trial of Saddam Hussein on charges of genocide against Iraq’s Kurds resumed Monday, after a nearly three-week hiatus.
As loved ones recited the names of the dead at ground zero, a wounded but resilient America paused to remember a calamitous day.
The day of ceremony and remembrance was bracketed by fresh scenes of violence in Iraq and Afghanistan and renewed jitters at home.
From out of nowhere, the Pirates’ Freddy Sanchez could become the most unheralded National League batting champion since Ralph Garr in 1974.
President Bush sought to place the war in Iraq in the context of an epic battle between tyranny and freedom.
Carnegie Hall played host to a communal sing arranged by the Juilliard School to commemorate the fifth anniversary of the terror attacks.
It was an Open that was more about the past than the present, with Andre Agassi and Martina Navratilova drawing the curtain.
The decision reaffirmed a contempt charge against the journalist who was sent to prison for refusing to cooperate with an investigation into a protest.
A group of companies led by Chevron could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government.
Lottery Numbers.
CBS is heading into the fall season as the most watched network in prime time, but in the treacherous world of broadcast TV, there is little certainty.
Hurricane Florence blew out windows, peeled away several roofs and knocked out power to thousands in Bermuda.
Two brothers from the Dominican Republic know exactly how Brooklyn customers like to order their pizza.
Thousands of workers were determined not to dwell on the horrible history of the day as they marched through Lower Manhattan, wishing for a routine day at the office.
Genentech said that approval of its colon cancer drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer would be delayed by at least a year.
Hewlett-Packard came under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks.
The Braves are five and a half games behind N.L. wild-card leader San Diego, with five other teams also ahead of them.
Stanford University Medical Center’s new policy is intended to limit industry influence on patient care and doctor education.
The candidates in New Jersey’s race for a United States Senate seat have been running away from divisive members of their own parties — and their own political pasts.
A tentative agreement between the Fatah faction and Hamas is an attempt to regain Western aid donations.
The former teammates of Lance Armstrong said they used a banned drug in preparing for the 1999 Tour de France.
After struggling offensively in their season opener, the Seahawks on Monday acquired wide receiver Deion Branch from the New England Patriots.
Two private equity groups are dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor for more than $16 billion, people involved said.

If a strategy to end the violence in Iraq exists, it seems unlikely that President Bush could see it through the filter of his fantasies.
Thousands of police officers from across New York and the country honored State Trooper Joseph A. Longobardo, while a case was built against his suspected killer.

Political allies of President Jacques Chirac went on trial, charged with vote-rigging in Paris 17 years ago while Mr. Chirac was the city’s mayor. Jacques Dominati, one of 15 people being tried, is accused of having drawn up a list of 300 phantom voters to help ensure his re-election as mayor of the city’s Third Arrondissement. Mr. Chirac’s conservative party swept to victory in the elections. As president, Mr. Chirac is shielded from charges.

A Jewish settler who is believed to have hoped to halt Israel’s withdrawal from the Gaza Strip last year was convicted in Jerusalem for the August 2005 shooting deaths of four Palestinians in the West Bank. The man, Asher Weissgan, 41, killed the Palestinians the day Israel began evacuating settlers from Gaza.

A Russian military helicopter carrying senior officers on an inspection tour in Chechnya crashed in southern Russia, in North Ossetia, killing most of the 14 or 15 people on board, news agencies reported. There were conflicting reports of four or five survivors. The cause was also not clear, but a state-run television channel said the helicopter had been flying in fog and might have hit a tree.

The government has approved paromomycin to treat visceral leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease that kills an estimated 500,000 people a year, 90 percent of them in India, Nepal, Bangladesh, Brazil and Sudan. The approval is the first for the Institute for OneWorld Health, a San Francisco charity focusing on treatments for neglected diseases. The $10, 21-day treatment provides lifelong protection against the disease, known in India as kala azar, or black fever.

A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The colonel, Juan Antonio Rodríguez Buratti, was one of nine military and police officers accused of kidnapping and then killing María Claudia García in 1976. Ms. García was the daughter-in-law of the Argentine poet Juan Gelman, who has campaigned so doggedly for justice on her behalf that the case has become an issue in relations between Argentina and Uruguay.

A man was charged with receiving terrorism training this spring in southeast England and another was charged with financing terrorism. The men, Yassin Mutegombwa, 22, and Hassan Mutegombwa, 20, were among 14 people seized in raids on Sept. 1. Yassin Mutegombwa is accused of receiving weapons training near a trailer park in Hampshire and near a farm in Berkshire. Hassan Mutegombwa, 20, is charged with procuring funds for terrorism.

Japan launched its third intelligence-gathering satellite, increasing its ability to spy on its neighbors. Even with a fourth satellite planned in a few months, it is expected to remain largely dependent on the United States for information.

A man cleared of killing his former girlfriend 15 years ago pleaded guilty in London to her murder in the first case to go to court since the 800-year-old double jeopardy law was relaxed. The man, Billy Dunlop, was formally cleared in 1991 after two juries deadlocked. He later confessed. Last year the law was changed in murder cases in which compelling new evidence has surfaced.

South Ossetia, in northern Georgia, said it would hold a referendum Nov. 12 on independence, the latest act of defiance against President Mikheil Saakashvili’s government, which has pledged to bring the region back under federal control.

A press monitoring agency said it had issued 70 warnings to a popular newspaper that has a circulation of 100,000.

Facebook, the popular social networking Web site that has mainly focused on college students, is preparing to open its membership to everyone.

The secretary of state said the United States might suspend efforts to impose sanctions if Iran suspended uranium enrichment.
A parade of global companies have been unfurling plans in recent days to assemble cars in India for domestic sale and export.
David Cameron sought Monday to distance his party from what he called a “slavish” bond between Britain and the United States.
Dell said that it would delay filing second-quarter financial reports while it cooperates with a widening investigation into its accounting practices.

The move brought intense speculation that the Russian government may seek to leverage the investment into a strategic partnership with the company.

A 26-year-old man was fatally shot last evening just south of Prospect Park, the police said. The man, who neighbors said grew up in the neighborhood, but whom the police did not identify, was found in front of 95 Woodruff Avenue shortly before 6:30 with three bullet wounds in his torso, the police said. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The police said they were questioning a 27-year-old man The police found a .357 Magnum at the scene.

Day laborers who have accused a suburban village of harassing them on the streets as they looked for work dropped all claims of First Amendment violations yesterday rather than reveal their immigration status. The decision, just before the start of a trial in Federal District Court, means that the plaintiffs will no longer argue that the village of Mamaroneck, 23 miles north of New York City, was attacking their rights to free speech and free association. The case now rests on the workers’ 14th Amendment claim that they were discriminated against because they are Hispanic.

Anthony Ricci, the son of a former Gambino crime family captain, testified yesterday that he did not feel threatened when he visited John A. Gotti in prison in 2003 and that he had never knowingly passed any message from Mr. Gotti. In addition to facing racketeering charges at his trial in Federal District Court, Mr. Gotti is charged with witness tampering. Prosecutors say he tried to use Mr. Ricci, the son of the former captain, Michael DiLeonardo, to stop Mr. DiLeonardo from testifying against Mr. Gotti. Mr. Ricci, now 20, said he visited Mr. Gotti in prison in February 2003 because he considered him part of the family. But Mr. Ricci did acknowledge that he had written two letters to his father after the visit, in which he tried to persuade him not to cooperate with prosecutors. Mr. DiLeonardo, who gave potentially damaging testimony against Mr. Gotti earlier in the trial, said he interpreted his son’s visit to Mr. Gotti in an upstate New York prison as a signal to himself that Mr. Gotti had influence over his son.

Rebuffing an effort from the Department of Justice, New Jersey’s acting attorney general, Anne Milgram, is defending the state’s effort to subpoena five telephone companies to determine whether any violated the state’s consumer protection laws by providing records to the National Security Agency. The state was the first, experts said, to question the agency’s program to compile calling records to monitor terrorist activities, but the Justice Department filed a lawsuit in June to block that effort. On Friday, New Jersey demanded that a federal judge dismiss the Justice Department’s lawsuit because it would throw “an impenetrable cloak insulating the federal government’s domestic surveillance activities from all judicial scrutiny,” according to Ms. Milgram. In other parts of the country, the courts have issued mixed rulings, with one judge in Detroit last month ordering an end to the program because it violated free speech and privacy rights.

Six days after one of its buses rolled over on its way to Boston, injuring 34 people, a Chinatown company reached an agreement with Massachusetts state inspectors yesterday that keeps its fleet on the road. The owners of the company, Fung Wah Bus Transportation, were ordered to appear before Massachusetts regulators after the bus tipped over in Auburn, Mass., last Tuesday. The driver was cited for speeding. Under the agreement, Fung Wah buses will be subject to scheduled and unscheduled inspections and driver checks over the next 30 days. The company has also agreed to improve safety, including ceasing to use buses that have not been maintained in a safe and sanitary condition.

A former state public works official was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to two years of probation for lying to federal investigators during their inquiry into corruption in the administration of former Gov. John G. Rowland. The official, Richard F. Piotrowski, 61, of Plainville, was sentenced for making false statements in connection with the investigation. Mr. Piotrowski, a former bureau chief in the Department of Public Works, was also ordered to perform 150 hours of community service.

A New Haven alderwoman pleaded guilty yesterday to embezzling $49,000 in federal money that was supposed to help residents of public housing. The alderwoman, Barbara Rawls-Ivy, 43, said she had not decided whether to resign. Ms. Rawls-Ivy was the executive director of the Alliance for Strong Communities, a nonprofit group created by the New Haven Housing Authority to provide social services to public housing residents, from 2000 to 2003. She admitted that from May 2001 until April 2003 she embezzled grants from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development that were supposed to reduce drug activity. Ms. Rawls-Ivy faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000 at sentencing, set for Dec. 4.
Government lawyers said Monday that American courts had no authority to stop the military from transferring an American citizen to an Iraqi court.
The shuttle Atlantis slid into place Monday morning at the International Space Station, clearing the way for construction of the station to begin again.
One day after his coalition swept to power, Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic said Monday that he might soon step down.
