A front-page article on Thursday about an announcement by President Bush that 14 high-profile terror suspects had been transferred from secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency to the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, incompletely described the interrogation technique of waterboarding, which intelligence officials say was used on one suspect. The technique involves strapping a prisoner to a board with his feet elevated above his head and placing a wet cloth down his throat or over his nose and mouth to create the sensation of drowning.

Charles Aug was a retired real estate executive who helped create a specialty in the commercial brokerage business — marketing storefront space.

MORE BUSINESS TRAVEL About 35 percent of respondents to the twice-yearly Accenture travel survey said they expected to make more business trips in the next six months than in the previous six months. More than 50 percent said they expected to make about the same number of trips, while about 8 percent said “slightly less,” 5 percent said “much less” and the remainder weren’t sure. The survey found that convenient schedules were the top priority for most business travelers (57 percent) in choosing an airline, but 35 percent cited frequent-flier program benefits as the top priority. Accenture, a global management and consulting firm, said there had been what it called a sustained shift toward more use of major carriers and away from discount carriers since 2004, and a similar shift away from budget hotels to midpriced chain hotels.
For most, the new security regulations have been merely annoying. For flight attendants, it’s been just one more brick on the load.
Canada’s second-largest telecommunications company said it would abandon its current stock ownership in favor of an income trust.
No one knows the varieties of limbo being wandered these days by rogue priests the Catholic Church had to drop from service once its pedophilia scandal fully surfaced.
Many designers at the spring 2007 shows seem to favor voluminous clothes and dresses shaped either like tents or sacks.
ABC aired an inaccurate tale of how the 9/11 ringleader Mohammed Atta bought his ticket in its dramatic mini-series “The Path to 9/11,” even after complaints surfaced.

LONG BEACH, Calif. — Ken Koroll, a 32-year-old compliance officer for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, stutters so badly that he often writes his questions to the companies he inspects rather than speaking them. But Mr. Koroll, who lives in Peoria, Ill., said he had come to terms with his inability to speak fluently.

Green companies, because of a desire to do well financially and do good for the environment, must operate under constraints that less idealistic enterprises can ignore.
The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 — Thomas J. Perkins, the former director who set off a firestorm in Hewlett-Packard’s boardroom, has had the upper hand so far in his public-relations battle with the chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn. But his e-mail forwarding button may have cost him points.

RAMEY--Dr. Estelle R., age 89. Retired professor of Physiology and Biophysics at Georgetown University Medical School died at her home in Bethesda, MD on September 8th, 2006. She is survived by her beloved husband of 66 years, James T. Ramey, former commissioner of the Atomic Energy Commission during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations; her children James N. Ramey M.D. (Margaret E.) of Bethesda and Drucilla Stender Ramey (Marvin Stender) of New York City; her grandchildren James T. Ramey (Daniela Michel), Sarah M. Ramey, Jessica S.R. Stender, Margaret M. Ramey, and Caitlin E. Vaughn; her brother Jack Rubin. Interment. Private. A memorial service will be held at Georgetown University in the near future. Memorial contributions may be made to The Association for Women in Science, 1200 New York Avenue N.W., Suite 650, Washington, D.C. 20005 or to Sanctuary For Families, P.O. Box 1406, Wall Street Station, NY, NY 10268. Please view and sign the family guest book online at pumphreyfuneralhome.com

Interns working the arduous shifts common in their training are more likely to stick themselves accidentally with needles and other medical equipment, new research has found. Researchers had already established that the exhaustion that comes with being on call for 24 hours or more leads to problems away from the hospital, like car accidents. But this study suggests that doctors may also be in some danger at work, since needle sticks can expose medical workers to H.I.V. and hepatitis.

With the American League East title all but assured, the Yankees are in no hurry to get Mariano Rivera back on the mound. The trainer Gene Monahan told Rivera, who has not pitched this month because of tightness near his right elbow, to wait until Wednesday to play catch. Rivera played catch Sunday, when he intensified his throwing. Though Rivera said he felt improvement, Monahan decided to back up his next session, which had been scheduled for Tuesday. Rivera said he might throw off a mound this weekend. ''He's just being cautious,'' Rivera said. ''The good thing is I'm feeling better every day.''

To the Editor: On this fifth anniversary of 9/11, I wanted to let the city of New York as well as everybody else affected know that you are in our thoughts and prayers. All across this great land we have not forgotten, nor will we ever forget. To this day the memories still bring tears to my eyes and great pain to my heart knowing that we will never be the same again. I only hope that from all of this pain we have become a stronger country and that we can still reach out a helping hand to one another.

A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Aug. 30 about the number of female law clerks hired by Supreme Court justices misstated the percentage of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's clerks since 2000 who have been female, and a correction in this space yesterday misstated the year of her retirement in some copies. From the 2000 term until Justice O'Connor's retirement, 52 percent of her clerks were female, not 46 percent. She retired in January 2006, not 2005.

Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain dodged raucous demonstrators and endured a series of diplomatic snubs on his first official visit to this country, offering help for the Lebanese Army and vowing to renew efforts to bring peace to the Middle East. His message was largely lost on a population angry at his failure to demand an earlier end to the fighting, which had killed nearly 1,200 Lebanese, an overwhelming majority of them civilians.

SMIT--Jacobus Wilhelmus (Wim) at his home in the Netherlands on July 19th at the age of 75. Adored husband of the late Pamela Richards Smit, beloved father of Tyn, Michiel, Guy and Marijke, and brother of Johan Smit. Wim was born on August 25th, 1930 in Utrecht, the Netherlands. He joined the faculty of the University of Utrecht after receiving his doctorate in history there in 1958. In 1965, Wim joined the Columbia University faculty as the Queen Wilhelmina Professor of the History of the Low Countries. He was a widely recognized authority in the social, religious, cultural, and economic history of early modern Europe. While he wrote prolifically in his earlier career, Wim became most renowned for his dedication to teaching and was a friend and mentor to countless students, particularly through teaching all four of Columbia's Core Curriculum courses. In 1984, the Columbia College Student Council presented Smit with the Mark Van Doren Award for Great Teaching, and in 2003, he was a co-recipient of the first award for Distinguished Service to the Core Curriculum. Smit was a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, served on the Governing Board of Columbia's Society of Fellows in the Humanities and was consulting editor for the Records of Civilization series published by Columbia University Press. Wim was also an avid piano player and lover of music, as well as a prolific cook, cyclist, and, in his earlier years, semi-professional soccer player. Smit most relished his role as husband, father, and mentor. His legacy lives on in the hearts and minds of the thousands of students, colleagues, and friends who had the honor to know him and learn from him, over the years. A memorial service for him will be held on campus at St. Paul's Chapel at 5pm on Monday, September 18, 2006.

BRICKMAN - Roslyn. Zahava and Moshael J. Straus (YU and RIETS Trustee) are YU Benefactors who named The Joseph and Gwendolyn Straus Chair in Talmud at the Mazer School of Talmudic Studies, The Joseph and Gwendolyn Straus Chair in Jewish Education at the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration of which Board he is Chair, and have also supported scholarships at YU's Cardozo School of Law and our undergraduate schools. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

Pregnant women who do not get enough vitamin E may give birth to children who are at higher risk of developing asthma, a new study finds. Other studies have offered mixed results about whether taking the vitamin may help people with breathing problems. The authors of the new report say it appears there may be an early window when taking it makes the most difference.

He said that after three consecutive years of budget surpluses, the administration had built up a $3 trillion debt -- not deficit.

A Jewish settler who is believed to have hoped to halt Israel's withdrawal from the Gaza Strip last year was convicted in Jerusalem for the August 2005 shooting deaths of four Palestinians in the West Bank. The man, Asher Weissgan, 41, killed the Palestinians the day Israel began evacuating settlers from Gaza. GREG MYRE (NYT)
''For all Americans, this date will be forever entwined with sadness. But the memory of those we lost can burn with a softening brightness.'' MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG. [A1]

South Ossetia, in northern Georgia, said it would hold a referendum Nov. 12 on independence, the latest act of defiance against President Mikheil Saakashvili's government, which has pledged to bring the region back under federal control. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

After struggling offensively in their season opener, the Seattle Seahawks moved quickly yesterday, acquiring wide receiver Deion Branch from the New England Patriots in exchange for a 2007 first-round draft pick. Unhappy with his contract, Branch forced his way out of New England by holding out. The Patriots eventually gave Branch's agent permission to seek a trade, and Branch is expected to sign a multiyear deal with the Seahawks.

SCHNELWAR - GLADSTEIN-Judith. 62, deceased after a courageous long battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife of Gary Gladstein, mother of Andrew and Steven Schnelwar, stepmother of Jeffrey Gladstein and Mindy Grafstein, grandmother of Casey and Daniel Grafstein, sister of Sandra Wiener. Judi is known for her passion, intelligence, strength, philanthropy and zest for life. She will live in our memories and be remembered for the courageous, extraordinary woman she was. Born and raised in the Bronx, she graduated Summa Cum Laude from Hunter College and was an executive recruiter until her retirement. She was a Director of the Bible Lands Museum in Jerusalem and the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation in New York. She was a very outspoken supporter on Human Rights, the co - existence movement among Israeli Arabs and Jews and the state of Israel. Donations can be made to the American Friends of the Bible Lands Museum in Jerusalem, 317 Madison Avenue, Suite 707, NY, NY 10017 or the Abraham Fund Initiatives, 9 East 45th Street, NY, NY 10017. $(6$)SCHNELWAR - GLADSTEIN-Judith. The Officers, Board of Directors and Staff of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation mourn the passing of our cherished friend and esteemed Board Member. Her wisdom and devotion was instrumental in the Foundation's growth; her courage and determination a testament to her strength. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Gary, Board Member and Treasurer, and to their family. May your memories be an everlasting source of comfort. Michael Nierenberg, Chairman of the Board of Directors Samuel Waxman, M.D., Scientific Director Merle Kailas, Executive Director $(6$)SCHNELWAR - GLADSTEIN-Judith. THE CLAIM -- Heart attacks are more common on birthdays. THE FACTS -- If the stress of a pink slip or the strain of physical exertion can set off a heart attack, then why not the emotion associated with birthdays?

The Foie Gras Factor Q. What are the consequences of fatty liver? If you eliminate all fat from the diet to fight it, will the metabolism become deranged? A. Fatty liver, or steatosis, is an abnormal storage of fat in the liver. It is usually not harmful in itself, but it can be a sign of deeper problems. Sometimes it progresses to a form of liver inflammation called steatohepatitis, which in turn can progress to full-blown cirrhosis. This scarring and hardening of the liver severely compromise its many cleanup jobs in the body and can be fatal.

A Russian military helicopter carrying senior officers on an inspection tour in Chechnya crashed in southern Russia, in North Ossetia, killing most of the 14 or 15 people on board, news agencies reported. There were conflicting reports of four or five survivors. The cause was also not clear, but a state-run television channel said the helicopter had been flying in fog and might have hit a tree. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The colonel, Juan Antonio Rodríguez Buratti, was one of nine military and police officers accused of kidnapping and then killing María Claudia García in 1976. Ms. García was the daughter-in-law of the Argentine poet Juan Gelman, who has campaigned so doggedly for justice on her behalf that the case has become an issue in relations between Argentina and Uruguay. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

Between football and the 9/11 anniversary, television viewers still found some room for comedy on Sunday. A two-hour CBS documentary, ''9/11,'' drew 10.6 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates, but NBC's first Sunday Night Football game far overshadowed it as well as the start of Fox's Sunday night lineup. The much-hyped matchup of the Indianapolis Colts and New York Giants, right, gave NBC a windfall of about 22.7 million, better than ABC's Monday Night Football openers in recent years. Nonetheless Fox's slate remained solid, especially among younger viewers. At 8 p.m. the premiere of the 18th season of ''The Simpsons'' led the night for Fox with 11.51 million viewers: third overall but second to NBC among adults 18-49. ''The Simpsons'' also lifted Fox's ''American Dad'' at 8:30, which drew 8.95 million, up 14 percent from its premiere last season. At 9 the ''Family Guy'' premiere posted a fourth-place 9.85 million, but in the 18-to-49 demographic was second only to football. It did not, however, do much for the premiere of Fox's only Sunday night live-action comedy, ''The War at Home,'' which drew a middling 7.35 million at 9:30. BENJAMIN TOFF

Political allies of President Jacques Chirac went on trial, charged with vote-rigging in Paris 17 years ago while Mr. Chirac was the city's mayor. Jacques Dominati, one of 15 people being tried, is accused of having drawn up a list of 300 phantom voters to help ensure his re-election as mayor of the city's Third Arrondissement. Mr. Chirac's conservative party swept to victory in the elections. As president, Mr. Chirac is shielded from charges. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)
BLAKEMAN--Irene. 9/12/04. You are constantly with us. We love you very much. Joan and Janet

An article on Sunday about lessons for New Jersey in the tax law changes that Michigan adopted in 1994 to lighten its rising property tax burden misstated the amount by which the sales tax increased. It rose to 6 percent from 4 percent -- an increase of 2 percentage points, not 2 percent.

A man was charged with receiving terrorism training this spring in southeast England and another was charged with financing terrorism. The men, Yassin Mutegombwa, 22, and Hassan Mutegombwa, 20, were among 14 people seized in raids on Sept. 1. Yassin Mutegombwa is accused of receiving weapons training near a trailer park in Hampshire and near a farm in Berkshire. Hassan Mutegombwa, 20, is charged with procuring funds for terrorism. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

LICHTERMAN--Dr. Sigmund, 96, of Coconut Creek, FL on September 10th. Formerly of Irvington, NY, he practiced dentistry in the Bronx until his retirement to Florida, where he devoted himself to his true passion, sculpture. His work has been shown in many galleries and museums. Boyish and optimistic, he derived great pleasure from life. Predeceased by his wife of 65 years, Betty, he is survived by his older brother Dr. Jacob Lichterman, many loving nieces, nephews, their children and their grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Humane Society of the United States.

Today is Primary Day in New York. Most polls are open from 6 a.m. until 9 p.m. Voters statewide will decide the Democratic candidates for governor, United States senator and attorney general, and the Republican candidate for United States senator. There are also races for numerous state legislative, Congressional and judicial posts. Voting information is available at http://vote.nyc.ny.us/ in New York City, or voters may call the New York Public Interest Research Group at (212) 349-6460 for poll information or to report problems.

The New York City medical examiner's office is trying to determine what caused the deaths of two men from the same neighborhood in Queens. The police say both men apparently died of drug use. But there is no reason at this point to believe the deaths are linked, according to the police.

UPHEAVAL AT BRISTOL-MYERS -- A court-approved overseer has recommended that the board of Bristol-Myers Squibb fire its chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, for the company's recent handling of a patent dispute that has led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made. [Page C1.] PRESSURE ON HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny over the investigative tactics it used against its directors, and the company's board spent a second day trying to find a way out of the crisis. [C1.] $1 BILLION OIL WINDFALL POSSIBLE -- A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which announced last week that they had discovered a giant new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for that oil. Chevron's shares fell along with those of other oil companies after news on oil production from OPEC. [C1.] VYING FOR FREESCALE -- Two private equity groups are now competing to acquire Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said. [C1.] RENEWED INTEREST IN UNIVISION -- A consortium of investors led by Grupo Televisa is considering a plan to mount a $13 billion bid for Univision Communications, the Spanish-language media company, after losing an auction for it this summer, executives involved in the negotiations said. [C4.] OPEC KEEPS OUTPUT STEADY -- OPEC said that it would keep its current production levels unchanged for the time being but hinted that it was ready to cut production, as some delegates voiced concerns that high oil inventories and slowing demand might ignite a plunge in prices. [C3.] CHICAGO WAGE PLAN VETOED -- Mayor Richard M. Daley vetoed a City Council plan to make Chicago the first city in the nation to single out ''big box'' retailers like Wal-Mart and Home Depot for wage minimums for their workers. [A14.] DELL TO DELAY RESULTS -- Dell said that it was delaying the filing of its second-quarter financial report as it worked to comply with a widening investigation into its accounting practices. [C3.] RUSSIA BUYS STAKE IN EADS -- European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the French-German military contractor, confirmed that a bank owned by the Russian government had acquired more than 5 percent of the company, the first time that a Russian institution had acquired a significant holding in a Western plane maker. [C7.] ABOUT-FACE AT TELECOM ITALIA -- Telecom Italia, in a reversal of a recent and expensive consolidation, announced plans to spin off its fixed-line and mobile phone businesses into two companies. Its chairman also said that he would consider offers to sell the mobile phone business. [C6.] TELUS CHANGES STRUCTURE -- Telus, one of the largest telecommunications companies in Canada, said that it would abandon its current stock ownership in favor of an income trust. [C3.] INDIA AS AUTOMAKER -- India's quest to be a leading carmaker has received a vigorous boost, with a parade of global companies unfurling plans to assemble cars there for domestic consumption and export. [C5.] CHINA TRADE SURPLUS GROWS -- China's trade surplus with the world ballooned last month to $18.8 billion as exports soared, setting a fourth consecutive monthly record, according to preliminary figures. The surplus gives fresh ammunition to requests by American officials that China intervene less in currency trading to hold down the value of the yuan. Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., above, is scheduled to visit Beijing late next week in his first visit to China since he took office in July. [C6.] NEW WAYS TO TREAT STUTTERING -- Scientists are making progress on new medical treatments for stuttering, including a drug by Indevus Pharmaceuticals. [F1.] THE FLU AND AIR TRAVEL -- Airline travel has a significant effect on the spread of influenza, a new study reports, raising the question of whether flight restrictions may be helpful in controlling a pandemic. [F9.] NEW MONOPOLY NAMES -- An updated edition of Monopoly will include tokens that are styled after name-brand products. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C3.] ONLINE DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. ASK THE NEWSROOM -- Richard L. Berke, assistant managing editor for news, is answering readers' questions at nytimes.com/business. FIRST LOOK -- A showcase for new features and services that are developing at NYTimes.com can be found at nytimes.com/technology.

President Bush used the solemn day to assert that the United States was engaged in ''a struggle for civilization'' that would be determined in part by the course of the war in Iraq. ''The safety of America depends on the outcome of the battle in the streets of Baghdad,'' Mr. Bush said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Report Urges More Troops And Aid for Western Iraq An assessment by Col. Peter Devlin, the senior Marine intelligence officer in Anbar Province, Iraq, said the situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops there. A1 Accord Reached, Abbas Says The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, said he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas to form a national unity government in an attempt to the end the Palestinians' isolation and the cutoff of Western aid. A1 Iran Closes 4 Publications Iran's press watchdog closed four journals, including a a major reformist newspaper that was shut down indefinitely for refusing to replace its director and publishing a cartoon that was considered insulting to the government, according to a statement by the press monitoring agency. A12 Rice Eases U.S. Stance on Iran Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice left open the possibility that the United States might suspend efforts to impose sanctions against Iran if it suspends uranium enrichment for two months. A12 Snubs for Blair in Lebanon Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain dodged demonstrators and endured a series of diplomatic snubs on his first official visit to Lebanon. Several ministers refused to meet him. A10 Political Rivals Court Uruguay Uruguay has become a main front in the struggle between the United States and Venezuela for dominance in South America. The Bush administration and President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela are trying to undercut each other in an attempt to win over Uruguay's left-wing government. A3 NATIONAL A14-21 Across the Nation, 9/11 Is Remembered From digital signs urging remembrance to elected officials' musing on the demands of guarding against terrorism at home, the many ways of observing 9/11 showed how deep an imprint was made -- not only by the attack, but by the surge of solidarity that followed. A18 President Bush used the fifth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks to assert that the United States is engaged in ''a struggle for civilization'' and sought to invoke a sense of national purpose in making his case anew for seeing through the war in Iraq. A16 Shuttle Reaches Destination The shuttle Atlantis slid gently into place at its destination, the International Space Station, clearing the way for construction of the station to begin again. A21 Computer Hacking Investigated The California Highway Patrol is investigating outside breaches of a computer system used by aides to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to store downloaded audio files, a spokesman for the patrol said. A14 Court Rejects Blogger's Appeal In a case closely watched by First Amendment advocates, a federal court panel has rejected an appeal by a freelance journalist and blogger who has refused to appear before a grand jury or turn over video he shot of a violent protest last summer. A14 EDUCATION No Early Admission to Harvard Harvard University will eliminate its early admissions program next year, arguing that such programs put low-income and minority applicants at a disadvantage in the competition to get into selective universities. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-9 Solemn Tributes Mark 5th Anniversary of 9/11 On the fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, thousands gathered at ground zero, at the Pentagon and in a field in Pennsylvania where the hijacked jetliners crashed. They included families and friends of the 2,973 people who died, President Bush and other public officials and countless strangers united by haunting but receding memories. A1 Thousands of workers marched through Lower Manhattan wishing for a routine day at the office, but the memories were too fresh and painful to ignore completely. B1 New York's politicians stopped campaigning on the eve of today's primary elections, solemnly marking 9/11, but their aides were busy mobilizing get-out-the-vote operations, releasing last-minute commercials, and trying to influence media coverage of tonight's results. B3 SCIENCE TIMES F1-10 Washing Away the Guilt Liars, cheats, philanderers and murderers feel a strong urge to wash their hands -- literally -- after a despicable act in an unconscious effort to ease their consciences, according to a new study. F5 Health & Fitness F5 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6 Cyclists Admit Drug Use Two of Lance Armstrong's eight teammates from the 1999 Tour de France have admitted for the first time that they used the banned endurance-boosting drug EPO in preparing for the race that year, when they helped Armstrong capture the first of his record seven titles. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Upheaval at Bristol-Myers A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made. C1 Scrutiny of Hewlett Grows Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny over the investigative tactics it used against its own directors, and the board spent a second day trying to find a way out of the crisis. C1 Revived Interest in Univision A consortium of investors led by Mexico's largest media company is considering a $13 billion bid for Univision Communications, executives said. 10 P.M. (ABC) MEN IN TREES -- Plop Carrie Bradshaw into ''Northern Exposure'' and you might get something like this new ensemble drama about a New York relationship coach who heads north to Alaska when her own romantic life goes south -- and discovers she may have been looking for love in all the wrong places. Jenny Bicks, a head writer and executive producer of ''Sex and the City,'' created this series starring Anne Heche (above), Abraham Benrubi, Derek Richardson and John Amos. James Mangold, who directed ''Walk the Line,'' also directs tonight's pilot. 8 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE -- Tonight, House denies his pain. But can he deny an alien invasion? 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- In this celebrity edition, contestants including Tempestt Bledsoe, Leif Garrett, Todd Bridges and Brande Roderick endure water torture, electric shock, maggots and exploding buildings for $50,000. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS -- Quiet on the set! In this third go-round of the competition series, celebrity windbags like Tucker Carlson and Jerry Springer (left, with his partner, Kym Johnson, a professional dancer) try to keep from putting their feet in their mouths. 9 P.M. (13) DEMOCRACY IN THE ROUGH -- ''Wide Angle'' watches as Congo holds its first elections in more than four decades, supported by $400 million dollars from the United Nations, and learns what this attempt at democracy means to the Congolese. 10 P.M. (13) THE BOYS OF BARAKA -- The statistics are grim: 61 percent of African-American boys in Baltimore fail to graduate from high school; 50 percent of them go on to jail. This ''P.O.V.'' documentary follows four boys who are out to beat the odds by attending a strict experimental boarding school in Kenya that literally plucks American boys from low-performing public schools and unstable home environments and tries to keep them from becoming just another number. 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE -- Dave Easton, a 155-pound, Ivy-educated lawyer, was always known as the thin, successful brother. His twin and roommate, Todd, a 290-pound would-be sportscaster, was the funny, fat kid. Tonight, the Fab Five help Todd reshape his image in more ways than one and, with some triathlon training, give his brother a run for the money. 10 P.M. (FX) NIP/TUCK -- A visually attuned older man (Richard Chamberlain) brings his boy toy (Thad Luckinbill, above right, with Mr. Chamberlain) to Christian for a tune-up, while offstage a stripper does a favor or two so that he'll perform breast-reduction surgery on her. Meanwhile, Sean and Julia try to come to terms with the future of their unborn baby. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Lionel Richie performs from his new album, ''Coming Home,'' which arrives in stores today. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

BARASCH--Anne. September 11, 2006 formerly of Flushing, NY. Daughter of the late Simon David Barasch and Ida Barasch. Sister of the late Dr. Julius Barasch, Mollie Back, Goldie Barasch, Charles Barasch and Dr. Aaron Harry Barasch. She is survived by her niece and devoted caregiver Gloria R. Back. Also survived by nephews and niece Ira F. Back, Joseph D. Back, Ida Barasch, David M. Barasch, Dr. Alan S. Barasch and Dr. Kenneth Barasch and grand nieces and grand nephews. Anne was a proud graduate of the City College of New York, class of 1936. She spent her entire working life in administrative positions in the garment industry. Graveside services Tuesday 1PM Mt. Hope Cemetery.
To the Editor: I was amused by ''When Toddlers Turn On the TV and Actually Learn'' (Sept. 5). Here's yet another article about yet another study on whether kids learn from TV.

A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Aug. 30 about the number of female law clerks hired by Supreme Court justices misstated the percentage of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's clerks since 2000 who have been female, and a correction in this space yesterday misstated the year of her retirement in some copies. From the 2000 term until Justice O'Connor's retirement, 52 percent of her clerks were female, not 46 percent. She retired in January 2006, not 2005.

CHESTMAN--Pearl. On September 10 at 89 years. Beloved and elegant mother of Laurie Berman (Alan) and Harvey (Jerilyn). Adoring grandmother of Amy Sukin, Jonathan Berman, and Pamela Cline. Cherished great-grandmother of Elizabeth, Caroline, Nicholas, Alexandra, Charlie, Katie, William, Samantha and Cole. Graveside service today 11:30 at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

UNLIKE the Chicago White Sox of last season, the Mets will not go wire to wire in first place. As good as the Mets have been this season, as terrific as their record is -- the best in the major leagues -- they long ago lost the opportunity to go from the start of the season through the end in first place. On the third day of their schedule, the Mets lost to Washington and fell into a tie with the Nationals for second. The Atlanta Braves beat the Los Angeles Dodgers that day and moved into first. It would be the last day the perennial champion Braves would lead the National League East and the last day that the Mets would not lead it.

EISENBERG--Kalman S., MD, 1939--2006, from leukemia, on September 10 after as he put it, ''giving it a pretty good run.'' Survived by his adored family: wife Joanie, late wife Nancy; children Janet (David), Dan (Rose), Sharon (Lorne), Lizl and Josh (Vanessa); grandchildren.

CYCLING LANDIS ASKS TO DROP DOPING CASE -- The lawyer for the Tour de France winner Floyd Landis submitted a petition to the United States Anti-Doping Agency yesterday to dismiss Landis's case, disputing the accuracy of the scientific testing done at the lab in France. Howard Jacobs, Landis's lawyer, said that the carbon isotope ratio test done on Landis's urine sample should have been read as negative for synthetic testosterone, based on World Anti-Doping Agency criteria. Jacobs said he expected USADA to decide whether to charge Landis with a doping violation next Monday.

COBLINER--W. Godfrey. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Cobliner (nee Hauser). Father of Bennet V., and brother of Eve Kraus (nee Cobliner). We love you, and will miss you. We know that you have found peace. Riverside chapel: 212-362-6600.

To the Editor: Re ''Dogs May Laugh, but Only Cats Get the Joke'' (Side Effects, Sept. 5): My cat not only has a sense of humor, but he is also an inveterate practical joker. Instead of merely placing a dead rodent on top of the bedspread or pillow as a token of love, he conceals it under the covers and watches expectantly for my inevitable cry of horror.

LEAHEY--Edward Berry, Sr., M.D. 87, formerly of S. Nyack, N.Y. , on September 9, 2006 in Dover, DE. Surviving are his wife of 60 years, Mary Carlin Leahey, four daughters Mimi, Anne, Frances, Patricia, a daughter-in-law Lynn and 12 grandchildren; his sons, Michael, Edward and Joseph predeceased him. A graduate of Fordham College(1941) and Georgetown Medical School (1944), Dr. Leahey was in private orthopedic practice in Nyack, N.Y. and was the Founding Director of the Nyack Hospital Rehabilitation Department. He received the AMA Physicians Recognition Award yearly from 1979 to 1991, a Distinguished Alumni Award from Fordham (1963) and Doctor of the Year Award from Nyack Hospital (1989). Dr. Leahey was Medical Director of the Center for the Physically Handicapped (Jawonio) in Rockland County for over 30 years and was on the clinical faculty of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Ann's in Nyack at 11am on Wednesday, September 13. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Leahey Foundation, 156 Strawtown Road, W. Nyack, New York 10994.

BANFIELD--John E. The partners, associates and staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter and Banfield express profound sorrow at the death of John E. Banfield, beloved father of our friend and partner, William E. Banfield. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Catherine, his sons William and Thomas and to the entire Banfield family on the loss of their beloved and cherished husband, father and grandfather. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter and Banfield

Bomber Attacks Funeral Of Afghan Governor A suicide bomber blew himself up at the funeral, below, of the assassinated governor of Paktia Province, Hakim Taniwal, who was killed in a suicide attack outside his office on Sunday. The funeral bombing killed at least seven people and wounded up to 40. Five of the dead were policemen, and two were children. President Hamid Karzai denounced the attack as a ''heinous act of terrorism'' and ''an act against Islam and humanity.'' PAGEA9 Pressure on Drug Chief A court-approved overseer of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has recommended firing the chief executive for his handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal inquiry. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 A New Look at Stuttering Using brain scans, DNA studies and other modern techniques, scientists are slowly shedding light on stuttering, a condition that has flustered its victims as far back as Moses. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 Windfall for Oil Companies A group of companies led by Chevron could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for oil from a gigantic new discovery in the Gulf of Mexico. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 SPECIAL TODAY Small Business He is president of Vince, a down-to-earth name in big fashion, and don't be surprised if he shows up at a department store near you to check out the Vince display. SECTION G

A Hit School Musical Abroad ''High School Musical,'' right, the surprise 'tween hit, that has become the most popular film in Disney Channel's history, and whose soundtrack is the No. 1 selling album of the year, is going global. A red-carpet European premiere in London on Sunday night, attended by Cherie Blair and the cast of ''Billy Elliot,'' among other celebrities, promoted the film's scheduled release on Disney Channels throughout Europe on Sept. 22. In most countries the dialogue will be dubbed, while the songs will remain in English. It will also be shown on Disney Channel India beginning Sept. 24, with the songs translated into Hindi and rerecorded with Indian instruments and rhythms ''to make it sound Bollywood,'' a Disney spokeswoman said. In the United States the film has been shown 14 times to a total audience of more than 40 million, and the soundtrack has sold 3 million copies. Two Diddys Prove to Be One Too Many It didn't take long after reports surfaced that the rapper and impresario Sean Combs (a k a Diddy, a k a Puffy, a k a Puff Daddy) had settled with a little-known British music producer, Richard Dearlove -- over the use of the name Diddy in Britain, agreeing to pay Mr. Dearlove $190,000 and relinquish the name there -- for a spokesman for Mr. Combs to dispute the figure. ''The damages reported are wholly inaccurate,'' said a spokesman at Dan Klores Communications, which represents Mr. Combs, ''and the request by Dearlove's attorney for legal fees in a case that has been settled is regrettable and is being vigorously contested.'' Mr. Dearlove said he had been doing business under the name Diddy for 14 years. A Disputed Pissarro The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum in Madrid will appeal last month's ruling by a Los Angeles court not to dismiss a lawsuit for the return of a Pissarro painting said to have been stolen by the Nazis from a Jewish family. Carlos Fernández de Henestrosa, the managing director of the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection Foundation, told The Associated Press on Friday, ''We are the owners of this painting.'' The work, ''Rue St.-Honoré, Après-Midi, Effet de Pluie,'' above right, a Parisian street scene made in 1897, has been on display at the state-owned museum since 1993, when the Spanish government paid $350 million to buy Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza's collection. The Spanish government had filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit by Claude Cassirer of San Diego, who says his grandmother was forced to sell the painting in 1939 for what was then $360; it now valued at an estimated $20 million. 'Ben-Hur,' Live in Paris Coming to a Paris soccer stadium: a re-enactment of some of the biggest scenes in ''Ben-Hur,'' the 1959 swords-and-sandals film starring Charlton Heston, below right. The live spectacle, mounted by the veteran French impresario Robert Hossein, is to be almost biblical in scale, with a cast of hundreds recreating a battle at sea, gladiatorial combat in ancient Rome and a live race in the 80,000-seat Stade de France, where France won the World Cup in 1998. Training the horses for the 14-minute chariot race has taken nine months at an equestrian center outside Paris, Reuters reported. The show is to open on Sept. 22 and run for five nights. Back to Bollywood Amitabh Bachchan, below, a veteran star of Indian film, has signed on to do his first new movie since he became ill last year, The Associated Press reported. Known througout India as Big B, Mr. Bachchan, 63, will be in ''Johnny Walker,'' a love story to be directed by Shoojit Sircar, he told The Times of India in an interview published Saturday. Mr. Bachchan said he chose the movie, about an older couple falling in love, to make his return because ''as an actor I feel the film has the potential to cut across global audiences.'' He underwent surgery last November for an intestinal ailment and did not act for four months; since then he has only completed the work to which he had already committed. For Stanley Kunitz Stanley Kunitz, below right, the former poet laureate of the United States who died in May at 100, will be celebrated in a free memorial tribute on Sept. 20 at the 92nd Street Y. Among those scheduled to reminisce and read from his work are the poets Mark Doty, Sharon Olds, Marie Howe, Galway Kinnell and Genine Lentine, and Gretchen Kunitz, his daughter. Mr. Kunitz had a long association with the Unterberg Poetry Center at the Y, first reading there in 1958. An archival film of one of his appearances is to be shown. Information: (212) 415-5500. Footnotes American Ballet Theater will present the premiere of a new production of Tchaikovsky's ''Sleeping Beauty'' on June 1, as part of its spring season. Choreographed by Kevin McKenzie with the assistance of Gelsey Kirkland, a former Ballet Theater dancer, it will have 11 performances through June 9, and will then travel to the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Costa Mesa, Calif., for four performances from July 20 to 22. Jayne Houdyshell, who was nominated for a Tony Award for ''Well'' last season, was anything but well last week. Bacterial pneumonia caused her to drop out of four performances of her new show, ''The Pain and the Itch,'' at Playwrights Horizons Thursday through Sunday; none of the six adult actors in the show have understudies. She did manage to play the Saturday matinee and Sunday evening shows. The show resumes its regular schedule tonight.

The theatrically curious will have a chance to see early glimpses of some new experimental plays at the fourth annual Prelude festival, Sept. 27 to 30 at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. Highlights among the 20-plus performances and open rehearsals of works in progress include a reading of several scenes from a new, untitled play by Will Eno, who wrote ''Thom Pain (based on nothing)''; an excerpt from Charles L. Mee's newest play, ''Gone''; and from Mabou Mines a fragment from Sharon Fogarty's ''Lucia Chapters,'' about James Joyce's daughter, starring Ruth Maleczech. Presentations will be followed by discussions with the artists. And admission is free. Information: (212) 817-1860. STEVEN McELROY

As a child who stuttered badly, Gerald Maguire learned the tricks of coping. When called upon in class, he would sometimes answer in the voice of Elmer Fudd or Donald Duck because he didn't stutter when imitating someone. He found easier-to-say synonyms for words that stymied him. And he almost never made phone calls because he stumbled over a phrase for which there was no substitute: his own name.

To the Editor: Re ''A Passion for Parrots and the Fight to Save Them in the Wild'' (Conversation, Sept. 5): Monk parrots are now established in 14 states and spreading north in New York. In their native ranges, they are sometimes serious agricultural pests of fruit crops. We will see what economic damage they cause here as their numbers expand. We don't know how much environmental damage they've already caused by competing with and displacing native species.

Following is an excerpt from the speech by President Bush last night, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript: nytimes.com/washington. For America, 9/11 was more than a tragedy: it changed the way we look at the world. On Sept. 11, we resolved that we would go on the offense against our enemies, and we would not distinguish between the terrorists and those who harbor or support them.

EASTWOOD--Edwin C. Jr. Esq. On September 9, 2006. Companion of Barbara Pillone. Father of Lauren, Lisa (Eric Steinberg) and Edwin III. Grandfather of Zoe, Michael and Anika. Brother of Kathleen Farrell. No services. Donations may be made to St. Peters Prep, Jersey City, N.J. or The Children's Therapy Center ,Fairlawn, N.J.

Design is inextricably linked to our lives, from the toothbrushes we clean our teeth with in the morning, to the roads we navigate en route to work, to the chairs we sit in at our desks, to the beds we sleep in at night. This is what I look forward to exploring in this space over the next several weeks.

Today I interviewed my first prime minister, Ricardo Mangue Obama Nfubea of Equatorial Guinea, and it wasn't so scary, though our initial approach into the room was a little daunting (Watch the video report.) Ministers in nice suits circled around us with Spanish greetings and video cameras of their own. We had a plane to catch, so our meeting was rushed, but the prime minister yielded questions well.

A group known as VoteVets.org just put up a negative ad against Senator George Allen, Republican of Virginia, and it strikes right at the heart of the body armor issue that had confronted soldiers in Iraq. It shows Pete Granato, an Army reservist who served in Iraq, firing an AK-47 "the rifle of choice for terrorists in Iraq and Afghanistan" into what he calls Vietnam-era body armor provided to some of the soldiers in Iraq.

With a flex of his moderate muscle, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Arlen Specter sent a bill to the floor that would allow a secret court to determine the constitutionality of the Bush administration's wiretapping program. Democrats unsuccessfully tried to block the measure, a compromise between Mr. Specter and the White House. The Democrats still have time to kill the bill or amend it on the floor. Mr. Specter even gave them a little help by voting for a competing bill sponsored by Sen. Dianne Feinstein, which would make wiretapping for intelligence cases the exclusive domain of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, so it could be debated further.Domestic surveillance has become perhaps the most tangible example of the post-Sept. 11 conflict between civil liberties and safety, and both parties, especially the G.O.P., are likely to make it an issue for November.

With all these complications and accusations at the highest level of the sport, it is occasionally a great relief to move down to the lower levels of racing. Yesterday, the day after my return from Monza, I was invited to the Angerville go-kart track about an hour's drive outside Paris for a presentation of the world karting championships, which will take place at the track from 29 September to 1 October.

Morgan Stanley has kept its No. 1 position among prime brokerages in Alpha magazine's Alpha Awards, despite tough competition from a number of firms that have stepped up their business catering to hedge funds.

Health Care REIT said on Wednesday it had agreed to buy Windrose Medical Properties Trust for about $451 million to expand its portfolio of senior housing and health-care real estate. Health Care, based in Toledo, Ohio, will also assume about $426 million of Windrose's outstanding debt, the company said.

Peter R. Dolan was dismissed as chief executive of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb yesterday after the board concluded that he mishandled a patent dispute involving the company's blockbuster drug, Plavix. James Cornelius, a company director, was named interim C.E.O.

In case this list went up under the radar, publishers, authors and readers take heed. The much-vaunted, much-studied New York Times Best Sellers List has now created a new category for best-selling political books. It will be updated every two weeks, with commentary by the list's editor, Deborah Hofmann. We've created a special place on the Politics page for it, and when the new list goes up, we'll do a new post by Ms. Hofmann. She'll watch how the list changes, buyers' preferences, and provide insight into what's up, and what's down, and what's new.

Lehman Brothers posted a 4 percent increase in profit for the fiscal third quarter amid strong gains in its equities trading business. The announcement came one day after Goldman Sachs reported a modest year-over-year decline in profit for the quarter, but still managed to exceed Wall Street's earnings expectations.

It's getting easier to be green, or at least to look like you’re trying.

Microsoft said Tuesday that Doug Burgum, the head of its division that makes specialized software for small and midsize businesses, was stepping down and would be succeeded by Satya Nadella, another Microsoft executive.

The firm behind popular online file-sharing software eDonkey has agreed to pay $30 million to avoid potential copyright infringement lawsuits from the recording industry, according to court documents filed Tuesday.

Europe's highest court ruled Tuesday that countries could not go after profits earned by subsidiaries in other European countries as long as the businesses were not "artificial" arrangements to avoid paying taxes.
The competition regulator for the European Union clashed with Microsoft again on Tuesday, this time over security upgrades in the company's new Windows Vista operating system.
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said on Tuesday that it was teaming up with the Rockefeller Foundation to increase agricultural productivity in Africa.

With a federal investigation into his company growing wider, Michael S. Dell said yesterday that he deserved a share of the blame for recent problems at Dell and reaffirmed his support for his chief executive, Kevin B. Rollins.

A private-sector group with ties to the Bush administration has been formed to recommend changes to the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act and other regulations seen by critics as hindering the competitiveness of nation's markets.

A Justice Department official on Tuesday defended the tactics used by federal prosecutors taking on corporations in the post-Enron era, but he also indicated that the agency might consider changes to the agency's guidelines.

Ford Motor, pressing ever harder to bring its auto business in line with harsh market realities, aims to slash its white-collar costs by nearly a third as part of a stepped up restructuring plan to be presented to its board on Wednesday, the Wall Street Journal.

Fresh from his June victory against the Securities & Exchange Commission - in which a federal appeals court tossed out a controversial S.E.C. rule requiring hedge funds to register with the agency - Phillip Goldstein is gearing up for another battle.

A federal judge sentenced the former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, Michael D. Martin, to 36 months in prison on Tuesday, the third time he has been sentenced for his part in a $2.7 billion accounting scandal that rocked the company.

The boardroom intrigue at Hewlett-Packard intensified Tuesday as the California attorney general, Bill Lockyer, said he had "enough information to indict people inside H.P. and outside" for snooping into confidential phone records.

An investment company backed by the private equity firm that counts Irish tycoons John Magnier, J.P. McManus and Dermot Desmond among its investors has snapped up one of Britain's oldest honey manufacturers for an estimated 70 million pounds ($131 million).

Francisco Partners is leading an investor group that plans to take Metrologic Instruments private in a deal valued at about $420 million. A hedge fund, Elliott Associates, and C. Harry Knowles, founder, chairman and chief executive, are joining Francisco in the leveraged buyout of the company, which makes laser and holographic-based scanners for commercial and industrial use.
A New York hedge fund is betting big time what apartment-obsessed New Yorkers have been whispering about for months: that the real estate boom is over.
Biotech companies setting up shop in the San Jose BioCenter no longer have to wait for days for their lab results to return from Southern California.

A satellite company, ProtoStar, said Tuesday that venture capitalists have committed $40 million in its second round of funding. The company, which has not yet launched a satellite, plans to put up three of them in geostationary orbit to transmit television in South and Southeast Asia and China.
NexTone Communications, which makes software for Internet telephone service, has secured a $25 million in debt financing.
A Silicon Valley venture capitalist, Bill Draper, has given $1 million to the Stanford Graduate School of Business to support the school's Stanford Social Innovation Review, Stanford said Tuesday.
Sept. 14 could be a landmark date for social networking in Asia. That's the day Mixi, Japan's answer to MySpace, launches an initial public stock offering.
Ping An Insurance, China's second-biggest insurer, may raise 20 billion yuan ($2.5 billion) in a domestic share sale in the first half of next year, Bloomberg News reported.

Vonage Holdings investors who have balked at paying for shares they bought in the company's initial public offering, now worth less than half of the original price, began receiving letters this week from brokerage firms telling them to write a check or risk legal action.

Athena Capital Partners, an investment bank that offers financial services for mergers and acquisitions, private capital raising and distressed company workouts, has added David Stepanek as a director.

Scotiabank has received regulatory approval to open a branch in Shanghai, becoming the first Canadian bank to do so. Scotiabank, which is based in Toronto, said Tuesday it had obtained approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission to open the branch in China's financial center.
A British on-line travel company, Travelzest, has agreed to buy itravel2000.com of Ontario for 51.5 million Canadian dollars in cash and shares, the companies announced Tuesday.
Warren Buffett cannot seem to get enough of eBay. After auctioning several lunches and his ukelele on the site, the billionaire investor has now put his Lincoln Town Car up for sale on eBay.
Barrick Gold said Tuesday that it had acquired 81 percent of the shares of a Canadian gold-exploration company, Pioneer Metals, beating out a rival offer from NovaGold Resources.
Diesel owner Renzo Rosso is said to have another quirky design house in his sights: Viktor & Rolf.
Damask, historically associated with formal interiors, is making a splashy comeback in a more casual decorating world.
The Reserve Bank of India has named the Industrial Development Bank of India as the winning bidder for United Western Bank.

Reynolds and Reynolds, which provides computer services to car dealerships, has set a special meeting on Oct. 23 for shareholders to vote on its sale to Universal Computer Systems, the company said on Tuesday.
The New York Times Company said Tuesday it would put its broadcast media group, which has nine television stations, up for sale to focus on building its print and Internet businesses.
Time Warner's magazine division Time Inc. confirmed Tuesday it would sell 18 of its titles, including Parenting, Field & Stream and Outdoor Life, as part of a move to focus on its biggest brands.

RealNetworks, a maker of software to play music and videos on the Internet, has agreed to buy WiderThan of South Korea for $350 million to add software for selling music and ring tones on mobile phones.
AT&T said Tuesday it has agreed to acquire USinternetworking, a privately held provider of specialized software for business customers, for about $300 million in cash and assumed debt.

India's leading television maker, Videocon Industries, is close to buying Daewoo Electronics of South Korea in what could be the biggest overseas acquisition ever by an Indian company, according to The Associated Press.

Bondholders are growing concerned that Electrolux, the world's second-biggest maker of household appliances, might be a takeover target, according to traders betting on the creditworthiness of companies through credit-default swaps.
CompUSA, owned by a Mexican conglomerate controlled by Carlos Slim Helú, is being shopped to potential investors, The Dallas Morning News reported.
Undeterred by a string of disappointing airline initial public offerings in the last months, the Irish carrier Aer Lingus confirmed plans on Tuesday to list on the London Stock Exchange next month.
UniCredit, Italy's biggest bank, agreed to buy the HVB Group's 78 percent stake in Bank Austria Creditanstalt for 12.5 billion euros ($15.9 billion).

Less than two years after emerging from bankruptcy protection, the RCN Corporation, a cable company, may put itself up for sale, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the plans.

SunGuard Data Systems has abandoned its attempt to take control of Misys, its British rival, according to The Times of London. The American software and systems group walked away from the sale process after Misys, a provider of information technology to industries ranging from banking to healthcare, said the bid was not high enough.

Goldman Sachs's shares surged 4.8 percent Tuesday after the securities firm reported better-than-expected results for the fiscal third quarter. Though Goldman's figures were a comedown from its stellar performance in recent quarters, they were seen as strong in light of the summer trading slump and expectations of a decline in investment banking.
With the Hamas-run Palestinian Authority cut off from Israeli and Western assistance, the economy in the Gaza Strip has entered a severe economic depression.

Already, at 8 A.M., the streets were filled. A few people carried umbrellas, but tons of kids played in the roads with little notice of the rain.

We try to keep that in mind with this project, but bear with me briefly as I step out of bounds:1) I picked 16th out of 16 teams in our office league (We grew the league to 16 teams from 12 to include as many people as possible in our department).2) I figured that if I wasn't going to get a high pick, I might as well have some fun.
