NOT too small and not too big, Chattanooga is really the undiscovered gem of Tennessee, where old-school Southern manners and grand Victorian mansions meet a thoroughly modern, eco-friendly Tennessee riverfront. You'll be called ''sir'' or ''ma'am'' everywhere, but 'noogans can have attitude to burn, too, like the wry bartender who showed the door to a wag yelling for ''Free Bird'' during a pub's original-music night. Chattanooga is a comfortable town, the kind of place where you can go high, at museums or the sculpture garden in the Bluff View Arts District, or low, at one of several kitsch attractions so bad they're good. It's somehow apt that Chattanooga's most famous citizen is Bessie Smith, the Empress of the Blues herself -- so, as she once sang, ''Baby, won't you please come home?'' Friday 5 p.m. 1) CITY ON THE TENNESSEE Walk downtown to Ross's Landing on the banks of the Tennessee River, where you'll find folks of all ages playing in the artificial waterfall that gently rolls down scores of steps. Seven large, elaborate Cherokee symbols adorn the walls and are decoded by plaques that tell of hundreds of years of the Cherokee Nation's history. Nearby, giant silvery tubes send jets of water arcing high in the air and down into the river. Where the boats dock, find a bench where it's quiet, and you might see a school of fish jumping as the mango sun begins to wane over Lookout Mountain. 7 p.m. 2) VITTLES AND DANCING Lick your lips at Sportsman's Bar-BQ (231 Signal Mountain Road, 423-265-1680), provider of cheap tasty thrills for Chattanoogans in the know since 1949. The outside looks like the kind of shack Jed Clampett lived in before he struck it rich in ''The Beverly Hillbillies.'' But inside, the barbecue is mouthwateringly good, with lean pork, chicken or ribs, with sweetly tangy sauce. Skip the so-so deviled eggs but not the hearty Brunswick stew. Afterward, work it off at the city's free Friday Nightfall summertime concert series at Miller Plaza, which features the rockabilly/R&B band Dave Alvin and the Guilty Men Sept. 15 and the Celtic group the Elders on Sept. 22 and closes with the soul singer Bettye LaVette on Sept. 29. Saturday 8:30 a.m. 3) UP LOOKOUT MOUNTAIN Just six miles from downtown, you can drive up the winding road that leads to the top of Lookout Mountain. Chattanooga, which means ''rock coming to a point'' in Muskogean, gets its name from this peak. Here you'll find Rock City (1400 Patten Road, 706-820-2531; www.seerockcity.com; $14.95), a 4,100-foot trail through boulders and over a wild, swinging 180-foot footbridge (don't look down), helpfully augmented by sculptures of fierce gnomes and fairy tale characters in grottolike caves, some creepily illuminated under black lights. At Lover's Leap, you'll see seven states, a waterfall and an improbably balanced 1,000-ton rock. Then drive over to the other side of the mountain to Ruby Falls (1720 South Scenic Highway, 423-821-2544; www.rubyfalls.com, $14.95), and, 1,120 feet underground, Ruby Falls Cave. The 145-foot waterfall pours down a vertical shaft highlighted by ruby-red spotlights and recorded trumpets. Noon 4) LIKE A KITCHEN IN MAYBERRY At Bea's (4500 Dodds Avenue, 423-867-3618), you just walk in and sit at a big table with a lazy susan in the middle, which you will share with whoever else happens to be sitting there, and wait for your server. She will arrive with any of 10 items, like huge plates of fried chicken, barbecue pork, pinto beans, fried okra and cherry cobbler, and place them on the lazy susan. And she will return, over and over again, until you tell her to stop -- because at Bea's, it's $9.75 for all you can eat. Bea's grandsons run the place now. You might even see a hometown celebrity there, like Samuel L. Jackson. 1:30 p.m. 5) CHATTANOOGA WOMEN At the African American Museum (200 East Martin Luther King Boulevard, 423-266-8658; www.caamhistory.com $5), you can pay homage to the blues legend Bessie Smith, born in 1894 in the city's long-gone Blue Goose Hollow section. This small collection, housed in a building where Smith performed in the days when it was a hotel, includes her writings, contracts, film clips and posters. Check out her black beaded dress from the Roaring 20's and marvel at her soul-searing voice, so powerful that it could be heard outside theaters in those days before microphones. Then walk north on Martin Luther King Boulevard to All Books (410 Broad Street, 423-266-0501), a used-book store where you can browse rare tomes about Chattanooga. While you're there, strike up a conversation with the opinionated owner and local historian, Polly Henry, and ask her about the day her sister spent with William Faulkner. 2:30 p.m. 6) REALLY HIGH ART Perched on an 80-foot bluff, the Hunter Museum (10 Bluff View, 423-267-0968, www.huntermuseum.org; $8) is the heavy hitter in the Bluff View Arts District. With the river and mountains as backdrops, you'll see a vast collection of American art, including that of the Hudson River and Ashcan Schools. Don't miss the River Gallery Sculpture Garden (free), next door, with its whimsical Jim Collins sculptures and surprises tucked around every turn. Hawks soar overhead as the Tennessee wends its way below. 4:30 p.m. 7) YOUR PET STURGEON All around the outside of the Tennessee Aquarium, billed as the world's largest freshwater aquarium (Ross's Landing, 800-262-0695; www.tennis.org; $17.95), artificial streams twist and turn and provide a refreshing chance to dip your tired feet. Inside the aquarium's River Journey building are 100-pound blue catfish to ogle and lake sturgeons you can actually pet, often to the subtle accompaniment of recorded bluegrass banjo music. In the Ocean Journey building, strategically placed white rocking chairs let you take a break and watch the world go by outside. 7 p.m. 8) BEYOND GRITS New York has wandered down to Tennessee -- specifically, to St. John's Restaurant (1234 Market Street, 423-266-4400), an upscale spot with a chef from the Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan, a knowledgeable but unobtrusive serving staff and fresh seafood flown in from all over. You can order ranch antelope with a cantaloupe chutney and stone-ground grits ($30), Hawaiian monchong fish ($25), seared Alaskan ivory salmon ($24) or strawberry pie ($8). It can be a bit quiet at St. John's, so if it's boisterous you want, go to the recently opened, buzz-worthy Blue Water Grille (224 Broad Street, 423-266-4200), with its lurid, Shaq-sized paintings of marlin and grouper and its fresh seafood from Florida (lump crab cakes, $10; lobster tacos, $10; jerk swordfish, $19). 9 p.m. 9) FROM ROADHOUSE TO RAVE With its wide-open, roadhouse feel, the most popular party venue in Chattanooga is Rhythm & Brews (221 Market Street, 423-267-4644; www.rhythm-brews.com; $12 to $15), where bands play bluegrass, blues, folk rock and other rocking regional styles. Afterward, head south to the Midtown Music Hall (820 Georgia Avenue, 423-752-1977, midtownmusichall.com; usually $5), where sports-bar types meet alt rockers, especially if the local alt-rock favorites Orange Julians are playing. Go light on the $4.25 mixed drinks: the bartender makes them strong. Finish the night at the intimate and hippie-ish Local (306 Cherokee Boulevard, North Chattanooga, 423-265-2171, $2 to $5), with the occasional rave night (they still have them in Chattanooga). Sunday 10 a.m. 10) THAT CHOO CHOO The old train station in town has been converted into a Holiday Inn (1400 Market Street, 800-872-2529 -- that's 800-TRACK-29; www.lookydaddy.com), where you can stay in old-fashioned sleeper cars. The kids can play engineer on a life-size (though, sadly, nonworking) model of the original Chattanooga Choo Choo steam locomotive. Take a ride on a creaky New Orleans trolley that rolls through a 25-minute tour of the 24 acres of train yards and hotel buildings ($2). Afterward, marvel at the Model Railroad Museum's elaborate display. The Basics If you're strapped for cash, check in at the quiet $37-a-night Microtel (7014 McCutcheon Road, 800-771-7171; www.microtelinn.com), near the airport. They throw in free Wi-Fi access and a Continental breakfast with pseudo-bagels and blueberry muffins. For a taste of the new Chattanooga, try the contemporary Chattanoogan (1201 South Broad Street, 800-619-0018; www.chattanooganhotel.com; $169 to $359). If you indulge in the indoor pool, whirlpool and spa, though, you may never get to see the sights. In the Fort Wood historic district, there's nothing quite like the Mayor's Mansion Inn (801 Vine Street, 423-265-5000, www.mayorsmansioninn.com, $125 to $275) bed-and-breakfast, especially if you want to immerse yourself in Victorian-era Chattanooga. The lush but poorly lighted Laurel Falls Suite boasts a 300-gallon marble tub and fireplace. Breakfast downstairs is elegant and plentiful. In a sitting room at the front of the house, find the window with the bullet hole from the early 1900's and ask to hear the story (or legend) about the lovers' quarrel that ended in tragedy.

To the Editor: Re ''I Spy; Doesn't Everyone?'' (Thursday Styles, Sept. 7): I spy for a living. But before I spy (recover and analyze old and deleted e-mail messages, telephone logs and so on), I remind clients of the mythological tale of Pandora, whose mere curiosity destroyed the Greeks' version of Eden and introduced the forces of evil to the human race.
MELVIN--Edward W. Of Southbury, CT, formerly of Manhasset, died September 12, 2006. Beloved husband of Norma (Dahl) Melvin, he leaves three sons, two daughters and 16 grandchildren.

ROTHPEARL--Elliot, 63, died in his sleep early Sunday morning. Elliot was the beloved husband of Missy (Norla)Rothpearl. He had lived in Jacksonville, FL since 1996. Born and raised in the Bronx, Elliot graduated from the High School of Music and Art(1960) and New York University(1964). He was a master guitarist, songwriter, publisher and producer, having owned three recording studios in New York. He was the former owner of Century Lumber Company in NYC. Elliot was a member of Beth Israel Messianic Congregation, where he was part of the Worship Team. Surviving him are his three sons from his previous marraige to Naomi Lasko Rothpearl: Scott(Corinne), Josef(Michele), and Jeremy(Inger) all of NY. Elliot also leaves behind two step-daughters, Diana McCarthy of Connecticut and Kelly Barrett-Williams of Jacksonville, and nine grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Dr. Allen Rothpearl(Tina) of New York, and two sisters: Sandra Gerson, of New York, and Susan Epstein(Alvin) of Connecticut as well as four nephews and three nieces. Services will be held at Riverside North Funeral Home, Great Neck, NY at noon on Friday September 15th. Donations in his memory may be made to Beth Israel Messianic Congregation for causes on Israel, Jacksonville, FL.

SMIT--Jacobus Wilhelmus (Wim) at his home in the Netherlands on July 19th at the age of 75. Adored husband of the late Pamela Richards Smit, beloved father of Tyn, Michiel, Guy and Marijke, and brother of Johan Smit. Wim was born on August 25th, 1930 in Utrecht, the Netherlands. He joined the faculty of the University of Utrecht after receiving his doctorate in history there in 1958. In 1965, Wim joined the Columbia University faculty as the Queen Wilhelmina Professor of the History of the Low Countries. He was a widely recognized authority in the social, religious, cultural, and economic history of early modern Europe. While he wrote prolifically in his earlier career, Wim became most renowned for his dedication to teaching and was a friend and mentor to countless students, particularly through teaching all four of Columbia's Core Curriculum courses. In 1984, the Columbia College Student Council presented Smit with the Mark Van Doren Award for Great Teaching, and in 2003, he was a co-recipient of the first award for Distinguished Service to the Core Curriculum. Smit was a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, served on the Governing Board of Columbia's Society of Fellows in the Humanities and was consulting editor for the Records of Civilization series published by Columbia University Press. Wim was also an avid piano player and lover of music, as well as a prolific cook, cyclist, and, in his earlier years, semi-professional soccer player. Smit most relished his role as husband, father, and mentor. His legacy lives on in the hearts and minds of the thousands of students, colleagues, and friends who had the honor to know him and learn from him, over the years. A memorial service for him will be held on campus at St. Paul's Chapel at 5pm on Monday, September 18, 2006.

The border war between the New England Patriots and the New York Jets is not over after all. Last week, the Patriots filed a tampering charge with the National Football League against the Jets because of their contract talks with the former New England wide receiver Deion Branch. The move was confirmed by an official within the N.F.L. who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak about the situation.

The Department of Defense has identified 2,662 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday: JORDAN, Alexander, 31, Specialist, Army; Miami; Fourth Battalion, 23rd Infantry, 172nd Stryker Brigade Combat Team.

STEVENS--Oswald, age 62, known as ''Ozzie'' to his family and many friends, passed away on Sunday, September 10, after a brief illness. Ozzie was the beloved husband of Theresa and loving and devoted father to his daughter Sunita and her husband Christopher Meyers. Ozzie was owner and chef-proprietor of Pandit India Restaurant on both the East and West sides of Manhattan for over 20 years. He nourished us with his wonderful food, his laughter and endless happy memories at his restaurants, as well as at his home. Ozzie will be dearly missed by his family and friends who will always cherish his smile that lit up a room, his love of life, his good humor and his generous spirit. To know Ozzie was to love Ozzie. We are blessed to have had him in our lives and we will hold his spirit close in our hearts. Reposing to be held at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 4307 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, New York 11104: 718-784-1525. Visitation to be held on Wednesday, September 13 and Thursday September 14; 2:00 PM5:00PM and 7:00 PM-9:30PM,; Funeral mass to be held at St. Raphael's Church, 3520 Greenpoint Avenue, Long Island City, New York 11101 September 15, 2006 at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Raphael's Church in memory of Ozzie Stevens.

Pope Faults West on Faith And Jihad on Violence Pope Benedict XVI took Islam and the West to task, saying the violence embodied in the Muslim idea of jihad, or holy war, is contrary to reason and God's plan while the West was too beholden to reason. Nonetheless, he offered reason as a common ground for a dialogue of cultures and religions. NOONAN-Loretta, 95, died September 11th in Brooklyn. Contact McLaughlin Funeral Home (718)-238-3600.

The Yankees' clubhouse before a game is usually a businesslike place, with little music, laughter or loud talk. So Derek Jeter's excited voice merited attention after he saw Hideki Matsui in uniform yesterday a few lockers to his right at Yankee Stadium. ''Hey, hey, hey -- Mat-soo!'' Jeter called to Matsui. ''You play today?''

An article on Monday about sermons in the New York region addressing the fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the name of the Roman Catholic church on Staten Island led by Msgr. Jeffrey Conway. It is Our Lady Star of the Sea, not Holy Star of the Sea.

In his first state visit to Iran, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki discussed the security situation in Iraq with the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and asked for his support in quelling the violence that threatens to fracture Iraq. ''We had a good discussion with Mr. Ahmadinejad,'' Mr. Maliki said at a news conference here on Tuesday, after the two met. ''Even in security issues, there is no barrier in the way of cooperation.''

A sports article last Wednesday about a racy invitation from the skin care company Nivea to an event for the Joe Torre Safe at Home Foundation misstated the date and the reason for the gathering. It is today, not tomorrow, and it marks the first donation from the Nivea Loving Touch Fund to the foundation; it is not a charity auction.

An article on Sunday about efforts by Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas to promote healthy eating in the state misstated his time in the 2005 Little Rock marathon. It was 4 hours and 38 minutes, not 3 hours and 38 minutes.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the Venice International Film Festival misspelled part of the title of the Chinese film that won the award for best picture. It is ''Sanxia Haoren'' (''Still Life''), not ''Sanxia Horen.''
''Diabetes unfortunately is the price you pay for progress.'' DR. A. RAMACHANDRAN, managing director of the M. V. Hospital for Diabetes in Chennai, India. [A1]

BOLT--Byron. His colleagues at the Harlem Educational Activities Fund note with profound sadness the sudden passing of Byron Bolt, a dear friend and devoted co-worker at HEAF since its inception. Byron's thoughtfulness, his kindliness and his unfailing dedication to HEAF were an inspiration to all. He will be warmly remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to his warm and loving family. Stephen Gessner, Chairman Danielle Moss Lee, President Daniel Rose, Chairman Emeritus

Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and development in Lower Manhattan misstated the time frame of a dispute between Jane Jacobs and Robert Moses over urban development. It was half a century ago, not half a decade.

The World Bank is spending far less on proven methods to combat tuberculosis in Africa, where almost 600,000 people die annually of the disease, than in India, China and Russia, according to a report released Tuesday by Results International, a nonprofit advocacy group. Though a third of the world's TB deaths occur in Africa, only about 5 percent of the bank's zero-interest lending to fight the disease has gone to African countries over the past five years, the report said.

A listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday in a preview of the new television season and an article in The Arts on Monday about Aaron Sorkin's new television series, ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' referred incorrectly to Amanda Peet's role in the series. She previously starred in ''Jack & Jill'' on the WB; her role in ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' is not her first on television.

LOEBENBERG--Dr. Ralph. Yeshiva University mourns the passing, in Canada, of the beloved brother of Dina and brother-in-law of Dr. Herbert C. Dobrinsky, cherished members of our YU family. Dr. Loebenberg was a distinguished obstetrician/gynecologist and leader of the Beth Israel Synagogue in Halifax. We extend heartfelt condolences to Carol Lee, his wife of 43 years; his children, grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees

8 P.M. (13, 49) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC OPENING NIGHT GALA CONCERT -- Timpani roll, please. Lorin Maazel (right) conducts the New York Philharmonic in this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' special featuring Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture and Symphony No. 3, and Mozart's Concerto for Two Pianos in E flat, with Emanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman as the dueling -- but only onstage -- pianists. 7 P.M. (TLC) THE MESSENGERS -- The three finalists take time to reflect and fine-tune their messages. 8 P.M. (BET) ACCESS GRANTED -- Janet Jackson gets lively on the set of her video for ''So Excited.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) ROCK STAR: SUPERNOVA -- Stormy weather? In tonight's season finale, Tommy Lee, Gilby Clarke and Jason Newsted select the lead singer of their new rock band, and send the bottom three contestants back to the safety of their garages. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES -- Brennan's past as a foster child impairs her judgment when a girl in foster care cries murder. 9 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC -- Debra Lafave (left), a 26-year-old former reading teacher in Florida, discusses having had a sexual relationship with a 14-year-old student, for which she is serving a sentence of house arrest. 9 P.M. (Fox) JUSTICE -- The firm shifts into protective gear when a bartender at a restaurant owned by Ron (Victor Garber) is accused of killing a runaway bride. 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE HILL -- Like they say, when the wind blows. In episode four of this six-part series, Congressman Robert Wexler, Democrat of Florida, speaks out -- loudly -- on behalf of Hurricane Katrina victims. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- Mr. Angel tries to survive being drowned alive as he is dragged through the ocean by his ankles while wearing a strait-jacket. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY -- Last week in Paris, Vincent finally got what he has long deserved -- auf'd! -- while Jeffrey became the first contestant with immunity to win a challenge. Tonight, the designers leave the fantasy world of couture behind and return to reality. New York, that is. 10 P.M. (HBO) INSIDE THE NFL -- The 30th season of football news and highlights with Cris Carter, Cris Collinsworth, Bob Costas and Dan Marino. 10 P.M. (ABC) JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE'S ALL-STAR SALUTE TO JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! -- Mr. Kimmel shows off his gift for gab in this hour-long special of highlights from the show's last three and a half years, including clips of celebrity cameos, music performances, comedy acts and segments from correspondents like Cousin Sal, Uncle Frank, Aunt Chippy and the security guard Guillermo. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

ENGEL--Morton. September 9. A devoted husband, loving father, great sailor and successful ocean - racer. He achieved considerable success in the 1960s as skipper of the first Bermuda 40. In the 1970s he sailed with distinction in the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit. In sailing and in life he combined wideranging knowledge with creative problem-solving and an iconoclastic spirit. To friends and family he was a fixer in the best sense. Predeceased by his wife Barbara, he leaves two daughters, Susan and Patricia, and countless friends.

Two weeks after a cease-fire agreement, villagers in Gulu, Uganda, remain scarred but hopeful for peace. (Producers: Courtenay Morris and Kassie Bracken)

One of the issues that never gets adequate attention is maternal mortality in the developing world, and partly for that reason it's one of the topics that Casey and I will be reporting on. It's simply a scandal that the number of women dying in childbirth around the world has been stuck at half a million for 15 years now -- when we know exactly how to get that number down.

Today I made my first attempt to talk to an African stranger in Yaounde, Cameroon. We had stopped in some worn-out area called the Mango Tree neighborhood, and I saw some boys playing hackeysack with a banana. A little girl was playing around them. Nick and Naka were stretching their legs behind the car, so I walked over to the boys.

As the Refco bankruptcy case nears a conclusion, a judge today approved a settlement that gives customers of Refco Capital Markets 70 cents on the dollar for what they are owed, while unsecured creditors receive 26 cents.
We've met a few people in Africa so far who have complained about Africa never receiving any positive press.
The bickering has begun anew in Connecticut.
International Herald Tribune managing editor Alison Smale reports on how Turkey's possible entry into the European Union has become a political touchpoint in the French elections.
One thing is clear about the growing fracas around Telecom Italia's decision to sell off its mobile and fixed-line units: No side comes away clean.
No, this has nothing to do with Peyton, Archie, Eli, or even Cooper, the "Daniel Baldwin" of the Manning family.

It's a rare occasion when Colin L. Powell, the former secretary of state, publicly breaks with President Bush. But when it comes to the treatment of prisoners, or what he views as potential risk to troops overseas, he -- as the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- and Senator John McCain, a former prisoner of war, own a little high ground.

So, it's official: We're about to begin shooting my new TV series, "It's All Geek to Me," which will appear on three of Discovery's channels: Discovery Times, Discovery HD, and (tentatively) Discovery Europe.

Eliot Spitzer is up on television today with a new commercial, "Responsibility Road," which sort of begs the question -- will the Republican candidate for governor, John Faso, raise enough money to begin advertising (and seriously)?

The average take-home compensation for professionals at private equity firms is expected to jump 45 percent in 2006 to $816,000, according to the latest edition of the Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst-Holt Compensation Study. The year-over-year increase would be the biggest since the survey began in 2002.

Newt Gingrich, speaking at the New School in the Village last night, told me that he would announce in September 2007 if he would run for president in '08.

Governor Pataki's speech in Cleveland Wednesday was called "The World Trade Center Memorial: The Construction of Healing.'' His hosts at the City Club note that "plans to develop a new Trade Center have not materialized.'' The Plain Dealer is reporting that Governor Pataki thinks that the time has come for America to return to ground zero, and Crain's Cleveland Business said that "while he didn't come right out and ask for the audience's pledges, flyers were thoughtfully laid out on a table just outside the room where Gov. Pataki spoke.''
New shows in New York include "The Man Himself" and "The Treatment."
ABN Amro's American Depository Shares were 1.45 percent higher in late-morning trading Thursday amid speculation that the Dutch bank might be taken over by Bank of America.

In recent months, Wall Street seems to have lost some of its appetite for shares of small investment banks. Even so, Petrie Parkman, a Denver-based boutique that specializes in advising on mergers of energy companies, hopes to serve up some more.

In an exclusive to The Times, John Broder reveals the formation of a Democratic organization called the September Fund, created by one of the party's top operatives, Harold Ickes, and some major party donors.
A roundup of news on scandals, gaffes and politicians' troubles:

I make a regular practice of scanning Digg.com (or, rather, its RSS feed, if you know what that is) for interesting tech tidbits. Digg is a rising star of the Internet, a collection of (mostly) technology-related links to articles all over the Web. Digg members rank each article, giving it a thumbs-up or thumbs-down; their cumulative wisdom drives the most interesting stories to the top.
The victims of Uganda’s Acholi war are desperate to put the nightmarish days behind them.
A Russian central banker, Andrei Kozlov, was assassinated in Moscow, victim of a shooting that the prosecutor general linked to his job regulating the nation's banks.

In the arcane world of stock lending, Lando is a big name. So big, perhaps, that the New York-area family has drawn the attention of federal prosecutors who are conducting a wide-ranging investigation into allegations of price gouging in the market for borrowed stock, TheStreet.com's Matthew Goldstein reports.
Adam Plus Eve, Richard Chai, Peter Som and Trovata.

In Ohio's scandal-torn 18th Congressional district, where Republican Congressman Bob Ney vacated his seat over his ties to convicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff, several candidates are vying to replace him in the primary on Thursday.
General Electric said on Thursday it would sell its advanced materials business to Apollo Management for about $3.8 billion.

Iamgold of Canadasaid on Thursday it had agreed to buy Montreal-based Cambior for about 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion) in stock, creating a gold mining company with more than 1 million ounces of annual production.

Kirkland & Ellis has hired a bankruptcy partner, Paul Basta, away from Weil Gotshal & Manges, a notable coup considering that both law firms are major players in large corporate Chapter 11 cases. Mr. Basta will join Chicago-based Kirkland & Ellis as a partner in its New York office, Kirkland said Wednesday. Earlier this year, James Sprayregen, who had been head of Kirkland's bankruptcy group, left the firm to take a position at the investment bank Goldman Sachs.

You can expect a lot of wrangling on the Hill Thursday, with some leading senators haggling over the president's proposals on trying terror suspects at Gauntanamo and with the House poised to consider its new border security measure. President Bush visited Capitol Hill this morning to meet with the Republican leadership of the House on Thursday morning, in an attempt to rally the party behind legislation that would allow for tougher interrogations of detainees.
Collections Alice Ritter, Anna Sui and Catherine Malandrino.

The leak mess continues. Robert D. Novak, the columnist who first outed Valerie Plame's C.I.A. credentials and set off a sprawling leak investigation that resulted in the indictment of Vice President Cheney's chief of staff, I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby, now accuses his first source, Richard Armitage, of understating his role in recent interviews.

As the Senate race in Virginia gets a little tighter, Sen. George Allen, the Republican seeking re-election, opened fire on Wednesday at his opponent, former Navy secretary James Webb. Mr. Allen held a news conference with several female graduates of the Naval Academy who contended that they were harassed or ridiculed as a result of an essay Mr. Webb wrote years ago opposing women in combat. For his part, Mr. Webb issued a statement saying that he was sorry. His campaign, though, fired back and accused Mr. Allen of opposing admission for women to the Virginia Military Institute.
Former Texas Gov. Ann Richards, died yesterday evening at age 73.

Bradford Plumer, a reporter-researcher at The New Republic, writes a piece in defense of pork at TNR Online. Without quite putting it this way, Plumer elevates pork to the level of a Madisonian check on the tyranny of the majority. The masses, Plumer implies, cannot be trusted to encourage their members of Congress to adopt what is (from Plumer's perspective) sensible liberal policy without the bribes that come in the form of federal contracts and projects. "[W]ithout pork, activist government would wither and die," Plumer writes.

Bear Stearns, extending a string of better-than-expected results from major Wall Street companies, reported a 16 percent rise in profit for the fiscal third quarter. The securities firm said Thursday that net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 was $438 million, up from $378 million a year ago. Net revenue jumped 17 percent to $2.1 billion.
Premier Foods has been forced out of the 1.7 billion pound ($3.2 billion) battle for United Biscuits after it struggled to raise enough cash to win the auction.

The company that produces the "Girls Gone Wild" tapes of young women baring their breasts and acting in sexual situations pleaded guilty on Tuesday to federal charges and agreed to pay fines totaling $2.1 million.

A former New York Stock Exchange floor trader charged with securities fraud took the stand in his own defense on Wednesday, telling a jury that he had never intentionally ordered illegal trading that cheated investors.

Fannie Mae's top regulator said on Wednesday it is "more than likely" the federal government will sue the former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, and other former company officers, seeking to recover bonuses and salary and perhaps impose fines for the mortgage finance company's accounting debacle.

The United States attorney's office in Manhattan said Wednesday that Richard C. Breeden, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had been hired to oversee the payment of hundreds of millions of dollars to investors defrauded by Adelphia Communications, the cable company that is in bankruptcy.

The Interior Department's chief official responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations accused the top officials at the agency on Wednesday of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.
Pirate Capital, an activist hedge-fund manager that presses troubled companies for changes to raise their stock prices, may be the one in trouble now.

California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing in part on a small private investigation firm in suburban Boston, operating out of a yellow house with black shutters in a quiet neighborhood.

Anadarko Petroleum, seeking to raise money to pay for two major acquisitions, said Thursday it would sell its Canadian subsidiary for nearly $4.1 billion to Canadian Natural Resources. Anadarko announced in June that it would put the unit up for sale, and it had been expected to fetch somewhere between $3.5 billion and $5 billion, The Globe and Mail reported.

Can Carlos Ghosn, the man who is arguably the world's most celebrated auto executive and anointed by some as the industry's savior, really fix General Motors? As the companies he runs, Renault and its partner Nissan, enter choppy waters, The New York Times takes a look at whether he's up to the task.

HgCapital of London bolstered its new services division on Wednesday as it agreed to back a 100 million pound ($187 million) management buyout of the SHL Group, a provider of psychometric testing services.
Metrologic Instruments announced a breakup fee yesterday that could total $27.4 million if a buyout announced Tuesday were not completed.
David takes a look at the new iPod family.

British private equity group Doughty Hanson is plotting to assemble a 400 million pound ($755 million) TV empire that could include bids for Scottish Media Group and UTV, the quoted broadcasters that are considering a merger.
Dogster, a San Francisco-based company that launched online dog- and cat-oriented communities in 2004, has secured its first round of funding.

Alvine Pharmaceuticals raised $21 million in a first round of venture funding led by Sofinnova Ventures along with investments from Prospect Venture Partners and InterWest Partners. Cargill Ventures and Flagship Ventures also participated in the financing.

One week after announcing that it had obtained rights to commercialize a new class of anti-inflammatory drugs, Anthera Pharmaceuticals has revealed a $36 million second round of venture funding that features contributions from four new investors.

True to its maverick reputation, Google has set up a charitable unit that is not going to be run of the mill. The ambitious founders of the popular search engine company have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming.

Shares of Mixi, Japan's fastest-growing Internet site, surged on the company's first day of trading, luring investors with a profitable social networking service that added 1.6 million members in four months.

Signaling the market's increasing certitude that the Nasdaq will make another run at the London Stock Exchange, Britain's treasury minister moved to assuage fears that the exchnage would be subject to stricter market regulations in place in the United States.

Riding a growing craze for infrastructure investment, the Macquarie Bank of Australia has staked its claim as the world leader in the high-stakes field. What was a small regional bank less than a decade ago now oversees more than $66.7 billion through its specialty funds business worldwide, more than five times its own market capitalization.

Still more Porsches may be rumbling along Wall Street in coming months as free-spending traders and investment bankers get ready for the yearend bonuses that should follow their firms' surprisingly strong financial performances.
Citigroup lost $20 million buying and selling gold and silver in 2002 and 2003 after a rogue trader hid contracts and reported bogus prices, New York Stock Exchange documents show.
China has slammed the door on western banks in order to give home-grown institutions more time to get their houses in order.

The TSX Group, operator of the Toronto Stock Exchange, is buying an interdealer bond broker, Shorcan Brokers, for an estimated $20 million, in the exchange's latest move into a new sector of the financial markets, according to unidentified sources quoted in The Globe and Mail.
TriZetto Group is buying privately held Quality Care Solutions, a health-care software provider, in a combination cash and debt transaction valued at up to $133 million.
Japan's largest mobile phone company plans to buy a large stake in a fuel cell maker to develop handsets with longer-lasting hydrogen-powered batteries that are friendly to the environment.
Aber Diamond will spend about $157 million to buy the 47 percent of the jewelry retailer Harry Winston that it does not already own, the company said Wednesday.
Citigroup has been cited as a potential buyer for a stake in Taiwan's Bank of Overseas Chinese, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Rupert Murdoch appears to be on a digital buying spree. News Corporation, Mr. Murdoch's media empire, is poised to acquire a British graduate recruitment Web site, Milkround Online, for an estimated 20 million pounds ($38 million), The Telegraph reported.
YouTube, Bankrate.com, eHarmony and Gawker are on a list of candidates for buyouts, according to an investment banker's presentation Wednesday morning to the Online Publishers Association.

A long-simmering Hollywood proxy battle got uglier Wednesday when a movie studio, Lions Gate, bashed a takeover target, Image Entertainment, for a variety of offenses and asked shareholders to boot out the current board of directors.
Oracle, the world's biggest maker of database software, on Wednesday offered to pay up to $531 million to lift its stake in its majority-owned Indian software developer, i-flex solutions.

Health Care REIT said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Windrose Medical Properties Trust for about $877 million, including debt, in a move to expand its senior-housing and health-care real estate portfolio.
Shares of Tellabs rose 5 percent Wednesday amid renewed speculation that it could become the telecommunications equipment industry's next big takeover target.

Most of Google's purchases have been so small as to barely attract notice, and the company has done little to highlight them. But taken as a whole, the company's record of acquisitions offers a few signposts toward its future, The Washington Post says.
German drugs and chemicals group Bayer has received bids for its H.C. Starck chemicals unit that are well above 1 billion euros ($1.3 billion), Reuters reported.

A lawsuit in which the coupon company Valassis Communications seeks to cancel its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December, a judge ruled on Wednesday.

On the eve of winning approval for its half-billion-dollar purchase of Hummingbird, the business software maker Open Text could soon find itself a takeover target, with technology industry heavyweight Hewlett-Packard seen by some as the most likely buyer for the combined company.

AWG, a utility whose Anglian Water unit serves 6 million customers in eastern England, said it may be taken over. The shares jumped as much as 14 percent to a record, valuing the company at 2.2 billion pounds ($4.1 billion).
Much of Wall Street heaved a nostalgic sigh on Wednesday when they learned that the Lincoln Town Car, the unofficial taxi for tired investment bankers, was in danger of extinction.
“Least Wanted: A Century of American Mugshots” provides photos from the American underbelly.

The founders of Google have set up a philanthropy, but unlike most charities, it will be for-profit, allowing it to fund start-up companies, form partnerships with venture capitalists and even lobby Congress. It will also pay taxes.

Last week, we discussed the Chris Cooley story. In a game last season, he said he knocked one of his fantasy teams out of the playoffs because of a good performance in a real game. In the article, a league spokesman was quoted as saying that there was no rule against players competing in fantasy leagues.
The character of Alma Winemiller has resurfaced with a new authoritative calm in the Hartford Stage’s gentle, insightful revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Summer and Smoke.”
Astronomers said they were baffled about how the planet, located 450 light-years away in the constellation Lacerta,  formed and why it appears puffy.
German leaders hailed the ordination as a milestone in the rebirth of Jewish life here.
Ann W. Richards galvanized the 1988 Democratic National Convention with her tart keynote speech.
Authorities described the shooting of Andrei Kozlov, a Russian bank regulator, as a contract killing.
A stone slab bears 3,000-year-old writing previously unknown to scholars, say archaeologists.
The dwarf planet formerly known as Xena received a new name, while Pluto was given a number to reflect the loss of its status as a planet.
The U.A.W. agreed on a program to  offer buyouts of up to $140,000 to all of Ford’s hourly workers in the U.S.
The Senate Armed Services Committee today endorsed legislation that would give suspected terrorists more legal protections than the president desires.

The new solar power plant for the International Space Station began unfurling early this morning, smoothly but behind schedule.
Kimveer Gill killed a woman and wounded 19 others before dying in a gun battle with the police.

Chinese officials said new rules restricting the sale of foreign wire-service news would not affect press freedoms, but they also strongly defended efforts to control the distribution of financial and economic news inside the country.
Maj. Gen. Udi Adam, who commanded Israel’s forces in Lebanon, resigned after widespread criticism over how political and military leaders had handled the war.
Airbus may delay delivery of its A380 airliner by more than a year amid rising production costs.
Gordon Paris will step down as the company shifts its New York-based corporate functions to its Chicago headquarters.
The Staten Island Yankees will have to find a solution to Chris Salamida, something only one other team has accomplished this season.
The I.M.F. said a cooling housing market is likely to trigger a slowdown in the United States economy and abroad.
Microsoft increased its dividend by 11 percent as the company seeks to distribute more of the $34 billion that it has on hand.
It took 11 innings, and a wild pitch and an error by the Marlins, but the Mets salvaged a win Wednesday, and now need only two wins to clinch their division.
The victory reduced the Yankees’ magic number to seven in their quest to clinch first place in the American League East.

The loss dropped Cincinnati to three and a half games behind San Diego in the National League wild-card race.
The U.S. led 25-4 after the first quarter and cruised from there, routing Nigeria 79-46 at the women’s basketball world championship.
Those familiar with Yvette D. Clarke's personal history say that her victory in the Democratic primary is part of her family's longtime desire to represent the 11th Congressional District.

El Niño, the periodic warming of the tropical Pacific Ocean that can stifle Atlantic Ocean hurricanes and parch southeast Asia, has abruptly blossomed and will probably persist into next year, said Vernon Kousky, a meteorologist at the Commerce Department’s Climate Prediction Center. Mr. Kousky said characteristic dryness had already spread over Indonesia and the Philippines but added that no one should relax about hurricane risks yet because other conditions in the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico continued to be favorable for such storms.
State Representative Jonathan L. Paton left the state last week to prepare to go to Iraq, but still captured 33 percent of the vote.
Teachers in Detroit voted to end their strike of more than two weeks and pave the way for 130,000 students to return to their classrooms today.

Valerie Wilson, a former C.I.A. officer, is suing Richard L. Armitage, the former No. 2 official at the State Department, accusing him of violating her right to privacy. Ms. Wilson added his name to a civil suit in Federal District Court against Vice President Dick Cheney; his former chief of staff, I. Lewis Libby Jr.; Karl Rove, the White House adviser. Ms. Wilson has accused the administration, although not Mr. Armitage, of conspiring to leak her name as retribution for criticisms of the war in Iraq by her husband, former Ambassador Joseph C. Wilson IV. Mr. Armitage, who was deputy secretary of state, admitted last week that he told two reporters in 2003 that Ms. Wilson worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

Conservative Episcopal bishops failed to win approval for their request to stay in the denomination without answering to its national leader, who supports gay relationships. The proposal was the subject of a private meeting in New York of 11 Episcopal bishops, organized at the request of the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, archbishop of Canterbury. In a statement, the bishops said they recognized the need to accommodate the seven dioceses that have rejected the authority of Presiding Bishop-elect Katharine Jefferts Schori. But they said they “were unable to come to common agreement on the way forward.”.

A Presbyterian minister was charged on Tuesday with breaking church law for performing a marriage between two women. The minister, the Rev. Janet Edwards, of the Community of Reconciliation Church in Pittsburgh, is accused of presiding at a June 2005 wedding in violation of church standards. In March, another Presbyterian minister, the Rev. Jane Spahr of San Rafael, Calif., was the first in the denomination to be tried for officiating at same-sex marriages. Ms. Spahr was acquitted, but an appeal has been filed.

Firefighters tried to keep a 27,000-acre wildfire from jumping Interstate 5 as the blaze crept within a mile of a mobile home park in Los Padres National Forest. Unpredictable winds drove the fire that was burning across the partly closed freeway from the park in the Paradise Ranch region, said Jim Turner of the United States Forest Service. Officials reported no immediate danger to residents. The blaze was 25 percent contained. Crews using torches lighted backfires along the edges of the traffic artery to burn potential fuel. Above, two firefighters, Gonzo Vazquez and Kasey Allen, watch the progress of a backfire near the Verdugo Oaks Boy Scout Camp. The fire began on Labor Day and has burned more than 42 square miles of forest about 30 miles northwest of Los Angeles.
Four men used what they learned in jail to later extort contractors on public and private construction projects across New York City, prosecutors said.
Firefighter Donald K. Casey knew something was wrong when a wave of dust and gravel suddenly sprayed his Chevy Impala as he drove on the Gowanus Expressway through Brooklyn about 9 a.m. yesterday.
The agency’s inspector general accused officials of widespread ethical failures from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.
Lawmakers vowed to respond to bribery scandals with reforms, but their pledges have come to next to nothing.
However, the White House ran into fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects held at Guantánamo Bay.
California prosecutors are focusing on how a small private investigation firm in Boston ended up handling work for one of the largest technology companies in the world.
The law, which was signed by Gov. George E. Pataki, raises the total number of so-called red light cameras the city can install to 100 from 50.

New York City and Port Authority officials remain far apart from the developer Larry A. Silverstein over tens of millions of dollars in rent in a framework for building four office towers at ground zero.
In Bergen County, N.J., researchers have found a surprising pocket of longevity among Asian women who live longer than any other ethnic subgroup of people in the nation.
Lance Armstrong said Wednesday that he never pushed teammates to use performance-enhancing drugs and did not know they had done so.
Unlike most charities, Google’s new philanthropy will be for-profit, a move that could greatly increase its range and flexibility.
More financing is needed to catch up with new, extensively drug-resistant strains of  tuberculosis.
I seem, to my own surprise now this late in life, to have grown up in a world full of men I admired without quite knowing how to admire them.
Anson Carter signed a one-year contract with the Columbus Blue Jackets. Carter, who has played nine years in the N.H.L., is coming off a career-best 33-goal season with Vancouver.

Blake Mitchell, the South Carolina starting quarterback, was arrested after a bar fight yesterday and has been suspended indefinitely from the team. Mitchell was booked on a charge of simple assault, a misdemeanor, the police said.
cycling.

The American Tom Danielson won the 17th stage of the Vuelta yesterday, and Alexander Vinokourov grabbed the overall race lead. Danielson, a 28-year-old rider for Discovery Channel, finished the 103.6-mile stage from Adra, Spain, to Granada in 4 hours 9 minutes 55 seconds.

Philadelphia Flyers center Keith Primeau has failed to receive clearance to play because of lingering effects of a concussion and is expected to announce his retirement at a news conference today at the Flyers’ practice facility in Vorhees, N.J.
World Bank president Paul D. Wolfowitz’s fight against corruption in poor countries has drawn criticism for its aggressive approach.
Phil Rizzuto, the oldest living member of the Baseball Hall of Fame, had his Most Valuable Player Award from the 1950 season sold at auction for $175,000.
The backup punter at Northern Colorado has been arrested on suspicion of stabbing the starting punter in the kicking leg.
A man dressed in a long coat and carrying an automatic rifle shot people on a college campus before being killed.
Annie Moore didn't go West to fulfill the American dream, as the story has it. She settled on the Lower East Side.
Mariano Rivera said he is not worried about pitching in the postseason, but the Yankees will be concerned until he is pain free in a game.

The siblings of a 7-year-old girl found beaten and starved to death in January have received dozens of letters from their mother, who is charged with the murder of their sister, and have visited their maternal grandmother without supervision, lawyers said in court yesterday.
As the Pentagon’s search for soldiers grows more urgent, gay rights groups are pushing to win repeal of the policy.
Mars Inc.’s new versions of CocoaVia, a line of “heart healthy”  chocolate bars may be less healthy than the originals.
The first effort in the nation to impose minimum wage regulations on “big-box” stores unraveled.
A federal district court judge dropped two counts against John A. Gotti yesterday involving two of his businesses that prosecutors claimed had been set up and operated with illicit funds.
Matching an earlier condemnation of Israel, the group accused Hezbollah forces of indiscriminate rocket attacks and “deliberate attacks on civilians and civilian objects.”
In their general-election battle for New York State attorney general, it is clear that Andrew M. Cuomo and Jeanine F. Pirro want to shred each other.
Columbia University’s new football coach, Norries Wilson, is pinning hopes for a winning season on a one-for-all approach to the game.
A popular restaurant that was rebuilt after a 2005 bombing is revered by its customers, but death visits the area with menacing regularity.
Lottery Numbers.
With the Palestinian Authority cut off from funds after the election of Hamas, the Gaza Strip is enduring a severe economic depression with growing signs of malnutrition.
Corrections
Tuesday’s primaries gave House Republicans an edge in a New Hampshire race while Democrats got a leg up on an open House seat in Arizona.
Companies are getting more mileage out of their commercials by streaming ads and creating archives on their own Web sites.
Patriots players have seemed stunned at how receiver Deion Branch’s battle with management disintegrated. He was traded to the Seahawks on Monday.
The game called Gold Rush promises to give away $100,000 in gold twice a week for seven weeks, culminating in a $1 million contest.
Under a new proposal, automakers would be required to include electronic stability control systems on all vehicles.
By The Associated Press.

The British police charged Atilla Ahmet, 42, a former aide to the imprisoned cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri, on eight counts, including soliciting to murder non-Muslims and to commit acts of terror. He was one of 14 men seized Sept. 1 in a hunt for people accused of training or recruiting terrorists. Three men ages 17 to 42 were charged with attending weapons training in rural areas in southeast England. Two men, ages 21 and 40, were charged with offenses including providing weapons training or possessing a short-barreled shotgun.

A United States Air Force major who disappeared for more than three days last week in Kyrgyzstan made her first public remarks, saying in an official statement in Germany that she was recovering and hoped to return soon to the United States. The major, Jill M. Metzger, vanished while shopping in Bishkek, the Kyrgyz capital. She resurfaced about 80 hours later, exhausted and with her hair cut and dyed, and telling the local police that she had escaped from kidnappers. Major Metzger said she needed privacy “while I rest and try to get through this.”.

An Australian academic who was given a $625,000 grant by a federal agency for a study on terrorism and suicide bombers has modified his proposal after the attorney general warned him that his research might run afoul of new antiterrorism laws. The academic, Riaz Hassan, a retired professor of sociology at The Flinders University of South Australia, planned to interview leaders of organizations like Hezbollah, Hamas and Jemaah Islamiyah in Indonesia. The attorney general, Philip Ruddock, said the interviews might violate laws that make it a crime to associate with terrorists.

A record area was cleared of land mines last year, but casualties from mines rose 11 percent to 7,328 in nearly 60 countries, with children making up about 20 percent of the victims, according to the Landmine Monitor Report, prepared by the International Campaign to Ban Landmines, based in Geneva. The rise in casualties was a result of conflicts in areas like Myanmar, India, Nepal and Pakistan, none of which are signatories to the ban, and in Colombia, which has signed the treaty and where there were more than 1,100 mine victims last year.

Militiamen loyal to the fundamentalist Islamic group that appears determined to rule Somalia are advancing on Kismayo, one of the last remaining commercial ports outside of their control, an official said. The official, Abdikarin Farah, the Somali ambassador to the African Union, spoke on the sidelines of an African Union meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Several hundred militiamen loyal to the Islamic group have been seen traveling in trucks mounted with machine guns to Kismayo, some 310 miles south of the capital, Mogadishu, the official and witnesses said.

Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cabinet has approved plans to send troops to the eastern Mediterranean to join the United Nations-led peacekeeping mission for Lebanon. Germany will deploy a naval task force of up to 2,400 military personnel to patrol Lebanon’s coastline and try to prevent weapons from reaching the Hezbollah militia by sea. The mission must still be approved by the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament. Mrs. Merkel said it reflected Germany’s special duty to the state of Israel and a solid solution for peace in the region.

The sole survivor of the four-man team of Syrians that attacked the American Embassy in Damascus on Tuesday died of his wounds without being questioned, Syria’s official news agency reported. The assailant’s death left Syrian authorities with nothing but the physical evidence left behind to piece together the origins of the attack and its possible motivations. The Syrian government and the embassy both declined to comment on the investigation.

Unesco has infuriated human rights organizations by awarding a medal to the widely criticized leader of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, left. The agency’s director general, Koichiro Matsuura, quietly handed Mr. Karimov its Borobudur gold medal last Friday for “strengthening friendship and cooperation between nations, development of cultural and religious dialogue, and supporting cultural diversity.” Uzbekistan’s government killed several hundred people in suppressing an uprising in the city of Andijon on May 13, 2005. The award was for Uzbekistan’s contribution to preserving World Heritage sites, said Suzanne Bilello, a Unesco spokeswoman in New York.

The police raided houses in a major security crackdown in Diyarbakir, the largest city in Turkey’s mainly Kurdish southeast, after a bomb blast killed at least 10 people, 5 of them children. It was the bloodiest attack in Turkey since suicide bombers killed more than 60 people in Istanbul in November 2003 and the latest in a series of explosions in Turkish cities that have killed at least 15 people.
The proposal, which Congress will vote on, would create a multimillion-dollar project to restore more than 150 miles of the river.
A letter that a priest wrote to the parents of a teenager, who later accused the priest of touching him in a sexual manner, appears to attempt to explain a physical relationship the pair had.
Mantra Films pleaded guilty to charges of failing to maintain proof of age for performers and agreed to pay fines totaling $2.1 million.
When it comes to homeland security, the Bush administration has repeatedly allowed corporate profits to trump safety.
The U.N. secretary general said most of the officials he met believed the invasion and its consequences have been catastrophic but were of two minds whether the Americans should leave Iraq.
A top Democratic operative and a group of major party donors have banded together to deliver a barrage of late advertising to secure victories in November.
Microsoft is battling a computer hacker who has repeatedly released a free program that strips away a software lock that protects digital movies and songs from being copied.
In less than an hour, the Twins went from euphoria at pitcher Francisco Liriano’s return to concern for his future and their suddenly uncertain postseason chances.

A high school junior collapsed during gym class at Beach Channel High School yesterday and later died at a hospital, the police said. The student, whom the police identified as Schermiela Palmer, 16, of Beach 63rd Street, was running on a track at the school in Rockaway Park when she collapsed at 11 a.m., the police said. She was pronounced dead about noon at Peninsula Hospital Center. Officials said an autopsy would be conducted today.

More than 20 state lawmakers filed a petition yesterday urging the State Public Service Commission to block Consolidated Edison from charging customers for repair costs associated with the July blackout in western Queens and a less extensive power failure this month caused by the remnants of Tropical Storm Ernesto. The lawmakers asserted that Con Edison cut its spending on maintenance, reduced the number of employees working on transmission and distribution and “ignored signs of the unreliability of the electrical system.”.

A city panel yesterday directed the owners of a 25-story commercial building in TriBeCa to provide maps showing where and how an estimated 80,000 gallons of diesel fuel is stored in the building. The issue regarding the tower, at 60 Hudson Street, has been a long-running controversy. The Buildings Department has granted a variance exempting the building from the usual limits on how much fuel can be stored there, but 13 neighborhood activists urged the city’s Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday to revoke the variance. They say so much fuel, which is used for backup generators for telecommunications equipment in the building, could lead to a major fire in a terrorist attack or other disasters. The board’s decision is expected later this year.

The City University of New York announced yesterday that it would receive a $30 million donation, the largest in its history, to buy a permanent home for its Honors College. The donor is William E. Macaulay, a financial adviser and investment manager, who graduated from City College in 1966. CUNY plans to buy a five-story townhouse at 35 West 67th Street from the 92nd Street Y to house the Honors College, which has more than 1,200 students on seven CUNY campuses. Honors College students get free tuition and other perks and take special classes together as well as classes on their home campuses.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined Kenneth J. Ringler Jr., the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and other city officials yesterday to announce an agreement on $39.5 million worth of projects to improve La Guardia and Kennedy Airports and help the neighborhoods around them. The money is part of $100 million that the Port Authority agreed to spend in 2004 when it renegotiated its lease of the two airports. It will pay for landscaping, street improvements, traffic studies and upgrades to the AirTrain at Kennedy.

An animal rights activist who was part of a group convicted of helping to incite threats and harassment against a company that tests products on animals was sentenced to prison yesterday in Federal District Court. The activist, Joshua Harper, a West Coast coordinator for Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, was sentenced to three years and ordered to help pay $1 million in restitution. On Tuesday, three other members of the group were sentenced to terms ranging from four to six years. In March, they were convicted of using a Web site to incite harassment against Huntingdon Life Sciences, a British company with a lab in East Millstone that tests products on animals.

A third person involved in a car accident on Route 35, also known as Amboy Road, died Tuesday night at University Hospital in Newark, the authorities said yesterday. The three-car collision took place just before 7 p.m. Tuesday, and two people — the driver and passenger of the vehicle that the police say caused the accident — were pronounced dead at the scene. The authorities identified the driver as Richard Dzyak, 17, and his passenger as Tony Teijeiro, 16, both of Woodbridge. Mr. Dzyak, driving a Chrysler 300, crossed into the oncoming lane and sideswiped a 1998 Hyundai before crashing head-on into a 2005 Jeep Wrangler, said Nicholas Sewitch, a Middlesex County assistant prosecutor. Three passengers in the Hyundai and the driver of the Jeep were treated for injuries that were not life-threatening, he said. But a passenger in the Jeep, Nancy J. Potter, 42, of Woodbridge, whose limbs were severed in the crash, died shortly before midnight, Mr. Sewitch said.

A Brooklyn teenager died last night after he hit his head while trying to climb a fence in front of a school in Ditmas Park, and the police said he may have been electrocuted. Luis Rivera, 17, of Rugby Road, was found unconscious shortly before 8 p.m. with head injuries in front of Public School 217 near the intersection of Newkirk and Coney Island Avenues, according to the police. He was taken to Maimonides Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. Consolidated Edison employees were at the scene last night trying to determine whether he had been electrocuted, the police said.

An elderly woman was found dead and her husband mortally wounded early yesterday, both shot in the head, minutes after the man had called 911 to report that she had committed suicide and that he would soon do the same, the police said. When police officers arrived at the home on Haig Place in Kings Park, they found Edith Zuckerman, 75, dead in the bedroom. Her husband, Martin, 78, died shortly after arriving at St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center in Smithtown. The police said they did not know whether Mrs. Zuckerman had shot herself. “All we know is he left a note saying that the two of them had decided to commit suicide,” said Detective Sgt. Edward Fandrey of the Suffolk County police. He said the note was signed only by Mr. Zuckerman. Neighbors said the Zuckermans were devoted to each other and inseparable. “If they ever argued, it was because she would not want him climbing a ladder, or doing something where he could get hurt,” said Corey Voboril, who lives next door. Sergeant Fandrey said neither of the Zuckermans had serious medical problems.
In absolving Bengals defensive end James Geathers for the hit, the N.F.L. emphasized that quarterbacks are responsible for avoiding hits by sliding.
Dr. Robert J. Gorlin helped write a definitive medical reference work on the causes of facial malformations.
Dr. Rowan, a noted expert on epilepsy, studied the disease in the elderly and helped investigate more effective medications to prevent seizures.
Nintendo plans to release its new Wii video game console in the Americas in November.
A plan would increase taxi fares by as much as 11 percent and create a flat fare of $45 from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport.
Barbara Ehrenreich has started an organization to help white-collar workers, be they unemployed, uninsured, downsized, stressed out or merely anxious.
NASA scientists reported that higher temperatures and a retreat of the sea ice over the last two winters offered new evidence that heat-trapping gases were influencing the Arctic’s climate.
The astronauts faced a balky bolt that could have cut short an attempt to install a new $372 million truss.
The emergency response to Typhoon Saomai last month had been trumpeted as a triumph, but in the storm’s aftermath, a very different account of events has taken shape.
President Bush, who is determined to pressure North Korea, will meet with President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea, who insists on coaxing the country out of its isolation.
Cabinet members submitted their resignations, but a new government may not be in place for weeks, and it is not clear whether Western countries will restore assistance.
Nissan-Renault’s chief Carlos Ghosn, anointed by some as the auto industry’s savior, suddenly seems to be on the defensive.
BORN Nov 21, 1964, in Brooklyn.
Three men in New York are accused of defrauding Medicaid of millions of dollars by billing the program for H.I.V. drugs and other medicines that were never given to patients.
The British Library said that an American antiquities dealer, who pleaded guilty to having stolen rare maps, deserves more than the 57 to 71 months in prison that prosecutors supported.
A judge is considering if tobacco companies should be tried on whether they deceived smokers about the safety of light cigarettes.
A planned protest against harsh economic and political conditions was crushed by riot police officers and militia and government threats against anyone who joined in.
Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the embattled chairman of the federal board that oversees most government broadcasts to foreign countries, narrowly survived an effort to oust him on Wednesday.
Mr. Vidal-Naquet, an eminent historian of the ancient world, became widely known for exposing wartime atrocities of the modern one.
As Iraqi police gathered up at least 60 bodies, several car bombs rocked the capital, killing and wounding dozens more.
Efforts to pass a measure called the Women’s Protection Bill have run into opposition from members of the governing coalition, as well as from Islamic parties.
Ned Lamont, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate in Connecticut, said that American troops should be shifted to Afghanistan to fight terrorism.
The Jets need a No. 2 receiver to keep defenses from double-teaming Laveranues Coles, and Jerricho Cotchery appears ready to take on that role.
The Education Department gave states final permission Wednesday to leave out the test scores of newly enrolled pupils who speak limited English when grading schools.
In the first game of the season, the Giants’ defense was solid but was undone by a few critical flaws.
Britain’s treasury minister said legislation will be introduced to ensure that the London Stock Exchange retains its openness to investment, if it is taken over.
Battered energy shares like Exxon Mobil rebounded as investors bet that interest rates would not rise anytime soon.
The lawsuit between coupon company Valassis and direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December.
Tyron Garner was one of two plaintiffs in the Supreme Court case in 2003 that overruled a Texas sodomy law, effectively making homosexual relations a basic civil right.
There is no indication of what is in store for a staircase that was used as an escape route at ground zero during the Sept. 11 attack.
Yahoo hired Hilary Schneider, a former Knight Ridder executive to oversee the company’s classifieds, travel and shopping sites.
Mortgage foreclosures rose to a four-year high in the second quarter, a sign that homeowners with good credit are having trouble paying their bills.
After an upset victory in the Democratic primary, Adrian M. Fenty, 35, expects to be Washington’s next mayor, the youngest in its history.
Richard C. Breeden has been hired to oversee the payment of  millions to investors defrauded by Adelphia Communications.
William Donald Schaefer, who served four terms as Baltimore’s mayor and two as Maryland’s governor, failed in his bid for re-election as the state’s comptroller.
The legislation would require construction of two layers of reinforced fencing along stretches of California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas.
A team of scientists says it was at Gibraltar 28,000 years ago, 2,000 years more recently than previously thought.
The system should be revamped to aid more workers displaced by a transforming economy, economists said as they released overhaul proposals.
Tom Masella became a firefighter when he graduated from college in 1981, but he never stopped dreaming of coaching football.
Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said China’s currency exchange rate is being viewed as a symbol of unfair competition.
Apple’s latest developments are laying the groundwork for some ambitious ideas down the road.
Maybe it’s too much to expect something new from American fashion, but, so far, the spring 2007 collections are putting out a lot of warmed-over goods.
A former New York City worker responsible for monitoring the water supply pleaded guilty yesterday to falsifying important records about the purity of the drinking water.
Desiree Dancy will be responsible for developing, recommending and leading the company’s diversity initiatives.
The Dutch are turning to bicycles in ever greater numbers. Sales are booming, and there is a proliferation of designs for all sorts of purposes.
Two independent teams of astronomers are reporting that they might be zeroing in on the time that bright galaxies began to light up the primordial universe.
Elisabeth Ogilvie was the author of 46 books, most of them tales of romance and mystery set on the craggy islands off the coast of Maine.
Aspiring animators on a budget may want to take a look at the latest version of Adobe’s video editing program, Adobe Premiere Elements 3.0.
Lehman Brothers reported strong third-quarter results amid weak markets, lackluster deal flow and higher global interest rates.
When Pet Butler, a service that collects dog waste and disposes it for a fee, began selling franchises, there was no shortage of office workers willing to trade briefcases for pooper scoopers.
There is no need to remodel the F.B.I. after Britain’s MI5: the agency has transformed itself into an intelligence-driven organization.
The exportation of the Fashion Week concept has been so successful that they are now held pretty much everywhere.
Passages from a folk legend’s latest album, “Modern Times,” echo a 19th-century Confederate’s verses.
