Whitney Houston files for divorce from Bobby Brown, Beyoncé to the rescue, Katie Couric regains the lead, another boy for Britney Spears and more culture news.
At the Venice Biennale, architects stare into a windowed, dystopian future, trapped within stylistic confines of their own making.
Was it really cooler in the 80’s? The answer may depend on what you mean by “it.”

Q. I look forward to having my beautiful pineapple lilies again next year, but hope to avoid storing them indoors. Will they survive in my protected Zone 7 garden? Some sources say they are hardy to Zone 6, others say Zone 8 or 9. Which is it?
Mikhail Baryshnikov invites one of his tutors, Azari Plisetski, to his center.

Thanks to potheads, water beds and freshman philosophy majors, “The Dark Side of the Moon” will continue to sell thousands of copies every month, and Roger Waters will continue to play it for sellout crowds.
The staff of “Today” greeted its new co-anchor, Meredith Vieira, with the kind of relief and giddy happiness that enveloped Corazon Aquino after Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos were ousted.
A celebrated party planner's 18th-century farmstead.
Midway through its run, the 31st Toronto International Film Festival embraced the alpha and the omega of hype and glory.
Now at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, which is reopening after being closed for the last decade: textiles, glassware and savoir-faire.
Trading a blush brush for a paintbrush to give old houses a new glow.
The Canadian Opera Company celebrates victory in a long campaign to build an opera house, just in time for the premiere of a new production of Wagner’s “Rheingold.”
Philip Gold examines the challenge for the 21st-century American military: few want to enlist, but even fewer want to see a revival of the draft.
This week, MisShapes will select the music for either the shows or afterparties of Calvin Klein, Tory Burch and L.A.M.B, the label of Gwen Stefani.
Manhattan.
Who is fashion’s muse? Goldie Hawn in “Laugh-In.” Plus three other spring trends.
A guide helps high schoolers find safe, tolerant colleges.
The New York architect, Steven Holl, designs a house for the Swiss ambassador.
“From Mambo to Hip-Hop” dances through the history of a borough that nurtured mambo, which evolved into salsa, and the hip-hop that arose from the most desperate days of the South Bronx.
Jason Moran’s Bandwagon and the Bad Plus, two piano trios sharing a double bill at the Blue Note this week, have scrambled jazz to suit themselves.
Balancing extremes to bring a room into harmony.
The Logitech ChillStream controller for PC’s contains a small fan that blows cool air onto your palms while you play.
The Garmin Nüvi 660 is one of the first wide-screen navigation units that is also a traffic warning system and a source of entertainment.
Belkin’s new Concealed Surge Protector combines function with form, and the ability to hide cables is just the start.
Do you like to solve bridge problems?
As flat panel displays have grown, categories have blurred. So which television type is better: L.C.D. or plasma?
Sony’s new S2 Sports Walkman players include a sensor that can determine your pace and automatically switch to your favorite playlists for running or walking.
Is it true that hard drives can get tired or aged?
THE Advocate College Guide for LGBT Students” recognizes 20 colleges and universities as “pioneering” lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender leaders in higher education.
Insiders know that Fashion Week is not officially under way until some photographer at the far end of the runway bellows, “Ladies, uncross your legs!’’
Starvation and loss of a period should alarm women in sports.
How can I light my yard without wasting lots of energy?
I'm usually suspicious of fashions embraced by the young.
Why are some educated people from Western countries so prone to fanaticism?
YES Network’s Jim Kaat is one of baseball’s best analysts, a master of the game’s nuances.  He will retire after calling Friday’s Red Sox-Yankees game.
Well known in their own countries, editors of foreign fashion magazines sometimes find themselves seated in Siberia at New York Fashion Week, or even fighting for standing room.
Some of the strongest words came from Turkey, possibly putting in jeopardy Pope Benedict XVI’s scheduled visit there in November.
Ann W. Richards galvanized the 1988 Democratic National Convention with her tart keynote speech.

Epilepsy has long made it difficult for Marvin Wasserman to vote. After all, taking in all the different races, which New York State generally requires to be displayed on a single ballot, is challenging even for people without a neurological disorder.
The searches of the Swiss home of Jan Ullrich and nine other homes and offices were part of an investigation into a Spanish doping scandal.
Attorney General Eliot Spitzer and the Republican candidate for governor, John Faso, exchanged salvos over their upbringings, records and visions for the state.
We Americans could benefit from looking in a mirror, and absorbing the shock of not recognizing what we’ve become.
For models’ faces, the runway walk is the only part that’s a stroll.
Nataliya Gotsii, a model from Borispol, Ukraine, is crazy about her skin.
In Bridgehampton, where “Arf!” means “Charge it!”
The Patriots and Red Sox are coming to New York this weekend, but neither team is quite the same only two seasons after they won championships.
There has been a gap between President Bush’s visions and the means his administration has devoted to realize them.

Kicking off their general-election battle for New York State attorney general yesterday, Andrew M. Cuomo and Jeanine F. Pirro could not have smiled more, sounded nicer, or done a poorer job of concealing their true feelings: they want to shred each other. Ms. Pirro, the Republican candidate, said she would run a ''positive, issues-oriented campaign'' and challenged Mr. Cuomo to do the same, and then found five different ways to describe him as totally unqualified for the job.

The British police charged Atilla Ahmet, 42, a former aide to the imprisoned cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri, on eight counts, including soliciting to murder non-Muslims and to commit acts of terror. He was one of 14 men seized Sept. 1 in a hunt for people accused of training or recruiting terrorists. Three men ages 17 to 42 were charged with attending weapons training in rural areas in southeast England. Two men, ages 21 and 40, were charged with offenses including providing weapons training or possessing a short-barreled shotgun. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

THIS fall, stacked amid the hefty new college admissions books like ''The Best 361 Colleges'' and ''Financial Aid for the Utterly Confused'' is a guide about an entirely different sort of college acceptance. ''The Advocate College Guide for LGBT Students'' (Alyson Books) profiles 100 of the country's ''best campuses'' for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender students, and it arrives at a time when gay students are more vocal and visible.

BOBRINSKOY --Nicholas, Alexis (Count). February 8th 1921 -September 12th 2006. Grand Prior of the Sovereign Order of Orthodox Knights Hospitaller of St. John of Jerusalem, great - great - great grandson of Empress Catherine the Great of Russia. He was married to Tatiana N. Timasheff (daughter of the eminent sociologist Professor Nicholas S. Timasheff), 2 children Alexis and Catherine and four grand children. The wake will be held on Thursday September 14th at 7:00pm. An article in Business Day on Friday reported that the Walton Family Foundation had made contributions to four conservative research groups whose analysts wrote articles favorable to Wal-Mart Stores for newspapers and journals around the country. The Times article said that the groups and their employees had consistently failed to disclose the donations, and it said in the first paragraph that the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research was one of them. But a Manhattan Institute author had told The Times that he had indeed disclosed contributions from the Walton Foundation in an article he wrote, a fact that should have been included in the Times article. The article also reported that Tim Kane of the Heritage Foundation and Karl Zinsmeister, formerly of the American Enterprise Institute, were among those who wrote articles favorable to Wal-Mart after their foundations received a donation. Both those groups were called for comment for the Times article. Mr. Kane, who was not called, subsequently said that he did not know about the Walton Family Foundation contribution and that he had criticized Wal-Mart's call for a higher federal minimum wage in an article he wrote. The Times also did not ask Mr. Zinsmeister to comment, but he declined to do so when reached after the Times article was published. Both Mr. Kane and Mr. Zinsmeister should have been asked to comment before publication.

MOORE--John McDonald. 1/11/19/19-9/14/99 A book I have, a friend gave, Whose pencil, here and there Had notched the place that pleased him, At rest, his fingers are. Now, when I read, I read not, For interrupting tears , Obliterate the etchings Too costly for repairs. (E. Dickinson

Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet has approved plans to send troops to the eastern Mediterranean to join the United Nations-led peacekeeping mission for Lebanon. Germany will deploy a naval task force of up to 2,400 military personnel to patrol Lebanon's coastline and try to prevent weapons from reaching the Hezbollah militia by sea. The mission must still be approved by the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament. Mrs. Merkel said it reflected Germany's special duty to the state of Israel and a solid solution for peace in the region. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

An article last Thursday about a hearing in a lawsuit seeking to reduce class size in New York City public schools referred imprecisely to a decision by the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, in a separate case concerning school financing. It ruled that the state had to provide adequate financing for city schools, but did not set a specific amount. (Last March, a lower court, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, ordered the Legislature to allocate anywhere between $4.7 billion and $5.63 billion extra to city schools.)

CHESS--Stuart, passed away September 12, 2006 at age 68. Survived by sons Mitchell, Jeffrey, Jonathan, Douglas Chess and their families. Former V.P. at Paine-Webber on Wall St. Interment Mt. Hope Cemetery, Rochester, NY. Donations may be made to The American Diabetes Association in his memory.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined Kenneth J. Ringler Jr., the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and other city officials yesterday to announce an agreement on $39.5 million worth of projects to improve La Guardia and Kennedy Airports and help the neighborhoods around them. The money is part of $100 million that the Port Authority agreed to spend in 2004 when it renegotiated its lease of the two airports. It will pay for landscaping, street improvements, traffic studies and upgrades to the AirTrain at Kennedy. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)
HARAN - Jacques. You're loved and remembered always. WFF

The Mets began the day with a chance to clinch their first division title since 1988. They needed a victory over the Florida Marlins and a doubleheader sweep by Atlanta against Philadelphia. Charlie Samuels, the Mets' equipment manager, made sure the clubhouse was stocked with the obligatory celebration Champagne, and a sense of anticipation filled the air. But any Mets celebration was short-circuited early when Philadelphia erased a five-run deficit to defeat the host Braves in their first game, 6-5. That left the Mets looking to lower their number to clinch the division to two games. It took 11 innings, a wild pitch and an error by the Marlins, but the Mets salvaged something from the day, winning, 7-4.

The sole survivor of the four-man team of Syrians that attacked the American Embassy in Damascus on Tuesday died of his wounds without being questioned, Syria's official news agency reported. The assailant's death left Syrian authorities with nothing but the physical evidence left behind to piece together the origins of the attack and its possible motivations. The Syrian government and the embassy both declined to comment on the investigation. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

Sarah Cihat, above, a Brooklyn designer known for printing abandoned dishes with images of rock stars, animals and crossbones, now has a collection all her own. Called Dirt, the hand-cast porcelain pieces include vases with dogwood blossoms ($450 to $650), cups and bowls with a stonelike surface ($60 to $95) and decorative wolf heads ($500). The dogwood motif is from Ms. Cihat's childhood in Tennessee; the rest she imagined. ''I needed an outlet during all the dish rehabbing,'' she said. She also has, with Joya Candle of Brooklyn, a line of candles with screen-print images of skulls, horses and anchors ($75). All at Barneys New York, 660 Madison Avenue (60th Street), (212) 826-8900, barneys.com. TIM McKEOUGH

FELD--Rachel Amato, 94. On September 13, 2006, at home in Manhattan. Dear mother of Joanne Craig and Alice Golbert. Cherished Nana. Services private.
To the Editor: Re ''A Simple Remedy for Fear of Flying,'' by Eleanor Randolph (Editorial Observer, Sept. 7):

A meeting of NATO countries in Belgium on Wednesday failed to win new troops to patrol southern Afghanistan, where a resurgent Taliban rebellion has challenged the international force. Gen. James L. Jones, NATO's military chief, had called the meeting to persuade countries to deliver on past commitments and to meet a request by the NATO command for up to 2,500 extra troops for Afghanistan.

Whitney Houston Files For Divorce From Bobby Brown Whitney Houston has filed for divorce from her husband, Bobby Brown, both right, her publicist said, The Associated Press reported. The publicist, Nancy Seltzer, would not say where or when Ms. Houston filed the divorce papers, and said the singer had no statement to make. Mr. Brown, a former member of New Edition, married Ms. Houston in 1992. His solo career took off with singles like ''Don't Be Cruel,'' but he became progressively known more for his drug and alcohol arrests. Ms. Houston has also drawn attention for drug problems. The couple have one child, a 13-year-old daughter, Bobbi Kristina. Another Boy For Britney Spears It's a boy for Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Federline, The Associated Press reported, citing entertainment magazines. Mrs. Federline, 24, is the singer Britney Spears, right. Mr. Federline, 28, dances and raps. The child, born by scheduled Caesarean section early on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, is the couple's second. They have another boy, Sean, who turns 1 today. Mr. Federline has a son and daughter with the actress Shar Jackson. Movie Studios File Piracy Lawsuit Six major Hollywood studios have filed copyright infringement suits against a Chinese company they accuse of selling pirated copies of their movies in two of its stores in Beijing, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 90 percent of films sold on DVD in China are believed to be illegal copies, the Motion Picture Association of America said in a statement announcing the suit by 20th Century Fox, Walt Disney, Paramount Pictures, Universal Studios, Warner Brothers and Columbia Pictures against the Beijing Shiji Haihong Commerce and Trade Company. The lawsuit, seen as a shift from previous efforts to control piracy by complaining to the government, seeks $247,000 in damages. The Chinese company was not immediately available for comment. Footnotes John Updike, right, has been named the winner of the annual $30,000 Rea Award for the Short Story. The award, established in 1986 by Michael M. Rea, a passionate reader and collector of short stories, goes to a living American or Canadian writer whose work has made ''a significant contribution to the discipline of the short story as an art form.'' The Poetry Foundation, publisher of Poetry magazine, has announced plans for a Children's Poet Laureate award. The $25,000 honor, to be inaugurated on Sept. 27 at the Pegasus Awards ceremony in Chicago, will be given to a living American writer in recognition of a career devoted to writing exceptional poetry for young children.

The City University of New York announced yesterday that it would receive a $30 million donation, the largest in its history, to buy a permanent home for its Honors College. The donor is William E. Macaulay, a financial adviser and investment manager, who graduated from City College in 1966. CUNY plans to buy a five-story townhouse at 35 West 67th Street from the 92nd Street Y to house the Honors College, which has more than 1,200 students on seven CUNY campuses. Honors College students get free tuition and other perks and take special classes together as well as classes on their home campuses. KAREN W. ARENSON (NYT)

An article in some copies yesterday about primary election results around the nation referred incorrectly to Michael Steele, the lieutenant governor of Maryland, who is now the Republican candidate for Senate. If elected, he would be the only black Republican in the Senate, not the first. (Edward William Brooke III, a Republican from Massachusetts who served from 1967 through 1979, was the first black elected to the Senate by popular vote. In the late 19th century, when senators were elected by state legislatures, Mississippi had two black Republican senators.)

Ann W. Richards, the silver-haired Texas activist who galvanized the 1988 Democratic National Convention with her tart keynote speech and was the state's 45th governor until upset in 1994 by an underestimated challenger named George W. Bush, died Wednesday at her home in Austin. She was 73. Ms. Richard died, surrounded by her four children, of complications from the esophageal cancer, the Associated Press reported.
A picture caption in some copies yesterday about a New York City councilwoman who won a House seat from Brooklyn misspelled her surname. She is Yvette D. Clarke, not Clark.
''Simply stated, short of a crime, anything goes at the highest levels of the Department of the Interior.'' EARL E. DEVANEY,inspector general of the department. [A1]
To the Editor: Re ''Venezuela's Passion: Twisting the Tail of an Angry Beast'' (news article, Sept. 10):

Among the subplots of last night's 8-4 Yankees victory over Tampa Bay at Yankee Stadium was the audition for the fourth slot in the postseason rotation. Cory Lidle, the starter, had a chance to make his case. But Lidle failed to finish five innings, leaving with a two-run lead. His performance probably enhanced the chances of Jaret Wright, another starter, who will pitch Saturday against Boston.
GEFFNER--Lilyan, died September 12. Survived by her husband Leonard, her children Adrienne Star and Neal Geffner and sister Shirley Cohen. Funeral services were on Wednesday September 13.
To the Editor: Re ''Vice Must Wash Hands Before Returning to Work'' (column, Sept. 13):

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the selection of Garry F. McCarthy, New York City's top crime strategist, to head the Newark Police Department referred imprecisely to his role in Compstat, the data collection program for crime statistics. He did not help set it up; he helped put it into effect.

Rosie O'Donnell (far left, with Barbara Walters amid a shower of confetti on Sept. 6) tries to do for Mr. Letterman what she has done for ''The View.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

After a dry summer, the music industry needed a hit, and last week Beyoncé arrived like a superhero. Her new album, ''B'Day'' (Columbia), right, released on Sept. 5, has sold 564,000 copies, more than any album in four months, easily reaching No. 1 on the Billboard chart. Another new album, Audioslave's ''Revelations'' (Epic), opened at No. 2 with 142,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Bob Dylan's ''Modern Times'' (Columbia), last week's top seller -- and Mr. Dylan's first No. 1 album in 30 years -- dropped two spots to No. 3, with still-strong sales of 128,000. The girl group Danity Kane's self-titled album, on Bad Boy/Atlantic, was at No. 4; the ''Cheetah Girls'' soundtrack, on Disney, climbed one spot to No. 5; and Christina Aguilera's newest, ''Back to Basics'' (RCA), dropped two to No. 6. Iron Maiden reached the Top 10 for the first time in its three-decade history with ''A Matter of Life and Death'' (Sanctuary), which opened at No. 9 with 56,000 sales. BEN SISARIO

A United States Air Force major who disappeared for more than three days last week in Kyrgyzstan made her first public remarks, saying in an official statement in Germany that she was recovering and hoped to return soon to the United States. The major, Jill M. Metzger, vanished while shopping in Bishkek, the Kyrgyz capital. She resurfaced about 80 hours later, exhausted and with her hair cut and dyed, and telling the local police that she had escaped from kidnappers. Major Metzger said she needed privacy ''while I rest and try to get through this.'' C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

Matching an earlier condemnation of Israel, Amnesty International on Thursday accused Hezbollah forces of war crimes and ''serious violations of international humanitarian law'' during the Lebanon war, including indiscriminate rocket attacks and ''deliberate attacks on civilians and civilian objects.'' On Aug. 23 the group criticized Israel's behavior, saying its bombing campaign amounted to indiscriminate attacks on Lebanese civilians.

Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy minister, and Ali Larijani, the Iranian nuclear negotiator, postponed a meeting in Paris on Iran's enrichment program. Mr. Solana's office said both sides would instead hold a meeting ''at expert level.'' ''The meeting between Solana and Larijani was postponed because both sides agreed more time was needed,'' said Cristina Gallach, a spokeswoman for Mr. Solana. JUDY DEMPSEY (IHT)

The emerald necklace of Caribbean islands known as the Turks and Caicos are the ''it'' paradise: so close to the American mainland, and yet so exotic; so private -- but look, there's Bruce Willis's yacht! They have one of the world's greatest reefs, and beaches so white they might have been poured by Domino. Now a hotel impresario, Cem Kinay of the O Property Company, is adding famous architects to the mix. His $1 billion Dellis Cay resort and residential complex has a master plan and marina by Zaha Hadid, hotels by Piero Lissoni, villas by Shigeru Ban and David Chipperfield and a spa by Kengo Kuma.

SOKOLOW--Jack, M.D. September 11, 2006. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Devoted father of Steven (Abby) and Andrew (Crista); loving and adored grandfather of Brian and Becky, Michael and Daniel. He will always be remembered for his enthusiasm and his zest for life.

BELL--Elise Stone. Died September 6, 2006 in Flemington, NJ. Married 62 years to former Roslyn Mayor Bob Bell. Beloved mother of Robert, Wendy and Jean. Accomplished freelance writer. Founding member, Clock Tower Party. A memorial tree will be dedicated October 21st at 11 AM at Bryant Library 2 Paper Mill Road, Roslyn, NY 11576. Donations accepted. All are welcome!

Unesco has infuriated human rights organizations by awarding a medal to the widely criticized leader of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, left. The agency's director general, Koichiro Matsuura, quietly handed Mr. Karimov its Borobudur gold medal last Friday for ''strengthening friendship and cooperation between nations, development of cultural and religious dialogue, and supporting cultural diversity.'' Uzbekistan's government killed several hundred people in suppressing an uprising in the city of Andijon on May 13, 2005. The award was for Uzbekistan's contribution to preserving World Heritage sites, said Suzanne Bilello, a Unesco spokeswoman in New York. ILAN GREENBERG (NYT)

David Weeks, a designer who opened his Brooklyn studio in 1996, said his new Bound Rocker, below, is the final incarnation of an evolving project: it began as a modular couch with woven seats, and later he reworked it as a taller freestanding chair. He eventually arrived at the current version, he said, which works better because it is more comfortable and has a slightly more familiar shape.

''The Apple Tree,'' the 1966 Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick musical -- a collection of three one-act musicals, actually -- about men, women and the temptation that ensues, has found a home in Studio 54. The Roundabout Theater Company revival is based on the production in the 2004-5 season of City Center's Encores! series, which was directed by Gary Griffin (''The Color Purple'') and starred Kristin Chenoweth, above. Both are following the production to the Roundabout. Performances are scheduled to begin on Nov. 28, with an opening date set for Dec 14. Stephen Spinella, a Tony winner for his role in ''Angels in America'' and a recurring character on the television show ''24,'' will join the Broadway cast of ''Spring Awakening'' as the adult male lead. The producers also announced that the show's previews have been advanced one day and will begin Nov. 16. The opening is still set for Dec. 10 at the O'Neill Theater. Sarah Benson, the theater director who has been the associate artistic director of the SoHo Repertory Theater for the last two years, will become its artistic director, announced Jon Dembrow, chairman of the SoHo Rep board. Ms. Benson will take over from Daniel Aukin, the artistic director since 1999, who announced in May that he was leaving to pursue a freelance career as a director. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

MALLEY--Simon. Age 83. Egyptian - born journalist, founder and editor of Afrique Asie, long-term and passionate advocate for Third World causes, died at his home in Paris, France, on September 7th, 2006. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Barbara, his children Nadia, of Arlington, Virginia, Robert of Washington, DC, and Richard, of Beverly, Massachusetts; his grandchildren Christopher, Miles, Blaise, Bobby, Sasha and Frances; and his brother Edouard. The funeral will be held at the cimetiere du Pere Lachaise in Paris on September 15th and a reception to honor his memory will be held at the Institut du Monde Arabe in Paris on September 16th. Memorial contributions may be made to The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, Rene Aquarone, c/o UNRWA HQ Amman, PO Box 140157, Amman, 11814 Jordan or www.unwra.org.

For information Graham Funeral Home, Rye, (914) 967-0129.

ONE team is like New England clam chowder without enough clams, the other team is like Boston without Faneuil Hall and the Old North Church. The Patriots and the Red Sox will be visiting the Jets and the Yankees this weekend, but suddenly neither team is quite the same only two seasons after they ruled the Super Bowl and the World Series.

In Iraq's Grim Capital, Bodies Lie Everywhere Nearly 90 Iraqis were killed or found dead in Baghdad, an Interior Ministry official said, making for a grim day even amid the intense sectarian violence. Of the 60 bodies found, nearly all were shot in the head, had clear signs of torture or were blindfolded, bound or gagged. But American military officials, who have been challenging body counts, disputed the number found. At Saddam Hussein's trial, a prosecutor accused the judge of letting defendants ''treat the chamber as a political forum.'' PAGE A10 Wolfowitz Draws Criticism Critics say that Paul D. Wolfowitz, president of the World Bank, is taking an approach to fighting corruption in poor countries that is interfering with the bank's central mission. Richards of Texas, who galvanized the 1988 Democratic National Convention with her tart keynote speech and was later upset by a challenger named George W. Bush, was 73. IN the five years she has worked at fashion shows in New York, Paris and Milan, Fabiana Semprebom, a Ford model from Londrina, Brazil, has had her ear singed by a hair iron, her eye swollen shut by errant makeup, her scalp poked by bobby pins and her skin rubbed raw by repeated makeup application and removal. ''But the worst is when they glue on fake nails for the first show and rip them off at the next show. It hurts,'' said Ms. Semprebom, 22, as she settled into a chair backstage last Sunday at Fashion Week in New York. It was 7:30 a.m., and Ms. Semprebom was waiting to have her hair and makeup done for the Lela Rose show. ''By the end of the week, your nails look broken and cracked and you want to cut them very short,'' she said.

The studied restraint of Biedermeier offered ''an unpretentious style for those who could afford it,'' said Laurie Winters, curator of an exhibition on the 19th-century movement running Saturday through Jan. 1 at the Milwaukee Art Museum. Biedermeier designers also produced ornate wallcoverings, and as backdrops to the show Studio Printworks, a New York wallpaper company, has reproduced two 1827 wood-block prints as silk screens on vinyl: Lindenzweig, above left, a botanical in blue with black, and Biedermeier Plaid, in electric lime. Rolls 27 inches wide and 5 yards long are $120 and $200, respectively, at the museum store; 700 North Art Museum Drive, (414) 224-3210; mam.org. CRAIG KELLOGG

Sensing both political danger and opportunity, a top Democratic operative and a group of major party donors have banded together to deliver a barrage of late advertising and on-the-ground action to secure Democratic victories in November. The operative, Harold M. Ickes, a top aide to former President Bill Clinton and informal adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and a group of allies are soliciting money for a new organization called the September Fund.

ENGEL--Morton. September 9. A devoted husband, loving father, great sailor and successful ocean - racer. He achieved considerable success in the 1960s as skipper of the first Bermuda 40. In the 1970s he sailed with distinction in the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit. In sailing and in life he combined wideranging knowledge with creative problem-solving and an iconoclastic spirit. To friends and family he was a fixer in the best sense. Predeceased by his wife Barbara, he leaves two daughters, Susan and Patricia, and countless friends.

ZIFF--William B. Jr. Jeffrey Haber and employees at Acordia were deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Mr. William Ziff. Our sincere condolences to his family, his wonderful wife Ann and his remarkable sons, Dirk, Robert, and Daniel.

LEVINE--Carl S., a great man a giant loss, we are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and counsel. We will never forget all the good years we had together. Your memory will live on in our hearts forever. Our condolences to Louise, Evan, Josh, and Amanda. Love, Jesse, Peter, Stephen, and Jonathan Halperin $(6$)LEVINE--Carl. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member Carl Levine, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Louise and family. Old Westbury Golf and Country Club David Simon, President Steven Tolman, Secretary $(6$)LEVINE--Carl S. The Officers and employees of Spartan Petroleum Corp. mourn the passing of our dear friend Carl S. Levine. Our prayers go out to Louise and their children. Hank Alpert, President Ellen Roizen, Secretary

A subheading in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the expansion of an inquiry into accounting at Dell referred imprecisely to a recent product recall by the company. It recalled laptop batteries made by Sony, not the laptops themselves.

BLOOM--Doris T. On September 12, 2006. Beloved wife of Harold, mother of Jacky and Leslie, mother-in-law of Tom Mueller, grandmother of Jessie Mueller and sister of Martin Tekulsky. Her career as an occupational therapist spanned many years of work with children and geriatric patients. Contributions to Hospice Care Network. Services Friday 10am at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer'' (Queens Blvd and 76 Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the primary victories of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Spencer in New York omitted a word from a quotation from Mr. Spencer, the Republican nominee, in some copies. He said she was ''in for the fight of her life,'' not ''in the fight of her life.''

An obituary on Tuesday about Tom Suzuki, a graphic designer who revolutionized the appearance of textbooks, referred imprecisely to the history of the Chouinard Art Institute, where he studied, and misstated the name of its successor. Chouinard and the Los Angeles Conservatory of Music merged and became the California Institute of the Arts. Chouinard is not now the California School of Fine Arts.

AMICO--Joseph C., M.D. On September 12, 2006. Beloved husband of Mildred (nee Cassidy). Father of Paul, Joseph (Madelon), Phillip, Christopher (Kim) and Matthew. Cherished grandfather of seven. Attending physician for over 50 years at The Brooklyn Hospital; past-president of the Kings County Medical Society; president of 27 Prospect Park West Co-op Board. Funeral Saturday 9:15 AM from the McManus Funeral Home, 4601 Avenue N (corner East 46th St), Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10AM, St. Francis Xavier Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2:00-4:30PM and 7:00-9:00PM.

BOLT--Byron. His colleagues at the Harlem Educational Activities Fund note with profound sadness the sudden passing of Byron Bolt, a dear friend and devoted co-worker at HEAF since its inception. Byron's thoughtfulness, his kindliness and his unfailing dedication to HEAF were an inspiration to all. He will be warmly remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to his warm and loving family. Stephen Gessner, Chairman Danielle Moss Lee, President Daniel Rose, Chairman Emeritus

INTERIOR AGENCY CRITICIZED -- The inspector general of the Interior Department accused top agency officials of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence, and then dismissing criticisms with ''a promise not to do it again.'' [Page A1.] GOOGLE'S APPROACH TO CHARITY -- Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin, founders of Google, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming. But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit, allowing it to fund start-up companies, form partnerships with venture capitalists, and even lobby Congress. It will also pay taxes. [A1.] WOLFOWITZ'S CORRUPTION FIGHT -- As president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, and he has drawn criticism for an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to countries including India, Chad and Bangladesh. [C1.] U.S. WARNS CHINA -- In the administration's toughest warning yet to China on economic issues, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that Chinese leaders were imperiling their nation's future by engaging in policies that Americans and others see as unfair. [C3.] NINTENDO TO RELEASE CONSOLE -- Nintendo of Japan plans to announce that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States. The move may allow Nintendo to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, Sony. [C1.] MICROSOFT VS. HACKER -- A solitary computer hacker has entangled Microsoft in a battle of wits by repeatedly releasing a free program to strip away the software lock that the company created to protect digital movies and songs from being freely copied by Internet users. [C5.] HIGH HOPES FOR ONLINE GAME -- AOL and Mark Burnett, producer for reality television, kicked off an ambitious online game called ''Gold Rush,'' which they hope will become a national sensation somewhat on par with the one Mr. Burnett created six years ago with the ''Survivor'' series. [C3.] STRONG EARNINGS AT LEHMAN -- Lehman posted strong third-quarter results amid weak markets, lackluster deal flow and higher global interest rates, and its shares surged. [C13.] MARKETS RISE -- Stocks rose, sending major indexes to their highest levels since May, as battered energy shares like Exxon Mobil rebounded and investors bet that interest rates would not rise any time soon. [C13.] ROUGH TIME FOR NISSAN CHIEF -- Despite Carlos Ghosn's gilded reputation, his companies, Renault and its partner, Nissan Motor Corporation, are not performing well right now -- a fact their boss readily acknowledges. [C1.] CHICAGO WAGE EFFORT FAILS -- The first attempt in the nation to impose minimum wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled as Chicago's City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto. [A18.] PLAN FOR JOBLESS INSURANCE -- The unemployment insurance system, which has hardly changed since its inception in 1935, should be revamped to aid more workers displaced by a transforming economy, economists said as they released overhaul plans. [A21.] HELP FOR WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS -- Barbara Ehrenreich, author of ''Nickel and Dimed,'' has started an organization called United Professionals to help white-collar workers, be they unemployed, uninsured, downsized, stressed out or merely anxious. [A21.] H.P. AND SPYING CASE -- California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing on a small private investigation firm operating out of a house in suburban Boston. It is not clear how such a tiny firm ended up handling work for H.P., one of the largest technology companies. But other private investigators said it was not surprising, because corporations who are in need of such services often end rely on subcontractors. [C1.] TRIAL SET FOR DIRECT MARKETER -- The lawsuit in which the coupon company Valassis Communications seeks to cancel its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December, a judge ruled. [C5.] ONLINE A BANK REBUILDS -- Gary Rivlin of The Times spoke with chief executive of Liberty Bank, Alden J. McDonald Jr., about struggling to rebuild after Hurricane Katrina. An audio report is at nytimes.com/business. ETHANOL USE -- As proponents of ethanol push for its use, Alexei Barrionuevo of The Times went on a road trip through the Midwest to find out how available the fuel is to the American driver. His report is at nytimes.com/business. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. AIRBUS MAY DELAY DELIVERY of its A380 airliner by more than a year amid rising production costs, said Mike Turner, chief executive of BAE Systems, which owns 20 percent of Airbus. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE SUN-TIMES MEDIA GROUP, formerly Hollinger International Inc., said its chief executive, Gordon Paris, would step down at the end of the year as the newspaper publishing company shifts all of its New York-based corporate functions to Chicago. (AP)

INTERNATIONAL A3-17 90 Killed or Found Dead On a Grim Day in Baghdad Nearly 90 Iraqis were killed or found dead in Baghdad, an Iraqi Interior Ministry official said, making for a particularly grim day even amid the intense sectarian violence that has gripped the capital. A10 Shooting at Montreal College A man carrying an automatic rifle shot and killed a woman and wounded 19 other people, several critically, at the campus of a junior college in Montreal. The gunman died after exchanging shots with police. A17 Resistance to Rape Law The Pakistani government has run into difficulties, including a postponed vote, in its efforts to pass a law to end the worst abuses suffered by women who report rape or are accused of adultery under an Islamic ordinance. A8 Report Criticizes Hezbollah Amnesty International accused Hezbollah of war crimes and ''serious violations of international humanitarian law'' during the Lebanon war. In August the group criticized Israel's behavior during the war. A17 Chinese Storm Claims Disputed China's emergency response to Typhoon Saomai in August was trumpeted as a triumph. But an internal report by the official New China News Agency, compiled in the days after the storm and intended just for the authorities, bluntly contradicted the official picture. A3 NATIONAL A18-25 Some Movement Is Seen On National Security Plans The White House took a critical step in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects being held at Guantánamo Bay. A1 Pet Projects Rule Is Delayed Leaders of the House of Representatives postponed consideration of a rule requiring individual lawmakers to sign their names to some of the pet projects they tuck into major tax and spending bills. A22 Big-Box Wage Rule Fails The first efforts to impose minimum-wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled in Chicago, as its City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto of the measure. A18 Push to Repeal Military Law Gay rights groups are making the biggest push in nearly a decade to repeal a 1993 law, known as ''Don't Ask, Don't Tell,'' that bars openly gay people from serving in the military. A18 Border Fence Plan in House House Republicans announced that they would move swiftly to pass legislation requiring the Bush administration to build 700 miles of fencing along the Mexican border to help stem the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs. A24 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 An Immigrant's Tale Turns Out to Be Just That Genealogical researchers have uncovered the truth about Annie Moore, the immigrant memorialized by bronze statues in New York Harbor and in Ireland. She was indeed the first immigrant to set foot on Ellis Island -- but she did not, as legend has it, go to Texas, marry a descendant of the Irish liberator Daniel O'Connell and die under the wheels of a streetcar. A1 A Letter From a Priest A letter written in 1984 by Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh, the former chief fund-raiser for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, to the parents of a man who accuses the priest of abusing him as a teenager has resurfaced. The man says the letter shows that Monsignor Kavanagh touched him in a sexual manner. B1 Thoughts on Longevity Asian women in Bergen County, N.J., -- who live longer than any other ethnic subgroup of people anywhere in the nation, according to federal statistics -- attribute their longevity to a healthy diet, belief in God and their close-knit communities. B1 OBITUARIES D8 Governor Ann Richards The former governor of Texas, a witty and flamboyant Democrat who went from homemaker to national political celebrity, she was 73. D8 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Interior Department Ethics The Interior Department's inspector general, Earl E. Devaney, responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations, accused the top officials at the agency of tolerating widespread ethical failures. A1 Google Founders' Charity The founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion. But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Port security won't bankrupt us; extreme tuberculosis; Verlyn Klinkenborg on the death of a farmer. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge: E9 TV Listings: E11 Crossword: E8 Weather: D7

Because of an editing error, a music review on Tuesday about John Zorn and four ensembles at the oy!hoo festival, also known as the New York Jewish Music and Heritage Festival, referred incorrectly to a laptop computer improviser who performed. The improviser, Ikue Mori, is a woman.

IT'S a yin-yang, masculine-feminine moment, in the home as on the runways. ''The hard and the ruffly,'' said Stephen Sills, the New York decorator, referring to current trends in decorating. ''There's no middle ground now.''

ABC waltzed to the top Tuesday night, led by a healthy third-season start for ''Dancing With the Stars.'' The two-hour premiere drew 20.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, up 2.6 million over last season's premiere and helping to install the new Anne Heche series, ''Men in Trees,'' at No. 1 for 10 p.m. with 12.2 million viewers over all (although the audience declined considerably throughout the hour). On Fox, ''House'' had another strong showing, making it No. 1 at 8 among adults 18 to 49 and second in total viewers (15 million). Meanwhile, the fierce competition in that hour tamped down the ratings for Mike Malin's victory on the finale of CBS's ''Big Brother: All-Stars'' (8.4 million). At 9, the new Fox series ''Standoff'' posted 9.2 million viewers, but it was edged aside for No. 2 among adults 18 to 49 behind the penultimate episode of CBS's ''Rock Star: Supernova'' (7.1 million). A repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.8 million) at 10 fared better than the network's other offerings for the night: the ''Fear Factor'' finale at 8 (4.7 million) and a repeat of ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' at 9 (6.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

LEBRECHT--Ilse. Passed away peacefully at her home on September 9. Beloved cousin and friend. We will always remember her vitality and zest for life. Services private. Donations to the Leukemia Society of America, or Alzheimer's Association.

Palestinian cabinet members submitted their resignations Wednesday night to allow for the creation of a national unity government that is expected to include a broad range of factions, Palestinian officials said. The new government may not be in place for weeks, and it is not clear whether Western countries will be prepared to restore assistance that was halted when the militant Islamic movement Hamas came to power earlier this year.

An obituary on Tuesday about Charles Aug, a pioneer broker of retail real estate, referred incorrectly to one of his places of residence. South Beach is a section of the city of Miami Beach, not an incorporated area in Florida.

With autumn coming, it's almost time to rake and bag leaves. Many people use biodegradable paper bags that can tip over and spill the leaves. To avoid this awkwardness, Bart Mulle, a homeowner in Hammond, Ind. (and a casino dealer by profession), has designed a simple solution: the Yard Bag Chute, a polypropylene and plastic insert that fits inside standard paper leaf bags, keeping them rigid as they are filled. With the bag on its side, leaves can be raked in directly.

The viewing patterns for the three main network newscasts remained in flux on Tuesday night, with the ''CBS Evening News With Katie Couric'' effectively reclaiming the electronic version of the yellow jersey. It finished in first place over all on Tuesday, compared with third place the night before, followed by ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' and ''World News With Charles Gibson'' on ABC. Ms. Couric's program was seen by an estimated 8.6 million viewers on Tuesday, while Mr. Williams was watched by about 8.1 million and Mr. Gibson by about 7.9 million, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research released by CBS. Ms. Couric's audience on Tuesday was substantially smaller than it was, on average, last week, her first on the evening news, but it remains more than a million larger than what the ''CBS Evening News'' had been drawing in recent months and years. JACQUES STEINBERG

An Australian academic who was given a $625,000 grant by a federal agency for a study on terrorism and suicide bombers has modified his proposal after the attorney general warned him that his research might run afoul of new antiterrorism laws. The academic, Riaz Hassan, a retired professor of sociology at The Flinders University of South Australia, planned to interview leaders of organizations like Hezbollah, Hamas and Jemaah Islamiyah in Indonesia. The attorney general, Philip Ruddock, said the interviews might violate laws that make it a crime to associate with terrorists. RAYMOND BONNER (NYT)

WHEN Matt Unger married a few years ago, he gave his groomsmen Leatherman multitools. ''Some friends use them while camping or fishing,'' said Mr. Unger, a 39-year-old filmmaker in Manhattan, ''but otherwise they sit in drawers or glove compartments.'' Such is the conundrum of the multitool. It's a useful -- but often unused -- gadget.

Up ahead, a huge logging truck was turned on its side. Beside it, stuck deep into a muddy hole was another car. Some people had been waiting for five days for the car to be moved.

In my essay for this contest, I wrote about seeing Kevin Carter's Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph of a vulture preying on a Sudanese girl. Later, people asked if Carter was really helping the girl by taking her picture, and in my essay, I said I wanted to be able to make decisions like that for myself.

Only about one in seven Democrats voted in the New York primary on Tuesday. That's not surprising, since the results turned out to be predictable and a consensus appeared to have formed early in every race. In fact, every candidate selected by the Democratic convention last June was nominated.

We are planning a trip to Vietnam and would like to fly directly to Bangkok from New York for a three-week trip, but then fly home via a two- or three-week stopover in Paris. I have heard about the financial advantages of buying tickets in Bangkok. We will have assistance getting from Bangkok to Vietnam, but it's getting to Thailand, then Paris and back to New York that has me stumped. - Amy Schachter, New York

The big surprise for many in today's data was a 0.1 percent decline in industrial production in August. The consensus forecast was for an increase of 0.2 percent.

Everybody's been talking about Senator Barack Obama's foray into Iowa this weekend and what that portends for 2008 aspirations/ambitions/testing of the waters, etc. On the heels of his trip to Africa, where he was followed like a rock star, the buzz keeps growing around him.

Congressman Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, entered a plea agreement with federal prosecutors this week, admitting that he made false statements, conspired to commit fraud and violated lobbying laws in the sprawling Abramoff corruption investigation.
On scandals, gaffes and politicians' troubles:

Perhaps President Bush, who has been said to have an off-the-charts emotional I.Q., has the Clintonian (or Lyndon Baines Johnsonian) ability to allow visitors to walk away from a conversation having heard want they wanted to hear. Washington Post columnist David Ignatius sits down with Bush in the Oval Office for a "one-on-one interview" and concludes, "I came away with a sense that Bush is serious about finding a peaceful solution to the nuclear crisis, and that he is looking hard for ways to make connections between America and Iran."

Ohio Representative Bob Ney decided not to announce his plea bargain in the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal until late Thursday, after the special Ohio primary to pick his replacement on the ballot, but we doubt that would have really changed the outcome. The most well known candidate, the one he endorsed, state Senator Joy Padgett, won easily.

The Times told readers last spring that Google had decided to stop being the outsider, and go full force into the ultimate insider's game of lobbying. In that article, we mentioned the Republican heavy-hitters, among them the DCI group well-connected to Karl Rove and Ken Mehlman, as well as bipartisan firms they were hiring, PodestaMattoon among them. At that time, they were considering setting up a a political action committee, but were a bit hesitant. Most of their donations in the '04 cycle had been to Democrats, and they'd been counseled since to be more bipartisan.
Vampires come alive at night. Frankly, they have no choice. This has its advantages...
