Schering-Plough is considering a merger with Bristol-Myers Squibb in what would be a union of two pharmaceuticals giants, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported, citing "three people with direct knowledge of Schering-Plough's deliberations."

National Portrait GalleryIt wasn't that long ago that the portrait of former President Bill Clinton, in a striking pose, was unveiled at the White House. But for some insight into how past presidents viewed their portraits, and the portraits themselves, the National Portrait Gallery offers a great glimpse of this particular art form in the newly renovated Patent Office Building in Washington, D.C.
Pedro Martinez struggled in his first start in more than a month and the New York Mets missed a chance to clinch the N.L. East on their own.
The elements of men's style according to Kevin Harter of Bloomingdale's.
With Congress and the executive branch regularly clashing over national security and other issues, constitutional questions are the stuff that today's headlines are made of.
About 155 athletes from 14 countries are competing in the World Barefoot Water Ski Championships.
Guidant, the maker of implanted heart devices, settled a fraud suit over its recalled defibrillator for an undisclosed amount, a plaintiffs' lawyer said yesterday.
Air America is denying intense rumors that the ratings-challenged progressive radio network will declare bankruptcy this week and attempt to reorganize to stay on the air for the November elections.

The billionaire tycoon Ricardo Salinas Pliego and the Securities and Exchange Commission of the United States reached a settlement on Thursday in the first lawsuit against a foreign company under the corporate governance rules of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

Peter Dicks, chairman of the online gambling site Sportingbet, resigned Thursday, within minutes of a court ruling in New York City that he could leave the United States. The company's shares rose 25 percent in London.
Word of mouth is one crucial marketing tool for a lawyer. Getting your name on a list of top lawyers can be another, unless the list is distributed to consumers in New Jersey.
Ted Leonsis, the boisterous entrepreneur turned sports mogul who has been a top leader of AOL for 13 years, will give up his management responsibilities at the end of the year.

A state judge on Thursday refused to remove himself from the civil action by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, to recover part of the compensation package of the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso.
The tangled web of Hewlett-Packard's snooping scandal has taken another twist, as prosecutors try to unwind the threads that may eventually lead to criminal indictments.

No one doubts that the murder of Andrei Kozlov, the deputy chairman of the Russian Central Bank who was gunned down in Moscow, was a contract killing, linked to his key position at the Central Bank, BusinessWeek says.

A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that the accounting firm KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals.
Vornado Realty Trust late Thursday said that it has agreed to buy up to 44 previously closed Toys "R" Us stores for as much as $190 million.
CCMP Capital Advisors, which spun out from J.P. Morgan Chase in August, has inked a deal to acquire standby generator provider Generac Power Systems.
AIG Global Investment Group, an investment arm of insurance concern American International Group, has closed its first co-investment fund at $664.4 million, exceeding its $500 million target.

With the goal of making solar power as easy to buy as satellite dishes, SolarCity, a provider of solar power installation and maintenance services, has raised $10 million in its first round of funding.

Shortly after Amicus Therapeutics canceled its attempt at going public, venture investors have poured $60 million in fourth-round funding into the Cranbury, N.J.-based maker of drugs that treat genetic enzyme deficiencies.
Kryptiq has closed a $6.57 million Series C round and is positioning its software products to take advantage of widespread technology upgrades amid the health care industry.

Doughty Hanson, a London-based buyout firm, plans to raise 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion) in an initial public offering of a private equity fund, following rivals Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management.

A former head of BAWAG, the Austrian bank linked to the collapse last year of the New York commodities brokerage Refco, was arrested Thursday in France on fraud charges, the Austrian authorities said.
The private placement market has exploded globally in recent years, attracting a wider array of issuers from a multitude of countries.
U.S. diagnostic test maker Cytyc launched a A$497 million ($374 million) bid for Australia's Vision Systems, topping a rival offer by Ventana Medical Systems and driving up Vision's shares.
Over the last three years, the stocks of the five largest publicly traded radio companies are down between 30 percent and 60 percent as investors wonder when the industry will bottom out.

The Ford Motor Company announce today that it will delay selling brands or other assets until Alan Mulally, who succeeded Chairman William Clay Ford Jr. as chief executive officer this month, has a chance to study such proposals, Bloomberg News reported.
Aviator style takes off.

U.S. court has denied miner NovaGold Resources' request for an injunction to halt a $1.5 billion hostile takeover by Barrick Gold but acknowledged that the two have a "genuine dispute" over terms of the proposed acquisition.

Tribune and California's Chandler family are close to unwinding two controversial partnerships at the heart of the boardroom battle that has roiled the company since early June, The Chicago Tribune reported.
MAN, a German maker of commercial vehicles, may offer 9.4 billion euros ($11.9 billion) for rival Scania to become the region's biggest truckmaker, Bloomberg News said.
Intercontinental Exchange, an electronic energy market whose shares have risen 78 percent this year, agreed yesterday to acquire the New York Board of Trade for about $1 billion in cash and stock.
Power producer Dynegy said Friday it would merge with privately held LS Power Group in a deal valued at more than $2.3 billion.

Rupert Murdoch, who spent nearly two decades coveting an American satellite broadcaster before acquiring control of the DirecTV Group three years ago, is now in talks to trade his stake to the financer John C. Malone in return for Mr. Malone's stake in Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, according to press reports.
After months of tangling with state regulators, Exelon threw up its hands and abandoned its $17.8 billion purchase of New Jersey's Public Service Enterprise Group.

Known for their secrecy, hedge funds have for some time been fighting against efforts to impose stricter regulations and demands for more transparency in the industry. So it is not without some irony that one such fund is going willingly into the fray that is the public market.

The first case studies have already been assigned at many of the nation's business schools, as the latest class of M.B.A. students reports for duty. For two years, they will pore over management models and income statements in hopes of earning a job in finance or management.

Now that the big kids are firmly installed in their classrooms, the small ones are monopolizing the
spotlight in clothes that are clearly too cool for school.
Photographs by Hiroshi Sugimoto of Richard Serra's sculpture "Joe."
Our homeowners' association has not held an annual meeting in more than five years. How can we get the board to hold a meeting?
A 1901 landmark, a country colonial and more.

ESPN has tried to convince us that Monday is the biggest day of the football week, when we all know Sunday is clearly better. But fans in large pockets of the country still build their schedule around Saturday, and this week is for them.
Giorgio Armani is the world's richest designer, and yet retirement is not an option.

It is recommended that you go here, scroll down and listen to a few music samples from NFL Films (my favorites are Roundup, Raiders and Classic Battle) before viewing the rankings. It helps set the mood. To go a step further, to goosebump level, watch and listen to this, as the Raiders and the Steelers seemingly try to kill each other (Note: Jack Tatum is not the one delivering that vicious clothesline hit about halfway through. He's No. 32).
About 50 colleges across the country have a six-year graduation rate below 20 percent - numbers that have prompted a debate in education circles about who is to blame.
Extreme sportswear shows some skin.
Peter Scanavino's approach to his instrument-no muss, no fuss.

Communic8 Yr Personality
Communica8 yr personality with accessories that feel as gr8 as they look.
Casey Parks gets her first real taste of travel in Africa: a dirt track through the rain forest of Cameroon. (Produced by: Naka Nathaniel)
Limited almost exclusively to tourist attractions, this documentary glimpse at the sights and sounds of occupied Tibet amounts to a rhetorically inflated vacation video.
Patricia Foulkrod’s documentary about the war in Iraq stands out as an especially pointed indictment of the American military’s treatment of its own people on and off the battlefield.
This dark British comedy exudes the comfy familiarity of a vintage episode of “Alfred Hitchcock Presents” stretched into a feature-length film.
Using archival clips and talking-head interviews, this documentary makes the case that John Lennon was a much better person than Richard Nixon.
Tony Goldwyn’s remake of a popular Italian film is thin and clumsy, but nonetheless unusually candid in its treatment of human sexual misbehavior.
Animated in name only, “Everyone’s Hero” follows a 10-year-old baseball fanatic who finds himself in possession of Babe Ruth’s stolen bat.
Class, race and preposterous narrative contrivance mix it up in the Cayman Islands in this non-linear nonsense from the producer of “Crash.”
Jumping from heartwarming to murderous, this sports-as-rehab movie wants to have its lawlessness and cure it, too.
Brian De Palma drains the life out of James Ellroy's take on the spectacularly cruel 1947 murder of a young Los Angeles woman known as the Black Dahlia.
Anyone who has cringed while watching the home movies of newlyweds bumbling through their own corny, personalized nuptials will appreciate the comic potential of this British mock documentary
Based on a 1976 play by Allen Swift, “Checking Out” is stagy, stiff and marinated in egg cream.
Miserable in Minneapolis, a damaged slacker (Joshua Jackson)finds his life heating up when he connects with the nurse (Juliette Lewis) looking after his grandfather.
How long must we nod knowingly at Virgil Thomson’s dismissal of the New York Philharmonic in 1940 as being irrelevant to the intellectual life of the city?
Officials continued to investigate an outbreak of E. coli bacteria that has so far claimed one life and sickened more than 90 people in 20 states.
The violent city will be  sealed off with a series of trenches and traffic checkpoints to control movement in and out.
Muslim leaders around the world accused Pope Benedict XVI of dividing religions and demanded an apology.
Representative Bob Ney pleaded guilty to two charges related to his dealings with the lobbyist Jack Abramoff.
Oriana Fallaci was a dissecting interviewer of the powerful and an iconoclastic journalist.
The Republican candidate for attorney general sharply criticized her husband for causing trouble once again.
The president made it clear that he is not abandoning the main pillars of his anti-terrorism agenda despite opposition by key Republican senators.
A prosecutor said today that John A. Gotti’s defense of having quit the Mafia was an elaborate ruse.
Also, a senior Palestinian intelligence officer and four others were shot to death in their car on Friday in Gaza.
A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.
Ford said that it would cut 10,000 more salaried jobs, close two more factories and eliminate its stock dividend.
Steve Slaton’s speed and Maryland’s sloppiness turned West Virginia’s first anticipated test of the season into a laugher.
The American cyclist Tyler Hamilton faced a new doping investigation, less than two weeks before his two-year suspension for blood doping is lifted.
The Asian tribe won the first “Survivor: Cook Islands” challenge: puzzle solving. The black tribe came in last. Oops.
Hewlett-Packard’s use of a Boston-based group to investigate suspected news leaks provides an intriguing geographic link for prosecutors.
Rupert Murdoch is said to be in talks with the financer John C. Malone to trade his stake in the DirecTV Group.
The former New Jersey Senate president, John A. Lynch Jr., is expected to plead guilty to charges of tax evasion and misusing his public office.
Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign seemed happy to face a conservative Republican, which may highlight her fight against those allied to the Bush administration.
The airstrike that killed four United Nations observers in July was the result of inaccurate maps, Israel said in a report.
A makeshift lineup led by Hideki Matsui’s home run and Robinson Canó’s three runs batted in won the game for the Yankees, their sixth victory in a row.

The former head of Bawag, the Austrian bank linked to last year’s collapse of the commodities brokerage firm Refco, was arrested in France on fraud charges, Austrian authorities said. French authorities took the former executive, Helmut Elsner, who was Bawag’s general manager, into custody at his villa in southern France, a Justice Ministry spokesman told the Austria Press Agency. Bawag, the acronym for Bank Für Arbeit und Wirtschaft A.G., has been under investigation for lending the former chief executive of Refco, Phillip Bennett, several hundred million dollars just before Refco filed for bankruptcy in October.

The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, an energy exploration and production company, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian unit for about $4.24 billion to Canadian Natural Resources, partly to pay off debt associated with its acquisition of the Kerr McGee Corporation and Western Gas Resources. The sale excludes Anadarko’s interests in the Mackenzie Delta and other Arctic frontier properties, which remain for sale. Tom Covington, an analyst with A. G. Edward, said Anadarko was trading out lower-growth properties for higher-growth properties acquired from Kerr McGee and Western Gas.

Petróleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian energy company known as Petrobras, canceled a meeting of its executives and Bolivian government officials after Bolivia took steps this week to take over the company’s oil operations in the country. Petrobras said the Bolivian measures, which included the takeover of two refineries, the only ones in Bolivia, and its distribution system, would render its Bolivian operations “unviable.” The meeting had been scheduled for Friday.

Iamgold, a Canadian mining company, said that it would buy Cambior, a rival, for about 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion) in stock, to create a gold mining operation with more than one million ounces of annual production. The deal will push Iamgold to the top of the midtier gold producers and comes six months after the miner bought Gallery Gold of Australia. “We believe it sets the stage for us to join the senior ranks as we move forward in this company,” Iamgold’s chief executive, Joe Conway, left, said.
The vaccination rate for black children in the United States has caught up to that of youngsters in other racial groups.

The number of illegal immigrants who died crossing into the United States from Mexico more than doubled from 1995 to 2005, according to the Government Accountability Office, the nonpartisan investigative arm of Congress. Most of the deaths occurred from heat exposure in the Arizona desert, as more immigrants avoided urban areas like San Diego and El Paso that have tough border-security efforts. The federal auditors also found there was little evidence that the Border Patrol’s efforts to reduce the number of deaths had been successful.

The Supreme Court will post transcripts of oral arguments on its Web site the same day they occur, beginning in October. The change, long desired by court watchers, comes as Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. begins his second term at the head of the court. The court occasionally has made available audio tapes on the day of argument in major cases. Usually, however, arguments have been transcribed from audio recordings and made available roughly two weeks later.

A judge struck down the state’s new voter identification law as an unconstitutional infringement on the right to vote. The law required voters to show a federal or Missouri-issued photo ID at the polls. The judge, Richard Callahan of Cole County Circuit Court, said that was an unconstitutional burden on voters because the paperwork required to get those ID’s was not free. In Georgia, a federal judge blocked that state from enforcing its voter identification law during local special elections next week. Georgia’s law requires voters show a valid form of government-issued identification.

The legislature overstepped its authority when it fired the entire Public Service Commission over a steep utility rate increase, the state’s highest court ruled. Under the 6-to-1 ruling by the Court of Appeals, four of the five commissioners will keep their jobs; the fifth has quit. The General Assembly, controlled by Democrats, fired the commission in June. That prompted a veto by Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican who appointed four of the five members and backed the panel in the face of an impending rate increase of 72 percent. Lawmakers overrode the veto.

The widow of a Nevada soldier killed in Afghanistan has won state approval to place a Wiccan religious symbol, a five-pointed star inside a circle, on his memorial plaque, something the federal Department of Veterans Affairs has refused to do. The woman, Roberta Stewart, said she was “honored and ecstatic.” Her husband, Sgt. Patrick Stewart of Fernley, died last September. Sergeant Stewart, 34, was a follower of the Wiccan religion, which the Department of Veterans Affairs does not recognize. State officials concluded that federal officials had no authority over state veterans’ cemeteries.

About 100 people were evacuated in Southern Illinois after a freight train derailed, including three tankers carrying chemicals, a Marion County sheriff’s official said. The tankers were being examined for leaks after the derailment north of Salem, a town of about 6,000 residents 70 miles east of St. Louis. There were no immediate reports of injuries, the authorities said. A Canadian National spokesman, Jim Kvedaras, said two derailed tankers contained phosphoric acid. He did not know what was in the third tanker.
The move will allow Intercontinental Exchange to expand into nonenergy commodities for the first time.

For the second time in two months, Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for attorney general, was charged yesterday with speeding — this time for driving 51 miles an hour in a 25-mile-an-hour zone in White Plains.
By The Associated Press.
The Yankees invited pitching phenom Phil Hughes and two other Trenton pitchers to work out with the team and get acclimated to the Yankees’ locker room this week.

Two more men were charged in connection with an investigation into an alleged terrorist recruitment network, the police said. They were among 14 arrested across London in overnight raids on Sept. 1. The two latest charges bring to 12 the number of suspects charged in connection with the investigation. The remaining two have been released without charge. Both of them will appear before the City of Westminster Magistrates’ Court today.
New city data showed that the number of rodent exterminations has plummeted, and more than 30 percent of city streets are not in good condition.

A journalist in Turkmenistan for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, who had recently been convicted in a closed trial of possessing ammunition, died in prison under unexplained circumstances, her family learned. The journalist, Ogulsapar Muradova, 58, had been sentenced to six years in prison on Aug. 28, after a swift trial in which she had no lawyer. Her supporters said she had been the victim of fabricated charges in one of the world’s most repressive regimes. Her two adult daughters were taken to a morgue in the capital, Ashgabat, and given their mother’s body. Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty said in a statement that Ms. Muradova appeared to have suffered a head injury.
A plane evacuating a 71-year-old stroke victim took off for Taiwan from China, the first direct medical flight since the island and the mainland severed ties in 1949.

A Syrian man arrested in connection with a foiled plot to blow up commuter trains has been released, the German general prosecutor said in a statement. Fadi al-Saleh, 23, had been suspected of helping two Lebanese men to place two suitcase bombs on trains in the cities of Dortmund and Koblenz on July 31. The federal court in Karlsruhe cited lack of evidence against Mr. Saleh as it ordered his release.

Ban Ki-moon, South Korea’s foreign minister, won for the second time in a Security Council straw poll of announced candidates to succeed Kofi Annan as secretary general. As in the first secret balloting of the 15 Council members on July 24, Mr. Ban was first, Shashi Tharoor of India, the under secretary general for communications, was second, and Surakiart Sathirathai, Thailand’s deputy prime minister, was third. Fourth was Prince Zeid al-Hussein, Jordan’s ambassador to the United Nations, who announced his candidacy last week, and fifth was Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, former under secretary general for disarmament. More candidates are expected to enter the contest, which will be decided in October when the Council is to recommend one name to the General Assembly for ratification.

Eighteen Hamas lawmakers who were ordered released from Israeli military prisons on Tuesday will remain in custody at least until next week while military prosecutors appeal the ruling, an Israeli military court in the West Bank said. It scheduled a hearing on Monday for the lawmakers including the speaker of the Palestinian parliament, Aziz Dweik, and three cabinet ministers. Israel has arrested about 40 Hamas legislators and cabinet ministers in the West Bank since Palestinian militants, including members of Hamas’s armed wing, seized an Israeli soldier on June 25 and took him to the Gaza Strip. Israel, which classifies Hamas as a terrorist group, arrested the men for belonging to an illegal organization.

Ukraine’s new prime minister, Viktor F. Yanukovich, said that he was putting off trying to join NATO but that he would press on for membership in the European Union. “Because of the political situation in Ukraine, we will now have to take a pause,” he said after a meeting at NATO headquarters during his first visit to Brussels after becoming prime minister. He said membership in NATO would be submitted to a referendum once the country had undergone political and economic reforms. Analysts and NATO officials said Mr. Yanukovich’s statement should not be interpreted as a sign that Ukraine was being pulled back into Moscow’s orbit or distancing itself from the West.
Prosecutors say they suspect San Diego Chargers linebacker Steve Foley was on steroids when he was shot three times by an off-duty police officer earlier this month.
Comcast said it will make eight CBS prime-time series available to customers through its on-demand service at no extra cost.

Closing arguments began yesterday in Federal District Court in the racketeering trial of John A. Gotti, with prosecutors saying that Mr. Gotti’s claim that he quit the Gambino crime family in 1999 was no more than a scheme to avoid a long prison sentence. Miriam E. Rocah, a federal prosecutor, said that Mr. Gotti, left, devised the plan while in federal prison from 1999 to 2004 on unrelated racketeering charges. Mr. Gotti’s defense is that he retired from the Mafia before mid-July 1999, a time frame that would protect him from prosecution because of the five-year statute of limitations on the racketeering charges. But the government contends that Mr. Gotti had known that his prison conversations with visitors at Ray Brook federal penitentiary were being recorded, and that was why Mr. Gotti told people that he wanted to leave “the life” behind him.

Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have prohibited admission or other fees at the World Trade Center memorial, museum or visitor center, his office said yesterday. Mr. Pataki said the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation could not rule out charging the public, given what he estimated would be the $50 million annual cost of operating a memorial and museum at ground zero. State Senator Martin J. Golden, the Brooklyn Republican who introduced the bill, had said “there should be no barriers,” including fees, that would prevent people from paying their respects.

Police Director Jose Cordero said 76 people, including 53 who were members of the Bloods or Crips gangs, were charged with various drug offenses. Mr. Cordero said 106 envelopes of heroin, 376 bags and 13 vials of cocaine and 75 bags of marijuana were seized after a two-month investigation.

The state police charged a Long Island truck driver with careless driving and equipment violations yesterday, a month after an accident on the New Jersey Turnpike that killed four people. The trucker, Dimitrios S. Tseperkas, will not face criminal charges, the state police said. Mr. Tseperkas was hauling a load of bricks and traveling at 70 miles per hour on Aug. 14 when he encountered traffic congestion, said Sgt. Stephen Jones, a state police spokesman. The truck slammed into several vehicles, killing three members of a Queens family and a South Jersey woman.

Two New Jersey horses were euthanized last week after contracting mosquito-borne illnesses, state agricultural officials said. One horse, a 14-year-old mare in Middlesex County, became ill with West Nile virus on Sept. 6 and was euthanized the next day. A 6-year-old mare in Burlington County was destroyed on Saturday after Eastern encephalitis was diagnosed the day before. Both diseases affect the brain tissue; neither can be transmitted to humans from horses.

The police said yesterday that they had dismantled a crack cocaine network that operated in three Far Rockaway public housing developments. They said 81 people had been arrested on drug-related charges, including a man alleged to be a local leader of the Crips gang. The police continue to search for 15 more people connected to the drug ring, which the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, described as operating “like a retail sales business.”.

A woman breast-feeding her 7-month-old son in a Toys “R” Us store in Times Square on Monday said yesterday that she was asked by staff members to move to the basement or leave. “There were three or four women standing over me at one time, harassing me,” said the mother, Chelsi Meyerson, 29, of Brooklyn. “I’ve never experienced such treatment while breast-feeding. I’ve received looks before, but I’ve never been humiliated or confronted.” The New York Civil Liberties Union asked for a meeting with the officials from the toy chain yesterday, said Donna Lieberman, the executive director. A representative of the store said there was a private area for breast-feeding mothers and denied that employees had asked Ms. Meyerson to leave.

A 64-year-old Staten Island man died this month of West Nile virus, city health officials said yesterday. It is the year’s first fatal case involving a city resident. The man, from Port Richmond, died on Sept. 1 while on a trip to Tennessee, his wife said. Neither the city health department nor the man’s widow would authorize the release of his name. The health department said it was not clear where the man contracted the virus. There have been 10 cases of West Nile in city residents this year, compared with 46 cases and 4 deaths in 1999, when the virus was first reported.

A landlord was fatally shot in the face yesterday while sitting in a van parked outside a Brownsville building, the police said. The victim, Paul E. Siddo, 41, of Canarsie, was shot at 12:40 a.m. in front of a building of which he was a co-owner at 661 Watkins Street, the police said. He was pronounced dead at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, officials said.

In what music and movie industry groups are describing as one of the largest raids in the United States, law enforcement officials yesterday confiscated 40,000 bootlegged CD’s and DVD’s and 208 disc burners from a garage in the Bronx and an office in Manhattan. Investigators from the New York Police Department’s trademark infringement unit raided a garage on Commonwealth Avenue in the Bronx at about 7 a.m., where 23 duplicator towers with the 208 disc burners were found. Shortly after noon, they raided an office on West 37th Street office in Manhattan and found the discs. The police arrested Abdouraitamance Diallo, 19, of the Bronx. He was charged with trademark counterfeiting.

A Bridgeport man was charged on Wednesday with raping a 12-year-old girl he met through the MySpace Web site, the police said yesterday. The man, Bienvenido Garcia, 19, was arrested by United States marshals at his apartment at the P. T. Barnum complex, said Lt. James Viadero. The investigation, reported yesterday in The Connecticut Post, began last month when the girl’s mother presented the Bridgeport police with 16 pages of computer correspondence that was “sexual in nature,” Lieutenant Viadero said. Mr. Garcia was charged with first-degree sexual assault and risk of injury to a minor, the police said. MySpace officials said they did not comment on investigations in progress.
ConAgra Foods announced plans to close five plants and eliminate about 400 jobs as part of a long-term plan to cut costs.
Segway is recalling its self-balancing scooters because of a malfunction that can make its wheels unexpectedly reverse direction.
A federal judge overturned a bankruptcy court ruling that allowed Mesaba Aviation to void the labor contract of its flight attendants.
Gains among blacks and Puerto Ricans drove infant mortality rates to a record low in New York City last year, city officials reported Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 — The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee plans to pour hundreds of thousands of dollars into an advertising campaign trying to unseat John Sweeney, a Republican congressman from upstate New York, Democratic officials said on Thursday.
A 30-second commercial for Eliot Spitzer, the Democratic nominee for governor, began running statewide yesterday on broadcast and cable television stations.
The Senate Armed Services Committee endorsed legislation that would give suspected terrorists more legal protections than the president desires.
Lottery Numbers.
The former New Jersey governor wanted his book to be viewed as a story of redemption, but he finds himself cast as an irresponsible expectant father.
Robert D. Novak said in his column that Richard L. Armitage had “obscured” the details of their conversation to make the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer’s identity seem less deliberate.

A 40-year-old Bronx woman on her way to work was stabbed to death at the edge of Battery Park in Lower Manhattan yesterday, and the police last night were questioning her estranged husband in the attack, the police said.
About 50 colleges in the U.S. have a six-year graduation rate below 20 percent. Who should be held accountable?
Tina Thompson scored 19 points and Candace Parker added 17 as the United States defeated Russia to finish the first round of the women’s world basketball championship with a perfect record.
The U.A.W. agreed on a program to offer buyouts of up to $140,000 each to all of Ford’s hourly workers in the U.S.
California is betting that it can reduce emissions without wrecking its economy, and inspire other states to follow its example.
In a highly unusual move, Dean P. Baquet said he was defying the Tribune Company and would not make the cuts it requested.
Duane Chapman, a bounty hunter and the star of a reality television series, faces charges from his capture of a rapist in Mexico.
Bob Ney would be the first member of Congress to admit crimes in the inquiry into Jack Abramoff’s corruption.
Struggling to prevent the loss of billions in oil and gas royalties, the Interior Department is close to a deal with 2 of the 56 companies that hold lucrative drilling leases in the Gulf of Mexico.
A wealthy, largely white Long Island high school helped a poorer rival, made up predominately of minorities, field a team.
Lawmakers are rushing to pass a bill on the treatment of terrorism suspects that would have minimal impact on antiterrorist operations but could cause profound damage to justice and the American way.
The internal rule would require lawmakers to sign their names to some of the items they sponsor but would only apply to a fraction of such provisions.
In his final months, Gov. George E. Pataki has locked in hundreds of policy-making and regulatory positions.

Barry Bonds’s personal trainer asked a federal appeals court to free him from prison for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating Bonds. The trainer, Greg Anderson, who has appeared five times before two federal grand juries, filed court papers late Wednesday through his lawyer, Mark Geragos.
soccer.

Mark R. Downs Jr., 29, accused of offering an 8-year-old money to bean an autistic teammate so he could not play, was convicted yesterday in Uniontown, Pa., of corruption of minors and criminal solicitation to commit simple assault. Fayette County authorities said Downs offered to pay a player $25 to hit a 9-year-old autistic teammate with a ball while warming up before a June 2005 playoff game.
The United States Tennis Association will increase the number of women and minorities working as chair umpires at its tournaments, after an investigation into possible discrimination.
Despite a recent defeat in Chicago, proponents of living wages have the moral high ground, and are increasingly finding a political voice.

United States Soccer Federation officials have spoken to Sven-Goran Eriksson in their search for a new manager for the men’s national team, replacing Bruce Arena, according to a person who requested anonymity for fear of jeopardizing a relationship with federation officials.
Billionaire tycoon Ricardo Salinas Pliego and the S.E.C. reached a settlement in the first lawsuit against a foreign company under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
Whether a cease-fire in Uganda’s Acholi war lasts may depend on whether a rebel commander is given amnesty.
Congress is scrambling to pass long-delayed domestic and border security bills, as Republicans and the Democrats try to control the issues.
Chinese officials promised that new rules restricting the sale of foreign wire service news would not affect press freedoms.
An outbreak of E. coli in eight states killed one person and sickened at least 49, officials announced.
Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making as broadcast radio scrambles to regain its groove.
Corrections: For the Record
The chairman and vice chairman announced they would forgo  stock compensation to create an estimated $2 million annual pool for bonuses to employees.
A planned merger that would have created the largest utility in the United States collapsed, a month after New Jersey regulators demanded better terms for consumers.
Sprinter Marion Jones announced Thursday that she would not compete again this year, even though she was recently cleared of a doping violation.
Fantasy baseball expert Ron Shandler was asked to join an advisory board with the St. Louis Cardinals in 2004.
Some of the strongest words came from Turkey, possibly putting in jeopardy Pope Benedict XVI’s plan to visit there in November.
Peter Dicks, chairman of the online gambling site Sportingbet, resigned after a court ruling that he could leave the United States.

The Discovery Channel pro cycling team is “considering all legal options” against former team captain Frankie Andreu, in the wake of Andreu’s confession that he used EPO in preparation for the 1999 Tour de France.

STEVENS--Oswald, age 62, known as Ozzie to his family and many friends, passed away on Sunday, September 10, 2006 after a brief illness. Ozzie was the beloved husband of Teresa and a loving and devoted father to his son Anil, his daughter Sunita and her husband Christopher Meyers. Ozzie was owner and chef-proprietor of Pandit India Restaurant on both the East and West sides of Manhattan for over 20 years. He nourished us with his wonderful food, his laughter and endless happy memories at his restaurants, as well as at his home. Ozzie will be dearly missed by his family and friends who will always cherishhis smile that lit up a room, his love of life, his good humor and his generous spirit. To know Ozzie was to love Ozzie. We are blessed to have had him in our lives and we will hold his spirit close in our hearts. He was reposed at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 4307 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, NY 11104; (718) 784-1525. Visitations were held on Wednesday September 13 and Thursday September 14; 2-5 pm and 79:30 pm; Funeral Mass to be held today, September 15, 2006 at 10 am at St. Raphael's Church, 3520 Greenpoint Avenue, Long Island City, NY 11101; (718) 729 8957. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Raphael's Church in memory of Ozzie Stevens.

(CMT) CROSSROADS -- Steve Earle and Rosanne Cash (right) have a lot in common: both were born in the 50's, both have traversed the worlds of country and rock, both have written fiction, and both called Nashville home before moving to New York. The news that the Jets worked out three place-kickers Tuesday did not faze Mike Nugent, who missed an extra point and two field goals Sunday at Tennessee. ''You're going to see that in every position, not just kicking,'' Nugent said. ''You're going to see players brought in. It's something you just can't let yourself think about too much. It was one bad day where I wasn't hitting the ball like I normally can. I'm just going to have to make up for it.''

WATCHING a freestyle rap on television or in a documentary can be daunting. The lyrics, delivered by top talent, seem so witty and flow so freely that it's hard to imagine they can be what they are -- unscripted and delivered off the cuff. But aspiring rappers (or M.C.'s) have places to go, too. Freestyle rap has evolved, and while the underground freestyle hip-hop circuit is still a place where top M.C.'s hone their skills, there are also plenty of events where amateurs can ''spit'' lyrics or ''battle'' just for fun and local respect. A weekly Tuesday battle at the Apache Cafe in Atlanta usually draws about 300 people to watch as up to 16 people get onstage and battle. A panel judges the contestants on best lyrics and delivery. The event's founder, Andre Lett, is a purist who strictly enforces the rule that participants not recite prewritten lines. Anyone caught doing so is banned. ''We know when it's freestyle and when it's written,'' Mr. Lett said. Those who dispute a ban can contest it in Mic Club Court.

HAMILTON--Jean Thomson passed away peacefully at her home on September 13, 2006. Born December 31, 1896, she was a true definition of a great lady. She is survived by her daughters Nancy Brown, Rye, NY and Joan Damon of Greenwich, CT; five grandchildren, Bill Sandberg, Riverside, CT; Chrissy Connor, Rye, NY; Jeff Brown, Stamford, CT; Jean Brown, NY, NY; Charlie Brown, Chicago, Il; and six great grandchildren, Tyler and Griffin Sandberg; Emma and Owen Brown; and Scott and Katy Connor. She was a member of the Rye Presbyterian Church, the American Yacht Club and the Westchester Country Club, where she lived for the last 23 years. She was also a member of the White Plains Women's Club for over fifty years. Predeceased by her husband of 63 years, Sydney J. Hamilton. She was born in New York City and lived in White Plains, NY for 60 years. Known to many, she was loved and adored by all who knew her, and she will be dearly missed. ''The mighty atom''-we love you. A memorial service will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church at 1 P.M. Sunday, September 17. Contributions in her name can be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church Music fund, 882 Boston Post road, Rye, NY 10580 or the New England Retina Research and Educational Foundation , 2200 Whitney Ave., Hamden, CT. 06518

The jazz avant-garde has always been a multinational affair. Its early explorers sought inspiration from European as well as African and Far Eastern sources; its audience base stretches across borders, as does its economic infrastructure. So it should not be altogether shocking that one of the most vibrant record companies on the scene is based in Lisbon. What the ascent of Clean Feed Records illustrates is just how fluid the global exchange has become. Established in 2001, the label counted 40 stylishly designed titles in its catalog within four years, as well as a physical space in Lisbon -- Trem Azul, Portuguese for Blue Train -- that doubles as a record shop and performance loft. Next week Clean Feed will present a minifestival, not in Portugal but in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where many of the artists on its roster reside. Each night at Barbès will feature three bands in roughly hourlong sets. Tuesday's program begins with Transit, a quartet led by the drummer Jeff Arnal, and goes on to feature groups led by the bassist Ken Filiano, with Tony Malaby and Michaël Attias on saxophones; and the saxophonist Steve Lehman, with John Hebert on bass and Gerald Cleaver on drums. On Wednesday Mr. Attias, who often books Clean Feed artists in a weekly series at Barbès, will perform with a sextet before ceding the spotlight to the trombonist Joe Fiedler and the trumpeter Dennis Gonzáles. Thursday appears to be the most lyrical evening of the run, with chamberlike ensembles led by the accordionist Will Holshouser; the saxophonist Rodrigo Amado, on loan from Lisbon; and the guitarist Joe Morris (above). (Tuesday through Thursday at 7:30, 9:30 and 10:30 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, 718-965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10 per set, or $25 for the night.) NATE CHINEN

This 64-year-old German-born American sculptor wields circular handsaws, angle grinders, scoopers and sanders with the safety covers removed. Though this sounds dangerous, she is no stranger to fear; she spent the early years of her life in refugee camps after her parents were forced to flee Poland during World War II. These days she carves monumentally scaled wooden sculptures, several of which are on display at Galerie Lelong, showing concurrently with ''Mad. Sq. Art: Ursula von Rydingsvard,'' an outdoor exhibition of four of her sculptures at Madison Square Park (above). She cuts and carves imposing semiabstract forms from sweetly aromatic cedar wood beams stacked and glued together into towering piles. The designs are intuitive and improvised, though they will often recall treasured domestic items from her childhood: bowls, cups, a comb. Sometimes she finishes the sculptures with graphite powder to give them a burnt look, but more recently she has been leaving them rough, dimpled and bare, paying attention to the natural, lightly textured wood surfaces. Such are a pair of colossal wall-mounted plates at Lelong, measuring 10 feet high and several feet wide. The surface detailing is at once ragged and delicate, the artist letting her power tools run amok. (''Ursula von Rydingsvard,'' Galerie Lelong, 528 West 26th Street, Manhattan, 212-315 0470 or www.galerielelong.com, though Oct. 21. ''Mad. Sq. Art: Ursula von Rydingsvard,'' Madison Square Park, between Madison and Fifth Avenues, from 23rd to 26th Street, through Dec. 31.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

LEVINE--Carl S. 59, devoted husband of 29 years to Louise Levine, dedicated father of Evan, Joshua and Amanda, passed away peacefully on September 13, 2006 after a two year battle with ALS. In addition to practicing law for 33 years, he also served on the Boards of Directors of Envirosure Mgt Corp and Teltronics, Inc and several private companies. He was active as an affiliate member of the Empire State Petroleum Assoc for 30 years and served as an Associate Judge in the Village of Old Westbury, NY. Carl was best known, however, for his unconditional loyalty to friends and family as well as his wonderfully witty sense of humor. He had an irrepressible willingness to risk his own welfare for the benefit and trust of those whom he loved, a selflessness that was best reflected by the scores of visitors who came from across the globe to see him in his final days.

MALLEY--Simon. Age 83. Egyptian - born journalist, founder and editor of Afrique Asie, long-term and passionate advocate for Third World causes, died at his home in Paris, France, on September 7th, 2006. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Barbara, his children Nadia, of Arlington, Virginia, Robert of Washington, DC, and Richard, of Beverly, Massachusetts; his grandchildren Christopher, Miles, Blaise, Bobby, Sasha and Frances; and his brother Edouard. The funeral will be held at the cimetiere du Pere Lachaise in Paris on September 15th and a reception to honor his memory will be held at the Institut du Monde Arabe in Paris on September 16th. Memorial contributions may be made to The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, Rene Aquarone, c/o UNRWA HQ Amman, PO Box 140157, Amman, 11814 Jordan or www.unwra.org. $(6$)MALLEY--Simon. Died September 7, 2006. We knew and admired Simon ever since the days of his journalistic career at the United Nations in New York through the decades he masterminded his publication ''Afrique Asie'' in Paris. Our sympathy goes to his wife Barbara, children, Nadia, Robert, and Richard, and six grandchildren. Joan and Woody Slomanson

EACH day as I passed the Schoenfeld Theater on West 45th Street, where the revival of ''A Chorus Line'' is opening in two weeks, I looked upward and felt a kinship with the tense yet hopeful auditioners on the poster. Like them I was looking to beat the odds on Broadway. I was in search of a cheap ticket, the cheapest to be found, and that meant rushing each afternoon to the lottery line for ''Avenue Q'' -- at the Golden, two doors down from the Schoenfeld -- where I waited with a few dozen others in penny-pinching anticipation for a young man in a T-shirt to pick my name out of a white plastic bucket and save me $80.

Anything Ethel Merman can do, Mary Martin can do better. Even if you don't believe that -- and what real musical theater fan would? -- it's still worth seeing Ms. Martin's different interpretation of the title role of ''Annie Get Your Gun'' in a 1957 production being presented in a series at the Museum of Television & Radio this weekend. A collection of rare live telecasts of musicals are being presented from the 1950's, that bygone era when television executives actually cared about Broadway. (The Tony Awards show hardly counts). ''Wonderful Town'' -- believe it or not -- was once in the CBS lineup, and a production starring Rosalind Russell is among the five shows preserved on kinescopes presented as part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' featuring John Raitt and Reta Shaw with Ms. Martin, will be shown tomorrow, along with the Broadway tryout production of the rarely seen ''Omnibus: The Ballad of Baby Doe'' (left) and ''A Salute to Broadway's Dorothy Loudon,'' a compilation reel of numbers featuring that brilliant comic actress, who died in 2003, including clips from ''Tonight'' and the Tony Awards. On Sunday, ''One Touch of Venus,'' a production of the Kurt Weill-Ogden Nash musical that was televised on NBC, precedes ''Wonderful Town,'' which stars Sydney Chaplin, Jacquelyn McKeever and of course Ms. Russell. (''Musicals on Television'' will run tomorrow and Sunday, Museum of Television & Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, 212-621-6800.) JASON ZINOMAN

Booker Prize Finalists Announced Six authors were named yesterday to the shortlist for the $93,700 Man Booker Prize for Fiction. The winner of the prize, Britain's leading literary award, is to be announced in London on Oct. 10. The surviving candidates, chosen from a group of 19, are Kiran Desai for ''The Inheritance of Loss'' (Hamish Hamilton); Kate Grenville for ''The Secret River'' (Canongate); M. J. Hyland for ''Carry Me Down'' (Canongate); Hisham Matar for ''In the Country of Men'' (Viking); Edward St. Aubyn for ''Mother's Milk'' (Picador) and Sarah Waters for ''The Night Watch'' (Virago). Last year's winner was ''The Sea'' (Picador) by John Banville. Marianne Faithfull Tour Is Postponed by Cancer The British singer and actress Marianne Faithfull has received a diagnosis of breast cancer and has postponed her world tour, The Associated Press reported. Scheduled to begin in Paris on Oct. 7, it would have taken her to the United States, Canada, the Netherlands, Sweden, Norway, Switzerland, Hungary and Spain before ending on Dec. 18 in London. In a statement released by her press representative, Rob Partridge, Ms. Faithfull, left, 59, said: ''I have absolute faith and confidence in my fantastic medical team, and of course I will be well again, if not better than ever. Next year's tour, I want to assure fans, will be one big celebration.'' Ms. Faithfull, a girlfriend of Mick Jagger in the 1960's and the singer of ''As Tears Go By,'' later battled drug addiction, re-emerged in 1979 with the album ''Broken English'' and has found new audiences as a sophisticated chanteuse. Separation, Not Divorce, For Houston and Brown? What seems clear is that Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown are in splitsville after 14 years of marriage. Initial reports on Wednesday said they were headed for divorce, but yesterday, Phaedra Parks, a lawyer in Atlanta who represents Mr. Brown, said that the description of the papers filed by Ms. Houston last Friday in Orange County Superior Court in California was not accurate, The Associated Press reported. ''It's a legal separation,'' she said. ''It is not a divorce or a divorce petition.'' The couple separated once before, a few years ago. Harry Survives Again J. K. Rowling, the creator of Harry Potter, said she won an argument with New York airport security agents last month in the days after the British authorities said they had uncovered a plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airliners. Ms. Rowling, below, was returning to England after a charity reading in New York, carrying with her the manuscript of the seventh and concluding Harry Potter book. ''The heightened security restrictions on the airlines made the journey back from New York interesting, as I refused to be parted from the manuscript of Book 7,'' she wrote on her Web site, www.jkrowling.com. ''A large part of it is handwritten, and there was no copy of anything I had done while in the U.S. They let me take it on, thankfully, done up in elastic bands.'' Carry-On Revisions British restrictions on carry-on luggage, including musical instruments, are likely to be relaxed next week after government discussions with airline operators, The Guardian of London reported yesterday. Orchestras and soloists have complained about the impact of the rules imposed last month. A statement from the Department for Transport said it would present new proposals ''aimed at lessening the burden on both passengers and operators while allowing us to maintain a rigorous security regime.'' Footnotes Ed Harris, last seen at the Public Theater in the 1994 production of Sam Shepard's ''Simpatico,'' will return on Sept. 26, when previews begin for the United States premiere of ''Wrecks,'' written and directed by Neil LaBute. The monologue, about a man's love for his recently deceased wife, opens officially on Oct. 10. Ashlee Simpson will make her London stage debut on Sept. 25, when she assumes the role of the flapper Roxie Hart in ''Chicago'' at the Cambridge Theater. David Robertson has extended his contract as music director of the Saint Louis Symphony Orchestra for two years, through 2010. Mr. Robertson became the music director in September 2005. Paul Simon will perform at Radio City Music Hall on Oct. 21. Tickets for the concert, at 7:30 p.m., with the Jerry Douglas Band, go on sale on Monday at 10 a.m.

RICHARDS--Ann. The Board, staff and friends of Freedom Institute mourn the death of a great leader and true champion, whose openness about her recovery from alcoholism inspired so many. Nancy I. Stahl, Board Chair Connie Murray, Exec. Dir. $(6$)RICHARDS--Ann. September 13, 2006. Respected and beloved Trustee of Save the Children, the independent organization creating lasting change for children in need in the United States and around the world. She also worked tirelessly for children in our programs in the United States. She did not hesitate to use her influence, values and global network to call upon governments, institutions and supporters to help improve the children's lives. They and we have lost a unique voice of humanity, humor and hope. Our deepest condolences to Ann's children, Cecile, Daniel, Clark and Ellen Richards, and her eight grandchildren. The legislature overstepped its authority when it fired the entire Public Service Commission over a steep utility rate increase, the state's highest court ruled. Under the 6-to-1 ruling by the Court of Appeals, four of the five commissioners will keep their jobs; the fifth has quit. The General Assembly, controlled by Democrats, fired the commission in June. That prompted a veto by Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican who appointed four of the five members and backed the panel in the face of an impending rate increase of 72 percent. Lawmakers overrode the veto. GARY GATELY (NYT)

An article in Business Day last Friday about the development of crops for energy production misstated a figure on ethanol conversion from a Department of Energy report. The report said that even if the nation's entire corn crop was converted to ethanol, it would replace only 15 percent of the nation's transportation fuel needs -- not its overall petroleum needs.
To the Editor: Re ''The Fictional Path to 9/11'' (editorial, Sept. 12):

Congressman From Ohio Is Said to Agree to Plea Representative Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, has agreed to plead guilty to federal criminal charges related to his dealings with the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, lawyers and others with knowledge of the investigation said. A guilty plea would make Mr. Ney the first member of Congress to admit to criminal charges in the Abramoff investigation. An article in The Arts on Wednesday about George Steel, the executive director of Miller Theater at Columbia University, and the ''New Ballet Choreographers'' program there omitted a co-presenter. Works & Process at the Guggenheim is presenting the program with the theater.
An article in The Arts on Saturday about movies at the Toronto International Film Festival misidentified the setting of one, ''The Wind That Shakes the Barley.'' It is Ireland, not Northern Ireland.

SAPER--Bernard, Ph.D., The New York State Psychological Association is saddened by the death of a respected friend and accomplished professional, Past-President Bernard Saper, Ph.D. We extend our condolences to his wife Johanna and family.

The International Atomic Energy Agency has complained about a staff report from the House Intelligence Committee, saying that it ''contains erroneous, misleading and unsubstantiated information'' about Iran's nuclear program. Agency officials said Thursday that their concerns had echoes of their arguments with the Bush administration over Iraq three years ago. The charges were contained in a letter dated Sept. 12 and sent to Rep. Peter Hoekstra, the Michigan Republican who is chairman of the committee. Its unclassified staff report, released in mid-August, was widely seen as an effort to prod American intelligence agencies to be more aggressive in their examination of Iran's nuclear program, amid charges from some conservatives that the mistakes made in assessing Iraq's programs four years ago had bred an overly cautious atmosphere.

Ukraine's new prime minister, Viktor F. Yanukovich, said that he was putting off trying to join NATO but that he would press on for membership in the European Union. ''Because of the political situation in Ukraine, we will now have to take a pause,'' he said after a meeting at NATO headquarters during his first visit to Brussels after becoming prime minister. He said membership in NATO would be submitted to a referendum once the country had undergone political and economic reforms. Analysts and NATO officials said Mr. Yanukovich's statement should not be interpreted as a sign that Ukraine was being pulled back into Moscow's orbit or distancing itself from the West. DAN BILEFSKY (IHT)

A sports picture caption on Sunday with a Cheering Section article about Zack Hample, who has collected 2,930 major league baseballs, misstated the year he began the collection. It was 1990, not 1999.

The Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron were selected yesterday to design a new $208 million home for the Miami Art Museum in Museum Park on Biscayne Bay. Terence Riley, the museum's director, said of the architects' work in a telephone interview yesterday: ''Every project is a step forward. Every one is an innovation. There is no cookie cutter. There are no repeats.'' The firm's latest projects have included the new de Young Museum in San Francisco, which opened last October, and the Walker Art Center expansion in Minneapolis, completed in April 2005. The museum's Architecture Research Committee considered the work of 75 architects and visited 26 buildings in 5 countries. Mr. Riley recommended Herzog & de Meuron at a public meeting yesterday at the museum, after which a civic panel endorsed the choice. Mr. Riley, who took over in March, was previously chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art. Miami's public was included in the process because $100 million of the project's costs will be covered by bonds approved by voters in 2004. The rest will be raised by the trustees. The museum hopes to complete the project late in 2010. ROBIN POGREBIN

If the peace lasts may depend on whether Joseph Kony, the phantom rebel commander, and his top deputies are given amnesty. WIST--Milton. On September 15, 1966, his too-short life ended and our lives changed forever. He lived fully and was adored by many. Two grandsons carry on his name. Reba, Ronda and Andrew

FORD TO OFFER BUYOUTS -- In the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive, the Ford Motor Company agreed to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to all its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs. [Page A1.] HEDGE FUND MAY GO PUBLIC -- A hedge fund named Fortress Investment Group is considering an initial public offering for later this fall in a deal that could value the company in the range of $5 billion to $7 billion, according to people who have been briefed on the plans. [C1.] RUSSIAN REGULATOR IS KILLED -- Andre Kozlov, below, a top Russian bank regulator who had been engaged in an effort to reform Russia's corrupt and risk-laden banking system, died yesterday after being shot on the street the night before. Mr. Kozlov, 41, the first deputy chairman of Russia's central bank, had been leading a drive to combat money laundering and to bring stability to Russia's rapidly expanding banking sector. Among many programs in his portfolio, he had been closing disreputable banks by withdrawing their licenses, a practice his colleagues said had made him enemies in criminal circles. [A3.] SETBACK FOR U.S. ON SHELTERS -- A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals. [C1.] TALKS TO SELL DIRECTV -- Rupert Murdoch, who spent more than two decades coveting the satellite broadcaster DirecTV before acquiring control of it three years ago, is now in talks to sell it to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night. [C1.] UTILITY MERGER ABANDONED -- The Public Service Enterprise Group of Newark, the parent company of New Jersey's largest utility, and Exelon of Chicago called off their merger, saying that their differences with New Jersey regulators were ''insurmountable.'' [B5.] CHINA AND NEWS SERVICES -- Chinese officials promised that new rules restricting the sale of reports by foreign news agencies would not have an effect on press freedoms. But the officials also strongly defended efforts to control the distribution of financial and economic news inside the country. [A10.] CALIFORNIA'S EMISSIONS FIGHT -- California is betting that it can succeed in reducing greenhouse gas emissions without wrecking its economy, and therefore inspire other states -- and countries -- to follow its example on slowing climate change. [A1.] AOL EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE POST -- Ted Leonsis, who has been a top leader of AOL for 13 years, will give up his jobs as president of what AOL calls its audience business, which creates Web sites and sells advertising on them. He will remain vice chairman of the company. [C4.] MICROSOFT'S MUSIC PLAYER -- Hoping to upstage the Apple iPod, Microsoft said that its Zune player, which it plans to release in time for the holiday season, will include wireless technology to allow Zune owners to easily share their favorite songs and playlists with one another. [C3.] MEXICO SECURITIES SETTLEMENT -- The billionaire investor Ricardo Salinas Pliego and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission reached a settlement in the first case against a foreign company under the corporate governance rules of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. [C3.] BATTLE OVER JOB CUTS AT PAPER -- The editor of The Los Angeles Times appears to be in a showdown with the paper's owners at the Tribune Company over newsroom job cuts. [C3.] RESHAPING RADIO -- Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making. Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest radio operator, is considering selling some of its 1,200 stations in smaller markets, according to industry analysts. The CBS Corporation did the same thing recently and now says it is looking at further station sales. Walt Disney recently struck a deal to get out of the radio business altogether, and Susquehanna Broadcasting has been sold to another broadcaster. [C1.] INDIA'S CELLPHONE GROWTH -- India has become the fastest-growing cellular market in the world, adding a net 5.9 million cellular subscribers in August, the Cellular Operators Association of India said. The gain outstripped China's increase of 5.19 million subscribers. [C4.] SMALL RISE IN RETAIL SALES -- Retail sales rose 0.2 percent in August after a surge of 1.4 percent in July. Another report showed that weekly first-time claims for jobless benefits fell. [C4.] STOCKS END THE DAY MIXED -- Wall Street closed mixed, with blue chips falling and technology stocks managing a slight gain. [C8.]

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Maria Sharapova's victory over Justine Henin-Hardenne for the United States Open women's singles title referred incorrectly to Sharapova's on-court remarks afterward. She acknowledged Henin-Hardenne as well as Billie Jean King; she did not thank only King.

Diner's Guide presents excerpts from recent restaurant reviews. Trestle on Tenth Extending the recently formed restaurant row on 10th Avenue another few dozen feet to the north, Trestle on Tenth serves rebelliously hearty and sometimes seductively homey fare that reflects the Swiss upbringing of its chef and owner, Ralf Kuettel. On a concise menu with standouts like saddle of lamb, veal kidneys and pork loin, there were a few too many disappointments, but Mr. Kuettel, who knows wine, has put together a list of affordable, adventurous selections from small producers, most of them European. It's a model of what a restaurateur without tons of money or storage space can do. 242 10th Avenue, at 24th Street, Chelsea; (212) 645-5659, trestleontenth.com. Dinner entrees, $18 to $25. * [Rating: One Star] Japonais An offshoot of a restaurant already established in Chicago and bound for Las Vegas, Japonais inhabits a genre of glossy, gargantuan Asian-fusion extravaganzas that has gone from plump to morbidly obese in no time flat. That doesn't mean it and its Japanese-French cooking aren't enjoyable at times. A riff on Peking duck was wonderful, as were some of the sushi rolls. But the kitchen's performance was erratic, the service was often off-key, and the whole production is familiar to anyone who's spent time in Morimoto, Ono, Nobu 57 and so many other peers. Anyone who hasn't may well find Japonais enchanting. 111 East 18th Street, Manhattan; (212) 260-2020. Sashimi, sushi and sushi rolls, $3 to $38; entrees, $26 to $58. * [Rating: One Star] Felidia Lidia Bastianich's celebrity (television shows, books) goes far beyond this terrific restaurant, which helped set her on her path. But the enduringly splendid Istrian and northern Italian food at Felidia shows that she isn't neglecting her roots. Felidia excels at game, organ meat, risotto and pasta dishes that showcase slow-cooked sauces using fatty meats. This is big stuff, and the best of it commands attention without groveling for it, hitting a midpoint between regal and rustic that's all its own. The wine list, emphasizing northern Italy, is great. 243 East 58th Street, Manhattan; (212) 758-1479, felidia.lidiasitaly.com. Dinner entrees, $25 to $36; pasta, $20 to $30. *** [Rating: Three Stars] Sip Sak Many of the best dishes from the chef Orhan Yegen aren't on the menu at this plain but comfortable Turkish restaurant with sunshine-colored walls. You have to know to ask for the shavings of lamb gyro over sautéed cubes of pita in a yogurt sauce. Or for the Turkish pizza, which is really Syrian pizza. Or the special lamb sausage. And if you do ask for them, you can have a superbly flavorful, satisfying experience, despite the unfilled water glasses, no-reservations policy and meager wine list. Otherwise, you'll encounter peaks (manti in a garlicky yogurt sauce) and valleys (dry chicken kebabs) in equal measure. 928 Second Avenue, at 49th Street, Manhattan; (212) 583-1900, www.sip-sak.com. Entrees, $9.50 to $17.50. * [Rating: One Star] What the stars mean: (None) Poor to satisfactory; * Good; ** Very good; *** Excellent; **** Extraordinary.
NESTLER--Arthur. We grieve with our dear Ginger, Mark and the family, at the loss of our loved, lifetime friend Arthur. May you rest in peace. Willa and Ed

BERKLEY--Alison Beth. Died peacefully on September 14, 2006. Devoted mother to Kate B. Heim and daughter to Robert Berkley and the late Barbara Glasgall Berkley. Graduate of Cornell University, Class of 1965, she also earned a Master's degree from Yale University and a law degree from Benjamin Cardozo School of Law. Diagnosed with cancer some fifteen years ago, she nevertheless had a wonderful, fruitful life in the company of glorious friends and family. She was an inspirational friend to vast numbers of people, all of whom adored her. So many lives have been enhanced by their friendships with Alison. Her wisdom, charm, beauty and loyalty were unbelievable. Above all, her sense of humor was extraordinary. Alison will never be forgotten by all she encountered in all walks of life. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, 428 East 72nd St., Suite 300, NY, NY 10021. Services Sunday, September 17th at 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Interment at Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey.

Oliver Kamm/5BE Gallery 621 West 27th Street, Manhattan Through Oct. 14 Poetry readings should be weekly events in Chelsea: say, every Saturday afternoon, to catch maximum art district foot traffic, with various galleries rotating as hosts. New writing would benefit from the new audience, new art would benefit from an infusion of live energy, and Chelsea itself might be lifted from its present lackluster and anodyne condition.

The conservative pundit Tucker Carlson got the ax on Wednesday night from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' results show, which included a surprise appearance from the singer Tom Jones. The show drew 16.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, putting ABC on top at 8, far above the conclusion of CBS's ''Rock Star: Supernova,'' in which the band crowned the goth rocker Lukas Rossi, right, its lead singer. The ''Rock Star'' finale drew 7.1 million viewers, second to ABC among adults 18 to 49, but behind in total viewers to Fox's ''Bones'' (8.4 million) and NBC's predator-catching ''Dateline'' (7.1 million). A second ''Dateline'' at 9 featured an interview with the teacher Debra Lafave, who discussed her relationship with a 14-year-old student. It led for the hour, with 10.7 million viewers, besting ''Justice'' on Fox (7.54 million), a repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' on CBS (9 million), and two half-hour ''Sneak Peek'' previews on ABC (9.1 million for comedy and reality shows, 6 million for dramas). At 10, a special ''Salute to Jimmy Kimmel Live!'' on ABC held up poorly (4.4 million) against repeats of CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (9.9 million) and NBC's ''Law & Order'' (8.9 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Chemistry is the It word. Kobe Bryant said the United States basketball team needed more of it. Winning next weekend's Ryder Cup will depend on it. The front-running Yankees and Mets do not want to disrupt it. Tony Kornheiser and Joe Theismann hope to develop it.

An article on Aug. 13 about a reporter's trip around Staten Island misstated its size ranking compared with other islands in the continental United States. Although there is apparently no definitive list, Staten Island is at most the 13th largest, not the sixth largest. The error was pointed out by a reader just after the article appeared; this correction was delayed for research.

''The Persians,'' Aeschylus' elegiac play about an arrogant ruler who rushes into a disastrous war against a seemingly undermanned Greek army, opened to great word of mouth around 2,500 years ago. But until recently, it has rarely been produced. The play, told from the somber perspective of the Persians, has come into some vogue; the Pearl Theater mounted it in 2004, and the Shakespeare Theater in Washington earlier this year. Now the National Theater of Greece is bringing its new version, starring and directed by Lydia Koniordou, to City Center.

The House of Representatives took a modest step on Thursday to illuminate the practice of inserting special-interest provisions into major tax and spending bills by passing an internal rule that would require lawmakers to sign their names to some of the items they sponsor. The resolution would address only a small fraction of such provisions and, as an internal rule, would expire at the end of the current session in just a few weeks.
To the Editor: Re ''Ends Without Means'' (column, Sept. 14):

Petróleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian energy company known as Petrobras, canceled a meeting of its executives and Bolivian government officials after Bolivia took steps this week to take over the company's oil operations in the country. Petrobras said the Bolivian measures, which included the takeover of two refineries, the only ones in Bolivia, and its distribution system, would render its Bolivian operations ''unviable.'' The meeting had been scheduled for Friday. PAULO PRADA (NYT)

Kitchell and the late Renee Carpenter Draper. She graduated from The Ethel Walker School (where she later served as a trustee) and attended Parsons School of Design and the Sorbonne in Paris. She lived in Paris, Senegal and New York before moving to Greenwich in 1976 to raise her family. She was also a former resident of Palm Beach, Florida. Club affiliations include the New York Yacht Club and the Sailfish Club of Palm Beach. She had an amazing love of life and every day found joy in her friends, her family, her garden, and always--her dogs. She is survived by her family; Ariane deBraux Triay of Darien, Sabrina C. Bullock of Santa Fe, NM, Karena R. bullock of NYC, Sylvia Bullock Clarkson of Greenwich, James W.S. Bullock of El Dorado, AK, and David D.R. Bullock of NYC; her sisters, Renee K. Lickle, Margaretta K. Stabler, Missy K. Lickle, and Tory K. Difenderffer, all of Wilmington; and six grandchildren. She was married to Peter deBraux, of Singapore and the late H. Ridgely Bullock, of New York. A celebration of her life will be held at 11 am on September 19th at The New Stanwich Congregational Church, 202 Taconic Road, Greenwich, CT 06831. A service will also be held on October 12th at 12:00 at the duPont Family Chapel, 215 Buck Road E, Greenville, Delaware. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Brain Tumor Society, 124 Water Street, Suite 3-H, Watertown, MA 02472, or www.tbts.org. For more information contact Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06830.
To the Editor: Re ''As Parents Go Unpaid, Gaza Children Go Hungry'' (front page, Sept. 14):

Ban Ki-moon, South Korea's foreign minister, won for the second time in a Security Council straw poll of announced candidates to succeed Kofi Annan as secretary general. As in the first secret balloting of the 15 Council members on July 24, Mr. Ban was first, Shashi Tharoor of India, the under secretary general for communications, was second, and Surakiart Sathirathai, Thailand's deputy prime minister, was third. Fourth was Prince Zeid al-Hussein, Jordan's ambassador to the United Nations, who announced his candidacy last week, and fifth was Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, former under secretary general for disarmament. More candidates are expected to enter the contest, which will be decided in October when the Council is to recommend one name to the General Assembly for ratification. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

Aljira Emerge 7 Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art 591 Broad Street, Newark Through Sept. 30 Aljira's ''Emerge'' program, now in its seventh year, is a concentrated career management seminar for New York and New Jersey artists; it ends with a big group show. The current one was selected by Franklin Sirmans and Jennifer Moon. With 40 participants -- 24 women and 16 men -- no one can make a huge splash, but the lineup itself is substantial, and certain names do stand out.

Couples DC Moore Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, Manhattan Through Oct. 7 The quirky realism, deliberate surfaces and modulated colors of Alexi Worth's new canvases indicate an attention to ultra-conscious abstract painting (Myron Stout's for example) balanced by admiration for Magritte and the smooth, sculptural claymation figures in the ''Toy Story'' and ''Wallace and Gromit'' films. His human (all too human) subjects don't stop Mr. Worth from making various formal points.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a new wireless device from Apple that will play digital music and video on a television included an incorrect reference to its operating requirements. The device, iTV, will work with both Macintosh and Windows-based computers, not just Macintosh.

Duane Chapman, a bounty hunter and the star of a reality television series, was arrested by federal marshals yesterday morning on charges stemming from a capture three years ago in Mexico. Mr. Chapman captured Andrew Luster, the Max Factor heir who was convicted of raping three women. Mr. Chapman, 53, was arrested at his house in Hawaii along with his son Leland Chapman, 29, and Timothy Chapman, 41, no relation.

A picture caption last Friday about striking Detroit teachers and their supporters misstated the number of people on strike. It is 9,500 teachers and staff, not 129,000 teachers. (The Detroit school district has 129,000 students.)
To the Editor: Re ''Outsourcing Homework: At $9.95 a Page, You Were Expecting Poetry?'' (Week in Review, Sept. 10):

BASSUK--Irving, of Jamaica, NY, died at home with hospice on September 13, at age 95. Attorney and partner at Bassuk Brothers Inc., a real estate management company, for almost 60 years. Loving husband to the late Molly Bassuk. Devoted brother to Arnold and the late Albert, Sidney and Edward Bassuk. Cherished father to Carol & Jeff Koplan, Ellen Bassuk, Susan & Andre Louis and Jane Bassuk. Beloved grandfather of Adam, Kate, Dan, Sara, Janine, Jean-Daniel, Michele, Vivian and great - grand daughter Nadou. Lovingly cared for by Lydia Lopez and Ann Whiley. May his memory be a blessing. We will miss him. Service at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer,'' 114-03, Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, Friday, at noon. Shiva announced at service.

Robert D. Novak, the columnist who first disclosed the identity of the intelligence officer in the C.I.A. leak case, has disputed statements by his primary source, Richard L. Armitage, who said his mention of her identity was inadvertent. In his syndicated column published on Thursday, Mr. Novak said that Mr. Armitage, a former deputy secretary of state, had ''obscured'' the details of their conversation on July 8, 2003, in a way that made Mr. Armitage's disclosure of the identity of the Central Intelligence Agency officer, Valerie Wilson, seem less deliberate.

The Museum at FIT Fashion Institute of Technology Seventh Avenue at 27th Street, Manhattan Through Dec. 16 Valerie Steele, director and chief curator of the Museum at FIT, has a knack for setting up polar opposites and then following them over the course of scores of carefully selected, beautifully displayed garments and accessories until they meet. ''Love and War: The Weaponized Woman'' is no exception.

NEVER is it easy to challenge daddy, especially the first time. In the inevitable power struggle at the intersection of self-interest, the old man reserves right of way. ''Even when you go, when you're out on your own, he always wants to keep that thing over you, the hammer that he had as the boss,'' said Jeff Van Gundy, whose coaching father figure, Pat Riley, turned forbidding and foul during those pro basketball scrums we fondly recall around here as Knicks versus Heat.

On Wednesday, her first morning as a co-host of ''Today'' on NBC, Meredith Vieira helped the show draw an estimated 6.9 million viewers, about 2.5 million more than ''Good Morning America'' on ABC, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research released by NBC. While smaller than the audience of 8.4 million that watched ''Today'' on Katie Couric's last day, May 31, the crowd that got up to welcome Ms. Vieira, above, was larger than the audience of 5.8 million that, on average, watched the program each day over the previous 12 months. JACQUES STEINBERG

A Syrian man arrested in connection with a foiled plot to blow up commuter trains has been released, the German general prosecutor said in a statement.
