Filling a crucial oversight post for New Jersey's child welfare agency, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has appointed a prominent pediatrician as the state's next independent child advocate. The pediatrician, Dr. E. Susan Hodgson, has extensive experience working with children who have been abused or neglected. She has been co-medical director of the Dorothy B. Hersh Regional Child Protection Center in New Brunswick, where she works with children under the child welfare agency's care. For the past eight years, Dr. Hodgson has also helped state officials review the circumstances surrounding the deaths of children that have been caused by abuse and neglect.

New England (1-0) at Jets (1-0) 4 p.m., Channel 2 NICK MANGOLD VS. VINCE WILFORK The Jets' Mangold can tell from watching film that he is going to have his hands full containing the 325-pound nose tackle Wilfork, who was credited with five tackles, three of them unassisted, against the Bills. ''His nimbleness really stands out on film,'' Mangold said of Wilfork, who outweighs him by 25 pounds. Wilfork, a third-year pro, has played in 33 N.F.L. games and started 23. Mangold, below, a rookie center out of Ohio State, is making his second start. ''You can tell he can read schemes well,'' he said. ''It's going to be a battle out there.'' JONATHAN VILMA VS. TOM BRADY There is a reason Brady has won his last six games against the Jets and is 8-1 against them. ''He is such a good quarterback at reading defenses,'' Vilma said. Brady completed only 11 passes in a victory against Buffalo last week, but two of those went for touchdowns. Vilma and the other linebackers -- Victor Hobson, Eric Barton and Bryan Thomas -- must work as one to make the pocket uncomfortable for Brady. KAREN CROUSE

FALLACI--Oriana. Rizzoli International Publications mourns the death, on September 15, 2006, of a fearless and controversial writer. Born in Florence, Italy and politicized from a very early age by her anti-Fascist father, Oriana Fallaci began a career in journalism as a teenager, and often discussed her participation in the Resistance during WWII. As a war correspondent, Oriana Fallaci covered the greatest conflicts of her time including Hungary, Vietnam, Latin America, Mexico, the Middle East, and the Persian Gulf. Known for her piercing interviews with world leaders and celebrities, Oriana Fallaci's subjects included Henry Kissinger, the Ayatollah Khomeini, the Shah of Iran, Yasser Arafat, the Dalai Lama, Golda Meir, Indira Gandhi, Federico Fellini, and Walter Cronkite, among many others. Author of many works of fiction and non-fiction, Oriana Fallaci's last two books, ''The Rage and the Pride,'' and ''The Force of Reason,'' expressed her fury at what she defined as the post-9/11 failure by Europe and the United States to deal appropriately with Islamic Fundamentalism, a position that incited both considerable support and lawsuits accusing her of racism. Ill for over ten years, Oriana Fallaci fought her brutal disease with the same fierce passion that defined her as a woman, and as a journalist and author.

Mozart: Symphonies Nos. 40 and 41, 'Idomeneo' Ballet Music Les Musiciens du Louvre, conducted by Marc Minkowski. Deutsche Grammophon Archiv B0006506-02; CD. WHEN the period-instrument movement made its first major incursions into the Mozart symphonies, in the late 1970's (after sporadic earlier skirmishes), the goal was to recapture the weight and timbre of the late-18th-century orchestra as Mozart knew it. That aim engendered angry debate then; today it is such an entrenched expectation that modern orchestras have adopted the movement's ideas about scale and weight.

THE borough may need some extra help, but at least it's not a laughingstock. After some residents warned that cash-strapped Ringwood would be ridiculed by late-night television hosts if the borough turned down $500,000 in so-called extraordinary aid from the state, as had been proposed, the Borough Council voted 5 to 2 Tuesday night to take the money after all. It will be part of the $14.2 million municipal budget for 2006.

The State Department of Transportation will begin widening Interstate 95 in Darien in November. Paul H. Breen, an assistant district engineer with the department, said Tuesday that an additional lane would be added between Exits 10 and 11 on the northbound and southbound sides of I-95.

The most important pitches for the Yankees yesterday might have come before their doubleheader. Mariano Rivera, who has not pitched off a mound this month, made 26 throws off a mound during batting practice and reported no pain. ''It was absolutely everything you're hoping for,'' Manager Joe Torre said.

I have spent the past year filming model school-food programs around the country for a documentary called ''Two Angry Moms'' (Lisa Belkin, Aug. 20). While most districts I've visited haven't been able to perform controlled double-blind studies, there is unanimous agreement that better school food correlates to higher test scores, improved attendance, fewer nurse visits, increased focus, better behavior, fewer discipline call-outs and even dramatic improvements in athletic performance -- all goals that educational policy strives to achieve. Amy Kalafa Weston, Conn. How many parents have received a note from school reminding them to feed their child a hearty, nutritious breakfast on standardized-test day? School leaders clearly understand the connection between a healthy meal and higher test scores. Why then, is it so difficult to understand the connection between year-round better school food and improved cognition, behavior and short- and long-term health? Nancy Huehnergarth Chappaqua, N.Y.

NOBODY asked for the timing. But there it was last week, in this state called the land of steady habits. There was a remarkable confluence of life, death and politics, events that are indeed becoming steady these days.

Gayle Robin Klinger and Samuel Ames Gradess were married on Thursday evening by Rabbi Joel S. Goor at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. Mrs. Gradess, 39, was until May an associate for marketing and public relations at MSGI Security Solutions, a New York provider of security, surveillance, and encryption products and services. She graduated from Boston University. She is the daughter of Carol and Gerald Klinger of New York.

The start of a new school year has brought nothing but more problems for the Roosevelt school district. The district, which has been under state control for the last four years because of substandard student performance and fiscal difficulties, has uncovered more financial problems. Earlier this month, when the district closed its financial books for the 2005-6 school year, its new business manager, Stanley Bronski, uncovered a deficit that was at first estimated to exceed $5 million for a budget of $67.6 million. That has since been recalculated to $4.3 million, said Tom Dunne, a spokesman for the State Education Department.

Authorities in Newark, piecing together the events that led to a triple homicide in the Vailsburg neighborhood over Labor Day weekend, have arrested one of the three suspects. The suspect, John Wessels, was arrested Tuesday as he arrived for work as a mover, said the Essex County prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. He was being held in the Essex County Jail on $2 million bail.

For his first collection of men's wear, Isaac Mizrahi unzipped tradition with a new take on proportion control. Pump up the volume with a parka, Mizrahi says, but offset its bulk with narrow pants, as demonstrated above. ''I let proportion dictate,'' says the designer, whose collection -- available exclusively at Bergdorf Goodman -- is rich in decadent fabrics and Savile Row-inspired details like silk linings and zippered interior pockets. Mizrahi's mantra for this effort is ''careful, considerate, careful, considerate,'' and his gems of wisdom, above, are words to dress by. Jonathan S. Paul

Time to take the starch out of neckwear.
The shawl collar ascends.

Although Maria Bartiromo, the television and magazine business journalist, is the subject of a cover story on balancing work and life in the second issue of Success magazine, she readily concedes she hasn't achieved this balance. ''I can't say I have mastered that work-life balance -- my life has been so much about work,'' she said at a party at Elaine's in New York last week celebrating her photo on the magazine's cover.

To the Editor: ''Who's Killing Long Island Sound?,'' by Tom Andersen (Op-Ed, Sept. 3), could not have been better timed. As beaches along the coast closed to swimming on Labor Day weekend, many people were reminded that clean water is not a luxury. It is a necessity. The Clean Water Fund makes our waterways suitable for fishing and swimming. The region has made progress in fulfilling its promise of restoring Long Island Sound by 2014, but it has begun to break that promise.

Not only are children moving back home after college and asking Mom and Dad for monthly subsidies, but in a growing number of states children can now stay on their parents' health insurance plans well into their 20's. Call it another example of adultescence. With 18- to 34-year-olds the fastest growing group of uninsured, states are extending the time that children can be a dependent for insurance purposes.

Neil Rolnick: 'Digits' Kathleen Supové, pianist; Peter Eldridge, vocalist; Paul Dresher Electro-Acoustic Band. Innova 656; CD. THE four recent works by Neil Rolnick on this disc draw on the oversize gestures of Liszt's piano music, the introspective figuration of Robert Johnson's blues guitar, song forms and avant-garde theater. That's a broad expanse, but the thumbprint that runs through these scores is Mr. Rolnick's manipulation of timbre and gesture.

FOR the first few Wednesdays after her husband died last month, Marie Dandrea skipped the evening rosary services scheduled at the shrine they had founded on the farm here where he was born -- a stark white stucco and steel triangle that pierces the sky like a sailboat blown far inland. She visited daily, but not at the one time when she knew that 200 other worshipers would also be visiting, praying to St. Padre Pio. ''Eight o'clock Mass, then to the cemetery to see Petey, then here,'' she said, meaning her husband of 53 years, Pete Dandrea. ''But not on a Wednesday. I just couldn't do it.''

GUNDLACH--Robert, 90. Well-known New York set designer and member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, died on August 8, 2006, after a brief illness in Mitchellville, MD, where he had lived for four years at The Collington Retirement Community. His diverse career encompassed movies, television, and theatre. He also had been a Vice-President and Trustee of The United Scenic Artists, New York Local 829. Survivors include his wife of fiftyone years, Marguerite (Maggie Brown) Gundlach, of Mitchellville; a son, David Brown Gundlach, of Pearl River, NY, and two brothers, Wiliam Gundlach (Captain U.S. Navy retired), of Chapel Hill, NC, and Richard Gundlach, of Staten Island, NY.

In mountain climbing, unlike social climbing, it's better to blaze your own trail. Take the pioneering alpinist Steve House, who last year forged a new 13,500-foot path up the Rupal Face of Nanga Parbat (nickname: the Maneater) in Pakistan. A native of Oregon, House, 36, has been climbing all his life and has endured rock falls, illness, excruciating weather and exhaustion; he once climbed nonstop for two and a half days. All the while, he's maintained a certain utilitarian chic, thanks in part to a Patagonia sponsorship. ''When you're 25 and living in a truck and making $10,000 a year, a new jacket is a big deal,'' he says. Now he's fairly indifferent to making a fashion statement. After all, his greatest achievement, he jokes, is surviving. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

PART of his annoyance stems from his years of commuting in Europe, which prides itself on high-quality public transportation. There is also his belief that any business should strive for a clean, professional appearance. Whatever the reason, Benjamin Heckscher Jr. says the source of his aggravation is the terrible condition of Connecticut's trains and their stations.

THIS school district has been changing, house by house, as Orthodox Jewish families have flocked here over the last two decades, gradually at first and then in growing numbers. While not yet a majority, the Orthodox have nonetheless emerged as the dominant force in a clash of cultures. And the front line in this battle is Lawrence's once highly regarded public school system.

CECILE LINDSTEDT cares so much about how the downtown looks in this village along the Hudson that for years she has led a volunteer effort to plant shrubs and flowers along Main Street. But when dogs, which were being curbed by their owners, started to kill the plants, she decided last month to post more than 25 laminated signs along the street, telling residents where the pets could and could not go. The signs are rather direct. One says, ''Dogs Pee Here,'' with a picture of a dog raising a leg; another shows a squatting dog with a red slash through the picture.

To the Editor: I read with interest the article ''When Pet Friendliness Has Its Limits'' (The Hunt, Sept. 3). When we were buying our West Side co-op, we told the broker that we had a big dog. She said, ''Don't worry, it is a pet-friendly building.'' When we filled out the application for the co-op board where it said, ''any pets'' we put, ''1 dog, a Bouvier des Flandres.'' True to the broker's words, at the board interview, nobody asked any questions about the dog.

Chicago Connection A story line leading into 2005 was how the new Bears wide receiver MUHSIN MUHAMMAD, above, would connect with quarterback REX GROSSMAN. The relationship did not materialize; Grossman was injured yet again and Muhammad failed to record a single game with more than 100 yards. Last week was a different story: Grossman found Muhammad six times for 102 yards. Muhammad will try to prove it was not a fluke today against the Lions, a team with a defense known for big plays and inconsistency. Room for Improvement Dolphins quarterback DAUNTE CULPEPPER had a poor first game with his new team, and his two interceptions brought back memories of his awful 2005. But coming off a major knee injury, and facing the Steelers, a Super Bowl-winning defense, Culpepper did throw for 262 yards. Facing off today against the Bills, who last week surrendered two passing touchdowns to the Patriots, who do not have a major receiving threat, Culpepper will look to connect with the solid targets CHRIS CHAMBERS and MARTY BOOKER. Hot Potato Famous for demanding the ball while with the Jets, KEYSHAWN JOHNSON, above, is suddenly the centerpiece of an offense he had no intention of leading. The Panthers, who were a top contender going into the season, struggled last week with Johnson replacing the injured STEVE SMITH as the top receiver. If the Panthers are to avoid an 0-2 start, Johnson and quarterback JAKE DELHOMME will need to prove they don't need the speedy Smith. Defensive Stoppers Coach Jim Mora Jr. had the Falcons' defense in fine form last week against the Panthers, and the defense gets another chance to shine against the Buccaneers, who failed to record a point against the Ravens. Even without defensive end JOHN ABRAHAM, who is listed as questionable for the game, the Falcons should be able to contain CHRIS SIMMS, a major disappointment last week.

WATSON--John W. On September 1, 2006. Retired from NYNEX, John's civic-minded dedication included working at Keewaydin Camp in Salisbury, VT, caring for and feeding the homeless in NYC, and advocating for peace and justice. He will be missed by all who knew his generous spirit. He is survived by his wife Hanan, son Nessim, daughter-in-law Peach, and granddaughter Maya, sister Allyan, and nephew Plinio. A service celebrating John's life will be conducted at All Souls Unitarian Church, 80th and Lexington Ave, Sunday, September 24, 4 p.m. Inquiries about contributions may be directed to All Souls at 212-535-5530.

An article last Sunday about the making of the film ''Marie Antoinette'' misstated the location of Café de Flore, where the director, Sofia Coppola, was interviewed. It is in Paris on the Left Bank, not the Right.

Elyssa Nicole Folk, the daughter of Rochelle and Jerald Folk of Livingston, N.J., is to be married today to William Clifford Friedland, the son of Marilyn and Lawrence Friedland of Manhattan. Rabbi Yaakov Kermaier is to officiate at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan. The bride, 25, graduated from Yale and is a third-year law student at Columbia. Her father is a partner in Deloitte, the accounting firm, in Manhattan. Her mother, who is retired, taught second grade at Public School 32 in Great Kills, Staten Island.

For a long time Rialto Pictures has been reliably restoring old movies and, even better, exhuming films from obscurity. Recently the company has made lost French policiers something of a specialty, introducing American audiences to neglected masterworks like Henri-Georges Clouzot's ''Quai des Orfevres'' and Jean-Pierre Melville's ''Cercle Rouge,'' two films that never had a proper theatrical opening in the United States. Earlier this year Rialto released another Melville gem, ''ARMY OF SHADOWS,'' a dark, suspenseful World War II drama from 1969. Using some of the conventions of film noir to create an atmosphere of anxiety and menace, Melville probes the logistical and moral predicaments of a small group of resistance operatives, who work in secret and in constant fear of betrayal. Unlike most other postwar reconstructions of the fight against the Nazis, ''Army of Shadows'' offers no inkling of eventual triumph; its characters pursue a just cause that for all they know is also doomed to fail. Melville's style is deliberate and absorbing; his images seem to have not only depth but weight as well. And LINO VENTURA, as his world-weary protagonist, expresses the burden of his duties -- which include killing treacherous comrades as well as enemies -- in every nuance of posture and facial expression. SIMONE SIGNORET was never better. If you didn't get to ''Army of Shadows'' the first time around, don't miss it when it returns to Film Forum on Wednesday for a two-week engagement. 209 West Houston Street, west of the Avenue of the Americas, South Village, (212) 727-8110. The film will also be shown through the end of the year at theaters around the country. A schedule is at rialtopictures.com.)

In their attempts to court a more manly clientele, some spas are pumping up the testosterone. The men's-only John Allan's clubs in New York (www.johnallans.com) feel more like the first hour at a banker's bachelor party than a salon, and the manicures at Guise in Chicago www.guisestyle.com) are done at the bar. Between the Red Stripe and the ESPN, who cares what's happening to your cuticles? The new Townhouse Spa in Midtown Manhattan (below, www.townhousespa.com) is vying for the boardroom set: Bank of America recently booked 80 executives there for a corporate retreat. The men's floor has Wi-Fi, a flat-screen TV and Xboxes in addition to its team of manicurists, pedicurists and masseuses. What better way to prepare for a presentation (or a stag party) than a shave and a round of Mortal Kombat 3 on an antique leather sofa while downing a double whiskey? Men have subdued styling rooms at Frédéric Fekkai's new L'Atelier de Frédéric in Henri Bendel (www.fredericfekkai.com), but they must pass through four women-filled floors of Bendel to get to them. Not that it's a bad thing, at least on the way out. OLIVER SCHWANER-ALBRIGHT

FOR Democrats in Congress and those hoping to join them, the troublesome war in Iraq presents both a significant political opportunity and an exquisite dilemma. Some recent polls show that voters consider the war the most important issue facing the country today and are very uneasy about the way the Bush administration is handling it.

My mother, a dermatologist, told me (without revealing confidential information) that a young teenager who smoked cigarettes came to her office with acne. My mother advised her that the acne would not clear up until she stopped smoking. In truth, only the prescription medication was needed. My mother said that she was only trying to improve the health of her patient. Was she right? name withheld

Soren Andreasen, 33, a geology student from Copenhagen, with his 10-month-old daughter, Lucca: ''My wife is a nurse, and in Denmark, women can stay at home to take care of newborns for one year. So I took a few months off university, we rented out our apartment, and we just traveled around the Philippines for three months with Lucca and our 5-year-old son. It was a bit tough since Lucca woke up so early every morning because of the heat. I didn't necessarily want to be up that early. But when I went out and I sat there on the beach, it was amazing to be there so early in the morning, to see all those fishermen coming out as the sun was coming up, just me and my daughter. It was a beautiful place to be.'' As told to Austin Considine
The elements of men's style, according to Kevin Harter of Bloomingdale's.

LAURIE COLES has always loved the nightly ritual she shares with her 7-year-old daughter, Madeline, of planning the next day's outfit. Madeline makes the choices, and her taste is bohemian-glam. One day during summer vacation, for instance, she wore a striped tank top with a knee-length pink petticoat layered under her jean skirt. Choosing her own outfits is important for ''her ability to be an individual,'' Ms. Coles said. ''It teaches her to embrace diversity on every level, even in dress.''

RED sauce, move over. There's a new comfort food in town. Extracted from the original Indian, with its highly spiced foundation of garlic, ginger, chili peppers, cardamom and cumin, it's Indian lite. It is served at Piquant Bread Bar and Grill in New Brunswick, a spalike space that is the most interesting, most innovative ethnic fusion restaurant that I've found in nearly eight years of eating in central New Jersey. Kirti Rahi, the executive chef and owner, grew up cooking to please her big brother, who often asked her to replicate foods he had tried outside their childhood home in Delhi. But then she went to school, pursued a career in information technology, moved to the United States, married and became a mother.

CECILE LINDSTEDT cares so much about how the downtown looks in this village along the Hudson that for years she has led a volunteer effort to plant shrubs and flowers along Main Street. But when dogs, which were being curbed by their owners, started to kill the plants, she decided last month to post more than 25 laminated signs along the street, telling residents where the pets could and could not go. The signs are rather direct. One says, ''Dogs Pee Here,'' with a picture of a dog raising a leg; another shows a squatting dog with a red slash through the picture.

TODAY is the 81st running of the Yonkers Marathon, which may be the most famous race most people have never heard of. The race, first run in 1907, is the second-oldest in the country, behind the Boston Marathon. From the 1940's through 1960, a top finish in the Boston and Yonkers races was required for Olympic hopefuls.

Capitalize on your good taste with an investment-grade watch. You can get started for $1,000, but remember: 'complications' will cost you. IN THE UNIVERSE OF FINE WATCHES, time moves slowly. Serious European collectors and a growing cadre of wrist-conscious Americans concern themselves exclusively with watches powered by a spring technology invented over 300 years ago. If it needs a Duracell, a watch snob isn't interested. To keep matters simple, the vital parts in a watch are called the movement. But it's the quest for super-intricate movements that makes the watch world tick. If car nuts count horsepower, the horologically obsessed count complications: mini-mechanical performances like chiming on command or tracking the earth's orbit (which, incidentally, can fuel astronomical prices at auction). To draw attention to these goings-on, watchmakers back the watch case with a clear crystal pane, opening a window on the workings of time. Curiously, even the most expensive of these wonders may never be as accurate as a battery-powered Swatch. But then, what else is there in life but time and irony? Credits for the watches on these pages appear on Page 162. Fashion editor: David Farber. Set stylist: Megan Caponetto.

The ''LAW & ORDER'' franchise starts its 17th season on NBC this week with a raft of new faces but, as usual, a minimum of sentiment. For the first time on the original ''Law & Order'' (Friday, 10 p.m.), Lieutenant Van Buren and Assistant District Attorney McCoy both start a season with new minions -- Milena Govich as a freshly promoted detective with a lot to prove, Alana De La Garza as McCoy's sixth hottie subordinate -- and little breath is wasted mourning the characters they replace. Dennis Farina's Detective Joe Fontana gets one mention in passing, and Annie Parisse's poor A.D.A. Alex Borgia, stuffed into a trunk in last season's finale, doesn't even rate that. Over at ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (Tuesday, 9 p.m.), Jamey Sheridan's James Deakins gets just as little respect: Eric Bogosian materializes as the new captain, makes a few snide remarks about the eccentric methods of Detective Goren (Vincent D'Onofrio) and they're off to the races. But on ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (Tuesday, 10 p.m.), where the character played by the recently pregnant Mariska Hargitay is only going away for five episodes, the producers are kinder: Detective Olivia Benson gets the central role in the season opener as well as a handy plot twist to explain her imminent absence. Viewers saddened by the temporary separation of Benson and Christopher Meloni's Detective Stabler on ''S.V.U.'' can turn to PBS's ''MYSTERY'' (Sunday, check local listings), where the latest ''Inspector Lynley'' series is on view. In these well-made BBC thrillers, Nathaniel Parker, as the toffish Lynley, and Sharon Small, as his sergeant, are a sort of British Mulder and Scully, forever separated by class (or maybe not).

To the Editor: I've been a Mets fan for 38 years, since I was 8 years old. Supporting a team that has seen more adversity than success teaches humility, and I believe that is at the heart of their appeal to fans old and new. In many ways, the Mets' travails mirror our own, all of us hard-working New Yorkers just trying to get ahead.

VAN HOVEN--John Emerson Jr. of Mystic, CT., September 12. A graduate of Williams College, John had a productive career in marketing and medical publishing. Noted for his innovative approach to pharmaceutical marketing, John brought new media properties to existing and emerging medical segments such as Physician's Assistant magazine. An avid outdoorsman and craftsman, John had a life-long interest in architectural restoration, nautical tradition, and nature conservation. He was a member of The Corinthians, the National Ski Patrol, and the Montclair Ski Club. A devoted husband and father, John is survived by Sandra, his wife of 47 years, his daughters Pamela Van Hoven Clark and husband Michael, of Darien, CT., Tracy Van Hoven Hoyt and Sherman of Winchester, MA., and son John Avery Van Hoven and wife Leigh of Nantucket, MA., four granddaughters Avery Emerson Clark, Caitlin Ryder Clark, Noel Brinkerhoff Hoyt, Keziah Van Hoven Hoyt and his brother James Brinkerhoff Van Hoven of Essex, N.Y. His life will be celebrated at a Memorial service at The Road Church, Stonington, CT. at 11:30 a.m. on Monday, October 23rd, 2006. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Mad River Glen Ski Patrol, Waitsfield, VT. or Camp Dudley, Westport, N.Y.

American museums have been so occupied for the last few years with matters far from home, among them the call for greater coverage of Islamic culture, that they have often passed over domestic themes and issues. One of these is the situation of Native American artists in the contemporary art world, the subject of a fun and intriguing, but not entirely successful, exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn. Usually such exhibitions herd together disparate artists with any amount of Native American blood in their veins, the idea being that the appellation belongs to anyone who claims the ancestry. So it was reasonable to expect that the artists in ''No Reservations: Native American History and Culture in Contemporary Art'' would be descendants, no matter how remote, of American Indians, Eskimos or Aleuts.

He successfully applied the defibrillator paddles to Lanvin's once-clinically dead women's wear. Now the label's designer and artistic director, Alber Elbaz, is reviving its moribund men's line. And the signs of recovery are good. Along with Lucas Ossendrijver (formerly the head designer under Hedi Slimane at Dior Homme), Elbaz is responsible for one of the fall's strongest collections. Although compact, the 28 luxurious pieces form a complete wardrobe -- from cashmere underwear to tuxedos and Elbaz's signature bow ties. A slightly disheveled mix of luxe and louche, it's perfect for the wannabe blue blood. ''When we created the collection, we actually had in mind a French preppy, or as they say in Paris, un garçon de bonne famille,'' Ossendrijver says, ''someone a little bit aristocratic, with a good education, who knows about quality but is not a showoff about it.'' Available at Barneys New York. HORACIO SILVA
Aviator style takes off.

Tami Swartz, a soprano, and Adam Charles Josef Klein, a tenor, were married yesterday at the Felicita Garden Resort and Spa in Harrisburg, Pa. The Rev. John C. Grove, a United Methodist minister, officiated. The bride, 38, and bridegroom, 46, met in 2002 while performing in ''Mrs. Satan'' by Victoria Bond at Guild Hall in East Hampton, N.Y. They have sung together since then, most recently in July at the Liederkranz in New York, in the premiere of an opera written by the bridegroom, ''Leithian,'' based on J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Silmarillion.''

A FEW days after the terror arrests in London last month, a small commuter plane with three tourists was banking off the coast of Costa Rica when a sudden sound, like a muffled explosion, shattered the calm. The rear door of the plane, improperly shut, had blown open. There was a moment of panic for two of the passengers. But Roger Knox, a graphic designer making a connecting flight before boarding a jetliner home to San Francisco, was not worried. He had just doubled his usual preflight dose of Ativan, a prescription anti-anxiety drug, in anticipation of the ride on the small plane.
LIPPMAN--Gladys. Loving, caring grandma and greatgrandma to Ali, Brad, Serena and Josh. You will live in our hearts forever, Mamala.

Michael R. Gordon (Aug. 20) reports on the frequent problems that Iraqi soldiers have in receiving proper pay from headquarters and notes that the duties of Col. Tom Greenwood include frequent trips to Baghdad to ''wrestle with the Iraqi bureaucracy'' over pay issues. Once, more than three years ago, we were told that American troops were in Iraq to protect us from Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction. When that justification was proved false, we were told that Americans were risking their lives in Iraq to bring ''democracy'' to that country. Now, as the prospects for Iraqi democracy dim, I wonder if your article is the first sign of a new justification in the making: Americans must fight (and sometimes die) in Iraq to ensure that Iraqi soldiers get paid on time. Steve Burns Madison, Wis.

The annual BESSIES awards ceremony is the occasion at the beginning of each season when downtown modern dance celebrates itself. You will probably never hear the word ''community'' uttered more often within a two-hour span. Now in its 22nd year, the event is presented by the three major downtown dance purveyors -- Dance Theater Workshop, the Danspace Project and the Joyce Theater -- with the choreographers STEPHEN PETRONIO and BEBE MILLER as hosts. The awards will honor innovation in dance and ''related performance work,'' interspersed with short performances by some of the winners. Sunday at 5 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800; $15. The first major arrival in the wash of European choreographers and dancers to hit our shores this season will come on Thursday, with the Argentine-born, New York- and Amsterdam-trained, Berlin-based choreographer CONSTANZA MACRAS. At Dance Theater Workshop Ms. Macras will offer the American premiere of ''Back to the Present,'' her first work for her company, the 18-member international Dorky Park. The work was originally seen in 2003 as a four-hour site-specific spectacle in a derelict Berlin department store and was retooled for the stage the following year. Thursday through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077 or dtw.org; $20. Last summer Dancing in the Streets presented its first ''dance charrette,'' in which five choreographers were asked to fashion a short dance for a site they were told about only five days before. There has already been a second installment this summer, but a hit from the 2005 show, Larry Keigwin's ''82 Decibels,'' will be presented again this week in expanded form (20 minutes, not 7) at the 2005 site, the picturesque Tobacco Warehouse in Dumbo, Brooklyn. Last year this involved 23 dancers gabbing into cellphones and being propelled horizontally along one of the warehouse's brick walls. Today at 1:30 and 5 p.m. and Tuesday at 6 p.m., rain or shine, Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park, (212) 635-3505 or dancinginthestreets.org, free.

An article and picture caption last Sunday about five classical music artists poised for breakthroughs misspelled the given name of one. She is Alisa Weilerstein, not Alicia. The article also misstated the date she graduated from Columbia. It was 2004, not 2002.

THIS school district has been changing, house by house, as Orthodox Jewish families have flocked here over the last two decades, gradually at first and then in growing numbers. While not yet a majority, the Orthodox have nonetheless emerged as the dominant force in a clash of cultures. And the front line in this battle is Lawrence's once highly regarded public school system.

1901 Landmark $2,295,000 BROOKLYN: 104 Buckingham Road (Albemarle Road) A 16-room center-hall three-story house with five fireplaces, stained-glass windows and doors, interior columns, leaded-glass bookcases, seven bedrooms, four and a half baths, porch, front and back stairways and two-car garage. Mary Kay Gallagher (718) 282-3141; www.marykayg.com TAXES: $6,500 a year PROS: With a parlor floor befitting an embassy, this well-preserved Prospect Park South house has retained the grand proportions, interior detail and classic columned exterior of its era. CONS: Most of the yard is on the exposed side of the house. The enormous kitchen and bathrooms could use an update. Upper West Side Co-op $1,275,000 MANHATTAN: 121 West 82nd Street (between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues), #1B A one-bedroom, two-bath brownstone co-op with a private garden. Krys Mitkiewicz, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 906-9361; www.brownharrisstevens.com MAINTENANCE: $1,708 a month PROS: This duplex apartment is made for entertaining. Its living room has 10-foot ceilings and a wall of glass that faces north and opens onto a lovely landscaped garden. CONS: The space being used as the bedroom is spacious and has its own bathroom, but it's below ground and has no window. The kitchen is very small. Country Colonial $1,395,000 CONNECTICUT: 30 Easton Heights Lane, Easton A 6,300-square-foot colonial with five bedrooms, four full and three half baths, on a 3.44-acre lot abutting preservation land. Regina McNamara, Prudential Connecticut Realty (203) 520-4846; www.prudentialct.com TAXES: $19,000 a year PROS: Both house and yard are pristine. The sellers are offering to pay the first six months of the buyer's mortgage, up to $25,000. CONS: The location is not ideal for commuters headed south, as the nearest access for the Merritt Parkway is about a 15-minute drive away. Upper East Side Co-op $650,000 MANHATTAN: 233 East 70th Street (between Second and Third Avenues), #2T A one-bedroom, one-bath in a doorman building. Carolyn Levitan, Bellmarc Realty (212) 517-9100, ext. 210; www.bellmarc.com MAINTENANCE: $979 a month; additionally, through December, an assessment of $273 a month. PROS: Though it is in a postwar building, this apartment has been renovated with details like crown moldings, French doors and beamed ceilings. The kitchen, although small, is well laid out, with granite counters and subway tile. The apartment has two large closets with built-in shelves and drawers -- perfect for anyone with a big wardrobe. CONS: The apartment is on the second floor and looks onto Second Avenue, which has a busy restaurant scene and can be noisy. Long Island Modern $989,000 NASSAU: 15 Beaver Drive, Bayville A 1963 modern ranch with three bedrooms and two baths, across the street from a private community beach, on a cul-de-sac. Ruth Press, Daniel Gale Sotheby's International (516) 526-2291; www.danielgale.com TAXES: $10,629 a year PROS: There are floor-to-ceiling windows in the living room and eat-in kitchen. A marble-floored sunroom has sliding doors to the foyer and yard. It is a great house to show off Barcelona chairs and Saarinen tables. CONS: It is a long way to the major parkways and the train station.

The latest project by YO-YO MA's earnest and eclectic endeavor, the SILK ROAD PROJECT, culminates this weekend with concerts at Zankel Hall. The Silk Road Ensemble, a mingling of Western and traditional Eastern musicians, has spent the last 10 days preparing new pieces in a workshop with young players under the auspices of Carnegie Hall's educational wing, the Weill Music Institute. Their efforts can be heard at two concerts on Sunday under the title ''Tradition and Innovation: A Festival Weekend.'' 4 and 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800; $15. For the downloading set, one of the top sellers on iTunes will help open the Metropolitan Museum of Art's concert season on Monday. She is JANINE JANSEN of the Netherlands; her Vivaldi ''Four Seasons'' recording is a popular download. Ms. Jansen, whose come-hither album art is accompanied by top-flight fiddle-playing, and the conductorless ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA will play excerpts from ''Four Seasons,'' along with Bach's Violin Concerto in E (BWV 1042) and Concerto for Two Violins in D minor (BWV 1043). 7 p.m., (212) 570-3949; $60. Vivaldi and Bach crop up again this week at one of the city's newest small concert halls: the Morgan Library auditorium, which was constructed as part of the Morgan's renovation. In opening the new hall's season on Wednesday the ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE offers works by Handel as well as Vivaldi and Bach. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., also Saturday at 3 p.m., Gilder Lehrman Hall, 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 594-6100; $25 to $35. It is the time for season-opening concerts, and the CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER takes its turn on Thursday with a smorgasbord. Ten composers are represented, from Vivaldi to Maw. None of the works will be duplicated, but they offer a taste of things to come, like future performances of works by Nicholas Maw, Leon Kirchner and Bright Sheng, and references to a festival of early-20th-century British composers: works by Arthur Bliss and John Ireland. 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 875-5788; $28 to $70.

GASPARD ULLIEL He might look composed, but Gaspard Ulliel arrived for his photo shoot wearing a bloody shirt. ''The night before the shoot, I had a crash riding my scooter,'' explains the 21-year-old actor, who wears Dior Homme here. ''I spent most of the night at the hospital to check my girlfriend's arm, so I wasn't able to change.'' Ulliel has grown accustomed to the splatter: 2007 will see him in ''Young Hannibal,'' a prequel to ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' As for his favorite leather jacket, the scooter spill only made it better: ''I like it because every mark and scratch tells a story.''

To the Editor: ''Shutting Out Minorities'' (editorial, Sept. 3) was a welcome call for rebuilding failed public middle schools in underserved areas. Yet your prescription to remedy the problem reinforces, rather than dismantles, a barrier to meaningful school reform.

''There's this plan in place to take care of homeowners, but I've heard nothing about helping renters. Where are we supposed to live?'' LIONEL SMITH, 46, a longtime resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans. [14]

Kirsten Judith Axelsen, a daughter of Judee K. Axelsen of Seattle and Carl Axelsen of Portland, Ore., was married last evening to David Albert Carmel, a son of Ann E. Carmel and Dr. Peter W. Carmel, both of Manhattan. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk officiated at the bridegroom's mother's weekend house in Brant Lake, N.Y. The bride, 31, is a director of global market analytics and an economist at Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company in Manhattan; she researches the impact of government health-care policy on patients and pharmaceutical companies. From January to March she worked in Ethiopia on a Pfizer research fellowship with the International Trachoma Initiative, a nonprofit organization dedicated to eliminating blinding trachoma. She graduated from the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, Wash., and has a master's degree in economics from the University of Texas..

I was so pleased to see Gloria Steinem's smiling face on your interview page (Deborah Solomon, Sept. 3). Iwas lucky enough to meet Steinem some years ago when she introduced Ms. magazine, and I found her to be surprisingly friendly and generous with her time. It's obvious from her responses to your reporter's questions that she has lost none of her brilliance. Who else couldso accurately and cogently delineate the ethos of both Hillary Clinton and the flawed Condoleezza Rice? I wish her well in her new radio venture. Michael Maxtone-Graham New York Did Gloria Steinem need to diminish Condoleezza Rice because she doesn't share her political views? Isn't the whole idea behind feminism about women thinking for themselves? This is a woman whose goal is to be the commissioner of the National Football League. How Ms. can you get? Ruby Whitman Ossining, N.Y. Steinem does nothing to promote women as a whole, only to reassert sets of categories like ''woman'' or ''African-American'' and their relationship to contrived political ideologies. Condoleezza Rice, though I do not personally agree with her on many issues, does a service to women and men alike by her sheer success in transcending such categories and by epitomizing the original goal of feminism: that a girl should be able to grow up and be whatever the hell she wants to be. A more pointed question for Steinem: Can an old dog learn new tricks? Kelly D. Cook Ithaca, N.Y.

Skin / (skin) / n. / a protective covering of the body: ' ''My new Swedish jeans fit like a second skin''; an animal pelt: ' ''Just what the world needs now, a dressing gown made of goat skin''; [slang] of, relating to or depicting pornography, e.g., ' ''There was more flesh on the catwalk than in a 70's skin flick''; getting under one's skin, a figure of speech for riling someone up, as in, ' ''People who can't drive stick really get under my skin.''

Budapest is not one of those places that immediately come to mind when discussion turns to centers of modernist ferment during the early years of the 20th century. But Oliver A. I. Botar, an art historian at the University of Manitoba whose specialty is Hungarian art, is seeking to set the record straight in an exhibition centered on László Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946), a Hungarian national and an important figure in international modernism in the 1920's and 30's. The exhibition, at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick, concentrates on the years just after the end of World War I up to 1922-23, when the artist began making the Constructivist-inspired abstract and geometric paintings and designs for which he is known.

Thanks to a fashion intervention this fall, men may finally have what they need to be good communicators: statement belts. To really say what you feel, or to get your name out there, consider a custom-made belt. One-off needlepoint designs, like the one below from Itz a Stitch, take about six weeks to arrive. There is a $50 surcharge for a graphics request that falls outside the company's library of preppy iconography. Belts, $300. Go to www.itzastitch.com. For bespoke Western belts, consult Cowboy Cool in Dallas (800-966-0122). Large ''trophy'' buckles can be made to spec, as can smaller buckle sets and leather straps (available in hippo and elephant hides). Buckles, from $150; straps, from $85. Craftmasters of Nantucket (508-228-0322) commissions scrimshaw artists to etch your fancy onto a buckle of woolly mammoth ivory. Leather straps can be stamped with your name or nautical imagery. Tooled belt straps, $65 to $95; scrimshaw buckles, $95 and up. For tradition with a twist, Tiffany & Company offers nine styles that can be engraved. Buckles, $140 to $1,950, plus engraving. At Tiffany & Company. Barneys New York sells Trafalgar belts, which let you pair a strap ($75 to $110) with a monogram-ready buckle ($65 to $260). Bettanin & Venturi, a luxury shoemaker known for flashy leathers, custom-dyes belts to your multicolored wishes (about $800). Also at Barneys New York. Or geek out with an electronic buckle fitted with an L.E.D. screen to scroll your messages. From $25. Go to www.thinkgeek.com. JONATHAN S. PAUL

Re ''Precisely False vs. Approximately Right: A Reader's Guide to Polls,'' by Jack Rosenthal (Aug. 27): Having spent a good deal of my professional life conducting and analyzing statistical data, I cringe and shout at my television every time I hear ''margin of error.''

After six years of shifting plans and political intrigue, the county Board of Legislators voted Monday night to lease a county-owned parking lot in downtown White Plains to a development team charged with constructing 200 units of low-income housing for the elderly. Housing advocates say the project would mark a small but significant step toward the county's goal of building 10,678 new low-income units by 2015.

Mr. Marsalis is an award-winning writer, player, bandleader and tireless jazz educator, and his efforts in all those areas constitute a lasting legacy these tin-eared critics can't erase. ANDY SPANO called again. It was one of those automated phone messages that we Westchester residents get from the county executive occasionally. This time, he was warning us about hurricanes. It was a beautiful sunny day. Of all the things I was worried about -- and there are always plenty -- hurricanes in Westchester were not at the top of my list. A catastrophe at the Indian Point nuclear power plant -- that's something that keeps me up nights. A terrorist attack along the commuter lines or in Grand Central Terminal -- another frightening thought.

BRYER--Jeffrey. Your 64th birthday today, my dearest Jeff. Always remembered with love. Mother

Art books aren't easy to display because an open page in an exhibition vitrine, squinted at through glass, gives only a hint about what a whole text and its illustrations are like. Books want to be held, read, thumbed through. So people tend to stroll past them in exhibitions where there is much else to see, as there is in ''CÉZANNE to PICASSO,'' the show that just opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Devoted to the French dealer AMBROISE VOLLARD (1866-1939), it includes a gallery of illustrated books, two-thirds of the way through, where a visitor's patience and feet may start to flag. Resist the fatigue. Mr. Vollard made his reputation, and a stupendous fortune, selling Cézannes and Gauguins around the turn of the century. This provided him with the comfort and means to do what he really wanted. In 1900 he published ''PARALLELEMENT'' by PAUL VERLAINE, with its erotic illustrations by BONNARD that float through the text. Bonnard's women and Verlaine's musing on religion and sexual perversion scandalized the French minister of justice, who demanded the work be recalled. Now, as it should be, it's a landmark in book design. ''LE JARDIN DES SUPPLICES,'' by Octave Mirbeau, has equally remarkable color lithographs by RODIN. The story describes a dissolute Frenchman abroad in the Far East. He has an affair with a beautiful Englishwoman, who takes him to a prison with a garden where the flowers bloom from the blood and excrement of torture victims. Torture (Mirbeau goes into great detail and variety) functions as an erotic stimulant, inspiring Rodin to create swimmy, sensuous illustrations of women. Publishers, mindful of the recent scandal over ''Parallelement,'' naturally wanted nothing to do with the book. Except for Vollard, who persuaded Auguste Clot, the great printmaker, to reproduce Rodin's designs, which are so lovingly made that they look like original watercolors. Through Jan. 7, (212) 535-7710.
To the Editor: Re ''Make Way, Marathoners, Here Come the Newbies'' [Sept. 10]:

To the Editor: Re ''Steve Lonegan's Nativist Quest'' (editorial, Sept. 10): So, Mayor Steve Lonegan of Bogota and some of his like-minded constituents are in such high dudgeon over a billboard advertising hamburgers in Spanish that they wish to conduct a referendum that would have the effect of establishing English as some sort of ''official'' language in the borough.

To the Sports Editor: As Maria Sharapova celebrated her United States Open victory by wending her way through the stands to hug her father, it seemed that she had abundant energy to play a longer match (''Title Is the Strongest Endorsement,'' Sept. 10). The Open women's final was decided in two sets for the 11th consecutive time. It is high time to bring another level of parity with the men by introducing best-of-five matches for major finals.

The New York label generating the most sizzle made its debut -- fittingly -- on a boat called the Frying Pan. The photographer Matthew Sandager, along with the designers Oliver Helden and Paul Marlow (who have worked with Marc Jacobs, among others), created Loden Dager with two other partners as a solution for men in search of classic casual clothes with a modern tweak. The moniker is a mix of the designers' surnames, just as the collection is an amalgam of their personal styles. Mordant wit + downtown cool + erudite references = light V-neck cashmere sweaters; slim-fitted, well-proportioned corduroy pants; and versatile canvas jackets. ''We are so not cutting edge,'' Sandager says. ''We simply outfit boys who love books and bicycles.'' Aspiring Wes Andersons, rejoice. Available at Barneys New York and Ron Herman in Los Angeles, or go to www.lodendager.com. CATOR SPARK

To the Editor: Contrary to the thesis of ''The State of Research Isn't All That Grand'' (Sept. 3), United States government and industry support for research is robust and growing stronger. The president's 2007 budget request for research and development is a record $137 billion, more than 50 percent greater than the 2001 request. Support for the basic research category has increased by 32 percent over that same time. Over all, R.& D. spending (federal and nonfederal) is more than $300 billion, which as much as all other G-8 nations combined. In 2003 and 2004, the two most recent years for which data are available, this spending increased by 5.8 and 6.9 percent, respectively. This exceeds even the healthy G.D.P. growth in these years.

Jennifer Susan Kyne, the daughter of Barbara and W. Paul Kyne of Burr Ridge, Ill., was married yesterday to Mark Stephen Malseed, the son of Zoriana Kawka Malseed and Roger T. Malseed Jr. of Drexel Hill, Pa. The Rev. Nestor M. Iwasiw, a Ukrainian Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Ukrainian Catholic National Shrine of the Holy Family in Washington. Mrs. Malseed, 30, works in New York as a business strategy consultant in the global business services division of I.B.M. She graduated magna cum laude from Colgate University and received an M.B.A. from Yale. From 1998 to 2000, she was a Peace Corps volunteer in Parakou, Benin, where she was a small-business development volunteer. She is now a director of the Benin Education Fund in Annandale, Va., which provides educational support and scholarships to high school students in the northern region of Benin.

HALL--Dr. Craig D., age 50, passed away suddenly September 14. He was the devoted husband of Eve Hall (nee Kauders); loving father of Evan and Zoe Hall; beloved son of Helen Hall (nee Gutberlet) and the late Roger G. Hall; fond brother of Scott R. (Cate) Hall; son-in-law of Alexander and Rita Kauders; brother-in-law of Allan (Maggie) Kauders. Craig will be missed. He was loved by all. Services are private.

Way back in 1970 Neil Young wrote ''Southern Man,'' about the South's heritage of slavery and racism. Lynyrd Skynyrd replied in 1974 with ''Sweet Home Alabama,'' telling Mr. Young ''Southern man don't need him around'' and putting the message across with rock-ribbed guitar riffs. And in 1996 along came the DRIVE-BY TRUCKERS to heal the rift between Southern rock and liberalism and, incidentally, to merge Mr. Young's style of high-register vocals with brawny Southern-rock guitars. The Drive-By Truckers' songs are steeped in the particulars of Southern life: the farms and the churches, the shotguns and the beer bottles, but also the Wal-Marts and drug users. ''It gets so hard to keep between the ditches when the roads wind the way they do,'' they once sang. Their albums, like the unabashedly ambitious ''Southern Rock Opera'' and the thoughtful, twangy ''Decoration Day,'' sketch grand epics or pack short stories into four-minute songs. The Drive-By Truckers aren't doctrinaire liberals but populists with an eye on working-class predicaments, from stagnant wages and layoffs to the toll of war. With a three-guitar front line, the Drive-By Truckers love redneck music but not redneck assumptions, and they work as hard and steadily as the blue-collar characters in their songs: regularly putting out albums and constantly touring. This year they released their seventh album, ''A BLESSING AND A CURSE'' (New West), which sets aside the historical for the personal, including family memories and stormy love songs. On Thursday at Webster Hall they're sharing a bill with BOBBY BARE JR., a country songwriter's son who has his own rowdy version of Southern rock. 7 p.m., 125 East 11th Street, East Village, bowerypresents.com; $25.

To the Editor: As chairman of the Metropolitan Aircraft Noise Mitigation Committee appointed by the governors of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey and funded by Congress, I take strong exception to ''Paying the Fare for Quieter Skies,'' by Joseph Berger (column, Sept. 10). Flights bound for Westchester County Airport and La Guardia Airport can fly over Long Island Sound at 3,000 and 5,000 feet until descent. Despite existing regulations, Westchester controllers issue shortcut instructions for 1,000 feet and across heavily populated areas to save a few minutes. There is a very noticeable increase in low flights over Greenwich and Stamford, including what you call ''such anomalies as propeller-plane flights,'' especially on Sundays and holidays.

The Rev. John P. Manwell, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Belvedere Hotel. TO connoisseurs of comic books, Jack Kirby is known simply as the King, unequaled in both his output and in inventive concepts, from bold double-page spreads to the bulky creatures and fantastical machinery that filled his pages. In collaboration with Stan Lee, he created the Silver Surfer, Iron Man, Thor, the X-Men, the Hulk and the Fantastic Four, superheroes who are still being tapped for Marvel series, T-shirts, animated programming and film adaptations.

A Classical Music listing last Sunday in a preview of the new season misstated the role to be sung by Juan Diego Flórez in the Met production ''Il Barbiere Di Siviglia.'' It is Count Almaviva, not the title role. (That is scheduled to be sung by Peter Mattei.)

FUCHS--Cara Skoler. August 25, 2006. Professor in English and Core Departments at Fairleigh Dickinson University. Loving wife of Daniel. Devoted mother of Margot Schwartz and Sabrina Abrams. Beloved grandmother of Andrew, Natasha and Susannah. Her vibrancy and warmth will be missed.

To the Editor: In his review of Janna Levin's book ''A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines'' (Sept. 3), Jim Holt says that ''both Gödel and Turing exploited the ancient paradox of the liar.'' While it is true that there is an analogy between the liar paradox and Gödel's construction of a sentence that says of itself that it is not provable from given rules, his work stands on its own and in no way ''exploits'' that paradox. As for Turing's work, it has nothing whatever to do with the liar paradox. Martin Davis Berkeley, Calif. The writer, the author of ''Engines of Logic,'' is a visiting scholar at the University of California, Berkeley.

TIME seems to have stopped on the Princess Marie, one of the dozens of charter fishing boats on the waters off Long Island's South Shore. People are fishing much the way they have for decades. The sky may be a threatening gray, the air cold and heavy with moisture, and the waters rough, but a hardy group still shares the eagerness for that first catch and the anticipation of taking it home for dinner. The captain of the 65-foot boat, Dennis Kanyuk, 54, has spent most of his life on the water. But his life is no longer as simple as it once was. On a trip three to four miles off-shore late last month, he spent much of his time denouncing some politicians and what he says are senseless regulations that in the past 10 years have been ruining the recreational fishing industry. When not piloting the boat or talking with his customers, he was on his cellphone planning strategies that he hopes will save the industry.

IN a strip mall, between a Chinese restaurant and a takeout pizza place, there is a storefront school for children with special needs that is at the center of a dispute about schools here. The dispute has little to do with children or with disabilities, though, and everything to do with race and religion in Lakewood. The former resort town near the Jersey Shore is home to one of the nation's largest communities of strict Orthodox Jews, and its recent galloping growth has left Lakewood's schools in an odd situation. In a town where Orthodox Jews represent about half the population, nearly three-quarters of the town's children attend private Jewish day schools. But the public school district, by law, must finance special education for everyone. And state education officials have found that among preschool children in special education programs in Lakewood, there is a startling divide.

HEWLETT-PACKARD The News -- Patricia C. Dunn will step down as chairwoman of the Hewlett-Packard board, one of a series of moves intended to calm turmoil over a leak investigation. Behind the News -- The company still faces legal inquiries related to the investigation, in which surreptitious methods were used to obtain phone records of directors and reporters. But the board shake-up seemed to restore order in a company that has long set a standard for corporate behavior in Silicon Valley. Investors seemed satisfied as well: Hewlett-Packard's stock is at a five-year high. WORLD BANK The News -- Paul D. Wolfowitz, the head of the World Bank, has come under criticism within and outside the bank for a campaign against corruption in developing countries. Behind the News -- Mr. Wolfowitz's efforts have led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars of loans. Critics say under his approach lending may be shut off in an arbitrary way, jeopardizing the bank's goal of reducing poverty. But the criticism may also reflect lingering doubts about the selection of Mr. Wolfowitz, a neoconservative who as deputy defense secretary was a primary architect of the Iraq war. WAR ON TERROR The News -- Colin L. Powell, President Bush's former secretary of state, sided with some Republican senators in opposing the president's proposals for the trial and interrogation of terrorism suspects. Behind the News -- Mr. Powell said the president's plan, which provides fewer protections for suspects, would encourage nations to question the ''moral basis of our fight against terrorism.'' It was a rare public disagreement by Mr. Powell. But he had long expressed reservations about White House claims it should not be bound by the Geneva Conventions in the war on terror. SPORTS The News -- Frankie Andreu, a former teammate of Lance Armstrong, admitted he had used performance-enhancing drugs. Behind the News -- The admission by Andreu and another anonymous former teammate that they had used the drug EPO in 1999, the first year Armstrong won the Tour de France, put pressure on the cycling star, who has said he never used banned substances. But both teammates said they did not see Armstrong use drugs, and Armstrong said he had never pushed his teammates to use them and had not known they had done so. THE ENVIRONMENT The News -- A new study showed that global warming is responsible for the rising ocean temperatures in tropical regions that spawn destructive storms. Behind the News -- The report found that the rising water temperatures could only be explained by the buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The study did not address the issue of whether recent hurricanes have been stronger because of the warmer waters, but the researchers warned that continued warming might mean stronger storms in the coming decades.

We are planning a trip to Vietnam and would like to fly directly to Bangkok from New York for a three-week trip, but then fly home via a two- or three-week stopover in Paris. I have heard about the financial advantages of buying tickets in Bangkok. We will have assistance getting from Bangkok to Vietnam, but it's getting to Thailand, then Paris and back to New York that has me stumped. -- Amy Schachter, New York Bangkok offers great travel bargains. In fact, if you travel frequently to a particular place, it's often cheaper to book a one-way ticket (or a cheap round trip) to that destination and then book a series of round trips from there. Readers have recommended the Bangkok travel agents Ambika Tours, www.ambikatours.com; Thaifly.com; and DTC Travel, www.dtctravel.com.

Boxer-wearing telecommuters can now meet a company dress code in the blink of their Webcam's eye. The BusinessBib -- an all-in-one jacket, shirt and tie with a Velcro fastening at the back -- takes you from slob to suit in seconds, providing necessary coverage for above-the-shoulders videoconferencing. Those perplexed by the bib's Muppet-worthy proportions should consult the accompanying admonition: ''If you wanted sleeves, you should have bought a suit.'' $130. Go to www.businessbib.net. Anna Schneider-Mayers

THIS school district has been changing, house by house, as Orthodox Jewish families have flocked here over the last two decades, gradually at first and then in growing numbers. While not yet a majority, the Orthodox have nonetheless emerged as the dominant force in a clash of cultures. And the front line in this battle is Lawrence's once highly regarded public school system.
Come out swinging this fall, as new contenders enter the fancy-underwear ring. May the best shorts win. JONATHAN S. PAUL

Mal Edelstein and Gerald N. Daffner are to be married today. Rabbi Renée Feller is to officiate aboard Star of America, a yacht in New York. The bride, 67, was until Friday the design director at Extreme Linen, a New York company that designs and makes home furnishings. She is a consultant to other businesses in that industry. She graduated with an associate's degree from the Fashion Institute of Technology. She is the daughter of the late Catherine and Leander Otis, who lived in New York.
To the Editor: Re ''A Ban on Carry-On Luggage'' (editorial, Sept. 10): I agree with your suggestions, but feel they are still shortsighted.

DONALD R. CODEY JR., the general manager of Freehold Raceway, could not quite understand when several elderly residents stood up at a public meeting in Dover Township this month to complain about the prospect of having an off-track betting parlor in a vacant Grand Union supermarket on busy Route 37. They contended that it would cause undue traffic near their senior developments and induce elderly residents to gamble their savings away. ''When I look at who comes to Freehold, it is mostly people over 50, or even over 60, and it's their daytime enjoyment,'' said Mr. Codey, the brother of Senate President Richard J. Codey. ''Then another senior citizen got up and said there was a flotilla of buses just across the road that go to Atlantic City casinos every day, filled with seniors. Soon, they will be able to spend their money at home in what I think will be a great setting.''

BERKLEY--Alison Beth. Died peacefully on September 14, 2006. Devoted mother to Kate B. Heim and daughter to Robert Berkley and the late Barbara Glasgall Berkley. Graduate of Cornell University, Class of 1965, she also earned a Master's degree from Yale University and a law degree from Benjamin Cardozo School of Law. Diagnosed with cancer some fifteen years ago, she nevertheless had a wonderful, fruitful life in the company of glorious friends and family. She was an inspirational friend to vast numbers of people, all of whom adored her. So many lives have been enhanced by their friendships with Alison. Her wisdom, charm, beauty and loyalty were unbelievable. Above all, her sense of humor was extraordinary. Alison will never be forgotten by all she encountered in all walks of life. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, 428 East 72nd St., Suite 300, NY, NY 10021. Services Sunday, September 17th at 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Interment at Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey. $(6$)BERKLEY--Alison B, we are saddened of the passing of Alison. A charming and wonderful person, we offer our sincerest condolences to her loving family. The Spiegel Family

GROSSMAN -- Marilyn (Klein). Of Somers, died at age 76, on September 15, 2006, following a brief and courageous battle with cancer. Marilyn is survived by her husband Dave, children, Barbara Grossman (Jay Berger), Stephen Grossman (Sally Hellerman), Jeffrey Grossman, grandchildren, Alex, Benjamin, Sophia, Kyra, sister, Gloriane Klein Gamzon and adopted sister, Bella Pasternak. She will remain in our hearts and will be missed and loved forever. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

EPSTEIN--Barbara B. Beloved daughter of the late Muriel Wise Epstein and Max Irving Epstein, sister of Irene Spencer and member of the Epstein family of Boston, Massachusetts, aunt of Denise Hawks and loving greataunt of Casey Lam, departed peacefully at home after a short illness, on September 16th, 2006. A graduate of Goucher College in Baltimore, Maryland, and senior vice president RBC Dain Raucher, a stockbroker for many years. Active in the Women's Financial Association, Murry Bergtraum High School Mentoring program, Central Synagogue, the alumni association of Goucher College, she was a proud member of the American Film Society and the Roundabout Theatre. She was devoted to family, friends, fine dining and love of travel. Special appreciation to caring friend Veronica Walters. Donations may be made in her memory to Cochella Valley Desert Visionaires, 2471 Playa Circle, Palm Springs, California 92264, where she was a member of the board, or a charity of your choice. Funeral will be held at 1:30 PM, on Monday, Sept 18, at Frank Campbell, 81st and Madison Ave.

For years after moving to Westchester from the city, I missed my regular shopping trips to Chinatown for its wonderful vegetables, fish, herbs -- and ambience. But once I was introduced to Kam Sen in White Plains, the longing disappeared. At 20,000 square feet, Kam Sen is a full-service supermarket of Asian goods -- bigger than most outlets in Manhattan or even that epicenter of Asian food, Queens, where Kam Sen Foods, the store's owner, is based.

County and municipal officials in Westchester were flooded with complaints last week after residents began receiving denials of their claims by Consolidated Edison for food spoilage related to power failures caused by a storm in July. ''People really feel they were conned,'' said Paul Feiner, Greenburgh's town supervisor, noting that his office received dozens of complaints.

LEVOWITZ--Herbert J., M.D. Age 72, died at home in Great Neck, on Sunday, September 10th. Born and raised in the Bronx, he attended CCNY and upon graduation in 1955, received the first Jonas Salk Scholarship Award to attend medical school at NYU. He was a devoted and innovative child and adolescent psychiatrist at LIJ Medical Center and Woodhull Hospital, as well as an inspiring mentor. He was a brilliant and kind man. He is survived by his beloved wife of 48 years Micheline, and his brother Bernard S. Levowitz, M.D., a loving family and many friends here and in Europe. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

Sheila Jaya Kadagathur, the daughter of Sarah M. Gallivan and Gopal Kadagathur of Cambridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to John Ray Phillips III, a son of Karen Hooper Phillips and John Phillips Jr., both of Gallatin, Tenn. The Rev. James W. Savage performed the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church. The bride and bridegroom each received a law degree from the University of Chicago, where they met. They work in Washington as law associates, she at Baker Botts and he at Kirkland & Ellis.

DONALD R. CODEY JR., the general manager of Freehold Raceway, could not quite understand when several elderly residents stood up at a public meeting in Dover Township this month to complain about the prospect of having an off-track betting parlor in a vacant Grand Union supermarket on busy Route 37. They contended that it would cause undue traffic near their senior developments and induce elderly residents to gamble their savings away. ''When I look at who comes to Freehold, it is mostly people over 50, or even over 60, and it's their daytime enjoyment,'' said Mr. Codey, the brother of Senate President Richard J. Codey. ''Then another senior citizen got up and said there was a flotilla of buses just across the road that go to Atlantic City casinos every day, filled with seniors. Soon, they will be able to spend their money at home in what I think will be a great setting.''

Re ''Picturing the Conflict: Perspective Versus 'Balance' '' (Sept. 10): You didn't mention the most salient fact in determining whether the coverage by The New York Times was ''fair and accurate'' and put in proper context during the recent Lebanon conflict: that the toll of civilian casualties on both sides was caused by Hezbollah's deliberate targeting of Israeli civilians and deliberate sheltering of its military activities among Lebanese civilians.

HEEREN--Aimee de Sa Sottomaior, died at home Wednesday morning, of complications following pneumonia, aged 103. Mrs. Heeren was born in Castro in the Province of Parana, Brazil. When they were still in their teens, Aimee and her sister Vera accompanied their parents to Rio De Janeiro, where the family settled. Aimee was married young to a distant cousin, Luis Simoes Lopes, the right hand man to President Getulio Vargas. The couple lived at the presidential palace. The marriage lasted for only a few years. Then, the two sisters, who by then were exotic beauties, arrived in New York and immediately caused a stir due to their charm and originality. In 1941, Aimee met and, later in the year, married Rodman Heeren, the son of Fernanda Wanamaker of the Philadelphia department store dynasty, and of Spanish diplomat Arturo Hereen. Shortly after Rodman Heeren returned from the Pacific, where he served with the U.S. Army, the couple moved to Europe, establishing a base in Biarritz, France, from where they traveled frequently. Aimee, who had received only a basic education in Brazil, but armed with an all-consuming desire to learn, went about collecting friends among aristocrats, intellectuals, and artists who offered her their wisdom and experience. Very quickly she learned to speak six languages, not perfectly, but well enough so as to enable her to move around society in a spectacular manner. Initially, she was admired for her beauty and her charm, but soon she became known for her elegance, on one hand, and on the other for her graciousness as a hostess and for her talent in creating exquisite decors within her homes. She was elected to the Best Dressed List and later was admitted to the Fashion Hall of Fame, not just for adhering to fashion but more for reinterpreting it with originality and taste. She was the epitome of glamour. Rodman and Aimee maintained homes in Biarritz, New York, and, later Palm Beach, houses which illustrated the development of her refined taste in decorating. In her later years, her good health and extraordinary energy allowed her to lead an active life, surrounded by friends of all ages. She was generous towards her friends and relations, especially towards those who were less privileged than she was. Undoubtedly she was one of the last grand dames, and she will leave an imprint on her era. She is survived by a daughter, Cristina Noble, and her granddaughter Victoria Noble. Mrs. Heeren will be buried in Palm Beach following a Religious Service at St. Ann's Church at 310 North Olive Ave, West Palm Beach, on Monday September 18th at 10:30 a.m. On Thursday, September 21, a memorial service will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Ave. and 84th St. at 4:30 p.m. Flowers are welcome and so are donations to Voices for Children Foundation, 1500 NW 12th Ave., Suite 1117, Miami, FL 33136.
KATES--Arnold D. October 25, 1898--September 17, 1986 Deeply missed.

To the Editor: Ita Aber's suggestion (Letters, Sept. 3) that Levi Strauss, whose jeans I revere, coined the word ''denim'' is a charming but mistaken notion. While the word is probably an English abbreviation of ''serge de Nîmes,'' the Oxford English Dictionary lists uses of ''denim'' in English as early as 1695. The tough, inexpensive textile Strauss used to make his early jeans in the 1850's was probably manufactured in Britain or New England. Simon Renouf Edmonton, Alberta To the Editor: Ita Aber's Sept. 3 letter on the word''denim'' did not mention the origin of the term''jeans.'' According to an article on the history of denim by Birgit Lohmann on the Web site designboom.com, that word comes from an 18th-century name for the durable clothing worn by sailors from Genoa, Italy. DanT. Wallace Charlotte, N.C.

Peter Lieberson: 'Rilke Songs,' 'The Six Realms,' Horn Concerto Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, mezzo-soprano; Peter Serkin, pianist; William Purvis, hornist; Michaela Fukacova, cellist; Odense Symphony, conducted by Donald Palma and Justin Brown. Bridge 9178; CD. DURING a talk five years ago at Carnegie Hall, the composer Peter Lieberson admitted that he was almost embarrassed by the vocal music he had written before 1997. But in that year he met the great mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt, whom he would marry. With her guidance he grew to understand the ways of the voice and the expressive potential of a vocal line.

CECILE LINDSTEDT cares so much about how the downtown looks in this village along the Hudson that for years she has led a volunteer effort to plant shrubs and flowers along Main Street. But when dogs, which were being curbed by their owners, started to kill the plants, she decided last month to post more than 25 laminated signs along the street, telling residents where the pets could and could not go. The signs are rather direct. One says, ''Dogs Pee Here,'' with a picture of a dog raising a leg; another shows a squatting dog with a red slash through the picture.

IN a strip mall, between a Chinese restaurant and a takeout pizza place, there is a storefront school for children with special needs that is at the center of a dispute about schools here. The dispute has little to do with children or with disabilities, though, and everything to do with race and religion in Lakewood. The former resort town near the Jersey Shore is home to one of the nation's largest communities of strict Orthodox Jews, and its recent galloping growth has left Lakewood's schools in an odd situation. In a town where Orthodox Jews represent about half the population, nearly three-quarters of the town's children attend private Jewish day schools. But the public school district, by law, must finance special education for everyone. And state education officials have found that among preschool children in special education programs in Lakewood, there is a startling divide.
An article last Sunday about the increased popularity of the Mets misspelled the given name of the TV host who recorded a radio ad for the team. He is Jon Stewart, not John.

About 100 dedicated souls parked themselves behind the Mets' dugout before batting practice and screamed as if they were trying to make more noise than the 7 train. They shouted for David Wright, Carlos Beltrán and several others, shouts that were really pleas for the Mets to make history. What those fans wanted to witness was the Mets rumbling past the Pirates to clinch a National League East division that has been under their control for months. Once the inevitable occurred, the Mets and their eager fans could spend the next two weeks dreaming about a memorable October.
LIBERMAN--Edith. Good-bye, dear friend. Estelle and Leon Fassler

An Art listing last Sunday in a preview of the new season misstated the title of an exhibition opening Jan. 28 at the Neuberger Museum of Art. It is ''Fugitive Artist: The Early Works of Richard Prince, 1974-1977,'' not ''Richard Prince: Early Works.''

PART of his annoyance stems from his years of commuting in Europe, which prides itself on high-quality public transportation. There is also his belief that any business should strive for a clean, professional appearance. Whatever the reason, Benjamin Heckscher Jr. says the source of his aggravation is the terrible condition of Connecticut's trains and their stations.

To the Editor: Re ''Harvard Ends Early Admission, Citing Barrier to Disadvantaged'' (front page, Sept. 12): Harvard is setting a very nice example by eliminating its early decision admissions program. But a much more significant step for Harvard and other private universities would be to stop giving admissions preference to the children of their alumni.
