Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 212-448-9206 ext 237.

The fall men's shows in Milan were a lesson in war wear, from the modernist suits of armor at Prada to the updated army fatigues at Neil Barrett and the Austrian army coats at Dolce & Gabbana. But it was Roberto Cavalli and Alexander McQueen who, in looking east for inspiration, claimed the fiercest of warriors: the samurai. Cavalli's show, what he called his ''homage to the ancient Oriental art of seduction,'' was heavy on the glitz, with thickly embroidered kimono-style shirts (above) paired with shiny motocross pants. At McQueen, spectators were mesmerized by a troupe of Lestat look-alikes outfitted in silken japonaiserie. These clothes evoked a truly international gentleman, perhaps best personified by Richard Chamberlain in the 1980 miniseries ''Shogun.'' His character had the combination of ruggedness and refinement that always makes for a great sex symbol -- a bit rough but steeped in the mysteries of life. Think of Brian Wilson in his prime, sitting poolside at his Malibu dojo. While it's hard to fathom today's urban daddy having enough bravado to sport patterned silk leisure wear, wouldn't it be nice? CHRISTOPHER CAMPBELL

THE list of shows Kevin F. Harrington has directed and produced reads like a collection of Broadway playbills: ''Ragtime,'' ''Seussical,'' ''Evita,'' ''Sweeney Todd,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''Camelot'' and ''Man of La Mancha'' -- more than 200 in all. Mr. Harrington's company, Plaza Theatrical Productions, mounts polished versions of Broadway musicals at public libraries in Nassau and Suffolk and operates an arts-in-education program for children at several Long Island theaters. In the summer, he directs musicals at local parks. Last year, his company, the most prolific theater troupe on the Island, staged 287 performances of 10 different shows.

IT was 1971. The United States had just invaded Laos to shut down the Ho Chi Minh Trail, George Harrison had organized a benefit concert for starving Bangladesh -- and I had just graduated from St. Peter's College in Jersey City with a degree in classical languages. ''Wonderful training for an archbishop or a college don,'' my dad said sarcastically. But I was destined to be neither. Instead, I took what came my way: work as a telephone lineman for Bell Atlantic.

To the Editor: How nice to see that I'm not the only one (''Bought Low, Sold High and Blew Town,'' Aug. 27), who bought low (in my case, $130,000 in October 1996 for a tiny one-bedroom co-op on West 13th Street), sold high ($247,000 in April 1999) and blew town (six months driving around the West without a home base, a year in Montana, two years in Oregon, three years in New Mexico, a year in Ohio and now back to Montana).

Meant as commercials but treasured as keepsakes, show posters occupy an uncertain aesthetic middle ground. On Sept. 1 the NATIONAL THEATER in Britain colonized that middle ground when it started selling reproductions of artwork covering most of its history, from the 1964 Laurence Olivier-Maggie Smith ''Othello'' to ''Caroline, or Change,'' which opens there next month. The 650 posters available online at www.ntposters.org.uk include some famous images (the Cubist ''Equus'' horse) and some painterly delights (a diaphanous ''Blithe Spirit''), but what's most extraordinary is how workmanlike (in the good sense) they are. With their repeated typography and standardized formats, they might be circulars for fresh produce at a grocer's. They represent a culture of theatrical plenty. While Olivier is unnamed and unrecognizable on that ''Othello'' poster, the economic climate of Broadway requires that, if possible, a named and recognizable star (or a helicopter) should dominate the visuals. But noncommercial theaters, which needn't make long-lasting brands out of their limited-run shows, can risk more evocative solutions. Among plays arriving in New York this fall, two stand out for the aptness and loveliness of their artwork. For the Roundabout's ''Heartbreak House,'' now in previews, the illustrator Scott McKowen engraved a mansion adrift (or is it sinking?) in an oily ocean: Shaw's metaphor for England expanded to suggest a broader human fate. And for ''The Coast of Utopia,'' the Tom Stoppard trilogy playing from October through March at Lincoln Center Theater, Aivazovsky's 1850 shipwreck painting ''The Ninth Wave'' provides the perfect emblem for the folly of rationalism in the face of nature. As it happens, the best seller at the National Web site depicts another Stoppard play: the 1976 ''Jumpers,'' featuring Diana Rigg. Is it too painful a contrast to note that the all-time champ at Manhattan's Triton Gallery, which has handled Broadway show posters since 1965, is ''Cats''?

To the Editor: Re ''Rejection of Preservation Project Ripples Through Long Beach'' (Sept. 10): Why would a City Council that has been criticized for accentuating political discord suddenly find itself united in rejecting a generous government offer to protect itself from ocean flooding? The proposed Army Corps of Engineers project never addressed the subsequent flooding from the Reynolds Channel bay.

In his essay on disarming Hezbollah (Aug. 27), James Traub says that ''just because you can't see your way to a long-term solution doesn't mean you dispense with short-term palliatives.'' But short-term palliatives have been tried repeatedly over the last half-century to no avail, and most significant, every resort to palliatives has been treated by terror organizations as weakness, and weakness as an invitation to strike again. The hard proof is in Israel's withdrawals: Israel withdrew from Lebanon six years ago, recently withdrew from Gaza and has elected a party whose platform is to withdraw from the West Bank. The only withdrawal compatible with the charters of Hezbollah and Hamas is Israel's withdrawal into the Mediterranean. Hezbollah's oft-stated goal is the annihilation of the state of Israel, which it calls ''the Zionist entity.'' What palliative ''solution'' to annihilation works -- a compromise of only 50 percent annihilation? Ellen Schneider Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

IT seemed like a perfectly sensible plan at the time. Glynis Berry and Hideaki Ariizumi's popular little art gallery, Art Sites, in Greenport was too small to hold all the work they wanted to show, so the couple decided to move to bigger premises. Priced out of Greenpoint and Mattituck, they bought a beat-up cinder-block building, which had once housed a Jeep dealership, on two acres of land next to the Peconic River outside Riverhead. Being architects, they figured they would fix it up themselves.
LEVINE--Herbert Wald. 10/3/07-9/16/91. Gone 15 years. Missed and lovingly remembered. Continue to rest in peace.

YOU may have noticed that it was a banner year for chipmunks. This spring brought forth torrents of the chubby-cheeked rodents, scurrying up drainpipes, darting through stone walls, undermining shrubs, perennials and masonry with the brio of Brooklyn's mightiest tunnel sandhogs. The terrain around house and garden took on the perils of a prairie dog village, with ankle-spraining sinkholes every few feet. For the first time, I saw chipmunks scampering higher than squirrels in the pin oaks, doing greedy reconnaissance on the bird feeders below. This year's furry tide turned our middle-aged beagle, Maybelle, into a pup again. She stalked, dug, yipped and pounced herself into tiptop physical form. She has never caught a chipmunk in seven years of trying. They dart between her legs and chatter tauntingly from just beyond the perimeter of her electric dog fence. Sheer numbers increased her odds of bagging one this season. But suddenly, in early August, she gave up the chase. Heaving herself onto the sunny deck with a great sigh, she lay resigned, watching the wee marauders with the gimlet eye of a defeated old general surveying a superior ground force.

To the Editor: As a flight attendant for over 40 years for two major American international airlines, I would like to give you my view regarding ''The Flight Not Taken,'' by Michelle Henderson, as told to Howard Gold (Op-Ed, Sept. 10). In my opinion, her reaction to 9/11 was not a common one in the airline business. To my knowledge, not one flight attendant on any of my flights after 9/11 canceled because of emotional distress. However, my first flight after 9/11 was not an easy one. None of us really wanted to be there. As the flight leader, I asked each flight attendant how they felt about flying out that night. Everyone I asked was not going to let the terrorist attack stop them from going on. I'm proud to say they did a great job with the passengers we had while en route to Venice. Once in Venice, we all stuck together as ''one big family,'' which is something we usually do not do.

The Biopure scandal lurched closer to a conclusion last week when a Federal District Court entered final consent judgments against the company and its general counsel, Jane Kober. In April 2003, the Food and Drug Administration, citing safety concerns, derailed Biopure's planned clinical trials of its synthetic blood substitute, Hemopure. Despite this, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company continued to say publicly that Hemopure was on track for approval. That pushed up its stock price, which later plummeted when the F.D.A.'s concerns became known.

To the Editor: Jonathan Rauch's review of ''The Party of Death: The Democrats, the Media, the Courts, and the Disregard for Human Life,'' by Ramesh Ponnuru (Sept. 3), endorses Ponnuru's claim that because ''abortion-rights absolutists ... would allow abortions even in the latest stages of pregnancy ... their position gives them no firm purchase from which to oppose infanticide.'' This overlooks a point routinely made in introductory philosophy courses on moral problems: Having a right to life does not entail having a right to everything one needs in order to stay alive. If it did, sick people would have a right to blood transfusions and bone marrow transplants from unwilling donors and everyone would have a right to whatever medical care he needed in order to stay alive, making the Republican Party the party of death for opposing national health insurance. Felicia Nimue Ackerman Providence, R.I. The writer is a professor of philosophy at Brown University.
GUNDELL--Vera. Ten years ago today. Our Vicki, always in our hearts. The Gundell family

Tidy hedonists can store all of their vices in one place with the German watchmaker Glashütte Original's limited-edition Gentlemen's Corner. This $210,000 lacquered cabinet contains five of Glashütte's PanoMatic timepieces (including a $90,000 tourbillon), a remote-controlled watch winder, a cigar-filled humidor, a single-malt-stocked bar, a high-end audio system and a DVD player that comes with a film of the watches being made. Sorry, bartender not included. Call (866)203-8699 for information. SANDRA BALLENTINE

To the Sports Editor: Re ''2 Ex-Teammates of Cycling Star Admit Drug Use'' (Sept. 12): Since when is one guilty by association in our country? Frankie Andreu's and another former teammate's confessions do not make Lance Armstrong a doper. The focus should be placed on Armstrong's brilliant achievements in cancer survivorship and research. Tom Kaplan Las Vegas To the Sports Editor: I am writing to applaud Frankie Andreu's admission to the use of doping products. As someone who had been in and around the cycling industry and sport for the last 15 years, I can say without reservation that every person I have talked with who has raced for, or worked with, a team in Europe has been consistent in their description of a doping culture. It is important to consider the statements of Andreu and others in light of the fact that they speak out at risk to current and future employment. I only hope that his confession will have wide-ranging repercussions. Jon Kircher Flagstaff, Ariz. To the Sports Editor: The fact stands: in the hundreds of times Lance Armstrong was officially tested, he never tested positive for an illegal amount of a banned substance. Period. Jeremiah Schuur, M.D. New Haven To the Sports Editor: Re ''Armstrong Defends Himself as Official Raises Questions'' (Sept. 14): Back when I was a young infantry lieutenant in the Army, there was a saying concerning responsibility: ''The commander owns it.'' In other words, anything that happens or fails to happen in the unit ultimately falls upon the commanding officer's shoulders -- for good or bad, however removed he may be from the action. A captain cannot reap the advantages of his underlings' hard work if he is not prepared to take responsibility for their mistakes. I think there's a lesson in there somewhere for Lance Armstrong. Patrick Walsh Princeton, N.J.

To the Editor: In reading ''Our Slow Death,'' by William Keegan Jr. (Op-Ed, Sept. 10), about the 9/11 recovery process, I was struck by how much we as a nation are addicted to reliving the experience.

LAURIE COLES has always loved the nightly ritual she shares with her 7-year-old daughter, Madeline, of planning the next day's outfit. Madeline makes the choices, and her taste is bohemian-glam. One day during summer vacation, for instance, she wore a striped tank top with a knee-length pink petticoat layered under her jean skirt. Choosing her own outfits is important for ''her ability to be an individual,'' Ms. Coles said. ''It teaches her to embrace diversity on every level, even in dress.''

CECILE LINDSTEDT cares so much about how the downtown looks in this village along the Hudson that for years she has led a volunteer effort to plant shrubs and flowers along Main Street. But when dogs, which were being curbed by their owners, started to kill the plants, she decided last month to post more than 25 laminated signs along the street, telling residents where the pets could and could not go. The signs are rather direct. One says, ''Dogs Pee Here,'' with a picture of a dog raising a leg; another shows a squatting dog with a red slash through the picture.

To the Editor: Thank you for the budget tips in ''The Frugal Traveler Sees the World'' by Matt Gross. Regarding how to save money on ATM transactions, it's worth pointing out that Citibank has over 17,000 ATM locations worldwide in more than 50 countries like Spain, Chile, England and Canada. Citibank does not charge its customers transaction fees for its ATM withdrawals, but it does charge a 1 percent surcharge for the local currency. So it is worth setting up an account before taking an extensive trip; this will save you money. (And you have my word: I am a law student; I am completely unaffiliated with Citibank.) Serena Claire Josephs Miami To the Editor: I wish the Frugal Traveler had chosen a route more representative of the word ''world.'' This (otherwise entertaining) series should have been titled ''The Frugal Traveler Sees Europe and China.'' Raj Premkumar Santa Clara, Calif.

Jennifer Zahavah Korff and Josiah Abraham Klebaner are to be married today at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Rabbi Marc D. Angel is to officiate. The bride, 36, is keeping her name. She is a second-year student at Columbia Business School. Until August 2005, she was a senior director for business affairs for the digital business group of Sony BMG Music Entertainment in New York. She graduated from Brandeis University and has a law degree from New York University.

I was surprised and gratified bythe appearance of Vera Farmiga on the cover of the magazine (Lynn Hirschberg, Sept. 3). As an avid moviegoer, I've seen most of the films referred to in the article. The article illustrates the true problem in Hollywood. It's not that there aren't enough meaningful roles for an actor of Farmiga's talent; it's that most of the bigwigs mentioned either hadn't seen her work or even heard of her. Instead of worrying about what hot club to attend or getting a table at the trendiest restaurant, maybe they should actually watch some movies like the rest of us. David M. Korn New York As a young director, I was fortunate enough to be encouraged by my uncle, Alan J. Pakula. Alan loved great stories and serious actors, and he also had great respect for women: his warmth and vision encouraged a great artist like Meryl Streep to do some of her most memorable work. Lynn Hirschberg compares Vera Farmiga to Streep and describes Debra Granik's ''Down to the Bone'' as ''Farmiga's best work.'' But brilliant acting is nearly always linked to fine, thoughtful directing. After the award at Sundance in 2004, why did ''Close to the Bone'' get such a tiny release, and where is Granik's next film? I would venture that if Granik were a guy daring to make such truthful, edgy work, she'd be hailed as the next Scorsese. While France has encouraged numerous female ''auteur'' directors like Claire Denis and Agnes Varda, the American film industry is regrettably not the most welcoming place for women directors with strong voices. When that changes, there may be more compelling, authentic roles for Farmiga. Jennie Livingston Brooklyn While I would not argue withthe suggestion that there are not enough serious major-studio roles for actresses, I dodispute the notion that Vera Farmiga's particular experience is representative of some kind of historical nadir of modern filmmaking. We are told that Farmiga is talented, and I'll take the writer's word for it, but the comparison between her and Meryl Streep seems a bit extreme. Furthermore, over the course of the article Hirschberg mentions wonderful contemporary actresses, from Nicole Kidman, Reese Witherspoon and Kate Winslet to Julianne Moore, Annette Bening and Laura Linney to Cate Blanchett, Catherine Keener and Naomi Watts, who are managing to find challenging roles. Is it possible that Farmiga just isn't that great? In the meantime, I think we should all savor the fact that Streep, in her mid-50's, has just had the biggest mainstream success of her career in ''The Devil Wears Prada.'' Perhaps there is hope after all. Jon Pollack Pacific Palisades, Calif.

Nine Westchester high schools were among 228 statewide identified by the New York State Department of Education on Tuesday as in need of improvement after failing to meet testing goals in English, math or both subjects. One of the schools, Roosevelt High in Yonkers, which has been on the list of schools that need improvement since 2002, is required to undergo a major restructuring.

SINCLAIR--Thomas. Services have been held for Thomas Sinclair, 65, a well-known Broadway actor for over 40 years, who died in Santa Cruz, CA. Survived by his parents, Bernice & Daniel Fogarty of Santa Cruz, and sister and brother, Danette Smith and James Fogarty of Boise, ID. Contributions NY City P.A.L.

An article on Sept. 3 about the opening of new concert halls this season misstated part of the name of an ensemble that will regularly play the Carnival Center for the Performing Arts, making its debut next month in Miami. It is the New World Symphony, not New World Orchestra.

To the Editor: Re: ''I Spy; Doesn't Everyone?'' (Thursday Styles, Sept. 7), it goes both ways. I write an advice column for Girls' Life Magazine, and I have received many letters and e-mail messages from distraught daughters who were poking around online and learned about Mom's affair or Dad's interest in porn. I give advice to girls, not grown-ups, but may I make an exception? Parents, be discreet. Kids are looking over your shoulders, too. Carol Weston New York

BLOOM--Dorothy. On September 14, 2006. Beloved wife, dear mother, companion, friend, sister and aunt. A special person who will be missed by all. Service Sunday, 11:15 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St at Amsterdam.

KELLER--Charles. 91; died August 21, 2006; BA Cornell, 1936; studied Art Students League; lithographs, building NYC subway; Art Editor, New Masses; Editorial Cartoonist, People's Daily World. ''Artists on the Left'', Yale, 2002. Twenty solo exhibitions: Johnson Museum, Ithaca, NY, 1976, Susan Teller Gallery, NYC, 2004. Loving father, joyous patriarch, gifted artist, loyal friend, political activist, is deeply missed. Survived by Marthe, Daniel, Kathryn, former wife, Judith, grandchildren Cara, Alexi, Colter. Memorial: 212 614-7244. http:// charles.keller.com

A Film listing last Sunday in a preview of the new season misstated the history of film and television versions of the Robert Penn Warren novel ''All the King's Men.'' A forthcoming film with Sean Penn is the third such project, not the fourth, and no television movies were based on the book. (The previous productions were a 1958 live television show, directed by Sidney Lumet, and the 1949 film starring Broderick Crawford. A BBC production with the same title was not based on the novel.)
Extreme sportswear shows some skin.

YOU may have noticed that it was a banner year for chipmunks. This spring brought forth torrents of the chubby-cheeked rodents, scurrying up drainpipes, darting through stone walls, undermining shrubs, perennials and masonry with the brio of Brooklyn's mightiest tunnel sandhogs. The terrain around house and garden took on the perils of a prairie dog village, with ankle-spraining sinkholes every few feet. For the first time, I saw chipmunks scampering higher than squirrels in the pin oaks, doing greedy reconnaissance on the bird feeders below. This year's furry tide turned our middle-aged beagle, Maybelle, into a pup again. She stalked, dug, yipped and pounced herself into tiptop physical form. She has never caught a chipmunk in seven years of trying. They dart between her legs and chatter tauntingly from just beyond the perimeter of her electric dog fence. Sheer numbers increased her odds of bagging one this season. But suddenly, in early August, she gave up the chase. Heaving herself onto the sunny deck with a great sigh, she lay resigned, watching the wee marauders with the gimlet eye of a defeated old general surveying a superior ground force.

LEW--John Stephen, 72, of Ossining, NY, died September 14 after a long illness. He was born in New York on September 9, 1934, the son of Ann Light Lew and Edward A. Lew. He attended Mamaroneck High School and then Yale University, where he graduated in 1955. He earned a Ph.D. in Physics at Princeton University in 1960 and served in the U.S. Air Force in Albuquerque, NM, from 1960 to 1962. He taught applied mathematics at MIT and Brown University before taking a position in the Department of Applied Mathematics at the IBM Thomas J.Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, where he worked for twenty - four years. His avocations included literature and music. A long-time member of Mensa of Greater New York, he served for a time as the poetry editor of the Mensa Bulletin. For many years he wrote program notes for, and served on the board of Friends of Music of Ossining, NY. He is survived by his brother and sister-in-law Robert A. Lew and Elizabeth Wright and their children Carolina and Edward, of Lexington, MA; his daughter and son-in-law Jennifer Beulah Lew and Paul Nathan Foster and their sons Abram and Michael, of Baltimore, MD; and his son and son-in-law Nathaniel Geoffrey Lew and Jason Paymar Lorber and their son Maxwell, of Burlington, VT. A funeral will be held at 10 a.m. on Monday, September 18, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd, Larchmont. Memorial donations in his name may be made to Friends of Music, 251 Croton Dam Road, Ossining, NY 10562.
To the Editor: Re: ''Giving It Up for Mr. Met'' (Sept. 10):

Jolted last fall by the death of one player and stung by the controversy surrounding another, the National Basketball Association is for the first time requiring standardized cardiac screening for every player. The new rules, developed over the past year, were sent to teams this summer but were not publicized. The move is viewed as a significant step toward preventing heart-related deaths on the court. The N.B.A.'s program is the most extensive among the four major American sports leagues.

To the Editor: At last, a travel issue worth keeping. From Matt Gross and the kindness of strangers to the transformative water of the Virgin Mary's Nightingale Hill, I'm inspired to take flight -- or foot or rail or road -- to the many delightful, untrammeled corners of the globe before they're overrun or I'm too decrepit. As Charlotte Vale would say in ''Now, Voyager'': ''I'm not afraid.'' Deborah MacFadden Ridgefield, Conn.

THIS school district has been changing, house by house, as Orthodox Jewish families have flocked here over the last two decades, gradually at first and then in growing numbers. While not yet a majority, the Orthodox have nonetheless emerged as the dominant force in a clash of cultures. And the front line in this battle is Lawrence's once highly regarded public school system.
FRIEDMAN--Seymour (Hon.) Beloved father of our dear son-in-law, Matthew. Heartfelt condolences to Elaine, Matt, Mitchell and Barbara. Nancy and Gerry Sweder

To the Editor: A Classical Recordings review [Aug. 27] and a letter to the editor about the teenage composer Jay Greenberg [Aug. 20] both took potshots at an earlier musical prodigy, Erich Wolfgang Korngold. The reviewer Steve Smith even called Korngold ''a born genius who struggled long and hard to achieve mediocrity.'' This is the hoary old critical line on Korngold, whose early triumphs were interrupted by Hitler and Hollywood, and who found himself out of favor in the postwar years. But Mr. Greenberg or any young composer could do a lot worse than to aspire to be another Korngold, whose works, despite the continued carping of certain critics, are now widely praised, performed and recorded around the world. Preston Neal Jones Los Angeles

LIEBERMAN--Beverly (Trodgon) 54, of Highland Beach, FL and of Bigfork, MT peacefully left us on Sept 11, 2006 after a 12 year long battle with breast cancer. Her healing spirit, love of family and friends, and her ability to light up a room will be greatly missed. She is survived by her adored husband, Arthur Lieberman and her cherished children, Luke, Samantha, Mark & Ann Marie, Mitchell & Bethany, Shari & Amos Balaish, her nine grandchildren Timor, Andrew, Jake, Ori, Noah, Alex, Emma, Maytal and Rena, her parents Bill and Virginia Trodgon, her sisters, Jill Dwyer and Kathy Konigsberg and a large family of loving friends and relatives. She was a National Honor Student and Florida Regent Scholar in high school and graduated Magna Cum Laude at Sacred Heart University in Stamford, CT where she later served on the Board of Trustees. She had many accomplishments throughout her life and left us many gifts. She created SportsLab Theme Park which was Americas largest virtual interactive sports arena and it was later featured at the Summer Olympics in Atlanta, GA. Her visionary concepts for peace awarded her an invitation to be a part of the World Forum for Peace in NY and San Francisco, CA. With her sense of style and real estate savvy, she received the Award for Best Little House in America for one of the many homes she developed and was featured in House Beautiful Magazine and Log Cabin Magazine for their Log Cabin home in Montana that she designed and built with her husband. She was a seeker and passionate reader, pioneering new healing concepts. She was known for her infectious laugh and enjoyed family gatherings, friends, traveling, hiking and all things outdoors and near the water. The Memorial Service to Celebrate her Life will be held on Sunday, September 17, 2006 at The Coveleigh Club in Rye, NY at 11am (459 Stuyvesant Ave. directions at www.coveleighclub.com). The families will be accepting visitors Saturday -Monday, September 16-18. For details, please call (914) 741-0423. Her heart and soul will be forever laid to rest the following Thursday, Sept 21, 2006, 11 AM at their family home on Flat Head Lake in Montana where a service will be held for family and friends. Her passion for life, high energy, and her magnificent beauty will always be an inspiration for us for we were blessed to have known her. Donations are being accepted in her name online at Making Strides Against Breast Cancer. Go to MakingStrides.acsevents.org/Westchester and click on Find a Walker then Find her Team and type Love to Bev.

IT was 1971. The United States had just invaded Laos to shut down the Ho Chi Minh Trail, George Harrison had organized a benefit concert for starving Bangladesh -- and I had just graduated from St. Peter's College in Jersey City with a degree in classical languages. ''Wonderful training for an archbishop or a college don,'' my dad said sarcastically. But I was destined to be neither. Instead, I took what came my way: work as a telephone lineman for Bell Atlantic.

Q. Our co-op board is considering installing cameras in sections of our basement and lobby. The board gives two reasons: to protect residents' safety and to see who is dumping unwanted furniture, old television sets, etc. Are there any legal problems the board should consider? A. ''As long as the cameras are directed at public areas of the building, it is within the discretion of the board to install and monitor them,'' said Howard Schechter, a Manhattan co-op lawyer. He added that if the cameras photograph anyone violating the co-op's house rules, the pictures can be used as evidence.

SKIN / (skin) / n. / a protective covering of the body: ' ''My new Swedish jeans fit like a second skin''; an animal pelt: ' ''Just what the world needs now, a dressing gown made of goat skin''; [slang] of, relating to or depicting pornography, e.g., ' ''There was more flesh on the catwalk than in a 70's skin flick''; getting under one's skin, a figure of speech for riling someone up, as in, ' ''People who can't drive stick really get under my skin.''

INTERNATIONAL 3-13 Reform Eludes Iraqi Police Shiite militiamen and criminals entrenched throughout Iraq's police and internal security forces are resisting recent efforts by some Iraqi leaders and the American military to root them out and help win the trust of skeptical Sunni Arabs, Iraqi and Western officials say. 1 Dozens more bodies have been discovered in Baghdad, bringing the four-day total to at least 165 and prompting some Sunni Arab leaders to raise new questions about the recent security operation intended to take back Baghdad from the insurgents, deaths squads and militias who have been waging sectarian warfare. 4 Vatican Expresses Regret A top Vatican official said Pope Benedict XVI ''deeply regretted'' that a speech he made last week ''sounded offensive to the sensibility of Muslim believers.'' 3 U.S. Urges Banking Scrutiny The United States pressed the top finance officials of the world's leading industrial nations to crack down on what Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said was the exploitation of their banking systems by Iranian front companies involved in illicit activities. 8 South Africans Wage Taxi War Thousands of South African taxi owners, drivers and passengers have been killed and many more have been wounded in a guerrilla war between rival cartels that control thousands of low-cost minibuses that haul a large share of South Africa's urban commuters. 13 Drugs May Prevent Diabetes Drug therapy can prevent the development of Type 2 diabetes in millions of people who are at high risk for the disease, a major study suggests, potentially opening a new path for curbing a worldwide epidemic. The study involved about 5,000 people in 21 countries. 10 NATIONAL 14-32 Democrats' Ads Focus on Bush President Bush has become the marquee name in the Democrats' advertisement war. He is posed standing alone and next to Republican senators and members of Congress, and Republicans candidates are damned in the advertisements by the number of times they have voted with Mr. Bush in Congress. 1 Less Support for Renters As billions in housing aid begins to flow in New Orleans, most of it will go to homeowners. The renters of New Orleans, who once accounted for more than half the city's population, are on their own. 14 A Plague of Sticker Graffiti For several months someone has been plastering San Francisco's walls, public phones and newspaper boxes with postcard-size stickers reading ''BNE'' in big black letters, making him one of the most wanted people in the city. The mayor has offered a $2,500 reward for his capture. 14 Priests Hear of Abuse Hundreds of priests in the Philadelphia Archdiocese were summoned by the cardinal to hear from two adults who as children were molested by priests. The meeting was called to help teach members of the clergy about victims' struggles to rebuild their lives. 23 Tracking Tainted Spinach Packaged spinach salad disappeared from store shelves across the country, as investigators searched for the source of bacterial contamination that has now sickened more than 100 people and led to one death in Wisconsin. 20 Staying on Parents' Insurance Children can now stay on their parents' health insurance plans well into their 20's in a growing number of states. The trend stems from a concern that a healthy -- and profitable -- segment of the population is dropping out of the insurance pool. 1 NEW YORK/REGION 37-41 Tenants for the Freedom Tower The federal and New York State governments have tentatively agreed to serve as anchor tenants in the Freedom Tower, the tallest, most symbolic and most scrutinized skyscraper project at Ground Zero, under a plan expected to be announced today by Mayor Bloomberg and the governors of New York and New Jersey. 1 Youth Killed by Police Officer A police officer shot and killed an 18-year-old youth near a darkened East Harlem basketball court. Police officials defended the shooting, saying it appeared that the officer had fired in self-defense, but outraged residents insisted that the shooting was unprovoked. 38 Chess 41 Weather 42

The Posting article last Sunday about new condominiums in Murray Hill gave the wrong block for the Charleston at 225 East 34th Street. It is between Second and Third Avenues, not First and Second Avenues.

To the Editor: I am 76 years old. I have lived through World War II, the Holocaust, the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, the great civil rights movement and the protest against the Vietnam War. But the event that had the most impact, with the most lasting consequences, on my life and the lives of the next generation, our daughters and sons, was the feminist movement. To dismiss a creative work about these changes as trivial, as Alison McCulloch did in her review of my novel ''In the Name of Friendship'' (Sept. 3), is shocking. Since Ana Marie Cox did exactly the same thing to Katha Pollitt's recently published essays, it appears that the new position of the editors of the Book Review is that feminism is an illegitimate subject for literature. Marilyn French New York

He's collaborated with everyone from a porn star to Hugo Boss, so it's no surprise that the artist Jeff Koons has teamed up with the street label Supreme to create limited-edition skateboards that bridge the halfpipe between curators and skate rats. But these decks, available at Supreme's New York and Los Angeles stores, are made to be ridden, not hung on the wall. ''The whole appeal,'' says James Jebbia, the owner of Supreme, ''is to introduce Koons's work into our world, but in a real way.'' Offered in three styles, and one of them may just get you on board. Alex Hawgood

MANDEAU--Rolf A. Died tragically due to a truck accident. He was 80 years old. Leaves behind wife of 51 years, Eva, and his children, Daniel and Susan, and his grandchildren, Jeffrey, Michelle, Eric and Jackie.

To the Editor: Re ''Judge This 'Don Carlo' by the Company It Keeps'' [Sept. 10]:

MAJOR mistake to mention one's dearth of tattoos to Louis Rubino, a k a Tattoo Lou, 50 years into his very niche career as the godfather of the body art business on Long Island. Mr. Rubino, 66, gravel-voiced and grumpy beyond his years, has seen his clientele evolve from ''your sailors and bikers'' to your stereotypical suburbanites, soccer moms included. Mother-and-daughter tattoos -- the legal age is 18 in New York State, and piercing for under 18 in Suffolk County requires notarized parental permission -- on a floral or butterfly theme are a new conduit for intergenerational bonding. The oldest first-time client of Tattoo Lou's is a 98-year-old South Shore geezer who caught on to the tattoo trend and decided it wasn't too late, or too dangerous, to live dangerously in inky Technicolor.

IN a strip mall, between a Chinese restaurant and a takeout pizza place, there is a storefront school for children with special needs that is at the center of a dispute about schools here. The dispute has little to do with children or with disabilities, though, and everything to do with race and religion in Lakewood. The former resort town near the Jersey Shore is home to one of the nation's largest communities of strict Orthodox Jews, and its recent galloping growth has left Lakewood's schools in an odd situation. In a town where Orthodox Jews represent about half the population, nearly three-quarters of the town's children attend private Jewish day schools. But the public school district, by law, must finance special education for everyone. And state education officials have found that among preschool children in special education programs in Lakewood, there is a startling divide.
An article last Sunday about the Web site Facebook.com referred incorrectly to Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive and co-founder. He attended Harvard, but did not graduate.

WANG--C.C. The partners and staff of Funaro & Co., PC extend our sincerest condolences to Ken and Vera Wang on the loss of their father, C.C. Wang. He was an inspiration to us all and we cherish the more than 55year business relationship & personal friendship shared with him and your family. We honor his memory as a brilliant leader and industrialist, esteemed friend and devoted family man.

An education consultant with a background in reforming urban schools has been chosen to take over the Hartford district, which has a history of some of the worst test scores in the state. Steven J. Adamowski, who has worked with districts throughout the country on raising student performance and spent four years leading the Cincinnati schools, will take over as superintendent in Hartford on Nov. 15. Mayor Eddie Perez, who also serves as chairman of the Board of Education, announced Dr. Adamowski's appointment on Tuesday. He will replace the interim superintendent, Jacqueline J. Jacoby.

Dr. Elizabeth Blair Johnson, an obstetrician, was married yesterday to Dr. John Voorhees Wylie Jr., a cardiologist. The Rev. Susan Buchanan performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Bretton Woods, N.H. The bride, 34, and the bridegroom, 33, met at Harvard, from which both received medical degrees and where Dr. Wylie also received his undergraduate degree.

To the Editor: In his review of ''Orson Welles: Hello Americans,'' by Simon Callow (Sept. 3), Gary Giddins laments that ''Chimes at Midnight'' is ''unavailable -- rarely screened and almost impossible to find on home video.'' He will be happy to know that the film is in fact available on DVD and for rent, at least in New York. David Gordon New York
WINIKOFF--Ellen Ann. Dearest daughter, sister, aunt, on your birthday and every day we think of you, miss you, love you. Marcia, Stan, Linda, Amy, Kenny, Sami, and Eli
To the Editor: Re ''Jazz in America, to the Beat of a Smooth One-Man Band'' by Nate Chinen [Aug. 27]:

To the Editor: In reading ''Our Slow Death,'' by William Keegan Jr. (Op-Ed, Sept. 10), about the 9/11 recovery process, I was struck by how much we as a nation are addicted to reliving the experience. I just don't get all the hyped shows on TV revisiting what happened. Evidently they think that millions of people might forget that it happened.

DIAMOND--Milton. 88 of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Long Island, NY, passed away September 15, 2006. Beloved father of Marsha Chenoff and Susan Joy Diamond. Grandfather of Jodi & Tracy. Brother of Helen Forrest & Rose Epstein. Father-in-law of Robert Chenoff. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Diamond. He served in WWII and Korea and was a Lt. in US Army and earned the Purple Heart and Bronze Star. Funeral Service Sunday, September 17, 11:15 AM at Star of David Memorial Gardens, N. Lauderdale, FL 800-456-5252.

For sports-car enthusiasts, junk in the trunk is a rare amenity. Many measure a car's appeal using the golf-bag test: if the trunk can hold one, it passes. But Porsche's new midengine (and dual-trunk) Cayman and Cayman S coupes swallow the competition with more than 14 cubic feet of storage each, calling for the more extreme hockey test. If a 295-horsepower engine and 171 miles an hour aren't sport enough, the Cayman S's forward storage area can hold pads, skates, mouth guard and jock protection. With extra storage under the hatchback for sticks (or golf bags), there's space for everything but the net. Porsche Cayman S (above), base price $58,900, and Cayman, $49,400. Go to www.porsche.com. Jonathan S. Paul

When Christopher Caldwell characterizes ''perfectly healthy people annoyed by the din of kickball,'' he minimizes a growing problem (Aug. 13). The trend toward overindulgent, permissive parenting (as well as neglectful parenting, owing to societal and workplace failures to provide adequate child-care options to working parents) is leading to a generation of young people who are dangerously apathetic to the rest of the world around them. Privileged kids roam the streets with credit cards and cellphones. It's not just playful noise but also a disregard for others. It's small wonder many adults are instinctually retreating: if there are a few kid-free bastions left these days, bring 'em on. Irene Barnard San Francisco Caldwell quotes a typical resident of a child-free community: ''When you get to be a certain age, you want to be in a community where people around you are the same age you are.'' While that is true, there may be deeper reasons. As a 12-year-old, I think children constantly remind the elderly of their mortality. Madeline Ochi Granite Bay, Calif.
Vampires come alive at night. Frankly, they have no choice.

HARRIS--Richard A. Age 88. On September 16, 2006, of Hackensack, NJ. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Sirotin). Devoted father of Peggy, Lynn and Liz. Loving grandfather of Jennifer Backer, Megan and Ryan Hardiman, Justin and Molly Schaeffer. Great-grandfather of Garrett and Nina Backer. Mr. Harris spent his entire career at Macy's, rising to Senior Vice President and Director of Bamberger's, a division of R.H. Macy and Co. He was a WWII Navy veteran. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ. For information 800-522-0588.

8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- In this two-part, pre-season special, Ty Pennington and his team build a high-tech home in Bergenfield, N.J., for the Llanes family, which has several members who are legally blind and another who is deaf. Famous guests include the actress Marlee Matlin (above right, with Paige Hemmis, a designer) as team leader; Don Lafontaine, the movie-trailer voiceover artist, as narrator; and the gospel group the Blind Boys of Alabama, which will perform. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THREE MOONS OVER MILFORD -- There are some things you just don't want to have to hear. Tonight, the residents start confessing to each other after the town priest gives up his profession. 8 P.M. (History) THE SAHARA -- Once as lush as the Garden of Eden, the Sahara is now the most unforgiving place on Earth. This special explores the environmental and sociological changes in the world's largest desert across more than 2,500 years, and examines the myth that, in 525 B.C., a Persian army of 40,000 warriors was buried beneath it by a sandstorm. 8 P.M. (Lifetime) CRIES IN THE DARK -- A detective (Eva LaRue) investigates the murder of her nine-months-pregnant sister, and the kidnapping of her baby. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS -- The White Stripes (left) perform in a benefit concert to raise money for Bart after his drumming arm is mangled by a tiger. 8:30 P.M. (CBS) THE AMAZING RACE 10 -- In this season premiere, 12 teams of two contestants each, including a coal miner and his wife and a couple of reigning beauty queens, prepare to travel more than 40,000 miles across 13 countries on four continents in under a month for a cool $1 million. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE INSPECTOR LYNLEY MYSTERIES, SERIES V: IN THE GUISE OF DEATH -- Did a horse trainer's money troubles really lead him to hang himself? In this new ''Mystery!'' episode, Inspector Thomas Lynley (Nathaniel Parker) contemplates murder, and tightens the noose around his future. 9 P.M. (Discovery) ASSAULT ON WACO -- On April 19, 1993, after a 51-day standoff with federal agents, the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., went up in flames, killing 76 members of the religious group, including 27 children and its leader, David Koresh. This documentary goes inside the compound (where the Mount Carmel Chapel, above, now stands as a memorial) using archival film footage, and recreates the F.B.I.'s efforts to bring Koresh in. 10 P.M. (E!) THE GIRLS NEXT DOOR -- ''I See London, I See France.'' Bet that's not all Hugh Hefner sees when he tours Europe with his three girlfriends. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
Dandy flourishes for the Wilde at heart.

Three years ago, new ownership turned The Good Food Store, which offered all kinds of food and culinary accessories, into Good Food Good Things. The ''things'' now take up three-quarters of the store, and the remaining quarter, the Good Food section, is owned by Diane Browne, a caterer, with Stacey Campbell as chef. A large kitchen, visible behind the main display counter, is the home base of Ms. Browne's catering service and the origin of baked goods, sandwiches, salads and soups made daily. A freezer display case features tasty ready-to-reheat items like quiches, soups and pies. Bakery items include brownies, blondies, fruit tarts, giant cookies, pies and cakes made to order. Stools and counters make it possible to eat on the premises. In warm weather you can sit at picnic tables on a deck in the rear, facing the parking lot.

Mathieu Amalric ''It's very difficult for me to go in shops,'' says Mathieu Amalric, 40. ''I just wear things that lovers offer me.'' His shirts are sometimes courtesy of his father, ''because he likes to go places where they sell lots of not-very-expensive shirts.'' After winning a César in 2005 for his role in ''Kings & Queen'' and gaining exposure in the United States as an elegant French informant in ''Munich,'' Amalric can be seen in October in ''Marie Antoinette'' (albeit briefly). This month he begins filming Julian Schnabel's ''The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,'' but he's most looking forward to directing his own film, ''because I am most of all a director.'' Naturellement. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

Score One for France THE French are used to the Germans getting attention for automotive engineering, but when Mercedes-Benz, with the flowing lines of its CLS, and BMW, with its controversial Chris Bangle designs, steal the limelight in style, something must be done. For Peugeot, that something is the 908 RC, a design study to be displayed at the Paris auto show this month. The sleek black 908 RC is an answer to the S-Class or 7 Series, a lux limo powered by a 700-horsepower V-12 diesel designed for endurance racing.

Kim Alyson Krawitz, a daughter of Beverley and Theodore Krawitz of Fayetteville, N.Y., is to be married today to Jonathan Robert Stadin, the son of Audrey and Richard Stadin of Manhattan. Rabbi Charles Sherman is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, with Rabbi Harlan Wechsler participating. The bride, 33, is a field producer in Manhattan for ''Dateline NBC.'' She graduated from Syracuse University. Her father retired as a first vice president for investments in the Syracuse office of Wachovia Securities.

On its Web site, the R. H. Donnelley Corporation crows that its management team ''represents a virtual who's who of industry over-achievers.'' Each senior manager's biography lists his or her college degrees -- except for the company's chairman and chief executive, David C. Swanson. In two earlier press releases and an earlier version of its Web site, Donnelley, the Yellow Pages publisher based in Cary, N.C., said Mr. Swanson graduated from St. Cloud State University in Minnesota.

To the Editor: A problem with Robert Olen Butler's brilliant conceit in ''Severance'' (Sept. 3): After decapitation, consciousness remains in the severed head not for a minute and a half, as your reviewer explains Butler's premise, but for about 30 seconds. In 1905, a French physician timed how long the eyes responded when he called the decapitated man's name. (See my book ''Losing Our Heads: Beheadings in Literature and Culture.'') The Scottish artist Douglas Gordon made an installation piece, ''30 Seconds Text'' (1998), of a dark room, a single light bulb and a text (about consciousness's duration after decapitation) readable in the 30 seconds before the light goes out. To appreciate the full pathos of Butler's subjects, readers may want to pause at the end of the first 80 words, when the thinking has to stop. Beyond that lies only the author's hope. Regina Janes Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The writer is a professor of English at Skidmore College.

A Film listing last Sunday in a preview of the new season omitted the name of a director of the documentary ''The U.S. vs. John Lennon.'' In addition to David Leaf, John Scheinfeld also directed the film.

DONALD R. CODEY JR., the general manager of Freehold Raceway, could not quite understand when several elderly residents stood up at a public meeting in Dover Township this month to complain about the prospect of having an off-track betting parlor in a vacant Grand Union supermarket on busy Route 37. They contended that it would cause undue traffic near their senior developments and induce elderly residents to gamble their savings away. ''When I look at who comes to Freehold, it is mostly people over 50, or even over 60, and it's their daytime enjoyment,'' said Mr. Codey, the brother of Senate President Richard J. Codey. ''Then another senior citizen got up and said there was a flotilla of buses just across the road that go to Atlantic City casinos every day, filled with seniors. Soon, they will be able to spend their money at home in what I think will be a great setting.''

LAURIE COLES has always loved the nightly ritual she shares with her 7-year-old daughter, Madeline, of planning the next day's outfit. Madeline makes the choices, and her taste is bohemian-glam. One day during summer vacation, for instance, she wore a striped tank top with a knee-length pink petticoat layered under her jean skirt. Choosing her own outfits is important for ''her ability to be an individual,'' Ms. Coles said. ''It teaches her to embrace diversity on every level, even in dress.''

In my formative chess years, in the 1940's, there were too many abstract principles and not enough concrete tactics to carry them out. This had the effect of giving the principles a bad name. But it was really the lack of road maps that was to blame. Take, for example, the advice to avoid the exchange of pieces when your advantage is primarily that of space. All well and good, but there are times when it is just a matter of choosing which exchange to make.

Government and team officials are scheduled to break ground Tuesday in Harrison, N.J., on a 25,000-seat stadium for Major League Soccer's New York Red Bulls, as the MetroStars were renamed after being bought in March. Red Bull, the Austria-based energy drink maker that bought the team, is splitting the $100 million cost to build the stadium with the team's former owner, Anschutz Entertainment Group, said Nick Sakiewicz, president of Anschutz's New York division. Anschutz will manage the stadium, he said.

Top officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention received premium bonuses in recent years at the expense of scientists and others who perform much of the agency's scientific work, agency records show. Those inside the office of the centers' director, Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, have benefited the most, the records show.

The memory of 1974 still hangs heavily over this troubled New Mexico town, like a bad spirit drifting down from the sandpaper mesas and scrub-speckled hillsides. That was the year the bodies of three Navajo men were found in nearby Chokecherry Canyon, burned and bludgeoned. The three white high school students charged in their killings were sent not to prison but to reform school.

SCRIBNER--Eunice Russell Bastedo, 96, died on August 15, 2006. Beloved by son, David Scribner Jr. of Manhattan, daughter Susan Heitner of Brooklyn, and Waterbury Ctr., VT, six grandchildren, and 10 great-grandchildren. Descendant of early Dutch and French settlers and founder of the Officers' Club of New York in 1941. Eunice was a daughter of old New York and a mother of the new. Contributions in her memory may be make to Vassar College; (845-437-5465).

To the Editor: In response to ''Call It Booklyn,'' by Sara Gran (Sept. 10), about Brooklyn as the epicenter of the hip and intellectual (read: elitist), I would like to point out that the real Brooklyn exists to the east of the literary mecca of Park Slope.

Dozens more bodies have been discovered in Baghdad in the past two days, bringing the four-day total to at least 165 and prompting some Sunni Arab leaders to raise new questions about the recent security operation intended take back Baghdad from the insurgents, deaths squads and militias who have been waging sectarian warfare. ''If the result of the security plan is an increase in bodies and killings according to their identification, I think it moves toward a catastrophe,'' said Dhafir al-Ani, a senior member of the main Sunni Arab political bloc in Parliament.

Nebraska cornerback Andre Jones evolved this week from an obscure junior-college transfer to a lightning rod. Jones not only predicted that the No. 19 Cornhuskers would win at No. 4 Southern California on Saturday, but he also projected a ''restored order'' in the college football universe.

THALI is an innovative new restaurant in New Haven whose chef, Prasad Chirnomula, is determined to change the way we think about Indian food. Dishes come from all over India. They are unusual, exciting, and so varied that I am never bored with eating there. The atmosphere, a mix of traditional and contemporary, is more upscale than many of the Indian restaurants I've been to. In the entryway is an exquisite display of roses floating in free-standing copper vessels. Inside, tableware is chic and contemporary. The service is gracious and careful, with an eye toward educating the clientele.

There are two reasons to stop at Culinary Creations in Hillsborough in the morning. The first, of course, is breakfast -- plum and pecan pancakes, for example, prepared with buckwheat flour, fresh plums and pecans ($5.25). Or a crab meat strata, an egg casserole filled with lump crab meat and fresh tomatoes, topped with Swiss cheese ($6.95). Or corned beef hash patties ($2.50 each), or eggs over easy with red-potato home fries, and a choice of herb-grained wheat bread or panella toast, from a round Italian loaf ($3.99). Around 9 o'clock, lunch specials are posted, and ''that's the time folks order lunch or dinner to go,'' said Andrew Pantano, the executive chef and proprietor of the cafe, which has been open since 1995. He is a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

Loren Foster Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Oliver Smith III of Rye, N.Y., was married there last evening to Michael Sadlier Dinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sadlier Dinger of New York. The Rev. Daniel Love performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church, where the Rev. Carlos Quintana Puente, a Roman Catholic priest, participated. Mrs. Dinger, 28, works in Stamford, Conn., as an associate in the foreign exchange group of UBS, the Swiss bank. She graduated from Yale and received a master's degree in international relations from Johns Hopkins.
To the Editor: Re ''Cheney's Power No Longer Goes Unquestioned'' (front page, Sept. 10):

In 1949, when the freethinking novelist Boris Vian wrote his ''Manual of Saint-Germain-des-Prés,'' this neighborhood, which straddles the Boulevard Saint-Germain in Paris, was wild with postwar jubilation. Since then, the raucous cellar dives that nurtured luminaries like James Baldwin and Jean Genet have been eclipsed by establishments of a decidedly more consumerist nature. Still, anyone who spends more than five minutes on the Place Sartre-Beauvoir will see that the people passing through are prêt à party.

LAURIE COLES has always loved the nightly ritual she shares with her 7-year-old daughter, Madeline, of planning the next day's outfit. Madeline makes the choices, and her taste is bohemian-glam. One day during summer vacation, for instance, she wore a striped tank top with a knee-length pink petticoat layered under her jean skirt. Choosing her own outfits is important for ''her ability to be an individual,'' Ms. Coles said. ''It teaches her to embrace diversity on every level, even in dress.''

To the Editor: Re ''The Stranger in the Mirror'' (column, Sept. 14): Bob Herbert caused me to contemplate Franklin D. Roosevelt's famous line, ''The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.'' What did F.D.R. mean when he said we should fear the emotion of fear? Mr. Herbert provides the answer.
Absent a clear party stance, some Democrats keep their comments on Iraq vague; others offer specifics. With the public split, there are risks either way. Week in Review.

Bob Sheppard, the Yankees' public address announcer, gingerly made his way into the Boston locker room before the first game of the doubleheader in search of the rookie reliever Craig Hansen. Sheppard had followed Hansen's career at St. John's, where Sheppard had been the public address announcer long before Hansen pitched there. (Hansen was named Big East pitcher of the year in 2005.) Sheppard told Hansen, 22, how he had announced the names of St. John's pitchers like Frank Viola. Hansen had never pitched at Yankee Stadium, and Sheppard said he hoped to announce his name this weekend.

To the Editor: Richard Brookhiser's essay ''John Adams Talks to His Books'' (Sept. 3) reminds us that literature -- and by literature I do not intend to limit the discussion to canonical texts -- is interactive and engages the reader in real-time dialogue. Texts inspire us, anger us, frustrate us, delight us and elevate us, but most important, they invite us to enter the forum they inhabit and participate in the discourse they generate. The metaphysical implications of this phenomenon are intriguing, albeit abstruse (hence Derrida's ''Il n'y a pas de hors-texte''), but it is helpful to bear in mind that during its nascent stages writing was monopolized by the priestly class and the oracles. These philosophical ramblings, unfortunately, digress from Brookhiser's central thrust and are best left in the margins. Lawton King Camp Fallujah, Iraq
To have and to hold on to.

HERE'S something to think about as college students across the state settle into campus life. According to a recently released study by the Department of Education, paying for college is a greater burden for New Yorkers than in any other state. The costs for low- and middle-income students to attend public universities and community colleges here represent nearly 50 percent of their annual family income. Furthermore, a new study on higher education put out by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, a nonprofit group, gave New York a failing grade for affordability.

YOU may have noticed that it was a banner year for chipmunks. This spring brought forth torrents of the chubby-cheeked rodents, scurrying up drainpipes, darting through stone walls, undermining shrubs, perennials and masonry with the brio of Brooklyn's mightiest tunnel sandhogs. The terrain around house and garden took on the perils of a prairie dog village, with ankle-spraining sinkholes every few feet. For the first time, I saw chipmunks scampering higher than squirrels in the pin oaks, doing greedy reconnaissance on the bird feeders below. This year's furry tide turned our middle-aged beagle, Maybelle, into a pup again. She stalked, dug, yipped and pounced herself into tiptop physical form. She has never caught a chipmunk in seven years of trying. They dart between her legs and chatter tauntingly from just beyond the perimeter of her electric dog fence. Sheer numbers increased her odds of bagging one this season. But suddenly, in early August, she gave up the chase. Heaving herself onto the sunny deck with a great sigh, she lay resigned, watching the wee marauders with the gimlet eye of a defeated old general surveying a superior ground force.
They stroll the streets in Euro-preppy style.

D'ELISA--John E. , age 66, died on August 24, 2006.He was born on December 28, 1939 in NY, to the late John B. D'Elisa and Frances Sofarelli. He graduated from Lawrence HS in 1957, Bucknell Univ. (BS, Elec. Engineering) in 1961 and Polytechnic Inst. of NY (MS, Elec. Engineering) in 1968. John spent over 25 years on Wall Street where his innovative mind led him to success at Prudential Bache, Bear Stearns, Josephthal & Co., Ladenburg Thalmann and, most recently, G.C. Andersen Partners. One particularly notable account of John's business acumen, integrity and savvy is memorialized in the 1995 book, 'Serpent on the Rock.? John was an avid golfer, sports-car lover and longtime NY Giants fan and his enthusiasm was pervasive in any setting. Those close to John will remember him for his passion, determination and absolute devotion to family. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Marjorie; sons, Paul, John, Thomas and James; daughters, Vera and Allison; grandchildren Nicole, John, Michael, Matthew, Kyle and Christina. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his sister, Amelia (Gildersleeve).
Communic8 yr personality with accessories that feel as gr8 as they look.

Dr. Jennifer Mei-Ling Tsung and Dr. Derek Lewis Fried, veterinarians, were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul Rock performed the ceremony at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, with Rabbi Richard Davis taking part. Dr. Tsung, 31, is keeping her name. She practices at the Animal Clinic of Bensonhurst in Brooklyn and at the Staten Island Veterinary Group. She graduated cum laude from New York University and received her veterinary degree from the Royal Veterinary College, University of London.

As Hewlett-Packard struggled with the stormy reaction to its hiring of private investigators who spied on its own directors, several employees and some journalists, it is easy to wonder if anyone at the company ever thought to summon the help of someone known as ''a modern-day James Bond.'' That someone is Ira Winkler, a company employee who labeled himself thusly in his 2005 book ''Spies Like Us.'' Though he has been identified at security conferences as the company's ''chief security strategist'' or ''chief security evangelist,'' Mr. Winkler actually sells information technology services, and does not chase board room leakers.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Turkey: A Christian Shrine in a Muslim Land'' by Scott Spencer: People may indeed be surprised that the final home of Mary, mother of Jesus, according to pious legend, is in Ephesus, now part of Turkey (above). Until the Turks arrived about 700 years ago to settle permanently, the region had been Greek for about 2,000 years (it was, at different points throughout its Greek history, under the influence of the Persians, Romans or Byzantines). Mary is not only mentioned more than 30 times in the Koran, but she is also the only woman to have a sura, or chapter, named after her. The Rev. Edward Franks Boston

THE historic marker reads simply, ''Old Burial Hill.'' Next to Main Street, or Route 25A, in Huntington, just a block east of Route 110, what was the main cemetery of the Towns of Huntington and Babylon three centuries ago has gone largely unnoticed for decades. It was so neglected that weeds, vines, saplings and trees had taken root.

Your ''Recipe Redux'' on meringue indeed took me back (Aug. 20). I grew up under the kitchen tutelage of my mother, who made adequate basic meals on a tight budget and fabulous desserts.We were a minister's family in small-town North Carolina, and there were always guests at our table and endless receptions,meetings, church suppers and open houses. Meringues were her specialty. She made them large and small and topped them with incredible concoctions. My favorite was homemade peppermint ice cream with chocolate sauce, sprinkled with crushed peppermint candy. Although the recipe is simple, the timing can be tricky, and also the weather. I loved the chewy little meringues that, because they hadlost their crisp perfection in hot, humid summer, my mother wouldn't serve to company. Rena Ruark Lindstrom Provincetown, Mass.

At 26, the actor Peter Scanavino is more than the sum of his parts. Which is good, because he can claim only two major roles (on the New York stage, that is).But they're both stunners. Last spring, he made his Broadway debut as an Irish rent boy in Conor McPherson's Tony-nominated ''Shining City.'' Starting this month, he appears as an alcoholic Air Force veteran in the off-Broadway revival of Eric Bogosian's ''SubUrbia.'' Scanavino's clothes aren't the only thing that's casual on these pages: he also takes the no-frills approach to grooming. ''I've been cutting my own hair for the past four years,'' he says. ''My hair's kind of crappy. And if I comb it, it's much worse.'' Both onstage and off, Scanavino uses small gestures to say a lot. ''Sometimes when I get too styled up, I feel a bit phony.'' During the day, he prefers something more sincere: a vintage Japanese T-shirt of the only band that matters, the Clash. Paul L. Underwood

To the Editor: ''Who's Killing Long Island Sound?,'' by Tom Andersen (Op-Ed, Sept. 3), could not have been better timed. As beaches along the coast closed to swimming on Labor Day weekend, many people were reminded that clean water is not a luxury. It is a necessity.

The On the Street column on Sept. 3 referred incorrectly to the lips-and-tongue logo of the Rolling Stones. It was designed by John Pasche, not Andy Warhol. (Mr. Warhol did create the cover for the band's ''Sticky Fingers'' album, which included the logo on the inside sleeve.)
George Sprott (1894-1975)

The Explorer column on Sept. 3 about Ephesus, Turkey, misstated the origin of the belief that the Virgin Mary once lived there. Although a German nun in the 1800's did indeed say that a house in Ephesus appeared in her visions as the residence of the Virgin Mary, the association between the town and the Virgin Mary dates to the early years of Christianity. Also, an accompanying map included an outdated name for a Turkish city near Ephesus. It is now known as Izmir, not Smyrna.

American museums have been so occupied for the last few years with matters far from home, among them the call for greater coverage of Islamic culture, that they have often passed over domestic themes and issues. One of these is the situation of Native American artists in the contemporary art world, the subject of a fun and intriguing, but not entirely successful, exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. Usually such exhibitions herd together disparate artists with any amount of Native American blood in their veins, the idea being that the appellation belongs to anyone who claims the ancestry. So it was reasonable to expect that the artists in ''No Reservations: Native American History and Culture in Contemporary Art'' would be descendants, no matter how remote, of American Indians, Eskimos or Aleuts.

ROMAN ROTH, who has mastered modern technology and cellar methods, did not trample out the vintage for the 2001 merlot he has just released under his new label, the Grapes of Roth. Instead, he used his hands and heart. Mr. Roth, the winemaker at Wölffer Estate, on the South Fork, bought the grapes at Martha Clara Vineyards, on the North Fork, for his first personal release.

For most chief executives, stepping down means a hefty cut in pay. But that is not how things went for Clifton H. Morris Jr., when at 71 he gave up the top job at the AmeriCredit Corporation after 14 years as chief executive. Last year, when AmeriCredit's board approved a salary of $950,000 for Mr. Morris's successor, Daniel E. Berce, 52, it also granted Mr. Morris a $100,000 raise, lifting his salary as chairman to $900,000, according to a document filed last week.

VERENA and Rolf Baumgartner have been married for 34 years and have run Brasserie Swiss for nearly 29. One imagines that entering the Ossining restaurant is like visiting their home, with its upright piano against one wall, pictures of Switzerland everywhere and soft yodeling playing in the background. It is a comfortable, friendly place and -- this is the key to its appeal -- emphatically untrendy. There is no chocolate lava cake or the latest take on pan-seared sea bass. Instead, you'll find authentic, delicious interpretations of traditional Swiss favorites. The menu and décor may not have changed in decades, but both are presented with care and love.

The latest Siena poll not only has Spitzer maintainig his commanding lead over John Faso, this time at 51 percentage points, but also shows him leading among Republican voters. The poll found that Spitzer holds an 8-point lead among members of Mr. Faso's own party.

The truckmaker Scania rejected a 9.6 billion euro ($12.2 billion) takeover bid from a German rival, MAN, on Monday. Overall crime rates continued to decline in New York last year, as vehicle thefts dropped almost 13 percent, although robberies edged up from 2004, according to a F. B.I. report. The rate of violent crime in New York increased 1.2 percent, similar to the 1.3 percent increase nationally. The level of crimes tracked by the F.B.I. declined 3 percent from 2004, largely because of a 12.7 percent drop in motor vehicle thefts and a 3.8 percent decline in property crime.

A 3-month-old girl died Saturday at a shelter where she and her mother had been staying, the police said yesterday, and the incident is being investigated by the Administration for Children’s Services. The infant’s 18-year-old mother left the baby in the care of another resident at Fox House, a shelter on East 117th Street where they lived, while she went out on Friday night, the police said. When the mother returned, she took the infant with her back to her room and at some point vomited into a plastic bucket, the police said. She found the infant in that bucket about 2:40 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. The police questioned the mother but released her without bringing charges.

Italy won its first Fed Cup title yesterday, beating Belgium, 3-2, after Justine Henin-Hardenne was forced to retire because of searing knee pain during the deciding doubles match at Charleroi, Belgium. Henin-Hardenne, the runner-up at the United States Open and the French Open champion, won both her singles matches during the weekend despite assorted health problems. She abandoned the final during the third set of doubles. The Italian duo of Francesca Schiavone and Roberta Vinci defeated Henin-Hardenne and Kirsten Flipkens, 3-6, 6-2, 2-0.

A new advertisement touting the work of city police detectives will be placed on 490 buses around New York beginning today, according to officials with the Detectives’ Endowment Association, the union that represents about 5,200 working detectives. The ad is designed to “boost morale within the ranks” and raise public awareness about detectives’ contribution in reducing crime, said Michael J. Palladino, the detectives’ union president.

Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for state attorney general, assailed her Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo, yesterday on the issue of reducing fraud in the Medicaid system. At a news conference in Lower Manhattan, Ms. Pirro noted that Mr. Cuomo, in a meeting with editors at Crain’s New York Business, had called the notion of amnesty for businesses involved in Medicaid fraud “intriguing.” Ms. Pirro said, “His approach is to give amnesty to Medicaid cheats. This kind of approach makes it very clear that my opponent does not understand the role of the attorney general.” Wendy Katz, a spokeswoman for the Cuomo campaign, said that amnesty was not part of his plan for reducing Medicaid fraud and added, “The fraud is in the misleading attacks against Andrew just three days after Ms. Pirro pledged to run a positive campaign.”.

A teenager was fatally stabbed early yesterday in what the police said was an argument over a boy. The victim, Elsa Comacho, 17, of Yorktown Heights, was a student at Yorktown High School. She was pronounced dead at Westchester County Medical Center. New York State Police arrested another 17-year-old last night and charged her with first-degree manslaughter. They did not name the suspect but said she attended Lakeland High School. Sgt. Rodney Rogers, at the state police’s Troop K barracks in Cortlandt, said the suspect was scheduled to be arraigned today. The two girls began arguing by phone over a mutual male friend late Saturday night and then met, each accompanied by friends, Sergeant Rogers said. Their argument escalated and led to the stabbing, he said.

David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat on the City Council and the chairman of its Finance Committee, urged the Department of Finance yesterday to suspend its efforts to collect about $11.5 million in unpaid taxes from customers for cigarettes purchased online. In 2003, the city began to crack down on Internet-based cigarette vendors, some of whom had falsely claimed that they were not required to collect sales taxes. The city is trying to collect $6.95 million in unpaid taxes from more than 16,000 customers of dirtcheapcigs.com and $4.48 million from 12,012 customers of esmokes.com. Mr. Weprin said that many of the customers were misled by the vendors and should not have to pay back taxes if they made only a few purchases.

Shots were fired last night in at least two places in a crowd that had massed in Harlem to watch a parade, and three young men were wounded, the police and witnesses said. All three were considered likely to survive, a police spokesman said. Thousands of people had gathered to watch the African-American Day Parade, and many lingered into the evening, after the parade ended. The shootings set off panic in the throng, as people ran and dived for cover. One man was shot at 135th Street and Lenox Avenue, and two others at 131st Street and Eighth Avenue.

A man was fatally shot in a Bedford-Stuyvesant park on Saturday night by a robber who wanted his necklace, the police and the man’s friends said yesterday. The man, Kyle Barnes, 23, was in Tompkins Park shortly before 11:30 p.m. on Saturday when a man approached and demanded his necklace depicting Jesus, said his friend Tommie Walton, 50. When Mr. Barnes refused, the robber shot him, near the corner of Tompkins and Greene Avenues, Mr. Walton said. The police said there were no arrests yesterday. Mr. Barnes had lived in the neighborhood around the park for several years before moving to East New York in December, and he returned often, his friends said.

EYES ON THE FED The main news of the week will be the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at which the central bankers are widely expected to keep interest rates steady (Wednesday). Last week’s news that the Consumer Price Index had risen 0.2 percent in August, down from 0.4 percent in July, looked to some economists like validation that inflation was slowing, a trend that would not tempt the Fed to raise rates. But the Producer Price Index for August also comes out this week, helping to inform any decision (Tuesday). Other reports this week will include the second-quarter current-account deficit (Monday), August housing starts (Tuesday) and leading economic indicators (Thursday).

Tiny El Salvador is pulling out all the stops to sell itself as the business-meeting hub for Central America.
The war in neighboring Iraq has provided a significant charge to Jordan’s economy and status as a business-travel destination.
Business travelers are flocking to Almaty, Kazakhstan's largest city. And the country's oil riches are paying for vast improvements on hospitality.
This former Portuguese colony, which was returned to China in 1999, is not just booming, it’s being radically transformed.
With globalization, your next destination might be a location of odd reputation.
