To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of business travelers who write blogs have learned that their Web journals are more than online platforms to blow off steam.
Offsetting, the practice of achieving carbon neutrality, is gaining popularity among companies wishing to make a show of their green credentials.
As travel has gotten harder, Web conferencing has gotten easier. All it takes is a broadband connection, a laptop and a Webcam. So why does anybody go anywhere any more?
For frequent business fliers, eating good regional food can break up the grinding monotony of travel. And the people who design airport terminals are responding.
Penny-pinching corporate travel departments and miserly per diems have made life miserable. But spirited competition among lower-priced lodgings has given business travelers hope.
Many companies are finding that the higher cost of using private business jets is balanced by the gains achieved in time and efficiency.
Innovation has yielded a new crop of lean consumer electronics that are poised to transform how businesspeople do their work without compromising speed, power and function.
For the weary but well-off business traveler, the best hotels can be a sanctuary — oases of good service and high thread-count linens, at a price, of course.
Henry Ford’s fabled Willow Run Airport, once the largest bomber factory in the world,  has gained new prominence and credibility in the post-9/11 universe.
Even with new and ever-changing security policies, business travelers can streamline their airport experience.
A number of airports and nearby hotels are making it easier for travelers to keep up with their exercise routines while on the go.
Numbed by the rising cost of air tickets, American travelers are increasingly aware of the vast web of European routes served by no-frills airlines.
The Patriots are 2-0 after their victory against the Jets on Sunday, but neither of the victories has been convincing.
President Bush’s national security adviser is negotiating with the senators who oppose permitting extreme interrogation techniques.
Ivan Luini helped bring plastic furniture out of the garden and into the American living room. Sergio Savarese also died in the crash, in Moffat County, Colo.
What we’ve seen over the past few years from Bush, Cheney & Company has been the stuff of Kafka, not Madison and Jefferson.
Upstaged by MySpace, MTV will introduce Virtual Laguna Beach, where fans can immerse themselves in virtual versions of the show’s  hangouts.
The Jets are 1-1 this season, while the Patriots lead the division. With these two teams, that’s the same old story.
Sunday’s game was a shot of inspiration for the Giants,  and a dose of reality for the Eagles.
Why is President Bush so determined to engage in torture?
CROHN--Michael. In honor of your 50th birthday. Forever missed, forever loved. Mom, Dad, Jeff, Kathy, Leah, Nolan, and Marion

A theater review on Friday about ''Theophilus North,'' at the Harold Clurman Theater, misstated a quotation from Tennyson's ''Ulysses'' that was used in the production. The quotation is ''I am a part of all that I have met,'' not ''all that I have seen.''

Forker--Helen Elizabeth ''Betty'', of Venice, FL, died of heart failure on September 14, 2006. She was born in New York City and came to Venice in 1992 from Southport, CT. She was a graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 91st St, and Manhattanville College. Mrs. Forker was a homemaker and real estate agent for Jenson Phillips Real Estate in Southport. She was a member of Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church and the Plantation Golf and Country Club in Venice. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Victor Sr.; sons, Victor Jr. of Chesapeake, VA, Peter of Chicago, IL, Paul of West Boxford, MA, and Philip of Tualatin, OR; daughter Elizabeth Larsen of New York City; and seven grandchildren. Mrs. Forker was the daughter of the late Judge John P. O'Brien, former mayor of New York City. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church on Wednesday, September 20th, at 2 PM. The family has requested memorial donations be made to Tidewell Hospice and Palliative Care, 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL 34238; or the American Heart Association, 1230 Tuttle Avenue, Sarasota, FL 34239. Contact Farley Funeral Home, Venice, FL, for further information.
To the Editor: Re ''Dying, but Aware'' (letter, Sept. 13):
RYDEN--Albert, G. December 22, 1907-September 18, 1981. How many times a day do I think of you? How many roses are sprinkled with dew? Your Loving Wife & Family

EPSTEIN--Barbara B. Beloved daughter of the late Muriel Wise Epstein and Max Irving Epstein, sister of Irene Spencer and member of the Epstein family of Boston, Massachusetts, aunt of Denise Hawks and loving greataunt of Casey Lam, departed peacefully at home after a short illness, on September 16th, 2006. A graduate of Goucher College in Baltimore, Maryland, and senior vice president RBC Dain Raucher, a stockbroker for many years. Active in the Women's Financial Association, Murry Bergtraum High School Mentoring program, Central Synagogue, the alumni association of Goucher College, she was a proud member of the American Film Society and the Roundabout Theatre. She was devoted to family, friends, fine dining and love of travel. Special appreciation to caring friend Veronica Walters. Donations may be made in her memory to Cochella Valley Desert Visionaires, 2471 Playa Circle, Palm Springs, California 92264, where she was a member of the board, or a charity of your choice. Funeral will be held at 1:30 PM, on Monday, Sept 18, at Frank Campbell, 81st and Madison Ave. $(6$)EPSTEIN--Barbara B. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Barbara. The years of our adult lives have been filled with the times we shared. We cannot look back without remembering her. We cannot look forward without missing her. We will always treasure her. As long as we live, she too will live; for she is now a part of us as we remember her. Muriel Siebert and June and Alex Jaffee $(6$)EPSTEIN--Barbara. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Barbara Epstein. We extend our condolences to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Howard Sharfstein, President

A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''The U.S. vs. John Lennon'' misspelled the surname of a University of California history professor who has written about Lennon and appears in the film. He is Jon Wiener, not Weiner.

HARL--Sidney W. The Board of Directors of the William S. Paley Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of Sidney W. Harl, a dedicated and longtime Director and officer. For over 50 years our colleague was a trusted personal and financial advisor to the late William S. Paley and the Paley Foundation. His insights, wisdom and friendship will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family, Kenneth Harl, and Karen, Danny, Melissa and Jessica Cicale. Dr. Henry A. Kissinger, Chairman Patrick S. Gallagher George J. Gillespie III Daniel L. Mosley William C. Paley

IF water always finds its own level, so do pro football teams. And with yesterday's 24-17 loss to New England, the Jets had to realize that their level remains well below that of the Patriots, the perennial American Football Conference East champions. The Jets showed resolve in rallying from a 24-0 deficit early in the third quarter on wide receiver Jerricho Cotchery's handstand at midfield en route to a 71-yard touchdown, and on wide receiver Laveranues Coles's jitterbug dash on a 46-yard touchdown. But their defense couldn't stop third-down passes by Tom Brady that triggered the Patriots' surgical 53-yard drive that swallowed about eight of the last nine minutes.

LINDENBAUM -- Belle (nee Axelrad). Died peacefully in her 98th year on September 17, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Abraham M. (Bunny). Devoted mother of Sandy and Linda. Loving grandmother of Erica (Steven M. Tishman) and Laurie (Robert A. Horne). Cherished greatgrandmother of Adam, Stuart and Julia Tishman, and Sarah, Max and Rachel Horne. Adored sister of Claire Feiden and Pearl Grey. She was the family's beautiful and elegant matriarch. Her warmth, love, generosity and, especially, her sense of humor will never be forgotten. Funeral services private. Shiva will be observed on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the home of Linda and Sandy Lindenbaum, from 5 to 8 pm. $(6$)LINDENBAUM -- Belle. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Lindenbaum family. Belle was an incredible sister and sister-in-law who was always there for us. She and her late husband Bunny were the glue that held the family together. We will always remember and miss her intelligence, caring and fantastic sence of humor. Claire and Murray Feiden $(6$)LINDENBAUM -- Belle. The elegant matriarch of the family, ''Bammy Belle'' loved to laugh and share her many wonderful memories of growing up in a big family. Bammy was the best grandmother and great-grandmother in the world. We will miss you and always love you. Love, Erica, Laurie, Steven and Bob $(6$)LINDENBAUM -- Belle. My deepest sympathy and love to the entire Lindenbaum family. Aunt Belle, who I loved and adored my entire life. We laughed, gossiped and shared decades of memories together till the very end. I will miss her forever. Rica Tarnoff

While Army fell short of upsetting Texas A&M (3-0) on Saturday, the Cadets are making steady progress under their third-year coach, Bobby Ross. Trailing by 28-24, Army (1-2) had a first down at the Texas A&M 2-yard line with 13 seconds left and no timeouts. After an incomplete pass, running back Tony Moore was tackled for a loss on the final play.

To the Editor: In ''How to Win by Losing'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 13), Ramesh Ponnuru argues that Republicans could ''win by losing'' if they fail to maintain control of the House but keep the Senate in 2006, because this would put the G.O.P. in a better position to win in 2008.

Nels Cline ''New Monastery: A View into the Music of Andrew Hill'' (Cryptogramophone) The compositions of Andrew Hill, one of the best composers in the last 50 years of jazz, don't glow with the recognizable style of a certain time. They use unusual harmonies and can sometimes seem to be missing the proper signposts. Nobody performs them as effectively as his own groups, with Mr. Hill on piano. Not even close.

LIEBER--Stanley. We deeply mourn the passing of our founding member and devoted friend, and pray that Anita and the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Eliot Peyser, President

WANG--C. C. The Board of Governors and members of The Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Cheng Ching Wang. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. William Murphy, President

A new advertisement touting the work of city police detectives will be placed on 490 buses around New York beginning today, according to officials with the Detectives' Endowment Association, the union that represents about 5,200 working detectives. The ad is designed to ''boost morale within the ranks'' and raise public awareness about detectives' contribution in reducing crime, said Michael J. Palladino, the detectives' union president. AL BAKER (NYT)
ROUBLEV--Flora Ohana. 102 years. Friday, September 15. She touched many hearts. Service Monday, September 25, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, at 2 pm.

The Israeli government established a committee on Sunday to investigate the political and military leadership's handling of the recent war in Lebanon, which has come under intense public criticism in the month since the fighting ended. In Israel, which expects swift and decisive military victories, many citizens say that the military campaign in Lebanon was poorly planned and executed, and that leaders should be held accountable. Israel could not halt the rocket fire into northern Israel by the Lebanese group Hezbollah, and it has not achieved the return of two soldiers Hezbollah captured in the cross-border raid on July 12 that ignited the monthlong conflict.
To the Editor: ''Death of a Farmer,'' by Verlyn Klinkenborg (The Rural Life, Sept. 14), is a lesson for all of us who come from farms, that when the older generation dies, something is lost.

BEHIND ABC'S 9/11 SERIES -- It is little wonder that ABC's mini-series ''The Path to 9/11'' drew stinging criticism for its invented scenes, made-up dialogue and unsubstantiated accounts. A more puzzling question is why ABC spent $30 million on what amounted to a five-hour public service announcement. [Page C1.] FROM HUNTER TO HUNTED -- Duane Chapman, the star of A&E's ''Dog the Bounty Hunter,'' found himself on the other side of the handcuffs last week because of a three-year-old charge stemming from one of his captures. The latest turn in the story probably won't hurt ratings. A&E plans a special on him tomorrow night, and the stories about his travails are likely to add to his legend. [E1.] THE FUTURE OF SATELLITE TV -- The idea that Rupert Murdoch, who controls the News Corporation, would be willing to surrender his stake in DirecTV, the largest American satellite broadcaster, says a lot about the competitive pressures on the satellite business. [C5.] NEW LASER-GENERATING CHIP -- Researchers plan to announce that they have created a silicon-based chip that can produce laser beams. The advance will make it possible to remove the most significant bottleneck in computer design. [C1.] WANTING MORE FROM FORD -- Analysts were not satisfied last week as Ford called for 44,000 job cuts and other drastic changes. For all of the stunning admissions Ford made, Wall Street wanted more answers. [C1.] MTV'S VIRTUAL WORLD -- MTV aims to push the boundaries of fake reality one step further with Virtual Laguna Beach, an online service in which fans of the show can immerse themselves -- or, at least, digitized, three-dimensional characters called avatars -- in virtual versions of the show's seaside hangouts. [C1.] NICKELODEON FOCUSES ON PARENTS -- Nickelodeon, the children's cable channel, is seeking to move into a new demographic. Its first step is ParentsConnect.com, a social networking Web site. [C6.] BLACKBERRY'S NEW PUSH -- BlackBerry, whose service is irresistible to many businesspeople, is trying to spread its wireless e-mail addiction to mainstream consumers. [C5.] AWARDS FOR THE AUDIENCE -- As the latest example of Broadway's embrace of modern marketing techniques, the Nederlander Organization has created an awards program for theatergoers. [E1.]

To the Editor: ''In the Netherlands, Life Runs on 2 Wheels (Sometimes 3)'' (Ijmuiden Journal, Sept. 14) says the increase in bicycle ownership is a result of ''greater affluence and more free time'' in the Netherlands.

A Sept. 7 article on lightweight men's T-shirts included comments by John Dewis, an actor, who praised shirts made by American Apparel. The Times has since learned that Mr. Dewis once modeled other clothing by American Apparel in its advertisements. His comments would not have been included in the article had The Times known of his association with the company.

INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Pope Issues Rare Apology For Remarks on Islam Pope Benedict XVI sought to extinguish anger among Muslims by issuing what experts describe as a first in recent memory, a personal apology for having caused offense with a speech that cited a reference that said Islam had introduced ''things only evil and inhuman.'' He said the quotations came from a medieval text and did not express his personal thoughts. A1 Chinese in World Bank Territory Eager for stable friends in Southeast Asia, China is making large-scale loans to countries that used to be the sole preserve of the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, the United States and Japan. China's loans in that region are often more attractive than the condition-based, complicated loans from the West. A1 Conservative Wins in Sweden Sweden voted to reject its prime minister, Goran Persson, whose party, the Social Democrats, has governed Sweden alone or in coalitions for 65 of the past 74 years. He was replaced by a conservative candidate who has pledged to revise the Swedish welfare state. A16 Tribes Unite Against Al-Qaeda Twenty-five of about 31 tribes in Anbar Province, Iraq, have agreed to join forces and fight Al-Qaeda insurgents and other foreign-backed ''terrorists,'' an influential tribal leader said. Iraqi government leaders encouraged the movement. A12 Afghan Forces See Local Anger American and Afghan forces moved into Andar District, Afghanistan, as part of a broader operation to reassert control in Ghazni, a strategically important province near Kabul. But while they encountered little insurgent activity, they did face anger from the local population. A3 German Far Right Gains Ground Germany's National Democratic Party, which openly espouses xenophobic and neo-Nazi views, won seats in a state election in Mecklenburg-West Pomerania. A16 NATIONAL A19-24 New Details Emerge On Hewlett's Investigation A secret investigation of news leaks at Hewlett-Packard was more elaborate than previously reported, and almost from the start involved theft of private phone records and surveillance of board members and journalists, said people briefed on the company's review of the operation. A1 Threat Response Is Criticized Project BioShield, a $5.6 billion push to exploit the country's top medical and scientific brains and fill an emergency medical cabinet with new drugs and vaccines for a host of threats, has largely failed to deliver, critics say. A1 Virginia Senate Race Tightens Democratic strategists see a seat in Virginia as one of the six they need to regain a majority in the Senate. Their candidate, a highly decorated Vietnam veteran, James Webb, is in an uphill battle against a paragon of sunbelt conservatism, Senator George Allen, Republican. A1 Nuclear Plants' Safety Faulted An analysis of nuclear reactors by a safety group has found that they are prone to costly, lengthy shutdowns for safety problems regardless of their age or the experience of their managers. The finding could have implications for companies considering building new reactors. A19 White House Seeks Deal President Bush's national security adviser signaled that he was seeking a compromise with the Republican senators who are rebelling against the administration's proposal to permit certain severe interrogation practices against terrorism suspects. A20 Curbing Politics of Churches The Internal Revenue Service, in response to increased political activity from charities, including churches, during the 2004 elections, announced a renewed effort to enforce laws that limit charities' involvement in partisan political campaigns. A20 E. coli Outbreak Continues A second California company has been implicated in the E. coli outbreak linked to spinach, the Food and Drug Administration said. A23 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Candidates for Governor Endorse Pataki's Vision Eliot Spitzer and John Faso, the two major candidates for governor of New York, gave their support to an agreement announced by Gov. George E. Pataki under which federal and state agencies would become the anchor tenants of the Freedom Tower under construction at ground zero. B1 Riverside Minister to Retire Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister at Riverside Church, announced that he plans to retire next year after 18 years of service, stating that he wants to concentrate on a new ministry aimed at ''maximizing the witness for spiritual revitalization and the nation's spiritual revitalization.'' B1 ARTS E1-10 Broadway Audience Rewards The Nederlander Organization, in the latest example of Broadway's fervent, if sometimes awkward embrace of modern marketing techniques, has announced the creation of Audience Rewards, an awards program for theatergoers. Nederlander executives say the program's eventual goal will be something similar to frequent flier miles and credit card points. E1 OBITUARIES A25 Patricia Kennedy Lawford A sister of President John F. Kennedy who had a front row seat to history and forged new links between her brother's administration and Hollywood through her marriage to the actor Peter Lawford, she was 71. A25 Ivan Luini Founder and president of the New York-based Kartell US, Inc., who helped popularize plastic furniture, he was 46. A25 Sergio Savarese A designer known for lyrical shapes and a founder of the furniture store Dialogica, he was 48. A25 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 New Chip Moves Data Faster Researchers plan to announce that they have created a silicon-based chip that can produce laser beams. The advance will make it possible to use laser light rather than wires to send data between chips, removing the most significant bottleneck in computer design. C1 ABC's 9/11 Series The ABC mini-series ''The Path to 9/11,'' which drew stinging criticism before it ran, was unable to land sponsors, and the network essentially gave away five hours of network time in promoting the show as a public service. C1 MTV Virtual Reality Show MTV is aiming to push the boundaries of reality television with Virtual Laguna Beach, an online service in which fans of the program can immerse themselves in virtual versions of the show's familiar seaside hangouts. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: A real test for the Palestinians; teaching math, Singapore style; the ghosts of corruption present; a vote for a smarter census. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather A22

Looking Ahead After a smorgasbord of action Saturday that pitted ranked teams against each other in seven games, the pairing of top-25 teams is lighter this week. Only two games match ranked teams: No. 1 Ohio State (3-0) will play host to No. 24 Penn State (2-1), and No. 20 Arizona State (3-0) will visit No. 22 California (2-1). There are, however, other intriguing matchups, like No. 12 Notre Dame (2-1) visiting Michigan State (3-0) and No. 8 Louisville (3-0) traveling to play Kansas State (3-0). Louisville will be without the junior quarterback Brian Brohm, who had surgery yesterday to repair sprained ligaments in his throwing hand. He will miss four to six weeks. Line of the Week 24 of 48, 234 yards, 3 TD's, 3 INT's Brady Quinn struggled in second-ranked Notre Dame's 47-21 home loss to No. 11 Michigan, dealing a setback to his Heisman campaign. The Wolverines produced 17 points off three of his four turnovers. Quinn, a senior quarterback, entered the game having not thrown an interception in 143 pass attempts, a team record, but threw three Saturday. Frantic Finish Murray State 59, Indiana State 40. The Division I-AA teams combined for 1,116 yards of total offense and 54 first downs, and scored 42 points in the fourth quarter. The Sycamores (0-3) have lost 20 straight games. A Strong Start Before the season, Oklahoma tailback Adrian Peterson, below, predicted that he would rush for 2,500 yards. After three games, he is averaging 171.7 yards a game, leaving him behind in his quest. To reach his goal, Peterson, a junior, will need to average 198.5 yards the rest of the season and the Sooners (2-1) will have to qualify for a bowl. If Oklahoma plays in the Big 12 championship game and a bowl, he will need to average 180.5 yards. Show of Strength Just six days after his father died of a heart attack, the Iowa junior linebacker Mike Klinkenborg made eight tackles in No. 16 Iowa's 27-17 victory over Iowa State. The team's leading tackler, he helped hold the Cyclones scoreless in the game's final 23 minutes. The Hawkeyes (3-0) had lost six of their eight meetings to Iowa State (2-1). Horned Frogs on a Run Texas Christian is 4-0 against Big 12 Conference teams since 2005 after Saturday's 12-3 victory against Texas Tech (2-1). The Horned Frogs (3-0), who upset Oklahoma last season, have won 13 games in a row, the longest winning streak in Division I-A. Numbers Adding Up The Northern Illinois senior tailback Garrett Wolfe rushed for 263 yards and 2 touchdowns in a 31-13 victory against Buffalo. Wolfe broke the 200-yard mark for the eighth time in his career, a team record. His 630 rushing yards this season (an average of 210 yards a game) are the highest total in Division I-A and make him a dark horse to win the Heisman.

The Southern California Trojans continued to fight on Saturday night, just as the university's fight song told them to. The Trojans played to a capacity crowd of 92,000 at the Los Angeles Coliseum and won their 28th consecutive home game, rolling over Nebraska, 28-10.

HALL--Craig D., M.D. September 14. Brilliant, talented, generous and a great friend. Words cannot capture our sense of loss. The quality of our lives and no doubt the lives of all those who knew you will be diminished by your absence. You were a cornerstone friend whose spirit will continue to live within us. Our heartfelt condolences and love to Eve, Evan and Zoe. Bruce Batkin Ferne Traeger

The special section Broken Ground last Monday misidentified the birthplace of Rafael Viñoly, one of the architects who submitted designs for a master plan for the World Trade Center site. It is Uruguay, not Argentina.

Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for state attorney general, assailed her Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo, yesterday on the issue of reducing fraud in the Medicaid system. At a news conference in Lower Manhattan, Ms. Pirro noted that Mr. Cuomo, in a meeting with editors at Crain's New York Business, had called the notion of amnesty for businesses involved in Medicaid fraud ''intriguing.'' Ms. Pirro said, ''His approach is to give amnesty to Medicaid cheats. This kind of approach makes it very clear that my opponent does not understand the role of the attorney general.'' Wendy Katz, a spokeswoman for the Cuomo campaign, said that amnesty was not part of his plan for reducing Medicaid fraud and added, ''The fraud is in the misleading attacks against Andrew just three days after Ms. Pirro pledged to run a positive campaign.'' SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

CIFU--Robert, M.D. Born May 18, 1928, died peacefully at home September 16, 2006, after a short illness. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Anne; son Adam and daughter-in-law Sarah, and joy-ofjoys grandchildren, Ben and Amelia, as well as sisters, Palma Cifu and Miriam Driscoll. Loved by a large family, including nieces Palma and Marisa Driscoll, nephew Craig Inciardi and wife, Joan. Psychoanalyst, gardener, cook, wit, scholar and lifelong student, voracious reader, traveler, wonderful friend in person and on the phone, superb conversationalist and endlessly supportive father and loving husband. Contributions in his memory can be made to The Robert Cifu M.D. Memorial Scholarship Fund at LaSalle Academy, 44 East Second Street, NYC 10003. Family visitation will be private.

With the Senate race continuing to focus on the war in Iraq and national security, both Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and his Democratic challenger, Ned Lamont, have tried to explain to voters where the country's military strategy has gone wrong. But both candidates are having trouble articulating precisely what to do next.

Cibelle ''The Shine of Dried Electric Leaves'' (Six Degrees) Looking for the epitome of a freak-folk song? Try ''Flying High'' on ''The Shine of Dried Electric Leaves,'' the second album by Cibelle. The song twinkles along for six minutes with glockenspiel and piano, as Cibelle's airy voice intones ''So many good times,'' and all sorts of other elements -- electronics, static, instruments running backwards and countless overdubbed Cibelles -- drift in and out of her hazy contentment. Or try ''Phoenix,'' in which Cibelle wants to ''glide up like little birds'' amid music boxes, synthesized peeps and neo-Baroque cello.

DJ Shadow ''The Outsider'' (Island) DJ Shadow, the quintessential vinyl sound collagist, may not seem an obvious fit for the juiced-up hip-hop style known as hyphy. But the man and the movement are both rooted in the Bay Area, and their alliance hardly comes out of left field. ''The Outsider,'' DJ Shadow's new full-length album, includes cameos by the Federation, a hyphy crew, and E-40, a leading rapper in the style. Keak Da Sneak, another top M.C., shares billing with Turf Talk on ''3 Freaks,'' a track that appeared on some hyphy mixtapes months ago.

BOEGNER -- Margaret Phipps. Died peacefully on September 16, 2006, at her house in Old Westbury, Long Island. Born in London, 1906, only daughter of John S. and Margarita Grace Phipps. Married J. Gordon Douglas Jr., 1930, and Etienne Boegner, 1950. She is survived by her loving family, her children, Dita Naylor-Leyland and J. Gordon Douglas III; three step-children, three grandchildren, Dita Amory Nickson, Nicholas Naylor-Leyland, and Michael G. Douglas; and one great-grandchild, Serena Nickson. Founder of Wakefield Bookshop. Founder, President, and Chairman of the Old Westbury Gardens. Funeral service Tuesday, September 19, 2006, at 11 am, Church of the Advent, 555 Advent Street, Westbury, NY 11568. The Old Westbury Gardens will host a centennial celebration of her life in midNovember. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Old Westbury Gardens, P.O. Box 430, Old Westbury, NY 11568. As with most musicians who have been around since the 1970's, Elton John's hits collections rank high among his more than 35 albums. ''Greatest Hits'' from 1974 ranks 17th on the Top 100 list of the Recording Industry Association of America. ''The Captain and the Kid,'' the latest collaboration between the singer (above, in a September performance) and Bernie Taupin, his longtime lyricist, is an older, wiser sequel to the autobiographical, edgy ''Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy'' (1975). SHELLY FREIERMAN

XM Satellite Radio, Washington, named Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its creative account, which had been at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., also part of Interpublic. Spending was estimated at $50 million.

Merrill, who described Arizona voters as moderate. He is a political scientist and professor of journalism and mass communication, not a political science professor, at Arizona State University.

Fergie ''The Dutchess'' (will.i.am/A&M/Universal) ''The Dutchess'' is Fergie's solo debut. But since will.i.am, a fellow Black Eyed Pea, produced most of the tracks and appears on a few, it's essentially a Black Eyed Peas album with two fewer rappers. That's an improvement: two down, two to go.

BACHENHEIMER--Kather ine. Wife of the late Howard Bachenheimer, died peacefully at age 95, on September 10, 2006. A businesswoman and activist, she was devoted to improving public life in the City. Her spirit and wit will be missed by her family members and friends.

LEBERFELD--Lily. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Leberfeld, devoted mother of Laraine Fergenson and Andrea Kahn, beloved grandmother and great-grnadmohter. Service Tuesday, 1 pm, Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd, Millburn, NJ.
A fashion review on Tuesday misspelled the surname of the artist who painted a shower curtain that the designer Bryan Bradley made into an evening dress. She is Lisa Yuskavage, not Yuskavitch.

The last time that occurred was in 2000, Coach Mike Leach's first season at Texas Tech, in a 56-3 loss to top-ranked Nebraska.

The controversy over the plot twist in the new season of ''Survivor'' on CBS, dividing the competing teams along racial lines, took its toll on the show's appeal to advertisers, judging by the commercial lineup in the premiere episode on Thursday. Before the episode ran, many major national marketers that had bought commercial time during previous seasons of ''Survivor'' said they would not return. The list included Campbell Soup, Coca-Cola, General Motors, Home Depot, Johnson & Johnson, Procter & Gamble and United Parcel Service. None of them attributed their withdrawals to the race-based format.

Bank of America said Tuesday that it hired Anne Yang to join its recently created transaction development group as a managing director. Ms. Yang, who previously spent six years at Goldman Sachs, will start her new position at the group's Banc of America Securities unit in November. Bank of America said it created the transaction development group earlier this year to "identify, develop and present strategic transaction alternatives" to commercial and investment banking clients.

France 2, the state-supported channel, is suing three Internet critics who questioned the channel's veracity.

Richard Bernstein, Merrill Lynch's chief investment strategist, did not mention the word "Amaranth" in a short note he published Tuesday, but it is fairly clear what he had on his mind as he warned of the perils of leverage. Since Monday's revelations that Amaranth, a hedge fund, lost billions of dollars in a short time on natural-gas trades, speculation has been rife about how much of that bet was leveraged, or made with borrowed money.
An Ontario court dismissed an appeal by Sears Holdings on Tuesday of the decision by Canadian securities regulators to halt its takeover offer for its Canadian unit, Sears Canada, Reuters reported.

Goldman Sachs ranks first among investment banks in terms of "prestige," according to a survey of bank employees by Vault.com. Vault, a career Web site that collects employees' opinions on the companies they work for (or have worked for), said it surveyed more than 970 banking professionals, asking them to rate banking companies from 1 to 10, with 10 being "the most prestigious."

As companies prepare to go public, they regularly tweak their prospectuses to add new earnings data, include recent business developments and even fix grammar mistakes. Something a bit more intriguing, though, cropped up in the latest filing from Hertz Global Holdings, which hopes to raise as much as $1 billion in an initial public offering.

For someone looking for a real eco-tourism adventure, a bit more than an excursion to Costa Rica, I suggest the Dzanga-Sangha area in the Central African Republic. Sure, CAR is suffering from a bit of a civil war in the north, and it's difficult to get to. But Dzanga-Sangha in the southwest - where we have been the last few days - is extraordinary. Especially for someone who has already seen the game parks of East Africa or southern Africa, this is the place to come.

It's probably a bit confusing for readers of Casey's blog or viewers of her vlog to see pictures of us with gorillas in Central African Republic and then read a column of mine about AIDS that is still from Cameroon. Sorry, but that's the delay that comes from reading ink on dead trees. The written columns almost always lag a bit behind my physical location.

The NFL's Peyton Manning goes incognito for Sprint's mobile service, by TBWA\Chiat\Day.
UCBH Holdings, a California bank serving Asian-American communities, said on Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Summit Bank of Atlanta for $175.5 million in stock and cash.

Our trip is a little more than halfway finished, and I have really, really loved getting all of the comments. We want to try to answer questions people might have, so comment if you have any particular ones. I know one reoccurring question is how you might be able to help more directly. I'll snoop around a bit and see if I can find some easy ways to contribute. One thing I've always loved about Nick's columns is that he doesn't tell a sad tale then leave you hanging with no idea of what to do. He almost always gives a clear way readers can help change these problems. I want to be able to do that, too. I know it is so important.

In a New Republic essay titled "Kneel before Izod," Michael Crowley speculates that Planet Houston no longer rules American politics. The rise of Howard Dean and Ned Lamont, along with the fall of Tom DeLay and the reconstruction of George H.W. Bush's historical reputation, signal the return to power of the WASP establishment toppled by Ronald Reagan in 1980. He writes: "The George Bush who summers in Crawford is a discredited lame duck. The George Bush who summers in Kennebunkport has been vindicated on matters of foreign policy and fiscal responsibility. Why, perhaps this calls for a regatta!"
An investor education company, INVESTools, said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy an online broker, the thinkorswim Group, for about $340 million in cash and stock.

An investor group that launched an unsuccessful, last-minute bid for Freescale Semiconductor has ended talks with the chip maker, Reuters reported on Tuesday. Shares of Freescale, which recently accepted a $17.6 billion takeover offer from another consortium, slipped more than 2 percent Tuesday as expectations of a bidding war between the two factions faded.

Credit Agricole Structured Asset Management of France has bought Ursa Capital, an asset manager in the United States and will pay between $57 million and $80 million for the business, the French investment group said on Tuesday.

Though it is easy to see Dr. Pipi as the villain when reading about Prudence, the actuality of the situation isn't so cut and dried. The day we arrived, he worked 15 hours. After leaving at 10:30 p.m., he arrived the next day at 5:30 a.m.
No profound thoughts today--only some bits and pieces.
Morgan Stanley has gotten a facelift. Again.

Larry W. Sonsini, the lawyer who reportedly told Thomas Perkins that Hewlett-Packard's investigation into the source of boardroom leaks passed legal muster, may have been a target of that inquiry as well, The Los Angeles Times reported Tuesday.
The man could be a link between Hewlett-Packard and detective agencies in Boston and Florida hired to ferret out a leaker of company information.

EchoStar Communications said Monday that the vice chairman, Carl Vogel, has been appointed president effective immediately, taking responsibility for operations of its satellite television service, the Dish Network.
A former Enron executive, David W. Delainey, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison yesterday after prosecutors urged leniency, saying he helped unravel crimes at the energy company.

Revlon, the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, has ousted its chief executive, Jack L. Stahl, after four years of losses, and replaced him with the finance chief, David L. Kennedy.

A court ordered Google on Monday to remove all links to French- and German-language newspaper reports published in Belgium after an association of local publishers won a case that accused the company of violating the country's copyright laws.
Home Depot's chief executive, Robert Nardelli, under pressure from investors for his compensation, may face a pay cut.

The detention of the heads of an Austrian online gambling company by French authorities has raised the stakes in a Europe-wide battle between lucrative state-sponsored betting monopolies and their upstart rivals on the Internet, raising eyebrows at the European Commission in Brussels.
A former trader at the New York Stock Exchange was found not guilty on Monday of securities fraud for his role in a scheme that prosecutors said cheated the Big Board's customers.
The Virgin Group, the cluster of companies founded by Sir Richard Branson, is introducing its particular brand of corporate philanthropy to the United States today.
The billionaire financier Carl Icahn is poised to gain control of one-third of the board of ImClone Systems and push to replace the biotechnology company's management.
Browns tight Kellen Winslow is angry again. About Cleveland's offense. About being taken off the field on third down. About life.
The California attorney general, Bill Lockyer, may decide as early as this week who to indict over Hewlett-Packard's improper investigation of board members and journalists.

The accounting firm KPMG struck back yesterday against 16 former employees and the federal judge overseeing their coming tax shelter trial, filing court papers seeking compensation from certain defendants and saying that it would appeal a ruling ordering a related trial over their legal fees.
The business software maker CA expects to recover some of the money it lost to former executives involved in a $2.2 billion accounting scandal, the chief executive, John Swainson, said yesterday.

When the Bristol-Myers Squibb chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, sought to blunt a federal prosecutor's investigation of the company in 2003, he made a seemingly canny move. Mr. Dolan hired as an adviser a former federal judge greatly admired by the prosecutor.

Enormous losses at Amaranth Advisors, one of the nation's largest hedge funds, resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.
The investor Warren E. Buffett is feeling the heat from buyout firms at a time when private equity groups are raising unprecedented mountains of cash to go hunting for new deals.
The unending search for higher returns has driven many mutual fund managers to place bets on private equity investments.

Ashikaga Bank, taken over by Japan's government three years ago because of mounting bad loans, may get bids from companies including General Electric and Lone Star Funds and Nomura Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

Less than a year after raising $5 million in a Series A round from Sequoia Capital and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, PeakStream has closed $17 million in a new round that investors expect to be the company's last.

Three former TL Ventures partners will head Guggenheim Partners' new venture capital business that focuses on networking, communications and semiconductor deals in the underserved Mid-Atlantic, Southwest and Pacific Northwest regions.

A drugmaker, Warner Chilcott, leads a busy calendar of initial public offerings with a rare $1 billion stock offering this week, as the I.P.O. market attempts to quicken the pace for the fourth quarter.
Guidance Software registered Friday for an initial public offering of up to $80 million in common stock, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Facing a frozen share price and another assault from Carl Icahn, Time Warner's chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, is readying to play one of his remaining cards: an initial public offering of part of the company's cable unit.

Ed Rogers, head of Deutsche Bank's prime services in Japan until May, is starting a $500 million fund of hedge funds that's the first of its type to let investors in the United States take part in the recovery in Japan, which has the world's second-largest economy.

Wall Street's biggest securities firms are showing no signs of losing their profitability despite a third quarter in which fees from acquisitions fell 14 percent, trading of government bonds dropped 6 percent and commodities lost the most in two decades.
Fox Rothschild of Philadelphia will merge with Grotta, Glassman & Hoffman, a 60-lawyer management-side labor firm in Roseland, N.J.

Sears Holdings argued on Monday that the Ontario Securities Commission should not have accused it of "abusive" treatment of shareholders of Sears Canada because its behavior breached no specific provisions of the Ontario Securities Act.
EMC said Monday that it had acquired an information technology security company, Network Intelligence, in a deal valued at about $175 million.
The Norwegian state-controlled oil company Statoil on Monday announced the purchase of three oil prospects in the Gulf of Mexico from Plains Exploration & Production of Houston for $700 million.

Smithfield Foods, the nation's largest hog producer, said Monday it would acquire a smaller rival, Premium Standard Farms, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $810 million, including the assumption of about $117 million in debt.

The Henderson Group, a British money manager, agreed to buy John Laing for 886.9 million pounds ($1.67 billion) to add a a developer and investor focused on state contracts to run clinics, hospitals and schools.
A shareholder-activist group is pressuring the Jean Coutu Group to address concerns that a deal to sell its drugstores in the United States to Rite Aid might not make it through an antitrust review.
Is MAN's bid for Scania dead in the water? Or is the Swedish truck maker waiting for its German rival to sweeten its 9.6 billion euro ($12.2 billion) bid?
The Federal Communications Commission declared the latest and most lucrative auction of the public airwaves closed on Monday, with bids totaling nearly $13.9 billion.

Is The Los Angeles Times set to go on the block? Reports have resurfaced that Tribune is under increasing pressure to sell its largest paper, just as the company is close to working out a truce with the Chandler family, the former owner of the paper and one of the company's largest shareholders.

Napster, the subscription music-download service, is looking for a buyer. The company, which got its start as a free music-download, file-sharing site, said Monday that it had hired UBS to find a major strategic partner or to be acquired completely.

Actavis Group, the Icelandic maker of generic heart and flu drugs, will not raise its $2.5 billion bid for Pliva, leaving Barr Pharmaceuticals to buy eastern Europe's largest drugmaker after a three-month fight.
The telecommunications giant Motorola said Tuesday it would buy Symbol Technologies, a maker of hand-held bar-code readers and other mobile devices, for $3.9 billion, or $15 a share.
The jaw-dropping losses recently revealed by hedge fund Amaranth do not appear to be roiling world markets or triggering some kind of financial domino effect.

Last week's proposed fantasy matchup of former Tennessee players against former Florida players was initially a lot closer than I expected, school pride being tough to count on when no one actually plays on the same field anymore. Using our stripped-down scoring system, here's how the game played out:Florida Quarterback Rex Grossman threw for 289 yards and 4 TD's, looking like the Florida version of, well, Rex Grossman. Running back Fred Taylor was his usual productive self, gaining 92 yards on 22 carries. Darrell Jackson (5 catches, 127 yards, 1 TD), Travis Taylor (3 catches, 65 yards) and Reche Caldwell (2 catches, 14 yards) showed that Florida receivers never forget how to get open, and Ben Troupe (0 catches) showed why N.F.L. teams usually shop for speed, not size, in Gainesville.Point totalsGrossman 35Taylor 11Jackson 18Taylor 6Caldwell 1Troupe 0Team: 71

The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously released the nomination of Stuart J. Rabner as attorney general yesterday to the full Senate. A confirmation vote is scheduled for Sept. 25. Mr. Rabner, 46, a former federal prosecutor who has served as Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s chief counsel since January, has been nominated to replace Zulima V. Farber, who resigned in August after an independent review found she had broken ethics rules by intervening in a traffic stop involving her companion.
Jevon Kearse, the Eagles’ star defensive end, is out for the season after sustaining a knee injury in Philadelphia’s loss to the Giants on Sunday.

About a third of attention deficit cases among American children may be linked with tobacco smoke before birth or to lead exposure afterward, according to new research. Even levels of lead the government considers acceptable appeared to increase a child’s risk of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, the study found. The study is to be published online today in the journal Environmental Health Perspectives. The disorder affects up to 12 percent of school-age children.
Robert Earl Jones was a stage and screen actor and the father of the actor James Earl Jones.
The Yankees missed Mariano Rivera on Monday, using four relievers in the ninth to finish off a shaky victory over the Blue Jays.
By beating the Marlins Monday, the Mets became the first team other than the Braves to win the N.L. East division since the 1993 Phillies.

About $200,000 of a $22 million bond issue for capital improvements in Detroit parks is being spent to make repairs at the mayor’s mansion, The Detroit News reported. The money will be used to repair damaged swimming pool tiles, cracked walkways, a front porch and outside lighting and to replace dead plants. The repairs are necessary to prevent accidents, said Matt Allen, a spokesman for Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick. “It is a public building,” Mr. Allen told WJBK-TV.

A judge blocked enactment of a law that would divide the Omaha school district into three racially identifiable districts. The law would have split the Omaha Public Schools into one mostly black district, one largely Hispanic and one predominantly white.

A freelance journalist and blogger who has refused to testify in front of a grand jury or turn over videotape of a violent protest he filmed in July 2005 was ordered back to jail. The journalist, Josh Wolf, 24, was found in contempt by a federal judge on Aug. 1 for refusing to cooperate with an investigation of the violence and spent a month in prison. In early September Mr. Wolf was released on bail, but on Monday it was revoked.

A couple were arraigned on kidnapping charges after they tied up their 19-year-old daughter, put her in their car and began driving to New York to force her to get an abortion, the police said. The daughter, Katelyn Kampf, escaped Friday at a shopping center in New Hampshire and called the police, who arrested her parents, Nicholas Kampf, 54, and Lola, 53, of North Yarmouth, Maine. At the hearing, prosecutors said the parents repeatedly “threatened to kill the victim, the unborn child, the father and his family.” A defense lawyer, Mark Sisti, said, “What we’re dealing with here is a terrible family tragedy with some unfortunate misunderstandings and some overreaction, perhaps on all sides but not an attempt to terrorize anybody.”.

Hurricane Helene continued to gain strength as a Category 3 storm in the Atlantic, and forecasters said it could threaten Bermuda at the end of the week. The storm, with top sustained winds of 125 miles an hour, was centered about 990 miles east-southeast of Bermuda and was moving west-northwest at 9 m.p.h. Meanwhile, Hurricane Gordon picked up speed over the open Atlantic with top sustained winds near 90 m.p.h.. A tropical storm warning was issued for the Azores.

The National Park Service said it would begin charging a fee for permits for weddings inside the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. There are about 600 weddings each year in the national park, five times as many as five years ago. Beginning Oct. 1, couples must pay a $50 nonrefundable fee for weddings in the park, which straddles the Tennessee-North Carolina border.More elaborate ceremonies that call for rangers for traffic control or other services require an additional $150 use permit. “We are not making money, we are just recouping our costs,” said Nancy Gray, a park spokeswoman.

Two premature infants died, and four others were in critical condition after being given adult doses of medication last week, prompting hospital officials to review drug-handling procedures. Adult doses of the blood thinner Heparin were placed in a drug cabinet at the newborn intensive care unit of Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, said Sam Odle, chief executive of Methodist and Indiana University Hospitals. The hospital said human error was to blame. Two-day-old Emmery Miller and five-day-old D’myia Nelson, died Saturday night. Both girls were born at 25 to 26 weeks’ gestation, Mr. Odle said. A full-term pregnancy lasts 38 to 42 weeks.
The owners of the bookstore's building have moved to evict the store and its owner, as he fell behind in rent, taxes and other fees.

New York City remained the safest big city in the nation in 2005, according to an F.B.I. report released yesterday. The report also showed that the city experienced a 4.3 percent drop in overall reported crime last year compared with a nationwide drop of 1.2 percent.

Three Hezbollah members seized by Israel in the recent fighting in Lebanon were charged with murder and other crimes. One, Hussein Suleiman, is accused of involvement in the July 12 cross-border raid in which three Israeli soldiers were killed and two were seized, precipitating the month of fighting. The others, Muhammad Sarour and Maher Qurani, were involved in border attacks against Israeli soldiers, Israeli officials said. Hezbollah is demanding a prisoner exchange for the seized Israelis, and will very likely seek the return of the three defendants.

A government official confirmed that 55 children had contracted the H.I.V. virus through contaminated blood or used needles at a hospital in the south. Health Minister Yerbolat Dosayev said final tests had been received for just half of the 9,800 children who came in contact with the needles and blood supplies in June and July.

Concern over the possibility of a copycat attack after the shooting rampage at a Montreal college last week caused the Quebec police to arrest a 15-year-old boy they said was posting Internet threats against students at his school near Montreal. They said the boy posted the threats on the same Web site used by the man identified by the police as the college gunman.

The terrorism trial of seven men was suspended after one said he would give no further evidence because he feared for his family in Pakistan. Omar Khyam said Pakistani agents had visited his relatives after he testified about receiving training there. The seven have denied charges of plotting to bomb targets including pubs and nightclubs. The trial was adjourned after the judge said the jury could “draw inferences” from Mr. Khyam’s refusal to testify. It is to continue today.

The government indefinitely suspended the current National Assembly session, putting on the back burner a proposed amendment that aimed to end abuses suffered by women who reported rape or were accused of adultery under an Islamic ordinance. Despite weeks of wheeling and dealing on the bill, which went before Parliament last month, fierce opposition by hard-line Islamic parties forced the government to delay trying to pass the bill while it seeks a broader consensus for it.

Simon Bikindi, a well-known Rwandan singer, went on trial at the Tanzania-based International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, accused of writing lyrics that incited killing in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

The police and protesters clashed in Budapest after thousands of Hungarians marched to demand that Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany, left, resign after admitting that he had told colleagues that his government had “lied in the morning and in the evening” about the economy to win April’s election. It was the first such street violence since the fall of Communism in the late 1980’s. Protesters hurled bottles and stones at the police, who fired tear gas to stop them from forcing their way into the state television offices. The protest was set off by a leaked audio recording of a closed-door meeting by Mr. Gyurcsany appealing to his party after the election to change its ways. The Socialist Party rallied behind its prime minister, who took office in 2004.

Voters in Moldova’s separatist region, Transnistria, also known as Trans-Dniester, overwhelmingly backed a plan to join Russia. The European Union said it would not recognize the vote. The tiny Russian-speaking territory declared independence from Moldova in 1991 with the support of Russian troops, which have stayed on. Russian officials have suggested that the future of Transnistria and three other separatist regions on the territory of the former Soviet Union — Abkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia, and Nagorno-Karabakh, fought over by Armenia and Azerbaijan — could be decided in plebiscites.
horse racing.

The New York Athletic Club will hold a dinner Oct. 11 to honor Al Oerter on the 50th anniversary of the first of his four Olympic gold medals. Oerter was a 20-year-old University of Kansas sophomore when he won the discus at the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne, Australia. He also won in 1960 in Rome, in 1964 in Tokyo and in 1968 in Mexico City. In each of those Games, he defeated the world-record holder and broke the Olympic record.
A judge dismissed a lawsuit by insurgent candidates seeking to depose the leadership of the 46,000-member Eastern Section of the United States Tennis Association.
Architect, Rem Koolhaas, will transform a warehouse, once an artist enclave, into luxury lofts.
Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat who pleaded guilty to impaired driving, has a Republican sponsor.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18 — A homeless black man who stabbed a white woman to death, saying that he wanted to start a race war, was sentenced on Monday to 25 years to life in prison, the maximum imposed on a charge of murder as a hate crime.
Four years after he was deported to Syria, where he was tortured, a Canadian man was exonerated by a government panel of any ties to terrorism.
A court-authorized overseer monitoring Bristol-Myers Squibb successfully recommended that the board dismiss the chief executive.
State Senator Wayne R. Bryant of New Jersey had a no-show job at the state’s medical and dental school that paid him “to lobby himself,” according to a report.
Lottery Numbers.
The Detroit Tigers increased their lead in the American League Central last night by defeating the Chicago White Sox, 8-2.
The leaders of the New York Democratic Party are so confident of outright victory that they are focusing on an electoral rebuke of President Bush and Gov. George Pataki.
Two truckers said their employer knowingly sent a lightly armed convoy of fuel tankers into a combat zone in April 2004.
Enormous losses at Amaranth Advisors resurrected worries that major bets by hedge funds could create widespread financial disruptions.

Three months before Gov. George E. Pataki leaves office, his administration is planning to relocate a number of state agencies and hundreds of employees to Lower Manhattan, as well as shuffle offices from other downtown neighborhoods to the World Trade Center site.
American International Group used obscure subsidiaries to elude restrictions on campaign donations in New York.
The Bloomberg administration plans to offer tax credits to offset child care costs and cash rewards to encourage poor people to stay in school.
A new exhibition called "Ecotopia" suggests the fragile ecology of the place we live — the glory of what it is and the sorrow of what we have done to it.
The more talk you hear about border security the clearer it will be that hopes for effective immigration reform this year are past saving.
France’s president suggested that Iran would not have to freeze major nuclear activities until formal negotiations began.
Mets Manager Willie Randolph reiterated that he still expected Pedro Martínez to start Game 1 of the division series.
A judge denied a request by J. P. Morgan Chase to have its powers expanded as temporary guardian of Brooke Astor’s assets in the legal battle over her care and finances.
Pragmatism among antiwar Democrats seems to have buoyed a Washington senator’s campaign.
The football coach at Bridgeport Central High School could be suspended for violating a conference rule that prohibits winning by more than 50 points.
The largest Muslim conference in North America hosted speed dating sessions called the “matrimonial banquet.”
A man crashed his vehicle into a security barricade near the Capitol on Monday morning and ran into the building with a loaded handgun before being arrested, the authorities said.

The New Jersey Nets, who once planned to move into an arena proposed for the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn as early as 2006, extended their lease at Continental Arena in New Jersey yesterday through the 2012-13 season.
The Padres, who for weeks have clung to a playoff berth with the pine tar on their fingertips, are starting to firm their grip.

Despite the California attorney general’s assertion that he has enough evidence to press charges against people inside and outside Hewlett-Packard, a criminal case may be hard to prosecute, legal specialists say.
Political leaders in the capital struggled to reach a deal that would end the fight over splitting Iraq into autonomous states.
To undermine the whole purpose of the court system by allowing special interests to buy judgeships, or at least try to, is the worst system of all.
Clarence E. Hill, who had his execution halted once by the Supreme Court, has appealed to the court again to stop his execution by lethal injection.
President Bush could make a difference if he devoted his speech to the United Nations General Assembly to the horrors of Darfur, and committed himself personally to stopping the genocide.
The provision in a bill that sets the Pentagon’s spending levels would allow military chaplains to offer sectarian prayers at nondenominational military events.
The National Retail Federation will predict a sales increase of 5 percent, to $457.4 billion, compared with last year.
The deal would authorize YouTube.com to show Warner Music videos and user-created clips that incorporate Warner music.
The companies have lost a court ruling that may result in their paying royalties on an experimental cancer drug to an Israeli research institute.
A week after Harvard abandoned early admissions as a program that puts low-income students at a disadvantage, Princeton has followed suit.
Maurice Clarett pleaded guilty Monday to aggravated robbery and carrying a concealed weapon and was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison.
Legal experts on both sides of the debate say President Bush wants latitude for using interrogation methods that the military is barred from using.
The heat is on Dolphins quarterback Daunte Culpepper, Chris Simms of Tampa Bay and Mark Brunell of Washington after two weeks of uninspired play.
Hoping to pay a proper tribute, fire buffs compiled the names and stories of those killed on duty in New York.
The three bombings, in one of the country’s worst days of violence against civilians, were a clear escalation in insurgent tactics.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran is scheduled to address the U.N. General Assembly just hours after President Bush.
The agreements do not address the central question: Spain’s objections to British control of the territory.
The accounting firm filed court papers seeking compensation from the former employees.
The outing of Lonelygirl15 has forced her audience to consider: Was Lonelygirl a simple hoax or high-concept art?
What troubles Wallace Hasan the most about children's murders was how quickly they seemed forgotten.

Sun Life Financial, a Canadian insurer, hired investment bankers to consider a possible sale of its United States money-management unit, which has had $16 billion withdrawn from its funds over four years. Sun Life did not disclose the name of the investment bankers. Sun Life, based in Toronto, said there was no assurance a transaction would result. MFS has lost $3.7 billion in mutual fund shareholder withdrawals this year through July 31, according to the Boston consulting firm Financial Research Corporation.

Statoil, Norway’s largest oil company, will pay $700 million for stakes in two oil and gas finds and one exploration prospect in deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico to offset an expected drop in domestic output. The company will buy 17.5 percent of the Caesar discovery and 12.5 percent each of the Big Foot find and the Big Foot North prospect from the Plains Exploration and Production Company of Houston, Statoil said. The discoveries are expected to increase production “significantly” after 2010, Statoil said. It did not estimate the size of the reserves in the stakes.

Collins Stewart Tullet, a British financial services company, outlined plans to break up to help it capitalize on a growing number of small American companies that are going to London for public listings. The company said it would separate its retail stockbroker and its institutional broker by year-end and return £300 million ($564 million) to shareholders. All the company’s United States equities business has been moved to the stock brokerage arm, Collins Stewart, which is building its presence in the United States. The company also reported results, saying profit more than doubled in the first half of the year, to £68.5 million ($128.8 million) from £26.1 million a year earlier.
In races during the Nascar Chase for the Nextel Cup, drivers not in the Chase often drive cautiously around cars racing for the season title.
Former Vice President Al Gore called for a popular movement to seek an “immediate freeze” in heat-trapping smokestack and tailpipe gases.
Member states of the International Monetary Fund voted to adopt a disputed plan to modify the fund’s power structure.
The Jaguars beat the defending Super Bowl champion Steelers 9-0 — the lowest-scoring game in “Monday Night Football” history.
Long before there were snakes on a plane, there were leopards in a carry-on, and monkeys down a pair of pants, according to a federal indictment handed down in Southern California on Monday.
CA Inc. expects to recover some of the money it lost in an accounting scandal, the chief executive, John Swainson, said.
Bids totaled nearly $13.9 billion in the latest and most lucrative auction of the public airwaves.
BP said the start of production at its Thunder Horse platform in the Gulf of Mexico would be delayed after tests showed safety problems.
By Bloomberg News.
India’s economy may be soaring, but the agricultural industry remains its Achilles’ heel. In 2003, 17,107 farmers committed suicide.
As crude oil prices have plunged, many traders say they have been dumping and short-selling stocks and futures contracts.
Officials are confounded about the best way to respond to the growing nuisance, according to city officials.
Margaret Phipps Boegner opened her family’s vast Long Island estate, Old Westbury Gardens, to the public.
The three-man crew aboard the International Space Station scrambled to deal with an overheated oxygen generator and a possible chemical spill.
An early analysis of data on the Prestige spinal disk shows it works at least as well as spinal fusion and has similar risks.

A man was fatally shot in his Brooklyn neighborhood last night, the police said. The man, Lawrence Falade, 28, was shot several times on a street in Flatbush about 8 p.m. He was taken to Kings County Hospital, where he later died. Friends said that the victim had immigrated from Nigeria and had a wife, who is pregnant. Investigators at the scene said it was unclear what the motive for shooting was.

Jury deliberations are scheduled to begin in Federal District Court today in the racketeering conspiracy case against John A. Gotti, the former Gambino crime family boss. The charges against Mr. Gotti, who is known as Junior, include ordering the kidnapping and beating of Curtis Sliwa in 1992, money laundering, extortion and witness tampering. Mr. Gotti’s defense is that he withdrew from the Gambino family before July 1999; if true, that would allow him to avoid conviction because of the statute of limitations on the racketeering charges.

Emergency repairs to stabilize a huge stone dam at one of New York’s City’s Catskill Mountain reservoirs should be completed by the end of the year, city officials said yesterday. So far, crews have installed about a third of the 79 large anchoring cables that are needed to shore up the Gilboa Dam, which holds back the Schoharie Creek to form a 20-billion-gallon reservoir 110 miles north of the city. The $24 million stabilization project began nearly a year ago after engineers from the city’s Department of Environmental Protection found that the dam did not meet current state safety standards.

A jury was selected yesterday in State Supreme Court for the trial of a boarder accused of killing his elderly landlord in October 2004. Prosecutors say the boarder, Howard Goldstein, 49, beat and stabbed the landlord, Rahamim Sultan, 75, wrapped his body in bed linens, towels and plastic bags, and kept it in the apartment they shared for several days. When officers arrived at the apartment on East 19th Street in Midwood to investigate, Mr. Goldstein was dressed as a woman, the police have said. His lawyer, Jay D. Cohen, has said Mr. Goldstein “operated under extreme emotional disturbance.”.

A 10th grader at Yorktown High School was killed early yesterday when the car she was riding in, headed the wrong way on the Saw Mill River Parkway, crashed into another car, said the Westchester County police commissioner, Thomas Belfiore. The girl, Emily Cornish, 16, was a passenger in a car driven by Ann Marie Ciarcia, 46, of Yorktown, who was heading north in the southbound lane about 4:40 a.m., Mr. Belfiore said. He said Ms. Ciarcia was charged with drunken driving, vehicular manslaughter and endangering the welfare of a child. Ms. Ciarcia was driving her daughter, Alexa, 15, and Emily home from Manhattan when she struck another vehicle in Dobbs Ferry, Mr. Belfiore said. Ms. Ciarcia, her daughter and the driver of the other car were reported in stable condition yesterday at Westchester Medical Center.

A courthouse reopened yesterday after tests over the weekend found no sign of the bacteria that causes Legionnaires’ disease, officials said. The Mercer County courthouse was closed on Thursday after a woman who works in the building tested positive for legionella, the bacteria that cause the disease. The woman was in serious condition at a hospital yesterday afternoon. Brian Hughes, the Mercer County executive, said that more than 25 test samples taken from the building over three days showed no signs of legionella bacteria. Legionellosis is a serious form of pneumonia that was given the name Legionnaires’ disease after a 1976 outbreak at an American Legion convention in Philadelphia.

Some of the last remaining lots seized by New York City in tax foreclosure cases will be used to build homes for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers under a plan announced yesterday by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The agency said it had selected 25 development teams, more than half of them nonprofit groups or businesses owned by minorities or women, to build 630 units on 236 lots in Brooklyn and the Bronx. To make the homes affordable to lower-income people, the city charged the teams only a nominal fee for the land. The lots are among the last remnants of what was once a large inventory of property taken by the city and used over the past 20 years to create and preserve low-cost housing.

A group of dissident transit workers announced a campaign yesterday to unseat Roger Toussaint, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, who led 33,700 members in a three-day strike last year that hobbled the city. Mr. Toussaint is running for re-election in a mail-in vote, with ballots due in mid-December, nearly a year after the pre-Christmas strike that shut down subway and bus lines. The dissident slate is headed by Barry Roberts, a union vice president and former bus driver. He has accused Mr. Toussaint of failing union members, who remain without a contract. At least one other slate is expected to run, which could help Mr. Toussaint by splitting the opposition vote in what could be a bruising campaign.

The 1,300 nurses at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital will start returning to work on Thursday, four days after they approved a new contract, ending a strike that began in late August, union officials said yesterday. The nurses approved the three-year pact on Sunday by a vote of 769 to 117. One of the key issues during the bargaining was health care coverage, which the union says has been greatly improved. The contract also includes wage increases of 3 percent in each year of the agreement.

The court ordered Google to remove all links to French- and German-language newspaper reports published in Belgium.
Managers from Ford and G.M. began meeting in July, according to Automotive News, but the talks are no longer occurring and no further action is expected.
The Food and Drug Administration wrote to California farmers last November, urging them to improve the safety of produce.
The deficit in the current account represents the amount the U.S. must borrow from foreigners to cover the shortfall between exports and imports.
Napster said that it had hired UBS Investment Bank to assist in the possible sale of the company.
Sir Richard Branson’s Virgin Group is introducing its particular brand of corporate philanthropy to the United States.
President Abdullah Yusuf was not hurt when a suicide car bomber rammed into his convoy outside the Parliament building in Baidoa.
Patricia Kennedy Lawford was a sister of President John F. Kennedy and was married to the actor Peter Lawford for 11 years.
A 14-year-old girl being held captive was able to summon help by sending a text message from the underground bunker where she was being kept, the authorities said Monday.
The Swedish truck maker Scania and its two largest shareholders rejected a takeover bid from a German rival, MAN A.G.
After a police officer called a black referee a “monkey,” a lesson in the complexities of Brazil’s racial politics followed.
Fighting between Fatah and Hamas is part of a power struggle in the one Palestinian area that Israel has largely abandoned.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,670 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who will retire Sept. 26, succeeded to a remarkable extent in destroying the old Japan.
Edward J. King, a governor of Massachusetts who defeated the incumbent, Michael S. Dukakis, in the 1978 Democratic primary for governor but lost a rematch in 1982.
Citing damage to salmon rivers, Russia on Monday withdrew environmental approval for the Royal Dutch Shell-operated Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas project.
Some education departments and schools should be shut down and others need vast improvement, said the report by a research group.
Hotels are increasingly charging nonnegotiable surcharges for amenities that used to be part of the room rate.
Stocks failed to extend last week’s rally Monday as the price of oil rose and inflation concerns spurred investors to sell shares of retailers.
The bodies of 11 Muslim men were found hacked to death in the country’s east. Government and ethnic rebels traded blame.
France, Brazil, Britain, Norway and Chile plan to raise at least $300 million next year to help pay for the treatment of children with AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.
Having been largely dormant for months, the big donors and secretive groups that spent more than $600 million to influence the 2004 election are beginning to exert some late-season muscle.

Higher vitamin D intake has been associated with a significantly reduced risk of pancreatic cancer, according to a study released last week.
The Canadian Opera Company’s decision to assign each opera in Wagner’s “Ring” to a different director creates a sequence of imagery and ideas that alternately baffled and dazzled.

Four of Gustav Klimt’s paintings go to the auction block, and a story about justice and redemption after the Holocaust devolves into yet another tale of the crazy, intoxicating art market.

BUSINESS TRAVEL COSTS RISE Reflecting robust demand in business travel, airfares, hotel rooms and rental cars all cost more in the second quarter of this year, compared with the second quarter of 2005, according to the American Express Business Travel Monitor, in a report to be released today. The report found that the average paid one-way coach fare jumped 13 percent, to $247, for 329 domestic city pairs tracked by American Express. On 160 international routes tracked, the average one-way coach fare increased 9 percent, to $1,150; one-way business-class fares were up 6 percent, to $4,088; and first-class fares were up 4 percent, at $6,000. Average paid domestic hotel rates, including all categories of hotels from budget to deluxe, rose 3 percent, to $139. Internationally, average hotel rates rose 11 percent, to $237. The average daily cost to rent a car domestically rose 4 percent, to $67.26. “Over the last year, fleet pricing has been rising at a double-digit pace,” said Frank Schnur, a vice president at American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. Rising prices are “a trend we expect to continue,” he said.
Mick Watson has volunteered to coach the U.S. team that will play in the Homeless World Cup soccer tournament, beginning this weekend in Cape Town.
With AIDS still killing 8,000 people every day worldwide we need to acknowledge that the present strategy to fight it isn’t adequate.

A chart on Friday showing New York City data included in the Mayor's Management Report for the 2006 fiscal year misstated the number of 311 hot line calls made to the city and mislabeled the unit measured. There were 14,245,000 calls, not 14,245, and the measurement was in millions, not thousands.

An analysis by The New York Times of 155 campaign commercials from the 11 most competitive Senate races reveals the themes Republicans and Democrats are hoping will resound with voters this fall. The survey was based on the advertisements the candidates featured on their Web sites. FARHANA HOSSAI

Concern over the possibility of a copycat attack after the shooting rampage at a Montreal college last week caused the Quebec police to arrest a 15-year-old boy they said was posting Internet threats against students at his school near Montreal. They said the boy posted the threats on the same Web site used by the man identified by the police as the college gunman. CHRISTOPHER MASON (NYT)

The move was seen as a possible face-saving compromise. LEWISOHN--Dr. Marjorie. Died in New York Hospital September 16. Beloved sister of Joan, Betty and Ginny. Devoted aunt of ten nephews and nieces. First woman Trustee of Johns Hopkins University. Gathering of friends to share memories at the Cosmopolitan Club, Saturday, September 30 at noon. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to PBS Channel 13 of New York City.

The Drilling Down column in Business on Sept. 11, about efforts by the Audit Bureau of Circulations to measure readership of business publications by combining their online traffic with their print readership, misstated the period of time used to measure the Web traffic for Advertising Age in June. It was a month's worth of unique visitors, not a day's worth.

An article on Thursday about a new Democratic political organization known as the September Fund misstated the legal structure of the campaign activities of MoveOn.org. It conducts its campaign activities as a political action committee, not under an alternative structure known as a 527, after a relevant section of the tax code.
