BELBOUL--Salim E. Died at the age of 97 on September 15th, 2006. Beloved husband of Hanina and father to Ida and David. Caring brother, two sisters, Rachel and Saida. His presence will be missed by his friends and family.

The Dallas Cowboys' matchup with the Washington Redskins handed NBC another Sunday night victory, easily overshadowing two competing season premieres on CBS and ABC. Excluding the pregame show and adjusting for time-zone discrepancies, NBC drew 18.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Meanwhile, ABC's premiere of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' with Marlee Matlin as a guest team leader, garnered 10.9 million viewers in back-to-back episodes from 8 to 10 p.m. Its performance just bested the start of CBS's 10th ''Amazing Race,'' which drew 10.1 million total viewers from 8:30 to 10. In the vaunted demographic of adults 18 to 49, however, neither show could top Fox's durable comedy lineup, second only to football: ''The Simpsons'' at 8 (8.9 million), ''American Dad'' at 8:30 (7.7 million) and ''Family Guy'' at 9 (9.3 million). The audience notably dropped off at 9:30 for Michael Rapaport's ''War at Home'' (6.7 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some copies on Sunday about tentative agreements by the federal and New York State governments to become anchor tenants in the Freedom Tower at ground zero misstated in some copies the number of employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. It is 84, not 74.

Ned Lamont, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, has secured the endorsement of one of the state's largest labor unions, which had backed Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in the primary. The switch by the union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is the biggest labor boost Mr. Lamont has received since winning the Democratic primary last month.

A front-page article on Sept. 8 about the background of Ralph J. Phillips, the escaped inmate known as Bucky who was the target of a manhunt in western New York for five months, misspelled the surname of his lawyer. He is John Keavey, not Keaney.

An effort to help identify false and misleading advertising for dietary supplements was announced yesterday by the national advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus and the Council for Responsible Nutrition, the supplement industry's trade association. A grant from the council will enable the division to hire a lawyer whose sole focus will be supplement ads.

LAYTON--John. 87, passed away on August 25, 2006. He was born in Brooklyn on April 22, 1919. He lived in his early years with his family in Levittown, LI. He moved to Melbourne, FL in 1987. He was a Route man for the New York Times and the Daily News. He joined the East Meadow Fire Department in 1955 and was a lifetime member. He was preceded in death by his late wife Dorothy. He was survived by his children, Dorothy McIntire, Jacqueline Hubesch and son Thomas Layton and his wife Karen. His grandchildren are Joey, Darlene, Stacy McIntire, Jesse and Dorothy Hipsch, Thomas Jr., Denise, Christopher, Michael and Timothy Layton and eleven greatgrandchildren and one greatgreat granddaughter. Memorial Service will be held at Graveside at later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Heart Association or the Cancer Center in Melbourne, FL.

Progressive Corp., Cleveland, has awarded the creative account for Progressive Direct insurance to Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas. Spending was estimated at $150 million to $250 million. Since 1999, Progressive had worked with Doner, Southfield, Mich., which resigned last spring after a review for the account began.

The Los Angeles Department of Animal Services ordered the artist Banksy on Sunday to wash down an elephant that he had painted with nontoxic paint as part of an art installation, titled ''Barely Legal,'' in a downtown warehouse. The animal services office had issued two permits allowing the Indian elephant, a 38-year-old female named Tai, to be painted and used in the show. The elephant was part of a piece that noted ''the elephant in the room,'' or problems like war and human suffering that people pretend to care about but will not discuss. After animal-rights advocates complained to the animal services department, Ed Boks, the department's general manager, ordered the elephant to be washed, a change of course that was first reported in The Los Angeles Times. The order came a few hours before the weekend-long show was scheduled to end. EDWARD WYATT
ROUBLEV--Flora O'Hana. Flora was a dear friend of the late Henry and Erna Leir. She was a woman of great wit, charm, spirit and intelligence. Estate of Henry J. Leir

(13) TWELVE DISCIPLES OF NELSON MANDELA -- In 1960, Benjamin Pule Leinaeng, a black South African, and 11 of his comrades left their home in Bloemfantein on a mission: to tell the world about the brutality of the apartheid system and their support for the African National Congress and its leader, Nelson Mandela. In this ''P.O.V.'' documentary, Leinaeng's stepson Thomas Allen Harris looks back on the life of the man who reared him, but whom he could never call father. 10 P.M. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A group of countries led by France plan to raise at least $300 million next year, mostly through taxes on airline tickets, to help pay for the treatment of children with AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, a senior French official said yesterday. The countries, acting through a new Geneva-based organization called Unitaid, plan to pool their buying power and have asked former President Bill Clinton's foundation to negotiate with drug companies for volume discounts.

Survived by his wife of 35 years, Roberta, three sons, David, Jonathan and Billy, two daughters, Susan and Amy as well as a younger brother Alan. WORRIES OVER HEDGE FUNDS -- Enormous losses at Amaranth Advisors, one of the largest hedge funds, resurrected worries that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions. [Page C1.] RISE OF AN INDEPENDENT MONITOR -- In 2003, Bristol-Myers Squibb's chief executive, Peter Dolan, retained the advising services of a former federal judge admired by the federal prosecutor who was investigating the company. Last week, the former judge successfully recommended that the board fire Mr. Dolan. [C1.] HIGH HOPES FOR THE HOLIDAYS -- The nation's retailers are beginning to talk about an above-average shopping season, despite higher gas prices and a sluggish housing market. [C1.] CHANGING BETS ON OIL -- As crude oil prices have plunged about 18 percent over the last six weeks, many traders say they have been dumping and short-selling stocks and futures contracts. In many cases, traders are betting against the very bets they made only a few weeks ago. Market Place. [C1.] TOUGH CASE FOR PROSECUTORS -- Despite the California attorney general's assertion that he has enough evidence to press charges against people inside and outside Hewlett-Packard, a criminal case may be hard to prosecute, legal specialists say. [C4.] KPMG STRIKES BACK -- The accounting firm KPMG struck back against 16 former employees and the federal judge overseeing their coming tax-shelter trial, filing court papers seeking compensation from certain defendants and appealing a ruling that their rights were violated. [C4.] POWER SHIFT AT THE I.M.F. -- Member states of the International Monetary Fund voted to adopt a disputed plan to modify the fund's power structure and take steps to expand the voice of China and other rapidly developing nations. [C4.] A TWIST ON CORPORATE CHARITY -- Virgin Group, the cluster of companies founded by Richard Branson, is introducing Virgin Unite, a charity that combines financing and volunteers from the company with financing and volunteers from the public in social outreach work and philanthropic undertakings. [C4.] AFTER THE ACCOUNTING SCANDAL -- The business software maker CA expects to recover some of the money it lost to former executives involved in a $2.2 billion accounting scandal, its chief executive said. [C4.] A RASH OF FOOD POISONING -- Federal health officials said that before the current E. coli outbreak there had been 19 food-poisoning outbreaks since 1995 linked to lettuce and spinach. [A21.] AN ONLINE LESSON FOR MARKETERS -- The outing of Lonelygirl15, the online creation whose confessional video diaries captivated hundreds of thousands of YouTube fans, has forced her audience to consider: Was Lonelygirl a simple hoax or high-concept art? Advertising. [C5.] COURIC STRONG OUT OF THE GATE -- Katie Couric has made the ratings race among the three network newscasts more competitive than it has been in nearly a decade. In preliminary results, Ms. Couric, left, beat her counterparts at NBC and ABC by 70,000 and 370,000 viewers, respectively. [C5.] G.M. AND FORD HAD TALKS -- Word has emerged that General Motors briefly pondered a linkup with Ford. [C8.] GAS PROJECT ON HOLD -- Citing damage to salmon rivers on the Sakhalin Island, the Russian government withdrew environmental approval for the largest private energy investment in the country, the Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas project operated by Royal Dutch Shell. [C11.] REVLON OUSTS CHIEF EXECUTIVE -- Revlon, the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, has ousted its chief executive, Jack L. Stahl, after four years of losses. Liddy, was stepping down at the end of 2006. He will be succeeded by the company's No. 2 executive, Thomas J. Wilson, the president and chief operating officer. To the Editor: Re ''Exercise = Weight Loss, Except When It Doesn't'' (Personal Health, Sept. 12): As a person who swims, runs, bikes and uses an elliptical trainer every week, I take issue with the assertion that biking and swimming use fewer calories than running, walking or stair climbing. A recreational biker or swimmer may not burn many calories, but I can attest that my heart rate in swimming and biking is as high as in running or use of an elliptical trainer, or higher.

Jury deliberations are scheduled to begin in Federal District Court today in the racketeering conspiracy case against John A. Gotti, the former Gambino crime family boss. The charges against Mr. Gotti, who is known as Junior, include ordering the kidnapping and beating of Curtis Sliwa in 1992, money laundering, extortion and witness tampering. Mr. Gotti's defense is that he withdrew from the Gambino family before July 1999; if true, that would allow him to avoid conviction because of the statute of limitations on the racketeering charges. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS (NYT)

To the Editor: In ''Updating Prescriptions for Avoiding Worldwide Catastrophe'' (Conversation, Sept. 12), the scientist James Lovelock makes the absurd claim that ''even the results of an all-out nuclear war pale into insignificance as unimportant compared to what's going to happen'' with global warming. Rather, the nuclear winter after such a war would lead to mass starvation, killing most of the world's population.
POLISAR--Jonathan. On August 15th, beloved son of Betty Polisar Reigot and loving brother of Paula Anne, Diana Jean, and Katherine Lynne Schwartz.

WILSON--Don A. ''Hap''. Died unexpectedly on September 15, 2006. Born in West Palm Beach, FL on October 5, 1962, Don's life encompassed his family, his friends and the pursuit of nature through fishing, hunting, and his active partnership in Wolf Creek Ranch in Kenansville, FL. Don is survived by his wife, Serena, and their two daughters, Alexis and McKenzie. In addition, Don is survived by his mother, Sandra T. Kaupe; a sister Shari Wilson; and brother Peter Kaupe. Don graduated from St. Andrew's School in Boca Raton, and earned a degree in history from Roanoke College. His interest in fishing began as a young boy. As a teenager he caught and sold bait and taught himself rod wrapping after school. He became an accomplished big game fisherman, catching his 200th blue marlin in 1991. He fished extensively aboard the ''Sandra T'' in South Florida, the Bahamas, Mexico, and the Virgin Islands and was an avid proponent of tag and release programs and marine conservation. Don was an active, contributing member of several organizations including the West Palm Beach Fishing Club, the Sailfish Club of Florida, the Coastal Conservation Association, the National Coalition for Marine Conservation, The Florida Aquarium and The Clearwater Marine Science Center. A Memorial Service will be held at 4:00 PM on Tuesday, September 19, 2006, at St. Edwards Catholic Church, Palm Beach, FL, with a gathering immediately following at the West Palm Beach Fishing Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Palm Beach County Fishing Foundation c/o West Palm Beach Fishing Club, P.O. Box 468, West Palm Beach, FL 33402 to support programs for underprivileged children. Hap will be remembered for his joyful spirit and generosity and missed by all.
POCKELL--Hannah K. On September 18. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Fred H. Pockell and Laura(Robert N) Glassman. Devoted Grandmother of Howard and Jill.

Q. If the normal trajectory of weather in the continental United States is from west to east, why is the normal trajectory of a hurricane from south to north? A. A hurricane can go in almost any direction, but its path is subject to belts of wind at different heights and latitudes and to its own internal winds, said Francis Kredensor, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University.

RANDAZZO--Carmine. His senseless loss reminds us that there are no guarantees for a noble life lived. He will live on in three of New York's Finest, Joe, Anthony and Carmine. We know he has taken his place among the mighty in Heaven. We send our love and deepest sympathies to the entire family. Joseph and Erika Ades.

To the Editor: Re ''To Fight Stuttering, Doctors Look at the Brain'' (Sept. 12): As the mother of an 11-year-old boy with profound dysfluency, I feel relieved and hopeful that this disorder may finally be getting the attention it deserves.

CIFU--Robert, M.D. Born May 18, 1928, died peacefully at home September 16, 2006, after a short illness. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Anne; son Adam and daughter-in-law Sarah, and joy-ofjoys grandchildren, Ben and Amelia, as well as sisters, Palma Cifu and Miriam Driscoll. Loved by a large family, including nieces Palma and Marisa Driscoll, nephew Craig Inciardi and wife, Joan. Psychoanalyst, gardener, cook, wit, scholar and lifelong student, voracious reader, traveler, wonderful friend in person and on the phone, superb conversationalist and endlessly supportive father and loving husband. Contributions in his memory can be made to The Robert Cifu M.D. Memorial Scholarship Fund at LaSalle Academy, 44 East Second Street, NYC 10003. Family visitation will be private.

To the Editor: Re ''In a Rare Step, Pope Expresses Personal Regret'' (front page, Sept. 18): Careful reading of Pope Benedict XVI's remarks in Regensburg, Germany, for which he has now issued a statement of personal regret, should reveal to the reader his intent: a call to dialogue and reason among people of faith, not prejudice and violence.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sept. 11 about the assassination of an Afghan provincial governor misstated the time period during which he went into exile and referred incompletely to where he lived. He left Afghanistan during the 1980's, not in 1996 when the Taliban took power; in addition to living in Australia, he also lived in Pakistan.

To the Editor: So the mayor wants to increase the number of bicycle paths throughout the city (news article, Sept. 13). What folly, without also significantly increasing enforcement of the traffic rules that also apply to bicyclists -- enforcement that would pay for itself and the additional paths. I am out and about our city as a pedestrian and driver. Often I am at risk from the bicyclists who are all over the road but not in the designated paths.

The Link by Link column in Business Day on Sept. 11, about the use of pseudonyms by bloggers and others to attack their critics, misstated the name of the Roy J. Carver professor of English at the University of Iowa and a director of the Walt Whitman online archive, who noted that Whitman anonymously reviewed his own work. He is Ed Folsom, not Ed J. Folsom.

HALL--Craig D., M.D. September 14. Brilliant, talented, generous and a great friend. Words cannot capture our sense of loss. Our heartfelt condolences and love to Eve, Evan and Zoe. Bruce Batkin Ferne Traeger

The New York Athletic Club will hold a dinner Oct. 11 to honor Al Oerter on the 50th anniversary of the first of his four Olympic gold medals. Oerter was a 20-year-old University of Kansas sophomore when he won the discus at the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne, Australia. He also won in 1960 in Rome, in 1964 in Tokyo and in 1968 in Mexico City. In each of those Games, he defeated the world-record holder and broke the Olympic record. Oerter became the first track and field athlete to win the same event in four consecutive Olympics. Only Carl Lewis, who won the long jump in 1984, 1988, 1992 and 1996, has done it since. FRANK LITSKY (NYT)

''This is a story of a shared and common humanity and overcoming political differences in a town known for its inhumanity.'' MAX CLELAND, former senator, on the relationship between Representative Jim Ramstad and Representative Patrick Kennedy. [A20]

A front-page article last Tuesday about an announcement by the Palestinian president of an agreement to form a unity government misstated a provision of the charter of Israel's conservative Likud Party regarding Israel's borders. The charter defines the Jordan River as the eastern border of Israel and does not call for an Israel on both banks of the Jordan, though some early participants and leaders in the party took that position.

Collins Stewart Tullet, a British financial services company, outlined plans to break up to help it capitalize on a growing number of small American companies that are going to London for public listings. The company said it would separate its retail stockbroker and its institutional broker by year-end and return £300 million ($564 million) to shareholders. All the company's United States equities business has been moved to the stock brokerage arm, Collins Stewart, which is building its presence in the United States. The company also reported results, saying profit more than doubled in the first half of the year, to £68.5 million ($128.8 million) from £26.1 million a year earlier. HEATHER STEWART (NYT)

A government official confirmed that 55 children had contracted the H.I.V. virus through contaminated blood or used needles at a hospital in the south. Health Minister Yerbolat Dosayev said final tests had been received for just half of the 9,800 children who came in contact with the needles and blood supplies in June and July. ILAN GREENBERG (NYT)

An obituary in some copies yesterday about Patricia Kennedy Lawford, a sister of President John F. Kennedy, misstated the location of her death. It was at her home in Manhattan, not her home in Southampton, N.Y. The article also erroneously included a survivor; her sister Rosemary Kennedy died last year. The obituary also misstated the place of residence of Mrs. Lawford's son, Christopher. He lives in California, not New York. A full obituary appears today on page B8.

COLLEGE DOMINICAN, N.Y.--Named Manny Rapkin men's assistant lacrosse coach. LAMAR--Named Aldrin Campos men's tennis coach. MEMPHIS--Fired Joe Lee Dunn, defensive coordinator. NORTHEASTERN--Named Thomas Murphy men's assistant basketball coach. NOTRE DAME--Named Michael Bertsch assistant sports information director. NOVA SOUTHEASTERN--Named Ann Walker assistant athletic director for compliance and senior woman administrator for the department of athletics. SIENA--Named Melissa Hershey diving coach. UCF--Suspended DB Travonti Johnson four games for a violation of team policy. VERMONT--Named Willie Mitchell men's assistant hockey coach. WAGNER--Suspended senior men's basketball F Durell Vinson for a violation of the student code of conduct. WASHINGTON--Named Jimmy Bean men's assistant track and cross country coach.

The questions began before President Bush's helicopter even touched down in Lower Manhattan yesterday for a three-day visit marking the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly: Would they meet face to face? Even by chance? The ''they'' in question were Mr. Bush and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, one of Mr. Bush's most prominent Middle Eastern foils. Mr. Ahmadinejad is scheduled to address the General Assembly just hours after Mr. Bush does today as the tense negotiations over Iran's nuclear program continue.

LINDENBAUM--Belle. Aunt Belle, you were a quintessential elegant lady. We mourn your passing, but cherish your legacy of wit, warmth and wisdom. Our love and sympathy to Sandy, Linda, and the entire Lindenbaum family. Karen and Paul Bonheim $(6$)LINDENBAUM--Belle. A bright, beautiful and caring sister who was always there for her family.
