The terrorism trial of seven men was suspended after one said he would give no further evidence because he feared for his family in Pakistan. Omar Khyam said Pakistani agents had visited his relatives after he testified about receiving training there. The seven have denied charges of plotting to bomb targets including pubs and nightclubs. The trial was adjourned after the judge said the jury could ''draw inferences'' from Mr. Khyam's refusal to testify. It is to continue today. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

Spain and Britain said Monday that they had resolved some of the thorniest issues in the longstanding dispute over Gibraltar, announcing accords on shared access to the airport there and on arrears that Britain will pay to Spanish pensioners. The agreements do not, however, address the central question: Spain's objections to British control of the territory.

An article on Sept. 8 about the mixed reaction in France to the government's decision to deploy troops to Lebanon referred imprecisely to the deaths of 58 French paratroopers and 241 Americans in Lebanon in 1983. The deaths occurred when two bombs exploded in separate locations almost simultaneously on Oct. 23; they were not caused by one suicide bombing.

Three Hezbollah members seized by Israel in the recent fighting in Lebanon were charged with murder and other crimes. One, Hussein Suleiman, is accused of involvement in the July 12 cross-border raid in which three Israeli soldiers were killed and two were seized, precipitating the month of fighting. The others, Muhammad Sarour and Maher Qurani, were involved in border attacks against Israeli soldiers, Israeli officials said. Hezbollah is demanding a prisoner exchange for the seized Israelis, and will very likely seek the return of the three defendants. GREG MYRE (NYT)

Willie Nelson in Drug Bust Willie Nelson and several members of his band were issued misdemeanor citations for drug possession early yesterday at a traffic stop on Interstate 10 near Breaux Bridge in St. Martin Parish, La., The Associated Press reported. State Trooper Willie Williams said troopers noticed a strong odor of marijuana when the driver opened the bus door, and about 1.5 pounds of marijuana and about 3 ounces of mushrooms were found during a search. Mr. Nelson, 73, right, of Spicewood, Tex., and four members of his band were released after they were given the citations. Crocodile Hunter Memorial Prime Minister John Howard of Australia, below, is to attend the public memorial service tomorrow for Steve Irwin, television's popular Crocodile Hunter, who died at 44 on Sept. 4 when his heart was pierced by a stingray barb while making a documentary. John Stainton, Mr. Irwin's manager, producer and longtime friend, said he was determined that the event, to be attended by some 5,500 people and televised live around the world, would not degenerate into a circus, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Stainton declined to divulge details of the memorial at the ''Crocoseum'' at Mr. Irwin's Australia Zoo, north of Brisbane, but said yesterday: ''It's very loose at the moment. I just want it to happen and everyone to enjoy it, and that's it.'' Gish Prize Winner Chosen An Iranian-born artist who lives in New York has been named the winner of the 2006 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize of about $300,000 and a silver medallion. The artist, Shirin Neshat, left, whose photographs, films and projections explore Islam and gender relations, will receive her awards at a ceremony on Oct. 12 at the Hudson Theater, where scenes from her feature film work will be shown. The Gish Prize, named for the sisters best known for their performances in silent films, is given annually ''to a man or woman who has made an outstanding contribution to the beauty of the world and to mankind's enjoyment and understanding of life.'' Previous winners include Bob Dylan, Ingmar Bergman and Arthur Miller. New Tolkien Epic Coming Fans of J. R. R. Tolkien, the author of ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings,'' have a new epic to look forward to. Houghton Mifflin announced yesterday that it had acquired the American rights to publish ''The Children of Hurin.'' Begun in 1918, it was a tale that Tolkien, right (1892-1973), worked on throughout his life and will take his readers once more among elves and men and dragons and dwarfs. Houghton Mifflin said in an announcement that although it had long been assumed that ''The Children of Hurin'' would remain unfinished, it had been reconstructed and edited by Tolkien's son Christopher, working from Tolkien's many drafts. Publication is scheduled for spring. Andrew Lloyd Webber Defends Maria Andrew Lloyd Webber has struck back at critics who are carping about the number of times his Maria, chosen in a televised contest, will sing weekly when his new production of ''The Sound of Music'' opens in London in November. Discussing plans for the winner, Connie Fisher, 23, right, to sing at the Palladium in six of the eight weekly performances, he said it was his ''duty'' to protect her voice, the BBC reported, and he added that it was ''absolutely normal'' for a young leading lady to sing fewer than eight performances weekly. ''This was the case when Sarah Brightman starred in 'The Phantom of the Opera' at the age of 22,'' he said. ''It was the same for Elaine Paige in 'Evita' and is true of Elena Roger, who is starring in the new production of 'Evita.' '' Ms. Fisher told BBC News: ''I would love to do eight shows a week. But I have to test my stamina.'' Baritone Wins in Toulouse A Chinese baritone, Song-Hu Liu, has won the top prize at the 46th international singing contest held every two years in Toulouse, France, Agence France-Presse reported. A first prize was not awarded to any of the six female finalists, but Elisabeth Donovan, a British soprano, was awarded second place. Mr. Song-Hu received a Sèvres vase and $8,200 donated by the city of Toulouse. Past winners in the contest, first held in 1324 and resurrected in 1954, include José Van Dam and Elena Vassilieva. Prisoners Build a Bohème Prisoners in Italy and Ireland have become opera aficionados, designing and making the sets and costumes to be used in a staging of Puccini's ''Bohème'' by Opera Ireland, Ireland's national opera company, in Dublin in mid-November, Reuters reported. The project, originating in 2004 at the high-security Maiano prison in Perugia, Italy, involves a collaboration between it and Mountjoy Prison in Dublin, where inmates have spent six months working from designs created by the Italians. ''They're all very proud of the work they're doing in Mountjoy, and they're learning new skills which they can use when they leave prison,'' said Conleth Teevan, a spokesman for Opera Ireland. He indicated that some prisoners would be allowed to attend the opera and that the rest would see it on video.

A front-page article on Sept. 9 about President Bush's strategy for speeches leading up to the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld about people who have criticized the way the administration has dealt with terrorists in Iraq and elsewhere. In an Aug. 29 speech, Mr. Rumsfeld said, ''This is not an enemy that can be ignored, or negotiated with, or appeased.'' He did not call the critics ''appeasers.''

To the Editor: Re ''The Stranger in the Mirror'' (column, Sept. 14): Bob Herbert writes: ''During the Cuban missile crisis, when the hawks were hot for bombing -- or an invasion -- Robert Kennedy counseled against a U.S. first strike. That's not something the U.S. would do, he said.''
GLUCK--Zoltan. On September 17, 2006. Beloved husband of Juliet. Devoted father of David and Libby. Services Tuesday 1 P.M., at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY.

The out-of-town scoreboard always seems to hover behind Dave Roberts, begging him to turn around and take a little peek. Roberts is a left fielder, and since many ballparks keep the out-of-town scoreboard by the left-field fence, stealing a glance should not be a problem. But because Roberts plays for the San Diego Padres, he generally needs more than just a glance. He often has to read up on half the league.

Chest-thumping leaders of the New York Democratic Party rallied here on Monday and predicted a clean sweep of statewide offices in the November election over the enemy -- identified by one Democratic speaker after another as ''the two Georges,'' Messrs. Bush and Pataki. The party's tight focus on President Bush and Gov. George E. Pataki, instead of the actual Republican candidates this fall, is the latest sign of the low regard in which Democrats say they hold their opponents. They are so confident of outright victory that they are now shooting for bigger game -- an electoral rebuke of Mr. Bush and Mr. Pataki.

To the Editor: Re ''How the Presidency Regained Its Balance,'' by John Yoo (Op-Ed, Sept. 17): While I don't for a second doubt the danger the United States and other democracies face from terrorists today, I can't believe that John Yoo is right when he thinks that one of the bulwarks against terrorism is Mr. Bush's ''reserving his right not to enforce unconstitutional laws.''

The government indefinitely suspended the current National Assembly session, putting on the back burner a proposed amendment that aimed to end abuses suffered by women who reported rape or were accused of adultery under an Islamic ordinance. Despite weeks of wheeling and dealing on the bill, which went before Parliament last month, fierce opposition by hard-line Islamic parties forced the government to delay trying to pass the bill while it seeks a broader consensus for it. SALMAN MASOOD (NYT)

The easiest way to get Nascar Nextel Cup drivers to sound like their racecars is to tell them about a rules change. Throaty grumbling tends to rev into whining. Two years ago, when Nascar's Chase for the Nextel Cup began, most drivers sounded as if they hated the format: the top 10 drivers in points through the first 26 races and any other drivers within 400 points of the leader would compete in the final 10 races for the series title. But after they saw how the Chase pumped up television ratings and generated excitement, they simmered down.

Several years ago, an obese, diabetic patient of mine insisted on knee-replacement surgery against the wishes of her doctors, who believed that it would be too dangerous. She came through with flying colors. While everyone rightly praised the efforts of her surgeon and physical therapist, another factor in her recovery was ignored: luck. Why are doctors and patients so reluctant to discuss a phenomenon that permeates medicine every day?

Voters in Moldova's separatist region, Transnistria, also known as Trans-Dniester, overwhelmingly backed a plan to join Russia. The European Union said it would not recognize the vote. The tiny Russian-speaking territory declared independence from Moldova in 1991 with the support of Russian troops, which have stayed on. Russian officials have suggested that the future of Transnistria and three other separatist regions on the territory of the former Soviet Union -- Abkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia, and Nagorno-Karabakh, fought over by Armenia and Azerbaijan -- could be decided in plebiscites. ANDREW E. KRAMER (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''My Plan to Save Network Television,'' by Charlie Hauck (Op-Ed, Sept. 16): Loved the article, but must caution network execs that there is no need to bar us ''oldsters'' from watching the Big Four. We stopped watching a decade ago!

An obituary in some copies yesterday about Patricia Kennedy Lawford, a sister of President John F. Kennedy, misstated the location of her death. It was at her home in Manhattan, not her home in Southampton, N.Y. The article also erroneously included a survivor; her sister Rosemary Kennedy died last year. The obituary also misstated the place of residence of Mrs. Lawford's son, Christopher. He lives in California, not New York. A full obituary appears today on page B8.

MELTZER--Barbara L., passed away at her sister's home on Sunday September 17, 2006. Beloved mother of Erica and Stephen, grandmother of Jon, Amy and Adam, sister of Herbert and Renee. Joseph W. Sorce F.H. Inc. (845) 358-4433
To the Editor: Re ''She Dreamed of the Stars; Now She'll Almost Touch Them'' (Sept. 12): Are there no limits to The Times's gushing admiration for all things orbital?

RE--Judge Edward D. The Board of Directors and Members of the Neponsit Property Owners' Association deeply regrets the loss of one of its Board members and wishes to express its heartfelt condolences to his family. Edward D. Re was Chief Judge Emeritus of the U.S. Court of International Trade and will be remembered for his dignified manner, kindness and commitment to our country and to our community. $(6$)RE--Edward D., on September 17th, 2006. Chief Judge Emeritus, U.S. Court of International Trade. Distinguished Professor of Law Emeritus, St. John's University School of Law. Retired Colonel, U.S.A.F, J.A.G. Department. Former Chairman of the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission of the United States. Former Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs. Beloved husband of Margaret A. (nee Corcoran). Loving father of Mary Ann Re, Anthony J. Re, Marina Re, Edward J. Re, Jr., Victor M. Re, Margaret T. Re, Matthew J. Re, Joseph R. Re, Mary Elizabeth Hoes, Mary Joan Re, Mary Ellen Caggiano and Nancy Cregan. Grandfather of 23 and great-grandfather of one. Reposing at Denis O'Connor F.H., 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach. Funeral Mass at St. Francis De Sales Church, Belle Harbor, on Wednesday at 10 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. $(6$)RE--Edward D. Hon. St. Johns School of Law notes with sorrow the passing of Honorable Edward D. Re, Distinguished Professor of Law Emeritus, alumnus, supporter, and friend. Honorable Edward D. Re., Chief Judge Emeritus of the U.S. Court of International Trade, served the administrations of both President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson as Assistant Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs and as Chairman of the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission of the United States. He was appointed a federal judge to the U.S. Court of International Trade by President Johnson in 1968, and, by appointment of President Carter, served as Chief Judge from 1977 to his retirement from the federal bench in 1991. Judge Re graduated from St. Johns School of Law in 1943. He was first appointed to the faculty at St. Johns School of Law in 1947. He taught Appellate Advocacy, International Law and Remedies to generations of students. In 1968, St. John's University awarded him an honorary Doctor of Laws degree, and in 2003, the Alumni Association presented him with the St. Thomas More Award, for moral courage. Judge Re was the recipient of twenty honorary degrees from universities in the United States and abroad. In addition to articles on advocacy, legal writing, international and comparative law, he was the author along with his son Joseph R. Re of, Re and Re on Remedies, 6th edition (2005), Foundation Press and Re and Re on Brief Writing and Oral Argument, 9th edition, (2005) Oceana Publications. Judge Re authored Selected Essays on Equity (1955); Freedom's Prophet: Selected Writings of Zechariah Chafee, Jr., (1961); Cases on International Law (with Lester B. Orfield)(1955; 1965); Foreign Confiscations in Anglo-American Law (1951). The entire St. Johns community will miss the friendship of this dedicated alumnus and friend.

WHEN is losing good for business? When the Mets are on the verge of clinching their first division title since 1988 and their fans buy tickets hoping to be at the game when they do. The Mets sold more than 10,000 extra tickets for last night's game at Shea Stadium because they had lost all three weekend games in Pittsburgh and still needed one victory to wrap up first place in the National League East.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Canadian Panel Faults U.S. For Role in Torture Case A government panel exonerated a Canadian computer engineer of any ties to terrorism and issued a scathing report that faulted both Canadian and United States authorities for his deportation four years ago to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tortured. A1 Suicide by Indian Farmers Rises Across India 17,107 farmers committed suicide in 2003 and anecdotal reports suggest the trend is continuing. New access to global competition and technology has become a double-edged sword, as farmers go deep into debt to compete with world markets and government subsidies have dried up. A1 Chirac Modifies Iran Stance In an effort to jump-start formal negotiations between six world powers and Iran over its nuclear program, President Jacques Chirac of France suggested that Iran would not have to freeze major nuclear activities until after the talks began. A14 Somali Leader Escapes Bomber President Abdullah Yusuf escaped an assassination attempt when a suicide car bomber rammed into his convoy and blew up outside the Parliament building in Baidoa. He was not hurt, but at least eight people were killed, according to officials. A11 NATIONAL A16-22 Congressman Won't Quit After Admitting Corruption Representative Bob Ney of Ohio, who agreed last week to plead guilty to federal corruption charges, has rebuffed demands that he resign, creating a dilemma for Republican strategists who want him off the public stage before he does more harm to the party. A18 Scare on Space Station The three-man crew aboard the International Space Station scrambled to deal with an overheated oxygen generator and a possible chemical spill that caused NASA to declare a brief station emergency. A22 Prayer Controversy Stalls Bill The bill that sets the Pentagon's spending levels is being held up by controversy over a provision that would allow military chaplains to offer sectarian prayers at nondenominational military events. A19 Women Face Bias in Science Women in science and engineering are hindered not by lack of ability but by bias and ''outmoded institutional structures'' in academia, a panel reported. A22 EDUCATION Princeton Ends Early Admission A week after Harvard abandoned early admissions, saying it puts low-income students at a disadvantage, Princeton followed suit. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Insurance Firm Exceeds Limit of Political Donations New York law prevents corporations from contributing more than $5,000 a year to candidates for state office, but one of the world's largest insurance companies has given almost 20 times that amount to some of New York's most prominent politicians, according to a review of data. A1 Freedom Tower Opposition City and state officials are celebrating their commitment to fill space in the Freedom Tower, but there seems to be less cheering among people who might actually have to work there. B1 Tax Credits for Poor Families The Bloomberg administration plans to offer tax credits, which would be worth up to $1,000 per child, to impoverished families to offset child-care costs and give cash rewards to encourage poor people to stay in school and receive preventive medical care. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Moving the Mississippi's Path A group of researchers considering ways to restore Louisiana's vanishing wetlands recommended a massive diversion of the Mississippi River, an idea that has long been dismissed as impractical. F1 Health & Fitness F5 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Betting on Gas and Oil Enormous losses at one of the nation's largest hedge funds revived worries that major bets by these investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions. C1 As crude oil prices have plunged, many traders say they have been dumping and short-selling stocks and futures contracts. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Take the lead on Darfur; immigration's lost year; judicial politics run amok; nature with an edge. Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, John Tierney Crossword B2 Obituaries B8 TV Listings B9 Weather C16

To the Editor: Your Sept. 11 editorial ''Denying the Vote'' says of laws disenfranchising felons, ''These laws are the worst in the free world.'' Wow. I should have thought that The Times would have reserved this honor for the Second Amendment. Seriously, what is so wrong with a law that says, if you aren't willing to follow the law, then you can't make the law for everyone else?

To the Editor: Re ''Modern Ways Open India's Doors to Diabetes'' (''The Price of Affluence'' series, front page, Sept. 13): As a naturalized American of Indian descent, I can attest to the fact that sweets do play a very important part in Indian culture.

Skinny models are nothing new, but the ultrathin women on some of this year's runways have led to a new sense of concern that designers are contributing to unhealthy and potentially life-threatening behavior among models, Eric Wilson writes in today's Thursday Styles.

I was a little disappointed to learn over the weekend of the People's Design Award, a contest introduced by the Smithsonian's Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and sponsored by Target. Visitors to the museum's Web site can browse various designs and vote for a favorite, or nominate one of their own.
Daily Gotham to the Greens: Please slink away.

Although it has been only a week and a half since the last race, and there's as much time to go until the next one, the amount of news that has been happening in Formula One is equivalent to that of a race weekend.
Dr. Jacques Ndemanga Kamoune turns down hundreds of women a year.
After nine days in Africa, I figured it was time to update my playlist.
An advertisement by the independent group Progress for America leads with the words "These people want to kill us."
After more than a week in Africa, Casey Parks rethinks her musical selections. (Producer: Naka Nathaniel)
Democrat Senator Robert Menendez on the Iraq war.
The latest poll shows that the Connecticut Senate race is still a statistical dead heat.
As you probably know, Apple's been in the news quite a bit lately. (That's "lately," as in, "pretty much every other month for the last five years.")

It has been snapping up New York skyscrapers at a rapid pace in the past year. Now, Dubai's Istithmar may be poised to buy an entire real estate investment trust. REIT Newshound, a real estate trade newsletter, reported that Istithmar was in talks to buy Crescent Real Estate Equities, which owns office buildings and resort properties.

The campaign of Tom Kean Jr. -- the Republican challenging Senator Bob Menendez in New Jersey -- may be in for a hard lesson about the lack of true anonymity on the Internet. Or it may all just be a dirty Internet trick.
As the newest hedge fund disaster plays out, watch for some patterns to develop.

The value of Chinese mergers and acquisitions is still relatively small. But big things could be in store, according to Jim Hemerling, a Shanghai-based director for Boston Consulting Group. Writing in BusinessWeek, he says that Chinese companies "have two things going for them that are necessary to move forward aggressively: encouragement from the government and plenty of available capital."
International Herald Tribune managing editor Alison Smale reports on rioting in Hungary. (Producer: Bommy Lee)
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Sept. 20 column, "Dumb as We Wanna Be."

Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost more than $3 billion dollars betting on natural gas prices, told investors that it had reached an agreement to unload its book of troubled energy trades. The fund did not identify the buyer, but sources familiar with the transaction confirmed to the New York Times that Citadel, another large hedge fund, and J.P. Morgan Chase will take on the portfolio.

President Clinton opened his second annual conference on global challenges this morning with an announcement by First Lady Laura Bush that the United States would devote $10 million to a new project to bring clean water to 10 million people in Africa by 2010.

"Flipping" by private equity firms -- defined as taking a company public within a year of acquiring it -- fails to create long-term value for investors, according to a study cited Wednesday by The Financial Times. These initial public offerings tend to underperform other I.P.O.'s and the market as a whole, according to the study, by Josh Lerner of the Harvard Business School and Jerry Cao of Boston College.

Frank Zarb's idea of temporary is not the usual one. In April 2005 he became the temporary chairman of American International Group, the insurer that was in crisis because of the actions of Maurice R. Greenberg, the longtime chairman and chief executive. Today the company announced he will step down on Nov.1. During his tenure A.I.G. seems to have recovered and to have overcome the legal problems Mr. Greenberg left behind.
As Thais awoke Wednesday morning to news of the coup, Gen. Sondhi Boonyaratkalin’s junta sought to consolidate its control.
Corrections
A newly formed high school put together a football team in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.
Lazard has appointed its Paris office head as the chief of a new pan-European team as part of an internal reorganization, the investment bank said Wednesday.

A survey of more than 4,000 recruiters found that the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business is the most appealing place for companies to find their new crop of M.B.A.'s. In their sixth annual survey, Harris Interactive and The Wall Street Journal ranked Ross first among national business schools, followed by Dartmouth University's Tuck School of Business, which took the No. 1 spot last year.
Mary Jane grows up and works out. Tina Vindum, personal trainer, wore Mary Janes while exercising on cardiovascular equipment, strength training and trail walking.
The Yankees clinched their ninth consecutive A.L. East title on Wednesday night when the second-place Boston Red Sox lost.

Bill Clinton hits town today for his big symposium, this time with a special guest: Laura Bush. Her husband, after facing off with Iran's president at the United Nations, won't stick around for the event, and will miss the star-studded party tonight, where the Clintonistas should be out in force.

Oops, they did it again: Writing at Balkinization, his group "blawg," Yale law professor Jack Balkin says John McCain, Lindsay Graham and John Warner are receiving too much credit as "brave defenders of human rights" for sponsoring a bill that would "eliminate the right of detainees to contest the legality and the conditions of their confinement through the ancient writ of habeas corpus." Balkin writes, "[T]he bill they have authored in the Senate is not a good bill; it is merely less terrible than the one the president is pushing."
Joan Nathan answers readers’ questions about preparing dishes for the Jewish holiday season.
What summer slump?

Goldman Sachs will take a 10.1 percent stake in the Climate Exchange of London, the carbon emissions futures exchange, as part of a deal that will give full ownership of the Chicago and European climate exchanges it runs to the London exchange, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Christopher Cox defended the controversial Sarbanes-Oxley law before a Senate panel Tuesday, but agreed with critics who say part of it needs to be changed.

Conrad W. Hewitt, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sought Tuesday to clarify the proper accounting for backdated options, reserving the harshest accounting for companies that followed a practice of reducing the exercise price after options were issued.

Broadcom, which is restating results to reflect $1.5 billion in costs related to options irregularities, said William J. Ruehle quit as senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective immediately.

The world's largest insurer, the American International Group, said on Wednesday its board had elected a former chief operating officer of Citigroup, Robert Willumstad, as its chairman, effective Nov. 1.
Rupert Murdoch said on Tuesday that his wife, Wendy Deng, was working with senior News Corporation executives to help bring the company's popular MySpace social networking site to China.
The French financier Vincent Bolloré is likely to make a play to take over the media buying group Aegis, according to a leading London analyst.

Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, pledged $50 million on Tuesday to help set up an international nuclear fuel bank that aspiring powers could turn to for reactor fuel instead of making it on their own.
A consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may raise its offer for Coles Myer, the Australian retailer that rejected a bid of 17 billion Australian dollars ($13 billion) from the buyout group.
Hewlett-Packard conducted feasibility studies on planting spies in the news bureaus of two major publications as part of an investigation of leaks from its board, according to The New York Times.

At least 28 parties have said they would like to kick the tires at the niche magazines that the embattled media giant Time Warner is trying to unload, according to The New York Post. Potential bidders are expected to be heavily weighted toward financial players, followed by European publishers who are benefiting from a strong euro. Only a few strategic bidders in the United States have lined up so far.
A solar photovoltaic company, Solaria, said Tuesday it had completed a second round of funding, collecting $22 million, and that it expects to bring solar concentrator products to market next year.

In a worrying sign for the future integrity of the corporate community, a new study has found that, of all the types of graduate students, M.B.A. students are the most likely to cheat. And perhaps even more troubling was the most widely cited reason for doing it: The assumption that everyone else was doing it, too.
Al Gore wants his YouTube.

Silicon Graphics, the once-high-flying computing business, released its reorganization plan Wednesday after approval by a United States bankruptcy court. With the ruling as well as exit financing from Morgan Stanley and General Electric Capital, the company plans to emerge from Chapter 11 next month.
Cell Therapeutics said this morning it has a deal to sell 23 million shares of stock to select investors at $1.73 a share in an offering that would raise $40 million.
China should let insurers invest more money in shares to help develop the stock market, the Shanghai Stock Exchange's president, Zhu Congjiu, said.
Negotiations between Tribune Company and the Chandler family may not be going as smoothly as reported.

The accounting firm Ernst & Young confirmed on Tuesday that United States regulators have visited its London headquarters to carry out inspections under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. Under the act, regulators are required to report every year on foreign audit firms with more than 100 clients with listings in the United States and every three years on those with fewer than 100 such clients.

The Canadian telecommunications giant BCE filed on Tuesday to sell a stake worth as much as $400 million in its Telesat Canada satellite arm in an initial public offering, the latest corporate revamp in a transforming telecom sector.

A group of nine of the world's biggest investment banks said on Tuesday they planned to set up a new system for reporting share trades, bypassing the major European stock exchanges and ahead of new European securities regulations due to come into force later this year.

While hedge funds like Amaranth Advisors do not typically disclose the identities of their investors, some became apparent yesterday. Amaranth was a favorite of so-called hedge funds of funds, investment pools that buy into various portfolios to try to minimize risk.

In a move that is expected to catapult Centerview Partners to new prominence, James M. Kilts, the former chairman and chief executive of Gillette, announced Wednesday that he is joining the firm to spearhead its private equity fund.
CDW said Monday that it would buy Berbee Information Networks for $175 million in cash, only the second acquisition in CDW's 24-year history and one that marks a strategic shift.

An asset manager, Amvescap, said it has completed its acquisition of the fast-growing PowerShares Capital Management in a move designed to bolster its presence in the mushrooming exchange-traded-fund business.

A pair of Canadian uranium companies are teaming up to form a 1 billion Canadian dollar ($887 million) producer in hopes of creating a mid-sized miner poised to lead the next round of consolidation in the fragmented sector.
Antitrust authorities said on Tuesday they had approved plans by Lockheed Martin to buy a privately held military support and training company, Pacific Architects and Engineers.

To many people inside and outside MFS Investment Management, the question about an ownership change at the company, one of Boston's biggest and oldest money-management firms, became when, not if. Now the answer seems to be sooner rather than later.

Telecom Egypt said on Tuesday it would try to lift its stake in Vodafone Egypt, one of the country's two mobile operators, with a tender offer valued at 5.86 billion Egyptian pounds, or $1.02 billion.

Three weeks after taking the reins at Viacom following the ouster of the former chief executive Tom Freston, Philippe Dauman told investors Tuesday that the company is in the hunt for small acquisitions to raise its presence online.

The chief executive of Mediaset, the Italian broadcaster controlled by former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, said Tuesday the company is eyeing changes in the Italian media landscape but is not in talks with Telecom Italia, the incumbent phone carrier that is making a foray into the country's media sector.

Peabody Energy of the United States raised its bid for Australia's Excel Coal by nearly 12 percent to 2 billion Australian dollars($1.5 billion), but speculation about a rival offer pushed Excel shares above the new bid.
Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings will take a "disciplined" approach to acquisitions even as rivals ride a global wave of consolidation, its chief financial officer said Monday.
Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth Lewis, discounted recent acquisition talk on Tuesday, telling reporters in Singapore that the bank has "no strategic imperatives" regarding acquisitions.

In a sign that Oracle's acquisition strategy is paying off, the company announced Tuesday that its quarterly profit rose 29 percent on a sharp rise in sales in its business software unit, beating analysts' forecasts.

Shares in the British construction company John Laing rose sharply as investors speculated that a rival bidder may seek to trump the 887 million pound ($1.67 billion) takeover by the fund manager Henderson.

Borsa Italiana's chief executive Massimo Capuano has announced his 21.5 billion euro ($27.2 billion) plan to merge three of the continent's largest stock exchanges. At a meeting in Rome on Monday with Euronext's chief executive, Jean-Francois Theodore, Mr. Capuano set out a proposal to unite the two exchanges with Deutsche Borse to form a European super-exchange, according to The Telegraph.

A day after disclosing that a disastrous bet on natural gas prices had produced losses of more than $3 billion, Amaranth Advisors, once among the nation's largest and hottest hedge funds, was locked in negotiations with several Wall Street banks and other hedge funds in an effort to sell its energy portfolio to try to keep the fund company afloat.
The plan for a dialogue between high-level teams meant that immediate progress on currency and trade issues was unlikely.
In the late 1990's, early access to a hot initial public offering was seen as the ticket to quick profits on Wall Street.
When a curator wanted one last exhibition, all of Maine got into the act.
Housewares, a bar you can take for a walk, pillows, quilts, rugs and more.
Who wants to sleep with Old Man Winter? As the seasons change, a way to keep cozy from toes to nose.
Cities in Ohio, Minnesota and Colorado hope so.  A brief tour of their designs.
Navigation system, smart phones and vanity cases.

There had seemed to be a bit of hope for Prudence, the woman I wrote about in Sunday's column from Cameroon. She was fighting fervently for life and lived far longer than the doctors had expected she would. When I updated yesteday on her fight for life, I thought just maybe she would pull through.
The Samkon Gado Watch is a weekly look at the best players available in more than 50 percent of fantasy leagues.
A reader, Michael Wolfe of Westport, Conn., shares his pain.We've all been there, Michael, and we're here for you:
Blair Betts, Adam Hall and Brandon Dubinsky scored for the Rangers in a span of 4:16 against Martin Brodeur, last season's runner-up for the Vezina Trophy as the N.H.L.'s top goalie.
Freemans is the kind of unlikely restaurant you’d sooner expect to find in a David Lynch movie than in reality.
Like “Y Tu Mamá También,” Alfonso Cuarón’s first feature, made 15 years ago, is a rambunctious sex comedy shadowed by mortality.
Kelly Reichardt’s film is a triumph of modesty and of seriousness that also happens to be one of the finest American films of the year.
Two women reach out to each other from opposite sides of the socioeconomic divide in Jeffrey M. Togman's marvelously revealing documentary about the psychology of poverty.
The world will never tire of the stories told by good bottles of Burgundy and its more familiar descendants. But perhaps some distant cousins have tales worth hearing, too.

The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 15 through Sept. 19 with 1,131 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,007 said they were registered to vote.
The disregard for Congress is the most intense it has been since 1994, when the Democrats lost control of both houses, the latest Times/CBS News poll found.
The Dalai Lama was responding to an invitation extended by the university’s international studies program two years ago.
President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela bitterly assailed President Bush in a speech at the United Nations.
Jeffrey Mark Deskovic was freed Wednesday after a review of DNA evidence showed that he wasn't the one who killed a Peekskill High School classmate 16 years ago.
One of the men accused of killing David E. Rosenbaum, a retired reporter for The New York Times, pleaded guilty today to murder and robbery charges.
President Pervez Musharraf today called the pope’s recent remarks on Islam “most unwarranted.”
The Federal Reserve continues to bet that inflation will remain contained as the economy cools.
With extra inspections showing no problems, NASA today cleared the space shuttle Atlantis for a Thursday morning landing.
If Lucy, the famous woman from the deep human past, had a child, it might have looked like the latest discovery.
Gen. James L. Jones described a battle that lasted several weeks in the southern province of Kandahar.
Defense lawyers said they could not receive a fair trial after Iraq’s prime minister removed the judge yesterday.
hinzo Abe, the nationalist politician who has pledged to revise Japan’s pacifist Constitution, won the leadership of the governing party today.
A summary of the top stories from Russian newspapers on Wednesday.
Thailand will probably not restore democracy for at least a year, the commander who seized power said today.

A disabled 52-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her first floor apartment yesterday, the police said. The victim, Paula Nieves, of Fulton Avenue in the Bronx, was found with numerous stab wounds in her living room about 1:30 p.m.
The tribute took place at Australia Zoo, north of Brisbane and was televised live last night in the United States on Animal Planet.
Deval Patrick  easily won the Massachusetts Democratic primary for governor and Senator Maria Cantwell and Mike McGavin won their parties’ Senate primaries.
By The Associated Press.

Trevor Hoffman earned his 476th career save last night as the San Diego Padres rebounded from their wild loss the night before in Los Angeles to beat the visiting Arizona Diamondbacks, 5-2, and return to first place in the National League West.
Justin Morneau had a career-high five hits, and Jason Bartlett and Torii Hunter each homered last night for the Minnesota Twins in a 7-3 victory over the Red Sox in Boston.

A former aide in the Homeland Security Department pleaded no contest to charges that he had sexually explicit online conversations with a person he thought was a 14-year-old girl. The former aide, Brian J. Doyle, 56, could face up to five years in prison and 10 years’ probation. Sentencing is scheduled for Nov. 17. Mr. Doyle resigned shortly after his arrest in April. Prosecutors said he wrote “very graphic” descriptions of sexual acts in online chats with “Ashlynne,’’ actually an undercover sheriff’s detective. “I just want to say one thing: I am very, very sorry,” Mr. Doyle said at the Polk County courthouse.

Hurricane Gordon weakened as it sped toward the Azores islands, and Hurricane Helene was expected to stay at sea, forecasters said. Hurricane Gordon had top sustained winds near 85 miles an hour, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said. It was centered 375 miles west of Terceira in the Azores and moving east. Hurricane Helene had top sustained winds near 110 m.p.h. and was moving west. The storm was expected to turn to the northwest.

A Maryland man accused of running through the Capitol with a loaded handgun on Monday appeared in court and will undergo days of psychiatric evaluation and treatment before being arraigned. Federal prosecutors said the man, Carlos Greene, 20, should be considered a flight risk because he was on parole for assaulting a police officer and was on probation in Maryland for a disorderly conduct charge. Magistrate Judge John M. Facciola ordered Mr. Greene held until a hearing on Friday.

The mother of a man accused of abducting a girl who eventually sent a cellphone text message for help was charged with helping her son elude the authorities and survive in underground bunkers. The man, Vinson Filyaw, was charged last weekend with kidnapping and raping the 14-year-old. Sheriff Steve McCaskill of Kershaw County said Mr. Filyaw’s mother, Ginger N. Cobb, was arrested after the police had learned that she was working with Mr. Filyaw’s wife to provide him food, water and other supplies.

Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales said Congress should require Internet providers to preserve customer records, adding that prosecutors need them to fight child pornography. Testifying to a Senate committee, Mr. Gonzales acknowledged concerns that such legislation might be overly intrusive and encroach on privacy rights. But he said the government’s lack of access to such information was the biggest obstacle to deterring child pornography.

John M. Karr, the former suspect in the JonBenet Ramsey murder case, was offered a plea deal in Sonoma County Superior Court on charges of child pornography that would free him on probation. The assistant district attorney, Joann Risse, said prosecutors would waive three of the five charges of possession of child pornography if Mr. Karr pleaded guilty on the two remaining ones. Mr. Karr, 41, would receive credit for time served and would be on probation for three years. His lawyer, Robert Amparan, said that he would discuss the deal with Mr. Karr but that he believed his client was innocent. Mr. Amparan said the public had received a “false picture” of Mr. Karr, whom he described as a “Southern gentleman with a sense of humor.”.

The government should limit the use of Social Security numbers in employee records to help protect against identity theft, an advisory panel said. Citing breaches at agencies like the Veteran Affairs Department, the panel recommended “steps to eliminate, restrict or conceal” the use of Social Security numbers. The numbers are intended for Social Security benefits and taxpayer identification. The panel, which President Bush appointed in May, is scheduled to issue its final report in November.
George Lucas said his Lucasfilm Foundation would give $175 million to the University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts.

One year after Hurricane Katrina displaced the New Orleans Saints for the entire season, they have sold out the entire regular-season home schedule at the Louisiana Superdome. It is the first time in the history of the franchise, founded in 1967, that every available seat is owned by a season-ticket holder. The Saints return to the Superdome on Monday night against Atlanta.

Katie McGregor, the 2005 United States 10,000-meter champion, will make her marathon debut at the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5. McGregor, 29, joins a women’s field that includes Deena Kastor of the United States, the 2004 Olympic marathon bronze medalist; Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia, the defending champion; and Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, the 2004 Olympic marathon silver medalist.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 19 — For Garry F. McCarthy, the nominee for Newark police director, the trouble began last year with a parking infraction at a rest stop on the Palisades Interstate Parkway. It spiraled into a wrangle — part wrestling match and part shouting match — that led to his arrest and handcuffing.

Justine Henin-Hardenne may be sidelined until the women’s tour season-ending event in November because of a knee injury that forced her to quit during the decisive match of the Fed Cup final between Belgium and Italy on Sunday.

The San Diego Chargers obtained quarterback Billy Volek from the Tennessee Titans yesterday to give them a veteran behind the first-year starter Philip Rivers. Volek wanted out of Tennessee after being demoted to third string behind the rookie Vince Young after the Titans signed Kerry Collins in August.

Forty-six-year-old Morten Andersen is returning to the Atlanta Falcons after Michael Koenen failed in his attempt to do all the kicking. Andersen, the second-leading scorer in N.F.L. history, last played in 2004, when he kicked for the Minnesota Vikings. He will handle extra points and field-goal attempts except those well beyond 50 yards. Koenen, who made just two of eight field-goal attempts in Atlanta’s first two games, will continue to handle the kickoff and punting duties. Andersen played for Atlanta from 1995 to 2000.
Martin Brodeur saw his first action of the preseason and the rust was evident. Brodeur gave up three first-period goals as the Rangers beat the Devils, 3-1, at Continental Arena.

The University of Southern California has complained that ABC’s Brent Musburger revealed privileged information in play-by-play commentary during Saturday’s victory against Nebraska. The university sent a letter to ESPN, which oversees sports programming on ABC. The letter said that Musburger, with less than 10 minutes to play and the Trojans leading, 21-10, began describing how U.S.C. quarterback John David Booty lets receivers know he has spotted a certain kind of coverage by using a thumb and little-finger gesture.

Tie Domi, an enforcer for 16 N.H.L. seasons and a fan favorite for the Toronto Maple Leafs, announced his retirement yesterday to take a television commentary job with The Sports Network, Canada’s version of ESPN.
MARATHON.
If last season is any indication, the Giants may be in for a frustrating afternoon on Sunday due to the crowd noise at Qwest Field in Seattle.
As a reward for clinching the division on Monday, Manager Willie Randolph gave all the regular position players the night off, but they won anyway.
The debate swirls around whether taxpayers should be paying for some of the priciest government offices in the United States.
A panel studying U.S. policy toward Iraq said that Iraq’s prime minister must take immediate action to improve security if he wants to retain American support.
President Bush and Iran’s president seemed to speak past each other in speeches at the United Nations.
Pamela Gluckin, who admitted to stealing $4.3 million in the Roslyn school district scandal on Long Island, was sentenced on Tuesday.

A boarder who killed his landlord, lived with the body for a few days and answered in women’s clothing when police officers knocked at the door pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday, agreeing to serve 20 years in prison.
The Q train announcement was, actually, decipherable. That’s not to say it was easy to comprehend.
Gary Sheffield was activated from the disabled list on Tuesday and is adapting quickly to first base in practice.

Joseph Kony and his deputy, Vincent Otti, the leaders of the Lord’s Resistance Army, the rebel movement that has terrorized Ugandans for nearly two decades, missed the deadline yesterday to gather at an assembly point in Sudan, Ri-Kwangba, as part of a truce, mediators said. Mr. Kony and Mr. Otti are wanted on war crimes charges by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, but Ugandan officials have said they will offer them amnesty if they surrender. “They have not assembled yet,’’ said Maj. Gen. Wilson Deng Kuoirot, the head of a Sudanese monitoring team. “They have missed the deadline, and it is going to be considered a violation on their part.’’ Sixty other rebel fighters have assembled at the camp. Two days ago, the leader of the rebels’ negotiating team said Mr. Kony and Mr. Otti had arrived there. Mr. Kuoirot said some 850 fighters had assembled at another Sudan location, Owiny-Ki-Bul, in the three weeks since the truce was signed.

India, which was accused last week of undermining the fight against polio, vowed to eliminate the disease by next year. The World Health Organization says a polio outbreak is threatening other countries and accuses India of exporting the disease to Bangladesh, Nepal, Angola and Namibia, which had been declared free of polio. In a statement, the health minister, Anbumani Ramadoss, said the government “intends to eliminate polio from the country by 2007” but gave few details, except to say he would travel to the worst-affected state, Uttar Pradesh, to meet workers conducting immunizations. India has reported 283 cases this year, more than four times the 66 recorded through 2005. Ninety percent came from Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state. Experts say tens of thousands of children there were missed by health workers during immunizations over the last year.
President Bush wants to station U.N. peacekeepers in Darfur, but Sudan’s president objects to any forces other than those from the African Union.

London’s Metropolitan Police Service denied failing to protect Jean Charles de Menezes, left, the 27-year-old Brazilian electrician shot dead last year by officers who apparently mistook him for a suicide attacker after the London Transport bombings. The Crown Prosecution Service brought charges against the force under regulations normally associated with the workplace, saying the police failed to ensure Mr. Menezes’ “health and safety” on July 22, 2005, when officers opened fire at point-blank range in a subway car. The Metropolitan Police said it questioned whether health and safety laws were the right vehicle for cases resulting from counterterrorism operations.

The trial of 29 people accused in the 2004 Madrid train bombings, which killed 191 people, is to get under way in February, a senior judicial source told reporters at a briefing. He said the trial should end by July, with the verdict handed down in October. The 29 defendants, mostly Spanish or Moroccan, were charged in April with murder and other crimes related to the four bombs that were placed on commuter trains just days before a national election. The attacks contributed to the defeat of the conservative government.

Three men sentenced to death by firing squad for leading a Christian militia that killed more than 200 Muslims in Central Sulawesi in 2000 are to be executed tomorrow, the national police said, announcing beefed-up security to head off any unrest. The three — Fabianus Tibo, Marinus Riwu and Dominggus da Silva — were to be executed last month but were given a last-minute reprieve after Pope Benedict XVI appealed for clemency. The authorities denied any connection. The executions would come shortly after the pope set off a worldwide controversy in a speech that some Muslims said linked Islam with violence. Islamic groups have been urging the government to proceed with the executions; the Christian minority has protested. Some 4,000 police and military forces are to be deployed to ensure calm.

The giant helium balloon that crashed into a light pole in Times Square during the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade last year injuring two people was traveling in an area significantly narrower than Macy’s own guidelines allowed, according to a city task force investigation.
Years of frustration and doubt were thrown aside Tuesday when the New York Red Bulls broke ground on a new $200 million, 25,000-seat stadium.
Hewlett-Packard conducted feasibility studies on planting spies in news bureaus for two major publications as part of its investigation of news leaks.

A team has hit four consecutive home runs before, but never in a situation like this — bottom of the ninth inning, down by four runs, first place on the line, division rival in the field, and elite closer in the bullpen.
The Canadian software engineer said he wanted the United States to explain why he was sent to Syria, where he was jailed and tortured.
Soaring salaries and increased competition are forcing young athletes into home schooling to stay in the game.
After a tip about exotic animals in a house on Long Island, the authorities who arrived at the scene said they were unprepared for just how many they found.
In hopes of tapping into interest in genealogy, BT, the former British Telecom, has published more than a century of its phone books on the Web.
The life sentence for murder, torture and kidnappings during Argentina’s “dirty war” was one of the first since amnesty laws were scrapped last year.
Amaranth Advisors was scrambling yesterday to salvage something from its battered portfolio of energy trades after losing more than $3 billion dollars on natural gas investments.
Former Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey began a 60-day publicity campaign to promote his autobiography, "The Confession."
The Yankees’ magic number is down to one after beating the Blue Jays, while this week's Sports Illustrated cover story focuses on Alex Rodriguez and his complicated place in the clubhouse.
After nearly 80 years of watching the Ryder Cup crisscross the Atlantic Ocean but never hitting Ireland, some 25,000 fans passed through the gates on Tuesday just for the opening warm-up session.
U.S. and Iraqi officials are questioning if Nuri Kamal al-Maliki can keep Iraq from descending into civil war.
Even as Amaranth Advisors lost billions of dollars betting on natural gas, more fortunate traders raked in big profits in recent weeks counting on gas prices to fall.
The use of mediation in civil complaints against New York City police officers has become much more common.
Warren E. Buffett wants to set up an international nuclear fuel bank from which countries could buy reactor fuel instead of making it on their own.
Across the nation’s 36 races for governor, Republican candidates are playing up their liberal positions.
A mob figure who could face the death penalty at his coming federal trial is now under investigation for plotting to kill the judge who is to preside over his case.
The son of Egypt’s president proposed  that his country pursue nuclear energy, raising expectations that he is being positioned to replace his father as president.
As Chicago prepared to play the Tigers on Tuesday night, the team acknowledged that it might have difficulty gaining even a wild-card berth into the postseason.
The White House has dropped its insistence on redefining the obligations of the United States under the Geneva Conventions, members of Congress said.
Proposed cuts to bus and subway service for next year mean that riders could face longer waits for many buses and trains, which would be more crowded.
San Diego County’s pension fund’s investments included Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that announced Monday it had suffered big losses in natural gas trading.
Leaders of Thailand’s armed forces seized control of Bangkok, suspended the constitution and declared martial law on Tuesday.
Yahoo said that it would still meet its financial goals for the third quarter, but that its profit and revenue would be toward the bottom end of its forecast range.
Israel is clearly reluctant to stay much longer in southern Lebanon, even though the U.N. force is still thin on the ground.
The turbulent re-election campaign of Senator George Allen took another unexpected turn Tuesday when Mr. Allen, a Virginia Republican, issued a statement confirming his Jewish ancestry.
The contract will be initially valued at $80 million instead of the $2 billion estimate given for the six-year deal, officials said.
NASA told the space shuttle Atlantis to stay in orbit while engineers try to identify an object seen floating nearby the spacecraft.
The Metropolitan Opera and Sirius Satellite Radio will collaborate on a channel to broadcast four performances live from the Met each week.
The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has found that there is evidence of the hostile work environment at Madison Square Garden.
By Bloomberg News.
By The Associated Press.
By The Associated Press.
Chrysler said it would cut its production schedule for the rest of the year by 16 percent because of slumping sales as a result of high gas prices.
Since May 2003 the Maine Troop Greeters have welcomed every military transport flight that has arrived in Bangor, Me.
Yahoo said the new online video programming venture will combine professional and user-generated video clips.
EUROPE.
Lottery Numbers.
In the spirit of conciliation, the pope and other top Vatican officials must accept that genuine interfaith communication cannot occur on their terms only.
While Hewlett-Packard has a right to crack down on boardroom leaks, it has a responsibility to do so legally.
The increase resulted from a sharp rise in sales in its business software unit, the company said.
While the future of Nicholas M. Maounis’ fund remains uncertain, his reputation has suffered a severe blow.
As the college application process has become increasingly available through the Web, many companies are offering search engines that help students build a list of colleges to consider.
If the Senate votes to build a double-layered 700-mile-long fence on the Mexican border, it may have a 75-mile gap because of opposition from the Tohono O’odham Indian tribe.

A former medical student has been charged with theft of human remains. Middlesex County prosecutors say he took a hand from a cadaver and gave it to an exotic dancer. The former student, Ahmed Rashed, 26, of Los Angeles, turned himself in to the police in South Plainfield on Monday, said Judson Hamlin, an assistant prosecutor. He was released after posting $1,000 bail. Prosecutors said Mr. Rashed was a student at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark in 2002 when he hacked the hand from a cadaver that had been donated to the school. Mr. Judson said that Mr. Rashed had become acquainted with the dancer, Linda E. Kay of South Plainfield, in 2002, though he said it was unclear when he gave her the hand. Ms. Kay, who has been charged with unlawful disposition of human remains, had danced at Hott 22, a club in Union. She has pleaded not guilty. The identity of the cadaver from which the hand was taken has not been established.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,675 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.

Local 8 of the United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to racketeering in a case involving the alleged extortion of more than $2 million from roofing contractors, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Through its lawyer, Bruce Maffeo, the local admitted that it was a member of a criminal enterprise, which prosecutors said was set up to make money for the Genovese crime family. As part of the plea, the union forfeited $200,000 and has agreed to supervision by a court-appointed monitor for at least five years, prosecutors said. Mr. Maffeo said the plea was an opportunity to “put this behind us.”.

A state judge yesterday rejected a legal challenge by community groups to a plan to build a waste transfer station on the East River at 91st Street, lawyers for the city said. Justice Michael Stallman of State Supreme Court ruled that the construction was consistent with city policy and rejected the claim that the environmental review was insufficient. The station’s construction is part of a city plan to reduce the number of trucks carrying trash to other boroughs and New Jersey, city officials said.

Two men have pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to conspiracy to smuggle heroin from Ghana into the United States, federal prosecutors said yesterday. One of the men, Attah Evan Kwasi, was a large-scale trafficker who was extradited from Ghana last year, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said the other man, Newman Ayiwah, was the New York City distributor and was arrested in the Bronx last year on charges of possessing more than a pound of heroin. Mr. Garcia said the conspiracy involved couriers who swallowed pellets containing heroin in Ghana and traveled to the United States on commercial airliners. Each man faces a possible sentence of 10 years to life in prison, prosecutors said.

One man was killed and another wounded in a knife fight last night, the police said. The man who died, identified by the police as Devonne Dover, 29, was stabbed in the neck and chest around 6:30 p.m. in front of his building at 22 Hubbard Place in Gravesend. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The other man, whom the police did not identify, was stabbed in the back and left hand. He was in stable condition in the same hospital last night, the police said.

Testimony began yesterday in State Supreme Court against a Queens woman accused of killing a man she had married in what prosecutors say was part of an insurance fraud conspiracy. The woman, Lory M. Scott, is charged with second-degree murder. Prosecutors said she married a hospital security guard, Tyrone Alston, 37, who had legally changed his name to Nubian Knight. Mr. Knight was found beaten and slashed to death in December 2003, a few months after the wedding, in his apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant. In court yesterday, prosecutors called his sister Danielle L. Singleton, who lived a block away from her brother and saw him twice a week, to testify that she had been unaware of the marriage. Ms. Singleton described her brother as “very fun-loving, jovial, you know, happy-go-lucky, but he was very gullible.”.
Recently there has been a roiling debate about how to describe living standards in this country.

Edward Forbes Smiley III, an antiquities dealer who admitted having stolen nearly 100 rare maps from leading libraries and institutions, asked a federal judge yesterday to consider a sentence of 30 to 36 months in prison. Last week, the British Library, one of the victimized institutions, recommended 78 to 97 months, but said that even 10 years, the maximum possible, “could not be deemed to be too severe.” Mr. Smiley’s lawyer, Richard A. Reeve, asked the judge to give his client credit for having cooperated with the authorities once he was arrested. Mr. Reeve argued that the “consequences of the case could be highly beneficial” to the institutions if “the hard lessons” it taught led them to enhance security and update their inventories.

Brooke Astor, the socialite and philanthropist, developed skin cancer on her nose this year and required weekly radiation treatments during the summer, her son, Anthony D. Marshall, said in a court filing yesterday in which he further defends himself in the legal battle over his mother’s care and finances. The court papers said that her doctors concluded that her condition would worsen significantly if left untreated. Mr. Marshall, 82, said he decided against opening Mrs. Astor’s Holly Hill estate in Westchester over the summer because he wanted her to be close to her medical team in Manhattan. Since a short stay at Lenox Hill Hospital in late July Mrs. Astor, who is 104, has been living at Holly Hill. In an affidavit that was part of Mr. Marshall’s filing, one of the socialite’s chefs said her weekday nurse was so aggressive about feeding Mrs. Astor that she once broke some of her teeth and another time burned her tongue, causing her to scream. “I do not believe that anyone told Mr. Marshall about either of these things,” the chef said in the affidavit.

A Pleasantville woman was indicted yesterday on murder charges in connection with the death of her mother, whose body was discovered in her home in Ossining on May 14, prosecutors said. The suspect, Anne Trovato, 26, is charged with killing her mother, Patricia Mery, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester district attorney. Ms. Mery, a popular Spanish teacher in Stamford, Conn., was stabbed more than 20 times and hit in the head with a metal baseball bat, the police said. Ms. Trovato has denied involvement in the killing.
Touring events, exhibits and other promotional efforts are becoming more popular as advertisers seek to forge closer emotional bonds with consumers.

Conrad W. Hewitt, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sought yesterday to clarify the proper accounting for backdated options, reserving the harshest accounting for companies that followed a practice of reducing the exercise price after options were issued.
Joseph Hayes wrote the novel “The Desperate Hours,” which he later turned into a Tony Award-winning play and a movie.
David Ball’s fierce determination is a big reason why his name is mentioned in the same sentence as that of Jerry Rice, who still holds multiple Division I-AA receiving records.
One of two men sought in the weekend shooting of five Duquesne University basketball players was arrested Tuesday, the police said.

An article last Wednesday about espresso misstated the origin of coffee beans used at Ninth Street Espresso in the East Village. Israel hopes to pull its last troops out of Lebanon by sundown on Friday, the beginning of the Jewish New Year, the chief of the Israeli military, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, said Tuesday. Withdrawal by then is ''the working assumption,'' a parliamentary spokesman quoted the general as telling a committee, ''if all goes without a hitch, to the satisfaction of all sides.''

Laura Frankel, the author of ''Jewish Cooking for All Seasons'' (John Wiley & Sons, $34.95), is the chef and an owner of Shallots, a kosher restaurant in Chicago that once had a Manhattan branch. Her new cookbook provides a modern chef's approach not just to Jewish cooking, but to kosher cooking. And instead of traditional matzo ball soup, chopped liver and tsimmes, the recipes expand the repertory. Parsnip and roasted garlic bisque, duck breast schnitzel with maple mashed sweet potatoes and braised chard, and a very good cocoa and canola oil devil's-food cake with a pareve egg-based chocolate mousse filling, so it can be served with either meat or dairy, make this book worthwhile.

Following the discovery that Bob Dylan used language from the Civil War era poet Henry Timrod in the lyrics for his new album, ''Modern Times,'' Entertainment Weekly reports that the photograph on the cover of the album appeared on the cover on the 1995 record ''Hedgehog'' by the group Luna. The photograph, ''Taxi, New York Night,'' was taken in 1947 by Ted Croner. Geoff Gans, who designed the ''Modern Times'' cover, told Entertainment Weekly he had never seen the Luna album. A publicist for Mr. Dylan said that the report was accurate, and that the Dylan camp had been unaware that the photograph was previously used. DINITIA SMITH

Cowgirl Chocolates of Moscow, Idaho, known for its spicy confections, is now selling nut brittles, one with zip and two without. All are buttery and crunchy. There's a mild-mannered classic peanut brittle, and an equally tame but delicious triple-nut brittle made with pecans, cashews and pistachios. The spicy pistachio brittle packs heat. All are $19.95 for a 10-ounce bag packed in a corrugated box; they can be ordered from (888) 882-4098 or cowgirlchocolates.com.

But She Can Still Sing When people in show business say, ''Break a leg,'' the command is not supposed to be taken literally. But maybe it's best not to discuss that today with the Canadian soprano Adrienne Pieczonka, right, acclaimed for her Sieglinde in ''Die Walküre'' in the new Canadian Opera Company production of Wagner's ''Ring'' in Toronto. Over the weekend she broke her ankle. When ''Die Walküre'' is performed tonight Ms. Pieczonka, with her ankle in a cast, will still be onstage and singing, but stationary. The soprano Irmgard Vilsmaier will act the role of Sieglinde. Archaeologists Approve Acropolis Filming Nia Vardalos, below, the writer and star of the hit 2002 film ''My Big Fat Greek Wedding,'' has accomplished a rare feat. She has been granted permission by the Central Council of Archaeology in Greece to film a new comedy on the Acropolis in Athens and at other historic sites, including Delphi, Olympia, Thermopyles and Epidaurus, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the producer, Mark Hufam. The film, ''My Life in Ruins,'' scheduled to go before the cameras late next month, tells of a group of tourists introduced to ancient Greece by a Greek-American guide, played by Ms. Vardalos. Agence France-Presse reported that the last filmmaker to be granted access to the Acropolis was Francis Ford Coppola, for a segment of the 1989 film ''New York Stories.'' Saving Aboriginal Art The National Trust of Australia has issued an urgent call for protection of ancient rock art regarded as an Aboriginal Bible, CBC Arts reported. The National Trust, an independent agency that safeguards such sites, appealed in a report last week for a moratorium on industrial development and a heritage listing for the art, situated in the rugged Dampier Archipelago, an island chain off northwest Australia. The report said the petroglyphs are menaced by acid rain from petrochemical plants in the area and by development projects that involve blasting. The million carvings, said to be the largest such collection in the world, are 6,000 to 30,000 years old and chronicle ancient Aboriginal societies. Footnotes Usher, right, has extended his run as the lawyer Billy Flynn in the musical ''Chicago'' for two weeks, through Oct. 14, at the Ambassador Theater. The Irish Repertory Theater in Chelsea will open its 19th season with the 1922 Eugene O'Neill play ''The Hairy Ape.'' The story of a brutish stoker aboard an ocean liner and his encounter with the beautiful, spoiled daughter of the shipowner will begin previews on Sept. 29, open officially on Oct. 5 and continue through Nov. 19.

RE--Honorable Edward D. The Board of Trustees and members of The Historical Society of the United States Court of International Trade note with sorrow the passing of the Honorable Edward D. Re, Chief Judge Emeritus of the United States Court of International Trade. Judge Re was recognized for his integrity, fairness and clarity of decisions by practitioners before the Court. The history of the United States Court of International Trade will forever be tied to his vision and tireless efforts, which led to the enactment of the Customs Courts Act of 1980 and brought expanded jurisdiction, increased remedies and greater access to judicial review to litigants seeking the peaceful resolution of customs and international trade disputes. We extend our condolences to Judge Re's wife, Margaret, and to the entire Re family.

To the Editor: Samuel G. Freedman (''The Not-So-Public Part of the Public Schools: Lack of Accountability,'' On Education column, Sept. 13) claims that the Leadership Academy's use of private money has ''shielded it from inquiries about just how cost-effective it has been.'' The academy is a nonprofit organization that prepares aspiring and current principals for the challenges they encounter leading New York City public schools. It is accountable to a board of directors (which includes the chancellor and the deputy chancellor for teaching and learning).

TRADITION has it that there is a dumpling for every Jewish holiday: kreplach, the Jewish tortellini, for the meal before Yom Kippur; dough pockets filled with cottage cheese for Shavuot; and matzo balls for Passover. But Jewish food has become so diverse, how about a taste of another kind of tradition for Rosh Hashana on Friday night? A new dumpling for the holiday.

Adam Rapp, Lisa Kron, Lanford Wilson, Lypsinka (a k a John Epperson) and other theater professionals who first found success in some of the city's smallest sites were among the presenters at the second annual New York Innovative Theater Awards, on Monday night at the Great Hall of Cooper Union on Astor Place in the East Village. For the second year, Charles Busch was the host of the event, which drew more than 600 spectators to witness the recognition of achievement in Off Off Broadway theater. Besides awards for acting, direction, design and in other categories, a lifetime achievement award, presented by Ben Vereen, went to the director Tom O'Horgan. Though he has never won a Tony Award, Mr. O'Horgan is the only director to have had four productions running simultaneously on Broadway: For a few months during the 1971-72 season, ''Hair,'' ''Lenny,'' ''Inner City'' and ''Jesus Christ Superstar.'' STEVEN McELROY

An Op-Ed article yesterday, about electronic health records, incorrectly described some people who say that portability of such records should be delayed or prohibited. They are advocates of a House bill regulating electronic health records, not opponents.

The North Carolina Museum of Art is to announce tonight a $138 million expansion, designed by Thomas Phifer. In addition to the new building, the project includes an adapted reuse of the museum's existing Edward Durrell Stone building. The new permanent galleries and gardens will include the Iris Cantor collection of Rodins, recently given to the museum. Work is to begin next month, with a completion date of spring 2009. ROBIN POGREBIN
ALTSHULER--Mathilde September 15th --95 years, beloved wife David, loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother.

Yahoo said yesterday that it was creating a new online video programming venture with Current TV, the media company founded by former Vice President Al Gore. The service will combine professional and user-generated video clips. Current's editors intend to weed out videos that are offensive or contain copyrighted materials, in an attempt to make viral videos -- one of the hottest trends on the Internet -- attractive to advertisers. Most clips will be preceded by a 15- or 30-second commercial -- the first time Yahoo has included commercials with user-generated content.

In the official start of the fall television season, NBC knocked CBS off its perch as No. 1 in total viewers on Monday nights. While the premiere of CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 p.m. drew 17.2 million viewers, making it the most watched show of the night, the total was 2 million below that of last year's premiere. Meanwhile, the debut of the new Aaron Sorkin drama, ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' gave NBC a lift in the hour with 13.4 million total viewers. From 8 to 10, the two-hour premiere of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' drew 15.6 million viewers, eclipsing CBS's comedy lineup. At 8 p.m. CBS's new show ''The Class'' drew 10.6 million, while ''How I Met Your Mother'' posted 10.5 million at 8:30. Among adults 18 to 49, both series were third in their time slots, behind the fifth installment of Fox's hourlong drama ''Prison Break'' (9.4 million). CBS fared better at 9 with ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.1 million) and also at 9:30 with ''New Adventures of Old Christine'' (12.1 million). On ABC back-to-back episodes of ''Wife Swap'' delivered 7.1 million viewers at 8 and 8.7 million at 9. BENJAMIN TOFF

THE pinot noirs this week didn't have the stylistic coherence of a particular region. But the ones I preferred had a common characteristic: a hint of smokiness and an underpinning of good acidity and minerality. They could certainly be served with grilled or roasted meats or poultry, or flavorful fish like salmon or tuna. But I'm giving the starring role to a supporting dish that could accompany any of these choices.

CIFU--Robert, MD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society deeply mourn the passing of a distinguished and beloved member and colleague. Bob was a brilliant clinician and teacher who, as Psychiatristin-Chief, left an impressive legacy for which we are profoundly grateful. Dr. Cifu had particular expertise in work with adolesence but he was a true scholar of many subjects covering vast areas. He gladdened his many friends and he took inestimable joy in his adoring family. Our sincere condolences to all who feel this great loss. Joerg Bose, MD, Director, White Institute Clark Sugg, MD, President, White Society Charles C. Harrington, Ph.D., President, Board of Trustees

LIKE everything else in my life, salads grow more complicated in the fall. In June and July, I like lettuce plain, with olive oil and vinegar splashed on straight from the bottle, plus salt and pepper. It is one of the skills I am secretly exceptionally proud of, this ability to dress a salad in the bowl without mixing up the dressing on the side first. I am convinced that salad tastes better this way, though I can't figure out why. And I enjoy doing it -- I feel more in tune with the greens, and also more picturesque (which, by the way, is a vast and unexplored category of human satisfaction). If you don't already know how to do it, here is the secret: use more oil than you think you should, less vinegar than you think you should, and be generous with the salt.
