WHO CAME OUT AHEAD -- Even as Amaranth Advisors lost billions of dollars betting on rising natural gas prices, reports began streaming out from the energy-trading industry that other traders had raked in profits betting that gas prices would fall. Still, the details remain unclear, underscoring the secretive nature of hedge funds, which are unregulated and do not have to report their wins and losses in over-the-counter financial trades. Page C4. PENSION FUND'S ALTERED OUTLOOK -- Until this week, it looked as if the $7.5 billion pension fund of San Diego County had a winning strategy for investing the retirement money of county workers. But much of the pension fund's strategy was based on a basket of hedge funds that included Amaranth Advisors. Now that Amaranth is in trouble, officials at the San Diego fund are remembering that the price of big returns is big risks. Page C4. A MANAGER'S COMEDOWN -- Nicholas M. Maounis, the 43-year-old founder of Amaranth Advisors, rose rapidly from trader to billionaire hedge fund manager, and he impressed potential investors with his marketing pitches that stressed risk management and teamwork. But his once-golden reputation has suffered a severe blow now that his fund has lost more than $3 billion. Page C5.

For flavoring a cake or flaming over crepes, the finest aged spirits are not required. Recognizing that a cook's needs are not the same as those of a connoisseur quaffer, Boulard, a maker of fine Calvados in the Pays d'Auge region of Normandy, has introduced Réserve du Chef, a light but extremely apple-rich Calvados for cooking.

Joining the growing number of universities that are improving financial aid for low- and middle-income students, Columbia announced yesterday that it will replace loans with grants for undergraduates from families that earn less than $50,000 a year, beginning with the academic year 2007-8. The change will apply to all of the university's undergraduates, not just entering freshmen.

She is survived by her husband Joseph Lyon Bower, her children Jonathan Bower and Deborah Brodheim and their children Eliza and Aaron Kano-Bower, and Adam, Hannah, and Max Brodheim, as well as her father Louis Milender. The funeral will be at Temple Israel, 477 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA, on Thursday, September 21, at 1:30 pm. Parking available on The Riverway. Remembrances may be made to the New England Conservatory of Music, (Joseph & Nancy Bower Family Fund), 290 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA 617-277-8300

Paul Huston, the owner of Hunter's Point Wines & Spirits, has a strong sense of place. His new wine shop, his first, at 47-07 Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, tips its hat to the nearby tunnel that connects that borough to Manhattan, and to the train tunnels of yore, with an arched stone passageway that runs between the front, retail part of the store, and the glass-walled section for rare wines and the tasting room in back. Mr. Huston's very personal selection of wines emphasizes small estates, and even among the spirits there are some hard-to-find bottles. Mr. Huston, who was the wine director at Scalini Fedeli in Manhattan, has also built temperature-controlled wine-storage vaults that rent for $2 a case per month; (718) 472-9463.

To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Universe'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 18): Like Ronald D. Moore, and a legion of starry-eyed science-fiction aficionados, I was swept up in the swashbuckling idealism of Capt. James T. Kirk. Not to mention the cool rationalism and flawless logic of his half-Vulcan first officer, Mr. Spock. But there was more to ''Star Trek'' than space opera. After centuries of war, strife and intolerance, the people of Earth had finally shed their fears and prejudices and attained the best of all possible worlds: global peace.

9 P.M. (13, 49) ANDY WARHOL: A DOCUMENTARY FILM -- No one screamed Pop Art more loudly than Warhol (above, in 1966). And chances are no pop artist was more famously misunderstood. In this two-part ''American Masters'' film, Ric Burns places Warhol's vast output within the turbulent context of his life and times to create a portrait of an enigmatic man who, perhaps most profoundly of all, blurred the boundary between art and commerce. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER -- Fifty contestants -- one from each state -- arrive at the Biggest Loser Ranch, where 14 will whittle away the pounds at a spa-like boot camp for a prize of $250,000, while the other 36 are banished to work out back at home, alone. 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO -- Hellooo! Anyone out there? When a psychedeliclooking mushroom cloud suddenly appears on the horizon, some small-town Kansans are forced to ponder whether they are the only people left alive. Gerald McRaney, Pamela Reed, Lennie James and Ashley Scott play a few of the lost souls in this new drama; Skeet Ulrich (above, left) is the mayor's son, who mysteriously reappears in time for the mayhem. 8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL -- Anything for fame, huh? Another round of 13 semifinalists take it all off for a revealing photo shoot in this premiere of the competition series, which falls just short of promising wannabe runway stars a ticket to the top. (So far, it hasn't happened.) But tonight, no one, it seems, can outdo Tyra Banks in terms of shock value. 8 P.M. (13, 49) JEAN-MICHEL COUSTEAU: OCEAN ADVENTURES -- ''We can't protect what we don't understand,'' says Jean-Michel Cousteau, Jacques's son, explaining in part why he carries on the family legacy. In this series's final episode, Jean-Michel and his children Fabien and Céline explore 13 littleknown national marine sanctuaries in the United States, where they witness sea turtles laying their eggs on a shore in the middle of the night, kelp forests that rival the California redwoods in size and girth, and the rusting wreck of the ironclad warship the Monitor. 10 P.M. (NBC) KIDNAPPED -- When their 15-year-old son (Will Denton) is kidnapped on his way to school and his bodyguard (Mykelti Williamson) left to die, a self-made millionaire (Timothy Hutton) and his wife (Dana Delany, above right, with Mr. Hutton) hire a professional investigator (Jeremy Sisto) to do whatever is required to get him back -- even if it means breaking the law. Delroy Lindo plays a veteran F.B.I. agent who postpones his retirement to help solve the case. He has his reasons. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

NEWDOW--Ira. September 19, 2006 in Rockleigh, N.J. Beloved husband and partner of Rosalyn for 57 years. Devoted father of Mark(wife Terry), Michael and Julie, loving grandfather of Adam, Emily, Adriana, Glen, Joshua and Tamara; cherished brother of Miriam(Elliot). Extraordinary man, brilliant engineer and real estate developer and lover of music, he earned a Master's of electrical engineering from NYU. To the Editor: Re ''Uganda Peace Hinges on Amnesty for Brutality'' (front page, Sept. 15): Amnesty International is disturbed by the assertion that lasting peace in northern Uganda depends on whether Joseph Kony, indicted by the International Criminal Court for war crimes and crimes against humanity, will receive an amnesty.

Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, pledged $50 million on Tuesday to help set up an international nuclear fuel bank that aspiring powers could turn to for reactor fuel instead of making it on their own. Mr. Buffett's aim is to curb the risks of nuclear proliferation by providing an alternative to the kind of indigenous production of nuclear fuel that Iran is embarking upon, and that countries like Argentina, Australia and South Africa have recently announced plans to pursue.

To the Editor: Re ''Canadians Fault U.S. for Its Role in Torture Case'' (front page, Sept. 19): I, like many Americans, do not bleed when true terrorists are punished. But when an innocent person, no matter what ethnicity, is tortured, I am outraged.

Roman Abramovich, the Russian tycoon who owns the Chelsea soccer club, has an apartment there. So does Bruce Oldfield, Princess Diana's favorite fashion designer. But Knightsbridge probably is most familiar to Americans as the home of Harrods department store, the shopping fantasyland where you can buy everything from high fashion to 300 varieties of cheese. This central London neighborhood also has some of the most expensive property in London, with prices exceeding £2,500, or more than $4,500, a square foot. A new report from the Savills real estate agency said the average house price in Knightsbridge now tops £892,100, or about $1.7 million.

Hewlett-Packard conducted feasibility studies on planting spies in news bureaus of two major publications as part of an investigation of leaks from its board, an individual briefed on the company's review of the operation said yesterday. The studies, referred to in a Feb. 2 draft report for a briefing of senior management, are said to have included the possibility of placing investigators acting as clerical employees or cleaning crews in the San Francisco offices of CNET and The Wall Street Journal.

The parking lot at Dodger Stadium, famous for luxury cars that arrive late and leave early, was the site of a memorable traffic snarl Monday night. Exits clogged in the bottom of the ninth inning, when drivers who were leaving the ballpark met drivers who were coming back in. Those listening to Vin Scully on the car radio made quick U-turns. A line of taillights became a river of headlights.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Bush and Iranian Clash Over Iran Nuclear Aims President Bush and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, separated by several hours, clashed at the United Nations over Iran's nuclear ambitions as diplomats continued the delicate work of setting terms for talks with Iran over its uranium enrichment program. A1 Military Takes Over Thailand In Thailand's first coup in 15 years, military leaders seized control of Bangkok and declared martial law in the capital. A1 Iraqi Leader's Abilities in Doubt Senior officials are beginning to question whether Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has the political muscle to hold Iraq together. A1 The top American commander in the Middle East said more than 140,000 soldiers would probably be needed in Iraq at least until next spring. A8 Egypt Considers Nuclear Power Gamal Mubarak proposed that his country pursue nuclear energy, raising expectations that Mr. Mubarak is being positioned to replace his father as president. A14 Israel Plans to Finish Pullout Israel hopes to pull its last troops out of Lebanon by sundown Friday, the chief of the Israeli military said. A3 NATIONAL A16-24 Redefining Geneva Rules Is Dropped by White House The White House has dropped its insistence on redefining the obligations of the United States under the Geneva Conventions, members of Congress said. A18 Red Cross officials plan to begin a series of face-to-face visits in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, with the 14 prisoners who until this month had spent as much as four years in secret Central Intelligence Agency custody. A18 Shuttle's Return is Delayed NASA told the space shuttle Atlantis to stay in orbit for at least one extra day while engineers try to determine if a mystery object seen floating nearby is an indication of possible damage to the spacecraft. A22 Senate to Vote on Border Fence The Senate is expected to vote on legislation to build a double-layered 700-mile-long fence on the Mexican border, a proposal already approved by the House. A24 Arrest in College Shooting One of two men sought was arrested in the weekend shooting of five Duquesne University basketball players, the police said. An arrest warrant was issued for the second suspect, whom the authorities said should be considered armed and extremely dangerous. A22 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Mediation on the Rise In Police Complaints The process of mediation, a program created by the Civilian Complaint Review Board so that accusations against New York police officers could be handled by an independent agency, has become considerably more common in recent years. A1 Battle for Schools, Revisited Mayor Bloomberg has embarked on a high-profile offensive to make permanent the 2002 law that gave him nearly unfettered power over New York's public schools. B1 ARTS E1-10 Religious Films From Fox Hollywood took another step toward America's vast and apparently growing Christian audience as 20th Century Fox unveiled a new division that will release up to a dozen religious-oriented films each year. Lykken A researcher whose studies of criminal behavior and the genetics of personality in twins helped undermine some of the most cherished notions of social science, he was 78. London's Metropolitan Police Service denied failing to protect Jean Charles de Menezes, left, the 27-year-old Brazilian electrician shot dead last year by officers who apparently mistook him for a suicide attacker after the London Transport bombings. The Crown Prosecution Service brought charges against the force under regulations normally associated with the workplace, saying the police failed to ensure Mr. Menezes' ''health and safety'' on July 22, 2005, when officers opened fire at point-blank range in a subway car. The Metropolitan Police said it questioned whether health and safety laws were the right vehicle for cases resulting from counterterrorism operations. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran suggested Tuesday that Pope Benedict XVI had satisfactorily ''modified'' his remarks on Islam, one sign of an easing of anger since the pope issued an apology on Sunday for having caused offense with a speech he delivered last week. ''We respect the pope and all those interested in peace and justice,'' Mr. Ahmadinejad, an observant Muslim and a hard-liner against the West, said in Venezuela before leaving for the United Nations in New York. ''I understand that he has modified the remarks he made.''

A brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday misstated the position that Larry Djeck, who will be the manger at Ferro's, a new restaurant at 145 East 50th Street, held at Elaine's. He was a waiter, not a manager.

To the Editor: In ''Awake and Scream'' (column, Sept. 16), Maureen Dowd expresses understandable frustration with President Bush's apparent inability to look at new realities, or to adjust both his strategies and his rhetoric to handle the changed circumstances. Contrary to the often repeated assertion that Mr. Bush demonstrates strong leadership qualities, psychologists would suggest that the president's decision-making style actually reflects an extreme rigidity that confirms a serious character flaw: No commander in his right mind would insist upon marching his soldiers over a bridge that was in the process of collapsing.

More than 450 artists sent a letter yesterday to the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum in Poland demanding the release of seven paintings created by a California woman during her imprisonment there in 1944. ''The fundamental principle that art belongs to the artist who create it is recognized everywhere except totalitarian countries,'' said the letter, signed by Stan Lee, the creator of Spider-Man; Lynn Johnston, the cartoonist of the ''For Better or For Worse'' comic strip; and the Pulitzer Prize winners Art Spiegelman and Michael Chabon, among others. ''One would hope that Poland, having been liberated from totalitarian rule, would not revert to the mentality that regards everything as the property of the state.'' Museum officials have refused for more than 30 years to return the artwork to Dina Gottliebova Babbitt, 83, of Felton, Calif., above, a retired Hollywood animator. Mrs. Babbitt was unaware that her paintings had survived until the museum contacted her to authenticate them in 1973. Museum officials said last month that the paintings' historical significance as Holocaust documentation was more important than Mrs. Babbitt's claims of property rights. STEVE FRIESS

The Metropolitan Opera now has a home on satellite radio. The opera company and Sirius Satellite Radio said yesterday that they would collaborate on a channel to broadcast four performances live from the Met each week. The channel, 85, will also carry 10 Met archival recordings weekly. It will run 24 hours, with 16 hours made up of programming from the Met and the rest provided by Sirius, a spokeswoman for the opera company, Sommer Hixson, said.

READERS' GUIDE: Starting today, The Times is introducing several design changes in its daily news pages to underscore the distinctions between straightforward news coverage and other journalistic forms that provide additional perspective on events. These special forms -- news analysis articles, columns and others -- adhere to standards different from those of the editorial and Op-Ed pages. The news and editorial departments do not coordinate coverage and maintain a strict separation in staff and management. All articles, columns, editorials and contributions in the newspaper are subject to the same requirements of factual accuracy. A readers' guide to the various forms in the news sections and the opinion pages is published on this page today. It will remain online at nytimes.com/readersguide.

In the News Sections MAN OR WOMAN IN THE NEWS: A portrait of a central figure in a news situation. It is not primarily analytical, but highlights aspects of the subject's background and career that shed light on that figure's role in the current event. REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A writer's collection of several anecdotes or brief reports, often supplementing coverage of major news events like a summit meeting or an important trial. The items provide glimpses behind the scenes that flesh out the reader's sense of a major story. MEMO: A reflective article, often with an informal or conversational tone, offering a look behind the scenes at issues or political developments. The article (with a title like Political Memo, White House Memo or Memo From London) may draw connections among several events, or tell the reader who and what shaped them. JOURNAL: A sharply drawn feature article focusing on a place or event (and labeled with the place name, whether foreign, national or regional). A Journal is closely observed and stylishly written, often light or humorous in tone. It is intended to give the reader a vivid sense of a place and time. NEWS ANALYSIS: A close examination of the ramifications of an important news situation. It includes thorough reporting, but also draws heavily on the expertise of the writer. The article helps the reader understand underlying causes or possible consequences of a news event, but does not reflect the writer's personal opinion. APPRAISAL: A broad evaluation, generally by a critic or a specialized writer, of the career and work of a major figure who has died. The article often accompanies an obituary. REVIEW: A specialized critic's appraisal of works of creativity -- movies, books, restaurants, fashion collections. Unlike other feature writers, critics are expected to render opinions in their areas of expertise. NEWS-PAGE COLUMN: A writer's regularly scheduled essay, offering original insight and perspective on the news. The column often has a distinctive point of view and makes a case for it with reporting. (Columns in the news pages are displayed with the writer's name and the column's title inset into the text.) The news sections also present a number of regular feature articles that carry labels indicating the topics - for example, the Saturday Profile in the foreign pages and Market Place in Business Day. In the Opinion Pages EDITORIAL: A sharply written, generally brief article about any issue of public interest. Editorials are written by the editorial board of The Times, which includes the editorial page editor, the deputy and assistant editors, and a group of writers with expertise in a variety of fields. While the writers' opinions are of great importance, the editorials also reflect the longtime core beliefs of the page. Unlike the editors of the news sections, the editorial page editor not only reports to the publisher, but consults with him on the page's positions. Editorials are based on reporting, often original and in-depth, but they are not intended to give a balanced look at both sides of a debate. Rather, they offer clear opinion and distinct positions. EDITORIAL OBSERVER: A signed article by a member of the editorial board. These articles have a more distinct personal voice than an editorial. They often reflect personal experiences or observations, and may be written in the first person. These articles are not intended to be policy pronouncements, but do not contradict the board's positions. OP-ED COLUMN: An essay by a columnist on the staff of The Times, reflecting the opinions of the writer on any topic. Columnists are expected to do original reporting. Some travel extensively. Op-Ed columns are edited only for style and usage, not for content. Columnists do not submit their topics for approval, and are free to agree or disagree with editorial positions. OP-ED CONTRIBUTION: An article by a person not on the staff of The Times, reflecting opinions about a topic on which the author is an expert or has provocative and well-reasoned ideas. These articles, most of which are solicited by the editors, are not intended to reflect the positions of the editorial board. Indeed, the Op-Ed page is seen as a forum to air diverse and challenging viewpoints.

CHRYSLER PLANS RESTRUCTURING -- Chrysler said it would cut its production schedule for the rest of the year by 16 percent, because of slumping sales as a result of high gas prices, on the heels of similar cuts at General Motors and Ford. The head of Chrysler, Thomas W. LaSorda, above, signaled that it would embark on its second restructuring in six years. [Page C1.] AFTER THE STORM -- A day after disclosing that a disastrous bet on natural gas prices had produced losses of more than $3 billion, Amaranth Advisors, once among the nation's largest and hottest hedge funds, worked with commodity exchange officials to reassign its trades. [C1.] OTHERS PROFIT FROM GAS DECLINE -- Even as Amaranth Advisors lost billions of dollars betting, in essence, that natural gas prices would rise, more fortunate traders raked in big profits in recent weeks counting on gas prices to fall. [C4.] RIPPLE REACHES SAN DIEGO -- Much of San Diego County's pension fund strategy was tied to a basket of hedge funds that included Amaranth Advisors. [C4.] MARKETING PITCH BITES BACK -- When Nicholas M. Maounis, founder of Amaranth Advisors, marketed his hedge fund to potential investors, he would stress his firm's significant investment in its risk management and teamwork techniques. Now, having lost more than $3 billion through a series of disastrous bets on natural gas futures, there is a hollow ring to Mr. Maounis's marketing pitch. [C5.] RUSSIA CRITICIZED IN OIL DISPUTE -- Japan, Britain and the European Union expressed worries about a dispute between the Russian government and a consortium led by Royal Dutch Shell that is developing one of the world's largest oil and natural gas deposits on Sakhalin Island. [C7.] QUESTIONS ABOUT LEGALITY -- An e-mail exchange from within Hewlett-Packard suggests that key members of the team supervising the board's leak investigation knew about the questionable legality of some methods as early as January 2006. [C1.] FOX UNIT FOR CHRISTIAN FILMS -- Hollywood took another step toward America's vast and apparently growing Christian audience, as 20th Century Fox unveiled a new division, FoxFaith, that will release up to a dozen religious-oriented films each year. [E1.] BUFFETT MAKES PLEDGE -- Warren E. Buffett pledged $50 million to help set up an international nuclear fuel bank that aspiring powers could turn to for reactor fuel instead of making it on their own. [A14.] UNREST AMONG CONTROLLERS -- A drive by the Federal Aviation Administration to cut the number of air traffic controllers nationally by 10 percent below negotiated levels is producing tension, anger and occasional shows of defiance among controllers. [A16.] WARNING ON GLOBAL GROWTH -- The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Rodrigo de Rato, said that world economic growth ''may be turning'' down, and prodded policy makers to revive stalled global trade talks. [C3.] MORE SIGNS OF SOFT LANDING -- A day before the Federal Reserve's decision on where to set interest rates, the Labor Department reported fresh evidence that inflation is doing exactly what the central bank has said it would do: slow down with the economy. [C3.] YAHOO PLUNGES ON SOFT AD SALES -- Shares of Yahoo fell more than 11 percent after the company disclosed that it had sold less advertising in recent weeks than expected, largely because of a slowdown in automobile and financial advertising. Yahoo said that it would still meet its financial targets for the third quarter, but that its profit and revenue would be toward the bottom end of its forecast range. Market Place. IF I were to ask someone who knows about the world's cuisines, ''Where is the combination of chili, cumin, garlic and lamb a classic?'' the most likely answers would be North Africa, the Middle East or elsewhere in western Asia. But this dish is straight from Mongolia, via the street vendors of Queens, and it's little more than those four ingredients. On the street, the lamb is marinated for who knows how long, threaded onto skewers, grilled quickly over very hot charcoal and sold for a buck -- maybe two -- a stick. If you wanted to do it that way at home, you could, with good wood charcoal and a grill rack pretty close to the heat. You want to sear the lamb, but keep it medium rare.

To the Editor: David Brooks, in ''Is Chemistry Destiny?'' (column, Sept. 17), about recent research on biologically based sex differences in the brain, draws the conclusion that ''happiness seems to consist of living in harmony with the patterns that nature and evolution laid down long, long ago.'' Don't the societal structures that humans create for themselves to advance their own interests contribute anything to happiness -- or more likely, despair if one is unlucky enough to be born female in most parts of the world?

''There's no security, no job opportunities, no services, nothing at all. This government hasn't done anything better than the previous one.'' MUHAMMAD JABAR ABDUL RIDHA, an Iraqi construction worker. [A8]
The Times is introducing several design changes in the news pages today. Details are on Page A2.

MOSKOWITZ--Benjamin, 92, peacefully in his sleep on September 19th. Beloved husband of late Sylvia, loving father of Deanna Glassmann, Joseph Moskowitz and Phyllis Figluizzi. Devoted grandfather of Leonard, Dina, Steven, David, Minda, Robert, Adam and the late Michael. Cherished great-grandfather of Jennifer, Erica, Gabrielle, Abigail and Sylvia. A Master Mason of the Cornerstone Lodge and Past Potentate of Mecca Temple Shriners. He lived a long and fruitful life, rising from the humble role as a delivery/warehouse man in the butter, egg and cheese industry to president and CEO of several importing companies. Major philanthropist and supporter of the State of Israel. It was his passion during his lifetime and thereafter that his grandchildren and great-grandchildren would have the resources to pursue college careers. Services Thursday, September 21, 10am, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI. 516-921-5757.

The top American commander in the Middle East said Tuesday that more than 140,000 soldiers would probably be needed in Iraq at least until spring because of continuing sectarian violence and the need to secure Baghdad. ''I think that this level probably will have to be sustained through next spring, and then we'll re-evaluate,'' the commander, Gen. John P. Abizaid, told reporters at a breakfast round table.

GUMPORT--Robert A., Sr. of Carlsbad, CA, formerly of Rancho Santa Fe, CA and Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully on September 19 at age 83. Bob is survived by Lois, his wife of 58 years, children, Robert Jr. and Bonni of Rancho Santa Fe, CA, Barbara of McKinney, TX, and Patricia of Stanford, CA, grandchildren, Benjamin, Brian, Lauren, and his sister, Jean Gumport Black of Naples, FL. Bob served in the US Army in WWII in the Pacific Theater. A graduate of Lafayette College, Bob had a successful career of 30 years with Bloomingdale's, during which time he was awarded Ordre du Merite Agricole by the Minister of Agriculture of France, designated a Membre Honoraire of Le Grand Conseil L'Academie du Vin de Bordeau, and recognized for his invaluable service to the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade, Inc. After retiring, he used his expertise to write for ''Gourmet Retailer'' magazine and was an international consultant on wines and gourmet foods. Bob was also a 30year veteran of the Scarsdale Special Patrol and a Cub Scout Master and Boy Scout Leader. Services are private. Donations, in his memory, may be given to The Glenbrook Nursing Facility, 1950 Calle Barcelona, Carlsbad, CA 92009 or the charity of your choice. $(6$)GUMPORT--Robert Sr. My wonderful brother Bobby a country apart yet always in my heart. I will cherish our memories for ever. Love, Jean ''Sam'' and Gary

LAWFORD--Patricia Kennedy. Kennedy Child Study Center is saddened by the passing of our Board member, Patricia Kennedy Lawford. Mrs. Lawford served diligently for many years and we will forever be indebted to her for her guidance and contributions. She will be sorely missed. Board of Directors

UNGER--Stewart. On September 14, 2006, at age 73. Beloved proprietor of the Time Will Tell vintage watch store on Madison Avenue. Co-author of the book, ''American Wristwatches: Five Decades of Style And Design

A. O. Scott reviews "All the King's Men," starring Sean Penn, Jude Law and Kate Winslet.

We've been receiving some really great feedback from the first round of BETA testers for the Times Reader. Not surprisingly, one group that we have been hearing some negative feedback from are Mac users. Sadly, at present, the Times Reader is only available for Windows XP and Windows Vista Beta users.

A couple of people have asked how to get money directly to Prudence's or Pascal's families. Roger Seukap, a reproductive health expert who traveled with us through Cameroon, is willing to take the money directly to them. Roger is a great great great guy (I can't say enough. I burst open with happiness thinking about him), and otherwise, there isn't a direct connection to them (no post offices).

The Falcons signed Morten Andersen. Again. He's 46. The Danish genes must be some serious age-defying helixes. I'm "only" 38 (well, 39 in December), yet I already feel like I'm sixty-eight after playing three years of semi-pro football. Not 24 years of pro football, mind you, like Morten. No, I've played three measly years of semi-pro ball - I'm a kicker, too -- and after games I sometimes hobble around my apartment like Willis Reed.

The road to Manga is empty. It's one of the better roads in northern Central African Republic, but people are too afraid to travel on it now. Two weeks ago, bandits killed a pregnant woman, her six-month old baby and their driver. Last year, bandits raided Manga itself, leaving the village with nothing.
The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that Yahoo might buy the social-networking site Facebook for close to $1 billion, and the instant punditry is well under way.

Some readers have been asking about maternal mortality figures, so let me explain them a bit. But the starting point is that we don't really know - in poor countries, nobody is counting the number of people who die or why they die. And the reasons are typically complex. For example, malaria is much more likely to kill pregnant women than non-pregnant women, so such a death is both caused by malaria and also an instance of maternal mortality.

One of the most basic questions about global poverty is this: Does foreign aid work? I have a long essay about the topic, and looking at how to make humanitarian aid more effective, in the new issue of the New York Review of Books. It's a review of the provocative new book on aid by William Easterly, taking the opposite point of view of Jeff Sachs. You can post any comments on the subject here.
A new advertisement by the independent group Progress for America features a retired lieutenant general discussing terrorism.
Republican Thomas Kean Jr. in his first ad, featuring Arizona Senator John McCain.
A new ads from Senator Robert Menendez  works to tie his opponent with George W. Bush.

The boardroom tumult at Hewlett-Packard has prompted Fortune columnist Justin Fox to wonder why companies should have boards of directors. He studied that matter, and was unable to find a convincing answer.

Following on the heels of John Faso's speech, Eliot Spitzer tried to highlight his pro-business bona fides to the Business Council of New York this morning, outlining a number of ideas aimed at reducing the cost of doing business in the state.
The proliferation of private-equity deals is creating employment opportunities for top corporate executives.
A private equity firm, Apax Partners said on Thursday it had agreed to acquire Incisive Media, a financial information provider, for about 199 million pounds ($375 million).
New shows in New York include "Richard II" and "Esoterica."
A tour of the Sasakwa Lodge, the new ultra-exclusive game reserve in Tanzania.
Hillary vs. Spencer, Friday, Oct. 20, 7-8 p.m., in Rochester.
Time Warner's plan to sell off AOL's European assets continues apace, as two finalists have emerged for the Internet provider's British arm.
The largest land owner and developer in downtown Los Angeles will seek to raise up to $500 million by taking his firm public, The Los Angeles Times reported Thursday.

On Friday, September 15th, 2006, we sent e-mail to about 3,200 readers who'd asked to be among the first to try Times Reader. We wanted to get initial feedback on the installation process, the log in process, and the synchronization process before opening up Times Reader to everyone. We've gotten some great feedback and have been working this week on fixing and debugging a number of issues. We hope to put out a new build of the application shortly which addresses some of these issues. Once we do, we'll open up Times Reader to everyone. If you'd like to be notified when Times Reader launches, please sign up here.

Bank of America has appointed Richard L. Prager as its global head of commodities, a platform that incorporates energy products like oil and gas, base and precious metals. He will report to Tom Connor, global head of liquid products, the bank said Thursday.
The largest private-equity-backed initial public offering of the year made it out of the gate on Thursday, although the I.P.O. was smaller than expected.
Suez and Gaz de France proferred a raft of proposals to the European Commission to win approval for their planned merger, including spinning off parts of their Belgian gas business.
Pedro Martínez looked more comfortable in his latest playoff tuneup, but he was outpitched by Florida rookie Anibal Sanchez on Thursday night.

The two candidates for governor spoke this morning at the annual meeting of the Business Council of New York in Bolton Landing, an audience tailor made for John Faso as he seeks to convince people there's a palatable alternative to Eliot Spitzer.
The car of the future may be environmentally and socially responsible, but it doesn't have to give up on speed, luxury and looks.
Today's secret words: PlayPumps and sock puppets.
In an editorial titled "The Great Wall of America," The Wall Street Journal editorial page criticizes the Congressional push to build a fence along the U.S.-Mexico border [$]:

The media conglomerate Time Warner said Thursday it would sell AOL France's Internet access business for about $365 million, taking a step toward its goal of exiting the Internet access business in Europe. Time Warner is also in the process of changing AOL into a free, Web-based service.
A new exhibit at the Fashion Institute of Technology features fashion inspired by war.
David falls head over heels for TiVo's latest digital video recorder.
God, love, death and dessert are the menu in “Domains of Wonder: Selected Masterworks of Indian Painting” at the Museum of Fine Arts.

Google refused Wednesday to comply with a Belgian court decision that required the company to publish the original text of a court ruling on its sites, calling that requirement "unnecessary" and "disproportionate." The move could turn out to be a pricey one for Google, which might face a daily fine of $634,000 until it complies.

Perhaps in pursuit of a little Dutch courage, Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, was arrested and accused of public intoxication in Dallas earlier this month, but he will not go to jail early for violating the terms of his $5 million bond, The Houston Chronicle reported.
Robert Willumstad once led the world's largest bank. Now he'll lead the world's largest insurer.
In one of the harshest Wall Street punishments in years, a New York Stock Exchange specialist is facing 27 months behind bars for making illegal floor trades ahead of his customers.

California, which has battled the automotive industry over new global warming regulations for years, sued the world's six-largest automakers Wednesday, demanding that they pay for environmental damage caused by the emissions from their vehicles.

In a decidedly ironic turn of events, Hewlett-Packard's embattled chairman, Patricia Dunn, accepted a hall of fame leadership award at a gala dinner in San Francisco on Wednesday night, where she received a standing ovation from local executives.

Investigators at Hewlett-Packard sought a meeting last January with the chief executive and the chairwoman to describe internal efforts to trace news leaks and get their leaders' advice, according to e-mail exchanges between the investigators and a senior company lawyer.
The director Sofia Coppola opens her black book of addresses in Paris.
As Tribune faces the Chandler family at a board meeting Thursday, the newspaper industry is riveted by another skirmish inside the company: the growing rebellion at The Los Angeles Times.

It was a win-some, lose-some day for Carl Icahn. ImClone Systems shareholders added Mr. Icahn and his slate of hand-picked nominees to the board, but the billionaire investor then lost a board vote to replace the current chairman.

Coles Myer, Australia's second-largest retailer, is pledging to raise profit by 35 percent within two years. That may force potential buyers to bid more than the 17 billion Australian dollars ($13 billion) that was rejected two weeks ago.
CVC Capital Partners is seeking about 4 billion euros ($5.1 billion) from investors after losing its record as manager of Europe's biggest leveraged buyout fund, Bloomberg News reported.

Big media companies, from CBS Broadcasting to MTV Networks, made it plain during the CTIA Wireless conference last week that mobile phones need to be ready soon for prime time as a way to consume songs, images, and other media.

Bucking conventional wisdom that more computing applications will migrate from personal computers to cell phones, a mobile startup, SoonR raised $6 million from Clearstone Venture Partners and Intel Capital in a bid to maintain the relevancy of PCs.

Shares of Electronic Arts fell almost 2 percent on Wednesday after the company said that the Securities and Exchange Commission has requested certain documents and information related to its stock option grant practices.
Canesta said Wednesday that Honda Motor has invested more than $5 million in the company to help develop new automotive safety features.

Sir John Bond, the former chairman of the financial firm HSBC and one of Britain's most prominent business figures, is to be paid $25,000 a day as a special consultant to Bill Ford Jr., the embattled chairman of Ford, The Times of London reports.
Miasole, one of the fast-rising companies in solar technology, will try an I.P.O. within 12 to 18 months, teh chief executive, David Pearce, said.

Singapore Aircraft Leasing Enterprise, a unit of Singapore Airlines, may raise as much as $1 billion selling securities backed by planes, the first such sale in Asia, to help pay for its fleet expansion.

In a signal that the I.P.O. market has had enough of ethanol makers for the moment amid falling gas prices, Hawkeye Holdings postponed its $350 million initial public offering, the third deal from the emerging mini-sector to fall flat.

Chinese companies are the biggest source of new share listings for Nasdaq Stock Market and do not appear to be discouraged by stricter regulatory requirements, the exchange's international president said Wednesday.
After Marsh & McLennan's announcement Tuesday that it would test market interest in its Putnam Investments unit, some analysts have been hoping for a spin-off rather than an outright sale.
Bear Stearns, aiming to consolidate its equities business, named Bruce Lisman and Steven Meyer as co-heads of global equities on Wednesday.
Hilton Hotels has sold five hotel properties in three Canadian provinces to a privately owned hotel management company, the Westmont Hospitality Group, for $243-million.
Lehman Brothers has bought a minority stake in the electronic exchange BATS Trading.

Once again, internet upstart YouTube is the object of takeover rumors. The New York Post, citing industry sources, reports that the video site will not take anything less than $1.5 billion from a would-be buyer.
Sovereign Bank's chief executive officer assured shareholders yesterday that a Spanish bank's acquisition of a major stake in the thrift did not weaken their say on a future sale.

Hospira, the hospital supply company spun off from Abbott Laboratories, agreed to buy Mayne Pharma for $2 billion in cash, adding medicines in Europe to become the world's biggest makers of generic injectable drugs.
The social-networking site Facebook is in serious talks to sell itself to Yahoo for an amount that could approach $1 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Merck is back. The German drugmaker that lost a bid for a rival, Schering, this year agreed to buy Serono of Switzerland for 10.6 billion euros ($13.5 billion) to become Europe's largest biotechnology company.

As Amaranth Advisors, the hedge-fund company that imploded after making wrong-way bets on natural gas, said Wednesday that its losses had swelled to $6 billion, reports began to surface that Citigroup might buy a stake in the firm.
The space shuttle Atlantis glided to an uneventful landing Thursday, concluding a mission that marked NASA’s resumption of construction on the International Space Station.
The poet is to receive the National Book Foundation’s annual medal for distinguished contribution to American letters.

After a few quiet weeks, speculation about the fate of two popular Web sites is getting louder. Thursday brought two separate reports on Facebook and YouTube, suggesting once again that these Internet businesses were considering a sale.

In a cover story called the "75 Most Powerful Blacks on Wall Street," Black Enterprise magazine has named the African American investment bankers, private equity executives and other financial professionals that it considers to be among the industry's elite.
What in the world is going on at the board of Hewlett-Packard?
Robert Polidori’s photographs of a post-Katrina New Orleans, now showing at the Met, try to locate order in bedlam.
“Six Degrees,” the latest series from J. J. Abrams, which begins Thursday on ABC, is a religious drama, a story of a half-dozen strangers who find themselves in an enchanted network, as if chosen.
“Shark,” a new drama on CBS, doesn’t follow the usual stern and self-righteous prosecutor model. Sebastian Stark, played by James Woods, is ruthless, glib and sleazy.
The latest cable television slapfight is something we would love to ignore, but unfortunately, it involves the N.F.L.
This documentary chronicle of the hardcore punk movement in the first half of the 1980’s imagines an underground culture that was more than a new generation’s style of hormonal eruption.
The White House reached an agreement with key Republican senators on interrogation techniques and trial procedures for terrorism suspects.
The Israeli military said it targeted the Palestinians because they were spotted handling the rocket launcher after it had been used to fire on Israel.
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad refused to say whether he would comply with a demand to withhold arms from Hezbollah.
The results of a new, comprehensive state testing system help explain the state’s low high school graduation rates.
A summary of top stories in Russian newspapers on Thursday.
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s remarks today seemed to suggest that Iran might embrace talks if the threat of sanctions is set aside.
Richard Branson of Virgin plans to invest in efforts to find renewable, sustainable energy sources.
The pilot program appeared to mark the first time that Wal-Mart has used its influence to lower health care costs.
Three Christians convicted in connection with anti-Muslim communal violence in 2000 were executed in spite of protests from the European Union.
The space shuttle concluded a mission that resumed NASA’s construction work on the space station.
David Ortiz hit his 50th home run Wednesday night to match a Red Sox record, but Torii Hunter’s three-run shot in the eighth inning sent the Minnesota Twins to a victory.
The Yankees lost in Toronto, but captured the American League East anyway when the Red Sox were beaten by the Twins.
Dontrelle Willis pitched eight and one-third innings, hit two home runs and added a run-scoring single in the Marlins’ victory.
The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that he intended to block $20 million in bus and subway service cuts proposed for next year.

Pete Rose unveiled his latest marketing venture yesterday on his Web site: for $299, plus $4.99 shipping and handling, fans can order a baseball inscribed, “I’m sorry I bet on baseball,” along with Rose’s autograph. The offering came two days after an auction house confirmed that 30 baseballs inscribed the same way would be available for bid next April.
Taylor Twellman and Andy Dorman scored goals last night to give the visiting New England Revolution a 2-0 win over the Red Bulls and hurt the Red Bulls’ playoff hopes.
Henrik Lundqvist posted a shutout in his first exhibition game this season, and Greg Moore set up both goals in the Rangers’ 2-0 victory over the Devils last night at Madison Square Garden.
hockey.

Evgeni Malkin was injured during his first N.H.L. exhibition game last night when he collided with his Pittsburgh teammate John LeClair early in the second period against Philadelphia. Malkin, a rookie Russian center, was taken to a hospital for further evaluation, the team announced. Mark Recchi, a veteran winger for the Penguins, also was sent to a hospital after he was hit with a high stick in the first period.

The father of a high school softball player in Meriden, Conn., was sentenced to five years’ probation yesterday for beating his daughter’s coach with a bat during a practice last year. Mark Picard, 48, of North Branford, also received a five-year suspended sentence. He was arrested May 17, 2005, after beating John Crovo, the coach at Sacred Heart Academy in Hamden. Authorities said Picard was upset that Crovo had suspended his daughter Melanie, a senior co-captain at the time, after she missed a game to attend her boyfriend’s prom.

Coach Jeff Fisher lashed out at critics of the Tennessee Titans’ dealings with Billy Volek, saying yesterday that Volek lied to him and never took advantage of the opportunity to be the starter. The Titans traded Volek on Tuesday to the San Diego Chargers for a sixth-round draft pick that could become a fifth-rounder depending on playing time. Fisher said Volek asked to be traded the day the Titans signed Kerry Collins last month. The Titans are 0-2 with Collins.

Columbus Blue Jackets center Sergei Fedorov will be out four to six weeks after injuring his left shoulder in an exhibition game Tuesday night. Fedorov, 36, who spent most of his 16-year N.H.L. career with Detroit, was hurt in the second period of a 4-1 victory over Buffalo.

Three South American riders were suspended from competing yesterday at the world road championships in Salzburg, Austria, because of irregular blood levels, although the ban did not mean they were caught doping. Tests before the event showed excessive hematocrit levels for Martin Garrido and Matias Medici of Argentina, and Magno Nazaret of Brazil. They were not allowed to race for two weeks. In all, 18 riders were tested from Brazil, Argentina, Australia, the United States and Switzerland. Hematocrit testing checks the percentage of a person’s packed red blood cells.
Iran’s president sparred with the Council on Foreign Relations, exasperating his questioners and angering the Bush administration and Jewish groups.
The Pataki administration took a proposal to convert the city’s main post office to a grand transit hub off the table again rather than risk a vote against it.

Responding to a rising national fury, the government fired the health minister, Yerbolat Dosayev, along with the governor of South Kazakhstan Province, where 55 children, including infants, contracted H.I.V. through blood transfusions and injections at a hospital in the city of Shymkent. The dismissals were for “poor performance of their duties,” an official with Kazakhstan’s Security Council said. Tests have been completed on just half of the nearly 9,800 children under 3 who were patients at the children’s hospital and are thought to have been exposed to contaminated blood and needles. Health care workers were frequently critical of Mr. Dosayev, whose background is in finance and banking.

Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front, opened his presidential campaign on the battlefield of Valmy in the northeast, where in 1792 a French revolutionary army fended off an invading force of Prussians seeking to restore Louis XVI to the throne. The battle was an important victory of the French Revolution, and the symbolism was typical of the 78-year-old Mr. Le Pen, who shocked France in the 2002 elections by finishing second to Jacques Chirac. He told a gathering of several hundred followers that he called on everyone in France, including “the French of foreign origin,” to rally around his crusade against illegal immigration. He wants France to expel all illegal immigrants, estimated at as many as 400,000. His backing has increased in recent months, a result of the riots that swept through France’s poor and mainly immigrant suburbs last year.

Yemenis turned out in force for a landmark election to choose a president and local council representatives, and the nation’s electoral commission extended voting by two hours. Lines of men and women stretched around the block at some polling places. Results of the presidential vote, in which President Ali Abdullah Saleh faced his first serious challenge after 28 years in office, must be released within 72 hours.

An attack on Kosovo’s minority Serbs brought a sharp warning to Albanian leaders from United Nations officials trying to guide Kosovo through talks on its future to watch their words, after one forecast a “revolt” if independence from Serbia was denied. The comments by the Kosovo Parliament speaker, Kole Berisha, that “if our aim of independence is not realized, then citizens’ revolts are expected in Kosovo,” outraged Serbia. Hours later, a grenade was lobbed into an apartment in western Klina, injuring four elderly Serbs. At the United Nations, the nations overseeing Balkan diplomacy — Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Russia and the United States — authorized their mediator, Martti Ahtisaari, to propose a final status plan for Kosovo and achieve a settlement by the end of this year that neither Serbia nor Kosovo could unilaterally block from advancing.

A methane explosion and fire ripped through a large coal mine, killing at least 41 workers. A number of miners were missing, but more than 300 others managed to escape to safety, according to local reports. The sprawling Lenin coal mine in the central Karaganda region is owned by Mittal Steel of the Netherlands, Kazakhstan’s biggest employer.

Israeli security forces raided the offices of 13 moneychangers in the West Bank in what the military said was an attempt to prevent the transfer of Iranian money to armed Palestinian factions. The military said that about 5 million Israeli shekels and 170,000 Jordanian dinars (more than $1.3 million altogether) were seized, along with documents, in Ramallah, Nablus, Tulkarm and Jenin. According to the military, Iran and the Lebanese group Hezbollah are sending the money to Palestinian factions, including Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades “to finance terror attacks.”.
A model subway train by the Lionel company will use sounds recorded in the New York City transit system.

The federal Justice Department filed a lawsuit against the City of Boca Raton challenging a zoning ordinance that it said discriminated against people with disabilities. The lawsuit says the ordinance, passed in 2002, excludes housing for recovering alcoholics and drug addicts in the city’s residential areas, in violation of the Fair Housing Act. The regulations “impose conditions and prohibitions on housing for persons with disabilities that are not imposed on housing for an equal or greater number of persons without disabilities,” says the lawsuit, which seeks monetary damages for victims, civil penalties and a court order to stop future discrimination.

The police are trying to identify a woman who they believe was dragged behind a vehicle for more than a mile. The woman’s body was found early Monday in a hilly subdivision south of Denver, and officials for the Douglas County Sheriff’s Office have arrested 36-year-old Jose Luis Rubi-Nava in the case. Mr. Rubi-Nava is an illegal immigrant living in Glendale, said a spokeswoman for the sheriff’s office. He was arrested after he was identified in a photograph found near the crime scene. The photograph also shows a woman, but officials are uncertain if that woman is the victim because the victim’s body was unrecognizable after the dragging. The cause of death, the sheriff’s department said, was strangulation and head injuries.
Women were warned that their risk of blood clots in the legs and lungs may be higher if they use the birth-control patch instead of the pill.

A company posing as a Canadian pharmacy offering inexpensive versions of generic drugs over the Internet was really a “backyard chemist” that sent millions of fake pills to hundreds of unsuspecting customers, federal agents in Atlanta said. Eleven people have been charged with two felony counts of conspiracy each in connection with the manufacture of 24 unapproved or adulterated drugs that were sold by Hi-Tech Pharmaceuticals, a company based in Norcross, Ga. The drugs were made in an “unsanitary house” in Belize and sold over the Internet through spam e-mail messages and Web sites, drug enforcement agents said. “When you buy drugs over the Internet you don’t know what you’re getting,” said Sherri Strange, special agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Atlanta.
The House Intelligence Committee approved by voice vote a bill that would put into law the Bush administration’s program of wiretapping without warrants.

Congress called for emergency preparedness plans that include helping individuals and families with pets, under legislation sent to President Bush. The bill calls for state and local emergency preparedness plans to make provisions for families with pets and individuals with service animals. It grants the Federal Emergency Management Agency the authority to help state and local governments develop emergency and evacuation plans that take pets and service animals into account. It also authorizes some federal financial help for states establishing emergency shelters for people and their pets.
The owners of a nursing home where 35 patients died in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina were indicted on charges of negligent homicide and cruelty to the infirm.

A third premature infant died after being accidentally given an adult dose of a blood thinner at a hospital. The baby girl, Thursday Dawn Jeffers, died late Tuesday at Riley Hospital for Children five days after she was born at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis. She had been transferred to Riley once her condition worsened from receiving an adult dose of the drug Heparin, a drug routinely given to premature babies. The two other girls, D’myia Sabrina Nelson and Emmery Miller, both less than a week old, died Saturday in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at Methodist Hospital. They were given the drug after a pharmacy technician accidentally stored adult doses in the neonatal unit’s drug cabinet.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveled to an inner-city high school in Los Angeles to join the mayor for an announcement on safety, and was confronted again about whether he plans to run for president.

A former police officer about to face trial on drug charges and five inmates held as members of a violent drug gang escaped from a privately run federal jail near the Mexican border by overpowering a guard and cutting through at least four fences, officials said. More than 60 law enforcement officers were searching near the East Hidalgo Detention Center, in La Villa, a facility owned by a Lafayette, La., company about 20 miles north of the border. Among the escapees was a former McAllen police officer, Francisco Meza-Rojas, whose trial was scheduled to begin Oct. 3. The other escapees were accused of being members of the Raza Unida drug gang. La Villa is about 40 miles northwest of Brownsville.
The African Union said it would strengthen its peacekeeping force in Darfur while trying to persuade Sudan to allow U.N. troops to take over.
The decision put Jacob Zuma one step closer to seizing control of the African National Congress party and, eventually, the nation’s presidency.

A former jail guard was convicted yesterday of violating the civil rights of an inmate who died after he was kicked into a coma. A jury in Federal District Court deliberated for four hours before finding the former guard, Paul Cote, 39, guilty in the case of Zoran Teodorovic, a mentally ill homeless man who died in December 2001, 14 months after the beating. Prosecutors said the altercation, on Oct. 10, 2000, started when Mr. Teodorovic punched another officer at the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla and the officer, Mark Reimer, wrestled him to the floor. Mr. Cote rushed over and “pummeled Zoran because he was carried away with his power as a corrections officer,” said a prosecutor, Cynthia Keefe. Mr. Reimer, who agreed to testify in exchange for immunity, said he had had Mr. Teodorovic down and had tried to stop the attack, which included punching, kicking and stomping him. No date was set for sentencing. Mr. Cote faces up to 10 years in prison.

A bookkeeper at the Five Towns Community Center here has been indicted on charges involving a check-cashing scheme that cost the center $50,000, prosecutors said yesterday. The bookkeeper, Anthony Savage, 41, of the Bronx, was charged with second-degree grand larceny, said Kathleen Rice, the Nassau County district attorney. Ms. Rice said from that from February 2004 to February 2005, Mr. Savage created 61 fraudulent checks on the community center’s accounts. He has pleaded not guilty, prosecutors said. The center is a nonprofit organization that receives government funds.

New York Water Taxi plans to raise the fare for a ferry ride between Pier 11, near Wall Street, and a dock on the Jersey City waterfront to $9 from $6 because of a dispute with Goldman Sachs, the investment bank that owns the dock. New York Water Taxi, owned by Douglas Durst, the Manhattan developer, said it had lost $1.2 million in the two years it has operated the route and blamed an “onerous” contract that requires it to carry Goldman’s employees at no charge between the morning and evening rushes. Goldman, which has thousands of workers scattered around Lower Manhattan, built an office tower, which houses about 2,000 employees, on the west side of the Hudson River in 2004. “We do it very reluctantly,” Tom Fox, president of New York Water Taxi, said of the fare increase, which takes effect next week. The price of a monthly pass will go to $321 from $192, a 67 percent rise. A Goldman spokesman declined to comment on the dispute.
Federal health officials have drawn up a national plan for autopsies and tissue sampling of 9/11 workers who die years later in order to determine the effect of exposure to World Trade Center dust.

One person was killed and two others were rescued after a sailboat and a freighter collided in Long Island Sound early yesterday, the Coast Guard said. The collision, between a 600-foot freighter and a 92-foot sailboat, occurred about 4:30 a.m. north of Riverhead, along Long Island’s North Shore. The crash sank the sailboat, which was headed to Greenwich, the Coast Guard said. Rescuers from the freighter and the Coast Guard recovered the three members of the sailboat’s crew: two were in good condition, but the third was pronounced dead at Yale-New Haven Hospital, the Coast Guard said. Their names were not released.

A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested and charged yesterday in the fatal shooting of a cabdriver early Tuesday morning in Weeksville, Brooklyn. The suspect, Rico Roberts, is one of two young men investigators believe were involved in the robbery and shooting of the driver, Mohammad N. Bhuiyan. While he was waiting for the bus at Utica Avenue and Fulton Street, Mr. Bhuiyan, 36, was shot in the face. He later died at Interfaith Medical Center. Mr. Roberts was charged with murder and robbery.

Fourteen years after the body of a young woman was found stuffed inside a garbage bag near the New Jersey Turnpike, Hudson County officials said yesterday that they had charged a Jersey City woman with the murder. The woman, Shirley Deonaraian, 54, was arrested on Monday after investigators used new technology to examine forensic evidence, said the Hudson County prosecutor, Edward J. De Fazio. Ms. Deonaraian is accused of killing Rose Marie Wright, 19, who had given birth shortly before her body was found on Aug. 15, 1992, prosecutors said. Ms. Deonaraian’s son is the child’s father, and a dispute over custody of the child appears to have been the motive for the killing, Mr. De Fazio said.

The Turner Corporation has won a $615 million contract to replace Yankee Stadium with a smaller but more luxurious baseball park. Turner, a subsidiary of Hochtief AG, Germany’s biggest construction company, said it had already started work on the 50,800-seat stadium for the developer, Tishman Speyer. Work on the stadium is to be finished before the start of the 2009 baseball season. Situated in the Bronx next to the 1923 original stadium, the new park is to recreate features including the facade and an Art Deco frieze that rings the outfield seats.

The state will add $5 million to the $10 million it has already provided for restoration of the historic facade of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. The work will include inspections, removal and replacement of worn mortar, restoration of ornamentation and statuary repair, resurfacing of stone and replacement of brackets. The Beaux-Arts building opened in 1911 — then the largest marble structure in the country. The facade restoration is to be scheduled for completion in time for the library’s centennial celebration in 2011.

SMITH--Bailey, 76, of Sayville, LI, on September 19, 2006. Survived by her pets Deirdre, Maude and Polly; her cousins Richard Wallace Smith and Bailey Smith and their children, and Virginia Louise Smith, as well as countless devoted and caring friends. Reposing Friday, 2-4:30 & 79:30 p.m. at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy, West Sayville, LI. Religious service Saturday, 9:30 a.m. at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Sayville. Interment to follow in the parish cemetery. Contributions in her memory to the Guide Dog Foundation, 371 East Jericho Tpke, Smithtown, NY 11787 are appreciated.

Early next week, three kinds of textiles will be offered at discount prices: Penn & Fletcher, a custom-embroidery company known for theater and movie costumes, will sell 18- to 20-inch-square silk and velvet throw pillows for $45 to $65 (usually $125 to $165). Antique and vintage quilts from the collection of Christina Weppner, a theatrical set designer, will be on sale; a Tumbling Blocks pattern, 70 by 80 inches with 1930's floral fabric, will be $370 (originally $700). And Jeanne Heifetz, a Brooklyn rug designer and weaver, will sell four-by-six-foot wool rugs for $900 each (originally $1,800). From Sept. 25 to 28, at Penn & Fletcher, 21-07 41st Street (5th Floor), Long Island City; (212) 239-6868. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

For months, Buffalo Sabres fans compared the club's new logo to a slug and a toupee. Now all is forgiven. When the Sabres skated onto the ice at HSBC Arena on Saturday for a scrimmage wearing a new logo and uniform, more than 9,000 fans provided a standing ovation. It created an atmosphere of a regular-season game, though it was only the third day of training camp.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about an agreement by 25 tribes in Iraq's Anbar Province to fight Al Qaeda insurgents misattributed a response from one of two tribal leaders on the military strength of the tribes. The response, ''The terrorists have different kinds of weapons while we have only AK-47s,'' and that, with sufficient help, ''their force will collapse in one month,'' was from Sheik Fassal al-Guood, a prominent tribal leader from Ramadi, the capital of Anbar, not Sheik Abdul Satttar Buzaigh al-Rishawi, leader of Rishawi tribe, a subset of the Dulaimi tribe, the largest in Anbar.
To the Editor: Re ''Presidents Spar Over Iran's Aims and U.S. Power'' (front page, Sept. 20):

SCHWED--Antonia Holding, 86, died peacefully in her New York City home on September 10. A published novelist, writer and poet, she was particularly well-known for her exceptionally crafted enamel jewelry and wood-based sculptures. The beloved wife of the late Peter Schwed, she is survived by her four children, Kathy, Greg, Laura and Roger, and six grandchildren, Alex, Emily, Sarah, Griffin, Ben and Stephen. We will miss her and love her always.

There is enough for Trey Teague to worry about this week without the added distraction of his homecoming. It is true that the Jets play at Buffalo this weekend, and it is true that Teague played center for the Bills for the past four seasons. Given the circumstances, however, he does not have time for such things. There are many other issues occupying Teague's mind. There is the question of whether he can play on Sunday, given his recovery from a broken left ankle sustained in an off-season workout in June. Then there is the question of what position he might play if he does suit up. He may be asked to spell the injured left guard Pete Kendall, even though the nine-year veteran Teague has never played guard.

A music review on Saturday about Elaine Stritch, at the Café Carlyle, misstated the name of the Rodgers and Hart musical that includes the song ''To Keep My Love Alive,'' which she sang. It is ''A Connecticut Yankee,'' not ''A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court.''

Cocktail party conversation is usually restricted to the witty and the batty: insubstantial, gossip-laden, aphoristic, blithe. An authority no less than Oscar Wilde once remarked upon its tendency toward fluff: ''Conversation should touch on everything, but should concentrate on nothing,'' he said.

Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about plans by heirs of Ferdinand and Adele Bloch-Bauer to sell four paintings by Gustav Klimt at auction misspelled the middle name of a lawyer who represented the heirs in seeking the return of the works from Austria. He is E. Randol Schoenberg, not Randall.

To the Editor: Those who read ''Gay Groups Renew Drive Against 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' '' (news article, Sept. 14) should not forget that the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy prohibits not only openly gay troops from serving, but also openly gay lawyers in the Judge Advocate General's Corps of the Navy and gay translators of Arabic within the military, among other positions.

FINEMAN--Barbara S. Died September 16, 2006. She is survived by her brother, niece, grand nephew and countless friends. In lieu of flowers, please make a dontation in Barbara's name to the New York City ASPCA.

The Bush administration expressed support on Wednesday for the efforts by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, to establish a national unity government with Hamas, but said the United States would continue to withhold aid from the Palestinian Authority. Washington's European allies have been pushing President Bush to engage more fully in peace efforts in the Middle East. An announcement on Wednesday by the four powers of the so-called quartet that have been working to promote peace negotiations -- the European Union, the United States, Russia and the United Nations -- that they supported Mr. Abbas's efforts came as part of talks on the periphery of the General Assembly.

An article in The Arts yesterday about a new division of 20th Century Fox that will make religious-oriented films misspelled the given name of the author of the novel ''Christ the Lord: Out of Egypt,'' which, in another sign of interest in Christian audiences, is being developed into a film. She is Anne Rice, not Ann.

On the strength of its hit ''Dancing With the Stars,'' which averaged 18.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, ABC posted its best Tuesday in a season-opening week in six years. But even as ''Dancing With the Stars'' propelled ABC to No. 1 for the night, the highest-rated program in the prized demographic of adults 18 to 49 was Fox's ''House,'' with Hugh Laurie, which drew 13.4 million viewers at 8 p.m. In the next hour Fox's ''Standoff'' failed to capitalize on the ''House'' lead-in and garnered a series-low 7.9 million viewers. Meanwhile NBC's premiere of ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' fared well with 11.6 million viewers, topping the CBS premiere of ''The Unit'' (12.1 million) among adults 18 to 49 for the hour. ''Criminal Intent'' was up 29 percent in that demographic from its premiere last year on a Sunday. At 10 p.m. the longtime leader, NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' made its eighth season debut with 14.4 million viewers, besting ABC's premiere of ''Boston Legal'' (11.6 million) and Ray Liotta's new show, ''Smith,'' on CBS (10.7 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

LIEBERMAN--Beverly. The law firm of Ganfer & Shore, LLP notes with deep saddness the passing of Beverly Lieberman, the beloved wife of our partner Arthur M. Lieberman and we extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to Arthur, their children and grandchildren and their families.

Israeli security forces raided the offices of 13 moneychangers in the West Bank in what the military said was an attempt to prevent the transfer of Iranian money to armed Palestinian factions. The military said that about 5 million Israeli shekels and 170,000 Jordanian dinars (more than $1.3 million altogether) were seized, along with documents, in Ramallah, Nablus, Tulkarm and Jenin. According to the military, Iran and the Lebanese group Hezbollah are sending the money to Palestinian factions, including Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades ''to finance terror attacks.'' GREG MYRE (NYT)

For his first exhibition of furniture in New York, which opens today at the Ralph Pucci showroom, the Parisian designer Hervé Van der Straeten is presenting limited-edition and one-of-a-kind pieces intended to ''create movement and a strong effect,'' he said. Mr. Van der Straeten, 40, has designed jewelry for Jean Paul Gaultier and Christian Lacroix; he began making furniture when he opened his Paris store, Galerie Van der Straeten, in 1998. The show includes a convex mirror with a swirling bronze frame ($19,153), below, and a lacquered console table of slabs unevenly stacked on cast-bronze beams ($61,403). Ralph Pucci, 44 West 18th Street (Sixth Avenue), by appointment; (212) 633-0452; www.ralphpucci.net.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the United States Senate race in Washington State misstated the given name of the Bush family member who campaigned this summer on behalf of Mike McGavick, a Republican seeking to unseat the incumbent, Maria Cantwell. She is Laura Bush, not Barbara. The article also referred incorrectly to Dal LaMagna, who was once a potential primary opponent of Senator Cantwell. He joined the Cantwell campaign as a volunteer; Ms. Cantwell did not hire him as an employee. (Another potential challenger, Mark Wilson, is on her campaign staff and is paid $8,000 a month.)

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Michigan's 47-21 victory at Notre Dame misstated the year in which Notre Dame lost at home to Purdue by 51-19. It was 1960, not 1950.

FORGET laces. Shoe companies are designing Mary Jane styles for low-impact gym workouts and easy hiking. No patent leather or heels, just a strap (or two). These athletic shoes offer a pared-down feminine alternative to lace-up indoor cross-trainers and low-cut hikers. All of these shoes have at least a slightly lugged outsole for traction and cushioned soles. But do they provide adequate support and traction for exercisers?

Yemenis turned out in force for a landmark election to choose a president and local council representatives, and the nation's electoral commission extended voting by two hours. Lines of men and women stretched around the block at some polling places. Results of the presidential vote, in which President Ali Abdullah Saleh faced his first serious challenge after 28 years in office, must be released within 72 hours. HASSAN M. FATTAH (NYT)

John Isaacs will be there today when George Gregory Jr. is inducted posthumously into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame at the New York Athletic Club in Manhattan. ''George was a leader of men, on and off the court,'' said Isaacs, 90, the last surviving member of the Harlem Renaissance Five, a barnstorming team of black all-stars during the Depression years. ''I was one of the neighborhood kids who looked up to him.''

''Civil War,'' the limited series from Marvel Comics that pits heroes against one another as they take sides on the government's Superhuman Registration Act, has resulted in another rift, and a death. In issue No. 4, which went on sale yesterday, Invisible Woman, left, packed her bags and left Mr. Fantastic and their children. That couple are half of the Fantastic Four. Invisible Woman's decision stemmed from her husband's use of a superpowered clone who killed Goliath, an antiregistration hero, in battle. The series, and its exploration of war, has been successful for Marvel, with sales of the first installment exceeding 300,000 copies. Issues No. 2 and 3 each sold just short of that. Invisible Woman's Dear Reed letter to her husband read, in part: ''I also didn't want your last memory of me to be tainted with all the blazing fights we've had in recent weeks. Hence the oily fish dinner (good brain food), the bottle of your favorite claret (an excellent antioxidant) and making love one final time (good for the immune system).'' GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

SCIAMSI--Bernardette MarieJosee. Miss Bernadette Sciamsi (73) returned to her Heavenly Father Tuesday morning after a courageous battle with cancer for the past several years. Bernadette was born in Paris, France and emigrated to the United States with her parents Charlotte and Assaad Sciamsi and sisters in August of 1953 and became a U.S. citizen in the spring of 1966. Miss Sciamsi worked at Galerie Felix Vercel in Manhattan for many years then retiring to her home on the east side of Manhattan. Besides her godmother, life-long companion and beloved sister, Marie Jeanine Sciamsi, Bernadette also leaves another loving sister Lydia and brother-in-law Charlie Khouri; nieces Christine (Joseph Kissick), Genevieve (Martin Schmidt) & Brigitte (Stephen Kahn); great-nieces and nephews: Joseph, Marielle, Charles, Danielle, Martin, Martine, Andrew, Robert, and James. Bernadette was a faithful member of the Cathedral of Saint Patrick in New York City for over twentyfive years. Mass of Christian Burial today at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, Hicksville, NY at 10 a.m. after a brief wake service from 8:30-9:30 a.m.
