UNITED STATES Tiger Woods Age -- 30 World rank -- 1 Past Ryder Cups -- 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 7 wins, 11 losses, 2 halves Perhaps it would have been different if Tiger Woods had also hung a poster of Billy Casper next to the one of Jack Nicklaus on the wall of his childhood room. It is Casper who holds the American record for most points won during a Ryder Cup career, with 23 1/2. But Woods has long been much more focused on Nicklaus's career mark of 18 major victories. Phil Mickelson Age -- 36 World rank -- 2 Past Ryder Cups -- 1995, 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 9-8-3 As Woods has rattled off birdies and victories, it has been easy to forget that three months ago, Mickelson was one hole away from becoming the world's dominant golfer. All he had to do was par the 18th at Winged Foot in June to win the United States Open and his third straight major. But he had a meltdown instead, ending with a double bogey. Mickelson has not come close to winning since, and he has not played a tournament in September. Jim Furyk Age -- 36 World rank -- 3 Past Ryder Cups -- 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 4-9-2 Chris DiMarco Age -- 37 World rank -- 15 Past Ryder Cups -- 2004 Record -- 2-1-1 David Toms Age -- 39 World rank -- 16 Past Ryder Cups -- 2002, 2004 Record -- 4-3-1 Chad Campbell Age -- 32 World rank -- 22 Past Ryder Cups -- 2004 Record -- 1-2-0 Stewart Cink Age -- 33 World rank -- 23 Past Ryder Cups -- 2002, 2004 Record -- 2-4-1 Scott Verplank Age -- 42 World rank -- 37 Past Ryder Cups -- 2002 Record -- 2-1-0 Zach Johnson Age -- 30 World rank -- 42 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie Vaughn Taylor Age -- 30 World rank -- 60 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie J. J. Henry Age -- 31 World rank -- 64 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie Brett Wetterich Age -- 33 World rank -- 68 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie Tom Lehman (Nonplaying captain) age -- 47 Past Ryder Cups -- 1995, 1997, 1999 Record -- 5-3-2 Europe Sergio García Age -- 26 Country -- Spain World ranking -- 8 Past Ryder Cups -- 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 10-3-2 Putting troubles and an uneven temper have kept him from winning a major. He delivered 4 1/2 points out of a possible 5 last time around at Oakland Hills. Luke Donald Age -- 28 Country -- England World ranking -- 9 Past Ryder Cups -- 2004 Record -- 2-1-1 Anointed Europe's next big thing, Donald looks more like a steady, mature performer: an English expatriate who does everything well but lacks the strapping frame and power game to hang with Woods and Mickelson on a week-in, major-out basis. Rejected at Stanford, Woods's alma mater, Donald ended up studying at Northwestern, where he won the national collegiate title and majored in art. Henrik Stenson Age -- 30 Country -- Sweden World ranking -- 11 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie The K Club would probably not have been Stenson's first choice for his Ryder Cup debut. While playing there during the 2001 European Open, he was so overwrought that he quit midway through a round. Sports psychology ultimately proved helpful. Stenson, a Swede, is one of the most intimidating long-iron players in the game, which leads to plenty of birdies, and that should lead to plenty of four-ball play at the K Club, despite the memories. David Howell Age -- 31 Country -- England World ranking -- 13 Past Ryder Cups -- 2004 Record -- 1-1-0 Modest is a word often applied to Howell: from his modest beginnings in the down-market English town of Swindon to his modest reaction to the brilliant 6-iron at the 17th hole that kept the 2004 Ryder Cup at Oakland Hills from swinging the Americans' way. It was a shot Howell quickly conceded was a mis-hit. Howell has had some terrific results in the past year, staring down Tiger Woods (politely) in the final group to win the HSBC Champions Tournament in Shanghai, then winning the BMW Championship by five shots in May. Colin Montgomerie Age -- 43 Country -- Scotland World ranking -- 14 Past Ryder Cups -- 1991, 1993, 1995, 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 19-8-5 This event puts Monty in a parallel universe, one where he is no longer distracted by the gallery chatter, clicking cameras and final-day pressure that have conspired to deprive him of a major championship. Paul Casey Age -- 29 Country -- England World ranking -- 17 Past Ryder Cups -- 2004 Record -- 1-1-0 Not long after playing a small role in Europe's 2004 victory, Casey gave a harsh critique of American culture in an interview with The Sunday Times. ''Americans,'' he said, ''can be bloody annoying.'' As for the American Ryder Cup team, he said, ''We properly hate them.'' Seldom has a bulletin board had so much advance material. Casey has since apologized to various American golfers, including Tom Lehman. Padraig Harrington Age -- 35 Country -- Ireland World ranking -- 18 Past Ryder Cups -- 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 7-4-1 Harrington once studied accounting in Dublin, figuring golf was no sure thing, but he has ended up with plenty of prize money and Ryder Cup points. He won four of five matches in 2004. With a chance at this year's United States Open, his game disintegrated, and he has missed cuts at the British Open and the P.G.A. Championship. But he likes the K Club, having finished second in two European Opens, and the crowd will help him. José María Olazábal Age -- 40 Country -- Spain World ranking -- 19 Past Ryder Cups -- 1987, 1989, 1991, 1993, 1997, 1999 Record -- 15-8-5 Darren Clarke Age -- 38 Country -- Northern Ireland World ranking -- 24 Past Ryder Cups -- 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 7-7-3 Robert Karlsson Age -- 37 Country -- Sweden World ranking -- 36 Past Ryder Cups -- Rookie Lee Westwood Age -- 33 Country -- England World ranking -- 51 Past Ryder Cups -- 1997, 1999, 2002, 2004 Record -- 11-8-1 Paul McGinley Age -- 39 Country -- Ireland World ranking -- 53 Past Ryder Cups -- 2002, 2004 Record -- 2-1-3 Ian Woosnam (Nonplaying captain) age -- 48 Country -- Wales Past Ryder Cups -- 1983, 1985, 1987, 1989, 1991, 1993, 1995, 1997 Record -- 14-12-5
VEDRO--Carl (Leo Krassen) 98, lifelong social activist, died September 10, at the Jewish Home -San Francisco.

Last year, seeing an opportunity to bring higher quality and customer service to the firewood delivery business, Adam Rubin, right, and Ted Whitehead quit their corporate jobs -- Mr. Rubin, 44, was a stockbroker, Mr. Whitehead, 43, a lawyer -- to start thewoodman, an upscale firewood company based in Brooklyn. They sell seasoned logs and logs that are kiln-dried with the bark intact. ''It has a golden luster,'' said Mr. Rubin, who talks about wood the way a sommelier discusses wine. ''When the sun shines on it, it's so beautiful we feel badly parting with it.'' A quarter face cord of wood -- a stack about 2 feet high and 4 feet long -- starts at $85; (718) 554-3251 or www.thewoodman.com. SARAH ROBERTSON

Locked in a standoff with the State Assembly over financing for a $900 million plan to convert the city's main post office to a grand transit hub, the Pataki administration took the proposal off the table again yesterday rather than risk a vote against it. State officials have been pushing to get the long-awaited project, called Moynihan Station, approved by the Public Authorities Control Board so that construction can begin before Gov. George E. Pataki leaves office in January. But a vote was delayed last month when Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, who controls the state board together with Governor Pataki and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, raised questions about the project's financing.

The Republican National Committee has amassed a significant fund-raising advantage, according to campaign finance records filed Wednesday, feeding Democrats' fears about remaining competitive in the intense final weeks before the midterm elections. The Democrats' House and Senate campaign committees have been unusually successful raising money compared with past election cycles. House Democrats have nearly as much as Republicans, while Senate Democrats have $10 million more than their Republican counterparts.

A playful, eclectic collection of furniture by Isay Weinfeld, a São Paulo-based architect, is making its American debut at the Brazilian design importer Espasso's new showroom in TriBeCa. Mr. Weinfeld, 53, a modernist architect who is well known in Brazil (he designed São Paulo's Fasano Hotel), has created pieces like the steel-and-wood armchair ($6,950), below, which has oversize cushions meant to look somewhat disarrayed. His square bar cart ($11,573), above, holds trays and boxes made of three kinds of wood; its sides open like drawers and it has a leather leash so it can be ''pulled around, as a little dog,'' Mr. Weinfeld said. Espasso, 38 North Moore Street (Hudson Street); (212) 219-0017; espasso.com.

Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front, opened his presidential campaign on the battlefield of Valmy in the northeast, where in 1792 a French revolutionary army fended off an invading force of Prussians seeking to restore Louis XVI to the throne. The battle was an important victory of the French Revolution, and the symbolism was typical of the 78-year-old Mr. Le Pen, who shocked France in the 2002 elections by finishing second to Jacques Chirac. He told a gathering of several hundred followers that he called on everyone in France, including ''the French of foreign origin,'' to rally around his crusade against illegal immigration. He wants France to expel all illegal immigrants, estimated at as many as 400,000. His backing has increased in recent months, a result of the riots that swept through France's poor and mainly immigrant suburbs last year. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

Receiver Laveranues Coles was walking off the field after the Jets' season-ending victory against the Bills on Jan. 1 when a Bills' linebacker approached him and made a homophobic comment having to do with Coles's revelation earlier in the season that he was molested as a child. Coles was asked if the comment by the player, whom he refused to identify but who is still with the Bills, would add to his motivation to perform well Sunday. ''No,'' Coles said. ''I compete. I play hard.'' He added: ''People are going to have negative things to say. There's nothing I can do about that.''
To the Editor: ''The Pope's Act of Contrition'' (editorial, Sept. 20) is unfair to Pope Benedict XVI.

An article on Friday about the discovery of a low-density planet rendered its name incorrectly. It is HAT-P-1b, not HAT-1-P. The article also misstated the density of Jupiter. It is 133 percent as dense as water, not 133 percent greater in density. (HAT-P-1b is about one-fourth as dense as water.)

Michael Anastassiades, a London designer, does not inspire dull moments. Schooled in engineering and industrial design, Mr. Anastassiades, above, combines his technical and creative know-how to make bedside tables that double as vibrating alarm clocks, cups that store voice messages when upside-down (and play them back when turned right side up) and the so-called Social light, which is activated by ambient noise (its counterpart, the Anti-Social light, illuminates in the absence of sound). ''I'm interested in creating a deeper, more psychological relationship between the object and the user,'' said Mr. Anastassiades, 39, a native of Cyprus, who has also designed fashion show sets for the clothing designer Hussein Chalayan.

A methane explosion and fire ripped through a large coal mine, killing at least 41 workers. A number of miners were missing, but more than 300 others managed to escape to safety, according to local reports. The sprawling Lenin coal mine in the central Karaganda region is owned by Mittal Steel of the Netherlands, Kazakhstan's biggest employer. ILAN GREENBERG (NYT)

CHOOSING a blanket used to have more to do with climate than style. But now many blankets are seasonless in homes that are air-conditioned in summer and well heated in winter. Anki Spets, the owner of Area, a bed linen company in New York, said that a cotton blanket is warm enough for most people year round. But there are blankets in other fibers for those who enjoy changing their beds as the seasons change -- or those who like snuggling up beneath cashmere, wool or silk. 1. Southern Donegal, a cashmere spread by Ralph Lauren, is $3,800 in queen size and $4,000 in king; at Ralph Lauren, 867 Madison Avenue (72nd Street), and other stores (locations: 888-475-7674). 2. The Reversible Pinstripe blanket, of medium-weight wool in gray or chocolate brown, comes in twin ($210), full/queen ($270) and king ($330); at Williams-Sonoma Home, wshome.com or (888) 922-4108. 3. Woven of soft, lofty alpaca, Eileen Fisher's Ultra-Soft Alpaca Blanket in white, oatmeal or chocolate brown comes in twin ($298), full/queen ($398) and king ($478); from Garnet Hill, garnethill.com or (800) 870-3513. 4. A blend of 70 percent bamboo fiber and 30 percent cotton, West Elm's blanket comes in brown, orange or gray. A twin size is $79, full/queen is $99 and king is $119; westelm.com or (888) 922-4119. 5. This luxurious four-ply cashmere blanket, which comes in brown, white or red (other colors can be special-ordered), is $500 for a queen size and $595 for a king; from chicstuff.com or (323) 876-7719. 6. Washable cotton Alma blankets come in queen size ($235) or king ($280); from Area, arealinenshop.com or (212) 924-7084. 7. A soft-to-the-touch blanket in a silk, polyester and cotton blend comes in all bed sizes, for $99.99 to $179.99, at Target; target.com or (800) 800-8800. 8. Hudson's Bay Point Blankets have been sold at L. L. Bean since 1925. Quintessential wool bed coverings, they come in all sizes, from twin to king, for $249 to $399; llbean.com or (800) 441-5713.

An article last Thursday about Hortulus Farm in Wrightstown, Pa., misstated the farm's hours. Its nursery is open Monday through Saturday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., year round. Its gardens are open from May through October.

Seiler, M.D., Pres. $(6$)DONER--Sylvia. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind note with sorrow the death of Sylvia Doner, beloved mother-in-law of Lawrence Goldschmidt, our esteemed Board Member and former Chairman. Our deepest sympathies to Larry, his wife Maya and the entire family. Pauline Raiff, Bd. Chairman Alan R. Morse, Pres. & CEO

ROSENBERG--Michael J. The NYU community mourns the loss of its devoted alumnus and trustee, Michael Rosenberg. A recipient of an MBA from NYU's Leonard N. Stern School of Business, he had a distinguished business career, and was decorated for valor for his military service in Korea. He served NYU with devotion; he was twice elected President of the NYU Club, was a recipient of the NYU Alumni Association Meritorious Service Award, was chair of the Stern Fund Steering Committee, was immediate past president of the NYU Alumni Association, and was elected a Trustee Associate in 1997. He was a warm and caring man, and his generosity to NYU and other institutions with his time, his energy, and his wisdom exemplified the finest traditions of the University and speaks volumes about his character. On behalf of the NYU community, we extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Kathleen, his daughters Emily Roth and Ann Rosenberg, and all his loved ones. His absence will be keenly felt by us all. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU

AUDITORS TURN AGAINST INTERIOR -- Four government auditors who monitor leases for oil and gas on federal property say the Interior Department suppressed their efforts to recover millions of dollars from companies they said were cheating the government. Many of the accusations appear in four lawsuits unsealed in Oklahoma. [Page A1.] JAPAN'S FEARS ABOUT QUALITY -- A recent surge in recalls of defective products has set off national hand-wringing and soul-searching in Japan. Even in noodle shops, the conversation turns to bruised pride and fears that Japan may be losing its edge. [A1.] PROFIT SOARS AT MORGAN -- Morgan Stanley reported its third-quarter profit rose 59 percent, to $1.85 billion, from the quarter a year earlier, excluding a one-time charge in the 2005 quarter. The results were a further sign that changes put in place by the chief executive, John J. Mack, above, were taking root. [C13.] HEDGE FUND SELLS ENERGY TRADES -- Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that lost $5 billion betting on natural gas prices, sold its book of energy trades to a partnership that includes J. P. Morgan and Citadel Investment Group, according to two people briefed on the negotiations. [C1.] FED HOLDS RATES STEADY -- The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted to keep interest rates unchanged, committing themselves for the second time in six weeks to the proposition that the slowing economy will eventually dampen a still-troublesome inflation rate. [C1.] DECISION LIFTS STOCKS -- Wall Street closed higher, holding on to its gains after the Federal Reserve kept short-term interest rates steady. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 72.28 points, to 11,613.19. [C13.] TRIBUNE SHOWDOWN AVERTED -- A showdown between top executives of The Los Angeles Times and the newspaper's owner, the Tribune Company, has been temporarily averted. Now the Tribune board is expected to focus on another problem: a demand by the company's biggest investor to unravel partnerships with Tribune. [C1.] AMERICAN-CHINESE DIALOGUE -- The United States and China, struggling to surmount the discord in their economic relations, established high-level teams in both countries to conduct a ''strategic economic dialogue,'' to be led on the American side by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary. [C3.] H.P. INVESTIGATION -- Internal investigators in the Hewlett-Packard spying case sought in January to meet with and describe particulars of the investigation to the chief executive and chairwoman, according to e-mail exchanges. [C3.] AIR STRATEGY -- Gas guzzling and noisy, the MD-80 is the aging, seemingly indestructible jalopy of the skies. Allegiant Air, an upstart low-cost carrier based in Las Vegas, has built a quirky but profitable strategy around the plane. [C1.] F.D.A. NOMINATION ADVANCES -- A Senate committee voted to approve Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach, the acting commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, to head the agency, but hurdles to his confirmation remain. [A27.] DEFENDING CHEMICAL PLANTS -- After nearly five years of debate over whether the chemical industry should be required to better protect plants against a terrorist attack, a fierce struggle is going on behind the scenes in Congress to deal with one of the nation's most serious vulnerabilities. [A29.] CHILD PORNOGRAPHY INITIATIVE -- As part of the battle against child pornography on the Internet, an initiative has begun that would allow sites offering illicit images of minors to be shut down or blocked. The initiative is expected to be announced at a Congressional hearing. [A22.] PENNEY'S NEW LABEL -- J. C. Penney, which has created billion-dollar in-store brands like Arizona and St. John's, is making its biggest bet yet on a private label with the introduction of Ambrielle, a line of intimate apparel products set to reach stores in January. [C3.] WAL-MART DRUG PLAN -- Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer and a lightning rod for criticism of employer health benefits, will announce an experiment to offer generic prescription drugs to its workers and customers at sharply reduced prices. [C4.] ICAHN ELECTED TO IMCLONE BOARD -- Shareholders of ImClone Systems elected Carl C. Icahn and two associates to the board in the hope that the billionaire investor could help stabilize the company. Mr. Icahn called again for the ouster of the ImClone chairman, David M. Kies. [C6.] 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' CHANGES -- NBC announced changes to its perennial late-night hit ''Saturday Night Live,'' paring the cast from the 16 performers of last season to 11 for the coming season. The cuts come as many institutions at NBC have been asked to find budget savings. [E3.] ONLINE NOTIONS ON HIGH AND LOW FINANCE -- Floyd Norris discusses the implications of the Amaranth Advisors hedge fund disaster in his blog at norris.blogs.nytimes.com. HOME AWAY -- From tropical storms to full-fledged hurricanes and tornados, managing a second home means dealing with whatever mother nature dishes out from afar. A report is at nytimes.com/realestate. HELPING HUNGRY WORKERS -- Elite firms are balancing job demands by simplifying the quest for food. A report is at jobmarket.nytimes.com.

The Philadelphia Orchestra plans to announce today that it has become the first major United States orchestra to open its own downloadable music store online. While many orchestras sell downloads through third parties like Apple's iTunes service, the Philadelphia Orchestra intends to open its own store at www.thephiladelphiaorchestra.com featuring a free download of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony as performed last September with Christoph Eschenbach conducting. The site also intends to offer more than a dozen other recent and archival performances, with additions throughout the coming season. Full symphonies will generally cost about $5 in MP3 format and $6 in a higher-quality format called FLAC. To create the site, the orchestra has worked with nugs.net, an online music company best known for creating music download sites for rock acts. SETH SCHIESEL

Because of editing errors, an article in some copies yesterday about primary elections in Massachusetts and Washington State misstated the surname and the business background of the winner of the Republican Senate primary in Washington. He is Mike McGavick, not McGavin. He is the former chief executive of Safeco, an insurance company with more than 9,000 employees and revenue of more than $6 billion; he is not a former insurance salesman.

INTERNATIONAL A3-20 Pope Re-clarifies Remarks; Non-Muslim Dissent Grows Three days after saying he was ''very sorry'' about the reaction to his remarks on Islam, Pope Benedict XVI sought to clarify them again. But around much of the world that is not Muslim, there were voices saying the pope did not need to keep explaining himself. A4 Higher Death Toll in Baghdad A new United Nations report says that 5,106 civilians in Baghdad died violent deaths during July and August, a number far higher than reports that have relied on figures from the city's morgue. A18 A Mideast Force From Germany Germany's Parliament voted to send troops to patrol the waters off Lebanon, after resisting sending soldiers to the Middle East for fear of potential clashes with Israeli troops. A19 Japan Secures Next Leader After securing the Liberal Democratic Party's presidency, Shinzo Abe will become Japan's first prime minister born after World War II, with a clear eye toward re-examining the postwar era. A12 Africa to Extend Darfur Mission The African Union declared it would extend the life of its peacekeeping force in Darfur and seek to persuade Sudan to accept United Nations participation in the area. The New-York Historical Society announced that it would mount a $3.5 million exhibition, ''New York Divided: Slavery and the Civil War,'' to open on Nov. 17. The show will present about 300 artifacts, documents, drawings, maps and other images in a sequel to last year's exhibition ''Slavery in New York,'' which drew 175,000 visitors. The time frame of the first show ended in 1827, when black New Yorkers celebrated emancipation in New York State. Dr. Louise Mirrer, the society's president, said the new show would focus on the persistent effects of racism in the state and New York City through the Civil War and Reconstruction, including the draft riots of 1863, as well as the economic and political connections between New York and the system of slavery. The exhibition will document the ways in which ''New York was the economic capital of the capital that was financing the South,'' said James Oliver Horton, the Benjamin Banneker Professor of American Studies and History at George Washington University, the exhibition's chief historian. GLENN COLLINS

In December 1971, John Lennon sang at an Ann Arbor, Mich., concert calling for the release of a man who had been given 10 years in prison for possessing two marijuana cigarettes. The song he wrote for the occasion, ''John Sinclair,'' was remarkably effective. Within days, the Michigan Supreme Court ordered Mr. Sinclair released. What Lennon did not know at the time was that there were F.B.I. informants in the audience taking notes on everything from the attendance (15,000) to the artistic merits of his new song. (''Lacking Lennon's usual standards,'' his F.B.I. file reports, and ''Yoko can't even remain on key.'') The government spied on Lennon for the next 12 months, and tried to have him deported to England.

GRUBER--Wendy. The award-winning and noted artist died peacefully in her Tiburon, CA home on September 12, 2006 from complications of leukemia. She was 55 years old. Originally from New Jersey, Wendy painted ''en plein air'' capturing the beauty of her beloved Marin County, Latin America and Europe. Her paintings are now part of private and public collections throughout the country. Wendy is survived by her husband Rick Klein of Tiburon, CA, her parents Alice and Jesse Gruber of Lake Hopatcong, NJ, and Key Biscayne, FL, her brothers and sisters-in-law Peter and Madeleine Gruber of Miami, FL and Michael and Laryssa Gruber of Lake Hopatcong, NJ, her sister and brother-in-law Kathy and Gary Sharpless of Sherborn, MA, and by a niece and six nephews. Donations can be made to the ''Wendy Gruber Art Scholarship Fund''-Box 713, Tiburon, CA 94920.

And dreamy Meredith (Ellen Pompeo, above left) ponders the fate of her heart after her hospital assignation with Derek. ''Grey's Anatomy: Complications of the Heart,'' an hourlong special of highlights from this coming season and last, leads in at 8. 9 P.M. Tonight, an aspiring dancer is killed backstage during a Cirque du Soleil performance in Las Vegas, John Mayer performs two singles from his album ''Continuum'' in a cameo role, and Danny Bonaduce plays a former rocker who gets his. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MURDER CITY -- How'd they manage that? A couple of lovers are killed by a single bullet as they share a bed in a London hotel room. 10 P.M. (CBS) SHARK -- A shrewd defense lawyer has a pang of conscience and switches teams in this new drama series. James Woods (right) is Sebastian Stark, who decides to play for theprosecution after he wins the freedom of a particularly nasty client; Jeri Ryan is the ambitious D.A. who despises his ruthless strategies. Spike Lee directed this pilot episode. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The major candidates for governor here have signature attributes of generations of Massachusetts politicians. They have Irish surnames and Harvard degrees, and both rose to financial prosperity from humbler origins. But this election bears little resemblance to a classic Massachusetts race.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about radio talk shows aimed at women developed by a new company, GreenStone Media, misspelled the given name of a host at one point. She is Maureen Langan, not Mauren.

Catholic Channel Ready to Go on Air The Catholic Channel, announced in May, will begin broadcasts on Tuesday on Sirius Satellite Radio, the Archdiocese of New York and Sirius announced yesterday. On the air 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on Channel 159, it will include talk, a live daily Mass from St. Patrick's Cathedral, frequent appearances by Cardinal Edward M. Egan and University of Notre Dame football and basketball games. Bjork and Sugarcubes Reunite for Anniversary Bjork, below, will rejoin her old band, the Sugarcubes, to commemorate its 20th anniversary with a concert in Reykjavik, Iceland, on Nov. 17, the BBC reported. Proceeds from the reunion will benefit the band's record label, Bad Taste, one of the most important in Iceland, which releases albums by other bands, including Sigur Ros and Gus Gus. Bjork said on her Web site, bjork.com, that the money would allow the company ''to continue to work on a nonprofit basis for the future betterment of Icelandic music.'' The Sugarcubes had the top single in Britain, ''Hit,'' in 1992 but dissolved soon after, when Bjork left to pursue her solo career. Footnotes Justin Bond, perhaps better known as the boozy and bedeviled songbird Kiki, half of the team Kiki and Herb, will appear tomorrow night with the backup band Freudian Slippers and the performance artist Meow Meow at the Spiegeltent at South Street Seaport. The Gypsy guitarists Tchavolo Schmitt, Dorado Schmitt and Samson Schmitt will appear with the accordionist Ludovic Beier, the violinist Alexandre Cavaliere, the bassist Brian Q. Torff and nightly guests at the Django Reinhardt Festival at Birdland in Manhattan from Nov. 7 to 12. Rachael Ray, the Food Network host, has teamed up with Epic Records to issue a series of recordings of songs chosen by her, as well to distribute ring tones featuring messages from her.

For Johnny Damon, it was the perfect convergence of joy and duty. The Yankees' game had ended with a 3-2 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays on Wednesday night, but the scoreboard told the players that the Boston Red Sox were also losing. They all knew what that meant.

Responding to a rising national fury, the government fired the health minister, Yerbolat Dosayev, along with the governor of South Kazakhstan Province, where 55 children, including infants, contracted H.I.V. through blood transfusions and injections at a hospital in the city of Shymkent. The dismissals were for ''poor performance of their duties,'' an official with Kazakhstan's Security Council said. Tests have been completed on just half of the nearly 9,800 children under 3 who were patients at the children's hospital and are thought to have been exposed to contaminated blood and needles. Health care workers were frequently critical of Mr. Dosayev, whose background is in finance and banking. ILAN GREENBERG (NYT)

An obituary on Saturday about the iconoclastic Italian journalist Oriana Fallaci misstated the title of one of her books and its publication date, and described incorrectly an element of the plot. The English title of the book is "Letter to a Child Never Born," not "Letter to a Child Unborn." It was published in 1975, not 1976, and it is about a single woman's conversation with a child that she ultimately miscarried, not aborted.
SHEFLIN--Eric, D.O. The NYS Chapter of the ACOFP mourns the loss of our past executive director, who dedicated over 35 years to his patients, colleagues and profession.

Galas like the New York City Opera's ''Night at the Opera'' on Tuesday night are part music, part self-celebration and part sales pitch. The targets and the beneficiaries were dressed-up patrons who, the company hoped, would enjoy the talent both young and older and leave behind some money afterward. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke. The company's intendant, Paul Kellogg, spoke. Beverly Sills spoke. Plácido Domingo spoke from California via recording. Carol Vaness spoke (four times). Julius Rudel, whose connection with the City Opera goes back to World War II, conducted two numbers. Old-timers who later moved on and up in the opera world -- Ms. Vaness, Vinson Cole and Samuel Ramey -- sang.

In a big week for new releases, Justin Timberlake's ''FutureSex/LoveSounds'' (Jive) sold 684,000 copies, earning Mr. Timberlake, the former 'N Sync star, his first No. 1 for a solo album. John Mayer's ''Continuum'' (Columbia) opened at No. 2, with 300,000 copies sold last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Bob Seger's first album in 11 years, ''Face the Promise'' (Capitol), reached No. 4. (Billboard also reported that Mr. Seger might go on tour this fall for the first time in a decade.) Lionel Richie's ''Coming Home'' (Island) opened at No. 6, returning him to the Top 10 after 20 years. The Mars Volta's new ''Amputechture'' (Universal) reached No. 9. Last week's biggest seller, Beyoncé's ''B'Day'' (Columbia), fell to No. 3, with 162,000 sales, a 70 percent decrease from last week, and Bob Dylan's ''Modern Times'' (Columbia), which topped the chart two weeks ago, fell two spots to No. 5. BEN SISARIO
For the first time New York's Metropolitan Opera allowed the public to attend, free of charge, the final dress rehearsal of Puccini's Madama Butterfly. (Producer: Matthew Orr)
Jillian Straus fell in love with Brian Sampson while researching a book that discusses the obstacles of falling in love for today's 30-somethings. (Producer: Michele Monteleone)
Meet the Friedmans, an empty-nester couple who recently bought a West Village pied-a-terre, as they get to know their new neighborhood. (Producer: Jigar Mehta)
"Lending," says The Economist in this week's cover article, "is a sober business punctuated by odd moments of lunacy"
Shortwave radios are all but dead. The International Herald Tribune's Doreen Carvajal explains the historical value of the dying technology.
The Caucus turns a mere two weeks old, and it's the beginning of the High Holy Days and Ramadan.
A friend of Mike Bloomberg is a friend of Jeanine Pirro. But is a friend of Rick Santorum still a friend of gay people?

One of the goals of this trip was to take someone with fresh eyes. How long does it take for fresh eyes to lose their gleam? This morning we visited a village that, in 2003, had been destroyed. Bandits burned down every house, leaving only one unharmed. The houses have all been rebuilt now, but bandits intermittently attack those who own cattle or kidnap children and demand a ransom.

During last evening's taping of C-SPAN's "Newsmakers," Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, told Sheryl Gay Stolberg of The Times that she would be coming to Connecticut next month to campaign beside Joe Lieberman in his independent bid to hold onto his Senate seat:

Patricia C. Dunn, the Hewlett-Packard chairwoman who ordered a controversial investigation into leaks at the company, will step down immediately, to be succeeded by company C.E.O. Mark Hurd. Friday's announcement came as H.P. made its first public comments on the spying scandal that has enveloped the company in recent weeks.
When I wrote about Prudence the first time, readers reached for their wallets and asked how they could help. I've been thinking about it for a week, and here are some suggestions.

Buckeye television viewers must be bleary-eyed by now, from all the political ads flooding their airwaves. Ohio's Senate race is one of the most closely watched in the country. It tops the list for the most money spent on political commercials among this year's Senate contests, nearly $8.26 million since May.
A reader, Michael Wolfe of Westport, Conn., who earlier wrote about the pain of receiving zeros from star players, takes a stab at "How to Respond to Ridiculous Trade Offers." Take it away, Mike:
This is the second installment of our Political Books Best Seller List.
The improbable happens.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Sept. 22 column, "Anyone, Anything, Anywhere."
"Insurance Horror Stories"

Merrill Lynch analyst Edward Najarian has downgraded Wachovia Securities after he "reassessed" the bank's planned acquisition of Golden West Financial. He now rates Wachovia's stock "neutral," down from a "buy."
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Sept. 22 column, "Insurance Horror Stories"
From today's mailbag:

Lighter regulatory oversight at the InterContinental Exchange, the Atlanta-based electronic futures exchange, may have contributed to last week's $6 billion loss at hedge fund Amaranth, some industry analysts say. The debate about commodities-trading rules comes as energy traders have been increasingly taking their business to the ICE rather than the New York Mercantile Exchange, which has stricter reporting requirements.
In his "On Language" column in the upcoming issue of The New York Times Magazine, William Safire takes note of Internet sock puppets and other unsavory phenomena:

So much talk these days focuses on the ever-larger sums that private equity investors are willing to pay for their takeover targets. So it was refreshing to hear about the deal MFI, Britain's largest furniture retailer, struck for its 200-store retail arm with buyout shop Merchant Equity Partners.
An advertisement by the independent group Progress for America leads with the words "These people want to kill us."
The N.R.S.C. on immigration. The ads says that Democratic challenger Sherrod Brown "let us down."
Democratic challenger Sherrod Brown on U.S. trade agreements.
The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee on taxes and U.S. trade agreements.

With Rosh Hashana and the High Holy Days beginning Friday evening,some readers of The Caucus were quite offended by Senator George Allen's comments about the fact that, even though he's now disclosed his Jewish heritage, he still had a ham sandwich for lunch the other day. Anne Kornblut takes a look at the mix of religion and politics in the wake of Senator Allen's week. He's talking on Friday at the Family Research Council's "Values Voter Summit."

While some Democrats are talking up the party's Dan Maffei's chances of defeating Representative James T. Walsh this fall, independent analysts say the Republican incumbent is in much better shape than he appeared to be a few months ago.
No, this is not a post about Senator George Allen eating traife - that is, non-kosher food.
The N.R.S.C. on immigration. The ads says that Democratic challenger Sherrod Brown ''let us down.''

Dozens of hedge funds have withdrawn their registrations with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the wake of a court decision that threw out a more-stringent oversight rule, Bloomberg News reported Friday. The figure is not exactly the mass exodus that some in the industry had anticipated, but it does suggest that the court's ruling is having an effect.
Democratic challenger Sherrod Brown on U.S. trade agreements.
The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee on taxes and U.S. trade agreements.

Texas"How hard could it be?" asks Kinky Friedman, a country music satirist running for governor of Texas. The real difficulty is in keeping track of all the (viable) candidates. Meanwhile, Mr. Friedman has been taking heat for his racially charged comments.
John Faso, disguised in a woman's creepy voice, breaks with Campaign Strategy 101 and embraces a darkly negative and pessimistic message for his first campaign ad in the race for governor.

Kevin Hunsaker is the Hewlett-Packard senior counsel who oversaw the company's investigation of media leaks. At one point, he reportedly updated Chairwoman Patricia Dunn in an email on the fake product information that, using a fake persona ("Jacob"), he fed to a CNET News.com reporter in an attempt to track the leaks. "I won't quit my day job," he wrote to Ms. Dunn, "but hopefully neither the name nor the information on the slide are terribly off-base."
The House Ethics committee found no problem with this situation:

"We proposed a more direct approach to bringing clarification. This one is more of the scenic route, but it gets us there," said Dan Bartlett, White House counselor, of the agreement reached with rebellious Republican senators on detainees.

Fifty-six percent of the public agreed that the government would work better if all-new people were elected this year, according to a nationwide Times/CBS News poll published in Thursday's paper. Some of the respondents agreed to follow-up interviews:

The proposed $4.1 billion buyout of West Corporation has triggered litigation and some sharp criticism from a few institutional shareholders who claim the offer price is too low. But directors and officers are probably not complaining. A recent filed proxy statement highlighted by Footnoted.org notes that, as a group, West's directors and officers stand to receive more than $98 million in payments for options that have vested or will vest as a result of the merger.

Fridays are normally slow here at the Buzz -- but do we have a treat for you. Our own Michael Cooper rolls out a close look at G.O.P. gubernatorial nomineee John Faso's past work as a lobbyist, including one incident in particular: Mr. Faso's role in one of the biggest financial deals in state history. Read it now, so you aren't baffled by Eliot Spitzer's attack ads later.
Single women in this country are so, so bitter about Iraq.

I note the hand-baggage restrictions at airports in North America and Britain since the airline bomb scare in August. But is a similar degree of vigilance applied to checked luggage? And will mobile phones be banned as carry-on items in view of their suspected role in terrorist acts in London and Madrid, and their potential to interfere with flight navigation? - Joseph Ting, Brisbane, Australia

In the fall, the crowds begin to subside. Roads clear, animals come out of hiding and coveted rooms at lodges inside America's most popular national parks open up. Share your experiences visiting the national parks in the off-season.
I live in a market-rate rental apartment that is in a building that was converted to a co-op. Do I have to vacate?

Georgetown law professor Marty Lederman, as usual, offers the most influential analysis (at least among critics of torture) of the deal struck by the White House with Senators Graham, McCain and Warner on the rights of detainees and the obligations of the government under the Geneva Conventions. Lederman headlines his instant take, in part: "U.S. to be First Nation to Authorize Violations of Geneva." Josh Marshall of Talking Points Memo puts it this way: The Senate "agreed not to reinterpret the Geneva Conventions," so that the Bush administration could "continue violating them."

An executive with the United States unit of Samsung Electronics of South Korea agreed to plead guilty and serve prison time for taking part in price fixing in the computer memory chip business, the Justice Department said yesterday.
These days, it takes a billion -- at least.

For those who think they have heard it all when it comes to backdating -- the big names, the criminal and civil charges -- think again. In restating its earnings for the past three years and for the first quarter of 2006, Cablevision Systems admitted the strangest instance of backdating yet.
A high-flying trader takes big risks and produces spectacular returns before imploding - and possibly taking the firm down with him.
Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, to explain what appears to have been a greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated.

Blackstone Group, Nordic Capital and CSFB Private Equity will buy Altana's pharmaceutical unit for 4.5 billion euros ($5.7 billion) to expand market access for Nycomed Holding, a Danish drugmaker they own.
Connections made during Silicon Valley's late 1990's halcyon days have helped launch RingCube Technologies, a start-up developing technology for transferring data between computers.
Web 2.0 companies are all the rage these days, but how much money is actually flowing into this loosely defined category of next-generation Internet start-ups?

Like most technology investors, companies that made heavy bets on venture capital during the dot-com boom spent the last several years licking their wounds. Now they're getting back in the game, investing in start-ups from telecommunications to biotechnology.

Sir Richard Branson, the British magnate and adventurer, said yesterday that his personal profits from airlines and a rail company that he controls - a sum he estimated at $3 billion over the next 10 years - would be invested in developing energy sources that do not contribute to global warming.
Media software maker DivX on Thursday raised $145.6 million with an initial public offering that priced above its forecast range, according to an underwriter.
Riverbed Technology broke though what has been an ice-cold market for venture-backed initial public offerings Thursday as the company debuted 48 percent above its price range.

Reiterating their commitment to their $10.8 billion merger, NYSE Group and Euronext plan to create a Dutch foundation and a U.S.-based trust to protect the regulatory independence of the five stock markets that would be combined if the deal is completed.
Shares of China Merchants Bank, the country's most profitable lender, surged on their Hong Kong debut after investors ordered 53 times the stock offered in its $2.4 billion share sale.
Industrial & Commercial Bank of China may sell about 18 percent of the stock in its $19 billion initial public offering to about a dozen Hong Kong corporate investors, Bloomberg news reported.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and a group of takeover firms may pay above-average yields to borrow 4.5 billion euros ($5.7 billion) in Europe's biggest sale of non-investment grade bonds.
The global commodities investment surge, especially in oil and gas, has Russia's economy roaring. A shortage of office space, however, has put Moscow office prices on a par with London and Paris.

Andrew Clarke has resigned from law firm Allens Arthur Robinson to become managing director and head of M&A at Citigroup covering Australia and New Zealand. His new job starts at the beginning of 2007, and he replaces John Hanson who left for Merrill Lynch in August.
The buzz about Schering-Plough on Wall Street is that the company is in play.

MTV, the cable TV channel some critics have accused of straying too far from its musical roots, is to acquire Harmonix Music Systems, a maker of music-oriented video games, for $175 million in cash, The New York Times reported.
Washington Mutual is again the subject of takeover speculation.
The Dutch government agreed to sell its remaining 8 percent stake in Royal KPN, the biggest Dutch phone company, for about 1.7 billion euros ($2.17 billion).

Speculation is rising that the world's largest insurance broker, Marsh & McLennan, might orchestrate a multi-billion pound break-up of itself after it confirmed it was considering a sale of its fund management arm, Putnam Investments.
Is Facebook really worth $1 billion? Analysts easily agree the answer is yes. Whether it's worth that much to Yahoo, however, is a more complicated question.

As prospects for an equity alliance linking Renault and Nissan with General Motors appeared to fade, speculation is ramping up that Renault-Nissan C.E.O. Carlos Ghosn may resume talks with Ford Motor.

Tribune said Thursday night that it would consider selling any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations, a move that could reshape the media landscape. The properties include The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun.
Photographs from Casey Parks's trip to Africa with Nick Kristof.
A garment district loft, a Clinton Hill Queen Anne and more.
The Peculiar Works Project is marking the work of early downtown theatrical pioneers with a walking tour that will meander through Greenwich Village.
A tudor near Detroit, a Washington bungalow and more.
What I'm wearing now.
London's happening again. Finally. The hot young British designers, including Christopher Kane,  Marios Schwab and Todd Lynn.
Patricia Dunn resigned Friday, effective immediately, in the wake of the company’s ill-fated investigation of media leaks, Chief Executive Mark Hurd announced today.
On the ABC drama “Brothers and Sisters,” a black sheep returns home to find her siblings stressed.
Wandering the twisting streets of Guanajuato, Mexico, incites a kind of dream state in which the past overwhelms the present.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended yesterday that all adults and teenagers have H.I.V. tests as part of routine medical care. The agency also urged the removal of two major testing barriers: separate signed consent forms and lengthy counseling before each test.
A simple tale of beauty, the geek and the Internet, this Japanese romantic comedy follows the halting courtship of a 22-year-old nerd and his subway crush.
Michel Gondry's beguiling new film is so profoundly idiosyncratic, and so confident in its oddity, that any attempt to describe it is bound to be misleading.
The grim, dystopian world of this animated French film is the product of a computer technique that evokes the sharp, linear style of a graphic novel.
Like an electioneering candidate, Steve Zaillian's version of “All the King’s Men” makes a lot of promises but fails to deliver the goods.
Hector Galán’s film about the Texas trio of brothers who won a Grammy in 2005 is a worshipful disappointment.
Debased, infantile and reckless in the extreme, this compendium of body bravado and malfunction makes for some of the most fearless, liberated and cathartic comedy in modern movies.
The ambitiously genre-crossing yet disastrously executed “They’re Just My Friends” is hands down the most excruciatingly inept film to creep its way into theaters in some time.
Empty headed and egregiously polite, this nostalgia trip to the First World War is what you’d get if Norman Rockwell directed “Top Gun.”
Jet Li says goodbye (supposedly) to the martial arts genre with this decent blend of old-school chopsocky and new school superproduction.
If there were more experimental films as entertaining as this Hollywood ghost story, the notion of a thriving avant-garde cinema might not be so intimidating to the moviegoing public.
This riveting documentary explores Kids on Fire, a summer camp in Devils Lake, N.D., that grooms children to be soldiers in "God's army."
The newcomer Nathan Lopez delights as the flamboyantly gay Maxi, the youngest son in a family of thieves who falls in love with a handsome police officer.
In this furious documentary about the disenfranchisement of black voters, the director Ian Inaba builds a compelling case around the general elections of 2000 and 2004.
The crash was a setback to magnetic levitation technology, which aims to narrow the speed gap between trains and planes.
Patricia C. Dunn resigned over the disclosure of an internal spying operation. Also, two key members of H.P.’s investigation task force will leave, people briefed on the plans said.
The priest, Monsignor John G. Woolsey, 69, was accused of stealing more than $800,000 from his former church, St. John the Martyr.
Hamas’s position could complicate efforts to form a unity government and win renewed Western assistance.
Pakistan’s president tried to convince President Bush that he was not backing away from fighting the Taliban.
At former President Bill Clinton’s conference on global challenges, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for a concerted attack on the “feminization of poverty”
Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah told a crowd in Beirut that the militant group had 20,000 rockets and would never disarm.
Top stories from Russian newspapers on Friday.
The United States team is in the familiar role of pursuer after the morning four-ball matches were concluded today at the K Club course in County Kildare.
The agency is plagued with poor management and  internal squabbling, according to a report.
Palm, the maker of Treo smart phones, said profit slipped on stock option expenses and slow sales growth amid tougher competition.
The drugstore chain said its quarterly loss narrowed as a result of an income tax benefit and increased sales of generic drugs.
An executive with the U.S. unit of Samsung agreed to plead guilty for taking part in the price fixing of computer memory chips.
ConAgra Foods said quarterly profit fell 66 percent from a year earlier.
The world’s No. 1 maker of sport shoes said profit fell as stock-based compensation weighed on results.
Quarterly profit beat expectations on strong growth in its international, ground and freight segments.

A grand jury has indicted two women and one man on federal charges of participating in an interstate prostitution ring, prosecutors said yesterday. They are charged in connection with prostitution operations in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey, said Kevin O’Connor, the United States attorney in Connecticut. One suspect, Aleksander Dubogryzov, 44, a Ukrainian citizen living in Brooklyn, is accused of concealing the prostitution businesses by advertising them as massage parlors. Mr. Dubogryzov is accused of soliciting women, most from Eastern Europe, to work in the brothels.
A Harlem mother was arrested yesterday after her 3-month-old daughter accidentally drowned in a bucket of the mother’s vomit early Saturday morning, the police said.
The five innings that Pedro Martínez pitched were encouraging but inconclusive. He held the Marlins without a hit until the fifth, but then allowed four runs in that inning before departing.

House Republicans tentatively agreed to prohibit Customs agents from seizing prescription drugs that Americans buy in Canada and bring back into the United States. The deal would let Americans carry up to a 90-day supply of medication to the United States from Canada, House and Senate Republicans said. But it would not let Americans buy cheaper prescriptions over the Internet or by mail-order, officials said. Senator David Vitter, a Louisiana Republican, led the fight in the Senate to prohibit the seizing of prescription drugs at the border.

The International Committee of the Red Cross said a team that would travel to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in the coming days would not begin face-to-face visits with the 14 new detainees there until Oct. 1. Red Cross officials said the team would meet with other detainees and detention center officials next week before conferring with the 14 detainees who until this month had spent as much as four years in the secret custody of the Central Intelligence Agency. The team will then spend about two weeks on its first round of visits with the new prisoners.

A federal judge ruled in favor of Vice President Dick Cheney’s former chief of staff in a fight over release of classified information in the Valerie Wilson case. The judge, Reggie B. Walton of Federal District Court, decided that he would not impose strict standards sought by prosecutors who wanted to limit the classified information used in the trial of the aide, I. Lewis Libby Jr. Judge Walton said that once he rules on which evidence is relevant government lawyers could propose parts to be blacked out or summarized. Mr. Libby is accused of lying to the authorities about discussions he had with reporters about Ms. Wilson’s job at the Central Intelligence Agency.

A Superior Court judge chastised the state’s attorney general, saying his office had leaked to the press a letter telling relatives of 100 people killed in a nightclub fire that the club owners would plead no contest to involuntary manslaughter charges and that one would not face jail time. The judge, Francis J. Darigan Jr., said the leak was “unethical” and “reprehensible.” Judge Darigan said the court mailed its own letter to families Wednesday and that he had intended for them to receive word of the deal before the news media. The office of Attorney General Patrick C. Lynch had planned to send a separate letter telling families he objected to the deal, but his letter was faxed to a television station and was made public a short time later. He did not say if his office had faxed the letter to the station, and his spokesman did not return for comment.

Attorney General Steven Rowe asked a federal court to dismiss a lawsuit against the Maine Public Utilities Commission over inquiries into whether Verizon provided the phone records of state residents to the federal government. Earlier this year Verizon told the commission it did not provide Maine phone records to the government; when Mr. Rowe asked the company to confirm this in a sworn statement the federal government sued the state. Mr. Rowe said that the government did not have jurisdiction and that the government’s claim that “state secrets” would be divulged was not applicable.

Law-enforcement officials now believe that a marine who disappeared during a hike is alive, the Boulder County Sheriff’s office said in a news release. The sheriff’s office said it had uncovered videotape of a man officials believe is the marine, Lance Hering, 21, buying a bus ticket in Denver shortly after 6 a.m. on Aug. 30. That day rescuers began an elaborate search for Mr. Hering, who was on leave when he and a friend, Steve Powers, 20, went hiking in Eldorado Canyon. Mr. Powers said Mr. Hering fell during the hike and was knocked unconscious. On Wednesday, officials showed the videotape to Mr. Hering’s parents who, the sheriff’s office said, were 99 percent sure that their son is the person buying the ticket.
The results, for the first time, allowed state officials to pinpoint where student achievement falls off sharply.
Under special teams coach Mike Westhoff, the Jets’ special teams have consistently been among the best in the league.

Five years ago, Michael F. Bradway of Cornwall, Conn., told his in-laws that their grandson was gravely ill and might not live very long. His son had received a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, he said, and needed expensive care.
A Columbia University dean invited the president of Iran to speak and in less than a day, withdrew the invitation. That was long enough to put Columbia into another Middle East-related contretemps.
The proposal is more stringent than an industry-backed plan that many other Republican senators had already endorsed.
George Steinbrenner gave a surprising interview last week to The Associated Press and told the news service that his health is fine.
Two reporters were ordered jailed Thursday, pending an appeal, for refusing to testify about who gave them grand jury testimony from Barry Bonds and other elite athletes.
The Mets ended their relationship with Norfolk, Va., Thursday when they agreed to a two-year contract to make New Orleans their Class AAA affiliate starting next season.

Four men charged with firing shots at an Oslo synagogue on Sunday have also been accused of plotting to blow up the United States and Israeli Embassies in Oslo, said a lawyer for one of the suspects, a man of Turkish descent. Earlier, the police said they had expanded their charges against the four to include a charge of terrorism, but they gave no further details. A lawyer for another suspect, a Norwegian of Pakistani descent, confirmed that the terrorism charge referred to a plot to attack unspecified buildings.

Justice Minister Piet Hein Donner and Housing Minister Sybilla Dekker accepted responsibility for a catalog of safety failings cited in a long-awaited report into a deadly fire at a jail complex at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam last October, and they promptly resigned. The fire killed 11 illegal immigrants, but the report by the Dutch Safety Board said “there would have been few or no victims to mourn if fire safety had received attention.’’ The fire, which investigators said could have been caused by a discarded cigarette or arson, brought wide criticism of the government’s treatment of illegal immigrants. Last month, it decided that 39 survivors of the fire would be allowed to remain in the Netherlands.

The main opposition party, the center-right Fidesz, called off its planned antigovernment rally this weekend, which the government had warned would cause weeklong protests to escalate. The move lifted the hopes of Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany of the Socialist Party of riding out the storm of public anger set off by his admission, leaked to the press, that he had lied repeatedly about the economy to win re-election in April. Protesters, meanwhile, continued to gather in Budapest.
President Yahya Jammeh told supporters that he ruled through God and that “no coup d’état or elections can remove me.’’

Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski announced that he was firing his deputy, Andrzej Lepper, left, the leader of the small populist party called Self-Defense, abruptly ending the conservatives’ rocky coalition with the party and bringing the country to the brink of an early election. The firing came after weeks of bickering over the budget and plans to send more troops to Afghanistan. Mr. Kaczynski told a news conference that he would try to cobble together another majority in Parliament but also said a snap election was possible. The entry of Mr. Lepper, a onetime pig farmer who became a leading anti-European Union activist and whom critics accuse of demagoguery, into the coalition four months ago stunned many Poles and caused concern among Poland’s European partners, isolating Warsaw in the bloc. The leader of the opposition, Donald Tusk, said: “This was a wasted year, a year of argument and conflict. The only way out is an early election.”.

A court ruled in favor of teachers who objected to being forced to sing the national anthem at school events, saying the Tokyo city government’s orders to do so infringed upon freedom of thought. The ruling comes as conservative lawmakers, including Shinzo Abe, poised to become prime minister next week, seek to inject more patriotism into classrooms.

The authorities eased some of the restrictions on airline carry-on luggage imposed last month after the discovery of what the police said was a plot to bomb trans-Atlantic airliners. The Department for Transport said travelers would be allowed a single carry-on bag of roughly 22 inches by 18 inches by 10 inches, more than twice the volume currently permitted. The authorities also said musicians could take larger instruments on board, subject to a separate security check. Restrictions on liquids remain.

Afghanistan nominated Ashraf Ghani, a former finance minister and World Bank executive who is now the chancellor of Kabul University, to join six other announced candidates to succeed Secretary General Kofi Annan. Two straw polls of the Security Council have shown Ban Ki-moon, the foreign minister of South Korea, in the lead and Shashi Tharoor of India, the United Nations under secretary general for communications, second. The candidacy of the man in third place, Surakiart Sathirathai, the deputy prime minister of Thailand, has been cast into doubt by the coup on Tuesday that deposed Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister.

A court sentenced an Iraqi woman to death by hanging for her part in the bombings of three Amman hotels last November that killed more than 60 people. The woman, Sajida Mubarak al-Rishawi, confessed on television days after her arrest that she was to be the fourth suicide bomber but that her explosive belt had failed. Her lawyer argued that the confession had been made under duress. The other bombers, all Iraqis, including her husband, died. Investigators said at that time that she had participated because three of her brothers had been killed in Iraq. Ms. Rishawi showed little emotion in the packed courtroom as the verdict was read. Under the law, death sentences are automatically appealed.
The Giants play at Seattle on Sunday, where their kicker Jay Feely missed three potential game-winning kicks last season.
Officials urged the removal of two major barriers to testing: separate signed consent forms and lengthy counseling before each test.
Quality not quantity should be the federal government’s guide in setting payments to health care providers, said a report.
Brian Bruney's presence has helped rest the Yankees' bullpen and has given the team a third right-hander who throws 97 miles an hour.
Under the deal, President Bush dropped his demand that Congress redefine the nation’s obligations under the Geneva Conventions.
Senator George Allen of Virginia is in a growing group of political figures who discovered Jewish roots late in life.

A federal judge ruled yesterday that Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly could not testify as a defense witness or be deposed by plaintiffs in lawsuit over mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention. The plaintiffs, some of the hundreds of protesters arrested, had wanted to question Mr. Kelly on the policy decisions that led to the arrests. Defense lawyers argued, however, that Mr. Kelly should be exempt, in part because of the pressures of his schedule. Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV of Federal District Court made the ruling. A city lawyer, Peter Farrell, declined to comment. The New York Civil Liberties Union, which is representing the plaintiffs, said in a statement that he was disappointed by the ruling, but pleased that Mr. Kelly would not testify.

A painter who worked at the World Trade Center has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he stole more than $1 million by falsely claiming that he was permanently disabled in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The money came from the Department of Justice September 11th Fund. Prosecutors said it was the largest amount anyone had been accused of wrongly receiving from the fund. The painter, Michael Mastellone, 39, of East Windsor, N.J., faces up to 40 years in prison if convicted. He was released yesterday on $1 million bail. Peter Bark, Mr. Mastellone’s lawyer, said his back injuries and psychological problems had been confirmed by the fund’s doctors.

Princeton Day School was shut down yesterday after school officials found what seemed to be a threatening note left on the high school’s floor on Wednesday evening. After a police investigation, school officials determined that the note referred to a laser tag game being played by some students, said Michelle Ruess, a spokeswoman for the school. The school has 900 students from pre-kindergarten to 12th grade.

A trooper who the police believe was shot in the back by the former fugitive Ralph J. Phillips was semiconscious on Thursday after a month in a medically induced coma, the state police said. The trooper, Donald Baker Jr., 38, did not speak, but he opened his eyes and moved his head for the first time since the Aug. 31 shooting, said Rebecca Gibbon, a state police spokeswoman. Trooper Baker and Trooper Joseph Longobardo, 32, were ambushed by a sniper hiding in the woods outside the home of Mr. Phillips’s former girlfriend. Trooper Longobardo, who was shot in the leg, died from his injuries on Sept. 3.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has agreed to schedule two debates with her Republican rival, John Spencer, the former mayor of Yonkers.

An Ocean County man sent his 9-year-old son to school yesterday, then fatally shot his wife before turning the gun on himself, the authorities said. The police said an argument between the man, David Walters, 42, and his wife, Rosemarie, 37, ended with both lying dead in the garage of their house, while their 6-year-old daughter was sitting in the living room. The authorities had no immediate motive for the killings, and neighbors said there had been no signs of trouble. The police found the bodies after responding to an emergency call from Mr. Walters’s mother. The authorities said he had apparently called her to the house to care for his daughter.

Higher than normal levels of radium have been found in part of a federal park on Staten Island, the authorities said yesterday. The contamination was found during part of a counterterrorism operation: helicopter surveillance of the city to discover low-level radiation. A parcel the size of a football field in the park, the Gateway National Recreation Area, has been closed, the authorities said. Paul J. Browne, a spokesman for the Police Department, said that the site might once have been an industrial facility.

Two pedestrians whose identities were not released were struck in unrelated incidents yesterday morning, one by a sanitation truck, another by an M.T.A. bus. About 8 a.m. on Broadway near Driggs Avenue in Williamsburg, a 40-year-old woman walked into the path of a sanitation truck owned by Action Carting Environmental of Newark, the police said. She was listed in critical condition last night at Bellevue Hospital Center. The driver, Charles Patterson, 40, was charged with operating the vehicle with a suspended license. About 11 a.m., a 78-year-old man crossing 60th Street near Seventh Avenue in Sunset Park was struck by a B9 bus, the police said. He was listed in critical condition last night at Lutheran Medical Center.

Animal rights activists, upset by the death of a carriage horse in Central Park last week, demonstrated outside City Hall yesterday and called for a citywide ban on carriages. Juliet, a horse who spent 17 years taking visitors through the park, died last Friday, several hours after collapsing before a crowd of onlookers. “Manhattan’s streets are no place for a horse,” said Michael McGraw, a spokesman for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. Juliet, whose owner said she was probably stricken with colic, was the second carriage horse to die this year.

Japan’s trade surplus was sharply higher in August compared with a year earlier as companies shipped more cars and steel to global markets. The trade surplus widened 95.5 percent, to 200.5 billion yen ($1.71 billion) as exports to the United States grew 19.3 percent and sales to China expanded 20 percent, government data showed. The value of exports of automobiles to the United States rose 49.3 percent from a year earlier, the fastest pace since January 1997.

A German chemical and pharmaceutical company, Altana, said that it was selling its drugs business to Nycomed Holding of Denmark for 4.5 billion euros ($5.75 billion), following through on its intention to split the company and focus on its chemicals operation. Altana, based in Bad Homburg outside Frankfurt, is selling the business because it is too small to compete in the global drug industry. Altana said it would focus on its specialty chemicals business and keep its stock exchange listing. Nycomed, which focuses on prescription drugs for gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases, is owned by a consortium of private equity companies: the Blackstone Group, CSFB Private Equity, NIB Capital Private Equity and Nordic Capital. It will distribute Altana’s top-selling drug, the ulcer treatment Pantoprazol, in Nordic countries and Belgium.

ThyssenKrupp and Salzgitter, the largest steel makers in Germany, agreed to the highest wage increases for their workers in more than 10 years. Salaries for 85,000 workers at steel makers will increase 3.8 percent from the beginning of 2007, IG Metall, the steel workers’ union, said. Wages last rose that much in 1995, when they increased 4 percent. IG Metall had been seeking a 7 percent wage increase for 12 months, while employers had offered 3 percent.

Pernod Ricard, the liquor maker, said its annual profit rose less than forecast as a result of higher spending on advertising. Profit for the year ended June 30, excluding interest, taxes and amortization, was 1.26 billion euros ($1.6 billion), missing some analysts’ estimates. Net income rose 32 percent, to 639 million euros. The results are the first full-year numbers since Pernod bought Allied Domecq for $13 billion last year. Pernod, which is based in Paris, said it increased its marketing spending during the year to 1.04 billion euros from 593 million a year earlier.
Ela Medical, a producer of implantable heart devices, said it had received a subpoena seeking information about payments to doctors using its products.

Mr. Feelgood took the lead coming out of the final turn and held off Cactus Creek to win the Little Brown Jug in 1:503/5 yesterday in Delaware, Ohio. It is the second leg of the Triple Crown for 3-year-old pacers. Mr. Feelgood, the 9-5 favorite driven by Mark MacDonald, drew the No. 1 post position for the final but yielded the lead out of the starting gate. MacDonald won his first Jug by moving the colt from second to first down the stretch.

Bill Britton won his second consecutive New Jersey P.G.A. Championship yesterday when Frank Esposito Jr. three-putted from 3 feet for a bogey on the final hole. Britton sank a 5-foot putt to save par on the 18th green at Manasquan River Golf Club in Brielle, and then sat back and watched Esposito miss a short but slippery birdie putt to win the $57,000 tournament. Esposito ran his first putt 6 feet past the hole. He then missed his par putt coming back up the hill to give Britton a one-shot victory. Britton had a final round one-under-par 71 and finished at four-under 212.

Brian Savage retired from the N.H.L. yesterday after a 12-year career that included stops in Montreal, Phoenix, St. Louis and Philadelphia. Savage, 35, appeared in 647 regular-season games, recording 192 goals and 167 assists for 359 points. He played at Miami of Ohio and was selected by the Canadiens in the eighth round of the 1991 draft. Savage won a silver medal at the 1994 Olympics as part of Canada’s team. He also played for Canada at the 1993 and 1999 world championships. He had his best season in 1996-97, when he had 60 points on 23 goals and 37 assists in 81 games for Montreal.

The defender Kate Markgraf will return to the United States women’s team for the first time since giving birth to a son on July 18 when the Americans play Taiwan next month. Markgraf, who played for the World Cup champions in 1999, was one of 24 players invited to a training camp for the Oct. 1 game. Coach Greg Ryan will choose 18 players to face Taiwan.

The Discovery Channel team is dropping several riders who helped Lance Armstrong win one or more of his seven straight Tour de France titles. George Hincapie of the United States, long considered Armstrong’s most important teammate, is staying with the squad.

Atlanta Hawks guard Speedy Claxton is questionable for the beginning of the season after breaking a bone in his left hand. Claxton, who was injured during a workout Monday, was examined yesterday by Dr. Michael Bernot, a team physician, and will see the hand specialist Dr. Stephen McCollam today. Claxton, 28, was expected to be Atlanta’s starting point guard and signed a four-year, $25.5 million deal in July.

Parched and rugged terrain provided inspiration for the last album by the Gebhard Ullmann-Steve Swell Quartet, ''Desert Songs and Other Landscapes'' (CIMP). Not long before the album was recorded, the trombonist Steve Swell spent a few nights camping out in the Sahara. The German saxophonist and clarinetist Gebhard Ullmann, above, had traveled through the American Southwest. When the two musicians came together for a tour and subsequent recording in July 2004 -- with the flexible rhythm team of Hilliard Greene on bass and Barry Altschul on drums -- they easily found common ground in abrasive textures and arid atmosphere. Of course, given their chosen style of aggressive free improvisation, things might have turned out much the same even without a theme. Mr. Ullmann, a prominent figure on the Berlin avant-garde scene, has a tirelessly interrogatory approach to improvisation, as he has proven on recent albums. (His latest is a bare-bones trio recording, ''Cutitout,'' on Leo Records.) Mr. Swell is more of a blusterer, after the exuberant tradition of Roswell Rudd; but he also puts clear thought into his compositions and ensemble organization. (His band Slammin' the Infinite has a new release, ''Remember Now,'' on the Not Two label.) The band now known as the Ullmann/Swell 4 will be touring Europe for the first time this fall, but first it has a few dates in New York. No two performances will be alike, though it's safe to assume that certain qualities, including a sort of scorched-earth intensity, should carry over from one to the next. (Sunday at 9 p.m., Jimmy's No. 43, 43 East Seventh Street, East Village, 212-982-3006, freestylejazz.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. Wednesday at 8 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. Thursday at 8:30 p.m., Roulette at Location One, 20 Greene Street, at Grand Street, SoHo, 212-219-8242, roulette.org; $15.) NATE CHINEN

The authorities eased some of the restrictions on airline carry-on luggage imposed last month after the discovery of what the police said was a plot to bomb trans-Atlantic airliners. The Department for Transport said travelers would be allowed a single carry-on bag of roughly 22 inches by 18 inches by 10 inches, more than twice the volume currently permitted. The authorities also said musicians could take larger instruments on board, subject to a separate security check. Restrictions on liquids remain. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

To the Editor: It came right out in my hand, that U-shaped piece of rebar on the face of the Rinnenspitze in the Stubai area of the Austrian Alps that according to ''Hit the Heights, but Take the Stairs'' (Sept. 15) was supposed to be ''permanent and built to weather decades of exposure.'' Both feet were, fortunately, on firm rebar ladder rungs below as I held up the failed step for a picture on that trip in 1993. Betsy Carpenter Portola Valley, Calif.
KORNFELD--Irving. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Irving Kornfeld, associated with The Times from August 31, 1961 until retiring in September 1, 1980.

The Republican Congressional leaders who oversee Department of Homeland Security operations reached agreement Thursday on a plan that would give federal officials the power to shut down high-risk chemical plants that do not comply with proposed new anti-terrorism measures for that industry. The proposal is more stringent than an industry-backed plan that many other Republican senators had already endorsed.

Whitney Museum of American Art 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street Through Jan. 7 Some younger painters seem to be countering the strictures of late Modernism by revisiting the early Modernist cusp between abstraction and representation, an area that includes Mondrian's flower paintings, Jawlensky's masks and Malevich's robotlike peasants, where the figurative, the geometric, the spatial and the visionary still remain tangled. There they seek paths not taken, tangents not explored. That their searches have not been in vain is evidenced by work as varied as that of Tomma Abts, Wade Guyton, Eileen Quinlan, Sergei Jensen, Cheyney Thompson and a host of others, including the Los Angeles painter Mark Grotjahn.

Jennifer Aniston! On Broadway! O.K., it's for one night only, but she has been announced as one of the actors in the sixth annual ''24 Hour Plays on Broadway,'' in which 6 writers, 6 directors, 24 actors and production crews have 24 hours to write, direct and perform six 10-minute plays. Joining Ms. Aniston, above, for the event on Oct. 23 at the American Airlines Theater, will be Elizabeth Berkley, Rachel Dratch, Rosie Perez, Lili Taylor and Patrick Wilson. Proceeds go to Working Playgrounds, a nonprofit organization that supports arts in schools. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
