A 27-year-old man was killed in Queens last night when his motorcycle slammed into an oncoming city sanitation truck that was turning into a driveway, the police said. It was the second serious accident involving a sanitation truck this week.
Warren Buffett’s 2001 Lincoln Town Car was sold for $73,200 at a charity auction held on eBay’s Web site.
Chien-Ming Wang tied Minnesota’s Johan Santana for the major league lead in victories with 18 while Mariano Rivera and Gary Sheffield both returned in the Yankees win.
By The Associated Press.

Civilian employees rather than the police stopped an armed intruder at the Capitol, the authorities said. The man, Carlos Greene, 20, accused of carrying a loaded handgun and crack cocaine, assaulted one civilian employee and struggled with another before a third got him in a bear hug and officers caught up with him Monday, the police said. “It was the civilians who did have him corralled or subdued,” said Sgt. Kimberly Schneider, a police spokeswoman. “We were hot on his trail. We just didn’t get there in time.” On Monday, the acting chief of the Capitol Police, Christopher M. McGaffin, said his officers subdued Mr. Greene.

Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, said in a letter to followers this month that he was seriously ill, and he asked the Nation of Islam’s leaders to carry on in his absence to make sure the movement “will live long after I and we have gone.” Mr. Farrakhan, 73, said he began suffering pain earlier this year similar to 1998, when he was found to have prostate cancer and underwent surgery. He said doctors discovered an ulcer in his anal area during a visit to Cuba in March. Since then, he has lost 35 pounds while battling “serious infection and inflammation,” Mr. Farrakhan said in a letter dated Sept. 11 and published in the Nation of Islam’s newspaper The Final Call.

Hasbro Inc. is recalling parts of a toy workbench set after the deaths of two children who apparently choked on large plastic toy nails, company officials said. The company’s chief executive, Al Verrecchia, said the voluntary recall applied to two plastic nails in the Playskool Team Talkin’ Tool Bench. The workbench is designed for children ages 3 and older, company officials said. Both victims were younger than that. Consumers who return the nails will receive a $50 gift certificate. The toy was sold for about $35 at Toys R Us, Wal-Mart, Target, KB Toys stores and various other stores nationwide.

Federal prosecutors in Chicago dropped a charge that an alleged fund-raiser for the Palestinian group Hamas gave material support to terrorists, a move that surprised defense lawyers. Prosecutors gave no explanation in court and declined to comment afterward. The man, Muhammad Salah, 53, who has been the focus of a high-profile terrorism investigation for nine years, remains charged with racketeering conspiracy and lying by denying membership in Hamas.

A federal jury in North Dakota sentenced a convicted sex offender to execution for kidnapping and killing a college student in after she left a shopping mall Nov. 22, 2003. The man, Alfonso Rodriguez Jr., 53, of Crookston, Minn., was convicted Aug. 30 of kidnapping resulting in the death of the woman, Dru Sjodin, 22. North Dakota’s last execution was in 1905. The state no longer has the death penalty, but it is allowed in federal cases. Mr. Rodriguez was charged under federal law because Ms. Sjodin was taken across state lines.

Gov. Jeb Bush signed a death warrant for Danny H. Rolling, who pleaded guilty to the 1990 killings of five college students in Gainesville. Mr. Rolling is to be executed Oct. 25, Ms. Bush’s office said. Mr. Rolling, right, pleaded guilty in 1994 to the murders. Mr. Rolling, a drifter from Shreveport, La., terrorized Gainesville in late August and early September 1990, killing four women and a man in their off-campus apartments. One victim was decapitated and others were mutilated and sexually assaulted. Killed were Christa Hoyt, 18, of Gainesville; Sonja Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach; Christa Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; and Tracy Paules, 23, and Manny Taboada, 23, both of Miami.

Law enforcement authorities have identified the woman whose battered body was found after she was tied to a vehicle and dragged for more than a mile. The woman, Luz Maria Franco Fierros, 49, a fast-food worker whose body was found Monday, was identified by her fingerprints matched to Mexican voter registration records. Her live-in boyfriend, José Luis Rubi-Nava, is in jail, accused of killing Ms. Franco Fierros.
By The Associated Press.

The Mets lost for the sixth time in eight games, but that seems to be irrelevant. There are two goals for the rest of the regular season: avoid injuries and nurse players like Pedro Martínez back to full strength.

Amid renewed protests against Pope Benedict XVI on the Muslim day of prayer, the pope invited ambassadors from Muslim countries to meet him on Monday to tamp down tensions over his speech last week that portrayed Islam as tied to violence. He is to meet ambassadors accredited to the Holy See, along with his top official for inter-religious dialogue, at Castel Gandolfo, the papal summer palace outside Rome. A week and a half after he made his speech in German — quoting a medieval Byzantine emperor calling Islam “evil and inhuman” — protestors in Jordan, Afghanistan, Malaysia and other Muslim countries again demanded a fuller apology from the pope for the remarks.

The government said it would no longer offer a direct subsidy to the Catholic Church, ending a tradition of many decades that critics said blurred the separation between church and state. Taxpayers would still be able to earmark a certain percentage of their tax money for the church, so it would still receive public financing. But the government would no longer add to that amount. In exchange, the government said taxpayers would be able to direct a larger portion of their taxes each year to the church. The government provides the Catholic Church with about $170 million each year, about $35 million of it in direct subsidies.

The war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, is likely to begin in April. The United Nations-backed Sierra Leone Court, in The Hague for this trial, announced the date at a procedural hearing. Mr. Taylor, a former warlord and long one of West Africa’s most feared men, is now imprisoned here, charged with multiple crimes, including ordering the dragooning of children into combat, the hacking off of limbs and the killing of thousands of civilians in the 1990’s.

The military rulers appointed an anticorruption commission in what appeared to be a move toward investigating and perhaps seizing the assets of Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister stripped of his job by a coup on Tuesday. They also continued their search for an interim prime minister and received the official blessing of King Bhumibol Adulyadej in a ceremony broadcast on national television, where a statement was read on behalf of the king. His backing for the coup appears to be a main reason why former Thaksin supporters, even in rural areas considered the bastion of his support, now express support of the military takeover.

United Nations human rights monitors accused Sudan’s army of dropping bombs on villages in North Darfur this month, killing and injuring scores of civilians. “All indications are this kind of attack is continuing.” José-Luis Díaz, the spokesman for the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, told a briefing in Geneva. He said the “indiscriminate aerial bombardment by government aircraft” was a campaign against rebel movements that had not signed a peace agreement in May.

A tribunal sentenced Vladimiro Montesinos, Peru’s former intelligence chief, to 20 years in prison for brokering a deal to send 10,000 assault rifles to Colombian guerrillas. Judges ruled on evidence that put Mr. Montesinos, 61, in the middle of a complex web of negotiations to bring rifles from Jordan to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. Mr. Montesinos, the spymaster under former President Alberto K. Fujimori, is already serving a separate 15-year term on corruption charges at a high-security naval prison in the port of Callao.

A report from the Home Office acknowledged shortcomings in the handling of the aftermath of the London bombings 14 months ago that left some survivors and bereaved families “feeling forgotten and unimportant.” The 23-page report was the latest in a series of official analyses of the suicide bombing attacks on the London transportation system that killed 52 people. It said that in the aftermath “those trying to find loved ones found it difficult to get information about which hospitals people were being treated in.” There were “concerns about the time it took to identify victims,” the report said, and “some families were not kept in touch with the process of identification.” The authorities, it suggested, were overwhelmed, with the number of people calling about their relatives peaking at about 43,000 calls an hour. In addition, emergency services were communicating over overloaded cellphone systems and creaky radio networks.

Militants ambushed a bus carrying construction workers in the volatile south, killing 19 of the laborers. The attack in Kandahar Province began when a roadside bomb exploded near the bus, said Zmary Bashary, the Interior Ministry spokesman. Some of the laborers may have been killed by the bomb, while others were shot by militants who attacked the panicked workers with gunfire, he said. It was not immediately known who the laborers worked for.

A woman in western Lobez who grew marijuana to calm the nerves of her cow has been charged with cultivating a narcotic. The cow had been “skittish and unruly” — once breaking someone’s arm — until someone suggested mixing marijuana in with the feed, the woman told the police. The plants, grown from seeds bought at a market, reached nearly three yards tall, and the cow, the woman said, “became as calm as a lamb.”.
Savarin DeJesus was arraigned in the death of her 4-month-old baby, Niah Ford, who died after falling into a bucket partly filled with water, cleaning solution and Ms. DeJesus’ vomit.

Top-seeded Martina Hingis beat Tamarine Tanasugarn, 7-5, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the Sunfeast Open semifinals in Calcutta, India. Hingis will play fifth-seeded Sania Mirza, who beat Aravane Rezai, 6-4, 7-5.

The condition of forward Sam Ashaolu, one of five Duquesne players shot after a campus dance last weekend, was upgraded to serious from critical yesterday. Ashaolu, who was shot in the head twice, is the only player who remains hospitalized, and he has begun to speak softly.
Basketball.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York called for a concerted attack on the “feminization of poverty” to destroy political and economic barriers that trap women.

The Hall of Fame basketball coach Morgan Wootten will receive a kidney from his 33-year-old son, Joe, in an operation scheduled for next month. Morgan Wootten, 75, had the highest all-time winning percentage for a high school coach, .869 (1,274-192), over 46 years at DeMatha in Hyattsville, Md. He had a liver transplant in 1996.

Top-ranked Amélie Mauresmo defeated Lindsay Davenport, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the China Open in Beijing. Mauresmo beat Davenport for the first time in 10 matches, since the final of the Sydney International in 2000, and is 4-12 against her over all. Mauresmo will face sixth-seeded Jelena Jankovic, who topped Nadia Petrova, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.

The Champ Car driver Cristiano da Matta flew home to Miami from Wisconsin yesterday as he continued to recover from a head injury sustained in an accident Aug. 3, when his car collided with a deer during a test session at Road America in Elkhart Lake.

Point guard Dajuan Wagner, who has been out of the N.B.A. for almost two years, signed with Golden State yesterday. Wagner, drafted sixth over all by the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2002, was found to have colitis during the 2004-5 season, and his colon was removed last October.

Goalie Rick DiPietro and Ted Nolan, behind the bench in the N.H.L. for the first time in nine years, got off to rough starts last night in the Islanders’ first exhibition game, a 5-1 loss to Boston in Moncton, New Brunswick. DiPietro allowed 3 goals on 14 shots in 33 minutes in his first game since signing a 15-year, $67.5 million contract. Mike Dunham, in camp on a tryout, played the final 27 minutes in goal for the Islanders.

Evgeni Malkin, the second pick in the 2004 N.H.L. draft, will be out indefinitely after dislocating his left shoulder in his first game with the Pittsburgh Penguins, the team said yesterday. Malkin, who signed with Pittsburgh earlier this month after leaving his Russian Super League club, collided with his teammate John LeClair in a preseason game Wednesday against Philadelphia.

Karrie Webb moved into contention for her fourth L.P.G.A. Tour victory of the year, shooting a two-under-par 70 yesterday for a share of the second-round lead with Jeong Jang in the Longs Drugs Challenge in Danville, Calif.

The referee who was suspended after Oregon was mistakenly awarded possession after an onside kick in a victory against Oklahoma on Saturday will work today’s game between Southern California and Arizona. On Monday, the Pacific-10 Conference suspended the referee of the Oklahoma-Oregon game, Dave Cutaia, and the rest of the seven-man on-field crew for one game. But the suspensions must be staggered so the conference has enough officials to cover its games, the Pac-10 said. Arizona is coached by Mike Stoops, the brother of Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops.

State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi acknowledged this week that he had used a state employee as his wife’s chauffeur and that he failed to reimburse the state for some of those driving services despite his pledge more than three years ago to do so.
Patricia C. Dunn resigned and will be replaced by Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive. Also, two high executives who supervised investigators are said to be leaving.
The death of Nixzmary Brown, 7, in Brooklyn in January demanded a reckoning but time appears to be standing still in court.
Ever since Hugo Chávez, the president of Venezuela, held up a copy of Noam Chomsky’s “Hegemony or Survival” during a U.N. speech, sales have spiked.
Some say the bare-knuckled succession struggle for the presidency could foretell how robust South Africa’s young democracy is.
A visual survey of history’s less-than-subtle architectural downsizings.
Jeff Gordon ended a 47-race pole-position drought Friday by qualifying first for Sunday’s Nascar Nextel Cup race at Dover International Speedway.
Sheik Hassan Nasrallah told a mammoth crowd in Beirut that the militant group had 20,000 missiles and would never disarm.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 — As several Democrats and civic groups called Friday for an investigation into whether John Faso, the Republican nominee for governor, should have registered as a lobbyist for some work he performed last year, an official at the state’s lobbying commission suggested that an inquiry could already be under way.
The suit, launched against two top Republican officials in Texas, says that an antifraud law is being used to intimidate minority voters casting ballots by mail.
Dean E. Wooldridge was a crucial figure in the development of the technology of nuclear warfare in the 1950’s.
By The Associated Press.

An off-duty New York City police officer was killed and a colleague was injured and charged with drunken driving after the car they were riding in crashed on a Long Island highway early yesterday, the authorities said.
Amaranth Advisors pledges to regain investors’ trust after suffering $6 billion in natural gas trading losses.
Few in the automotive industry are betting that the latest drop in gas prices will undo the damage done to Detroit.
Feverish matchmaking during Bill Clinton’s second annual gathering on global problems netted 215 commitments.
Now named Athena, the vessel that sank the Andrea Doria 50 years ago revisits New York.
The report is likely to intensify a debate about the safety of the nation’s drug supply and the adequacy of government oversight.
The Europeans rode the emotion of Ireland’s first day as Ryder Cup host, racing out to a 5-3 lead over the United States.
Carl Pavano has not pitched for the Yankees in 452 days, but the team made sure his latest physical problem did not keep him out of the clubhouse.
The commander of United States forces in Baghdad said he needs 3,000 more Iraqi troops there but is having trouble getting them.
The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China’s I.P.O. could set a record by raising a projected $19 billion.
Antidoping officials this week formally charged Floyd Landis with using performance-enhancing drugs during this year's Tour de France.
A lawsuit charges the famed Lakeside Golf Club in California with sex discrimination and violating a host of state civil rights laws.
The Patriot Act and its sister Real ID provision have inadvertently damaged America’s excellent record of giving refuge to the persecuted.
Officials acknowledged that while a new strategic economic dialogue between the U.S. and China was an accomplishment, it does not equal achievement of results.
Republican leaders set the House and Senate on a path to approve a compromise struck with the White House over the prosecution of terrorism suspects.
Pay-per-click advertising fraud is becoming more pervasive as spurious clicks can be generated through automated programs.
Pakistan’s president tried to convince President Bush that the deal would rid lawless areas of Qaeda and Taliban influence.
The leaders of Venezuela, Iran and Sudan presented themselves as Davids of the third world seeking to slay the American Goliath.

Hundreds of uniformed city workers in the Reserves participated in a financial arrangement offered by the city and now many are discovering it can have huge costs.
Officials improperly selected the members of review panels that awarded large grants, a searing report found.
Lottery Numbers.
Federal officials narrowed their investigation and reminded consumers that spinach grown outside the three California counties implicated in the outbreak was safe to eat.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 22 (AP) — A giant liquefied natural gas terminal proposed for Long Island Sound poses safety and security risks that would require more firefighters, escort boats and other measures to prevent accidents or terrorist attacks, according to a Coast Guard report released Friday.
Quarterback Troy Smith and receiver Ted Ginn Jr. were boyhood friends and are now fueling Ohio State.
Google defied a court order to publish a ruling that prevents it from running summaries of news reports and links to articles in Belgium.
The listing of victims’ names around the pools marking the site of the twin towers has reached an intensely emotional impasse.
Congress should not allow conservative, anti-environmental ideologues  to tamper with the federal courts under a false mantle of reform.
The finding came a day after New York State released the results of the 2005-6 reading and writing exam.
A deal between the nation’s top two pork packing companies signals the future of American agriculture — do away with the farmer by doing away with competitive markets.
The U.S. regional commander cast the exercise as a step toward a deeper relationship he hopes to foster between the militaries.
The bill on jailing, interrogating and trying terror suspects contains narrow definitions of rape and sexual assault that must be fixed before Congress can responsibly pass the legislation.
The jury in the racketeering conspiracy trial of John A. Gotti deliberated Friday for a fourth day without reaching a verdict.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran spoke to about two dozen members of the Council on Foreign Relations on Wednesday.
Gazprom moved closer to being the monopoly supplier of Russian natural gas to Europe and may soon get a similar role in Asia.
The market reversed as some statistics suggested economic growth might be slowing more than traders had anticipated.
A 117-page offering memorandum suggests strongly that the days of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village as an unpretentious middle-class bastion in Manhattan may well be numbered.

In “Hegemony or Survival: America’s Quest for Global Dominance,’’ Noam Chomsky offers a broad critique of American foreign policy from the 1950’s to the Bush administration’s war on terrorism, arguing that United States actions in Cuba, Nicaragua, the Far East and elsewhere are part of a long tradition of foreign interventions carried out by an oppressive power. Excerpts follow.

A priest and former pillar of the Roman Catholic Church in New York experienced an extraordinary downfall yesterday as a judge sentenced him to four years in prison for stealing tens of thousands of dollars from his parish on the affluent Upper East Side.
The European counterterrorism chief criticized the suggestion that the Geneva Conventions should not be considered sacrosanct.

New York City’s public hospital system wants to suspend 39 employees for prying into the medical records of Nixzmary Brown, the 7-year-old girl whose beating death exposed flaws in the city’s system for protecting abused children, officials said yesterday.
Cardinal O’Malley, the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, just started a blog, complete with Internet slang and personal stories.
Wide receiver Laveranues Coles, limited again in practice yesterday because of an unspecified calf injury, remained questionable for the Jets’ game at Buffalo on Sunday.
Sergio García seemed to be in total control Friday in leading Europe to a 5-3 lead over the United States in the 36th Ryder Cup, though he deflected some of the praise.
The crash was a setback to magnetic levitation technology, which aims to narrow the speed gap between trains and planes.
Richard D. Caleal helped create the hugely popular 1949 Ford credited with lifting the company out of its postwar financial slump.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,680 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
A schism in the chess world will be healed by next month in a poor and barren Russian republic on the Caspian Sea.
In a Madonna concert that includes a crucifixion scene and the exclusion of religious references from “VeggieTales,” critics see a double standard.
The chief executive of the Panera discussed his company’s no-longer-white-hot stock price and a recent Barron’s article.
Getting an angle on serious knives for serious cooks, from craftsmen who learned in the land of the Samurai.
Wall Street’s growing pessimism about the economy sent stocks down for a second straight day.
The prospect of scuba diving in the Northeast may not conjure visions of crystal clear water, but there is an equally enticing siren of underwater adventure: shipwrecks.
Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany said it was his intention to solve the economic problems his administration covered up.
The Durham district attorney said in court that he now thought that a reported sexual assault at a Duke lacrosse team party last March lasted 5 to 10 minutes.
Roy M. Brewer was an ardent anti-Communist who headed the Hollywood branch of the movie industry’s leading union of stagehands during the blacklist era.
Hamas leaders said Friday that the group would not be part of a Palestinian government that recognizes Israel.
This 30-second advertisement for John Faso, the Republican candidate for governor, began running yesterday on upstate broadcast and cable stations.
How do you get on the Metropolitan Opera stage? Stand in line.
Ronald Harwood, a screenwriter skilled in the art of adapting complicated books for the screen, defies the numbers by keeping busy.

A midstream switch of ferry operators will head off a sharp rise in fares next week for some Hudson River commuters and leave most of them paying less next month, ferry company executives said yesterday.
A former midlevel Dynegy executive was resentenced to six years in prison for his role in a fraudulent accounting scheme.
Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie faces, and vividly describes, a defining history of her native Nigeria in her new novel, “Half of a Yellow Sun,” without having experienced it.
The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, led by its new artistic directors, the pianist Wu Han and the cellist David Fincke, opened its 39th season on Thursday with a classical sampler.
Christiane Amanpour lends her authority and acuity to the newly energized cause of Africa tonight on her CNN special “Where Have All the Parents Gone?”
Credit reports are now free but that hasn’t made decoding them or correcting the errors you’re likely to find on them one whit easier.
PBS censors itself again, Auguste Rodin on display in London, “Grey’s Anatomy” strikes again with a ratings win, a sculptor files a lawsuit against Wal-Mart and more culture news.

Watching the opera of “Sophie’s Choice” is like reading a book: the action proceeds largely through the characters telling you about it, while the music tells you about what the characters were telling you about.
Nanotechnology could enable engineers to combine the functions of memory chips and disk drives on a device the size of a dime.
Joe Lovano, leader of a Coltrane birthday tribute at Birdland, has internalized Coltrane as both an instrumental model and a conceptual ideal, folding those lessons into his own style.
The German group Constanza Macras/Dorky Park brought Berlin bohemia to the Dance Theater Workshop on Thursday.
An increasingly popular choice when investing for retirement is using target-date, or life cycle, mutual funds.

It took all of four minutes to drive in, order and drive out of the Burger King on Market Street in Saddle Brook, juggling a Triple Whopper with cheese, medium fries and a Diet Coke. Fast food indeed.
TRENTON.
Claude Coleman Jr., the drummer for Ween, has his own band and years after a bad accident, is slowly building himself up.

Calling him “the face of evil,” a State Supreme Court justice sentenced a homeless black man on Sept. 18 to serve 25 years to life in prison for stabbing a white woman to death in a parking garage near the Galleria shopping mall in White Plains.
MORE than a hundred years after going on display at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, the mummy Pa-Ib has been determined to be authentic.

PRESIDENT BUSH is coming to Greenwich on Monday to raise money for the State Republican Party in an effort to bolster the campaigns of Connecticut’s Republican candidates for Congress, three of whom are locked in tight races.

The charm of being in the dark and making do with candles in power outages wears thin in today’s ultra-wired universe.

The mutt may be America’s favorite dog, accounting for 46 percent of dogs owned in the United States, according to a 2005-6 survey by the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association, but fans of its pure-bred ancestors can be just as passionate. MILFOIL, an invasive lake weed, has wrecked many lovely days on the water by wrapping its slimy tendrils around boat engines or swimmers’ bodies. That is disturbing to lake lovers, but perhaps not as disturbing as the weed’s astonishing vitality: pieces of milfoil that get chopped off simply float away, grow roots and start new plants.
The officials who solemnly sit in judgment as show dogs strut, weave and occasionally fumble in the ring have, for many years, been judged themselves.

IN presenting its long-awaited reconstruction plan for the 15-mile stretch of Route 347 in Suffolk County last month, the State Department of Transportation said it had been developed in a “community-sensitive” manner.

The Nassau and Suffolk County executives have announced their budget proposals for 2007, focusing on easing or limiting taxes on residents. The Legislature in each county, which a budget-adoption deadline of Oct. 31, has less than six weeks to decide whether some revenue assumptions will hold up.

Pulled pork, smoked brisket and savory Kansas City ribs are served in a former bar that was a farmers’ hangout across from the old Cutchogue train station.

KOCHENTHAL--Irma Kruger, 96 years old; mother of Peter Kochenthal, Susan Griffing (Stephen), and Wendy Prescott; grandmother of Evan and Matthew Griffing, Jennifer Pagliaroli (Tony), and Josh Prescott passed away on September 21, 2006 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Friends and family are invited to express their condolences at the home of Peter Kochenthal, 225 E. 74th Street, Apartment 1K, New York, on Monday, September 25, between the hours of 6-9 pm. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

The inaugural Warren Buffett Cup, which ended in Ireland on Thursday, was a great success and close until the United States ran away from Europe over the last three rounds. In bridge's answer to the Ryder Cup in golf, Europe and the United States each sent six pairs. After the pair and team events, Europe enjoyed a 9-point lead. And after 7 of the 11 individual rounds, that margin had been maintained. But the United States won all 6 matches in Rounds 8 and 9 to build a 15-point advantage. In the penultimate round the United States, by gaining another 4 points, put the match away, since there were only 12 points available in the last round. In that final session the United States scored a further 4 points to win by 23.

STOCKHAUSEN--Thomas C. 93, on September 21, 2006 of pneumonia. Devoted husband of Anne. Loving father of Michael and Patricia. Adoring grandfather of T.J. Emmerman. Yale class of 1936. WW II veteran. Former Executive Vice President of W.R. Grace. Member of the Sands Point and Garden City Golf Clubs and University Club. His gentleness, intelligence and integrity will be missed. Services private at St. Ignatius Loyola.

To the Editor: Re ''Your Medical History, to Go'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 19):

A Sheraton hotel in Midtown Manhattan was the scene of feverish matchmaking over the past three days during Bill Clinton's second annual gathering on global problems. Only those who promised to do something concrete about poverty, disease, conflict or climate change were invited. The entry fee for aspiring philanthropists was $15,000. Hundreds lined up for the privilege.
To the Editor: Re ''On India's Despairing Farms, a Plague of Suicide'' (front page, Sept. 19):

WAL-MART TO CUT PACKAGING -- Wal-Mart Stores announced a five-year program with its suppliers to help reduce overall packaging by 5 percent. In the latest step to polish its environmental record, Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, said it would begin the initiative in 2008, and it could help Wal-Mart save $3.4 billion in its own costs. In the five-year plan, Wal-Mart will push its 600,000 global suppliers to find more efficient packaging methods. It estimates total supplier savings of $11 billion. Wal-Mart said it would start working with suppliers in November to prepare for the changes. Last October, the company's chief executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., above, said Wal-Mart would become a leader in environmental issues with three goals: reducing waste to zero, moving toward using only renewable energy and offering more products made in a way that preserves the environment.

Ohio State, ranked first in the nation, is favored to defeat No. 24 Penn State today in Columbus, Ohio, but Coach Jim Tressel of the Buckeyes will have none of that. In a classic bit of coachspeak, he said of the Nittany Lions: ''Their skilled people: tremendous, explosive speed. Their return men are frightening. Their receivers are outstanding.'' Penn State Coach Joe Paterno, above, was more realistic about his team's challenge: ''What do you do? You go in there and pray. You got a good prayer to St. Jude for hopeless causes or something?''

This 30-second advertisement for John Faso, the Republican candidate for governor, began running yesterday on upstate broadcast and cable stations. PRODUCER -- Greener and Hook. ON THE SCREEN -- A single, dying light bulb hangs from a cord in darkness, buzzing on and off, as the announcer's words appear in a jagged font that recalls the violent slasher movie ''Saw.'' A gray image of Eliot Spitzer, looking mean, appears with the words ''special interest friends,'' ''spending'' and ''taxes.'' With the final words of the ad, an outstretched hand reaches up and clicks off the flickering bulb. THE SCRIPT -- A sober-sounding female announcer says: ''New Yorkers already pay some of the highest taxes in the nation. Our kids are moving elsewhere for better jobs. And some can't even afford to pay the taxes on their homes. Now candidate Eliot Spitzer is making promises to his special-interest friends. Almost $70 billion in new spending. His new spending will mean thousands more in new taxes for every New York family. If Eliot Spitzer gets his way, it may be time for the last one in upstate New York to turn out the light.'' ACCURACY -- New York State taxes are relatively high, and both candidates say that young people and homeowners are abandoning the state. Mr. Spitzer has promised to increase spending on education by $4 billion to $6 billion and has proposed expanding health care and investing in transportation projects, among other things. But his campaign disputes Mr. Faso's estimate of $70 billion over four years, saying it will be only $8 billion to $10 billion a year at most. Mr. Spitzer has proposed $11 billion in budget cuts and $6 billion in property tax cuts, and has said he has no intention of raising taxes. Mr. Faso, an experienced budget analyst from his days as an Assembly leader, says there is no way Mr. Spitzer can deliver so much new spending without raising taxes. SCORECARD -- This is Mr. Faso's first ad of the general election, and it is a doozy: Rather than introduce himself or present an optimistic message -- both political rules of thumb -- the Faso campaign turns darkly negative and suggests that upstate is on death's door. Yet Mr. Faso clearly believes that shock value is what he needs. He is a staggering 50 percentage points behind Mr. Spitzer in the polls; if Mr. Faso cannot boost his own positive ratings quickly, then he must tear down Mr. Spitzer's. The ad is running only upstate, and an antitax message has traditionally been popular in that Republican voter base (though Democrats have made inroads). The pessimism in the ad may turn off some viewers, but it will resonate with others and leave the impression (fairly or not) that Mr. Spitzer will raise taxes. PATRICK HEALY

BASEBALL Major League Baseball MLB--Suspended Colorado RHP Jose Mesa and San Francisco RHP Jamey Wright three games apiece and San Francisco manager Felipe Alou one game for the two pitchers intentionally throwing at an opposing hitter in a Sept. 19 game. American League DETROIT TIGERS--Activated INF Placido Polanco from the 15-day DL. SEATTLE MARINERS--Named Alonzo Powell hitting coordinator. National League MILWAUKEE BREWERS--Named Bruce Seid west coast scouting supervisor and Ray Montgomery central scouting supervisor. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS--Extended the contract of Walt Jocketty, general manager, through the 2008 season. Promoted Jeff Luhnow, director of scouting, to vice president of amateur scouting and player development. Named Bruce Manno special assistant to the general manager and senior director of professional scouting.

A dance review last Saturday about the performance art troupe Yubiwa Hotel, at the Japan Society in New York, misstated the history of its appearances in the United States. Its first was in Portland, Ore., earlier this month, not at the Japan Society.

To the Editor: The online paper mill featured in ''Term Paper Project, Part II'' (Week in Review, Sept. 17) states that the biggest academic con is that college professors do not read their students' term papers.

A sports article on Wednesday about the Los Angeles Dodgers' 11-10 victory over the San Diego Padres in 10 innings on Monday night misidentified the broadcaster who called the ninth inning on radio station KFWB. It was Charley Steiner, not Vin Scully. (Scully's call, ''Believe it or not, four consecutive home runs, and the Dodgers have tied it up,'' was on the television broadcast, not on the radio.)

The government said it would no longer offer a direct subsidy to the Catholic Church, ending a tradition of many decades that critics said blurred the separation between church and state. Taxpayers would still be able to earmark a certain percentage of their tax money for the church, so it would still receive public financing. But the government would no longer add to that amount. In exchange, the government said taxpayers would be able to direct a larger portion of their taxes each year to the church. The government provides the Catholic Church with about $170 million each year, about $35 million of it in direct subsidies. RENWICK McLEAN (NYT)

DANIELS--John Hancock, 84. of Mulberry Plantation, Camden, South Carolina, died Monday, September 18, 2006. Born in St. Paul, Minnesota, October 28, 1921, he was the son of Thomas Leonard Daniels and Frances Hancock Daniels and the grandson of John W. Daniels, one of the founders of Archer Daniels Midland Co. He is survived by his wife, the former Martha Hill Williams, to whom he was married December 23, 1942. He leaves two sons, John H. Daniels Jr. of Minneapolis, MN and Christopher W. Daniels of Denver, CO and two daughters, Martha M. Daniels of Washington State and Mulberry Plantation and Dr. Jane D. Moffett of Sleepy Hollow, NY, as well as eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Mr. Daniels was graduated from the Phillips Exeter Academy, 1939, Yale University, 1943, and the Advanced Management Program, Harvard, 1957. In World War II he served from 2nd Lt. to Capt., in the European theatre, with the 738th Field Artillery Battalion of 8-inch howitzers. He was awarded the Bronze Star. In later life he served as Civilian Aide to the Secretary of the Army, and was awarded the U.S. Army Outstanding Civilian Service Medal. After World War II, he joined Archer Daniels Midland Co., an agricultural products firm then based in Minneapolis, where he served in various capacities for 50 years. He became President and CEO of ADM in 1958. He served on ADM's Board of Directors from 1958 through 1996, performing as Chairman of the Board from 1968 through 1972. He also served as a member of the Executive Committee. In his final two years as a Board member he Co-chaired with former Canadian PM, Brian Mulroney, the Special Shareholders' Committee which represented the interests of ADM's shareholders in a Federal law-enforcement investigation into the misconduct of ADM executives. He served as President of Mulberry Plantation, Inc. from 1970 until 1993. He was a Master of Foxhounds of The Camden Hunt (SC). He cofounded and served as the joint master of two foxhunts, The Long Lake Hounds (MN) and The Old Stonington Hunt (Ill.) Mr. Daniels became a member of The Business Council in 1962. He was a member of the Committee for Economic Development. He was a member of the Woodhill Country Club, The Elizabethan Club, The Grolier Club, The Links Club, The Lafayette Club and The Camden Country Club and a former director of The Springdale Hall Club. While at Yale, Mr. Daniels was a member of the singing groups, The Wiffenpoofs and The Spizzwinks and remained a lifelong supporter of those organizations. Also at Yale, Mr. Daniels was captain of the Yale Polo team, a sport he continued to play and follow later in life. He has served as a Trustee of the Yale Library Associates, The Exeter Trustees Council and as Permanent Secretary, 738th Field Artillery Battalion Association. For many years and until his death he was a member of the Board of Directors of the Carolina Cup and Colonial Cup steeplechases, held in spring and fall in Camden, SC. A longtime collector of rare sporting books, John Daniels, with his wife, donated some 5,000 volumes to help launch The National Sporting Library in Middleburg, Virginia, where he served as Director and Director Emeritus. He was the author of several articles, monographs and books, including ''War Diary''(1948),''And Then What Happened? MayDec 1945'' (1982), ''Nothing Could Be Finer''(1996/reprint 2006),''Affectionately H''(1999) and ''In the Boat! -A Ninety Year History of The St. Croix Fly - Fishing Club''(2003). Services will be held at The Quaker Cemetery, Camden, South Carolina, at 3 PM, Saturday, September 23, 2006. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to The Fine Arts Center of Kershaw County, P.O. Box 1498, Camden, South Carolina 29021. Kornegay Funeral Home Camden Chapel is in charge of the services.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Massachusetts governor's race referred incorrectly to the executive director of the Democratic Governors Association, who commented on the party's efforts in the state. Penny Lee is a woman.
To the Editor: Re ''A Real Test for the Palestinians'' (editorial, Sept. 18):

A picture caption with an article on Sept. 14 about efforts by gay groups to repeal the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy in the military misidentified the tattoo on the arm of Tim Smith, a gay former marine. Although the tattoo featuring a dagger and the initials USMC was inspired by Mr. Smith's service in the Marines, it was not the official Marine Corps symbol of an eagle, a globe and an anchor. The article also misstated the timing of Mr. Smith's marriage, which ended in divorce. He and his wife were married after he joined the corps, not before.
To the Editor: Your disturbing article ''When Is Thin Too Thin?'' (Thursday Styles, Sept. 21) left me with the question: What do designers (and the linked model agencies) think they are doing?

The military rulers appointed an anticorruption commission in what appeared to be a move toward investigating and perhaps seizing the assets of Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister stripped of his job by a coup on Tuesday. They also continued their search for an interim prime minister and received the official blessing of King Bhumibol Adulyadej in a ceremony broadcast on national television, where a statement was read on behalf of the king. His backing for the coup appears to be a main reason why former Thaksin supporters, even in rural areas considered the bastion of his support, now express support of the military takeover. THOMAS FULLER (IHT)

An article on Wednesday about volunteers who greet military transport flights at Bangor International Airport attributed an erroneous distinction to the airport. It is not the easternmost airport in the United States; that is Lubec Municipal Airport, also in Maine.

A report from the Home Office acknowledged shortcomings in the handling of the aftermath of the London bombings 14 months ago that left some survivors and bereaved families ''feeling forgotten and unimportant.'' The 23-page report was the latest in a series of official analyses of the suicide bombing attacks on the London transportation system that killed 52 people. It said that in the aftermath ''those trying to find loved ones found it difficult to get information about which hospitals people were being treated in.'' There were ''concerns about the time it took to identify victims,'' the report said, and ''some families were not kept in touch with the process of identification.'' The authorities, it suggested, were overwhelmed, with the number of people calling about their relatives peaking at about 43,000 calls an hour. In addition, emergency services were communicating over overloaded cellphone systems and creaky radio networks. ALAN COWELL (NYT)
WALLIS--Dr. Robert, died peacefully on August 27th at 106 years old. Eminent physician and loving husband of Celestina Wainwright Wallis. Father of four sons and grandfather of eight grandchildren.
A headline with an article yesterday about violence in the Gaza Strip misstated the number of Palestinians killed in an Israeli military operation. It was five, not seven.

A 30-second commercial for Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for attorney general, began running statewide yesterday on broadcast and cable television stations. PRODUCER -- Jimmy Siegel. ON THE SCREEN -- The ad begins with a close-up of Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, the Democratic candidate for governor, speaking about Mr. Cuomo. The close-up shots alternate with a screen filled with Mr. Spitzer's words about Mr. Cuomo, including ''Rooted out corruption,'' ''Fought bigotry and gun violence'' and ''Most qualified.'' THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Spitzer appears on screen and is the only voice in the ad. He states: ''You don't judge a fighter by how many times he wins, but who he beats. When Andrew Cuomo turned around a troubled agency under Bill Clinton, he was in charge of 300 lawyers who took on very powerful interests, demonstrating the kind of fearlessness that got him confirmed twice by the U.S. Senate, by both parties. He rooted out corruption. Stopped the bad guys. Fought everything from bigotry to gun violence. Which is why he's the most qualified to be your next attorney general. Because he not only has the experience and integrity. He's got the guts.'' ACCURACY -- The advertisement includes well-documented information about Mr. Cuomo's years as Secretary of Housing in the administration of President Bill Clinton. Under Mr. Cuomo's leadership, the department did undertake a number of antidiscrimination housing suits. But the agency also came under fire when one of its signature programs, meant to improve housing in poor neighborhoods, turned out to be riddled with fraud and left some areas in worse shape than they had been. SCORECARD -- This is Mr. Cuomo's first television commercial since winning the Democratic primary on Sept. 12. And as such, it is the first time he has been able to use the political cachet of Mr. Spitzer, who enjoys wide popularity, even among Republicans. For voters who see Mr. Spitzer as an authoritative, reliable voice, it will undoubtedly help lend gravitas to the Cuomo campaign in the wake of a bruising primary. By highlighting how many lawyers worked under Mr. Cuomo, it also seeks to undercut criticism about his lack of legal experience. While the ads by his Republican opponent, Jeanine F. Pirro, attacked the Democratic candidate, the Cuomo ad does not mention Ms. Pirro. Republican politicians, however, will undoubtedly see Mr. Spitzer's claims of ''fearlessness'' as hyperbole. JONATHAN P. HICKS
To the Editor: Re ''Top Republicans Reach an Accord on Detainee Bill'' (front page, Sept. 22):

In a bitterly worded letter, the Israeli ambassador to the United States on Friday accused the Council on Foreign Relations of making a ''terrible mistake'' by inviting President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran to a meeting with the group earlier this week. ''Some of those upset with the council's decision have compared it to hypothetically inviting Hitler to a meeting in the 1930's,'' the ambassador, Daniel Ayalon, wrote to the council's president, Richard N. Haass. ''In fact, meeting with Ahmadinejad is worse: Hitler did not openly call for genocide in the 1930's, and today we have the lessons of the 1930's to guide us. Foremost among those lessons is that appeasing fanatics like Hitler and granting them legitimacy leads to genocide and war.''

The flirty surgeons prevailed over the forensic investigators in Thursday night's much-anticipated television matchup. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy,'' starring Patrick Dempsey, below, whose character is often referred to as ''Dr. McDreamy,'' captured 25.1 million viewers. It topped the premiere of CBS's Thursday goliath, ''CSI,'' by 45 percent in the vaunted demographic of adults 18 to 49. ''CSI'' drew a formidable 22 million total viewers, although that figure was down 24 percent from last year's debut. NBC's premiere of ''ER'' led at 10 p.m. with 15.6 million viewers. Although the ''Grey's Anatomy'' momentum slowed at 10 p.m., ABC's ''Six Degrees,'' the latest from J. J. Abrams (''Lost''), still fared 38 percent better among adults 18 to 49 than CBS's older-skewing ''Shark,'' with James Woods, which drew 15 million total viewers. Notably, however, ''Six Degrees'' lost 4 million viewers in its second half, averaging 13.3 million viewers for the hour. In the 8 p.m. slot, CBS's ''Survivor: Cook Islands'' held relatively steady from last week with 17.3 million viewers, while premieres of NBC's ''My Name Is Earl'' (8.9 million) and ''The Office'' (9.1 million) were third behind ''Survivor'' and a special ''Grey's Anatomy'' retrospective (13.5 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

A tribunal sentenced Vladimiro Montesinos, Peru's former intelligence chief, to 20 years in prison for brokering a deal to send 10,000 assault rifles to Colombian guerrillas. Judges ruled on evidence that put Mr. Montesinos, 61, in the middle of a complex web of negotiations to bring rifles from Jordan to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. Mr. Montesinos, the spymaster under former President Alberto K. Fujimori, is already serving a separate 15-year term on corruption charges at a high-security naval prison in the port of Callao. SIMON ROMERO (NYT)

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Hezbollah Leader Declares Militia Can't Be Disarmed Hundreds of thousands of Lebanese stood and chanted ''God, God, protect Nasrallah.'' It was the moment they had waited for: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, in person, declaring that his militia was stronger than ever and that no army in the world could force it to disarm. A7 Pakistani Defends Deal President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, left, tried to convince President Bush that a deal with tribal leaders in one of his country's most lawless border areas would drive out Qaeda and Taliban forces, rather than give them more freedom. A6 German Train Collision Kills 25 A futuristic high-speed train collided with a service vehicle during a test run in northwestern Germany, killing 25 people and dealing a setback to magnetic levitation technology, which aims to narrow the speed gap between trains and planes. A5 European Faults U.S. on Accord The European Union's counterterrorism coordinator, Gijs de Vries, criticized a Bush administration official who suggested that the Geneva Conventions should not be considered sacrosanct, and that the legal framework for the treatment of terrorists should be amended. A4 First China-U.S. Navy Training The United States Navy reached a milestone when it conducted an exercise with a Chinese ship off the coast of southern California, the top American commander for the Pacific region said. This was the first time ships from the two navies had worked together in a search-and-rescue training session. A5 NATIONAL A8-9; 12 Report Calls For Shake-Up Of U.S. Drug-Safety Policy The nation's system for ensuring the safety of medicines needs major changes, and consumers should be wary of drugs that have been recently approved, a study says. A1 Chávez Speech Boosts Book Sales of Noam Chomsky's book have climbed best-seller lists at Amazon.com and BN.com ever since the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, held up a copy during a speech at the United Nations. A1 Education Officials Broke Rules Department of Education officials violated conflict of interest rules when awarding grants to states under President Bush's billion-dollar reading initiative, steering contracts to favored textbook publishers, the department's inspector general said. A8 Deal on Terrorism Suspects Republicans put aside their differences, setting the House and Senate on a path to approve a compromise struck with the White House on the detention and interrogation of terror suspects. A9 Top Texas Officials Are Sued Texas Democrats have sued two top Republican state officials over enforcement of an antifraud law that they say is being used to intimidate minority voters who cast ballots by mail, usually for Democrats. A12 ARTS B7-14 NBC Draws Conservative Ire NBC has drawn protests from religious conservatives over the content of two television shows, but for different reasons -- in one instance for excluding references to God and the other for possibly including religious imagery. B7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Justice for Slain Girl, 7, Is Stalled in Brooklyn Court Consequences were swift in some quarters when Nixzmary Brown, 7, was found beaten to death in her Brooklyn home last January. Child welfare workers were suspended and the mayor created a new position for the protection of children. But through a series of court filings, the case against her mother and stepfather has moved through the courts at a snail's pace. A1 Rent Deregulation Predicted The seller of two Manhattan apartment complexes that are a bastion for middle-class renters predicts that by 2018, the proportion of rent-stabilized units could plummet from 70 percent to less than 30 percent. B1 Religion Journal B5 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 H.P. Chairwoman Resigns The furor over Hewlett-Packard's spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn. The move was announced by Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive, who will succeed her. A1 Low Gas Prices and S.U.V.'s Now that gas prices have fallen almost 50 cents in the last month, to less than $2 a gallon in some markets, car shoppers might be lured once again to S.U.V.'s and other big vehicles. C1 Pay-Per-Click Fraud DiamondHarmony.com, an online jewelry store, added an elaborate search engine marketing effort that included a pay-per-click advertising campaign based on key words and phrases. For its trouble, the company became ensnared in click fraud. SENNETT--Ted. Suddenly on September 21, 2006; beloved husband of Roxane, proud father of Bob and John, David and Donna and Karen. Adoring grandfather of Katie and Ben. Brother of Dan and Judy Sennett, brother-in-law of Roslyn and David Nitzberg and uncle to many nieces and nephews. A lifelong fan of movies and Broadway, Ted's zest for life will be missed. Services Monday, September 25, 1 PM at Temple Beth El, Closter N.J

Should the developers scale back the proposed -- and mammoth -- Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn by 6 percent to 8 percent, as recent reports suggest they might be considering, the decision would hardly be novel. Indeed, history teems with myriad similar, if less subtle, downsizings. New York World's Fair, 1940 The 1939-40 New York World's Fair wore a new look in its second year, exemplified by the Trylon and Most of the Perisphere, as the giant symbol became officially known. The balance sheet was seriously out of balance, and the belt-tightening that followed spared nothing. On a rosier note, converting 1939 Bakelite replicas of the original Trylon and Perisphere into 1940 versions spread like wildfire as a hobbyist activity. H.M.S. Flotsam, 1921 Cutting costs to the bone on the fiercely competitive North Atlantic route led Britain's Washing Line to institute an across-the-board 6 to 8 percent reduction in building costs for its new liner. The 6 to 8 percent shorter hull was assembled with 6 to 8 percent fewer rivets -- an all too vital element, as it turned out, in the technical condition that master shipbuilders call buoyancy. Tasmania, 1957 An austerity-minded new island government cut administrative costs by lopping 6 to 8 percent from Tasmania's official size. Those marooned without utilities or public services had to pay $20,000 each for readmission to the mainland -- creating an overnight budget surplus and restoring the island's missing 6 to 8 percent. Alas, the costs of defending against a tsunami of related lawsuits forced the government to revoke the revocation, and official Tasmania today remains only 92 to 94 percent of its former self. Eiffel Tower, 1949 The government of economically ailing France first switched to ''Liberté, Égalité, Austérité'' as the nation's new motto and then downsized the Eiffel Tower by a symbolic 6 to 8 percent to imprint the seriousness of the situation on the minds of the citizenry. Tourists can visit the missing top of the structure in a suburban Paris storage bin -- for a fee, of course. Bust of Fungus Bulbous, A.D. 213 After the hard-bargaining Roman land developer Fungus Bulbous chiseled the bill for a marble bust of himself down by 6 to 8 percent, the resentful sculptor chiseled the bust down by the same amount, right where it showed. Pyramid of Chops, 2500 B.C. Budget cuts in the Department of the Afterlife forced the Pharaoh Cheops -- snidely known thereafter as Chops -- to slash the cost of his eternal resting place by making it the Egyptian equivalent of 6 to 8 percent less massive. His royal architect, archeologists agree, did a ham-handed job of it.

Well before the season began, a 1,300-square-foot screen at One Times Square was flashing a 15-second video once an hour. It was promoting Brian Leonard, the Rutgers senior fullback, above, as a leading Heisman Trophy candidate. As originally scheduled, the electronic billboard, a gift in kind from a Rutgers supporter, will end next Saturday. Leonard seems happy about that.

The European counterterrorism chief, Gijs de Vries, criticized a Bush administration official who suggested that the Geneva Conventions should not be considered sacrosanct, and that the legal framework for the treatment of terrorists should be amended. The State Department's legal adviser, John B. Bellinger III, said in an interview published Thursday in The Financial Times that he questioned whether the Geneva Conventions should be ''the immutable legal holy grail as to what the rules ought to be in the 21st century.''
ORTNER--Evelyn. Dearest friend, mentor and travelling companion. We will miss you greatly. The Friday Night Family Clem, Norma and Jim Judy and Larry Monica and Joe

The sculptor who created a 7,000-pound charging bull sculpture that has become a favorite tourist photo stop at the foot of Broadway has filed suit in federal court in Manhattan against Wal-Mart, complaining that it is selling lithographs of his work without his permission. Arturo Di Modica, who made the sculpture with his own money as a tribute to America's rebound from the 1987 stock market crash, also sued several other companies for what he described as unauthorized use of his work, including North Fork Bank, which has used an image of the bull in a television advertising campaign, the lawsuit said. In the dead of the night in December 1989, Mr. Di Modica used a truck and crane to bequeath the fierce-looking sculpture illegally to the Wall Street area, plunking it down near the New York Stock Exchange. It was hauled away but was later returned by the city's Parks Department and installed in nearby Bowling Green, where it has remained. In 1998 Mr. Di Modica registered the bull with the United States Copyright Office. For many years he has sought to recoup his costs for the work by selling it to someone who will agree to leave it where it now stands. John Simley, a spokesman for Wal-Mart, said the company had not yet been served with papers in the case and would wait to comment. RANDY KENNEDY

8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE -- (1962). What lies beneath? That's the question on nearly everyone's mind in John Frankenheimer's Cold War noir about a Korean war hero (Laurence Harvey) who returns home with an agenda, one that's hidden even from him. Frank Sinatra plays a comrade whose dreams have infiltrated his reality. Angela Lansbury (above, with Harvey) is mommy dearest. 8 P.M. (History) VICTORIAN REBORN -- In this ''Save Our History'' special, Steve Thomas documents the efforts to revive the George Barber-designed McCubbins-McCanless House in Salisbury, N.C., from the cracks in its foundation to the tip of its crumbling chimney. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) KRAKEN: TENTACLES OF THE DEEP -- Movie buffs named this one by voting on the channel's Web site in July. The premise: a marine biologist and a couple of sailors go in search of vast riches watched over by a beast of terrifying proportions (above) -- the same creature that killed one's parents years before, but not before their son gouged out an eye. You get the picture. Victoria Pratt, Jack Scalia and Charlie O'Connell, perhaps best known as ''The Bachelor'' of Season 7, play the daring trio. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICA'S MOST WANTED: AMERICA FIGHTS BACK -- This show just keeps adding notches to its belt. Tonight, police use DNA evidence to link a man who attacked a homeless woman in New York to three attempted rapes in Miami. 9 P.M. (BBC America) MALE, 33, SEEKS PUBERTY -- Danger: raging hormones. In this documentary, Lawrence Koomson, a London doctor, undergoes treatment to increase his testosterone from the level found in a 12-year-old boy to that of a grown man, in only a year. 10 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS MYSTERY -- Was it the butler in the galley or the captain in the private dining room? In this first whodunit of the 10th season, an aspiring actress is found dead in her cruise-ship cabin. 11 P.M. (Fox) MAD TV -- What's that you say? Tonight's guest, Howie Mandel (left) of ''Deal or No Deal,'' leaves behind his hotline and suitcases to join Bobby Lee in a ''24'' spoof; the rapper Chingy performs. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Mark Schultz has been named the winner of the National Arts Club's $15,000 Kesselring Prize for Playwriting, awarded annually to a playwright of exceptional promise. Mr. Schultz is the author of the drama ''A Brief History of Helen of Troy,'' seen in 2005 at SoHo Rep under the title ''Everything Will Be Different.'' Bruce Norris, the author of ''The Pain and the Itch,'' now at Playwrights Horizons, received an honorable mention, carrying a $5,000 prize. Previous recipients of the prize, named in honor of the playwright Joseph Kesselring (''Arsenic and Old Lace'') include Tony Kushner, Paula Vogel and last year's winner, Deb Margolin (''Three Seconds in the Key''). The awards will be presented on Nov. 19 at the club. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

LEVY--Leon. Hillcrest Jewish Center mourns the passing of long time member and past president Leon Levy and extends its condolences to the entire Levy family. Leon was a generous and inspirational presence in our community and will be missed.

An article yesterday about the gubernatorial campaign in Texas referred incorrectly to the length of time a governor can serve. Voters may re-elect a governor to as many four-year terms as they choose; there is no two-term limit. The article also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a guitarist for the Texas band ZZ Top, which played at a fund-raiser for one candidate, Kinky Friedman. He is Billy F. Gibbons, not Gibson.

The war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, is likely to begin in April. The United Nations-backed Sierra Leone Court, in The Hague for this trial, announced the date at a procedural hearing. Mr. Taylor, a former warlord and long one of West Africa's most feared men, is now imprisoned here, charged with multiple crimes, including ordering the dragooning of children into combat, the hacking off of limbs and the killing of thousands of civilians in the 1990's. MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

Headlines with an article yesterday about work conducted by John Faso, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, for the state's Public Asset Fund misidentified the branch of government that helped him secure legislation sought by the fund. It was the governor's office, not the Legislature.
To the Editor: Re ''Stop Reckless Bicyclists'' (letter, Sept. 19):

A theater review on Wednesday about ''Nami,'' at the Kirk Theater on West 42nd Street in Manhattan, misidentified a character and the actor who plays him. Lil's husband is Harry, not Donovan, and is played by Mark Rosenthal. (Donovan, played by Michael Gladis, is the landlord.) It was Mr. Rosenthal's performance that was described as becoming ''unhinged,'' not Mr. Gladis's. The review also misidentified the lighting designer. He is Jason Jeunnette -- not Lex Liang, who is the costume designer.

LUBELL--Nathaniel, 90 of Fort Lee, NJ died in his home on Sat., Sept. 17th. He was the beloved stepfather of Robert Dow, of Tuxedo Park, NY and Lawrenceville, NJ, and the beloved uncle of David Buskin of NYC; John Buskin of Montclair, NJ; David Lubell of Ossining, NY; Elizabeth Kozart of Philadelphia, PA; Jack Kaplan of NYC; and Gail Kaplan of NYC. Loved and respected also by the spouses and children of all the above, he represented the last vestige of his generation to his large extended family. Nathaniel Lubell was born in 1916. He graduated from the City College of New York, where he first began to achieve renown as a world-class fencer. His 1936 CCNY Fencing Team won the New York City Championships, and he is a member of the CCNY Athletic Hall of Fame. He went on to become a three-time Olympian ( 1948, '52 and '56 ). He was the U.S. National Foil Champion in 1948, and at the 1951 Pan American Games, he won the bronze medal in the individual foil and helped the team capture the gold medal in the team foil and saber. He was a lifelong member of The New York Fencers' Club, serving as its President during the 1970's. He also coached fencing at West Point from 1962-1966. Fiercely independent and aggressively iconoclastic, his acerbic wit and characteristic irascibility were a source of considerable family lore. He was an institution among his many descendants, and he will be greatly missed.

COHEN--Theodore, M.D., 80, passed away on September 21. He was the loving husband of Barbara for 59 years, devoted father of Mitchell, Judy and Robert, and adoring grandfather of Allison and Jamie. He was the beloved son of Dora and Irving, brother of Sidney, uncle of Michael, Douglas and David, brother-in-law of Jerry and Sheila. His family will love him always. Funeral services took place on September 22.

Rodin on Display in London A major exhibition featuring 300 pieces by the French sculptor Auguste Rodin (1840-1917) was to open today at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, the first British exhibition of his work in nearly 20 years, Agence France-Presse reported. The show, which runs through Jan. 1, features a variety of works, including ''The Kiss,'' ''The Thinker,'' left, and ''The Gates of Hell,'' inspired by Dante's ''Inferno.'' Many of the works, organized around 10 chronological themes, are on loan from the Musée Rodin in Paris and from Rodin's home in Meudon, a Paris suburb. Several are being shown outside of France for the first time. Another Cancellation For Reggae Singer In response to complaints from patrons, the Highlands Hollywood nightclub and restaurant in Los Angeles has canceled a performance, scheduled for Oct. 2, by the reggae singer Buju Banton, The Associated Press reported. Some of Mr. Banton's songs include violent lyrics about gay men and lesbians; ''Batty Rider'' and ''Boom Bye Bye'' glorify the shooting of gay men. Mr. Banton has caused controversy before: in July, for example, protests forced the cancellation of a scheduled performance at Concorde 2 in Brighton, the English seaside resort. ''We felt it was the right thing to do after doing some research on the matter,'' said Adam Manacker, the director of promotions for Highlands, speaking of the Hollywood cancellation. Almodóvar Film Wins International Award The International Federation of Film Critics awarded the annual Fipresci Grand Prix for the best film of the year to ''Volver,'' directed by Pedro Almodóvar, at the opening ceremony of the 54th San Sebastian International Film Festival in Spain. The award, presented each year since 1999, highlights the overall artistic value of a film, according to the federation's Web site, www.fipresci.org, and more than 350 critics from over 60 countries cast votes to choose a film released between July 2005 and July 2006. The film, starring Penélope Cruz, above, was released in Spain on March 17 and is set for release in the United States on Nov. 3. This is the second time the Fipresci has been awarded to an Almodóvar film: ''All About My Mother'' won in 1999. Footnotes The board of directors of National Public Radio has announced that Ken Stern, the organization's executive vice president since 1999, will become chief executive effective Oct. 1. Kevin Klose, who has served as N.P.R.'s president and chief executive since December 1998, will remain president and a member of the board of directors.

ROSENBERG--Michael J. It is with great sadness that we note the passing of our esteemed New York Road Runners Foundation Board Member, Michael J. Rosenberg. A dedicated runner and friend of New York Road Runners, Michael completed many marathons, often with his wife Kathleen. His deep involvement, unstinting effort, sincere interest and intensity of commitment in support of the Foundation's activities for the youth of the nation shall be remembered always. ''We will miss you, Michael.'' Board of Directors and Staff New York Road Runners New York Road Runners Foundation

Even 200-year-old political cartoons aren't immune from the PBS censor's blurring machine when they depict naked male genitalia. David Grubin, the writer, producer and director of ''Marie Antoinette,'' a documentary portrait of the French queen, right, to be broadcast on Monday night, was asked this week by PBS stations to blur the images on two phantasmagorical political cartoons shown in the film. The fear was that, unedited, they would violate the Federal Communications Commission's indecency standards. Mr. Grubin said in an interview that he found the requested changes ''disturbing,'' but that he wasn't upset with the stations. ''I don't blame them,'' he said. ''The fines are $325,000, and that could bankrupt a station.'' The F.C.C.'s policy of ruling on indecency issues only after it receives complaints ''is forcing filmmakers and PBS to censor ourselves because we can't risk the fines,'' he said. Stations were not concerned about other cartoons in the film that show the queen's bare breasts, which will not be obscured. In August PBS rescinded a policy it had put in place in May that required its filmmakers to not only bleep out offensive language but also to obscure digitally the mouth of the person uttering the offensive word, so that viewers would not be able to read lips. Filmmakers had complained that PBS's policy went too far. ELIZABETH JENSEN

One of the more enduring debates coming out of the midterm elections of 1994 - and one that takes on special resonance in this equally contested midterm of 2006 - is whether the decision by Republicans to run on a "Contract with America," an agenda of proposals they would enact if they gained power, helped them in their rout of Democrats. This is no academic matter: one of the big decisions for Democrats in this midterm is whether they need to run on a what-we-will-do agenda to win, or whether it is enough to step to the side and let Republican incumbents sink in the sea of voter discontent.

Though I never met Susan Sontag, I have read nearly everything she wrote (Sept. 10). Sontag spoke of the dialectical exchange between self-revelation and self-concealment, and sheleaned toward the latter. She seemed never to reveal too much of herself in her work. Her novels had a bold yet cold intelligence about them. She allowed more pathos in her essays than in her fiction. This made her essays, for me at least, more pleasurable. I always hoped she would allow herself to write a more moving novel.

An article last week about the making of the bullfighting film “Manolete” referred incorrectly to Ernest Hemingway’s book about Antonio Ordoñez, grandfather of Cayetano Rivera Ordoñez, a matador who helped train the film’s star, Adrien Brody. Antonio Ordoñez was a subject of “The Dangerous Summer,” Hemingway’s nonfiction account of a season of bullfighting, not “Death in the Afternoon.” In addition, the article also misstated the real name of another torero, Espartaco, who helped train Mr. Brody. He is Juan Antonio Ruiz Román, not Augustín Espartinas. (Mr. Espartinas is Mr. Brody’s double in the film.).

To the Editor: As company historian for Levi Strauss & Company, I was intrigued by Ita Aber's letter (Sept. 3) regarding''Jeans: A Cultural History of an American Icon.'' For some reason the history of jeans lends itself to legends and misinformation, even when a new book has all the facts straight. So, in the interest of historical accuracy, I would respectfully like to correct the letter writer as follows: a) Levi Strauss was never married; b) Levi Strauss never went to Provence; c) He obtained all of his denim from American textile mills; and d) Denim was originally called serge de Nîmes, a name that was anglicized in the United States as early as the 18th century. For more -- and accurate -- information about the history of denim and jeans, I suggest readers go to the ''heritage'' section of our Web site at www.levistrauss.com. Lynn Downey San Francisco

To the Editor: In Michelle Higgins's ''Air Travel: What to Do When Bumped From a Flight'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 10), it was mentioned that some airlines have computerized systems to reassign travelers to other flights -- systems that are faster and fairer than having airline employees manually reassign passengers. The article goes on to imply that choosing an airline that ''still rewards those with sharp elbows'' is not such a bad idea. Why would I want to reward an airline for unfair, inefficient behavior? I'd rather travel on one that doesn't give selfish troublemakers better access to coveted seats, and instead uses a fair system to allocate such scarce resources. Shaun Breidbart Pelham, N.Y.

WHEN the Bedford Community Church started about 25 years ago, it was attended by a mere 13 or 14 people. Today, the evangelical church has an average attendance of 260 to 285 adults every Sunday, said the Rev. Dwight Ford, its pastor. Because the church holds only about 230 people, there are two services.

The officials who solemnly sit in judgment as show dogs strut, weave and occasionally fumble in the ring have, for many years, been judged themselves. Each must have at least 10 years' experience as an owner, breeder and exhibitor and must pass a written test on his or her chosen breed and an open-book test on American Kennel Club rules and procedures, as well as sit for an oral interview. Each must also complete a practice round of five judging assignments in the breed. Group judges must be qualified in all breeds in a group, and best-in-show judges must be qualified in at least one of the seven groups and have judged that group at least five times. The process can take years of watching dogs and slowly developing a sure eye.

MILFOIL, an invasive lake weed, has wrecked many lovely days on the water by wrapping its slimy tendrils around boat engines or swimmers' bodies. That is disturbing to lake lovers, but perhaps not as disturbing as the weed's astonishing vitality: pieces of milfoil that get chopped off simply float away, grow roots and start new plants. ''It's like revenge of the body-snatchers,'' said Larry Marsicano, the executive director of the Candlewood Lake Authority, which has agonized over the weed.

To the Editor: Re ''Some Good News Arrives at Last for a Bad News Bear'' by Mark Olsen [Sept. 17]: As good as it was to see your spotlight trained on the former child actor Jackie Earle Haley, I was disappointed that the author failed to mention Mr. Haley's work in what has to be among the most disturbing performances by any child actor. He played the bratty, and female, child actress Adore, who is stomped to death by Donald Sutherland's character at the horrifying climax of the 1975 John Schlesinger film ''The Day of the Locust.''

WHEN they renovated their 1735 three-level home in Upper Saddle River, N.J., last year, Robert and Mary Wortmann thought of everything: a home theater, a billiards room, a wine cellar and, the ultimate modern convenience, an elevator. It has power gates, a mahogany interior and a marble floor with wood inlays. Total cost: about $55,000.

Riding crops, silk bondage ropes and $450 titanium vibrators are some of the tamer wares that Jennifer Zuccarini sells to a well-heeled crowd at Kiki de Montparnasse, the elegantly kinky SoHo sex shop, which Ms. Zuccarini founded with her friend Andrew Pollard. ''There was nowhere for people to buy things to enhance their intimate life in a luxurious, beautiful environment,'' she said, explaining why a high-end erotic salon seemed so very necessary. The shop, which opened in May, sells goods as varied as lingerie, racy ready-to-wear designed by Ms. Zuccarini, beauty products and chocolates -- ''everything to do with romance,'' she explained. Romance, indeed.

Liz Claiborne Inc. will bid goodbye to its chairman and chief executive, Paul R. Charron, 64, with more than a gold watch when he retires later this year. To honor his work on the company's campaign against abusive teenage relationships, Liz Claiborne is setting up a nationwide hot line for adolescents. It will give $1 million to fund the service, to be run by the National Domestic Violence Hotline in Austin, Tex. The company has long supported education on teenage dating violence, including developing a curriculum that is in use in 450 schools.

To the Editor: As an alumnus of Lawrence High School and a former resident of Cedarhurst, I was saddened to read ''At Odds Over Schools'' (Sept. 17). That community always had families of every religion, race, ethnic and economic status living in harmony.

Clint Dempsey, the only American player to score a goal in last summer's World Cup in Germany, said he planned to leave Major League Soccer for the English Premier League in January. ''England is a great country to play in and I want to leave M.L.S.,'' Dempsey, 23, said in yesterday's editions of the Daily Mail of Britain. ''Teams abroad are willing to pay me 10 times more money, and I don't want to be here. There is no way I am staying in the M.L.S.''
