Q: As the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, you are trying to revive the institution by poaching the populist luster of Hollywood and Broadway. Tomorrow night, the fall season opens with a ''Madama Butterfly'' that has been directed by a filmmaker, Anthony Minghella. In order to attract a new audience, it is necessary for the Met to be thought of as a place which is more than just singers standing and singing. I'm trying to demonstrate that opera can be great theater and not just great music.

EVERYONE loves a makeover. Turn on the television and somewhere a poor soul is getting an overhaul of his wardrobe, his body or his home. Restaurant renovations are just as popular, a case in point being Trattoria Grasso, which reinvented itself in July as Grasso's Fine Dining and Jazz. The changes here are more than cosmetic. This is no longer a casual Italian cafe but an upscale American restaurant. The menu features steaks, chops and fish with a few Asian spins, like ahi tuna crusted with sesame seeds and accompanied by mango relish and wasabi mashed potatoes, or an appetizer of mussels steamed with coconut milk, red curry paste and lemon grass. At the bottom of the menu, almost as a postscript, are five entrees labeled ''always-available favorites.'' These holdovers from the old menu include tagliatelle Bolognese; the pasta has a stand-up-and-take-notice meat sauce touched with cream.

THE dogs seemed to be enjoying the sunny Sunday afternoon. The grounds of Lyndhurst, the 19th-century Gothic Revival estate in Tarrytown, were dotted with blue and white striped tents and a few yellow ones. It could have been a bustling county fair or a particularly ambitious farmers' market, had it not been for the unusual number of well-groomed collies, beagles, Afghan hounds and their diverse cousins in attendance. The 89th Westchester Kennel Club All-Breed Dog Show, on Sept. 10, was under way. The vizslas were strutting in one of the competition's 15 outdoor rings. Smoke was rising from the grills in the food tent, and a fluffy white standard poodle was looking imperiously bored while his human parents happily sorted through dog-themed T-shirts and sweatshirts.

An article last Sunday about a plan by the General Theological Seminary to drill geothermal wells into the sidewalk misstated the age of the seminary. It is 189 years old, not 99, and it has been in Chelsea since 1826.

The Education Divison and the entire staff of the Brooklyn Museum record with deep sorrow the passing of our longtime friend Evelyn Ortner, docent and Community Committee member, and extend heartfelt condolences to her husand Everett.

ANTHONY BOURDAIN When traveling, the writer Anthony Bourdain packs the important stuff: his laptop, an iPod and ''as many of my own brand of cigarettes as possible.'' His Gauloises Blondes help him get through the tribulations of trotting the globe in search of exotic delicacies -- like porcupine and raw seal meat -- as the host of his show, ''Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations,'' on the Travel Channel. Bourdain, a longtime chef, took his try-anything spirit to Singapore, where he sampled the city's street foods (Page 126). His latest book, ''The Nasty Bits'' (Bloomsbury USA), came out this May, and he recently elebrated his 50th birthday at the dive bar Siberia in New York. The cuisine? Papaya King hot dogs.

WHEN they renovated their 1735 three-level home in Upper Saddle River, N.J., last year, Robert and Mary Wortmann thought of everything: a home theater, a billiards room, a wine cellar and, the ultimate modern convenience, an elevator. It has power gates, a mahogany interior and a marble floor with wood inlays. Total cost: about $55,000.

Jay Leno The pope got a pick-me-up bouquet from Salman Rushdie. Told the pope to hang in there, that this will blow over in another 30 or 40 years. Al Qaeda's leaders have announced they're joining forces with an insurgent group in Algeria to fight the French. Here's my question: How lame is this group in Algeria if they need help fighting the French?

To the Editor: Emily Bazelon, in her otherwise lucid review of my book ''Not a Suicide Pact: The Constitution in a Time of National Emergency'' (Sept. 10), says that I neglect to mention that President Lincoln issued his order unconstitutionally suspending habeas corpus ''when Congress was in recess, and sought approval for it upon the Legislature's return to Washington.'' In fact, I state on Page 39 of my book that when Lincoln suspended habeas corpus ''Congress was not in session, and there is an argument for recognizing an implicit presidential authority to suspend habeas corpus when Congress is unable to do so but the public safety requires that it be done.'' (Congress's subsequent acquiescence could mitigate but not expunge the constitutional violation.) I go on to note that Lincoln claimed the right to violate the suspension clause in an emergency (Page 40), and that he refused to obey a habeas corpus order issued by the chief justice of the United States (Page 85). Bazelon's oversight is not important in itself; what is important is that we understand that a great president claimed a moral right to violate the Constitution in circumstances of dire necessity. Richard A. Posner Chicago

To the Editor: Re ''Playing It by Ear, in Her Life if Not Her Art'' [Sept. 17]: It's a bit of a disappointment that neither Stephen Holden nor his subject, Diana Krall, acknowledged Shirley Horn's importance to Ms. Krall's success, something the younger woman has done before. In the late 1980's Horn, a singer and pianist, returned to the world of vocal performance and almost single-handedly reminded us of what it meant to really understand the great American Songbook.

''WATCH where you walk. Don't touch or move anything. You can make maps, take notes. I'll be back to get you in a little while.'' With those simple instructions, William Wheeler, a science teacher, let loose the first group of five high school juniors and seniors in a classroom once used to teach music but now marked by blood smears on the floor, a dinner table set with partly eaten chili and half-smoked cigarettes and a bloodied wooden baton and cotton cloth.

There is a hint of ''Death of a Salesman'' in Julia Cho's poignant new play, ''Durango.'' But when Arthur Miller's beaten-down Willy Loman loses his job and his bearings, at least the play focuses on his struggle. In ''Durango,'' the newest production at the Long Wharf Theater's Stage II, Boo-Seng Lee (James Saito), a 56-year-old widower, packs up his pain along with the contents of his desk. He doesn't even tell his sons, who share his Arizona home, the bad news. When Boo-Seng comes home that night, looking forlorn, one boy asks, ''Is he O.K.?'' And the other answers, with teenage apathy, ''Is he ever?'' They sit down to their dinner, bowls of Dinty Moore beef stew, and Boo-Seng announces that it is time for a family trip. The destination will be Durango, Colo.

Joseph Guarino Jr. and Dr. Graham Thomas McMahon were married yesterday afternoon in Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Gregory Schmidt, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church. Mr. Guarino (above, left) is 38. He is the director of software training and technology solutions at the Stride Rite Corporation, the footwear company in Lexington, Mass. He graduated from the University of Massachusetts and is studying for a master's degree in computer information systems at Boston University.

Forget stock-picking. Anyone can do that. The true test of Wall Streeters' mettle is if they can forecast something really important, like what films will be the summer's big winners, and how they will rank. To gauge this essential talent, Thomas Weisel Partners has its Summer Blockbuster Movie Sweepstakes. And the winner is well, Don De Laria of Regal Entertainment, the cinema chain, who scored the highest, picking 7 of the top 10 films (''Pirates of the Caribbean,'' ''Cars,'' ''X-Men,'' and so on). But because nonbrokerage clients were not eligible for prizes, Rolfe Winkler of Matador Capital Partners was the official winner, taking home two tickets to a premiere of ''Employee of the Month.''

INTERNATIONAL 3-14 Iraq's Impact on Terrorism An assessment of terrorism trends by The National Intelligence Estimate has concluded that the American invasion and occupation of Iraq has helped spawn a new generation of Islamic radicals and that the overall terrorist threat has grown since the Sept. 11 attacks. 1 An explosion in the Sadr City district in Baghdad killed at least 35 people, mostly women and children, when a bomb detonated next to a line of women waiting to receive heating fuel from a tanker truck, according to residents and Iraqi officials. 8 Signs of Change in Somalia Islamic leaders in Mogadishu, rather than imposing Taliban-like constraints as expected, seem to be moderating their views, at least officially, and bringing at least the beginnings of order to one of the world's most violent cities. 1 Bolivia's Navy Seeks Open Sea An 1879 loss to Chile in a conflict known as the War of the Pacific cut off Bolivia's access to the coast. Bolivia has a frustrated navy that is confined to patrolling the country's rivers and lakes. Bolivia's president is slowly trying to press for the return of even a sliver of the Pacific coast. 3 Putin Rejects Europe's Fears President Vladimir Putin of Russia dismissed concerns over his country's growing interest in the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company at a meeting in France with his French and German counterparts. 4 British Debate Afghan Conflict The British Army defended itself against charges by officers in Afghanistan that British ground troops had received inadequate air support in their fight against the Taliban. Leaked e-mail messages from officers display a lack of faith in the Royal Air Service but also suggest inaccurate casualty reports. 8 NATIONAL 22-33 Families Rethinking Spinach Beyond the raw statistics of a national outbreak of E. coli linked to fresh spinach are individual stories of a sudden, mysterious, life-threatening illness that struck most often in the homes of those who viewed themselves as more health conscious than many other Americans. 1 Clinton Faults Bush on Terror Former President Bill Clinton, defending his efforts to capture Osama bin Laden, accused the Bush administration in an interview set for broadcast today of doing far less to stop Mr. bin Laden before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. 30 NEW YORK/REGION 35-39 Incumbent Changes Tactics Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a moderate Connecticut Republican, has changed tack in her campaign for a 13th consecutive term in Congress, shifting from focusing on domestic issues to criticizing her Democratic opponent, Christopher S. Murphy, as weak on national security. 35 Venezuelan Minister Detained Venezuela's foreign minister was detained at Kennedy International Airport while trying to fly home after the United Nations General Assembly meeting, prompting the State Department to apologize. 37 READERS' GUIDE In its daily news pages, The Times presents both straightforward news coverage and other journalistic forms that provide additional perspective on events. The campaigns for Gov. M. Jodi Rell, a Republican, and John DeStefano Jr., her Democratic challenger, said on Monday that they were negotiating to hold at least one debate in October. But they disagreed on whether third-party candidates should participate. Clifford W. Thornton Jr., the Green Party of Connecticut's candidate for governor, and Joseph A. Zdonczyk, the candidate of the Concerned Citizens Party of Connecticut, both qualified to be on the November ballot by getting the required 7,500 signatures on petitions.

To the Editor: I have only one criticism of ''Too Good for a Trade?,'' by Paul Levine (Op-Ed, Sept. 17): the curtailment of vocational education is not merely a Westchester problem -- it is a national problem.
To the Editor: Re ''How to Become a World Citizen, Before Going to College'' (Sept. 3), about students who take a year to participate in programs overseas after their graduation from high school:

Few thirsts run deeper these days than the one for self-improvement, and few recent books have slaked it better than the ubiquitous bumble-bee-colored titles in the ''For Dummies'' series. Since it began in 1991 with ''DOS for Dummies,'' which helped computer neophytes navigate the user-unfriendly program that predated Windows, the series has swelled to more than 1,000 titles and sold more than 150 million copies.

As the fall foliage season approaches, avid leaf-peepers can use a variety of Web sites to help plot their pilgrimage. On foliagenetwork.com, updated twice a week, some 550 leaf-spotters from the Northeast, Southeast and Upper Midwest report on color conditions in their area, which are compiled and plotted onto color maps. Meanwhile, those wanting to avoid the crowds should visit travelnotes.org, which has a list of the best fall foliage sites across America, some very much off the beaten track. Why not see the Texas oaks or the Alabama hickories this year?
Chapter 1

HAVING discerned zoning loopholes that can turn legal stand-alone studios for working artists into illegal rentals and surreptitious guest cottages, pool houses or storage space, officials in the artist-rich Town of East Hampton have proposed tightening the rules to separate professionals from poseurs and dabblers. But artists, an influential group here since the 1870's, contend that the proposed revisions would empower snooping building inspectors and town board members to decide who is an artist and what is art, questions that are unsettled in the wider world.

Erin Marie Trainor, a research analyst, was married on Cape Cod yesterday to Michael Rogers Blanton, an astronomer and physics professor. The Rev. E. Bonnie Goodwin, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Chatham Bars Inn in Chatham, Mass. Mrs. Blanton, 30, is an energy analyst at Medley Global Advisors, a research firm in New York. She graduated from Cornell and received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia.

To the Editor: Alan Wolfe, reviewing ''What's Liberal About the Liberal Arts?'' by Michael Bérubé (Sept. 10), says ''Left-wing domination of academia is so obvious a fact that Bérubé never tries to deny it.'' Obvious to whom? To people who wish to believe it? Is it true? Where are the facts? I have taught at numerous colleges and universities for over 30 years and have found that the political spectrum of colleges pretty much mirrored the poltical climate outside the so-callled ivy walls. But I supply a mere anecdote, and I do not attempt to pass it off as fact. It is obvious that the sun ''rises'' and ''sets,'' but that is not exactly true either. Louis Phillips New York The writer is professor of humanities, School of Visual Arts.

MILFOIL, an invasive lake weed, has wrecked many lovely days on the water by wrapping its slimy tendrils around boat engines or swimmers' bodies. That is disturbing to lake lovers, but perhaps not as disturbing as the weed's astonishing vitality: pieces of milfoil that get chopped off simply float away, grow roots and start new plants. ''It's like revenge of the body-snatchers,'' said Larry Marsicano, the executive director of the Candlewood Lake Authority, which has agonized over the weed.

The No. 1 Buckeyes, behind by 3-0 at halftime, scored 21 points in the fourth quarter, including two touchdowns on interception returns, to beat No. 24 Penn State, 28-6. Nittany Lions Coach Joe Paterno, who had the flu, had to leave the game in the second quarter and did not return until the start of the fourth. No. 9 Georgia survived Colorado. No. 6 Michigan beat Wisconsin and is 4-0. Break up Rutgers: Scarlet Knights are 4-0. Connecticut (2-1) won at Indiana. COMPLETE COVERAGE, PAGES 6-8

It's hard to know what to believe about the car of the future. Will we be forced to trade horsepower for solar power? Will wanting to drive a solid, comfortably appointed car that zips along the highway brand you as someone who is blithely hastening the planet's demise? Will we have to drive tiny electric pods that are energy-efficient -- but so cramped on the inside, and in need of recharging so often, that Americans' love affair with the road will become a thing of the past? The blanket answer to all these questions is that things may not be as dire as they seem. The internal-combustion engine isn't headed for extinction anytime soon, but that doesn't mean that some car-company engineers aren't trying to make it greener, creating a turbo engine that promises more power, but with lower fuel consumption and emissions, than its conventional counterpart. And in Silicon Valley, a young company has developed a sleek, high-performance electric sports car that its creators say is more fuel efficient than the hybrids now on the market while boasting acceleration that gives the Porsche a run for its money.

Ah, to be a pal of Gov. George Pataki. Or the relative of a pal. Or somebody who has worked, even briefly, for the departing governor. As Mr. Pataki fades from office, he is planting a field of friends -- hundreds of them -- in every nook and cranny of the New York State government. Some have been quietly moved from insecure, high-visibility political posts to safer jobs in the bureaucratic shadows where they hope to be spared the next governor's ax.

POLISAR--Jonathan on August 15th. Beloved son of Betty Polisar Reigot, loving brother of Paula, Diana Jean, and Katherine Schwartz. His zest for life, creativity, buoyant nature, and loyalty defined him. May his soul rest in peace.

GOTTLIEB--Anne. Died a few days short of her 100th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Martin Gottlieb, noted real estate attorney, mother of Professor Leslie Gottlieb, Dorothy Naskin and Sandra Ornstein. Grandmother of Dr. Steven Naskin, Susan Naskin, Michael and David Gottlieb. Great-grandmother of Benjamin Martin, Jacob Michael, Sara Michelle and David Mathew. Graduate of Hunter College, majoring in mathematics, she was founder and past president of Stephen Wise and Sutton Place Hadassah groups. She held many positions in charitable organizations. She will be missed. Funeral arrangements will be private.

To the Editor: Your item on my book ''The Righteous Men,'' published under the name Sam Bourne (TBR: Inside the List, Sept. 10) and the fate of an unflattering review of it for The Guardian, contained a crucial misrepresentation of the facts. The Guardian's editor did not, as you state, simply ''refuse to run the review.'' Rather he accepted an unprompted offer from the reviewer himself, made when he submitted the piece, to withdraw it for a ''modest kill fee.'' Indeed, the editor told the paper's ombudsman that had the critic ''not volunteered to withdraw the review and accept a kill fee, the paper would have published it.'' Put simply, the idea of not using the review arose only because he, the reviewer, raised it. The ombudsman made all this clear in his article on the matter. Jonathan Freedland London

In the year since its opening, Farmer Bar (also known as the Cutchogue Barbecue Company) has built a loyal following of Northerners who have a hankering for real Southern pit barbecue. Pulled pork, smoked brisket and savory Kansas City ribs are served in a former bar that was a farmers' hangout across from the old Cutchogue train station. Renovated by Dan Reyburn and Ron Philipp, who also own Big Mama's Creole Kitchen, a Cajun restaurant in Southold, the roadhouse has been outfitted with dark brown wainscoting, paintings of hogs and roosters, and a sign declaring, ''We're Big on the Pig.'' But don't underestimate this country kitchen: There is some sophisticated cooking going on inside.
This protein-friendly town can't get enough of the flame-broiled patty. Here, the ones to try.

A Film listing on Sept. 10 in a preview of the new season erroneously included an actor in the cast of ''A Night at the Museum.'' Ernest Borgnine is not in the film. In addition, the listing referred incorrectly to the role played by Dick Van Dyke. It is a main character, not a cameo.

LAST month, Gov. George Pataki vetoed a bill that would have prevented mentally ill prisoners from being placed in solitary confinement. More than a decade ago, as a judge, I would have been concerned with the legal implications of the treatment of prisoners diagnosed as mentally ill, but my concern is more personal now. You see, in 1993, I pleaded guilty to harassment, was found to be suffering from bipolar disorder and was sentenced to serve 15 months in a mental health unit of a federal prison. While incarcerated, I was stabbed by another inmate. For my protection I was locked down in what the state calls a ''special housing unit'' -- and what prisoners call ''the box,'' ''the hole,'' or simply ''solitary confinement'' -- which is used to manage the approximately 8,000 mentally ill inmates in the New York prison system.

SUSSAL--Pearl. Died peacefully Friday, September 22, with her family at her side, Mt. Sinai. Born December 3, 1919, in Brooklyn, to Fanny and Charles Pivnick, she was the last remaining of sisters Annette, Libby and Selma. Graduating from King Country Nursing School in 1941 with still best friend Charlotte she is survived by her adoring husband of 65 years, Morris, loving children Carol and partner Marquita, Jeffrey and devoted daughter-in-law Joan, Richard and partner Barbara, five beloved grandchildren, Jennifer, Joshua, Michael, Mikki, Emily, their spouses Wade, Jen, Gina and Adam, seven great-grandchildren, Marleigh, Olivia, Jack, Lucas, Brianna, Brandon and Noah, caring nieces, nephews, great-nieces and nephews, brother - in - law Alex, and a dynamic circle of friends. All will miss her special, nurturing love and bright, vivacious warmth. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to the Pearl Sussal Memorial Fund which will create a safe and warm environment for abused children through the Children's Advocacy Center at WIHD, 914-493-8147. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, corner 91st, Monday, September 25, 12:30.

IN presenting its long-awaited reconstruction plan for the 15-mile stretch of Route 347 in Suffolk County last month, the State Department of Transportation said it had been developed in a ''community-sensitive'' manner. But not everyone agrees.

Dr. R. Krishna Chaganti and Dr. Seshadri Chary Mudumbai were married yesterday in Bridgewater, N.J. Sri Bhadram Venkataramanacharyulu, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Sri Venkateswara Temple. The bride and bridegroom are research fellows, she in rheumatology at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan and he in anesthesiology at Stanford University Medical Center. The bridegroom is also an attending anesthesiologist at the Veteran Affairs Palo Alto Healthcare System in California.

ZUCCAIRE--Jacques. 97, on September 7, 2006; passionate artist, art director, advertising executive. Father of Philip Zuccaire and Jacqueline Auerbach, grandfather of Gabrielle Auerbach. He will be remembered for his great talent, wit, charm and friendship.

FOR the last two decades, Nathaniel Gibbons has parked his van beneath busy highway viaducts in southwest Connecticut. Meticulously, he cases the structures. His benign mission: taking lush, large-format photographs of the bridges of Fairfield County, specifically, the neo-Gothic and Art Deco-style spans on the Merritt Parkway. Mr. Gibbons, a fire inspector for Westport, describes himself as a preservationist bent on documenting the splendors of a road that is on the National Register of Historic Places. Printed on metal using a century-old ''wet plate'' technique, his moody, elegiac portraits detail the corbels, eagles, owls and urns wrought in concrete from 1938 to 1940 by 2,000 Depression-era workers grateful for the job.

Jennifer Joy Sodaski and Brendan Edward Tierney were married yesterday at St. Thomas of Villanova, a chapel on the campus of Villanova University. The Rev. Richard T. O'Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Tierney, 26, is an associate specializing in the marketing of energy derivatives to corporate clients at J. P. Morgan Chase in New York. She graduated from Princeton.

An article last Sunday about the ventriloquist Jay Johnson and his Broadway show misstated the title of a television program on which he planned to appear as part of a publicity campaign. It was ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' not ''Late Night With David Letterman.''

Nate Fackler, 35, an American who has been teaching English literature at a high school in Istanbul for four years: ''This place is only 250 kilometers from Istanbul, but it's a whole other world and a nice break from the pollution, traffic and rush of the big city. I think I was drinking Zagorka beers, standing in the sand at a beach bar with some hard-drinking locals, when I noticed the sun rising over the Black Sea. After the sun got high enough, I just decided to lay back and relax.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

Ah, to be a pal of Gov. George Pataki. Or the relative of a pal. Or somebody who has worked, even briefly, for the departing governor. As Mr. Pataki fades from office, he is planting a field of friends -- hundreds of them -- in every nook and cranny of the New York State government. Some have been quietly moved from insecure, high-visibility political posts to safer jobs in the bureaucratic shadows where they hope to be spared the next governor's ax.

WADLER--Herman E. Herman Wadler, the last surviving founder of the Wadler Bros. Inc, building supply center of Fleischmanns, New York, passed away Tuesday morning at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old and had started the family business in 1959 with his older brothers, Bernard Wadler and Arthur Wadler. A lifelong skier and gardener, Herman Wadler was an outspoken defender of the economic and environmental interests of the Catskills, where he spent his life. He was a member for over 50 years of the Fleischmanns Volunteer Fire Department: a member of the Coalition to Save Belleayre Ski Center; the treasurer for 30 years of the Pine Hill-Fleischmanns Rotary Club; and a vigorous opponent of watershed regulations in the Catskills. His wife, Shirley Wadler, passed away in 2001. He is mourned by his children, Jason Wadler; Lisa Wadler; Steven Wadler and his wife Karen; and grandson Alex Wadler; as well as the many nephews and nieces he taught to swim, ski, and bike. In lieu of flowers and in recognition of his love of his community, the family asks that donations be made to your local fire department.
The Latest Cells Do A Lot More Than Dial.

To the Editor: I read with interest Caren Osten Gerszberg's ''Grandparents and Grandchildren: Bonding on Family Trips (Without the Parents)'' (Journeys, Sept. 10). I do not believe that grandparent-grandchild travel has be to exotic locations. My 4-year-old granddaughter and I live in St. Louis. My father lives in Maine. He is disabled and unable to travel. I recently traveled with my granddaughter to Maine for my father's 90th birthday. During the party, my granddaughter would not go over to him, having never met him. However, when his birthday cake was brought out, she pulled up a chair and asked if she could help him blow out the candles.
An article last Sunday about the jazz artist Diana Krall referred incorrectly to the location of her home in Canada. It is on Vancouver Island, not in Vancouver.

WHEN the Bedford Community Church started about 25 years ago, it was attended by a mere 13 or 14 people. Today, the evangelical church has an average attendance of 260 to 285 adults every Sunday, said the Rev. Dwight Ford, its pastor. Because the church holds only about 230 people, there are two services.

Because of an editing error, the Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of ''Hugo Chávez,'' Nikolas Kozloff's book about the Venezuelan president, misstated its subtitle. It is ''Oil, Politics and the Challenge to the U.S.,'' not ''Oil, Politics and the Emerging Challenge to the United States.''

A translator is caught up in a plan for a Congolese coup in le Carré's latest novel. BLIND WILLOW, SLEEPING WOMAN: Twenty-Four Stories, by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Philip Gabriel and Jay Rubin. (Knopf, $24.95.) A career-spanning grab bag of work. KENSINGTON GARDENS, by Rodrigo Fresán. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) This novel's unbalanced narrator, a children's writer, juxtaposes his life with that of J. M. Barrie, the author of ''Peter Pan.'' SCAR TISSUE, by Charles Wright. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Wright's poetry extols the world's paradoxically permanent flux. THE MYSTERY GUEST, by Grégoire Bouillier. Translated by Lorin Stein. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) Bouillier's highly literate memoir gives sad, funny shape to a broken love affair. TOUCHY SUBJECTS: Stories, by Emma Donoghue.(Harcourt, $24.) Lucid contemporary tales in a variety of styles, with humor ascendant. WINTER'S BONE, by Daniel Woodrell. (Little, Brown, $22.99.) This novel's tough heroine seeks her fugitive father across the Ozarks, a milieu rendered in a ramshackle, beautiful realism. TWICE A STRANGER: The Mass Expulsions That Forged Modern Greece and Turkey, by Bruce Clark. (Harvard University, $29.95.) Both the diplomatic and the human stories of the two countries' post-World War I population exchange. THE PUNISHMENT OF VIRTUE: Inside Afghanistan After the Taliban, by Sarah Chayes. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) A journalist and aid worker's close portrait of a land still in danger. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

It is fair to say that the local reaction to the giant floating natural gas depot that Broadwater Energy has proposed for Long Island Sound has been overwhelmingly negative. The project, a joint venture of Shell and the TransCanada Corporation, has already been charged, tried and convicted of being an industrial menace by a chorus of politicians and environmentalists. This assuredness seems out of place or at least premature, given how much of Broadwater's potential benefits and drawbacks remain in the realm of the arguable and unsettled. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the agency that will decide whether Broadwater gets a license, has not issued a draft environmental impact statement yet, because the government has only just completed its official analysis of the safety and security issues Broadwater raises. The report was to be released on Friday by the Coast Guard, after more than a year of study.

Blast Near Group of Iraqi Women Kills at Least 35 An explosion in the Sadr City district of Baghdad killed at least 35 people, mostly women and children, when a bomb detonated next to a line of women waiting to receive cooking fuel from a tanker truck. Many of the victims were burned to death, residents said. Not long after graduating from Princeton in the early 1990's, Jennifer Senior got a job as a clerk in the Washington bureau of The New York Times -- ''which basically means I spent two years getting coffee, stapling faxes and answering phones,'' she said in an e-mail message. But she also wrote some articles for the paper, and when she was 24 she began covering Congress for a brand-new publication called The Hill, a competitor to Roll Call. Senior, who grew up in Brooklyn and Chappaqua (''I can actually give people directions to the Clinton house''), has now been writing about politics and a variety of other subjects in New York magazine for the better part of a decade.

Thais like to think of their capital as Asia's Milan, a city that's both a business center and a place that embraces forward-thinking design. Now, with the economy booming and local demand for unique-to-Bangkok fashion on the rise, a handful of Thai designers (many of whom have studied and worked in the West) are opening their own prêt-à-porter shops, most in the upscale malls of the central Siam Center/Siam Paragon shopping area. Here's the best of the new crop. SHERIDAN PRASSO

NOBODY wants to clean out the garage, although magazines regularly run articles featuring shelving units and stackable bins, pegboards for tools and racks for hanging garden gear. Such attempts to turn the garage into a clean, well-lighted space ignore the reality of suburbia's heart of darkness. Garages are dangerous places, the repository of poisons and sharp implements, accelerants like charcoal lighter and kerosene, gasoline-powered machines of greater or lesser menace. Usually windowless and damp as dungeons, garages speak of toil. Here live the shovels, the rakes, the hoes, the lawn mower.

To the Editor: Re ''Finding Real New York Noise for a Miniature Subway Line'' (front page, Sept. 21): While some find value in the ''racket'' of a subway car, many New York commuters do not. Over time, just 15 minutes of daily exposure to these noises can cause permanent hearing loss.

To the Editor: Jonathan Rauch's discussion of ''The Party of Death,'' by Ramesh Ponnuru (Sept. 3), was most welcome. However, one small point needs to be made. Rauch asks if evena life-threatening (to the mother, we assume)pregnancy could be aborted if abortion were to be considered infanticide. Heclaims that we do not have a ''health exception'' to the murder laws. Yes, we do; it is called self-defense. Arlene Kalley Troy, Mich. To the Editor: As a hard-line abortion rights supporter, I want to clear up a confusion in Rauch's mind between private moral considerations and public law. Abortion rights supporters have never said that a 10-day-old embryo is morally comparable to an appendix, or that pregnancy is comparable to appendicitis.I have argued that the decision to get an abortion should be a private decision by the pregnant woman -- no more regulated by the state than the decision to get an appendectomy. Pregnancy can pose moral, social, economic, emotional or medical problems for a woman that only an abortion can solve. Inserting the government into those considerations is what we abortion supporters want to avoid. If a woman becomes attached to a pregnancy and toher childwhen it is an embryo -- as your reviewer's friend did -- then of course she should carry thepregnancy to term and have the baby. We pro-choice peoplebelieve that the creation of human lifeshould always involve the willing cooperation of the woman in whose body it is going to happen. Adriane Ann Wallace Stamford, Conn
Hotels open as frequently as the networks cancel sitcoms. These are the newer ones to know.
A Pop Music listing on Sept. 10 in a preview of the new season misstated the name of the forthcoming album from the rapper the Game. It is ''Doctor's Advocate,'' not ''The Devil's Advocate.''

THE dogs seemed to be enjoying the sunny Sunday afternoon. The grounds of Lyndhurst, the 19th-century Gothic Revival estate in Tarrytown, were dotted with blue and white striped tents and a few yellow ones. It could have been a bustling county fair or a particularly ambitious farmers' market, had it not been for the unusual number of well-groomed collies, beagles, Afghan hounds and their diverse cousins in attendance. The 89th Westchester Kennel Club All-Breed Dog Show, on Sept. 10, was under way. The vizslas were strutting in one of the competition's 15 outdoor rings. Smoke was rising from the grills in the food tent, and a fluffy white standard poodle was looking imperiously bored while his human parents happily sorted through dog-themed T-shirts and sweatshirts.

It was a parking ticket that quickly descended into a screaming and shoving match at a rest stop on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, and now there are questions for Newark's new mayor and his choice for police director. Garry F. McCarthy, 47, was tapped this month by Mayor Cory A. Booker to become the city's top law-enforcement official. But on Tuesday he was admonished by a judge in Hackensack, who said Mr. McCarthy, a 25-year veteran of the New York City Police Department, used ''extraordinarily poor judgment'' while arguing a parking ticket.

SITTING at a table overlooking Bethpage State Park's vaunted Black Course, Steve Carl, a small man with shoulders permanently frozen in an Ed Sullivan hunch, is not too shy to disclose that he spent $10 million out of his very own pocket to renovate the dilapidated clubhouse that was the pride and joy of Robert Moses when it opened in 1935. Now it is Mr. Carl's pride and joy. Even if New York State owns the whole spread. ''Public-private partnerships are where it's at,'' he said.

Jacksonville Jaguars (2-0) at Indianapolis Colts (2-0) 1 p.m. The Jaguars were a surprise Monday night, shutting out the Steelers. The road only gets steeper, though, as they travel to face the Colts, an always difficult American Football Conference South rival. True, Ben Roethlisberger, the Steelers' quarterback, was not at full strength barely two weeks after an emergency appendectomy. Still, the Jaguars' stacked defense ruined the Steelers' running game and held the Super Bowl champions to 153 yards of total offense in a 9-0 victory.

PRESIDENT BUSH is coming to Greenwich on Monday to raise money for the State Republican Party in an effort to bolster the campaigns of Connecticut's Republican candidates for Congress, three of whom are locked in tight races. State party officials said they hoped to raise at least $400,000 at the event, being held at a private home in the Riverside section of Greenwich. Those attending will pay $15,000 each.
LEVITT--Stacy. 18 years ago we parted in the dentist's office. Miss you, sweetie. Mommy and Michael
To the Editor: Re ''Another Storm Renews Power Concerns'' (Sept. 10):

1. The Getty Center (1200 Getty Center Drive; 310-440-7300; www.getty.edu). Don't miss the Greek and Roman marble statues, the 17th-century Dutch and Flemish portraits, and the gardens, which include a natural ravine and a stone waterfall, perhaps the city's most relaxing spot.

Jonathan Mahler's article on Mayor Bloomberg was thoughtful (Sept. 10). The mayor is willing to stake out politically unpopular positions and believes that financial issues must be factored into any publicly financed projects. The World Trade Center site is fraught with emotion, and the mayor's positions may be deemed unsentimental, but I don't believe he is insensitive to the public's need to remember 9/11 in an appropriate manner. Since he has no legal authority over the site, it makes sense that he concentrate on the surrounding area. The atmosphere of Lower Manhattan before 9/11 was anachronistic, and the migration of business uptown made sense. Deputy Mayor Daniel Doctoroff accurately stated the Bloomberg approach: create an opportunity out of a problem. The quality of downtown life has been enhanced by TriBeCa, and now Lower Manhattan can become another hub of New York City life by including office and residential buildings, parks and a waterfront that is a magnet rather than an eyesore. Steven A. Ludsin East Hampton, N.Y

To the Editor: Re "Broadway for Dummies (and Ventriloquists)'' [Sept. 17]: I very much enjoyed Jesse Green's article on the ventriloquist Jay Johnson. But it should have noted that no matter the ventriloquist's skill at lip control, if a skilled actor is not there, it is all for naught. Mr. Johnson is a masterly actor.

An entry in the Paperback Row column on Sept. 10 about ''God's Gym,'' a story collection by John Edgar Wideman, misspelled part of one story's title, the given name of a jazz musician who figures in the plot. It is ''The Silence of Thelonious Monk,'' not Thelonius.

To the Editor: As an alumnus of Lawrence High School and a former resident of Cedarhurst, I was saddened to read ''At Odds Over Schools'' (Sept. 17). That community always had families of every religion, race, ethnic and economic status living in harmony.

Never shy about expressing his opinions, Ted Turner last week called President Bush's decision to invade Iraq one of the ''dumbest moves of all time.'' ''Before Iraq, we were the most popular nation in the earth,'' he said at a program held by Reuters at its Times Square headquarters in New York, ''and now we're one of the most feared and distrusted.''

I read Michael Kimmelman's loving remembrance with delight (Sept. 10). I had the good fortune to know his father well. I am a registered nurse who worked at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, where I met Dr. Kimmelman, and later worked for him in his office at 10 Downing Street for a few years in the 1960's.At that time, the overwhelming battle was for voter registration in the South for African-Americans, and a number of patients came to the office whom he had met in Mississippi when he went to support integration efforts. I remember meeting Martin Luther King Sr. and Bayard Rustin when they came in together shortly after Martin Luther King Jr. was awarded the Nobel Prize. There were many well-known Village residents who were patients. Barney Josephson, who owned the Cookery, was a charming man, and I remember our many conversations, mainly about jazz. Dr. Kimmelman was entertained by the fact that my husband was a jazz drummer, and I spent much of my life in the company of jazz musicians. He picked up on that lingo too. We returned to our home city, Rochester, in 1973, so I didn't see Dr. K. again after that, although we spoke occasionally on the phone. I feel that the times I spent in his company were among the most delightful of my life. Patricia Livingston Victor, N.Y. It was a surprise for me to see the picture of my dear comrade and friend David Kimmelman and his son, Michael, in Red Square in 1967. I was a member of that delegation. Dr. Kimmelman was a pre-eminent ophthalmologist and an engaging and warm human being. Because of his politics, he did some brave and humane things, like bringing the most modern surgical techniques to places like Cuba and Vietnam. On our two-week trip, it was clear to everyone in our group that David and Edythe were loving parents and that young Michael adored them. As I see it, Dr. Kimmelman's belief in peace, socialism, economic andsocial justice put him on the right side of history. When it came to parenting, we all should be so lucky to have had a mother and father like the Kimmelmans. Jarvis Tyner Executive Vice Chairman Communist Party USA New York I was a patient of Dr. Kimmelman's from the time I was about 5 years old (and for many years after). What I remember was a very gentle man who used to reassure me that my copious reading was not harmful, that it was O.K. to be an industrious student and thata little girl who wore thick-lensed glasses was cute and likable, in spite of the teasing endured fromclassmates. Each trip to the doctor was an aid in building self-esteem. Ethel L. Murphy Berkeley, Calif.

KOCHENTHAL--Irma Kruger, 96 years old; mother of Peter Kochenthal, Susan Griffing (Stephen), and Wendy Prescott; grandmother of Evan and Matthew Griffing, Jennifer Pagliaroli (Tony), and Josh Prescott passed away on September 21, 2006 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Friends and family are invited to express their condolences at the home of Peter Kochenthal, 225 E. 74th Street, Apartment 1K, New York, on Monday, September 25, between the hours of 6-9 pm. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

When an immigration judge granted asylum last week to an orphaned Pakistani youth who grew up in Queens, one argument she considered was that he was so Americanized, ''he would stick out like a sore thumb'' in his native land. Can you be too Americanized to be deported?

It took all of four minutes to drive in, order and drive out of the Burger King on Market Street in Saddle Brook, juggling a Triple Whopper with cheese, medium fries and a Diet Coke. Fast food indeed. So it may seem hard to swallow that the owner of that very franchise on Saddle Brook's main drag fought successfully to uphold a local ban on fast-food restaurants after township zoning officials voted to make an exception to it.

AT first there was something charmingly old-fashioned about it: Dad, Mom and the children gathered around, reading by candlelight and flashlight; people idling with neighbors they scarcely knew before; lunches and dinners cooked on outdoor grills. But the charm of a plague of darkness like the kind that struck Westchester three times this summer wears thin in today's ultra-wired universe. The children want to watch a DVD rather than turn the pages of a book or play gin rummy. They don't even know what gin rummy is. Husbands and wives need to check their e-mail 24/7, even on lazy holiday weekends. Cellphones and iPods need to be recharged. Trader Joe's frozen jasmine rice goes bad when the refrigerator dies.

To the Editor: In ''At Odds Over Schools'' (Sept. 17), about Orthodox Jews taking control of a school board on Long Island, it is suggested that Orthodox Jewish families do not ''feel invested'' in public education, since it is ''a system they do not use.''

To the Editor: Re ''The Good News About Oil Prices Is the Bad News'' (On the Contrary, Sept. 17), on why higher oil prices are good for the economy and the planet: The column said that ''the burden of higher oil prices, unfortunately, will fall most heavily on the world's poor.'' But this is not necessarily so.
MINES--Bea Maister (nee Browdy). We are sad to announce the passing of our wonderful mother and role model on September 8, 2006. Fredricka ''Ricki'' Maister Joanne ''Jody'' Millstone
KARP--Leonard David. September 26th, 1924 to October 15th, 1968. Forever Loved. Your daughter, Carolyn

The grounds of Lyndhurst, the 19th-century Gothic Revival estate in Tarrytown, were dotted with blue and white striped tents and a few yellow ones. To the Editor: Your article about General Seminary's geothermal initiative (''Plan to Drill Deep Wells Puts Some On Edge,'' Sept. 17) contains serious omissions. While stating that neighbors have sought official documents filed by the seminary, the article does not mention that we have already provided them. Also not mentioned was a public meeting we hosted (with more to come), and an e-newsletter we created to keep the neighbors informed.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the reasons some rich people go broke misidentified the University of California campus where Brad M. Barber, one author of a 2001 analysis of the psychological dimension of stock trading, is a professor. It is at Davis, not Berkeley.

Jets (1-1) at Buffalo (1-1) 1 p.m., Channel 2 JETS RECEIVERS VERSUS BILLS SECONDARY This year on draft day, the Bills, much like the Jets before them, passed on quarterbacks Matt Leinart and Jay Cutler to select safety Donte Whitner out of Ohio State at No. 8. The choice, roundly second-guessed at the time, suddenly looks terribly smart. In his regular-season debut, Whitner intercepted New England's Tom Brady, and in his first start, he made seven tackles at Miami. Joining him as a starter in the secondary is another rookie, Ko Simpson. Their challenge will be to limit the yards gained after the catch by Laveranues Coles (assuming he plays with a left shin injury he nursed all week), as well as by Jerricho Cotchery and Justin McCareins, above. NICK MANGOLD VERSUS LONDON FLETCHER Twelve seconds into the Bills' season opener at New England, Fletcher, Buffalo's middle linebacker, recovered a fumble by Brady and raced into the end zone. After the first two weeks, he has more touchdowns than running back Willis McGahee and wide receiver Peerless Price combined. While Fletcher was registering four sacks for the Bills last year, Mangold, the Jets' rookie center, was not allowing a single sack as a senior at Ohio State. KAREN CROUSE (NYT)
To the Sports Editor: Re ''For New-Sport Athletes, High School Finishes 2nd'' (Sept. 20): I'm not a parent, but if I were, I would certainly want my children to graduate from high school.

Three years ago, the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission took on its new name -- it was formerly the Department of Motor Vehicles -- and it has since made improvements in efficiency and customer service, according to an independent poll. But this past week felt like the old days of complaints about the agency, because its computer system was inoperable for several hours Tuesday morning and again in the afternoon, causing operations to come to a halt.

When the dust settles, the pianist DANILO PEREZ will be looking like one of the best things that happened to jazz around the turn of the millennium. This Panamanian musician is literate in Latin American rhythms, and so part of the wave of the recent, more culturally specific and vastly improved Latin jazz scene. But he is also, in a larger sense, defining post-Hancock, post-Jarrett mainstream jazz piano, with his harmonic knowledge and his will to make a piano trio exciting and fluid. He plays next weekend at the Jazz Standard with Ben Street on bass and Adam Cruz on drums. Thursday through Sunday at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m. (with a third set at 11:30 on Friday and Saturday nights), 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212)576-2232; $25 and $30. What changes jazz as time goes along may not be the quality of the musicians playing it so much as the conditions that create it. And a setting that was once integral to jazz culture but has almost completely passed out of it is the church, as expressed through certain kinds of melodies, in performance practice, in attitudes toward audiences. A program at the Miller Theater, ''JAZZ GOES TO CHURCH,'' should make the point nicely. The three featured performers are house wreckers: the pianist CYRUS CHESTNUT, the singer CARLA COOK and the saxophonist JAMES CARTER. Saturday night at 8, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799; $25.

To the Sports Editor: ''Putting all the Elements Together'' (Sept. 15) cites important team-building concepts that lead to better chemistry. Research has shown that cohesion is the most important of these concepts, so much so that the terms cohesion and chemistry are often used interchangeably in the literature of sport psychology and sport psychiatry.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''As Yankees March On, a Reminder of Rodriguez's Summertime Swoon,'' Sept. 20: Fans are not frustrated with Alex Rodriguez because of his bloated contract, but because of his arrogance, which he displays with disturbing frequency.

Giants (1-1) at Seattle (2-0) 4:15 p.m., Channel 5 JAY FEELY VERSUS HIMSELF Feely became the subject of a parody on ''Saturday Night Live'' after missing three potential game-winning kicks against the Seahawks last season -- one in the fourth quarter (40 yards) and two in overtime (54 and 45 yards). ''I'm sure they've got a Jay Feely Fan Club'' in Seattle, he said last week, insisting that he would be able to block out the memories if called upon to win the game this season. GIANTS OFFENSIVE LINE VERSUS THE CROWD Last season, the Giants committed 11 false-start penalties as they were razzed by the fans at Qwest Field. But the Giants want to do more than avoid penalties; last week, they allowed Eli Manning, above, to be sacked eight times and struggled to open holes for the running backs against the Eagles. A picture caption on Page 22 of the Book Review today about ''The Other Side of War: Women's Stories of Survival and Hope,'' by Zainab Salbi, omits the credit. The photographer is Lekha Singh.

NOBODY wants to clean out the garage, although magazines regularly run articles featuring shelving units and stackable bins, pegboards for tools and racks for hanging garden gear. Such attempts to turn the garage into a clean, well-lighted space ignore the reality of suburbia's heart of darkness. Garages are dangerous places, the repository of poisons and sharp implements, accelerants like charcoal lighter and kerosene, gasoline-powered machines of greater or lesser menace. Usually windowless and damp as dungeons, garages speak of toil. Here live the shovels, the rakes, the hoes, the lawn mower.

The police said they confiscated about $1 million in cash in a drug-related arrest in Dobbs Ferry, the largest such seizure ever in the village. The police said they discovered the money as authorities, acting on a tip from the New Jersey State Police, arrested Angel Sanchez, 32, of New York City, as he left an apartment at 383 Ashford Avenue in Dobbs Ferry on Sept. 13. The police said they believed that Mr. Sanchez was an associate of a man recently arrested on charges of possessing 10 kilograms of cocaine during a traffic stop in New Jersey.

GRIST--Barbara E. Of Oyster Bay, formerly of Lattingtown, LI, on September 22, 2006. Beloved mother of George H. and the late Keith. Visiting at the Funeral Home of DodgeThomas, Glen Cove, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass St. Patrick R.C. Church, Friday, 10 AM.

There are only six works by the Long Island sculptor Arden Scott in the current show at Dowling College in Oakdale: four free-standing metal sculptures and a pair of mobiles made of bamboo, cloth, resin and other materials. But that is more than enough to make a formidable exhibition, for some of the pieces are quite large, and each has its own discrete beauty and charm. Originally from New York City, Ms. Scott moved 25 years ago to Greenport, a once-sleepy North Fork fishing village that is gradually being overrun by affluent Manhattanites.
''Here you think you're feeding your child a great, healthy meal. But here I was, poisoning him.'' DENNIS KRAUSE, on the tainted spinach that left his 9-year-old son gravely ill. [1]

BENZ--Thomas Paul of New York City, NY died at home at the age of 41 on September 18,2006 after a valiant battle with cancer. Tom was the beloved son of Dr. Paul Benz of Pittsburgh and the late Mickey Benz; dear brother of Kathy Lawten and the late Rick Lawten of New Canaan, CT; Carol and Tom Holloway of Mt. Lebanon, PA; Patti and Jeff Mansmann of Raleigh, NC; Susan and Tom Callahan of Pittsburgh, PA; special uncle of 11 nieces and nephews. Also survived by business partner and friend Gail Schlentz and devoted girlfriend Jessica Jamieson. Tom was a Senior Vice President, Head of MBS/ABS Asset Risk Management for HSBC Securities (USA) Inc. A former Senior Vice President at Lehman Brothers, Tom also worked with Clayton Group and Bear Stearns. Tom was a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh and Chapter President of Acacia Fraternity. An avid parachutist and hot air balloonist, Tom will be missed for his kindness, compassion and sense of humor. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, September 30, 2006 at 12 noon at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 W 16th St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to Smile Train (www.smiletrain.org)

The officials who solemnly sit in judgment as show dogs strut, weave and occasionally fumble in the ring have, for many years, been judged themselves. Each must have at least 10 years' experience as an owner, breeder and exhibitor and must pass a written test on his or her chosen breed and an open-book test on American Kennel Club rules and procedures, as well as sit for an oral interview. Each must also complete a practice round of five judging assignments in the breed. Group judges must be qualified in all breeds in a group, and best-in-show judges must be qualified in at least one of the seven groups and have judged that group at least five times. The process can take years of watching dogs and slowly developing a sure eye.

In the move to improve corporate governance, companies have been adding deans of business schools to their boards. But that idea may have backfired on the Developers Diversified Realty Corporation, a property manager in Beachwood, Ohio. Last weekend, the chairman of the company's governance committee, Mohsen Anvari, 57, was arrested in a hotel a half-mile from its headquarters and charged with complicity to possess drugs, a felony. Mr. Anvari was visiting from California, where he was the dean of the business school at the University of San Diego.

Calling him ''the face of evil,'' a State Supreme Court justice sentenced a homeless black man on Sept. 18 to serve 25 years to life in prison for stabbing a white woman to death in a parking garage near the Galleria shopping mall in White Plains. The man, Phillip Grant, 44, who was found guilty in July on a charge of murder as a hate crime, told the police in a videotaped confession that he killed the woman, Concetta Russo-Carriero, because he wanted to start a race war.

Venezuela's foreign minister was detained at John F. Kennedy Airport yesterday while trying to fly home after the United Nations General Assembly meeting, prompting an apology from the State Department. The minister, Nicolas Maduro, was returning to Caracas, Venezuela, when he was prevented from boarding his plane, said Joanne Moore, a duty officer at the State Department.

An article today on the cover of Real Estate on adjustable-rate mortgages refers imprecisely in some copies to the current average interest rate for fixed-rate mortgages. It is 6.36 percent for 30-year fixed-rate loans, not for all fixed-rate loans.

A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about a 2005 book on information security threats misstated its title and referred incorrectly to its author, Ira Winkler. It is ''Spies Among Us,'' not ''Spies Like Us,'' and Mr. Winkler no longer works at Hewlett-Packard; he resigned in 2004.

To the Editor: What else could one say about the Orthodox Jews of Lawrence, N.Y., who now control the Lawrence public school system (''At Odds Over Schools,'' Sept. 17)? First, no one should be allowed to be on the board unless he or she has a child in the school system.

It's not every Connecticut town that has an honest-to-goodness New York-style deli. Westport has been fortunate in being the long-term home of Gold's Delicatessen, where some members of the staff have worked for decades. Cathy Bellardinelli, for instance, has been a waitress there since Julius Gold opened the deli in 1958.

With ''JESUS CAMP,'' two documentary filmmakers, Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, take us into the Christian heartland for a penetrating look into the future. Young children are exhorted to repent their sins, speak in tongues and pray for salvation, and they weep copious tears of ecstasy, inspiration and (it appears) pure hysteria. This is a very particular summer camp, run by Christian youth ministers bent on shaping young leaders of the fundamentalist right; their mandate is to take back America ''for Christ.'' The film is startling and gets to know three very determined young people. The close-up portrait makes you wonder how these children will change as they reach maturity and the age when they question their own conventions (like, is global warming really a media invention?). Opened Friday at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village, (212) 995-2000; and AMC Empire 25, 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, (212) 398-3939; expands on Sept. 29 to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington and Chicago. Two Buster Keaton classics, ''THE CAMERAMAN'' and ''SPITE MARRIAGE'' will play at Film Forum on Monday, the tail end of their BEST OF BUSTER KEATON series. In ''The Cameraman'' (1928), which was lost for decades in the middle of the last century, this incomparable comedian is in love with a pretty girl who works on MGM newsreels, and sets out to impress her with his camera work. (There's live piano accompaniment for two of the screenings.) In ''Spite Marriage'' from 1929, Keaton's last silent picture (with sound but no dialogue), he plays a star-struck dry cleaner who falls in love with, then unexpectedly marries, a Broadway diva. It's noted for a legendary scene of physical comedy in which Keaton desperately tries to put his drunken bride to bed. 209 West Houston Street, west of Sixth Avenue, South Village, (212) 727-8110.

To the Sports Editor: What is wrong with Pedro Martínez's crying (''Tears Shed by Martínez Are Not for Joy,'' Sept. 16) after his disappointing return to the Mets' starting rotation?

''WATCH where you walk. Don't touch or move anything. You can make maps, take notes. I'll be back to get you in a little while.'' With those simple instructions, William Wheeler, a science teacher, let loose the first group of five high school juniors and seniors in a classroom once used to teach music but now marked by blood smears on the floor, a dinner table set with partly eaten chili and half-smoked cigarettes and a bloodied wooden baton and cotton cloth.

To the Editor: Re ''Attica Endures: Walled-Off Facts From the Old Prison Riot,'' by Francis X. Clines (Editorial Observer, Sept. 17): We are the lawyers who won a $12 million settlement after decades of obfuscation by New York State in the 1971 Attica prison riot. ''Crucial details'' that the article claims have been denied to the hostages' families -- how the state police came to kill the hostages, how official discipline collapsed and where the lie that the inmates murdered the hostages originated -- were presented in detail to a federal jury in Buffalo in 1991-92 as part of Al-Jundi v. Rockefeller, the class-action suit by the Attica Brothers, a group of prisoners.

To the Editor: In ''At Odds Over Schools,'' John T. Fitzsimons, the schools superintendent in Lawrence, N.Y., asks: ''What's the lesson we're teaching the children?'' Here is what you are teaching the children: that public education is not worth supporting; that people's own interests are more important than the greater public welfare; and that one of our most important democratic institutions is dying.

To the Sports Editor: Anyone -- besides me -- happen to watch the Mets' clubhouse celebration Monday night while listening to the exuberant fourth movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, the ''Ode to Joy,'' on WQXR?

Anne Petronilla Davis, a daughter of Helen and John R. Davis Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Charles Lance Wollenhaupt, the son of MaryAnn and Charles T. Wollenhaupt of Stockton, Calif. The Rev. Sarah M. Kinney performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Greenwood, Va. The bride, 38, is an associate at Arnold & Porter, a Washington law firm. In 2003 and 2004 she was on leave as an assistant prosecutor at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia at The Hague. She graduated from Dartmouth and received a law degree and a master's degree in education from the University of Virginia.

The Middle East, says Syrian President Bashar Assad, 40, seems to be teetering on the brink of chaos. He spoke with SPIEGEL about his country's difficult relationship with the United States, the pressure to go to war, and the consequences of the wars in Lebanon and Iraq. SPIEGEL: Mr. President, the foiled attack on the US embassy in Damascus killed six people and has once again focused the world's attention on Syria's complicated relationship with the United States. What do you know about the background of the attack?
Eco-Mania ... Emotional Baggage ... Sydney's Billyburg ... Flight Survival.

The Greek Store in Kenilworth may indeed be Greek to you. The spanakopita, or spinach pie, probably won't stump you, but some other foods at this specialty shop, which has an extensive array of imported and homemade goods, may be deliciously unfamiliar. At the olive bar you'll find not only the expected Kalamata but also nearly 30 other types of olives, including Nafplion, Agrinion and Volos varieties ($2 to $13 a pound). There are olives stuffed with feta, peppers or lemon rind. The Mount Pelion black olives are good to serve at a party, perhaps with salty kefalotyri cheese, pita and one of the many different dips you will find here.

George Butterfield | Trailblazer, Raconteur, Scout As a founder of Butterfield & Robinson, the Toronto-based biking and walking tour company, now celebrating its 40th anniversary, George Butterfield roams the world by the seat of his pants. Not surprisingly, he is known as a travel seer. (B.&R.'s next hot spots? Tunisia and Tibet.) Have travelers changed since you started? They expect more. People freak out if the hotel shampoo bottle isn't the size of a milk jug. Have you ever been scared on a trip? No, I feel warm and fuzzy when challenged. You get paid to travel. Do you ever feel you're getting away with something? I go bicycling in Burgundy, sit down with foie gras and a glass of wine at lunch, and say to myself, ''George, remember, you're working.'' So I did sneak one by here, yeah. Any lessons to impart? Slow down and enjoy. There are no second chances. Paul L. Underwood

An article last week about the making of the bullfighting film ''Manolete'' referred incorrectly to Ernest Hemingway's book about Antonio Ordoñez, grandfather of Cayetano Rivera Ordoñez, a matador who helped train the film's star, Adrien Brody. Antonio Ordoñez was a subject of ''The Dangerous Summer,'' Hemingway's nonfiction account of a season of bullfighting, not ''Death in the Afternoon.'' In addition, the article also misstated the real name of another torero, Espartaco, who helped train Mr. Brody. He is Juan Antonio Ruiz Román, not Augustín Espartinas. (Mr. Espartinas is Mr. Brody's double in the film.)

Meghan Hammond, a daughter of Patricia and Robert Hammond of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Brian Shedlick, a son of Judy Dennis and a stepson of James Dennis of Glen Head, N.Y. The Rev. William J. Rueger performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Mrs. Shedlick, 26, is a physical therapist at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in Manhattan. She graduated from Manhattan College and received a master's degree in physical therapy from Hunter College. Her father is the managing director of advertising operations at The New York Times. Her mother, a registered nurse, is a health care consultant at Stuart Levine & Associates, in Jericho, N.Y., which advises executives on business.

An article last Sunday about the departure of Latino businesses from Clinton Street in Manhattan misstated the length of time that Clinton Plastic Covers, a slipcover maker, spent at 20 Clinton Street before leaving last year. It was 10 years, not nearly 40.

ESPERANTO: As its name suggests, the city's hottest new restaurant is an international affair, fusing Japanese, French, African and Scandinavian influences in dishes like wagyu roast beef with smoked seaweed porridge and wild rice jelly. The exquisite cuisine comes with a price: a seven-course menu with wine runs about $480 for two. Kungstensgatan 2; 011-46-8-696-2323.

The Nassau and Suffolk County executives have announced their budget proposals for 2007, focusing on easing or limiting taxes on residents. The Legislature in each county, which a budget-adoption deadline of Oct. 31, has less than six weeks to decide whether some revenue assumptions will hold up. Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, submitted a $2.4 billion budget without any tax increases. Its passage would make Nassau the only county in the state to deliver a budget with no tax increase for the fourth consecutive year.

THE thump of stamping presses, the snap-snap of spot-welding robots, the whir of air wrenches: These are the sounds of building vehicles, one of the most complex activities undertaken by humans. Although they are not set up to deliver vehicles to customers, several assembly plants offer tours to visitors wishing to witness the mechanical ballet in which thousands of parts are transformed into a running car or truck.
To some, parity is an ugly six-letter word. To Commissioner Bud Selig, parity is pretty. This season, he said, reflects that development. ''Absolutely,'' he said emphatically.

To the Editor: Your Sept. 17 editorial ''Hope and Housing'' correctly identified a major regional problem: the lack of affordable housing. Here are three additional suggestions that might encourage people to want affordable housing in their backyard:

COHEN--Theodore, M.D., 80, passed away on September 21. He was the loving husband of Barbara for 59 years, devoted father of Mitchell, Judy and Robert, and adoring grandfather of Allison and Jamie. He was the beloved son of Dora and Irving, brother of Sidney, uncle of Michael, Douglas and David, brother-in-law of Jerry and Sheila. His family will love him always. Funeral services took place on September 22.

It was remarkable enough that ''Urinetown,'' born at New York's outrageous downtown Fringe Festival, landed on Broadway, winning the 2002 Tony Awards for best score, book and direction of a musical. (The voters threw best musical to ''Thoroughly Modern Millie,'' possibly for its more tasteful title.) But it is amazing that the profoundly urban ''Urinetown'' has turned up in regional theater. The cast of the Gateway Playhouse's production has an uphill battle winning over its audience. At the matinee last Saturday, it seemed that people were puzzled during Act I, then talked it over during intermission and decided to like the show. Act II received a much warmer welcome.

DANCE has never had quite the same kick in Westchester County as other performing arts, and the reason, some would argue, is space. Musicals, operas, chamber ensembles, film series -- ''there are many places in Westchester that can do them all,'' said Paula Rubenstein, coordinator of cultural affairs at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, ''but they can't bring on a dance company because of stage limitations.''

POSTWAR: A History of Europe Since 1945, by Tony Judt. (Penguin, $20.) One of the Book Review's 10 best books of 2005, this is a brilliant account of Europe's recovery from the wreckage of World War II. As Judt observes, some 36.5 million Europeans died between 1939 and 1945 because of the war, and in its aftermath the continent was scarred with violent retribution, purges and outbreaks of civil war. The book offers a country-by-country analysis of how Eastern Europe shed Communism, and it traces the impact of the Marshall Plan and the rise of the European Union. ''Few would have predicted it 60 years before,'' Judt writes, ''but the 21st century might yet belong to Europe.'' In the Book Review Anthony Gottlieb called ''Postwar'' a ''rich and immensely detailed book.''

A coyote attacked a New York woman at the southbound rest area in Branford on Interstate 95 last Sunday night. It was the first recorded case in Connecticut of a coyote biting a person, according to the State Department of Environmental Protection. Master Sgt. J. Paul Vance, a spokesman for the State Police, said that the woman, Maria Gicana, 36, of Queens, N.Y., was bitten in the back of the knee. The Associated Press reported that she was attacked from behind in the parking lot while walking to the McDonald's restaurant at the rest stop.

questing / kwes ti / v. / going on a quest; seeking, as in, ' ''He's off to Germany again, questing for porcelain,'' or, ' ''We're aware that people are questing for great architecture -- that's why we're building this gazillion-dollar museum right here in Grand Rapids!'' A buzzword that captures the desire of been-everywhere-done-everything travelers to give focus to their wanderings by going narrow and deep.
