Dorothy Parker once called this megalopolis ''72 suburbs in search of a city.'' For an out-of-towner, that's a lot of ground to cover. T has sorted out the best of the sprawl -- first-rate sushi in Studio City, emerging art on Hollywood Boulevard, nightclubs without a Hilton in sight -- so you can spend more time enjoying the weather and less time battling the traffic on the 405. Text by Maura Egan

NOBODY wants to clean out the garage, although magazines regularly run articles featuring shelving units and stackable bins, pegboards for tools and racks for hanging garden gear. Such attempts to turn the garage into a clean, well-lighted space ignore the reality of suburbia's heart of darkness. Garages are dangerous places, the repository of poisons and sharp implements, accelerants like charcoal lighter and kerosene, gasoline-powered machines of greater or lesser menace. Usually windowless and damp as dungeons, garages speak of toil. Here live the shovels, the rakes, the hoes, the lawn mower.

HAVING discerned zoning loopholes that can turn legal stand-alone studios for working artists into illegal rentals and surreptitious guest cottages, pool houses or storage space, officials in the artist-rich Town of East Hampton have proposed tightening the rules to separate professionals from poseurs and dabblers. But artists, an influential group here since the 1870's, contend that the proposed revisions would empower snooping building inspectors and town board members to decide who is an artist and what is art, questions that are unsettled in the wider world.

An article on Sept. 10 about renting luxury fashion goods misspelled the surname of the founder of BorrowedBling.com, which sells and rents jewelry and other accessories. She is Carol Wexler, not Wechsler.

Starting Oct. 1, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on Sunday increases to $5 in the New England and Washington regions. The change reflects higher costs of paper, production and distribution. Monday through Saturday prices are unaffected.

JULIA CHO says that she writes about Asian-Americans for a lot of reasons, and not all of them are sociologically complex. ''I do feel some kind of responsibility to give Asian-American actors jobs,'' she said with a laugh. ''It's very pragmatic.'' Ms. Cho, 31, was taking a break from rehearsals of her play ''Durango'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. She has worked at Long Wharf before. ''BFE,'' her drama about a young Korean-American girl in an isolated Southwestern town, opened there last spring before moving to Playwrights Horizons in New York.

PATRONS of the old Westport Bank and Trust Company would never recognize the old vault these days. The lower premises now house Zest Cafe and Restaurant, a new informal place in downtown Westport, across from the Y.M.C.A. The owners of Zest, Pietro Scotti (also chef and owner of the local Da Pietro's) and his wife, Janine, have converted the limited space into a casual restaurant that serves food almost all day long. The color motif is green: avocado walls with a flowery mural on two of them and pleasing touches like mirrors, a glass vase here and there and a handsome barrel-vaulted ceiling with pine louvers that channel the excellent overhead lighting. The space is L-shaped. I like the more private area in the rear called the Vault Room, though it isn't really a separate room; it uses the old bank vault as part of the décor.

To the Editor: John Yoo, a former deputy assistant attorney general in the Bush administration, acknowledges that President Bush's unique approach to the law, which the president has insisted is necessary to fight terrorism, is motivated by the ''broader'' goal of strengthening executive power (Op-Ed, Sept. 17). Mr. Yoo cites this goal as a reason the administration has fought a ''pre-emptive'' war, ''data-mined communications in the United States to root out terrorism,'' detained terrorists without ''formal'' charges and conducted ''harsh'' interrogations.

Dance performances would be free, in the best of all possible worlds, with all artists earning living wages. The FALL FOR DANCE FESTIVAL, which opens on Thursday at City Center, can't provide that, for all the ingenuity of its conception. But the festival offers an extraordinary range of dance in six programs, featuring 30 companies from around the world and the United States, at $10 a pop. Why see ''The Covenant,'' when the likes of Trisha Brown's signature ''Set and Reset,'' Paul Taylor's fast-moving ''Syzygy,'' traditional Korean dance by the Yi-Jo Lim Sum Dance Company are on offer this week, along with performances by the Dutch National Ballet, the Pennsylvania Ballet, the French hip-hop troupe Compagnie Franck II Louise and others. Through Oct. 8, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan (212) 581-1212 or nycitycenter.org. Katherine Dunham, larger than life even after her death in May, will be celebrated on Saturday in ''A SALUTE TO THE EXTRAORDINARY LIFE OF MISS KATHERINE DUNHAM.'' There will be performances by companies including Ms. Dunham's Children's Dance Workshop, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Dance Theater of Harlem and Philadanco. The tight-knit family of vivid original Dunham dancers will be on hand, in an afternoon of reminiscences about an artist who was truly a great lady. At 2 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, Upper West Side, symphonyspace.org; free The Chocolate Factory in Queens is presenting yet another wonderfully nutty-sounding dance and performance event this week. The piece, ''LOVE CERVERE,'' is a collaboration between two veterans of the downtown scene: the dancer-choreographer Elizabeth Ward and Heather Vergotis, a saxophonist and experimentalist composer. Performed Thursday through Saturday, ''Love Cervere'' was inspired by a pantherlike medieval mythological creature known for the sweet smell of its breath, here an inhabitant of the factory's tomblike basement. 5-49 49th Avenue, Long Island City, (212) 352-3101 or theatermania.com; $15.

Anne Dobbin Sherwood, a photojournalist in Bozeman, Mont., was married there on Monday afternoon to Otto Conrad Pohl, a freelance writer in New York. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church. The bride, 36, is keeping her name. She graduated from Princeton. She is the daughter of Elisabeth Dobbin Sherwood and John Roberts Sherwood III of Annapolis, Md. Her father, who is retired, was a real estate consultant there and retired earlier as a lieutenant commander in the Naval Reserve.

IT had to be white, or at the very least, off-white. The sofa that my mother knew would be her last on this earth could not be dark or murky or even neutral. It would be a bold statement that at last, at very long last, she would own a wildly impractical piece of furniture.

As designers begin a parade of pink in women's clothing and accessories to mark October as Breast Cancer Awareness Month, Butterfly Studio Salon and the jewelry designer Dyanne Belle have created a token that can be worn by women and men. A leather lanyard bears a small silver medallion with an engraved butterfly and tiny embedded pink sapphire on one side and the words ''courage, hope, strength, promise, cure'' on the other.

Pennant Race Glance After today's games, a look at the remaining schedules for the teams with realistic chances for a playoff spot: Holding at Second Nick Johnson of the Nationals has hit the most doubles this season, 46, without a triple. Since 1900, two players have hit more than 50 doubles without a triple: Craig Biggio, 56 with the 1999 Astros; and Edgar Martinez, 52 with the 1995 Mariners. Clout in Colorado The Rockies have three players in the National League top 10 in batting average: Matt Holliday (.332), Garrett Atkins (.324) and Todd Helton (.305). Since its inaugural season in 1993, Colorado has had five batting champions: Andres Galarraga in 1993; Larry Walker in 1998, 1999 and 2001; and Helton in 2000. Pittsburgh Workhorses Salomón Torres,above, of the Pirates leads the majors in appearances this season with 90 and is closing in on the club record, 94, set by Kent Tekulve in 1979. Torres's teammate Matt Capps leads all rookies in appearances with 80 and is the seventh rookie to appear in at least 80 games since 1900. THE WATCH LIST The last week of the season will serve as extended spring training for a number of playoff-bound players coming off the disabled list. Tigers second baseman Plácido Polanco, right, was scheduled to return yesterday after being out since Aug. 15 with a separated shoulder. He should have four or five starts to find his swing and is an upgrade over Neifi Pérez at the plate. Rich Harden is scheduled to make his second start since June 4 on Tuesday after allowing one run and striking out seven in three innings last week. Harden, who was out with a sprained elbow, will be limited to 75 pitches. Depending on how he does this week, he could be a dangerous addition to Oakland's postseason rotation. Playoff positions have been clinched, but there are plenty of things left to watch in New York this week, including Pedro Martínez's calf, Jason Giambi's wrist, Mariano Rivera's right arm and Gary Sheffield's rushed transition to first base.
ROTH--Ida. September 26, 2000. Our beloved ''Granny.'' Six years in a world without you. Forever in our hearts. Diane and Larry

THE dogs seemed to be enjoying the sunny Sunday afternoon. The grounds of Lyndhurst, the 19th-century Gothic Revival estate in Tarrytown, were dotted with blue and white striped tents and a few yellow ones. It could have been a bustling county fair or a particularly ambitious farmers' market, had it not been for the unusual number of well-groomed collies, beagles, Afghan hounds and their diverse cousins in attendance. The 89th Westchester Kennel Club All-Breed Dog Show, on Sept. 10, was under way. The vizslas were strutting in one of the competition's 15 outdoor rings. Smoke was rising from the grills in the food tent, and a fluffy white standard poodle was looking imperiously bored while his human parents happily sorted through dog-themed T-shirts and sweatshirts.

OF the more than half a million New Jerseyans who served in World War II, perhaps none is remembered so grandly or persistently as the immigrant tailor's son in whose name 22 bands, 150 marching units, thousands of spectators and a Marine general will gather this Sunday in this small riverside mill town in the middle of the state. What draws them all is the epic saga of John Basilone, a Marine sergeant who received the Medal of Honor for holding off the Japanese on a critical night during the Battle of Guadalcanal at the war's beginning, and then returned to combat and was killed on Iwo Jima at its end.

South Boston's dingy waterfront, known mainly for its convention center, is readying for this fall's most hotly anticipated new building: the 65,000-square-foot Institute of Contemporary Art (100 Northern Avenue; www.icaboston.org), designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro. The first new art museum in the city in almost 100 years, it will feature a glass-walled top floor that swoops out above the water, a digital-media room suspended from a gallery for horizonless views and nary a support beam in sight. Add a Wolfgang Puck cafe and a theater, and it's no wonder city planners believe the ICA can help revitalize the district. Two other recent additions: the Westin Boston Waterfront hotel (425 Summer Street; 800-937-8461; www.westin.com; doubles from $359) and L.T.K. (Legal Test Kitchen), Legal Sea Foods' high-tech -- digital menus and iPod docks at tables -- Asian-fusion outpost (225 Northern Avenue; 617-330-7430; entrees $9-$24). HILLARY GERONEMUS

MORE than a hundred years after going on display at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, the mummy Pa-Ib has been determined to be authentic. Ronald Beckett and Jerry Conlogue, co-directors of the Bioanthropology Research Institute at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, performed tests, including X-rays, on Pa-Ib (pronounced pah-EEB) on Sept. 14. The results: Mr. Beckett said the bones and organs appeared to be human.
SCHLESINGER--Ruth Rubin. Gone one year. You flew away so fast. Sadly missed and lovingly remembered. Rest in Peace, my Sister. Love, Claudia

To the Editor: Rick Lyman's ''Hungary: Budapest Is Stealing Some of Prague's Spotlight'' (Journeys, Sept. 3) certainly identifies the rising standard of living and the activities and people who are making Budapest an exciting travel destination. I would like to mention another aspect of the city that impressed me. Statue Park reminds visitors of the culture's horrible Russian past. In this park are approximately 40 Soviet statues. If it were up to me, I'd rename it Remembrance Park. It has statues of Lenin, Marx and Engels, as well as other leaders from Hungary's Communist era.

FOR the herd of Black Angus cattle that roams Alexander Saunders's rolling 140-acre farm here, home has become something of an interactive playground. A group of local artists installed 35 sculptures and other works of site-specific art in August, and the cows have gotten involved -- knocking things over, moving sculptures around, taking the occasional bite. ''In our prospectus to the artists, we made it clear that the pieces had to be cow friendly -- no cables, no pointy edges, no holes,'' said A. Eric Arctander, an artist and founding member of Collaborative Concepts, the nonprofit association of artists that organized and administered the exhibition, which runs through Halloween.

GIVEN the ubiquity of former Gov. James E. McGreevey, who promoted his new autobiography on ''Oprah'' and, seemingly, in every news outlet in America, you might think that the hallways of the State House in the past week would have been filled with talk about what Mr. McGreevey says about whom in the book. Or, given that both Senator Robert Menendez and his Republican opponent, State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., got boosts from several high-profile partisans during the week, you might think that their race for the United States Senate was the talk of the political establishment, too.

The empire -- waist, that is -- continues to reign, in the form of cozy knitwear. Two of the fall's best transition pieces are cashmere sweaters made by the Color of Mustard, which are perfect for layering as winter approaches. The first, above, is a heavy-ply empire-waist cardigan ($328), with gathers at the bodice and a midthigh length. It can be worn as a jacket or under a coat. The second is a lighter weight A-line pullover with a mini-rib empire band at the rib cage, which hits at the hip ($228, both at Searle stores). They come in rich chocolate brown or basic black. Wear them with skinny jeans or leggings if you dare.

To the Editor: Re ''Teaching Math, Singapore Style'' (editorial, Sept. 18): I wholeheartedly agree with your assertion that more math and science specialists need to be teaching America's students. But as a graduating engineering student, I have two choices: Work in the private sector for an average starting salary of $55,000, or teach math and science in a public school, making far less money and settling for a lower standard of living.

LEWISOHN--Dr. Marjorie. Died in New York Hospital September 16. Beloved sister of Joan, Betty and Ginny. Devoted aunt of ten nephews and nieces. First woman Trustee of Johns Hopkins University. Gathering of friends to share memories at the Cosmopolitan Club, Saturday, September 30 at noon. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to PBS Channel 13 of New York City.

Two close artistic partnerships go head to head -- to head to head -- this week. ERIC BOGOSIAN'S ''SUBURBIA,'' directed by his wife, JO BONNEY, opens off Broadway at the Second Stage Theater on Thursday, the same night that the ventriloquist JAY JOHNSON comes to Broadway with his longtime professional partner, a wisecracking wooden guy named BOB. Ms. Bonney has directed many of Mr. Bogosian's monologues. But she has also proved to be an assured shaper of nifty ensemble work, notably the recent revival of Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July.'' ''SubUrbia,'' for those who missed the original production in 1994 and the Richard Linklater movie, focuses on nine disaffected youths hanging out outside a convenience store on a restless, aimless night. Mr. Bogosian has updated the text for the new production, setting it in the present. So the disgruntled youngsters no longer have to drop dimes in the pay phone to place a call. The promising cast includes KIERAN CULKIN, GABY HOFFMAN (of Wendy Wasserstein's ''Third'') and PETER SCANAVINO (''Shining City''). ''SubUrbia'' kicks off what could be construed as a comeback season for Mr. Bogosian. It will be followed this winter by a revival of ''Talk Radio'' on Broadway, starring Liev Schreiber. Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. Meanwhile a mere block away, at the Helen Hayes Theater, Mr. Johnson shares the stage with a former block of wood whittled into the smiling form of Bob, in ''Jay Johnson: The Two and Only.'' Mr. Johnson and his collaborator rose to fame in the 1970's sitcom ''Soap,'' and the aesthetic partnership has now lasted rather longer than the average American marriage. The show combines aspects of a club act with autobiography and a sort-of standup dissertation on the art of ventriloquism. It had a successful run off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Company in 2004. 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200.

As if there aren't enough breathtaking Picassos on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's exhibition ''Cézanne to Picasso: Ambroise Vollard, Patron of the Avant-Garde,'' along comes ''PICASSO AND AMERICAN ART,'' opening Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Ten years in the making, the show will examine this artist's effect on the course of 20th-century American art. It promises to be big, with about 165 paintings and drawings, nearly 40 of them Picassos, as well as a small number of prints, sculptures and photographs. Much of the focus will be on nine American artists who have been particularly influenced by Picasso and whose work has, in turn, had an impact on the next generation of artists in this country: Stuart Davis, Willem de Kooning, Arshile Gorky, John Graham, Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein, Jackson Pollock, David Smith and Max Weber. The show, on view through Jan. 28, will also include other important contemporary figures in American art, from Warhol and Man Ray to Claes Oldenburg and Marsden Hartley. But if you don't have the strength to tackle this blockbuster, several smaller exhibitions are opening this week too. One is ''SET IN STONE: THE FACE IN MEDIEVAL SCULPTURE,'' which is running Tuesday through Feb. 19 at the Met and consists of 80 sculptures, half from the museum's permanent collection and half loans from the United States and Europe. The sculptures date from the third century through the early 1500's and are made from materials like marble, limestone, polychromed wood and silver gilt. It will be organized to explore different thematic issues like the evolving notion of the portrait in sculpture. Also opening Tuesday at the Met and on view through Jan. 15 is SEAN SCULLY's first solo show in New York. Based on his ''Wall of Light'' series, it includes 60 works inspired by his travels in Mexico. The series -- paintings, watercolors, pastels and acquatints -- was begun in 1998 and explores patterns of light and shadows on the stacked stones of ancient walls and of Mayan stone.

Bita Emilia Nikravesh, a television news producer, and Dr. Matthew Dennis Ryan, a dentist, both in New York, were married yesterday. Babak E. Nikravesh, who is the bride's brother and a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the Peninsula Golf and Country Club in San Mateo, Calif. The bride, 33, will continue to use her name professionally. She produces segments on ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams.'' She graduated cum laude from the University of California, Davis, and received a master's degree in broadcast journalism from Boston University. She is the daughter of Ashraf and Abbas Nikravesh of Foster City, Calif.
To the Editor: Frank Rich's Sept. 17 column, ''The Longer the War, the Larger the Lies,'' leads to a very simple solution to the war: Let the Iraqis vote on whether they want us to stay or leave.

Back in the 60's, when Chinese food meant chop suey and chicken chow mein, and no one cared that the maraschino cherries in their sweet-and-sour pork would have been laughed at in China, there was a brief passion for Chinese barbecued spareribs.

SCHULMAN--Nathan July 8, 1905-Sept. 27, 1984. In memory of our dear father, Nat Schulman. A very special man. Brenda and Evelyn

MILFOIL, an invasive lake weed, has wrecked many lovely days on the water by wrapping its slimy tendrils around boat engines or swimmers' bodies. That is disturbing to lake lovers, but perhaps not as disturbing as the weed's astonishing vitality: pieces of milfoil that get chopped off simply float away, grow roots and start new plants. ''It's like revenge of the body-snatchers,'' said Larry Marsicano, the executive director of the Candlewood Lake Authority, which has agonized over the weed.

DESPITE a couple of changes in name and ownership over the years, many customers still refer to River City Grille as Benny's, opened in 1943 by Benny D'Agostino. And though the facade has been freshened and its chrome bands polished, the structure remains a dining car, with a bit of diner thrown in. Today's patrons seem to like it that way. The restaurant still functions much as it did in the old days; it is a friendly spot with few pretensions, and sometimes it seems that the whole neighborhood has turned out, particularly on weekends, for a convivial drink or dinner.

WHEN they renovated their 1735 three-level home in Upper Saddle River, N.J., last year, Robert and Mary Wortmann thought of everything: a home theater, a billiards room, a wine cellar and, the ultimate modern convenience, an elevator. It has power gates, a mahogany interior and a marble floor with wood inlays. Total cost: about $55,000.

VANDER ELS--Estella (nee Smith), died peacefully on Friday, September 22, 2006, at her home in Wyckoff, NJ. Estella, a descendent of the original Dutch settlers of Bergen County, was born in Waldwick, NJ, and lived there until moving to Wyckoff, NJ, in 1961. A 1931 graduate of Douglass College in New Jersey, she received her Masters Degree from New York University. Estella taught English at the Ramsey High School for many years. She was a former member and president of the Ridgewood League of Women Voters and a former member of The Ridgewood College Club. Estella was a member of the Wyckoff Reformed Church. Estella was pre-deceased by her husband Nicholas in 1986, with whom she was blessed with the opportunity to travel the world on many of the great ships, including the Queen Mary, the QE I and the QE II. Receiving of friends will be Tuesday, 10 until 11 AM, followed by the funeral service at 11 AM, at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. Interment will follow at the Valleau Cemetery in Ridgewood, NJ. www.vanderplaatfuneral home.com.

Louis Vuitton recently invited nine artists to riff on the company's products for an exhibition at its Espace Louis Vuitton gallery in Paris (101 Champs-Élysées; 011-33-1-5357-5203; through Dec. 31). Here, the French interior designer Andrée Putman explains her reinterpretation of the classic steamer bag. ROBERTA BERNSTEIN

The growing crop of super-long-haul flights -- Chicago to Shanghai on American Airlines began this spring; New York J.F.K. to Mumbai on Delta starts soon -- is a convenience with a caveat: 14-plus hours in the air can wreak havoc on your body, and new carry-on regulations prohibiting water, lotions and toothpaste make staying shipshape more difficult than ever. The best defense? A well-stocked travel tote. Elizabeth Schatz Passarella

Who really cares that CALISTA FLOCKHART is coming back to prime time, four years after her loved-and-hated character Ally McBeal wore her last miniskirt in court? ABC's ''BROTHERS AND SISTERS,'' which has its premiere on Sunday at 10 p.m., has all sorts of movie- and television-star power, including SALLY FIELD, TOM SKERRITT and RACHEL GRIFFITHS (late, so to speak, of ''Six Feet Under''). It is much more exciting that JON ROBIN BAITZ, the wildly talented Off Broadway playwright, is a creator, along with KEN OLIN. This could mean some blend of ''The Substance of Fire'' and ''Thirtysomething.'' It's about an extended California family with its own business, struggles and political differences. Oh, and its series premiere follows the season premiere of ''Desperate Housewives.'' Sydney Pollack has never made a documentary before, so he didn't know any better than to make ''SKETCHES OF FRANK GEHRY'' filmic (Wednesday night on PBS, check local listings). ''Sketches,'' part of the ''American Masters'' series (it also had a theatrical release last spring), takes a close look at the work and working style of Mr. Gehry, the risk-taking Pritzker Prize-winning architect. At one point he looks at a desktop model and announces, ''That is so stupid looking that it's great.'' You can wait until the Sofia Coppola movie opens next month, with Kirsten Dunst as Marie Antoinette. (The idea of Jason Schwartzman as Louis XVI is almost irresistible.) Or you can opt for the portraits and dramatizations of documentary reality in David Grubin's ''MARIE ANTOINETTE'' on Monday night (PBS, check local listings). Much of the first hour is devoted to Louis XVI's severe sexual problems, discussed in almost shockingly graphic detail. But 10 minutes or so into the second hour French citizens are storming the Bastille, and the queen's story turns to more public politics.

WHEN the Bedford Community Church started about 25 years ago, it was attended by a mere 13 or 14 people. Today, the evangelical church has an average attendance of 260 to 285 adults every Sunday, said the Rev. Dwight Ford, its pastor. Because the church holds only about 230 people, there are two services.

In this historic backwater, where the meandering Rondout Creek meets the mighty Hudson, Essel Hoenshell-Watson runs a tiny shop called the Alternative Baker. Kingston's claim to fame is that in 1777 it became the first capital of New York State and was subsequently burned to the ground by the British; Mr. Hoenshell-Watson's claim to fame is the delectability of his lemon velvet cakes. Made from a 1930's recipe, the cakes live up to their name; their velvety interiors are deeply perfumed with lemon and protected by a sugary coat of armor. Baked in fluted molds, they have the look of small, beautifully formed sandcastles.

A snarky caption contest probably was not what Buick had in mind last week when it sent around a photograph of its celebrity spokesman, Tiger Woods, with a new crossover vehicle called the Enclave. The picture, at right, was meant as a teaser for Mr. Woods's appearance with General Motors' chief executive, Rick Wagoner, in November at the Los Angeles auto show. But the writers at Jalopnik.com, a Web site that regularly mocks the car companies, could not resist spicing things up a little. They asked readers to submit their own ideas, then put them to a vote.

To the Editor: Representatives Jim Ramstad and Patrick J. Kennedy describe intervening moments that led them to seek treatment for alcohol and drug addiction (''Democrat, Republican and a Bond of Addiction,'' front page, Sept. 19). For Mr. Ramstad, it was going to jail; for Mr. Kennedy, a well-publicized car accident. It is important to note that family and friends can also instigate life-altering change. In creating an advertising campaign designed to motivate people to intervene on behalf of a loved one, or spur those in the throes of addiction to seek treatment for themselves, we confronted the barrier attitudes that prevent millions of Americans from getting the help they need. ''They won't listen if I talk to them about their problem'' and ''Treatment doesn't work'' are common sentiments.

SENNETT--Ted. Suddenly on September 21, 2006; beloved husband of Roxane, proud father of Bob and John, David and Donna and Karen. Adoring grandfather of Katie and Ben. Brother of Dan and Judy Sennett, brother-in-law of Roslyn and David Nitzberg and uncle to many nieces and nephews. A lifelong fan of movies and Broadway, Ted's zest for life will be missed. Services Monday, September 25, 1 PM at Temple Beth El, Closter N.J.

IT had to be white, or at the very least, off-white. The sofa that my mother knew would be her last on this earth could not be dark or murky or even neutral. It would be a bold statement that at last, at very long last, she would own a wildly impractical piece of furniture.

THE last thing he remembers is this: it was a hot day, and he was in a Hoboken nightclub hanging fliers to promote a gig by his band Amandla. He looked out a window and saw a parking-meter reader heading for his car. To avoid a ticket, he scrambled out the door, ready to call it a day. The next morning he would be heading out on a cross-country tour with his other, better-known band, Ween. When Claude Coleman Jr. woke up four days later, he was in a Newark hospital's critical-care unit with partial paralysis, a pelvis fractured in six places and brain damage. A truck had struck his car on I-78 West, sending it careening across the median and through several lanes of traffic; his wife and parents were unable to locate him for two days.

The celebrations of the 250th anniversary of Mozart's birth have not quite ended, and a late installment that begins this week may prove particularly interesting. VLADIMIR FELTSMAN, who redefined himself as a Classicist after being promoted at first as a Russian firebrand, is looking beyond the palette of the modern piano and exploring Mozart's piano sonatas on a reconstruction of a Mozart-era Walter fortepiano. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Tishman Auditorium of the New School, 66 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village; Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan; also Oct. 3 and 10 at Mannes, and Oct. 12 at Tishman; (212) 229-5488, newschool.edu/feltsman; $25, $10 for students and 65+, $100 for all five concerts. A highlight of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival was the streamlined, semistaged period instrument performance of Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' led by William Christie. Mozart operas are at their best when the scale is intimate, but the grand opera approach survives as well. For listeners who like these works sounding big and beefy, the Metropolitan Opera revives its ''IDOMENEO'' on Thursday. The cast includes DOROTHEA RÖSCHMANN, OLGA MAKARINA and BEN HEPPNER, with JAMES LEVINE conducting. 7:30 p.m., (212) 362-6000; $15 to $375. Though it has received less attention than the Mozart anniversary, the Shostakovich centenary is this year as well. His 13th Symphony, with its moving text by Yevgeny Yevtushenko, commemorated the 1941 massacre at Babi Yar, and its first movement is the centerpiece of ''BABI YAR REMEMBERED: YEVTUSHENKO AND SHOSTAKOVICH IN WORD AND SONG'' at the Museum of Jewish Heritage. (It will be played in the composer's two-piano version by Mischa and Cipa Dichter and the bass Valentin Peytchinov.) The program offers other Shostakovich works as well, and Mr. Yevtushenko will read his poetry. Wednesday at 7 p.m., 36 Battery Place, Battery Park City, (646) 437-4202, mjhnyc.org; $25 to $65.

WHEN they renovated their 1735 three-level home in Upper Saddle River, N.J., last year, Robert and Mary Wortmann thought of everything: a home theater, a billiards room, a wine cellar and, the ultimate modern convenience, an elevator. It has power gates, a mahogany interior and a marble floor with wood inlays. Total cost: about $55,000.
A Car for Living In

You won't find a knockoff of this watch on the corner. Sjoo Sandstrom of Sweden has just introduced its unisex Chronolink Worldtimer to the United States. The Chronolink, combining Swedish design with Swiss mechanical movement, has the straightforward good looks of a classic. Made of stainless steel and titanium, the watch has an analog face, which shows the local time. If you flip it up, a digital display shows the hour in a choice of 25 cities. Handmade by a team of four, the Chronolink has a leather strap in brilliant green, orange, blue or plain brown and a matching or contrasting dial. Then there's the fairest, most Nordic Chronolink of all, the Swedish Blonde Chronometer -- pale strap, white dial -- produced in a limited edition of 100 a year. (About $6,900, exclusively at Clearly First, 980 Madison Avenue; 212-988-8242.) SUSAN GUERRERO

WHEN the Bedford Community Church started about 25 years ago, it was attended by a mere 13 or 14 people. Today, the evangelical church has an average attendance of 260 to 285 adults every Sunday, said the Rev. Dwight Ford, its pastor. Because the church holds only about 230 people, there are two services.

PACHMAN--Emanuel: (''Manny'') died Wednesday September 6th, 2006 in Brooklyn N.Y. after a battle with cancer. Mr. Pachman was born in Brooklyn on October 1st, 1929. He attended Erasmus Hall High School and graduated from New York University in 1950. He spent 35 years as a CPA and founding partner of Wiss and Company in Livingston N.J., subsequently he was VP of Clement & Muller, a beverage distribution firm in Philadelphia, P.A. He was as dedicated and loyal to those he worked with as he was to his family. Manny worked tirelessly in support of many causes, most notably the state of Israel through his work with the United Jewish Federation of Central N.J. Manny was preceded in death by his wives, Margaret Patterson Pachman (1986), and Marcia Zamoiski Pachman (2004). He is survived by his sons Jeff and Greg, stepsons Joseph and Jason Zamoiski, and grandchildren Jessica and Hunter Pachman and Jordan Zamoiski. Donations may be made to www.uja.org, or the American Cancer Society.

Though I never met Susan Sontag, I have read nearly everything she wrote (Sept. 10). Sontag spoke of the dialectical exchange between self-revelation and self-concealment, and sheleaned toward the latter. She seemed never to reveal too much of herself in her work. Her novels had a bold yet cold intelligence about them. She allowed more pathos in her essays than in her fiction. This made her essays, for me at least, more pleasurable. I always hoped she would allow herself to write a more moving novel. I felt like a voyeur reading these journal entries. Still, I find these words irresistible. They reveal a vulnerability that we never saw in her fiction or her essays. They are so spontaneous, so raw, so uncalculated -- in other words, they are so unlike the published writing she let the world see. M. Reese Senn San Luis Obispo, Calif.

Robert King's new play ''The Best Man'' is set at a church minutes before a wedding is to take place, but neither the bride nor the priest who is to perform the ceremony ever makes an appearance. Patrick, the nervous groom-to-be, describes how Father O'Malley assured him that his future bride, Doreen, would soon be presenting him with the greatest of gifts -- her virginity. It is hard to believe he is talking about the same notoriously generous young woman we have been hearing about earlier in this funny if generic buddy romp, which is opening the season at the New Jersey Repertory Company.

Though there is ample evidence that a sizable audience still exists for ''Dune,'' Frank Herbert's multivolume saga of the desert planet Arrakis, there seems to be no surefire method for distinguishing these people from the public at large. There are no semiannual gatherings I know of where devoted readers -- Dune-iacs? Duneheads? Herbertologists? -- dress up like the noble Paul Atreides or the wicked Baron Harkonnen. And the once proud cries that the disowned three-hour cut of David Lynch's film adaptation be granted its proper place in the cinematic canon have diminished to a whisper. These days the only reliable mark of a true fan is his e-mail signature, where he can safely inscribe a line or two of the axiomatic wisdom that Herbert dotted across his ''Dune'' novels -- proverbs like ''A process cannot be understood by stopping it,'' or ''The real universe is always one step beyond logic'' -- as a coded electronic wink to his fellow pilgrims driving their caravans across the sands of cyberspace.
After dark, there's more to L.A. than tribute bands on the Strip.

To the Editor: After reading ''Jordan: In Historic Petra, Dazzling Sights for a Small Audience'' (Next Stop, Sept. 6) by Michael Janofsky, I'm seized with the impulse to pack my bags and hop on the next Royal Jordanian Airlines flight to Amman. Had the writer included John William Burgon's immortal couplet from the poem ''Petra,'' ''Match me such marvel save in Eastern clime/ A rose-red city -- half as old as time,'' I think that impulse would have proven irresistible. James V. Dolson Springfield, Va.

MILFOIL, an invasive lake weed, has wrecked many lovely days on the water by wrapping its slimy tendrils around boat engines or swimmers' bodies. That is disturbing to lake lovers, but perhaps not as disturbing as the weed's astonishing vitality: pieces of milfoil that get chopped off simply float away, grow roots and start new plants. ''It's like revenge of the body-snatchers,'' said Larry Marsicano, the executive director of the Candlewood Lake Authority, which has agonized over the weed.

NOBODY wants to clean out the garage, although magazines regularly run articles featuring shelving units and stackable bins, pegboards for tools and racks for hanging garden gear. Such attempts to turn the garage into a clean, well-lighted space ignore the reality of suburbia's heart of darkness. Garages are dangerous places, the repository of poisons and sharp implements, accelerants like charcoal lighter and kerosene, gasoline-powered machines of greater or lesser menace. Usually windowless and damp as dungeons, garages speak of toil. Here live the shovels, the rakes, the hoes, the lawn mower.

LAST month, Gov. George Pataki vetoed a bill that would have prevented mentally ill prisoners from being placed in solitary confinement. More than a decade ago, as a judge, I would have been concerned with the legal implications of the treatment of prisoners diagnosed as mentally ill, but my concern is more personal now. You see, in 1993, I pleaded guilty to harassment, was found to be suffering from bipolar disorder and was sentenced to serve 15 months in a mental health unit of a federal prison. While incarcerated, I was stabbed by another inmate. For my protection I was locked down in what the state calls a ''special housing unit'' -- and what prisoners call ''the box,'' ''the hole,'' or simply ''solitary confinement'' -- which is used to manage the approximately 8,000 mentally ill inmates in the New York prison system.

HOCHHAUSER--Marshall. At this very special time of the year, we remember the joy of our years together; how very much you remain a part of our lives, andour love that never fades. This year welcomed Max. May Marshall, Mae, Sophie, Emily and Max follow in the steps of your honored path. Love, Joyce, David, Scott and Beth

WATCH where you walk. Don't touch or move anything. You can make maps, take notes. I'll be back to get you in a little while.'' With those simple instructions, William Wheeler, a science teacher, let loose the first group of five high school juniors and seniors in a classroom once used to teach music but now marked by blood smears on the floor, a dinner table set with partly eaten chili and half-smoked cigarettes and a bloodied wooden baton and cotton cloth.

SWEDEN The News -- Voters in Sweden rejected the center-left government of Prime Minister Goran Persson in favor of a conservative coalition. Behind the News -- Mr. Persson, prime minister for 10 years, took responsibility for the election loss and said he would resign as the head of the Social Democrats, who have governed, alone or in a coalition, for most of the last 70 years. Political analysts said the defeat reflected a feeling among Swedes that the government was adrift and that the social welfare system had encouraged too many people to stay out of work. IRAQ The News -- American and Iraqi officials are expressing doubts about the ability of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to keep Iraq from sliding into full civil war. Behind the News -- Critics say Mr. Maliki, in office since May, has been unable to build consensus in the country's unity government. He is seen as reluctant to make decisions, in part because of his unwillingness to alienate fundamentalist Shiite leaders and his need to reach out to Sunni groups to end a Sunni-led insurgency. But in public, at least, Bush administration officials say that Mr. Maliki just needs more time. THAILAND The News -- Thailand's prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, was overthrown in a military coup while he was in New York for a United Nations meeting. Behind the News -- Mr. Thaksin had broad support in rural areas and his party won three elections, beginning in 2001. But opposition had grown in Bangkok and other urban areas amid accusations of government corruption and discontent with his efforts to muzzle press criticism. The military, which had staged 18 previous coups since the 1930's, vowed that it would return civilian rule but gave no timetable. HUNGARY The News -- Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany of Hungary came under pressure to resign after he admitted lying about the state of the economy to win election in the spring. Behind the News -- Mr. Gyurcsany's admission led to the worst antigovernmental violence in Hungary since the 1956 uprising, with more than 200 people injured. The prime minister refused to resign and insisted he would push for cuts in public spending, tax increases and new charges for health care and education. Critics noted that he and his party had postponed action on such economic reforms for several years. JAPAN The News -- On the eve of becoming Japan's new prime minister, Shinzo Abe came under fire from critics concerned about his conservative ideology. Behind the News -- Mr. Abe, 52, wants to revise Japan's postwar constitution, which limits the country militarily, and emphasize moral values and tradition in schools. Supporters applaud these moves, which they see as making Japan more independent and a stronger player on the world stage. But critics say Mr. Abe's tinkering risks undermining the values that have made Japan stable -- and wealthy.

Jack Banta, whose superb relief stint as a sidearming rookie right-hander helped propel the Brooklyn Dodgers to the 1949 National League pennant on the season's final day, died last Sunday in Hutchinson, Kan. He was 81. The cause was cardiovascular disease, said his son, Michael.
WALLIS--Dr. Robert, died peacefully on August 27th at 106 years old. Eminent physician and loving husband of Celestina Wainwright Wallis. Father of four sons and grandfather of eight grandchildren.

Some 15 years ago, I was a copywriter for an ad agency near the Union Square Cafe (Deborah Solomon, Sept. 10). Occasionally my art director and I would splurge and head there for lunch, just to sit and eat at the bar. Danny Meyer was usually up front greeting the line of waiting patrons. Scruffy and jeans-clad though we were, he treated us like favored guests and as though our business really mattered to him. He was so gracious that to this day, I still have warm feelings for the restaurant. And the food is fabulous. Robin Landis Ridgewood, N.J.

The officials who solemnly sit in judgment as show dogs strut, weave and occasionally fumble in the ring have, for many years, been judged themselves. Each must have at least 10 years' experience as an owner, breeder and exhibitor and must pass a written test on his or her chosen breed and an open-book test on American Kennel Club rules and procedures, as well as sit for an oral interview. Each must also complete a practice round of five judging assignments in the breed. Group judges must be qualified in all breeds in a group, and best-in-show judges must be qualified in at least one of the seven groups and have judged that group at least five times. The process can take years of watching dogs and slowly developing a sure eye.

When I first began to read comic books, in the mid-1970's, I fell in love with ''The Adventures of Tintin,'' the chronicle by the Belgian artist Hergé of the boy reporter and his dog, Snowy, who get mixed up in exotic, hazardous undertakings; in one episode, Tintin even goes to the moon. For a little boy living in sleepy suburban Australia, Tintin had an exciting, enviable life. Tintin's adventures closely paralleled events of the period in which they were created, including the Cold War and space exploration. In a similar manner, the best work in ''Masters of American Comics,'' on view simultaneously at the Newark Museum and the Jewish Museum in New York, meshes art, entertainment and politics. No doubt thousands of Americans feel the same way about Charlie Brown, Krazy Kat, Popeye, Dick Tracy, Skeezix or Little Nemo as I do about Tintin. These comics grapple with issues like immigration, world wars, racism and the invention of television.

When beginning any relationship with Ronald O. Perelman, personal or professional, it may be wise to get everything in writing beforehand. Mr. Perelman -- whose divorce from his fourth wife, the actress Ellen Barkin, was final on Valentine's Day -- fired yet another chief executive from Revlon last week and named a new one, the fourth chief in six years. But Jack L. Stahl, the latest ex-C.E.O., lined up a nice severance package before he signed on in 2002. In addition to being obligated to pay him for another three years, at $1.3 million annually, Revlon will forgive a $1.8 million loan it made to him to pay taxes on the one million shares of stock it gave him when he arrived. It will also forgive a $2 million mortgage it gave him when he moved to Manhattan from Atlanta.

Set for Takeoff Wide receiver SANTANA MOSS, above, is undoubtedly unsatisfied with failing to break 70 yards in either of the Redskins' two games. Today, he should return to his 2005 form (84 catches for 1,483 yards). He goes against the Texans, who have the lowest-ranked pass defense in the N.F.L. Glory Days Much has been made of Ravens running back JAMAL LEWIS's success against the Browns leading into their matchup today, but Lewis's troubles against the rest of the league have recently applied to Cleveland as well. Although he has tormented the Dog Pound in the past, the last two seasons have been a different story. All of the attention may provide the bulletin board material the porous Browns defense needs to improve its run defense, ranked 28th in the league. Failure to Launch The former engine of the Colts' offense, Cardinals running back EDGERRIN JAMES has produced below his career norms this season. The poor play of the offensive line has been part of the problem; his per-carry average is down by more than a yard from 2005. The Rams, who have given up 100-yard games to TATUM BELL and FRANK GORE this year, may be an ideal opponent for James to get back on track. Piling On Having repeatedly failed to produce this season, and having been regularly replaced by the rookie VINCE YOUNG, Titans quarterback KERRY COLLINS, above, faces the Dolphins today. He has never thrown a touchdown pass against the Dolphins in 12 seasons, but he has managed to throw eight interceptions.

James Traub describes latter-day Bohemians as being threatened ''not by penury but by gentrification'' (Sept. 10). But there are still plenty of starving artists in New York -- perhaps just not many left downtown. If, as the rest of your issue appears to suggest, being a neo-Bohemian simply means being a hipster, then downtown is certainly still a Bohemian capital. However, far from being threatened by gentrification, these cool kids seem to have plenty of spending money. While I fail to appreciate what is particularly gritty or oppositional about a lifestyle that includes Manhattan rents, limited-edition ''counterculture'' T-shirts and boutiques like the ones you feature, maybe I'm just bitter because I can't afford the new vie bohème. Chloe Holzman Brooklyn

IT had to be white, or at the very least, off-white. The sofa that my mother knew would be her last on this earth could not be dark or murky or even neutral. It would be a bold statement that at last, at very long last, she would own a wildly impractical piece of furniture.

Q. I am a month-to-month tenant and have received a 30-day notice of termination. Thirty days is not a lot of time to find a new place and move out. Can I request an extension? How should I go about doing this? And if the request is denied, can my landlord just throw me out without finding me a new place to stay? A. ''The 30-day notice of termination is the first legal step required for a landlord who seeks possession of an apartment,'' said Jamie Heiberger, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer. If a tenant does not move out by the date in the notice, the landlord can then start a court proceeding known as a holdover action to gain possession of the apartment. Ms. Heiberger noted that the letter writer can ask the landlord for an extension either before the expiration of the notice of termination or in the context of the court proceeding.

An article last Sunday about ways to invest for college referred incorrectly to some federal tax rules. While interest income on Series I United States savings bonds bought in a parent's name may be exempt from income tax in some circumstances, it is taxable for families whose income is above certain thresholds. In addition, the tax-exempt status of some provisions of Coverdell Education Savings Accounts, including withdrawals for elementary and secondary school expenses, will expire in 2010; other withdrawals from Coverdell accounts will remain tax-exempt.

10 P.M. (ABC) BROTHERS & SISTERS -- A collection of flawed adult children try to reflect their parents' perceived perfection in this new drama from Ken Olin and Jon Robin Baitz. Tonight, Kitty Walker (Calista Flockhart) returns home to California after having been estranged from her mother (Sally Field) for three years, and Kitty's sister Sarah (Rachel Griffiths) is lured back into the family business by her father (Tom Skerritt, above, with Ms. Flockhart). 7 P.M. (CBS) 60 MINUTES -- Thirty-nine and holding, at least this season, which begins tonight. 7 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- Christmas comes early in this two-part season premiere, in which Ty Pennington and his team set out on their 50-state renovation tour. First stop: North Pole, Alaska, where they give Betsy Rogers and her 12 family members the gift of more rooms, an extra-large water heater and, for those subzero winters, insulation. Matt Hasselbeck, Shaun Alexander and Lofa Tatupu of the Seattle Seahawks play Santa's helpers. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS -- Marge discovers a talent for carpentry and goes into business for herself. Homer becomes her frontman. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THREE MOONS OVER MILFORD -- Goodnight, moon. Hello, new life, which for Laura (Elizabeth McGovern) means a legal separation and for Michelle Graybar (Nora Dunn) an attempt at online dating. 8 P.M. (TLC) MY HUSBAND'S THREE WIVES -- Pam dreamed of a big family when she married her husband, Brian, 20 years ago. She just didn't think it would mean living with six children and his other wife as well. Tonight, Brian goes about getting a third. 9 P.M. (BET) LIONEL RICHIE SPECIAL -- He's not just Nicole's father anymore. Here, Mr. Richie (right) performs ''Zoom'' and other singles from his new album, ''Coming Home,'' and proves he's still got the stuff. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE INSPECTOR LYNLEY MYSTERIES, SERIES V: THE SEED OF CUNNING -- A floater in the Thames leads Inspector Thomas Lynley (Nathaniel Parker) and Sgt. Barbara Havers (Sharon Small) from the political gutter to the lofty corridors of power. Meanwhile, Havers tries to get a social life. 9 P.M. (HGTV) NATIONAL HARDWARE SHOW 2006 -- The newest and niftiest in home repair, improvement and safety. 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES -- Rain is dousing Wisteria Lane in this season premiere, and spirits are as damp as the weather. Gabrielle tries to hold it together with Carlos, Orson (Kyle MacLachlan, left, with Marcia Cross as Bree) becomes less of a mystery man, and Lynette, never one to brag about her bra size, tries valiantly to embrace her newly extended family, including her husband's buxom former fling. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

WATCH where you walk. Don't touch or move anything. You can make maps, take notes. I'll be back to get you in a little while.'' With those simple instructions, William Wheeler, a science teacher, let loose the first group of five high school juniors and seniors in a classroom once used to teach music but now marked by blood smears on the floor, a dinner table set with partly eaten chili and half-smoked cigarettes and a bloodied wooden baton and cotton cloth.

Should tobacco companies be blamed for the misperception that light cigarettes are less addictive than regular cigarettes, or should smokers bear the responsibility for the risks they take whenever they light up?

Do a Google search for "It's not easy being green," and you'll get more than 50 million hits. Humble Kermit had no idea what he was starting back in 1970 when he first lamented spending "each day the color of the leaves." Even though the contemplative Muppet sang of trees, mountains and oceans, it's kind of remarkable that his plaintive refrain (written by the lyricist Joe Raposo) has, in slightly amended form, become our most recognizable slogan for sustainable living: It's easy being green.

Last week in The Times, I reviewed the expensive but delicious new TiVo Series 3 video recorder. One key mission of the article was to explain why video fans might consider buying a box that costs $800 plus $13 a month, when they could rent a generic, bare-bones recorder from their cable companies for $5 a month.

At its height, law firm Coudert Brothers had offices all over the world, including London, Singapore and Moscow. Late last week, however, Coudert turned up in a far less exotic locale: the federal bankruptcy court in the Southern District of New York.

An unidentified "big hedge fund" is under investigation for trying to cash in on the tragedy wrought by Hurricane Katrina, TheStreet.com reported Monday. The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into whether the fund made improper short sales in shares of Hibernia, a New Orleans-based bank, just as Katrina's full impact was becoming known. The bet, according to TheStreet.com, was that Capital One would cut the price of its planned acquisition of Hibernia.

A Monmouth University/Gannett New Jersey poll released today shows that the New Jersey senate race remains tight, with the Republican, State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., receiving 44 percent among likely voters and the Democrat, United States Senator Robert Menendez, receiving 38 percent. 14 percent of likely voters said they are still undecided.

Have we reached The Year of the Depend Adult Undergarment? In the indefinite future that is the setting for David Foster Wallace's "Infinite Jest," the celestial jukebox/television has arrived, and viewers can time-shift to their heart's content, as everything in recorded history is on-demand, all the time. But when one character is asked the open-ended question, "What do you miss?", he replies, "I miss TV." He later explains, "The choice, see. It ruins it somehow. With television you were subjected to repetition. The familiarity was inflicted. Different now."

The global luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton has long employed investigators and lawyers to fight counterfeiters who churn out fake Vuitton bags and Dior sunglasses. A 46-year-old man was stabbed in the torso early yesterday in an apartment on Mount Hope Place, in the Tremont area, where the police said he appeared to have been using drugs with his attacker. The victim, identified as Michael Wilson, was pronounced dead at St. Barnabas Hospital, and another man, Jeffrey Williams, 47, was arrested at the apartment and charged with murder, the police said.

A Staten Island woman was killed when a car driven by an off-duty New York City police officer flipped over in the eastbound lanes of Interstate 78 about 4 p.m. yesterday, the state police said. The victim, Stacy Rasmussen, 25, died at a Pennsylvania hospital. The car’s driver, Donna Bartuccelli, 37, and another passenger, Susan Amundsen, 32, both of Staten Island. were in stable condition at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Police were investigating but said last night that no charges had been filed.

The body of an infant was discovered yesterday in a plastic bag in a vacant lot in Park Hill, the police said. The child’s identity, sex and cause of death had not been determined last night. The police said someone walking a dog found the body in the lot at Oder Avenue and Steuben Street about noon and stopped a passing fire truck. Firefighters then called the police. It was unclear how long the body had been there, and the case was being investigated by the medical examiner, the authorities said.

A 20-year-old man was arrested and charged in the killing of another man. The arrested man, Shamar Simms of Duryea Avenue in the Bronx, was charged with murder, criminal possession of a weapon and menacing. The police said he was one of three men seen fleeing the scene of the shooting of David Omar White Floyd, 22, outside the Edenwald Houses at 1150 East 229th Street in the Edenwald section of the Bronx about midnight on Saturday.

A 62-year-old man died of head injuries yesterday after he was beaten by his nephew at their Bruckner Boulevard apartment, the police said. A dispute between the men over money escalated into a physical fight shortly after 7 a.m., the police said. The uncle, whom they identified as Simroy Spencer, was pronounced dead at Jacobi Medical Center. His nephew, Alrick Hemmings, 31, was arrested, though he had not been charged last night, the police said. Neighbors in the building in Castle Hill said Mr. Hemmings was quiet and polite and was known for his attentiveness to his grandmother, who also lived in the apartment. During a power failure, one neighbor said, Mr. Hemmings was seen carrying her down 14 flights of stairs to the ground floor.

Officials with Local 387 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees have accused the State Department of Correction of promoting a low-quality training program for correction officers. The union officials also said the department had not accurately reported correction officers’ training hours and that many were not getting adequate training. In a letter sent last week to Correction Commissioner Theresa Lantz, the leaders of the local said their concerns were shared by two other union locals that represent correction workers, The Hartford Courant reported. A spokesman for the department said it was looking into the union’s assertions.

Hewlett-Packard has said that it spied on its directors and on journalists to try to determine the source of leaks from its directors’ meetings. Among the witnesses at the hearing will be Mark V. Hurd, the company’s chief executive and chairman; Patricia C. Dunn, who resigned as chairman on Friday; Ann O. Baskins, the general counsel; and Larry W. Sonsini, a lawyer from the firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati who advised Hewlett-Packard. (Thursday.).

A front-page article on Sept. 11 about President Bush's visit to ground zero to commemorate the fifth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks omitted the name of one of the two victims who were sons of Jane Vigiano, who sat beside Mr. Bush at St. Paul's Chapel. Besides her son Joe, a New York police detective, Ms. Vigiano also lost her son John, a firefighter.

Scissor Sisters ''Ta-Dah'' (Universal Motown) Two years ago this over-the-top American band became a British sensation. They scored a left-field smash -- a Bee-Gees-ish cover of Pink Floyd's ''Comfortably Numb'' -- and then kept making hits, converting young clubbers and old Elton John fans alike. (The band also converted Sir Elton, who has become a mentor.) By the time the year was done, the self-titled Scissors Sisters debut album sold over 1.5 million copies in Britain, making it that country's best-selling CD in 2004.

With political relations between the United States and Venezuela already very tense, the brief detention of the Venezuelan foreign minister over the weekend in New York worsened matters here on Sunday. Demonstrators allied with President Hugo Chávez protested the treatment of Nicolás Maduro, the foreign minister, who was detained Saturday for about an hour at Kennedy International Airport while trying to fly home after the United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York last week.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's trip to California last week was as much about raising money for his new political paisan, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, below, as anything else. But people who attended the fund-raisers seemed struck by the New York mayor and his politics, despite Mr. Bloomberg's repeated denials of having any national ambitions. ''I just think he's refreshing,'' said Preston Butcher, a real-estate developer who attended the first fund-raiser, at a hotel in East Palo Alto. ''He doesn't talk out of both sides of his mouth. He's more interested in people than he is in the party.''

Brett Favre, right, became the second player to throw 400 touchdown passes as he led the Packers to a 31-24 victory at Detroit yesterday. He joined Dan Marino in the 400 club with his first touchdown pass. He threw for two more on his 340-yard day and will need another 18 to reach Marino's total of 420. Mark Brunell, right, of the Redskins completed a record 22 straight passes. Chris Simms had his spleen removed. The Broncos defeated the Patriots. PAGES D5-D8
To the Editor: Re Bob Herbert's observation that the Democrats ''have gone into a coma'' (''The Kafka Strategy,'' column, Sept. 18):

CATE--William Clark, Sr. 86, WWII veteran, life time resident of Cambridge, MA, died peacefully at home September 22, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Vaughan Downer Cate. Survived by five children: Vaughan C. Grubbs, Cambridge, MA, Araline U. Cate, Portland, OR, Lisa C. Stiegel, Sudbury, MA, Wm. Clark Cate, Jr., Ocean Grove NJ, and Delavan B.D. Cate, Brookline MA; six grandchildren: Alisa, Sarah, Jessica, Anna, Kurt, Greg and a brother; Philip T. Cate, Jr., of Santa Fe, NM. Relatives and friends are welcome at the family home on Tuesday, September 26 between 3:00 and 8:00 pm. In lieu of flowers please send contributions in his name to the Lake Sunapee Protective Assoc., 72 Main St., PO Box 683, Sunapee, NH, 03782.

Janet Jackson ''20 Years Old'' (Virgin) Janet Jackson starts her new album, ''20 Years Old,'' with a spoken reminder that over the last 20 years she has done songs about ''racism, spousal abuse, empowering women.'' Of course none of those topics are what made her a star: sex. Janet (as she now bills herself) has happily devoted most of her career to teasing, pleasing and heavy breathing, and she's not stopping on ''20 Years Old.''

Study of Iraq War and Terror Stirs Political Responses Reacting to an intelligence report that found that the Iraq war had invigorated Islamic radicalism, Democrats said a new war strategy was needed, while Republicans defended the American presence in Iraq. To the consternation of some New York Republican leaders, their candidate for governor, John Faso, is asking them to pay for ''Faso for Governor'' lawn signs, which campaigns typically provide free. Although Mr. Faso is struggling financially, lagging millions of dollars behind the Democratic nominee, Eliot Spitzer, his advisers say this version of pay-for-play has nothing to do with fund-raising.

OSTOW--Mortimer. We announce with a deep sense of loss the passing of Dr. Mortimer Ostow, who was for many decades the director and scientific leader of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund. His leadership established the intellectual exchange of colleagues in the field of psychoanalysis with many resulting publications. His own creative studies and publications in so many areas of the human experience was a model to all of us. We shall continue to follow his legacy. Peter B. Neubauer, MD Henry Nunberg, MD, Executive Secretary of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund $(6$)OSTOW--Mortimer. 88, September 23, 2006. Husband of the late Miriam. Father of Robin, M. Jeremy, Abigail and Rachel. Father-in-law of Carmen, Arthur and Brian. Grandfather of Natascha, Rachel, Todd, Micol, Naomi, Oliver, Joseph, David, Nurit, Sarah, Ilana, Micah and Hannah, and great-grandfather of Miriam Lubrich. Brother of Evelyn Mandelker and Shari Friedman. Devoted to his family, dedicated physician, distinguished scholar and teacher and committed Jew. He is called friend, beloved. And they enjoy from him counsel, and sound wisdom, understanding, and strength. Funeral services Monday, 12 noon at Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th Street, Riverdale (Bronx), NY 10471. Shiva at 4421 Douglas Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471, Monday evening through Friday afternoon, and Saturday evening.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.N. Force, on the Ground, Says Its Hands Are Tied The United Nations Security Council resolution was seen at the time as the best way to halt the war between Israel and Hezbollah, but the resolution's language leaves open the question of what kind of policing power would be given to the international forces. A1 Iran's Right Seeks More Power Political jockeying by fundamentalist clerics in Iran for the coming election of the Assembly of Experts, the group charged with overseeing the country's supreme leader, is raising concerns that the government will move further toward authoritarianism. A12 Iraqis Agree to Autonomy Talks Iraqi political leaders agreed to start debate on a bill that has been at the heart of one of the most critical and divisive issues in Iraq: Whether Shiites in the south will be able to form semi-independent regions, as Iraqi Kurds have done in the north, that would control their own security as well as billions of barrels of oil. A4 Weighing In on Report Democratic lawmakers, responding to an intelligence report that found that the Iraq war has worsened the global terrorist threat, said the assessment demonstrates that the Bush administration needs to devise a new strategy for the war. Republican Congressional leaders did not dispute the accuracy of the reports, although they continued to defend the American presence in Iraq. A10 More Details on Torture Case A report by a commission in Canada offers new insight into American actions in the deportation of Maher Arar. It describes the evidence behind the decision to send him to Syria, an attempt by American officials to deceive Canada about where he was, and confusion among top American officials about the two countries' roles in the case. A10 Brazilian Ahead Despite Trials President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's support and legitimacy were sapped by the biggest corruption scandal in the country's modern history. But victory in the election seems probable anyway. A8 Thailand Bans Book on King A detailing new and comprehensive history of the modern Thai royalty, written by an American journalist has been banned in Thailand. The book argues that in his 60-year reign King Bhumibol Adulyadej has generally exercised a preference for order over democracy. A3 Chinese Official Detained The powerful party boss of Shanghai, Chen Liangyu, has been detained for corruption, the Chinese state media confirmed. The action is considered part of an expanding crackdown by President Hu Jintao on graft that has focused on his political opponents. As Shanghai party boss, Mr. Chen enjoyed considerable leeway to run China's wealthiest urban region and his machine is considered one of the most corrupt. A10 NATIONAL A14-23 G.O.P. Brawn Put to Test In Pennsylvania Race As the midterm campaign enters its final stretch, Republican fortifications will be tested around the country but arguably nowhere as much as in Pennsylvania. Senator Rick Santorum has lagged behind State Treasurer Bob Casey in opinion polls, at times by double digits. His seat has become the Democrats' best hope for one of the six seats they need to regain a Senate majority. A1 Christian Right Weighs Tactics Openly anxious about grass roots disaffection from the Republican Party, conservative Christian organizers are reaching for causes to turn out voters this November, including raising the novel argument that recognizing same-sex marriage could also limit religious freedom. A16 Strains of War Show on Unit The pressures that the conflict in Iraq is putting on the Army are apparent in southeast Georgia, where the Third Infantry Division is preparing to go back to Iraq for a third tour. A1 Congress Leaves Much Undone Procrastination, power struggles and partisanship have left Congress with substantial work to finish before breaking for the elections. The fast-approaching recess and Republican focus on national security legislation makes it likely that much that remains will fall by the wayside. A20 Medicare Under Scrutiny Government records and interviews with federal officials show that Medicare's mistaken refund of 230,000 premiums was only the latest example of an often dysfunctional relationship between Social Security and Medicare. A14 Industry Fears Cost of E. Coli The halt in the spinach harvest ripples through all kinds of businesses and trades, from pickers left without work to packers left without product to restaurateurs left without ingredients. A14 Fate of a Monorail in Doubt Before the breakdowns and the budget problems it was a fantasy made real. But now the Seattle monorail, which opened in 1962 for the World's Fair, mostly sits, waiting for repair, and affirmation. A23 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 In Tiny New York Courts, Abuses of Law and Power A yearlong examination of New York's justice courts has found overwhelming evidence that people have often been denied fundamental legal rights, defendants have been jailed illegally and others have been subjected to racial and sexual bigotry so explicit it seems to come from some other place and time. A1 Needle Exchange Rethought New Jersey lawmakers may well pass a bill soon to that would allow pilot needle exchange programs in the state. B1 Abuse Cited at Two Centers A 134-page report released by Human Rights Watch and the American Civil Liberties Union on two juvenile facilities for girls in upstate New York concludes that the teenage girls are being abused, neglected and subjected to sexual harassment and assault. B3 SPORTSMONDAY D1-9 U.S. Golfers Lose in Ireland After two years preparing for a tussle in the 36th Ryder Cup in Ireland, America's top golfers lost to the European team. The Europeans have defeated the United States in three consecutive Ryder Cup matches and five out of the last six. D5 ARTS E1-10 MTV Courts Young Latinos MTV is starting MTV Tr3s as a replacement for the all-Spanish language ''MTV en Español,'' a 15-year-old video jukebox that MTV executives now say was a placeholder while they tried to figure out more fitting programming for the Latino youth audience. E1 OBITUARIES B7 Sir Malcolm Arnold One of the best-known British composers of the 20th century, who wrote nine symphonies, composed 132 film scores and won an Oscar for the soundtrack to ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' he was 84. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Companies and Surveillance While Hewlett-Packard may be in the spotlight for the spying imbroglio in its boardroom, it is far from alone in diving into the murky world of private investigators and secret surveillance. C1 Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has had to apologize for his inaction related to the spying scandal. But he also has won the benefit of the doubt within the company and among investors because he has done so well turning the company around. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Chemical plants, still unprotected; routine testing for the AIDS virus; the roadless rule takes a new turn; blasé guardians at the money trough. Column: Bob Herbert. Bridge E3 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather D10

ROSE--Leila. Softly passed at home on Friday, September 22. Acclaimed singer and song stylist. Her beauty was only surpassed by her talent and class! Magnificent Wife, Mother, Nana, and Gigi. Her music will resonate in our hearts forever. Services September 25, 10 am, Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring St., NYC (Soho) 212-431-6712.

9 P.M. (NBC) HEROES -- A total eclipse leads a genetics professor to deduce that the superhuman live among us. One can fly. Another can paint the future. A third can stop time. And together they can save the world. Among the cast in this new drama series: Hayden Panettiere (above left), as a high school cheerleader who, through cringe-inducing testing methods, discovers that her flesh is indestructible. Ouch. 8 P.M. (NBC) DEAL OR NO DEAL -- They call Missouri the ''Show Me State'' -- as in show me the money! Tonight, a roster of Missourians try their luck at winning $1 million. 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK -- Well, that's one way to bury treasure. Michael and Lincoln start going door to door after they discover that a housing development has sprouted atop Westmoreland's stash. Meanwhile, T-Bag makes goo-goo eyes at a comely suburbanite. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP -- Give me a C, for competitive. A hyperkinetic cheerleading coach trades places with a Web-logged mother who offers her husband and son sustenance at their computers. 8 P.M. (11) 7TH HEAVEN -- Just when you thought it was safe again, CW brings on the 11th season of the show that just won't go away. Tonight, the unstable Lucy delivers a sermon, Martin makes his intentions clear to Sandy, Sandy lets it be known that she has switched majors, and an angelic neighbor (Jewel, in a cameo) sings Savannah to sleep. 9 P.M. (11) RUNAWAY -- And they seem like such nice folks. In this new crime drama, a successful lawyer (Donnie Wahlberg, above right, with Dustin Milligan, far left, and Nathan Gamble) wrongfully accused of murder picks up his Maryland family and plops them down in small-town Iowa, where they live under an assumed identity while trying to evade the law -- and the real killer -- mostly by breaking it. 9 P.M. (13, 49) MARIE ANTOINETTE -- A look at the travails of the teenage bride, who, through her frivolity, excess and simple immaturity, became one of the most controversial monarchs in history. 10 P.M. (Showtime) WEEDS -- File it under ''with friends like these . . . .'' Thanks to a balloting error, Celia beats Doug in the election and in the snap of her false tips announces the city's new drug-free policy. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Ray Liotta talks about playing a career criminal in his new show, ''Smith''; Elvis Costello and Tony Bennett (right) perform from Mr. Bennett's 80thbirthday tribute album, ''Duets,'' coming out tomorrow. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

LYONS--Dr. Albert S. Physician, surgeon and author, died Sunday, age 94. He wrote ''Medicine, An Illustrated History,'' was often honored for his significant contributions to patients and colleagues, and will be remembered as the gentlest and kindest of men. Survived by his wife Barbara Lyons, daughters Terry and Leni, step-daughter Alix, step-son Fred, grandchildren Michelle and Crispen, and great-granddaughter Sarah Rose. He will be remembered with love by all who knew him. Services at the Campbell Funeral Home, 81st and Madison Avenue, NYC, at 11:30 am, on September 26.

With another undefeated opponent -- the 4-0 Purdue Boilermakers -- scheduled to face Notre Dame this Saturday, Fighting Irish Coach Charlie Weis will soon turn his attention away from Saturday night's improbable 40-37 victory at Michigan State. But the game at Spartan Stadium will be hard to forget, at least for this week and maybe for a long time. Had the Irish (3-1) not overcome deficits of 17 points at halftime and 16 points after three quarters, their record would have fallen to 2-2.

ALBECK--Suzy. Born in Paris, died in Berlin, on September 23, at the age of 72. Woman of the world. Beloved mother of Jacques and devoted grandmother, Suzy is the cherished sister of Allen Oster and sister-in-law of Carla Fine of NYC. Suzy's spirit and smile reflected a resilience shaped by a history of facing life's hardships by honoring the joy that each day brings. We will miss her kindness, her generosity, her laughter and her vital presence. Au revoir.
To the Editor: Re ''Insurance Horror Stories,'' by Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 22):

Dance Theater Workshop has awarded creative residency grants to 12 individual choreographers in a significant expansion of its Outer/Space program, which gives space subsidies to studios in boroughs outside Manhattan. The residencies will take place at three studios, which helped to select the individuals along with Workshop staff members. Topaz Arts in Woodside, Queens, will play host to Miguel Gutierrez, above, Colleen Hooper, Jessica Morgan and Mikuni Yanaihara; Susan Hefner, Christopher Morgan, Isabella Bruno and Mark Lonergan will be in residence at the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance ( B.A.A.D!) in Hunts Point; and Pele Bauch, Luciana Achugar, Rebecca Davis and Selma Trevino will be at the CAVE Organization in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Each artist will be given 50 hours of free rehearsal space, spread over a three-month period to begin at the end of this month or in early October, depending on individual schedules. They will also be paired with creative advisers chosen by Dance Theater Workshop, who will offer critical perspectives at the beginning and end of each choreographer's tenure. CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

SETTEL--Elmer H. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Father of John F. and Howard D. Settel. Grandfather of Joel, Anthony, Elizabeth, Joanne, Katherine and Douglas. Great-grandfather of 10. Services will be Thursday, September 28th, 9:30 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday in some copies about Pham Xuan An, who was a reporter for Western news organizations during the Vietnam War while spying for North Vietnam, rendered the name of his son incorrectly, omitting the family name. He is Pham Xuan Hoang An, not Pham Xuan Hoang.

Now they're talking. After sniping at one another from afar for the last few weeks, the Senate candidates in New Jersey and those in Connecticut will face one another in a series of debates in each state before the Nov. 7 election.

COHEN-FEINSTEIN--Ann Riva. July 27, 1945-September 22. Loving mother of Jonathan and Jill, daughter of Edith Cohen. Loving sister of Matthew and confidante of Seth.

A lifelong sportswoman, extraordinary cook and homemaker. The ambience of her homes was notable to all who entered. Involved in children's charities, most notably, Schneider Children's Hospital at L.I.J. A lady of class who will be missed by all who knew her. The Schepps Family
