Devoted mother-in-law of Maurine Stein, Nancy Shavel Gabel and the late T.K. Flatley. Adoring grandmother of Harold, Alexis, Isabel and Julia Gabel and Cecilia and Charlotte Flatley. Daughter of the late Hugo and Ruth Eckstein and sister of the late David Eckstein. Private funeral.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about efforts by the government to control the border referred incorrectly to a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute who commented on plans to secure the border. Tamar Jacoby is a woman.

For the first time since 1976, Rutgers is in the Associated Press top 25. Fresh off a 56-7 victory against Howard, a Division I-AA team, on Saturday, Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano and his players said there was little doubt they deserved to be ranked among the nation's best teams. ''We're 4-0,'' Schiano said after the game. ''I don't get to see everybody else. I only get to see who we're playing. I voted us that the last, I don't know how many weeks. My vote would say that, yeah.''

To the Editor: It was astonishing to read, in ''Bloomberg Re-emphasizes School Control'' (news article, Sept. 20), the mayor's statement, ''We continue to put the interest of our students first, and the interest of the people who work in the system or benefit from getting contracts in the system last.''
To the Editor: Re ''Leafy Green Sewage'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 21):

EWEN--Susan de Armas. 65, died on September 22 following spontaneous cerebral hemorrhages. She was the beloved wife of Ira, cherished sister of Douglas and Scott Velsor and Joan Petrillo, loving stepmother of Rani Dalgin, Jessica Kahan, Lara Ewen and Britt Ewen. She is also survived by four nieces, a nephew, two aunts, and many cousins and grandchildren. Her light will shine forever on those who loved her. Susan's career began at the Ford Foundation. She then worked for 30 years as an educator for the New York City Department of Education and was the founding principal of the award winning High School of Economics and Finance, the first high school of its kind in New York City. She was also the Assistant Director of the national program of courses about economics, the Academy of Finance, that has been adopted by more than 400 schools. After retirement, she was a mentor for principals, assistant principals, and teachers, and she led Sanford Weill Institute seminars for high school students. Her gentle wit, wisdom, kindness, charity, and devotion to the arts, cooking, sports and nature will be profoundly missed by her dearly cherished colleagues, students, family, and friends. There will be a memorial service at Trinity Church at Wall Street and Broadway on Monday, October 16 at 10 A.M. Her family requests that contributions be sent to the Susan Ewen Scholarship Fund, WISE, 227 East 56 Street, Suite 201, New York, NY 10022, which will be used to award an annual meritbased scholarship.

H.P. CHIEF AND SPY CRISIS -- Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has had to apologize for his inaction related to the spying scandal there. But he has also won the benefit of the doubt within the company and among investors because he has done so well turning the company around. [Page C1.] SPOTLIGHT ON CNET -- Dawn Kawamoto, below, a 10-year veteran of News.com, a technology industry news site produced by CNet Networks, is the author of a story that ran in January revealing strategic changes under consideration at Hewlett-Packard. From that point forward, Patricia C. Dunn, who was the company's chairwoman until she resigned last week, embarked on an ambitious quest to learn the source of information leaked to Ms. Kawamoto. The effort has thrown a spotlight on Ms. Kawamoto and on CNet Networks, which has been described as the home page for Silicon Valley. [C4.] COMPANIES AND SURVEILLANCE -- Hewlett-Packard is far from alone in diving into the world of private investigators and secret surveillance. Despite concerns about the legality of such actions, security experts say there are plenty of reasons that companies need to be involved in the spy game, or at least bolster their intelligence-gathering apparatus. [C1.] NOT SO FUNNY IN HOLLYWOOD -- For the last few years, a tight network of stars, agents and managers has dominated comedy in Hollywood. But that is changing as relationship are fraying and as studios crack down on the prices they are willing to pay for top performers and reduce the overall number of films they release. [C1.] PARALLEL MEDIA VENTURES -- The founders of Digg, a Web site where users submit links to news accounts around the Internet, are working on expanding Revision3, an Internet video production firm. Revision3's most successful offering so far is a show called ''Diggnation,'' where two hosts talk about some of the most popular stories on Digg.com that week. [C1.] COMICS ONLINE -- Platinum Studios, a relative newcomer in the comics industry, plans to begin publishing its books online before they go to press for traditional distribution through stores and newsstands. [C8.] DONATION DRIVE -- Recognizing that procrastination is an enemy of good intentions, a new public service effort, to be announced today, aims to persuade Americans to actually act upon their altruistic impulses. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] NEW MTV CHANNEL -- Today, MTV is introducing MTV Tr3s as a replacement for the all-Spanish language ''MTV en Español,'' a 15-year-old video jukebox. The new channel will not shun Spanish, but it will mostly reflect a fusion of American and Latin music, cultures and languages, MTV executives said. [E1.] HEADBUTT, BY NIKE -- When Zinédine Zidane, the French soccer star, leveled an Italian defender, Marco Materazzi, with a blow to the chest during the World Cup final in July, the incident nearly overshadowed Italy's victory over France. Now, in celebrating their soccer superiority, some Italians, and their sponsor, Nike, are taking a few jabs at the French in a new advertising campaign. [C7.] FAIR-TRADE CLOTHING VENTURE -- An online store called Fair Indigo will rely mostly on the Web and catalogs to sell what executives say is the first mainstream clothing line made in accordance with fair-trade practices. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C4.] INTERNET ANTECEDENTS -- As Fred Turner points out in his new book, ''From Counterculture to Cyberculture: Stewart Brand, the Whole Earth Network, and the Rise of Digital Utopianism,'' the romantic, utopian culture of the 1960's, with its deep suspicions about modernity and machinery, is closely linked to the recent Internet revolution. Edward Rothstein: Connections. [E3.]

Silicon Valley is awash in serial entrepreneurs, those who start a company, run it for a while, and then after success, failure or something in between, move on and start again. Jay Adelson, 36, and Kevin Rose, 29, are parallel entrepreneurs -- starting a second company just as the first one is taking off.

Attorney General Spitzer may be 50-some percentage points ahead in the polls in the last weeks of the New York governor's race, but the constant attacks from his opponent, Mr. Faso, appear to be getting under the his skin. On Thursday, the two addressed the Business Council of New York State in Bolton Landing, in the Adirondacks.

To the Editor: The decisions by Harvard and Princeton to end early-decision admissions (news article, Sept. 19) are good news for everyone, from the overstressed overprivileged, to highly qualified students in need of financial aid, to colleges themselves, should the practice be more widely abandoned beyond the Ivy League.

The Yankees still have work to do. They sprayed Champagne around the clubhouse last Wednesday, a reward for clinching the American League East. But there is a position to learn, a relief pitcher to fix and a playoff seeding to fight for. All of those tasks were on display at Tropicana Field on Sunday, and the result was an unsightly 11-4 loss to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.
''I just follow my own common sense. And the hell with the law.'' THOMAS R. BUCKLEY, a longtime justice in Dannemora, N.Y. [A1]

The download-to-own market, where users buy movies online, is ruled by a patchwork of studio licensing agreements. Some films, like ''V for Vendetta'' (above, starring Hugo Weaving) are available on Cinemanow.com, the largest site, and Movielink.com, its main competitor. Some, like ''Brokeback Mountain,'' can be rented on both sites but purchased on only one. A fairly new Cinemanow service allowing users to burn titles onto DVD's is still small, with only 103 offerings. SHELLY FREIERMAN

An article on Wednesday about plans by Columbia University to replace loans with grants for lower income undergraduates referred imprecisely to efforts by Harvard and Yale to help such students afford tuition. These universities have stopped requiring lower income parents to contribute financially to their children's education; they have not replaced their loans with grants. (As the article noted, Princeton has replaced its loans with grants.)

Laurence Boschetto, president and chief operating officer at Draft, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named to the same posts at DraftFCB, the agency being formed as Interpublic merges Draft with Foote Cone & Belding, effective on Jan. 1. Chris Jaques, chief executive for Asia at Y&R Advertising, Singapore, will move to New York and become chief executive for North America. He succeeds Gord McLean, who was named global managing partner, a new post. The changes are the first made by Hamish McLennan, the new chief executive at Y&R, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands unit of the WPP Group

Los Lobos ''The Town and The City'' (Hollywood) ''Where's the place that I once knew?'' David Hidalgo sings in ''Don't Ask Why'' on ''The Town and the City,'' Los Lobos' latest album. ''Gone away, disappeared into the blue.''

FEINSTEIN -- Ann Riva. Passed away on September 22, in NYC. She was the loving mother of Jill and Jonathan, the beloved daughter of Edith S. Cohen and the late Samuel S. Cohen, and the devoted sister of Matthew Cohen. We will miss her warmth, friendliness and generosity. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, Tuesday, September 26, at 11:15 am.

A Comedy Leads the Way The uninhibited comedy ''Jackass: Number Two'' (Paramount), right, collected an estimated $28.1 million in its premiere at North American box offices over the weekend, ending the one-week reign of ''Gridiron Gang'' (Sony) in the top spot and leaving that film in third place with $9.7 million for its second week in theaters. Between the two films came the martial arts mayhem of Jet Li's ''Fearless'' (Focus/Rogue), with $10.5 million in its debut. Fourth place, according to the box-office tracking company Exhibitor Relations, went to the brave World War I pilots of ''Flyboys'' (MGM), which opened with $6 million. The No. 5 film was the G-rated ''Everyone's Hero'' (Fox), the animated film about a little boy and Babe Ruth's bat, with $4.75 million. Exhibitor Relations reported that ''Jackass: Number Two'' earned back its production budget on its first day out, when it took in more than $11 million. Mel Gibson Dims His Star Keeping a profile so low that it reportedly included a mask and a wig, Mel Gibson, right, attended two screenings of his latest film, ''Apocalypto,'' in Oklahoma last week. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Gibson -- who made headlines in July when he was stopped for speeding in California, acted belligerently and made anti-Semitic comments -- attended screenings at the Riverwind Casino in Goldsby and at Cameron University in Lawton. At the first screening ''Apocalypto,'' an action film in the Yucatec Mayan language, set in that civilization's last days in the 15th century, was shown to an audience consisting mostly of American Indians. At the university Mr. Gibson arrived wearing a mask and wig to avoid being noticed, said Amber McNeil, a university spokeswoman. Earlier in the week she said he had canceled the screenings. ''Apocalypto'' is to be released on Dec. 8. Mourning Colors McCartney Oratorio On the eve of today's release of his fourth classical album, the oratorio ''Ecce Cor Meum'' (''Behold My Heart''), Paul McCartney, below, said work on the piece was halted for a year while he was recovering from the death of his first wife, Linda, who died of breast cancer in 1998, the BBC reported. The couple married in 1969. ''I had to take a year out just to grieve,'' he said, adding that the hiatus was followed ''by a big burst of sad music.'' A work in four movements, ''Ecce Cor Meum'' (EMI Classics), with lyrics in Latin and English, was commissioned by Magdalen College of Oxford University in honor of the college's new music hall. The oratorio is to be performed at Royal Albert Hall in London on Nov. 4. France's Literate Police Victor Hugo? The author of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' and ''Les Misérables'' was a miserly money grubber. How about the poet Rimbaud? He was ''a monstrosity,'' and his colleague and lover Verlaine ''a worthless human being.'' Where are such judgments to be found? In dust-covered French police files that were unearthed and compiled in a book by Bruno Fuligni, an employee of the French National Assembly, Agence France-Presse reported. The book, ''The Writers' Police,'' says the judgments were collected from 1879 to 1891 from informers and members of the secret police under the supervision of Louis Andrieux, himself the father of a renowned poet and novelist, Louis Aragon. The authorities began watching Rimbaud when he was only 15 and found his behavior repugnant. But, Mr. Fuligni said, ''The police spotted him before the literary inner circle did.'' The files he tapped continue well into the 20th century. Later files are no longer accessible, but Mr. Fuligni wonders if the spying has ended. ''Why,'' he asked, ''would practices so easily carried out in the era of pen and ink suddenly stop in the era of the telephone and the Internet?'' Britain Halts Turner Export The British culture minister, David Lammy, has placed a temporary export ban on ''The Blue Rigi,'' below, the J. M. W. Turner watercolor sold at auction in London in June to an unidentified buyer for nearly $11 million, the BBC reported. The ruling gives British arts institutions two months to express serious interest in buying the painting, depicting the calm of a Swiss sunrise interrupted by sudden movement as a gunshot impels a pair of dogs to leap from a boat toward a group of startled ducks. The buyer has applied for an export license to sell the painting, probably to a customer in the United States. If a British institution shows interest, the export ban will be extended until March to give it time to raise the money to buy it. Mr. Lammy acted on the advice of a review committee that declared ''The Blue Rigi'' to be of ''outstanding aesthetic importance'' and ''outstanding significance for the study of the work of J. M. W. Turner.''
To the Editor: Re ''Bias Is Hurting Women in Science, Panel Reports'' (news article, Sept. 19):

Ludacris Release Therapy (Disturbing tha Peace/Island Def Jam) ''You're going to take me serious on this album, I guarantee it.'' That's what Ludacris told MTV about his fifth major-label album, ''Release Therapy.'' And the album cover confirms this strategy. Where previous CD's depicted him holding a flaming $100 bill or getting ready to sink his teeth into a leg (distinctly human, and female), this one shows him with his eyes closed and his fingers folded. It's the universal symbol, one supposes, for seriousness.

GLADDON--Adrienne. (Everts and Van Aalst.) In her 99th year. Survived by husband, Jan Gladdon. Daughter Dianne Maxwell Albert, three grandchildren Tracy, Meredith, Richard, one greatgrandchild Michael Phillips. Memorial Spring '07 Holland.

New York Dance and Performance Awards, known as Bessies, were given to 24 dancers, choreographers, administrators, visual artists, composers and groups at the Joyce Theater last week. Awards covered both individual work and lifetime achievement. Predictably one of the hippest events of the dance year, this ceremony was unusually low-key and was distinguished by winners' frequent references to family members and their sources of inspiration. Special citations went to Dianne McIntyre, the modern-dance choreographer, teacher and mentor to generations of black female dancers in particular, and to Olga Garay, program director for the arts at the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. Choreographer/Creator Awards were given to Wally Cardona, Miguel Gutierrez, Susan Marshall, the collaborators who created Bebe Miller's ''Landing/Place''; Jennifer Monson; Jeremy Wade; Yasuko Yokoshi and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar. Bessies, named after the master teacher Bessie Schoenberg, were given for musical composition to Peter Drungle and Hahn Rowe. The Verdensteatret group won the Bessie for installation and new media for ''Concert for Greenland,'' and Norma Munn, a founder and the current chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, received the Susan E. Kennedy Award in recognition of two decades of arts advocacy. JENNIFER DUNNING

Two new Honda regional dealer associations in California have named agencies to handle their accounts. The Northern California dealers selected Pickett Advertising, San Francisco; spending was estimated at $10 million. The Southern California dealers chose Secret Weapon Marketing, Santa Monica; spending was estimated at as much as $50 million. RPA, Santa Monica, continues as the national agency for American Honda Motor. R. H. Donnelley, Cary, N.C., which publishes yellow pages directories and operates local search Web sites, consolidated its account and named Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, as agency of record. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The consolidation came after Donnelley, which had used Valentine Radford Communications, Kansas City, Mo., as its lead agency, acquired Dex Media, which had used Foote Cone & Belding, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

Buckeyes' Next Test Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel says he has been impressed with his young defensive unit, but expects to get a fuller measure of its ability next week when the top-ranked Buckeyes travel to No. 13 Iowa. Behind Drew Tate, the Hawkeyes are averaging 380 yards a game. Albert Young, a junior, led the Big Ten Conference in rushing last season. It will be up to Tressel's still-learning defense to preserve the national title hopes of Ohio State. Next for Tech? Tech Saturday's game between No. 11 Virginia Tech (4-0) and No. 24 Georgia Tech (3-1) in Blacksburg, Va., could decide supremacy in the Coastal Division of the Atlantic Coast Conference. Georgia Tech's loss came against Notre Dame in the season opener. Virginia Tech was lackluster Saturday in a 29-13 victory against Cincinnati (1-3). Virginia Tech's pass defense, which ranks seventh nationally and is allowing a little more than 131 yards a game, will be tested by wide receiver Calvin Johnson, below. He has 19 catches for 311 yards and 5 touchdowns this season. Line of the Week 0 0 0 0 -- 0 Robert Morris, a Division I-AA team, held Rowan, the No. 3-ranked team in Division III, to minus-19 yards in a 21-0 victory Saturday. That included minus-44 yards rushing, and only one first down, all school records. The senior defensive lineman Ray Gensler had four and a half sacks for the Colonials (2-2). Passing to a Record East Stroudsburg's senior quarterback, Jimmy Terwilliger, threw for 389 yards and 4 touchdowns in a 41-34 victory over California (Pa.) on Saturday to set an N.C.A.A. Division II record for career touchdown passes at 123. The previous mark, 121, was set by Marc Eddy of Bentley last season. Fantastic Finishes Notre Dame wasn't the only team providing late-game theatrics Saturday. Daniel Evans, a redshirt sophomore, helped take some pressure off Coach Chuck Amato when he rallied North Carolina State past Boston College, 17-15, with 8.5 seconds to play. At Arkansas, the freshman Mitch Mustain led the Razorbacks in a 24-23 double-overtime upset of Alabama. And at Georgia, the freshman Joe Cox relieved the ineffective Matthew Stafford, also a freshman, to save the Bulldogs from an embarrassing loss to winless Colorado. A Big 12 Surprise Missouri is 4-0 for the first time since 2003. The No. 25 Tigers are one of two undefeated teams in the Big 12 and the only team in the North Division without a loss. The sophomore quarterback Chase Daniel has thrown for 1,020 yards, 9 touchdowns and 2 interceptions. Missouri plays host to Colorado (0-4) on Saturday.
Republicans and Democrats began showing at least 30 new campaign advertisements in contested House and Senate districts across the country on Tuesday. Of those, three were positive.
Eliot Spitzer and John Faso sparred over school financing, abortion, gay marriage, ethics, and how to rejuvenate the upstate economy and a state government that both men portrayed as adrift.

Judging by the questions in the spin room after the debate, it seemed that the news of the night had to do with Eliot Spitzer's position and comments on his fellow Democrat, Alan Hevesi, the state comptroller. Mr. Spitzer has endorsed him.
There were a few extra minutes at the end of the debate, which left time for an extra question that John Faso obviously loved.
John Faso knew that mentioning Eliot Spitzer's family might get him riled up, and that is what he was aiming for when he asked about taking money from his father for his campaign.

Just a stylistic note. Eliot Spitzer seems more relaxed, striking a somewhat athletic pose and, while often gripping a pen in his right hand, he was free with his gestures. John Faso is staring at Mr. Spitzer as he talked, moving hardly an inch, and, for the most part, keeping his hands on the lectern.
John Faso has not had much of a chance to go after Eliot Spitzer yet, but he did try and get a dig as his opponent repeated a phrase he has used over and over.

President Bush agreed on Tuesday to release "key judgments'' of the National Intelligence Estimate, entitled, "Trends in Global Terrorism: Implications for the United States." The report was produced in April, and Mr. Bush complained that various segments had been leaked to reporters at the height of the mid-term elections. You can read the segments Mr. Bush ordered declassified here.

Aftter a rather bland beginning, a question about gay marriage brought the audience in the hall to life. Asked what he would do if the legislature passed a bill a legalizing gay marriage, Mr. Faso said, "I would veto it."Many in the crowd hissed at that response, but Mr. Faso pressed on, targeting Mr. Spitzer. "He says on day one he is going to force gay marriage down the throats" of the people of New York.

Bailey Hall is filled to capacity tonight. In fact, it only took about 36 hours to give away more than 1,200 free tickets. Hilary Beber, 21, said she was told that she got the last two tickets on Monday.

Bernard Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, reported to a federal prison in Louisiana on Tuesday to begin serving a 25-year term for his role in one of the biggest frauds in the nation's history.

Here's a bit of color from Bailey Hall on the Cornell campus in Ithaca, where Eliot Spitzer and John Faso will soon debate. The recently renovated hall is 94 years old and seats 1,324 people, and is mostly used for the university's huge introductory psychology course.

Debate Night: There's an hour to go until the gubernatorial debate between Eliot Spitzer and John Faso at 7 p.m. on the campus of Cornell University in Ithaca. We may do a bit of live-blogging here at The Empire Zone. The debate will be shown on NY 1 in New York City, Capital 9 News in Albany and News 10 Now in Syracuse. (Those without Time Warner Cable can listen on WNYC-AM 820.) Earlier today, Patrick Healy assessed the state of the race and looked at debate preparations. Other Empire Zone coverage is here.

Andrew Fastow, we now learn, was just one of a group of Enron people who were "drunk on the wine of greed," and therefore deserves some sympathy. Or so says a federal judge, who sentenced him to six years in prison, when he had agreed to 10 years in his plea bargain. He got credit for helping to convict his former bosses, Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling, and for the fact that the government, in pressuring him to enter a plea, put his wife in prison for a year on tax charges.

In Sunday's column, I noted that maternal mortality could be cut dramatically for sums that are an awful lot less than those we spend on, say, pet food. (Or bottled water, on which we spend $35 billion annually around the world.)
For the second staight day, Joe Lieberman went on the attack against Ned Lamont's position on Iraq, accusing the challenger of "waffling" in his position on the war.
Democrat Tessa Hafen responds to her opponent's negative ads and ties him with George W. Bush.
A second ad from Republican Rick Santorum questions the background of contributors to Bob Casey's campaign.

Republican Jon Porter on immigration and his opponent's Nevada roots.
Democrat Joe Donnelly on immigration and the record of his opponent, Chris Chocola, on the issue. The ad calls Mr. Chocola a liar.
A Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee ad slams Thelma Drake, a Republican congressman, as being a handmaiden of Big Oil.
Democrat Harry Mitchell on his opponent's ties to the former Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff.

Two years after spinning off its buyout business, the securities firm Morgan Stanley announced Tuesday that it was getting back into the game. In a press release, the firm said it plans to create a private equity group within its asset management division, to be led by Stephen Trevor, who will join Morgan Stanley from Goldman Sachs, and Alan Jones, who is now head of Morgan Stanley's corporate finance division.
Regulators say they have solved an insider trading mystery: It was the butler in the poolside office with the fax machine.

Campaigns are full of paranoia about infiltration by enemy spies who pose as volunteers. With new technology, however, aides to rivals can pretend to be supporters in the privacy and comfort of their own offices.

Last week's military coup that removed Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra from power has prompted one blogger to revisit last year's controversy involving the prime minister and Daniel Lian, Morgan Stanley's oft-quoted economist in Southeast Asia at the time. Mr. Lian created a stir when a gushing letter he wrote to Mr. Thaksin was leaked to the press, raising questions about whether the economist was too close to the Thai leadership.

Beginning Jan. 8, U.S. citizens returning by air will have to show their passports when entering the country. With roughly 73 percent of Americans lacking a passport, is the government equipped to handle an influx of applications?

Since it is being broadcast by Time Warner, the debate is expected to have limited viewership (perhaps why the candidates agreed?), although some NPR stations are expected to broadcast it.

The Emdeon Corporation, which provides information, communications and plastic components used in the health-care industry, said on Tuesday that it plans to sell a stake in a unit and begin a tender offer to buy up to 100 million shares of its stock at $12.25 each.

First off, I'd like to thank all of the private beta release users for all of the feedback. You've really helped us nail down some issues. I'm also really happy to see that most of the feature requests/changes you've made are ones we've already scheduled for the future.

Flanked by a group of African-American pastors on Monday, Senator George Allen vehemently denied using a racial epithet back when he was a student at the University of Virginia. He was responding to reports that first surfaced in the online magazine Salon, quoting a few of his former fellow football players and acquaintances, some of whom spoke anonymously and one at least an avowed Democrat rooting for his opponent, Jim Webb.

Six weeks until Election Day, and in Washington both parties are hitting hard on national security: Republicans by pushing for passage of legislation governing the prosecution of terrorism suspects and Democrats by focusing on an intelligence report that the Iraq war helped increase the terrorism threat. But there is little evidence that Republicans are having success in altering the political climate in the most competitive House and Senate races.
Hedge funds that solicit stock-picking ideas electronically from investment banks in return for big commissions were cleared by British regulators of the taint of insider dealing Monday.

It looks like 2006 is shaping up to be a banner year for deposing chief executives. In just the first 12 days of September, leaders at Bristol-Myers Squibb, Ford Motor and Viacom were removed, fueling the breakneck pace in which one C.E.O. departs every six hours.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating 52 companies that may have illegally backdated stock options, and more cases are on the way, its new criminal investigative chief said.

After last week's White House deal on detainees, President Bush reportedly has worked out another agreement to allow a broader range of foreign nationals to be held. John McCain was getting a lot of attention as the maverick Republican senator, but Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania is making a late showing, expressing concern that a provision to deny detainees' habeas corpus rights could be unconstitutional. Meanwhile, Mr. Specter made a deal with the White House that would allow the president to continue his warrantless wiretapping program, but without acknowledging his constitutional authority to do so.
A former manager of a New York hedge fund pleaded not guilty yesterday to illegally short selling shares of CompuDyne hours before the company announced a private share offering.

The former chief executive of American Tissue, Mehdi Gabayzadeh, was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison for organizing a fraud that cost banks and investors almost $300 million when the paper manufacturer collapsed.

In the wake of its $6 billion meltdown, Amaranth Advisors is being scrutinized by regulators including the Securities and Exchange Commission. A top Securities and Exchange Commission official confirmed to Dow Jones that the agency is investigating Amaranth, and the inquiry is focused on whether the fund misled investors.

Two Hewlett-Packard employees who directed the company's spying operations have been subpoenaed by a House committee to appear at a hearing this week after refusing invitations to testify, the committee said Monday.

Ohio's First Congressional DistrictChris Cillizza and Jim VandeHei, who might be the *only* people geekier than us, write about "microtargeting." ("There is no sexier topic," they write.) Representative Steven Chabot, a Republican, and his Democratic challenger, John Cranley, are data-mining to tailor their messages to each supporter.

Bernie Ebbers spent his last night of freedom doing what he loved best -- making deals, in this case with George Soros, who bought one of the biggest working farms in the United States from the former head of WorldCom, The New York Post reported.

SIG Holding, a Swiss maker of beverage cartons and packaging equipment, said Monday that it had rejected a 1.8 billion Swiss franc ($1.5 billion) offer from a British buyout shop CVC Capital Partners and a Norwegian packaging firm Elopak.

The investors who own ProSiebenSat.1 Media said they are not in talks to sell teh company, Germany's biggest broadcaster, denying a magazine report that said Apax Partners Worldwide and Goldman Sachs are in talks to buy the company.

Carrols Holdings, the operator of 540 fast-food restaurants in 16 states, has filed for an initial public offering to raise up to $210 million in the latest test of the investment market by the restaurant industry.

Goldman Sachs, the securities industry's most profitable firm, plans to sell shares in its Accordia Golf unit as early as Nov. 1.
Halliburton is pressing ahead with plans to spin off Kellogg Brown & Root in an initial public offering, a move that comes as the Army subcontractor scales back its work in Iraq.
Softbank may fail to refinance a 1.28 trillion yen ($11 billion) loan at its Japan mobile-phone unit by the end of this month, increasing interest costs, Bloomberg News reported.

Wachovia was ordered by an NASD arbitration panel to pay $3.8 million to a broker it fired in 2003 in connection with an investigation of improper trades.

Stuart Rabner, a former federal prosecutor who tackled political corruption and international terrorism cases, was confirmed yesterday as New Jersey’s new attorney general. The State Senate voted 35 to 0 for the confirmation. Gov. Jon S. Corzine nominated Mr. Rabner, 46, to become the state’s top law enforcement officer shortly after Zulima V. Farber, 61, resigned as attorney general in August. Ms. Farber stepped down after an independent review found that she had violated state ethics rules by intervening in a traffic stop for her companion.

After the crash, the suspect began swinging a knife at two Metropolitan Transportation Authority police officers, who shot him twice after he ignored their orders to drop it, officials said.

A grand jury in Suffolk County has called for establishing an inspector general’s office to oversee the more than 4,400 public schools across the state, after months of investigations that led to the arrest of a dozen school officials and employees in the county on charges of theft and mismanagement of school funds.

Rescuers in eastern Nepal said that they had found the wreckage of a crashed Russian helicopter chartered by the conservation group WWF and that all 24 passengers had died. The wreckage was found close to Ghunsa, where the helicopter took off Saturday. On board were Nepal’s forest minister, Gopal Rai; its national parks and wildlife conservation director, Narayan Poudel; the Finnish embassy’s chargé d’affaires, Pauli Mustonen; and the deputy director of the United States Agency for International Development in Nepal, Margaret R. Alexander. The WWF said its officials on the helicopter included Jill Bowling, its conservation director in Britain. Four of Nepal’s most respected conservationists were also on the helicopter.

More than 200 police officers raided a housing project south of Paris in a dramatic dawn roundup to catch suspects involved in a violent ambush last week of two officers who were beaten when they left their patrol car in the neighborhood. The raid came nearly a year after riots flared in the neighborhood and across France. Eleven people were detained after police officers braved a rain of bottles and other projectiles to move in on the tough housing project in the Corbeil-Essonnes suburb. The raid came after the interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, a leading presidential contender who has championed law-and-order policies, pledged to catch those responsible “one by one.”.

The African Union will add 4,000 troops to its Darfur peacekeeping mission, bringing the number of police officers and soldiers in the region to 11,000, a spokesman for the union said. The union said the soldiers would come from countries already contributing troops — Nigeria, Rwanda, South Africa and Senegal.

Justice Minister Christoph Blocher, left, the ultranationalist leader of the Swiss People’s Party, emerged as a big political winner from a vote on Sunday to restrict asylum seekers and non-European job seekers. Nearly 70 percent of voters backed the new rules, and the extent of the victory for policies closely identified with Mr. Blocher’s rightist party surprised observers.

A retired Supreme Court judge heard emotional testimony on the first day of a public inquiry into the 1985 bombing of an Air India Boeing 747 from Canada that exploded off the Irish coast killing all 329 people on board. A man whose wife died testified that the government had failed to support victims’ families and did not do enough to pursue suspects in the bombing. Prime Minister Stephen Harper called the inquiry in May, in response to mounting pressure on the government after two Canadian Sikh activists accused of plotting the bombing were set free last year because of insufficient evidence.

The navy said it sank 11 vessels of the separatist Tamil Tigers and killed 70 rebels in a fierce five-hour battle. The navy believes a top rebel naval commander was killed or injured during the clash at sea, 50 miles north of Trincomalee, a strategic northeastern harbor. It was one of the most serious naval battles since 2002. Chief Inspector Percy Perera of the National Security Center said the Tiger craft “were trying to bring in reinforcements and weapons.”.

Security forces took over Pavón prison, controlled for more than 10 years by inmates who produced drugs, lived in spacious homes and even rented space for shops and for restaurants that sold stews and tortillas. Seven prisoners died when 3,000 police officers and soldiers stormed the prison, 15 miles southeast of Guatemala City, just after dawn. Inmates fired back, but Interior Minister Carlos Vielmann told reporters the prison was controlled in less than an hour. The security forces then began emptying Pavón of its 1,600 inhabitants and transferring them to another prison. Guards, often corrupt, patrolled just the prison’s perimeter while inmates set up laboratories to produce cocaine and liquor and organized crime empires on the outside from cell blocks and houses they built on the prison’s large grounds. One had a Jacuzzi, while another was protected by guard dogs.

A judge said he would remove the Green Party candidate for Senate from the November ballot because the party did not have enough valid signatures in its nominating petitions. The candidate, Carl Romanelli, had been challenged by state Democrats. Mr. Romanelli’s place on the ballot was supported by the Republican incumbent, Rick Santorum, who hoped that Mr. Romanelli would siphon votes from his Democratic opponent, State Treasurer Bob Casey. Judge James R. Kelley of Commonwealth Court ruled that Mr. Romanelli, a railroad industry consultant from Wilkes-Barre, was 8,931 signatures shy of the 67,070 he needed to qualify as a minor-party candidate.
The Department of Homeland Security increased money to high-risk cities that had cuts earlier this year.

Young Zheng, 18, who fought for nearly four years to win asylum in the United States after being caught with false papers, has been approved for permanent residency, his lawyers at Fulbright & Jaworski said. Mr. Zheng, at 14, was supposed to work off a $60,000 debt with immigrant smugglers, but he attended school instead. After he was detained, he fought deportation to China, arguing that he would face death. His green card is to arrive shortly.

A minor earthquake awakened residents in northeastern South Carolina, the second quake to hit the area in several days. The magnitude 3.6 quake hit at 1:44 a.m. and was centered near Blenheim, according to the National Earthquake Information Center in Denver. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but the authorities received calls from residents awakened by their shaking houses. Earthquakes are not common to the area; the most devastating was one of magnitude 7.3 that struck near Charleston in 1886, killing more than 100 people.

American researchers using fish auction records from Hong Kong have calculated that the trade in shark fins kills 26 million to 73 million sharks a year. The new estimate, reported in the October issue of the journal Ecology Letters, is far higher than United Nations assessments. Shark fins are used in a soup traditionally served at Chinese weddings and other celebrations. The scientists, led by Shelley Clarke of the University of Hawaii, say that because sharks reproduce relatively slowly, the trade threatens the world’s shark species, many of which are already endangered.
The ruling was the most recent in a string of legal setbacks for the Bush administration’s public-lands policies.

The University of Michigan is debating whether it should replace some bleacher seats in 107,501-seat Michigan Stadium with luxury boxes.
The White House is seeking to draw as sharp a distinction between Republicans and Democrats on terrorism as possible, something it has done skillfully in the past two election cycles.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 — Responding to pressure from colleagues as well as the governor, State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, one of New Jersey’s most powerful legislators, agreed on Monday to step down temporarily as the chairman of the influential Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee.
By The Associated Press.
The scion of one of Kenya’s richest and most fabled white families is charged with killing a poacher on his family’s vast estate.
Crude oil prices dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time in six months on Monday before rebounding a bit.
The decision raises the possibility that cases involving light cigarettes will become a major legal threat to the tobacco industry.
Google is calling on the computer industry to create a simpler and more efficient power supply standard.
An article yesterday about the coming presidential election in Brazil misstated the date for a runoff, if one is necessary. It would be Oct. 29, not Oct. 15.
Starting this weekend, General Motors will run ads that tap into patriotism, positioning the Chevrolet Silverado as America’s truck.
The secretary of state urged international troops in southern Lebanon to act on a mandate that allows the use of force if necessary.

City University of New York trustees yesterday raised the salary of their chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, for the first time in three years. The increase, to $395,000 from $350,000, followed a review of his performance by Jonathan R. Cole, the former Columbia University provost, and raises for other CUNY executives and for CUNY’s faculty members. CUNY said Dr. Goldstein’s new salary was still below those of chief executives at many smaller universities, although the salary of the chancellor of the State University of New York, which is larger than CUNY, is $340,000.

Stuart Rabner, a former federal prosecutor who tackled political corruption and international terrorism cases, was confirmed yesterday as New Jersey’s new attorney general. The State Senate voted 35 to 0 for the confirmation. Gov. Jon S. Corzine nominated Mr. Rabner, 46, to become the state’s top law enforcement officer shortly after Zulima V. Farber, 61, resigned as attorney general in August. Ms. Farber stepped down after an independent review found that she had violated state ethics rules by intervening in a traffic stop for her companion.

An 18-year-old New Rochelle man convicted of murdering a nightclub promoter after an argument last year was sentenced yesterday in Westchester County Court to 20 years to life in state prison. The man, Rodney Alston, was charged with fatally shooting Dacheau Brown, 25, outside the Club Eclipse nightclub in New Rochelle on Oct. 10. Mr. Alston had been kicked out of the club earlier that night and wanted retribution, the police said, so he sneaked up behind Mr. Brown about 4 a.m., fired five shots and fled. He was eventually tracked down in Georgia through telephone records and arrested in February. He was convicted of second-degree murder and two counts of criminal possession of a weapon.

A 16-year-old Queens boy was fatally shot in the head yesterday afternoon in Far Rockaway by a group of teenagers, the police said. The boy, identified as Mario Young, of Far Rockaway, was taken to St. John’s Episcopal Hospital South Shore, where he was pronounced dead on arrival, according to the police. The shooting took place near 13-12 Beach Channel Drive shortly before 4 p.m., and the killers fled on foot.

A judge yesterday threw out a $10 million civil assault suit that had been brought against Liza Minnelli by her estranged husband, David Gest. In the suit, Mr. Gest said that Ms. Minnelli beat him so badly during drunken rages that he had to be hospitalized. Justice Jane S. Solomon of State Supreme Court granted Ms. Minnelli’s motion to dismiss on the grounds that the entertainer’s medical expert said Mr. Gest’s headaches were caused by a type of herpes, not by beatings, and that Mr. Gest’s doctor failed to rebut that assertion. Mr. Gest’s lawyer, Lorraine Nadel, said she would appeal. She said that although Ms. Minnelli’s physician diagnosed Mr. Gest’s headaches as being caused by herpes zoster — a strain that causes shingles, not genital herpes — Mr. Gest’s doctor said he had tested negative for the virus.

The former chief executive of one of the nation’s largest makers of paper products was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 15 years in prison after being convicted last year of engineering a $300 million fraud in a fruitless bid to save the failing company from bankruptcy. The defendant, Mehdi Gabayzadeh, the former head of American Tissue Inc., based in Hauppauge, was convicted in April 2005 of all charges in an eight-count indictment, including bank and securities fraud and conspiracy, after a nine-week trial. Mr. Gabayzadeh, 61, of Great Neck, was ordered to pay $65 million in restitution and sentenced to five years’ probation after his prison term. American Tissue was once the nation’s fourth-largest maker of toilet tissue and other paper products.
Republicans and Democrats scrambled to gain the advantage in their final week before breaking to campaign for crucial midterm elections.

Gov. George E. Pataki will lead a United States delegation to Budapest next month to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Hungarian Revolution, the White House announced yesterday. Mr. Pataki, whose ethnic background is Hungarian, will head a group that includes Peter Gogolak, a former New York Giants football player; Steven Udvar-Hazy, chairman of the International Lease Finance Corporation; and April H. Foley, the United States ambassador to Hungary. In 1956, Hungary became a symbol of struggle against Communist rule when it revolted against Soviet domination. The Soviet Union sent in tanks to crush the uprising, and Soviet-backed leaders retained power for 30 more years.

City officials unveiled a $17.5 million operations center for the Fire Department yesterday that will allow commanders to better coordinate and execute the response to emergencies. The command center, completed in July, was built in response to recommendations made in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. With more than 75 computers, the system can track the locations of Fire Department vehicles and access radio transmissions and live video from police and other helicopters. It will eventually be able to pull up images from 80 cameras installed throughout the city by the Department of Transportation. Officials can also call up aerial photographs of any building in the city and its surrounding areas, allowing those at the command center to alert firefighters at the scene of potential dangers.
A day after Jeremy Shockey said the Giants were outcoached during Sunday’s loss to the Seahawks, Eli Manning and Tom Coughlin condemned the comments.

The acquittal dealt a sharp setback to federal prosecutors in the case against the private detective Anthony Pellicano.

Safia Amajan, 65, a senior Afghan official specializing in women’s rights, was gunned down by suspected Taliban gunmen.
The last time prices fell from their year-earlier level was in April 1995, but the market slide might be beginning to ease.
Viacom said Sumner M. Redstone was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest.
By Reuters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (Reuters) — The Walgreen Company, the drugstore chain, posted a 25 percent increase in quarterly profit on Monday driven by strong sales of prescription medications, but its shares declined as earnings before unusual items fell short of expectations.

The Department of Defense has identified 2,689 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.

Seattle running back Shaun Alexander, named the most valuable player in the N.F.L. last season, has a broken left foot and will be out for at least two weeks.
Randy Johnson will miss his final start because of back spasms he experienced in Saturday’s loss to the Devil Rays.

UCB, a Belgian drug maker, said it had agreed to buy Schwarz Pharma of Germany for 4.4 billion euros ($5.6 billion) to gain experimental medicines for Parkinson’s disease, epilepsy and bladder control. Schwarz investors will get 91.10 euros a share in cash and stock, 20 percent more than the closing price on Friday, UCB said. The Schwarz-Schuette family, which owns 60 percent of the company, backed the offer. Schwarz, based in Monheim, Germany, is the third European family-owned drug maker to sell in less than a week as the cost of developing new products rises. UCB, which faces patent expirations on its top sellers starting next year, will get three drugs that may provide more than 2 billion euros in annual revenue.

Acciona, a Spanish builder, bought 10 percent of Endesa, the country’s biggest power company, for 3.4 billion euros ($4.3 billion), throwing a new twist into a takeover battle for Endesa. Acciona said it did not plan to make a takeover bid, but it did not rule out increasing its stake. The 10 percent share matches that of Endesa’s largest shareholder, Caja Madrid. Endesa is the target of competing takeover bids from E.On of Germany and Gas Natural of Spain. The price Acciona paid for its stake, 32 euros a share, is 26 percent more than E.On’s bid, a factor that might force E.On to raise its bid or to withdraw because of the high price, analysts said.

CVC Asia Pacific, a buyout firm, said it had agreed to buy the DCA Group for 1.7 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) to gain control of an Australian provider of hospitals for the elderly. CVC will pay 3.50 Australian dollars for each share of DCA, 35 percent more than the stock’s price on Sept. 8, when DCA said it had received takeover offers. DCA owns 229 X-ray clinics and 6,000 nursing home beds, mostly in Australia. CVC Asia is owned by Citigroup and CVC Capital Partners of London.

Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain’s biggest bank, agreed to buy 90 percent of Drive Financial Services of Dallas for $651 million, gaining a presence in 35 states with what is its first consumer finance move into the United States. The bank will buy the unit from HBOS, a British mortgage lender, and the management of Drive Financial. Santander will also pay as much as $175 million to some of Drive Financial’s management if the company meets goals in the next two years. Drive Financial offers financial services through 10,000 car dealers and had $2.4 billion of loans in August.

Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil said it had extended its 19 billion Canadian dollars ($17 billion) tender offer for the Canadian mining company Inco to give regulators time to approve the deal. Rio Doce said it extended the deadline to Oct. 16 from Sept. 28. Rio Doce, the world’s largest iron ore miner, has obtained regulatory approval from the Canadian Competition Bureau and from authorities in the United States, but must still get clearance from the European Commission and Investment Canada.
With plans for a second office in New Hampshire, Gov. George E. Pataki is putting his flag in states that have significant influence on the presidential nominations.

Gross receipts at Keeneland’s September yearling sale totaled nearly $400 million, making the 14-day sale the highest-grossing thoroughbred auction in the world. The $399,791,800 total was a 4 percent increase over 2005’s record of $384,349,900 at Keeneland. One yearling, a colt by Kingmambo, sold for $11.7 million, a sale record, and 32 yearlings sold for $1 million or more.

Nine Iranian weightlifters tested positive for doping, forcing the national team to withdraw from the coming world championships. The World Anti-Doping Agency tested all 11 Iranian weightlifters Sept. 10, and nine failed, the Iranian weightlifting federation said. Iranian officials blamed the team’s Bulgarian coach, Yourdon Georgy Ivanof, saying he gave the lifters food supplements containing testosterone. Those who failed were not named, but the statement said Hossein Rezazadeh and Asghar Ebrahimi did not test positive.

Jason Blake scored two of the Islanders’ four third-period goals Monday night at Madison Square Garden, rallying them past the Rangers, 5-2.

Rutgers receiver Shawn Tucker is out indefinitely after breaking an ankle against Howard on Saturday, leaving the Scarlet Knights with an even younger group of wideouts. The sophomore Tiquan Underwood, who had been rotating with Tucker, will take his place in the starting lineup Friday night, when No. 23 Rutgers opens its Big East season at South Florida.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 — The pilots of the regional jet that took off on the wrong runway at Lexington, Ky., leading to a crash last month that killed 49 people, appear to have had at least a few moments in which they could have caught their error, according to preliminary information released on Monday by the National Transportation Safety Board.

U.S. FEE SET FOR REGISTERED TRAVELER The Transportation Security Administration will charge vendors who operate Registered Traveler programs $30 a year for each member. The announcement was seen as a green light for wider introduction of the program, which aims to speed frequent travelers through airport security lines. “T.S.A. said all along that they wanted to hear from the industry about actual costs and to pin down their own anticipated costs before deciding on the fee, and their word was good,” said Steve Brill, whose company, Verified Identity Pass, operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear in Orlando, Fla., and has agreements to expand to four other airports. A competitor, Unisys, said it hoped to open programs soon at airports in Denver and Reno, Nev. Clear costs $79.95 a year; the T.S.A. fee will be added to that. Larry Zmuda, who leads the Unisys Registered Traveler initiative, said he expected Unisys charges to be in the same range.

When President Bush informed Pakistan after the Sept. 11 attacks five years ago that it faced a stark choice — to be with us or against us — neither he nor his counterpart, President Pervez Musharraf, could have imagined it would come to this.

Though she has trapped and tagged about 100 skunks in her research project, Luanne Johnson has only once been skunked herself. But she did not rely on tomato juice to remove the smell. That remedy will only mask the odor, she said. Instead she recommends a remedy offered by William F. Wood, a chemist at Humboldt State University in Arcata, Calif., which she has on a printed flier for anyone who needs it.
Hearing loss is the third most common chronic condition among older Americans, after hypertension and arthritis.

To the Editor: Re ''Time to Move the Mississippi, Experts Say'' (Sept. 19): The debate over big diversions has raged here for 20 years and there is little consensus, much less unanimity, on that issue. The scientists you quoted glossed over the impacts of diverting the river. The changes in temperature and salinity in the bays would have severe effects on fisheries, virtually ending oyster production in the nation's most productive areas.

FLAUM--Howard, age 89, died September 21, 2006 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was alifelong resident of NYC. Mr. Flaum was the son of the late Samuel & Lillian Flaum and brother of the late Roslyn Lieberman. He served in the US Army Air Force in WWII. He was a salesman at the Murphy Bed Co. for over 40 years. Mr. Flaum is survived by a nephew Lawrence Lieberman and loving cousins.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Fugitive Al Qaeda Leader Killed by British Solders A senior operative of Al Qaeda who engineered an escape from a high security American prison in Afghanistan was killed in a pre-dawn raid by British soldiers in the city of Basra in southern Iraq, an American official and an Iraqi official said. A1 Islamists Advance in Somalia After warlords fled Kismayo, one of Somalia's largest cities, and Islamic forces poured in, demonstrators hurled stones at the Islamists. They in turn fired on the demonstrators, killing at least one teenage boy, witnesses said. A12 Briton Makes Bid to Lead Party Gordon Brown, left, in what could be the final chapter of his campaign to replace Tony Blair as Britain's prime minister, is promising a pro-American government with ''a soul.'' Mr. Brown praised Mr. Blair's legacy and offered himself as the Labor Party's strongest candidate to fight the Conservative opposition. A6 Scion's Trial Opens in Kenya Thomas Patrick Gilbert Cholmondeley, the scion of one of Kenya's richest and most fabled white families who is charged with killing a poacher on his family's estate, went on trial today. It was the second time in little more than a year that he has shot to death a black Kenyan on the property. A12 Top Israeli Is Said to Meet Saudi An Israeli newspaper reported that Prime Minister Ehud Olmert held a secret meeting with a senior Saudi Arabian official to discuss issues that included Iran's nuclear program and prospects for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. A11 Rice Sees Tough Lebanon Force Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged the peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon to act on a mandate approved by the United Nations that grants international troops authority to challenge anyone who attempts to block their mission, and to use force if necessary. A11 NATIONAL A14-21 Europeans Raise Doubts On Sifting of Financial Data A European Union panel has serious doubts about the legality of a Bush administration program that monitors international financial transactions, the group's leader said, and plans to recommend tighter controls to prevent privacy abuses. A1 Air Travel Restrictions Relaxed Aviation security officials eased the ban on carry-on liquids for airline passengers, after weeks of testing to determine how much of a liquid explosive would cause catastrophic damage to an airplane. A14 Agreement on Border Fence House and Senate negotiators agreed to invest $1.2 billion to install hundreds of miles of fence and vehicle barriers along the Mexican border as part of a $34.8 billion spending plan for the Department of Homeland Security for next year. A21 Anthrax Not Weapon-Grade Seeking to clear up public confusion, an F.B.I. official has reiterated the bureau's judgment that the anthrax in the letter attacks five years ago bore no special coatings to increase its deadliness and had no hallmarks of a military weapon. A18 A.C.L.U. Ouster Sought More than 30 longtime supporters of the American Civil Liberties Union are calling for the ouster of the organization's leadership, saying it has failed to adhere to the principles it demands of others and jeopardized the organization's effectiveness. A14 Parties Jockey for Position Republicans and Democrats scrambled to gain the advantage in their final week before breaking to campaign for crucial midterm elections, with Republicans pushing bills for national security and Democrats focusing on the Bush administration's handling of the war in Iraq. A16 Calls for Report on Terrorism The top Republican and Democratic members of the Senate intelligence committee called for the White House to declassify the National Intelligence Estimate on terrorism that was produced in April, but Bush administration officials do not intend to make the document public. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Many Small-Town Judges Are Ignorant of the Law An unfamiliarity with basic legal principles is remarkably common in New York's town and village courts, which have been hailed as ''poor man's courts'' for generations. There are few more vivid spots to view their shortcomings than in one of New York's poorest corners, Franklin County, only one of the 32 local justices is a lawyer. A1 Lieberman's Plan for Iraq Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, in his first major speech on Iraq since his loss in the Democratic primary, called for the number of Americans embedded with Iraqi troops to be doubled or tripled, as a way to speed up the training of Iraqis and hasten the withdrawal of Americans. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 New Claim of Rare Bird Evidence Scientists are reporting they have found evidence of ivory-billed woodpeckers in Florida. But having observed the turbulent disputes among ornithologists and birders that followed the report last year that the bird had been found in Arkansas, these researchers are proceeding with caution. F2 Health & Fitness F5 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6 Homecoming Win for the Saints The New Orleans Saints defeated the Atlanta Falcons, 23-3, in their first game in the Superdome since Hurricane Katrina. D1 ARTS E1-10 Gibson's Image Clouds Film Mel Gibson, fiercely criticized for his anti-Semitic outburst after being arrested for drunk driving in July, held screenings of his still-unfinished new film, ''Apocalypto,'' in Oklahoma, where he wore a wig and disguise, and in Texas. In Texas, he compared the American troop deployment in Iraq to the kind of human sacrifice depicted in his film, about ancient Mayans. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 Ruling on Light Cigarettes A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often marketed as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim. A1 Home Prices Decline The national median price of a previously owned home dipped into the red in August, to $225,000. It was the first time that prices of existing homes had fallen on a year-over-year basis in more than a decade. LAZAR--Judy. It is with profound sadness that we mourn our friend, colleague and SAJES Board member, Judy Lazar. Judy was a dedicated supporter of Jewish education and a beloved member of this community. Judy touched many lives in many ways--chairing events and taking on countless leadership roles. Most important was her role as trusted friend, advisor and wise counsel. Judy's loss is immeasurable-for us at SAJES, the Suffolk YJCC and our UJA-Federation family. Our sincere condolences to Joel and to her beloved family. May Judy Lazar's memory always be for a blessing. David I. Rosenberg, President Deborah Friedman,Exec. Dir. SAJES

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged the peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon yesterday to act on what she termed ''a very robust'' mandate approved by the United Nations that grants international troops authority to challenge anyone who attempts to block their mission, and to use force if necessary. ''The language says that anything and anyone who keeps them from fulfilling their responsibilities is to be challenged on that, and they even have the right to use force if they need to,'' Ms. Rice said. ''That mandate was written in a very robust fashion.''

COURTISS--Dick. You impacted the lives of thousands of children and adults. From your childhood days in Boston to your legendary career as an all-American lacrosse player and football player at Syracuse to building Camp Vega, one of America's premier camps, you gave 100% in all you did with the most unique flair. We loved sharing days and times with you ''on the road,'' in Maine, in New York and in Duxbury. Thousands of campers and counselors were privileged to know you. We were privileged that you ''let us in.'' We miss you already. We will always be The Three Amigos. We're here for Kyle, Steve and the Courtiss family. Jeff Konigsberg Camps Takajo & Tripp Lake Keith Klein Camps Laurel & Laurel South $(6$)COURTISS--Dick. May 2, 1936September 23, 2006. It is with great sorrow that Camp Vega for Girls mourns the loss of retired camp director and past co-owner of one of Maine's premier girl's camps. Dick shall be dearly missed by Vega's family, alumnae and friends. Dick was a dedicated camp director who imparted inspirational messages to both campers and staff alike. Dick's direct, concise messages reminded young people that they should believe in themselves and acquire a good work ethic while being a good person. Dick's philosophical messages were often relayed through football coaching terms which inspired the camp community in recognizing ''team'' responsibility and maintaining a winning spirit. As a past team member of the Syracuse lacrosse and football teams, Dick's messages will continue as a legacy to all who knew and loved him.

Democratic challengers have begun a new wave of advertising intended to put Republican incumbents on the defensive over national security. The advertising highlights votes by House and Senate Republicans against increased benefits for veterans and better pay and equipment for troops. The incumbents say the ads are misleading or false. JOHN M. BRODER HOUSE: Virginia 2nd DEMOCRAT: Phil Kellam REPUBLICAN: Rep. Thelma Drake Mr. Kellam accuses Ms. Drake of voting against veterans' health programs and lower prescription drug costs for military families. Ms. Drake, who represents a district with thousands of military families, responds that she voted for major increases in benefits. SENATE: Arizona DEMOCRAT: Jim Pederson REPUBLICAN: Sen. Jon Kyl Mr. Pederson says that Mr. Kyl voted for a pay raise for himself and other members of Congress but against reimbursing veterans for lost pay while they served in Iraq. Mr. Kyl's campaign responds that he sponsored a measure to rescind the most recent Congressional pay raise.

An article on Sept. 15 about an expected guilty plea by John A. Lynch Jr., a former New Jersey Senate president, in a tax evasion and political corruption case misstated his position in 1998, the year of a business deal said to be the basis of the corruption charge. At the time, he was a state senator, not the Senate president.

He was the devoted and remaining brother of Sadie and Allan Fudell, Esther and Joseph P. Feldman, Lee and Henry Winokur. Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, a playwright and a writer for Marvel Comics, has a fondness for including details about New York City in his comic book tales. Such points have varied from the Human Torch, a member of the Fantastic Four, boasting about getting tickets for ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee'' to having Nightcrawler, an X-Man, investigate demons in the Dakota. In ''Sensational Spider-Man'' No. 30, right, which went on sale on Wednesday, Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa used the Whitney Museum of American Art as the setting for a battle between the wall crawler and Max Dillon, who happens to be a fan of fine art and is also the supervillain Electro. While Dillon is admiring paintings by Mark Rothko, a caption tells the reader, ''Before he was a supervillain, before he was a telephone-wire repairman, Dillon dreamed about being an artist. (The same way a young German man named Adolph once did.)'' Soon enough, however, the art lesson is over and a superpowered fight begins. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES
VOLK--William. 1911 to 2006; died at Applewood Estates, Freehold, N.J.,September 23, 2006. Survived by his wife of 66 years, Dorothy Thorsen Volk.

Researchers have found that smokers may be at higher risk for becoming infected with the virus that causes AIDS. The study, which appears in the journal Sexually Transmitted Infections, says it is not clear why smokers would be more likely to become infected with the virus, H.I.V., than nonsmokers.

SULLIVAN--Kathryn, RSCJ, prominent Catholic biblical scholar, longtime professor at Manhattanville University, died September 22 at Kenwood Convent, Albany, NY at age 101. Sr. Sullivan, of the Society of the Sacred Heart, became in 1947 the first woman elected to membership in the Catholic Biblical Association and in 1958 became its vicepresident. During and after 46 years at Manhattanville (1938-1984), she lectured at major Catholic seminaries in the U.S. and Rome. The funeral Mass is at 9 a.m. today, Tuesday, September 26, at Kenwood Convent. Memorial contributions may be made to Society of the Sacred Heart, 4389 West Pine Blvd, St. Louis, MO 63108

To the Editor: Re ''More Small Women's Colleges Opening Doors to Men'' (news article, Sept. 21): As a recent graduate of Smith College, I can say with certainty that choosing an all-women's college was the best decision I have ever made.

In leading their team to the playoffs next week, Omar Minaya and Willie Randolph are headed there with what is most likely a record. The Elias Book of Baseball Records doesn't list it. Neither Elias nor anyone else keeps track of it. But with a combined total of 23 unsuccessful job interviews before they got their jobs with the Mets, Minaya and Randolph most likely went through more questions and answers than any other playoff-bound general manager and manager.

More than 200 police officers raided a housing project south of Paris in a dramatic dawn roundup to catch suspects involved in a violent ambush last week of two officers who were beaten when they left their patrol car in the neighborhood. The raid came nearly a year after riots flared in the neighborhood and across France. Eleven people were detained after police officers braved a rain of bottles and other projectiles to move in on the tough housing project in the Corbeil-Essonnes suburb. The raid came after the interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, a leading presidential contender who has championed law-and-order policies, pledged to catch those responsible ''one by one.'' JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

An Israeli military appeals court in the West Bank on Monday reversed an earlier ruling and said that 18 Hamas lawmakers and cabinet ministers would have to remain in jail pending trial. A military court on Sept. 12 ordered Israel to release the Hamas members, but military prosecutors appealed. The men are charged with belonging to a terrorist organization. Aziz Dweik, the speaker of parliament and one of those being held, called the ruling a political decision.
An article yesterday about the coming presidential election in Brazil misstated the date for a runoff, if one is necessary. It would be Oct. 29, not Oct. 15.

The Katie Couric bounce further eroded last week as the ''CBS Evening News'' fell firmly behind ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams,'' which finished at No. 1 all five nights last week. According to Nielsen's estimates for the week of Sept. 18-22, Ms. Couric's third week on CBS drew 7.7 million total viewers, down 2 percent from her second week. On Thursday and Friday, CBS finished last behind ABC. NBC posted nearly a half-million more viewers than CBS for the week (8.2 million), and ''ABC's World News With Charles Gibson'' finished a close third with 7.6 million. In the crucial demographic of adults 25 to 54, the three networks tied with a 2.1 rating. BENJAMIN TOFF

THE CLAIM -- Chlorine in drinking water can increase the risk of cancer. THE FACTS -- Companies that sell water filters often claim that the chlorine in most tap water causes cancer. Is it true? Scientists say chlorination can produce at least one group of chemical byproducts, trihalomethanes, that are considered carcinogenic. But studies over the years have differed on whether levels of these compounds in tap water adversely affect health.

LIGHT-CIGARETTE SMOKERS CAN SUE -- In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit. [Page A1.] VIACOM HEAD RESTRUCTURES PAY -- In another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, left, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company's financial performance. [C1.] HOME MARKET COOLS -- After inching up slowly for most of the summer, the national median price of a previously owned home finally dipped into the red in August, to $225,000. It was the first time that prices of existing homes had fallen on a year-over-year basis in more than a decade. [C1.] INSURANCE COSTS SOAR -- Among the reasons that real estate is cooling in some of the hottest markets is the soaring cost of insurance. Along the coast from Texas to Maine, owners of apartments and houses are facing huge premium increases. [C1.] THE NEXT WAVE -- Companies like Samsung, Intel and NTT DoCoMo of Japan are spending heavily in a race to control crucial aspects of an evolving new technology known as fourth-generation wireless and to promote it as the next wave in Internet access. But its future is far from certain. [C1.] DOUBTS ABOUT AUTO ALLIANCE -- General Motors has raised doubts in talks with Renault of France and Nissan of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result. The sides agreed to explore an alliance in discussions that began in July. Renault and Nissan say an alliance could cover operations as varied as purchasing, manufacturing and product development. [C1.] LIQUIDS BAN RELAXED -- Aviation officials eased the ban on carry-on liquids for airline passengers, after testing to determine how much liquid explosive would cause catastrophic damage to a plane. [A14.] OIL IN RETREAT -- Crude oil prices dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time in six months before rebounding a bit, as nervous speculators retreated from the commodity markets. [C3.] OIL AND RATES LIFT STOCKS -- Stocks surged, with the Nasdaq rising more than 1 percent, as oil prices and interest rates hit multimonth lows, improving the outlook for corporate profits. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 30.14 points to 2,249.07, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.71 points to 11,575.81. [C11.] COMPUTER POWER -- Google engineers will present a plan calling on the computer industry to create a simpler and more efficient power supply standard that they say will save billions of kilowatt-hours a year. [C3.] PATENT POLICY -- I.B.M. plans to publish its patent filings on the Web for public review as part of a policy that, if widely adopted, could help curb patent disputes and litigation. [C5.] PROGRESS ON A TINY SCALE -- A lengthy assessment for Congress says the United States continues to lead the world in research into nanotechnology -- manipulation of atoms and small clusters of molecules -- but the impact of the government's investment in the field may take decades to become apparent. [C6.] PANEL ADVISES HEALTH CARE ACTION -- A federal advisory panel, the Citizens' Health Care Working Group, said that Congress should take immediate steps to guarantee that all Americans have access to affordable health care by 2012. [A17.] HOUSE CALLS H.P. FIGURES -- Two Hewlett-Packard employees who directed the company's spying operations have been subpoenaed to appear before the House Energy and Commerce Committee after refusing invitations to testify. [C2.] ENERGY LEASE SALE BLOCKED -- The Interior Department's plan to sell oil and natural gas leases in northern Alaska was blocked by a federal judge who ruled that the department had failed to do a sufficiently broad analysis of the plan's environmental impact. [A15.] EUROPEAN UNION EXPANSION -- Romania and Bulgaria will receive qualified endorsement to join the European Union on Jan. 1, but the bloc will warn that expansion must then halt until the organization makes needed changes, the European Commission president said. [A5.] WALGREEN PROFIT RISES -- The Walgreen Company, the drugstore chain, posted a 25 percent increase in quarterly profit, driven by strong sales of prescription medications. Walgreen shares declined, however, as earnings before unusual items fell short of expectations. [C2.] ACQUITTAL IN WIRETAPPING CASE -- A former telephone company worker accused of lying to a grand jury in Los Angeles that is investigating the Anthony Pellicano wiretapping scandal was acquitted of most of the charges against her, dealing a sharp setback to federal prosecutors. [C8.] WACHOVIA TO PAY EX-BROKER -- Wachovia was ordered by a NASD arbitration panel to pay $3.8 million to a broker it fired in 2003 in connection with an investigation of improper trades. [C9.] SENTENCE IN FRAUD CASE -- The former chief executive of a paper manufacturer, American Tissue, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for organizing a fraud that cost banks and investors almost $300 million when the company collapsed. [C8.] WAVING THE FLAG -- Chevrolet, the brand that likened itself to baseball, hot dogs and apple pie in commercials in the 1970's, now hopes to kindle the same feelings by positioning the Silverado as America's truck, in ads that will begin running this weekend. Advertising. [C3.]
