Mona Lisa Lightens Up The Mona Lisa, as she has seldom been seen, will put in a rare appearance next month at the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London. The painting, left, from a private collection, is an early copy in vibrant colors believed to reflect those of the Leonardo da Vinci original, CBC Arts reported. The reproduction, to be seen in London for the first time since 1902, is thought to have been traced from the original by an unidentified French artist a century after the masterpiece was painted between 1503 and 1516. Copies were not uncommon in that era, because seeing the originals required long journeys. Although the original, in the Louvre in Paris, has faded over the years, the reproduction shows the Mona Lisa in bright colors -- yellow sleeves, a forest-green gown -- under a dazzling blue sky. Martin Kemp, a professor of art history at Oxford University and a Leonardo specialist, told The Guardian, ''It will give people a real sense that the Mona Lisa was once a colorful painting.'' The copy, once owned by Sir Joshua Reynolds, who got it from the Duke of Leeds in 1790, will be on view from Oct. 10 to Feb. 11. James Nachtwey Wins Heinz Award The globe-trotting self-taught photojournalist James Nachtwey, below, of New York, whose images have recorded war, famine and discord, has won the $250,000 12th annual Heinz Award for Arts and Humanities. ''As a photojournalist, James Nachtwey has created art, not art that offers a new technique but art that powerfully exposes man's inhumanity to man,'' said Teresa Heinz, chairwoman of the Heinz Family Foundation, which confers the awards in five categories, including environment, human condition, public policy and technology, the economy and employment. ''He photographs people who need to be brought to our attention, people whose truths need to be known in a visual context.'' The awards will be presented at a private ceremony in Pittsburgh on Oct. 24. Stolen Munch Art To Be Seen Damaged by thieves, the Edward Munch masterworks ''The Scream'' and ''Madonna'' will briefly go on view beginning tomorrow at the city-owned Munch Museum in Oslo, where they were stolen by masked gunmen in broad daylight in August 2004, The Associated Press reported. Recovered by the police on Aug. 31, the works will be exhibited through Sunday in response to public demand, the museum said. The stolen ''Scream'' was damaged in one corner, and two one-inch holes mar ''Madonna.'' The museum said they can be repaired, but the restoration will be time consuming. Footnotes Robin Williams, below, who sought treatment for alcoholism in August, is to join the director Barry Levinson in a conversation moderated by Lillian Ross after a screening of their new comedy, ''Man of the Year,'' at noon on Oct. 8 at the Alliance Française as part of the New Yorker Festival. The festival has also added a second screening of the Sacha Baron Cohen film ''Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan'' at 12:30 p.m. on Oct. 8 at the Directors Guild of America, 110 West 57th Street, in Midtown. Stacey Kent, singing songs including Cole Porter's ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy,'' Frank Loesser's ''If I Were a Bell'' and Antonio Carlos Jobim's ''Corcovado,'' will open her new show, ''Love and the Lyric,'' on Oct. 3 at Feinstein's at the Regency.'' With the saxophonist Jim Tomlinson (her husband) as her guest, she will appear through Oct. 14. Julie Andrews has been chosen by the Screen Actors Guild to receive its Life Achievement Award, given annually to an actor who fosters the ''finest ideals of the acting profession.'' The award will be presented at a ceremony to be seen live on TNT and TBS on Jan. 28. After playing on Broadway and around the world, ''Stones in His Pockets,'' the Marie Jones comedy in which two actors play 15 roles in a story about a Hollywood film being shot in an Irish village, will return to London for a production in the West End at the Duchess Theater. Previews begin on Nov. 1.

A retired Supreme Court judge heard emotional testimony on the first day of a public inquiry into the 1985 bombing of an Air India Boeing 747 from Canada that exploded off the Irish coast killing all 329 people on board. A man whose wife died testified that the government had failed to support victims' families and did not do enough to pursue suspects in the bombing. Prime Minister Stephen Harper called the inquiry in May, in response to mounting pressure on the government after two Canadian Sikh activists accused of plotting the bombing were set free last year because of insufficient evidence. CHRISTOPHER MASON (NYT)
BITAR--Samir M.D. Suddenly and peacefully at 78 on September 24. Beloved husband of Hildegard; father of Karen and Nadia. Services private.

Q. What is vitamin K good for, and where can it be found? A. Vitamin K, named for the German word ''koagulation,'' meaning ''clotting,'' has a well-known role in blood clotting and preventing hemorrhaging. But recent evidence suggests that it may also be important for bone formation, preventing osteoporosis and keeping the circulatory and nervous systems healthy, said Dr. Sheldon S. Hendler, co-editor of the PDR for Nutritional Supplements, the standard reference in the field.

To the Editor: Re ''Updating Prescriptions for Avoiding Worldwide Catastrophe'' (Conversation, Sept. 12): Although James Lovelock is right about the immense problems posed by global warming, he is wrong when he proposes the concept of nuclear power to solve the dilemma. The process by which nuclear power is generated creates large quantities of global warming gases. This fact, together with the enormous expense of constructing and decommissioning reactors, the dangers of nuclear power in an age of terrorism and the problems associated with the disposal of radioactive waste, militate against the concept of nuclear-generated electricity.

City University of New York trustees yesterday raised the salary of their chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, for the first time in three years. The increase, to $395,000 from $350,000, followed a review of his performance by Jonathan R. Cole, the former Columbia University provost, and raises for other CUNY executives and for CUNY's faculty members. CUNY said Dr. Goldstein's new salary was still below those of chief executives at many smaller universities, although the salary of the chancellor of the State University of New York, which is larger than CUNY, is $340,000. KAREN W. ARENSON (NYT)

American researchers using fish auction records from Hong Kong have calculated that the trade in shark fins kills 26 million to 73 million sharks a year. The new estimate, reported in the October issue of the journal Ecology Letters, is far higher than United Nations assessments. Shark fins are used in a soup traditionally served at Chinese weddings and other celebrations. The scientists, led by Shelley Clarke of the University of Hawaii, say that because sharks reproduce relatively slowly, the trade threatens the world's shark species, many of which are already endangered. CORNELIA DEAN (NYT)

KIRSHENBAUM--Isidor. On September 24, 2006. Dr. Kirshenbaum was born on June 22, 1917 to Samuel and Kate Kirshenbaum. He obtained his PhD in Chemistry from Columbia University in 1942 and served on the Manhattan Project. After WW II, Dr. Kirshenbaum joined Esso Research and Engineering Company (currently Exxon) in Linden, New Jersey and retired in 1985 as a Senior Research Advisor and head of the Chemical Information Department. During his career, Dr. Kirshenbaum was awarded over 70 patents in the areas of nuclear research, petrochemicals and plastics, and authored a definitive work on the properties of heavy water (published by McGraw Hill in 1954) and over 35 scholarly articles. Dr. Kirshenbaum is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Lucy (nee Gutstein) of Scarsdale, N.Y., formerly of Westfield, N.J.; his four children and their spouses, Howard (Elaine), Steven (Nancy), Barbara (Mark Weliky) and Kenneth (Rena); his ten cherished grandchildren, and his brother Maurice (Carol). Funeral services will take place at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon, N.Y. September 26, 2006, 1:30 p.m.

For most gardeners, spending a gorgeous Saturday morning harvesting basil and organic heirloom tomatoes is a life-enhancing experience. But for green thumbs at one particular garden -- an innovative addition to a food bank for people with H.I.V. and AIDS -- the life-embracing quality of a bountiful harvest is quite literal. ''I'm not a California effete kind of person; it's important to get the nutrition,'' said Andrew Eckers, a 51-year-old volunteer gardener with a fondness for sorrel and pea shoots who, when the disease had him fully in its grip, spent eight years in a wheelchair. ''But this is also pleasurable.''

The resilient, pugnacious and form-shattering Jets awoke Monday to find themselves tied for first place in the American Football Conference East with the New England Patriots. Eric Mangini, the Jets' first-year coach, seemed underwhelmed. ''It grabs me better than the alternative,'' Mangini said with a weak laugh during his news conference Monday.

To the Editor: ''Rumsfeld Also Plays Hardball on Pentagon's Squash Courts'' (front page, Sept. 24): As a former Princeton varsity squash captain (class of 1975), I have one word for Donald H. Rumsfeld's on-court persona: bully.

STEWART--Thomas. Great artist, majestic singer, valued mentor and beloved friend, Thomas Stewart touched many lives as a superb performer, adored colleague and wise teacher. We will miss him terribly but no one will suffer his loss so deeply as his adored Evelyn. With our love and respect, Matthew A. Epstein Director of Vocal Divisions CAMI $(6$)STEWART--Thomas. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our friend and colleague, Thomas Stewart, who sang with us from 1966 to 1993. His vivid portrayals of heroic baritone roles were seen in 24 operas at the Met including ten new production premieres. we offer our sincere condolences to his wife Evelyn Lear, and all his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Dir.

LYONS--Albert S., MD. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Lyons, Clinical Professor of Surgery Emeritus, and Alumni Historian, was one of the first two physicians to graduate in 1942, from the Hospital's newly established Dept. of Surgery training program. A renowned gastric surgeon and author of many scientific papers, Dr. Lyons further served the institution by creating the Archives of The Mount Sinai Medical Center, preserving the history of Mount Sinai and its Alumni with painstaking diligence. In 1966, he was given the official title of Hospital Archivist. In 1969, he served as President of The Mount Sinai Alumni and, in 1974, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Lyons in acknowledgement of his many contributions as a physician and teacher, and the great distinction he brought to Mount Sinai. He exemplified our finest traditions of medical excellence and will be sorely missed. Barry Stimmel, MD, Pres. Elliot Rayfield, MD, V.P. Steven Itzkowitz, MD, Secy. Martin Goldstein, MD, Treas. $(6$)LYONS--Albert S., MD. The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus Albert S. Lyons, MD of the Department of Surgery. Dr. Lyons came to Mount Sinai in 1940, and spent his professional life here. He created the first clinic in the country for ostomates in 1951 and helped to found self-help groups for these patients. A gentleman and scholar, he authored articles in surgery as well as Medicine--An Illustrated History. He founded Mount Sinai's Archives and directed the History of Medicine Program from 1970-86. Because of his efforts, Mount Sinai's institutional memory remains vital. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, MD President, CEO and Dean $(6$)LYONS--Albert S., MD. The Department of Surgery at The Mount Sinai Hospital and Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourns the passing of our distinguished colleague and dear friend. As an esteemed & highly regarded professor and surgeon, Dr. Lyons served the department and the hospital for 65 years. He was recognized as a leader in the field of Surgery and a well known medical historian. He was an outstanding teacher to generations of surgical residents. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Michael L. Marin, M.D. Chairman Department of Surgery Mount Sinai School of Medicine

COHEN--Theodore, MD. The NYU Department of Medicine extends its condolences to the family of our distinguished colleague and friend, Theodore Cohen, MD, faculty member at NYU School of Medicine for over 50 years. Martin J. Blaser, MD, Chair Department of Medicine NYU School of Medicine

9:30 P.M. (Golf) BIG BREAK VI: TRUMP NATIONAL -- How do you say ''you're fired'' in golf-speak? Tonight, nine men and nine women tee off in a series of challenges at Trump National Golf Club in Los Angeles for a chance to compete in Champions and L.P.G.A. tour events. Donald Trump (above, far left, with contestants) makes a cameo appearance in this season premiere -- and sets up a few sand traps of his own along the way. 8 P.M. (11) GILMORE GIRLS -- When last we saw Lorelai, she was climbing into bed with Christopher after Luke refused her proposal to elope. This season opens with Lorelai waking up in bed with Christopher, then trying to erase Luke from her memory. Only now he's the one with the question. 8 P.M. (13) MYSTERY OF THE MEGAVOLCANO -- ''Nova'' investigates the greatest volcanic explosion of the last 100,000 years and looks at how this blast from the past affected Earth's future. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: CRIMINAL INTENT -- A dead father's womanizing ways lead detectives to a relationship between a teacher and her underage student. 9 P.M. (13) MOZART AT 250: THE SALZBURG FESTIVAL CELEBRATION -- The Vienna Philharmonic presents a birthday bash of high points from a few of Mozart's operas, performed by Magdalena Kozena, Patricia Petibon, Anna Netrebko, Rene Pape, Michael Schade, Ekaterina Siurina and Thomas Hampson. Daniel Harding conducts. 9:30 P.M. (ABC) HELP ME HELP YOU -- Some eccentric types try sorting through their troubles in a group session run by a therapist who may have the biggest problems of all. Ted Danson (left) stars as the inappropriately puffed-up Dr. Bill Hoffman; Jere Burns, who proved himself a team player in ''Dear John,'' is a patient with anger-management issues. 10 P.M. (FX) NIP/TUCK -- Case of the week: Shari Noble (Melissa Gilbert), whose dog bit off her nipple, wants breast reconstruction before her husband returns from Iraq. 10 P.M. (HBO) WAIT 'TIL NEXT YEAR: THE SAGA OF THE CHICAGO CUBS -- They used to be the best, but that was almost 100 years ago. Here, loyal fans talk about their dedication to the Major League Baseball team with the longest dry spell -- nearly a century -- between World Series titles. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- Well, that's one way to make an entrance. Jeffrey Coho (Craig Bierko, right) comes in with a bang when he takes on a client accused of murdering a judge on his first day at Crane Poole & Schmidt. Meanwhile, Denny's online date threatens to sue the firm, and Alan defends a cross-dresser who got fired for taking maternity leave. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

On this volcanic island at the tip of the Korean Peninsula, where kings once exiled dissidents and tourists now flock to casinos, South Korean engineers recently unveiled a prototype of a wireless network that they hope will revolutionize Internet access. In August, Samsung, the South Korean electronics company, gave the first public demonstration of its version of the network. One day, the company and others in the industry hope, the network will let users open a laptop anywhere and, without attaching a cable or looking for a Wi-Fi hot spot, immediately surf the Internet or download music and movies as fast as the fastest broadband.

A picture caption with the State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about the TiVo Series 3 high-definition digital video recorder, referred imprecisely to its capacity. While it is limited to 200 hours of standard-definition programming at medium quality, it can store 300 hours at basic quality.

Gov. George E. Pataki plans to head back to Iowa on Friday to open an office for his political action committee -- not only to help candidates in November, members of his staff said yesterday, but also to lay more groundwork for his own possible presidential bid in 2008. With plans in the works to open a second office soon in New Hampshire, Mr. Pataki is planting his flag in two states that have significant influence in the presidential nominating process. Iowa holds the first caucuses in the nation in 2008, on Jan. 14, and New Hampshire holds the first primary the following week.

To the Editor: Re ''A Psychiatrist Is Slain, and a Sad Debate Deepens'' (Sept. 19): One of the first things we were taught years ago as rookie psychiatrists when dealing with distrustful individuals was to appear somewhat officious, distant and stiff. Our instructor explained that for them, anger is the only sentiment they ''trust.'' We were also taught to have someone else present to ''chaperone'' the interview. And we were never to position ourselves between the patient and the door.

ANATOLE--Lucille, 87, of Greenwich, CT, and formerly of Egremont, MA, and Lawrence, NY, died at her home on September 24th, 2006. She will always be remembered as Babs. Beloved wife of David (Tolia) for 66 years, loving mother of Amy Schwab and her husband Jim, and Mark Anatole and his wife Jodi. Devoted Grammy to Kate and Joanna Schwab, and Emily and Carter Anatole. Grammy, we will always remember the ''Happy Times''. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

OSTOW--Mortimer. We announce with a deep sense of loss the passing of Dr. Mortimer Ostow, who was for many decades the director and scientific leader of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund. His leadership established the intellectual exchange of colleagues in the field of psychoanalysis with many resulting publications. His own creative studies and publications in so many areas of the human experience was a model to all of us. We shall continue to follow his legacy. Peter B. Neubauer, MD Henry Nunberg, MD, Executive Secretary of the Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund $(6$)OSTOW--Mortimer. 88, September 23, 2006. Husband of the late Miriam, father of Robin, M. Jeremy, Abigail and Rachel. Father-in-law of Carmen, Arthur and Brian. Grandfather of Natascha, Rachel, Todd, Micol, Naomi, Oliver, Joseph, David, Nurit, Sarah, Ilana, Micah and Hannah, and great grandfather of Miriam Lubrich. Brother of Evelyn Mandelker and Shari Friedman. Devoted to his family, dedicated physician, distinguished scholar and teacher and committed Jew. He is called friend, beloved. And they enjoy from him counsel, and sound wisdom, understanding, and strength. Shiva at 4421 Douglas Ave, Bronx, NY 10471, Tuesday through Friday afternoon and Saturday evening. $(6$)OSTOW--Mortimer. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and dear friend. Among the foremost psychiatrists and analysts in America, Dr. Ostow introduced into the training of rabbis at JTS a professional exposure to the fields of psychology and pastoral work. A lifelong student of Judaica, he also served as a creative catalyst for the promotion of interdisciplinary studies of anti-Semitism, Jewish mysticism, and religious ritual. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor-elect Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

Mel Gibson's eccentric promotional foray into the heartland with his new movie, ''Apocalypto,'' might have helped introduce the film to a vast potential audience. But it also left the beleaguered star with a lot more explaining to do. This filmmaker and actor, fiercely criticized for his anti-Semitic outburst after being arrested for drunk driving in July, first showed the still-unfinished movie at a casino and at Cameron University in Oklahoma, where he arrived in wig and disguise, according to an Associated Press report. Then he moved on to the Fantastic Fest film festival in Austin, Tex., where he compared the American troop deployment in Iraq to the kind of human sacrifice depicted in his film, about ancient Mayans, according to The Hollywood Reporter.
For Florida Republicans, the damage from Hurricane Katherine may not be over. First, Representative Katherine Harris, right, turned aside pleas from the party's leaders not to run for the Senate.

To the Editor: Re ''In Science-Based Medicine, Where Does Luck Fit In?'' (Sept. 19): The argument is made that our likelihood of developing, identifying and surviving disease is based on chance. In a sense, this is true. There are a plethora of unknown factors that might contribute to our ability to avoid or survive disease.

BURKES--Albert. Poppy--a million kisses and a thousand thank yous. I love you to the moon and back again. Jenny $(6$)BURKES--Albert (October 21, 1914-September 25, 2006). The one and only. From teenage love to lifelong soulmate of 65 years to the late Adele Burkes. Incomparable father to Susan, Lynn and Jeff and Sue Burkes. A very special Poppy and a true Pied Piper to the luckiest grandchildren. His impeccable mind, warmest heart and unbroken spirit we will forever carry. A beacon of light; our heart belongs to Daddy. Memorial services to be announced.

A contents entry on the front page of Business Day yesterday misspelled the surname of the French soccer star who leveled an Italian player with a blow to the chest, an incident that is the subject of a Nike ad campaign. He is Zinédine Zidane, not Zidan.

The Rams' Jeff Wilkins has made 11 of 13 field-goal attempts this season -- the most makes and the most attempts in the league -- and his high-kicking pace has him on course to break the league records for field goals (40 by the Cardinals' Neil Rackers) and attempts (49 by the Rams' Bruce Gossett).

Jeanine Pirro says she is the victim of a "political witch hunt and smear campaign." She said the investigation was timed to derail her campaign as the Republican candidate for attorney general against Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic nominee.
Is that the sound of checks being torn up?
Tampa Bay quarterback Chris Simms is not the first high-level athlete toponder a future without a spleen.

When it was announced Monday that Seahawks running back Shaun Alexander had broken his foot and would miss an undetermined amount of time, message boards lit up with talk of the Madden Curse, the theory that any player appearing on the cover of the Madden EA Sports video game will be injured or ineffective. What has not been mentioned as often is the Chunky Soup Curse.
First Mayor Bloomberg, now Governor Pataki. Is there a new Empire State chapter in Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's fan club?

When President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan sits down for dinner at the White House with President Bush and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan Wednesday night, he might have a little splainin' to do.
Who says Wall Street analysts have a prejudice in favor of buy recommendations?
The New York Republican Party chairman, Stephen J. Minarik III, on Jeanine F. Pirro:
New York City lost its bid for the Republican National Convention in 2008. The G.O.P. picked the Twin Cities of Minneapolis-St. Paul. There's more over at The Caucus.
The Times's Warren Hoge describes the upcoming selection process of the United Nations' new Secretary General. (Producer: Emily Hager)

The Republican National Committee announced today that its 2008 convention will be in (drum roll please ) Minneapolis-St. Paul, from Sept. 1-4. The other finalists included the Tampa Bay area, New York City, and Cleveland.

White House Press Secretary Tony Snow, formerly of Fox News, still likes to think of himself as a journalist by trade. But on Wednesday, the former newsman made clear his transition to pitchman is complete: He announced he has begun headlining fund-raisers for Republicans.

The pledge is a time-honored, generally toothless tradition in campaigns. Sometimes candidates break them out during debates, trying to make their opponents look bad for not vowing not to run negative ads. Or, if your opponent does sign, and slips up, there's always a chance to run your own, fully justified negative ad.

All the versions of the Wallace-Clinton showdown that first appeared on Fox News are back up on YouTube. Fox has decided on glasnost, and letting a thousand flowers bloom. So you can watch the exact clip fit with a "Bill Clinton Gone Mad!!!" title, or with a "Bill Clinton Destroys Chris Wallace And FOX news" title. Nice. You get to screen the same clip everyone's seen -- so you're not ignorant -- but you don't have to change your ideology one micron to accommodate it. The new American way.
Tune in to WNBC Channel 4 at 4 p.m., and probably NY 1 at 4:30 p.m., and judge for yourself if Jeanine F. Pirro's bid for attorney general is over.
Call it the Icahn effect.

The troubles at Milberg Weiss might be a rich source of schadenfreude for the editorial board of The Wall Street Journal, which has long derided the law firm for its role in waging shareholder class action suits against corporations.

Back from the debate in Ithaca last night, Eliot Spitzer was busy on the campaign trail in Yonkers this morning on behalf of Andrea Stewart-Cousins, who is trying to unseat Nicholas Spano from the State Senate for a second time, having lost her first bid in 2004 by 18 votes.

The Times Reader beta is now open to everyone. To participate, go to the Times Reader page on First Look and click the "Download" button. You will be asked to register for Times Reader and then invited to download the software.

Ah, vindication. Just days after Herb Greenberg of MarketWatch wrote a column for The Wall Street Journal excoriating "reverse mergers" involving Chinese companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in one of the companies he cited -- China Energy Savings.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Sept. 27 column, "Fill 'Er Up With Dictators."

MySpace, the online hangout that News Corporation acquired last year for about $600 million, has already "created billions of value for shareholders," Jordon Rohan of RBC Capital Markets wrote in a research note on Wednesday.
The Bank of Montreal said on Wednesday that its United States subsidiary had agreed to buy First National Bank & Trust of Indiana for $290 million.
A once strait-laced nation cultivates a more urbane image in its kitchens.

With President Bush apparently set to make another national address by the end of this week - the subject, we're told, is terrorism again - the White House campaign for public opinion on the war in Iraq and the terrorists Mr. Bush called "mean people" on Tuesday, remains at full throttle.
Jacob "Kobi" Alexander, the former Comverse chief executive charged with illegally backdating stock options, was detained in Namibia, according to the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn.

They just want two parties all the time: Green Party candidate Carl Romanelli has been tossed from the ballot in Pennsylvania's Senate race (where the major party candidates are Rick Santorum and Bob Casey Jr.) for not having enough valid signatures on his petition. "The Romanelli story has important resonance beyond the Casey-Santorum connection," writes The Philadelphia Inquirer's Dick Polman on his personal blog. "The bottom line is that it highlights the plight of third party candidates in general, and demonstrates the longstanding barriers erected by the two dominant political parties."

President Bush travels to Memphis on Wednesday, campaigning at a Tennessee Republican Party luncheon for Bob Corker in his contest against Harold Ford Jr. for Senator Bill Frist's seat. According to a pool report from Tuesday night, Mr. Bush attended a big fund-raiser at the home of Wayne Berman. Laura Bush, the first lady, back from her trip to Ohio and upstate New York on Tuesday, flies out again on Thursday to Iowa, to campaign in Davenport and Des Moines for two Congressional candidates, Mike Whalen and Jeff Lamberti, as well as for Dick DeVos, who is running for governor. Mr. Bush heads to Alabama on Thursday and then to Ohio, to campaign there for Representative Deborah Pryce.

The leak-investigation scandal at Hewlett-Packard has rocked the company's boardroom and drawn the attention of federal lawmakers. It has also inspired Martin Lipton, a prominent takeover attorney and a partner at the law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, to offer some advice to his clients in the form of a memo.
We'll start off with some of the usual suspects...
I keep thinking about the stories I didn't write.

In a sign that investors continue to crave a piece of the private-equity pie, the newly formed Centerbridge Partners has raised $3 billion for its first fund. The Financial News reported Wednesday that the sum is $500 million more than the firm originally expected to collect.
A detainee bill is likely before Congress closes shop at the end of the week. Warrantless wiretapping, not so likely.Detainee bills: S. 3930, H.R. 6166
The step up from a crib needn't be a big twin bed.
The "marriage gap" could be decisive in this year's election, USA Today writes, based on an analysis of Census data.
Potential presidential contenders are lining up to stump (and fund-raise) with Phil Angelides in his bid to unseat Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger in California.
Sales of new single-family homes increased by 4.1 percent last month, raising hopes that the steep slide in the housing industry may be leveling off.
Furnishings from "Star Trek" at Christie's.
Everyone's always asking me when Apple will come out with a cellphone. My answer is, "Probably never."
Collections: Bottega Veneta, Burberry, Ferragamo; Giorgio Armani, Marni and Prada.
Two Hewlett-Packard employees at the center of the company's controversail leak investigation scandal have left the company.

VirginiaThe Washington Post's Michael D. Shear expects all negativity all the time in the race between Senator George Allen and Democrat James Webb until Election Day. Senator Allen denied yet another accusation from a former acquaintance that he used racial slurs.OhioWith Republican Kenneth Blackwell's gubernatorial defeat looking increasingly likely, G.O.P. voters discouraged by the top of the ticket might not turn out for Senator Mike DeWine, who is in a much tighter race with Representative Sherrod Brown, a Democrat.

Tennessee's Ninth Congressional DistrictDoes a district belong to a race? A family? A faith? In Memphis, a scion of the powerful, African-American Ford family is running to replace his brother in the majority black district as an independent against the Jewish Democratic nominee.
Third Point, an activist hedge fund, said on Tuesday that it would try to oust the chief executive of Nabi Biopharmaceuticals, Thomas McLain, from the board.

Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, sued the mutual fund manager J. & W. Seligman on Tuesday, contending that it owes investors $80 million in compensation for improper market-timing trades.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether a hedge fund Pirate Capital, violated securities laws by failing to properly disclose it was selling stocks, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.

The former head of Citigroup's worldwide commodities trading pleaded guilty Tuesday to conspiracy in a scheme the government says was aimed at inflating trading profits and increasing his eligibility for bonuses.
In a boardroom coup, the upscale retailer Sharper Image said Tuesday that it had ousted its founder and chief executive, Richard Thalheimer, amid lower sales and share prices.
Intel, the world's largest computer-chip maker, won a court ruling to limit anti-trust claims by its closest rival, Advanced Micro Devices, to those covering sales in the United States.

In a letter from Verizon Wireless to a lawyer for a Hewlett-Packard director, George A. Keyworth II, a central figure in the internal leak investigation at Hewlett, provides a vivid illustration of one method used by the company's investigators: obtaining phone records through subterfuge, a practice called pretexting.
A record $20 billion of leveraged buyouts in Australia is increasing borrowing costs for the nation's biggest companies to a nine-month high, Bloomberg News reported.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is set to open the largest buyout fund of its kind anywhere in the world, according to The Telegraph. The newspaper said that Kohlberg Kravis is close to raising $16.5 billion for its 2006 fund, outstripping the $15.6 billion fund raised by a rival buyout shop, the Blackstone Group, earlier this year

Australian politicians on Tuesday called for the chief executive of Telstra to be dismissed because of a dispute between the government and company. The calls came a day after Solomon Trujillo, the chief executive of Telstra, in which the government is a majority stakeholder, publicly opposed Prime Minister John Howard's choice of a close associate to fill a board seat.

A materials science specialist, NGEN Partners of Santa Barbara, Calif., closed its second fund at more than double its first venture capital effort in 2001, landing $180 million from limited partners to invest primarily in energy and clean technology deals with a core component of proprietary composition technology.

As the market for smart-grid technologies lights up, a start-up company called GridPoint has unveiled a new business model, a new investor and $21 million in new financing to convince utility companies it has the cure for an aging energy infrastructure.
Intel Capital has made the largest investment yet from its $200 million China fund, with a $40 million round of funding for a 15-year-old Chinese software service providern, the Neusoft Group.
Shui On Land, owned by a Hong Kong billionaire, Vincent Lo, raised 6.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($797 million) in its delayed initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.

Announcements about the possible backdating of stock options have collectively erased at least $7.9 billion in market value, according to Bloomberg News. The practice, in which companies grant options to employees at below-market prices, is the subject of investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department.
Mindray Medical International, a medical device maker based in China, opened strongly in its initial trading Tuesday after its shares priced above their estimated range.
Insider trading by hedge funds is a big worry to securities regulators, an official of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Senate panel Tuesday.
Ping An Insurance, China's second-biggest insurer, may raise as much as 32 billion Hong Kong dollars ($4.1 billion) in a stock sale, part of a plan to offer a wider range of financial services.

the Irish state airline Aer Lingus set the price on Wednesday for its initial public offering at 2.20 euros a share, at the lower end of its range, valuing the group at 1.13 billion euros ($1.4 billion).

As London's financial district continues to gain traction as a place to stage an initial public offering or run a hedge fund, New York City's Economic Development Corporation has hired a consulting firm, McKinsey & Company, to find out why. A two-month review, part of a contract of up to $600,000 with the city, will analyze the strengths and weaknesses of the two cities' financial service sectors recommend policies to help New York maintain an edge over London.

Citigroup topped the table for advisory work on European deals in the first nine months of the year, after the Wall Street bank acted for San Paolo IMI, the Italian bank that was taken over by its rival Banca Intesa for $37 billion.

Citigroup held onto its number one rankings as the world's biggest debt capital markets house and the biggest global bookrunner of investment-grade bonds in the year to date, according to figures from Thomson Financial.

Six big Wall Street firms plan an electronic trading service for big "block" stock trades, adding competition for the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq Stock Market, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Executives at controversial drug company Biovail demanded the suspension of a critical Banc of America Securities analyst who soon after was fired by the financial giant, according to The New York Post.

Woolworths, Australia's biggest retailer, bought 10 percent of the Warehouse Group, the biggest publicly traded reailer in New Zealand, threatening efforts by the company's founder to take Warehouse private.

Millennium Pharmaceuticals said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy AnorMed, a Canadian biotechnology company with an experimental treatment for patients with blood cancer, for $515 million, topping an earlier bid from Genzyme.

Barrick Gold said on Tuesday it would extend its $1.3 billion hostile bid for NovaGold Resources for the second time. Barrick's decision to extend the offer to Oct. 12 comes one day after NovaGold said it would waive its shareholder rights plan because it was confident shareholders would reject the offer, previously set to expire this Friday.
Crow Holdings, the real estate investment firm headed by the Trammell Crow family of Dallas, said Tuesday that it would sell $2.2 billion of its properties to G.E. Real Estate.

The industrial conglomerate Danaher confirmed on Tuesday that it was in discussions to join the auction for Vision Systems, an Australian medical technology company already considering bids from two other suitors in the United States.

Vivendi Universal and Deutsche Telekom have been fighting for years for control of Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa, a Polish mobile operator, and analysts say that fight will probably continue, with Deutsche Telekom snubbing Vivendi's latest 2.5 billion euro offer for its stake.

Image Entertainment took the gloves off Tuesday in its takeover defense against Lions Gate Entertainment, essentially calling its much-larger rival a jealous hypocrite whose 'credibility and motives should be questioned.'
General Motors is reportedly demanding a "multibillion" dollar payment from Renault and Nissan as the price to join the French and Japanese companies' alliance, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Shares of Scania, Sweden's second-largest truckmaker, fell the most in 6-1/2 years after Volkswagen, Scania's largest shareholder, said its fellow German company, MAN, should abandon a hostile takeover bid and consider other options.

Edgar Bronfman, the chief executive of Warner Music, is preparing the ground for a fresh bid for EMI by targeting the British group's shareholders and emphasising the benefits of a future tie-up, according to a report from The Times of London.

Despite winning new support from European regulators, the German power company E.On was forced on Tuesday to raise its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa, a deal seen as a crucial test for breaking down barriers to cross-border energy mergers in Europe.

DaimlerChrysler and Kirk Kerkorian resumed their legal battle on Tuesday, this time in an appeal by Mr. Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who contends he was shortchanged in the 1998 "merger of equals" between Chrysler and Daimler-Benz.

For the Houston Texans, an 0-3 start has brought back memories of the humbling experience that was last season, when Houston finished 2-14. Now there are signs that this year could be even worse: The Texans have given up 98 points in their first three games and an average of 483.6 yards a game.
The Sony Reader, a hand-held portable device for reading electronic books, went on sale online yesterday after months of delays and technical tweaks.
Haruki Murakami has won the second Frank O’Connor International Short Story Award, a $44,700 prize billed as the world’s richest for short stories.
“Hunger’s Brides,” by Paul Anderson, has been whittled down to 768 pages from the original 1,360 pages.
John Webster, golf instructor, tests computerized swing simulators.

Given the United States team's crushing defeat at last weekend's Ryder Cup -- its fifth loss in six tournaments and its second consecutive blowout -- we offer this modest proposal: Send some of Wall Street's top leaders out next time. Could they do much worse than Phil Mickelson?
Turbans and other looks made a mysterious appearance at the Prada show.
Kevin Macdonald's queasily enjoyable fiction film creates a portrait of the Ugandan dictator Idi Amin from inside the palace walls.
Here in the heart of the Anderson Valley in Mendocino County, California winemakers are beating the French at their own game with perhaps the most unlikely of grapes.
With a new remote by Harmony, spouses can not only bicker over who controls the TV, but also fight over who controls the temperature and the lighting.
What's up for grabs? Passwords, private phone numbers, transactions.
While high-profile data breaches are common, there is no evidence of a surge in identity theft or financial fraud as a result.
Like many new technologies, Internet phone services, or VoIP, for voice-over Internet protocol, are a work in progress and come with trade-offs.
New online services are giving travelers more places to find road-trip companions, or just pointers for finding local favorites.
Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who invented the World Wide Web, speaks out in favor of equal access to the Internet.
If instant messaging has you thumb-tied, maybe Pinger could get you interested in exchanging brief messages by cellphone or computer.
The Nikon Coolpix S7c is a camera that send its photos over the airwaves while being small enough to slip into a pocket.
IPTV, one of the latest high-technology buzzwords to surface, promises something different to almost everyone right now, but that’s entirely the point.
Statistics about the rise of blogs.
State governments are beginning to play a critical role in shepherding new information technology systems into hospitals and doctors’ offices.
As hard drives have grown larger over the years, the need for even bigger drives to serve as backup machines has kept pace.
Fon, a start-up company based in Spain, hopes to build a hot-spot network around the world.
Some people have been fired for their remarks. Others get the go-ahead.
E-mailing from Bali once involved Velcro, suction cups and total silence.
New devices and services make lots of movies instantly available in your living room.
Vladimir Kramnik artfully sidestepped any complications in Game 4 of the world championship match and then forced the trade of almost all remaining pieces to create a draw against Veselin Topalov.
Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for New York attorney general, said she had discussed bugging her husband but had broken no laws.
Despite serious objections from some Democrats and a few Republicans, the legislation appeared headed to approval.
Transplants of insulin-making cells have not lived up to the promise they showed in an initial trial.
A gunman opened fire inside a high school outside of Denver today and was holding several students hostage, the police said.
A gathering of German goverment and Muslim leaders would like to see reinstated a production of an opera that was canceled for fear of offending Muslims.
Nasser al-Shaer was one of more than 30 Hamas officials detained by Israel over the past three months.
John A. Gotti was accused of racketeering related to his leadership of the Gambino organized crime family.
Patricia C. Dunn said she was in contact with those conducting the inquiry, but she was not its “supervisor.”
Terrell Owens said a combination of pills and supplements left him groggy; police had said it was a suicide attempt.
The Japanese-American was convicted of treason in 1949 for broadcasting propaganda, but was later pardoned.
For the first time since March, sales of new homes rose in August, the Commerce Department said.
Top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.
Carlos Ghosn’s comments came hours after he met with General Motors’ chief executive, Rick Wagoner.
The judge excluded Advanced Micro Devices’ foreign commerce claims from its antitrust suit against Intel for lack of jurisdiction.
In losing their ninth out of the last 12 games, the Mets again struggled to generate productive offense, stranding eight base runners.
By The Associated Press.
Heading into this season’s final week, the Yankees’ batting order and starting rotation is still a work in progress, but the defense is taking shape with the return of Hideki Matsui in left field.
Ryan Zimmerman went 3 for 4 and drove in three runs Tuesday night, leading the Washington Nationals to a victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
By The Associated Press.

Prosecutors have charged five doctors and three regional health officials with criminal negligence over the infection of at least 61 children with H.I.V. and the deaths of 5, local news media and officials said. The country’s health minister was fired last week. The children, between 2 months and 10 years old, were infected in recent months in a hospital in the south of the country, apparently after receiving transfusions of blood contaminated with the virus. About 2,000 more children are to be tested in the next few days.

A 46-year-old basket maker who hanged himself in custody had confessed to murdering some 30 elderly women in France, Germany and Switzerland, the police said. The man, Yvan Keller, was arrested in the eastern city of Mulhouse last week in connection with a robbery. According to a local prosecutor, Régis Delorme, Mr. Keller had admitted to killing dozens of elderly women who lived alone, all within 40 miles of Mulhouse, in the border region straddling France, Switzerland and Germany, starting in 1989. He claimed to have slipped into the women’s homes and smothered them in their beds with a pillow before making off with their money and jewelry, carefully closing doors or windows behind him. The police, seeing no sign of forced entry, had assumed the women died of natural causes.

Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld asked for the support of Europe’s newest country in the war on terrorism and promised to help train Montenegro’s modest army to NATO standards. He met Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic to discuss how the former Yugoslav republic, which became independent from Serbia three months ago, might help America’s military operations, perhaps with peacekeeping or special operations forces. Mr. Djukanovic made no commitment to provide troops to current American operations, according to United States officials, but he told reporters: “We are prepared to participate in the U.S.-led coalition to fight terrorism. What form that will take, we did not discuss in any great detail.” Montenegro has a population of just 650,000. It has just scrapped the draft and plans to reduce its current military force to around 2,500 from 4,000.

Fifty-six Kurdish mayors went on trial in southeastern Diyarbak{inodot}r on charges of helping Kurdish separatists. They are charged by state prosecutors with “knowingly and willingly” helping Kurdish rebels when they urged Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark not to close the Danish-based Kurdish satellite broadcaster ROJ TV. Turkey accuses ROJ of being a mouthpiece of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party. The mayors each face up to 15 years in jail if convicted. The judge adjourned the trial until Nov. 21.

A military court in Chelyabinsk sentenced an army sergeant, Aleksandr V. Sivyakov, to four years in prison for his part in the severe beating of a younger draftee. The draftee, Pvt. Andrei S. Sychev, was physically abused so badly his legs and genitals had to be amputated after the Jan. 1 beating by drunken superiors at the Chelyabinsk Tank Academy in the foothills of the Ural Mountains. Neither side was satisfied with the sentence. The prosecution had requested a six-year prison term, while Mr. Sivyakov’s lawyers had called for their client to be acquitted. Both sides said they would appeal. Two other defendants, also soldiers, were given sentences of one and a half years. Grave injuries and deaths from the military bullying ritual known as dedovshchina are not unusual. The Defense Ministry has recorded 16 deaths this year from the practice, which literally means “rule of the grandfathers.’’.

Poland’s main opposition party, the pro-business Civic Platform, filed a motion to dissolve Parliament and hold early elections. The party wants the motion put to the vote during the next session of the lower house, which opens on Oct. 10. The move comes as the conservative government, which fired a coalition partner last week and lost its parliamentary majority, scrambles to put together a new majority coalition to forestall elections.

The racketeering conspiracy case of John A. Gotti teetered on the edge of another mistrial yesterday after the jury declared itself deadlocked in its sixth day of deliberations and refused a request to stay later than its normal 5 p.m. quitting time.
Excerpts released Tuesday show that intelligence agencies found that the “Iraq conflict has become the ‘cause célèbre’ for jihadists.”
A newly declassified report describes a jihadist movement that, for now, is simply outpacing President Bush’s counterattacks.
The Irish prime minister described payments he received while he was finance minister as loans from friends to help him as he separated from his wife.
The city would set a limit of a half-gram of artificial trans fats per serving of any menu item.
A scene involving the severed head of the Prophet Muhammad prompted a threat to a German opera house.
After throwing Saddam Hussein out of court again on Tuesday, the judge  postponed the deposed dictator’s genocide trial until Oct. 9.

A top aide resigned from Representative Charles Bass’s office after admitting he posted misleading messages to political blogs using a government computer, Mr. Bass said. The aide, Tad Furtado, Mr. Bass’s policy director, posted messages professing support for Mr. Bass’s Democratic opponent, Paul Hodes, but discounting his chances of winning in November. Mr. Furtado’s actions were exposed after two bloggers traced the postings to the House of Representatives’ computer server, and Mr. Bass’s office investigated.

The Republican architects of the Senate immigration bill criticized the border security measures under consideration in Congress as piecemeal and inadequate. Senators John McCain of Arizona, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina said they supported border security, including a measure to add fencing to the border with Mexico. But they said that such measures alone would fail to deal with the illegal residence in this country of about 11 million immigrants as well as labor shortages in particular industries. The senators called for an approach similar to the Senate bill, which would tighten border security, toughen penalties for employers who hire illegal immigrants, put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship and create a guest-worker plan to address labor shortages. They acknowledged that passage of such legislation was unlikely before the elections.

American strategic and scientific interests at both poles will be threatened if replacements are not built soon for the Coast Guard’s two aging large icebreaking ships, said a panel convened by the National Academies.

A teenager convicted of murdering the wife of a prominent defense lawyer was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The teenager, Scott Dyleski, was 16 when he bludgeoned and stabbed his neighbor, Pamela Vitale, 45, in October 2005. He was convicted last month of first-degree murder. He avoided the death penalty because of his age. Ms. Vitale was married to Daniel Horowitz.

A state official admitted that prison guards had bungled the execution of the gang leader Stanley Tookie Williams last December, but denied that it constituted cruel and unusual punishment. The official, Dane Gillette, senior assistant attorney general, spoke at a federal court hearing in San Jose on lethal injection. He said officials had failed to connect a backup intravenous line to Mr. Williams’s left arm. Guards typically attach two lines to condemned inmates to assure the continuous flow of chemicals. “Williams was a lesson well learned that will not happen again,” Mr. Gillette said.

The chiefs of the infamous Cali cocaine cartel pleaded guilty to a federal charge of conspiracy to import cocaine into the United States and were each sentenced to 30 years in prison. As part of a plea deal, the men, Miguel Rodríguez Orejuela, 62, and his brother Gilberto, 67, spared their relatives in Colombia from prosecution on obstruction and money laundering charges. The brothers, responsible for most of the cocaine smuggled into the United States in the 1990’s, agreed to forfeit $2.1 billion in drug trafficking assets.
Both sides have described the midterm campaign environment as the most toxic  in memory.
Real Madrid, which lost by 2-0 two weeks ago to Lyon, rebounded with a 5-1 victory against Dynamo Kiev. Raúl González and Ruud van Nistelrooy each scored two goals, and José Antonio Reyes had one.

Chanda Rubin defeated Germany’s Martina Muller, 6-3, 6-0, yesterday to reach the second round of the Fortis Championships in Luxembourg. Rubin, ranked 342nd in the world, last won at Cincinnati in the summer of 2005, but she needed only 53 minutes to beat the 37th-ranked Muller.
Tom Watson, who captained the Americans to a victory in the 1993 Ryder Cup in England, said the United States should revise the points system it uses to pick players for the competition.

Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Antero Niittymaki will be out indefinitely with a left-hip injury, General Manager Bob Clarke said. Niittymaki, 26, was injured in practice yesterday. If surgery is needed, Niittymaki would be out six to eight weeks.

The Dallas Mavericks signed the All-Star forward Dirk Nowitzki to a contract extension. Nowitzki, 28, averaged a career-high 26.6 points as the Mavericks advanced to the N.B.A. finals for the first time. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
soccer.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26 — The federal government sued the village of Suffern for religious discrimination on Tuesday, charging that it denied a private group the right to run a home offering lodging and meals to Orthodox Jews visiting patients at a local hospital on the Sabbath and holy days.
The judge said he gave Andrew Fastow a lighter sentence in part because he has been "persecuted" since Enron’s collapse.
The investigation is widely seen as an effort by President Hu Jintao to consolidate his own power, rather than a campaign against corruption.
Congress all but gave up hope on a final bill to authorize the administration’s eavesdropping program.
AOL and a group of entertainment entrepreneurs have dissolved their venture to produce and distribute live concerts on the Internet and elsewhere.
George A. Keyworth II and his family were victims of repeated attempts to use pretexting to gain their cellphone records.

Basketball leaders, including N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern and the N.C.A.A.’s president, Myles Brand, met to discuss ways to improve youth basketball beyond the sport’s diminishing quality of play.

Debra Rigano, an accounts clerk whose job preparing checks made it possible for several Roslyn school officials to steal more than $11 million — and who took $852,000 of that sum for herself — was sentenced yesterday in Nassau County Criminal Court to two to six years in prison. Mrs. Rigano, 48, will serve her sentence at the same state prison, in Bedford Hills, where an aunt, Pamela Gluckin, 60, the former district business manager, is serving three to nine years. Mrs. Rigano was hired for the job in the mid-1990’s by her aunt, who pleaded guilty to embezzling more than $4 million in district funds.

An attempt by the Bergen County borough of Bogota to designate English as its official language ended on Monday when the State Supreme Court refused to hear the borough’s case. County officials had denied the borough’s request to place the language question on the ballot because the borough lacked the authority to designate an official language. The borough lost a legal challenge and appealed to the Supreme Court.

The budget surplus for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is likely to be even larger this year than previously predicted because of continuing strong tax revenues tied to real estate sales, officials said yesterday. The office of State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said the surplus would probably be $140 million greater than the authority’s earlier estimate of $711 million. The authority acknowledged this week that revenues from taxes related to real estate were currently $46 million ahead of projections but declined to give a new estimate for the year-end surplus. Peter S. Kalikow, the authority’s chairman, said last week that subway and bus service cuts and a 5 percent fare and toll increase that had been planned to help balance the 2007 budget would not be necessary.

Several dozen people were sickened yesterday afternoon after a worker at a trucking company near the New Jersey Turnpike broke an above-ground pipe and released sulfur dioxide into the air, officials said. The leak took place around 3 p.m. near the Ikea store alongside the turnpike and sent a cloud of gas into the area, said the fire director, Onofrio Vitullo. Nearly 50 people were sickened and treated near the scene, Mr. Vitullo said. Several people were taken to local hospitals with respiratory injuries. Mr. Vitullo said a worker “snapped the neck off of a pipe” while working on it, though he could not provide further details. As a result of the leak, officials shut down Interchange 13A on the turnpike and several roads in the area, creating severe traffic delays during the evening rush.

An Astoria man has been charged with impersonating a police officer after he stopped and questioned a pedestrian in July, prosecutors said. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said the events were recorded and later appeared on the Web site YouTube. The suspect, Gazi Abura, 21, was charged with second-degree criminal impersonation, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said a 15-year-old boy was walking home one night in July when three men, including Mr. Abura, emerged from a car, identified themselves as the police and told the teenager to stop and show his identification. The men then questioned the youth about a robbery they said had occurred in the area, Mr. Brown said. He said the 15-year-old later learned that the incident had been filmed and was appearing on the Internet. The authorities said the police were searching for the two other men.

Peter Braunstein, the writer accused of pretending to be a firefighter and sexually abusing a woman in Chelsea last Oct. 31, has been indicted on a robbery charge in Ohio, a Manhattan prosecutor said yesterday. The prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Maxine Rosenthal, reported the indictment during a hearing for the New York case in State Supreme Court, where Mr. Braunstein has pleaded not guilty to arson, kidnapping, burglary, robbery, sexual abuse and assault charges. In the Ohio case, the prosecutor said, Mr. Braunstein, 42, is accused of tying up a man, pointing a gun at his face and demanding his A.T.M. card and number.
An organization of 56 Islamic nations pressed Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday to apologize for his comments linking Muslims and violence.
The revived phone company Qwest has built up so much cash that it can think, cautiously, of buying another industry player.
The Texas Supreme Court is set to decide a case that will help define the evolving line between church and state.
Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings vowed to implement some of the measures recommended by a federal panel, the Commission on the Future of Higher Education.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 26 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the mayors of Philadelphia, Trenton and cities across Pennsylvania on Tuesday to lobby state lawmakers to approve a series of gun-control measures.
Prime Minister Tony Blair also declined to offer a formal endorsement of his presumptive heir, Gordon Brown.
The candidates for New York governor offered their views on abortion, ethics and school financing.
The techniques popularized on TV are being used to diagnose elder abuse and neglect.
The notion that some elective offices belong to minorities is being put to a sharp test in Memphis, as a veteran politician’s Congressional candidacy is being challenged because he is white.

Advanced Micro Devices and Intel are vying to be the first to create a new generation of chips with four processing cores.
The cost of employee health coverage rose 7.7 percent this year, more than double the overall inflation rate and well ahead of the increase in the incomes of workers.
As university officials prepared for Thursday’s “Day of Discourse” to address ways to prevent plagiarism, new accusations were made in the student newspaper against its business school.

The developer of a proposed 42-story condominium tower in the theater district has agreed to set aside part of one floor as office space for nonprofit theater companies to comply with an eight-year-old zoning rule.

The Transportation Security Administration should retain the near total ban on liquids and let the airlines supply passengers with ample beverages.
President Bush wants voters to focus on how dangerous the world is, and not on his utter lack of ideas for what to do about it.
Because of a rift with the Florida Marlins’ owner, Jeffrey Loria, Joe Girardi’s tenure as the manager is expected to end after only one year.
Kurt Warner will remain the starting quarterback for the Arizona Cardinals, Coach Dennis Green said on Tuesday.
Former team coach Alkis Panagoulias says he firmly believes that the United States team needs an American coach, or at least someone who currently works in Major League Soccer.
Byron Nelson was the winner of a record 11 consecutive professional golf tournaments in 1945 and one of golf’s most renowned figures.
Bombs in Helmand and Kabul killed 20 people Tuesday, and more than 150 civilians have been killed by suicide bombings this year.
Much of the pollution that made Steubenville, Ohio, a magnet for the field of environmental epidemiology has disappeared along with the steel industry.
Nothing is more important to Japan’s prosperity and security than normal relations with its giant neighbor, China.
José Orlando Padrón, who believes that cigar smoke brings him luck, has puffed his way through some challenging situations over the years.
The Bloomberg administration is giving up on its plan to buy the development rights over the West Side railyards from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for $500 million.

A picture caption on Saturday about an anti-Hamas rally in Gaza by supporters of the rival Palestinian group Fatah misstated the purpose of the rally. It was to protest what participants called an atmosphere of fear created by Hamas leaders, not over the stance of Hamas on recognizing Israel.
In two months, Boof Bonser has gone from being the doughy, ineffective right-hander with the catchy first name and to Minnesota’s possible Game 2 starter in the playoffs.
Israel had delayed leaving until now, saying that the United Nations forces were not up to strength.
Leaders of many of the biggest global car companies will be at this year’s Paris Motor Show at a seminal moment for the automobile industry.
The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian contends he was shortchanged in the 1998 “merger of equals” between Chrysler and Daimler-Benz.
Mets Manager Willie Randolph said he might wait until as late as Sunday or Monday before making his decision public.
Philadelphia has gone longer without a major pro title than any other city with teams in the four major professional sports. But as the baseball season winds down, the Phillies have fans optimistic.
Randy Johnson has a long memory of good games and bad. In two years as a Yankee, there has been plenty of each.
Another acquaintance of Senator George Allen said Tuesday that she heard him use an racial slur, contradicting a statement he made on Monday.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York suggested that her husband would have reacted differently as president if he had heard the same warnings about Osama bin Laden’s plans that President Bush had access to before 9/11.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Reuters) — The New York Stock Exchange’s regulatory unit said Tuesday that it expected to refer 140 potential insider trading cases to the Securities and Exchange Commission this year, up 26 percent from 2005.
Russia will ship fuel to a nuclear power plant it is building in Iran by March under an agreement signed by the two countries on Tuesday.

Accompanying a minor across a state line to obtain an abortion and avoid parental notification in the girl’s home state would become a federal crime under a bill the House passed.
Even after the addition of a new $10 million system, many Cubans said they still see only snowy interference where the anti-Castro television broadcasts should be.
Among nine cases the court selected Wednesday for the coming term is a dispute over “paycheck protection” laws.

In all, 27,500 union workers on Delphi’s payroll have agreed to leave their jobs as the world’s largest auto parts maker prepares to close most of its factories.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP) — Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, sued the mutual fund manager J. & W. Seligman & Company on Tuesday, contending that it owes investors $80 million in compensation for improper market-timing trades.

In her most successful fund-raising event of the general election campaign, Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for attorney general, took in about $750,000 yesterday at a breakfast that included many corporate executives.
Despite winning new support from European regulators, the German power company E.On was forced on Tuesday to raise its offer for the Spanish utility Endesa.
A panel put off a final report on the legality of an American program to monitor millions of international banking transactions but said it had concerns about the arrangement.
In the off-season, the Giants rebuilt the secondary and added linebacker LaVar Arrington.  But so far, nothing is better than it was a year ago.
A plan to split Italy’s largest phone company into separate mobile and fixed-line units has led to a political slugfest.
Bernard J. Ebbers began serving a 25-year sentence on Tuesday for his role in the $11 billion accounting fraud that toppled his company.

The Visteon Corporation said it would not meet its financial targets for the rest of the year because of production cuts by automakers.
The Lennar Corporation said profit fell 39 percent in its fiscal third quarter, partly as a result of incentives to lure buyers as the housing market slows down.

Alfred Mann was perhaps best known for his translations of and commentary on the works of the Austrian composer and musical theorist J. J. Fux.
Two aging tunnels leading to and from Logan International Airport are in need of major ceiling repairs, Gov. Mitt Romney said Tuesday.

For many owners of New York City restaurants, yesterday’s proposal for a virtual ban on the use of artificial trans fats in restaurants of all sizes was unsettling and alarming.

COHEN--Jean Bernstein, passed away peacefully at age 91 on September 23rd. Loving mother of Marilyn Cohen Skydell and Ruth Cohen Hindell, M.D. Beloved grandmother and greatgrandmother. Friend to many.
ZWILLINGER--Harold. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harold Zwillinger, associated with The Times from November 1, 1956 until retiring in January 6 , 1997.

The four fruit vinegars made by À L'Olivier in France come close to being sauces. They are not mere infusions, but have fresh fruit purée, sugar and pectin, giving them mouth-filling texture and making them extremely versatile. Each offers a different flavor profile: raspberry is the fruitiest, fig is earthy, passion fruit has bright tart-sweetness and tomato is the richest.

There is no urgency for Manager Willie Randolph to announce his Game 1 starter for the first round of the postseason. Randolph has Wednesday, when he will evaluate Pedro Martínez's final regular-season start, and Thursday, when he and Martínez will have their day-after conversation. ''It depends on how he feels when we talk to each other,'' Randolph said before Tuesday's game against the Braves. ''And it's a number of different things. How he feels physically. How he is mentally. What day we play. How we want to set it up. All that kind of stuff.''

A picture with a brief art review in Weekend on Friday about works by Mark Grotjahn at the Whitney Museum of American Art was published in error. The drawing ''MG 638,'' a digital copy of which was provided by the museum's press office, is not in the exhibition.

BURKES--Albert Bernard. ''And when he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine, That all the world will be in love with night, And pay no worship to the garish sun.'' Love, now and always, your little girl, Susie

LIKE all quick breads, so named because they contain no yeast and need neither rising time nor kneading, cornbread can be made in the time it takes to assemble dinner. But it is easier than most quick breads, and more substantial. The batter is about as complicated as pancake batter, and can be used as such. It contains ingredients you have, assuming you have cornmeal. You should use good cornmeal, which means stone-ground and not too fine. Those two stipulations, which will give you high-quality cornmeal with some texture and cornbread with a little crunch, probably mean you'll buy organic cornmeal, which of course is fine.

Dogmatic Gourmet Sausage System, a stand in the Bleecker Playground at Abingdon Square in the West Village, has a different way with hot dogs. Andrew Deitchman and Heather Baltz, the owners, have equipped their stand with a gadget, fairly common in Europe, called a spike toaster for toasting the interior of a length of baguette. Beef and turkey sausages cured by Violet Hill Farm in Livingston Manor in the Catskills are sizzled on a grill, then slid into the crispy opening in the bread, a Tom Cat baguette, no less.

To the Editor: Re ''Unfair Advancement,'' by Rodney LaBrecque (Op-Ed, Sept. 21): I agree that colleges focus too much on high school students taking Advanced Placement courses. Students feel pressured by the fact that colleges seem to care more about the number of A.P. courses they take, which forces students to fill their schedules with classes that don't appeal to them.
McGUIRE--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John McGuire, associated with The Times from February 8 , 1940 until retiring in January 1, 1979.

8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- What do you do when you work in a place where image is everything, and the image you project is not all that? In this new comedy series, America Ferrera (above) plays a displeasingly plump plain Jane from Queens trying to fit into an ultra-svelte, high-fashion world. Just the fact that she got hired is a slap in the face: she was the only executive assistant the magazine's publisher figured his son, the newly anointed editor in chief, wouldn't want to sleep with. Turns out he likes her. The cast beauties include Eric Mabius, Becki Newton, Michael Urie and Vanessa Williams. 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL -- Burt Reynolds plays the owner of the local strip joint, who agrees to loan Earl money if he can convince the club's most popular dancer to get back to work. 8 P.M. (Sundance) SIGNÉ CHANEL -- Tensions rise at the House of Chanel in the final days before the show, and the nerves of Madame Jacqueline, the head seamstress, begin to fray. 8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Zod morphs into Lex's body with designs on destroying the planet, while Clark is encased in the phantom zone and sent hurtling into space. 8 P.M. (Bravo) CIRQUE SU SOLEIL: CORTEO -- In this latest from the playful crew from Quebec, a festive parade is imagined by a clown. 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) DICK CAVETT -- In this 1972 interview, Alfred Hitchcock talks with Mr. Cavett about his filmmaking, his life and his career, and spills the beans on some of his special effects. 9 P.M. (Travel) MOMS ON THE ROAD: AFRICA -- Eight American mothers (right) go soulsearching during a grueling six-week adventure across southern Africa in this new reality series -- and return home with a better understanding of what matters most. 9 P.M. (Fox) CELEBRITY DUETS -- Lucy Lawless, Alfonso Ribeiro and Hal Sparks are all that's left in this competition series that pairs would-be celebrity singers with the real deal. Tonight, in Part 1 of the season finale, the three remaining couples perform, after which the audience will choose the winning vocalist, who will be awarded $100,000 for the charity of his or her choice tomorrow night. 10 P.M. (NBC) ER -- Abby's domineering mother (Sally Field, left, in a reprise of her Emmy-winning guest role) shows up at County General Hospital to comfort her daughter and Dr. Kovac as their son struggles to survive. John Stamos turns his guest spot as Tony Gates, a paramedic, into a fulltime role. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

With a Song in Her Heart Love, it seems, has found a way. Kate Moss and Pete Doherty, below, are together again. In the latest chapter of their on-again, off-again relationship, Ms. Moss, who normally carries the tag supermodel, accompanied Mr. Doherty, who often carries the tag drug-addicted, to Ireland, where his band, Babyshambles, was touring. What's more, witnesses said Ms. Moss took to the stage and sang beside Mr. Doherty before a crowd of 680 at a nightclub in Carlow, south of Dublin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Doherty checked himself out of a drug rehabilitation clinic in London last week. Short Story Prize Awarded Haruki Murakami of Japan has won the second Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award, a $44,700 prize billed as the world's richest for short stories, The Guardian of London reported. Mr. Murakami, below, is to share his prize for ''Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman: Twenty-Four Stories'' (Knopf) with his translators, Philip Gabriel and Jay Rubin. When the announcement of the winner was made in Cork, Ireland, the hometown of O'Connor (1903-1966), the jury hailed Mr. Murakami as ''a master of prose fiction,'' saying he ''writes with great integrity, unafraid of dealing with tough and difficult situations between people who constantly misunderstand each other.'' Another Fateful Traffic Stop Just as man occasionally bites dog, so does art sometimes ape life. Take ''In Vino Veritas,'' an episode of NBC's ''Law & Order'' that went before the cameras this week. In it, Chevy Chase guest-stars as a television celebrity who is pulled over by the police for drunk driving while wearing bloody clothes and whose religious prejudice emerges after his arrest. The episode, which recalls in part the arrest of Mel Gibson for drunk driving in July, when he made anti-Semitic comments, is to be broadcast on Nov. 3 from 10 to 11 p.m.

An article on Monday about the obstacles the Army's Third Infantry Division faces in preparing for combat misidentified the brigade commanded by Col. Tom James. It is the division's Fourth Brigade, not its Second Brigade.

The Colombian songwriter Shakira leads the nominees for the seventh annual Latin Grammy Awards, which will be presented Nov. 2 at 8 p.m. at Madison Square Garden in a show to be broadcast live on the Univision network. The awards, in 47 categories, cover a spectrum of Latin music spanning reggaetón, Brazilian rock, Mexican brass bands and Colombian vallenato. Among her five nominations, Shakira, right, is nominated for both album of the year and record of the year, as is the Mexican songwriter Julieta Venegas. Other performers with multiple nominations include the Argentine rocker Gustavo Cerati, the Guatemalan songwriter Ricardo Arjona, the Puerto Rican reggaetón group Calle 13, the Puerto Rican pop singer Chayanne, the Mexican songwriter Joan Sebastian and the Colombian songwriter Fonseca. The awards ceremony, which moved from CBS to the Spanish-language Univision network in 2005, will be held in New York City for the first time. A full list of nominees is at latingrammy.com. JON PARELES
