Top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday. GAZETA SOLDIER ABUSE TRIAL ENDS -- A Chelyabinsk military court on Tuesday sentenced the main defendant in the case of a soldier maimed during a hazing incident to four years in prison. Junior Sergeant Aleksandr Sivyakov was also stripped of his rank and will not be able to hold a command position in the Russian military for three years. Both sides in the case plan to file appeals. UKRAINE, RUSSIA CLASH OVER FAMINE -- A request by Ukraines foreign minister that the United Nations recognize the famine of 1932-1933 as genocide against the Ukrainian people has put further strain on the countrys relations with Russia. Moscow labeled the appeal an anti-Russian demarche. Russia voted against a similar initiative in 2003 and is expected to do so again if Ukraines current request comes to a vote before the U.N. General Assembly. NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA CONSTRUCTION OF BUSHEHR PLANT BACK ON TRACK -- Russian and Iranian officials signed an agreement on Tuesday to complete the Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran November 2007. Russias participation in the project had been called into question by Irans vice president, who criticized Russian contractors for delays. In addition to work on Bushehr, Russias major nuclear plant construction company is vying with companies from the United States and France for an $8 billion contract to develop Chinas nuclear energy infrastructure. LEADERS LECTURE YOUTH ON AUTHORITY -- The presidential administration and the United Russia Party held the first session of the School of Young Leaders on Tuesday, as part of a project to interest young people in political and business leadership. United Russias leaders, businessmen and leaders of professional unions, addressed about 400 school-aged students in seminars throughout the day. Representatives from opposition political parties were not invited. KOMMERSANT RUSSIAN PEACEKEEPERS MUST GO -- The ministers of foreign affairs of Georgia, Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Moldova have agreed to create their own police force to replace Russian peacekeepers in post-Soviet conflict zones. At the same time, the pro-West quartet is lobbying the United Nations to adopt anti-Russian resolutions on conflicts in the region. According to the newspaper, these initiatives come in response to fears that Russia will soon recognize separatist republics in their territories, particularly in Georgia and Moldova. NO TO REFERENDUM ON PUTINS THIRD TERM -- Russian citizens do not have the right to hold a referendum on a third presidential term for Vladimir Putin, the Central Elections Commission said on Tuesday. A civic organization in North Ossetia proposed such a referendum in September. By law, the State Duma, Federation Council and regional parliaments would have to approve a constitutional amendment changing the limit, which is now two terms of four years each. VEDOMOSTI RUSSIA SCORES LOW FOR COMPETITIVENESS -- Because of its lack of intellectual property protections and shoddy courts, Russia placed 62nd out of 115 countries in a World Economic Forum evaluation of countries competitiveness. The forum rated Russia the worst for the quality of its institutions. Russia scored well for its low level of state debt and its effective labor market. Russian and foreign investors, along with several economic experts, have expressed concern over what they see as systemic failures and bad government policies hurting Russias economic competitiveness. NOVYE IZVESTIA MOSCOWS TRASH PROBLEM -- According to Greenpeace, the level of garbage in Moscow has recently risen by between 5 and 9 percent, leading to the creation of unsanctioned garbage dumps, 158 of which were recorded in 2005. In a hearing last week on the citys garbage problem, Moscow Duma deputies blamed, above all, private garbage truck drivers who violate waste regulations. According to environmentalists, however, the main problem is a lack of modern technology for disposing of and recycling waste. ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA RUSSIAN PEACEKEEPERS READY FOR LEBANON -- The upper house of Russias parliament sanctioned on Tuesday the dispatch of Russian military engineers to Lebanon for peacekeeping missions. Russia rarely sends its troops abroad: the country sent an airborne unit a few years ago to Sierra Leone as part of a United Nations peacekeeping mission. The first battalion of Russian troops headed for the Middle East is expected to leave next Tuesday.

To the Editor: Re ''Dumb as We Wanna Be,'' by Thomas L. Friedman (column, Sept. 20): I'm sure that Dr. José Goldemberg, a Brazilian official and pioneer of Brazil's ethanol industry, views America's 54-cents-a-gallon credit offset on Brazilian ethanol as ''really stupid'': every Brazilian ethanol producer would love access to American taxpayer dollars.

The Nets, at least three years from leaving the Meadowlands for Brooklyn, are taking over advertising turf in Times Square. A 70-by-45-foot billboard featuring Vince Carter, Jason Kidd and Richard Jefferson will hang from the side of a movie multiplex and face Eighth Avenue, just off West 42nd Street, by Friday. A smaller one, featuring only Kidd, will be mounted next week above a Modell's Sporting Goods store around the corner on West 42nd Street.

An obituary on Friday about Henri Jayer, a leading Burgundian winemaker, misspelled part of the name of his best-known wine. It is Cros Parantoux, not Clos Parantoux.

QUINN--Patrick. It is with deep sorrow that the American Guild of Musical Artists, AFL-CIO mourns the sudden and untimely death of Patrick Quinn. On behalf of AGMA's officers, members and staff our prayers and sympathy go out to Patrick's partner, his family and loved ones and to all the members and staff of Actors' Equity Association. Patrick was a friend and a defender of the unionized men and women who create America's cultural heritage. Linda Mays, President Alan S. Gordon, Executive Director

An unofficial, longstanding city policy that allows people to unleash their dogs in most parks between 9 p.m. and 9 a.m. would be formalized under a proposal considered yesterday by the Board of Health. The dog regulations, which fall under the jurisdiction of health officials, would be turned over to the Department of Parks and Recreation, which for 20 years has relaxed the city's leash law at night and in the morning. But a civic group in Queens has filed suit against the city, claiming that unleashed dogs are a threat to people and other animals, and that parks officials must abide by the letter of the city's current regulations, which require dogs to be leashed at all times. The Board of Health said it would consider public comment on the proposal and vote on it in December. THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)

AMERICAN'S appreciation for chilies has been growing steadily, but for many people it's still one-dimensional. It's all about the heat. Popping a fiery jalapeño into your mouth might earn you points for bravado. But that jolt, produced by the compound capsaicin, can obscure what lies beneath, and what can be brought out in cooking chilies: a palette of flavors and perfumes.

Golf is not a favorite pastime here. Bulgaria, one of the poorest of the former Soviet bloc countries in Europe, never developed a tradition of playing and has just three golf courses. But as the country has become one of the Continent's hottest second-home markets, all that is about to change.

To the Editor: In ''Closing of a Nation'' (column, Sept. 24), David Brooks makes a cogent argument for the connection between insecurity and xenophobia in Iraq, with its many disastrous consequences. The lesson for our own country is, unfortunately, likely to be lost on supporters of the Bush administration, which encourages us to be perpetually frightened of a faceless and incomprehensible enemy.

The Republican architects of the Senate immigration bill criticized the border security measures under consideration in Congress as piecemeal and inadequate. Senators John McCain of Arizona, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina said they supported border security, including a measure to add fencing to the border with Mexico. But they said that such measures alone would fail to deal with the illegal residence in this country of about 11 million immigrants as well as labor shortages in particular industries. The senators called for an approach similar to the Senate bill, which would tighten border security, toughen penalties for employers who hire illegal immigrants, put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship and create a guest-worker plan to address labor shortages. They acknowledged that passage of such legislation was unlikely before the elections. RACHEL L. SWARNS (NYT)

In a neck-and-neck finish for No. 1 on Monday night, CBS placed first in total viewers, while NBC won the prized demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, Monday's most-watched show, ''CSI: Miami,'' drew 17.4 million viewers, extending its lead over ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' the new Aaron Sorkin drama on NBC, which declined moderately from its premiere, posting 11.2 million viewers. Meanwhile, NBC won the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots with its dependable game show, ''Deal or No Deal'' (13 million) and the new supernatural series ''Heroes,'' which drew 14.3 million viewers in its debut at 9. Among adults 18 to 49, ''Heroes'' placed just shy of Sunday's ''Brothers and Sisters'' premiere on ABC, which garnered the highest rating so far for any new fall series. On Fox, ''Prison Break'' (8.3 million) finished second among adults 18 to 49 for the 8 p.m. hour, but ''Vanished'' (6.5 million) continued to lag behind in fourth place at 9. Notably, CBS's much-anticipated new series at 8, ''The Class'' (8.5 million), lost nearly two million viewers from its premiere a week before. BENJAMIN TOFF

The City University of New York announced yesterday that it plans to open a graduate school of public health. The university has added several schools and programs in recent years, including an honors college and a graduate journalism school.

FERRIERA--Arthur. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Arthur Ferriera, associated with The Times from May 4 , 1958 until retiring in August 1, 1991.

To the Editor: Re ''More Small Women's Colleges Opening Doors to Men'' (news article, Sept. 21): A National Academies panel recently reported that gender bias keeps women in math, science and engineering departments at research universities from ascending to leadership positions. Female undergraduates at coed institutions face similar hurdles.

The war of words between the Bush administration and the Clintons intensified on Tuesday as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton suggested that her husband would have reacted differently as president if he had heard the same warnings about Osama bin Laden's plans that President Bush had access to before 9/11. In unusually blunt terms, Senator Clinton questioned the current administration's response to an intelligence briefing President Bush received about a month before the 9/11 attacks. It mentioned that Al Qaeda was intent on striking the United States using hijacked planes.

Not long after Labor Day, Grace Corradino, a real estate broker and owner of Fire Island Living, a real estate agency and rental management firm, had already drafted her fall housekeeping marching orders for her clients on the western end of Fire Island. Among her suggestions: replace torn screen doors, power wash the outdoor shower, pump out the septic system if it needs it and get rid of the clutter.

A former police sergeant was convicted yesterday of killing the mother of their two children and injuring a man in a shooting in January 2001. The former sergeant, Martin Peters, was found guilty of second-degree murder for fatally shooting the woman, Juliette Alexander, 29, and first-degree assault for injuring the man, Nigel Callender, at Ms. Alexander's apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant. At the time, Mr. Peters, 43, was questioned, suspended and disarmed, but the police did not identify him as a suspect. The police have said the three knew one another from Trinidad, their native country. Mr. Callender, 38, at first told investigators that his attacker was a stranger, the police have said. But after he was arrested on immigration charges in April 2005, he identified Mr. Peters as the gunman. Last Friday, Mr. Peters took the witness stand in State Supreme Court, testifying that Ms. Alexander had threatened to sue him for child support. ''I offered to pay her $500 a week, and I told her I'd buy clothes for the kids,'' Mr. Peters testified. ''She said, 'No, I'll take you to court instead and get double that; you won't be able to buy clothes for yourself.' '' He said that on the day of the killing, Jan. 16, 2001, he had been running errands. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

KOPPEL--Yehuda. September 25, 2006 in New York. Mr. Koppel, 89, was born in Kalish, Poland to Chaim and Sara Koppel. He left Poland at the age of 16 and resettled in Palestine. Mr. Koppel joined the British Army and was a member of the Jewish Brigade. He fought in WW II in Europe and retired from the British Army with the rank of Major. Mr. Koppel played an important role in the founding of the State of Israel as a leader in the Haganah. In the 1950's, he moved to New York where he opened the first American office of El Al, Israel's national airline, and where he lived until his death. Mr. Koppel was an avid reader of history and the classics, fluent in multiple languages, and a life master tournament bridge player. His love of family gave great meaning and joy to his life. He is survived by his wife, Zipora Goldman Koppel; sons Dan Koppel and Gil Koppel, daughter Abigail Koppel Wexner and son-in-law Leslie H. Wexner; & grandchildren Lee Koppel & Harry, Hannah, David, and Sarah Wexner. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to ''Friends of the Israel Defense Forces,'' 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 2011, New York, New York 10118. A private funeral service will be held in Israel. $(6$)KOPPEL -- Yehuda. The Trustees, President, and The Ohio State University family note with sorrow the death of Yehuda Koppel of New York City, father of Abigail Wexner and father-in-law of Trustee Leslie H. Wexner, and we offer our sincere condolences to the entire Koppel family

LYONS--Dr. Albert S. Friends at 88 mourn the passing of our neighbor, a kind, witty, and gentle man; a caring and conscientious physician; a distinguished writer; a host of exceptional charm; and a cherished friend. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife and family.

SHEFFER--Ralph, 93 of Westport, CT, died at his home on September 26,2006. He was the beloved husband of the late Betty Rabinowitz Sheffer and loving father of Ann Sheffer and Bill Scheffler, Douglas and Barbi Sheffer, and Jonathan Sheffer and Christopher Barley M.D. He was a devoted grandfather to Emily and Shachar Shem-Tov, Brian and Karen Reich, Betty Stolpen, Aaron Eduard Stolpen and Brooke Sheffer. Shiva will be held at the home of his daughters, 19 Stony Point Road, Westport, CT on Wednesday, September 27 from 7-9PM. Service will be private. $(6$)SHEFFER--Ralph. We mark with sorrow the passing of our beloved uncle and brother-in-law. We will miss his warmth, kindness and sense of humor. We will miss him terribly. With our love and respect. Susan Malloy, Jennifer Malloy Combs, Timon Malloy and the entire Malloy Family
''Human life is much more important than shelf life.'' LYNNE D. RICHARDSON, a member of New York City Board of Health, which plans to place sharp limits on trans fats in restaurant food. [B4]

A husband and wife in Borough Park were the victims of a home invasion and robbery on Monday night in which two masked men stole $400,000 in cash and jewelry, the police said yesterday. Officers responded at 9:45 p.m. after the suspects left the 54th Street home, the police said. The victims, a 58-year-old man and a 57-year-old woman, were not injured, the police said. The police said the couple told them that the thieves, wearing ski masks and black jumpsuits, brandished box cutters and tied their hands with duct tape before removing $200,000 in cash and $200,000 worth of jewelry from a safe. The men may have entered through a first-floor window, the police said, and they fled in a white Chevrolet Suburban that may have been driven by an accomplice. AL BAKER (NYT)

A picture caption on Saturday about New York City workers in the Reserves who are being asked to return pay they received from the city while on military duty gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of a police sergeant who was waiting at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn for fellow officers to arrive for a meeting. He is Joseph Mastrota, not Mastrola.
Broadway Panhandler, the cookware store that opened more than 30 years ago on Broadway in SoHo, then moved to Broome Street, has moved again, this time to Greenwich Village.

ALDERMAN--Joseph. Age 82 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. on September 23, 2006. Survived by his loving wife of 57 years Cylvia (Freedland) and four children, Mark (Sue Ellen), John (Nancy), Laurie and Ellen (Bill Harwood). Devoted grandfather to eight grandchildren. Joseph was born in Syracuse, New York, received his LL.B. degree from Columbia University and an LL.M. degree from the George Washington University. During WWII, he served as a lieutenant with the Air Force in the Pacific. He began his legal career at the Department of Justice in Washington D.C. and later became V.P. and Senior Counsel at RCA. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends who will always remember to ''accentuate the positive.'' Donations may be made for ALS research at the Jackson Laboratory, 610 Main Street, Bar Harbor, ME 04609.

To the Editor: The lack of a dynamic and competitive health care market allows Oxford Health Plans and United Health Group to flex their market power and dictate unfair business practices that are bad for patients and doctors (''Doctors' Group Sues Two Insurers, Charging Unfair Coercion,'' news article, Sept. 21). Patients do not appear to be benefiting from the remarkable reduction in the number of competing health plans. While mergers have eroded competition among health insurers, those remaining are posting historically high profits. Meanwhile, the premiums they charge rise without an expansion of patient benefits.

The Falcons-Saints game Monday night on ESPN, the first event at the Louisiana Superdome since before Hurricane Katrina struck last year, generated an average viewership of 14.9 million. For the third consecutive week, ''Monday Night Football'' set a viewership record at ESPN.

A military court in Chelyabinsk sentenced an army sergeant, Aleksandr V. Sivyakov, to four years in prison for his part in the severe beating of a younger draftee. The draftee, Pvt. Andrei S. Sychev, was physically abused so badly his legs and genitals had to be amputated after the Jan. 1 beating by drunken superiors at the Chelyabinsk Tank Academy in the foothills of the Ural Mountains. Neither side was satisfied with the sentence. The prosecution had requested a six-year prison term, while Mr. Sivyakov's lawyers had called for their client to be acquitted. Both sides said they would appeal. Two other defendants, also soldiers, were given sentences of one and a half years. Grave injuries and deaths from the military bullying ritual known as dedovshchina are not unusual. The Defense Ministry has recorded 16 deaths this year from the practice, which literally means ''rule of the grandfathers.'' MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ (NYT)

BALANCIA--Charles. The President, the Board of Trustees, and the entire staff at Montefiore Medical Center are profoundly saddened by the death of Charles Balancia, senior vice president of engineering. ''Charlie'' worked at Montefiore for 48 years and had a hand in raising every building on our campus and developing the engineering systems for the entire medical center. Blessed with mechanical gifts, a teacher who taught by example, Charlie was also a deeply caring human being who mentored and inspired all who worked with him. He was passionate about doing good for Montefiore's patients, neighbors, and colleagues, and full of ideas for helping others. Awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award by the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center in 2006, Charlie served in many ways to better the world around him, not only as an engineer and administrator at Montefiore, but also as councilman and then mayor of his hometown in Harrison, N.Y., as a member of the board of directors of SUNY Maritime College, and as a volunteer and civic activist. We will miss him deeply. Our heartfelt condolences and warmest sympathies are extended to his wife, Rosemarie; his children, Angelo, Teresa, Charles, and Guy; and his entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD. President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

Five female officers in the Fire Department sued the city yesterday in State Supreme Court, claiming that the department discriminates against women by blocking them from the highest ranks, their lawyer said. The women, two fire captains, an Emergency Medical Service captain and two E.M.S. lieutenants, claim that men are promoted to high ranks with less favorable recommendations and less experience than female candidates, said their lawyer, Yetta G. Kurland. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said 7 of 15 staff chiefs in the department are women. ''So just on the face of it, it didn't look to me like there was any basis for a discrimination suit, but I'll certainly take a look at it,'' he said. The mayor said the department had ''worked very actively to promote women and minorities and make sure that everybody has an opportunity.''

BOSNIAK--Samuel of Philadelphia, PA passed away peacefully on Sunday September 24th at age 90. He was the husband of the late Thelma Bosniak. Loving father of Dr. Stephen Bosniak of NYC, Mark Bosniak Esq. of Philadephia and Karen Patou of Palo Alto, CA. Cherished grandfather of Jordana Bosniak, David Henry, Laura and Caroline Patou.

ANATOLE--Lucille, 87, of Greenwich, CT, and formerly of Egremont, MA, and Lawrence, NY, died at her home on September 24th, 2006. She will always be remembered as Babs. Beloved wife of David (Tolia) for 66 years, loving mother of Amy Schwab and her husband Jim, and Mark Anatole and his wife Jodi. Devoted Grammy to Kate and Joanna Schwab, and Emily and Carter Anatole. Grammy, we will always remember the ''Happy Times''. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

BERNSTEIN--Helene. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Helene Bernstein. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her husband, Arthur, and other members of her family. Allen J. Ross, President

TRANS FATS BAN ADVANCES The New York City Board of Health voted to go ahead with plans to prohibit the city's 20,000 restaurants from serving food that contains more than a minute amount of artificial trans fats. Notebaert, the chief executive, has cut costs, stabilized revenue and built up so much cash that Qwest is actually in a position to buy another industry player. Leaders of many of the biggest global car companies will be in Paris at a seminal moment for the automobile industry. Ebbers, former chief executive of WorldCom, arrived at a federal prison in Louisiana to begin serving a 25-year sentence for his role in the accounting fraud that toppled his company. Now Mr. Prodi's government itself seems to be wavering. [C3.] STOCK RALLY CONTINUES Stocks extended their rally, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its second-highest close ever. The Dow climbed 93.58 points, or 0.81 percent, to 11,669.39. The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rebounded to 104.5 from a revised reading of 100.2 in August. [C6.] SUIT OVER GUIDANT DEAL Johnson & Johnson filed suit against Boston Scientific, Guidant and Abbott Laboratories for $5.5 billion in damages. The suit claims that the three companies illegally shared information on their way to scuttling Guidant's agreement to sell itself to Johnson & Johnson. INVESTIGATION'S METHODS A document now under Congressional review provides one of the most vivid illustrations yet of how Hewlett-Packard investigators obtained phone records through a practice called pretexting. A picture caption on Saturday about an anti-Hamas rally in Gaza by supporters of the rival Palestinian group Fatah misstated the purpose of the rally. It was to protest what participants called an atmosphere of fear created by Hamas leaders, not over the stance of Hamas on recognizing Israel.

The Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra will present a mix of chestnuts and intriguing contemporary works by composers including Osvaldo Golijov, Julia Wolfe and Peter Sculthorpe in its second season under Michael Christie as music director. Yesterday the orchestra announced the programs for its usual four concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The season opens Feb. 3 with two works by Mr. Sculthorpe, an Australian composer with whom Mr. Christie worked when he led the Queensland Orchestra, and Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring,'' with choreography by Nicholas Leichter. William Barton will play the didgeridoo, an aboriginal wind instrument from Australia. The Golijov program on March 10 will include his ''Last Round'' and a new orchestration of ''Dreams and Prayers of Isaac the Blind,'' along with Mahler's First Symphony. In addition to community and school concerts, the 53-year-old orchestra will present two ''genre-blending'' concerts, including a program with performances by Laurie Anderson, Nellie McKay, Joan Osborne and Suzanne Vega. DANIEL J. WAKIN

From the poor choices on American produce stands you would never know that hundreds of types of delicious mangoes are grown around the world. For the last few weeks, big Keitt mangoes, with skin that stays green when the fruit is ripe, have been available. They are worth buying now, for the lush silkiness of their golden-orange flesh.

Congress Makes Progress On Detainee Legislation Congress moved closer to passing legislation laying out rules for interrogating terrorism suspects and trying them before military tribunals. But lawmakers said it was doubtful that bills covering the National Security Agency's eavesdropping program could pass before Congress adjourned this weekend. PAGE A20 Afghan Attacks More Deadly Two bombings in Afghanistan killed 20 people, a new sign of the increasing size and power of suicide attacks and roadside bombs. The insurgents' tactics are becoming more like those seen in Iraq. DINING, PAGE F1 Japan's Assertive New Leader Japan's new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, picked a cabinet packed with social conservatives and foreign-policy hawks. PAGE A3 Byron Nelson Dies The golfer who won 18 professional tournaments in 1945, including a record 11 in succession, was 94. One of the sport's most renowned figures and considered the model for the modern golf swing, he won 52 times on the PGA Tour, including five majors. An obituary on Saturday about Dean E. Wooldridge, one of the founders of the military contractor TRW, misstated the year of his birth. It was 1913, not 1919. As the headline and obituary noted, he was 93.

Congress on Tuesday was headed toward a split decision on President Bush's pre-election national security agenda, moving closer to passage of legislation on the handling of terrorism suspects while all but giving up hope of agreeing on a final bill to authorize the administration's eavesdropping program. Lawmakers in both the House and Senate said it now appeared doubtful that bills covering the National Security Agency's eavesdropping program could pass both houses and be reconciled before Congress adjourns this weekend, an outcome that would deny Republicans one of the main achievements they hoped to take into the election.

Cherished grandfather of Natalie and Steven Drucker, Nora and Alex. Devoted brother of Dorothy Wiener. A long life well lived. Services Thursday, September 28th, 1pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.
A list of pinot noirs last Wednesday with the Wines of The Times column omitted the surname of the producer of one wine, a 2004 Les Salices from Languedoc. It is Jacques & François Lurton.
A leaking fire hydrant's pristine puddle, lined with autumn leaves, creates a sidewalk day spa for some European starlings and a sparrow to bathe in and drink from on a Brooklyn morning.

INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Combative Bush Releases Portions of Terror Study Under pressure, the White House released portions of a National Intelligence Estimate on terrorism that said Muslim jihadists are ''increasing in both number and geographical dispersion,'' and that current trends could lead to increasing attacks around the globe. A6 Thai Junta Plans to Remain One week after seizing power in a coup, the leader of Thailand's military junta said it would not disband after choosing a civilian prime minister in the next few days, but would stay on in an advisory role. A8 NATIONAL A18-23 New Campaign Ads to Air, More Negative Than Not Republicans and Democrats began showing at least 30 new campaign advertisements in contested House and Senate districts across the country. Of those, three were positive. A1 Two Senate Democrats proposed emergency legislation to reimburse states for printing paper ballots in case of problems with electronic voting machines on Nov. 7. A22 Progress on Detainee Bill Congress was headed toward a split decision on President Bush's pre-election national security agenda, moving closer to passage of legislation on the handling of terrorism suspects but not agreeing on a final bill to authorize the administration's eavesdropping program. The most prominent is a constitutional dispute over anti-union measures known as ''paycheck protection'' laws. A21 Boston Tunnels Need Repairs Two aging tunnels leading to and from Logan International Airport in Boston are in need of major ceiling repairs, Gov. Mitt Romney said. The findings are the result of an audit conducted after a woman was killed by falling concrete in a newer tunnel in July. A21 University Changes Sought Education Secretary Margaret Spellings vowed to help finance state universities that administer standardized tests, establish a national data base to track students' progress toward a degree, and cut red tape surrounding federal student aid. A22 NEW YORK/REGION B1-9 Small-Town Courts Persist Despite Calls for Reform New Yorkers have been complaining about their town and village court system, led by judges who for the most part are not lawyers and who receive little legal training, for nearly a century. Yet the cries for sweeping change have all but died out over the last few decades, even as the abuses continue. A1 Rezoning West Side Yards The Bloomberg administration is giving up on its plan to buy the development rights over the West Side railyards from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for $500 million. Instead, it plans to rezone the 13-acre parcel on 11th Avenue for high-rise development, allowing the M.T.A. to sell it to a developer through a bidding process. Turtle Beats Hare Eagles defensive tackle Mike Patterson, above, lumbered 98 yards to score on a fumble recovery in Philadelphia's victory Sunday over San Francisco. While chasing Patterson on the play, San Francisco tight end Vernon Davis broke his leg. Davis, a rookie whose five-year, $23 million contract makes him the highest-paid tight end in the league, is out for four to six weeks. A broken leg is probably the only thing that could have prevented Davis from catching Patterson. Davis ran his 40-yard dash at the scouting combine in 4.38 seconds, the fastest time ever by a tight end. Patterson, a first-round pick last year out of Southern California, was clocked in 4.83. To add injury to injury, the 49ers' Frank Gore was also hurt on the play. Gore, the 49ers' leader in rushing yards and receptions, sustained bruised ribs when Brian Dawkins's helmet rammed into his midsection and knocked out the ball. Trouble in Texas Again Houston tried to address its deficiencies on defense when it made defensive end Mario Williams the No. 1 pick in this year's draft, but Williams has eight tackles in his first three games and has yet to record a sack.

The Sports of The Times column on Saturday, about cheating in athletics, referred imprecisely to an admission of doping by the retired professional cyclist Frankie Andreu. Although he testified in a lawsuit involving his former teammate Lance Armstrong, he did not disclose it then. Andreu admitted to his use of a performance-enhancing drug in a subsequent interview with The New York Times.

BUXBAUM--Reba, We are saddened to announce the death of our mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, in her 95th year, on September 23, 2006. Arline Tarte Steve and Shelly Buxbaum, Scott and Karen Tarte, Elissa and Adam Beerman, Lisa and Adam Buxbaum, Evan, James, and Kaitlin Tarte.

In 2002, I was riding the bus with my friend Andrew when my cellphone rang. I remember answering, putting the phone away and turning to him to say, "I have to get off the bus. My mom has cancer." So began a heart-wrenching two years of near-weekly hospital visits, and an agonizing transformation of my mother, Carol, then just 57, from a vital, independent businesswoman, mother, world traveler and lover of art into someone who ultimately lost her arduous battle with breast cancer at 60.

Dennis Prager, the Los Angeles talk radio host, recently posted a very interesting article called "Left Behind" on the Web site of Focus on the Family, the conservative Christian group. It explores what Prager sees as the increasing out-of-touchness of American liberals since Sept. 11, a condition he equates with the "left's incapacity to deal with evil."

There was an interesting bit of psychological back-and-forth in Shanghai today where James Allen, the ITV commentator, asked Michael Schumacher what he thought of Pat Symond's claim that Fernando Alonso would handle the pressure better in the title race. Symonds, the Renault technical director, worked with both drivers when they won championships. With Alonso last year and Schumacher at Benetton in 1994 and 1995.

Mr. Lieberman's response: "I can forgive but I probably won't forget." And here's advice from a DailyKos diarist and Lamont operative on how his supporters can look past that Q poll this morning.

If you have a book on Amazon.com, you have the option to create an author profile on your page. You've probably seen them. They're those little sections at the bottom of the page that have some personal facts, a blog space and a silly little picture of the author (I've always wanted to change my photo so that I'm in an English fox-hunting jacket holding a brandy snifter and smoking a Chesterfield dangling from a cigarette holder made from the ivory of an endangered African elephant). The Amazon profile page is like a mini MySpace for authors. Minus the cleverly disguised pedophiles.

Eliot Spitzer and John Faso threw more salvos at each other today over the millions of dollars Eliot's father Bernard, a wealthy real estate developer, loaned to his son in the past to finance Eliot's campaigns for attorney general in the 1990's.
In 1992 it was shocking artwork. 14 years later it was $8 million worth of rotting seafood. Enter Damien Hirst, a squad of assistants, 200 needles and one brand new tiger shark.

Jeanine Pirro's campaign has released her letter to Attorney General Alberto Gonzalez, asking him to appoint a special prosecutor in her case and expedite its resolution within 20 days. The full text is here.

Thursday brought more trouble on the hedge fund front, as CNBC's David Faber reported that more than half of the investment professionals at Pirate Capital have left the firm. The reasons for the exodus were not clear, but Mr. Faber said at least some of the departures came after a meeting including Pirate's analysts and the head of the firm, Thomas Hudson, "failed to address concerns [the analysts] had about the fund's dealings with regulatory issues."

Some noteholders are suing Wendy's International in an attempt to stop the fast-food outfit from spinning off the rest of its Tim Horton's chain of coffee-and-doughnut shops. The transaction has been in the works for months, but news of the lawsuit came on the eve of the spinoff, which is scheduled for Friday. A hearing on the dispute was set for Thursday afternoon in New York. Wendy's called the suit "without merit."
Jeanine Pirro may be under federal investigation, but Joseph Bruno, the State Senate's Republican majority leader, is sticking by her. He issued this statement earlier today:

Despite some slight wrinkles in the merger, the tie-up between Arcelor and Mittal Steel is apparently going so well that the company has announced a new and more generous dividend policy. There is certainly reason to celebrate at the Mittal family, which could reap $780 million under the new plan, according to The Times of London.

American capitalism goes through periodic bouts of worry that it can no longer compete because someone else is going to take all our business, leaving us unable to cope. Now it is China and India that are so feared. Fifteen or 20 years ago, it was Japan.

Patricia Dunn, the former chairwoman at Hewlett-Packard, deserves credit for facing Congress rather than invoking the Fifth Amendment. Those under her, including the general counsel who finally quit today, chose that route.

Carl C. Icahn is one busy man these days. Shortly after he announced that he wants to buy up to $500 million in Federated stock, the billionaire investor said Thursday that he will seek to oust six directors from the board of drug maker ImClone.
Are deals in the technology sector increasingly being accompanied by inside tips?

Republican gubernatorial candidate John Faso did not exactly rush to the defense of Jeanine Pirro this morning at a meeting of county officials in Lake George, calling the reports of a federal investigation "very troubling." And when one reporter called Ms. Pirro his "running mate," he was quick to clarify.

Saudi Arabian Basic Industries, the largest listed company in the Arab world, said on Thursday it would buy the British division of the Huntsman Corporation, a chemicals manufacturer based in Texas for $700 million.
Jacob "Kobi" Alexander may have been found in Namibia. And it appears he will stay there for some time.
The poultry producer Pilgrim's Pride Corporation said on Thursday it would start a $20-a-share tender offer to acquire a rival, Gold Kist, after failing to agree on a deal with Gold Kist management.
Despite ominous accounts of the New York Stock Exchange losing initial stock offerings to London and China, shares in the stock exchange's parent company, NYSE Group, are up 38 percent since June.

The feud over a second National Intelligence Estimate heated up on Wednesday, with Representative Jane Harman, the ranking Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, demanding that the White House release the study, which is about the state of the war in Iraq and the potential for civil war there. Stock in AutoZone fell more than 1 percent on Thursday, a day after the hedge fund manager, Edward Lampert, said he would leave the company's board, stoking concern he was losing confidence in the ccmpany, the nation's largest auto parts retailer.

Who is the more foolish, the fool or the fool who follows him? With regard to the detainee bill before Congress, Yale law professor Jack Balkin says it's the latter: The Democrats who are abetting President Bush with their silence are moral cowards who deserve to remain in the minority in Congress, he writes on his group legal blog Balkinization. "Far worse than a misguided zealot is the moral coward who says nothing and allows that zealotry to do real harm," Balkin writes. He continues:

There are a few more reports out on Thursday that point to potential problems for voters overseas and in the military. USA Today's Richard Wolf reminds everyone that the overseas ballots are supposed to be out 45 days before the election, and we're now at 40.
In my column in The Times today, I conducted a Cellphone Simplicity Derby. I attempted to find a phone that wasn't a camera, music player, Internet terminal or GPS unit--just a darned good phone.

3i, the publicly traded British private equity firm, earned 627 million pounds ($1.18 billion) from cashing out investments in the first half of this year, a figure that lags its performance during the same period last year, The Times of London reported.

Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional DistrictA once safe Republican district is now competitive, after the incumbent, Representative Don Sherwood, admitted an extramarital affair last year.

As President Bush said on Wednesday, the body language between the presidents of Pakistan and Afghanistan would be something to watch at the White House dinner on Wednesday night. And indeed, it was. As they stood in the Rose Garden on either side of Mr. Bush, their hands clutched together in front of them, staring straight ahead, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and President Hamid Karzai, looked none too happy.While they did no fingerpointing, the two have sparred in recent, separate interviews over a resurgent Taliban and the responsibilities for quelling terrorism.

It has been a busy week for activist investors, who are reaching deep into their pockets to buy shares of some of the nation's best-known corporations. Kirk Kerkorian, Carl Icahn and William Ackman all appear to be preparing to raise their stakes in various companies, signalling a growing belief that there is profit to be made in shaking up businesses -- or, perhaps, by simply putting them on notice that a shake-up might be coming.

Lone Star Funds agreed on Thursday to acquire Tokyo Dome's Korakuen Finance, a mid-sized Japanese bank, for 50.5 billion yen ($429 million) in its first outreach to the country's consumer finance sector.

Republicans chose the Twin Cities for their 2008 nominating convention, assuring heavy media coverage in swing states Minnesota, Iowa and Wisconsin.

Hewlett-Packard's general counsel has resigned, the embattled computer maker said Thursday as current and former executives prepared to testify before a Congressional subcommittee about its controversial leak investigation.
Many Democrats are thrilled by the timing of former President Bill Clinton's heightened visibility, reports Mark Silva of The Chicago Tribune.

Democrats are increasingly hopeful about taking over the Senate. They would need to pick up six of seven possible opportunities in Virginia, Tennessee, Montana, Missouri, Ohio, Pennslyvania and Rhode Island, while holding on to New Jersey and Maryland. But with less than six weeks until the election, Republicans and Democrats know that while the races are highly competitive at the moment, a lot could change in the coming weeks.

The Quinnipiac University poll released this morning shows Senator Joe Lieberman with 49 percent, over Ned Lamont, at 39 percent, among likely general election voters in Connecticut. The poll was conducted from last Thursday through Monday (Sept. 21 to 25) and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

The Walt Disney Company is buying Climax Racing of Britain, its first European games acquisition, adding the maker of MotoGP and ATV Offroad Fury to expand its Buena Vista Games division outside the United States.

August A. Busch IV was named to become president and chief executive of Anheuser-Busch on Wednesday in a move that puts a member of the Busch family back in charge of the company, the nation's largest brewer.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused three former executives of RenaissanceRe Holdings, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda, of using fraudulent accounting to improve earnings reports.

The former chief executive of WorldCom, Bernard Ebbers, who began a 25-year sentence on Wednesday for directing one of the biggest frauds in United States history, will appeal his conviction to the Supreme Court.

In a scandal approaching operatic proportions, major players in Hewlett-Packard's controversial leak investigation, including the chief executive, Mark Hurd, the recently ousted chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, and the Silicon Valley uber-lawyer Lawrence W. Sonsini, will begin testifying before Congress Thursday.

Fees earned by buyout firms such as the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group are too high and could dampen their enthusiasm to make money for clients, according to the manager overseeing Britain's largest corporate pension fund.
The private equity firm Apollo Advisors plans to beef up its investment activity in Europe, despite its relative late arrival overseas.

Royal & Sun Alliance appeared to have finally extricated itself from its troubled United States business on Thursday after it agreed to sell its American operations to Arrowpoint Capital for a deferred consideration of 158 million pounds ($297 million).
STMicroelectronics, Europe's largest maker of computer chips, may be targeted for a takeover, according to traders betting on the creditworthiness of companies in the credit-default swap market.
A medical device maker SpinalMotion closed its series C round of venture funding after raising $20 million. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes artificial spinal discs.
A mass market email company, Visto, said Wednesday it had raised $51 million in venture capital. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., sells software used in wireless email.
Recent initial public offerings have been riding the market higher as the Dow Jones industrial average nears a record close of 11,722, but the pace of new offerings continues to lag.

Khazanah Nasional raised $750 million selling Southeast Asia's biggest Islamic convertible bond, allowing holders to exchange them into shares of Telekom Malaysia, the nation's No. 1 telephone company.
An oil and gas firm, EV Energy Partners, fell below its offering price Wednesday in the latest in a series of energy deals peppering the market for initial public offerings.
Societe Generale, France's third-largest bank, will sell 2.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) of stock to existing investors to make acquisitions in countries such as Russia.

Bank of America acknowledged yesterday that its lax operations allowed South American money launderers to illegally move $3 billion through a single Midtown Manhattan branch, closing the latest illicit-finance investigation brought by Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney.
Can Morgan Stanley avoid angering the private equity gods?

Harris Financial, a subsidiary of the Bank of Montreal, agreed to buy First National Bank & Trust of Indiana for $290 million. First National has $1.3 billion in assets, $920 million in deposits and more than $500 million in trust assets.
Vince, the five-year-old contemporary sportswear label of luxury basics that became a $50 million business, will be bought by Kellwood, the companies said yesterday.

Sears extended until Oct. 31 its $802 million offer to buy the 46 percent of Sears Canada it does not already own. The proposal may be further extended as the company seeks to appeal a regulatory ruling blocking its effort to buy the stake.

In a move that may aid The New York Post in its battle royale with arch nemesis The New York Daily News, the Post's parent, the News Corporation, has broadened its metropolitan-area presence with the acquisition of two newspaper groups that have 28 weekly papers primarily serving Queens and Brooklyn.
It's the small things, really, that make a deal come together. For JumpCut, the foosball table could have been the clincher to signing a deal to be bought by Yahoo.

The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, the country's largest lender, bidding to buy an Indonesian bank in what would mark the first acquisition by a mainland bank outside of greater China, according to reports.

Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance - raising the prospect of eventual talks with Ford.
The French national assembly approved a plan Wednesday to cut the state's stake in Gaz de France, clearing the way for a planned merger with Suez, the finance mMnister, Thierry Breton, said.
Martinsa, a Spanish developer, offered 4 billion euros ($5.1 billion) for Fadesa Inmobiliaria, a Spanish real-estate company.

On the same day that Carl C. Icahn and Daniel S. Loeb made waves with their latest shareholder activism, the investor William Ackman said he plans to buy more than $2 billion shares of McDonald's in what may become a bruising proxy fight.

Carl C. Icahn's announcement on Wednesday that he was seeking regulatory approval to acquire as much as $500 million of shares in Federated Department Stores, has industry observers wondering what the notorious activist shareholder is up to this time.

The Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications won approval from shareholders to be acquired by a group of private investors for $12.3 billion, clearing another hurdle in its long-running sale process. The vote was close, though, with Univision receiving the support of 63 percent of shareholders - only slightly more than 60 percent that was required to approve the deal.
The 65-34 vote means the bill could reach President Bush’s desk by week’s end. The House passed nearly identical legislation yesterday.

After much dispute (and a few poison pen letters), it looks like Daniel S. Loeb has finally gotten his way with Nabi Biopharmaceuticals. Responding to moves by Mr. Loeb's activist hedge fund, Third Point, Nabi said it is considering strategic options including selling itself.

Less than two weeks after its stunning admission that it had lost billions of dollars on bad natural gas debts, the hedge fund Amaranth Advisors is cleaning house. The group, which already sold its energy portfolio to J.P. Morgan Chase and the Citadel Investment Group, is planning to liquidate its assets or sell itself outright, according to The Financial Times.
“War Thoughts at Home,” discovered by a graduate student, will be published on Monday in The Virginia Quarterly Review.
The Poetry Foundation has named Jack Prelutsky its first children’s poet laureate, in the hopes that the appointment will raise awareness of the genre.
Some people like to spend their time speculating about the courtship habits of Hollywood stars like Jennifer Aniston and Vince Vaughn.

When Brett Favre threw his third touchdown pass in the Packers' 31-24 victory against the Lions on Sunday, it gave him 402 for his career. That put him at No. 2 on the N.F.L.'s career list behind Dan Marino (420), and on pace to pass Marino before the season is out.
“Ugly Betty” is a fashion victim who tries to find a home among the arbiters of style.
“Picasso and American Art” at the Whitney goes to extraordinary lengths to state the obvious: Picasso had a great impact on many young artists.

In an age of organic everything, childhood obesity and widespread food allergies, the feeding and misfeeding of children has become a tense, awkward point of debate between parents and baby sitters, Jodi Kantor writes in today's Thursday Styles.

The latest New York Times/CBS News poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 24 through 27 with 904 adults throughout the state. Of those, 734 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat, is making inroads in Republican strongholds and on traditional Republican issues, according to a new  Times/CBS News poll.

At the world chess championship, Veselin Topalov says his opponent took an excessive number of bathroom breaks.
Many of the bodies were killed execution-style and bore signs of torture. Several bombs exploded in Baghdad today.
A German opera house said it might reinstate a production it had cancelled for fear of provoking Muslims.
The government evidently has decided to permit the currency to appreciate much faster than before.
Duane R. Morrison, 53, assaulted students before killing one in a Colorado school, according to the sheriff.
Jeanine F. Pirro said she would not drop out of the race for New York attorney general, a day  after acknowledging that she is under investigation.

The bill, approved 65 to 34, establishes far-reaching new rules on the treatment of terrorism suspects and is expected to go to the president by  week’s end.
Stocks crossed the 11,722.98 mark, passing a point it has not reached since the frenzy of the technology boom.

Hewlett-Packard’s former chairwoman and its current leader tried to explain why they did not question the legality of an internal spying operation.
The largest shareholder urged the board to conduct a “strong” review of his proposal to work with two rivals.

A judge accused of taking bribes in divorce cases rejected a plea bargain yesterday, saying he wanted to go to trial. The judge, Gerald P. Garson, who has been suspended as a justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, is a central figure in a wide-ranging investigation by the district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, into political and judicial corruption. Several of Justice Garson’s associates have pleaded guilty to participating in bribery. Justice Garson, 75 and sick with cancer, was offered two consecutive sentences resulting in 16 months served in a local jail, where private doctors could treat him, in exchange for a guilty plea to two minor felonies.

Ron Philo survived a bogey on the final hole and finished with a three-over-par 75 for a 54-hole total of 216 to win the Met P.G.A. championship at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, Conn. The victory was the fifth of the year for Philo, the head pro of the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains, who qualified for the P.G.A. Championship at Medinah earlier this year.
With a few more starts, Pedro Martínez could tinker with his control and recapture his sharpness. Unfortunately for the Mets, he is out of time.
Chien-Ming Wang finished his first full major league season with his 19th victory over the Baltimore Orioles and will be the Game 1 starter of the division series on Tuesday.
By The Associated Press.
By The Associated Press.

A Brooklyn woman accused of killing her 7-year-old daughter has spoken to the girl’s siblings by telephone from jail despite a court order forbidding such contact, prosecutors said in State Supreme Court yesterday. Prosecutors have said they might call the children as witnesses against the woman, Nixzaliz Santiago, who is charged with second-degree murder in the death of her daughter Nixzmary Brown last January. The children, all younger than 10, are in the custody of the city’s child welfare agency. An assistant district attorney, Linda Weinman, said the children told prosecutors and therapists that they had spoken with Ms. Santiago during visits with their maternal grandmother at a location overseen by the child welfare agency. Ms. Weinman asked Justice L. Priscilla Hall to revoke Ms. Santiago’s telephone privileges. Ms. Santiago’s lawyer, Robert W. Abrams, denied the accusation and asked for an investigation. The judge declined to revoke the telephone privileges but ordered workers supervising the visits to make sure the children did not speak to their mother.

A man believed to be in his 20s was shot to death in Brooklyn last night as part of a dispute, the police said. The man, whom police were trying to identify last night, was shot three or four times around 8 p.m. at 569 East 94th Street in East Flatbush. He was dead at the scene. The gunman fled the scene and there have been no arrests, the police said.

A Flatbush man convicted of killing an Army sergeant outside a Canarsie nightclub last year was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 40 years to life in prison. Prosecutors said the sergeant, Terrence Balkissoon, 25, on leave from duty in Iraq, angered the man, Joseph Carrington, 25, by speaking to Mr. Carrington’s girlfriend outside the nightclub on Jan. 9, 2005. They said Mr. Carrington shot Sergeant Balkissoon in the back, then shot his brother Lawrence Balkissoon, who survived. Justice Albert Tomei sentenced Mr. Carrington to consecutive sentences of 25 years to life for murder and 15 years for attempted murder.

A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday and suspended on accusations that he used a stolen credit card, the police said. The officer, Eduardo Saillant, who works in the 60th Precinct in Brooklyn, was charged with grand larceny and criminal possession of stolen property.
Lottery Numbers.

Police Commissioner Robert Taggart announced his retirement during a news conference at City Hall yesterday, three years after he was appointed. His last day on the job is Nov. 2; the city’s mayor, Philip A. Amicone, said he would appoint a new commissioner in two weeks Commissioner Taggart, 57, joined the department in 1969. He said he was leaving to explore other opportunities in law enforcement.

A man believed to be in his 40’s was found dead on a West Village street yesterday, his body suspended by a studded leather collar around his neck from the spoke of an iron fence, the police said. The cause of death was unknown, and the medical examiner’s office said an autopsy would be conducted today. The police did not know the man’s identity, officials said. Witnesses said he was in black leather clothes and gloves and had a black mask covering his face. His body was discovered dangling from a three-foot-high fence in front of a four-story building at 424 Hudson Street shortly before 7 a.m. and bore no obvious signs of trauma, the police said.

A Long Island teacher who aroused suspicion while crossing into Canada with photographs of boys in their underwear was charged yesterday with possessing child pornography after a search of his home, federal prosecutors said. The teacher, Michael Kelly Reiner, 46, of East Meadow, was arrested after federal agents searched his home on Sept. 12 and found computer images of children engaging in sexual activity, according to a complaint. At his arraignment yesterday in Federal District Court, Mr. Reiner was ordered held pending a bail hearing. The complaint says Mr. Reiner came under suspicion on Aug. 4, when he tried to cross the border at Prescott, Ontario, and was found to have a laptop computer with about 1,000 images of young boys in sexually provocative poses. But because none were considered child pornography, he was permitted into Canada. After his arrest, Mr. Reiner was fired from the school, the Long Island School for the Gifted in Huntington Station.
The Giants are still coping with the aftermath of tight end Jeremy Shockey’s criticism of the team’s coaching following a 42-30 loss in Seattle on Sunday.

Robbers struck South Africa’s 800 or so armored cars at the rate of more than one a day over the last 12 months, the largest number of cash-in-transit robberies recorded since current recordkeeping began in 1996, the Police Service reported. The 383 armored-car robberies marked an increase of nearly 75 percent from the previous 12-month period. Business robberies and car and truck hijackings also rose; with armored-car robberies, those crimes are often the work of large organized gangs.

Georgian authorities arrested four Russian military officers in the capital, Tbilisi, and accused them of espionage, the interior minister, Vano Merabishvili, said at a news conference. Col. Gen. Yuri Baluyevsky, the chief of the general staff of the Russian armed forces, told Interfax that the arrests were an “outrage” and that he and the Foreign Ministry were “taking all the necessary steps to resolve the situation.”.

Polish politics had a whiff of scandal added to its continuing government crisis after the deputy of the governing Law and Justice Party, Adam Lipinski, left, who is in charge of Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski’s office, was caught on film trying to buy the support of an opposition member of Parliament in return for a cabinet position. The episode was recorded and broadcast by the TVN television channel. The conservative Law and Justice Party, which campaigned on an anticorruption platform, has been scrambling to rebuild a coalition after a falling-out with the small leftist party Self-Defense last week left the government without a parliamentary majority. It has been wooing lawmakers from Self-Defense to defect, including the one offered the government post, Renata Beger, and negotiating with the small centrist Polish Peasant Party. That party broke off coalition talks after the revelations, increasing the chances of an early election.

Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany apologized for the profanities in a leaked speech in which he admitted lying about the state of the economy to win April’s election. “Of course I am sorry,” he said at a news conference in Budapest. “These were the words of reproof, affection and passion.” The leak of the audiotape has caused protests around the country since Sept. 17, but the crowds have been getting smaller.

An Ankara court fined an elderly man 10,000 lira ($6,700) for criticizing Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan in a visitors’ book at the onetime home of Ataturk, who founded the Turkish Republic in 1923. The man, Fethi Dorduncu, in May visited the house in Thessaloniki, Greece, where Ataturk was born, and wrote in the visitors’ book that Mr. Erdogan, above, was a “traitor” bent on destroying Ataturk’s secular republic and building an Islamic state. Mr. Erdogan ripped the page from the book in anger when he later visited the house. The court ordered Mr. Dorduncu, who is in his 80’s, to pay damages for the pain and anguish he caused Mr. Erdogan, the Anatolian news agency said. Mr. Erdogan, who denies he has an Islamist agenda, has filed a number of lawsuits against his critics, including journalists and cartoonists. Last week, a British artist was detained after painting a picture of Mr. Erdogan as a dog.

Arsonists set four schools on fire in a possible act of defiance against the new military rulers, a military spokesmen said. The schools are in Kamphaengphet Province, north of Bangkok and a bastion of support for the deposed prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra. Col. Banyong Sirasunthorn, the spokesman, speculated that the arsonists might have opposed the closing of some 400 community radio stations, many of which had been used as mouthpieces for the fallen government.

French doctors performed what they described as the first operation on a human in weightless conditions, using an Airbus 300 adapted to simulate conditions in space. In the three-hour flight over southwest France, surgeons and anesthetists in harnesses successfully removed a cyst from the arm of a 46-year-old volunteer strapped to an operating table. Their instruments were held in place by magnets. The operation was part of a program backed by the European Space Agency to develop techniques for performing surgery aboard the International Space Station or other space vehicles.

Karim Mehdi, a Moroccan suspected of having links with two men involved in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, went on trial in Paris on a charge of “criminal association in connection with a terrorist enterprise.” Arrested in 2003, he is the only person to face charges arising out of a sweeping French investigation into the 2001 attacks. According to documents read in court, he was in contact with Ziad al-Jarrah, the hijacker pilot of United Airlines Flight 93, as well as Ramzi bin al-Shibh, one of the men accused of helping plan the attacks. Mr. Mehdi told the court that he met the two men only once, on a visit to Hamburg, Germany, where a cell of Al Qaeda whose members included the hijackers operated.

The government decided to raise significantly the pensions of veterans who fought for France as foreigners in World War II, finally paying them the same as their French comrades in arms. The decision coincided with the release of the film “Indigènes” (its English title is “Days of Glory”), which focuses on the discrimination suffered by troops from France’s colonies in Africa during the war. President Jacques Chirac ordered the pension adjustment after he saw the film in a private screening. According to his spokesman, Mr. Chirac told his cabinet that the decision was “an act of justice.” More than 250,000 troops from France’s colonies fought on the side of the Allies. The measure, which will go into effect next year, will affect about 80,000 veterans or widows from more than 20 countries and cost $140 million a year.

The Army brought charges against a military police officer who refused to return to Iraq after she said her supervisor had coerced her into a sexual relationship. The police officer, Specialist Suzanne Swift, 22, based at Fort Lewis, Wash., faces charges of being absent without leave and missing movement. The latter means she was not with her company when it left in January for a four-month tour of duty in Iraq, said a Fort Lewis spokeswoman, Sgt. Maj. Yolanda Choates. Specialist Swift could face a reprimand, a more serious nonjudicial punishment or a court-martial, Sergeant Choates said. Specialist Swift, who served in Iraq from February 2004 to February 2005, said she had been harassed or abused by three officers, two in Iraq and one at Fort Lewis.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed into law a global warming initiative that imposes the nation’s first cap on emissions of heat-trapping gases. “We simply must do everything we can in our power to slow down global warming before it is too late,” Mr. Schwarzenegger said before signing the bill on Treasure Island, in San Francisco Bay. California’s efforts on global warming have been in the spotlight since the governor and the state’s legislative Democrats reached an accord last month on the bill to cut emissions.

Two Hurricane Katrina recovery workers hired last year by the Federal Emergency Management Agency have been charged with trying to defraud the government by filing a false claim for damage to a houseboat, which resulted in an award of $25,500 in disaster assistance. One of the FEMA employees, Duane Adams, claimed to own the houseboat in Moss Point, Miss., and the other, Emily Fuqua, helped Mr. Adams file the false claim. The two, who worked in clerical administration and disaster recovery programs, have been placed on unpaid leave, a FEMA official said.

Wal-Mart opened its first store in Chicago, a little more than two weeks after Mayor Richard M. Daley vetoed an ordinance requiring all “big-box” stores to pay their employees $10 an hour by 2010. More than 15,000 people applied to work at the 142,000-square-foot store, which is in the economically depressed Austin section on the West Side. Wal-Mart officials estimated that the store would produce 490 jobs. Critics of the chain’s urban expansion, including some aldermen who were unable to override Mr. Daley’s veto, said they would continue to push for higher wages for employees of the city’s big-box stores.
The Commerce Department blocked the release of a document describing possible links between global warming and hurricanes, according to a news article in the journal Nature.

Three masked men robbed a suburban Atlanta sex shop after restraining the employees with black fur handcuffs and silver leg irons taken from the store shelves, the police said. The authorities said the men stole $230 from the cash register at the Starship Enterprise novelty store, along with several jewelry scales valued at $700 and a set of car keys. No one was hurt.

The Harris Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the Bank of Montreal, agreed to buy First National Bank & Trust of Indiana for $290 million. First National has $1.3 billion in assets, $920 million in deposits and more than $500 million in trust assets. It has 32 branches in Indianapolis and nearby areas, and provides banking, trust, investment and insurance services. Harris already has 200 branches in the Chicago area and considers Indianapolis an attractive market for its small- and midmarket business banking capabilities, according to Ellen Costello, who became chief executive of Harris on Aug. 1.

The Sears Holdings Corporation extended until Oct. 31 its $802 million offer to buy the 46 percent of Sears Canada it does not already own. The proposal may be further extended as the company seeks to appeal a regulatory ruling blocking its effort to buy the stake. The bid would pay Sears Canada stockholders 18 Canadian dollars a share and values the company at about 1.94 billion Canadian dollars ($1.74 billion). Sears also said it would ask the Ontario Court of Appeal to reconsider a decision by the Ontario Securities Commission that barred Sears Holdings from counting some shareholder votes toward the proposed purchase and effectively prevented the company from completing the acquisition.

Myles Brand, the N.C.A.A. president, was pleased with an overall increase of 1 percentage point in graduation rates for college athletes. For the second consecutive year, the N.C.A.A. released figures showing more than three-quarters of the athletes, 77 percent, graduate within six years, a slight increase over last year’s 76 percent.

Juan Pablo Montoya will make his stock car debut in the Oct. 6 ARCA race at Talladega Superspeedway in Charlotte, N.C. The car owner Chip Ganassi said yesterday he would put Montoya in the No. 4 Texaco/Havoline Dodge for the event. Montoya, the 2000 Indianapolis 500 winner, was released from his Formula One contract with McLaren last week and spent Monday testing an ARCA car at Talladega.

Hassan Adams, the Nets’ second-round draft pick, signed with the team yesterday after passing a physical on his recently broken right foot. Adams, a guard taken with the 54th pick out of Arizona, averaged 17.5 points and almost 5 rebounds last season. He is the only player in Pac-10 Conference history to record 1,800 points, 700 rebounds and 200 steals in a career. He hurt his foot in June during a workout for the Nets before the draft.

IN his March report on reform, Secretary General Kofi Annan said that the United Nations “lacks the capacity, controls, flexibility, robustness and indeed transparency to handle multibillion-dollar global operations.” Describing the organizational culture as “damaged,” he acknowledges that a recent audit points “to both mismanagement and possible fraud” in peacekeeping operations. He concludes that reform efforts have addressed the “symptoms and not the causes of our underlying weaknesses.”.

AS a former refugee, I attach special importance to ensuring peace, security and the protection of the most vulnerable groups. Too often during the past five years, the United Nations has focused on the letter, not the spirit, of its charter when it needed to protect civilians caught in warfare. The international community’s responsibility to protect must not be an empty concept but a genuine obligation, and United Nations peacekeeping mandates must be more robust.

THERE are many things the United Nations has done right. But like all institutions, it is fallible. Thus, as invidious as it may seem to single out one mistake, I must say that the violence in Darfur stands as an indictment against the United Nations. For three years, the suffering civilians there received little but hand-wringing, stopgap humanitarian efforts and an African Union peacekeeping force. Finally the Security Council last month voted to expand the United Nations mission in Sudan to include Darfur. That this resolution remains unenforced reflects the collective failure of the United Nations’ membership and its institutions, including the Secretariat.

REDUCING the United Nations presence in East Timor was a mistake that, given the chance to step back in time, I believe we would not make again. In May 2005, we pulled out the last of the peacekeepers, who had played a prominent role since 1999 in restoring peace to a ravaged land, leaving behind a small group of civilian advisers.

THE United Nations faces a daunting range of challenges in the 21st century: promoting development without fostering dependency; combating climate change without reducing growth; defending human rights without insisting on one true path. But in the past five years, a specter has risen, casting a shadow across the world: the specter of extremism, instability and injustice gripping the Middle East.

The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates running for secretary general of the United Nations this fall how they would reform the organization if they are selected.  Five candidates gave us their answers.
