SANDLER--Dr. Howard J. 64, of Northern New Jersey, on September 26, 2006. During the Vietnam War; he was Chief of Aerospace Medicine at McGuire Air Force Base from 1969-1971. Tireless in his clinical practice at Valley Hospital, he also served his profession as Instructor of Surgery at Veterans Affairs Medical Center in East Orange, N.J. Dr. Sandler was an internationally recognized physician for pioneering ultrasound-guided brachytherapy (seed implants) for the treatment of prostate cancer, only the second physician to perform the procedure in the United States. He also spearheaded the use of radiofrequency waves for benign prostatic hypertrophy. He presented his experiences at national meetings, through publications and has appeared on television network news. Survived by his beloved wife Marilyn (nee Katz), devoted sons Craig (Janice), Todd (Randi) brother Neil (Elise) adored grandchildren Daniella, Hunter, Emily, and Zachary. Services today 12 Noon, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel w-150 Rt. #
To the Editor: Re ''Opera Canceled Over a Depiction of Muhammad'' (front page, Sept. 27):

Sometimes all it takes to renew a tired room is a new lampshade, but interesting shades are hard to find. Now many are available at Just Shades, a 40-year-old SoHo store that has a new look and thousands of new lampshades, according to Marc Engelson, the new owner. Mr. Engelson has changed the inventory to include shades in bright colors, stripes, patterns and unusual shapes, including ellipses, cut-cornered squares, shallow drums and cubes. (For traditionalists, he still supplies the usual empires and coolies in white and beige.) Ready-made shades start at $30 and go to $300, and custom styles and colors are available. The store, open Tuesday through Saturday, is at 21 Spring Street (Elizabeth Street), (212) 966-2757, justshadesny.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

TWO weeks ago, Lisa Laurenzo, 42, traveled from her home in Hershey, Pa., to the Oscar Bond Salon in SoHo, where she sat for nearly four hours while a hairdresser, Jason Wilkerson, meticulously attached more than 200 human hair extensions to her frail tendrils. It was the third time in a year that she had paid for the $3,300 indulgence, which was originally precipitated by a butchered haircut. To mimic the shades of Ms. Laurenzo's chemically lightened hair, Mr. Wilkerson intertwined pale-blond and caramel-colored extensions so that it was impossible to tell which strands were her own.

WINOGRAD--Alfred A., on September 26, 2006. Longtime attorney-at-law in NYC. Former proprietor of The Gourmet Liquor Shop, NYC. Proud veteran of the 8th Army Airforce, WWII; retired Colonel, US Airforce. Star starting Center CCNY basketball team. Beloved husband of Betty (nee Weiss). Devoted father of Gloria and Steven. Adoring grandfather of David. Loving brother-in-law of Teddi. Dear uncle of Jerry, Susan, Barry, Lloyd, Ann, and Marcy. Also survived and loved by many other relatives and friends. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home Inc., 1297 First Ave (69-70 St), NYC, Friday 10am. Rabbinical Service 11am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

The United Nations selects its next secretary general this fall through a series of straw polls. The third of these -- the most decisive to date -- will be held today. In the vote, the 15 members of the Security Council ''encourage,'' ''discourage'' or venture ''no opinion'' on each of the candidates. To win, a candidate must have at least nine encouraging votes and no discouragement from any of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The winner is then presented to the General Assembly for ratification. The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates to respond to two questions. First, we asked them to discuss an avoidable mistake the United Nations had made within the last five years. Second, we asked them what major reform they would undertake as secretary general. Five candidates gave us their answers.

VAN VRANKEN--Nancy S. 68, of Jericho, NY, died September 23, 2006 , after a stroke. Daughter of the late Dale and Merle Sharp, wife of J. Frederick Van Vranken, Jr. and mother of Virginia V. Ziobro and Cynthia V. Keating. She was also the grandmother of Dale, Geoffrey and Christina Ziobro and Geoffrey, Meghan and Paige Keating. A graduate of Miss Porter's School in 1956 and Mary Hardin-Baylor University in 1959, she received a Master's Degree in Biology from the Columbia University School of Education in 1978. Nancy was an extraordinary science teacher at the American Museum of Natural History and at St. Bernard's School in NYC. In the late 1980s, she was one of only 50 science teachers in the U.S. selected by the Government to assist the Chinese Government in modernizing its national science program. She was Treasurer of the 15,000-member National Association of Biology Teachers and was a Board member of both The Association of Teachers in Independent Schools and The Triangle Coalition. In the 1970's, Nancy was a founder of The Teacher's Clearinghouse for Science and Society Education. She was an active member of the North Country Garden Club as well as the choir of St. John's Church. A memorial service will take place at 4PM on Saturday, October 28, 2006 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Rte 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Teacher's Clearinghouse for Science & Society Education, 194 Washington Rd, Princeton, NY 08540-6447 would be greatly appreciated.
KERR--Nora. 11/19/1943--9/28/2005. Beloved wife, mother, sister and friend. You've been gone a year, but you will always live in our hearts. Love, Gordy for all of us
To the Editor: Re ''Backing Policy, President Issues Terror Estimate'' (front page, Sept. 27):

Mark Zimmerman, a former first vice president of the Actors' Equity Association, was elected president yesterday by the union's governing council. The presidency had been vacant since Patrick Quinn, who died on Sunday, resigned in August to become executive director, a position he was to assume next week. Yesterday afternoon the council appointed three members of the executive staff -- Steve DiPaola, national director of finance and administration; Carol Waaser, the Eastern regional director; and Mary Lou Westerfield, the national director of policy -- to perform the duties of the executive director until a new one is appointed. Mr. Zimmerman has acted in the Broadway revivals of ''The Rainmaker'' and ''Brigadoon,'' and worked regularly on Broadway tours and Off Broadway. He was elected to the equity council in 1989 and became first vice president in 2000. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

MOORE--Charlotte Holg, 93, longtime resident of Bronxville, NY, died on Tuesday September 12, 2006 in Birmingham, AL. Executive secretary of Alpha Epsilon Delta, the national pre-med honor society, for over 44 years. Wife of the late Dr. Maurice Lee Moore for 70 years. Mother of Dr. D.R. Moore of London, Dr. Amanda L. Moore of Bronxville, and the late Margaret Moore Grindle of Birmingham. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday October 1, 2006 at West Center Congregational Church, 101 Pondfield Road West, Bronxville, NY 10708. Memorials may be made for the Maurice and Charlotte Moore Scholarship to Alpha Epsilon Delta, James Madison University, MSC 9015, Harrisonburg, VA 22807.

''Dancing With the Stars'' made ABC the most watched network on Tuesday night, but Fox's hit drama ''House'' posted top ratings in the important demographic of viewers 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ''Dancing With the Stars'' averaged 17.8 million over its 90-minute broadcast, while ''House'' made gains over its performance last week, drawing 14.2 million viewers. On CBS ''NCIS'' drew a healthy 13.8 million at 8 p.m., boosting ''The Unit,'' which drew 12 million viewers at 9. ''The Unit'' led overall in its second half-hour when the debut at 9:30 of ABC's new Ted Danson comedy, ''Help Me Help You,'' (11.9 million) halted the ''Dancing With the Stars'' momentum. Among viewers 18 to 49, ''The Unit'' edged out NBC's ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent'' (10.4 million) and Fox's ''Standoff'' (8.1 million), which tied for third for the hour. As usual, the 10 p.m. hour belonged to NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,'' with Christopher Meloni, which drew 14.3 million viewers, besting Week 2 of ABC's ''Boston Legal'' (10 million) and CBS's ''Smith'' (9.6 million). On the CW, the seventh season premiere of ''Gilmore Girls'' at 8 earned 4.6 million viewers, down 35 percent from its debut last year. BENJAMIN TOFF

There were 20 uniformed players on the field at Yankee Stadium for the national anthem last night. Eleven were All-Stars from the Staten Island team that played in the Little League World Series last month. Eight were Yankees, all current or former All-Stars. The exception was Chien-Ming Wang, the starting pitcher, who finished his first full major league season with a 16-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. Wang has never made the All-Star team, but the Yankees are counting on him heavily.

SHEFFER--Ralph. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Westport Public Library mourn the passing of our dear friend, Ralph Sheffer. His leadership of the Library while serving on the Board of Trustees from 1982 to 1990 and his Presidency from 1989 to 1990 provide inspiring memories to us all. His commitment to the Library and its central place in the community were unparalleled. We will miss him, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. James D. Seymour, President Westport Public Library Board of Trustees

CUSTOMERS LEFT BEHIND Big phone and cable companies have been reluctant to upgrade and expand their networks in sparsely populated places where there are not enough customers to justify the investment. One company, Verizon, is looking to sell the 1.6 million local phone lines it controls in Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. [Page A1.] AUTOMAKERS' TALKS Carlos Ghosn, below, who runs Renault and Nissan, said he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions fail to bring about an alliance with General Motors, raising the prospect of eventual talks with Ford. [C1.] FIGHTER ELUDES BUDGET-CUTTERS The F-22 Raptor fighter jet is an engineering marvel, a Maserati of the skies. But its biggest battles so far have been in Washington, where it has just taken on Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and Washington budget-cutters, and won. [C1.] H.P.'S EX-CHAIRWOMAN TO TESTIFY In remarks prepared for delivery at a Congressional hearing, Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, said she never had reason to believe that illegal methods were used in the leak investigation that led to her resignation. [C1.] A WIND POWER LEADER Wind power is quickly emerging as a serious energy alternative not just in affluent areas of the world but also in fast-growing countries like India and China. Leading the charge in India and elsewhere is a homegrown Indian company, Suzlon Energy. [C1.] NEWSROOM HERO In refusing to make a new round of cuts at The Los Angeles Times, Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher, has transformed himself in the eyes of Times employees. ''Jeff has really emerged as a hero to a lot of us in the newsroom,'' one reporter said. [C1.] NEWS CORP. ADDS WEEKLIES The News Corporation, owner of The New York Post, has broadened its New York presence with the acquisition of two newspaper groups that have 28 weekly papers primarily serving Queens and Brooklyn. [C14.] STOCKS ADVANCE Wall Street advanced for a third straight session, although the Dow Jones industrial average fell just short of touching its record high close. The Dow closed up 19.85 points, at 11,689.24. [C12.] HOME SALES REPORT A report showing that sales of new homes rose last month for the first time since March was -- at first glance -- a welcome respite. But economists warned that underneath the headline numbers, signs of a weakening housing market were more prevalent than ever. [C3.] MONEY LAUNDERING CASE In a settlement with the Manhattan district attorney's office, Bank of America acknowledged that lax operations allowed South American money launderers to illegally move $3 billion through a single Midtown Manhattan branch. [C3.] COMVERSE CHIEF ARRESTED Jacob Alexander, former chief executive of Comverse Technology, has been arrested in Namibia. He faces conspiracy, securities fraud and money laundering charges in the United States. [C3.] REINSURER'S EX-OFFICERS ACCUSED The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused three former executives of RenaissanceRe Holdings, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda, of practicing fraudulent accounting to improve earnings reports. [C7.] VERIZON DISCLOSES NETWORK COST Verizon Communications, the nation's second-largest telecommunications company, said it would spend $23 billion on its fiber optic network by 2010, in a report that reassured analysts but appeared to unnerve investors. [C4.] SPINACH RETURNS TO STORES Four East Coast grocery chains are restocking produce shelves with fresh spinach as federal officials continue to reassure consumers after the recent E. coli outbreak that spinach grown outside the Salinas Valley of California is safe. [A17.] REVIVING A BRAND Bromo Seltzer's new owner is seeking to revive interest in the moribund brand with a campaign centered on a slightly rude memory aid, the ''Bromo burp.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C12.]

Beam us up, Christie's. Starting Oct. 5, the Manhattan auction house will hold a three-day sale, ''40 Years of Star Trek: The Collection,'' of nearly 4,000 objects -- furniture, costumes and props like Tribbles, the infamous alien fur balls -- from the 5 television series and 10 feature films. Jim Mees, the set decorator on the series from 1988 to 2004, said he used mostly midcentury Modernist furniture like the armchair, top right, that appeared in the quarters of both Neelix and Torres ($200-$300). The Indonesian dresser, above left, was in Gralik's home ($100-$150), and the table, below, appeared on different sets ($200-$300). Christie's, 20 Rockefeller Plaza (49th Street at Ave. of the Americas); (212) 468-7100 or christies.com/startrek.

GARSIDE--Grenville, the members of the Robert M. Morgenthau Association, mourns the loss of our dear friend and former colleague as an Assistant United States Attorney. Grenville was an outstanding lawyer and a fine human being. He will be sorely missed, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Robert M. Morgenthau

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 U.S. Claims Shiite Cleric Has Lost Control of Militia Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite Iraqi cleric, has lost control of portions of his Mahdi Army militia, which is splintering off into freelance death squads and criminal gangs, a senior coalition intelligence official said. A14 A German Call to Restore Opera The participants at a conference for representatives of Germany's government and its Muslim population would like to see the Deutsche Oper of Berlin reinstate the Mozart opera it canceled, said Wolfgang Schauble, the interior minister. A10 U.S. Warns Sudan Over Darfur Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice raised the threat of more international sanctions against Sudan if the government did not stop military operations in the Darfur region and unconditionally accept a United Nations peacekeeping force. A14 Iran and Europe Begin Talks The European Union's foreign policy chief and Iran's senior nuclear negotiator met in an effort to resolve the dispute over Iran's nuclear program, after the Iranian representative, Ali Larijani, had twice postponed meetings with Javier Solana, the European foreign policy official. A14 Israel Releases Hamas Official An Israeli military court released the Palestinian deputy prime minister, Nasser al-Shaer, one of more than 30 Hamas lawmakers and cabinet ministers in the Hamas-led government who have been detained by the Israelis over the past three months. A10 Hague Court Sentences Serb A senior wartime leader of Bosnian Serbs, Momcilo Krajisnik, was sentenced by judges at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague to 27 years in prison for his role in the violent campaign to turn large parts of Bosnia into an ethnically homogeneous Serbian region. A8 NATIONAL A16-21 House Passes Detainee Bill As Senate Begins Debate Congress took major steps toward establishing a new system for interrogating and trying terrorism suspects as the House approved legislation sought by President Bush and the Senate defeated efforts to alter the measure. A20 Maine Reopens Salmon Season Maine, the last American bastion of wild Atlantic salmon, has opened its first wild salmon season in seven years, after closing its rivers to salmon fishing because of scarcity. A16 Two Die in Hostage Crisis An unidentified gunman and a teenage girl he had taken hostage in a high school southwest of Denver both died as a SWAT team stormed a classroom in an attempt to save the student and the gunman opened fire, shooting her and then himself, the police said. A16 Refugee Admissions Decline The number of refugees admitted to the United States fell 23 percent this year because of provisions in two antiterrorism laws that have sharply reduced the number of refugees resettled here, State Department officials said. A21 Governor Bush Split on Law Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has been speaking out about the No Child Left Behind Law, mixing dollops of praise for it with measured criticisms. He has been caustic, for instance, about the requirement that 100 percent of the nation's students be proficient in reading and math by 2014. A1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Diabetes Trial Falls Short A new study finds that transplants of insulin-making cells, which reversed severe diabetes in an initial trial, have not lived up to their early promise. The cell transplants did free patients from insulin shots, but only temporarily. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 U.S. Investigating Pirro On Talk of Spying on Spouse Federal prosecutors said they were investigating whether Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for attorney general of New York, and Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, illegally taped conversations of Ms. Pirro's husband last year to determine if he was having an affair. A1 Third Mistrial in Gotti Case For the third time in just over a year, a federal jury failed to reach a verdict in the racketeering prosecution of John A. Gotti, the former head of the Gambino crime family. The deadlock allowed him to walk free even though jurors said they believed that he was guilty of one of the main accusations against him. A1 Menendez's Extended Family Senator Robert Menendez comes across as a textbook Democrat at home in northern New Jersey, but in South Florida, Cuban-Americans and others hail him as a freedom fighter for his fervent anti-Castro views, and revere him as an adopted son who has done well for himself. B1 HOUSE & HOME F1-8 Co-ops Make a Comeback After a fallow period in the 1980's and much of the 90's, residential co-ops, where students cook and clean for themselves, have undergone a renaissance at the University of Texas and on other campuses across the country. F1 OBITUARIES B7 Iva Toguri D'Aquino The Japanese-American convicted of treason in 1949 for broadcasting propaganda from Japan to American servicemen in World War II as the seductive but sinister Tokyo Rose, she was 90. The United Nations selects its next secretary general this fall through a series of straw polls. The third of these -- the most decisive to date -- will be held today. In the vote, the 15 members of the Security Council ''encourage,'' ''discourage'' or venture ''no opinion'' on each of the candidates. To win, a candidate must have at least nine encouraging votes and no discouragement from any of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The winner is then presented to the General Assembly for ratification. The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates to respond to two questions. First, we asked them to discuss an avoidable mistake the United Nations had made within the last five years. Second, we asked them what major reform they would undertake as secretary general. Five candidates gave us their answers.

A caption in some copies yesterday with a grouping of front-page television images that illustrated the trend toward negative political advertisements referred incorrectly to the opponent of Joe Donnelly, who was shown in an ad. The opponent, Chris Chocola, a Republican of Indiana, is a man. Another caption gave an incorrect spelling in some copies of the given name of the Democratic candidate challenging John Sweeney, Republican of New York. She is Kirsten Gillibrand, not Kristen.

Last month, architecture students at Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, led by their professor, Nader Tehrani, top right, installed a transparent, undulating, sometimes gleaming, sometimes misty polycarbonate structure, top, outside the school's architecture building. The $70,000 installation was the result of a year's research by the students on transforming flat polycarbonate into three-dimensional structures. ''It's a sheet material, but because of its pliability, it has the ability to bend and twist,'' said Mr. Tehrani, a partner at Office dA, a design firm in Boston. He and the students started with a seat, he said, and ''grew the structure out of that.'' At its base, top left, the piece, which is held together by small rivets, looks like stacked horizontal ribbons and functions as a bench. As it rises, right, the ribbons twist into a series of four-sided openings before coming together to rest on top of an existing concrete beam that helps frame the entrance to the building. ''It rotates out and creates this bubbly effect, almost like it fizzles open,'' Mr. Tehrani said.

MOVING a toddler from a crib to a bed is a big step. Not all parents want a young child to go directly into a twin-size bed, which can seem vast compared with a crib, as well as uncomfortably high off the floor. Smaller bed frames, many of which accommodate a standard crib-size mattress (28 by 52 inches), can make the transition easier. And the styles go from sleek and modern to whimsical, to suit every taste. (None described here come with mattresses.) 1. The platform of Amar, a toddler bed that holds a crib-size mattress, is 42 by 58 inches. It comes in walnut and has removable side rails; $1,875 from moderntots.com or (877) 289-0453. 2. The Hensvik bed frame, with a side rail, looks like a little daybed. It takes a mattress 27 1/2 by 63 inches, larger than a crib size but smaller than a twin; $89.99 at Ikea, ikea.com (800-434-4532 for store addresses). 3. The Oeuf Toddler Bed by Sophie Demenge and Michael Ryan, designers in Brooklyn, is 54 by 30 inches and sits six inches off the floor. It comes in white with a birch platform, or in white with walnut. The bed takes a crib-size mattress and costs $516 in birch and $536 in walnut; babygeared.com or (888) 868-8139. 4. Petra is a toddler bed by Jenny Argie and Andrew Thornton, another Brooklyn design team. It has detachable side rails and comes in five finishes: white, birch, red maple, walnut and cherry. The eight-inch-high platform is 60 by 36 inches and holds a crib mattress; $395 from argington.com or (800) 482-0522. 5. The Red Race Car Toddler Bed is 53 by 29 inches and holds a crib mattress. The shape of the bed -- as unusual as it is familiar -- is intended to appeal to young car enthusiasts; $199.99 from toddlerbeds.com or (800) 608-9695. 6. Mammut is a junior bed that takes a mattress 63 by 27 1/2 inches (larger than a crib mattress, but smaller than a twin). It comes in pink with stubby red feet or blue with blue feet; $139 at Ikea, ikea.com or (800) 434-4532.

STICHMAN--Murray James age 90, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Queens and formally from Kings Point, Long Island on September 25th 2006. Born in Brooklyn, son of Abraham and Fanny Stichman, brother of deceased Arnold and Bert, survived by beloved wife, Rita, son, Barton, daughter, Laurie and brother Bob, grandchildren Miles and Brian. His love, devotion and generosity to all in his family will live in their hearts forever. His wonderful sense of humor, intelligence, combined with his genuine caring for everyone will never be forgotten. A formidable tennis player, golfer, and world traveler with his wife, he enjoyed all aspects of his life. Retired as President of the Roy Rasol Fuel Oil Company, Pelham, NY, World War II Veteran. His positive spirit and compassion was a gift and an inspiration to us all! Memorial Service will be October 22 at Temple Emanuel, Great Neck, NY.

An article on Monday about a shootout at a Long Island home that left a 9-year-old boy in critical condition misidentified the homeowner. According to property records, the home is owned by Luigi and Joanne Mucciacciaro, not by Albert R. Aloisi, who is a tenant.

Republican officials announced Wednesday that they had chosen Minneapolis and St. Paul as the site of the party's 2008 presidential nominating convention. It is the first time in nearly three decades that they have selected a site in the Midwest, which has become increasingly contested by both parties.

A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about textiles on sale at Penn & Fletcher, a custom-embroidery company in Long Island City, gave an incorrect address. It is 21-07 41st Avenue (not 41st Street).

COMPUTERIZED swing simulators, once available only to golf pros at exorbitant prices, now allow players to wield their drivers and irons at home for under $300. Far from the social crowd on the green, players can concentrate on the essentials: consistency of their shots and tweaking their tempo so their down swing is much faster than their backswing. The setup is simple. Users strike an actual ball (ideally into a net) while watching a course on screen. For those who prefer to spend time on the links while improving their game, golf watches make it possible to track statistics, if a player is willing to patiently enter them after each shot. Some even include heart rate monitors to alert a stressed player when his or her heart rate spikes. Others have internal sensors that can compare the ratio of backswing to downswing.

Six weeks before Election Day, the Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate. In Virginia, a state that few expected to be seriously competitive, Senator George Allen looks newly vulnerable after a series of controversies over charges of racial insensitivity, strategists in both parties say. In Tennessee, another Southern state long considered safely red, Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., a Democrat, has run a strong campaign that has kept that state in contention.

An article in Business Day yesterday about high-ranking auto executives at the Paris Motor Show misidentified the Chinese automaker that caused a stir when it displayed a subcompact at the Detroit auto show in January. The company is Geely, not Chery.

FREID--Herman Louis, age 82, of Boca Raton, FL and Barrington, RI, passed away peacefully on September 26, 2006. Devoted former husband of Nina Freid. Beloved father of David, Laura & her husband David, Jocelyn and Alice & her husband Dan. Cherished Papa Heshy of Michael, Rachel and Galen. Loving brother of Jack and devoted brother-in-law and friend of Sylvia & Gilbert, Doris & Jerry, Rita & Tom, Sally & Gerry, Bobbi, Max, and Irwin. Loyal friend to many at Young Israel in Long Beach and Chabad West Boca. Publisher of Uncommon Common Sense and a founder of the World Combat Veterans Foundation and the Shelter Rock Jewish Community Center, Herman was an entrepreneur with a zest for life and a love of ideas. He will be remembered by all for his warmth and devotion to family, community and Judaism. His spirit will resonate in our hearts forever. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 631 Amsterdam and 91st St, NYC on Friday September 29 at 12pm. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Chabad West Boca, 9040 Kimberly Blvd, Boca Raton, FL 33434.

Pop Charts: Justin Timberlake Rolls On Justin Timberlake, below, has fended off a challenge from Clay Aiken to extend his reign atop the Billboard 200 chart for a second week, with estimated sales of 217,000 copies of ''FutureSex/LoveSounds'' (Jive), bringing the total to 901,000 despite a drop of 68 percent in sales this week. Mr. Aiken's new entry, ''A Thousand Different Ways'' (RCA), stood at No. 2, with 205,000 sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Another newcomer, ''The Dutchess'' (will.i.am/A&M), the solo debut album from the Black Eyed Peas vocalist Fergie, finished third with 142,000 sold. Kenny Chesney's ''Live: Those Songs Again'' (BNA) took fourth place on the 200 chart with 137,000 copies sold, enough for first place on the Billboard Top Country Albums chart. John Mayer's ''Continuum'' (Aware/Columbia) dropped to fifth place from second, with 133,000 in sales, and in its third week in release Beyoncé's ''B'Day'' (Columbia) slipped to sixth place from third, with 91,000 sales. Turmoil at Auction Of Paintings by Hitler Protesters disrupted bidding on watercolors attributed to Hitler at an auction on Tuesday in Lostwithiel, a town in Cornwall, England, the BBC reported. One was Aaron Barschak, left, a self-styled ''comedy terrorist'' who in 2003 wore a pink dress, false beard and Osama bin Laden-style turban, and scaled the walls of Windsor Castle to crash Prince William's 21st birthday party. The other was an unidentified man dressed as Hitler. They were ejected from the auction of 21 works and 2 pencil sketches, which fetched a total of $224,000. Mr. Barschak said he was protesting because he found the sale offensive, and his wife, Tamara, said: ''If it was in London, there would have been protests. Adolf Hitler was a mass murderer, and to make money from that is wrong.'' Some relatives of Holocaust survivors also denounced the auction of the art, found in an old suitcase in an attic in Belgium, near where Hitler served in World War I. Ian Morris, the auctioneer, said: ''These are historical documents, and we can't change history. Maybe it's not so bad to bring this man back to the fore, so the things he did are never forgotten.'' Robert Frost Poem Is Discovered A previously unknown poem by Robert Frost (1874-1963) is to be published on Monday in The Virginia Quarterly Review. Found by a graduate student, Robert Stilling, in a collection of books and manuscripts bought by the University of Virginia, the 35-line poem, ''War Thoughts at Home,'' was written in 1918, not long after Frost's friend and fellow poet Edward Thomas was killed in World War I. It deals with a woman who learns that her husband has died in combat. In the Virginia review it is accompanied by critical essays by Glyn Maxwell, poetry editor of The New Republic, and by Mr. Stilling. Paris Hilton Charged Paris Hilton, below, was charged yesterday with drunken driving after her arrest earlier this month, Reuters reported. Ms. Hilton, 25, faces a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine, but Frank Mateljan, a spokesman for the Los Angeles city attorney, said first-time offenders were often given probation and required to attend alcohol counseling. Ms. Hilton, accused of driving under the influence of alcohol and driving with a blood-alcohol level above the California legal limit of .8 percent, said after her arrest that she had spent the day shooting a music video and had a drink on an empty stomach at a charity party. Crocodile Hunter Had a Premonition Steve Irwin, television's Crocodile Hunter, always believed he would die young, but not that he would be killed by an animal, his widow, Terri Irwin, said in an interview broadcast yesterday, The Associated Press reported. ''I never thought it would be an animal; he never thought it would be an animal,'' Ms. Irwin told the Nine Network in Australia. ''I thought he would fall out of a tree; he thought it would be a car accident.'' Mr. Irwin, 44, died when he was stabbed in the chest by the barb of a stingray on Sept. 4 while filming a television show on the Great Barrier Reef. Ms. Irwin said her husband ''had a very strong conviction'' that he would die early. ''To the point where I'm grateful, in a way, because we're prepared,'' she said.

The pulsating sound of the reggaeton CD forced Albert Pujols to raise his voice to be heard. For the first time in more than a week, joy flowed through the St. Louis Cardinals' clubhouse Wednesday night thanks to Pujols, and those parallels to the 1964 Phillies seemed out of place -- for now. Pujols may have saved the Cardinals' postseason hopes with what Manager Tony La Russa called his biggest hit of the season. In the eighth inning, with the Cardinals four outs away from their eighth consecutive loss, Pujols pulled a long three-run homer over the Big Mac Land sign into the third deck in left field to beat San Diego, 4-2.

Karim Mehdi, a Moroccan suspected of having links with two men involved in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, went on trial in Paris on a charge of ''criminal association in connection with a terrorist enterprise.'' Arrested in 2003, he is the only person to face charges arising out of a sweeping French investigation into the 2001 attacks. According to documents read in court, he was in contact with Ziad al-Jarrah, the hijacker pilot of United Airlines Flight 93, as well as Ramzi bin al-Shibh, one of the men accused of helping plan the attacks. Mr. Mehdi told the court that he met the two men only once, on a visit to Hamburg, Germany, where a cell of Al Qaeda whose members included the hijackers operated. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Wednesday raised the threat of more international sanctions against Sudan if the government did not stop military operations in the Darfur region and unconditionally accept a United Nations peacekeeping force. ''If the Sudanese government chooses confrontation -- if it continues waging war against its own citizens, challenging the African Union, undermining its peacekeeping force, and threatening the international community -- then the regime in Khartoum will be held responsible, and it alone will bear the consequences,'' Ms. Rice said during a speech to the Africa Society.

RILANDER--Arthur, age 95, of Rockville Centre, NY passed away on September 26, 2006 of natural causes. Devoted husband of Beverly for 68 years. Adored father of Harvey (Lynda) and Kenneth (Nancy); and cherished grandfather of Adam and Allison. He was loved and respected by those who knew him. He was a graduate of Fordham University '32, a decorated veteran of WWII and partner in DeLuxe Sportswear. He will be remembered by his strength of character and interest in others. He will be missed by his family and all those who knew him. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery at 11AM today.

Of the 10 party rooms at the ''21'' Club, the restaurant in midtown Manhattan, the least popular, until recently, has been the Winchester Room, a dark brown 1960's temple of machismo, left, decorated with rifles owned by the likes of John Wayne and Buffalo Bill. ''Most of the party planners are women,'' said Bryan McGuire, the general manager. To transform the room into something more feminine, Robert Zimmer and his wife, Dolores, designers in Santa Fe, N.M., created an homage to the orchid, above, with pen-and-ink drawings of the flower by Francesca Anderson, a Brooklyn artist, and live plants. The room reopened Sept. 11; 21 West 52nd Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 582-7200, 21club.com.

To the Editor: Your Sept. 25 editorial ''Chemical Plants, Still Unprotected'' does not include some basic facts. The chemical security legislation we negotiated will give the secretary of homeland security new authority to set mandatory standards for high-risk chemical plants and, equally important, to enforce those standards.

The United Nations selects its next secretary general this fall through a series of straw polls. The third of these -- the most decisive to date -- will be held today. In the vote, the 15 members of the Security Council ''encourage,'' ''discourage'' or venture ''no opinion'' on each of the candidates. To win, a candidate must have at least nine encouraging votes and no discouragement from any of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The winner is then presented to the General Assembly for ratification. The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates to respond to two questions. First, we asked them to discuss an avoidable mistake the United Nations had made within the last five years. Second, we asked them what major reform they would undertake as secretary general. Five candidates gave us their answers.

The growing number of casualties in Canada's military mission in Afghanistan and the resulting political fallout has led Prime Minister Stephen Harper to begin a campaign to reassure Canadians that it is worth the money spent and the lives lost. The pace of casualties has been growing since spring as Canada's 2,300 troops have taken on greater responsibilities in the dangerous Kandahar Province of southern Afghanistan as part of the NATO force in Afghanistan. Critics say the government spent little time preparing Canadians for the inevitable rise in casualties that would come with a larger role in the mission.

A few weeks before hurricane season, the Commerce Department blocked the release of a document describing possible links between global warming and hurricanes, according to a news article today in the journal Nature. The journal cited e-mail exchanges between officials and scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration obtained under Freedom of Information laws by the environmental group Greenpeace. Jordan St. John, a NOAA spokesman, said the document was an information sheet being prepared for journalists but not finished in time. Scientists do not agree on the influence of global warming on hurricane activity. ANDREW C. REVKIN (NYT)

Robbers struck South Africa's 800 or so armored cars at the rate of more than one a day over the last 12 months, the largest number of cash-in-transit robberies recorded since current recordkeeping began in 1996, the Police Service reported. The 383 armored-car robberies marked an increase of nearly 75 percent from the previous 12-month period. Business robberies and car and truck hijackings also rose; with armored-car robberies, those crimes are often the work of large organized gangs. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

A picture caption with an article on Sunday about Shabaa Farms, an area controlled by Israel and claimed by Lebanon, misidentified the animals shown. They are goats, not sheep. The article also misstated the size of the area. It is 10 square miles, not a 10-mile-square area.

The government decided to raise significantly the pensions of veterans who fought for France as foreigners in World War II, finally paying them the same as their French comrades in arms. The decision coincided with the release of the film ''Indigènes'' (its English title is ''Days of Glory''), which focuses on the discrimination suffered by troops from France's colonies in Africa during the war. President Jacques Chirac ordered the pension adjustment after he saw the film in a private screening. According to his spokesman, Mr. Chirac told his cabinet that the decision was ''an act of justice.'' More than 250,000 troops from France's colonies fought on the side of the Allies. The measure, which will go into effect next year, will affect about 80,000 veterans or widows from more than 20 countries and cost $140 million a year. ELAINE SCIOLINO (NYT)

A review in The Arts on Wednesday of the play ''John Ferguson'' referred incorrectly to the production. It is playing Off Broadway, not Off Off Broadway. The article also gave an incorrect telephone number for the box office. It is (212) 315-0231.

To the Editor: John Tierney (''Academy of P.C. Sciences,'' column, Sept. 26) dismisses the National Academy of Sciences report on women in the sciences as a triumph of political correctness over data. He suggests that the reason there aren't more female science faculty members at our best institutions is simple: girls just don't like hard science, and boys do.

A judge accused of taking bribes in divorce cases rejected a plea bargain yesterday, saying he wanted to go to trial. The judge, Gerald P. Garson, who has been suspended as a justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, is a central figure in a wide-ranging investigation by the district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, into political and judicial corruption. Several of Justice Garson's associates have pleaded guilty to participating in bribery. Justice Garson, 75 and sick with cancer, was offered two consecutive sentences resulting in 16 months served in a local jail, where private doctors could treat him, in exchange for a guilty plea to two minor felonies. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

The United Nations selects its next secretary general this fall through a series of straw polls. The third of these -- the most decisive to date -- will be held today. In the vote, the 15 members of the Security Council ''encourage,'' ''discourage'' or venture ''no opinion'' on each of the candidates. To win, a candidate must have at least nine encouraging votes and no discouragement from any of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The winner is then presented to the General Assembly for ratification. The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates to respond to two questions. First, we asked them to discuss an avoidable mistake the United Nations had made within the last five years. Second, we asked them what major reform they would undertake as secretary general. Five candidates gave us their answers. REDUCING the United Nations presence in East Timor was a mistake that, given the chance to step back in time, I believe we would not make again. In May 2005, we pulled out the last of the peacekeepers, who had played a prominent role since 1999 in restoring peace to a ravaged land, leaving behind a small group of civilian advisers.

Is anyone around here ready to pitch in the playoffs next week? Other than Johan Santana, that is. What about Pedro Martínez, Randy Johnson, Brad Radke, Justin Verlander, Chris Carpenter? Carpenter may be ready to pitch, despite his poor performances in his past two starts, but he may not have a team to pitch for. St. Louis hasn't yet guaranteed itself a spot in the postseason. The Cardinals have a shockingly shrinking game-and-a-half lead over Houston.
ENKEN--Leonore daughter of Gertrude and Leon, mother of Jules Feinman. A woman of great talent and wide ranging interest. Graveside Services Thursday 2pm, Riverside Cemetary, Saddle Brook, NJ.

The United Nations selects its next secretary general this fall through a series of straw polls. The third of these -- the most decisive to date -- will be held today. In the vote, the 15 members of the Security Council ''encourage,'' ''discourage'' or venture ''no opinion'' on each of the candidates. To win, a candidate must have at least nine encouraging votes and no discouragement from any of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The winner is then presented to the General Assembly for ratification. The Op-Ed page asked all seven candidates to respond to two questions. French doctors performed what they described as the first operation on a human in weightless conditions, using an Airbus 300 adapted to simulate conditions in space. In the three-hour flight over southwest France, surgeons and anesthetists in harnesses successfully removed a cyst from the arm of a 46-year-old volunteer strapped to an operating table. Their instruments were held in place by magnets. The operation was part of a program backed by the European Space Agency to develop techniques for performing surgery aboard the International Space Station or other space vehicles. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

An obituary on Wednesday by The Associated Press incorrectly reported that Paul Vance, the co-writer of the 1960 hit song ''Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini,'' died in Ormond Beach, Fla., on Sept. 6. The man who died was named Paul Van Valkenburgh, whose widow asserted that he had written the song under the name Paul Vance. The Paul Vance who wrote the song is alive, in Westbury, N.Y. A corrective article appears today on Page B7.

An article on Friday about the start of jury selection in the trial of two former students at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., accused of starting a fatal dormitory fire in 2000, misidentified the New Jersey hometown of Aaron Karol, one of the three students killed. It is Green Brook, not Dunellen.

CLARKE--Roderick. The Trustees, Headmaster, and faculty of Canterbury School mourn the passing of Roderick Clarke class of 1946, Canterbury's fourth headmaster. A true renaissance man, Rod was an exceptional teacher and great school leader who had a genius for joy, service, and friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to Rod's family. $(6$)CLARKE--Roderick, 78, of New Milford, CT and Barneveld, NY, died September 26 in Utica, NY. Graduated from Amherst in 1950; Masters from Georgetown in 1952; Honorary Doctorate from Georgetown in 1984. On faculty of Canterbury School from 1954 until retiring as headmaster in 1990. Survived by sisters Margaret Howland and Kate Cardamone, brother Brian and sister-in-law Ann Clarke, and brothers-in-law James Kernan and Richard Cardamone. Pre-deceased by sisters Marietta von Bernuth and Agnes Kernan, brother Tyler Clarke, sister-in-law Rosanne Clarke and brothers-inlaw Anton von Bernuth and George Howland. Also survived by numerous nieces, nephews and friends. Memorial Mass on September 30 at 12:30pm at Historic Old St. John's Church, John St., Utica. A day of remembrance will be held at Canterbury on November 11. Details at www.cbury.org. Donations may be made to a fund in Rod's name at Canterbury School, 101 Aspetuck Ave., New Milford, CT 06776. Rod was beloved and is missed by us all.

Georgian authorities arrested four Russian military officers in the capital, Tbilisi, and accused them of espionage, the interior minister, Vano Merabishvili, said at a news conference. Col. Gen. Yuri Baluyevsky, the chief of the general staff of the Russian armed forces, told Interfax that the arrests were an ''outrage'' and that he and the Foreign Ministry were ''taking all the necessary steps to resolve the situation.'' MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ (NYT)

SCHMELTZER--Gertrude. The Talmud teaches us that it is possible for one to die without sin and for the living to mourn without guilt. The Officers, Board of Trustees and staff of American Friends of Magen David Adom-ARMDI mourn the passing of Gertrude Schmeltzer at the age of 96. Gertrude was President of the Riverdale AFMDA Chapter and a pillar of the organization for more than 50 years. A true woman of valor, no task was too small or too daunting for her. Although she had no children, she was a second mother and grandmother to her niece, Madelon RosenSolomon, husband Larry & children Samantha & Philip. The family requests that donations in Gertrude's memory be made to ''American Friends of Magen David Adom'', 888 7th Ave, #

GREITER--Mary Jeanne (nee Bantle), on September 27, 2006, of Briarcliff Manor, formerly of the Bronx. Survived by husband Charles L., five children and 12 grandchildren. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, on Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm & 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Theresa Church, Briarcliff Manor, on Saturday at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Contributions to the Alzheimer's or American Heart Association.

CHODOSH--Alice. Wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Susan and Meryl. Dear sister of the late William Perlman and his wife Dorothy. Dear grandmother of Jenifer and David. A loving heart and inspiration to all. Services were previously held.
STEWART--Thomas. He was vocal royalty--and one of the nicest human beings you could ever meet. We were privileged to have heard and known him. Marilyn Horne The Marilyn Horne Foundation

MARKS--Theodore. It is with great sadness and sorrow that the family of Theodore ''Ted'' Marks announces his passing on September 26, 2006. Ted was born on April 2, 1919 in New York City, NY. He graduated from the City College of New York with a bachelor's in Engineering and served in the US Army during WWII, leaving with the rank of Captain. He married Rose Bengis, his childhood sweetheart, in 1943. He was an entrepreneur and founded a company, American Technical Industries, in Mt. Vernon, NY, that eventually was taken public and listed on the American Stock Exchange. Ted resided much of his life in Ardsley, Westchester County, retiring to Boynton Beach, FL, but maintaining a home in Mahopac, NY. He was active in synagogues at the Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry, NY and Temple Beth Shalom in Mahopac, NY. He served as the President of GHC. He was an avid handball, tennis player and fisherman, active until the last few years of his life. Ted is survived and will be missed by his wife of 63 years, Rose. By their four children, Arthur, Eugene, David and Irene; and by their spouses. By ten grandchildren. By their adopted daughter, Gail and her daughter. By his sister, Wilma Melamed, her spouse and their four daughters. By sister-in-law Pearl Levy and her daughter. By dozens of cousins and hundreds of friends. Ted will be remembered at a service at 11 am, Thursday, September 28th, at the King David Chapel in the Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home on 288 Main St, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549 914666-4840. Following the service there will be a cortege to Riverside Cemetery in NJ. A memorial will be held at 1 pm at 12 Mark St, Saddle Brook, NJ 07663; 201-843-7600.

Lisa Smith, a New York-based product designer, was working on a series of crescent-shaped bowls and platters for the home accessories company Magppie when Hurricane Katrina hit last year. Ms. Smith, who has many friends in New Orleans, wanted to do something to aid the city's recovery, so she called the line the Crescent collection (after the Crescent City) and arranged to donate 2 percent of net sales to Common Ground, a nonprofit organization helping the recovery effort. Available next month, the stainless steel bowls range in price from $59 for a set of four to $80 for a single large bowl; platters are $114 for a set of two. For information, magppie.com; (469) 361-7167. ARIC CHEN

Legislation Advances On Terrorism Trials Congress took major steps toward establishing a new system for interrogating and trying terrorism suspects as the House approved legislation sought by President Bush and the Senate defeated efforts to alter the measure. The House voted for extensive new rules on the questioning of suspects and on military tribunals. The Senate is expected to follow suit. PAGE A20 Iraqi Militia Is Splintering The radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr has lost control of portions of his Mahdi Army militia, which are splintering off into freelance death squads and criminal gangs, a senior coalition intelligence official said. The question of how tightly Mr. Sadr holds the militia is of critical importance to American and Iraqi officials. PAGE A14 Push to Mend a Crucial Fence Keeping the peace has not been easy for President Bush this week as he has played host to the presidents of Afghanistan and Pakistan, who blame each other for problems with the resurgent Taliban. The three dined together at the White House last night. PAGE A15 Soft Drinks a Firing Offense In an age of organic everything, childhood obesity and food allergies, the feeding and misfeeding of children has become a tense debate between parents and the babysitters they hire to oversee the care of their children. THURSDAY STYLES, PAGE G1 Music for Iraq, Accompanied by Kalashnikovs The Iraqi National Symphony Orchestra has tried to lift that country's spirits, but its musicians realize that though art can provide a brief respite from reality, it cannot stand forever as a bulwark against war. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 $40 Million Fraud Alleged Using their social and church connections, a woman, her daughter and another relative in Virginia perpetrated one of the largest mortgage frauds in American history, a lawsuit claims, reportedly amounting to at least $40 million. PAGE A19 Diabetes Treatment Setback A new study found that transplants of insulin-making cells, which reversed severe diabetes in an initial trial, have not lived up to their early promise. PAGE A16 Unraveling a Leak Scandal Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, is expected to tell Congress that she did not know of tactics used in its leak investigation. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 'Tokyo Rose' Is Dead Iva Toguri D'Aquino, the woman known as Tokyo Rose, died at age 90. Mrs. D'Aquino was convicted of treason in 1949 but received a presidential pardon in 1977. PAGE B7
TANNEY--O. Morley. Dad, we miss you on what would have been your 90th birthday. Mom, Barbara, Gail, Denis and spouses and all nine grandchildren and five great-grandchildren
I lost my girlfriend's ring today. It slipped off my finger while I was throwing away my lunch at the airport. The trashcan compacted it immediately.
Charles Walters was happily surprised when girlfriend Sarah Davie agreed to join him on a year-long trip around the world. (Producer: Michele Monteleone)
Reporter Charlie LeDuff interviews Randall Warner, a farmer in Lebanon, Kan., and his son Travis.

Who was the man, mentioned in my column today, who sold 259 billion shares of stock in CMKM Diamonds, a stock that sold for fractions of a penny, and took in $53 million from sales of the stock? And where did he get the shares?
I'll admit outright: I've never taken an economics class. I haven't donated money beyond a few dollars here and there to people set up outside stores around Christmas.
The Times's Joe Sharkey talks about traveling with pets, including Rosie, his African gray parrot.
The big news in the attorney general's race erupted just as the latest New York Times/CBS poll was wrapping up. For that reason, the numbers need to be taken with more than a grain of salt.
Adam Liptak reports on a New York Times investigation into money and politics behind state Supreme Court judges. (Produced by: Emily B. Hager)

Responding to a previous ad, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee says that Republican Michael Steele "likes puppies, but he loves George Bush."

On a recent KLM flight from Amsterdam to Kilimanjaro, I was bumped from business class to economy, despite a confirmed reservation and seat assignment, because of overbooking. The KLM agent said I'd be reimbursed for the difference between the two fares for this leg of the trip. I had paid $4,300 for my round-trip business-class ticket; on the day I booked, the lowest coach fare was $1,300, so I naively assumed KLM would reimburse me half the difference - $1,500. Eight weeks later, Northwest Airlines (a partner of KLM) credited my Visa account with $105, explaining that their calculation of the fare difference for a refund is based on an internal formula, unrelated to the relative price of the fares at the date of purchase. Do I have any recourse? - Robert Munoz, Seattle
An ad from Republican Congressman John Sweeney attacks the record of Democrat Kristin Gillibrand.
An ad featuring a faux telephone message from George W. Bush to Congressman Steve Chabot.

Giuliani's acrimonious divorce from Donna Hanover.
Hitting three subjects dear to Brazilians -- soccer, beaches and sex -- a compromising vacation video of a Merrill Lynch banker and his girlfriend has taken the South American nation by storm.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, after tackling crime and schools, now seems determined to convince the nation that living in New York City is actually good for your health.
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Sept. 24 column, "Stuff Happens Again in Baghdad."

Morgan Stanley's annual survey of chief financial officers suggests that companies are getting much more bullish about mergers and acquisitions going into 2007. However, they will face stiff -- and maybe insurmountable -- competition from financial investors as they seek out takeover targets, according to Henry McVey, Morgan Stanley's chief U.S. investment strategist.
Readers respond to Frank Rich's Sept. 17 column, "The Longer the War, the Larger the Lies."
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Sept. 29 column, "Islam and the Pope."

A lawsuit involving some well-known hedge funds has taken a bizarre turn. The New York Post reported Friday that an accountant who is a defendant in Fairfax Financial Holdings's $5 billion suit, which alleges that hedge fund SAC Capital and others engaged in a wide-ranging scheme to drive down it stock price, was actually an informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

For Daniel Gross, who writes about business for Slate (and for The New York Times), the money and attention being lavished upon social-networking Web sites like MySpace, Facebook, and YouTube carries the stench of a previous era. "Big media types" are once again talking about "monetizing eyeballs," he notes. And, he advises, "close those eyeballs for a moment, and it almost seems like 1999."
Tribune has retained Citigroup and Merrill Lynch as financial advisers, as the newspaper chain continues to explore an exploration of a sale of some of its assets.

The relatively fat fees charged by investment bankers based in the United States seem safe for now despite the fact that their less-expensive London-based counterparts are grabbing more market share, TheStreet.com's Laurie Kulikowski concludes.
The New York Republicans probably don't need any more bad news today, but here it is: Eliot Spitzer is heading for a blowout, according to our new poll. (Bet you didn't see that coming, eh?)
