(BET) BET'S TOP 25: MONEY, POWER, RESPECT -- This special counts down influential African-Americans, including Jay-Z, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Senator Barak Obama of Illinois, and Stanley O'Neal, chief executive of Merrill Lynch. Tony Rock (right) is host. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

National League Two early games turned up the pressure at night. In the Central, the Astros threw a shutout to draw within half a game of the Cardinals, who lost later at home. The Dodgers won a slugfest to pull half a game behind the Padres in the West and a game and a half ahead of the Phillies for the wild card. Their games were later. American League In the Central race, the Twins tied their game against the Royals in the ninth and won it in the 10th to pull even with the Tigers, who lost in the afternoon. Coverage, Page D4

The 36 Hours column last Friday referred imprecisely to the rivalry between Texas A&M University and Texas Christian University. When the ''Gig 'em Aggies!'' yell and hand gesture were developed 75 years ago as a taunt at T.C.U.'s horned frog mascot, the two schools were considered archrivals. That is no longer the case.

Jay-Z Raps Into History Jay-Z made history by headlining the first hip-hop concert in the Royal Albert Hall in London, on Wednesday, and Gwyneth Paltrow, right, surprised the crowd by taking to the stage to sing the chorus of ''Song Cry'' from Jay-Z's album ''Blueprint,'' the BBC reported. Jay-Z said, ''I want people to wish a happy birthday to my good friend Gwyneth Paltrow.'' Ms. Paltrow turned 34 yesterday. ''She was a bit nervous, but her performance was really excellent,'' said the 1Xtra disc jockey G Money. Other guests at the concert, in which Jay-Z was backed by a 25-piece orchestra and a disc jockey, included Ms. Paltrow's husband, Chris Martin of Coldplay; Beyoncé; and the rap star Nas. Superman Takes On the Pirates Superman has a new fight on his hands: film piracy in China. Release of the Man of Steel's latest cinematic adventure on DVD in China has been timed and priced by Warner Brothers to scuttle the pirates, Agence France-Presse reported. The company released ''Superman Returns,'' starring Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth (left), in China yesterday, two months ahead of its release in the United States and Europe, and the company issued it at an especially low price, $1.77 or, when packaged with a documentary, $3.54. The Motion Picture Association of America has estimated that more than 90 percent of films sold in China on DVD are pirated copies. Chomsky Book Still Rides The Chávez Wave Venezuela's president, Hugo Chávez, said this week that he was expecting a visit soon from the linguist and left-wing political commentator Noam Chomsky. When and if Mr. Chomsky, right, visits, perhaps he will bring a lavish gift for Mr. Chávez. Sales of his book ''Hegemony or Survival: America's Quest for Global Dominance,'' published in 2003, are continuing to surge in the aftermath of a recommendation from Mr. Chávez during a speech last week at the United Nations, where he held up a copy and advised ''those who have not read this book, to read it,'' The Associated Press reported. At that time the publisher, Henry Holt, announced a new printing of 25,000, and this week it commissioned another 25,000 paperback copies. Tara Kennedy, a Holt spokeswoman, said, ''Demand is not slowing down.'' Paris Hilton Hearing Has Been Delayed Paris Hilton's arraignment on drunken driving charges has been postponed until Dec. 5 in Los Angeles Superior Court, The Associated Press reported. A spokesman for the city prosecutors said it was not unusual for a first court date to be set back. She is not required to appear. Jeff Timmons of the 1990's boy band 98 Degrees has been sentenced to a year's probation and ordered to undergo treatment for alcohol and substance abuse, and perform 50 hours of community service. He pleaded no contest on Wednesday in Cape Canaveral, Fla., to misdemeanor charges of reckless driving and refusing to sign a citation. First Gramophone American Awards The inaugural WQXR Gramophone American Awards, honoring the year's recording achievements in American music and by American artists, were announced yesterday, the fruition of a collaboration between WQXR (96.3 FM), the classical music radio station of The New York Times, and Gramophone, Britain's pre-eminent classical records magazine. The awards went to Peter Lieberson's ''Rilke Songs,'' ''The Six Realms'' and Horn Concerto (Bridge Records); Osvaldo Golijov's ''Ayre'' (Deutsche Grammophon); and Steve Reich's ''You Are (Variations),'' released by Nonesuch. A special award went to Mark Morris, the dancer, choreographer and leader of the Mark Morris Dance Group, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary. Los Angeles Opera Plans a 'Ring' The Los Angeles Opera will introduce its Wagner ''Ring'' cycle by presenting each of the four works in seven-performance installments in the 2008-9 and 2009-10 seasons, Plácido Domingo, the general director, announced yesterday. In the summer of 2010 the company will present three full ''Ring'' cycles, performing all four operas -- ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Die Walküre,'' ''Siegfried'' and ''Götterdämmerung'' -- in order in the course of a few days. The production will be conducted by the music director, James Conlon, and directed and designed by Achim Freyer. The cast will include Mr. Domingo as Siegmund, the Ukrainian bass Vitalij Kowaljow as Wotan, the British heldentenor John Treleaven as Siegfried and the American soprano Linda Watson as Brünnhilde. Staging Soap Opera The Drama Dept. will try something different when it opens its 2006-7 season with ''The Cartells'' on Oct. 16. Written by Douglas Carter Beane (''The Little Dog Laughed''), this play about a wealthy oil family takes its cue from prime-time soap operas. The four-part series is to be presented on successive Monday nights through Nov. 6 at the Comix performance space at 353 West 14th Street, in the West Village. Patricia Heaton, below, who won two Emmys playing the wife of (Everybody Loves) Raymond, has been cast in the Second Stage Theater's production of ''The Scene,'' the black comedy by Therese Rebeck that received high praise at the 2006 Humana Festival. ''The Scene'' will begin previews on Dec. 12, with an opening date set for Jan. 11. The Mint Theater has extended its revival of ''John Ferguson,'' the 1919 St. John Ervine drama about a poor and pious Irish farmer, through Oct. 29. The run of the Bruce Norris comedy ''The Pain and the Itch'' has been extended through Oct. 15 at Playwrights Horizons. Kathryn Lipuma, executive director of the Signature Theater, will leave in the spring at the end of its August Wilson series to return to Chicago after eight years with the company. It announced a national search for her successor.

A day after the State Education Department ordered the closing of the Taylor Business Institute, a two-year commercial college, saying it was academically substandard, the college president defended the school. ''We truly feel we are delivering a quality education,'' the president, George Shu, said in an interview yesterday. On Wednesday, the department ordered Taylor, a college on West 17th Street with about 600 students, to stop operating by January. Mr. Shu said Taylor had provided the state with volumes of material showing that it had corrected deficiencies, but ''we don't feel that they read those reports.'' KAREN W. ARENSON (NYT)

GALLO--Christopher Columbus. Passed away September 23, 2006. He was the kindest, most generous, brilliantly creative person we have had the privilege to know. He will always be loved and admired not only by our family, but all his friends and colleagues in the world of interior design. From the bottom of our hearts, we love you, Chris. Patricia,Barry and Liz Berkule

Taxter & Spengemann 504 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through Oct. 7 The works in Daniel Lefcourt's second solo show at this gallery somehow survive looking as if they could have been made in 1967. At first they seem to hail from a time when Frank Stella's shaped paintings, with their repeating bands of metallic color, had painters doing everything possible to avoid conventional paint on canvas and square corners. But ultimately Mr. Lefcourt's efforts layer together enough ideas of their own to land in the present, where abstraction is neither a dead horse nor a religious calling.

H.P. FIGURES TESTIFY Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman and its current leader faced an admonishing and sometimes incredulous House subcommittee as they tried to explain why they never questioned the legal foundation of an internal spying operation. [Page C1.] SCANDAL AIRED ON CAPITOL HILL The Hewlett-Packard spying scandal turned into a spectacle as a House committee brought all the perpetrators to a packed hearing room on Capitol Hill so that lawmakers could chastise them before the television cameras. [A1.] H.P. COUNSEL RESIGNS Ann O. Baskins, the Hewlett-Packard general counsel, resigned over the company's spying case. She is the fourth official to leave the company in recent weeks or to announce an intention to do so. [C6.] INVESTOR PRESSES G.M. Kirk Kerkorian, below, the billionaire investor, said he was willing to spend another $400 million on General Motors stock in an apparent bid to pressure G.M. to redouble its efforts to explore a possible alliance with Renault and Nissan. The two sides have been talking since July 14 but with less than three weeks to go before a self-imposed deadline, the discussions appear to be stalling. [C1.] F.D.A.'S ROLE EXAMINED A federal advisory group has derided the Food and Drug Administration as a feckless watchdog unable to protect consumers from unsafe medicines. But many company executives, investors and analysts say the F.D.A. has already responded to a barrage of criticism over the last two years by quietly becoming more assertive. [C1.] THE YUAN'S RISE In the last two weeks, China has stepped up the appreciation of its currency, the yuan, producing cautious hope in the Bush administration that the Chinese government may be lifting its opposition to a revaluation that could ease China's huge trade surplus with the United States. [C1.] INSURING TERRORISM RISKS Insurance and business groups are gearing up for a battle to preserve a government program that would cover most of the losses from another major terrorist attack. [C4.] DOW MILESTONE The Dow Jones industrial average briefly rose above its record high close of 11,722.98 set on Jan. 14, 2000. It closed at 11,718.45, up 29.21 points. [C9.] EX-COMVERSE CHIEF IN COURT Jacob Alexander, former chief executive of Comverse Technology, made his first appearance before a magistrate in Windhoek, Namibia. [C4.] DISMISSALS AT PARTS RETAILER The CSK Auto Corporation, an auto parts retailer, dismissed its chief operating officer and chief administrative officer and said its chief executive was retiring, after an accounting investigation identified errors that would lead to restatements of financial results. [C9.] AHOLD WILL NOT BE PROSECUTED The Justice Department said Royal Ahold, parent of U.S. Foodservice, will not be prosecuted in connection with a criminal fraud investigation that led to charges against a top company official and a shareholder lawsuit. [C5.] HELP OFFERED TO E. COLI VICTIMS Natural Selection Foods, the California produce company at the epicenter of a recent E. coli outbreak, is taking steps to restore consumer confidence in its products and assist those who became ill after eating its tainted spinach. [A21.] REPORT ON IRAQ CONSTRUCTION In a sweeping new assessment of reconstruction failures in Iraq, a federal inspector told Congress that 13 of 14 major projects built by the American contractor Parsons that were examined by his agency were substandard. [A12.] BELGIUM FAULTS DATA DISCLOSURE The banking consortium Swift breached European privacy rules when it aided a United States antiterrorism program by providing confidential information about money transfers, Belgium's privacy protection commission concluded. [A10.] ICAHN SEEKS DIRECTORS' OUSTER The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said that he was seeking approval from shareholders of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems to remove six members of its board and bring in one of his own nominees. Mr. Icahn, who holds a 13.85 percent stake in ImClone, was elected to the 12-member board this month, together with three associates. [C5.] BANK'S COMEBACK When it comes to comebacks, Pittsburgh sports fans would point to the fairy tale Super Bowl win by the Steelers. But PNC Financial, the big regional bank that has its headquarters in downtown Pittsburgh, could run a close second. Street Scene. [C8.] INQUIRY AT BLACKBERRY MAKER Research In Motion, maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device, said it began an investigation into its handling of stock options. [C11.] YAHOO-H.P. DEAL Yahoo said it had reached a deal with Hewlett-Packard to place Yahoo's search service and other services on H.P. personal computers sold in the United States and Europe. [C11.] HEDGE FUND TURMOIL Pirate Capital, a hedge fund that takes pride in heckling management at underperforming companies, lost half its investment team this week. In addition, Pirate is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to alert the S.E.C. when it was selling stock, according to one person briefed on the inquiry. [C4.] NEW PITCH, NEW MEDIA After 10 years, John Hancock Financial Services has decided it's time to change advertising campaigns. Its new pitch, which is being taken online and to satellite radio, carries the theme, ''The future is yours.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.]

Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy chief, said Thursday that ''some important progress'' had been made in two days of talks over resolving Iran's nuclear ambitions and that more talks would be held next week. ''We have had the opportunity of being together for several hours and of working with great intensity,'' Mr. Solana said after the talks with Ali Larijani, Iran's chief nuclear negotiator. ''We have made some important progress on the elements related to how the potential negotiations can take place.''
The pace of global debt and equity underwriting slowed in the third quarter. Here is how the big investment banks ranked in underwriting and in M. & A. advising as of yesterday.

Simmering diplomatic tensions between Russia and Georgia increased significantly a day after Georgian authorities arrested at least five Russian military officers and at least 10 Georgians and accused them of spying. Russia's foreign and defense ministers demanded their immediate release, while lawmakers and others denounced Georgia with war-like rhetoric, saying the government should free the detainees by force, if necessary. Russia announced that it would withdraw its ambassador and evacuate some Russians living in Georgia. The Russian Embassy in Georgia's capital, Tbilisi, announced it had stopped issuing visas to Georgians hoping to visit Russia. The Georgian police, meantime, maintained a cordon around a building in Tbilisi used by the Russian military, which is slowly withdrawing forces it has stationed there since the collapse of the Soviet Union. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, the Democratic candidate for governor, is making inroads both in Republican strongholds and on traditional Republican issues, with voters seeing him as the most likely to improve the economy, help avert terrorism and hold taxes steady or lower them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Five weeks before the election, about 8 in 10 voters said that they had no opinion of Mr. Spitzer's Republican rival, John Faso. Mr. Spitzer, a Democrat, is supported by a majority of those surveyed not only in the Democratic-dominated city, but also in its more heavily Republican suburbs and in upstate areas.

FOSTER--Ronald M. Jr. Longtime resident of New York City died at the age of 80 on September 26, 2006, in Da Nang, Vietnam, while doing what he loved the most, traveling the world. He is survived by his loving wife, Marcia Worthing, his five children, Alison (David), Thomas (Denise), Alexander, Christopher and Geoffrey, his eight grandchildren, Justin, Zachary, William, Max, Jacob, Kelly, Alexander Jr. and John, as well as his three brothers Hugh (Rune), Theodore and Alan (Sue). Graduated from Harvard, Class of 1947, and on the editorial board of the Harvard Crimson, Ronald spent most of his career as a consultant for employee benefits and also authored a book on the subject. After retiring, Ronald served as the president of the board of trustees for the Calhoun School in Manhattan. An original season ticket holder for the Jets, a lifetime Mets fan, an avid theatergoer, a lover of the ballet and the arts, Ron was a true New Yorker. When he was 75, he returned to school and earned his Master's in American Studies from Columbia University in 2004, the oldest graduating member of his class. He will be remembered for his wit, enthusiasm, warmth, curiosity, optimism and untiring love of life. The esteemed patriarch, he cherished his family above all else, and he will be greatly missed.

A front-page article on Sept. 14 reported that the inspector general of the Interior Department had accused top officials at the agency of tolerating widespread ethical failures. The article said that the inspector general in a 2004 report had described J. Steven Griles, a deputy secretary accused of more than two dozen ethical lapses, as a ''train wreck waiting to happen.'' That quotation was taken out of context. The quotation said in full: ''Framed within the context of a train wreck waiting to happen, the Department of the Interior was presented with its most complex set of ethical issues with Mr. J. Steven Griles appointment at a time that, following years of neglect, demise and compartmentalization, the ethics program was wholly incapable of addressing them.'' The article also said that Mr. Griles resigned after the accusations against him surfaced. In fairness, the article should have made clear that his resignation came nine months after a government ethics office and his boss concluded that he had committed no ethical breach. The article also said that efforts to reach Mr. Griles for comment the night before publication were unsuccessful. But the article was posted on the Web site of The Times that night shortly after a message was left for Mr. Griles. In fairness, further efforts should have been made to contact Mr. Griles between the time of the Web posting and the final deadline for the print edition.

MACK--William. 76, of Jackson Twp, NJ. Formerly of Lincroft, NJ, died on Saturday, September 23, 2006 at home. Mr. Mack was born in Philadelphia, PA, lived in Lincroft, NJ for many years before moving to Jackson Twp. three years ago. Mr. Mack was a U.S. Army veteran. Mr. Mack was an insurance executive with 56 years of experience in the insurance industry. Mr. Mack was President of American International Marine Agency in New York City, NY; Chairman of American International Marine Agency in New York City, NY; Senior Vice President of American International Underwriters in New York City, NY; and Chairman of American Institute of Marine Underwriters, New York City, NY. Mr. Mack began his career with Insurance Company of North America in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Mack was a member of St. Thomas Lutheran Church in Brick Twp, NJ and also on the Board of Trustees of St. Thomas Christian Academy, Brick Twp, NJ. He was predeceased by his parents Conrad & Martha Mack. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Elizabeth Dickerson Mack. His daughter & son-in-law Kathleen & George Hornfeck of Jackson Twp, NJ; his son & daughter-in-law William Jr. & Ruth-Ellen Mack of Houston, TX; & by his five grandchildren Emily, Will, Michael, Lauren, and Lindsey. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral ceremony on Saturday, September 30, 2006 at 11:00 A.M. at St. Thomas Lutheran Church, 135 Salmon Street, Brick Twp, NJ 08723 with The Rev. Stanley Ellison officiating. A private cremation will follow. There are no viewing hours. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the memory of Mr. Mack to The St. Thomas Christian Academy, 135 Salmon Street, Brick Twp, NJ 08723, and would be greatly appreciated. For information and directions contact The George S. Hassler Funeral Home, 980 Bennetts Mills Rd, Jackson Twp, NJ or 732364-6808 or visit us at www. hasslerfuneralhome.com

taza taza Little Cakes Little Gallery 625 East Sixth Street, Apartment 1B, East Village Through Oct. 7 Little Cakes used to operate out of the tiny East Village apartment occupied by the gallery's founders, Hanna Fushihara Aron and David Aron, and their several pets. An article yesterday about an organization of scientists and engineers interested in science policy misidentified a government agency whose Web site briefly -- and erroneously -- suggested there was a link between having an abortion and developing breast cancer. It was the National Cancer Institute, not the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

CLARKE--Roderick. The Trustees, Headmaster, and faculty of Canterbury School mourn the passing of Roderick Clarke class of 1946, Canterbury's fourth headmaster. A true renaissance man, Rod was an exceptional teacher and great school leader who had a genius for joy, service, and friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to Rod's family. $(6$)CLARKE--Roderick, 78, of New Milford, CT and Barneveld, NY, died September 26 in Utica, NY. Graduated from Amherst in 1950; Masters from Georgetown in 1952; Honorary Doctorate from Georgetown in 1984. On faculty of Canterbury School from 1954 until retiring as headmaster in 1990. Survived by sisters Margaret Howland and Kate Cardamone, brother Brian and sister-in-law Ann Clarke, and brothers-in-law James Kernan and Richard Cardamone. Pre-deceased by sisters Marietta von Bernuth and Agnes Kernan, brother Tyler Clarke, sister-in-law Rosanne Clarke and brothers-inlaw Anton von Bernuth and George Howland. Also survived by numerous nieces, nephews and friends. Memorial Mass on September 30 at 12:30pm at Historic Old St. John's Church, John St., Utica. A day of remembrance will be held at Canterbury on November 11. Details at www.cbury.org. Donations may be made to a fund in Rod's name at Canterbury School, 101 Aspetuck Ave., New Milford, CT 06776. Rod was beloved and is missed by us all.

SULLIVAN--Kathryn (RSCJ), 101 years old, died September 22nd at the Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart in Albany, New York. Sr. Sullivan graduated from Manhattanville College in 1926 with a bachelor's degree. Two years later, she entered the Society of the Sacred Heart and, in 1937, earned a doctorate from the University of Pennsylvania. She taught history and scripture at Manhattanville College until 1970. Well recognized as a biblical scholar worldwide, Sr. Sullivan left a long legacy with generations of Manhattanville students. On behalf of the entire Manhattanville College community, we send our sincere condolences to her family and the Religious of the Sacred Heart. Richard A. Berman President, Manhattanville College

OPATUT--Joel In Remembrance of Joel Opatut. The Boards of Trustees and physicians and staff of Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Medical Center Foundation are deeply saddened by the passing of Joel Opatut on September 23, 2006. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and friends and honor the memory of a true philanthropist, whose generous spirit will live on in the community programs he so proudly supported. While we will greatly miss this remarkable individual, his legacy of compassion, generosity and human kindness will forever remain with us and continue to touch the lives of future generations. Memorial donations may be made to Joel Opatut Cardiac Rehabilitation Center at Monmouth Medical Center or the Radiation Oncology Department at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ.
To the Editor: Re ''In China, Children of the Rich Learn Class, Minus the Struggle'' (front page, Sept. 22):

Three terminals at Kennedy International Airport were locked down last night and vehicular traffic was diverted when a suspicious package was found in a nearby parking lot, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. The New York Police Department bomb squad was called in to investigate the package, which was found at 8:10 p.m. No passengers were allowed in or out of Terminals 1, 2, and 3. No arriving flights were delayed, but as of midnight five departing flights had been held up because passengers were barred from the terminals. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

Dario Robleto Fear and Tenderness in Men D'Amelio Terras 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through Oct. 14 (VanDerBeek) and Oct. 28 (Robleto) Whether by plan or accident, these side-by-side gallery debuts form a spirited seminar about different approaches to art-making. Subjects of debate include truth to materials, appropriation of images and other detritus, and the challenge of imbuing an artwork with meaning.

WHO -- Greg Davis, 49, a landscape architect and contractor from Beverly Hills, Calif. WHAT -- 1-bedroom house WHERE -- Twentynine Palms, Calif. I grew up in Hawaii, so I know about being connected to the natural life force of the land. I bought my first house in this area eight years ago to use with family and friends. They all said, ''You're from Hawaii; what are you doing in the desert?'' But the desert is very much like Hawaii. Nature has been supported, not paved over. I soon started to rent out that house, buy others in the area, and now I own 12 desert homes that I rent out through my company, Joshua Desert Retreats.

A front-page article on Wednesday about New York City's plan to bar restaurants from serving food with more than a minute amount of artificial trans fats referred erroneously to a similar proposal in Chicago. It would impose trans fat limits on restaurants with more than $20 million in annual sales, not less than $20 million.

SCHER--Pearl Crystal. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish HeritageA Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of our dear Pearl: World War II veteran, community activist and beloved member of our Museum family. We extend our condolences to her family and to her multitude of loving friends. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Ph.D., Dir. $(6$)SCHER--Pearl Crystal. Born February 24, 1915 in Brooklyn. Pearl gave of herself wholeheartedly as a teacher, assistant principal, and principal in the New York City school system, as a marine during World War II, and, in retirement, as a politician and activist. She served on the town board in Somers, New York, and--after moving to Battery Park City at the age of 85--on Community Board 1 in lower Manhattan. Pearl leaves behind many who admire and love her for her passion, her spirit, and her inspiring example. Donations should be made to Americans United for Separation of Church and State. Services Friday 9:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed separatist Kurdish Workers' Party, or P.K.K., called on his militants to begin an unconditional cease-fire. Rebel violence has surged in the past year and has spread to tourist destinations. In a statement sent to news agencies from his prison on an island near Istanbul, Mr. Ocalan said, ''Let's stop forever the armed fight.'' His guerrilla group has made a number of cease-fire declarations in the past. More than 30,000 people have died since 1984, when the militants took up arms for a separate state in the predominantly Kurdish southeast. SEBNEM ARSU (NYT)

President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan arrived here on Thursday and found himself facing accusations that his country's intelligence service had indirect ties to Al Qaeda and that his government committed widespread human rights abuses as an ally of the United States in its effort to curb terrorism. He arrived after a rocky visit in Washington, where President Bush used a White House dinner to try to mediate between the Pakistani leader and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan over their mutual accusations of responsibility for the resurgence of the Taliban, Afghanistan's former rulers.

For a second consecutive Wednesday, the CBS lineup led over all, but ABC proved a formidable challenger. CBS drew its largest audiences with a double dose of crime dramas: ''Criminal Minds'' attracted 16.5 million viewers at 9 p.m., and ''CSI: NY'' pulled in 16.1 million at 10, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 8 p.m. Harry Hamlin's departure from ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' put ABC on top for the hour, but the second installment of CBS's ''Jericho'' (11.4 million) fared well, improving over its premiere among viewers 18 to 49. At 9 and 10, ABC finished solidly in second with a clip show recapping the last two seasons of ''Lost'' (9.5 million), and a Barbara Walters ''20/20'' exclusive with Terri Irwin, the widow of Steve Irwin, the Crocodile Hunter (13.3 million). Fox and NBC trailed considerably behind for the night. ''Bones'' (7.7 million) and ''Justice'' (7.1 million) were up from a week ago on Fox, while NBC's two-hour ''Biggest Loser'' (7 million) and ''Kidnapped'' (6.3 million) continued to struggle. On the CW, a positive Week 2 for ''America's Next Top Model'' (4.8 million) -- first among adults 18 to 34 for the 8 p.m. hour -- gave a boost to the fourth-season premiere of ''One Tree Hill'' (3.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

In the days since Jeanine F. Pirro announced that she was the subject of a federal investigation into whether she illegally taped her husband’s conversations, there has been one major player in state politics who has been little seen or heard: Andrew M. Cuomo, Ms. Pirro’s Democratic rival for attorney general.

Four Russian intelligence officers accused this week of espionage faced a court in Tbilisi, the capital, and were ordered to be held for two months. A fifth officer had been released earlier. The police and security forces continued to surround the Russian military headquarters in the capital, in an attempt to detain another officer accused of spying. The case has severely strained the already tense relationship between Russia and Georgia. On Thursday, Russia recalled its ambassador from Tbilisi, and yesterday it flew out more than 70 diplomatic staff members and their families, Interfax reported.

The United Nations said Israel has refused to give its investigators access to the military commanders responsible for directing a precision-guided bomb attack on a post in southern Lebanon on July 25 that killed four unarmed observers despite more than a dozen warnings during the day from United Nations officials that its people were under fire. Israel has said the airstrike was an error.

Mayor Ken Livingstone of London defended his policy of eradicating pigeons from Trafalgar Square amid a stir over the cost. The Liberal Democrats, Britain’s third party, calculated that since 2003 the cost of hiring a pair of hawks — along with their handler — to fly over the square to frighten away the pigeons has been £226,000, or $423,000. Altogether, the party said, 2,500 pigeons have disappeared, putting the average cost per bird at £90, or $168. “At a cost of £90 per pigeon, serious doubts should be raised about the effectiveness of the scheme as well as its value for money,” said Mike Tuffrey, a Liberal Democrat from London. About 1,000 pigeons remain, and a spokesman for Mr. Livingstone said that the control measures would continue “as long as necessary,” adding that they helped “reduce the cost of cleaning the architecture in the square.

An Israeli military strike killed two Palestinian brothers, 16 and 13, as they approached a rocket launcher near northern Beit Hanun. The military said the two were there to collect the launcher, used to fire five rockets into southern Israel in recent days. Medical workers at Kamal Adwan Hospital said it was not clear whether the boys rode their bike toward the launcher to retrieve it or out of curiosity.

Natascha Kampusch, the schoolgirl held captive in a cellar for eight years before she escaped last month, has left the Vienna hospital where she had been staying since her escape and moved into her own apartment. “She is starting a new life in freedom,” said her lawyer, Gerald Ganzger. Ms. Kampusch, 18, will continue to have counseling.

The state-owned newspaper The Zambia Daily Mail, citing a survey of voters leaving polls, reported that Michael Sata, a populist former cabinet minister, held a commanding lead over the incumbent, Levy Mwanawasa.
Esperanza Spalding sang and played Cuban and Brazilian grooves with energy and optimism at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday.

The gunman who killed a 16-year-old girl and then himself in a small mountain town southwest of Denver on Wednesday had sent a rambling 14-page letter to a relative that day that officials said made reference to suicide and his pending death. In a news conference, Sheriff Fred Wegener of Park County said the gunman, Duane Morrison, sent the letter from a post office 30 miles from Bailey, where Mr. Morrison held six girls hostage at the Platte Canyon High School before killing one of them, Emily Keyes. The Associated Press reported that a brother received the letter. A motive for the attack is still unknown.
The government should invest more money in understanding hurricanes because they are so deadly and expensive, according to a draft of a federal report.

The military dismissed a rape charge against an Air Force Academy graduate whose case had been delayed twice because the accuser’s therapist refused to turn over her medical records. Maj. Gen. Marc E. Rogers of the Air Force issued the dismissal against the graduate, Capt. Joseph Harding, who had been accused of raping a woman at the academy in 2000. Captain Harding maintains his innocence. Jennifer Bier, the therapist, called the military’s actions “unconscionable.”.

The Archdiocese of Los Angeles could sign a $60 million settlement with dozens of people who said they were victims of sexual abuse within days, several lawyers said. The settlement being drafted by lawyers for the archdiocese, the nation’s largest, and the accusers would give 45 claimants a total of $60 million, said Venus Soltan, a plaintiffs’ lawyer. It would encompass accusers whose claims are not covered by the church’s insurance policies, Ms. Soltan said. A spokesman for the archdiocese, Tod Tamberg, said that both sides were working on a deal but that similar negotiations fell apart last year.
A redwood tree discovered in a remote California forest has turned out to be the world’s tallest tree, edging out one nearby that had been the titleholder.
Consumers can resume buying and eating fresh spinach, the Food and Drug Administration said.

The husband of the state controller, Kathy Augustine, was charged with her murder after an autopsy found she had been poisoned. The husband, Chaz Higgs, 42, was taken into custody in Hampton, Va., nearly three months after Ms. Augustine, 50, died in a Reno hospital. Results of the autopsy, conducted by the F.B.I., were returned to Reno police this week and showed that Ms. Augustine had been injected with succinylcholine-chloride, a drug that causes paralysis. Ms. Augustine collapsed on July 8 and died four days later. Mr. Higgs, a nurse, told the police she had had a heart attack.

In the recorded literature of jazz — and of American music, really — there is no greater document than the stack of three-minute sides made by Louis Armstrong for the OKeh label in the mid- to late 1920’s. Leading two successive bands billed as his Hot Five (and, briefly, a Hot Seven), Armstrong delivered a series of performances bursting with bravura and invention, in the process introducing a heroic new language of improvisation.

A headline in some copies on Thursday with an article about the selection of the site for the 2008 Republican National Convention omitted one of the two cities chosen. Besides Minneapolis, St. Paul -- and its Xcel Energy Center -- will be one of the host cities.

The On Baseball column yesterday about the Mets' postseason chances without pitcher Pedro Martínez misattributed the quotation, ''What a revoltin' development.'' It was Chester A. Riley's catchphrase in ''The Life of Riley,'' a sitcom in the 1950's, not Jimmy Durante's.

The New York Film Festival began in 1963, a high point in what is now recalled as a golden age of international art cinema: the storied epoch when international masters like Bergman, Fellini, Kurosawa and Godard were at the height of their powers, and their work could find an American audience whose boundless passion made up for its limited size. It is thus fitting that, alongside this year's festival (and continuing beyond it), the Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting a retrospective celebrating the 50th anniversary of Janus Films. Janus, founded by two farsighted theater owners, has probably brought more certified masterpieces to American screens than any other distributor of any kind. Thirty of these -- including ''The Rules of the Game,'' Jean Renoir's sublime and permanently timely comedy of class struggle (above), which opens the program tonight -- will be shown in new 35-millimeter prints over the next four weeks. Cash in your vacation time and plan to spend a month at the Walter Reade Theater on West 65th Street (or else take out a loan and purchase the lavish 50-DVD, 50th-anniversary Janus box set, ''Essential Art House,'' available Oct. 24). The golden age is now. A. O. SCOTT

A pop music entry in Weekend yesterday for Madness at the Canal Room in TriBeCa on Tuesday night misidentified the performer. It is the rapper Madness, not the British ska band of the same name.

State of Denial Bush at War, Part III By Bob Woodward 560 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30. In Bob Woodward's highly anticipated new book, ''State of Denial,'' President Bush emerges as a passive, impatient, sophomoric and intellectually incurious leader, presiding over a grossly dysfunctional war cabinet and given to an almost religious certainty that makes him disinclined to rethink or re-evaluate decisions he has made about the war. It's a portrait that stands in stark contrast to the laudatory one Mr. Woodward drew in ''Bush at War,'' his 2002 book, which depicted the president -- in terms that the White House press office itself has purveyed -- as a judicious, resolute leader, blessed with the ''vision thing'' his father was accused of lacking and firmly in control of the ship of state.

In the days since Jeanine F. Pirro announced that she was the subject of a federal investigation into whether she illegally taped her husband's conversations, there has been one major player in state politics who has been little seen or heard: Andrew M. Cuomo, Ms. Pirro's Democratic rival for attorney general. Mr. Cuomo, whose calendar going into the Sept. 12 Democratic primary was filled with nearly daily campaign activities, has not held a public event since Wednesday afternoon, when he announced at a news conference an endorsement from an abortion rights advocacy group in Westchester. And he has no public events scheduled until Tuesday.

The Indian economy grew at an unexpectedly brisk pace of 8.9 percent in the second quarter of 2006, propelled by a sharp turnaround in its once-laggard manufacturing industry, the government reported. Stifling regulations and patchy infrastructure have for years kept India from emulating China's emergence as a factory to the world. But with policies changing and companies finding ways to get around the constraints, manufacturing output in the three months through June grew 11.3 percent from a year earlier, beating a 10.6 percent expansion in the roaring Indian services trade of call centers and software shops. ANAND GIRIDHARADAS (NYT)

KOPPEL--Yehuda. The Hillel family notes with sadness the passing of Yehuda Koppel of New York City. We are forever indebted to proud Zionists like Mr. Koppel who believed in, and risked their life for, the creation of the State of Israel. The seeds he planted allowed Israel to grow and flourish. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter, Abigail Koppel Wexner, and sonin-law, Leslie H. Wexner, and to the entire Koppel family. May the marvelous legacy he left for the Jewish people give them comfort at this difficult time. Edgar M. Bronfman, Lynn Schusterman, Michael Steinhardt, Hillel International Board of Governors

Ayman al-Zawahri, Al Qaeda's deputy leader, branded President Bush a ''lying failure'' and Pope Benedict XVI a ''charlatan'' in a video released Friday. The 18-minute video, Mr. Zawahri's second in a month, also responded to recent reports that senior members of Al Qaeda had been transferred to the United States detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba; to the planned deployment of peacekeeping troops in Darfur; and to Pope Benedict's controversial comments in a lecture this month in which he cited a 14th-century description of aspects of Islam as ''evil and inhuman.''

DOLSON--William, died Saturday, September 23, 2006 at the Northeast Center for Special Care in Lake Katrine, NY, after battling lung cancer. Bill was born in Beacon, NY on September 18, 1951 and graduated from Our Lady of Lourdes High School, Poughkeepsie, NY in 1969. A Magna Cum Laude graduate in 1973 from Fordham University with a degree in philosophy, Bill was chosen to be the Philosophy Graduate Fellow at the University of Pennsylvania in 1974. William Dolson was a man of great passion, humor and supreme intellect whose logic and philosophical approach to life touched the lives of many people; he will be sorely missed. Bill is survived by his mother and father, Margaret and William A. Dolson and his brothers Robert and Paul. Bill passed peacefully and without pain; he will be cremated and his ashes spread along the Hudson River Valley in accordance with his wishes. Memorials may be made to Hospice Inc., 374 Violet Ave, Poughkeepsie, NY.

A sports article yesterday about a demand by the president of the Dallas police union that Terrell Owens of the Cowboys apologize for disputing the account of officers who responded to a 911 call from Owens's house gave an incorrect spelling in some copies of the name of a prescription painkiller the officers said he had overdosed on. It is hydrocodone, not hydrocordone.

LYONS--Rabbi Maurice, of St. Louis, MO, on September 28th, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Berenice Lyons. Devoted father of Simcha and Tiki. Adored grandfather of Yakov and Ruchie, David and Rachel, Avi and Ilana, Jenny and Benjamin. Dear great-grandfather of nine. Burial in Jerusalem

Standard Chartered, the British bank, said it would buy Hsinchu International Bank for $1.2 billion in the largest foreign purchase of a Taiwanese bank. Standard Chartered's chief executive, Mervyn Davies, below, said during a conference call that the acquisition doubled the number of Mandarin speakers within the bank. Standard Chartered, which already derives two-thirds of its business from Asia, has been looking to grow in Taiwan for some time, Mr. Davies said. The bank is paying more than a 30 percent premium to Hsinchu's closing stock price yesterday. C. W. Wu, Hsinchu's president, said that the offer had the support of Hsinchu's board.

Randy Johnson has a herniated disk in his lower back and the Yankees have a potential problem. Penciled in as the Game 3 starter next week in the American League division series, Johnson may instead be sidelined for part or all of the postseason. ''I can't guarantee you that he'll be there for us,'' Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, referring to the postseason. ''But I'm not counting him out at all.''

LINDER (LOSKOWITZ)--Ira Roy. 90, born August 2, 1916 Brooklyn, NY died September 29, 2006, of Lake Worth, FL. Devoted son of Archibald and Claire Loskowitz. Loving husband of 65 years to Sylvia Radin Linder. Devoted father of deceased Theodore Charles and surviving sons Andrew and Arthur. Adored father-in-law of Arlene Linder, V.J. Horgan and Rise Linder. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Linder, Eric Linder, Jacob Linder, and Dana Linder. Dedicated brother-in-law of Rose Ullman and Ruby Radin. Admired uncle of Amy and Ellen Ullman and Theodore Radin and Geri (Radin) Glanzman. Ira was a man of strength and determination. His message for all of us was that the sun will always rise tomorrow. My - T - Fine. Graveside services Sunday October 1st 10:30 A.M. at New Montefiore Cemetery, Exit 35, Southern State Parkway, Wellwood Ave. Pinelawn, NY 631-249-7000.

From the highest rows of the upper deck, the commotion quickly worked its way down through Busch Stadium in St. Louis in the bottom of the fifth inning last night until most of the crowd of 41,718 was doing something foreign yet strangely appropriate -- the tomahawk chop. Cardinals fans peering into the press box, where televisions showed the Braves-Astros game, cheered and chopped to celebrate the final out of Atlanta's 4-1 victory. By the time the score went up on the main scoreboard moments later, the chop chant was working its way around the stadium.

To the Editor: Re ''From 'Death Ship' to Cruise Ship'' (news article, Sept. 23): Although fault in the 1956 collision was never determined by a court, and is still debated, the evidence in a post-collision hearing showed that the Andrea Doria sped through dense fog and failed to use its radar equipment properly and that at the last minute, her master ordered a hard turn to port at full speed that brought his ship straight into the path of Stockholm.

Financial Impact of Film Piracy A new report from the Institute for Policy Innovation, a conservative Texas-based research group, has found that motion-picture piracy not only hurts the movie industry but also results in the loss of tens of thousands of jobs outside the industry and costs billions of dollars in lost wages, lost tax revenue and diminished overall economic output. The report was released yesterday at a Washington news conference held in conjunction with the United States Chamber of Commerce's third annual antipiracy and counterfeiting summit. As a starting point, the report, written by Stephen E. Siwek, used a study commissioned by the Motion Picture Association of America in 2004 and released in May that determined what revenues movie companies would have earned if pirated products had not been available; it found a loss of $6.1 billion in 2005. According to the new report, a domino effect ensues, affecting many other industries. Nashville Celebrates Bluegrass Tim O'Brien's ''Look Down That Lonesome Road'' won song of the year at the 17th annual International Bluegrass Music Awards, presented onstage at the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville on Thursday night. Mr. O'Brien, right, also walked away with the award for male vocalist of the year. For the eighth consecutive year, Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder was the instrumental group of the year, and this year's top vocal group was Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver. The event was part of the World of Bluegrass festival, which has taken over Nashville since Monday. Events continue this weekend and include today's Fan Fest, a marathon concert at the Nashville Convention Center that will include appearances by the Grascals (entertainer of the year at Thursday's awards show) and Hot Rize, Mr. O'Brien's Colorado-based band. Harsh Words for Bush From Oliver Stone At the San Sebastian International Film Festival in Spain on Thursday, the director Oliver Stone, left, strongly criticized President Bush, The Associated Press reported. ''We have destroyed the world in the name of security,'' he said before a screening of ''World Trade Center,'' his latest film, which stars Nicolas Cage and Michael Peña as Port Authority police officers trapped in the rubble on Sept. 11, 2001. ''From Sept. 12 on, the incident was politicized, and it has polarized the entire world,'' Mr. Stone said. Also at the festival, the Iranian director Bahman Ghobadi said it had become hard to work in Iran, where his film ''Half Moon'' was banned because a woman sings in it.

A picture in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about new research into hysteria was published in error, based on information from the photo agency. It showed an ancient bas-relief depicting Asclepius, the god of healing and medicine. It was not of Hippocrates, who suggested marriage as a treatment for hysteria.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 U.S. May Cut Funds for Iraq Over Rights Violations American officials warned Iraqi leaders that the United States might have to reduce aid to the Interior Ministry police because of a law that prohibits financing foreign security forces that commit ''gross violations of human rights.'' A1 India Depletes Its Groundwater India is running through its groundwater so fast that scarcity could threaten whole regions, drive people off the land and stunt the country's ability to farm and feed its people. Surveyors have divided the country into 5,723 geographic blocks, out of which 1,000 are considered overexploited, up from only 250 two decades ago. Nazarbayev, to the White House. A5 NATIONAL A8-11; 13 Congressman Resigns After Sexual Accusations Representative Mark Foley, Republican of Florida, resigned abruptly after being confronted with sexually explicit Internet messages he reportedly sent to under-age Congressional pages. He is accused of being the very kind of predator he had denounced as leader of the House caucus on missing and exploited children. A1 Defense Spending Bill Passes Less than a year after two bribery scandals produced bipartisan calls for Congress to overhaul the way it finances lawmakers' pet projects, the $436.6 billion military spending bill passed filled with such projects. A10 F.D.A. C10 READERS' GUIDE In its daily news pages, The Times presents both straightforward news coverage and other journalistic forms that provide additional perspective on events. These special forms -- news analysis articles, columns and others -- adhere to standards different from those of the editorial and Op-Ed pages. The news and editorial departments do not coordinate coverage and maintain a strict separation in staff and management. A readers' guide to the various forms is online: nytimes.com/readersguide

An article last Saturday about the return to New York of the ship originally known as the S.S. Stockholm, which struck and sank the Andrea Doria in 1956, referred imprecisely to some of the passengers described in accounts of the day. The description of Hungarian ballet dancers, a Hollywood actress, a Canadian nun and a group of oil executives was of a scene on the Andrea Doria.

Starting tomorrow, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on Sunday increases to $5 in the New England and Washington regions. The change reflects higher costs of paper, production and distribution. Monday through Saturday prices are unaffected.

An article in Business Day on Sept. 21 about a standoff between the publisher of The Los Angeles Times and his bosses at the Tribune Company over cutbacks referred incorrectly to Warren Christopher, a former secretary of state, who urged the company to stop making cuts. Mr. Christopher is one of 20 Los Angeles citizens who sent a letter to the company. He is not head of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce and is not president of the city's chapter of the Urban League. (Those leaders are among the 20 who lobbied the Tribune Company.)

An Israeli military strike killed two Palestinian brothers, 16 and 13, as they approached a rocket launcher near northern Beit Hanun. The military said the two were there to collect the launcher, used to fire five rockets into southern Israel in recent days. Medical workers at Kamal Adwan Hospital said it was not clear whether the boys rode their bike toward the launcher to retrieve it or out of curiosity. GREG MYRE (NYT)

An article in Business Day on Monday about the practice of surveillance within corporate America referred imprecisely to three companies that once employed Charles Mittelstadt, a security consultant who said that ''pretexting'' -- or getting information by pretending to be someone else -- could be a valuable investigative tool. While Mr. Mittelstadt indeed worked for Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Georgia-Pacific at various times, his work for the companies did not involve pretexting in any form.

700-Mile Border Fence Wins Senate Approval The Senate approved building 700 miles of fence along the Mexican border, fulfilling a demand by conservative Republicans to take steps to slow the flow of illegal immigrants. President Bush has promised to sign the bill, despite his push for a more comprehensive approach. ABC's ''Ugly Betty,'' starring America Ferrara, below, became the most-watched new show of the fall season in its Thursday night debut, besting the Sunday premiere of ''Brothers & Sisters'' on ABC by 400,000 viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. ''Ugly Betty'' drew 16.1 million viewers, lifting ABC over CBS for the night in the crucial demographic of adults 18 to 49. CBS attracted the most total viewers every hour, starting with ''Survivor: Cook Islands,'' which topped ''Ugly Betty'' with 16.6 million viewers. At 9, CBS's ''CSI'' (23.5 million) returned to form, edging out ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC (23.2 million) for the top spot, but ''CSI'' finished second by 19 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS's new drama ''Shark,'' with James Woods, led at 10 with 14.7 million viewers, but it, too, lagged among adults 18 to 49. ABC's ''Six Degrees'' (10.8 million) took second in that demographic by a 5 percent margin, while the leader, NBC's ''ER'' (14.2 million), outperformed ''Shark'' by 45 percent. BENJAMIN TOFF

A photograph of a building at the top of the Transactions column on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday was misidentified. The tallying of Zambia's presidential election was held up after a ballot shortage delayed voting in some provinces, but the state-owned newspaper The Zambia Daily Mail, citing a survey of voters leaving polls, reported that Michael Sata, a populist former cabinet minister, held a commanding lead over the incumbent, Levy Mwanawasa. Mr. Sata was reported to have healthy leads in both Lusaka and the northern Copperbelt Province, the two most populous regions. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''The Grand Delusion,'' by David Brooks (column, Sept. 28):

TIEFER--Rosalind Crost, 92, Meadowview, Mt. Vernon, NY, died September 28, 2006. Born to Brooklyn Jews of Dutch descent, graduated from Brooklyn College ('33), Juilliard, and Columbia Teachers' College. Rosalind won piano prizes and a Philharmonic scholarship, played in Simeon Bellison's Clarinet Ensemble and countless concerts, trained student bands, choruses and orchestras, directed musicals at summer camps, prepared young musicians for auditions, and taught both music and world history from 1938 to 1971 at Walton and Theodore Roosevelt High Schools. After ''retirement,'' Ros performed with the Bronx Opera, American Landmark Festivals, Hudson River Choral Society, and at Community Church of New York. After the death of her deeply loved husband Abraham David in 1981 she became an intrepid world traveller and active member of Westchester NOW and its book club. She directed Yonkers Temple Emanu-El Women's Chorus concerts at nursing homes for a decade. Ros leaves her grieving children, Leonore and Charles, daughter-in-law Hillary, and beloved grandsons Max and Roy. Her lifelong undimmable passions for great music, intellectual rigor, progressive politics, and family are her legacy. Memorial service to be announced.

To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's description of Prudence Lemokouno's last hours (''Prudence's Struggle Ends,'' column, Sept. 24) was heartbreaking, and the fact that these needless deaths are concentrated among poor, rural African women is blatantly unjust.

The United Nations said Israel has refused to give its investigators access to the military commanders responsible for directing a precision-guided bomb attack on a post in southern Lebanon on July 25 that killed four unarmed observers despite more than a dozen warnings during the day from United Nations officials that its people were under fire. Israel has said the airstrike was an error. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

Robert Downey Jr., below, an Academy Award nominee for best actor for ''Chaplin,'' will be the man behind the armor in ''Iron Man,'' the big-screen interpretation of the Marvel Comics superhero. The film, scheduled to arrive in theaters on May 2, 2008, tells the tale of Tony Stark, a wealthy industrialist, who creates a powerful suit of armor and uses it to combat a global threat. ''Iron Man'' will be directed by Jon Favreau (''Elf''), who expressed excitement about the casting on his MySpace blog. ''I can say with absolute certainty that there is no better choice,'' he wrote. ''The humor and emotional dimension he brings truly raises the bar on this project. Get ready.'' GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

DENHAM--Mary Orr Actress and author, died September 22, 2006 at age 94. She was preceded in death by her husband, Reginald Denham, with whom she collaborated on writing scripts for the theater, notably ''Wallflower'' which premiered on Broadway at the Cort Theater in 1944. She published many works of her own including the short story ''The Wisdom of Eve'' which appeared first in 1947 in Cosmopolitan Magazine and resulted in the 1950 Academy Award winning movie ''All About Eve.'' Mary is survived by nieces, Lenschen Witte and Jessica Ivan of Ohio, and step grandchildren Tamara Ustinov, Mark Warrington and Elizabeth Warrington of the UK. Services will be private.

Four Russian intelligence officers accused this week of espionage faced a court in Tbilisi, the capital, and were ordered to be held for two months. A fifth officer had been released earlier. The police and security forces continued to surround the Russian military headquarters in the capital, in an attempt to detain another officer accused of spying. The case has severely strained the already tense relationship between Russia and Georgia. On Thursday, Russia recalled its ambassador from Tbilisi, and yesterday it flew out more than 70 diplomatic staff members and their families, Interfax reported. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ (NYT)

''I'm a big fan. I know it can be abused. But if used properly, along with other punishments, a few pops can help turn a school around. It's had a huge effect here.'' ANTHONY PRICE, a middle school principal, on the corporal punishment he recently reinstated. [A1]

It's time for President Bush to go to China. I don't mean that literally, but metaphorically. It's time for George Bush to do what Richard Nixon did - perform an act whose effectiveness is a function of the fact that he is the last man anyone would have expected to do it. What would that act be? It won't be - and shouldn't be - agreeing to a face-to-face, one-on-one debate with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, if only because when you accept the other guy's invitation you cede him the initiative and the position of leadership, and we all know that George Bush will never willingly do that. No, it has to be something that a) makes clear that he is the one in charge, and b) is so surprising and (apparently) out of character that its very announcement alters the geopolitical landscape and disarms criticism in advance.

An essay last Sunday about Tasti D-Lite and its customers referred incorrectly to its business structure and its relationship with its parent company, and also misstated the location of that company’s corporate headquarters. Tasti D-Lite is a trademark of A Matter of Taste Inc.; it is not a corporation. In addition, it operates under a licensing model; it is not a franchise. A Matter of Taste Inc. has its offices on the Upper East Side, not near Herald Square.

National League It's all over for the Phillies; their spirited late-season run came to an end yesterday when victories by the Dodgers and the Padres knocked them out of wild-card contention. Los Angeles and San Diego remained tied atop the West. If they finish the regular season tied, the Padres will win the division on a tie breaker and the Dodgers will face the Mets in the first round. In the Central, the Cardinals defeated the Brewers, and the Astros stayed alive by beating the Braves, 5-4. The Astros trail the Cardinals by one and a half games, and they need a lot of help to end the season tied with the Cardinals and force one final game to determine the division winner. American League By losing to the White Sox, the Twins increased their chances of falling into the wild-card spot and facing the Yankees in the division series. The Tigers could have helped themselves, but didn't, losing to the last-place Royals instead of clinching the A.L. Central title. Full coverage, Pages 4-5

BLOCK--Amie Willard, of Washington, DC, died peacefully on September 23rd. Beloved wife of Huntington T. Block, loving mother of Huntington M. Block, Bonnie B. Levison, William B. W. Block and Amie B. Ratajczak and adoring grandmother to seven grandchildren. A memorial service will take place on Saturday, November 4th, at 2 PM at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, 1820 Connecticut Ave. NW, Washington, DC. A private interment will be arranged at a later date on Nantucket Island. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Siasconset Union Chapel, POB 201, Siasconset, MA 02564.

THE annual Scottish Festival held by the St. Andrew's Society of Connecticut is a daylong celebration of Scottish culture featuring bagpiping, dog shows, traditional Highland dance exhibitions and rowdy athletic competitions. The festival, which will be held on Saturday, is the year's biggest event for the St. Andrew's Society, a 350-member charitable organization based in Litchfield that donates to camps and hospitals in Connecticut and Scotland, and gives educational awards to students learning about Scottish culture. Last October, around 6,000 people showed up for the 22nd annual festival, according to Ellen Waff, the society's president.

ON local streets, new home and business construction may be leveling off, but it is booming on college campuses across the region. Educators and real estate analysts say that colleges and universities, public and private, big and small, are adding classrooms, dormitories, student centers and athletic centers at a scope and rate that have not been seen in decades. While students consider many factors when choosing a college, educators say that first-rate physical facilities are becoming increasingly important in attracting students.

THE first thing the hostess at Trattoria Lucia asked my husband after he requested a table for four was: ''Will you be needing any high chairs?'' Not singular but plural -- high chairs -- as though there was a real possibility that he had two children under the age of 2 in tow. ''Family friendly'' is a term tossed around fairly loosely in the context of restaurants, but Trattoria Lucia raises family friendliness to an art form. Here, children in high chairs and booster seats abound, feasting by hand on buttered spaghetti and fried calamari. Teenagers happily palm big slices of pizza. Everybody loves the gelato.
