To the Editor: Readers may wish to know that the architect of the restored 1887 Cancer Hospital at 455 Central Park West at 105th Street (Big Deal, ''Five Turrets, No Dungeons,'' Sept. 17) was Charles Coolidge Haight. Haight's works, mainly institutional and ecclesiastical, include the double quadrangle of the General Theological Seminary in Chelsea and St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church at 552 West End Avenue. Earlier scholarship misattributed the Cancer Hospital to James Renwick Jr. Bannon McHenry Manhattan

DIG we must for a better New York. Over the summer, Judlau Contracting Inc. of College Point, Queens, won a $428 million contract, along with a Spanish construction company, to carve a 22-foot-high tunnel through hard rock 140 feet deep under the Upper East Side, as part of a project to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal.

TULIA: Race, Cocaine, and Corruption in a Small Texas Town, by Nate Blakeslee. (PublicAffairs, $14.95.) From 2000 to 2003, Tulia, in the Texas panhandle, became notorious for a bogus drug sting that unjustly sent many of the town's blacks to prison. A native Texan, Blakeslee broke the story for The Texas Observer, drawing national attention to the arrests, which were based on the inconsistent testimony of a single undercover officer. ''Tulia'' follows the legal battle that ultimately led to the reversal of the convictions, and is a devastating critique of Texas' judicial system and the nation's drug laws. Our reviewer, Sara Mosle, called ''Tulia'' a ''riveting legal thriller'' that resembles a ''modern-day 'To Kill a Mockingbird' -- or would, that is, if the novel were a true story and Atticus had won.''

WHEN Stevens Cadet didn't show up at Elmont Memorial Junior-Senior High School for a Saturday morning test-preparation session one day last year, he got a call from his teacher, Patricia Klein, who keeps the telephone numbers of her students programmed into her cellphone. ''Wake up, it's Saturday,'' Stevens, now 14, recalled Ms. Klein's saying into the phone. If she had not awakened him, Stevens said, one of his friends would have called to urge him to get to class. ''Most of the kids are here on Saturday, and the faculty is always here,'' he said.

An editorial last week noted that Gov. George Pataki named Charles Gargano, a close associate, to two public jobs. Both positions are unpaid. Mr. Gargano's job as head of the Empire State Development Corporation pays a salary of $145,000 a year.

ROSE--Irl W. II. Age 83, Sarasota, FL passed away peacefully on September 29th. Beloved husband of Susan Baar Rose. Devoted father of Carol Rose Munson and family friend Heleen, Debbie Rose Meinsen and Stephen Meinsen and Peggy Rose Turchioe and Robert Unger. Cherished Pop-Pop of Lauren and James Munson, Brian and Elisabeth Turchioe, Danny and Andrew Meinsen and great-grandfather of Taylor Madison Munson. Graduated from Horace Mann School Class of 1940 and Dartmouth College Class of 1944. He served in World War II and retired as a US Army Captain in 1958. He will long be remembered for his loyalty to family and friends and for his sense of humor. Private graveside service October 10th.

FOR more than 40 years, this North Shore hamlet of about 15,000 people has not had a hotel. Then came a proposal for not one but two hotels, within a short distance of each other on Main Street. The proposals have raised concerns in Port Washington and surrounding municipalities about increased traffic and the size of the buildings. The need for a hotel, however, appears to be generally accepted.

The Real Room, a corridorlike space near the entrance to Real Art Ways, is usually devoted to young and emerging artists. But this month it plays host to the drawings of Ken Morgan, a Connecticut resident whose tightly focused, energetic drawings pick up on wider art world trends. On view are four dozen miniature pen and ink sketches on ledger paper. They are minimal, but instantly captivating, the little doodlelike designs seemingly bursting out of the page. And they do, in a way, for Mr. Morgan sometimes combines multiple sheets of paper, tearing open the top layers to give his drawings depth and texture. A viewer's first impression is of abstract designs, since the sketches don't look like anything familiar. But more patient viewing reveals glimpses of another world -- broken, fragmentary scenes from the artist's unusual childhood.

Ann Veronica Keating, a daughter of Margaret and Dwight M. Keating of Pittsburgh, was married on Friday to Remy Palmer Ash, a son of Deborah and James V. Ash of New York. The Rev. Thomas W. Dagle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Charles Borromeo in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. Mrs. Ash, 32, is an oncology nurse in the surgery clinic at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. She graduated from Georgetown and received a master's degree in nursing from the University of Virginia. Her father is a vice president and the chief investment officer at the Claude Worthington Benedum Foundation, a charitable organization in Pittsburgh, which supports education and economic development in southwestern Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

The Houston Astros can add another thrilling piece to their stretch run Sunday if pitcher Chris Sampson, who has only two starts this season, can somehow compete with John Smoltz. But even with one more improbable victory, the Astros still might not be able to save their season.

TAKING BACK SUNDAY, of Amityville, has sold nearly two million records. Head Automatica, fronted by Daryl Palumbo of Bellmore, is on the cover of the underground rock magazine Alternative Press this month. Brand New, of Levittown, had the top-ranked album in the emo category in Rolling Stone in 2003. These bands, along with their brethren like Nightmare of You, and Men, Women and Children, have been part of a recent spike in Long Island musical exports that calls to mind the heyday of Lou Reed, Pat Benatar and Billy Joel. A few years back, theirs was a more or less cohesive sound falling into the category of emo: a navel-gazing sensitive guy's rock music, with lyrics full of teen angst. These days, the category is being transformed by some of the same players who spawned it.

NEW YORK is one of the few states without unilateral no-fault divorce, which means that New York couples can get a no-fault divorce only by mutual agreement. Judith Kaye, New York State's chief judge, set out to change all that. Earlier this year, the matrimonial commission she formed recommended that the state enact full unilateral no-fault divorce. Judge Kaye highlighted the proposal in her annual address about the state of the judiciary, and the idea was promptly endorsed by the New York Bar Association and the Women's Bar Association, as well as major newspapers.

IN the beginning, there were Lots 16 and 17, as designated in the Battery Park City master plan. Then Lots 16 and 17 became One River Terrace. One River Terrace begat Aquaterre. Aquaterre became One Rockefeller Park. One Rockefeller Park begat Riverhouse, One Rockefeller Park. Then the marketers rested and said it was good. Such were the permutations that went into the marketing and naming of Riverhouse, a 31-story condominium under construction at the northern end of Battery Park City, across the street from the riverfront Nelson A. Rockefeller Park. Sales began last month, and the project is scheduled to open next summer.

Upward Trend After starting the season with an unimpressive 30-yard effort, Dolphins running back RONNIE BROWN, above, has improved each week, gaining 90 yards last week against the Titans. Today's game against the Texans should be the first chance for the Miami offense to break out, and Brown, with wide receiver CHRIS CHAMBERS, should be the biggest beneficiaries. Lone Star Cowboys wide receiver TERRY GLENN was expected to have a drop in production this season, but he has stood out as the team's top option despite the addition of TERRELL OWENS. With Owens nursing a broken hand and fending off reporters curious about his recent overdose, Glenn may be asked to shoulder more of the load against an awful Titans defense, ranked 29th in the league. Smash Mouth The Vikings' CHESTER TAYLOR has brought a power-running game to the team, with Coach Brad Childress embracing his straight-ahead running style. Averaging 25 carries a game through three weeks, Taylor will try to be the first back to rush for more than 100 yards against the Bills this season. Running and Gunning Lost amid a season that has started 0-3, Browns quarterback CHARLIE FRYE, above, has rushed for three touchdowns and has increased his passing yardage each week, topping out last week at 298 yards against a tough Ravens defense. Frye should be able to use the second-year wide receiver BRAYLON EDWARDS as a deep threat against the Raiders, a team that has the same record as the Browns, but none of the upside.

Tory Grice, 29, of Brisbane, Australia, a science communicator for the Queensland Environmental Protection Agency: ''This was my first overseas holiday, so it was super-exciting. I'm a big animal person and bird-watcher, so Borneo felt like the ideal place to go. It still seems like a far-off, exotic land even though it's quite close to Australia. That afternoon my boyfriend, Andrew, was having a snooze, so I got my binoculars and camera and went for a wander. I got fantastic photos of the mangroves in silhouette, with the sun setting behind them, and saw some woodpeckers, which we don't have in Australia. I actually found Andrew half an hour later: he was filming monkeys fighting on the beach. More of a boy's thing. I know I've got nothing to compare it to because it was my first holiday, but it was just so excellent.'' As told to Seth Kugel

SIG'S WATER STREET CAFE, a new restaurant in Chester, occupies the space that once housed Fiddler's Seafood Restaurant. Sig is the nickname of the owner, Mark Signor, previously part-owner of Azul in West Hartford, now closed. I first tried Sig's for lunch, with my husband, on a Saturday at the end of September, taking a spectacular drive north from Guilford on Route 145 past ponds blanketed with water lilies. It was clear that Mr. Signor had done some renovating, opening up the space for a more contemporary feel, decorating in earth tones with exposed pine walls, and redoing the bar so that it held a more central place in the restaurant.

To the Editor: Anthony Tommasini's piece about Mozart's early demise, ''If Mozart Had Had Better Health Care'' [Sept. 17], reminded me of the old joke: Two music lovers are discussing his passing and the first says, ''Just think if Mozart had lived.'' The other replies, ''What more did you want from him?'' Michael Conroy Southampton, N.Y.

Q -- Can regular monthly payments that are made along with common charges but are listed separately under Capital Reserve Fund be used to increase the tax basis for a condominium when calculating capital gains? A -- Martin M. Appelbaum, a certified public accountant in Manhattan, said assessments levied by a condominium board for capital improvements, whether paid as a lump sum or in monthly increments, can indeed be used to increase the tax basis of individual units, thus reducing the profit when the apartment is sold. This assumes that the board has complied with Internal Revenue Service guidelines. Mr. Appelbaum said that under I.R.S. regulations affirmed in numerous court decisions, the board must pass a resolution and notify unit owners that the funds being raised will be used for capital improvements only and not for operating expenses or ordinary repairs.
CORENTHAL--Ruth. On September 26, 2006. Beloved sister of Gloria Schwartzberg. Loving aunt of Nancy, Marty and Gary.

WANG--C.C. Cheng Ching Wang was born in Peking China October 17, 1918 the younger son of Wang Han Su and Wang Wen Shuen, a military general and later, War Minister under Generalissimo Chiang-kai-chek. He graduated from Yenching University with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Chemistry in 1938. After working in the National Oil Refinery in Chungking China from 1939 to 1941 he served in the Chinese Nationalist Army from 1941 to 1943 as a Lieutenant Colonel during which time he married Florence Wu in 1942, in Chungking, then the war capital of China. In April 1943, after flying over the Himalayas to Calcutta, then sailing in an unarmed and unescorted British ship, he arrived in the U.S. where he obtained a Masters Degree in Chemical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1945. After a stint as Development Engineer at Dupont and Firestone from 1945 to 1947, he returned to China in 1947, obtaining an Honorable Discharge from the Nationalist Army with a rank of Colonel. In 1947 he founded Summit Industrial Company, and in 1948, U.S. Summit Corporation with three of his beloved classmates from MIT: Dr. C.D. Shiah, J.T.Shaw and P.M. Yen. They named the company to represent the sum of MIT. Together they went on to build an international pharmaceutical distribution business, a trading company and an oil refining business. They were among the first pioneers of modern industry in Asia after the turmoil of World War II. Throughout a life filled with adventure, exploration, and a passion for business, he did have a few other abiding loves--golf (he owned a private course in Westchester for over 35 years) and homes: He maintained residences in NYC, Pound Ridge, Palm Beach, Southampton, Singapore and Shanghai. He remained a true devotee to all things beautiful, a man of great insight and wisdom and someone who possessed an unfailing passion and respect for life. He also honored a lifelong commitment to his beloved wife Florence and his family. Although he never foresaw owning a fashion business, he was the sole backer of the Vera Wang Company and served as Chairman from its inception in 1990 to 1998. His many business positions were as follows: Director, Singapore Petroleum Company Pte. Ltd., Chairman & President, Oceanic Petroleum Corporation, Chairman & President, Oceanic Pe troleum (Asia) Corporation, Chairman & President of Summit Group of Companies, Chairman of the Vera Wang Group 1990-1998. He is survived by his daughter Vera, son Kenneth, son-in-law Arthur Becker, daughter-in-law Doreen Wang, a sister Wang Pe-chen, a member of the Chinese parliament of the Republic of China for 43 years, and three grandsons, Kevin, Darren and Harry Wang, and two granddaughters, Cecilia and Josephine Becker. He passed away on September 14th at the age of 87. The Memorial Service for C.C. Wang will be held at 1:00 p.m. on Thursday, October 19th at Christ Church, 520 Park Avenue in New York City. Donations may be made in memory of C.C. Wang to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.
To the Editor: Re ''Time to Settle in Mamaroneck'' (editorial, Sept. 24):

To the Editor: In his review of Frank Rich's ''Greatest Story Every Sold'' (Sept. 17), Ian Buruma wrote that ''someone reporting on the persecution of Jews in Germany in 1938 would not have added 'balance' by quoting Joseph Goebbels.'' In fact, American journalists reporting from Germany in the 1930's worried about providing balance in news stories about German Jews. A 1935 journalism textbook actually used ''the Jewish persecution by the German Nazi government'' to illustrate the need for ''both sides in a controversial matter'' to be ''given a chance to have their position stated.'' Balance was necessary, the text explained, because the story is about a struggle ''between rival groups, each of which is strong in its own right, and each of which is anxious to get as much propaganda across to newspaper readers as is possible.'' Laurel Leff West Hartford, Conn. The writer teaches journalism at Northeastern University and is the author of ''Buried by The Times: The Holocaust and America's Most Important Newspaper.''

Starting today, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on Sunday increases to $5 in the New England and Washington regions. The change reflects higher costs of paper, production and distribution. Monday through Saturday prices are unaffected.

SCHOOLS in Westchester and on Long Island performed better over all than other schools in New York State on the new English tests given to elementary and middle school students last spring, according to results released by the state on Sept. 21. But schools around the state, with few exceptions in Westchester and Long Island, showed a decline in performance among middle school students compared with elementary school students.

WHEN Stevens Cadet didn't show up at Elmont Memorial Junior-Senior High School for a Saturday morning test-preparation session one day last year, he got a call from his teacher, Patricia Klein, who keeps the telephone numbers of her students programmed into her cellphone. ''Wake up, it's Saturday,'' Stevens, now 14, recalled Ms. Klein's saying into the phone. If she had not awakened him, Stevens said, one of his friends would have called to urge him to get to class. ''Most of the kids are here on Saturday, and the faculty is always here,'' he said.

Seattle Seahawks (3-0) at Chicago Bears (3-0) 8:15 p.m. This game is a matchup of unbeaten teams and leading Super Bowl contenders. It also matches one team, the Bears, that lives by defense and one, the Seahawks, that has a strong defense, an imaginative offense and a tailback with a broken foot.

To the Sports Editor: If the Ryder Cup were truly a team competition, and not just competition between individuals who happen to be on a team, then there is no reason for the matches to continue after one team has won.

It seems that the prisoners at Guantánamo are rewarded if they betray their political and religious beliefs and give information that may result in the death of their comrades (Tim Golden, Sept. 17). An American citizen who did that would be disgraced and, if he was a soldier, tried and imprisoned. It is clear that their lives and the lives of their families will be in danger if they become ''compliant'' and word gets out. The prisoners know that word will eventually get out as to who cooperated and who did not. Lastly, these men are not cowards. Their treatment does not meet reasonable standards. They, their friends, relatives and fellow believers will have very personal reasons to seek revenge, and they will. Treating them this way will surely come back to haunt us. Edward W. Hayes, esq. New York

To the Editor: Your Sept. 24 editorial ''The Coast Guard on Broadwater'' says the Coast Guard's report considers Broadwater Energy's planned floating natural gas depot in Long Island Sound ''an entirely manageable risk.'' In fact, the report concludes there are substantial risks associated with this gigantic facility.

ONYX Restaurant and Lounge is a sparkler. Patrons entering through the main door of this Williston Park newcomer see an onyx-topped bar lit from below, with flashing squares of colored lights on the wall behind it and inviting white leather sectional seating nearby. The entrance to the dining rooms is equally striking. Two waterfalls enclosed in glass flank the doorway, and high-backed banquettes, covered in creamy leather, line the walls.
Pictures last Sunday with an article on the making of John Cameron Mitchell's film ''Shortbus'' misstated the name of the company that provided them. They were courtesy of ThinkFilm, not ThinkFilms.

Dr. Jessica Meredith Weiser was married last evening to Timothy Michael McCarthy at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Susanna Stefanachi Macomb, an interfaith minister, officiated. The bride, 32, will be known as Dr. Weiser-McCarthy. She is an assistant professor of medicine at Weill Medical College of Cornell University and an associate director of the internal medicine residency program at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. She graduated summa cum laude from Yale and received her medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

Now that he is back in Arizona as a private citizen, Richard H. Carmona will continue to pursue what was one of his main goals when he was the surgeon general: persuade more people to pay more attention to the importance of good nutrition, smaller portion sizes and regular exercise. On Tuesday, Dr. Carmona, whose four-year tour in Washington ended in August, will become vice chairman of the Canyon Ranch Company, which operates luxury spas in Lenox, Mass., and in Tucson.

The sophomore quarterback Graham Harrell threw a 37-yard touchdown pass to Robert Johnson in the right corner of the end zone with 26 seconds remaining to lift Texas Tech past host Texas A&M. Less than two minutes earlier, Texas A&M kicker Layne Neumann had connected on a go-ahead 32-yard field goal.

When Jon Glaser whips out a bottle of water from his special pocket and floods the spot where hisdog goesNo. 1, all he is doing is assuaging his own misguided guilt (The Funny Pages, Sept. 17). He asserts that he is sanitizing the scene of the crime, but unless his bottle is filled with a strong disinfectant, he is merely spreading the bacteria to a wider area. Glaser is alsorisking serious damage to a rotator cuff with hisconstant attempts to pat himself on the back; not to mention dooming himself to years on a psychiatrist'scouch, dealing with what is clearly a desperate need for affirmation from complete strangers. He should stop doing ''the thing that makes me better than you'' immediately, before he hurts himself. Louise Kane Vimmerstedt Tucson Glaser may never have considered his actions from his dog's point of view. Dogs communicate with one another by marking territory with urine. To a city dog, the sidewalk is just one big aromatic blog. Dogs can tell gender, age, health, breed, diet and sexual availability, all from smelling urine and other doggie doings. Jon's dog has probably given up trying to figure out why his owner censors every message she sends, deleting entire blocks of text with his water bottle. David Rockwell New York

MICHAEL RICE has built his fortune in potato chips and pretzels, but the home he plans to build here has gotten him into somewhat of a pickle. A group of his neighbors, calling themselves Save Avalon Dunes, intends to take Mr. Rice to court to stop him from building a 14,881-square-foot summer house on the dunes around 52nd Street. Many of the opponents -- who have started a boycott of Utz snacks, the company that Mr. Rice is chief executive of -- have million-dollar homes themselves in this Cape May County resort.

To the Sports Editor: There is too much commotion being made over crowd noise at N.F.L. games (''For N.F.L., Crowd Noise Has Become a Headache, Sept. 24). It is an inherent part of the football fan's experience to affect the communication on the field, especially when it disrupts the opposing team. Before it puts a policy in place to limit the impact of crowd noise, the N.F.L. should consider three factors.

To the Editor: Like Michelle Wildgen, I was in a relationship with an alcoholic. After all of his lying and blaming, he ended the relationship. Fortunately, this was a blessing in disguise, because each day I would be uncertain of when another relapse would be looming and my partner would turn into someone with dead eyes.

Help is on the way for families and young people on Long Island who cannot afford to buy a house but make too much to qualify for traditional low-income housing programs. A new grant program for first-time home buyers is aimed at college graduates, municipal and union employees, hospital workers, professionals and families who would otherwise be priced out of the Long Island housing market, according to Peter Elkowitz, the president of the Long Island Housing Partnership. The partnership, a nonprofit group, will manage the program.

Al Guenther, a tattoo artist in Little Egg Harbor, is not planning to stick around to learn what effect the new 7 percent sales tax will have on his business. ''We're heading for Virginia,'' said Mr. Guenther, 58, owner of Al's Tattooing. ''We're probably going to pack up and close down.''

Most people return from far-flung vacations with fleeting food cravings, but only in extreme cases are their eating habits forever changed. James Oseland is one of those cases. Twenty-four years after he went to Jakarta on summer break to visit a college pal, he still eats turmeric-tinged rice with his right hand and grinds spices the day he's going to use them, and if he hears someone speaking Bahasa Indonesia at, say, Ikea, chances are he'll invite him to lunch. ''That kind of travel has permanent underpinnings on how you perceive the world,'' he said on a recent Saturday morning as his pickup truck barreled down the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway toward Elmhurst, a neighborhood in Queens that functions as his wormhole to Southeast Asia.

DRY blends, red and white, are a significant part of the East End's portfolio of wines. The latest editions of two white blends from Channing Daughters, in Bridgehampton, the 2005 Sylvanus and 2005 Vino Bianco, are especially complex. Both are inspired by blends of Friuli, in northeastern Italy, whose regional cuisine requires quicksilver whites.

To the Editor: ''This Bud's for the Children'' (Sept. 24) suggests that fund-raising by Washington University alumni and their friends is an appropriate occasion for overdrinking. Using this activity to provide funds for ball teams in Harlem is specious.

ON local streets, new home and business construction may be leveling off, but it is booming on college campuses across the region. Educators and real estate analysts say that colleges and universities, public and private, big and small, are adding classrooms, dormitories, student centers and athletic centers at a scope and rate that have not been seen in decades. While students consider many factors when choosing a college, educators say that first-rate physical facilities are becoming increasingly important in attracting students.

THIS will not be the kind of authoritative parenting column that we all need. It will not be a parenting column like this:

WHEN Stevens Cadet didn't show up at Elmont Memorial Junior-Senior High School for a Saturday morning test-preparation session one day last year, he got a call from his teacher, Patricia Klein, who keeps the telephone numbers of her students programmed into her cellphone. ''Wake up, it's Saturday,'' Stevens, now 14, recalled Ms. Klein's saying into the phone. If she had not awakened him, Stevens said, one of his friends would have called to urge him to get to class. ''Most of the kids are here on Saturday, and the faculty is always here,'' he said.

Michael Bérubé and I share the same politics; so do the vast majority of our colleagues (Sept. 17). Bérubé doesn't think that's a problem, however, because our students continue to challenge us in the classroom. But that's hardly a fair match, and Bérubé knows he can win it every time. Wouldn't our intellectual lives be richer if we faced sustained and sophisticated challenges from other professors, rather than from 18-year-old neophytes? People like Bérubé and myself are fond of criticizing President Bush for surrounding himself with like-minded ideologues. Maybe it's time we looked in the mirror. Jonathan Zimmerman Professor of Education and History New York University New York To suggest that liberal professors could sway their conservative students in the voting booth is somewhat akin to the old argument that gay teachers could sway straight students to a different lifestyle. To illustrate the dubiousness of this premise, I would point out that there was a generation of students on American campuses in the 60's and 70's who stood shoulder to shoulder with self-declared socialists and flagrantly liberal professors, all wanting to start the revolution. Many of these baby boomers voted for Republicans in the last two elections. So much for the influence of those professors. Jeanne Spreier Dallas Michael Bérubé is certainly right to say that if professors are doing their jobs right, students of all stripes should be made ''to feel uncomfortable'' about their beliefs. But I'm surprised that he does not see that that is just why the liberal bias in humanities departments is so damaging to education; students on the left seldom hear arguments from their teachers that might make them reconsider their positions. Thomas Peyser Associate Professor of English Randolph-Macon College Ashland, Va.

WEST--Ormand J., Jr. (6/21/36-9/20/06) A long-time television director (30 years with WCBS-TV News in NYC), Orm ''faded to black'' on September 20, 2006. A graduate of Manchester, CT High School (''Best-Natured, Class of '54'') and the U. of Miami (FL) School of Communications (Iron Arrow member), Orm was known for his upbeat spirit, his irreverent sense of humor, his quick wit, his infectious laugh, his sense of adventure, his gentle strength, and his deep kindness and respect toward others. He was truly an honorable man. He had an all-consuming interest in every news story and every NY Yankee game until the very end. All those Orman touched--as a devoted and loving husband, father, son, brother, colleague, and friend--are richer for having known him. He will be greatly missed, but his incredible zest for life will live on in all of us. Survived by wife Patricia, daughter Kristin and her husband Guillermo Gonzalez, sister Carol and her husband Ramon Perez, niece Kimberly and her husband Troy Smith, and nephew David. Predeceased by son Andrew.

To the Editor: Re your Sept. 24 editorial ''Facing Facts on Iraq'': The time has come to consider United Nations peace negotiations on Iraq, using Lebanon as a model. This means talks with the Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds that aim for a cease-fire; withdrawal of American forces; United Nations peacekeepers; and the division of Iraq into three autonomous regions.

Tiger Woods had his worst day of the American Express Championship Saturday, but it was still good enough to give him a six-shot lead heading into the final round as he tries for his sixth consecutive victory on the PGA Tour. With a vociferous gallery behind him at The Grove in this village north of London, Woods followed up his opening rounds of 63 and 64 with a four-under-par 67. The Australian Adam Scott was in second place, and Jim Furyk and Brett Quigley were in third, seven shots off the pace.

Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest THE LOST: A Search for Six of Six Million, by Daniel Mendelsohn. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Grappling with the Holocaust in both its personal and geopolitical dimensions, Mendelsohn reconstructs the story of his great-uncle's family. YOKOHAMA BURNING: The Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire That Helped Forge the Path to World War II, by Joshua Hammer. (Free Press, $26.) Hammer argues that the disaster in the cosmopolitan city marked a turning point in Japan's embrace of militant nationalism. IT'S GETTING LATER ALL THE TIME: A Novel in the Form of Letters, by Antonio Tabucchi. Translated by Alastair McEwan. (New Directions, paper, $15.95.) Letters by 17 men to distant or long-lost lovers, and a single reply to them all. CREATIONISTS: Selected Essays, 1993-2006, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $24.95.) Respectful, text-centered literary musings on Poe, Twain, Fitzgerald, Dos Passos and others. FORGETFULNESS, by Ward Just. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) In this novel, one of Just's best, a small-time American spy uneasily revisits his earlier life after his French wife is murdered. THE INHABITED WORLD, by David Long. (Houghton Mifflin, $23.) This novel's hero, a ghost, looks back ruefully on his suicide and longs to help a woman survive her own despair. BLUE FRONT, by Martha Collins. (Graywolf, paper, $14.) Poems built around a 1909 lynching in the hometown of Collins's father. ANCESTOR STONES, by Aminatta Forna. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) This debut novel's emigrant heroine learns about the history of Sierra Leone, her homeland, from tales told by her four aunts. THE THEOCONS: Secular America Under Siege, by Damon Linker. (Doubleday, $26.) A study of a group of Roman Catholic thinkers who have helped spread America's religious revival from the masses to the intelligentsia. THINGS I DIDN'T KNOW: A Memoir, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $27.95.) Writing after a near-fatal car crash, the Australian art critic describes his formative years and the evolution of his craft. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

FOR more than 40 years, this North Shore hamlet of about 15,000 people has not had a hotel. Then came a proposal for not one but two hotels, within a short distance of each other on Main Street. The proposals have raised concerns in Port Washington and surrounding municipalities about increased traffic and the size of the buildings. The need for a hotel, however, appears to be generally accepted.

To the Editor: Something I learned in second grade profoundly shaped my view of school uniforms (''Do Clothes Make the Student?,'' Sept. 17). One day a girl in my class came to school wearing a jacket I had outgrown. Before that day, we were all clad in the same maroon jumper. After that day I learned two things: not everyone was as lucky as I was, and because of that uniform no one need know her family's situation.

Melissa Ha Nguyen and John Winthrop Fitzpatrick were married last evening. The Rev. Thomas Lawrence, a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York. Ms. Nguyen, 32, is keeping her name. She is the vice president and an owner of Silverline Partners, an investment management firm in New York. She graduated from Dartmouth and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. She is a daughter of Kathy L. Mai and Joe Q. Nguyen of Seattle.

DUNHAM--Margaret (''Toddy''). On September 28, at age 98. Widow of the late C. Dary Dunham, M.D. She was graduated from Columbia Presbyterian Nursing School, 1935. Longtime member of Rusticus Garden Club where she served as artistic judge. Awarded the Garden Club of America Medal of Merit in 1997 for exceptional leadership. Survived by children Deborah D. Gershon (Arnold) and Betsy Blachly Chapin (Henry), both of Manhattan, and C. Dary Dunham (Laurie) of Sharon, CT; grandchilden Wylie, Christopher (Lindsay), Nicholas, Margaret (Catlin) and James, and great-grandsons Wyatt and Miles. Her keen mind and indomitable spirit remained clear to the end. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Rusticus Garden Club Memorial Fund, PO Box 732, Bedford, NY 10506.

To the Editor: As an avid cyclist and occasional bike-commuter, I was both delighted and disturbed by ''Queasy Rider,'' your Sept. 24 article about the dangers of riding in the city. Those of us who ride regularly have seen dramatic improvements to the city's cycling infrastructure in the last few years, and we are hopeful for even more. However, of the seven cyclists shown in the article's four photographs, only one appears to be wearing a helmet.

Playing is optional this weekend for the Yankees' regular lineup. Derek Jeter is in it and charging toward a batting title, one point behind the leader with one game to play. Jason Giambi took a day to rest his left wrist, which almost certainly needs surgery. Manager Joe Torre named Gary Sheffield as his first baseman for the playoffs yesterday, and that was a relief to Giambi, who will be limited to being a designated hitter. He took grounders during batting practice and said, ''It felt like my glove was coming off.''

JOE TORRE was never the victim of his father's abuse, but growing up in a violent household still left a mark on him. Mr. Torre remembers the shouting and the screaming as his father tormented his mother, Margaret. He can remember standing in the kitchen, as his father -- a police officer -- escalated the terror by reaching into a drawer for his revolver. He recalls his older brothers and sisters trying to shield him, the youngest of five, from what was going on. Yet even into his mid-50's, Mr. Torre, the manager of the Yankees, who is now 66, hadn't connected his feelings of insecurity and anxiety to growing up in a violent home. It wasn't until he attended a weekend self-help retreat in 1995 with his wife, Ali, that he began to connect emotionally with his childhood.

EACH year, more than 140,000 New Yorkers are injured on the job. For most, the main source for paying medical expenses and replacing lost wages is the workers' compensation system. As a lawyer whose career is devoted to representing these injured workers, I have spoken to thousands of people over the years about their individual cases and about the limitations of the system. I've spent many unhappy hours explaining that even though someone may not be able to pay rent or feed his family on his benefit amount, he is getting the most the law allows. Often, I have had to tell clients that they cannot have necessary medical testing or treatment until they get approval from their insurance company. And recently, I have had to explain to workers with problems related to 9/11 that they've missed the deadline for claims because of technicalities in the Workers' Compensation Law.

Dr. Jennifer Beth Fisher, a daughter of Lynn Fisher and John Fisher of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Grenville Taylor, the son of Linda W. Taylor and Charles Taylor of Wynnewood, Pa. Jon Hurwitz, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at Eolia, a mansion in Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, Conn. The bride and bridegroom met at the University of Pennsylvania, where each received a medical degree in May. The bridegroom also received a doctorate in bioengineering. They are interns in Philadelphia, she at Albert Einstein Hospital and he at Pennsylvania Hospital.

To the Editor: I am shocked at the matter-of-fact tone of Mr. Williams's article about the use of anti-anxiety medications for flying. As a licensed therapist credentialed in treating alcohol and drug addiction, I can assure you that Xanax, Ativan and other benzodiazepines are extremely habit forming, especially for (but not limited to) people who tend to overuse alcohol and other drugs. This is a larger part of the population than you may think.

On a recent KLM flight from Amsterdam to Kilimanjaro, I was bumped from business class to economy, despite a confirmed reservation and seat assignment, because of overbooking. The KLM agent said I'd be reimbursed for the difference between the two fares for this leg of the trip. I had paid $4,300 for my round-trip business-class ticket; on the day I booked, the lowest coach fare was $1,300, so I naively assumed KLM would reimburse me half the difference -- $1,500. Eight weeks later, Northwest Airlines (a partner of KLM) credited my Visa account with $105, explaining that their calculation of the fare difference for a refund is based on an internal formula, unrelated to the relative price of the fares at the date of purchase. Do I have any recourse? -- Robert Munoz, Seattle Your flight was covered by the new European Union rules for consumer compensation, under which you could have chosen to volunteer your seat in return for cash negotiated with the airline; in that case, you should also be offered a refund or another flight, meals, refreshments and overnight accommodation if necessary. Compensation varies according to length of flight and delay in getting to your destination. Passengers who are bumped, or whose flight has been canceled, can claim compensation of up to 600 euros, or $760 at $1.29 to the euro, for a delay of more than four hours.

The air is suddenly sharper. The scent of newly cut grass has given way to the smokiness of decaying leaves. It's time for finding those scarves and caps and ordering hot chocolate instead of iced tea. It would be hard to find a thicker, richer brew than the one that Angela Ingrao whips up in the back room of Cocoa, her pink and brown closet of a chocolate shop in downtown Larchmont. What makes Ms. Ingrao's chocolate extraordinary is that it has only a trace of sweetness, just enough to dull the bitter edge of cocoa and to enhance the intense chocolate flavor. Her base chocolate blocks come from Callebaut in Belgium.

To the Editor: I read about the lengths people are willing to go in ''You Are Cleared for Takeoff'' with a mixture of amusement, astonishment and horror. It strikes me, though, that rather than this being viewed as a pathology that needs treatment, it may in fact be a sensible and natural human reaction.

His leadership and personal generosity were key elements in Calhoun's transformation to the vibrant community we enjoy today. We extend deepest condolences to Ron's wife Marcia and the entire family--many of whom are members of the multi-generational Foster legacy atCalhoun: children Alison (David), Chris '95, Geoff '96; grandsons Justin Bosch '00 and Max Bosch '07. The Calhoun School Steve Nelson, Head of School Eric Ryan, Chair, Board of Trustees

To the Editor: As a born-and-bred Austinite living in Rochester for the past 20 years, I was quite pleased to see Seth Sherwood shine his spotlight on my much beloved hometown in ''Going to Austin'' (Sept. 17). However, I must take issue with what I consider a grave omission. You failed to mention the Austin City Limits Music Festival (www.aclfestival.com), which was taking place on the very day your article ran. The festival just finished its fifth year and is considered by many to be one of the world's best music festivals. This year alone, there were over 200,000 people in attendance. Artists included Tom Petty, Van Morrison, Willie Nelson, K. T. Tunstall, John Mayer, Damian Marley, the Shins, Los Lobos and the Subdudes. We're talking eight stages for three full days and nights. It will soon rival South by Southwest. Cindy Winetroub Rogers Rochester

THE first thing Seret Scott would like people to know about her play ''Second Line'' is that it is not autobiographical. The play, which covers a period from the 1960's to the 80's, focuses on two middle-class African-American college students and how they were affected by the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War. Ms. Scott, who calls herself ''a child of the 60's,'' said the time span of the play was a life-shaping period for her.

The credits for two photographs accompanying the Streetscapes column on June 11 about the architect Gaetan Ajello were reversed. The photo of Ajello in 1910 was from MetroHistory.com; the photo of 575 West End Avenue was from the Museum of the City of New York. The error was pointed out by a reader in late September.

He will always be loved and admired not only by our family, but all his friends and colleagues in the world of interior design. From the bottom of our hearts, we love you, Chris. Patricia,Barry and Liz Berkule

To the Editor: Your Sept. 24 editorial ''The Coast Guard on Broadwater'' says the Coast Guard's report considers Broadwater Energy's planned floating natural gas depot in Long Island Sound ''an entirely manageable risk.'' In fact, the report concludes there are substantial risks associated with this gigantic facility.

CHATZOPOULOS--Nikolaos. 64, of Roselle Park, NJ, died on September 19, 2006. Born in Constantinople (Istanbul), Turkey, Mr. Chatzopoulos immigrated to the United States in 1969, and worked as a chemist in the field of precious metal refining for 37 years. Active at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church in Union, NJ for 32 years, he was co-founder and past president of World Hellenism and co-founder of the Federation of Greek-American Societies of New Jersey. He was invested as Archon Aktouarios of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, awarded the Archdiocesan Medal of St. Paul, and was a member of the Metropolitan Council of New Jersey, the archdiocesan delegation to the worldwide meetings of the Council of Hellenes Abroad (SAE), the board of trustees of SAE America District #

Loving sister of the late Sophie, the late William, the late Mac, the late Mina, the late Evelyn, and the late Nettie. Cherished grandmother of Beth, Adam, David (Claudia), and Joyce. Fond great-grandmother of Maxwell.

MICHAEL RICE has built his fortune in potato chips and pretzels, but the home he plans to build here has gotten him into somewhat of a pickle. A group of his neighbors, calling themselves Save Avalon Dunes, intends to take Mr. Rice to court to stop him from building a 14,881-square-foot summer house on the dunes around 52nd Street. Many of the opponents -- who have started a boycott of Utz snacks, the company that Mr. Rice is chief executive of -- have million-dollar homes themselves in this Cape May County resort.

The village of Rye Brook's Board of Trustees voted 4 to 0 last Tuesday night to tighten height, bulk and setback restrictions on new houses in the Byram Ridge section of town, becoming the latest Westchester municipality to place curbs on outsize, cookie-cutter houses commonly called McMansions. Lawrence A. Rand, the mayor of the village, lives in Byram Ridge and abstained from the vote. But with a wave of large homes washing across the neighborhood in recent years, he said, he supported the zoning changes as a way to preserve the village's character as ''truly a residential community.''

SETTEL -- Elmer H. The Board of Directors and staff of VISIONS/Services for the Blind and Visually Impaired records the passing of Elmer H. Settel. He was a member of the Board of Directors and Advisory Council for 49 years. Our deepest sympathy is expressed to his family. Nancy T. Jones, President Nancy D. Miller, Executive Director

BENEATH the stained-glass windows and stenciled walls of the Charter Oak Cultural Center, dancers from the Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble and the singers of Women of the Cross, a spiritual trio, acted out the lives of inmates from the York Correctional Institution, a women's prison in Niantic. In their rehearsal last month for the upcoming performance of ''Time In,'' an exploration of time spent behind bars, the performers spoke of waiting for the hours to pass, of how they came to be inmates and of how they supported one another.

FOR the past five springs, a pair of Baltimore Orioles has returned to our yard to nest. This year I was worried. The last I had seen of the dazzling orange patriarch, he was bravely, desperately leading a screeching redtail hawk away from his brood. Then they all vanished. Thus when Daddy-O returned this spring, I rejoiced -- and followed the flash of wings to the hammocklike nest swinging high in our maple tree. The fledging of the ensuing baby orioles took place at a tender time in our human nest; our 16-year-old son, Sam, had gotten his driver's permit. It was a milestone I've dreaded since he began taking solid food. So it was only natural that I would do the sappy Mom thing and anthropomorphize the avian drama. I envied Mama Oriole her apparent sangfroid as the baby birds plunged, flapping, into the void. The female chick was cautious, taking short test flights to nearby branches. Her two snazzy brothers favored the kamikaze approach; death-defying free falls landed them, tweeting and flailing, in the trumpet vine. Every time they made it back to the nest, a squawky fracas ensued that sounded to my fretful maternal ears like a warbled equivalent of ''What were you thinking?''

In 1992 it was shocking artwork. Fourteen years later it was $8 million worth of rotting seafood. Enter Damien Hirst, a squad of assistants, 200 needles, an ocean of formaldehyde and one brand new 13-foot tiger shark. By Carol Vogel, Page 28.

An editorial last week noted that Gov. George Pataki named Charles Gargano, a close associate, to two public jobs. Both positions are unpaid. Mr. Gargano's job as head of the Empire State Development Corporation pays a salary of $145,000 a year.

To the Editor: ''The Lonesome Casita'' (Sept. 17), about Clinton Street on the Lower East Side, makes it seem as if yuppie business owners are driving out Latino businesses in the neighborhood. Anyone who has spent any time on Clinton Street knows that it is one of the only truly integrated neighborhoods left in this city. Most of the newer businesses that have opened are run by people who live in the neighborhood and who are genuinely invested in making Clinton Street a place for everybody. Mark Foster, the owner of P-13/China House Tonics, is a perfect example of this.

The Yankees completed their postseason roster yesterday, with an asterisk. The decision on Randy Johnson may take a while. Johnson, who had an epidural Friday for the herniated disk in his lower back, made 60 throws in the outfield yesterday, the final eight to a catcher in a squat. The bigger test will come this morning, when he throws 40 pitches off a bullpen mound.

To the Editor: ''The Mayor's War on Poverty'' (editorial, Sept. 24) appropriately praises the mayor's Commission for Economic Opportunity for its systematic plan to reduce poverty. However, its limited vision for the nation's wealthiest and most unequal city is disappointing. The commission's focus on children under 5, working poor adults and young people out of work and school perpetuates the unfair distinction between ''deserving'' and ''undeserving'' poor. Further, this choice includes only half of those living in poverty. This segmentation makes it harder to tackle the real causes of poverty: low wages, insufficient jobs, inadequate schools and poor health.

To the Editor: Sol Wachtler's personal account of solitary confinement in a ''special housing unit'' (''A Cell of One's Own,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 24) graphically describes the sad, neglectful and dangerous handling of our mentally ill offenders in the New York State prison system. It is shameful that Governor Pataki vetoed a bill that would have prevented such treatment.

To the Editor: In a letter in the Book Review (Sept. 17), Martin Davis, a logician for whom I have enormous respect, charges me with a double blunder. I asserted in my review of Janna Levin's novel, ''A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines'' (Sept. 3), that Kurt Gödel, in proving the incompleteness of arithmetic, and Alan Turing, in proving the undecidability of logic, both exploited the ancient paradox of the liar. Davis claims I am wrong on each count: Gödel's work ''in no way 'exploits' '' this paradox, he says, and Turing's work ''has nothing whatever to do with the liar paradox.'' But it is Davis who -- uncharacteristically -- errs here. In crucial parts of their proofs, both Gödel and Turing do indeed exploit the self-referential flip that is the essence of the liar paradox. And I am hardly the only one to have noticed the connection that Davis denies. ''The key idea [in Gödel's incompleteness proof] was to modify the ancient Antinomy of the Liar,'' writes John W. Dawson Jr., Gödel's biographer and the co-editor of his collected works (''Logical Dilemmas: The Life and Work of Kurt Gödel,'' Page 65). As for Turing, the distinguished French logician Gilles Dowek writes that ''one recognizes in [Turing's] argument a variation on the paradox of Epimenides, the Cretan philosopher who claimed that all Cretans are liars'' (''La Logique,'' Page 47). I might not be grousing about this if the Book Review hadn't printed Davis's letter concerning my supposed falsehoods under the heading ''Liar, Liar.'' That stung. Jim Holt New York

A COAST GUARD report on the safety and security of Broadwater Energy's proposed floating natural gas plant in Long Island Sound has something to please the company as well as the project's opponents, even though their interpretations of the findings are at polar opposites. Their reactions are a sure indication that the fight over the Queen Mary 2-size plant is far from over.

FOR more than 40 years, this North Shore hamlet of about 15,000 people has not had a hotel. Then came a proposal for not one but two hotels, within a short distance of each other on Main Street. The proposals have raised concerns in Port Washington and surrounding municipalities about increased traffic and the size of the buildings. The need for a hotel, however, appears to be generally accepted.
SHAPIRO--Elsie. September 27, 1992. Remembered every day with love.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the number of patent lawsuits filed in Marshall, Tex., referred incorrectly to Samuel F. Baxter, a principal at the law firm of McKool Smith. He is a trial lawyer who handles patent cases; he is not a patent lawyer who specializes in obtaining as well as protecting patents.

ROBINTON--Madeline Russell on September 13 2006, at the age of 97. Wife of the late Hermann Robinton. Beloved Aunt of Anne Russell Sullivan, great-aunt of Kyle and Sean Sullivan. Professor Emeritus of History, Brooklyn College, from its formative period in 1931 to her retirement in 1976. Graduate of Hunter High School and an Honors and Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Barnard College in 1929, she won an international fellowship after receiving her Bachelor's degree that permitted study in England and Germany. Professor Robinton earned M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Columbia University in 1931 and 1944. She served as Trustee of Barnard College and a Fellow of the British Royal Society of the Arts, volunteer for Phi Beta Kappa and a History Book Review Editor for its Key Reporter. Professor Robinton was a gifted and inspirational teacher. Her many students kept in touch with her through the years, dedicating publications and awards to her and always commenting that her guidance had a profound effect on their scholarly endeavors and their perspective on life and the world around them. Graceful and articulate until the end, Professor Madeline Robinton will be sorely missed by her family and friends. Condolences may be sent to 3331 Bennett Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90068 anners@aol.com Anne Russell Sullivan

BENEATH the stained-glass windows and stenciled walls of the Charter Oak Cultural Center, dancers from the Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble and the singers of Women of the Cross, a spiritual trio, acted out the lives of inmates from the York Correctional Institution, a women's prison in Niantic. In their rehearsal last month for the upcoming performance of ''Time In,'' an exploration of time spent behind bars, the performers spoke of waiting for the hours to pass, of how they came to be inmates and of how they supported one another.

The way the National Rifle Association is promoting a universal right to bear arms left me wondering about the N.R.A.'s position on the rights of nation-states to arm themselves (Joshua Kurlantzick, Sept. 17). If removing the right to own a weapon is the first step toward eliminating civil rights, then limiting a nation's ability to arm itself may be the first step toward making it vulnerable to invasion. As weapons of all kinds have become more powerful, the gun-ownership debate might open new paths for discussion on nuclear-arms control. Alexandra Ballantine Brewster, N.Y.

To The Editor: What a difference 26 years make. Danielle Pergament's ''Paros, Greece: A Jam-Packed Island That's an Open Secret'' (Next Stop, Sept. 17) was all about that jazzy, jam-packed island of today that would be unrecognizable to my husband, Sam, and me. Back in 1980, the ferry took us to a beautiful but serene place, where we walked to a hotel on the sea with no prior reservations and booked a room. The proprietor prepared the island specialty fish soup, with 14 kinds of fish including the excellent barbounia, just for us.

WHEN Stevens Cadet didn't show up at Elmont Memorial Junior-Senior High School for a Saturday morning test-preparation session one day last year, he got a call from his teacher, Patricia Klein, who keeps the telephone numbers of her students programmed into her cellphone. ''Wake up, it's Saturday,'' Stevens, now 14, recalled Ms. Klein's saying into the phone. If she had not awakened him, Stevens said, one of his friends would have called to urge him to get to class. ''Most of the kids are here on Saturday, and the faculty is always here,'' he said.

An essay last Sunday about Tasti D-Lite and its customers referred incorrectly to its business structure and its relationship with its parent company, and also misstated the location of that company's corporate headquarters. Tasti D-Lite is a trademark of A Matter of Taste Inc.; it is not a corporation. In addition, it operates under a licensing model; it is not a franchise. A Matter of Taste Inc. has its offices on the Upper East Side, not near Herald Square.

At the Princeton Review, no expense is too small to escape the finance chief's attention -- if it is coming out of his own pocket. The company, based in Manhattan and best known for its test-preparation books and courses, amended the year-old employment contract of its chief financial officer, Andrew J. Bonanni, to include reimbursement of up to $375 a month in parking expenses.

HECHT--Fredric, of Hecht & Associates, 10 East 40th St., NY, NY. Formally at 3305 Hewlett Ave., Merrick, NY. Died December 14, 2005. Cemetery Mount Ararat, 2pm, October 8th, Sect. 52, PlotC 28. The Hecht Family

The cozy, unostentatious Vanilla Bean Café in Pomfret, inside a restored 19th-century barn at the crossroads of Routes 44, 97 and 169, may look like it is in the middle of nowhere. But people in this part of the state know better. When two brothers and a sister -- Barry, Brian and Eileen Jessurun -- opened the cafe in 1989, it had 16 seats. Now there are two large rooms, one big enough for the music groups that perform folk, bluegrass, blues or jazz every Saturday night. The Bean, as it is called, is the most popular drop-by spot in the area, with good food freshly prepared at moderate prices.

Residents of the Town of Huntington who own hybrid or other alternative-fuel vehicles will be eligible for a variety of free parking benefits under a law adopted Tuesday by the town board. They can receive free parking at all town meters, free beach passes and free parking at the town's four Long Island Rail Road stations beginning Jan. 1. Stuart Besen, the councilman who sponsored the measure, said Huntington was the first municipality in the state to offer such incentives. He said a goal of the law was to create a demand for such vehicles so that car makers will mass-produce them.

LIBERMAN--Kenneth H. Died September 20, 2006. Beloved son of Irene Brown and the late Bertram Liberman. Brother of Nancy Cohen and brother-in-law of Harvey Cohen. Uncle of Jill, Jodi and Wendy. Stepson of Robert H. Brown. Services private.

FOR more than 40 years, this North Shore hamlet of about 15,000 people has not had a hotel. Then came a proposal for not one but two hotels, within a short distance of each other on Main Street. The proposals have raised concerns in Port Washington and surrounding municipalities about increased traffic and the size of the buildings. NEW YORK STATE requires a lot of people to report suspicions of child abuse. It is surprising to find certain professions, like chiropractors, podiatrists and dental hygienists, on the state's list of ''mandated reporters.'' Others, like pediatricians, social workers and psychologists, are more predictable, since they regularly work with children. Teachers and school administrators are also no-brainers. They are knowledgeable about child development and are attuned to day-to-day behavioral changes. Sometimes, a teacher is the only safe adult in a child's life.

To the Editor: Re ''An Uncertain Threat in Venezuela'' (Off the Shelf, Sept. 17), a review of my book ''Hugo Chávez: Oil, Politics and the Challenge to the U.S.'' (St. Martin's Press), which documented how the ''Washington consensus'' has ravaged South America and Venezuela in particular: In his review, Roger Lowenstein calls free-market reforms a ''medicine'' that has "worked better than anything else." Indeed? It was precisely Venezuela's adherence to free-market reforms that proved utterly devastating, sparking massive urban riots in Caracas in 1989.

As his Red Sox blew apart this August like a graying dandelion, David Ortiz looked at the Tigers, specifically the hard-throwing rookies Justin Verlander and Joel Zumaya, and issued a warning to the rest of baseball. ''They're going to cause trouble,'' Ortiz told Sports Illustrated. ''You know why? Power pitching. That's what wins in the playoffs.''

DIAZ--Frank, Born in Puerto Rico, Frank was sent to the U.S. as a young boy without knowing English. He obtained a dictionary & read whatever he could. He graduated from Xavier High School & Holy Cross, became a Stone Scholar at Columbia Law School, served in the Army, returned to graduate from Fordham Law School at night & became an Acting Supreme Court Justice in NY. As a judge, a lawyer, a husband and father, Frank taught the importance of hard work & helping of others. He had an excellent mind but an even better heart. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, two sons, and two granddaughters.

MASSIVE ATTACK is one of those British groups that -- to its members' credit, perhaps -- has never quite made sense in America. Across the ocean Massive Attack helped set the agenda for British music in the 1990's, helping to inspire a generation of singers and rappers and D.J.'s; performers ranging from Dizzee Rascal to Beth Orton owe this group a debt. Suffice it to say that the group's 1991 debut album, ''Blue Lines,'' didn't thrill Americans quite the same way. But in the years since, Massive Attack has built a respectable cult of fans here. And this week it is scheduled to arrive in New York for a three-night stand at the Roseland Ballroom in support of a recent greatest-hits compilation (of sorts), ''Collected'' (Virgin). The group emerged from the Bristol hip-hop scene, but right from the start Massive Attack's sound drew heavily from reggae and jazzy R&B. (The reggae singer HORACE ANDY is a longtime collaborator, and he is touring with the group.) Massive Attack often used hip-hop beats to build songs that were both dreamy and heavy, and early singles (like ''Safe From Harm'' and ''Unfinished Sympathy'') helped pioneer the genre that's sometimes called trip-hop. Compared with American rap records, Massive Attack productions sound smooth and slightly posh, but in Britain the group's rise felt a bit like an insurgency: proof that hip-hop-inspired music need not sound like an imitation of America. (The group also helped birth a British star: the raspy, slow-motion rapper Tricky.) Since ''Blue Lines,'' Massive Attack has released three more full-length albums, and the genre known in Britain as ''urban music'' has spawned its own subgenres, like grime; compared with that frenetic style, Massive Attack's mellow tracks seem old fashioned but not unwelcome. And while it's not usually a great sign when a group decides it's time for a victory lap, this one is certainly well earned. Tuesday through Thursday at 8 p.m., 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171; $50.

Funeral service Wednesday, 11 AM, at the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 334 E. 74 St. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. The big news this week: the return of ''LOST'' (ABC, 9 p.m. Wednesday). The nearly as big news: the return of ''VERONICA MARS'' (CW, 9 p.m. Tuesday). But it's a rich seven days in less publicized precincts too. On PBS it's practically a premiere week, not that the network would be so crass as to call it that. There are new seasons of ''FRONTLINE'' (Tuesday; check local listings for all PBS programs), which kicks off in a timely manner with ''Return of the Taliban,'' and ''AMERICAN EXPERIENCE'' (Monday), which takes another route: the first PBS broadcast since 1993 of the much-honored civil rights documentary ''Eyes on the Prize.'' Also new is an episode of the recurring science magazine ''NOVA SCIENCENOW'' (Tuesday) that includes a look at whether the asteroid Apophis will hit Earth, and Bill Moyers's latest news program, ''MOYERS ON AMERICA'' (Wednesday), which begins with a reconstruction of the Abramoff scandal. On completely different, but no less serious, notes: ''SOUTH PARK'' (Comedy Central, 10 p.m. Wednesday), the one place where they really know what satire means, returns for its 10th season. ''THE STREET'' (BBC America, 10 p.m. Tuesday), a six-part drama set on a street in a northern English town, has impressive credentials: the cast includes Jim Broadbent, Jane Horrocks and Timothy Spall, and the lead writer is Jimmy McGovern, who created the series ''Cracker'' and wrote the fine feature film ''Liam.'' And finally -- O.K., this is less serious -- the season premiere of that show all those people you don't know are watching, ''BATTLESTAR GALACTICA'' (Sci Fi, 9 p.m. Friday). What's a Cylon, you ask? All you need to know is that it's much better looking than a Klingon.

Some of the best, and certainly the most provocative, artworks in the Hudson River Valley right now are scattered along the riverfront in two new displays -- one enduring, the other endearingly temporary. Outdoor sculpture and site-specific installations are part of the Peekskill Project, a dynamic, monthlong citywide exhibition, now in its third year, sponsored by the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill. This year's presentation features work by 111 artists selected by 16 curators and placed at about 70 sites around the town and riverfront. It can take days to see everything.
AARON--Gregg Richard. 9/19/67--10/01/01 Remembered with love. Love, Mom

FINKEL - LEVIN--Phyllis. A Memorial Service for Phyllis Finkel-Levin on October 8th at 2pm in Sea Cliff, LI. For details and response, email: ralanbrunette@aol.com

FOR the past five springs, a pair of Baltimore Orioles has returned to our yard to nest. This year I was worried. The last I had seen of the dazzling orange patriarch, he was bravely, desperately leading a screeching redtail hawk away from his brood. Then they all vanished. Thus when Daddy-O returned this spring, I rejoiced -- and followed the flash of wings to the hammocklike nest swinging high in our maple tree. The fledging of the ensuing baby orioles took place at a tender time in our human nest; our 16-year-old son, Sam, had gotten his driver's permit. It was a milestone I've dreaded since he began taking solid food. So it was only natural that I would do the sappy Mom thing and anthropomorphize the avian drama. I envied Mama Oriole her apparent sangfroid as the baby birds plunged, flapping, into the void. The female chick was cautious, taking short test flights to nearby branches. Her two snazzy brothers favored the kamikaze approach; death-defying free falls landed them, tweeting and flailing, in the trumpet vine. Every time they made it back to the nest, a squawky fracas ensued that sounded to my fretful maternal ears like a warbled equivalent of ''What were you thinking?''

MICHAEL RICE has built his fortune in potato chips and pretzels, but the home he plans to build here has gotten him into somewhat of a pickle. A group of his neighbors, calling themselves Save Avalon Dunes, intends to take Mr. Rice to court to stop him from building a 14,881-square-foot summer house on the dunes around 52nd Street. Many of the opponents -- who have started a boycott of Utz snacks, the company that Mr. Rice is chief executive of -- have million-dollar homes themselves in this Cape May County resort.

Ted Turner was back at the Time & Life Building in New York last week, but it wasn't to visit any friends he made while on the Time Warner board, which he left in May. Instead, the ''Mouth of the South,'' as the outspoken Mr. Turner is known, was in the company's signature skyscraper in Rockefeller Center to open a New York outpost of his Ted's Montana Grill restaurant chain.

In Washington, there is no higher art form than the non-denial denial, in which politicians try to rebut a storyline without quite denying the specifics. That is what is underway now with Bob Woodward's latest book, ''State of Denial,'' an unflattering portrait of an administration riven by discord over the Iraq war.

BALDWIN--Alfred Jay of Spring Hill, FL died Monday, September 25th, after a brief battle with cancer. Born in Litchfield, CT, he moved to Florida 19 years ago from Parsippany, NJ. He was an Army Air Corps veteran of World War II attached to the 463rd Bomb Group. Lieutenant Baldwin was a bombardier flying on B-17s. On his 20th mission his plane was shot down. He and a few others who survived, parachuted out and spent the rest of the war in a German P.O.W. camp. He retired as Vice President of the book publisher Oxford University Press. He is predeceased by his wife, Louise Vi, and his daughter, Kristine Baldwin. He is survived by his daughter, Ayn Riehle of Vermont, his son, A. Jay Baldwin of New Jersey, eight grandchildren and one great grandchild. A memorial service will be held in Litchfield, CT on October 21st.

RANALD--Ralph Arthur. We are devastated to announce the sudden death of our husband, father and grandfather. Friend to many, teacher to all. Viewing October 3rd at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 10am. Funeral Mass at 12:30pm at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 213 West 82 nd Street.

PRESCOTT--Lilias W. Died September 26, 2006, age 98. Beloved wife of the late Orville Prescott, daily literary critic of ''The New York Times'' for many years. She was past President of the New Canaan, CT Sewing Group, past Chairman of the Friends of the New York Philharmonic in New Canaan and an active volunteer in other local organizations. She was a graduate of Smith College, Class of 1930. Survived by her daughter, Jennifer Prescott McLean of Chappaqua, NY, five grandchildren, and six great - grandchildren. Also predeceased by her son Peter S. Prescott. No public services. Contributions may be made to the New Canaan Library, 151 Main St., New Canaan, CT 06840 or the New Canaan Sewing Group, P.O. Box 215, New Canaan, CT 06840.

Will New Jersey drivers encounter more deer carcasses on the side of the road starting this Sunday? That is unclear, but what is clear is that towns and counties now have to figure out how to deal with the carcasses. In a cost-cutting move announced in June, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said that the state would no longer remove deer carcasses from county or local roads after Sept. 30.

The first time it passed out its shiny little men in 1929, for the years 1927 and 1928, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had the good sense to recognize an essential and animating divide: the Oscar (as the statuettes came to be called) for ''outstanding picture'' went to a war movie called ''Wings,'' while the award for ''unique and artistic picture'' went to the sublime drama ''SUNRISE: A SONG OF TWO HUMANS.'' The two trophies were a tacit acknowledgment of the underlying tension between art and industry, a tension that now plays out each time another studio dependent steals critical thunder from its big studio brother and that will play out with increasing feverishness over the next five months. Directed by the German import F. W. Murnau, ''Sunrise'' stars George O'Brien and Janet Gaynor as a young country couple nearly undone by the temptations of the big city, and it remains a triumph of the classical studio system as well as one of its saddest cautionary tales. Brought to America by Fox to class up its act, Murnau quickly became a bridge between the cinema of the old world and the new. The writer was Austrian, the set designer German and one of the two cameramen, an Englishman in Hollywood, had worked with Murnau in Germany. During production, studio luminaries like Frank Borzage visited the vast set constructed on the Fox lot; John Ford declared ''Sunrise'' the greatest picture ever made and even went off to Germany later to shoot exteriors for one of his own films. But critical praise did not translate into box office success for what turned out to be the most expensive silent film made at Fox, which abandoned Murnau to cinema immortality. The academy, meanwhile, learned its lesson: never again did it give an award to a ''unique and artistic picture.'' Sunday at 6 p.m., Wednesday at 7:45 p.m., Museum of Modern Art, (212) 708-9480.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about cover versions of the 1966 song ''Everybody's Talkin' '' misstated the name of the company that now owns a new song, ''I Don't Care What Your Friends Say,'' after claiming it bore a resemblance to the earlier tune. It is Six Palms Music, publisher of ''Everybody's Talkin' '' -- not Third Story, which is the parent company of Six Palms.
