To the Editor: Re ''We Ate and Drank While the Warning Lights Flashed'' (Modern Love, Sept. 17):
To the Editor: Re ''Combine and Fail,'' by Kevin E. Ciak (Op-Ed, Sept. 17), concerning the merging of New Jersey school districts:

JOEL--Yale. Noted photographer and member of the original Life Magazine staff, died early Saturday morning at the age of 87, of cardiac arrest, in Manhattan where he lived. His some 60 years of images reflect his wit, originality and rapport with people --the same characteristics he brought to his family and friends. He leaves behind his wife of 57 years, Shirley; two sons, both photographers, David of Chicago and wife Susan; Seth of Los Angeles and wife ''Charlie'' Sara Jane; a daughter, Louisa Fanger of Boston and husband Peter; four grandchildren: Max, Sam, Toby and Zoe Joel. Yale, we miss you, your anecdotes, and your love already.

Sometimes New York State's $100 billion-plus budget seems a little like Albany's own Treasure Island. Dig here, under a mountain of paper, or excavate there, behind big closed doors, and -- eureka -- suddenly there are hundreds of millions of extra dollars for state leaders to hand out like gold doubloons to the districts of favored legislators. Insiders have a lot of names for these secret pools of slush: member items, bullet aid (as in shooting a bullet of cash to somebody's favorite cause) and GLOP, short for General Legislative Operations Programs. After heavy pressure from journalists and a few politicians recently, Governor George Pataki and legislative leaders -- Joseph Bruno in the Senate and Sheldon Silver in the Assembly -- have begun providing a few details. We now know who got some of these items. What we don't know is who gave them. Data released by the Senate -- at www.senate.state.ny.us/sws/2006cpf/senatecpf06.pdf -- lists almost 3,500 grants. Without a Senate password, it is hard to sort the data by county or ZIP code to figure out which area got the most. ''It may not be wrapped up for you in a tidy little package,'' Mr. Bruno's spokesman said. ''But it's public.''
To the Editor: Re ''The Echoes of His Mind Just Keep Reverberating'' [Sept. 24]:

DENHAM--Mary Orr Actress and author, died September 22, 2006 at age 94. She was preceded in death by her husband, Reginald Denham, with whom she collaborated on writing scripts for the theater, notably ''Wallflower'' which premiered on Broadway at the Cort Theater in 1944. She published many works of her own including the short story ''The Wisdom of Eve'' which appeared first in 1947 in Cosmopolitan Magazine and resulted in the 1950 Academy Award winning movie ''All About Eve.'' Mary is survived by nieces, Lenschen Witte and Jessica Ivan of Ohio, and step grandchildren Tamara Ustinov, Mark Warrington and Elizabeth Warrington of the UK. Services will be private.

ROSENBLATT--Elaine D. on September 25 after a short illiness. Survived by daughter Hermine Trauner, son-in-law Richard, grandchildren Rachel and Matthew, brother Stuart Eckert. Donations to Hadassah Israel would be appreciated.

It's fitting that ''THE CLEAN HOUSE'' and ''MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE'' start performances on Thursday, since each play, in very different ways, raises the same question: What took so long? ''My Name Is Rachel Corrie'' is a solo drama based on e-mail messages and journal entries written by Ms. Corrie, an American demonstrator for Palestinian rights who was killed in Gaza by an Israeli bulldozer in 2003. The play has been at the center of one of the most furious controversies in the theater in years, even though few people in New York have seen it. The brouhaha began earlier this year after the New York Theater Workshop announced that it was delaying the play. Critics cried censorship, while representatives from the theater said it needed more time to ''contextualize'' the play. When ''Rachel Corrie'' begins performances at the Minetta Lane, we can finally see what the fuss is about. Previews begin Thursday; runs Oct. 15 to Nov. 19, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village, (212) 420-8000; $45 to $65. SARAH RUHL, a 32-year-old playwright, has been celebrated across the country, winning several prizes and receiving major productions at prominent regional theaters like the Arena Stage in Washington, the Goodman Theater in Chicago and the Berkeley Repertory Theater. But her plays have been notably absent from New York, until now. ''The Clean House,'' a fantastical romantic comedy, begins performances at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Thursday. The timing is impeccable, since the play, which was a finalist for the Pulitzer, arrives soon after Ms. Ruhl was awarded a MacArthur fellowship (popularly known as the ''genius grant''). That should draw even more attention to this long-awaited debut. Set in what the script refers to as a ''metaphysical Connecticut,'' ''The Clean House'' involves a doctor who hires a Brazilian maid with an odd professional quirk: she hates to clean. Previews begin Thursday, runs Oct. 30 to Dec. 17, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200; $75 ($70 for previews).

When the Wharton Club of New York revived its Joseph Wharton Awards after a 15-year hiatus, it gave one of the honors to a rug merchant. Not just any rug merchant, of course, but Connie K. Duckworth, a retired managing director of Goldman Sachs, for her work as founder of Arzu, a nonprofit group that employs Afghan women as carpet weavers and provides education and health care for their families. Ms. Duckworth said her Wharton training ''helps me bring private-sector skills to apply to public-sector problems.'' Arzu has sold 350 rugs to buyers like Laura Bush and Nicky Hilton; Ms. Duckworth said it would soon sell 1,000 annually.

FAGAN--Frank, Poet. Author of The Moonlit Door, The Derelict Genius of Martin M, Maginn, and Pick A Word. Poet, soldier, editor, political organizer, Frank Fagan died swiftly September 22nd. He was 68. Novelist Burt Cole wrote that his poetry transmuted ordinary, everyday agonies into things of beauty and that no poet was more aware of the absurdities and indignities of existence. Frank lived intentionally, with great human dignity, elegance, and wit. He leaves the products of that life to us. He is survived by his family, dear friends, loves.

MICHAEL RICE has built his fortune in potato chips and pretzels, but the home he plans to build here has gotten him into somewhat of a pickle. A group of his neighbors, calling themselves Save Avalon Dunes, intends to take Mr. Rice to court to stop him from building a 14,881-square-foot summer house on the dunes around 52nd Street. Many of the opponents -- who have started a boycott of Utz snacks, the company that Mr. Rice is chief executive of -- have million-dollar homes themselves in this Cape May County resort. Meanwhile, up north in Rumson, two other wealthy homeowners are sniping at each other over whether one's new caretaker's house will ruin the views of the other.

IN New Jersey, the debate over the debates is an annual rite of the campaign season. Both sides fight over the location, the time, the format and every other detail. And by the time they have compromised on the logistics, the end product is often bland, harmless and of interest only to political devotees. But this year could -- or, perhaps more aptly, should -- be an exception. That's because, with only six weeks left before the election, the two candidates for United States Senate are largely unknown quantities.

SPAGNOLI--Ilya, 78. Passed away on September 15th, 2006. Loving wife of the late professor emeritus John J. Spagnoli of Brooklyn College. Beloved aunt, compassionate counselor to the bereaved, instructor Hofstra University and Molloy College. Donations Channel 13 PBS NY.

An article last Sunday about American women in combat misstated their role in the initial invasion of Iraq in 2003. Although they were not in combat units, they did serve as leaders and in support units.

A picture caption on Sept. 17 with the Dance entry in the Week Ahead report misidentified the dancer in ''Back to the Present,'' a work that was choreographed by Constanza Macras and that had its American premiere at Dance Theater Workshop last month. She is Yeri Anarika Vargas Sanchez, not Ms. Macras.

As Connecticut pursued what was left of its legal battle to have the federal No Child Left Behind law declared unconstitutional last week, state officials and local educators are trying to grapple with an increase in the number of schools that did not show enough improvement. More than half of Connecticut's elementary and middle schools met the increasingly rigorous standards that were measured on statewide reading, writing and math tests given last March, according to the State Department of Education, which released results in August.

To the Editor: Your article about nervous fliers portrays the medical management of post-9/11 flight fright. But anti-anxiety medication by itself cannot overcome the fear of flying for the majority of flight phobics.
Members of Congress are expected to help fill their parties' campaign chests, a form of dues-paying that is central to the Democrats' strategy to overtake the Republicans. Page 25.

More than a dozen flavors of gelato are made at Mara's Café and Bakery in Westwood, including amaretto, chocolate-dipped strawberry and coconut. But if you love Italian confections, you'll want to try flavors like tiramisù and stracciatella (chocolate chip). The machinery and the recipes are directly from Italy, and the gelato is made right in the cafe. Gelato not only tastes good, it's better for you than ice cream. Made with whole milk, it has a lower fat content, and with less air whipped into it, it's a denser product -- creamy-tasting, without the cream.

The Marsh & McLennan Companies chose its finance chief, M. Michele Burns, to succeed E. Michael Caulfield as chief executive of its Mercer Human Resource Consulting unit, which advises companies on how much to pay their top officers. Ms. Burns, it should be noted, left a number of shareholders, creditors and employees at her previous employer, the Mirant Corporation, disgruntled over the amount she was paid while the company was in bankruptcy reorganization.

The chief state's attorney, Kevin T. Kane, closed a criminal investigation into M. Lisa Moody, Gov. M. Jodi Rell's chief of staff, last Tuesday, defusing an election-year controversy. In a letter to the chairmen of the Legislature's Government Administration and Elections Committee, which had asked Mr. Kane to investigate Ms. Moody, Mr. Kane wrote, ''There is no evidence that would support a criminal prosecution.''

KATZ--Barbara Ann Cohen, 72, of New York and Massachusettes. Beloved mother of Debra and Nancy, sister of Martin Cohen of CT. President German Wine Society, Inaugural Member Les Dames d'Escoffier, Officer Wine and Food Society, member La Chaine des Rotisseurs and Le Tastevin. Private service was held. We'll never forget you. Memorial foundation contributions call 917-687-5214.
HIRSCHFELD--Phyllis D. Our special, forever friend, ''Dusty,'' whose love for life enhanced all those who were privileged to know her. Elaine and Al Corwin

BENEATH the stained-glass windows and stenciled walls of the Charter Oak Cultural Center, dancers from the Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble and the singers of Women of the Cross, a spiritual trio, acted out the lives of inmates from the York Correctional Institution, a women's prison in Niantic. In their rehearsal last month for the upcoming performance of ''Time In,'' an exploration of time spent behind bars, the performers spoke of waiting for the hours to pass, of how they came to be inmates and of how they supported one another.

THE industrialists, the trust-fund babies and the Wall Street heavy hitters are having to make way for a new group of buyers of hugely expensive, high-status apartments in New York City: the real estate boom millionaires. At the Trump International Hotel and Tower at 1 Central Park West, at the foot of the park, a king of American sausage turned the keys of his condo over to a developer who built shopping centers for Wal-Mart.

To the Editor: Your editorial about the sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village (''A Battle on the Lower East Side,'' Sept. 17) acknowledges that Manhattan is becoming more off-limits to all but the truly wealthy, yet insists that resources be directed only to producing affordable housing in the other four boroughs. I do not share your vision of Manhattan as an enclave for only the richest New Yorkers.

ERENBURG--Frieda of Boca Raton, FL passed away September 26, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Saul, loving mother, grandmother and greatgrand mother. Services were held in Boca Raton. For information: Gutterman's 1-800-992-9262

To the Editor: The claim that he spent more than $35,000 per year on average per child for 16 years of education suggests that Michael Wolff, the reviewer of Daniel Golden's ''Price of Admission'' (Sept. 17), has lost his mind. We here in the flyover states, with our decent public schools and great state universities, could, only with real effort, spend $12,000 per year on average for our children for 16 years, and that includes all the costs of full fare at Harvard: just to make it clear, this is less than $200,000. A more rational parent would invest Wolff's $566,000 a head in a mutual fund, which the children could use to get on with their lives. Raymond Carroll College Station, Tex.

Maybe you're thinking the world is in sorry shape? That the human race is terminally dysfunctional? That plain old everyday life is surreal beyond words? Cartoonists could not agree more, as you'll discover in ''MASTERS OF AMERICAN COMICS,'' a show of some 500 books, zines, strips and sketches by 15 artists, ranging from Winsor McCay (''Little Nemo in Slumberland'') and George Herriman (''Krazy Kat'') in the early 20th century to contemporary figures like Gary Panter and Chris Ware. The difference of course is that cartoonists do what all artists do: they see what's funny and awful before we do, then make us see it. Think of Mad magazine. Think of ''Maus.'' And think you will at this show, which is divided between two locations: the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, and the Newark Museum. Through Jan. 28, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org; Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, (973) 596-6550, newarkmuseum.org. Connoisseurs of everyday surrealism will certainly want to schedule a jaunt to the Milwaukee Art Museum sometime before Jan. 1 for ''BIEDERMEIER: THE INVENTION OF SIMPLICITY.'' The Biedermeier period lasted in Northern Europe for a scant 15 years (1815-30), but its name became code for the charmless comfiness of the bourgeois culture. The real story is stranger and more complicated than that, and is told here in 400 pieces of furniture, silver, glass and metalwork that manage to be designed to a fare-thee-well and look clunkily maladroit, right down to a stack of proto-Tupperware coffee bowls. And for something completely different, let me recommend the permanent collection display that just opened at the Fowler Museum at the University of California, Los Angeles. Titled ''INTERSECTIONS: WORLD ARTS, LOCAL LIVES,'' the selection of 250 objects includes Burmese marionettes, Asian-Pacific textiles, Northwest American Indian masks and contemporary work from Haiti, Mexico and South Africa. Spanning centuries of multicultural creativity, this exhibition is the kind of art experience that might restore your faith in the sad old human comedy. How nice that the installation is on long-term view.

An editorial last week noted that Gov. George Pataki named Charles Gargano, a close associate, to two public jobs. Both positions are unpaid. Mr. Gargano's job as head of the Empire State Development Corporation pays a salary of $145,000 a year.

ABADIE--MJ. Died Wednesday, September 13, 2006, in Nacogdoches, Texas. She authored and co - authored many published books, assisting with and designing The Mythic Image (1974) by Joseph Campbell, with whom she worked for many years. She met Mr. Campbell when she edited for Bollingen Press. A woman of great brilliance, generosity, and talent, Ms. Abadie counseled people, traveled Europe and was a gourmet cook. She had moved back to Texas to be with family and to write. She is survived by her nephews Victor Hugo Abadie III; J. Paul Abadie; Marcus G. Abadie, MD; Carl Abadie; and her only niece, Margaret Jeanne Marie Abadie Whittaker.

While it's essential to look out for exciting events and performers who work on the margins of New York's mainstream cultural institutions, this week the big news in classical music is being made by the behemoths. Carnegie Hall opens its season on Wednesday night with a gala concert by the mighty CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA, the first of three programs. The orchestra's visit is timely, since many concertgoers and critics still seem to be making up their minds about the highly skilled and serious-minded 46-year-old Austrian conductor FRANZ WELSER-MÖST, now in his fourth season as the orchestra's music director. Two soloists will be featured: the splendid Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 17, and the elegant German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff in a group of Mahler songs. There will also be some waltzes and overtures by Strauss, repertory Mr. Welser-Most conducts with grace and buoyancy. Wednesday at 7, Thursday and Saturday at 8, (212) 247-7800; $37 to $190. Meanwhile Lincoln Center's Great Performers season opens on Saturday with the LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA in Beethoven's Symphonies No. 2 and 3 (''Eroica''), conducted by the eminent BERNARD HAITINK, the first of five programs surveying all nine Beethoven symphonies. Mr. Haitink's recent recordings of these works with this orchestra, now available on the LSO Live label, are probing, fresh and brilliantly played. Sunday afternoon's program offers Beethoven's Fifth and Eighth. Saturday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500; $35 to $85.

THE Powder Ridge ski area in Middlefield, one of the state's oldest ski slopes, has announced that it will not operate this season, because of financial problems. Ken Leavitt, who bought the ski area from the previous owners, the Zemel family, in 1997, said that he wanted to build a water park there and operate it year-round. He said, however, that a 10-year battle with the town to obtain the permit for the water park, begun before he took ownership, cost him $3 million in legal fees and studies and left him short of money. He received the permit in 2003, but did not build because he did not have enough funds.

Lori Ann Alvino was married yesterday to Matthew Dempsey McGill at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Patrick Flynn performed the ceremony. Ms. Alvino McGill, 29, was until July a law clerk to Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court. She graduated from Columbia, where she also received a law degree as a Kent scholar.

VIRGINIA The News -- George Allen, the Republican senator from Virginia who is in a tough re-election fight, was accused of using racial slurs decades ago. Behind the News -- The claims by three former acquaintances kept alive questions about Mr. Allen's racial sensitivity that have dogged his campaign since the spring. Mr. Allen denied ever using racist language, but the accusations raised doubts among political analysts that he can hold off the Democratic challenger, Jim Webb. And the controversy seemed to quash any presidential aspirations for Mr. Allen. NEW YORK The News -- Federal prosecutors said they were investigating whether Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for New York attorney general, illegally taped conversations of her husband. Behind the News -- Ms. Pirro acknowledged talking about taping her husband, who she thought was having an extramarital affair. She said she did nothing illegal, and accused the investigators of conducting a witch hunt. But party leaders were not rushing to her defense, and there were doubts whether her candidacy could survive this latest controversy. NEW JERSEY The News -- Senator Robert Menendez, the New Jersey Democrat, severed ties with a political adviser and fund-raiser who was taped seven years ago pressuring a contractor to hire someone as a favor to Mr. Menendez. Behind the News -- The adviser, Donald Scarinci, said that his actions were not requested by Mr. Menendez. Still, the revelation was the latest in a string of ethics-related problems for Mr. Menendez, who was appointed to the Senate in January and is now considered vulnerable in his re-election race against Thomas H. Kean Jr. WASHINGTON STATE The News -- The Republican candidate for Senate from Washington State, Mike McGavick, dropped in some polls after revealing various transgressions including an arrest for drunken driving in 1993. Behind the News -- Mr. McGavick's unprovoked late-summer confessional, in which, among other things, he also admitted to lying to employees of his company about layoffs, was a calculated gamble that voters would appreciate his honesty. But polls since the revelations showed he was still struggling against the incumbent Democrat, Maria Cantwell. FLORIDA The News -- Representative Mark Foley, a five-term Florida Republican who was sailing toward re-election, resigned abruptly after it was reported that he had sent sexually explicit electronic messages to underage male Congressional pages. Behind the News -- It was a startling downfall for Mr. Foley, who just last summer had introduced legislation to protect children from exploitation by adults over the Internet. And it raised new political problems for Republicans trying to keep control of the House, as a ''safe'' seat became wide open overnight.

Starting next February, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority will begin swapping about a million E-ZPass transponders belonging to customers whose current models are losing battery life. The G2 model, which has been in circulation for several years and operates on a lithium battery, has a flaw that causes it to use more power by broadcasting a signal on the same frequencies as many cellular phones, said Joseph Orlando, a spokesman for the Turnpike Authority. The new G3 model -- which looks the same on the outside -- uses the same battery but broadcasts on a dedicated E-ZPass signal. Its battery has an expected life of about seven years.

The Habitats article on Sept. 17 about Sven and Janet Lapiner and their home in Brooklyn Heights misstated the surname and omitted the middle initial of the broker who handled the sale. He is Kevin J. Carberry, not Carbury. The article also misstated Mr. Carberry's professional status. He is a broker, not a Realtor.

10:30 P.M. (E!) HOUSE OF CARTERS -- What doesn't kill you makes you stronger, right? (11) EVERYBODY HATES CHRIS -- And that includes Louise, a new neighborhood grandmother played by Whoopi Goldberg (right, with Tyler James Williams as Chris) in a recurring role. In this season premiere, Louise decides to take control of the block. 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION -- Let the tears flow! To start off this new season, Ty Pennington and his crew rebuild the Michigan home of Maryann Gilliam and her six children, who have been shuttling among friends and family since their father died unexpectedly on Christmas Eve from complications from mold spores growing in their house. The Practical Traveler column on Page 6 of today's Travel section includes outdated information about changes in passport rules for Americans returning to the United States. Because of legislation passed after the section went to press, changes in the rules for travel by land or sea have been delayed until June 1, 2009. Americans returning by air will have to show their passports beginning Jan. 8, as noted in the column.

GARSIDE--Grenville, 76, at home in Norfolk, Conn.on September 22. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Lawrence Garside of Norfolk; his sister, Helen G. Randolph, Cambridge, Mass.; his daughter, Elizabeth R. Garside, Washington, D.C.; his sons, Jonathan H. Garside, St. Louis, Mo.and Alexander C. Garside, Portsmouth, N.H.; and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held November 4 at Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk.

SCHULTZ--Frances. The family of Frances Schultz announces with sorrow the passing of its beloved matriarch on September 28, 2006. Services Wednesday, October 4th at Plaza, Amsterdam and 91 St, NYC at 12 noon.

SCHNEIDER--Lillian. 95, formerly of Long Beach, NY, currently of New York City, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on Thursday, September 28, 2006. She will always be remembered by those near and dear to her. Her zest for living life to the fullest was immeasurable. She lived by the motto ''laughter is the best medicine.'' Lillian's greatest joy in life was her family, her son & daughter-in-law, Steven & Ann, her daughter, Dorothy, her grandchildren, Jodi, Gary, David & Rosanne, & Lisa & Scott, her great grandchildren, Joshua, Melissa, Zachary, Stephanie & Ian, her two sisters' Edna & Eunice and her brother, Lou, as well as her nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. ''Lilly,'' you'll always be in our hearts! Services will be held Sunday, October 1st at 11:30 AM, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, NY.

BENEATH the stained-glass windows and stenciled walls of the Charter Oak Cultural Center, dancers from the Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble and the singers of Women of the Cross, a spiritual trio, acted out the lives of inmates from the York Correctional Institution, a women's prison in Niantic. In their rehearsal last month for the upcoming performance of ''Time In,'' an exploration of time spent behind bars, the performers spoke of waiting for the hours to pass, of how they came to be inmates and of how they supported one another.
To the Editor: Re ''You Are Cleared for Takeoff'' (Sept. 17), by Alex Williams:

PERCHED high above the Saw Mill River Parkway in this well-to-do hamlet, the Reader's Digest global headquarters look more like a college campus than a corporate nerve center. Meadows, trees and pink flowers ring the property. And the company's original brick Georgian-style office building still stands on the western edge of the 120-acre campus, topped with a 32-foot-high white cupola visible from the parkway.

GREENE--Jerome D. II (Jerry). 83, of Guilford, CT, and Bondville, VT, died on September 29, 2006, after a valiant struggle with many illnesses. Jerry was the founder and President of MarketMath, Inc in 1965 in New York City, a highly respected statistical consulting firm. He and his firm received many awards for their contributions to the media and publishing industries. He graduated from Harvard, Class of '45, and served in the U.S. Merchant Marine in WWII. He was a member of the Harvard Club of NYC, as well as the ASA, MRA, AAPOR and the Modeler's Group in NYC, which he founded. His survivors include his beloved wife of 35 years, Helen Wippich Greene; a daughter, Sarah Wrightson of Santa Fe, NM; a sister, Elizabeth G. Crichton of Bondville, VT; a half-sister, Charlotte O'Brien Young of San Francisco; an uncle, David Greene, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL; and nephews, Kyle and Marc Crichton among others. A memorial service will be scheduled in Bondville, VT, at a later date.

SINCE Nancy Solomon, a folklorist, moved to Long Island from Montpelier, Vt., in 1987, she has been documenting and trying to help preserve the vernacular architecture of ordinary life. Working closely with local historians, she has focused on buildings constructed by American Indians, African-Americans and Dutch and English settlers, ranging from modest farmhouses and barns, gristmills and slave cabins to stores and windmills.

To the Editor: I am a full-time wheelchair user because of polio and wanted all my fellow disabled travelers to be aware of the outstanding service offered by Qantas Airlines. They have, onboard all standard trans-Pacific flights, a full-size aisle chair and a bathroom to accommodate it, unless there is a last-minute change of aircraft. The Qantas staff was absolutely on top of my needs before I could anticipate them, and actually asked me if I needed to use the facilities on a regular basis. I must also add that as a first-time visitor to Australia, the onboard purser was there to inform me of procedures regarding the return of my motorized chair at Sydney Airport, and offered me tips on touring and accessibility in Sydney. Daniel Holleb Palm Desert, Calif.

For many years now Paul Berman, a self-described ''literature-and-politics man,'' has rigorously examined the contradictions of ideological commitment, most recently in his books ''Terror and Liberalism'' and ''Power and the Idealists.'' Berman's own ideological path has taken some interesting turns. A participant in the Columbia University protests of the late 1960's, he later wrote skeptically about leftist governments in Latin America.

JUST blocks from the campus of Yale, a group of women are also attending classes, but they are learning a basic survival skill: how to sew. The women compose a patchwork of lives shipwrecked by society, families or personal demons; they have ended up without steady homes, in shelters or doubled up with family. Some are fighting crack or alcohol. But they are bolstered by a three-year-old program called Village of Power and its lyrically titled offshoot, Growing Through Sewing.

JOE TORRE was never the victim of his father's abuse, but growing up in a violent household still left a mark on him. Mr. Torre remembers the shouting and the screaming as his father tormented his mother, Margaret. He can remember standing in the kitchen, as his father -- a police officer -- escalated the terror by reaching into a drawer for his revolver. He recalls his older brothers and sisters trying to shield him, the youngest of five, from what was going on. Yet even into his mid-50's, Mr. Torre, the manager of the Yankees, who is now 66, hadn't connected his feelings of insecurity and anxiety to growing up in a violent home. It wasn't until he attended a weekend self-help retreat in 1995 with his wife, Ali, that he began to connect emotionally with his childhood.

Rebecca Haggerty and Mark Patrick Williams were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Kevin Sullivan, the executive director of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Haggerty Williams, 29, is the fund-raising specialist at the National Museum of the American Indian of the Smithsonian Institution in New York. She was until April the assistant director of communications and marketing at Catholic Charities. She graduated from Fordham and received a master's degree in public administration from Baruch College.

To the Editor: Like Stanley Crouch in his review of Flores Forbes's memoir, ''Will You Die With Me?'' (Sept. 10), I welcome some truth-telling that corrects the bloated hero worship of the Black Panthers. Most of the revelations in the book were previously outlined in an article I wrote for New Times magazine 28 long years ago (''The Party's Over,'' May 1978), the culmination of an eight-month investigation by me and the reporter Paul Avery under the auspices of the Center for Investigative Reporting in San Francisco. After the piece appeared, Huey P. Newton and his attorney, Michael Kennedy, called a press conference announcing a $6 million lawsuit against me and New Times while parading around little Panther children with signs accusing me of taking away their breakfast program. The lawsuit was never filed. The hagiography of Newton actually increased after his death. Then, one by one, the top brass wrote their own versions of Panther history, now blaming everything bad on the dead Newton and his terrible cocaine habit. But that habit was in full force long before that, when I wrote my article, and so was the extortion, the fraud, the mud-holing draconian punishment for Panther rank and filers. Nothing seemed to dent the Panthers' good press during those years. It's encouraging to read of Forbes's escape from his former life and his obvious rehabilitation. But I was disappointed that Forbes didn't see fit to even mention murders carried out under Newton, including the time when Newton was a fugitive in Cuba. The murder of Betty Van Patter, the white bookkeeper for the Panthers who disappeared after she threatened to go public with illegalities she had uncovered in doing the books for the Panther bar, the Lamp Post, does not appear anywhere in Forbes's book. At the time Elaine Brown was running for an Oakland City Council seat, and Van Patter's going public could have sunk her campaign. Van Patter was last seen alive at the Lamp Post, where she'd been summoned. Her body was found 35 days later in the San Francisco Bay. Whatever Forbes may know about this and other murders, he has not chosen to share it with readers. Furthermore, it is with great skepticism that I regard Forbes's assertion that the idea for the (botched) assassination attempt on the witness in Newton's murder trial was Forbes's own idea. Throughout the book he details his absolute loyalty in a rigid top-down organization. He was the youngest of the squad of enforcers and the most disciplined. He is covering up in my opinion, and quite possibly it is to protect those who orchestrated it and are still very much alive. I did learn a few new things from Forbes's book: Mayor Lionel Wilson spared Forbes -- when Wilson was a judge -- on an early charge after Elaine Brown promised him full Panther support for his first mayoral run; and, far more surprising, Forbes writes that he considered the Oakland ''pigs'' (cops) to be downright decent compared to the police in Los Angeles. Who knew! Kate Coleman Berkeley, Calif.

FOR the past five springs, a pair of Baltimore Orioles has returned to our yard to nest. This year I was worried. The last I had seen of the dazzling orange patriarch, he was bravely, desperately leading a screeching redtail hawk away from his brood. Then they all vanished. Thus when Daddy-O returned this spring, I rejoiced -- and followed the flash of wings to the hammocklike nest swinging high in our maple tree. The fledging of the ensuing baby orioles took place at a tender time in our human nest; our 16-year-old son, Sam, had gotten his driver's permit. It was a milestone I've dreaded since he began taking solid food. So it was only natural that I would do the sappy Mom thing and anthropomorphize the avian drama. I envied Mama Oriole her apparent sangfroid as the baby birds plunged, flapping, into the void. The female chick was cautious, taking short test flights to nearby branches. Her two snazzy brothers favored the kamikaze approach; death-defying free falls landed them, tweeting and flailing, in the trumpet vine. Every time they made it back to the nest, a squawky fracas ensued that sounded to my fretful maternal ears like a warbled equivalent of ''What were you thinking?''

EVERY Yom Kippur for what seemed an eternity, evening services at the Orthodox synagogue here opened with the improbably huge voice of a surprisingly small man, the revered cantor Hirsch Chazin, chanting the mournful Kol Nidre. When he died at the age of 97, he was laid to rest in a small cemetery near the reservoir at the edge of town, among congregants in whose eyes he had raised tears for decades. ''I can still hear that basso-profundo voice,'' said Dr. Mona Shangold, whose great-grandparents were among the earliest members of Congregation Shaarey Tefiloh, when this immigrant city was home to a thriving Jewish community.

To the Editor: Re ''In Tiny Courts of New York, Abuses of Law and Power'' (''Broken Bench'' series, front page, Sept. 25): As a former village justice in Dobbs Ferry, I commend your article about the problems and shortcomings of the town and village court system of New York State.

LANIGAN--Thomas L. A leading editor in chemistry, biochemistry, and molecular biology died on Sunday, September 24, 2006 in Passaic, New Jersey. He was the founder of the Science, Technology and Medicine publisher The Humana Press, Inc. Born on August 23, 1938, in Oswego, New York, Mr. Lanigan earned a bachelor'S degree in chemistry from Le Moyne College, Syracuse, New York, and a master's degree in physical chemistry from St. John's University. While working on his PhD he entered scientific publishing as an editor, first at Academic Press, then at Plenum Press in New York City. Mr. Lanigan founded Humana Press in 1977 and built it into a leading publisher of cutting-edge research in molecular biology and molecular medicine, cancer research, heart disease, neuroscience, and neurology, a list of over a thousand titles and twentyfour journals, serving a wide spectrum of the scientific and medical research communities. Humana Press was recently acquired by Springer Science and Business Media, which will maintain the Humana imprint. Humana Press also published belles lettres, a lifelong passion of Mr. Lanigan, including novels by Demetrio Aguilera-Malta, the celebrated magic realist of Ecuador, and the autobiography of Vincent Zigas, an early researcher in prion disease. Although his main focus for the past thirty years has been to build Humana Press, Mr. Lanigan indulged his passion for the theater, music, and visual arts, and continued to write poetry. He was an avid collector of contemporary paintings and graphics. He was a philanthropist and, with his wife, endowed an interdisciplinary chair at Le Moyne College to promote the study science, medicine, and ethics, and their interactions. Mr. Lanigan is survived by his wife of 41 years, Julia Bartko Lanigan, who served as Humana Press's vice president of operations from 1991 to 2006 and by their son Thomas B. Lanigan of Weston, Florida, who was marketing director of Humana from 1993 to 2006. Also surviving are his mother, Mary Ellen Lanigan of Oswego, and his brothers and sisters, James of Manchester, NH; Mary of Syracuse; Charles and Frances of Oswego; Terance, of Phoenix, Arizona; Elizabeth of Rochester, NY; and Patrick of Watertown, NY.

The Footsteps column on Sept. 17 about Morelia, Mexico, a town used as a setting for part of Wallace Stegner's novel ''Angle of Repose,'' misstated the position in the Roman Catholic Church held by Don Vasco de Quiroga, the subject of a statue in the town. He was a bishop, not a monk.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Tennessee Williams and his play ''The Parade, or Approaching the End of a Summer,'' which examines his relationship with Kip Kiernan, misspelled the given name of the Russian dancer whom the playwright thought Kiernan resembled. He was Vaslav Nijinsky, not Vasla.

JAPANESE and French cuisines, teamed at restaurants around the globe, seem fundamentally dissimilar: Simple, minimal and pure versus complex, baroque and heavy. Yet at Ixora, in Whitehouse Station, Timothy Chang, the restaurant's owner and executive chef, standing on a foundation of Japanese classics, uses some French techniques and finds global inspiration, to delicious effect.

To the Editor: Something I learned in second grade profoundly shaped my view of school uniforms (''Do Clothes Make the Student?,'' Sept. 17).
To the Editor: Re ''Some Good News Arrives at Last for a Bad News Bear'' by Mark Olsen [Sept. 17]:

THE photo album on the coffee table in this toy-strewn house, a souvenir of a summer wedding that kicked off what should have been a festive Fourth of July weekend in 2005, is a tear-jerker, and for all the wrong reasons. To leaf through it is to take a sentimental journey with the cruelest ending imaginable. The album is bound in white satin, but the name stenciled in gold on its cover is not that of the bride, nor does it focus on the bride and groom. Instead, it chronicles an extroverted 7-year-old flower girl in an ivory party dress with a pink sash the color of the rose petals she tossed on the beach the day her aunt was married, a day that ended with the decapitation of the flower girl, Katie Flynn, in a grisly crash that the police say was caused by a drunken driver in a pickup truck careering north in the Meadowbrook Parkway's southbound lanes.

SCHOOLS in Westchester and on Long Island performed better over all than other schools in New York State on the new English tests given to elementary and middle school students last spring, according to results released by the state on Sept. 21. But schools around the state, with few exceptions in Westchester and Long Island, showed a decline in performance among middle school students compared with elementary school students.

Alison Lee Massagli and Matthew Thomas Carrano were married yesterday. The Rev. Eleanor Applewhite Terry, an Episcopal priest and a friend of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Wesleyan Memorial Chapel in Middletown, Conn. Mrs. Carrano, 28, is a project manager for government and business security matters at Telemus Solutions in Falls Church, Va. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in May in security studies from Georgetown University.

THE voters of the Republican Party have been fractious, with cultural conservatives vying with antitax and antispending blocs for the president's attentions. But the G.O.P. is a portrait of unity compared with the Democratic electorate. Democrats have been called a collection of interest groups. Rather than the donkey, perhaps the cat, notoriously resistant to herding, would make a better symbol.

After the force play at second for the final out, Cardinals second baseman Ronnie Belliard stepped off the bag and raised his arms, and shortstop David Eckstein pumped a fist. For the first time in a week and a half, the Cardinals and their fans could exhale. The collapse appeared to have abated just short of historic, and it brought a postseason spot finally in sight. Thanks to pinch-hitter Scott Spiezio's three-run triple in the eighth against Milwaukee closer Francisco Cordero, the Cardinals outlasted the Brewers, 3-2, on Saturday to clinch a tie for the National League Central title.

Sometimes New York State's $100 billion-plus budget seems a little like Albany's own Treasure Island. Dig here, excavate there, and -- eureka -- one suddenly discovers hundreds of millions of extra dollars for state leaders to hand out like gold doubloons to the districts of favored legislators. These secret pools of slush are known, most commonly, as member items. After heavy pressure from journalists and a few politicians recently, legislative leaders -- Joseph Bruno in the Senate and Sheldon Silver in the Assembly -- have begun providing a few details. We now know who got some of these items. What we don't know is who gave them. Data released by the Senate -- at www.senate.state.ny.us/sws/2006cpf/senatecpf06.pdf -- lists almost 3,500 grants. Without a Senate password, it is hard to sort the data by county or ZIP code to figure out which area got the most. ''It may not be wrapped up for you in a tidy little package,'' John McCardle, Mr. Bruno's spokesman said. ''But it's public.''

To the Editor: Liz Ureneck says of Tasti D-Lite, ''If I close my eyes, I can recite the location of every branch within a 20-block radius of any point in Manhattan,'' in her love letter to the low-calorie frozen dessert (''Why They Scream for Not-Quite Ice Cream,'' New York Observed, Sept. 24). But I bet that with her eyes closed, she couldn't taste the difference between chocolate macaroon and bananas Foster. All those flavors; the secret is that they all taste the same.

Casey Lee Emmer and David Richard Wright Jr. are to be married this evening by Vignetta Charles, a Universal Life minister, at Skytop Lodge in Pennsylvania. The bride, 28, is a program analyst in the Health and Human Services Department in Washington, specializing in public health and medical emergency response plans. She graduated from Emory and received a master's degree in public health from Harvard.

An article on Sept. 17 about the abundance of satire in American culture referred incorrectly to an episode of ''South Park.'' In it, the character Cartman tricks another child into eating his own parents in a bowl of chili; Cartman himself does not eat them.

JOE TORRE was never the victim of his father's abuse, but growing up in a violent household still left a mark on him. Mr. Torre remembers the shouting and the screaming as his father tormented his mother, Margaret. He can remember standing in the kitchen, as his father -- a police officer -- escalated the terror by reaching into a drawer for his revolver. He recalls his older brothers and sisters trying to shield him, the youngest of five, from what was going on. Yet even into his mid-50's, Mr. Torre, the manager of the Yankees, who is now 66, hadn't connected his feelings of insecurity and anxiety to growing up in a violent home. It wasn't until he attended a weekend self-help retreat in 1995 with his wife, Ali, that he began to connect emotionally with his childhood.

Don't expect balloons, a chorus of singers or an ice cream cake at this birthday bash. This is Pinter Land, where menace and mystery rule, the pause is king, and nothing is quite as it seems. ''The Birthday Party,'' written in 1957 by Harold Pinter, 2005 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, is receiving a first-rate production at McCarter Theater Center's Berlind Theater under the deft direction of Emily Mann. Ms. Mann has assembled a superb cast of seasoned players for this revival and, in her shaping of the play, has shown a keen ability to give resonance to the terror and imminent doom that inform so much of Mr. Pinter's work.

The Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, says that the preservation of farmland continues to be a priority for him. During the past two years, the county has saved more than 900 acres of farmland, including 26 working farms, and on Tuesday Mr. Levy signed three new farmland measures. The measures included resolutions to acquire 700 acres of active farmland; to allow 49 parcels of farmland totaling more than 1,100 acres to join existing county agricultural districts, making the owners eligible for tax abatements and grants; and to authorize the acquisition of development rights to Smoke Run Farm, a five-acre horse farm in Stony Brook.

Like Wyatt Mason's father, I am 79, a veteran of the U.S. Navy, and I, too, rage against what the Bush right-wing political machine has done to our country (Sept. 17). Both us old guys vent our anger at the madness around us by wrestling with the news in the columns and op-ed pages. Wyatt is also perturbed, but he doesn't confront. He quells his frustrationby taking ''shelter in the ridiculous,'' the satirical discourses of the Jon Stewarts and Rob Corddrys night after night on TV. I stopped watching them a long time ago. It's an exercise in futility. I, and apparently other members of my generation, are wary (and weary) of playing that game. Jack Rothman Los Angeles If the national news media have served to ''contain'' the outright lies served up by this administration, to package them in such a way as to make them seem within the parameters of acceptable political discourse, haven't satirists like Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, however inspired, also served to contain our outrage at this process by packaging our potential for anger in exquisitely written and produced comedy? Parallels with the Roman Empire are instructive: I wonder if something similar happened when Roman citizens, unable to act meaningfully against the original fascists, resorted to honing their wits rather than their weapons? Daniel Shannon Syracuse

To the Sports Editor: Re ''That Season Ticket on eBay? It Could Cost Seller the Seat'' (Sept. 25): eBay, the Yankees, the Mets and others are complicit in facilitating a thriving secondary market for tickets that values wealth over fan loyalty and packs stadiums in the postseason with the highest bidders rather than the most diehard fans.

ON local streets, new home and business construction may be leveling off, but it is booming on college campuses across the region. Educators and real estate analysts say that colleges and universities, public and private, big and small, are adding classrooms, dormitories, student centers and athletic centers at a scope and rate that have not been seen in decades. While students consider many factors when choosing a college, educators say that first-rate physical facilities are becoming increasingly important in attracting students.

SILVER--Martin J. On September 29th, 2006. Beloved husband of Joan, much loved and respected father to Andrew and Jan, Peter and Nancy, a very special and devoted ''Pop'' to Harry and Emily, loving brother of Hugh. He will always be remembered with love.

In the Sept. 3 column, the Ethicist told an art collector that accepting a proposal from a fellow collector to agree not to bid on the same prints in eBay auctions would be unethical. I agree. The Ethicist also reported a lawyer's advice that ''collusive bidding is illegal in the auction world,'' adding that it ''may not be illegal online -- Internet auctions are largely unregulated.'' But the federal antitrust laws apply to competition on Internet auctions as much as to physical auctions. Agreements between bidders not to bid against one another or to bid at certain prices are criminal violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act, punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Scott D. Hammond Deputy Assistant Attorney General Antitrust Division Department of Justice Washington

JOE TORRE was never the victim of his father's abuse, but growing up in a violent household still left a mark on him. Mr. Torre remembers the shouting and the screaming as his father tormented his mother, Margaret. He can remember standing in the kitchen, as his father -- a police officer -- escalated the terror by reaching into a drawer for his revolver. He recalls his older brothers and sisters trying to shield him, the youngest of five, from what was going on. Yet even into his mid-50's, Mr. Torre, the manager of the Yankees, who is now 66, hadn't connected his feelings of insecurity and anxiety to growing up in a violent home. It wasn't until he attended a weekend self-help retreat in 1995 with his wife, Ali, that he began to connect emotionally with his childhood.

Elizabeth Christine Froehlich, the daughter of Patricia and Edmond C. Froehlich of Toledo, Ohio, was married yesterday to Peter Joseph Zenobi, the son of Claudia and Gino Zenobi of Westlake Village, Calif. The Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Yale Club in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Zenobi work for advertising agencies in New York.

LEDERMAN--Abraham, 95 on September 23, 2006. Career optometrist at A&S. Cherished husband of Sylvia, father of Judith Landau, Marcia Riley and Rhoda Gena, grandfather of seven, great grandfather of three. A generous, devoted family man, Abe loved music, reading and politics.

The bulk of FALL FOR DANCE -- the too-good-to-be-true annual season that offers City Center audiences a plethora of companies from all over the world for just $10 a seat -- takes place this week. It's all worth attending, but the program on Thursday and Friday nights stands out. Pacific Northwest Ballet, performing Paul Gibson's lush ''Piano Dance,'' will be of particular interest to New Yorkers eager to see how this ensemble looks under the stewardship of the former City Ballet dancer Peter Boal. And the vivid visual tableaus by the New York choreographer Christopher Williams; the hallucinogenic merger of live and video bodies by the Bridgman/Packer company; and Random Dance's sharp, athletic ''Polar Sequences'' by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor should make for a terrific mix. 8 p.m., 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 247-0430 or NYCityCenter.org. ODILE DUBOC is the Trisha Brown of French contemporary dance, much admired during the late 1980's and early 90's for an autodidactic style that -- unlike the work of most of her contemporaries -- focused strongly on pure movement. Her company, CONTRE JOUR makes its American debut in a full evening of Ms. Duboc's work at the French Institute Alliance Française. The program includes an extract from her ''Trois boléros,'' and the 2003 ''trio,'' and -- most intriguingly -- offers a new solo performed by the 65-year-old Ms. Duboc. Wednesday and Thursday at 8 p.m., Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6160; $25. The 70th birthday of the composer STEVE REICH is being celebrated all over town, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music has a particularly inviting offering: a double bill, set to Mr. Reich's music, of ANNE TERESA DE KEERSMAEKER's rigorously austere duo ''Fase'' and AKRAM KHAN's ''Variations for Vibes, Pianos and Strings.'' Mr. Khan, known for his blend of Indian Kathak and contemporary dance technique, will appear alongside two dancers, the South Korean Young Jin Kim and the South African Gregory Maqoma, who should bring their own styles to the mix. Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m., 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100 or bam.org; $20 to $55.
THIS will not be the kind of authoritative parenting column that we all need. It will not be a parenting column like this:
To the Editor: Re ''On the Ocean, a Trump Deal,'' by Robin Finn (The Island column, Sept. 24):

This fall, designers are using ruffles as flourishes in varied and lovely ways. Whether in a classic jabot at the throat of a blouse, in micro-rows at the cuff of a sleeve or in one striking ripple down the front of a coat, ruffles are no longer party-girl tacky but are, by turns, racy, elegant, flirtatious and anything but predictable. Fancy that. 1. A single gorgeous ruffle tumbles down the front of Etro's striking coat like an endless length of ribbon candy ($2,230 at Saks Fifth Avenue stores). 2. A leopard-print Roberto Cavalli blouse has an unconstructed neckline and gracefully drapes at the shoulders and the sleeves ($1,425 at Roberto Cavalli boutiques). 3. Ruffles go bohemian on Be&D's suede handbags with beaded drawstrings and buckle shoulder straps (in red and chocolate, $1,280 at Saks Fifth Avenue stores). Serious handiwork in the form of four rows of suede ruffles adorns Bergdorf Goodman's rich brown nappa leather gloves ($195 at Bergdorf Goodman). 4. A sheer pink silk blouse with ruffles and a detachable ascot by Juicy Couture conjures up visions of a modern-day Marian the Librarian ($158 at Saks Fifth Avenue). The sharp tailoring of a Robert Rodriguez shirt is offset by micro-ruffles at the cuffs ($275 at www.eLuxury.com). 5. Nanette Lepore's High Society top has three tiers of frills and comes in red or cream silk (top, $195; pinstripe vest dress, $325, at Nanette Lepore in New York, 212-219-8265). 6. A felted striped cardigan by Marc by Marc Jacobs has an oversize offhand ruffle down one side ($248 at www.shopbop.com). Tory Burch's navy wool sweater gets an extra infusion of chic from print frills at collar and cuffs ($295 at www.toryburch.com). 7. A stretchy copper-hued knit dress by Hengst is a sexy standout with a yoke framed with a single ruffle ($418 at Searle stores).

To the Editor: Sol Wachtler's personal account of solitary confinement in a ''special housing unit'' (''A Cell of One's Own,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 24) graphically describes the sad, neglectful and dangerous handling of our mentally ill offenders in the New York State prison system. It is shameful that Governor Pataki vetoed a bill that would have prevented such treatment.

In New Jersey, the most recent statewide test results showed an increase over last year in the number of schools that improved their overall performance under the requirements of the federal No Child Left Behind law. But dozens of schools, unable to improve their test scores over several years, face the prospect of reorganization, state education officials said. A quarter of New Jersey's schools failed to meet the federal law's requirements this year, compared with a third of the state's schools in 2005, according to a preliminary report released by the state Department of Education in August. Under the law, students undergo statewide testing in math, reading and writing to determine whether a school meets the state's standards for academic performance.

PRESIDENT PERVEZ MUSHARRAF of Pakistan was in Washington, New York, and on TV screens across the United States last week to promote his country's efforts to counter Al Qaeda, but that was not all. He was also promoting his new autobiography ''In the Line of Fire: A Memoir.'' Speaking at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York Tuesday, the general repeatedly made statements that his critics, and some experts, questioned. Here are some of his remarks as transcribed by the Federal News Service, with responses from United Nations, Pakistani and United States officials. Economic Growth ''Today, our G.D.P. growth over the last four years is 7 percent. Our per capita income has more than doubled. Our G.D.P. has doubled.''

To the Editor: The answer to the question in your article (The Hunt, ''When Modern is Out of Fashion,'' Sept. 24) about why there is so much midcentury modern in the West and so little on the East Coast is this: A vast majority of modern homes in North America were built after World War II from 1945 to 1970. The West experienced a housing boom during this period caused by a confluence of the end of the war, the G.I. Bill of Rights, available space and the migration of people West. All of this intersected with the modern aesthetic that had taken root right before the war. Richard Corff Seattle The writer is the founder of 360degrees Modern, a real estate brokerage company.

An article last Sunday about young British fashion designers misspelled the given name of a designer famous for his minimalist style. He is Helmut Lang, not Helmet.

TIEFER--Rosalind Crost, 92, Meadowview, Mt. Vernon, NY, died September 28, 2006. Born to Brooklyn Jews of Dutch descent, graduated from Brooklyn College ('33), Juilliard, and Columbia Teachers' College. Rosalind won piano prizes and a Philharmonic scholarship, played in Simeon Bellison's Clarinet Ensemble and countless concerts, trained student bands, choruses and orchestras, directed musicals at summer camps, prepared young musicians for auditions, and taught both music and world history from 1938 to 1971 at Walton and Theodore Roosevelt High Schools. After ''retirement,'' Ros performed with the Bronx Opera, American Landmark Festivals, Hudson River Choral Society, and at Community Church of New York. After the death of her deeply loved husband Abraham David in 1981 she became an intrepid world traveller and active member of Westchester NOW and its book club. She directed Yonkers Temple Emanu-El Women's Chorus concerts at nursing homes for a decade. Ros leaves her grieving children, Leonore and Charles, daughter-in-law Hillary, and beloved grandsons Max and Roy. Her lifelong undimmable passions for great music, intellectual rigor, progressive politics, and family are her legacy. Memorial service to be announced.
CHAPTER 2

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about bicycling in New York misstated the location of a view along Houston Street. Bicyclists in the photograph were crossing the Bowery, not Second Avenue.

A COAST GUARD report on the safety and security of Broadwater Energy's proposed floating natural gas plant in Long Island Sound has something to please the company as well as the project's opponents, even though their interpretations of the findings are at polar opposites. Their reactions are a sure indication that the fight over the Queen Mary 2-size plant is far from over.

LEVITAN--George. Devoted husband of Florence, beloved brother of Frank, cherished father of Carol Smolen, Barbara Muller and Joanne Levitan and loving grandfather of Jamie Kristofco, Danielle Smolen and Brooke Feingold, passed away peacefully at home in New Rochelle, NY on September 28.

To the Editor: Mary Duenwald writes with classic travel writer assurance about her journey to Michoacán State in ''Wallace Stegner's Mexico: Following Fact and Fiction Into a Colonial City'' (Footsteps, Sept. 17). Perhaps she ought to consider journeys closer to home to discover something many residents of Chicago already know -- a large percentage of Mexican immigrants here in Chicago and its environs are from Michoacán State. A visit to neighborhoods like Pilsen and Albany Park will reveal restaurants, clubs and markets all with Michoacán in their names. It is not a mysterious, exotic alternative trip for many Chicagoans, but a place they think of as home. Jeanne Mellett Chicago

To the Editor: Re ''A Dog's Life, Upgraded: At Luxury Pet Resorts, Pedicures and Steaks'' (Sept. 24): If we really loved our dogs, we'd take them on long walks, or let them go for a swim or roll around in some mud. We'd treat dogs like dogs instead of creating vast networks that treat them as overindulged teenagers.

For decades, the State Department of Environmental Protection has forecast that the peak of the foliage season is usually in the middle of October. But this year, it has changed that prediction to a week later. Donald H. Smith, the state's forester, said Monday that the peak foliage this fall would most likely come around Oct. 20. He said he had based the latest prediction on recent observations.

LONGACRE--Sarah, 58, died of cancer September 26th, in Manhattan. A painter, photographer, and editor, she spent a life-changing summer at Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, and was a graduate of Bennington College and Yale Grad School. Her career included The SoHo News, Time Inc., Stewart Tabori & Chang, Random House, and Scholastic Inc. She photo edited such best sellers as ''A Short Guide to a Happy Life'', ''Dutch'', ''Get Happy'', and ''Hilary's Choice''. Sarah was a delight to all and beloved by family and friends. She is survived by her daughter Vanessa, husband Michael, brother Norman Cook, sister Ferris Cook, and parents Nancy and Topper Cook. Memorial details at sarahlongacre.com

Bob Woodward is slated to appear on Larry King Live Monday night on CNN, as his book, "State of Denial," has forced the White House to delve into records and archives to rebut Mr. Woodward's characterizations of the administration.
Republican Senator George Allen's response to the controversial ad by his challenger, James Webb, featuring former president Ronald Reagan.
The controversial ad by Democrat James Webb featuring former president Ronald Reagan.

Dennis Hastert exited his newsless news conference without taking any questions Monday afternoon, but he did take questions afterward,, and his return to Capitol Hill just as Congress finished business for the election recess has been quite news in and of itself. The tale of the Congressman and his "inappropriate emails" continued to occupy the blogs today, as the original story of Florida Republican Mark Foley's resignation branched out over the weekend into accusations of a Congressional cover-up and questions of "who knew what when?"
Beckman Coulter, a maker of biomedical testing and laboratory products, said on Monday it had agreed to acquire a privately held diagnostic technology company, Lumigen, for $185 million in cash.
Oct. 2 - Two American researchers won the Nobel Prize for discovery that specific genes have on-off switches.
William A. Carter, the Albany City Court judge who recently sentenced the alleged coffee-thrower State Senator Ada Smith to anger management, might need some himself.
Democratic challenger James Webb responds to a George Allen ad questioning his views on women in the military.
Scientists say that physical fitness may prevent the onset of frailty and  declining health in people like 71 year old runner Witold Bialokur.

Chad Hurley, the CEO of YouTube, says that his site's videos are loaded with metadata. Metadata that -- to the trained eye -- might reveal dates, places, even names associated with the making or uploading of the videos.
A sampling of Empire Zone reader comments on the separate controversies embroiling two statewide candidates:
Nick and Casey tell the story of Prudence. (Produced by: Naka Nathaniel)

Federal filings made public last week show that the Managed Funds Association has hired a big-time Washington lobbying firm, Williams & Jensen, to help it with "legislation involving the registration of hedge funds."

It's unclear whether Representative Mark Foley of Florida, whose furtive Internet chats with an under-age page were disclosed by ABC News, forced the congressman's quick resignation and threw the G.O.P. into crisis mode just weeks before the midterm elections, knew that his X-rated rhapsodies were being saved - or even that they could be saved. As co-chairman of the House Caucus on Missing and Exploited Children, however, he probably should have.
We hear Senator Joe Lieberman and former New York City Mayor Ed Koch will appear together at Grand Central tomorrow from 4 to 5 p.m. to shake hands with Connecuticut commuters on their way home.
Brian Hunter, the young energy trader at Amaranth, has taken much of the blame for the hedge fund's implosion after his bets on natural gas blew up in his and his firm's faces last month.

The coal producer Massey Energy said on Monday it had hired the Wall Street investment firm Goldman, Sachs to review strategic opportunities as operational shortfalls made it lower production estimates.
The locks have been changed at the offices of the suddenly departed Mark Foley of Florida, his official Congressional Web site has been shuttered, and his name plaque stripped off the door.

Man, I wish people would quit getting all excited about these LED illuminated keyboards. You know, the ones that beam the image of a computer keyboard onto the tabletop, so that you can type without having to carry around an actual keyboard.

One thing seems incontestable about former Rep. Mark Foley's instant-message chats with former House pages: They're not good for the Republicans. "For Florida political junkies, consider this," writes Steve Bousquet, the Tallahassee bureau chief for the St. Petersburg Times, at his newspaper's Florida politics blog, The Buzz. "In all or part of eight Florida counties on Nov. 7, the general election ballot will feature Katherine Harris atop the Republican ballot followed by Mark Foley. (How's that for a winning ticket?)"
Medialink Worldwide said on Monday it had sold its press release distribution division to the PR Newswire Association, a unit of United Business Media for between $18 million and $23 million in cash.
Electronic Arts said on Monday that it had bought Digital Illusions CE of Sweden, known for the Battlefield game franchise, for about $24 million.
Why did Op-Ed columnist Nick Kristof choose Casey Parks to join him on a reporting trip to Africa? (Produced by: Naka Nathaniel)

As people got around to reading Bob Woodward's new book over the past week, the Bush administration faced mounting questions about its handling of the Iraq war. Members of the Sept. 11 Commission said they were not told about a meeting detailed in the book between George Tenet, then the C.I.A. chief, and Condoleezza Rice, then the national security advisor, in which Mr. Tenet reportedly tried and failed to persuade her to take action against an imminent Al Qaeda attack. White House aides spent Sunday morning denying the claims in "State of Denial."

The Intertape Polymer Group said it had hired TD Securities to help the packaging maker explore strategic alternatives, including a sale. The announcement comes alongside a warning on its 3rd-quarter revenue and cost-cutting.
The Wall Street Journal examines Democrats' efforts to use the economy, and the gap between the rich and the middle class in this midterm election season.
Senator Barack Obama called on Democrats to engage in the security debate in Davenport, Iowa, over the weekend.

Florida's 16th Congressional DistrictState Representative Joe Negron touts himself as the most likely to keep Representative Mark Foley's seat in Republican hands. Other potential replacements are Gayle Harrell, also a state representative, and Tom Rooney, a lawyer and grandson of late Pittsburgh Steelers owner Art Rooney.
Gilead Sciences, one of the nation's largest biotech companies, has agreed to acquire Myogen for $2.5 billion, the companies said on Monday, gaining control of Myogen's experimental heart medicines.
A Mason-Dixon poll shows Democrats could take the Senate, with candidates virtually tied in Tennessee and Ohio, and Jon Tester beating Senator Conrad Burns in Montana.
Comme des Garcons, Junya Watanabe and Undercover collections.

The casino operator Harrah's Entertainment said Monday it had received a proposal from two private equity firms to be acquired for $81 a share, or about $15 billion. The offer, from Apollo Management and the Texas Pacific Group represented a 22 percent premium to Harrah's closing share price on Friday. Combined with the more than $10 billion in debt that Harrah's has on its books, the buyout proposal ranks among the largest of the year.

CNBC's "Fast Money," which ran for 13 weeks over the summer and is now being tested in various time periods before it gains a permanent berth, is CNBC's latest attempt to regain its programming footing, particularly in the hours after the market closes.
Directors' pay at Britain's top companies soared by 28 percent last year, more than seven times the rate of average pay and 11 times the current rate of inflation, according to The Guardian.
Pier 1 Imports, the home furnishings retailer, said Marvin J. Girouard, its chairman and chief executive, will retire on Feb. 28, after 32 years with the company.
The preppy fashion retailer, J. Crew Group, which went public on June 28, said Friday that three of its directors, including its co-founder, are leaving the company's board.
Chip Bergh works fast. When the Procter & Gamble veteran left his job in Singapore, he trained his successor in less than three weeks.

Congress passed legislation Saturday that curbs financial payments from banks to offshore Internet casinos that are illegal under United States law. The law follows the recent prosecutions of online gambling Web sites such as BetOnSports and SportingBet.

At MTV Networks, the only thing as unsettling as last month's ouster of Tom Freston as chief executive of the networks' parent, Viacom, was the uncertainty about what his departure would mean for a management team he had personally built over 20 years.

A Boston technology services firm, Keane, still recovering from the resignation of a chief executive accused of sexual harassment, said on Sunday it had fired the executive many on Wall Street had expected to succeed him.

After the congressional hearings and with criminal charges still possible, the question for Hewlett-Packard is whether its spying scandal will more seriously damage one of the most storied names in corporate America.

The billionaire investor Edward Lampert, chairman of Sears Holdings, is ready to continue the retailer's winning stock performance - by turning the retail chain into a Berkshire Hathaway-type investment vehicle.
Some of the juicier media news to emerge recently may be just part of an ongoing battle between the rival networks Fox News and NBC.
Private equity and trade buyers are lining up bids for the U.S. Foodservice division of the Dutch retailer Ahold, the British newspaper The Business reported.
A British water company AWG said on Monday it had agreed to be bought by a group of Australian, Canadian and British investors for about $4.12 billion.
Misys, a British provider of software to the world's largest financial institutions, said it ended takeover discussions after failing to receive an offer.
The private equity firm Carlyle Group is expected to buy Libya's European oil company, Tamoil, The Business newspaper of Britain reported.

The hedge fund Appaloosa Management may be near an agreement that could give it up to a one-third stake in the bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi when it emerges from court protection, The Wall Street Journal reported. Appaloosa, headed by a billionaire, David Tepper, might inject billions of dollars into Delphi for the increased stake, according to the report.

Ted Turner was back at the Time & Life Building in New York last week, but it was not to visit any friends he made while on the Time Warner board, which he left in May to devote himself to philanthropy and tending a herd of 45,000 bison on his Montana ranch.

With venture capital funds amassing ever greater piles of cash to invest in technology start-ups, some of the smaller ventures are getting a pass from investors. To fill this hole - and to fatten their wallets in doing so - some V.C.'s are now opening what The San Jose Mercury News calls microfunds.

Eurasia Gold, a gold mining firm in Kazakhstan is set to become the latest company from the former Soviet Union to seek a high-profile flotation in London when it makes what could be a 150 million pound ($281 million) offering next year.
Shares of the Internet photo service Shutterfly gained as much as 11.5 percent in their market opening on Thursday, giving the company an initial market capitalization of about $354 million.

Renewing speculation that it might spin off its brokerage unit, the Man Group, the British hedge fund manager, said that it would report first-half figures that exceed market expectations. In a statement, the group said profit will top the $691 million analysts expect for the first six months of the year.

Morgan Stanley, seeking to limit defections to rival securities firms, has created a plan that offers millions of dollars in incentives to its top traders and bankers. The investment bank is letting highly paid employees put part of their annual bonus into Morgan Stanley's hedge funds and private equity funds and is offering low-interest loans that allow them to triple the size of their investments, Bloomberg News reports.
The Belgian bank Fortis will make Houston the headquarters for its energy-trading business when it moves its financial trading staff there from New York.

Middle-aged male bankers in Britain could be among the first to sue their employers using age discrimination legislation that took effect in Britain on Sunday. The corporate law firm Addleshaw Goddard has predicted investment banks could suffer a wave of age discrimination cases to match the run of sex discrimination suits that have grabbed headlines in the past few years.
Andrew S. Fastow is telling all, naming names, and the lawyers suing Enron's former banks on behalf of investors say that his words could lead to billions of dollars in fresh settlements.

Politics and worries about oil supplies may have caused gasoline prices to go up at the pump earlier this year, but one big investment bank quietly helped their rapid drop in recent weeks, according to some economists, traders and analysts.
Bolstering its push into the Bay Area, the biotechnology giant Amgen said Friday it had agreed to buy Mountain View, Calif.-based Avidia for up to $380 million.
Foster's Group, Australia's biggest beer and winemaker, is unlikely to either buy another company or be taken over in the coming year, the chief executive, Trevor O'Hoy, said.

Before it became a verb, Google, with a $1 million bankroll, was a two-man start-up working out of a rented garage. But the Internet giant, which now boasts a market capitalization of $12 billion dollars, has not forgotten its roots.
Tokyo Electric Power, the biggest power producer in Asia, said it might sell fiber-optic networks to KDDI, a mobile phone operator in Japan, for about 100 billion yen ($847.2 million).
