Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis of Manhattan and Councilman David I. Weprin of Queens urged the State Senate yesterday to act on a bill that would make it easier for adult children to receive coverage under their parents’ health insurance plans. Current law allows parents to continue coverage of a dependent beyond age 19, so long as the child is attending college, until age 23. The bill, sponsored by Mr. Grannis and passed by the Assembly in June, would raise the age limit for coverage to 25 and remove the requirement that the child be a student. In June, the Senate passed a separate measure, sponsored by Senator William J. Larkin Jr., an Orange County Republican, that would allow, but not require, insurance companies to continue coverage of adult children up to age 25.

A Holbrook man was killed and his two passengers were injured yesterday morning when the man’s Honda spun off a wet road and crashed into a utility pole, the Suffolk County police said. The accident occurred about 5 a.m. at Expressway Drive South and County Road 83, the police said. The driver, Anthony Fronzoni III, 24, was pronounced dead at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, and his passengers, Brittany Frevolla, 20, of Selden, and Gregory Dietrich, 26, were hospitalized with serious injuries, the police said.

Green-Wood Cemetery has been designated a national historic landmark by the United States Department of the Interior. The designation, announced on Thursday, made the 478-acre cemetery the ninth such landmark in Brooklyn, according to the National Register of Historic Places. “It is gratifying that we are the first cemetery so honored in New York State,” said Richard J. Moylan, the cemetery’s president. The property, established in 1838, “is outstanding for its cohesive, picturesque character, integrated Gothic Revival architecture, and high integrity,” said the secretary of the interior, Dirk Kempthorne. Nearly 600,000 people have been buried at Green-Wood, an active cemetery that is the resting place of Boss Tweed, Leonard Bernstein and the original Brooks Brothers. Mr. Moylan said the designation could be useful in efforts to preserve the view, which has been threatened by high-rise development, of the Statue of Liberty from the cemetery’s hilltop statue of Minerva. “We can now make the case,” Mr. Moylan said, “that the view is landmark to landmark.”.

Three young men have been arrested in connection with a fatal shooting in Washington Heights on Saturday morning, the police said yesterday. The three, Rafelito Sanchez, 18, Luis Paulino, 18, and Johan Cabrera, 16, all of Manhattan, have been charged with murder, the police said. The three are accused of shooting Kenneth Ferreira, 24, in his apartment on West 160th Street, the police said, adding that a gun had been recovered. The police did not elaborate on the circumstances of the shooting yesterday.

Three months after severe flooding caused 12 upstate counties to issue a disaster declaration, New York State is giving $2 million to 8 of those counties for temporary housing aid and living expenses, the Governor’s Office for Small Cities announced yesterday. The money will be divided among more than 850 affected households in Broome, Delaware, Herkimer, Montgomery, Oneida, Otsego, Sullivan and Tioga Counties. Each county will get $250,000 for low- and moderate-income households. The money is part of the state’s $35 million disaster relief program, which was announced shortly after the Southern Tier and the Mohawk Valley were hit hard by flooding in late June.

A woman was injured yesterday when a Lexus, right, spun out of control on the East Side and struck a parked BMW, which then pinned her against a restaurant’s glass window, the police said. Restaurant workers and passers-by rushed to pull the car off the woman, who suffered minor injuries, said the police and witnesses. The accident occurred shortly after noon on Lexington Avenue when the Lexus lost control on the wet street, spinning until it struck two parked vehicles on East 62nd Street, witnesses said. One car, the BMW, shot onto the sidewalk, pinning the woman to a glass window at the Fig and Olive restaurant, the police said. “She was suspended in midair,” said Tom Rizzo, the manager of a nearby pharmacy. “She had no protection. She just got nailed.” About a dozen men struggled to pull the BMW away from the woman, but it remained immobile until a man kicked in one of its windows and placed it in neutral gear, witnesses said. Neither the victim nor the driver of the Lexus was identified yesterday. The driver passed a Breathalyzer test and was not expected to be charged, the police said.

Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, Borough President Scott M. Stringer and Councilman Alan J. Gerson, all Manhattan Democrats, held a news conference yesterday at Stuyvesant High School to urge the federal government to pay for research, medical screenings and health insurance for students who attended school in Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 terrorist attack. They were joined by Amit Friedlander, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 2002. Mr. Friedlander, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, recently received a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and suspects toxic dust from ground zero was a cause. Federal officials have acknowledged delays in helping responders and recovery workers who were sickened at ground zero, but the effect on students in Lower Manhattan has only recently received public attention.

DURANT--Helen von Dongen, Bratteboro, VT--Helen von Dongen Durant, 97, a resident at Hilltop House in Brattleboro since 2002, died Thursday night, September 28, 2006 at the Thompson House Nursing Home on Maple Street, following a period of declining health. Mrs. Durant was born in Amsterdam, The Netherlands on January 5, 1909, the daughter of Andreas Johannes and Louise Marie Constance (Mathieu) van Dongen. She was educated in Paris, Berlin, Vienna and London and began her professional career as a film maker around 1927. She was the youngest member of a group of students, avant-guard artists and professionals in Amsterdam who founded FILM LIGA in protest against the low quality of the imported commercial films then being shown in the cinemas of Europe. Extensive experimentation took place not only to improve the artisitc quality of films but also to add sound and color to the hitherto silent films. During the 1930's she attended the newly developed Western Electric sound recording system at Tobis Films Sonores in Paris and the RCA System at UFA Film Studios in Berlin. Her accrued technical knowledge, artistic application and a facility with foreign languages took her to many of the countries of Europe. Among her early major productions was the filming of the construction of the powerful Dutch sea-like dike which would seperate the Zuiderzee from the North Sea, thereby creating more new dry land for the building of housing. From 1934-1936 she lectured and taught film editing and the new science of adding speech and sound to the hitherto silent films, at the Academy of Cinematography in Moscow. She also collaborated at the film productions of such renowned Russian film producers and directors as Pudowkin, Eisenstein and Wertow. In 1936 she received an invitation to lead an experimental film project for Rockefeller Foundation in New York for their Commission on Human Relations. She also produced and edited Joris Ivens famous film, The ''Spanish Earth,'' with commentary by Ernest Hemingway. In 1939 she directed an experiment in Technicolor with miniature puppets-in stop-action, for the Combined Petroleum Industry, shown at the Worlds fair in New York City. During the war years, 1941-1945 she produced films both independently as well as for the U.S. Signal Corp. in Holywood and for the office of War Information in New York. From 1945-1946 she was appointed Deputy Film Commissioner for the Netherlands East Indies, in charge of the outfitting of modern studios and labratories, as well as educational film production. After one year this project was abandoned because the former East Indies colonies declared themselves independent from the motherland, Holland. Upon her return from one year of research in Europe, she produced and directed the film, ''Of Human Rights'', for the United Nations. From 1946-1948 she produced and retained the editorial supervision of Robert Flaherty's film, ''Louisiana Story.'' Looking forward to a more quiet and private life she and her husband, Kenneth Durant, settled on their farm in Jamaica, Vermont. During the following 15 years both collaborated on an extensive study of the origin and evolution of the Adirondack guide-boat, a handmade craft without which travel through the Adirondack wilderness in the early years was impossible. When Kenneth Durant died in the fall of 1972, Helen continued this study and wrote the book, ''The Adirondack Guide Boat,'' published by the Adirondack Museum at Blue Mountain Lake, New York, in 1980 and since reprinted in 1986 and 1990. In 1988 she became a resident of Brattleboro, Vermont and became a volunteer teacher of creative writing for three years at Saint Michael's School for grades 3,4, and 5. She also volunteered at Bridget's Kitchen, operated by Saint Michael's Parish, the former Linden Lodge Nursing Home as well as at the Brattleboro Museum and Art Center. Her considerable gift of fine art books to the museum now forms the nucleus of the Mrs. Kenneth Durant Art Library. Mrs. Durant was a communicant of Saint Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Brattleboro. Survivors include one nephew, Fred Durant III, and his daughter Pixie Gable and her husband Peter all of Raleigh, N.C., half sister; Nettie Hendricks and husband Herman of The Netherlands. The Liturgy of Christian Burial will be celebrated Tuesday at 11:00 A.M. at Saint Michael's Church on Walnut Street. Committal Rites and burial wil follow in the Durant lot in Saint Michael's parish cemetery. Ther are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Mrs. Durant's name may be made to; Hilltop House 65 Harris Ave., Brattleboro, VT. 05301, Mrs. Durant's home for the past four and a half years or to : Grace Cottage Hospital Foundation, P.O. Box 232, Townshend, VT. 05353, c/o Robert W. Backus, MD. Services are under the direction of the Atamaniuk Funeral Home.

Beck ''The Information'' (Interscope) The jokey videos Beck includes on a DVD with his new album, ''The Information,'' can't conceal how apocalyptically glum he is this time around. Amid his savvy samples and hip-hop beats, Beck has never been the most cheerful lyricist. But he used to be flippant or oblique. Now everywhere he looks he sees decline, loss, religious hypocrisy and war.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the singer Janet Jackson and the release of her new album, ''20 Y.O.,'' misstated the number of years since her last Top 10 single. It has been five years, not six.

It was odd but somehow appropriate. Cardinals fans at Busch Stadium burst into cheers as Juan Encarnación circled back to the dugout after flying out in the fifth inning. And for the second time in three days, the organist chimed in with a few bars of the music that had become familiar to Cardinals fans: the Atlanta Braves' tomahawk chop chant. Houston had just lost, 3-1, in Atlanta, giving the Cardinals what had eluded them for almost two weeks -- their third consecutive National League Central title. The Cardinals needed help Sunday because Anthony Reyes, Manager Tony La Russa's surprise choice to start over the 2005 Cy Young Award winner, Chris Carpenter, did not make it out of the first inning, giving up four runs in a 5-3 loss to Milwaukee.

HELPING ENRON PLAINTIFFS -- In his last few weeks of freedom, Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer for Enron, is briefing plaintiffs' lawyers about the role that banks played in helping the company disguise how much debt and how little cash it had. [C1.] DEBATE ON ANONYMOUS SOURCES -- Canada's news media have been pulled further into the debate over news leaks involving the treatment of a Canadian engineer who was suspected of ties to Al Qaeda and deported by the United States to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tortured. A Canadian government commission faulted Canada, the United States and Syria for their treatment of the engineer, Maher Arar, above, whom it found to be completely innocent. [C6.] TEST FOR CNBC -- ''Fast Money,'' which ran for 13 weeks over the summer and is now being tested in various time periods, is CNBC's latest attempt to regain its programming footing, particularly in the hours after the market closes. [C1.] VIACOM AND MTV -- At MTV Networks, the only thing as unsettling as last month's ouster of Tom Freston as chief executive of the networks' parent, Viacom, was the uncertainty about what his departure would mean for a management team he had personally built over 20 years. The chief questions surrounded the future of Judith McGrath, the chairwoman of MTV Networks. But now Ms. McGrath has made it clear that she will stay. [C1.] EUROPEAN BARGAIN HUNTER -- At 80, Albert Frère continues to prowl corporate Europe in a restless chase for a bargain -- buying, selling and swapping pieces of some of the most prominent businesses in Germany, Italy, France and his native Belgium. [C1.] NEW SITES FOR CLASSIFIED ADS -- A new breed of Web sites aims to simplify the classified ad process for sellers by offering templates and step-by-step instructions for creating classified ads and then posting the ads, sometimes free, on all the major listings services. [C4.] AWARD FOR MOVIE ORACLE -- Netflix, the online movie rental service, plans to award $1 million to the first person who can improve the accuracy of movie recommendations based on personal preferences. To win, a contestant will have to devise a system that is more accurate than the company's current recommendation system by at least 10 percent. [C5.] CELLPHONE AD TACTICS -- Instead of trumpeting low prices and new phones in their advertising, more cellphone providers are pointing out the shortcomings of their competitors. [C7.] 'DREAM DOCTOR' DISEASE -- Listeners were concerned. Was Charles McPhee, the syndicated radio personality who is the host of ''The Dream Doctor,'' broadcasting his show while drunk? No, but the answer turned out to be devastating; he has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. [C6.]

Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, Borough President Scott M. Stringer and Councilman Alan J. Gerson, all Manhattan Democrats, held a news conference yesterday at Stuyvesant High School to urge the federal government to pay for research, medical screenings and health insurance for students who attended school in Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 terrorist attack. They were joined by Amit Friedlander, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 2002. Mr. Friedlander, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, recently received a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma and suspects toxic dust from ground zero was a cause. Federal officials have acknowledged delays in helping responders and recovery workers who were sickened at ground zero, but the effect on students in Lower Manhattan has only recently received public attention. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

PETERS--Gabrielle Fellner. After a long illness, on September 29, 2006. Beloved wife of Andrew Voya Peters. Devoted mother of Nicholas and Thomas. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

A look at top sales of children's DVD's at Barnes & Noble online shows a mix of animated movie titles and those featuring television characters, with a few DVD's of actual actors, like the ''Anne of Green Gables'' series starring Megan Follows. ''We Are the Laurie Berkner Band,'' which was released in February, has already sold three million copies. Disney's new version of 1989's ''The Little Mermaid'' (above), to be released tomorrow, has already topped best-seller lists at Barnes & Noble online. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Because of an editing error, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about Paris Hilton's being charged with drunken driving misstated the legal limit for blood-alcohol level in California. It is .08 percent, not .8 percent.

DOWD--Elizabeth D. (Davis), 63, of Scotch Plains, NJ, died October 1, 2006, at the Barbara E. Cheung Memorial Hospice in Edison, NJ. Received her nursing degree from Kings County Hospital; worked as a registered nurse for several New York State hospitals, more recently a school nurse for Amherst Central School District. Born in Brooklyn; lived in Snyder before moving to Scotch Plains. Wife of Brian M., mother of Brian C. (Susan), Sean (Jacqueline). Grandmother of Jack, Kate, Michael and Christopher; sister of Anne Barber and Patricia Keegan. Funeral Mass Tues, October 3, 11:15am in Queen of Peace Church, North Arlington. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington. Visitation at Parow Funeral Home, 185 Ridge Rd, North Arlington, Monday, 2-4 & 7-9.

Commissioner Bud Selig and so many other people in baseball love the wild card, swear by it, get excited because it keeps so many more teams in contention in the late stages of the season, which means more fans flock to the ballparks to watch their contending teams play. Major League Baseball has set an attendance record for the third successive season and Saturday eclipsed 75 million for the first time. It's difficult to argue with those economic developments.

A television review on Tuesday of the ABC series ''Help Me Help You'' included an outdated quotation of dialogue from the show. A joke referring to the CNN correspondent Anderson Cooper that appeared in preview DVD's sent to critics was removed before the first episode was broadcast.

Politicians often say they do not pay attention to polls. But Mr. Spitzer seems to be relishing his huge edge, which puts him as far as 50 percentage points ahead of Mr. Faso. On Thursday, after Mr. Faso told reporters that during his campaigns for attorney general, Mr. Spitzer ''took $9 million from his family, he hid it, he lied about it, and then he finally had to fess up to it,'' Mr. Spitzer struck back by mocking the troubles the Republican ticket has been having this year.

Red Bull energy drinks stowed out of sight of the cameras, the men of CNBC's ''Fast Money,'' four financial traders and the ringmaster, Dylan Ratigan, began their pumped-up, sound effects-laden dissection of the day's business news. In the control room, Susan Krakower, who created the show with Mr. Ratigan and is its temporary executive producer, scolded the staff when an interview with Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of CNBC's parent, NBC Universal Television Group, stretched to three minutes.

HIRSCHFELD--Phyllis, dearest Phyllis you were my closest friend for nearly 60 years. We weathered many a storm and enjoyed life's gifts together. You will live in my heart forever. Love, Polly $(6$)HIRSCHFELD -- Phyllis. To Phyllis, my mother's best friend: I always found validation and inspiration in the enthusiasm and interest you took in my life, and I am thankful to have had you as a role model. We will miss you deeply and will now have to find contentment in the many cherished memories that you leave us with. Your intellect, elegance and beauty have shed a sparkling radiance for all who knew you to bask in forever. Love, Liz

The Houston Astros claimed they did not pay much attention to the out-of-town scoreboard at Turner Field in Atlanta. And who could blame them? The Astros were too busy with their own frustrations Sunday to focus on another St. Louis stumble. While the Cardinals were falling behind the Brewers, the Astros were leaving 11 runners on base and committing defensive blunders that led to two unearned runs in a loss.

Several hours before the Mets knew they would be playing the Los Angeles Dodgers in the opener of the National League division series that begins Wednesday, David Wright said that the team sitting in the other dugout would not really matter. Wright, the third baseman, was not being disrespectful toward the Dodgers about a potentially perilous first-round meeting for a Mets team that has weathered some disturbing news lately. He was simply expressing confidence in the only team that he believes matters to the Mets. That team is the Mets.

Advertising Week 2006 in New York ended Friday with results from two competitions. Four additional ad characters and slogans were selected to join the Madison Avenue Walk of Fame after nearly a million consumers voted online for their favorites.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Trail of Toxic Sludge Ends In Tragedy in Ivory Coast Trafigura, a global oil and metals trading company, has been accused of dumping toxic waste in Ivory Coast, on the doorstep of some of the world's poorest people. Eight have died, and dozens have been hospitalized. A1 Serbia Seeks to Retain Kosovo As the United Nations seems increasingly likely to grant independence to Kosovo, Serbia's government voted overwhelmingly to pass a new Constitution that once again asserts what it considers its irrefutable rights to the province. A8 Vote in Bahrain Is Faulted Just before Bahrain is to hold parliamentary and municipal elections, a former government adviser has released a report of what he says is a vast conspiracy to rig the election to ensure Sunni domination over the country's majority Shiites. A3 Rice Travels to Bolster Abbas Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice departed for the Middle East on a trip billed by aides as an effort to bolster Mahmoud Abbas in his struggles with the militant Islamic group Hamas and to consult with Arab allies on Iran's nuclear program and the turmoil in Iraq. A9 Vote in Zambia Sets Off Riots Zambia's president, Levy Mwanawasa, surged into the lead as vote-counting in that nation's presidential election neared a conclusion, leading angry supporters of the main opposition candidate, Michael Sata, to riot in some urban centers. A8 Incumbent Faces Runoff President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, his momentum checked by a last-minute corruption and ethics scandal, finished first in the presidential vote but fell just short of the majority he needed to avoid a runoff on Oct. 29. With more than 95 percent of the ballots tabulated, Mr. da Silva had 49.1 percent of the vote. A6 NATIONAL A10-15 Justices Begin Session: Defining Moment for Court During the first term under the leadership of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., the Supreme Court was able to find common ground with some regularity by agreeing not to decide much. Chances are high that the new term will be different. A1 F.B.I. Investigating Foley Case As leaders of both parties demanded new inquiries, law enforcement officials said the F.B.I. had begun a preliminary inquiry into whether former Representative Mark Foley broke any federal laws when he reportedly exchanged sexually explicit e-mail messages with underage Congressional pages. A15 Mr. Foley's resignation left many former pages shaken. They burned up the phone lines and sent e-mail messages flying as they reached out to old friends who remain tightknit years after leaving Capitol Hill. A1 A Power in the House Outside Washington, Representative John P. Murtha, a Vietnam veteran and longtime hawk, may be best known for his turn against the Iraq war last fall. But inside the Capitol, he is best known for turning pet spending projects, known as earmarks, into power. A1 Pakistani-Americans Return Two American citizens of Pakistani descent returned to the United States five months after they were denied permission to fly home to California unless they submitted to an interrogation by the F.B.I. A10 Wal-Mart to Cut Worker Costs Wal-Mart, the nation's largest private employer, is pushing to create a cheaper, more flexible work force by capping wages, using more part-time workers and scheduling more workers on nights and weekends. Terrell Owens, below, caught five passes for 88 yards but no touchdowns as the Cowboys rolled past the Titans, 45-14. Evanescence ''The Open Door'' (Wind-Up/Sony BMG) In 2003 Evanescence struck it huge with ''Fallen.'' That album balanced Amy Lee's airy voice with a barrage of heavy guitars; it was bright enough to win over fans of Avril Lavigne and dark enough to win over fans of European goth-rock bands like HIM and Lacuna Coil. ''Fallen'' eventually became one of this decade's biggest hits: it has sold more 6.5 million copies in America, and nearly 14 million worldwide. Look in the liner notes for ''The Open Door,'' and you'll see that Amy Lee is about the only familiar name. Ben Moody, the guitarist who helped write much of ''Fallen,'' quit less than a year after that CD was released; since then he has collaborated with Kelly Clarkson and, as it happens, Ms. Lavigne. No surprise, then, that the Moody-free Evanescence sounds gloomier and thornier than the old one. Ms. Lee is finally free to be as bombastic as she wants to be.

To the Editor: I agree with Thomas L. Friedman's views on Islam's leadership (''Islam and the Pope,'' column, Sept. 29). But tones of belligerence, fear, hate and blame are not confined to one religion or nationality. We need changes in leadership around the world and in media coverage. We need people from all countries and faiths who can promote a compassionate, moderate view that can recognize the injustices in this world and promote an alternate path to their resolution. This is not unprecedented (think Nelson Mandela).

''In 30 years of doing this kind of work I have never seen anything like this. This kind of industrial waste, dumped in this urban setting, in the middle of the city, never.'' JEAN-LOUP QUÉRU, an engineer with a company hired to clean up toxic waste in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. [A8]

An art review in Weekend on Sept. 22 of the exhibition ''Tesoros/Treasures/Tesouros'' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art referred incorrectly to an early-17th-century Peruvian sculpture of the child Jesus. It is holding half an avocado in its left hand, not half a heart. A credit with a picture of the painting ''Portrait of a Woman in Mourning'' by José Campeche, which is in the exhibition, misspelled the surname of the work's owners, based on information from the museum. They are Marilynn and Carl Thoma, not Thomas.

On Wednesday, Vertigo, an imprint of DC Comics, will release the first issue of ''The Other Side,'' a mini-series about the horrors of the Vietnam War. It tells the parallel stories of two 19-year-old farm boys -- one from the United States, one from Vietnam -- who become soldiers in the conflict. The series's writer, Jason Aaron, is a cousin of Gustav Hasford, whose novel ''The Short-Timers'' was adapted into the film ''Full Metal Jacket.'' The series's artist, Cameron Stewart, traveled to Vietnam for inspiration. ''It was enormously helpful,'' he said. ''I don't think I could've done the job that I've been doing without it.'' Mr. Aaron's next series, ''Scalped,'' about a modern-day Indian reservation in South Dakota and its conflict with the United States government, begins in January and will be a continuing series. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

To the Editor: Re ''Applied Science,'' by John Etchemendy (Op-Ed, Sept. 27): As a current college student who underwent the admissions process last year, I disagree with Mr. Etchemendy's assertion that early-admission policies do not worsen the hectic and frenzied nature of the process ''for those students who are clear in their first-choice college.''

By 11 a.m. yesterday, Barry Bonds hadn't heard the news. On this, the final day of a disappointing season, Bonds, baseball's second greatest home run hitter, sat in front of his dressing area, watching his beloved 49ers get shellacked by the Kansas City Chiefs. Bonds wasn't aware that names had been disclosed in connection with the continuing peril of the use of human growth hormone.

Speaking to Supreme Court justices, cabinet members, politicians and hundreds of judges and lawyers gathered here on Sunday to celebrate a special Mass marking the start of the judicial calendar, Archbishop Donald W. Wuerl of Washington rejoiced in what he called the resurgence of faith in the shaping of public policy and urged those before him to remain rooted in their religion. ''What we do and how we act, our morals and ethics, follow on what be believe,'' Archbishop Wuerl told a standing-room crowd at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Matthew downtown. ''The religious convictions of a people sustain their moral decisions.''

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice departed Sunday for the Middle East, on a trip billed by aides as an effort to bolster the embattled Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, in his struggles with the militant Islamic group Hamas, and to consult with Arab allies on Iran's nuclear program and the turmoil in Iraq. The State Department sought to play down expectations for Ms. Rice's trip, her first to the region since an agreement brokered by the United Nations ended the one-month war between Israel and Hezbollah this summer.

Security forces in Yemen on Sunday killed two fugitive members of Al Qaeda who had escaped from a high security prison six months before, the Yemen official news agency, Saba, reported. The two fugitives, Fawaz Yahya al-Rabeei and Mohamed Daylami, had been sentenced to death for an attack on the French oil tanker Limburg in 2002. They were killed early Sunday in a raid by security forces in Sana, Yemen. Saba reported that an aide to Mr. Rabeei had been arrested in the raid and was being questioned.

Audi of America in Auburn Hills, Mich., owned by Volkswagen, has placed in review the creative part of its account, which had been handled since 1993 by McKinney & Silver in Durham, N.C., part of Havas. Spending was estimated at $75 million to $100 million.

KARTEN--Rachel. Born in Swirz, Poland October 21st, 1913 died peacefully at home Saturday, September 30. She came to the United States in 1947 after surviving the Holocaust in which her first child was killed. Rachel died in the presence of her children, Mark and Arlene. She was predeceased by her husband of 40 years, Isak. She is mourned by her grandchildren Stephanie, Pamela, Abigail and Melissa, her son-inlaw Joe, her daughter-in-law Lorraine, and her brother Bill.

FIER--Robert Daniel, age 79, passed away peacefully Sunday morning at his New Rochelle home surrounded by his family and caregivers. Beloved husband and best friend of Elaine Reyman Fier, Bob was born in Brooklyn, March 6, 1927. A veteran of the Navy in World War II, he graduated from MIT with a B.S. and M.S. in chemical engineering and then New York University Law School. He had a successful 40 year career as a patent attorney at Kenyon & Kenyon in New York City. He was an avid outdoorsman, enjoying skiing, sailing, and fly fishing, particularly at his home in Stratton, VT. He leaves behind his wife of 52 years, brother Elihu, children Steven and Sue, Debbie and Philip, and Froma, and grandchildren Keith, Joanna, Reyna, Jordan and Sofia. A service will be held celebrating his life on Wednesday, October 4, at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon. Contributions can be made to The Doctors' Cancer Foundation, c/o Dr. Bernard Berrhardt, 50 Guion Pl, New Rochelle, NY.

When the Atlantic Coast Conference welcomed Miami and Virginia Tech from the Big East in 2004, there was some concern that they and Florida State would dominate the league's football landscape. In the A.C.C., still best known for its basketball, football has long been synonymous with Florida State, which has 12 conference titles. Although Florida State and Virginia Tech played in the conference's inaugural championship game last year, parity is beginning to take shape in the conference this year.

DUCHESNE--Elizabeth Stack Elizabeth Stack Duchesne, 83, died Tuesday, September 19, 2006 at Riverview Medical Center, Red Bank, NJ. Born in Johnstown, PA. Bette was a long-time resident of New York City and Monmouth Beach, NJ. She worked for Ladies Home Journal and became Merchandising Director for Family Circle Magazine in New York City, retiring in 1984. Surviving are her daughter and son-in law, Paris Anne and Christopher Niesterowicz, of Baltimore, MD. Arrangements were under the direction of the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Letters of condolence can be e-mailed through the funeral home's website to www.sidun.com.

To the Editor: Re ''Bouquet of Roses May Have Note: 'Made in China' '' (front page, Sept. 25): The Chinese government's effort to make the flower industry successful should go beyond the major investments in new infrastructure and ensure that those employed in this sector work under conditions that do not threaten their health or fundamental labor rights. In Ecuador and Colombia, the countries that produce most of the cut flowers exported to the United States, these jobs tend to be characterized by rampant labor rights violations. Workers who try to unionize to defend their rights are generally fired.

STALOFF--Charles, on September 30th, at age 98. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Loving father of Hazel and Robert. Adored grandfather, brother, friend and colleague. He was an Eagle Scout and US Navy veteran. Principal of P.S. 7 and Junior High School 139 of the Bronx. Services on Tuesday, October 3, 11:30 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

Basic Books says it will soon publish what it calls the first inside account of life as an Al Qaeda operative. ''Inside the Jihad: My Life with Al Qaeda, A Spy's Story,'' by Omar Nasiri, is a first-person narrative of Mr. Nasiri's time in an Al Qaeda training camp in Afghanistan in the 1990's, followed by a stint as a spy for a Western intelligence service.

The Decemberists ''The Crane Wife'' (Capitol) For their whimsy, ambition and erudition, the Decemberists have stood out from the recent pack of indie-rock bands. ''The Crane Wife'' promises to keep that streak going, despite the technicality that it is being released on a major label. As a sustained effort, it represents the band's sharpest and most satisfying work, and one of the most accomplished albums of its kind this year.

General Motors has made decisions affecting two accounts with spending estimated at $850 million. G.M. expanded its relationship with the Marina del Rey, Calif., office of Deutsch, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, by naming the agency to share the General Motors corporate account with the Birmingham, Mich., office of McCann Erickson, part of the McCann Worldgroup unit of Interpublic. Spending is estimated at $100 million.

The Insider column in Business Day on Friday, about lessons learned from the loss of $6 billion at the Amaranth Advisors hedge fund, misstated the movement of a spread between two natural-gas futures contracts that hurt trades made by Amaranth. The spread narrowed; it did not widen.

An article in Weekend on Sept. 22 about the walking tour and performance ''Off Stage: The West Village Fragments,'' which examines the history of Off Off Broadway theater, referred imprecisely to Charles Mingus, who found a job for the playwright Sam Shepard when Mr. Shepard moved to New York in 1963. He is the artist Charles Mingus III, not his father, the jazz musician.

SOLOMON--Irving. Temple Bethel of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Irving Solomon. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

When a New Wave lad suddenly trades his velvet dinner jacket for a bandoleer, there is only one logical response: uh-oh. Brandon Flowers, the lead singer of the Killers, emerged with 2004's ''Hot Fuss'' as a fully formed rock star with a striking persona. A Las Vegas-bred Mormon, he sang like a British fop, dressed like a dissolute lounge lizard and condemned drinking, drugs and fornication through perfectly glossed lips. When he trashed his peers and equated the Killers with greats like David Bowie, it seemed like media-baiting shtick: synth-pop pro-wrestling. Unfortunately he was serious. He has become a Wild West bard, the kind who wears a string tie and sings, ''Godspeed you boy, this river is wild.'' On the painful, Americana-themed ''Sam's Town'' (Island/Def Jam) the band scraps its dance-pop for pretentious stadium rock, grasping for the grandeur of 1970's Bruce Springsteen and ''The Joshua Tree''-era U2. ''I'm sick of all my judges/So scared of letting me shine,'' Mr. Flowers gripes in the title song, referring to naysayers who consider him a shallow pretty boy. But what about the five million people who bought the excellent ''Hot Fuss''?

Because of an editing error, an architecture review on Wednesday about an exhibition at Yale University focusing on the Team 10 architectural alliance, which formed in reaction to Modernism, misidentified the movement described in the review as ''wider-ranging in its ideals than most people think.'' It was Team 10, not the Modern movement.

Michael and George, the mother-inlaw of Tara, the grandmother of Eric, Cassandra, Manuel and Christopher and the great-grandmother of Alexandra, Michael and Isabella. Family will receive friends on Tuesday, 5-8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 Street. Funeral service Wednesday, 11 AM, at the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 334 E. 74 St. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. The family requests that instead of flowers, donations be made to Autism Speaks, 2 Park Avenue, New York.
MARGETT--Hon. Charles. 10/02/97. A special man lovingly remembered, always. Your Family

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the appointment of the journalist Orville Schell as director of the Asia Society's new Center on U.S.-China Relations included incorrect information from the society about his reporting on the war in Indochina. Although he wrote for several publications, The New Yorker was not one of them. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Schell's academic record at the University of California, Berkeley. Although he worked toward a doctoral degree in Chinese studies and passed his Ph.D. oral examination, he did not earn his doctorate.

Because of an editing error, a report in ''Arts, Briefly'' on Friday about the casting of Patricia Heaton in the play ''The Scene'' misspelled the given name of the playwright. She is Theresa Rebeck, not Therese.

Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Sunday that President Bush had called to affirm his support in the midst of an uproar over a new book raising questions about Mr. Rumsfeld's management of the war in Iraq. The president ''made some comments in a larger group, by secure video, and then he called me personally,'' Mr. Rumsfeld told journalists traveling with him to a meeting here of defense ministers from the Western Hemisphere.

POLISH--Muriel Wallick, after a tenacious fight against cancer. The end came abruptly on September 30. Beloved wife of Jack, devoted mother of Beth and Nathaniel, dear sister of the late Ruth Wallick Lipson and Mel Wallick, loving mother-in-law of Philip Friedman and Ellen Schorr, adoring grandmother of Anna Rose and Isadora. Peerless hostess, ardent New Yorker, compassionate social worker, elegant and discerning dealer in decorative objects, deeply missed by the countless friends she nurtured. She was gracious, brave, and classy to the very end. Services at Plaza, 91st St. and Amsterdam, Tuesday, 1 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Human Rights First, 333 7th Ave, NYC 10117.

Law enforcement officials said Sunday that the F.B.I. had begun a preliminary inquiry into whether former Representative Mark Foley broke any federal laws when he reportedly exchanged sexually explicit e-mail messages with under-age Congressional pages as leaders of both parties demanded new inquiries. Officials described the F.B.I. action as a review of the evidence and relevant statutes to determine whether to open a full investigation, though one appeared likely.

ROSE--Irl W. II. Age 83, Sarasota, FL passed away peacefully on September 29th. Beloved husband of Susan Baar Rose. Devoted father of Carol Rose Munson and family friend Heleen, Debbie Rose Meinsen and Stephen Meinsen and Peggy Rose Turchioe and Robert Unger. Cherished Pop-Pop of Lauren and James Munson, Brian and Elisabeth Turchioe, Danny and Andrew Meinsen and great-grandfather of Taylor Madison Munson. Graduated from Horace Mann School Class of 1940 and Dartmouth College Class of 1944. He served in World War II and retired as a US Army Captain in 1958. He will long be remembered for his loyalty to family and friends and for his sense of humor. Private graveside service October 10th.

Alfonse M. D'Amato says he is really trying his best to be a loyal Republican. ''I try to be a person who supports our party,'' he says. But try as he might, he can't bring himself to endorse John Faso, the candidate for governor whom he supported for the Republican nomination.

LAXER--Abraham. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member, and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Assoc Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

Derek Jeter tapped his chest with his glove. Why was Andy Cannizaro, a rookie wearing No. 63, jogging toward shortstop just before the top of the ninth inning yesterday? ''Me?'' Jeter said to Cannizaro, and then he understood. Jeter's quest for the American League batting crown was over, and so was his regular season. The acting manager, Bernie Williams, had given the fans one last chance to salute Jeter in the regular season.

Remember that other political sex scandal? James E. McGreevey, the former governor of New Jersey, had a coming-out party of sorts last week in Greenwich Village, where he fielded questions about his extramarital affair with a male aide and his subsequent resignation in 2004.

To the Editor: Paul Rieckhoff's combat experience in Iraq (''Do Unto Your Enemy ,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 25) and Arthur T. Hadley's combat experience in World War II (''Firing Potent Words, From a Tank,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 25) show the benefits of strict compliance with the Geneva Conventions and the power of ''America's moral integrity'' in Europe until Germany's defeat; and at first in Iraq, until we lost it through noncompliance. The same dynamics held during the war in Vietnam, and American units that complied were more effective and benefited; others were frequent violators, and it cost them and the United States.

So, who is the common denominator in the scandals and inquiries roiling state politics? Paul Shechtman. He may not be a household name, but he is all over the place. Consider Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's decision to use a state worker to drive his wife around, and his tardiness in reimbursing the state. That is being investigated by the State Ethics Commission, whose chairman is -- Paul Shechtman, below.

If you read Monday's article in the Times's main Sports section -- "Two Countries, Three Teams, One Passion for Football" -- you can already answer this football trivia question: which three pro teams are located closest to one another (excluding arena teams)?

We started our live blog coverage of round one of this year's Major League Baseball playoffs with the opening game of the Yankees-Tigers series. To follow the action as it happened, click on the words "Read more..." for our complete inning-by-inning account, written as the game was played.
Before the game began, the national anthem was performed behind home plate by the West Point Glee Club, which completed the song in 1 minute, 17 seconds.
The lawyer for Mark Foley announced at a news conference on Tuesday night that the former Congressman was sexually molested by a clergyman when he was a teenager himself. (Video)

Everything feels different in the playoffs and some of it is measurable. For instance: the parking prices. During the regular season, it costs $13 to park in the garage next to Yankee Stadium. On Tuesday night, for Game 1 of the first round with the Tigers, the price was $26, the new number slapped over the old one on the sign.
The United Nations has informally picked its next Secretary General.  Warren Hoge describes the challenges he will face in his new job. (Produced  by: Emily B. Hager)

Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, who could soon be the state's top Republican, said this afternoon that Jeanine Pirro has not been hurt by news that the feds are investigating her for plotting to bug her husband.

President Bush offered a brief set of remarks - his first public comments - about the Mark Foley scandal outside an elementary school in Stockton, Calif., that has been named after him (meaning George W. Bush). And in those brief remarks was a very brief defense of House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, whose management of the deepening mess has led to calls for his resignation from the leadership post.

A national WNBC/Marist Poll finds that former Mayor Rudy Giuliani is the leading contender for the Republican presidential nomination and that Hillary Rodham Clinton is the leading contender for the Democratic nomination.
How to make eggs the centerpiece of a dinner. From the New York Times's upcoming PBS series "Best Recipes in the World with Mark Bittman."
The Dow's new high today is a triumph for the old economy, not to mention for the old addictions.

At a ribbon-cutting ceremony this morning at Barretto Point Park - a magnificent $7.2 million expanse along the Bronx River, with gorgeous views of Manhattan -- Mayor Bloomberg was asked whether he would field a beach volleyball team.

Everywhere he looks, Senator Joe Lieberman has somebody looking for an opportunity to capitalize on his loss in the Democratic primary. And now, the latest comes from Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, who just a couple of months ago was out in Connecticut rallying the troops to re-elect the three-term incumbent.
It is about time for the outside directors at Keane Inc. to step in and sort things out in the executive suite, where the knives are out in ways that make the company a laughingstock.

Ben Smith of The Daily Politics suggests that blogs don't argue with each other enough, so he offers his own thoughtful analysis on the Pirro-Cuomo race challenging my take that the current controversy could help Jeanine.

The Democratic senatorial candidate, Ned Lamont, who is still trying to move within margin-of-sampling-error range of incumbent Joe Lieberman, announced this morning that he's contributing another $500,000 to his own campaign.

Spotted: Another Hollywood Republican: Richard Kiel, whom you might remember as Jaws in the old James Bond movies. He was a celebrity guest at the fund-raising event for Representative Richard Pombo in Stockton, Calif., on Tuesday, where the star attraction was President Bush.
An ad by Republican Randy Kuhl attacks his opponent on taxes saying "if he gets his way, we all pay."
An ad on taxes by Republican Charles Bass says that "we can't afford Paul Hodes."
Republican Robert Simmons says that his opponent, Joe Courtney, "has a weakness....for raising your taxes."

Things are not getting easier for venture-backed companies aspiring to go public. Just eight of these kinds of companies staged initial public offerings in the third quarter, raising $934.2 million. It was the slowest quarter for such I.P.O.'s since 2003, according to the Exit Poll report by Thomson Financial and the National Venture Capital Association.
Republican Congressman Curt Weldon attacks his opponent over taxes.

Michael Capellas, the former chief executive of both Compaq Computer and MCI, has joined the technology-focused buyout firm Silver Lake Partners as a senior adviser. It is a notable combination, given Mr. Capellas's experience leading large technology companies and Silver Lake's experience in taking them private.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg weighed in today on the resignation of Representative Mark Foley and the scandal that has engulfed Republican leaders in Washington. But he did not answer directly when asked, at a news conference in the Bronx, to discuss how Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, the powerful upstate Republican who chairs the National Republican Congressional Committee, have handled the scandal.

If it's October, it must be time for Bats, The New York Times's postseason baseball blog, a tradition stretching back nearly as far as Gary Sheffield's career as a first baseman. With the experience of live blogging World Cup soccer, U.S. Open tennis and N.F.L. football firmly under her belt, The Gray Lady now steps up to the plate to describe for you, in real time, the inning by inning progress of New York's two favorite baseball teams as they attempt to get across town for the first Subway Series since, well, July.
Craig Monroe and Marcus Thames, two 29-year-old outfielders for the Detroit Tigers, have been swimming together toward the common goal of excelling in the major leagues.

Few things are ranked and re-ranked with as much zeal as the nation's institutions of higher learning. The coming of autumn usually brings a bumper crop of such lists, and this season is no exception.
Talk of mergers, reorganizations and potential job cuts shared the stage with some clever and innovative design studies and production vehicles.
During the heady days of Wall Street research -- that is, the 1990's market boom -- analysts lived for their annual ranking by Institutional Investor magazine.
Derek Jeter tied the postseason record for hits, going 5-for-5 with a home run to lead the Yankees over the Detroit Tigers in its postseason opener.
You know the classic Google logo? Those colorful letters in that distinctive font?
Readers respond to David Brooks's Oct. 1 column, "Democrats Work the Factory Floor."
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's Oct. 2 column, "Poisoned on Eno Road"
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his Oct. 2 column, "Things Fall Apart."
Pressure on Republicans has been escalating in the wake of Mark Foley's resignation from Congress, with outrage mounting on the right as well as the left.

More conservatives have begun to flay Dennis Hastert for failing to do more to investigate former Rep. Mark Foley's creepily friendly e-mails to House pages. The editorial page of The Washington Times calls on Hastert to resign as speaker of the House in an editorial that describes the scandal as "a disgrace for every Republican member of Congress." The Washington Times editorial pretty much calls Hastert a liar. ("Hastert dissembled, to put it charitably, before conceding that he, too, learned about the e-mail messages sometime earlier this year.") The editorial continues:
The $15 billion takeover offer for Harrah's Entertainment has many analysts and members of the gambling industry guessing which casino giant might be the next target for private equity firms.

The Republican plan to focus the last five weeks of the campaign on national security has given way to a frantic scramble to contain the fallout from Representative Mark Foley's resignation over reports that he sent sexually explicit messages to Congressional pages. Democrats suddenly have a real chance of capturing Mr. Foley's seat in South Florida. The broader questions are whether the Foley case feeds the sour political mood - the approval ratings for Congress are already among the lowest in a decade - and whether it bolsters the Democrats' assertions that Republicans are incompetent and corrupt, and have been in power too long.The Foley news broke just after a book by Bob Woodward, "State of Denial," focused new attention on President Bush's handling of the Iraq war, further distracting attention from the Republican security message when many of the party's candidates are struggling to gain an edge.

President Bush is making fund-raising a top priority, and he has already raised $180 million for the Republicans and individual candidates, more than he did in 2002. Also, make sure to check out the new feature in our electoral map that tracks travel by Mr. Bush and his predecessor, Bill Clinton.

When Andrew S. Fastow received a six-year prison sentence last week on conspiracy charges -- well below the 10-year maximum -- some critics wrung their hands at what they considered to be too light a punishment for his role in Enron's collapse.

In our third weekly installment of analysis of New York's top three political races, we find a debate that stirred little debate, a confident candidate looking beyond New York, and a marital brouhaha overshadowing just about everything else.

ExecutiveThe White House confirms Bob Woodward's report that George Tenet, who was then head of the C.I.A., did brief Condoleezza Rice about the looming Al Qaeda threat in July 2001. Mr. Tenet told the Sept. 11 commission about the meeting, according to a transcript and a member of the panel.
VirginiaAs some voters turn away from the incumbent, Senator George Allen uses an unusual two-minute appeal to refocus the campaign on issues after a series of gaffes.

The fugitive businessman Jacob "Kobi" Alexander, accused in the United States of hatching a scheme to pocket millions of dollars by secretly manipulating stock options, was granted bail by a Namibian court Tuesday.

MassachusettsWith his popularity in decline, Gov. Mitt Romney could be a political liability for his second-in-command, Kerry Healey, in her race against the Democrat Deval Patrick. Meanwhile, Ms. Healey charges that Mr. Patrick's policies would require a tax increase.
A suicide bomber blew himself up and wounded three NATO soldiers and three civilian passers-by, the police said.

Brian Walton, a spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee, broke through the sound-bite drudgery of the campaign season last week when he said this about Senator Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan: "Michigan would be better off if they had one of Willy Wonka's Oompa Loompas in the Senate."

Amid a torrent of bad news for Republicans in polls across the country, there was one bright spot for them, and it was in California of all places. Two new polls show Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, left, solidly ahead of his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Phil Angelides.
In her new film, Annette Bening plays a pill-popping, celebrity-obsessed narcissistic housewife — this year's Belle de Jour.

How much is freedom worth to Jacob (Kobi) Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology? At a bail hearing in Namibia today, an F.B.I. agent testified that Mr. Alexander had offered a former colleague $5 million, and then offered to raise the amount, if the colleague would take the blame for the options backdating scandal that resulted in Mr. Alexander's indictment.
Oct. 3 - A pair of Americans have won the Nobel physics prize for work that helped cement the big-bang theory of the universe, John Mather of Maryland and George Smoot of California.
A Chinese solar power equipment maker, LDK Solar Hi-Tech, plans to raise about $300 million in a listing on the Nasdaq stock market next year, the South China Morning Post reported.

BlackRock and the money-management arm of Merrill Lynch said Monday that they had completed their previously announced merger, a combination that creates one of the world's largest investment-management firms with more than $1 trillion in assets.

The Metromedia International Group, the media company controlled by the 92-year-old billionaire John Kluge, is in talks to sell assets and may shut down. The company, Mr. Kluge's last media operation, received a $480 million bid for Magticom and its other holdings in the republic of Georgia from investors including Dubai-based Istithmar, Metromedia International said in a statement Tuesday.
E-Trade Financial will trade fraud charges in court with bankrupt MarketXT Holdings over a 2002 deal in which E-Trade bought MarketXT's Tradescape electronic brokerage units.
Google has consolidated 500 of its advertising and engineering staff into a single location in the fashionable former meatpacking district of lower Manhattan, the company confirmed on Monday.

The Marvell Technology Group cut its third-quarter revenue outlook and said it would restate past financial results because of problems with the way it accounted for stock options, sending its shares down 18 percent.

The former chief executive of the American International Group, Maurice R. Greenberg, has won the right to see memos that were turned over to the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, before the state accused Mr. Greenberg of fraud.

Mills, a shopping mall developer whose accounting practices are under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Monday that its chief executive retired over the weekend - the second top executive to leave the company recently.

A federal judge in Brooklyn sentenced a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent on Monday to six years in prison for racketeering and securities fraud related to the inside-trading prosecution of a former stock picker, Anthony Elgindy.

The New York Stock Exchange has quietly pushed back a plan that would prevent brokers from voting their clients' shares in board elections when the stockholders have given no voting instructions of their own.
This has not been a good month for Lawrence W. Sonsini.

Hewlett-Packard sought the advice of a well-known intelligence specialist, Brian Jenkins of the RAND Corporation, on how to find the source of a boardroom leak, according to a report compiled by H.P.'s law firm and provided to a House subcommittee.
Marine Terminals, the family-owned operator of terminals at 13 ports on the West Coast, may be put up for sale, Bloomberg News reported.

Softbank, owned by a Japanese billionaire, Masayoshi Son, will reduce funding costs for the purchase of Vodafone's Japanese operations because it will use assets to secure 1.45 trillion yen ($11 billion) of debt, Bloomberg News reported.

Atlas Copco, the world's biggest maker of air compressors, may have received a $4 billion offer for its construction-gear rental unit from Ripplewood Holdings, said James Moore, a Goldman Sachs analyst.

The British water group AWG was at the center of a bid auction on Monday after a 2.2 billion pound ($4.2 billion) offer from pension funds and private equity groups quickly flushed out approaches from two other potential predators.
Their pockets bulging with cash, private equity firms have found a new business where they can place their multibillion-dollar bets: gambling.
Among the many measures of a successful foreign investment, helping to set off a coup d'état is definitely not one of them.

A Nextel co-founder, Morgan O'Brien, has raised $4 million to bolster his effort to convince the government that public airwaves should be set aside for private industry to use in creating a wireless network for first responders.

NASA has joined a partnership with a venture capital fund to get an early look at technologies relevant to its space mission. Called Red Planet Capital, the $75 million investment fund is being managed by Red Planet Capital Partners, a new firm based in San Mateo, Calif., that will invest over the next five years in early-stage companies running the gamut from information technology and communications start-ups to energy and biomedical ventures.

Shares of Nomura Real Estate Holdings, which raised the most money in an initial public offering of any Japanese company this year, surged as much as 11 percent on their opening on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Nasdaq Stock Market plans to raise the annual fees it charges the almost 3,200 companies that list their shares on the electronic marketplace.
Shares of Western Union rose more than 4 percent in their first day of trading on Monday after a spin-off from First Data.

Shutterfly raised $87 million in its initial offering last week leaving open the question of who they will go after, given the plethora of emerging online photo and video sites out there. Then again, Shutterfly, at less than $400 million in market valuation, might be an acquisition target for someone else.
Targeting small and mid-size firms, the boutique investment bank Signal Hill Capital Group is looking to step into a space generally overlooked by big Wall Street banks.

For many Wall Streeters, the last philosophical tome they picked up was Sun Tzu's The Art of War. But investment bankers have been rushing to a Columbia Business School Course taught by Srikumar Rao, according to Investment Dealers' Digest.
Balenciaga, Ann Demeuleester, Yohji Yamamoto and Tao.
A Canadian trucking company, Vitran, has acquired Pjax Freight System, a freight carrier based in Pittsburgh, for $132 million to expand its network in the United States.
Imagination Technologies Group, a British software developer, said on Monday that it had sold a 3 percent stake in the company to Intel, sending its shares up 10 percent.
The Federal Communications Commission on Monday approved the $1 billion acquisition of Midwest Wireless Holdings by the rural telephone operator Alltel.

The battle between the movie studio Lions Gate Entertainment and Image Entertainment raged on Monday, with Image urging its shareholders to re-elect its board of directors and reject Lions Gate's nominees.
Arcelor Mittal, the world's largest steelmaker, may fail in its bid to buy a stake in Laiwu Steel of China because it "lacks support'' from some government departments, an executive at Laiwu said.
Wachovia, the nation's fourth largest banking company, said Monday that it had completed its $24 billion takeover of Golden West Financial, the second-largest savings and loan in the country.

Shares of Bank of Overseas Chinese rallied on Tuesday after a report that HSBC Holdings and Standard Chartered are trying to break up a deal in which the Chinese bank would be bought by Citigroup, the world's largest bank.

The Federal Communications Commission comes to Los Angeles on Tuesday to kick off the newest installment of its controversial deliberations into loosening ownership restrictions on the broadcast industry. But, like many sequels, says The Los Angeles Times, this one might have trouble matching the drama of the 2003 original.
Is the turnaround at General Motors for real?
A certain theater owner in Hoopeston, Ill., might not have been entertained by "Jackass: Number Two," but the film's private investors are probably laughing all the way to the bank.
The world’s largest annual book fair will focus on the flourishing literary scene in India.
Tour three houses on the market in New Rochelle, N.Y.; Ridgway, Colo.; and Medina, Wash., priced at about $10 million.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The best-selling author answered readers’ questions about writing fiction and more.
If the season is anything like the pilot, this new drama about high school football could be great in the way of a poem or painting.
Business writer Joe Sharkey today recounts the harrowing experience of being a passenger aboard a 13-passenger jet when it collided with a Boeing 737 flying 37,000 feet above the Amazon rainforest.
The Nickel Mines, Pa., community copes with the aftermath of Monday's school shooting.
Brace yourself for a barrage of T.O. talk this week as the Cowboys prepare to visit Philadelphia.

We hope you're coming here to post a comment after watching our video report. We finished our reporting trip to Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon and the Central African Republic with more questions than answers. We're hoping that, with your help, we'll be able to sort out some things. We look forward to the discussion.  Nick and Casey.
Female physicists, astronomers and mathematicians are up against more than 2,000 years of convention that has long portrayed these fields as inherently male.
Many doctors prescribe medicine without providing detailed information about it to patients, a new study suggests.
The Twins had won 23 consecutive starts at home by pitcher Johan Santana, who had gone 16-0 since a loss to Oakland on Aug. 1, 2006.
The first deliveries of Airbus’ troubled A380 super jumbo jet were delayed again today, this time by as much as another year, pushing the program off by a full two years.

After days of flirting with its all-time peak, the Dow Jones industrial average finally set a new record this afternoon, closing at 11,727.34. The latest record came as oil prices fell about 3 percent and dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time since March.
Bangalore, where dozens of multinational companies have operations, will completely shut down on Wednesday as part of a protest over a border issue.
Britons wonder whether David Cameron can rewrite his party’s narrative into a new script for electoral success.
Russian officials said that the sanctions Moscow has imposed on Georgia will remain indefinitely.
President Bush made his first comments on the messages sent by Rep. Mark Foley to teenage Congressional pages.
The report brought the total number of American troops killed on Monday to at least eight.
The Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades said they would be killed so “these filthy people can be made an example.”
A group of foreign academics, lawyers, and activists sent an open letter to Chinese President Hu Jintao today.
The Japanese Foreign Ministry said today that it was making arrangements for him to visit Beijing and Seoul next week to meet with top leaders in each country.
The astronomers uncovered evidence about the origin of the universe and how it grew into galaxies.
While the pilots have not been charged, the order was issued as a “preventive measure.”
The government called an emergency meeting of health officials to try to control an outbreak that has left 14 dead.
The man who seized control of a one-room Amish school on Monday apparently planned an extended stay, Pennsylvania State Police said today.
The U.S. has warned that it would seek U.N. sanctions that carry the threat of military action if North Korea were to try to test a nuclear weapon.
The father of Oklahoma’s star running back, Adrian Peterson, will not be able to attend the game between the No. 14 Sooners and No. 7 Texas in Dallas.
Lawyers for 25 men being held in Afghanistan filed a court challenge to President Bush’s plan to prosecute and interrogate terrorism suspects.
Hewlett-Packard sought the advice of an intelligence specialist, Brian Jenkins of the RAND Corporation, according to the report.
Manager Joe Torre said he could not go wrong arranging so many powerful hitters, but the implied message is that batting sixth could help Alex Rodriguez relax.
If a 15th Subway Series is nigh, it is time to study anew the passions of fans of New York’s two playoff baseball teams.
Antoine Wright is one of several young, unproven players the Nets hope will help them improve on last season’s run to the second round of the playoffs.
House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert faced intensifying questions about the response to Representative Mark Foley’s messages to a teenage page.
For Coach Eric Mangini and the Jets, their fourth-down call against the Colts ended with Chad Pennington throwing an interception.

Environmentalists and citizen groups sued the federal government and the state highway commissioner, saying the state rigged the process for choosing a route to extend Interstate 69 from Indianapolis to Evansville. The plaintiffs contend that upgrading existing Interstate 70 and U.S. 41 would be significantly less expensive and cause less environmental damage. Gary Abell, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation, said, “These same groups and individuals have tried every conceivable method over the years to try to stop I-69, and really this is just the latest in that same old story.”.

Former Representative Helen Chenoweth was killed in a car crash near Tonopah, her daughter Meg Chenoweth Keenan said. Ms. Chenoweth, 68, whose archconservative, often libertarian and sometimes extreme views made her popular with militia movements; she was a Republican representative from Idaho for three terms, beginning in 1995, before retiring. She gained national attention when she held “endangered salmon bakes” as campaign fund-raisers, serving canned salmon and ridiculing the listing of Idaho salmon as an endangered species.

A British native and career Interior Department employee has been confirmed by the Senate as director of the National Park Service. The new director, Mary A. Bomar, left, was one of four Interior Department officials confirmed by the Senate at 2 a.m. on Saturday as lawmakers rushed to finish work before recessing. Ms. Bomar succeeds Fran P. Mainella, who announced her resignation in July.

Doctors upgraded the condition of the co-pilot who survived the crash of Comair Flight 5191 in Louisville, and a hospital spokeswoman said he might be able to begin rehabilitation soon. The pilot, James Polehinke, who was the lone survivor of the Aug. 27 crash, was upgraded to fair condition from serious condition, said a University of Kentucky spokeswoman, Kelley Bozeman. Mr. Polehinke could leave the university’s hospital as early as this week to begin rehabilitating at another medical facility, Ms. Bozeman said.

Newark’s school district canceled classes for all 6,700 students because vandals damaged the city’s school bus fleet twice during the weekend. The shutdown was intended to give the police time to investigate all 50 buses for damage and evidence that could lead to the vandals, said Karen Truett, a spokeswoman. Ms. Truett said they had discharged fire extinguishers, dumped trash in the buses and stuffed paper in the gasoline tanks.

Little Rock, the capital city, unveiled its new nickname: the Rock. The name came after a yearlong process to find a replacement for City of Roses. The five other finalists were America’s Gem, River City, Southern Comfort, Rock Town and Rock City. The city is named for a rock formation found by Bernard de la Harpe, a French explorer, while mapping out the Arkansas River in 1722. “A rock, there is something substantive about it,” Mayor Jim Dailey said.
In the second half of the season, David Wright hit only six home runs, a troubling statistic for the Mets entering Game 1 of their National League division series.

An engineer at a nuclear power plant near Sacramento has been charged with sending threatening letters containing a powdery substance to a country club where President Bush will appear today for a Republican campaign event. The engineer, Michael L. Braun, 51, was arraigned in Federal District Court on two federal charges of sending threats in the mail. The letters contained threats to President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and Representative John T. Doolittle, Republican of California, a statement from the F.B.I. said.

San Jose has the worst roads in the nation, with Los Angeles and the San Francisco/Oakland area ranking second and third, according to a study released by TRIP, a transportation research group in Washington. The study said an increase in urban traffic, up 38 percent from 1990 to 2004 in the nation’s largest cities, and less money for repairs have resulted in bumpy, disintegrating roads in cities with more than 500,000 people. It said cities in the top 10, including Kansas City, Mo.; New Orleans; San Diego; Sacramento; St. Louis; Omaha; and New York, cost the average motorist an extra $560 to $705 annually to pay for vehicle maintenance and excess fuel consumption used when driving bumpy roads. Sixty-six percent of San Jose’s major roads are in poor condition, the group said.

Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans signed an order requiring that large businesses use as many local and minority-owned companies as possible when they seek tax incentives and grants for Hurricane Katrina recovery. The executive order requires applicants for the incentives to involve 50 percent local businesses and 35 percent business controlled by women or members of minorities whenever possible. A similar requirement has been in place for government contracts, but the mayor’s order expands it to businesses applying for aid promised by various federally financed recovery programs that are administered by the city and the state.
pro basketball.
Though optimism abounds as the Knicks open training camp with new Coach Isiah Thomas, the problems inherent in their roster have not changed.

During the New York City mayor’s race in 2001, an unusually diverse coalition that included tenants, developers and bankers came together to urge the next mayor to tackle the increasingly pressing issue of housing. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went on to do just that. Now that coalition, Housing First!, is trying to repeat its success with the next governor.

President Enrique Bolaños unveiled plans to build a rival to the Panama Canal at a cost of $18 billion in order to allow larger ships to traverse the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. The public-private partnership, disclosed at a meeting in Managua of defense ministers from throughout the Western Hemisphere, would take more than a decade to complete. Panama will hold a referendum on Oct. 22 on a $5.25 billion plan to upgrade its canal, opened in 1914. “The galloping increase in world business demands another canal in addition to a widened Panama Canal,” Mr. Bolaños said.

The police broke up what they said was a cell providing financial and logistic support for an Algerian extremist group with reported ties to Al Qaeda. The police said they arrested four Algerians and a Tunisian near Milan, with a sixth suspect arrested in Switzerland. The suspects, the police said, were members of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, which has been accused of several attacks in Algeria.

Prime Minister Bertie Ahern has repaid business friends more than $100,000 in hopes of defusing a scandal, government officials said. They confirmed reports that Mr. Ahern mailed checks on Friday to a dozen friends who had given him cash when he was finance minister, in 1993 and 1994. He did not disclose having received the money — which he called loans from friends who had refused repayment — until the newspaper The Irish Times reported details of the payments. He is to answer questions about the money in Parliament today.

Prosecutors said they did not have enough evidence to prosecute Wu Shu-chen, the wife of President Chen Shui-bian, over accusations that she received gift certificates from a department store chain seeking government permission for a change of management.

At least 15 people were wounded when unknown assailants threw two grenades into a cafe in the Aegean port city of Izmir. The police chief, Huseyin Capkin, told reporters that the attack had “no political links.” He did not give details. Kurdish separatists and far-left and Islamist groups have carried out bomb attacks in Turkey.

The tanks and troops that ousted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra on Sept. 19 were off the streets of Bangkok, a day after Surayud Chulanont, a retired army commander, was sworn in as prime minister. The country’s respected central bank chief, Pridiyathorn Devakula, told reporters that he had agreed to join the cabinet. His appointment was most likely intended to show investors and the private sector that the interim government can handle the economy. Meanwhile, the Thai Rak Thai party of Mr. Thaksin appeared to be collapsing, with dozens of members resigning. Mr. Thaksin remains in London.

King Gyanendra, reduced to a figurehead since being forced to cede political power in April, made his first public comments since then, in his traditional message for Dasain, the national festival. In the message, circulated by the state-run news agency with excerpts read on radio, he urged unity and reconciliation and called for success for the peace process between the government and Maoist rebels.

A new United States-financed program to provide mass integrated treatment of neglected tropical diseases like trachoma, river blindness and elephantiasis will soon get under way in East and West Africa, officials with the Agency for International Development said. Congress has appropriated $15 million for the undertaking, up from $2 million in 2005. Pharmaceutical companies are donating the drugs; the federal funds will help cover the costs of distributing them.
