The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct concluded yesterday that William A. Carter, the Albany City Court judge who recently sentenced State Senator Ada L. Smith to anger management classes, should be censured over two courtroom incidents. According to the commission’s report, in 2004, the judge left the bench, “threw off his glasses and judicial robes” and confronted a defendant who had denounced the court proceedings, asking, “You want a piece of me?” Last year, the judge responded to a defendant’s obscene gesture by suggesting that a court officer “thump” him, the report said. The commission overruled the recommendation of its staff to remove Judge Carter, instead voting for censure and letting him keep his job. The Court of Appeals will review the decision before a final ruling from the commission. Ada Smith will not be so lucky, having lost in the recent Democratic primary. Earlier this year, after an aide accused Ms. Smith of throwing hot coffee in her face, Judge Carter fined Ms. Smith and ordered her to take anger management classes.

The state attorney general’s office said yesterday that it would not file criminal charges against a Queens drug abuse clinic accused by state regulators of defrauding the state’s Medicaid program of millions of dollars. Officials with the attorney general’s office said that after a long investigation of the clinic, Community Related Services Inc., they could not prove that clinic officials had intended to cheat the government. On Sunday, the state Medicaid inspector general’s office and the Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services announced a $16.5 million fine against the company and issued 25 findings of “serious Medicaid fraud, waste and abuse.” Efforts to obtain a working phone number were unsuccessful.
A federal prosecutor said news coverage of reports that Roger Clemens and five other baseball players used banned substances contained “significant inaccuracies.”

Subway service will be increased for fans attending playoff games at Yankee and Shea Stadiums, New York City Transit said yesterday. Before the Yankees home games tonight and tomorrow night, trains on the No. 4 line will run every four minutes, beginning 90 minutes before scheduled game time. After the games, trains on the No. 4 and the D lines will arrive at the 161st Street-Yankee Stadium station every two to three minutes. Before the day game at Shea tomorrow, two express trains and two local trains will be added to the No. 7 line schedule during the 90 minutes before the game. On Thursday night, there will be three additional express and three additional local trains on the No. 7 line during the 90 minutes preceding the game. After the Mets games, Manhattan-bound No. 7 trains will run every two to three minutes. The Long Island Rail Road will also be running expanded service to Shea Stadium, on its Port Washington branch. Schedule information can be found on the Web site mta.info.

The New Jersey family whose van crashed on the Staten Island Expressway on Sunday and burst into flames, killing a couple and injuring their three children, was apparently returning from a visit with relatives in Brooklyn, a spokeswoman for Staten Island University Hospital North said yesterday. She also said that the children, who were rescued from the burning van by police officers, were in stable condition last night, surrounded by their extended family. Their parents, Arturo Lopez-Mendez, 29, and Christina Guardado, 30, of Elizabeth, N.J., were killed. The police continued to look into the cause of Mr. Lopez-Mendez’s loss of control of the van. Robert A. Massina, president of the Kelly Masonry Corporation of Mineola, N.Y., where Mr. Lopez-Mendez worked, said the company was establishing a nonprofit foundation to raise funds for the children: Elizabeth, 9; Catherine, 3; and David, 2.

A teenager was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy in Far Rockaway last week, the police said. The suspect, Shakil Chandler, 19, of Far Rockaway, was also charged with criminal possession of a weapon. Investigators said he shot the boy, Mario Young, in the head on the night of Sept. 25 on Beach Channel Drive. The police said the two, both of Far Rockaway, were involved in a continuing dispute.

A Connecticut couple from Clinton have been indicted on federal child pornography charges involving a girl who was told that sexually explicit photos would help her modeling career, the authorities said yesterday. The couple, Robert Gamble, 59, and his wife, Renee Jones, 44, were charged with conspiring to produce child pornography. Mr. Gamble was also charged with production and possession of child pornography. Mr. Gamble, a professional photographer, began photographing the girl when she was 13, prosecutors said. At first, she was photographed fully clothed, but eventually she posed nude and in sexually explicit positions, the authorities said. Mr. Gamble regularly gave the victim sexually suggestive massages and what he called “lessons,” when he encouraged her to be more liberated sexually, prosecutors said. Ms. Jones was also present and observed some of the photo sessions, the authorities said. Mr. Gamble was arraigned in Federal District Court in Hartford. Ms. Jones has been released on $100,000 bond.

A man who once served as an F.B.I. informant was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to 90 years in prison for a series of bank robberies, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Giubilo, 61, of Belleville, was convicted on Feb. 10 of robbing banks in West Caldwell and Millburn in 2003 and 2004, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Giubilo was arrested by federal agents as he was about to enter the Bank of New York in Millburn, Mr. Christie said. At trial, he said, Mr. Giubilo claimed that he had been set up by the F.B.I. In 1997, a federal judge ordered that Mr. Giubilo stop working as an informant because of his continued criminal activity, including weapons possession and eluding the police, Mr. Christie said.

Yankees (97-65) vs. Detroit (95-67) Does good pitching always stop good hitting? This series should help to answer that question, pitting the majors' top pitching staff (the Tigers) against the majors' most productive offense (the Yankees). Detroit did not impress the Yankees this season, losing five of seven meetings between the teams. PITCHING YANKEES -- Unless his blisters open, the Game 1 starter Chien-Ming Wang should be fine. Mike Mussina, who will start Game 2, pitched a complete-game shutout against Detroit on May 31. Randy Johnson's back is a critical issue for Game 3. Mariano Rivera says his arm can handle the rigors of October, but Kyle Farnsworth has an awful playoff past. TIGERS -- The Tigers had the majors' best earned run average, at 3.84. The setup man Joel Zumaya is far more intimidating than closer Todd Jones, but each had an E.R.A. of 1.80 after the All-Star Game break. The only starter with postseason experience is Kenny Rogers. HITTING YANKEES -- The Yankees led the majors in runs, and their lineup is so deep that Joe Torre may never need a pinch-hitter. Johnny Damon and Bobby Abreu make the Yankees faster on the bases, more patient at the plate and more left-handed than in past Octobers. Hideki Matsui and Gary Sheffield have regained their timing, and Robinson Canó has been on a tear for eight weeks. TIGERS -- Detroit has a curious offensive formula, ranking second in the league in strikeouts with the second-fewest walks. In seven games against the Yankees, the Tigers hit .205 and averaged 3.3 runs a game. Their two victories came when Mariano Rivera was unavailable. Craig Monroe homered to beat Scott Proctor in August, but he has batted .181 since. FIELDING YANKEES -- The Tigers will challenge the below-average arms of Hideki Matsui in left field and Johnny Damon in center. Gary Sheffield has less than two weeks of experience at first base, and third baseman Alex Rodriguez matched a career high with 24 errors. Look for left fielder Melky Cabrera and first baseman Andy Phillips to be late-inning defensive replacements. TIGERS -- Catcher Iván Rodríguez can shut down any running game, but the Tigers have no outfielders who throw especially well. Plácido Polanco is a solid defender at second. Although third baseman Brandon Inge can make spectacular plays, he is also prone to wild throws. Carlos Guillén led A.L. shortstops in errors, with 28. X-FACTOR YANKEES -- So much has changed for Alex Rodriguez since he dominated the 2004 division series. There may be no player in the postseason with more pressure on him, and no player with more motivation to silence his doubters. He must remember how to harness his immense talent when it matters most. TIGERS -- The Tigers lost their last five games, giving away a division title that was in their grasp nearly all season. Was their slump meaningless, or an omen? Manager Jim Leyland, who led the wild-card Florida Marlins to a championship in 1997, will try to take the same route again. His players believe in him. TYLER KEPNER 1. Today at Yankees 8:19 p.m. FOX DET Robertson (13-13) YANKS Wang (19-6) 2. Tomorrow at Yankees 8:09 p.m. ESPN DET Verlander (17-9) YANKS Mussina (15-7) 3. Friday at Detroit 8:09 p.m. ESPN YANKS Johnson (17-11) DET Rogers (17-8) 4. Saturday at Detroit if necessary 5. Sunday at Yankees if necessary

To the Editor: Re ''Passing the Buck to Mom and Dad'' (editorial, Sept. 27): Under New York State law, dependent children can remain on their parents' policies beyond age 19 as long as they are enrolled in college. This law leaves many young adults who are not enrolled in college without access to affordable health care coverage.

The Metropolitan Opera says it will offer 200 orchestra seats to the general public at a cost of $20 each for performances Monday through Thursday, starting tonight. The seats, at the sides and toward the back of the hall, would normally cost $100. Tickets will be available the day of the performance. A grant for this season from a Met patron, Agnes Varis, right, is paying for the program, said Peter Gelb, the general manager. The Met already provides discount tickets for students and corporate employees in its 3,800-seat house. DANIEL J. WAKIN

If faced with the choice of attempting a short field goal from the Colts' 2 in a 14-14 game or going for a touchdown, would Dungy have gone for the touchdown, as Mangini did late in the third quarter?

President Enrique Bolaños unveiled plans to build a rival to the Panama Canal at a cost of $18 billion in order to allow larger ships to traverse the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. The public-private partnership, disclosed at a meeting in Managua of defense ministers from throughout the Western Hemisphere, would take more than a decade to complete. Panama will hold a referendum on Oct. 22 on a $5.25 billion plan to upgrade its canal, opened in 1914. ''The galloping increase in world business demands another canal in addition to a widened Panama Canal,'' Mr. Bolaños said. MARC LACEY (NYT)

Sunday may be ''Football Night in America'' on NBC, but ABC and CBS made it a three-way race for viewers this week. In the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, however, ABC handily finished first, buoyed by ''Desperate Housewives,'' which drew 21.2 million viewers for the 9 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. ABC also got a boost from ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (14.7 million) and its new drama with Calista Flockhart, below left, ''Brothers & Sisters,'' at 10 (13.9 million). CBS held steady all night, starting at 7 with a much-publicized Mike Wallace ''60 Minutes'' interview with Bob Woodward (17.5 million). CBS's ''Amazing Race 10'' (13.3 million) improved on its week-ago performance at 8, while ''Cold Case'' (13 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (14.9 million) were off from their premieres but solid. NBC's live broadcast of the Seattle Seahawks and Chicago Bears game averaged 16.9 million viewers for the night, in time-zone adjusted estimates. On the CW, the premiere of ''Everybody Hates Chris'' (2.4 million) slipped 72 percent in viewers 18 to 49 from its hyped Thursday debut last season -- its worst showing to date except for reruns. BENJAMIN TOFF

The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it had created a new curatorial department to focus exclusively on the growing number of contemporary artworks that use sound and moving images in gallery installations. The media department, once part of the department of film and media, will deal with works that use a wide range of modern technology, from video and digital imagery to Internet-based art and sound-only pieces, said Klaus Biesenbach, who was named chief curator of the new department. Mr. Biesenbach, right, who has been a MoMA curator since 2004 and the chief curator of P.S. 1, the museum's Queens affiliate, since 2002, said that works relying on media techniques and ideas of conveying motion and time had become much more prominent over the last two decades at international art fairs and exhibitions. ''And it's even more visible now,'' he said. ''I think artistic practice is evolving, and so museums are evolving as well.'' The creation of the new department brings the number of curatorial departments at the museum to seven. The other six are architecture and design, drawings, film, painting and sculpture, photography, and prints and illustrated books. RANDY KENNEDY

The Republican plan to focus the last five weeks of the campaign on national security has given way to a frantic scramble to contain the fallout from Representative Mark Foley's resignation over reports that he sent sexually explicit messages to Congressional pages. Democrats suddenly have a real chance of capturing Mr. Foley's seat in South Florida. The broader questions are whether the Foley case feeds the sour political mood -- the approval ratings for Congress are already among the lowest in a decade -- and whether it bolsters the Democrats' assertions that Republicans are incompetent and corrupt, and have been in power too long. The Foley news broke just after a book by Bob Woodward, ''State of Denial,'' focused new attention on President Bush's handling of the Iraq war, further distracting attention from the Republican security message when many of the party's candidates are struggling to gain an edge.

Big-Game Pitcher Tomorrow's scheduled Game 1 starter for the Dodgers against the Mets, Derek Lowe, last pitched a postseason game in New York in 2004, when he started Game 7 of the American League Championship Series for the Red Sox against the Yankees. Lowe pitched six innings, allowing one hit and one run and got the victory. That season he became the first pitcher in history to win the series-clinching game in three postseason series. Fast Relief Four of the five rookie leaders in strikeouts by a relief pitcher are in the playoffs. Their innings pitched and strikeout totals: Speed to Burn JosÉ Reyes of the Mets led the majors in triples with 17 and stolen bases with 64. He almost out-tripled the Yankees, who hit 21 as a team. He also stole more bases than the Athletics (61), Tigers (60) and Cardinals (59). Dome-Field Edge Johan Santana of the Twins was 12-0 at home this season and has not lost at the Metrodome since August 2005. The pitchers with the most victories at home without a loss since 1957: Road Warrior Chris Young of the Padres has not lost in his last 24 road games. He is 9-0 in those starts. His last road loss was on June 20, 2005, against the Angels when Young was with the Rangers. Power Supply Frank Thomas (39 home runs) and Nick Swisher (35), below, of the Athletics had the most homers as teammates among the American League playoff teams and the second most over all to the Mets' Carlos BeltrÁn (41) and Carlos Delgado (38).

To the Editor: Re ''Hearing Loss Is Common, but Often Untreated'' (Personal Health, Sept. 26): My own gradual and progressive hearing loss led to a surgical intervention that enabled me to continue working as a psychologist in the hearing world. Even mild hearing loss affects one's ability to enjoy and participate in life. More severe loss is isolating and may lead to inadequate care for other medical problems. Because much hearing loss is gradual, it can easily go unnoticed or be dismissed.

HOUSING COSTS GROW -- The burden of housing costs on people living in nearly every part of the country grew sharply between 2000 and 2005, according to new Census Bureau data being made public today. The numbers illustrate vividly the impact, often distributed unevenly, of the crushing combination of escalating real estate prices and largely stagnant incomes. [A1.] ASSESSING G.M.'S PROGRESS -- Is the turnaround at General Motors real? That is a crucial question that the G.M. board must consider when it meets today. G.M.'s biggest investor, Kirk Kerkorian, clearly disagrees with management's assertion that the turnaround is taking hold. [C1.] STOCK EXCHANGE PLAN DELAYED -- The New York Stock Exchange has pushed back a plan that would prevent brokers from voting their clients' shares in board elections when the stockholders have given no voting instructions. Catherine R. Kinney, president of the exchange, above, said that the rule change was not dead but that it was being scheduled to go into effect in 2008. [C1.] DATA FROM WRECKAGE FOUND -- Rescue workers found voice and data recorders in the wreckage of an airliner that crashed in the Amazon rainforest last week, killing all 155 people on board. Investigators continued questioning the American pilots of a business jet that Brazilian authorities say they believe collided with the larger aircraft in midair. [A10.] HIT IN MIDAIR -- Joe Sharkey, columnist for The Times, describes what it was like to be inside the business jet that was hit and forced to make an emergency landing in Brazil. [A1.] UNIFORM TEST AT WAL-MART -- Wal-Mart has begun testing a new look for its 1.3 million workers in the United States: khaki pants and a navy blue polo shirt, according to employees briefed on the plans. [C1.] FALLOUT FROM THAI DEAL -- In hindsight, the $1.9 billion purchase of a controlling stake in Thailand's dominant telecommunications conglomerate early this year by a group led by the Singapore government's investment arm, Temasek Holdings, was less than ideal, analysts and people close to the deal say. [C1.] HARRAH'S ATTRACTS OFFER -- Harrah's Entertainment, the largest casino operator in the world, said that Apollo Management and Texas Pacific Group had offered to acquire it for $15.05 billion in cash. [C3.] BLOW TO ONLINE BETTING FIRMS -- Companies that operate Internet betting sites and payment systems lost billions of dollars in market value after the United States government moved to criminalize the processing of online wagers. [C3.] ACTIONS OF EX-CONVERSE CHIEF -- After arriving in Namibia two months ago, Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology wanted in the United States on stock option fraud charges, transferred about $16 million to Namibia from Israel, bought a house and put his children into a local school, a Windhoek court was told. [C3.] INDIA'S ECONOMIC ZONES -- India is using privately run special economic zones as a partial solution to the extreme weaknesses in India's infrastructure: narrow, pothole-filled roads; erratic supplies of electricity and other utility services; and inadequate communication links. But opposition to the zones is mounting from political parties, farmers' groups and economists. [C5.] STOCKS FALL -- The Nasdaq composite index dragged down stocks as slowing growth among manufacturers heightened concern that the economic expansion is weakening. [C12.] TOO MUCH ANIMATION -- Analysts and industry executives have long warned of a coming glut of computer-animated movies. Now that time has come. With so many movies for audiences to choose from, some are failing to meet expectations or are flopping outright. For example, This summer's ''The Wild,'' from Walt Disney, proved anything but for moviegoers, bringing in only $37 million at the domestic box office. [C1.] NEW REAL ESTATE REALITY -- Without a white-hot market to drive the plot, the producers of ''Million Dollar Listing'' and other television shows about real estate now have to rethink their formats. [C9.] CONCERN ON AD RULE -- When an advertiser's relationship with its agencies goes sour, a breakup is often the best course for everyone involved. But some people in London's marketing world are now concerned that a new regulation could threaten this easy-come, easy-go existence. [C9.]

Q. How do birds in which both sexes look alike know which is which, for mating purposes? A. Some birds do in fact look so much alike that researchers have to rely on DNA analyses to tell which of the birds they have been studying are male and which are female.

If a 15th Subway Series is nigh, it is time to study anew the passions of Mets and Yankees fans. Or, to demonstrate scrupulous objectivity, let us also refer to them as Yankees and Mets fans. There is, evidence shows, a greater population of one breed (Yankees fans) than the other, which is not as shocking a development in baseball analysis as, say, a complete game.

REINLIEB--Edith. Passed away peacefully on October 1st at Aventura Hospital, Aventura, FL. She was 99 and predeceased by her beloved husband of 56 years, Julius Reinlieb. Mrs. Reinlieb is survived by her sons, Laurence and Joel. Interment will be private.

To the Editor: Re ''One Cook Too Many,'' by John Tierney (column, Sept. 30): Defenders of trans fatty acids warn that their bogyman, the nanny state, stops eaters from following their tastes. But no one has ever asked for a serving of trans fat. The food industry added trans fat to extend shelf life, modify texture and increase profits. Safe, affordable alternatives are available.

''This is a political problem, and we need to step up and do something dramatic.'' REPRESENTATIVE RAY LAHOOD, Republican of Illinois, on the reaction to former Representative Mark Foley's messages to teenage pages. [A1]

Scientists have developed an ''intelligent'' prosthesis that closely mimics the action of a human foot. Ossur's Proprio Foot uses motion sensors, actuators and software to replace lost muscle function and keep track of where it is in space. Costing $12,000 to $18,000, the device automatically positions itself on stairs or steep ramps -- situations that can be difficult for an amputee. In initial fitting, a ''gait profile'' is created by having the wearer take 15 consecutive steps on level ground. The foot can be worn with or without shoes. FRANK O'CONNELL Adapting to its environment 1. Accelerometers sample the foot's position more than 1,000 times a second. A change in the gait signals that the person may no longer be on a level surface. 2. A motor drive pivots the heel up and down. 3. A sensor in the joint measures the foot's angle, ensuring that the foot is correctly positioned for the next step. Automated advantage Unlike previous artificial feet, the Proprio flexes automatically to the proper position, allowing for more natural walking. Different modes for special situations STAIR MODE Goes into action when the sensors detect two stairs in succession. It rotates the ankle to accommodate steps. RELAX MODE Allows wearer to sit more naturally by lowering toe toward the floor. CHAIR EXIT MODE By tapping the heel in relax mode, wearer flexes ankle forward so the foot can be pulled back. The heel provides shock absorption and allows a more natural walking motion. Its height can be adjusted up to 2 inches via a keypad to accommodate different shoe styles. Developments in prosthetic feet WOODEN LEG 1800's Peg leg for above-theknee amputees. SACH FOOT 1950's Solid ankle, cushion heel. Durable, inexpensive and lightweight. SEATTLE FOOT 1980's First energy-storing foot. Uses a lightweight plastic spring mechanism. FLEX FOOT 1980's First carbon fiber foot. Simulated the spring of a normal foot. COLLEGE PARK FOOT 1990 First to be produced with humanlike joint configuration, allowing ankle motion. (Sources by Ossur; Mark Edwards, Northwestern University Prosthetics-Orthotics Center; University of Manchester Medical School Museum; College Park Industries)

As Alex Rodriguez embarks on another postseason tonight, he will hit sixth in the Yankees' lineup, the lowest spot he has hit from in more than 10 years. Manager Joe Torre said he could not go wrong arranging so many powerful hitters in any order. But the implied message was that batting sixth could help Rodriguez relax.

An article in Weekend on Sept. 22 about the jazz musician Ornette Coleman erroneously included an instrument among those for which notation must be transposed to fit the ''concert key'' of C in Western music. They do not include the violin.

A chart on Sept. 22 about the electoral and popular votes in presidential elections referred incorrectly to the election of John Quincy Adams in 1824. He was chosen by the House of Representatives, not by the Electoral College, and he did not win a majority of the popular vote. (Adams's opponent Andrew Jackson had more electoral votes -- 99 to Adams's 84 -- but not a majority because two other candidates received electoral votes, forcing the House to decide.)

A dedicated Board member for forty-five years, she will be greatly missed, and our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her family. Paul A. Volcker, Chairman Donald L. Cuneo, President

San Diego (88-74) vs. St. Louis (83-78) A year ago, the Padres went to the playoffs with a team that finished two games over .500, and they were promptly swept by the Cardinals. This season, the Padres are significantly better built for postseason success. The Cardinals do not seem as balanced as they were the past two seasons. PITCHING PADRES -- San Diego has two starters in their prime (Jake Peavy and Chris Young) and two in their twilight (David Wells and Woody Williams). No team in the National League boasts a deeper or healthier rotation. San Diego's ultimate strength remains its bullpen. The bridge from Cla Meredith to Scott Linebrink to Trevor Hoffman took the Padres from summer to fall. CARDINALS -- Jeff Suppan and Jeff Weaver need to be effective behind Chris Carpenter. With Jason Isringhausen (left hip surgery) out for the season, the closer's role falls to the rookie Adam Wainwright, who had two key saves in the final five days. HITTING PADRES -- It is hard to believe that a lineup featuring Geoff Blum and Russell Branyan is seriously entertaining thoughts of playoff advancement. The Padres do not have any sluggers who inspire much fear, or even attention. No one on the team has more than 24 home runs or 83 runs batted in. Perhaps the most significant threat has been Dave Roberts, the leadoff hitter. When Roberts reaches base -- a fairly common occurrence -- the Padres are able to drive him in with Brian Giles, Adrian Gonzalez, Mike Piazza and Mike Cameron. CARDINALS -- Jim Edmonds returned from postconcussion syndrome last week, but his role could be limited. He has a sore left foot, and Manager Tony La Russa will not use him against left-handed pitchers. FIELDING PADRES -- If Khalil Greene is able to come back from a finger injury, the Padres will show off a double-play combination as smooth as any in the league. With Greene at shortstop, Josh Barfield at second and Mike Cameron in center, the Padres' only problem up the middle is catcher Mike Piazza, always a target for opposing base-stealers. CARDINALS -- The outfield is only decent without Jim Edmonds; the same for the infield without David Eckstein. So Taguchi and Juan Encarnación played center field in the last two regular-season games, and each was a step down from even a hobbled Edmonds. Catcher Yadier Molina threw out 42 percent of runners trying to steal against him. X-FACTOR PADRES -- Low-scoring games tend to favor the Padres, and at Petco Park low-scoring games are nearly a sure thing. Petco is a pitchers paradise, and the Padres are built around their pitchers. San Diego hitters used to be frustrated by their home field, but they have learned to manufacture runs. CARDINALS -- Saving the team's season, Scott Spiezio hit a pinch-hit three-run triple in Saturday's 3-2 victory over Milwaukee. More than two-thirds of his 52 R.B.I. came with two outs. Spiezio is no stranger to postseason heroics. He had 19 R.B.I. for the Angels in the 2002 playoffs. LEE JENKINS and PAT BORZI 1. Today at San Diego 4:09 p.m. ESPN ST. L. Carpenter (15-8) S.D. Peavy (11-14) 2. Thursday at San Diego 4:09 p.m. ESPN ST. L. Suppan (12-7) S.D. C. Young (11-5) 3. Saturday at St. Louis TBA S.D. Williams (12-5) ST. L. Weaver (5-4, N.L.) 4. Sunday at St. Louis if necessary 5. Monday at San Diego if necessary
RUBIN--Fay. January 20, 1923 to October 3, 1996. In Loving Memory, Joyce

President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney probably do not watch many PBS ''Frontline'' documentaries about Iraq and Afghanistan, and for the sake of their blood pressure, it's probably just as well. Nothing could be more maddening that the slow, methodical drip, drip, drip of unflattering image and fact -- especially when framed by the grave, reproachful voice-over of Will Lyman, a longtime narrator on ''Frontline.'' ''Return of the Taliban,'' on PBS tonight, examines why the United States appears to be losing ground against Al Qaeda and Taliban forces in Afghanistan. It gives two stark reasons: the Jihadists' single-minded determination to expel foreign troops and Pakistan's ambivalence about rooting out Taliban strongholds along its border.

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of works made from dollars and other currency at the Pavel Zoubok Gallery on West 23rd Street, misstated the surname of an artist whose work is being shown there and part of the name of a group he founded with Mark Wagner, another artist whose work is being shown. The artist is C. K. Wilde, not Wolfe, and the group is the Booklyn Artists Alliance, not the Brooklyn Artists Alliance.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about Frederic Wakeman Jr., a scholar of Chinese history, misstated the relationship of Orville Schell, dean of the graduate school of journalism at the University of California, Berkeley, to Dr. Wakeman. Dean Schell is a former student of Dr. Wakeman, not a former teacher.

An article in some copies on Sept. 24 about several stabbings and shootings in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood where the nightclub Club Reflections, the scene of one stabbing, is located. It is Flatbush, not Kensington.

People living below the poverty line are more likely to have very high levels of C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation that increases the risk for heart disease and death, a new study has found. C-reactive protein is produced in response to injury or infection, but some people have chronically high levels of it. The study, published in the September issue of Brain, Behavior and Immunity, found no significant difference by socioeconomic status in those with moderate or high levels of C-reactive protein, but there was a significant difference in very high levels.

To the Editor: Re ''Academy of P.C. Sciences'' (column, Sept. 26):

Minnesota (96-66) vs. Oakland (93-69) After losing their young star, the left-hander Francisco Liriano, to an elbow injury, the Twins patched together a pitching rotation behind Johan Santana, won 96 games and overtook Detroit for the division title on the final day of the season. The A's thrived in the second half (48-26, best record in baseball). PITCHING TWINS -- The Twins will be in trouble if Johan Santana is their only effective starter. Boof Bonser was great in September (4-1, 2.63 earned run average in six starts), but he is a rookie. Brad Radke pitched all season with a torn labrum, and Carlos Silva has been inconsistent. Minnesota's strength is its bullpen, anchored by Joe Nathan, who compiled 36 saves in 38 chances with a 1.58 E.R.A. ATHLETICS -- The left-hander Barry Zito is 3-2 with a 2.76 E.R.A. in postseason games, but he has never started a Game 1. Rich Harden, back after missing most of the season with back and elbow problems, gave Oakland a late-season boost. HITTING TWINS -- The batting champion Joe Mauer and the M.V.P. candidate Justin Morneau get most of the attention, but Michael Cuddyer (24 homers, 109 runs batted in) finally blossomed into the cleanup hitter the Twins had sought for more than a decade. The so-called Little Piranhas -- Nick Punto, Jason Bartlett and Jason Tyner -- make this team go. ATHLETICS -- The A's finished near the bottom of the league in every major hitting category, and batted .243 with runners in scoring position. Frank Thomas's comeback-player-of-the-year season included a big second half (20 homers, 68 R.B.I. in 72 games) with no letup. He had 11 homers and 34 R.B.I. from Sept. 1 on. Shortstop Bobby Crosby (back problems) is not expected to play in this series. FIELDING TWINS -- Nick Punto, a utility infielder, provided Gold Glove-caliber defense at third base in the second half of the season, and shortstop Jason Bartlett and second baseman Luis Castillo were solid. Manager Ron Gardenhire says this infield may be almost as airtight as the 2002 unit, which featured the Gold Glove first baseman Doug Mientkiewicz. Center fielder Torii Hunter appears close to full speed after more than a year of foot and ankle problems. ATHLETICS -- This has been a bright spot. Marco Scutaro filled in well for shortstop Bobby Crosby, second baseman Mark Ellis made two errors all season, and the outfield of Milton Bradley, Mark Kotsay and Jay Payton covers a lot of ground. X-FACTOR TWINS -- The Metrodome crowd does not have the effect it once did; the Twins have lost five straight home playoff games since 2002, the last four to the Yankees. Closer Joe Nathan's phenomenal season has received little national attention. In a short series, when runs may be scarce, an effective Nathan could be the difference. ATHLETICS -- Rich Harden, though roughed up by the Angels on Sunday (6 runs in three and two-thirds innings), had allowed only one run and struck out 12 in eight innings over his two previous starts since returning from a strained elbow. One well-pitched game by Harden could swing the series. PAT BORZI 1. Today at Minnesota 1:09 p.m. ESPN OAK Zito (16-10) MINN Santana (19-6) 2. Tomorrow at Minnesota 1:09 p.m. ESPN OAK Loaiza (11-9) MINN Bonser (7-6) 3. Friday at Oakland 4:09 p.m. ESPN MINN Radke (12-9) OAK Harden (4-0) 4. Saturday at Oakland if necessary 5. Sunday at Minnesota if necessary

Amid a torrent of bad news for Republicans in polls across the country, there was one bright spot for them, and it was in California of all places. Two new polls show Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, left, solidly ahead of his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Phil Angelides. Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has been busy making deals with Democrats in the Legislature and courting the political center, led Mr. Angelides by 17 percentage points, 50 percent to 33 percent, in a Los Angeles Times poll this past weekend. And he was ahead 13 percentage points, 49 percent to 36 percent, in a Mason-Dixon poll released yesterday.

LUKENS--Pjay Phelps passed away at home on October 1 following a private and courageous battle with cancer. Jay was the cherished husband of Susan for nearly 30 years and beloved father of Clinton, Ashley and Walker. Jay grew up in Minnesota and later moved to Florida where he was a Thomas Presidential Scholar at Eckerd College. Jay completed his Ph.D in Economics at Texas A&M University earning the Alfred Chalk award. Jay started his career with AT&T in Basking Ridge, but in1985 moved to Texas to work for Transco Energy. In 1997, Jay started Lukens Energy Group. Despite his successes however, Jay always remained modest and placed the greatest value on close friendships with his partners, co-workers, and many colleagues within the energy industry. Jay supported many benevolent causes and was a trustee on the Board of Eckerd College. The family is grateful to MD Anderson and the brillance of Dr. Chris Logothetis. In lieu of flowers, Jay wished that donations be made to Eckerd College, Grace School and the St. Francis Episcopal Day School Mission Honduras. Jay's funeral service will be held at Memorial Drive Presbyterian Church on October 5th, 1 p.m., and a viewing will be held at the Bradshaw-Carter Funeral Home from 5-8 on October 4th. Online tributes may be posted at www.bradshawcarter.com

A picture caption on Sunday with a Congressional Memo article, about developments before Congress took a break for midterm elections, misspelled the surname of a staff member for Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, as he and aides shared a meal with the senator. He is Ty Matsdorf, not Natsdorf.
BINN--Sheldon. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sheldon Binn, associated with The Times from January 17, 1957 until retiring in January 1, 1989.

To the Editor: Re ''White House Disputes Book's Account of Rifts on Iraq'' (news article, Sept. 30): Bob Woodward revealed that Henry A. Kissinger has been advising President Bush about Iraq, telling him that ''victory is the only meaningful exit strategy.''

A man who once served as an F.B.I. informant was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to 90 years in prison for a series of bank robberies, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Giubilo, 61, of Belleville, was convicted on Feb. 10 of robbing banks in West Caldwell and Millburn in 2003 and 2004, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Giubilo was arrested by federal agents as he was about to enter the Bank of New York in Millburn, Mr. Christie said. At trial, he said, Mr. Giubilo claimed that he had been set up by the F.B.I. In 1997, a federal judge ordered that Mr. Giubilo stop working as an informant because of his continued criminal activity, including weapons possession and eluding the police, Mr. Christie said.

JOURNEY--Drexel. 80. Retired partner in Schiff Hardin LLP, former General Counsel of the Federal Power Commission and past President of the Federal Bar Association Democracy Development Institute, died August 22 in Washington, DC. Mr. Journey attended the Merchant Marine Academy during World War II and served in the Pacific Theater of Operations. He earned undergraduate (1950) and law (1952) degrees from the University of Wisconsin and a graduate law degree (1957) from George Washington University. Survivors include his wife of 53 years, Vergene; daughter, Dr. Ann Marie Journey (Ray Wuolo); sisters; brother; nieces; nephews; and grandsons, Eric, Karl, Anders and Magnus Wuolo-Journey. Inurnment in the Columbarium at Arlington National Cemetery will take place at 10 a.m., October 12. Memorial service follows at noon at Westmoreland Congregational United Church of Christ.

HALE--Nathan. A Memorial Service will be held to celebrate his life, Thursday October 5th at 5 P.M., The Harvard Club of New York City, 35 West 44 St. Donations may be made to The ''Hale Memorial Fund'' at The Damariscotta River Association, PO Box 333, Damariscotta, ME 04543.

To the Editor: Re ''Understanding and Empathy Aren't Enough'' (Behavior, Sept. 26): I think Dr. Richard A. Friedman made some important and valid points in his discussion of empathy in psychotherapy. But I would say that while empathy and understanding may not be enough, they are almost always a prerequisite to the rest of the therapy. Dr. Friedman is right that there are times when clients need to be confronted. But despite his example of a very successful case, it is hard for most people to be confronted if they don't first feel they are understood.

The rookie Gerris Wilkinson said Monday that Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had not yet told him that he was the team's new starting weakside linebacker. But Wilkinson said he was preparing as if he would make his first N.F.L. start Sunday. A player proceeds at his own peril when he assumes Coughlin will do something. Yet Wilkinson, a third-round draft choice from Georgia Tech, appears to be the best option the Giants have to replace the injured Carlos Emmons.

Nascar is reaching out to Canada in its latest effort to expand, putting Montreal on its Busch Series schedule in 2007 with a road-course event at Circuit Gilles-Villeneuve on Aug. 4. Officials from the racetrack and Nascar made the announcement yesterday during a news conference in Montreal. VIV BERNSTEIN (NYT)

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 After Major Afghan Battle, Local Anger and Gratitude After NATO forces scored one of their biggest victories in Pashmul, Afghanistan, killing 500 Taliban fighters and capturing 136, local villagers trickling back to their homes were divided over who was to blame for the heavy destruction, NATO or the Taliban. A1 New Security Plan in Iraq Faced with sectarian killings and growing anger from Sunni leaders, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced a new security plan calling for neighborhood leaders to try to defuse sectarian crises in their own areas and for new supervision of the media. A12 Russia Blocks Travel to Georgia Georgia released four Russian military officers arrested on charges of espionage after Russia annouced it was suspending air, rail, sea and road transportation between the two countries. A9 Recorders Found at Crash Site Rescue workers found voice and data recorders amid the wreckage of a Brazilian airliner that crashed in the Amazon rain forest, killing all 155 people on board. Investigators questioned the pilots of a business jet that authorities believe collided with the aircraft. A10 Hungarian Leader Calls for Vote The prime minister of Hungary called for a parliamentary vote of confidence in his national government after his party was swept out of power in regional elections. A11 Rival Parties Lead in Bosnia Partial results of elections in Bosnia showed parties led by Haris Silajdzic, the Muslim who was prime minister during the civil war, and Milorad Dodik, the most prominent Serb politician, were likely to dominate the country's main institutions. A9 Palestinian Factions Clash Hamas and Fatah traded gunfire and recriminations for a second straight day in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, leaving two dead and about 20 wounded. A6 NATIONAL A17-24 G.O.P. Tries to Limit Damage in Foley Case Republicans faced intensifying questions about why they did not react more aggressively to Representative Mark Foley's messages to a teenage page as members of his party, fearing a political debacle, demanded a strong response to the furor. A1 At least two news organizations, The St. Petersburg Times and The Miami Herald, were tipped off to e-mail messages sent by Representative Foley long before the story of his sexually explicit remarks to teenage pages broke last week. A20 Shooting at Amish School A dairy truck driver walked into a one-room Amish schoolhouse in Pennsylvania and systematically tried to execute the young girls there, killing four and wounding seven before killing himself, the police said. A1 Schools around the country were on alert after the second hostage taking, and third homicide, in less than a week in a public school. A22 Terrorism Meeting Confirmed A review of White House records has determined that George J. Tenet, then the director of central intelligence, did brief Condoleezza Rice and other top officials on July 10, 2001, about the looming threat from Al Qaeda, a State Department spokesman said. A18 Nobel Prize Goes to Americans This year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine has been awarded to two American researchers, Andrew Z. Fire and Craig C. Mello, for a discovery about how genes are controlled within living cells. A17 OBITUARIES C15 Isabel Bigley An actress who won a Tony award in 1951 for her role in the Broadway hit ''Guys and Dolls,'' she was 80. C15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Burden of Housing Costs Is Felt Across the Nation The burden of housing costs on people living in nearly every part of the country grew sharply between 2000 and 2005, according to new Census Bureau data being made public today. In New York City, more than half of all renters now spend at least 30 percent of their gross income on housing, a figure commonly used to estimate housing affordability. A1 Better Chemical Sniffers The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it would spend $3.9 million to further upgrade a network of chemical sensors that sniff the air at Grand Central Terminal for signs of a poison gas or chemical attack, and install a similar system in Pennsylvania Station. B1 Help in Shrinking Hospitals The Bush administration has agreed to pay New York $1.5 billion over five years to help stabilize the state's financially troubled hospital industry, state and federal officials announced. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Eerie Feelings and the Brain Experiences often attributed by those who have them to paranormal forces can be induced by delivering mild electric current to specific spots in the brain, according to recent work by neuroscientists. Paul Getty Trust, one of the world's richest cultural organizations. The inquiry determined that the trust's former president, with the approval of the Getty board, misspent trust money. C1 Glut of Animated Movies With more than a dozen computer-animated movies being readied for release, Hollywood is facing the prospect of serious viewer fatigue. The most popular number on shirts here these days is 40, the number on pitcher Chien-Ming Wang's Yankees jersey. When a local convenience store chain sold a limited edition of subway fare cards bearing Wang's picture, people lined up for two days, fights broke out and the police had to be called. Lawmakers forgave a colleague who fell asleep during a meeting after he explained that, like many Taiwanese, he had stayed up to watch a Yankees game that was shown live in the middle of the night here. Yankees games have some of the highest ratings on Taiwanese television, even for broadcasts that start at 1 a.m. because of the 12-hour time difference.

Morgan Stanley said it had purchased Nan Tung Bank, a small commercial bank in Guangdong Province. Though the bank has just one branch and 40 employees, the deal could help the investment bank increase its presence substantially in China because it gives Morgan Stanley a commercial banking license. The license will allow Morgan Stanley to offer loans and other products to corporations in foreign currencies, but not in local currency. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. HEATHER TIMMONS (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''Shifting Power to a President'' (news analysis, front page, Sept. 30): The detainee treatment bill recently passed by Congress will allow the president to label anyone an ''unlawful enemy combatant,'' detain prisoners indefinitely and shield the decision from review by the courts.

Our public editor reminded us last week that we have not corrected two errors we made in the past year. In an editorial on April 26, we should have written that the Strategic Petroleum Reserve had a capacity of 727 million barrels, not gallons. In an editorial on Dec. 30, we said that the top basic tax rate was 31 percent before the 1990 increase. It was 28 percent. The deal raised it to 31 percent.

8 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS -- Praise be to the pigskin. This heavily anticipated series, inspired by the book and the movie, worships at the altar of football, the established religion of Texas, as it follows the team from a rural town where state championship rings mean everything. Kyle Chandler plays the new head coach; Scott Porter (above, center, with Taylor Kitsch, left, as Tim Riggins and Gaius Charles as Brian Williams) is the star quarterback whose padded shoulders still may not be broad enough to withstand the pressure of a new season. 8 P.M. (13, 49) NOVA SCIENCE NOW -- Neil deGrasse Tyson, the astrophysicist and director of the Hayden Plantarium at the American Musem of Natural History, takes over as host of this ''Nova'' offshoot. He starts tonight with a look at asteroids --specifically, what could happen if a ''doomsday asteroid'' the size of the Rose Bowl hits the Earth in 2036, and what NASA can do to stop it before impact. 8:30 P.M. (BBC America) MASTERCHEF GOES LARGE -- Talk about putting the chicken before the egg. As more than 100 chefs begin to endure rigorous challenges in this new 30-episode British cooking competition, some get a little ahead of themselves -- like the woman who wants to be a television cook but has never worked in a real kitchen. 9 P.M. (11) VERONICA MARS -- It's a new school year, and Veronica (Kristen Bell, right) the high school super-sleuth has moved on to college, along with her sidekicks Logan, Wallace and Mac. Pop quiz: Who stole Wallace's roommate's stuff? 9 P.M. (13) RETURN OF THE TALIBAN -- ''Frontline'' begins a new season by infiltrating a tribal area along the Afghan-Pakistani border, where a resurgent Taliban militia has gained control. President Pervez Musharraf tells why Pakistan's strategy to get the militants to lay down their guns has failed, and reports on what may be next. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT -- The great Dane Connie Nielsen plays a New York warrants officer -- and the new partner of Detective Stabler (Christopher Meloni) -- for a six-episode arc while Mariska Hargitay is on maternity leave. 10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON LEGAL -- Ivan Tiggs (Tom Selleck, in a recurring guest role) wants to invalidate his post-nuptial agreement so that he can divorce his new wife and asks Shirley Schmidt, his old wife, to represent him. Meanwhile, Denny Crane's Internet date shows that small people can make a big ruckus. 10 P.M. (FX) NIP/TUCK -- Is there a doctor in the house? Dawn Budge, a lottery winner played by Rosie O'Donnell, tries to get Christian (Julian McMahon, above, with Ms. O'Donnell) to tweak her entire family. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Marjorie G. Lewisohn, a Manhattan internist who was the first woman to be a trustee of Johns Hopkins University, died Sept. 16 in Manhattan. She was 87. Her death was announced by her sister Elizabeth L. Eisenstein of Washington, who survives her, along with two other sisters, Joan Crowell of Quogue, N.Y., and Virginia L. Kahn of Cambridge, Mass.

Both parties and independent political groups have spent heavily for competitive races in the Northeast and the Rust Belt, adding large sums to what candidates are spending from their own fund-raising accounts.

This will come as a jolt to all New Yorkers currently giddy over the prospect of a Subway Series: Not a lot of people out there care about the fabled transfer at Grand Central Station. Yes, the Yankees are a national institution, as demonstrated by the way television will show Yankee games in prime time, but a Subway Series? That's our New York preoccupation, not necessarily shared by folks west of our mass transportation system.

SILVAN--Matthew, We are devastated to announce the sudden passing of Matthew Silvan. Dr. Silvan, a Ph.D. in psychology and a gifted clinician, was a graduate of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, a psychoanalyst in private practice, and the director of Psychocutaneous Medicine at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York City. He was greatly admired and respected by his colleagues and immensely loved by his family and friends. He is survived by his adoring wife Carmen Grau, Ph.D., his daughters Ariana, 13, and Mia, 10, his brother Jon and sister-in-law Marnie, his sisters Melanie and Dany and their families, his parents Mark Silvan and Helaine Shlasko (widow of his stepfather Bernie Shlasko), his stepmother Abby, his mother-in-law Felisa, his entire family in Barcelona, Spain, his many nieces and nephews, and numerous friends. We will miss him terribly and remember him forever for his passion for learning, his dedication to his profession, and his keen intellect. He was a devoted son and brother, an extraordinary husband, and an absolutely amazing father. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapels, 180 West 76th Street, Tuesday, October 3rd at 4pm. Contributions can be made to The Stroke Fund, Dept. of Neurology, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, NY, NY 10029 $(6$)SILVAN--Matthew. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledges with deep sadness the untimely passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Matthew Silvan, Ph.D, Director of Psychocutaneous Medicine in our Department of Dermatology. A member of the hospital staff since 1988, Dr. Silvan was loved by his patients and deeply respected by all who knew him and worked with him. He will be greatly missed. To his wife, Carmen Grau, Ph.D., his two young daughters, the entire Silvan family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Richard F. Daines, M.D. President and CEO Donna Mendes, M.D. President, Medical Board Vincent A. DeLeo, M.D. Chairman, Deptartment of Dermatology

Mets (97-65) vs. Dodgers (88-74) The Mets took the lead in the National League East on April 6 and never looked back. This is their first playoff appearance since 2000, when they reached the World Series. The Dodgers overturned their opening-day bullpen and three-fifths of their rotation and managed to win the wild card. PITCHING METS -- Without the injured Pedro Martínez, the Mets will send out two playoff-tested starters for Games 1 and 2. Orlando Hernández is 9-3 with a 2.55 earned run average in 19 postseason appearances, and the 290-game winner Tom Glavine, the Game 2 starter, has made 32 career postseason starts. After that it can get dicey. DODGERS -- Derek Lowe and Greg Maddux are perhaps the most formidable duo in the N.L. The rookie Hong-Chih Kuo, a left-hander, pitched six shutout innings against the Mets last month. Brad Penny has been hampered by back problems. Closer Takashi Saito is 3-0 with a 1.30 E.R.A. since taking over the role in August. HITTING METS -- A dynamic combination of speed and power anchors the most complete lineup in the N.L. Three players -- David Wright, Carlos Beltrán and Carlos Delgado -- had 114 or more runs batted in this season, and seven reached double digits in home runs. The speedy leadoff batter José Reyes is disruptive when he gets on base. DODGERS -- The Dodgers are more prone to tack on hit after hit and run other teams ragged than play for a three-run home run. Nomar Garciaparra and J. D. Drew share the team lead with 20 homers, but they are two of the seven starters who are batting higher than .280. Rafael Furcal has the second-highest on-base percentage among regular leadoff hitters and ranks among the league leaders in runs and stolen bases. FIELDING METS -- The team tied a franchise record this season by going 12 consecutive games without an error. The defense is solid over all, though not exceptional. Carlos Beltrán has 13 assists, tops among center fielders. Cliff Floyd is hindered by soreness in his left Achilles' tendon and has narrow range in left field. DODGERS -- Defense is the Dodgers' biggest weakness. Their 115 errors this season are the most among playoff teams. Rafael Furcal's rifle arm allows him to make plays other shortstops cannot, but he is not always on target. He committed 27 errors this season, the third-highest total in baseball. At first base, Nomar Garciaparra has made a seamless transition, boasting a .996 fielding percentage. X-FACTOR METS -- Of the Mets' projected starters, four -- José Valentín, Cliff Floyd, Carlos Beltrán and Shawn Green -- have playoff experience. Carlos Delgado and Paul Lo Duca, both 34 years old, are making it for the first time. They will be guided by a manager, Willie Randolph, who will begin his 18th postseason. DODGERS -- The Dodgers are the streakiest team in the playoffs. After going 48-42 in the first half, they lost 13 of 14 games after the All-Star Game break. Then they reeled off an 11-game winning streak and 17 victories in 18 games. They enter the playoffs having swept consecutive road series in Colorado and San Francisco. BEN SHPIGEL 1. Tomorrow at Mets 4:09 p.m. ESPN L.A. Lowe (16-8) METS O. Hernández (11-11) 2. Thursday at Mets 8:19 p.m. FOX L.A. Kuo (1-5) METS Glavine (15-7) 3. Saturday at Los Angeles TBA METS Trachsel (15-8) L.A. Maddux (15-14) 4. Sunday at Los Angeles if necessary 5. Monday at Mets if necessary

To the Editor: Re ''Alfred Nobel and the Prize That Almost Didn't Happen'' (Sept. 26): Dr. Lawrence K. Altman states, ''The reason for the peace prize is less clear.'' Actually, there is no mystery. The peace prize resulted from Nobel's friendship with Bertha von Suttner, an Austrian who had briefly worked for him but had become famous for her novel ''Lay Down Your Arms.''

A new United States-financed program to provide mass integrated treatment of neglected tropical diseases like trachoma, river blindness and elephantiasis will soon get under way in East and West Africa, officials with the Agency for International Development said. Congress has appropriated $15 million for the undertaking, up from $2 million in 2005. Pharmaceutical companies are donating the drugs; the federal funds will help cover the costs of distributing them. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

Senator George Allen, the Virginia Republican recently hit by charges of racial insensitivity, has begun a new wave of advertising that accuses his Democratic challenger, Jim Webb, of insensitivity to the rights of women, based on a 1979 article Mr. Webb wrote arguing against women's admission to the Naval Academy or combat service. Yesterday, Mr. Webb fired back. ROBIN TONER

To the Editor: While a lot of news coverage has used a partisan framework to address the new voter restrictions (''Stricter Voting Laws Carve Latest Partisan Divide,'' front page, Sept. 26), what's really at stake is the fundamental functioning of democracy.

Book Fair to Honor India The annual Frankfurt book fair, the world's largest, begins tomorrow and will focus on the flourishing literary scene in India, this year's guest of honor country, as well as the rise of the Internet as a challenge to the printed word. About 70 of India's most successful writers, including Amitav Ghosh, left, and Kiran Desai, are scheduled to present their work at the five-day event, which is expected to draw nearly 300,000 visitors to see some 7,000 exhibitors from 111 countries, Agence France-Presse reported. This year's event will also focus on the boom in electronic publishing, and Google Inc. is expected to be in the spotlight, since its efforts to make extracts of every book printed available online have prompted concerns with authors and publishers over copyright. Up All Night in Toronto Adventurous people of Toronto -- more than 400,000 of them -- stayed up and out on Saturday night and into Sunday morning at their first Nuit Blanche festival, which transformed the city into an art gallery, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. For 12 hours, beginning at 7:01 p.m. on Saturday, visitors attended more than 130 exhibits in galleries, churches and parks in what Mayor David Miller called ''an extraordinary night for the city.'' Toronto adopted the idea from Paris, where the first Nuit Blanche was held in October 2002. The event has since spread to Rome; Madrid; Naples, Italy; and Riga, Latvia. This year's Parisian version starts at sundown on Oct. 7. Woes for George Michael The British singer George Michael was arrested over the weekend when London police found him slumped over the wheel of his car and in possession of cannabis, Reuters reported. ''At about 3.22 a.m. on Sunday morning officers were informed of a stationary vehicle with a driver inside causing an obstruction,'' a police spokesman said. Mr. Michael, 43, was arrested in February this year in a scenario that was almost exactly the same as last weekend's. The singer's partner, Kenny Goss, told reporters Sunday night that Mr. Michael had no comment about the arrest. ''He's fine and I've got him a McDonald's,'' Mr. Goss said. Plácido Domingo in Print: Learn From a Master In ''The Joy of Opera,'' scheduled for publication in 2009, the renowned tenor Plácido Domingo, below, will offer insights into masterpieces and how opera works -- and can be enjoyed -- on both sides of the curtain, Reuters reported. ''Opera for so many people remains a mystery, a curious and strange art form, when it really should be much more part of our everyday lives,'' Mr. Domingo writes in the book, according to the publisher W. W. Norton, which has acquired the worldwide rights. Mr. Domingo, 65, is the general director of both the Los Angeles Opera and the Washington National Opera and continues to perform and conduct. Footnotes Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman are both slated to direct productions for the Sydney Theater Company in Australia in 2007. Ms. Blanchett's production of ''Blackbird,'' by David Harrower, will be her directorial debut. The actor Stephen Rea (''The Crying Game'') and the director Garry Hynes (''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'') will be among the participants in an Irish Theater Symposium at Princeton University Oct. 13 to 15, featuring discussions, readings and performances reflecting on Ireland's long theatrical history. The Very End The results of a survey released yesterday indicate that James Blunt's ''Goodbye My Lover'' is the song most requested at British funerals and remembrance services, with Robbie Williams's ''Angels'' coming in second. The survey, sponsored by The Bereavement Register, which removes from databases the names and addresses of people who have died, found that 51 percent of respondents ask for a specific song to be played at their funeral, and that 79 percent have talked with family and friends about possible choices. Some choices were ambiguous, though. Is it the deceased or someone left behind whom we are to imagine singing the words of the No. 9 song, Police's ''Every Breath You Take''? It includes the lyrics ''Every move you make/Every step you take/I'll be watching you.''

SCHULTZ--Frances. The family of Frances Schultz announces with sorrow the passing of its beloved matriarch on September 28, 2006. Services Wednesday, October 4th at Plaza, Amsterdam and 91 St, NYC at 12 noon.

Todd Jones threw 45 pitches Sunday, all in vain. He retreated to the Detroit Tigers' clubhouse at Comerica Park and took off his spikes. All around him were T-shirts and caps, placed neatly at each locker, billing the Tigers as champions of the American League Central. There was plastic protecting the lockers, and dozens of bottles of Champagne. Jones went back to the dugout, hoping the Tigers could beat the Kansas City Royals, win their division and stay at home to start the playoffs.

A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''The Guardian'' referred imprecisely to the motto ''That others may live.'' It is the motto of the Coast Guard Rescue Swimmers, the subject of the movie, and other rescue groups -- not of the Coast Guard as a whole. (The Coast Guard's motto is ''Semper Paratus'' -- ''Always Ready.'' )
