Falcons quarterback Michael Vick had his second 100-yard rushing game last week, with 101 in a victory over Arizona. Not surprisingly, he holds the N.F.L. record for 100-yard games by a quarterback, with seven.

Kansas looks so brown and smoothly flat from the sky. I've seen it before, but I didn't expect the view. It looks like the top of a chest of drawers, not a landscape of home. I'm not sure where home is exactly, though. I haven't been to Mississippi, where I went to college, in months. Georgia, where I lived until I was 11, is just memories of cobblestone roads or trees my brother and I used to climb. And Louisiana, where I lived during high school, doesn't feel right, either.

Last weekend, I participated in a panel at the West Coast Green conference in San Francisco. The topic for discussion was green building trends in the media - a group of editors was to discuss how the media covers green design, what new trends are emerging, and what we all thought about "greenwashing" (that is, giving a positive public image to putatively environmentally unsound practices). As I began answering questions from the moderator and the audience, it occurred to me that having the time to concern oneself with sustainability is increasingly becoming a luxury. The current mantra of "living green" seems to have everything to do with increased consumption of goods and services when it should in fact be the reverse.

GAME 2 RESCHEDULED FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON Wednesday night's Game 2 of the American League division series between the Yankees and the Tigers at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx was postponed because of rain. The game is now scheduled for 1:09 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday. The Yankees lead the best-of-five series, 1-0. ESPN, which was to broadcast the game, reported at about 9:35 p.m. that the game would start at 10 p.m., but shortly afterward reported that the game was postponed. ESPN commentators said a second wave of rain about 90 miles away was most likely the culprit. Having already lost about two hours because of a delayed start, baseball officials had to weigh getting the game in (no guarantee) against possibly wasting starts by one of the Yankees' top pitchers and one of Detroit's. ESPN said it would broadcast Thursday's afternoon game.

It is 90 minutes before the Yankees play the Tigers in Game 2 of the first round of the baseball playoffs. As fans line up with tickets at Gate 2, security guards check to see what they have in their bags and in their pockets. Anyone with beverages in plastic bottles is asked to take a sip. Presumably, this will prove the liquid is not destructive.
Sportswriters who cover the Titans learned last Wednesday that quarterback Vince Young would start Sunday's game against Dallas, but they did not report it until Saturday.

In "The Energy Diet," a story in Thursday's Home & Garden section, Andrew Postman describes his efforts to reduce his family's production of CO2 (one of the so-called greenhouse gases), despite his devotion to his 37-inch flat-panel high definition TV.
METS TAKE GAME ONE, 6-5

Amid the outpouring of anger, accusations and conspiracy theories swirling around Mark Foley's resignation, some bloggers tried to re-focus their commentary and complaint on other issues. Outside the Beltway questioned the reasoning behind a ban on online poker sites attached to a port security bill by Senate Majority leader Bill Frist. The site contends that the ban, an attempt to protect children and consumers from online gambling sites, would only keep them from the heavily regulated internationally driven sites, not from some domestic sites with fewer safety nets. This issue, the blog said, reflects "yet another reason for libertarian minded Republicans to be glad when Frist is gone."
Oct. 4 - Roger D. Kornberg won a Nobel prize 47 years after his father did.
So, where is Andrew Cuomo? A sighting.

A special investigative committee has found that Apple Chief Executive and cofounder Steve Jobs was aware of some stock options backdating, but did not personally benefit from the practice, the company said in a statement Wednesday.

It is a rumor that has been swirling around since at least July, but the notion that chip giant Intel might acquire Nvidia seems to have gotten a second wind. Shares of Nvidia surged nearly 10 percent on Wednesday to $31.08, a move that Reuters attributed to fresh speculation that a takeover was imminent.

Update: 5 p.m. or so: While The Associated Press first went up with new details from Kirk Fordham, who resigned under fire on Wednesday from his post as top aide to Congressman Tom Reynolds, the chief architect of the House Republicans' campaign machine, Jeff Zeleny, a new member of The Times's Washington bureau, also interviewed Mr. Fordham.
Marvin Girouard is shaking things up on his way out of Pier 1 Imports.

William Ford, who became president of General Atlantic early last year, has taken the role of chief executive at the private-equity firm. The new job will put Mr. Ford in charge of operations, staffing and raising capital, General Atlantic said in a press release on Wednesday.
(The Samkon Gado Watch is a weekly look at the best players available inmore than 50 percent of fantasy leagues.)

Kirk Fordham, top aide to Representative Tom Reynolds of New York who is spearheading the Republicans' efforts to retain their majority in the House, resigned on Wednesday, citing the Foley page scandal.
Democratic Senator Robert Menendez says Republican Tom Kean Jr. "conspired with a convicted felon to smear his opponent."
Talks on a historic alliance among General Motors, Renault and Nissan broke down on Wednesday, 11 days before a deadline set by the three companies for reaching a decision.
Republican Tom Kean Jr. links Senator Robert Menendez to an infamous New Jersey scandal, suggesting that Mr. Menendez could become "the next Bob Torricelli."

The aide to Congressman Tom Reynolds who appeared to be at the center of the Foley manueverings resigned today, after reports surfaced that he had tried to get ABC to agree to not printing some of the more alarming emails that Representative Mark Foley sent to a male page.
An unusually chatty George M. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, talked openly with reporters on his way out of the Stadium after the Yankees' 8-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers last night.
The camera always seems to find Derek Jeter's father sitting in the stands of Yankee Stadium during the playoffs.

Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, and four other people will be named in indictments expected to be filed by California's attorney general on Wednesday in the spying case at the company, lawyers involved in the case told The New York Times.

Jeanine Pirro has repeatedly accused an assistant United States attorney, Elliott Jacobson, as being the man behind what she calls a politically motivated inquiry into the Kerik-Al Pirro-Jeanine boat contretemps. Mr. Jacobson, of course, ran the investigation into Al Pirro's finances.

The backlog of merger-and-acquisition deals has hit another record, according to analysts at Merrill Lynch. In a report published Wednesday, Merrill said that the backlog of investment-banking fees for deals that have been announced, but not completed, stood at $8.9 billion at the end of September, up 5 percent from August -- also a record month for fee backlogs -- and more than 50 percent above last September's level.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Amid bubbly speculation about who might buy Facebook and what the price would be, The New York Post reports that Facebook previously agreed to pay Microsoft a breakup fee in the event it is acquired by a Microsoft competitor.
Several backstories have emerged in the Foley-page scandal since the congressman resigned last Friday, getting full treatment in media coverage Tuesday and Wednesday.
Many hedge funds are fleeing the energy markets these days. Are they pushing oil prices down in the process? Put more bluntly: Can we thank Amaranth and its ilk for cheaper visits to the gas pump?
In more than 40 years, R.W. Apple wrote about war and revolution, politics and government, food and drink, and the revenge of living well.
The printer and office service provider Xerox Corporation said on Wednesday it had agreed to acquire XMPie, a privately held company in Israel, for $54 million.
From Executive Editor Bill Keller:

The Bally Total Fitness Holding Corporation, which warned last month that it might not be able to fulfill its credit agreement, said on Wednesday that lenders had agreed to credit totaling $280 million.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Oct. 4 column, "If I Had One Wish."

Major universities are developing software for the Department of Homeland Security to help monitor negative sentiments towards the United States overseas. Meanwhile, a man who expressed his negative sentiments without solicitation to Vice President Dick Cheney and was arrested for harassment is suing the Secret Service.

The Mark Foley pedophilia sex scandal contains neither pedophilia nor sex: Discuss. National Review's Jonah Goldberg raised this point (without defending Foley) at The Corner earlier this week, when he proposed that liberals and gay rights activists will come to regret "having 16 and 17 year old teenagers classified as young children for legal/sexual/political purposes." Goldberg predicts, "[T]he standard being used against Foley is one that I guarantee will bite back in all sorts of interesting ways."

Invoking the spirit of the Times's David Rosenbaum, a master of scouring legislation for the fine print and the anonymous earmarks, Thom Shanker, our veteran Pentagon/foreign policy correspondent, has unearthed language in recent spending authorization bills that would allocate $20 million for victory celebrations honoring the troops who served in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court took a shot, so to speak, during oral arguments in two immigration cases.
Management-led buyouts have gotten some bad press lately, including a controversial article by Ben Stein in The New York Times stating that such transactions should be "illegal on their face."

This morning's Quinnipiac Poll re-enforces the usual buzz: Eliot Spitzer still has a 50-point lead in the governor's race and state Comptroller Alan Hevesi still has an 8 percent unfavorable rating, while their respective Republican opponents, John Faso and Chris Callaghan, are still largely unknown.
Private equity firms are circling Britain's Northgate Information Systems, which could lead to a buyout bid worth as much as 615 million pounds ($1.2 billion), The Times of London reported Wednesday.

Rhode IslandThe fathers of Senator Lincoln Chafee and his Democratic challenger, Sheldon Whitehouse, were lifelong friends.TennesseeRepresentative Harold Ford, Jr., the Democratic candidate, conveys a centrist message to appeal to conservative voters in eastern Tennessee, while the G.O.P. accuses Mr. Ford of attending Playboy parties in an ad in support of Bob Corker.National Republican Senatorial Committee adFord ad

Democrats are not soft but are "softer" on terrorism, President Bush told donors in California Tuesday. Meanwhile, Democrats attacked Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist's skepticism about the possibility of military victory in Afghanistan.
The Wall Street Journal examines how recent developments about the source of disclosures in the Plame leak case could aid the defense strategy of I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby.

OhioThe state Supreme Court rejected a Democratic lawsuit seeking to force the disclosure of donors who paid for commercials critical of Representative Ted Strickland, the Democratic candidate for governor.
Volkswagen said it had bought more than 15 percent of MAN AG, a German truckmaker, as part of a strategy to build up its commercial vehicles division and encourage cooperation with Scania AB.
Singer-songwriter Amos Lee plays songs from his new album "Supply and Demand" and reveals thoughts about songwriting. (Produced by Kassie Bracken and Winter Miller.)
Leaf cleanup the easy way.
After shedding its underwear and European meats businesses failed to improve its stock price, Sara Lee is now considering a private equity buyout, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.
Gear test with Mark Bowling, a rock climbing instructor.

A judge has denied a request from plaintiffs' attorneys representing Enron shareholders to temporarily release Andrew Fastow from prison to give a lengthy deposition in civil lawsuit against the company's banks.
Eastman Kodak said Tuesday it had hired a chief financial officer and postponed a key investor meeting as it pins down the fate of its health-imaging unit and prepares to introduce new products.
Saks said late Tuesday that stockholders will get a $4-a-share special dividend in November, marking its second extraordinary payout this year.
L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco, and Mark H. Swartz, the former finance chief, filed appeals yesterday to their convictions last year for looting the company.
General Motors said yesterday that its board voted to adopt majority voting for uncontested director elections and to require executives to give back bonuses in cases of misconduct or negligence.
In Sutter Creek (population 2,480), born at the dawn of the Gold Rush, Wild West kitsch mingles with breezy wine-country style.

After a five-year investigation, European officials examining the chip maker Intel have presented what they say they believe is a watertight argument for pursuing antitrust charges to an internal panel of so-called devil's advocates, according to press reports.

In the latest example of private equity's appetite for big companies, Baxter International agreed on Tuesday to sell its transfusion therapies business to a consortium led by the Texas Pacific Group and Maverick Capital for $540 million in cash.
In a deal that FinanceAsia describes as "groundbreaking," a private equity firm WL Ross, has bought a controlling interest in a textile manufacturer, OCM India for $37 million.

Freescale Semiconductor entertained several strategic moves, including possibly trying to buy Philips Semiconductor, before ultimately agreeing to sell itself to a private equity consortium for $17.6 billion last month, MarketWatch reported.

Getting the jump on stock and bond investors, traders in the credit-default swaps market were betting on a takeover of Harrah's Entertainment, the world's largest casino company, even before it announced a buyout bid.

Private equity has outdone itself in raising cash in one year. A report from Private Equity Intelligence says that the funds, led by Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, have hauled in $300 billion so far this year, already ahead of the $283 billion the industry raised for all of 2005.

Vonage's chairman, Jeffrey Citron, defended the Internet phone company's ill-fated public offering on Tuesday and dismissed claims that looming competition from cable companies has dimmed its prospects.

The London Stock Exchange bowed to concerns about regulation of its Alternative Investment Market, as it finally unveiled plans to crack down on brokers advising companies floating on the junior market.

In the latest counterfeiting dispute between fashion's high and low ends, the luxury handbag maker Coach has filed a $1 million lawsuit against Target, accusing the discount retailer of selling a fake version of one its purses.
Science Applications International Corporation set the terms of its $1.1 billion initial public offering Monday so that voting control will be kept firmly in employee hands.
A British private equity firm, Doughty Hanson, has abandoned plans to launch a 1 billion euro ($1.3 billion) listed fund on Euronext after failing to attract interest from investors.
The lawyer asked by Hewlett-Packard to examine the way it conducts investigations said Tuesday that it was ethics, not the law, that needed to be paid more heed.
Douglas Emmett is the second initial public offering to top $1 billion in planned proceeds this week, as the real-estate investment trust sets its proposed deal terms.

Xstrata, the Anglo-Swiss mining company, said it planned to raise 2.9 billion pounds ($5.5 billion) in a London rights issue, one of the world's largest, to pay for its 9 billion pound acquisition of Falconbridge.

Realogy, the nation's largest real estate broker, has been having a tough time since its spin-off from Cendent in July. The move to separate the company - which owns Coldwell Banker, Century 21, ERA, Sotheby's International Realty and, in the New York area, the Corcoran Group - came at the end of the hottest housing boom in decades.

The s Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ said Wednesday it would work with Malaysia's CIMB Group to provide a range of investment banking services specifically targeting Japanese firms operating in Malaysia.

As part of an unreported share scheme, Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, received about 15 million pounds ($28.2 million) in shares from Barclays bank last year as part of her compensation at the bank, according to the Guardian.

Morgan Stanley, striving to gain an edge in recruiting promising talent, is making it easier for up-and-coming brokers to earn bonuses. The firm has significantly lowered the targets for revenue and assets under management that brokers need to achieve to qualify for its "Rising Star" incentive pay package.
Citadel Security Software of Dallas has agreed to be acquired by the software company McAfee for about $56 million in cash plus other considerations, the company said Tuesday.

Antitrust authorities on Tuesday approved the planned merger of the government rocket launch units of Lockheed Martin and Boeing, a deal the companies say will save taxpayers $150 million annually in satellite launching costs.

American Capital Strategies said Wednesday it had rounded up $1 billion for a new private equity fund. About $670 million of the fund is dedicated to buying a chunk of the equity investments that American Capital already holds, the company said.
The shopping mall owner Heritage Property Investment Trust of Boston said on Tuesday its stockholders have approved the company's merger with the Centro Properties Group of Australia.

It may have taken them a month to wade through some 137,000 proposed amendments floated by opponents of the deal, but French lawmakers voted on Tuesday to approve legislation to privatize Gaz de France, helping clear the way for the natural gas company's state-backed merger with Suez.

Icap's chief executive, Michael Spencer, revived hopes of a 6 billion pound ($11.3 billion) merger between the inter-dealer broker and the London Stock Exchange after hinting a deal might still be possible.
British Nuclear Fuels, the state-owned operator of four ageing nuclear power plants in Britain, has put its trading and marketing arm up for sale, The Times of London reported.

Last-minute negotiations with minority shareholders and continued arguments about pricing have held up RusAl's $8 billion takeover of its rivals Sual and Glencore, a deal that would create the world's largest aluminum producer.
In a public hearing held by the Federal Communications Commission in Los Angeles on Tuesday, representatives of the news and entertainment industries came out against further consolidation.

The publisher of The Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald, its Spanish-language sister paper, resigned yesterday, saying he had lost control of his newsrooms over a growing controversy involving payments from the Bush administration to some reporters of El Nuevo Herald for their commentary broadcast on the anti-Castro outlets Radio and TV Martí.

In the latest salvo between company management and Carl C. Icahn, ImClone said in a filing Tuesday that the activist investor refused to support a $36-a-share bid last month for the biotechnology company.

The Toshiba Corporation, a Japanese maker of Electrical supplies, including nuclear plant components, said Wednesday it would raise its stake in Westinghouse Electric, a builder of nuclear plants in the United States, as part of a revised purchase agreement.
Minus two top starters, the Mets got dynamic postseason debuts from Carlos Delgado and David Wright to jump ahead of the Dodgers in their N.L. playoff series.
In 2004, Stu Hendel, co-head of U.S. prime brokerage at Morgan Stanley, did what many of the industry's talented sell-side professionals do these days: He bolted Wall Street and joined a hedge fund.
If you want to cook up a financial-services behemoth, be prepared to crack some egos -- even your own.
Michael Hurst and his partner open Full House, a store in Pennsylvania, clocks and more.
In “The Nine,” an ABC drama that begins Wednesday, a bank heist goes awry and nine hostages emerge sharing secrets and unexpected bonds.
Comedy Central’s animated “Freak Show” is designed for the children of the 1970’s, who grew up on a steady diet of “The Six Million Dollar Man” and the “Super Friends.”
Major League Baseball's postseason has begun. In the divisional series playoff games Tuesday night, the Yanks defeated the Tigers, the A's topped the Twins and the Cardinals beat the Padres.
John Cameron Mitchell's ode to the joy and sweet release of sex also manages to be a sincere, modest political venture that finds humor where you might least expect it.
A “what went wrong?” documentary that succinctly and ruthlessly dissects the battle for Ohio in the months leading up to the 2004 presidential election.
Thirteen years in the making, Christiane Cegavske’s stop-motion fairy tale is at once wondrously obsolete and perfectly au courant.
As informative as it is, this documentary portrait of the playwright Tony Kushner doesn’t have time to do more than scratch the surface of its fascinating subject.
Australia, land of fruit bombs and salesmanship and industrial wines with cute critter names, has stepped into the sacred circle and poured its rieslings into the chalice for judgment.
Roger D. Kornberg, an American, won the chemistry prize for research on how data in genes is used to make proteins.
The aide, Kirk Fordham, said that he had warned Republican leaders about Representative Mark Foley’s behavior prior to 2005.
The terms of the prize require competitors to sequence 100 human genomes of their choice within 10 days, and, within six months, those of a further 100 individuals chosen by the foundation.
David Cameron sought to persuade his Conservative party that change will bring them political power.
The companies said they could not agree on the savings the deal would bring or how to distribute the benefits.
Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, and four other people were indicted in California today on state criminal charges in the spying case that has rocked the company.
Javier Solana said the matter would be referred to the Security Council for possible sanctions unless Tehran agreed quickly to suspend uranium enrichment work.
Orlando Hernández, the scheduled Game 1 starter, could be added to the roster for the National League Championship Series.
The expansion would be part of a $26 million plan to shore up the Palestinian leader’s position, according to donors.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will take a trip to the West Bank to show support for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.
South Korea and China warned North Korea that a nuclear test would lead to a chill in relations.
Some players come to the Yankees and struggle to relax and fit in. But Bobby Abreu, who had two hits and four runs batted in Tuesday night, fits in smoothly.

The United States government filed a civil suit yesterday against a prominent New York Alzheimer’s disease specialist and his practice, accusing them of defrauding Medicare by falsely diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease and receiving payments for unnecessary services.
If you have been waiting to buy a Manhattan apartment until after prices come tumbling down, you may have to wait a little longer.
Derek Jeter tied a postseason record for hits in a game, going 5 for 5 and capping his night with a home run over the center-field wall in the eighth inning.
A state senator from Queens has apparently secured enough support from his Democratic colleagues to become the next Senate minority leader, several Democratic members of that body said yesterday.

The plain wooden coffin of Yakub Aminov was held high above a mob of friends and his relatives. It was borne safely out of Congregation Beth Gabriel yesterday and down 67th Avenue in Rego Park, Queens, toward a cemetery.

The playoffs have become an annual affair for the fans, who set an American League attendance record. But the Yankees, who won the World Series four times from 1996 to 2000, have not been able to produce title No. 27.
The reason Joe Torre is limiting Mariano Rivera is not because he is hurt, but because he is worried Rivera could reaggravate the muscle strain near his right elbow.
AMERICAS.

A state judge yesterday upheld a subpoena sought by the state lobbying commission in its investigation of whether State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, received an illegal gift from a businessman who is part of a group bidding for the state racing franchise. The decision by the judge, Joseph C. Teresi of State Supreme Court, means that the commission’s executive director, David M. Grandeau, will be able to compel the businessman, Jared Abbruzzese, to answer questions and provide documents about private flights provided to Mr. Bruno. Records already obtained by Mr. Grandeau from an airplane charter firm, Richmor Aviation Inc., show that Mr. Bruno took half a dozen flights with staff members and one with a relative. Mr. Abbruzzese is part of Empire Racing Associates, one of several groups bidding on the lucrative franchise. Mr. Bruno had no comment yesterday, and Mr. Abbruzzese’s lawyer, Brendan Tully, did not respond to a request for comment.

An appellate court ruled yesterday that New York City must help mentally ill inmates find psychiatric and other services when it releases them from jail wards in city hospitals. Three years ago, in settling a lawsuit, the city agreed that when it released mentally ill prisoners from jails, it would help arrange their medical care, psychotherapy, insurance and housing, rather than leaving them to fend for themselves. But the city argued that the settlement did not apply to prisoners discharged from city hospitals. The plaintiffs reopened the case, and a State Supreme Court judge ruled that the city’s policy violated the settlement. Yesterday, a panel of the Appellate Division of Supreme Court in Manhattan upheld that decision unanimously.

A woman pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to murdering her 14-year-old daughter, admitting that she repeatedly struck the girl with a hammer and a shovel as she slept, Union County prosecutors said. Under a plea agreement, the mother, Lynn Giovanni, 46, is to receive a 30-year prison term for the fatal beating of the girl, Nicole Giovanni, at their Roselle Park home in February 2005. After killing Nicole, Ms. Giovanni fled and tried to kill herself by driving into a guardrail, the authorities have said. Sentencing is set for Dec. 1.

The managers of Stewart International Airport announced yesterday that they had landed AirTran Airways, a low-fare airline that they hope will draw leisure travelers to their underused airport, about 55 miles north of New York City. AirTran said it would begin nonstop flights between Stewart and Atlanta and three Florida cities, Orlando, Fort Lauderdale and Tampa, on Jan. 11. Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates three other airports in metropolitan New York, have been studying whether Stewart could develop into a fourth.

Flanked by cabinet officials and state utility regulators, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced yesterday that the state would produce an energy master plan within a year to try to increase energy efficiency and the array of alternative energy sources by 20 percent by 2020. Mr. Corzine said demand for energy in New Jersey had outstripped population growth by three times over the last decade. The state now imports 25 percent of its electricity, but has not updated its energy plan since 1995, he said. Mr. Corzine said the state should look at all potential sources, including nuclear power plants, clean-coal technology and ethanol plants.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has joined a chorus of elected officials who have criticized the manufacturer of a new, heavily caffeinated soft drink called Cocaine. “The bottlers ought to have their heads examined,” the mayor said yesterday. “Given we have a drug problem, particularly among kids, to try to glorify something that is so destructive just is an outrage.” James T. Kirby, the owner of Redux Beverages L.L.C., which makes the beverage, has said that he did not advocate drug use but that “controversy sells.”.

A 42-year-old motorcyclist was killed yesterday in Coney Island when he slammed into two parked cars, the police said. The man, Michael Rebuffi, was traveling south on Shell Road about 7 a.m. when he apparently lost control of his Kawasaki near Neptune Avenue, the police said. Both cars he hit were unoccupied, the police said. Mr. Rebuffi, of Afton, N.Y., was taken to Coney Island Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, officials said. The police said speed might have been a contributing factor in the crash.

A 21-year-old Bronx man was fatally shot in the head last night, the police said. The victim, Joel Orellano of Bassford Avenue, was shot in front of 736 East 211th Street in the Bronx around 10:30 p.m. He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. There have been no arrests.

Five years after 9/11 and a year after Hurricane Katrina, most small and midsize businesses in New York City are unprepared for emergencies, according to a survey to be released today by the American Red Cross and the Center for Catastrophe Preparedness and Response at New York University. Almost half of the 200 businesses surveyed (46 percent) said they lacked information about preparing for a disaster, and 41 percent said they did not have enough money or personnel to devote to devising a plan. Bill Raisch, director of the university’s International Center for Enterprise Preparedness, said business owners tended to focus on the likelihood of each type of disaster, like a blizzard or a terrorist attack, rather than the much greater likelihood that any one of them might occur. He urged the legal, insurance and credit-rating industries to reward businesses for making emergency plans.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee started to show campaign commercials yesterday that attack United States Representative John E. Sweeney, an upstate Republican in a competitive re-election battle.
Isiah Thomas is vowing to give Eddie Curry all the playing time he needs to spread his wings, setting the stage for a long-awaited breakout season.

Maria Sharapova, the United States Open champion, has made herself available for Russia’s Federation Cup team for the first time, she said on her Web site yesterday. Russia, the champion in 2004 and 2005, will play Spain in Moscow next April.

The Belmont Stakes winner Jazil will not run in the Breeders’ Cup Classic at Churchill Downs next month. His handlers have set next year’s Dubai World Cup as their next goal. Jazil recently recovered from a bruised bone in his right hind leg.
The contaminated land at the end of Tiffany Street in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx has been transformed into a lush five-acre waterfront spot called Barretto Point Park.

Oklahoma City accepted a $3.8 million settlement offer yesterday to cover its expenses during the New Orleans Hornets’ temporary relocation and its share of revenue. The offer, approved unanimously by the mayor and the City Council, also includes terms for this season in Oklahoma City and an option for a third in case they cannot return to New Orleans as planned in 2007-8.

The Devils signed their leading scorer, Brian Gionta, and four other veterans yesterday after the N.H.L. gave the team $3.5 million in salary cap relief by placing the veteran forward Alexander Mogilny on the long-term injury exception list.
BASKETBALL.

Louisiana State University has started an inquiry into whether baseball players received improper housing benefits under the former coaches Skip Bertman and Smoke Laval. The Advocate of Baton Rouge reported former coaches and staff members have been interviewed.

Los Angeles Lakers Coach Phil Jackson had right hip replacement surgery yesterday and is expected to be released from a hospital today. The Lakers said there was no timetable for Jackson’s return to training camp, which opened yesterday.
Behind the scenes, senior Republicans weighed whether Speaker J. Dennis Hastert could survive the scandal surrounding former Representative Mark Foley.
Police investigators said the gunman may have been planning to torture and molest the female students.

More than a dozen groups, including one aligned with the tenants at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, are expected to deliver bids in what promises to be the largest real estate deal in American history.
Despite winning an election last month, Milo Djukanovic, the only Balkan leader to have held on to power since the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991, will resign.
The publisher of The Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald said he had lost control of his newsrooms over a growing controversy involving payments from the Bush administration.

TRENTON, Oct. 3 — A 12-year-old boy who violated a 6-year-old playmate with an object must register as a sex offender under Megan’s Law, even if the act was not sexually motivated, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

Levy Mwanawasa took the oath for a second term as president after being certified the winner of a hotly contested election. But the second-place finisher, the populist politician Michael Sata, promised to make Mr. Mwanawasa’s next five years in office an exercise in misery. Mr. Sata charged fraud, saying 400,000 votes from his strongholds were never counted. The election commission is investigating the claim. Scattered disturbances by Mr. Sata’s backers in Lusaka and Kitwe, a copper-mining city, died down after Mr. Sata urged calm. Mr. Mwanawasa took 43 percent of the vote, up from the 29 percent he won in his first election, in 2001. His party took half the seats in the 158-member Parliament, while Mr. Sata’s took 46.

A Belgian surveillance drone used by a European Union force crashed onto a street in Kinshasa, the Congolese capital, killing a woman. “We don’t know if it was a technical fault or if it was shot down like the last one,” said Lt. Col. Thierry Fusalba, a spokesman for the force, which was deployed to help a United Nations force secure elections in July. A drone was brought down by gunfire shortly before that round of voting. A runoff vote for president is set for Oct. 29. The force quickly removed the wreckage from the crash site, while a crowd of several hundred chanted anti-European slogans and hurled abuse at a convoy of United Nations vehicles that drove by. Many in the capital accuse both missions of bias toward the incumbent president, Joseph Kabila, over his challenger, Jean-Pierre Bemba.
The State Supreme Court said it did not have jurisdiction to rule on a lawsuit seeking the names of donors backing a group that ran advertisements critical of the Democratic candidate for governor.

A federal judge has denied a request by tobacco companies to continue marketing so-called light and low-tar cigarettes until an appeal is settled in the case. The judge, Gladys Kessler, ruled in August that the cigarette makers had violated racketeering laws and misled the public about the health consequences of smoking. In rejecting the request last week, Judge Kessler wrote, “Loss of market share, if it results from imposing an appropriate remedy to prevent and restrain past violations of the law, may well be the price defendants have to pay.”.

The 19th-century French-Italian explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza, who founded Equatorial French Africa, was reburied in a mausoleum built for him in Brazzaville, the town and now capital city he founded exactly 126 years ago. His coffin, transferred from Algiers, where he was buried in 1905, was carried by Congolese naval officers as President Denis Sassou-Nguesso of the Congo Republic and President Omar Bongo of Gabon inaugurated the glass and marble monument. Others attending included President François Bozize of the Central African Republic; the French foreign minister, Philippe Douste-Blazy; and King Nguempio of the Téké, who is the heir to King Ilo, who in 1880 signed a treaty authorizing Savorgnan de Brazza to settle on the banks of the Congo River.
Officials said the hijacker was apparently a convert to Christianity who wanted to communicate with Pope Benedict XVI.

Seven Danish Muslims arrested last month in Odense and accused of plotting to carry out a bomb attack in the country must remain in custody for four more weeks, a judge ruled. The authorities said the men had collected materials to make explosives for an attack in Denmark, which has troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. The potential target has not been revealed, but Justice Minister Lene Espersen called the case one of the most serious ever in Denmark.

Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, trying to end the biggest crisis of his nine years in power, apologized for accepting money from friends in the early 1990’s, which he has characterized as loans. His partners in the coalition government said they would continue to support him. “It was a misjudgment, although not in breach of any law or code of conduct,” he told lawmakers in the Parliament.

Thaksin Shinawatra, the deposed prime minister, resigned from the once all-powerful Thai Rak Thai Party he founded in 1998 in a letter faxed from London, after more than 200 colleagues quit the party this week as it crumbled after a military coup. He cited “the current atmosphere” and defended himself against accusations of wrongdoing.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger kicked off a campaign seeking voter support for a bipartisan $37 billion bond measure while gearing up for a showdown with Democrats in the race for governor. The bonds would finance highway expansion, public transit and school improvements, home construction and levees. The measures were put on the ballot by the California Legislature, which is led by Democrats, after lawmakers put partisan disagreements aside and agreed on the plan, which is intended to rebuild the state for the next generation. Opinion polls have shown mixed enthusiasm for the measures, and the Rebuild California Plan umbrella group has bought $4 million in television advertising in the last two weeks of campaigning. In the governor’s race, Mr. Schwarzenegger faces the state treasurer, Phil Angelides, in a televised debate on Sunday. Two polls released last week showed Mr. Schwarzenegger widening his lead over Mr. Angelides.

Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales announced an expansion of efforts to fight human trafficking. Speaking at a conference in New Orleans, Mr. Gonzales said the government would increase financing for prosecuting commercial slave traders by $8 million and build up a trafficking task force on the issue to 42 members from 32. Some of the money will be used to “put a stop to the exploitation and abuse of laborers” brought into the New Orleans area by traffickers to work in rebuilding after Hurricane Katrina last year.

A Vienna landlord who used his key to enter an apartment after he did not get an answer to letters announcing a rent increase found the tenant dead, and for quite a while. The police believe the 93-year-old man, a former university professor described as a recluse, might have died three or four years ago. His rent continued to be paid automatically from his bank account, which was automatically replenished by his pension.

The president of a temporary-labor contracting company operating in Ohio and Tennessee and two other people associated with the company pleaded guilty to federal charges of conspiring to send hundreds of illegal immigrants to work for an air cargo business, federal prosecutors and immigration officials said. As part of his plea, Maximino Garcia, 43, president of the Garcia Labor Company, agreed to forfeit $12 million in proceeds, including an office building in Wilmington, Ohio. Also pleading guilty were Dominga McCarroll, 53, Mr. Garcia’s sister and a former vice president of the company, and Gina Luciano, 40, director of human relations. Mr. Garcia admitted that he had sent more than 400 illegal immigrants to work loading cargo at ABX Air in Wilmington under contracts spanning five years.

Tracy Henke, the Department of Homeland Security official who helped supervise the distribution of antiterrorism grants, is resigning in the wake of criticism from members of Congress that the grant process was irrational or at least inexplicable. The criticism surged after big cuts were made in annual anti-terrorism grants to major cities including Washington and New York while a report showed that the department’s list of possible terrorism targets included an Indiana popcorn farm and an Alabama petting zoo.

A decorated Army veteran who was wounded in Iraq and then deserted to Canada to protest the war surrendered to the military. The veteran, Darrell Anderson, 24, flashed a peace sign before his mother and his wife drove him to the rear gate of the Army base at Fort Knox under a negotiated surrender that will probably see him released in a few days. His supporters said he was expected to receive a less-than-honorable discharge but not face a court-martial.

Nominations are closed for the Socialist Party’s primary election next month to choose a candidate for the presidential election in April. The popular favorite, Ségolène Royal, the president of the Poitou-Charentes region, is facing off against two more experienced opponents, a former prime minister, Laurent Fabius, and a former finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn. The party’s six-week campaign will end with an internal poll of the 200,000 card-carrying members on Nov. 16. Opinion polls of Socialist supporters give Ms. Royal a commanding lead over the other candidates for the nomination. She would face a conservative candidate almost certain to be the interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy.

The government of Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek, the leader of the conservative Civic Democrats, lost a vote of confidence in Parliament. Parliament has been deadlocked since an election in June left center-right and leftist parties each controlling 100 seats. The government got 96 votes of the 195 deputies present in the 200-seat legislature, two short of a needed majority. Under the Constitution, the cabinet must now resign and the president will appoint a new prime minister, who can make three attempts to form a government before new elections must be held. It was not clear when Mr. Topolanek would submit his resignation.

A former hospital nurse pleaded no contest to killing 10 patients nearly six years ago by injecting them with a drug used to temporarily halt breathing. The nurse, Vickie D. Jackson, 40, will be sentenced to life in prison, the maximum sentence she would have faced had she been convicted by a jury. The authorities have not offered a motive for the killings. They said the deaths occurred during Ms. Jackson’s night shifts at Nocona General Hospital in 2000 and 2001. Prosecutors said they were surprised by the plea, which came less than a week before her trial was to begin.

Prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty in the case of two men accused in random shootings in the Phoenix area. The men, Samuel J. Dieteman, 30, and Dale S. Hausner, 33, are charged with first degree murder and attempted murder in the killing of 2 people and the wounding of 14 in a string of shootings since May. They have pleaded not guilty. The police are trying to determine whether the men are linked to 21 other shootings that date to May 2005. In all, the shootings left 7 people dead and 17 wounded.
